name: Upgrade Chemical Container Closure and Transport Procedures
description: All acetone and solvent containers will be fitted with secondary containment caps featuring dual-lock mechanisms to prevent accidental dislodgement. Transport dollies will be upgraded with vibration-dampening suspension systems. Chemical inventory staff will complete re-certification training on proper bung sealing techniques and verification procedures. A new protocol will require visual inspection of bung security before every transport operation. Spill kits will be positioned within 10 meters of all chemical storage areas with monthly functionality checks documented.

name: Install Fixed Spill Containment and Ventilation Enhancement
description: Secondary containment bunding will be installed under all elevated solvent storage areas, designed to hold 110% of the largest container volume. The existing ventilation system will be upgraded to include real-time volatile organic compound (VOC) sensors with automatic activation of backup extraction fans when thresholds are exceeded. A permanent spill containment station with integrated absorbent materials and collection receptacles will be established. These engineering controls prevent environmental contamination and reduce exposure risk.

name: Install Real-Time VOC Monitoring System
description: Install continuous volatile organic compound (VOC) monitoring sensors in all injection molding clean rooms with audible and visual alarms when solvent vapor concentrations exceed 50% of the OSHA permissible exposure limit. The system will automatically trigger increased exhaust ventilation and alert operators to cease spraying operations until safe levels are restored. This engineering control directly addresses inadequate ventilation by providing real-time feedback and automated response capability.

name: Implement Pre-Spraying Ventilation Protocol
description: Establish mandatory administrative procedure requiring all employees to activate overhead exhaust systems and verify minimum airflow for 30 seconds before beginning any mold release agent application. Post laminated checklist cards at each spraying station. Train all production and maintenance staff on the new protocol during the next monthly safety meeting. Include verification in daily shift handover procedures and supervisor spot-checks.

name: Upgrade to Low-VOC Mold Release Agents
description: Substitute current solvent-based mold release agents with water-based or low-VOC formulations that maintain the same performance characteristics but reduce inhalation hazard by 80%. Coordinate with materials management to phase in new products over 90 days while maintaining production schedules. Conduct comparative testing to ensure final product quality is not compromised.

name: Install Secondary Containment Bunding
description: Replace existing open pallet storage system with enclosed secondary containment units featuring integrated drip trays sized for 110% of the largest container volume. Install for all drums over 30 gallons in the chemical storage area. Add absorbent material dispensers at each station and clearly mark containment zones with yellow warning lines. This engineering control prevents environmental release by capturing any spills before they reach storm water systems.

name: Implement Inventory Restraint and Verification Program
description: Install drum restraint straps on all raised pallet storage and require two-point verification before any drum movement. Create laminated checklist requiring visual inspection of drum condition, secure positioning, and strap integrity before handling. Train all materials handlers (Mélanie Fortin and Nicole Proulx) on proper restraint techniques. Conduct monthly audits of all chemical storage areas with photographic documentation.

name: Upgrade Storm Water Pre-Treatment System
description: Install oil-water separator with automated shutoff valve in the storm drain line from chemical storage area. System will divert contaminated water to secondary treatment tank for proper disposal rather than environmental release. Conduct quarterly maintenance and testing. This engineering control prevents environmental contamination even if spill containment procedures fail.

name: Establish Dedicated Pedestrian Walkways with Floor Markings
description: Paint bright yellow and white striped pedestrian walkways (48 inches wide) from the packaging station to designated loading zones. Install waist-height protective barriers along the dock edge to physically separate pedestrians from equipment zones. Add edge protection bumpers to all forklift access points. These engineering controls create physical separation between pedestrians and mobile equipment, eliminating the collision hazard entirely.

name: Implement Three-Point Communication Protocol
description: Establish mandatory radio communication procedure where forklift operators must announce their movements and direction before relocating equipment. Spotters must confirm receipt and relay all-clear before movement begins. All dock personnel must carry communication headsets. Conduct training for Raymond Tessier, Lucia Martinez, and all dock staff. Include protocol in daily safety briefing and enforce through supervisor observations.

name: Implement Daily Hydraulic System Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory daily inspection protocol for all injection molding lines focusing on hydraulic pressure readings, hose connections, and fluid leaks. Machine operators and setters will document gauge readings on a checklist at shift start and mid-shift. Any pressure fluctuations exceeding ±10 PSI from specification will trigger immediate shutdown and maintenance review. Training will be provided to all production staff on recognizing abnormal pressure patterns. This addresses the root cause of undetected gradual pressure drift.

name: Replace All Hydraulic Connections with Redundant Coupling Systems
description: Upgrade all hydraulic line connections on Lines A, C, and D with redundant quick-disconnect couplings that automatically shut off flow when separation occurs. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of pressurized fluid release during connection failure. Installation will be completed over two weeks during scheduled maintenance windows. Expected outcome is zero hydraulic spray incidents from connection failures.

name: Replace Wooden Pallets with Plastic Pallets in Production Areas
description: Phase out all weathered wooden pallets used in production zones A, C, and D and replace with food-grade plastic pallets that eliminate splinter hazards entirely. Plastic pallets are more durable, easier to clean for medical device production, and reduce maintenance costs. Purchase will begin immediately for gradual replacement over 60 days. This elimination control removes the hazard at its source rather than relying on employee awareness.

name: Implement Dual-Authorization Lockout/Tagout Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory two-person verification system for all machinery maintenance on CNC, injection molding, and milling equipment. Both the maintenance technician and the shift supervisor must independently verify equipment de-energization using a checklist before work commences. A physical lock mechanism must be placed on the main disconnect switch by both parties simultaneously. Training will be mandatory for all maintenance and production staff within 5 days. This administrative control eliminates miscommunication incidents.

name: Install Automatic Machine Stop Sensors on All CNC Equipment
description: Retrofit all CNC milling machines and precision equipment with pressure-sensitive safety mats and proximity sensors that automatically halt spindle rotation if human contact is detected. These engineering controls provide redundant protection against entanglement injuries. Installation will be prioritized for all equipment in the maintenance workshop over the next 30 days. Expected outcome is elimination of entanglement-related injuries through automatic shutdown.

name: Mandatory Refresher Training on LOTO Procedures
description: Conduct comprehensive refresher training for all maintenance and production supervision staff on lockout/tagout procedures, hazard recognition, and communication protocols. Training will include case studies of similar incidents and emphasis on the dual-authorization requirement. All personnel must complete within 10 days and pass written assessment. Sessions will be held during shifts to ensure 100% participation. This administrative control reinforces proper procedures.

name: Install Dual-Redundant Temperature Control System
description: Replace the single thermostat relay with a dual-channel temperature monitoring system featuring redundant sensors and automated shutoff valves. The new system will include continuous digital temperature display, automatic alert notifications when temperatures exceed 30°C, and fail-safe valve closure if both sensors detect abnormal readings. Installation will include quarterly calibration audits and real-time integration with the facility's main fire alarm system. This engineering control eliminates the single point of failure that led to the solvent cabinet overheating.

name: Establish Monthly Chemical Storage Equipment Inspection Program
description: Implement a mandatory monthly inspection protocol for all chemical storage cabinets, conducted by the Chemical Inventory Specialist and witnessed by an HSE committee member. Inspections will include thermostat functionality testing, coolant level verification, seal integrity checks, and temperature trend analysis. Results will be documented in the facility's CNESST-compliant safety log. This administrative control ensures early detection of equipment degradation and prevents future thermal runaway events.

name: Replace Analog Pressure Gauges with Digital Monitoring System
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with calibrated digital pressure transducers integrated into the PLC (programmable logic controller) system. Digital sensors will provide real-time pressure data with ±0.5% accuracy, automatic alarm thresholds at 95% of maximum safe pressure, and continuous trending logs for predictive maintenance. This engineering control eliminates gauge calibration drift and provides operators with reliable pressure monitoring. System will include redundant display panels visible from both sides of the machine.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Seal Inspection Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring quarterly inspection and replacement of hydraulic relief valve seals, pressure gauge seals, and hose connectors on all molding equipment. Inspections will be conducted by the Maintenance department with findings documented in the equipment maintenance log. Composite resin vapor exposure assessment will be added to each inspection to identify seal degradation patterns. This administrative control addresses the root cause of equipment seal failure from chemical vapors.

name: Introduce Thermal Gloves and Cooling Station for Hot Component Handling
description: Implement mandatory use of insulated thermal-resistant gloves rated for 60-70°C for all personnel handling recently molded components. Establish a cooling station with water baths (20°C) and cooling racks where components must cool for a minimum of 20 minutes before manual flash removal begins. Components will be marked with temperature-sensitive tape to indicate when safe for bare-hand handling. This engineering control reduces the risk of both thermal burns and tool slippage from mold release agent residue on warm surfaces.

name: Replace Manual Deburring Knives with Semi-Automated Flash Removal Tool
description: Procure pneumatic-powered flash removal tools with guarded blade design that significantly reduce operator hand proximity to sharp cutting edges. Tools will feature automatic feed mechanisms that hold components in place during trimming, eliminating the need for hand-stabilization. Training will be provided to all Assembly and Finishing personnel on tool operation, maintenance, and safety protocols. This substitution control replaces the hazardous manual knife technique with a mechanical process.

name: Conduct Mandatory Refresher Training on Sharp Object and Thermal Hazards
description: Deliver comprehensive training to all Assembly and Finishing personnel covering hand protection requirements, recognition of thermal residue hazards, proper tool handling techniques, and wound management first aid. Training will include case study analysis of similar hand injuries in the plastics industry. Training attendance will be mandatory for all personnel working with component finishing, with refresher sessions conducted quarterly. Documentation will be maintained in each employee's training file for CNESST compliance.

name: Implement Warehouse Material Stacking Height Limits
description: Establish and enforce maximum stacking heights for all raw material bags to no more than 4 feet, with additional weight-rated shelving inspections performed monthly. Install visual height markers on all storage racks. This directly addresses the root cause of the falling bags by reducing the potential for bag displacement and collapse. Train all warehouse staff on proper stacking procedures and load balancing during new employee orientation and quarterly refresher training. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in material spill incidents related to improper stacking within 12 months.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring in Materials Warehouse
description: Replace existing smooth concrete flooring in high-traffic areas of the Raw Materials Warehouse with commercial-grade anti-slip epoxy coating. Focus on areas around storage racks, loading zones, and material handling pathways. This engineering control will reduce slip hazards even when minor spills occur. Apply non-slip paint strips at 3-meter intervals to create visual guidance and improve surface traction. Expected outcome: Reduce slip-and-fall incidents in warehouse by 70% within first year of implementation.

name: Implement Composite Material Edge Finishing Standard
description: Establish a mandatory edge-finishing procedure for all cured composite components before they proceed to assembly. Components must be inspected for rough edges and exposed glass fibers using tactile glove test, then processed through automated edge deburring equipment or hand-sanded to acceptable smoothness. Create a visual SOP checklist posted at each assembly workstation. This administrative and engineering control eliminates the hazard of sharp glass fibers during handling. Train all assembly operators on the new procedure within one week. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of glass fiber laceration injuries within 30 days.

name: Install Protective Guards on All Industrial Ovens
description: Retrofit all 12 industrial ovens in the Post-Processing area with removable perforated steel guards that completely enclose exposed heating elements, coils, and hot surfaces. Guards will maintain at least 5 centimeters clearance from heating elements to allow heat dissipation while preventing accidental contact. Install warning labels and temperature indicators on each guard. This primary engineering control eliminates direct contact with high-temperature surfaces. Implementation timeline: 3 weeks. Expected outcome: Prevention of all thermal contact burns during routine oven operation.

name: Upgrade PPE Requirements for Heat Treatment Operations
description: Establish new PPE standards for all employees working with industrial ovens exceeding 150°C. Require use of Nomex-rated heat-resistant sleeves rated to at least 260°C, along with upgraded thermal gloves rated for 200°C minimum, and safety glasses with heat-resistant coating. Replace current insulated gloves (inadequate for direct element contact) with superior-grade gloves suitable for handling heated molds. Conduct fitting and training for all relevant personnel. This secondary control supplements engineering improvements. Expected outcome: Reduce severity and incidence of thermal injuries by 85%.

name: Implement Enhanced Oven Operation Safety Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training module on safe oven operation, focusing on proper body positioning, ergonomic techniques for part removal, emergency response procedures, and hazard recognition. Include hands-on demonstrations of correct glove usage and part extraction techniques. Require annual refresher training for all operators. Include near-miss reporting procedures to catch unsafe practices before injuries occur. This administrative control improves operator awareness and consistency. Expected outcome: Zero severity thermal injuries within 6 months.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Protocol
description: Establish a written, enforced lockout/tagout verification checklist requiring dual verification (operator and supervisor) before any maintenance begins on injection molding equipment. All equipment must be de-energized, pressure released, and verified with a multimeter. Workers must complete refresher LOTO training within 30 days. Supervisors must conduct weekly LOTO audits on Lines A-D. Install prominently visible LOTO signage at each injection unit emphasizing the requirement to verify de-energized state before work commences.

name: Install Machine Coupling Safety Guards
description: Design and fabricate metal mesh safety guards to completely enclose rotating couplings on all injection molding machines (Lines A-D). Guards must prevent hand access while allowing visual inspection of equipment status. Install guards within 5 business days. Include quarterly inspection schedule to ensure guards remain intact and properly secured. Document all installations with dated photos for compliance records.

name: Enhanced Supervisor Safety Training Program
description: Develop specialized 4-hour training module for all production supervisors covering LOTO compliance, equipment hazard recognition, and incident prevention. Training must include case studies of recent entanglement incidents in similar facilities. Supervisors must pass written certification exam scoring 90% or higher. Training mandatory for all supervisors before returning to shift oversight. Schedule monthly refresher sessions. Document all training completion dates and scores.

name: Install Automated Ventilation Failure Detection System
description: Install real-time ventilation monitoring system with automated alarms that immediately alert supervisors and facilities management when exhaust fan RPM drops below operational threshold or airflow sensors detect insufficient air exchange. System must include both audible alarm in the mixing room and automatic alert to supervisor mobile device. Integrate alarm with emergency lighting to indicate ventilation status. System installation must be completed within 15 days. Requires monthly functional testing and quarterly sensor calibration.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Equipment
description: Establish monthly preventive maintenance schedule for ventilation system including bearing lubrication, filter replacement, and motor inspection. Create maintenance log documenting all service activities. Schedule quarterly professional HVAC inspection by certified technician. Stock spare bearing assemblies and motors on-site to enable rapid replacement in case of failure. Assign responsibility to Maintenance and Engineering department. Conduct staff training on monthly visual inspection procedures to identify early warning signs of equipment degradation.

name: Establish Occupational Health Monitoring for Chemical Exposure
description: Implement baseline and periodic occupational health screening for all employees working in Chemical Storage and Mixing Room, including spirometry testing and questionnaire for respiratory symptoms. Conduct follow-up health assessment within 48 hours of this incident for the three affected employees. Document all findings in confidential health records. Establish threshold for medical referral if symptoms persist. Schedule annual occupational health assessments for all mixing room personnel. Provide workers' compensation claim guidance if needed.

name: Install Thermal Protective Gloves and Heat-Resistant Sleeves
description: Distribute insulated heat-resistant gloves (rated to 200°C) and arm sleeves to all injection molding operators working with high-temperature molds. These will be designated PPE for all mold cavity operations and stored at each production line. Conduct mandatory training on proper donning and doffing procedures. Establish monthly inspection protocol to ensure gloves remain in serviceable condition and replace worn items immediately.

name: Implement Mold Temperature Monitoring System Upgrade
description: Install temperature display panels at each injection molding line showing real-time mold surface temperatures. Add audible alarm system that alerts operators when mold temperatures exceed 85°C during part removal phases. Reprogram mold cooling sequences to reduce surface temperatures to 60°C before operators perform manual part extraction. Document all temperature readings in production logs for trend analysis.

name: Implement Load Stability and Weight Distribution Training
description: Mandate comprehensive retraining for all forklift operators (currently 4 active operators) on proper load stacking, center of gravity assessment, and weight distribution principles. Include practical scenarios simulating uneven loads and confined space maneuvering. Require operators to conduct visual load inspections before moving any pallet, documenting stability assessment on a checklist. Implement quarterly refresher training with emphasis on seasonal variations in material characteristics.

name: Upgrade Storage Rack Structural Capacity and Add Load Strapping System
description: Replace damaged racks with heavy-duty industrial racks rated for 2,000 kg per shelf (increase from 1,500 kg). Install cross-bracing on all vertical supports to improve lateral stability. Add mandatory load strapping system using nylon banding on all pallets exceeding 800 kg. Implement load weight signage on each rack section. Conduct monthly visual inspections of all racks for wear, bending, or structural compromise, with documented maintenance records.

name: Install Motorized Chemical Container Handling System
description: Install a permanently-mounted electric hoist and lifting frame system specifically designed for 20-liter chemical containers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The system will reduce manual lifting to near zero for containers exceeding 15 kg. All operators will receive comprehensive training on hoist operation, safety protocols, and emergency procedures. Establish preventive maintenance schedule with quarterly inspections. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of manual lifting of heavy containers.

name: Implement Mandatory Ergonomics Training and Job Rotation Program
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive ergonomics training to all production operators (20+ employees) covering proper lifting mechanics, body positioning, load assessment, and recognition of early warning signs of strain injury. Establish a mandatory job rotation system in UNIT-010 where operators alternate between manual handling, monitoring, and administrative tasks every 2 hours to reduce repetitive stress. Conduct ergonomic workstation assessments for all chemical handling areas.

name: Establish Chemical Container Storage Reorganization Protocol
description: Reorganize chemical storage layout to place frequently-used 20-liter containers at waist-to-shoulder height (optimal lifting zone, 60-120 cm), eliminating floor and high-shelf placements. Implement a labeled storage matrix system showing container locations, weights, and hazard classifications. Reduce the maximum number of containers stored in the manual handling zone to 12 units, requiring more frequent restocking from secondary storage. Establish weekly storage audits to maintain compliance.

name: Implement Locking Coupling System for Chemical Transfers
description: Install industry-standard quick-disconnect couplings with positive locking mechanisms on all acetone and solvent transfer lines in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Require all maintenance personnel to use the locking collar feature and conduct a visual inspection before any transfer operation. Provide training to all staff on proper coupling installation and verification. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of improper hose disconnection and ensures safer chemical handling practices.

name: Enhanced Chemical Transfer Procedure and Spill Kit Placement
description: Develop and post a mandatory chemical transfer checklist at all solvent handling stations, requiring visual inspection of coupling security before initiating transfers. Install spill containment kits (absorbent pads, barriers, collection containers) within 5 meters of all chemical storage and transfer points. Conduct quarterly refresher training for all personnel working with solvents on spill response procedures, including immediate evacuation protocols and hazard communication. Establish a pre-transfer buddy system where at least two trained personnel must be present.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Monitoring in Warehouse Section C
description: Install continuous air quality monitoring sensors in Section C to detect solvent vapor concentrations in real-time. Integrate these sensors with an automated alarm system that alerts personnel when vapor levels exceed 25% of the OSHA PEL (permissible exposure limit) and automatically triggers enhanced ventilation. Conduct a complete ventilation system audit to ensure airflow meets ANSI standards for chemical storage areas. This engineering control provides early warning of vapor hazards and prevents employee exposure.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedure Reinforcement and Competency Verification
description: Implement a mandatory retraining program for all maintenance and production personnel on Lockout/Tagout procedures with emphasis on the complete pressure relief sequence for hydraulic systems. Require documented competency assessments and annual refresher training. Establish a tracking system to ensure no employee works on equipment without current LOTO certification. Assign Gaétan Laplante as the LOTO Coordinator to conduct surprise compliance audits on all equipment maintenance activities. This administrative control ensures consistent adherence to safety procedures and prevents repeat incidents.

name: Install Automatic Hydraulic Pressure Relief Valve with Manual Override Lock
description: Upgrade all injection molding machines (Lines A-D) with secondary automatic pressure relief valves that activate during maintenance mode. These valves will prevent accidental pressure buildup regardless of operator actions. Additionally, install a physical interlock that prevents hopper access when the machine is powered, requiring complete system shutdown before any maintenance access is possible. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of unexpected hydraulic pressure release.

name: Restrict Propane Forklift Operations to Outdoor/Well-Ventilated Areas Only
description: Implement an immediate administrative control prohibiting propane-powered forklifts from operating in enclosed dock areas. Transition all indoor loading operations to electric-powered forklifts, which produce zero emissions and eliminate carbon monoxide hazards. For the loading area, deploy only certified electric equipment. Establish designated outdoor staging areas for any propane equipment use. Create a visual signage system clearly marking restricted zones. This substitution control eliminates the primary carbon monoxide exposure hazard.

name: Install Continuous Carbon Monoxide Monitoring and Alert System
description: Install fixed carbon monoxide monitors with audible/visual alarms at the Shipping and Receiving Dock that activate when levels exceed 25 ppm, providing early warning to all personnel. Integrate sensors with the building management system to automatically increase ventilation fan speed and activate backup ventilation when elevated levels are detected. Train all shift supervisors and dock personnel to respond immediately to alarms by evacuating the area and checking for equipment problems. Conduct monthly sensor calibration and testing.

name: Emergency Exit Clearance and Obstruction Prevention Protocol
description: Conduct an immediate audit of all emergency exits at the facility and remove all obstructions. Establish a weekly inspection checklist for supervisors to verify that all emergency exits maintain a 1.5-meter clear radius at all times. Paint bright yellow floor markings designating the emergency exit buffer zones where no materials or equipment may be stored. Integrate this requirement into the daily shift startup procedure. Post signage stating 'Emergency Exit - Keep Clear' at each location. This administrative control ensures constant evacuation capability during emergencies.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Chemical Transfers
description: Install a certified secondary containment tray (capable of holding 110% of largest container volume) at the chemical transfer station in the maintenance workshop. This engineering control will prevent spills from spreading across the workshop floor and reaching drains. The containment system will include absorbent materials storage and spill response kit mounted directly adjacent. All future chemical transfers must occur within this designated area. This directly addresses the root cause of uncontrolled spill spread.

name: Implement Quarterly Fluid Transfer Equipment Inspection Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring quarterly inspection of all hoses, connectors, and seals used in chemical transfer operations. Marco Rossi will lead a training session documenting inspection procedures, including visual checks for corrosion, wear, and proper connections. Maintenance technicians will complete a checklist form for each inspection. Equipment showing signs of degradation will be immediately replaced. This administrative control ensures early detection of equipment failure before catastrophic spills occur.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Emergency Activation Controls
description: Install push-button emergency ventilation activation panels at two additional locations in the maintenance workshop, clearly marked with signage. The system will automatically increase extraction capacity to maximum within 30 seconds of activation. Conduct staff training on proper activation procedures during hazardous vapor situations. This engineering control ensures rapid response to chemical vapor exposure, reducing inhalation risk during incidents.

name: Install Permanent Cable and Hose Management System
description: Install floor-mounted cable trays and hose guides along the entire perimeter of the Packaging and Labeling Station. All air hoses and electrical cables will be routed through these protective guides and secured using cable clips every 1.5 meters. This eliminates trip hazards by removing hoses and cables from walking paths. Additionally, yellow and black warning tape will mark any remaining floor-level obstacles. This engineering control directly prevents the mechanism of injury (tripping) that occurred in this near-miss.

name: Daily Housekeeping Checklist for Packaging Area
description: Patricia Martin will implement a mandatory daily housekeeping checklist completed at the start of each shift. The checklist includes: inspection of all hoses for proper routing and securing, verification that cables are confined to designated trays, removal of any debris or empty boxes from walkways, and confirmation that emergency exits are clear. Aaliyah Jackson and other assembly operators will sign off on completion. This administrative control ensures consistent maintenance of a hazard-free work environment and creates accountability for worksite conditions.

name: Install Shelf Edge Guards and Load Restraint Systems
description: Install 10-centimeter-high edge guards on all warehouse shelves above 1.8 meters. Additionally, install friction-based load restraint lips on each shelf designed to prevent items from sliding off during retrieval. All shelves will be reorganized to place heavier items (>8 kg) at waist height (0.9-1.2 meters) and lighter items on upper shelves. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of falling objects striking workers and reduces strain during retrieval of heavy components.

name: Implement Working at Height Safety Training Program
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training to all warehouse and maintenance personnel covering safe practices for accessing elevated storage areas. Training will include proper footing and body positioning, grip strength assessment, use of reaching assists (grabber tools, step ladders), recognition of unstable load conditions, and emergency response procedures. All personnel will complete a practical skills assessment before independent elevated storage access is permitted. This administrative control ensures workers understand hazards and proper techniques.

name: Provide Reaching Assist Tools and Personal Protective Equipment
description: Supply all warehouse associates with magnetic grabber tools (3-meter reach) for retrieving items from upper shelves without overextending or climbing. Additionally, provide anti-slip work gloves and wrist support braces for personnel regularly handling heavy components. Establish a policy requiring use of grabber tools for any retrieval above 1.8 meters. Store tools in accessible locations with clear usage instructions posted. This PPE/engineering control combination reduces both dropping risk and ergonomic strain injuries.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification and Quarterly Audits
description: Implement mandatory recertification of all production operators in lockout-tagout procedures with competency testing. Establish quarterly LOTO compliance audits conducted by the HSE office. Install visible LOTO procedure placards at all hopper access points. Require photo documentation of LOTO application before any maintenance or cleaning work begins. This addresses the root cause of inadequate lockout procedure compliance and ensures all employees understand the critical importance of isolation before servicing equipment.

name: Install Secondary Interlock System on Injection Line D
description: Engineer and install a secondary mechanical interlock that prevents hopper auger activation unless all access panels are fully closed and latched. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of unintended machine startup during maintenance. Conduct full system testing and validation. Train all operators on the new interlock system and response procedures if it activates during operations.

name: Two-Person Verification Protocol for Machine Servicing
description: Establish an administrative control requiring that any machine servicing, cleaning, or unjamming work must involve two authorized personnel—one performing the work and one designated as a safety observer stationed at the control panel. The observer holds responsibility for preventing any unauthorized startups and maintaining communication with the worker. Implement a sign-in sheet and checklist system to track compliance.

name: Replace Humidity Monitoring System with Redundant Sensors
description: Install dual humidity and temperature sensors in the Assembly and Finishing Department staging area with independent monitoring systems. Implement real-time alerts that notify HSE and production supervisors when humidity exceeds 55% RH or falls below 45% RH. Establish a monthly calibration schedule for all environmental sensors. This engineering control ensures early detection of storage condition deviations and prevents future mold contamination events.

name: Establish Environmental Monitoring SOP and Daily Logs
description: Develop a standard operating procedure requiring daily visual inspection and documentation of humidity/temperature readings in all storage zones. Create a digital log system accessible to shift supervisors. Define escalation procedures if readings approach alarm thresholds. Train all supervisory staff on the new procedure and interpretation of environmental data. This administrative control ensures consistent monitoring and rapid response to environmental deviations.

name: Implement Mandatory Deburring Process Before Warehouse Transfer
description: Revise production workflow to require that all injection-molded parts are deburred and edge-finished before transfer to warehouse staging areas. Establish a quality checkpoint where finished parts are inspected for sharp edges using tactile and visual verification. Only parts meeting edge finish standards can be released to warehousing. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at its source by ensuring sharp edges do not reach warehouse personnel.

name: Issue Cut-Resistant Gloves to All Warehouse Personnel
description: Provide ANSI A4 cut-resistant gloves to all material handlers and warehouse staff working with machined or molded parts. Establish a replacement schedule ensuring gloves are replaced immediately when damaged. Include glove usage in refresher training. This PPE control provides secondary protection while engineering controls are implemented.

name: Implement Quarterly Pallet Inspection Program
description: Establish a comprehensive inspection protocol for all wooden pallets in the warehouse. Damaged or degraded pallets must be immediately removed from service and replaced with new or certified pallets. A color-coding system will be implemented: green for approved pallets, yellow for pallets requiring repair, and red for pallets to be discarded. Inspections will occur every 90 days with documentation maintained in a tracking system. This addresses the root cause of pallet structural failure and prevents similar load collapses.

name: Upgrade Forklift Fleet Hydraulic System Maintenance
description: Contract with an external hydraulic specialist to conduct full system diagnostics on all 8 forklifts in the warehouse fleet. Install secondary containment trays beneath each parked forklift to capture any hydraulic leaks. Establish a preventive maintenance schedule with monthly fluid level checks and quarterly filter replacements. Train all forklift operators on pre-operation inspection procedures to identify leaks early. This engineering control reduces environmental contamination and equipment damage from hydraulic failures.

name: Redesign Material Storage Layout with Load Height Limits
description: Reduce maximum stack heights for resin bags from 8 pallets to 5 pallets, decreasing pressure on structural supports. Paint clear height limit markers on warehouse walls. Implement a load calculation system requiring material handlers to verify weight limits before stacking. Provide additional horizontal storage space by reorganizing Section A layout to discourage vertical stacking of heavier materials. This administrative and engineering control reduces load instability incidents.

name: Install Temperature Control and Monitoring System for Chemical Mixing Vessels
description: Replace all manual heating controls on chemical mixing equipment with digital PLC-controlled systems featuring dual temperature sensors and automatic shutoff at 150°C maximum. Install audible and visual alarms that activate at 145°C warning operators of excessive temperature. Implement real-time temperature logging to a centralized monitoring dashboard. Retrofit existing vessels with temperature sensors within 10 days. This engineering control prevents overheating incidents that create flash fire hazards.

name: Separate Flammable Materials Storage and Implement Fire Suppression Upgrades
description: Relocate all acetone, isopropanol, and other flammable solvents to a dedicated fire-rated storage cabinet located 20 meters from production areas. Install Class B dry chemical fire suppression units specifically designed for solvent fires at chemical mixing stations. Upgrade existing foam suppression system to dual-agent capability. Conduct quarterly fire suppression equipment inspections and annual full system testing. Establish 2-meter minimum clearance zones around all chemical storage areas.

name: Mandatory Chemical Handling Refresher Training and Standard Operating Procedures
description: Develop detailed written SOPs for all chemical mixing operations including mandatory equipment inspection protocols before use. Require all operators to complete a 4-hour hazmat refresher course covering flashpoint temperatures, incompatible material combinations, and emergency suppression system operation. Implement a buddy system requiring two qualified operators present during all chemical handling. Post laminated hazard placards at each mixing station. Conduct quarterly safety drills simulating chemical fire scenarios.

name: Implement Mandatory Two-Person Verification System for LOTO Procedures
description: Establish a new protocol requiring that no machine maintenance proceeds without: (1) primary technician completing full energy isolation on all sources (electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic), (2) independent verification by a second qualified person, and (3) placement of lockout hasps with both workers' locks. Create laminated LOTO checklists specific to each machine type. Require maintenance workers to sign and date energy isolation logs. Train all production staff that any equipment maintenance requires alerting the entire production team via announcement system. Violating LOTO procedures results in immediate disciplinary action.

name: Upgrade Injection Molding Machines with Interlock Safety System
description: Install mechanical and electronic interlock systems on all 32 injection molding machines preventing cycle activation when mold cavity access doors are open. Add redundant pressure relief valves to prevent unexpected mold closure during maintenance. Install motion-detection sensors that halt operations if human presence is detected in mold zones. Retrofit primary machines within 30 days, secondary machines within 90 days. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of unexpected machine activation.

name: Establish Machine Control Access Restrictions and Lockout Physical Barriers
description: Install physical barriers (collapsible gates) around each injection molding machine that must be opened before any cycle controls are accessible. Require maintenance workers to affix warning tags to all control stations when working on machines. Implement a digital system where maintenance activity is logged and broadcasted to all control stations, temporarily disabling remote cycle initiation. Conduct bi-weekly LOTO compliance audits with observations and corrective coaching.

name: Comprehensive Emergency Response and First Aid Training Program
description: Conduct quarterly emergency response drills focusing on machinery entrapment scenarios. Train all production supervisors and machine operators in advanced first aid including tourniquet application, shock management, and controlled blood loss procedures. Ensure all production areas maintain accessible emergency medical kits with tourniquet supplies. Establish protocol for immediate emergency notification with specific first responder routing. Conduct annual refresher certifications for emergency response procedures.

name: Install Dual-Channel Safety Interlock System on Injection Molding Equipment
description: Replace malfunctioning single-channel proximity sensors with redundant dual-channel safety interlock systems on all 32 injection molding machines. This engineering control will ensure that machine cycles cannot resume if a hand is detected in the mold area. The system will include manual override capabilities for authorized maintenance personnel only, with documented lockout/tagout procedures. Implementation includes sensor calibration testing and operator training on new safety features. Expected outcome: elimination of pinch point injuries from unexpected machine reactivation.

name: Enhance Machine Guarding and Part Removal Procedures
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all injection molding workstations and install additional physical guards around mold cavities. Develop and implement new standard operating procedures requiring two-handed control removal of parts or use of mechanical extraction tools instead of manual removal. Provide hands-on training to all production operators on proper part removal techniques and hazard recognition. Update job safety analysis documentation and post visual reminders at each workstation. Reinforce the importance of maintaining awareness of proximity sensors and reporting sensor malfunctions immediately.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Proximity Sensors
description: Establish a mandatory monthly preventive maintenance and calibration schedule for all proximity sensors across injection molding equipment. Maintenance technicians will test sensor responsiveness, clean sensor lenses, and document calibration results in the facility's maintenance tracking system. Any sensors showing drift or delayed response will be replaced immediately. This administrative control will catch sensor degradation before it causes incidents. Cross-train backup technicians to ensure consistent schedule adherence even during staff absences.

name: Install Cooling Station and Temperature Monitoring System
description: Establish a dedicated cooling zone in the Finished Goods Warehouse with wire mesh cooling racks and ambient temperature monitoring. Implement a mandatory cooling protocol requiring all hot parts to remain on cooling racks for a minimum of 20 minutes before handling or transfer. Install temperature sensors with automatic alerts if parts exceed safe handling temperatures (below 50°C). Provide staff with infrared thermometers to verify part temperatures before transfer. This engineering control eliminates contact with hot materials.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Hasp Inspection Protocol
description: Develop and enforce a documented lockout/tagout inspection checklist that must be completed and signed off by both the technician applying the lock and a second authorized employee before any panel work begins. The checklist will specifically verify that hasps are installed to manufacturer specifications, padlocks are fully engaged, and warning tags are legible and properly affixed. This checklist will be laminated and posted at each electrical panel. Conduct immediate retraining for all 12 authorized maintenance personnel on proper hasp installation techniques. Implement monthly audits where the Plant Manager randomly inspects five panels to verify compliance. Engineering controls include retrofitting all four deficient panels with improved hasps that have visual indicator windows.

name: Establish Quarterly LOTO Competency Verification
description: Implement a quarterly hands-on competency assessment for all 12 authorized lockout/tagout personnel. Each technician must demonstrate proper procedures on an actual electrical panel under supervision, including hasp installation, padlock application, tag placement, and breaker testing. Document results in employee training files. Any technician scoring below 95% on the practical assessment must complete refresher training before resuming unsupervised work. Conduct these assessments in rotation to identify emerging gaps in procedure compliance. This administrative control ensures sustained competency and catches procedural drift before incidents occur.

name: Install Visual Indicator Retrofit on All Electrical Panels
description: Replace all four substandard hasps on main electrical distribution panels with improved devices featuring visual inspection windows and mechanical indicators that clearly show when lockout is properly applied. Select hasps with ergonomic design that makes improper installation physically difficult or impossible. Verify compatibility with existing padlock types used throughout the facility. Schedule installation during planned maintenance window. This engineering control provides fool-proofing against hasp misinstallation by making the correct installation the easiest, most intuitive option.

name: E-stop Button Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Implement a monthly preventive maintenance schedule for all emergency stop buttons across production lines. This will include cleaning with compressed air to remove plastic dust, inspecting for mechanical responsiveness, and replacing any buttons showing signs of wear or contamination. A checklist will be created for operators to perform weekly visual inspections between scheduled maintenance. This addresses the root cause of potentially non-functional emergency equipment and aligns with ISO 45001 requirements for emergency response readiness.

name: Machine Guarding Upgrade and Inspection Protocol
description: Conduct a comprehensive assessment of all machine guards on hopper feed systems and injection molding equipment. Replace worn or damaged guards with new guards that meet or exceed ANSI standards, ensuring no gaps larger than 1/4 inch exist. Implement a quarterly inspection schedule with documented results. Train all operators on proper guard installation and reporting procedures for any damage observed. This engineering control eliminates the pinch point hazard identified on production lines.

name: LOTO Hardware Replacement and Certification
description: Replace all corroded hasp attachment points on production equipment with stainless steel hardware resistant to corrosion from resin exposure. Certify that all LOTO devices meet CSA standards and perform a functional test on each attachment point. Document the certification and create a maintenance schedule to inspect hasp points quarterly. Train the LOTO Coordinator and all authorized personnel on proper hasp attachment and lock engagement procedures.

name: Thermal Sensor Monitoring System Upgrade
description: Replace all manual thermal sensors on injection molding machines with automated digital monitoring systems that include redundant temperature sensors and alarm capabilities. Install real-time dashboard displays showing mold temperatures for each line. Configure the system to automatically trigger cooling cycles when temperatures exceed safe thresholds and alert operators when sensors malfunction. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the incident—sensor failure—and provides continuous safety monitoring.

name: Heat-Resistant Protective Gloves Implementation
description: Provide all injection molding operators with heat-resistant gloves rated to 200°C that are specifically designed for handling hot molds and parts. Gloves will be stored at each workstation and operators will be trained on proper fit and when to replace worn gloves. Establish a replacement schedule for gloves showing wear. Include glove wear inspection in the daily pre-shift safety briefing. This PPE control reduces burn severity even if contact occurs.

name: Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Critical Pumps
description: Establish and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all cooling water circulation pumps. Schedule seal replacements every 12 months (reduced from 18 months based on this failure). Create a detailed maintenance log for each pump tracking operating hours, pressure readings, temperature, and any anomalies. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance Planner and require technicians to inspect seals during quarterly maintenance checks. This administrative control prevents future catastrophic failures through proactive maintenance.

name: Secondary Containment and Isolation System Installation
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all cooling water pumps to capture leaks before they spread across the production floor. Upgrade isolation valve accessibility and install pressure relief valves set at 130 PSI maximum to prevent catastrophic seal failure from overpressure. Install dike systems around the pump area rated for 300-liter capacity. Clearly mark isolation valves and label emergency shutdown procedures at each pump location. This engineering control mitigates environmental and slip hazard consequences of future leaks.

name: Implement Secondary Containment System for Chemical Storage
description: Install secondary containment trays with 110% capacity of largest container beneath all chemical storage shelving in production areas. Trays will have absorbent material and drain valves with shut-off mechanisms. This engineering control eliminates the risk of spilled liquids reaching floor drains and contaminates the wastewater system. All staff will receive training on containment inspection and maintenance procedures. Expected outcome: 100% containment of future spills in storage and transfer areas, protecting clean room integrity and environmental compliance.

name: Establish Chemical Transfer Verification Protocol
description: Create a two-person verification checklist for all chemical container transfers requiring both personnel to confirm proper cap sealing before lifting. Implement color-coded caps for different chemical types. Provide refresher training to all production operators on proper handling techniques, including hand positions and lift mechanics. Establish monthly audits of chemical storage areas to verify compliance. This administrative control and training reduces human error during high-risk transfer operations.

name: Upgrade Clean Room Floor Drain Filtration
description: Install activated carbon filtration and sediment trap system on the clean room floor drain to capture any organic solvents and particulates before wastewater enters the main system. This will require engineering consultation and approximately 3 days of installation. System will have replaceable filter cartridges on a 6-month maintenance cycle. This engineering control protects environmental compliance and ensures medical device production standards are maintained.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish quarterly thermographic and acoustic monitoring of all injection molding machine hydraulic systems to detect pressure relief valve degradation and bearing wear before failure. Install condition monitoring sensors on high-risk machines (Line B and D) that provide real-time alerts. Create a predictive maintenance database tracking component performance trends. This engineering control approach prevents future failures before they occur, eliminating the risk of sudden loss of pressure control and potential operator injury.

name: Replace All Aging Drive Belts with Enhanced-Life Alternatives
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all injection molding machine drive belts and replace units showing wear patterns with high-performance synthetic belts rated for 50% longer service life. Establish 6-month replacement cycle for all drive belts regardless of apparent condition. Create visual inspection checklist for operators to identify fraying or cracking during morning shift startup. Train all machine operators on early warning signs of belt degradation. This preventive engineering control eliminates the risk of sudden belt failure.

name: Mandatory Burr Removal and Edge Finishing Protocol
description: Implement mandatory secondary finishing operation for all molded parts that contact human hands during assembly. Parts will pass through a deburring and edge polishing station using automated abrading wheels and hand finishing. Quality Control Manager Isabelle Tremblay will develop inspection criteria to identify any remaining sharp edges using tactile testing (gloved finger test) before parts reach assembly stations. Operators will be trained to identify and segregate any parts with rough edges immediately. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at source by removing sharp burrs.

name: Upgrade to Cut-Resistant Protective Gloves
description: Issue cut-resistant nitrile gloves (ANSI Level 3 or higher) to all assembly operators working with plastic components. Current inventory includes only standard nitrile gloves with minimal cut protection. New gloves will provide 3-5x greater protection against sharp plastic edges. Implement mandatory glove usage policy with daily audits. Conduct training on proper glove selection for different tasks and correct donning/doffing procedures. Maintain glove inventory to ensure availability in all sizes. This PPE control provides additional protection while engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Enhance Mold Quality Inspection Process
description: Establish monthly mold surface inspection and maintenance program to identify and repair cavity degradation before sharp edges develop. Install ultrasonic inspection equipment to detect micro-cracks and surface roughness in mold cavities. Create a mold maintenance checklist requiring surface polishing and defect repair. Require Quality Inspector sign-off on all parts in the first production run from any mold showing signs of wear. This administrative and preventive control ensures molds maintain proper surface finish specifications.

name: Upgrade Mold Handling Tools with Insulated Grips
description: Replace all current tongs and handling tools on injection molding lines with insulated-grip models rated for sustained contact with surfaces up to 100°C. Procure high-temperature silicone or neoprene-handled tongs that provide better grip stability in humid conditions. Establish a quarterly inspection protocol to ensure grip material remains effective. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate grip leading to contact with hot surfaces.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooling Cycle Verification Procedure
description: Establish a documented procedure requiring operators to confirm mold temperature has dropped below 70°C before part extraction using infrared thermometer checks. Add visual temperature indicators to each mold. Include this verification step in the daily production checklist. Train all Line D operators on the new procedure during next scheduled safety meeting. This administrative control ensures adequate cooling time is observed before manual part handling.

name: Implement Predictive Electrical Maintenance Program
description: Establish a comprehensive electrical maintenance schedule using thermal imaging and insulation resistance testing on all production equipment control panels quarterly. Schedule priority inspections for dryer control panels and material handling equipment. Contract with certified electrical technician to conduct baseline assessment of all panels within 30 days. Document all findings and create a replacement schedule for equipment exceeding safe operational thresholds. This engineering control prevents future electrical fires through early detection of deteriorating components.

name: Enhanced Fire Safety Drill and Response Training
description: Conduct mandatory fire safety refresher training for all employees working in high-risk areas (Regrind, Chemical Storage, Drying Rooms) within 14 days. Include specific scenarios for electrical fires. Verify all employees know location of fire alarm pull stations and evacuation routes. Establish monthly fire drill schedule with actual evacuation to ensure continuous readiness. Update emergency contact procedures and ensure clear pathways to all fire safety equipment.

name: Install Permanent Storage Rack Anchoring System
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all storage racks in Packaging, Shipping, and Material handling areas. Install floor-mounted anchor points for all storage racks exceeding 1.5 meters height or 500kg capacity. Use certified engineers to assess structural integrity and load-bearing capacity of each rack. Replace any racks that cannot be properly anchored or exceed weight limits. Establish monthly visual inspection protocol to verify anchor integrity. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of rack failure.

name: Establish Material Handler Safety Certification and Load Management Protocol
description: Develop standardized operating procedures requiring forklift operators to verify rack stability and load distribution before positioning materials. Implement load weight verification checkpoints using scale systems before placement in high-traffic areas. Provide refresher training to all material handlers on safe stacking practices, center-of-gravity concepts, and equipment limitations. Establish clear painted forklift traffic lanes in Packaging and Shipping zones with visible directional signage. Require monthly competency assessments for all personnel operating material handling equipment.

name: Install Falling Object Protection and Safety Netting
description: Install overhead protective netting or polycarbonate panels above high-traffic work zones adjacent to high-value storage racks to contain falling materials and protect personnel below. Position secondary containment platforms to capture dropped items before they reach floor level. Install perimeter warning barriers with reflective tape around vulnerable storage areas. This engineering control provides secondary protection in case primary anchoring fails.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a formalized quarterly inspection schedule for all injection molding machine cooling systems, including visual checks for cracks, corrosion, and coupling integrity. Technicians will use pressure gauges and thermal imaging to detect anomalies. Documentation will be maintained in the predictive maintenance system. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of delayed detection of the cooling line degradation and ensures early identification of similar hazards before catastrophic failure occurs.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays Under All Cooling Lines
description: Engineering control to contain potential cooling water leaks and prevent slipping hazards on the production floor. Stainless steel containment trays will be installed beneath all high-pressure cooling water supply and return lines on Lines A and B. Drain plugs will allow for safe disposal of accumulated water. This engineering control provides a barrier against environmental contamination and reduces slip/trip hazards associated with water spray events.

name: Establish Post-Maintenance Equipment Inspection Checklist
description: Maintenance technicians must complete a standardized post-work inspection checklist before leaving any work area, including proper storage of all hoses, cables, and tools in designated locations. The checklist will be signed off by both the technician and the area supervisor. This administrative control ensures that maintenance activities do not create new hazards for material handlers and establishes accountability for housekeeping. Implementation will include training for all maintenance staff on the checklist requirements.

name: Install Permanent Cable Management System in Regrind Department
description: Engineering control solution to eliminate trip hazards from hoses and cables in the materials handling pathways. Overhead cable tray system will be installed along all main aisles with clearly marked attachment points and storage zones for all pneumatic hoses, electrical cords, and instrumentation cables. Hoses will be color-coded by function. The system will include regular inspection points and maintenance personnel will be trained on proper storage. This eliminates the opportunity for hoses to be left across walkways.

name: Upgrade to High-Temperature Silicone Heat-Resistant Gloves
description: PPE upgrade to provide enhanced protection against thermal burns during part removal operations. Current cotton-blend gloves will be replaced with silicone-coated gloves rated for continuous contact with surfaces up to 250°C. These gloves maintain dexterity while providing superior thermal insulation. All Composite Materials Processing operators will receive new gloves and training on proper fit and inspection before each use. This PPE improvement directly reduces burn risk during hot-part handling activities.

name: Install Automated Part Cooling Tunnel with Mechanical Removal
description: Engineering control to reduce manual contact with hot plastic components. A new automated cooling tunnel will be installed at the exit of the injection molding station, where parts pass through controlled cooling air jets to reduce surface temperature from 65°C to below 40°C before entering the manual removal station. Parts will then be automatically ejected onto a conveyor belt, minimizing the need for direct hand contact with hot surfaces. This substitution of manual handling with automated mechanical removal significantly reduces burn exposure for all operators on Line C.

name: Implement Automated Deburring Station
description: Install a dedicated automated deburring and edge-finishing station between injection molding lines and assembly operations. This engineering control will eliminate manual handling of sharp edges on freshly molded parts. The station will utilize pneumatic edge-finishing tools with integrated vacuum collection to safely remove all sharp edges, flash, and burrs before parts reach quality control inspection. Implementation will include operator training on the new equipment and integration into the production workflow to prevent bottlenecks.

name: Establish Mandatory Cut-Resistant Glove Protocol
description: Implement a requirement for all assembly operators handling freshly molded parts to wear cut-resistant gloves rated ANSI A4 or higher. Conduct a hazard assessment to identify all assembly stations with sharp part handling. Purchase and distribute appropriate cut-resistant gloves to all affected employees and supervisors. Include cut-resistant glove usage and inspection in the weekly safety checklist. Provide initial training and refresher training every six months to ensure proper donning, doffing, and inspection of gloves.

name: Enhanced Quality Control Flagging System
description: Implement a color-coded labeling and segregation system for parts that require additional finishing operations. Parts with incomplete deburring will be labeled with red flags and physically separated from completed parts using dedicated containers. Establish a mandatory QC verification step where documentation must confirm deburring completion before parts advance to assembly. Train all quality control personnel and assembly supervisors on the new flagging protocol. Review system effectiveness monthly during JHSC meetings.

name: Mandatory LOTO for All Maintenance Activities
description: Establish a zero-tolerance policy requiring complete Lockout/Tagout procedures for every maintenance activity, regardless of duration or perceived hazard level. Update the facility LOTO procedure to include a pre-work verification checklist that must be signed by both the maintenance technician and a supervisor. All maintenance personnel will complete LOTO recertification training within 30 days. Implement a daily pre-shift briefing in the Regrind Department to review active maintenance zones and associated LOTO points. Install clearly visible LOTO point signage at the regrind hopper and all adjacent equipment.

name: Install Secondary Isolation Valve with Blind Flange
description: Install an additional isolation ball valve with a quick-disconnecting blind flange on the steam line adjacent to the regrind hopper discharge area. This engineering control provides redundant isolation capability and prevents accidental steam release even if the primary valve is not properly closed. The blind flange physically blocks steam flow when installed. Include installation of pressure relief signage and update all equipment schematics to show the new secondary isolation point. Train all regrind operators on the location and proper use of the secondary valve.

name: Establish Rapid-Response Spill Cleanup Protocol
description: Create a documented spill response procedure requiring immediate notification to maintenance and warehouse supervision when any hydraulic fluid, oil, or chemical spills are observed. Provide spill cleanup kits (absorbent pads, wet floor signs, cleanup supplies) at three strategic locations within the warehouse and regrind areas. Train all warehouse and night shift personnel on proper spill cleanup and hazard signage placement. Establish a maximum 30-minute response time for spill cleanup, with escalation procedures if response is delayed. Include spill response drills in monthly safety meetings.

name: Forklift Charger Maintenance Schedule and Leak Prevention
description: Implement a preventive maintenance schedule for the forklift charging station including monthly inspection of all hydraulic connections, hose assemblies, and quick-disconnect couplers. Schedule immediate replacement of any connections showing signs of wear, corrosion, or seepage. Install a secondary containment tray beneath the charging station to capture any potential leaks. Create a maintenance checklist that includes pressure testing of hydraulic lines annually. Assign responsibility for daily visual inspection to the night shift supervisor.

name: Implement Load Securing and Rack Stability Audit
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all storage racks in Raw Materials Warehouse to identify improperly stacked materials and implement mandatory load securing standards. All pallets must be secured with polyester straps rated for minimum 1000-pound load capacity. Establish monthly compliance inspections with photographic documentation. Train all material handlers on proper stacking heights (maximum 6 pallets) and weight distribution. Install load capacity placards on each rack section indicating maximum weight limits. This engineering and administrative control will eliminate the root cause of falling loads and prevent future near-miss incidents.

name: Mandatory Refresher Training on Warehouse Safety Procedures
description: Conduct mandatory 2-hour refresher training for all 12 warehouse and material handling personnel covering proper load securing, aisle clearance standards, and hazard recognition. Training will include case study analysis of this incident to reinforce consequences of non-compliance. Implement competency assessment requiring 90% minimum score before return to full duties. Document all training with sign-off from participants and supervisors. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand and follow proper procedures.

name: Replace All Pneumatic Regulators and Implement Maintenance Schedule Overhaul
description: Immediately replace all 32 pneumatic pressure regulators across injection molding lines with new units meeting NFPA standards for industrial duty cycles. Establish and enforce a computerized preventive maintenance management system (CMMS) with automatic email alerts 30 days before each replacement interval. Implement quarterly audits of the CMMS to verify no missed maintenance cycles. Update all technician logbooks to include pressure relief valve inspection protocols at each service interval. This engineering control eliminates equipment failure by replacing worn components and implementing administrative tracking to prevent future lapses.

name: Install Secondary Pressure Relief Guards and Post-Failure Inspection Protocol
description: Install reinforced polycarbonate guards around all pneumatic regulators and pressure relief points to redirect any dislodged components away from operator stations. Mount audible warning beepers on regulators that detect pressure anomalies and alert operators within 30 seconds of failure initiation. Develop post-maintenance inspection checklist requiring technicians to pressurize systems and listen for anomalous sounds with sonic detection tools. This engineering control provides passive protection and enables early detection of failing components before catastrophic release occurs.

name: Install Automated Robotic Arm Firmware Backup and Verification System
description: Implement automated firmware backup protocols that create read-only copies of all robot controller parameters every 4 hours to secure cloud storage with version control. Establish pre-operation firmware verification routines that compare current controller state against last validated backup before each shift begins, with automatic rollback capability if corruption is detected. Configure the robot to enter safe state (all arms retracted, all motion halted) if any firmware anomalies are detected. This engineering and administrative control prevents controller corruption from causing erratic robotic motion and ensures system reliability.

name: Install Automated Part Ejection System
description: Replace manual part removal with pneumatic ejector pins on all composite material presses in UNIT-005. This engineering control eliminates the need for operators to reach into the mold compression zone post-cycle, removing the hazard entirely. The system will automatically eject parts as soon as the mold opens, with pressure-sensitive guards preventing any re-engagement during ejection. Installation to be completed within 45 days. Expected outcome: 100% elimination of hand-in-mold hazard during part removal operations.

name: Implement Enhanced PPE Requirements for Assembly Operations
description: Mandate cut-resistant Level 5 sleeves (Kevlar-lined) and heat-resistant gloves (rated to 200°C) for all assembly operators working with parts that exceed 100°C. Conduct fitting sessions and provide 2-hour training on proper use and care. Update the standard operating procedure to document this requirement. While a lower-priority control, this provides interim protection while the automated ejection system is being installed and operational.

name: Conduct LOTO and Machine Guarding Refresher Training
description: Deliver a mandatory 3-hour training session to all 24 assembly operators on proper Lockout/Tagout procedures, mold safety features, and recognition of automatic cycle hazards. Training to include video review of incident sequence and near-miss scenarios. Implement quarterly refresher training. Competency assessment required with 100% pass rate before resuming duties on compression molding equipment.

name: Install Dual Redundant Temperature Control System on Resin Dryers
description: Retrofit all three composite material resin dryers (CTD-450, CTD-400, CTD-300) with independent backup thermostats and temperature monitoring with automatic shutoff at 95°C and alarm at 90°C. Install real-time digital display panels visible to operators. This engineering control provides immediate hazard detection and prevents future overheating incidents. Add automatic alert to supervisor smartphones if temperature exceeds 85°C. Implementation to be completed within 60 days with validation testing.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation System with Completion Verification
description: Create a documented preventive maintenance protocol requiring that ventilation filter changes in UNIT-015 must be followed by a 30-minute operational test and checklist sign-off before normal operations resume. Maintenance records to be posted on unit and logged in the facility management system. Assign responsibility to a specific technician for weekly verification that all maintenance work has included completion steps. This administrative control ensures maintenance gaps do not leave the facility vulnerable to vapor accumulation.

name: Implement Daily Operator Equipment Inspection Checklist
description: Develop and laminate a simple 2-minute daily inspection checklist for all UNIT-015 operators to complete before shift start. Include items: visual inspection of dryer vents, smell test for burning odors, verification that emergency shutdown button is accessible and labeled, and confirmation that ventilation ducts are not obstructed. Checklist to be signed and dated daily. Train all operators with competency verification. This administrative control creates early detection capability among frontline staff.

name: Install Mechanical Lift Assist Equipment at Packaging Station
description: Install motorized lifting tables and mechanical arm assists at the packaging station to reduce manual lifting of loads exceeding 20 kg. These devices will be calibrated for standard carton weights used in composite materials. Training will be provided to all packaging staff on proper use and maintenance. The solution eliminates the primary hazard by removing the need for manual heavy lifting, directly addressing the root cause of Ana's injury.

name: Implement Mandatory Ergonomic Assessment and Refresher Training
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessments for all packaging and material handling staff. Develop role-specific training modules covering proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, and workstation adjustment. Training sessions will be conducted quarterly with competency verification. Materials will be available in both French and English to accommodate the bilingual workforce.

name: Secure All Storage Racks to Building Structure
description: Install heavy-duty bolted anchors to secure all storage racks in the equipment storage room and maintenance workshop to the concrete wall and floor structures. This engineering control eliminates the risk of rack tipping or shifting. All racks will be professionally assessed for stability before and after installation. Anti-slip mats will be placed under all storage shelves.

name: Implement Storage Rack Load Distribution and Securing Standards
description: Establish and post clear labeling on all storage racks indicating maximum load capacity per shelf and weight distribution requirements. Implement a system requiring all items to be secured with appropriate straps or clips. Conduct weekly visual inspections for compliance. Training will be mandatory for all staff accessing storage areas.

name: Install Pressure Relief Valves and Automated Shutdown Systems
description: Install redundant pressure relief valves set at 5 bar on all mold cooling systems to prevent excessive pressure buildup. Implement automated shutdown systems that disengage the cooling pump when system pressure exceeds safe thresholds. Install pressure gauges visible to operators on all molding lines to enable real-time monitoring. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of sudden high-pressure fluid release.

name: Implement Lockout/Tagout Procedure for Cooling System Maintenance
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive LOTO procedure requiring all cooling systems to be depressurized and isolated before any manual connection work. Install quick-disconnect couplings with integrated check valves to prevent fluid backflow. Provide LOTO training certification for all operators and maintenance staff working with injection molding equipment. Procedures will be posted at each molding line in both French and English.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Thermal Protection
description: Provide all injection molding operators with enhanced protective gear including fire-resistant sleeves, aluminized heat-reflective aprons, and safety goggles with thermal protection.
