Create ergonomic assessment checklists for each workstation. Schedule follow-up assessments with the occupational health nurse at 30, 60, and 90 days post-implementation.

name: Install Automated Pressure Monitoring System with Alert Protocol
description: Implement an automated hydraulic system monitoring device on all injection molding machines that continuously tracks pressure levels and immediately triggers an audible alarm and visual alert if pressure exceeds 10 PSI during idle/maintenance mode. Integrate the system with the facility's SCADA platform to create automatic alert notifications to the maintenance team. Each machine will have a laminated quick-reference card showing normal vs. abnormal pressure readings. Conduct training sessions for all maintenance staff on interpreting system alerts and emergency response procedures. This engineering control will prevent unexpected equipment movement and potential crush injuries.

name: Enhance LOTO Procedures and Verification Protocol
description: Revise the Lockout/Tagout procedures to include a mandatory pre-maintenance pressure verification step requiring technicians to document hydraulic system pressure readings on a standardized form before initiating any maintenance work. Implement a peer verification system where a second qualified technician must visually confirm proper lockout placement and pressure readings before work begins. Create a digital work permit system that logs all LOTO activities with timestamps and employee acknowledgments. Conduct comprehensive LOTO retraining for all 15 maintenance staff members within 2 weeks, with emphasis on pressure system anomalies and emergency response protocols.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Develop a quarterly preventative maintenance schedule specifically focused on hydraulic system integrity. Partner with the equipment supplier to perform pressure system audits on all 12 injection molding machines. Replace aging pressure relief valves and seals proactively before failures occur. Create a maintenance tracking database that flags machines with recurring pressure anomalies for deeper investigation. This administrative and engineering control measure will reduce the likelihood of pressure-related near-misses and extend equipment life.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Industrial Ovens
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all heat treatment equipment with quarterly inspections and semi-annual full service intervals. Replace all hydraulic pressure relief valves on ovens regardless of age as part of an immediate equipment safety retrofit. Assign maintenance tracking through the new predictive maintenance software system to generate automated work orders. This addresses the root cause of deferred maintenance and ensures critical safety components are monitored before failure. Expected outcome: elimination of similar equipment failures within 12 months.

name: Upgrade Finished Goods Storage Area Containment
description: Install protective barriers and heat-resistant storage racks in the Post-Processing unit to physically separate finished inventory from potential discharge zones of pressure release systems. Relocate all finished component storage carts to designated zones at minimum 15 feet from all heat-generating equipment. Paint clear boundary lines and install warning signage. This engineering control prevents damage to finished goods from any future equipment malfunction in the area. Expected outcome: protection of high-value finished inventory during any foreseeable equipment discharge event.

name: Implement Mandatory Deburring Process Lock for Medical Device Components
description: Establish a hard stop in the production workflow that prevents any medical device housing from advancing to quality control unless it has completed and been verified as passing through the deburring station. This will be enforced through both physical process controls (barcode scanning at deburr station) and digital work order management. Train all production supervisors and line operators that bypassing deburring for any reason is a terminable offense. This engineering and administrative control ensures ISO 13485 compliance and eliminates sharp edge hazards before components reach inspection areas.

name: Revise Production Line Speed Protocols with Built-in Quality Checkpoints
description: Develop and implement a new policy requiring that any increase in production line speed on molding equipment must be approved by both the Quality Supervisor and HSE Coordinator, with mandatory compensatory QC measures documented before speed adjustment. Create a decision matrix that specifies additional inspection frequency, personnel, and testing requirements for each speed increment. Establish a 72-hour trial period for all speed changes with real-time monitoring before permanent implementation. This administrative control prevents future situations where production pressure overrides quality and safety requirements.

name: Upgrade Quality Control Workbench Ergonomics and Safety Design
description: Retrofit all QC inspection workbenches with rounded edge guards, non-slip work surfaces, and adjustable lighting to reduce employee reach requirements and improve component visibility. Provide anti-laceration gloves (ANSI A3 rated) to all QC personnel and make wearing them mandatory when handling any finished components, particularly polycarbonate and nylon products that can have sharp edges. Redesign the component staging area to minimize reaching across benches. These engineering and PPE controls reduce laceration hazards during quality inspection activities.

name: Implement Glove Replacement Protocol and PPE Inspection System
description: Establish a mandatory glove replacement schedule requiring new nitrile gloves every 60 minutes during solvent-intensive cleaning operations, or immediately upon visible damage. Create a visual inspection checklist that maintenance technicians must complete before starting any mold cleaning work. Supply high-visibility glove bins at each mold station with quantity tracking to ensure adequate stock. Train all personnel that using damaged PPE is grounds for immediate work stoppage. This administrative control ensures PPE maintains protective integrity during chemical handling tasks.

name: Upgrade Solvent Dispensing Equipment with Spill Prevention
description: Replace all open-pour acetone containers with automated pump dispensing systems that deliver exact measured quantities of solvent to a secondary containment tray. This eliminates large bulk containers and reduces splash exposure during dispensing. Install secondary containment trays under all solvent application stations sized to hold 150% of maximum single-use volume. Provide absorbent pads rated for acetone in dispensing areas. These engineering controls reduce the likelihood and volume of accidental solvent contact with skin during routine maintenance work.

name: Implement Quarterly Drum Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a formal quarterly inspection schedule for all chemical storage drums to identify structural defects before failure. All drums will be visually inspected for cracks, corrosion, and seam integrity. Defective drums will be immediately transferred to secondary containment and marked for disposal. Training will be provided to all chemical handlers on inspection procedures and documentation requirements. This measure directly addresses the root cause of premature drum failure by catching defects early.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment System
description: Install new, larger secondary containment vessels with improved drainage and collection capabilities throughout the chemical storage area. The current containment system was positioned too far from the spill location, delaying response. New containment will be positioned to capture leaks from all storage areas within the regrind and recycling department. The system will include integrated absorbent cartridges and quick-drain valves for faster cleanup. This engineering control eliminates the spread of future chemical spills.

name: Enhance Chemical Storage Area Ventilation
description: Upgrade the ventilation system in the chemical storage and mixing unit to provide improved air circulation and faster dissipation of chemical vapors. Install additional exhaust fans with improved HEPA filtration and secondary intake vents. This will reduce vapor concentration in the event of future spills and improve overall air quality in the storage area. Ventilation system maintenance will be scheduled monthly.

name: Mandatory Safety Interlock Restoration and Documentation
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all injection molding machines to identify any bypassed or disabled safety interlocks. All bypassed systems must be immediately restored to functional status. Implement a permanent lockable device registry that logs every safety system bypass, authorized by supervision with mandatory restoration timelines. No machine shall be placed into service without documented verification that all safety interlocks are functional. This administrative control ensures that critical safety systems cannot be circumvented without formal oversight and accountability.

name: Enhanced Lockout/Tagout Verification Procedures
description: Revise LOTO procedures to require a mandatory three-point verification protocol: initial lock placement, visual confirmation by a second qualified technician, and functional test before work begins. Implement color-coded LOTO devices specific to different machine types to prevent misidentification. Require all personnel performing machine maintenance to complete recertification on LOTO procedures within 30 days. This engineering and administrative control prevents unexpected machine operation during maintenance activities.

name: Install Automated Mold Guarding Systems
description: Install retractable safety guards on all injection molding machines that prevent hand access to mold closing areas during operation. The guards will be mechanically linked to the machine cycle and cannot be overridden. Guards will be transparent to maintain visibility while providing absolute physical protection. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of hand entrapment by physically preventing contact with moving mold components.

name: Implement Comprehensive Electrical Equipment Testing Schedule
description: Establish a mandatory annual electrical safety testing program for all power tools, extension cords, transformers, and electrical equipment in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop. Testing will include visual inspection, continuity testing, ground bond verification, and GFCI functionality assessment. All equipment will be tagged with test dates and results. Non-compliant equipment will be immediately removed from service and repaired or replaced. A computerized tracking system will maintain records and generate automated reminders for upcoming tests. This administrative control ensures ongoing electrical safety compliance.

name: Install Arc Flash Hazard Assessment and Labeling System
description: Conduct a professional arc flash hazard analysis on all electrical panels and equipment in the shop per NFPA 70E standards. Install appropriate warning labels and hazard category indicators on all electrical equipment showing arc flash boundary distances and required PPE. Provide training to all personnel on arc flash hazards and proper use of arc-rated clothing and equipment when working on energized systems. Update all LOTO and electrical maintenance procedures to include arc flash hazard protocols. This engineering and administrative control prevents serious burn injuries from electrical arc events.

name: Implement Ergonomic Workstation Redesign and Job Rotation
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessment of all injection molding part removal stations using certified ergonomist. Redesign workstations to include adjustable height work surfaces, wrist supports, and optimized component placement to reduce reach distances and repetitive motions. Implement mandatory job rotation program requiring operators to switch between tasks every 2 hours to reduce cumulative strain. Establish baseline ergonomic standards for all assembly and finishing operations and audit compliance monthly.

name: Mandatory Break and Stretching Program
description: Establish and enforce mandatory 10-minute micro-break intervals every 2 hours for repetitive motion tasks. Develop and deliver on-site stretching and ergonomic exercises training to all production operators. Create visual reminders and posted stretch guides at all workstations. Track break compliance through electronic time clocking at workstation breaks to ensure adherence and gather data on program effectiveness.

name: Early Symptom Reporting and Occupational Health Monitoring
description: Establish confidential symptom reporting system where employees can report pain, discomfort, or early signs of repetitive strain injuries without fear of reassignment or retaliation. Implement quarterly occupational health screening and pre-placement ergonomic assessments. Create fast-track access to occupational health assessment when symptoms are reported. Educate all supervisors and employees on early warning signs of RSI and importance of immediate reporting.

name: Implement Comprehensive Lifting Equipment Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Establish and enforce mandatory preventive maintenance schedule for all lifting equipment including overhead cranes, hoists, and chain falls. Schedule inspections every 6 months as per ASME B30.16 standards with documented certification. Implement digital maintenance tracking system with automatic alerts for upcoming inspections. Designate trained personnel to perform monthly visual inspections and report any anomalies. Replace aged lifting components proactively based on manufacturer recommendations regardless of apparent condition.

name: Install Load Limiting Devices and Safety Features
description: Retrofit all overhead cranes with load limiting devices (overload protection systems) that prevent operation if load exceeds safe working load. Install secondary safety devices including dual-hook redundancy systems on critical lifting points. Add proximity sensors and audible alarms to warn personnel when loads are being positioned overhead. Install load monitoring devices that display current load weight to operators in real-time.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays at Chemical Workstations
description: Implement secondary containment trays beneath all chemical transfer workstations in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. Each tray will be sized to contain 110% of the largest container being transferred. This engineering control eliminates the risk of chemicals reaching the floor and spreading to other areas. Training will be provided to all personnel on proper placement and regular inspection of containment trays.

name: Implement Mandatory Valve Fastening Verification Protocol
description: Develop and enforce a checklist-based procedure requiring double-verification of all chemical container valve fittings before and after use. Supervisors will conduct weekly audits of chemical storage practices. This administrative control ensures proper containment procedures are consistently followed, reducing the likelihood of accidental spills from loose connections.

name: Upgrade Chemical Handling PPE Requirements
description: All personnel working in the Chemical Storage area will now be required to wear chemical-resistant aprons, closed-toe shoes with chemical-resistant coating, and chemical splash goggles during all transfer operations. Additional nitrile gloves rated for solvent exposure will be provided. This PPE enhancement provides immediate protection during chemical handling operations.

name: Redesign Mold Ejection System with Enhanced Safety Features
description: Engineering will collaborate with mold design team to redesign the ejection system for Line B molds with improved mechanical features: increased clearance between components and guide rails, improved guide rail geometry, and addition of mechanical stops to prevent over-travel. All new molds will be tested in a controlled environment before deployment. This engineering control eliminates the physical binding condition that caused the injury.

name: Implement Comprehensive Machine Binding Recognition Training
description: Mandatory training program for all Injection Molding Line B operators on recognizing and safely responding to mechanical binding conditions. Training includes visual and auditory warning signs, proper emergency response procedures, and hands-on practice with simulator molds. Sessions will be conducted monthly with refresher training quarterly. This administrative control ensures operators can identify and respond to binding situations before injury occurs.

name: Install Automated Mold Position Sensors with Interlock System
description: Install pressure and position sensors on all injection molding machines in Line B that feed data to a safety interlock system. If binding or irregular mold motion is detected, the system will automatically trigger emergency stop and prevent cycle advancement. This engineering control provides redundant safety protection independent of operator response.

name: Provision of Heat-Resistant PPE at All Inspection Stations
description: Supply high-temperature nitrile-coated gloves (rated to 200°C) and long-sleeved protective sleeves at every post-processing inspection workstation. Inventory will be checked weekly and replaced as needed. Clear signage will indicate mandatory use of PPE when handling components within 1 hour of removal from ovens. This PPE control provides immediate protection for all personnel handling hot materials.

name: Install Automated Cooling Conveyors with Temperature Monitoring
description: Implement automated cooling conveyors with integrated temperature sensors that prevent component removal until surface temperature drops below 60°C. This eliminates the need for direct hand contact with hot materials immediately after removal from the oven, providing an engineering control that removes the hazard.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Injection Molding Equipment
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program requiring quarterly calibration and testing of all safety interlocks and proximity sensors on injection molding lines. All machines will be logged in a tracking system with documented inspection dates. Technicians will be trained to identify worn or malfunctioning sensors before they cause incidents. This addresses the root cause of the unexpected machine cycling and ensures early detection of safety system failures.

name: Mandate Enhanced PPE for Injection Molding Operations
description: Require all injection molding operators and maintenance personnel to wear cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 rated) and protective sleeves during machine adjustments and inspections. PPE will be provided at no cost to employees and proper fit will be verified during quarterly safety refresher training. This provides an additional barrier against hand injuries from moving machinery until engineering controls are fully optimized.

name: Implement Load Securing and Verification System at Shipping Dock
description: Install a weighing scale at the dock entrance with digital display and load limit alerts set to 85% of maximum forklift capacity. All incoming pallet loads must be weighed and certified before stacking. Develop written procedures requiring employees to use load straps and corner protectors for all multi-pallet stacks. Train all material handlers on proper weight distribution and load configuration. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of load instability and prevents future tip-over incidents.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Forklift Operator Retraining Program
description: Mandate refresher certification for all forklift operators, focusing on load dynamics, stability triangles, and emergency dismounting procedures. Include practical exercises on identifying unstable loads and proper techniques for safe exit from equipment. Sessions will be held in groups of 5-6 operators with hands-on assessment. This administrative control ensures operators can recognize hazardous conditions and respond appropriately to prevent injuries.

name: Install Anti-Slip Surfaces and Handrails on Forklift Access Points
description: Apply industrial-grade anti-slip tape to all forklift running boards and platforms. Install grab handles at entry and exit points with a minimum diameter of 1.25 inches. Ensure all surfaces are maintained regularly to prevent deterioration. This engineering control reduces the risk of slips and falls during normal forklift operations.

name: Implement Chemical Drum Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly inspection protocol for all chemical drums and coupling hardware with a maximum aging threshold of 24 months before replacement. All drums will be visually inspected for corrosion, structural integrity, and valve condition. A detailed log will track inspection dates and maintenance actions. Procurement will source only drums with corrosion-resistant stainless steel couplings rated for acetone compatibility. This eliminates the root cause of coupling failure through substitution and preventive maintenance.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Area with Engineered Containment and Drainage Control
description: Install a secondary containment berm with 110% capacity relative to the largest stored container, lined with impermeable material. Install diversion berms around storm drain inlets to prevent direct chemical migration. Add absorbent storage stations at strategic locations with clear signage. Ensure all floor drains connect to wastewater treatment rather than storm system. Conduct monthly integrity checks of containment systems. This engineering control prevents environmental discharge of chemical spills.

name: Enhance Chemical Handling Training and Emergency Response Procedures
description: Develop comprehensive training module covering proper drum handling, coupling inspection, spill response procedures, and emergency evacuation protocols. All employees working in the chemical storage area must complete certification before unsupervised work. Conduct monthly drill exercises simulating various spill scenarios with timed response metrics. Update emergency response procedures and post them visibly at all chemical work stations with QR codes linking to digital resources.

name: Implement Digital Preventive Maintenance System with Automatic Alerts
description: Deploy a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) to track all equipment maintenance schedules across the 32 injection molding machines. The system will generate automatic alerts 7 days before maintenance is due, ensure no service intervals exceed manufacturer specifications, and create audit trails of all completed work. Integrate real-time pressure monitoring sensors on all machines with pressure relief valves to immediately alert operators and maintenance staff of abnormal readings. This eliminates reliance on manual tracking and ensures hydraulic systems are serviced before critical failures occur.

name: Install Pressure Relief Valve Temperature and Flow Monitoring
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with inline temperature sensors and flow meters on hydraulic pressure relief valve discharge lines. Install visual and auditory warning systems that alert operators when pressure exceeds safe thresholds or temperature rises abnormally. Configure emergency shutdown protocols to automatically stop machine operation if pressure relief valve malfunction is detected. Include monthly verification testing of relief valve functionality as part of standard shift startup procedures.

name: Enhance Employee Burn Injury Prevention Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training on thermal burn hazards specific to hydraulic systems in injection molding operations. Training will include recognition of high-temperature fluid risks, proper use of heat-resistant protective equipment, emergency response procedures, and first aid for thermal burns. Conduct quarterly refresher sessions with all production operators on equipment with pressurized hydraulic systems. Create laminated hazard placards at each machine showing pressurized fluid temperatures and warning symbols.

name: Install Heavy-Duty Storage Rack Safety Barriers and Load Limiters
description: Replace existing storage racks in the Shipping and Receiving Dock with warehouse-grade racking systems equipped with integral load limiters and safety bars. Install physical guardrails and debris containment netting on all racks taller than 1.5 meters to prevent materials from falling. Implement load capacity labels clearly visible on each rack tier indicating maximum weight per level. Install anti-tip bracing on all racks to ensure structural stability even with uneven loading. Include annual professional rack inspection and certification by qualified warehouse engineering firms.

name: Develop and Enforce Material Stacking Standard Operating Procedures
description: Create detailed written procedures for proper material stacking in all warehouse areas, specifying maximum stack heights, stacking patterns, weight distribution requirements, and visual inspection protocols. Post laminated SOP placards at all storage locations with diagrams and maximum load information. Conduct mandatory hands-on training for all warehouse staff during their next scheduled shift, with competency verification by the warehouse supervisor. Implement a monthly audit checklist for supervisors to verify compliance with stacking procedures and corrective action for violations.

name: Install Forced Ventilation System with Pre-Maintenance Purge Capability
description: Install a dedicated forced-air ventilation system for all resin dryer and material preparation equipment. The system will include an automated 30-minute pre-maintenance purge cycle that evacuates volatile compounds before technicians access internal chambers. Install carbon-filtered ductwork with real-time vapor concentration sensors (photoionization detectors) that must show readings below safe exposure limits before maintenance can proceed. Include emergency shut-off valves and HVAC interlocks to prevent equipment operation during maintenance. Vent all exhaust through HEPA and carbon filtration units prior to discharge to outdoor environment.

name: Implement Confined Space Entry Procedures and Respiratory Protection Program
description: Establish formal Confined Space Entry Program compliant with Quebec occupational health regulations for all internal cavities of resin dryers and material preparation equipment. Mandate completion of Confined Space Entry certification training for all maintenance personnel before they perform internal equipment maintenance. Require continuous atmospheric monitoring using calibrated air quality sensors before and during all equipment maintenance. Provide and enforce use of SCBA (Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus) units for any work in chemical-exposed environments. Create a maintenance permit system requiring supervisor authorization and documented pre-work safety briefings.

name: Provide Enhanced Respiratory Protection Equipment and Training
description: Replace all standard N95 masks in the maintenance department with NIOSH-approved organic vapor cartridge respirators (P100 rated). Conduct formal respirator fit-testing for all maintenance staff and establish a mandatory annual re-certification program. Issue personal respirator kits to each technician for use during chemical exposure work. Create a respiratory hazard identification guide showing which tasks require respirators and which cartridge types are appropriate. Implement monthly equipment checks and cartridge replacement protocols with documented inventory tracking.

name: Implement Mandatory Task Rotation Program
description: Establish a structured task rotation system on all injection molding lines requiring operators to rotate between part removal, machine monitoring, and material handling duties every 90 minutes. This administrative control addresses the root cause of repetitive strain by varying muscle groups used. Line supervisors will track rotation compliance through production logs. The program includes mandatory 10-minute rest breaks every 2 hours with ergonomic stretching exercises. Expected outcome: 70% reduction in repetitive strain injuries within 6 months.

name: Install Semi-Automated Part Removal Assists
description: Engineer and install mechanical assist devices on Lines B, C, and D to reduce manual force required for part extraction by 60%. This includes pneumatic grip assists and angled part presentation trays to minimize wrist torque. These engineering controls directly eliminate the hazardous repetitive motion component of the task. Installation will be coordinated with maintenance during planned production downtime. Expected outcome: Near-elimination of carpal tunnel-related incidents.

name: Enhanced Ergonomic Training and Wrist Support
description: Conduct mandatory re-training for all production operators on proper ergonomic techniques for part removal, including hand positioning, grip pressure, and movement patterns that minimize strain. Provide high-quality ergonomic wrist braces to all operators working on molding lines. This administrative and PPE control provides immediate risk mitigation while engineering solutions are implemented.

name: Reduce Storage Rack Load Capacity and Install Load Indicators
description: Immediately reduce the rated load on all material storage racks in the warehouse by 25% to create a safety margin. Install highly visible load capacity placards on each rack tier. Install load pins that visibly deform when weight limits are approached. This engineering control prevents overloading by making visible the safe load capacity. Expected outcome: Elimination of overload conditions and visual feedback system for warehouse staff.

name: Implement Weekly Rack Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish a formal weekly inspection routine for all storage racks conducted by maintenance personnel, documenting structural integrity, bolt tightness, and visible deformation. Create a compliance checklist and maintenance log. Non-compliant racks will be taken out of service immediately. This administrative control ensures early detection of rack deterioration before catastrophic failure occurs.

name: Comprehensive Electrical Panel Labeling and Safety Upgrade
description: Immediately audit all electrical panels and distribution equipment throughout the facility. Install high-visibility color-coded labeling for all live conductors (red for 480V, yellow for 240V, green for ground). Install arc flash warning labels with appropriate hazard ratings on all panels exceeding 50V. This engineering control ensures all hazardous energies are clearly communicated. Expected outcome: 100% clear identification of all energized components.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Audit and Refresher Training
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all maintenance procedures to ensure LOTO is applied before any work on electrical systems. Require all maintenance personnel to complete refresher LOTO training with certification within 30 days. Establish a work permit system requiring documented LOTO verification before electrical maintenance begins. This administrative control strengthens the control system preventing unexpected energization.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring and Alarm System on Injection Molding Lines
description: Implement automatic temperature monitoring sensors on all injection molding machine barrels with high-temperature alarm thresholds set 10°C below maximum safe operating temperature. The system will trigger audible and visual alerts at the operator workstation and send notifications to production supervisors. Install pressure relief valve inspection program with quarterly testing. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of uncontrolled temperature and pressure escalation by providing real-time detection and early warning before dangerous conditions develop.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE and Procedure Training
description: Require all production operators to wear ANSI-certified heat-resistant gloves rated for 350°C exposure and flame-resistant sleeves during all material loading operations. Conduct mandatory 2-hour training session for all shift operators covering thermal hazard recognition, proper PPE donning/doffing, emergency response procedures, and operation of emergency cooling stations. Implement monthly refresher training and competency assessments. Document training completion and maintain records for CNESST compliance.

name: Enhanced Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Thermal Equipment
description: Develop and implement a monthly preventive maintenance protocol for all injection molding machine temperature control systems, including thermostat calibration checks, heating element inspection, and pressure relief valve functionality testing. Assign maintenance technician Christian Gosselin to coordinate quarterly deep maintenance cycles. Maintain detailed maintenance logs and establish metrics to track equipment performance trends. This administrative control ensures early detection of equipment degradation before failures occur.

name: Implement Component Deburring and Edge Finishing Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory deburring and edge finishing step in the assembly preparation process before components reach assembly operators. All plastic parts will be inspected and processed through a vibratory tumbler with fine media to smooth sharp edges and burrs. Quality Control Manager Isabelle Tremblay will validate this process through random sampling of components. Update assembly work instructions to require tactile and visual inspection of all components for sharp edges prior to assembly. This engineering control eliminates the hazard source by removing sharp edges at the material level.

name: Mandatory Lockout/Tagout Enforcement and Equipment Isolation
description: Implement strict lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures requiring all equipment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility to be de-energized, locked, and tagged before any internal cleaning or maintenance work begins. Install physical lockout points on all tank internal equipment with isolation valves. Require written LOTO permits signed by both the operator and supervisor before any internal tank work. Conduct immediate retraining for all night shift workers on LOTO compliance with competency verification. André Paradis will conduct weekly audits of LOTO compliance for 90 days. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the hazard of unexpected equipment activation and unsecured sharp edges.

name: Pre-Entry Atmospheric Testing and Confined Space Program
description: Develop and implement a confined space entry program in compliance with CNESST regulations for the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. All tank cleaning operations will require pre-entry atmospheric testing for oxygen levels, combustible gases, and hydrogen sulfide with documented test results. Implement a permit system requiring supervisor approval and atmospheric clearance certification before any entry. Provide all night shift operators with certified confined space entry training and respiratory protection fit testing. Install signage and engineering controls to prevent unauthorized entry. This administrative control ensures safe conditions before employees enter chemical storage areas.

name: Equipment Interior Inspection and Hazard Elimination
description: Conduct a comprehensive internal inspection of all mixing tanks and chemical storage vessels to identify and eliminate sharp edges, protruding fasteners, and unsecured internal equipment. Install protective guards or smooth coverings over any unavoidable sharp surfaces. Repair or replace any damaged internal equipment components. Establish a quarterly re-inspection protocol to ensure ongoing hazard control. This engineering control removes the source hazard by eliminating sharp contact surfaces inside work areas.

name: Install Machine Interlock Safety Guards on Discharge Zone
description: Design and install mechanical safety guards with interlock switches on all injection molding machine discharge chutes. The guards must prevent access to rotating mechanisms and trigger automatic cycle shutdown when opened. Install guards meeting ISO 14120 and RSST Article 2148 standards. Retrofit all 12 production line machines within 30 days. This primary engineering control eliminates the pinch point hazard by preventing direct access to dangerous moving parts.

name: Implement Maintenance Mode Lockout System with Dual Authorization
description: Install a maintenance mode system requiring two independent authorizations before automatic machine cycling is permitted. When activated, maintenance mode must lock out all automatic cycling functions and display active warning signals. Update LOTO procedures to mandate maintenance mode activation before any internal machine access. Conduct refresher training for all machine operators and setters on lockout/tagout compliance. This administrative and engineering control prevents unexpected machine startup during cleaning operations.

name: Revise Hopper Cleaning Procedures with Long-Reach Tools
description: Modify cleaning procedures to eliminate direct hand access to discharge zones. Provide specialized long-reach cleaning tools (minimum 1.5 meters) with remote actuation capability. Require all hopper blockage removal to use mechanical tools rather than manual extraction. Update work instructions and conduct mandatory training for all production personnel. Implement monthly procedure audits and observation cycles. This substitution control replaces the hazardous direct-contact method with safer mechanical alternatives.

name: Implement Preventive Ventilation Filter Replacement Schedule
description: Establish a mandatory preventive maintenance schedule for all ventilation system filters based on manufacturer specifications and operational load. Replace filters every 30 days in high-dust production areas (Injection Molding Lines, Assembly) and every 45 days in lower-exposure areas. Maintain detailed logs of all filter replacements. Conduct quarterly air quality testing in Assembly and Finishing areas to verify system effectiveness. Chemical Safety Officer will oversee compliance and maintain records.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Monitoring and Alerts
description: Install differential pressure sensors on all primary ventilation lines that trigger visual and audible alarms when filter clogging exceeds safe thresholds. Implement a dashboard system accessible to shift supervisors that displays real-time ventilation status. Train all shift leads on alarm response procedures. Include ventilation system status in daily safety briefings. System will automatically log alert events for trend analysis.

name: Resin Dryer Comprehensive Maintenance and Sensor Calibration
description: Conduct full preventive maintenance on all resin dryers including thermostat sensor inspection, calibration, and secure remounting. Test all thermal safety cutoff switches to ensure proper engagement at 5°C above maximum operating temperature. Replace all aging thermostat sensors with newer redundant sensor systems that provide backup temperature monitoring. Document all maintenance work and establish a quarterly recalibration schedule. Maintenance team will document baseline readings for comparison.

name: Equipment Failure Alert System and Operator Training
description: Install real-time equipment monitoring system on all critical production machinery including injection molding lines and dryers. System will alert operators and supervisors immediately when temperature, pressure, or other critical parameters deviate beyond safe ranges. Conduct comprehensive operator training on recognizing equipment malfunction indicators and proper emergency shutdown procedures. Include daily equipment status checks in shift handover meetings. Create visual reference guides at each machine showing normal vs. abnormal operating parameters.

name: Thermal Safety Cutoff Device Redundancy Implementation
description: Upgrade all resin dryers with dual-stage thermal protection: primary high-temperature cutoff switch plus a secondary independent thermal fuse rated at maximum safe operating temperature plus 8°C. Ensure both devices are physically independent to prevent common-mode failures. Establish monthly testing protocol for both safety devices. Create maintenance log documenting each test result and any replacements. Equipment must be tagged and tracked for compliance verification.

name: Implement Mandatory Mold Temperature Monitoring
description: Install real-time digital temperature sensors on all 32 injection molding machines to continuously monitor mold surface temperatures. Integrate alerts into the production control system that prevent part extraction until mold cooling cycle completes and temperature drops below 150°C. Require operators to confirm mold temperature readings before removing parts. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of unexpected hot surfaces by making temperature verification automatic and non-negotiable, regardless of production schedule pressures.

name: Revise Production Cycle Standards
description: Work with Production Engineering to establish minimum safe cooling cycle times for each material type and mold configuration. Document that production targets cannot override established cooling parameters. Provide supervisors with authority to refuse shortened cycles and train them on escalation procedures. Include cycle time requirements in daily production briefings and operator task cards to ensure compliance.

name: Relocate and Secure Battery Charging Station
description: Establish a dedicated, isolated charging station outside the chemical storage room, separated by a minimum of 10 meters from flammable materials storage. Install the station in a ventilated area with concrete flooring and fire-rated walls. All battery chargers must be mounted on fire-resistant racks with automatic shutoff after 8 hours. Install Class C fire extinguishers immediately adjacent to the charging station and provide staff with training on their use.

name: Install Overload Protection Devices
description: Replace all battery chargers with models incorporating integrated overload protection and thermal cutoff switches that automatically disengage power if temperature or current exceeds safe limits. Implement a preventive maintenance schedule with quarterly inspection and testing of all charging equipment. Create a log system for maintenance activities accessible to supervisory staff.

name: Implement Chemical Storage Segregation Protocol
description: Reorganize chemical storage to ensure incompatible materials are stored in separate cabinets with minimum 2-meter spacing. Create a visual inventory map identifying all flammable solvent locations and establish a monthly audit protocol. Train all material handlers on segregation requirements and conduct quarterly refresher training. Designate the Chemical Safety Officer as responsible for compliance verification.

name: Implement Drum Condition Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-use inspection procedure for all chemical drums and containers. All drums will be visually inspected for dents, cracks, corrosion, or prior damage before transfer. Damaged drums will be immediately quarantined, labeled, and segregated in a designated holding area for safe disposal. This inspection will be documented on a chemical container log maintained at the material drying and preparation room. Inspections will be conducted by trained material handlers during shift start and before any drum movement. This eliminates the transfer of compromised containers that pose rupture risks.

name: Enhanced Spill Response Training and Equipment Staging
description: Conduct comprehensive spill response retraining for all production and maintenance staff, emphasizing rapid assessment, containment hierarchy, and proper absorbent material selection based on chemical type. Pre-position spill response kits (absorbent pads, neutralizers, PPE, and collection containers) at three strategic locations: Composite Materials Area, Chemical Storage, and Main Production Building. Conduct quarterly tabletop drills simulating different spill scenarios. This reduces response time and ensures proper containment of future spills before escalation.

name: Upgrade Ventilation in Composite Materials Processing Area
description: Install additional local exhaust ventilation hoods above the epoxy resin mixing and transfer stations to capture chemical vapors at the source before they disperse into the general workspace. Integrate these hoods with the facility's existing HVAC monitoring system to track air exchange rates and filter efficiency. Conduct air quality baseline testing before and after installation to verify effectiveness. This engineering control eliminates worker exposure to solvent vapors during normal operations and chemical spill events.

name: Revise Chemical Storage Standards and Labeling
description: Implement new storage protocol requiring all solvent containers to be stored upright with caps facing up and secured with secondary containment trays beneath each container. Install clear signage on all storage cabinets showing proper storage orientation with diagrams. Establish a weekly visual inspection routine for all solvent storage areas to verify compliance and identify loose caps before incidents occur. Create a chemical inventory log with storage location codes to ensure consistent organization. This administrative control prevents accidental spills from improper storage practices.

name: Implement Enhanced Post-Processing Quality Inspection
description: Establish a mandatory secondary inspection station specifically for edge quality in post-processing. All composite and molded parts will pass through a dedicated inspection point where operators use both tactile gloves and visual inspection under LED lighting to identify and mark sharp edges. A trained quality inspector will verify compliance before parts reach assembly. This engineering control adds a physical verification step to catch defects before worker exposure. Implementation includes staff training on edge inspection techniques and documentation procedures.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Gloves at Assembly Stations
description: Issue ANSI Level 2 cut-resistant gloves to all assembly operators as PPE for handling freshly molded parts. These gloves will be available in multiple sizes and will be replaced monthly or when damage is observed. While a secondary control, this PPE measure provides additional protection during the transition period while enhanced quality checks are implemented. Training will emphasize proper glove fit and care.

name: Accelerated Equipment Replacement Program
description: Prioritize retirement of aging spare equipment components identified during investigation. Create an expedited procurement schedule to replace equipment showing signs of fatigue failure within 60 days. This eliminates the hazard by removing the deteriorating equipment entirely. Coordinate with production scheduling to ensure minimal disruption. Document all replaced components and establish baseline for newer equipment maintenance cycles.

name: Establish Hydraulic Safety Isolation Procedures
description: Implement mandatory lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures for all hydraulic maintenance work, even on spare equipment. Technicians must de-pressurize and isolate hydraulic systems before any coupling work. Provide pressure relief valve verification tools and training on safe depressurization sequences. This administrative control prevents unexpected pressurized releases during maintenance operations.

name: Install Anti-Slip Shelving with Raised Lip Guards
description: Replace or retrofit all storage racks in the warehouse with shelves featuring integrated 10cm raised lips on three sides and non-slip surface coating. This engineering control prevents parts from rolling or sliding off shelves. Install safety catch trays underneath higher shelves (above 4 feet) as secondary containment. Ensure shelving meets ANSI MH16.1 standards for industrial storage systems. Training will cover proper part placement techniques.

name: Implement Height-Restricted Part Storage Policy
description: Establish administrative procedures limiting manual retrieval of parts to shelves below 4 feet. Parts stored above this height must be retrieved using mechanical assist equipment (vacuum lifters or hoists). Heavier parts over 1.5kg must be retrieved using mechanical assistance regardless of height. Update warehouse layout diagrams and train all personnel on the new procedures. Include signage at storage areas indicating retrieval methods by part weight and location.

name: Install Thermal Warning Guard on Mold Line C
description: Install a removable thermal barrier guard around the mold temperature zone on Injection Molding Line C to physically prevent accidental contact with hot surfaces. The guard will be constructed from aluminum frame with silicone-based heat-resistant mesh (rated to 200°C) and will be positioned 15 centimeters from the mold surface. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard by preventing direct contact. The guard is designed for easy removal during legitimate maintenance requiring direct access.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE During Mold Work
description: Implement mandatory requirement for all personnel working on injection molding lines to wear ASTM F1506-rated flame-resistant sleeves and gloves rated for 200°C+ exposure. Establish a sign-out/sign-in system at each production line where heat-resistant PPE must be collected before work and returned immediately after. Conduct monthly audits to verify compliance. Update the Job Safety Analysis (JSA) for all mold maintenance tasks to explicitly require this PPE and document in employee training records.

name: Equipment Label Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a weekly cleaning schedule for all warning labels and safety decals on production equipment. Assign responsibility to the morning shift supervisor to inspect and clean labels on all active lines every Monday morning before production starts. Replace any faded, damaged, or obscured labels immediately. Create a log sheet to track label condition and replacements. This administrative control ensures critical safety information remains visible and effective throughout the equipment lifecycle.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Shelf System
description: Replace the existing chemical storage shelving system with heavy-duty industrial shelving rated for 300 kilograms per shelf. Install adjustable shelves with load-limiting brackets to prevent overloading. Reorganize chemical inventory to distribute weight evenly across shelves, maintaining maximum 120 kilograms per shelf as safety margin. Add clear weight-limit labels on each shelf. This engineering control eliminates the risk of shelf collapse and chemical spills that could cause exposure injuries.

name: Ventilation System Professional Assessment and Upgrade
description: Engage a certified HVAC engineer to perform a comprehensive air-flow analysis of the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility, measuring current ventilation rates against ASHRAE standards for chemical storage areas. Based on findings from the medical device expansion, upgrade the ventilation system to achieve minimum 12 air changes per hour as required for resin storage. Install new intake ducts, upgrade exhaust filtration, and install permanent air-velocity monitoring sensors with alert thresholds. This engineering control ensures adequate removal of potentially harmful chemical fumes.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Resin Dryers
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all resin dryer units based on manufacturer specifications and operating hours. Schedule quarterly thermostat calibration checks, semi-annual heating element inspections, and annual complete unit servicing. Implement a computerized maintenance tracking system to monitor equipment status and generate service alerts before failures occur. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance Workshop supervisor to ensure compliance. This administrative control reduces the risk of equipment malfunction-related hazards.

name: Install Real-Time Temperature Monitoring and Alert System
description: Install independent wireless temperature sensors in the Maintenance Workshop mezzanine and all chemical/equipment storage areas. Sensors will continuously monitor ambient temperature with automatic alerts if readings exceed 30°C, triggering immediate notification to maintenance and safety staff via SMS and facility dashboard. Install visual warning lights that activate when temperatures approach critical levels. This engineering control provides early warning of equipment malfunctions before they escalate to dangerous levels.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish and enforce a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all injection molding machine hydraulic systems, including annual valve service, pressure gauge calibration every 6 months, fluid analysis quarterly, and seal replacement per manufacturer specifications. Create a digital tracking system integrated with production scheduling to prevent missed maintenance windows. All maintenance work will be documented with completion certificates and pressure test results.

name: Install Secondary Pressure Relief Barriers and Warning Systems
description: Install redundant pressure relief systems and secondary containment barriers around high-pressure hydraulic connections on all 32 injection molding machines. Add automated pressure monitoring sensors with alarm thresholds set 10% below relief valve trigger points. Install audible and visual warning systems at operator stations. Implement quarterly testing of all secondary systems to ensure reliability.

name: Enhanced Operator Training on Equipment Failure Recognition
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training module for all production operators focusing on recognizing early warning signs of hydraulic system failure: unusual noises, pressure gauge fluctuations, fluid leaks, and temperature changes. Include case studies from similar incidents. Implement monthly refresher toolbox talks. All operators must pass a practical assessment demonstrating proper emergency response procedures.

name: Mandatory Forklift Load-Sensing System Calibration and Maintenance
description: Schedule immediate calibration of all electric forklift load-sensing systems by certified technicians. Establish quarterly calibration schedule and monthly functional testing protocol. Ensure all operators receive updated training on interpreting load indicator systems. Implement work order system requiring documented proof of calibration before any forklift can be operated. Non-compliant equipment will be tagged out of service.

name: Implement Load Balancing and Stacking Procedures with Visual Aids
description: Develop detailed illustrated load balancing procedures specific to different product types and weights. Install load balancing guides and weight distribution diagrams at all workstations. Require all warehouse personnel to pass certification on proper load centering and stacking techniques. Implement pre-shift checklist requiring verification of load balance before lifting. Conduct weekly audits of stacking practices with corrective feedback.

name: Implement Mandatory Hydraulic System Depressurization Protocol
description: Establish a written, step-by-step procedure requiring all hydraulic systems to be depressurized and isolated before any maintenance work begins. Create visual laminated cards posted at each injection molding line showing the depressurization sequence. Train all operators and maintenance staff on this procedure within two weeks. Conduct monthly audits to verify compliance and document each verification. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the root cause by ensuring system pressure is relieved before work begins, eliminating the hazard of pressurized fluid release.

name: Upgrade LOTO Procedures for Hydraulic Equipment
description: Revise the existing Lockout/Tagout program to include specific requirements for hydraulic systems, including pressure relief steps, line isolation, and energy dissipation procedures. Create color-coded tags for hydraulic energy sources. Conduct mandatory refresher training for all maintenance and production staff within one week. Establish a verification checklist that must be signed off before maintenance begins. This administrative control ensures that energy isolation procedures are clear, documented, and consistently followed across all hydraulic equipment.

name: Install Secondary Pressure Relief Valves with Manual Override
description: Install additional pressure relief valves with manual override capability on all injection molding lines. These secondary systems will serve as redundant safeguards to prevent unexpected pressure buildup. Conduct inspection and testing of all hydraulic systems to identify any weak points in pressure regulation. Schedule quarterly maintenance checks specifically for pressure relief systems. This engineering control provides an additional layer of protection by ensuring that even if primary relief mechanisms fail, secondary systems prevent dangerous pressure accumulation.

name: Redesign Storage Room Organization and Implement 5S Program
description: Conduct a complete reorganization of the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room using Lean 5S methodology (Sort, Set in Order, Shine, Standardize, Sustain). Establish maximum weight limits for upper shelves (no items exceeding 5 kg above 1.8 meters height). Create a labeled inventory system with designated locations for all tools and equipment. Assign Georges Plante (EMP-00179) as the storage area coordinator responsible for weekly inspections and maintaining organization standards. Document all procedures in a posted guide. This administrative control establishes clear expectations and accountability for storage practices, directly preventing similar incidents.

name: Install Safety Netting and Edge Protection on Mezzanine Shelving
description: Install high-visibility yellow safety netting along the front edges of all mezzanine-level shelving units to prevent object fallthrough and contain smaller items. Install rubber-edged guardrails on shelf corners and edges. Add anti-slip coating to mezzanine flooring in high-traffic areas. Mount inspection mirrors at strategic locations to improve visibility of stored items. These engineering controls provide physical barriers to prevent objects from falling and improve visibility for safe access to stored materials.

name: Provide Fall Protection Equipment Training and Install Safety Equipment
description: Equip the storage room with wall-mounted safety handrails for mezzanine access and install safety harness anchor points at the mezzanine level. Provide all material handlers with training on proper use of fall protection equipment, including harnesses and lanyards. Create a mandatory training module on working at heights (anything above 1.2 meters) and require certification before access to upper shelving areas. Conduct quarterly refresher training. This engineering control and administrative measure ensure workers are protected if they must access items at elevated heights.

name: Implement Automated Deburring and Edge Finishing Process
description: Introduce an automated tumble deburring system to process all injection-molded components before quality control inspection. The system will use media and controlled tumbling to remove sharp burrs and rough edges that result from the injection molding process. This engineering control eliminates the sharp edge hazard at the source by removing the dangerous condition before human handling occurs. Expected outcome: elimination of sharp edge injuries during handling and inspection of finished parts.

name: Issue Cut-Resistant Gloves and Hand Protection for QC Team
description: Provide all Quality Control Technicians with ANSI Level 4 cut-resistant gloves rated for handling sharp plastic edges. Ensure gloves are available in multiple sizes and materials (nitrile-coated nylon for better grip and tactile feedback during inspection). Include cut-resistant finger cots as an alternative for detailed inspection work. Conduct training on proper glove selection and fitting. Include sharp edge hazard awareness training in the next QC team meeting. This PPE control provides immediate protection while engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Establish a quarterly inspection schedule for all hydraulic hose connections and fittings on injection molding equipment. This includes visual inspection for wear, pressure testing, and replacement of hoses every 3 years or upon first sign of degradation. Documentation will be maintained in the predictive maintenance system. Training will be provided to all operators and technicians on early warning signs of hydraulic system failure. This addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance intervals and will prevent future hose failures.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Hydraulic Equipment
description: Install stainless steel secondary containment trays beneath all injection molding machines and high-pressure hydraulic equipment. Each tray will have a capacity of 110% of the largest single hydraulic reservoir. This engineering control will prevent spillage from reaching the floor and warehouse areas during future incidents. Containment trays will be equipped with drain plugs for controlled emptying and disposal of spilled hydraulic fluid, reducing environmental contamination and cleanup costs.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a daily visual inspection routine for all chemical storage containers in the mixing room, specifically checking for cracks, leaks, and corrosion. Operators will use a checklist system with photo documentation of container condition. Containers showing any signs of structural compromise will be immediately transferred to secondary containment and scheduled for replacement. Training will be provided to all chemical handling staff on early detection of container failure. This administrative control will catch issues before they result in vapor exposure incidents.

name: Replace and Upgrade Ventilation System Monitoring
description: Install real-time air flow monitoring sensors on the chemical mixing room ventilation system with automated alerts when airflow drops below 95% of baseline. The system will include pressure differential gauges visible to operators. Additionally, implement a schedule for bi-weekly filter inspections and monthly deep cleaning of ventilation ducts. This engineering control combined with administrative procedures will ensure continuous adequate ventilation and provide early warning of system degradation.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance and Machine Safeguarding Audit
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all injection molding equipment to verify lockout/tagout devices are functioning properly and accessible. Install additional mechanical lockout points on hydraulic lines to prevent residual pressure surges. Require photo documentation of locked equipment before any maintenance work begins. Implement weekly LOTO procedure verification audits on all production lines. All operators must complete recertification training within 5 days.

name: Install Hopper Safety Interlock System
description: Install automated safety interlock switches on all injection molding hopper access points that electronically disable machine operation when hopper covers are opened. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of accidental machine startup during material handling. System will include audible alarm and visual warning lights. Implementation to include retraining of all operators and setters on new safety procedures.

name: Enhanced Hazard Communication and Job Safety Analysis
description: Develop detailed Job Safety Analysis (JSA) for all hopper clearing procedures, emphasizing the critical importance of LOTO compliance and the dangers of residual hydraulic pressure. Create visual warning placards and laminated procedure cards for each production line. Conduct toolbox talks every morning for one month focusing on this specific hazard. Implement a peer-check system where one operator must verify LOTO compliance before another begins any maintenance work.

name: Replace All Storage Strap Hardware and Implement Inspection Schedule
description: Conduct complete inventory of all material storage straps and securing buckles throughout the warehouse. Replace all corroded or damaged hardware with stainless steel alternatives rated for 150% of maximum load. Establish monthly inspection schedule with documented verification. All warehouse staff must be trained to identify worn or corroded straps and report them immediately. Tag any compromised storage areas as out-of-service until repairs are completed.

name: Upgrade Solvent Transfer System with Pressure-Relief Couplers
description: Replace all manual hose connections on the acetone recovery system with proprietary dry-disconnect couplers featuring integrated pressure relief valves. These engineering controls will prevent spills during connection/disconnection operations. Couplers must be rated for the specific chemical composition and pressure specifications of acetone. Install secondary containment trays under all transfer points with 110% capacity of maximum transfer volume. Provide training to all personnel on proper use of new coupling system.

name: Enhanced Chemical Storage and Spill Prevention Procedures
description: Implement mandatory torque specification verification for all drum connections using calibrated torque wrenches. Create laminated procedure cards at each transfer station showing correct torque values for all connection types. Establish weekly equipment inspection checklist specifically for coupling integrity. Increase secondary containment drip tray capacity and position them under all high-risk transfer points. Stock acetone-specific absorbent material at each work station and conduct quarterly spill response drills with night shift personnel.

name: Install Thermal Insulation Barriers on All Molding Machines
description: Engineering control to reduce surface temperature exposure. Install high-temperature silicone foam insulation on all injection molding machine mold surfaces that exceed 60°C. Barrier material will reduce accessible surface temperature to below 50°C while maintaining production efficiency. Implementation includes custom-fitted covers for each machine model with quick-release mechanisms for maintenance access. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in thermal contact injuries. All 32 injection molding machines will be retrofitted in phases.

name: Mandatory Thermal Hazard and Part Removal Training Program
description: Administrative control establishing quarterly refresher training for all injection molding operators and setters. Training will cover: proper use of mechanical part removal systems, thermal hazard recognition, safe handling of hot components, and consequences of cycle-time shortcuts. Each operator must pass written and practical assessments. Sessions will be 90 minutes, conducted by Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier. Documentation of training completion will be maintained in employee files and required for performance evaluations.

name: Implement Automated Part Ejection Verification System
description: Engineering control adding optical sensors to injection molding machines to prevent manual part removal attempts before automatic ejection completes. System will lock the mold access gate until ejection sequence is finished, with audible and visual confirmation that it is safe to remove parts. Reduces operator discretion in bypassing safety protocols and eliminates the pressure to rush cycles. Installation will be phased over 60 days for all 32 machines, starting with high-volume production lines.

name: Implement Chemical Tank Lifecycle Management Program
description: Administrative control establishing a preventive tank replacement schedule based on manufacturer specifications and operational stress analysis. All chemical storage tanks will be tracked with purchase dates and retirement timelines in the facility management system. Tanks exceeding 5 years in service will be flagged for accelerated inspection and replacement planning. Monthly audits will be conducted by maintenance team to verify tank integrity and identify tanks approaching end-of-life. Replacement tanks will be sourced 6 months before projected retirement dates.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Tank Mounting to Ground Level
description: Engineering control eliminating the hazard of elevated storage tanks that require ladder access for inspection and maintenance. Phase 1: relocate the 3 largest chemical storage tanks currently on elevated shelves (500L, 750L, and 1000L capacity) to reinforced ground-level storage racks with secondary containment systems. This removes the need for ladder-based inspections and maintenance work, reducing fall risk and improving emergency response capability. Ground-level tanks are easier to inspect, monitor, and service safely. Implementation phases over 90 days.

name: Retrofit Chemical Containers with Ergonomic Grip and Anti-Slip Surfaces
description: Engineering control modifying all 25-liter and larger resin containers to improve grip security and reduce spillage from handling errors. Implementation includes: addition of rubberized grip handles on container sides, anti-slip coating on container bases, and weight-distribution markings for safe lifting techniques. All existing containers will be retrofitted with adhesive-backed grip pads and permanent marking labels. New containers will be sourced with integrated handles per revised procurement specifications. Cost includes retrofit materials and labor for approximately 120 existing containers in active circulation.

name: Implement Mold Deburring and Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory post-production mold inspection and deburring procedure that must be completed before each production changeover. All molds will be visually inspected for sharp edges, burrs, and defects using standardized checklists. Operators will use pneumatic deburring tools and hand files to smooth all internal surfaces. This engineering/administrative control directly addresses the root cause by ensuring no sharp edges remain on molds. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in mold-related hand injuries.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Glove Upgrade
description: Issue cut-resistant nitrile gloves (ANSI A4 rating) to all injection molding operators and machine setters. These gloves will be distributed immediately and made mandatory during part removal operations. Training will emphasize proper glove selection, fit, and care. This PPE enhancement provides secondary protection while primary engineering controls are being established. All operators will receive new gloves quarterly.

name: Establish Preventive Ventilation Maintenance Schedule
description: Implement a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all local exhaust ventilation systems, including visual inspections of all ductwork connections, flex coupling integrity, and seal effectiveness. Maintenance technician Georges Plante will conduct monthly walk-throughs to identify loose connections or deterioration. Maintenance logs will be maintained and reviewed monthly. This engineering control ensures ventilation system integrity is continuously monitored and issues are detected before they create exposure hazards.

name: Deploy Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring in Chemical Areas
description: Install continuous air quality monitors in the Material Drying and Preparation Room that detect volatile organic compound (VOC) levels and display readings at operator workstations. Alarms will alert operators when VOC concentrations exceed 50% of the OSHA PEL. This engineering control provides early warning before dangerous exposure levels occur. Annual calibration and maintenance will be conducted by qualified contractors.

name: Install Thermal Warning Signage and Temperature Indicators
description: Install high-visibility warning signs on all industrial ovens indicating residual heat hazards and safe handling procedures. Add permanent digital temperature displays and 'HOT SURFACE' labels on all oven exterior surfaces. Signage will be in English and French per Quebec requirements. This administrative/engineering control provides clear communication of hazard status to all operators.

name: Mold Interlock System Replacement and Certification
description: Replace the faulty safety interlock on Injection Molding Line B with a certified dual-channel safety system that meets ISO 13849-1 PLd standards. Conduct comprehensive third-party testing and certification before return to service. Implement quarterly interlock testing protocol with documentation. This addresses the root cause of the incident—the failed safety device that should have prevented mold closure when hands were detected.

name: Enhanced Machine Guarding Audit and Installation
description: Conduct a full audit of all injection molding equipment pinch points. Install additional fixed guarding around mold closing mechanisms on Lines A, B, and C to minimize operator hand access. Add secondary photo-eye guards at critical zones. Train all line operators on new guard locations and never bypass or disable safety devices.

name: Mandatory Retraining on Machine Safety and Emergency Procedures
description: Provide refresher training to all production operators on injection molding machine hazards, emergency stop procedures, and proper part removal techniques. Include certification on new guard systems and interlock operation. Document attendance and competency assessment. This administrative control reinforces proper work practices and awareness of hazards.

name: Installation of Non-Slip Flooring and Drainage System
description: Install anti-slip coating on all warehouse flooring in Materials Management and Packaging areas, particularly in high-traffic zones where equipment operates. Add sloped drainage channels to prevent water pooling during cleaning operations. This engineering control eliminates the slip hazard at its source by modifying the walking and driving surfaces.

name: Enhanced Cleaning and Floor Maintenance Protocol
description: Implement a documented cleaning schedule for all shifts with required signage (wet floor cones and caution tape) during operations. Assign a dedicated night shift staff member to coordinate cleaning during low-activity periods. Provide immediate notification system when floors are wet. Implement monthly audits of floor conditions with corrective action tracking.

name: Implementation of Secondary Containment for Laboratory Chemicals
description: Provide all chemical containers in the Quality Control Laboratory with secondary spill containment trays (absorbent spill kits and drip pans) rated for the specific chemical types. Organize workbench layout to minimize reach distances and ensure chemicals are stored in designated secondary containers. This engineering control prevents future spills from spreading and contacting workers.

name: Chemical Handling and Emergency Response Refresher Training
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all Quality Control Laboratory staff on proper chemical handling, eyewash station location and use, and immediate first aid procedures for chemical exposure. Review WHMIS labels and Safety Data Sheets (SDS) for isopropyl alcohol and other commonly used laboratory solvents. Document all training and competency assessments.

name: Enhanced Predictive Maintenance Protocol for Cooling Systems
description: Implement quarterly bearing vibration analysis and thermal imaging inspections on all cooling system pumps across the 32 injection molding machines. This will replace the semi-annual manual inspections and add pressure transducer monitoring with automated alerts set at 85% of maximum rated pressure. Establish a dedicated preventive maintenance log tracking failure patterns. This directly addresses the root cause of undetected bearing degradation and will enable intervention before catastrophic failure occurs.

name: Install Secondary Pressure Relief Valves on All Cooling Lines
description: Engineer and install redundant pressure relief valves on each injection molding machine's cooling circuit to prevent pressure buildup beyond safe operating limits. Valves will be rated 15% below maximum system pressure to provide fail-safe protection. This engineering control will eliminate the hazard of pressure-related line ruptures by automatically venting excess pressure. Training for maintenance staff on inspection and testing of these valves will be mandatory.

name: Implement Specialized PPE Requirements for Hydraulic Maintenance
description: Require all personnel performing maintenance on pressurized hydraulic and cooling systems to wear chemical-resistant nitrile gloves (minimum 8-mil thickness), face shields with anti-fog coating, and long-sleeved Nomex work shirts. Establish a tool kit requirement that includes quick-disconnect safety couplings for all maintenance procedures. Conduct mandatory training on proper PPE donning/doffing and recognition of pressurized system hazards. Post warning placards at all pressurized system access points.

name: Install Semi-Automated Material Transfer System
description: Procure and install an electric-powered pallet jack with adjustable height extension and three vacuum lift attachments specifically configured for composite material bags. Position two stations in the Material Drying and Preparation Room: one at storage area and one at the weighing station. This will eliminate manual lifting of bags over 30 pounds, reducing repetitive strain injuries by approximately 85%. Train all operators on safe operation of the equipment with emphasis on proper hand positioning and load centering.

name: Implement Mandatory Job Rotation Schedule
description: Establish a rotating job assignment schedule where operators performing repetitive material transfer tasks rotate to other duties (quality inspection, material preparation, packaging) every 2 hours to prevent cumulative repetitive strain injuries. Create a cross-training matrix ensuring all operators in the Materials Management department can perform at least 4 different tasks. Operators will maintain the same hourly rate during rotation.
