This administrative control distributes strain across different muscle groups and prevents overuse injuries.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Ergonomic Assessment and Training
description: Hire an external ergonomic consultant to assess all workstations in the Materials Management and Post-Processing departments. Consultant will measure work heights, reach distances, and load weights, then provide specific recommendations for workstation modifications. Mandatory 4-hour ergonomics training for all materials handling personnel covering proper lifting techniques, load limits, task pacing, and warning signs of repetitive strain injury. Training will be documented and reinforced quarterly.

name: Add Safety Interlocks to Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Revise the preventive maintenance matrix to include quarterly inspection and functional testing of all safety interlock switches on robotic arms, material handling equipment, and automated machinery. Establish a tracking system documenting each interlock test, with specific attention to switch contact resistance and response time. Any interlock switch showing response time greater than 50 milliseconds will be immediately replaced. This engineering control ensures detection of failing switches before they allow dangerous access to operating equipment.

name: Install Secondary Visual and Audible Warning Systems
description: Install bright amber strobe lights and audible alarm systems (85 dB minimum) outside all robotic equipment enclosures that activate whenever the safety interlock is triggered or malfunctioning. Lights will flash at 2 Hz intervals. This provides redundant warning to any personnel in the area that a guarding system issue has occurred. Warning system will be integrated with the facility's safety management system to automatically notify HSE and maintenance departments.

name: Implement Mandatory Part Deburring Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a standardized deburring and edge finishing inspection checkpoint before parts enter the post-processing cooling conveyor. All composite parts must pass visual and tactile inspection for sharp edges using standardized templates. Quality inspectors will receive additional training on edge identification and safe handling techniques. This engineering control will be implemented at the inspection station in UNIT-017 with sign-off requirements documented in the production log system.

name: Issue Cut-Resistant Gloves for Part Handling
description: Distribute ANSI A3 or A4 rated cut-resistant gloves to all personnel handling post-processed composite parts in UNIT-017. Gloves will be stored in accessible dispensers at workstations. This PPE control complements the deburring protocol and provides temporary protection during transition period. Training sessions will ensure proper glove usage and limitations awareness.

name: Strengthen Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Enforcement and Auditing
description: Implement mandatory LOTO compliance audits for all injection molding maintenance operations. Establish a dual-verification system requiring both the performing technician and a supervisor to confirm proper isolation before any maintenance begins. Update LOTO procedures to include photographic documentation of locked-out equipment. Schedule monthly LOTO refresher training for all operators and maintenance staff. Create a compliance tracking log with consequences for non-compliance. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of the incident.

name: Install Machine Isolation and Interlock Systems
description: Retrofit Line C injection molding machines with electrical interlock systems that prevent machine cycling when maintenance access doors are opened. Install emergency stop buttons at all maintenance work stations. These engineering controls will provide passive protection against unexpected machine operation during maintenance. Implementation includes equipment procurement, installation by qualified technicians, and comprehensive testing before return to service.

name: Provide Comprehensive Burn Prevention and First Aid Training
description: Conduct specialized training for all production and maintenance staff on thermal burn prevention, first aid response, and proper cool water immersion techniques. Include information on burn classification, when to seek medical attention, and post-burn wound care. Training will be documented and refreshed annually. This administrative control ensures rapid response to any future thermal injuries.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Spill Prevention System
description: Install epoxy resin-compatible secondary containment trays (capacity 150% of largest container) beneath all chemical storage shelves in UNIT-010. Implement anti-slip, textured grip sleeves on all 5-liter chemical containers to improve handling. Install drip trays with absorbent material at all transfer points. These engineering controls prevent chemical release and rapid vaporization. All containers will be subject to weekly inspection for integrity and grip condition.

name: Upgrade Emergency Ventilation and Personal Protection
description: Install ducted local exhaust ventilation (LEV) system directly above chemical transfer stations in the mixing room with dedicated outdoor exhaust. Install rapid-access eyewash and emergency shower stations within 10 meters of all chemical handling areas. Stock emergency respiratory protection (PAPR units) at the entrance to UNIT-010. Provide all staff with fitted cartridge respirators and annual fit-testing. Update WHMIS labels and safety data sheets at all workstations.

name: Implement Chemical Handling and Spill Response Training
description: Conduct comprehensive chemical safety training for all UNIT-010 personnel covering proper container handling techniques, spill response procedures, emergency ventilation activation, and respiratory protection use. Training will include practical drills with simulated spills using water-based demonstrators. Develop quick-reference laminated cards posted at each workstation. Require annual refresher training and incident-specific retraining following this event. Document all training completion.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Conveyor Systems
description: Establish a monthly vibration analysis program for all overhead conveyor systems using portable vibration monitoring equipment. Technicians will measure baseline frequencies and trending data to identify bearing degradation before failure occurs. This engineering control will integrate with the existing maintenance scheduling system to prioritize component replacement based on condition monitoring rather than time-based intervals. Expected outcome: eliminate 85% of unexpected equipment failures and extend component service life by 40-60%.

name: Install Secondary Containment Netting Under Overhead Conveyors
description: Design and install high-strength polycarbonate impact netting beneath all overhead conveyor systems in the warehouse that span work areas. This engineering control provides passive protection should any component or load fail. The netting will be rated for 5000-pound impact loads and professionally installed with quarterly inspection protocols. This serves as a backup safeguard while predictive maintenance prevents failures.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Work Gloves
description: Replace all standard cotton work gloves in injection molding areas with professional-grade aramid/silicone composite gloves rated for temperatures up to 250°C with heat-reflective outer layer. Distribute new gloves to all 45 operators on rotating shifts and establish a quarterly replacement schedule. Conduct mandatory hands-on training session demonstrating proper fit, care, and limitations. This PPE upgrade directly addresses the thermal exposure hazard while maintaining dexterity required for precision mold operations.

name: Install Automated Mold Ejection Assist System
description: Engineering control: Design and install pneumatic-assisted ejection pins with proximity sensors on Line B injection molding machines. This system reduces direct operator contact with hot mold surfaces by automating the initial ejection stage. Operators will use a foot pedal actuator positioned at safe distance from the mold cavity, allowing the system to perform the first 80% of part ejection automatically. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard exposure while maintaining operator control over part quality inspection.

name: Enhance Thermal Safety Training Program
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive thermal hazard awareness training for all production operators covering: mold temperature monitoring, burn prevention techniques, proper PPE selection and inspection, first aid response for thermal injuries, and emergency protocols. Include quarterly refresher sessions and competency assessments. Administrative control that reinforces engineering improvements with worker knowledge and safe work practices.

name: Install Continuous Ventilation System Monitoring with Automatic Alerts
description: Engineering control: Install a real-time monitoring system on all ventilation equipment in chemical storage and mixing areas that tracks airflow rates, pressure differentials, and filter status. The system will trigger audible and visual alarms when airflow drops below minimum thresholds, and automatically notify the night shift supervisor and on-call maintenance personnel via text and email. Additionally, implement a mandatory pre-shift ventilation system inspection checklist that must be completed and documented by the shift supervisor before chemical operations commence. Expected outcome: prevent future ventilation failures from going undetected.

name: Establish Chemical Exposure Work Rotation and Duration Limits
description: Administrative control: Implement a maximum continuous exposure protocol limiting chemical handling work to 90-minute periods followed by mandatory 30-minute fresh air breaks in non-chemical areas. Establish a rotation system where no single technician performs chemical operations more than 8 hours per 24-hour cycle. Document all exposure time in individual employee logs. Conduct training on early warning symptoms of chemical exposure (dizziness, nausea, headache) and establish clear reporting protocols for ventilation concerns.

name: Upgrade to Supplied Air Respiratory Protection System
description: Provide all composite materials technicians with powered air-purifying respirators (PAPRs) with supplied air cartridges rated for organic vapors and provide mandatory annual fit-testing and quarterly competency training. Although engineering and administrative controls are primary, this PPE enhancement provides critical backup protection during chemical handling operations. Install a cartridge storage system with expiration date tracking and establish replacement protocols.

name: Implement Mandatory Night Shift Ventilation Redundancy and Cross-Training
description: Engineering/Administrative hybrid: Ensure the night shift has sufficient staffing and cross-training so that at least one technician is trained in basic ventilation system troubleshooting and reset procedures. Install backup ventilation equipment (portable HEPA units) in chemical areas that can be immediately deployed if primary ventilation fails. Establish emergency escalation protocol requiring immediate facility manager notification if ventilation cannot be restored within 15 minutes, triggering facility evacuation or suspension of chemical operations.

name: Implement Heat-Resistant Glove Quality Control
description: Establish a monthly inspection protocol for all heat-resistant gloves used in injection molding operations. Damaged, worn, or compromised gloves will be immediately removed from service and replaced. Personnel will be trained to visually inspect gloves before each shift and report any degradation. Engineering will source enhanced insulated gloves with superior grip coatings rated for 100°C+ exposure. This addresses the root cause of slipped grip and ensures consistent PPE performance across all molding lines.

name: Install Temperature-Controlled Extraction Assist System
description: Engineer and install automated part ejection mechanisms with integrated cooling channels on all injection molding lines, starting with Line B. The system will pre-cool molded parts to safe handling temperatures (below 40°C) before manual removal is required. This eliminates direct contact with hot mold surfaces and represents an engineering control addressing the primary hazard. Implementation includes worker training on new equipment operation and safety interlocks.

name: Restore Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic lifting platforms and related equipment, aligned with manufacturer specifications and CNESST standards. Maintenance will be performed every 6 months (not 14+ months). A dedicated maintenance log will track all inspections, seal replacements, fluid analysis results, and repairs. All personnel involved in hydraulic system maintenance will receive refresher training. This administrative control restores critical oversight and prevents future seal failures.

name: Install Secondary Hydraulic Safety Blocks
description: Engineer and install mechanical safety restraint blocks beneath all elevated mezzanine platforms that will automatically engage if hydraulic pressure drops below safe thresholds. These passive safety devices will prevent catastrophic platform collapse regardless of cylinder failure. Additionally, install load-limiting sensors that prevent overloading. These engineering controls provide redundant fail-safe mechanisms independent of maintenance compliance and significantly reduce potential injury and equipment damage.

name: Mandate Fall Protection When Working at Mezzanine Heights
description: Establish and enforce mandatory fall protection protocols for all personnel working on mezzanine levels above 1.2 meters, including use of full-body harnesses, lanyards, and secure anchor points. Update facility signage and conduct mandatory training for all maintenance personnel. This administrative control combined with PPE reduces potential severity of injuries from falls or falling objects.

name: Implement Automated Resin Edge De-burring Process
description: Install automated edge-finishing equipment at the Packaging and Labeling Station that will machine-polish and de-burr all composite part perimeters before manual handling. This eliminates the primary hazard source—sharp resin edges—through engineering control. The system will be integrated into the production workflow upstream of manual trimming operations. Workers will be trained on the new equipment. This approach prioritizes hazard elimination over reliance on PPE.

name: Install Automated Temperature Monitoring System on Resin Dryers
description: Install digital temperature sensors with real-time monitoring and automatic shutdown capabilities on all six resin dryer units in the Composite Materials Processing Area. The system will include alarm thresholds set 10% below maximum safe operating temperature, with alerts sent to both the production supervisor and HSE department. Technicians will receive training on system operation and troubleshooting. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of thermostat failure by providing redundant monitoring and automatic intervention.

name: Implement Quarterly Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Thermal Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all heating and drying equipment, including inspection, cleaning, and thermostat calibration. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie will schedule quarterly inspections documented in the facility maintenance management system. Each inspection will include internal cleaning to remove accumulated resin residue and replacement of thermostats every 18 months regardless of apparent condition. This administrative control addresses the underlying maintenance gap that allowed equipment degradation.

name: Implement Enhanced Chemical Storage and Labeling System
description: Redesign the Raw Materials Warehouse chemical storage area with color-coded shelving and enhanced labeling using large, waterproof labels with QR codes linking to safety data sheets. All mold release agents and similar products will be stored in a dedicated secondary containment area with absorbent mats and drip trays. Storage locations will be documented in an inventory management system. This engineering and administrative control prevents future misidentification and contains potential spills at the source.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Lighting and Install Spill Response Stations
description: Upgrade LED lighting throughout the Raw Materials Warehouse to meet OSHA minimum foot-candle requirements (minimum 30 foot-candles in storage areas). Install four spill response stations strategically located with absorbent granules, spill kits, personal protective equipment, and emergency contact information. Conduct training with all warehouse personnel on spill response procedures, emphasizing immediate notification and safe cleanup protocols. This combination of engineering controls (lighting, equipment) and administrative controls (training, procedures) addresses root causes of the incident.

name: Conduct Chemical Handling Refresher Training
description: Mandate immediate refresher training for all warehouse and production personnel on proper chemical handling, container integrity checks, and WHMIS compliance. Training will include container cap inspection procedures, proper stacking and securing of hazardous material containers, and recognition of volatile organic compound (VOC) exposure symptoms. HR Generalist Noor Ahmed will schedule sessions within 2 weeks for all relevant shifts. Training records will be maintained and verified.

name: Replace Pressure Relief Valves and Install Safety Interlocks
description: Replace all aging pressure relief valves on hopper heating systems (8 units across Lines C and D) with modern fail-safe models certified to current industry standards. Install automated interlock systems that shut down heating elements if pressure exceeds safe thresholds. Additionally, install secondary containment shields around all pressure vessels to direct any discharge away from critical equipment. This engineering control eliminates the root cause by preventing pressure buildup and equipment damage.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Program for Pressure Systems
description: Implement a predictive maintenance program using vibration analysis and thermal imaging to monitor all pressure vessels and relief valves. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie will schedule quarterly inspections using non-destructive testing methods. Baseline measurements will be established for each equipment unit, and anomalies will trigger immediate inspection and replacement. This administrative control detects equipment degradation before failure occurs, preventing future incidents.

name: Install Protective Barriers Around Critical Quality Control Equipment
description: Design and install thermal and steam-resistant protective barriers around the spectrophotometer and other sensitive quality control instrumentation in the equipment zone adjacent to Injection Molding Lines C and D. Barriers will be constructed from stainless steel and insulating material. Additionally, relocate the spectrophotometer to a separate climate-controlled quality lab station when feasible to reduce exposure to production area hazards. This engineering control reduces vulnerability of expensive equipment to equipment malfunctions.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Ventilation System
description: Install a new dedicated ventilation system for UNIT-010 with increased air exchange capacity (minimum 12 air changes per hour), automated humidity and solvent vapor monitoring, and redundant intake filters on a weekly replacement schedule. Install explosion-proof lighting and eliminate all non-certified electrical outlets within the storage room, replacing them with ATEX-compliant equipment mounted at least 4 meters from chemical storage areas. This engineering control addresses the root cause of vapor accumulation and eliminates the ignition source.

name: Implement Chemical Storage and Fire Safety Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory quarterly training for all personnel working in or near UNIT-010 covering proper chemical handling, recognition of hazardous vapor accumulation, operation of the automated suppression system, and emergency evacuation procedures. Include hands-on demonstration of chemical transfer best practices and proper use of spill containment kits. All employees must complete competency certification before resuming chemical handling duties. Training to be administered by Karine Cloutier (Safety Trainer).

name: Establish Chemical Storage Maintenance Schedule
description: Create and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for UNIT-010 ventilation systems, monitored through TechnoPlast's predictive maintenance program. Schedule monthly filter inspections, quarterly vapor sensor calibration, and biannual professional HVAC system audits. Establish automated alerts in the maintenance management system for due dates. Assign Roland Dostie (Maintenance Planner) to oversee program implementation and ensure compliance with all maintenance deadlines.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Audit
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all hydraulic systems across production lines to identify any overdue maintenance items or missed service intervals. Replace all pressure relief valves on injection molding equipment that are approaching or past their recommended service intervals (typically 180-240 days). Create a digitized maintenance tracking system that automatically generates work orders 30 days before service due dates, with escalation alerts at 60 days overdue. Ensure backup documentation in cloud storage to prevent loss of maintenance records during system transitions. Roland Dostie will oversee this audit and implement improved tracking protocols.

name: Install Pressure Monitoring and Automatic Shutdown Systems
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with real-time hydraulic pressure monitoring systems that display current pressure relative to safe operating ranges. Install automatic emergency shut-off valves that trigger when pressure exceeds 110% of maximum rated operating pressure. These engineering controls provide redundancy to mechanical relief valves and prevent future overpressure incidents. System should include audible and visual alarms at 95% of maximum pressure to alert operators. Integration with facility management system will log all pressure anomalies for trend analysis.

name: Establish Pre-Shift Safety Walkthrough Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory 15-minute pre-shift safety inspection procedure for all production areas and dock operations. Assign designated safety champions (rotating among supervisory staff) to conduct structured walkthroughs before each shift begins, specifically checking for improperly secured loads, spills, blocked emergency exits, and equipment status. Create a standardized checklist and sign-off log that documents completion. Include this requirement in supervisor performance evaluations and maintain records for CNESST compliance verification. This administrative control ensures hazardous conditions are identified before personnel enter work areas.

name: Upgrade Pallet Securing Standards and Install Load Restraint Systems
description: Standardize all pallet securing requirements across UNIT-009 to require minimum four-point fastening for loads elevated above 4 feet. Install permanent load restraint systems at fixed storage positions with mechanical interlocks that prevent forklift departure until restraints are engaged. Provide training to all forklift operators on new requirements. Engineer the dock layout to eliminate storage positions where loads exceed 6 feet without overhead protection. These engineering controls will prevent load shifting and falling incidents.

name: Implement Shift-to-Shift Handover Communication System
description: Establish a digital shift handover log that outgoing shift supervisors complete, documenting any outstanding tasks, hazardous conditions, equipment issues, or incomplete material handling operations. Incoming shift leaders must review and sign the log before beginning operations. Use a secure shared platform accessible to all supervisory staff. Include this handover as part of the safety stand-up meeting at shift start. This administrative control ensures critical safety information is transferred between shifts and prevents hazards from being overlooked during personnel transitions.

name: Implement Daily Hopper Pressure Relief Valve Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily pre-shift inspection checklist for all injection molding hopper pressure relief valves on Lines A and B. Technicians must verify valve response by applying test pressure and documenting results on equipment log sheets. Any valve showing sluggish response or failure to relieve at proper threshold must be immediately replaced before machine startup. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance procedures and will prevent future material spills from pressurized hoppers.

name: Install High-Traction Safety Flooring at Material Loading Stations
description: Replace the current smooth epoxy flooring in the hopper loading zones with industrial-grade high-friction safety matting and non-slip coatings specifically rated for wet and oily production environments. This engineering control will significantly reduce slip hazards even when small amounts of hot plastic material contact the floor. Installation will occur during the scheduled maintenance window, with replacement matting placed at all injection molding line hopper stations.

name: Upgrade Composite Area Local Exhaust Ventilation System
description: Replace the existing local exhaust hood system serving the Composite Materials Processing Area with a modern variable-air-volume (VAV) capture system featuring capture velocity of at least 100 linear feet per minute at the source. Install automated airflow monitoring with daily self-check functionality and low-flow alarm notifications. This engineering control will eliminate the airborne glass fiber hazard at its source, providing the highest level of protection according to the hierarchy of controls.

name: Implement Respiratory Protection Program for Fiber Handling
description: Establish a comprehensive respiratory protection program specifically for composite materials operations, including fit testing for half-mask P100 particulate respirators, assignment of appropriate equipment to workers, and mandatory use protocols during all dry fiber handling activities. Provide training to all composite operators on proper donning/doffing procedures, maintenance, and limitations of respiratory protection. This administrative control and PPE measure will provide interim protection during the ventilation system upgrade.

name: Install Advanced Predictive Maintenance Monitoring System on All Ovens
description: Implement real-time temperature and electrical parameter monitoring on all post-processing ovens using Industry 4.0 IoT sensors connected to a central data analytics platform. System will continuously track heating element resistance, thermal gradients, and control system performance, generating predictive alerts when parameters deviate from baseline by more than 5%. Maintenance team will receive automated notifications enabling preventive element replacement before failure occurs. This engineering control will prevent recurrence of thermal runaway incidents by detecting incipient failures.

name: Replace Aging Oven with Modern Certified Equipment
description: Procure and install a new commercial-grade composite curing oven featuring UL-certified controls, redundant temperature limiting systems, and built-in thermal runaway protection. The new equipment will include automatic shutdown capability at 110% of setpoint, independent thermocouples for cross-verification, and fail-safe cooling system engagement. Installation will include comprehensive training for all operators and maintenance personnel on the new system's operation and diagnostic capabilities.

name: Implement Mandatory Pressure Relief and Cool-Down Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a written pre-cleaning checklist for all injection molding operators that mandates: (1) verification of mold temperature below 90°C using thermal imaging, (2) manual pressure release using designated relief valves on each mold ejection point, and (3) a minimum 10-minute cooling period after cycle completion. Post laminated checklist cards at each molding station. Conduct tool-box talks at all shifts explaining the hazard. This addresses the root cause of inadequate pressure relief procedures.

name: Upgrade to Thermal-Resistant PPE for Mold Cleaning Tasks
description: Replace standard cotton work gloves with ANSI/ASTM F2100-rated aluminized proximity gloves and provide flame-resistant sleeves (minimum FR rating 3.0) for all operators performing mold cleaning duties. Supply heat-resistant aprons for additional torso protection. Train all production personnel on proper donning, doffing, and care of thermal PPE. Issue new PPE within 5 business days and schedule quarterly replacement cycles.

name: Install Automatic Pressure Relief and Temperature Monitoring System
description: Retrofit injection molding machines (priority to Line D and similar high-capacity units) with automatic pressure relief valves that trigger when mold internal pressure exceeds safe thresholds, and digital temperature sensors that log cooling cycle data. Integrate sensors with production management system to prevent operator overrides. Engineering controls eliminate the reliance on manual procedures and human compliance, providing the highest level of hazard mitigation.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Automated Spill Prevention System
description: Design and install a engineered secondary containment system beneath all chemical transfer points with capacity for 110% of the largest single container volume (minimum 230 liters for acetone drums). Install low-level float switches that trigger automatic shut-off solenoid valves on the transfer pump, preventing overfill conditions. Add absorbent boom placement stations at stormwater drain access points. This engineering control prevents environmental release by containing the spill at source.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for All Chemical Transfer Equipment
description: Implement a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all hand pumps, drum valves, and transfer equipment, documented in a maintenance log. Inspection must include visual assessment for wear, pressure testing of seals, and functional verification of shut-off mechanisms. Replace any equipment showing degradation immediately. Technicians must be trained on inspection procedures and authorized to take equipment out of service.

name: Install Accessible Stormwater Isolation Valve and Train Emergency Response
description: Install clearly marked, accessible isolation valve on the stormwater drainage line with accompanying schematic posted at the facility entrance and chemical storage area. Include valve location in emergency response procedures. Train all night-shift personnel on valve location and isolation procedures during emergency response drills. Conduct quarterly drills simulating spill scenarios requiring drain isolation.

name: Upgrade Spill Response Kit and Conduct Quarterly Awareness Training
description: Audit and replenish spill response kits (one primary kit at chemical storage, satellite kits at three other locations) with MSDS sheets, absorbent materials (minimum 100 kg capacity per kit), acid-resistant gloves, respiratory protection, and containment barriers. Post clear signage identifying kit locations. Conduct quarterly 30-minute spill response refresher training for all personnel potentially handling hazardous materials, covering proper kit usage and immediate emergency notification procedures.

name: Implement Proximity Sensor Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Add all hydraulic press proximity sensors to the quarterly preventive maintenance schedule with documented testing and replacement intervals. Maintenance technicians will perform functional tests on each sensor using test blocks to verify proper activation distance. All maintenance records will be logged in the CMMS system and reviewed during monthly safety committee meetings. This engineering control will prevent sensor failures that disable critical safety interlocks.

name: Mandatory Lockout/Tagout Refresher Training
description: Conduct comprehensive LOTO refresher training for all machine operators and maintenance personnel working with hydraulic presses. Training will include real-world case studies, proper lock placement procedures, and verification protocols. Each employee will complete practical demonstrations on actual molds before returning to operation. Competency assessments will be documented and filed. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand their responsibilities during maintenance and mold changeover activities.

name: Install Dual-Channel Safety Monitoring System
description: Replace the single proximity sensor with a redundant dual-channel safety monitoring system that requires independent confirmation before mold closure is permitted. This engineering upgrade provides backup protection if one sensor fails. The system will integrate with existing hydraulic controls and include visual/audible alarms when sensor faults are detected. Installation will be completed by qualified technicians from equipment supplier.

name: Establish Preventive Dust Extraction Maintenance Schedule
description: Implement bi-weekly preventive maintenance for all dust collection systems serving composite processing areas. Maintenance technicians will inspect and replace HEPA filters, clean collection hoppers, and verify suction pressure at all extraction points. A new tracking system in the CMMS will generate automatic work orders and send notifications to the maintenance team. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of dust accumulation by ensuring extraction equipment functions at design capacity continuously.

name: Implement Daily Housekeeping and Dust Monitoring Protocol
description: Establish a daily end-of-shift housekeeping routine where production operators use damp wiping methods and HEPA-equipped vacuum equipment to remove dust from work surfaces, equipment tops, and ledges. A visual inspection checklist will be completed and signed off by shift supervisors. Monthly air sampling will be conducted to verify dust levels remain below 30% of CNESST exposure limits. Non-compliance triggers immediate corrective action. This administrative control ensures continuous dust management between equipment maintenance activities.

name: Implement Automated Deburring Station
description: Install a dedicated deburring workstation with precision pneumatic tools specifically designed for removing mold cavity burrs at the end of each production run. This station will be positioned between the mold removal area and part inspection. Operators will receive brief training to use the equipment safely. This engineering control eliminates sharp edges before parts enter the removal workflow, preventing hand contact with hazardous burrs entirely.

name: Implement Weekly Drum Integrity Inspection Program
description: Establish a systematic weekly inspection protocol for all chemical storage drums in UNIT-010, including visual checks for cracks, corrosion, leaks, and structural integrity. Each inspection will be documented in a logbook with date, inspector name, drum ID, and condition status. Any drum showing signs of deterioration will be immediately transferred to secondary containment and flagged for replacement. This engineering and administrative control addresses the root cause of inadequate preventive maintenance and reduces the probability of future chemical spills from container failure.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment Capacity
description: Expand the secondary containment system in the Chemical Storage Room to accommodate 110% of the largest single drum volume (approximately 65 gallons). Install secondary containment trays under all high-risk storage areas containing epoxy resins and hardeners. This engineering control directly prevents future spills from reaching the facility floor and protects groundwater. The enhanced containment system will include drain plugs for safe emptying of collected liquids and improved visibility for inspection purposes.

name: Mandate High-Temperature Thermal Gloves for All Molding Operations
description: Replace all standard nitrile gloves in injection molding areas with specialized aramid-lined thermal gloves rated for sustained contact up to 150°C. Gloves will meet ANSI Level 2 heat protection standards. Implement a mandatory use policy requiring thermal gloves whenever handling material from presses or hot processing equipment. Include thermal glove inspection and replacement in the daily pre-shift checklist. This PPE control provides immediate protection against burn hazards and directly addresses the root cause of this incident.

name: Install Automated Part Removal and Cooling System
description: Engineer an automated assisted part removal system for Molding Press #3 and similar high-volume presses that automatically removes finished parts and transfers them to a cooling chamber before manual handling. Alternatively, install a gravity-feed part ejection system that moves hot parts away from the worker's reach immediately after press opening. This engineering control eliminates direct contact with hot material during the most hazardous phase of the production cycle and represents the highest level of hazard control (elimination of exposure).

name: Implement Mandatory Burn Awareness Training and Recognition Program
description: Develop and deliver a 2-hour training module for all production staff covering thermal hazard recognition, proper thermal PPE use, emergency response to burn injuries, and first aid techniques specific to thermal burns. Training must be completed by all technicians within 30 days and refreshed annually. Include case study discussions based on this incident to reinforce risk awareness. Documentation of completion will be maintained in employee files. This administrative control enhances worker awareness and ensures proper emergency response procedures are understood.

name: Replace Corroded Solvent Container Couplings
description: All polycarbonate resin solvent storage containers will be inspected for valve coupling corrosion and replaced with stainless steel couplings rated for aromatic hydrocarbon exposure. A preventive maintenance schedule will be implemented requiring quarterly inspections of all chemical transfer equipment. This addresses the root cause of the valve failure and prevents recurrence of similar spills.

name: Upgrade Ventilation Monitoring System
description: Install real-time vapor detection sensors in the Material Drying and Preparation Room that automatically trigger enhanced ventilation when solvent vapor concentrations exceed 25% of the lower explosive limit. The system will include audible and visual alarms to alert nearby workers. This engineering control will provide immediate response to vapor accumulation and reduce worker exposure to inhalation hazards.

name: Enhanced Chemical Handling Training for Operators
description: Mandatory retraining for all chemical mixing operators on proper coupling inspection procedures, spill response protocols, and recognizing signs of equipment degradation. Training will include hands-on practice with the new stainless steel couplings and emergency response drills. All operators will be required to perform pre-transfer equipment inspections with documented checklists.

name: Implement Automated Crane Maintenance Scheduling
description: Establish a computerized preventive maintenance tracking system that automatically generates service orders for all overhead cranes when calibration intervals approach. Load cell sensors will be calibrated every 6 months by a certified third-party technician. All maintenance records will be maintained and accessible for CNESST compliance audits. This engineering control eliminates human error in scheduling and ensures equipment safety systems remain functional.

name: Install Redundant Load Monitoring System
description: Add a secondary load cell sensor with independent alerting to all overhead cranes as a backup to the primary system. If load readings diverge between sensors or exceed safe operating parameters, an immediate alarm will sound and the crane will enter safety mode. This dual-sensor approach provides engineering redundancy that protects against single-point sensor failures.

name: Mandatory Pre-Shift PPE Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a documented daily PPE inspection checklist that must be completed and signed off by each operator before beginning their shift. Inspections will include visual assessment of glove integrity, checking for holes, tears, or degradation. Any gloves showing wear will be immediately replaced. Supervisors will conduct spot-checks on compliance. This administrative control ensures PPE defects are identified before they create injury risk.

name: Reduce Thermal Glove Replacement Interval
description: Change the protective glove replacement schedule from 90 days to 60 days for employees working directly with heated injection molding parts. Establish an inventory management system that tracks glove issuance and automatically flags when replacements are due. New gloves meeting ISO 13732 thermal protection standards will be stocked in dedicated dispensers at each production line.

name: Install High-Temperature Protective Gloves
description: Replace standard nitrile gloves with specialized heat-resistant gloves rated for 300°C+ mold contact temperatures on all injection molding lines. Gloves will feature aramid fiber construction with silicone coating for enhanced thermal protection. Implement mandatory use through updated machine operating procedures and provide training to all Line C operators. Gloves will be stored in accessible stations at each molding machine. Expected outcome: elimination of thermal burns during normal part removal operations.

name: Implement Cooldown Cycle Monitoring System
description: Install visual temperature indicator labels on all Line C molding machines that display when equipment has cooled to safe handling temperatures (below 60°C). Integrate with machine control systems to delay part removal gates until cooldown threshold is reached. Add countdown timer display visible to operators. This administrative and engineering control will prevent premature part extraction during high-temperature phases. Training will be provided to all operators on the new system during next scheduled safety meeting.

name: Implement Powered Regrind Equipment Shutdown Procedures
description: Develop and enforce a lockout/tagout protocol requiring that all regrind equipment motors remain de-energized while technicians perform jam clearance. Install a lockable breaker switch dedicated to the regrind hopper drive. Provide training to all technicians on proper isolation procedures. Additionally, install engineering controls such as removable access plates with hinged guards to allow safe material removal without direct hand contact with conveyor areas. This addresses the root cause of bypass operation during maintenance activities.

name: Install Automated Pressure Monitoring and Control System
description: Replace aging mechanical relief valves with modern hydraulic relief systems featuring real-time pressure sensors and automated shutoff mechanisms. Install a centralized SCADA system that continuously monitors all vessel pressures, provides operator alerts at 2.8 bar (warning level), and automatically triggers controlled venting at 2.95 bar to prevent catastrophic relief activation. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of uncontrolled pressure releases. System will include data logging for compliance verification and predictive maintenance scheduling based on pressure trends.

name: Establish Monthly Pressure Relief Valve Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a preventive maintenance schedule requiring calibration and functional testing of all relief valves on reaction vessels every 30 days. Maintenance technicians will use certified pressure test equipment to verify valve opening pressure is within ±0.1 bar of setpoint. Any valves showing drift or sluggish response will be replaced immediately. All inspections will be documented in the facility's preventive maintenance system. This administrative control ensures early detection of valve degradation before failure occurs.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedure Implementation for Cleaning Operations
description: Establish and enforce a strict Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) protocol requiring that all injection molding machines be locked, tagged, and power-isolated before any cleaning, maintenance, or inspection begins. Every operator will be assigned a personal lock and key. A color-coded checklist system will be posted on each machine documenting LOTO completion. Daily audits will be conducted by supervisors during shift changes. All 200 employees will receive refresher LOTO training within 14 days, with competency testing required before returning to molding operations. Non-compliance will result in suspension of machine operating privileges.

name: Installation of Machine Startup Interlock System
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with dual-control interlocks that prevent startup if the access door is open or if mold-sensing switches detect foreign objects within the clamping area. Install pressure-sensitive safety gates that automatically disable the startup sequence when breached. Integrate these systems into the central PLC (Programmable Logic Controller) network with real-time monitoring and incident logging. Installation will be completed by external specialists over 8 weeks. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of accidental startup during maintenance.

name: Shift Handover Communication Protocol
description: Implement a formal 10-minute shift handover meeting at the beginning of each shift transition where all active maintenance, cleaning, or non-standard operations are verbally communicated to incoming shift personnel. Use a standardized log sheet signed by both outgoing and incoming supervisors listing all machines under LOTO, cleaning operations in progress, and equipment limitations. Deploy real-time digital communication boards in each production area displaying active work zones and machine status. This administrative control ensures all personnel are aware of ongoing operations and hazards.

name: Battery Charger Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all eight forklift battery chargers managed by contracted specialists. Maintenance will include thermal imaging inspection, electrical component verification, heat sink cleaning, and firmware updates. Maintenance logs will be tracked in the ISO 45001 management system with compliance audits conducted monthly. All chargers over four years old will be scheduled for professional refurbishment or replacement within 90 days. This engineering/administrative control prevents thermal malfunction incidents and ensures equipment reliability.

name: Battery Charging Station Relocation and Containment
description: Relocate the battery charging station to a dedicated, climate-controlled room (400 sq ft) separated from the HDPE regrind storage area by a fire-rated partition wall. Install forced-air ventilation with temperature monitoring (setpoint: 22°C). Implement 2-meter exclusion zones around the charging equipment with yellow warning paint and signage. Install a Class C dry powder fire suppression system (manual and automatic actuators) within the charging room. This substitution/engineering control removes the hazard from proximity to flammable materials and improves containment.

name: Cooling System Component Replacement Program
description: Replace all copper-nickel couplings and corroded fittings in the closed-loop cooling system with duplex stainless steel (2205) components rated for the plant's acidic process water conditions. Upgrade the cooling water treatment program by implementing a corrosion inhibitor (silicate-based) with pH buffering to maintain 8.0-8.5 pH range. Conduct a full system flush and passivation per ASTM standards. Establish a 24-month component replacement cycle for all couplings and fittings. This engineering control eliminates corrosion as a failure mechanism and extends system reliability.

name: Secondary Containment System Upgrade
description: Expand the secondary containment basin capacity from 100 liters to 200 liters (double capacity) and install an automated overflow sensor with dual functions: (1) audible and visual alarm to alert maintenance personnel when fluid reaches 80% capacity, and (2) automatic diversion valve that channels overflow into a separate collection tank with absorbent materials. Install absorbent pads (500 m total) pre-positioned throughout the chemical mixing areas. Post spill response procedures with emergency contact information at all hazardous storage locations. Conduct spill response drills quarterly.

name: Environmental Monitoring and Regulatory Compliance Documentation
description: Implement a documented environmental monitoring protocol with quarterly coolant system sampling and laboratory analysis (ethylene glycol, pH, corrosion inhibitor residual). Maintain compliance records for CNESST and Quebec's environmental regulations. Install floor drain plugs (manually actuated) at all points where contaminated water could potentially enter municipal storm systems. Train all night shift personnel (20 employees) on spill response, storm drain protection, and regulatory notification procedures. Establish a pre-authorized relationship with an environmental remediation contractor for rapid response to releases exceeding 100 liters.

name: Mandatory LOTO Re-Training and Certification
description: Implement comprehensive lockout/tagout re-training program for all production operators and maintenance staff at Injection Molding Line B. Training will include hands-on scenarios, proper use of lockout devices, and verification procedures. All personnel must demonstrate competency before returning to independent operation. Training sessions will be conducted by certified instructors and documented. Refresher training will be required annually and after any near-miss incident.

name: Install Hopper Safety Interlock System
description: Engineering control: Install electronic safety interlock on Line B hopper that prevents machine operation when the hopper access panel is open or when LOTO has been initiated. System will require manual reset after each maintenance cycle. This engineering control will eliminate the possibility of unexpected machine cycling during hopper maintenance. Interlock system will be integrated with existing emergency stop circuit and monitored for functionality monthly.

name: Daily Pre-Shift LOTO Equipment Inspection
description: Establish administrative procedure requiring daily visual inspection of all LOTO devices on production lines before shift start. Inspection checklist will verify presence, condition, and proper functioning of lockout hasps, tags, and emergency stops. Findings will be logged and any defective equipment immediately removed from service. Line supervisors will be accountable for completion and sign-off. This administrative control ensures equipment reliability and creates a culture of safety consciousness.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Cooling Systems
description: Install vibration monitoring sensors on all cooling water pumps and implement condition-based monitoring software. System will alert maintenance team when vibration, temperature, or pressure parameters exceed thresholds, enabling proactive intervention before failure. Predictive analytics will track bearing health and schedule replacement during planned maintenance windows rather than emergency downtime. This engineering control will prevent future catastrophic failures and reduce material waste. Training will be provided to maintenance staff on interpreting sensor data and responding to alerts.

name: Establish Monthly Cooling System Inspection Protocol
description: Administrative control: Create standardized monthly inspection checklist for all cooling water systems including pump condition assessment, filter cleanliness evaluation, fluid analysis, and bearing performance verification. Maintenance technicians will document findings and schedule corrective actions based on results. Inspections will be tracked in the maintenance management system with supervisory sign-off required. This procedure will catch early signs of degradation and enable planned maintenance versus emergency response.

name: Install Safety Netting on High Storage Racks
description: Engineering control: Install high-visibility safety netting or containment bars on all warehouse storage racks exceeding 6 feet in height. Netting will prevent items from falling to the ground level and striking personnel below. All existing racks in Warehouse and Shipping will be retrofitted within 60 days. New racks will be required to include containment systems at time of purchase. This eliminates the hazard of falling materials and creates a safer work environment. Monthly inspections will verify integrity of all safety netting systems.

name: Implement Proper Stacking and Load Securing Training
description: Administrative control: Develop and deliver comprehensive training on proper material stacking techniques, load stability assessment, and secure fastening methods. All warehouse personnel will complete certification. Training will emphasize the importance of maintaining stable loads, using proper equipment for high shelves, and recognizing unstable stacking patterns. Packaging supervisors will conduct weekly toolbox talks reinforcing safe stacking practices. Job aids with visual instructions will be posted at storage areas. This administrative control ensures personnel understand proper material handling and can prevent similar incidents.

name: Require Use of Mechanical Retrieval Equipment for High Shelf Access
description: Administrative control: Establish and enforce new procedure prohibiting manual reaching above 6 feet. All retrievals from high shelves must use articulating forklifts, scissor lifts, or mobile elevated work platforms. Equipment will be available in the warehouse and operators will be trained and certified. This control eliminates the hazard of workers overreaching and losing balance. Supervisory enforcement will be required with compliance audits conducted monthly. Supervisors will interrupt any unsafe reaching behavior and provide immediate coaching.

name: Implement Material Storage Zone Designation System
description: Establish clearly marked material storage zones in UNIT-018 using floor tape, painted lines, and permanent signage indicating designated locations for raw material pallets, finished regrind batches, and equipment circulation pathways. Storage zones will be maintained clear of equipment and materials at all times. Supervisors will conduct daily inspections using a checklist to ensure compliance. All material handlers will receive training on the new system during shift briefings. This administrative control prevents future obstruction of critical walkways and equipment movement paths.

name: Overhaul Pneumatic System with Safety Upgrades
description: Replace all corroded pneumatic couplings and air hoses in UNIT-015 with new, stainless steel components rated for composite processing environments. Install redundant pressure relief valves set at 60 psi maximum (below eye injury threshold) on all branch lines serving operator work areas. Install quick-disconnect emergency shutoff valves at each major work zone. Implement a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule with documented inspections of all coupling integrity and pressure regulator function. Technicians will document all maintenance activities in a centralized system accessible to supervisors. This engineering control directly addresses the mechanical failure that caused the incident and implements multiple redundant safety systems.

name: Mandatory Eye Protection and Compressed Air Safety Training
description: Mandate that all personnel working in composite processing areas wear ANSI Z87.1 rated safety glasses with side shields at all times, with enforcement through supervisor oversight and incident consequences. Develop and deliver a comprehensive compressed air safety training module covering proper coupling operation, hazard recognition, emergency response procedures, and eyewash station use. Training will include live demonstration of compressed air hazards using a pressure testing apparatus. All composite area personnel will complete training within 14 days, with documentation maintained by HR. Refresher training will occur annually and when personnel transfer to the department.

name: Install Accessible Emergency Eyewash and Shower Stations
description: Install an additional emergency eyewash/shower combination station within 30 seconds of walking distance from all composite processing workstations in UNIT-015. All existing and new stations will be positioned at correct height per ANSI standard and clearly marked with illuminated signage. Conduct monthly water flow and functionality tests with documentation. Develop laminated emergency response cards showing exact locations and usage instructions, posted at all workstations in English and French. Ensure all personnel can demonstrate proper eyewash station use within 30 days of hire. This administrative and engineering control ensures rapid access to emergency treatment if injury occurs.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Procedures for Hopper Clearing
description: Establish a written protocol requiring that all hopper clearing operations on injection molding lines must be preceded by complete lockout/tagout procedures, including physical lock placement and verification by the LOTO coordinator. All operators will receive refresher training on proper LOTO sequence before resuming hopper maintenance tasks. A laminated procedure card will be posted at each molding station. Compliance will be audited monthly by the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator to ensure adherence.

name: Repair and Test Proximity Sensor on Line D Hopper
description: Schedule immediate maintenance to repair the malfunctioning proximity sensor on the Line D hopper auger mechanism that caused the unintended activation. All proximity sensors on injection molding equipment will undergo preventive maintenance testing and calibration to ensure they are functioning within manufacturer specifications. Facilities Manager will coordinate with maintenance vendor to complete repairs within 48 hours and provide certification of sensor functionality.

name: Enhance Machine Guarding on Hopper Access Points
description: Install removable polycarbonate guards around hopper access points on all injection molding lines to create physical barriers that prevent hands from reaching rotating auger components. Guards will be designed to allow operator visibility and material inspection while preventing accidental contact. Installation will be completed on all 32 molding machines within 60 days, with priority given to Lines C and D where similar incidents could occur.

name: Implement Quarterly Drum Integrity Inspection Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule for all chemical storage drums in the Raw Materials Warehouse. All 55-gallon drums will be visually inspected quarterly for signs of corrosion, leaks, dents, or seam deterioration. A database will track inspection dates and findings. Drums showing any signs of compromise will be transferred to new containers or marked for disposal. Chemical Safety Officer will oversee program and maintain documentation for compliance records.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment Systems
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all solvent storage areas in the Raw Materials Warehouse. These trays will hold 110% of the largest drum volume to prevent environmental releases. Secondary containment will be designed with integrated drain plugs, sloped surfaces, and drip trays for routine inspection. All containment equipment will be labeled with contents and capacity. Facilities Manager will coordinate installation and establish monthly inspection protocol.

name: Establish Housekeeping Protocol for Material Handling Zones
description: Implement a daily housekeeping checklist for the Material Drying and Preparation Room that requires all air hoses, electrical cords, and cables to be properly routed and secured away from forklift traffic lanes. Hoses will be mounted on wall clips or overhead cable trays. Designated forklift pathways will be marked with yellow floor tape, and a pre-shift inspection will verify clear passage before operations begin. Facilities Manager will assign responsibility to night shift personnel and verify compliance weekly.

name: Install Dual-Channel Safety Interlocks on Injection Molding Lines
description: Replace single-point mold access sensors with redundant dual-channel safety interlocks that will prevent mold closure if any obstruction is detected. This engineering control will ensure that even if one sensor fails, the secondary system will halt the molding cycle. Installation will include monthly testing protocols and log documentation. The system will be retrofitted on all four injection molding lines (A, B, C, and D) to eliminate the crush hazard at the source.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Procedure for Mold Maintenance
description: Establish and enforce a comprehensive Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedure specifically for all mold-related maintenance and adjustments. All operators will receive updated training on proper mold access protocols, including hand placement restrictions and required use of mold guards. Supervisors will conduct daily toolbox talks on proper part removal techniques before each shift begins. Training will be documented and refreshed quarterly.

name: Add Physical Barriers Around Mold Access Points
description: Install rigid polycarbonate guards and adjustable access gates around the mold cavity opening on all injection molding lines to physically restrict hand entry into dangerous zones. These guards will force operators to use proper removal tools rather than direct hand contact. Barriers will be designed to allow necessary material flow while preventing unintended hand insertion.

name: Establish Daily Floor Inspection and Hazard Cleanup Protocol
description: Create and enforce a daily pre-shift floor inspection checklist for all production and material handling areas. Maintenance teams must document all spills, debris, and hazardous conditions before shift begins. Any oil, coolant, or fluid spills must be cleaned immediately using absorbent materials and documented on an incident log. A designated person will verify clearance before operations begin each shift. This administrative control will prevent accumulation of slip hazards.

name: Install High-Traction Floor Coating in Material Handling Zones
description: Apply industrial-grade anti-slip coating to all high-traffic areas in the Assembly and Finishing Department and Warehouse, particularly around storage racks and corners where pallet jacks operate. The coating will provide improved grip even when wet and will reduce tip-over incidents from loss of traction. Annual reapplication will be scheduled to maintain effectiveness. This engineering control addresses the root cause of the slipping condition.

name: Implement Pallet Jack Safe Operating Procedures Training
description: Conduct mandatory retraining for all operators on powered pallet jack safety, emphasizing reduced speed in corners, proper load distribution, and hazard recognition. Training will include hands-on demonstrations of safe turning techniques and will address the specific blind spots and stability issues with tight corners. Refresher training will occur annually and after any near-miss incident.

name: Redesign Assembly Workstations with Ergonomic Controls
description: Conduct a full ergonomic assessment of all assembly workstations by a certified ergonomist. Implement adjustable height work surfaces, wrist supports, and tool holders that minimize awkward hand positions and excessive force requirements. Install height-adjustable chairs and footrests to promote neutral postures. Ensure that frequently used components are positioned within the optimal reach zone (18-24 inches from body center). These engineering controls will reduce strain on wrists and forearms during repetitive assembly tasks.

name: Establish Mandatory Job Rotation and Micro-Break Schedule
description: Implement a documented job rotation system where assembly operators rotate between different assembly tasks and inspections every 2 hours to vary muscle group usage. Establish mandatory 5-minute micro-breaks every hour where workers perform gentle stretching exercises. Supervisors will enforce break compliance and document participation. This administrative control will reduce cumulative strain by distributing workload across different muscle groups.

name: Provide Ergonomics Training and Awareness Program
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive ergonomics training to all assembly and finishing operators covering proper work posture, wrist positioning, and early symptom recognition of repetitive strain injuries. Training will include demonstration of correct and incorrect techniques using real workstations. Workers will receive ergonomic awareness posters and wrist exercise guides. Supervisors will conduct monthly toolbox talks on ergonomic best practices. This will increase awareness and encourage workers to report early symptoms.

name: Implement Mandatory Full Face Shield Protocol for Colorant Handling
description: Establish and enforce a mandatory requirement for all personnel handling colorant masterbatches and powdered resin additives to wear full-coverage face shields in addition to safety glasses. Conduct immediate refresher training for all material preparation staff on proper PPE selection based on hazard level. Supply full face shields at all workstations in the Material Drying and Preparation Room and document daily PPE audits for 60 days. This administrative control combined with improved PPE compliance will significantly reduce eye splash incidents from powder materials.

name: Install Powder Containment Enclosure at Resin Transfer Station
description: Design and install a portable containment hood or enclosure around the material transfer station where colorant bags are opened. This engineering control will capture airborne powder particles at the source, reducing exposure to the worker and surrounding areas. The enclosure should include integrated ventilation connected to the facility's existing extraction system and be equipped with a clear viewing window for worker visibility. Installation should be completed within 14 days with supplier coordination.

name: Design and Install Finger Guard Devices on Assembly Stations
description: Conduct a comprehensive engineering assessment of all manual assembly stations to identify pinch point hazards. Design and fabricate protective finger guards or shields for assembly interfaces where operators must apply manual pressure during part alignment and curing. These guards should prevent fingers from entering the assembly joint space while maintaining worker dexterity and visibility. Prioritize Assembly Station 3 for immediate installation and expand to all similar workstations within 30 days. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard source.

name: Provide Assembly-Specific Hand Protection and First Aid Training
description: Issue cut-resistant gloves specifically designed for assembly work (nitrile-coated with reinforced palm areas) to all Assembly Department operators. Conduct hands-on first aid training focused on minor laceration treatment, bleeding control, and infection prevention. Ensure all assembly workstations have clearly labeled first aid kits positioned within arm's reach. Training should be completed within 5 days with documentation of attendance.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Checklist and Double-Check System
description: Develop and deploy a comprehensive LOTO verification checklist that requires two-person independent confirmation of all lockout procedures before any maintenance work commences. The checklist must include: (1) verification of correct energy disconnect points, (2) confirmation of lock placement and LOTO tag application, (3) pressure relief valve testing with documented readings, (4) attempt to energize the equipment to confirm no response, and (5) supervisor sign-off. Implement a buddy system requiring a second qualified technician to independently verify LOTO status for all equipment maintenance. Training mandatory within 5 days; procedure effective immediately.

name: Conduct Comprehensive LOTO Audit and Retraining Program
description: Engage an external LOTO compliance auditor to conduct a facility-wide assessment of all equipment, energy sources, and current LOTO procedures. Identify all deficiencies and revise lockout procedures for every machine in the maintenance workshop. Conduct mandatory hands-on retraining for all maintenance technicians, operators, and supervisors with competency testing and certification. Include hazard assessment for each piece of equipment identifying all energy sources (electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic, mechanical, thermal). Implement quarterly LOTO audits conducted by EHS staff with corrective action tracking.

name: Install Automated Energy Isolation and Confirmation System
description: Evaluate and install automated LOTO confirmation technology on high-risk equipment such as hydraulic presses. This could include pressure transducers that verify zero-PSI conditions, electrical sensors that confirm disconnect isolation, and visual indicator systems that display system status. Integrate alerts that prevent equipment restart if LOTO is not properly confirmed. This engineering control provides a technical safeguard against human error in the LOTO process.

name: Implement Mandatory Deburring Quality Gate
description: Establish a mandatory inspection checkpoint in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit (UNIT-017) where every component must pass a tactile inspection (using standardized touch-test procedures) for sharp edges before release to assembly. This includes installation of deburring equipment maintenance alerts and cross-training of staff on the consequences of skipped steps. A work order tracking system will be implemented to ensure no parts bypass deburring operations, with daily verification logs reviewed by the shift supervisor.

name: Upgrade Assembly Station PPE Requirements
description: Upgrade all assembly workstations in UNIT-005 to include cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 or higher) as mandatory PPE for all operators handling components with potential sharp edges. Implement a glove replacement schedule (weekly or as needed) and ensure proper sizing and fit training for all assembly staff. Install prominent signage at each station indicating required PPE and display proper donning procedures.

name: Enhance Cross-Departmental Communication Protocol
description: Create a daily production status meeting involving representatives from Post-Processing (UNIT-017), Assembly (UNIT-005), and Maintenance (UNIT-012) to communicate any equipment downtime, process deviations, or quality issues. Implement a digital work order communication system that automatically notifies downstream operations when a process step is skipped or delayed, requiring acknowledgment before parts proceed to the next operation.

name: Replace Acetone Transfer Hoses with Hardline System
description: Replace all flexible hoses in the acetone transfer system between Injection Molding Line D and the solvent recovery tank with rigid PVC or PTFE hardline piping rated for acetone compatibility. This engineering control eliminates the degradation and micro-crack issues inherent in flexible hoses over time. The new system will include quick-disconnect couplers with integral check valves to prevent spills during maintenance. Installation to be completed with minimal production downtime during a scheduled maintenance window.

name: Implement Quarterly Ventilation System Audit
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly inspection and maintenance schedule for all ventilation intake ducts, filters, and exhaust ports in chemical storage and processing areas. Maintenance technicians will use videoscope equipment to inspect for blockages, corrosion, and degradation. All findings will be documented with photographic evidence and corrective actions must be completed before the next operational period. Blockage alerts will trigger immediate cessation of operations in affected areas until resolution.

name: Install Heat Shielding Around Thermal Equipment
description: Install rigid aluminum heat shields with 2-inch air gap around all thermal stress testing units and high-temperature equipment in the Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). Shields must be rated for continuous exposure to temperatures up to 120°C and include warning labels. All compressed air lines, hydraulic hoses, and electrical conduits must be routed minimum 24 inches away from heat sources or protected with fire-resistant wrap rated for acetone-resistant applications. Engineering drawings must be updated to reflect all exclusion zones.

name: Mandate Chemical Handling Safety Training with Hot Work Awareness
description: Implement mandatory, role-specific training for all maintenance and operations personnel on proper chemical handling procedures, emphasizing the hazards of using acetone-based solvents near heat sources and hot equipment. Training will include recognition of temperature hazards, proper distance protocols, and alternative cleaning methods. All personnel must pass a competency assessment and complete refresher training annually. This administrative control ensures staff understand why procedures exist and consequences of violations.

name: Upgrade Fire Extinguisher Placement and Inspection
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all Class B and Class ABC fire extinguishers in UNIT-012 and throughout the facility. Ensure minimum 2 extinguishers per work area with hot equipment, positioned within 30 feet maximum travel distance. Install wall-mounted brackets with clear signage and conduct monthly pressure checks. Implement quarterly hands-on refresher training for all staff on proper fire extinguisher use (PASS technique) with documented completion records.

name: Install Spill Kit Stations at Chemical Handling Locations
description: Implement three dedicated spill response kit stations strategically positioned within the Chemical Storage and Mixing area, each containing absorbent pads, containment barriers, personal protective equipment, and cleanup materials. Each station will be clearly marked with signage and illuminated by glow-in-the-dark labels. Personnel will receive quarterly refresher training on proper spill kit usage and response procedures. This engineering and administrative control eliminates response delays during chemical emergencies and ensures immediate containment capability.

name: Implement Container Integrity Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection schedule for all resin and chemical containers to identify cracks, seal degradation, or structural damage before incidents occur. Inspections will be documented using a standardized checklist and logged in the facility's material management system. Any containers showing signs of compromise will be immediately quarantined and replaced. This administrative control addresses the root cause of improper container handling and prevents future spills through proactive identification of defective containers.

name: Enhance LOTO Procedure with Thermal Monitoring Requirements
description: Revise the facility's lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure to mandate the use of non-contact infrared thermometers to verify that mold surfaces have cooled to safe handling temperatures (below 50°C) before personnel are permitted to contact heated equipment. This engineering control will be documented as a mandatory step in the LOTO checklist. All machine operators and setters will receive updated training on this requirement during the next quarterly safety refresher. Thermometers will be permanently stationed at each production line and inspected monthly for calibration.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Protective Equipment for Maintenance Tasks
description: Implement a requirement that all personnel performing maintenance or adjustments on injection molding machines must wear high-temperature resistant gloves rated for 200°C contact and long-sleeved protective shirts made from fire-resistant material. Equipment will be provided by the facility at no cost to employees. This PPE requirement will be clearly communicated through updated work instructions posted at each machine station and reinforced during new employee orientation and monthly toolbox talks. Compliance will be verified through visual inspection by shift supervisors.

name: Install Thermal Caution Labels on All Heated Equipment
description: Apply highly visible warning labels and color-coded tape (international orange) to all injection molding machines, molds, and heated surfaces indicating temperatures that persist after shutdown. Labels will display retention time estimates and safe handling procedures. This administrative control provides visual reminders of ongoing thermal hazards even after equipment has been powered down, reducing the likelihood of inadvertent contact with residual heat.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Program for Safety Interlocks
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly inspection and lubrication of all safety interlock gates on injection molding equipment. Inspections will include mechanical function testing, alignment verification, and locking mechanism performance validation. A maintenance log will be maintained for each machine, and any identified wear or malfunction will trigger immediate repair or component replacement. This engineering control eliminates the risk of interlock failures that create gaps between machine state and control system display, directly addressing the root cause of this near-miss incident.

name: Upgrade Machine Status Monitoring System with Redundant Verification
