This will include pressure hose integrity testing, visual inspection for wear and abrasion, and replacement of hoses nearing end-of-life before rupture occurs. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie will create inspection checklists and track completion. Training will be provided to maintenance technicians on early warning signs of hydraulic system failures. Expected outcome: reduce hydraulic-related incidents by 85% and identify failing components before environmental contamination occurs.

name: Enhanced Spill Response Kit Placement and Training
description: Install four additional emergency spill response kits strategically throughout the production floor with absorbent materials, containment booms, and chemical disposal bags. Conduct mandatory training for all production operators and machine attendants on spill response procedures, including immediate shutdown protocols, area isolation procedures, and proper use of containment materials. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier will develop competency assessments to ensure staff proficiency. Kits will include laminated quick-reference guides. Expected outcome: reduce spill recovery time from 3 hours to under 30 minutes and minimize environmental impact.

name: Secondary Containment System for Hydraulic Equipment
description: Engineer and install secondary containment trays beneath all high-pressure hydraulic connection points on Injection Molding Lines C, D, and E. Trays will have a capacity of 150% of the maximum fluid volume in any single machine circuit. Install visual float indicators to alert operators to fluid accumulation. This engineering control eliminates direct floor contamination and enables rapid fluid recovery. Project will be managed by Maintenance team with external engineering consultation. Expected outcome: prevent future environmental releases from reaching facility floor or external areas.

name: Hazardous Waste Container Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Implement a monthly documented inspection program for all hazardous waste containers in storage areas. Each container will be assessed for structural integrity, corrosion, proper labeling, and secure closure. Containers older than 5 years or showing any signs of deterioration will be replaced immediately. Training Coordinator Amélie Roy will develop inspection checklists and maintain a central database tracking all container inspections, maintenance, and replacements. Weekly inventory audits will verify compliance. Expected outcome: prevent container-related chemical spills and ensure regulatory compliance with waste storage requirements.

name: Chemical Storage Area Environmental Controls Upgrade
description: Install secondary containment berms beneath all chemical storage racks in the Hazardous Waste Management Area with 110% sump capacity of largest container. Upgrade ventilation system to provide continuous air exchange with enhanced vapor capture. Install permanent spill kits with neutralization materials specific to acetone and other stored solvents. Install moisture control dehumidifiers to reduce corrosion rates in the storage area. Implement restricted access protocols with badge entry system. Expected outcome: eliminate container corrosion conditions and contain any future spills to prevent environmental release.

name: Warehouse Dust Control and Housekeeping Protocol Implementation
description: Establish comprehensive dust control procedures requiring daily cleaning of the Raw Materials Warehouse on all shifts, with emphasis on night shift compliance. Implement explosion-proof industrial vacuum collection at material handling stations and installation of HEPA-filtered dust collection systems above storage racks and electrical equipment. Create visual management charts showing required cleaning areas and daily sign-off requirements. Conduct weekly audits of warehouse cleanliness with photographic documentation. Assign responsibility for night shift cleaning compliance to shift supervisor Omar Said. Expected outcome: maintain dust accumulation below 500 microns at all times and reduce fire hazard to negligible levels.

name: Static Electricity Mitigation in Material Storage Areas
description: Install conductive flooring in all material handling and storage zones of the warehouse, including grounding strips and antistatic mats at high-traffic areas. Upgrade electrical grounding system for all metal storage racks and material handling equipment to create continuous conductive path to ground. Install antistatic gloves and footwear requirements at material contact stations. Implement monthly testing of electrical continuity and grounding resistance with documented results. Provide training to all warehouse personnel on static electricity hazards and proper handling procedures. Expected outcome: eliminate static electricity generation during material movement and reduce ignition sources for dust.

name: Fire Detection and Suppression System Enhancement
description: Install automated dust detection sensors throughout the Raw Materials Warehouse that trigger alerts when airborne particulate concentration exceeds safe thresholds (>100 mg/m³). Upgrade dry chemical fire suppression system with enhanced detection capabilities and ensure quarterly testing of suppression equipment. Install visual and audible alarm systems that alert all personnel to dust hazard conditions. Install emergency ventilation override procedures and train all shift supervisors on emergency response protocols. Create evacuation procedures specific to dust fire scenarios. Expected outcome: provide early warning system to prevent dust accumulation and enable rapid emergency response if conditions deteriorate.

name: Install Advanced Ventilation System in Chemical Storage
description: Design and install a dedicated mechanical ventilation system with real-time vapor detection in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. The system will include automated dampers that increase extraction rates when solvent vapor concentrations exceed 25% of LEL (Lower Explosive Limit). All transfer operations will be conducted within an enclosed fume hood with dedicated exhaust to roof. This engineering control directly eliminates the vapor accumulation hazard that caused ignition.

name: Establish Mandatory Equipment Inspection and Maintenance Program
description: Implement quarterly inspections of all transfer pumps, pressure relief valves, and related equipment in chemical storage areas. Create a documented maintenance schedule with predictive testing for pressure valve functionality. Maintenance technicians will be trained on proper pressure relief valve operation and replacement protocols. All equipment will be tagged with last service date and next inspection due date. This addresses the root cause of the malfunctioning pump that contributed to the incident.

name: Reorganize Equipment Layout - Separation of Hazards
description: Relocate industrial ovens and heating equipment to a minimum of 25 feet from all flammable solvent storage and transfer zones, in compliance with NFPA guidelines. Install fireproof barriers between chemical storage areas and any heat-producing equipment. Create designated flammable liquid transfer stations with enhanced clearance and integrated fire suppression nozzles. This engineering control eliminates the ignition source proximity that allowed the fire to develop.

name: Implement Pre-Assembly Component Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory 100% visual and tactile edge inspection procedure for all PC and ABS components before assembly operations. Quality Control personnel will use standardized edge gauges and tactile screening to identify sharp edges exceeding 0.5mm height. Non-compliant components will be returned to deburring or rejected from production. This administrative control directly prevents hand contact with sharp edges by removing defective parts before they reach assembly workers.

name: Calibrate Deburring Equipment for Resin Batch Specifications
description: Develop a resin batch-specific deburring protocol that adjusts equipment parameters based on resin type, brittleness index, and cooling characteristics. Maintenance technicians will perform equipment calibration verification before processing each new material batch. Create a reference chart correlating resin specifications to optimal deburring pressures, speeds, and tool selections. This engineering control ensures deburring equipment is properly configured to eliminate sharp edges for all material variations.

name: Install Secure Storage Racks with Retaining Systems
description: Replace existing open storage racks on the UNIT-025 mezzanine with engineered storage systems featuring integrated retaining clips, edge guards, and safety rails. All components will be stored in designated bins with secondary containment to prevent items from falling to lower levels. Racks will be designed to accommodate only items that will be safely retained even if impacted. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of falling objects by physically preventing parts from leaving the storage area.

name: Mandate Hard Hat and Safety Equipment in Overhead Hazard Zones
description: Establish and enforce a workplace standard requiring all personnel working in or beneath areas elevated more than 8 feet to wear ANSI-certified hard hats and eye protection at all times. Post highly visible signage at mezzanine entry points indicating mandatory PPE requirements. Conduct toolbox talks during each shift emphasizing overhead hazards. Non-compliance will result in immediate work suspension and retraining. While PPE is a last-resort control, this administrative requirement provides personal protection until engineering controls are fully implemented.

name: Implement Two-Person Retrieval Procedure for Elevated Storage
description: Establish an administrative procedure requiring that all components stored above 8 feet on mezzanine levels be retrieved using a two-person team with designated roles: one person operating the retrieval equipment and one person serving as a spotter positioned to observe and prevent objects from falling. For items weighing more than 5 kilograms, mechanical retrieval equipment (vacuum lifts or hoists) must be used rather than manual handling. Provide training on spotting procedures and equipment operation to all maintenance staff. This administrative control reduces risk through enhanced procedures and second-level verification.

name: Install Secondary Containment Barriers on Storage Racks
description: Install welded steel mesh safety barriers on all mezzanine-level storage racks to prevent items from falling to lower levels. Barriers will be installed at the leading edge of each shelf level, with 50mm spacing to allow air circulation while containing falling objects. All existing racks will be retrofitted within 14 days. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of falling objects by creating a physical barrier that prevents items from leaving the intended storage zone, regardless of vibration or improper securing.

name: Implement Quarterly Rack Inspection and Load Verification Program
description: Establish a formal quarterly inspection protocol for all storage racks where trained maintenance personnel verify load securing, shelf integrity, and weight distribution compliance. All items above 5 kg must be secured with redundant restraints (cables or straps). Inspections will be documented and filed. This administrative control ensures ongoing compliance with proper storage practices and identifies potential hazards before they result in incidents.

name: Require Safety Helmets in Equipment Storage Areas
description: Mandate that all personnel entering the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room must wear hard hats rated for falling object protection (EN 397 or equivalent). This requirement will be communicated via signage at all access points and reinforced during safety toolbox talks. While a PPE measure, this provides immediate personal protection given the high mezzanine storage configuration and the time required to fully implement engineering controls.

name: Implement Dual-Authorization LOTO Protocol with Lock Verification
description: Establish a mandatory procedure requiring two-person verification before any machine startup following LOTO removal. The operator must physically present their personal LOTO lock to the machine supervisor or second authorized technician, who will visually verify it is installed and secure before any equipment can be energized. All machine startup attempts will be documented in a log. This administrative control eliminates the possibility of a machine being operated while LOTO devices are absent or improperly installed by introducing a mandatory verification checkpoint.

name: Install Physical LOTO Verification Indicator Lights on All Injection Molding Units
description: Install green indicator lights on all 12 injection molding machines that illuminate only when proper LOTO devices are physically installed and electrically verified. The light provides visual confirmation that the machine is in a safe locked-out state. This engineering control provides real-time feedback that a machine cannot be safely operated unless LOTO is properly engaged, reducing reliance on human verification alone.

name: Conduct Mandatory LOTO Retraining for All Machine Operators
description: Require immediate retraining of all 18 production operators and maintenance technicians on LOTO procedures, emphasizing the critical importance of never temporarily removing locks during active work. Training will include case studies of similar near-miss and lost-time incidents, and each employee will be required to certify competency. Training will be delivered by the LOTO Coordinator within 5 days, with documentation maintained.

name: Implement Paper Handling Safety Guidelines and Workspace Organization Standards
description: Develop and distribute standardized guidelines for safe paper and documentation handling in administrative areas, including proper stacking techniques (maximum 5 cm height), use of document carts for transfers of more than 50 pages, and prohibition of loose paper stacks on work surfaces. Implement a workspace organization audit monthly to ensure compliance. All administrative staff will receive 15-minute training on proper techniques. This administrative control reduces the hazard by establishing safe work practices and preventing situations where paper bundles become unstable.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Injection Molding Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance system utilizing vibration analysis and thermal imaging to detect bearing degradation before failure. Schedule quarterly inspections of all cooling systems, hydraulic manifolds, and pressure relief valves on 32 injection molding machines. Maintain digital records with mandatory sign-offs and calibration certificates. Integrate with existing maintenance workshop operations to ensure technician availability. This engineering control will prevent future pump bearing seizures and cooling system contamination.

name: Replace All Pressure Relief Valves with Certified Units and Install Redundant Safety Systems
description: Replace the aging pressure relief valve on Machine #7 and conduct full audit of all 31 remaining injection molding machines. Install redundant relief valves on critical machines (250+ ton capacity). Establish a mandatory valve certification and recalibration schedule every 12 months with third-party verification. Train all machine setters on proper valve functionality checks. This substitution and engineering control eliminates the single-point failure mode that allowed hydraulic overpressure.

name: Replace HVAC Intake Filters and Recalibrate Ventilation System
description: Immediately replace all four intake filters in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room and conduct full ventilation system recalibration. Verify that exhaust velocity meets 150 lfm minimum specification across all mixing stations using professional anemometer testing. Establish mandatory filter replacement schedule every 6 months with documented records maintained in CMMS system. This engineering control restores proper negative pressure and chemical fume removal capacity to design specifications.

name: Repair and Calibrate VOC/CO Monitoring System and Establish Real-Time Monitoring Protocol
description: Engage certified industrial hygiene firm to repair the non-functional VOC and carbon monoxide sensor system within 48 hours. Install backup sensor units and real-time alarm notification system integrated with facility management system. Establish weekly calibration checks using certified gas standards. Train all chemical room personnel on alarm response procedures and emergency ventilation protocols. Schedule monthly professional monitoring and quarterly third-party air quality verification.

name: Replace Expired Eyewash Station Cartridges and Establish Monthly Inspection Protocol
description: Replace all expired rinse solution cartridges in the four emergency eyewash stations immediately. Implement monthly inspection schedule with documented sign-offs. Provide training to all chemical room employees on proper eyewash station use. Maintain inventory of replacement cartridges with 3-month supply buffer. Post emergency contact information and eyewash station locations at all entry points to mixing area.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protection Gloves to Silicone-Based High-Temperature Rating (250°C+)
description: Replace all nitrile-based heat-resistant gloves with premium silicone-coated gloves rated for 280°C+ continuous contact across all 32 injection molding machine stations. Conduct training session for all 45 production operators on proper glove selection, fit verification, and care procedures. Establish quarterly glove inspection and replacement schedule. Stock inventory to ensure immediate availability. This PPE upgrade provides enhanced thermal insulation and reduces burn risk by 85% based on industry data.

name: Install Automated Mold Cooling and Anti-Jam Ejector Pin System on Line D
description: Retrofit Machine #7 Line D with automated mold pin cleaning and cooling subsystem that performs micro-purges every 15 cycles to prevent polymer residue accumulation. Install pressure sensors on ejector pins to detect jamming resistance and automatically alert operators before mold opening sequence. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of incomplete mold opening and reduces mold surface temperature during part removal by pre-cooling the mold to safe handling temperature (below 70°C).

name: Implement Mandatory Thermal Imaging Inspections and Temperature Monitoring Protocol
description: Conduct thermal imaging inspections of all injection molding molds weekly to identify abnormal heat retention and partial cooling zones. Install infrared temperature sensors on high-risk machines (Line D, Machine #9, Machine #15) with real-time operator display showing mold surface temperature. Establish machine lockout if mold surface exceeds 100°C during part removal. Create administrative procedure requiring operators to wait minimum 30 seconds after cycle completion before accessing molds. Provide training to all production staff on thermal hazard recognition.

name: Upgrade Compressed Air Safety Couplings and Nozzles
description: Replace all existing compressed air nozzles and couplings throughout the facility with pressure-rated, quick-disconnect couplings featuring integrated safety retaining clips and check valves. Install pressure-limiting regulators on all air stations to ensure outlet pressure does not exceed 90 psi. Provide secondary backup shutoff valves at each machine air inlet. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of uncontrolled high-pressure air release by addressing the root cause—inadequate equipment specifications and lack of redundant safety systems.

name: Implement Compressed Air Safety Training and Daily Inspection Protocol
description: Develop and deliver mandatory compressed air safety training to all production operators and maintenance technicians, covering hazards, safe practices, and proper equipment inspection. Establish a daily pre-shift inspection checklist requiring operators to verify all couplings are secured with retaining clips, nozzles are pressure-rated, and hoses show no signs of damage. Create a log system to document inspections and any maintenance issues. Train supervisors to conduct weekly audits of compliance.

name: Install Secondary Containment Systems for Chemical Storage
description: Implement secondary containment trays and spill pallets beneath all bulk chemical storage and transfer stations in UNIT-010. Each containment system must have a capacity of at least 110% of the largest single container stored above it. Install absorbent drip pans under all transfer points and valve connections. Add clearly marked drain plugs with collection containers for emergency spill containment. This engineering control prevents spills from spreading across the facility floor and reaching drainage systems or personnel work areas.

name: Establish Chemical Container Valve Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Create a quarterly inventory and inspection protocol for all chemical storage container valve caps and seals. Replace all worn, damaged, or cross-threaded caps immediately and maintain spare valve caps on-site. Establish a labeling system to track valve condition and last inspection date. Provide training to all personnel handling chemical containers on proper valve cap installation techniques using a torque-limiting tool to prevent over-tightening and cross-threading. Document all inspections and replacements in a maintenance log.

name: Upgrade Spill Response Equipment and Station Accessibility
description: Install additional spill response stations within 50 feet of all chemical storage and transfer areas, each equipped with absorbent pads, spill kits, PPE (nitrile gloves, safety glasses, respirator cartridges), and emergency contact information. Mount wall signage identifying spill response procedures, hazard warnings, and evacuation routes. Conduct quarterly spill response drills with all shift teams to ensure competency and rapid response capability. Maintain monthly inventory checks of spill kits to ensure materials remain fresh and available.

name: Complete Hydraulic System Audit and Preventive Maintenance Schedule Overhaul
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all hydraulic systems throughout the facility, identifying all pipe couplings, seals, and connection points. Update the equipment maintenance database to include every hydraulic component with specific inspection intervals (monthly for pressurized connections, quarterly for all other components). Establish a color-coded tagging system for each component indicating last inspection date and next service due. Implement a digital maintenance tracking system with automated alerts to maintenance supervisors when inspections are due. This administrative control ensures no critical hydraulic connections are overlooked.

name: Install Hydraulic Drip Collection Systems Under Overhead Equipment
description: Install secondary containment trays and drip collection systems beneath all overhead hydraulic equipment and pipe runs on the mezzanine, designed to capture 110% of maximum fluid capacity. Connect collection trays to sealed holding tanks rather than to drainage systems, allowing for safe recovery and proper disposal of leaked hydraulic fluid. Install visual overflow indicators on all collection tanks. Add absorbent drip pads in high-risk areas around couplings and valve connections. This engineering control prevents environmental discharge to municipal drainage systems.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Inspection Schedule
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic hoses and fittings on injection molding equipment. All hoses will be inspected quarterly for wear, leaks, and pressure integrity. Hoses exceeding 5 years in service will be replaced proactively regardless of condition. A tracking database will be maintained to log all inspections and replacements. This engineering control eliminates the risk of unexpected hose failure by addressing degradation before catastrophic breakage occurs.

name: Install Secondary Containment Barriers
description: Install physical barriers and secondary containment trays beneath all hydraulic injection molding equipment to capture fluid in case of hose rupture. These engineered containment systems will prevent hydraulic fluid from spreading across the production floor and minimize environmental contamination. The barriers will be sized to hold 110% of system fluid volume and include drain valves for controlled disposal.

name: Upgrade Chemical Safety Eyewear Requirements
description: Mandate that all personnel working with organic solvents and cleaning agents in the Quality Control Laboratory wear chemical splash goggles certified for liquid and vapor protection, not standard safety glasses. Replace all existing eyewear in QC areas with appropriate chemical splash protection. Conduct training on proper donning/doffing procedures and inspection of eyewear for damage. This PPE upgrade directly addresses the root cause of inadequate eye protection when handling volatile solvents.

name: Establish Secondary Containment for Solvent Use
description: Install drip trays and secondary containment basins in all areas where acetone and other volatile organic solvents are stored, handled, or used in QC testing. Implement administrative control requiring that solvent transfers be performed within contained areas to prevent spills and splashes. Add absorbent pads rated for organic solvents to all workstations handling these materials. This engineering and administrative control reduces the likelihood of accidental solvent contact with personnel.

name: Implement Mandatory Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) for All Machine Maintenance
description: Establish a strict policy requiring that all safety interlocks must be engaged using formal lockout/tagout procedures before any personnel operate equipment. Eliminate temporary interlock bypasses in favor of properly documented LOTO procedures with physical lockout devices and warning tags. Create a log system where all LOTO activations and deactivations are recorded with employee names, times, and purposes. Conduct mandatory LOTO training for all production operators and setters within 5 days. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the possibility of unintended machine engagement during maintenance.

name: Install Visual Safety Interlock Status Indicators
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with prominent visual indicators (LED lights and status displays) showing real-time interlock engagement status. Red light indicates interlock is active/engaged; yellow indicates interlock has been bypassed (with audible alarm). This engineering control ensures all operators can visually confirm safety system status before approaching machine hoppers or moving parts.

name: Conduct Machine Safety Refresher Training
description: Implement mandatory retraining for all production operators and machine setters on proper hopper loading procedures, safety interlock functions, and recognition of disabled safety systems. Training will include case studies of similar incidents and consequences of bypassing safety controls. Competency assessments will be administered with passing required before return to full production duties.

name: Implement Overhead Cable and Hose Management System
description: Install overhead cable trays and hose management system in the Regrind and Recycling Department to route all air hoses, electrical cables, and hydraulic lines above head height and floor level. This engineering control will eliminate trip hazards by removing hoses from the floor entirely. Install cable clips every 2 meters and secure all hoses with color-coded identification. Conduct a facility walkthrough to identify all similar hazards in other departments and implement consistent standards facility-wide.

name: Establish Weekly Housekeeping and Hazard Inspection Audits
description: Create a formal weekly inspection checklist for all production areas and storage zones, focusing on floor hazards, cable routing, and emergency exit clearance. Assign responsibility to shift supervisors and materials handlers to conduct 15-minute pre-shift inspections. Results will be logged and reviewed in monthly JHSC meetings. Any identified hazards must be corrected immediately or work area cordoned off. Train all personnel on the inspection protocol during the next safety meeting.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic Press Safety Systems with Pressure Relief Redundancy
description: Install dual redundant pressure relief valves on all 32 injection molding and compression presses to prevent catastrophic pressure release incidents. Each press will have a primary and secondary relief valve configured to maintain safe pressure limits. Additionally, install proximity sensors that detect platen position and activate an emergency stop if movement exceeds normal parameters. Update the preventive maintenance program to include quarterly inspection and testing of all pressure relief systems. Conduct competency training for all operators and maintenance technicians on the new safety systems.

name: Revise Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Equipment
description: Update the facility-wide preventive maintenance schedule to include quarterly inspection and functional testing of pressure relief and check valves on all hydraulic equipment. Create a digital tracking system using work order software to ensure no maintenance items are missed. Include specific pressure relief valve testing procedures that verify proper operation at rated pressure. Assign maintenance responsibility to certified hydraulic technicians only. Audit compliance monthly and report results to the JHSC.

name: Implement Enhanced Machine Guarding and Awareness Training
description: Install clear warning labels and guard rails around all hydraulic press work stations to create exclusion zones during equipment operation. Implement a mandatory 2-hour retraining program for all operators covering pressure release hazards, emergency response procedures, and proper use of safety devices. Include role-playing scenarios for emergency situations. Conduct refresher training annually and after any incident or equipment modification.

name: Install Mandatory LOTO Status Indicator Lights and Signage
description: Install bright red LED indicator lights on the control panel of all 32 injection molding machines that illuminate when a machine is under LOTO status. Add large laminated signage on each machine showing current LOTO status and the name of the employee responsible for the lockout. Implement an electronic LOTO tracking system that logs all lockout events with timestamps and employee identification. The system will display real-time status on a centralized dashboard visible to all operators. This engineering control prevents accidental machine startup during maintenance.

name: Establish Formal Shift Handoff Safety Communication Protocol
description: Create a mandatory 15-minute shift overlap period where outgoing and incoming shift supervisors conduct a documented handoff meeting covering all active maintenance, LOTO status, machine conditions, and safety concerns. Use a standardized handoff checklist that specifically addresses lockout/tagout status for each piece of equipment. Both supervisors must sign off on the handoff document. Implement this protocol immediately with training for all supervisory staff. Include this procedure in the annual LOTO refresher training.

name: Implement Mandatory Double-Verification LOTO Protocol
description: Establish a new procedure requiring two independent workers to verify all lockout/tagout steps before any mold maintenance begins. Each verification step must be documented on a physical checklist and signed by both parties. Weekly audits will be conducted by the HSE department to ensure compliance. All machine operators and maintenance technicians will receive refresher training on the new protocol within 5 days. This engineering/administrative hybrid control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate LOTO verification.

name: Install Mold Safety Interlock Upgrade
description: Replace existing mold safety interlocks with advanced proximity sensors that prevent mold closure if any foreign object (including hands) is detected within the danger zone. The new system will include visual and audible warnings when the system is armed. Installation will be performed by qualified technicians over a 2-day period. Comprehensive testing will validate sensor sensitivity and fail-safe functionality. All line operators will be trained on the new system before production resumes.

name: Enhanced Chemical Container Inspection Program
description: Implement a bi-weekly visual inspection protocol for all stored chemical containers, focusing on integrity, seal condition, and signs of degradation. Inspections will be documented on a dedicated form and entered into the inventory management system. Any container showing signs of compromise will be immediately transferred to secondary containment and flagged for replacement. Training will be provided to warehouse staff and supervisors on identifying container defects. This administrative control eliminates the risk of future undetected container failures.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Environmental Controls
description: Install a temperature and humidity monitoring system in the chemical storage area to maintain consistent conditions (18-25°C, 40-60% RH). The system will include automatic alerts if conditions drift outside acceptable ranges. Climate control will be enhanced by adding insulation to external walls and installing a dedicated mini-split HVAC unit. This engineering control addresses the root cause of thermal stress on containers and reduces VOC release potential.

name: Establish Wet Floor Work Coordination Protocol
description: Create a daily communication system between cleaning operations and material handling teams. Before any wet cleaning occurs in production or warehouse areas, cleaning supervisors must notify the shift supervisor and request temporary rerouting of forklift traffic. No cleaning will proceed until alternate routes are confirmed and in place. A digital log will track all wet floor events and ensure coordination occurred. This administrative control prevents equipment/load conflicts during cleaning operations.

name: Install High-Friction Epoxy Flooring in Material Handling Zones
description: Replace the current epoxy floor coating in the Post-Processing and warehouse areas with a specialized high-friction epoxy product designed for wet conditions. The new coating will provide superior traction even when wet, significantly reducing slip risk for forklifts and pedestrians. Installation will occur over a 3-day period in two phases to maintain operational capacity. Product specifications require minimum slip resistance rating of R13 per ISO 13287 standards.

name: Install Thermal-Resistant Gloves and Enhanced Signage
description: Procure and distribute heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C) to all injection molding operators on Lines A through D, and post prominent warning signs at each mold station indicating mandatory glove use during manual interventions. Conduct mandatory toolbox talks emphasizing that automated systems must complete their cycles before any manual contact. This addresses the root cause of inadequate PPE and operator impatience during high-temperature operations.

name: Implement Mold Touch Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install temperature display panels on each injection molding machine showing real-time mold surface temperatures. This provides operators with immediate visual confirmation of safe-to-touch conditions, preventing premature manual interventions. Engineering controls reduce reliance on operator judgment and significantly decrease burn incident probability.

name: Replace and Reinforce Storage Rack Structural Integrity
description: Complete replacement of the affected storage rack with a new commercial-grade system rated for 500 kg per shelf tier. Conduct structural engineering assessment of all existing storage racks in the facility. Install secondary safety cables and anti-tip brackets on all racks. All mounting bolts will be upgraded to stainless steel with quarterly torque verification. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of structural failure and prevents future falling object incidents.

name: Implement Storage Rack Inspection and Load-Limit Labeling Program
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection schedule for all storage racks performed by maintenance technicians, with documented load weight limits clearly labeled on each shelf. Train all personnel in proper load distribution principles and implement a sign-off system requiring employee signatures when retrieving materials from height. Administrative controls will ensure ongoing compliance and early detection of structural degradation.

name: Issue Hard Hats and Shoulder Protection for Maintenance Areas
description: Distribute ANSI-certified hard hats and padded shoulder protection vests to all personnel working in storage and maintenance areas with overhead equipment or stored materials. Post mandatory PPE signage at all entry points to the mezzanine storage area. While PPE is the last control hierarchy, it provides critical protection while engineering and administrative controls are being implemented.

name: Install Color-Coded and Tactilely-Distinct Valve Systems
description: Replace all hydraulic relief and bleed-off valves on injection molding machines with distinctly different valve types: pressure relief valves with round red knobs, system bleed-off valves with square blue knobs, and drain valves with yellow rectangular handles. This engineering control eliminates operator confusion and prevents future valve misidentification. Include detailed valve location diagrams on laminated cards installed on each machine.

name: Establish Mandatory Hydraulic System Lockout-Tagout (LOTO) Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory LOTO procedure requiring all hydraulic systems to be depressurized, locked out, and tagged before any maintenance begins. Create a laminated LOTO checklist specific to each machine model, requiring technicians to follow a three-step verification sequence: (1) activate manual pressure relief, (2) open designated bleed valve, (3) verify zero pressure on gauge. Conduct quarterly refresher training on LOTO procedures for all maintenance personnel.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedures and Machine Interlock Installation
description: Install mechanical interlock systems on all injection molding machines to prevent startup when access doors are open. Implement mandatory lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures requiring equipment isolation before any maintenance work. Provide immediate retraining for all operators and maintenance staff on LOTO requirements under CNESST regulations. Establish a pre-work communication protocol between maintenance and operations teams via radio and visual signage. Place red 'Do Not Operate' tags on all machines undergoing maintenance.

name: Enhanced Machine Guarding and Safety Training Program
description: Upgrade machine guarding on all injection molding equipment to meet or exceed OSHA standards, ensuring no accessible pinch points or entanglement hazards. Implement quarterly refresher training for all production and maintenance staff on machinery hazards, proper lockout procedures, and emergency response. Document all training sessions and maintain records in the HSE office. Conduct toolbox talks before each shift focused on machine safety awareness.

name: Machine Guard Inspection and Replacement Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily inspection checklist for all grinding and material handling equipment, with particular focus on guard integrity and placement. Create a tracking system requiring sign-off documentation after any maintenance work confirming all guards are properly reinstalled. Design and install permanent, non-removable guards on the regrind station hopper entrance that still allow safe material feeding. Conduct immediate training for all maintenance personnel on proper guard reinstallation procedures.

name: Chemical Transfer Equipment Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all chemical transfer pumps, requiring inspection and seal replacement every 6 months or after 500 operational hours, whichever comes first. Establish a maintenance log tracked in the facilities management system. Upgrade all transfer nozzles to include secondary retention mechanisms preventing accidental detachment. Install drip trays and secondary containment under all chemical transfer points capable of holding 110% of container volumes. Train all operators on equipment inspection procedures and proper shutdown in case of malfunction.

name: Enhanced Chemical Spill Response and Containment Procedures
description: Develop comprehensive written procedures for all chemical spill scenarios with clear roles and responsibilities for response personnel. Install additional absorbent material stations throughout chemical storage and mixing areas with clear signage. Establish a dedicated emergency response team with quarterly drills to practice containment and cleanup procedures. Upgrade the floor drainage system with spill containment traps and shut-off valves accessible from multiple locations. Create a chemical spill response kit inventory checklist and ensure kits are maintained at full capacity at all times.

name: Install Thermal Barrier Guards on Mold Access Points
description: Engineering control to prevent direct skin contact with hot mold surfaces. Install removable polycarbonate barriers around all mold injection points on Line A, with clearly marked access gates for part removal. Barriers will maintain 15cm minimum distance from mold surfaces. This eliminates the primary hazard pathway while maintaining production workflow. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in burn contact incidents on this line.

name: Mandatory Hot Surface Handling Refresher Training
description: Administrative control requiring all production operators on molding lines to complete 2-hour refresher training on thermal hazards, proper PPE selection, and emergency response procedures. Training will be delivered by Amélie Roy (Training Coordinator) and include hands-on demonstration of appropriate heat-resistant gloves and sleeves. Quarterly refresher sessions will be scheduled. All operators must pass competency assessment before returning to mold handling duties.

name: Upgrade to Flame-Resistant Protective Sleeves
description: PPE enhancement requiring all operators on injection molding lines to wear Kevlar-reinforced heat-resistant sleeves rated for 400°C contact for minimum 3 seconds. Current inventory of basic cotton sleeves will be replaced with ANSI-certified thermal protection equipment. Sleeves will be inspected monthly for degradation and replaced every 6 months. Cost per operator: $45. This addresses the gap in current PPE adequacy.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring in Composite Processing Area
description: Engineering control to eliminate slip hazards in maintenance zones. Apply 3mm-thick polyurethane anti-slip coating to all floor areas beneath and around composite processing equipment where resin residue accumulates. The coating will be applied to approximately 200 square meters in the West Wing. Coating has 5-year durability and will be inspected quarterly. This eliminates the root cause of the slipping hazard.

name: Implement Shift-End Resin Cleanup Protocol
description: Administrative control establishing mandatory end-of-shift cleanup procedures for all composite processing areas. Evening shift operators must complete 15-minute resin residue removal using approved solvent wipes and floor squeegees before 11:00 PM. A checklist system will be implemented with supervisor sign-off. Cleaning supplies will be standardized and stored in designated carts. Weekly audits will verify compliance. This prevents hazardous material accumulation.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for All Solvent Storage
description: Engineering control to prevent liquid spills and vapor release. Install metal drip trays with 110% capacity of the largest container beneath all shelf-stored solvents in the Chemical Storage Room. Trays will have absorbent liners rated for organic solvents. Additionally, install self-closing cabinet ventilation with carbon filtration to capture fugitive vapors. The system will maintain negative pressure in the storage area. This eliminates the primary pathway for vapor generation and containment failure.

name: Mandate Vapor-Tight Lids on All Chemical Containers
description: Administrative/procedural control requiring all chemical containers larger than 1 liter to be stored with vapor-tight lids at all times, except during active dispensing. Supervisors will conduct daily pre-shift inspections of all storage areas, with documentation in the safety logbook. Non-compliant containers will be taken off-line for proper disposal and replacement. Staff will be trained on proper lid installation during chemical handling refresher sessions. This prevents vapor generation.

name: Implement Mandatory Night Shift Chemical Handling Certification
description: Administrative control requiring all night shift personnel handling chemicals to complete comprehensive WHMIS and chemical safety certification course before working unsupervised in chemical storage areas. Training will include solvent hazard identification, emergency response procedures, proper container handling, and respiratory protection requirements. Night shift coordinator will schedule training sessions in two cohorts. Certification must be renewed annually. Workers must demonstrate competency via practical assessment.

name: Implement Enhanced Mold Inspection Protocol
description: Develop and distribute a standardized visual inspection checklist for mold operators to identify contamination signs before production begins. The checklist will include criteria for discoloration, surface irregularities, and cooling channel issues. Training sessions will be conducted for all production staff on UNIT-001 to recognize early warning signs of mold contamination. A digital logbook will be maintained to track mold conditions over time, enabling predictive maintenance scheduling.

name: Upgrade Mold Cleaning Procedures
description: Establish a standardized mold cleaning protocol with defined cleaning intervals and approved solvents. This includes replacing the current wooden scrapers with approved plastic or brass tools that minimize micro-damage to mold surfaces. Documentation will specify which solvents are appropriate for each resin type to prevent residue accumulation. Staff will receive hands-on training in proper cleaning techniques to avoid future contamination incidents.

name: Install Flexible Protective Cable Covers and Reorganize Hose Routing
description: Implement flexible protective cable covers (minimum 3 inches high) over all air hoses that cross established walkways in UNIT-018. Hoses will be rerouted where possible to run along walls or ceiling using suspended clipping systems. All floor-level hoses will be secured with heavy-duty clamps every 3 feet and marked with high-visibility yellow and black striping tape. Emergency shut-off valves will be installed at key hose junctions to enable rapid depressurization if routing changes become necessary.

name: Conduct Workplace Hazard Awareness Training for Evening Shift
description: Schedule mandatory 30-minute training session for evening shift staff on trip hazard recognition and reporting procedures. Focus will be on identifying dislodged hoses, cables, and equipment before they cause incidents. Staff will learn proper communication protocols when discovering hazards and the importance of immediate reporting. A refresher session will be scheduled for all shifts quarterly, with particular emphasis on transition periods between shifts.

name: Mandatory Ladder Safety and Fall Protection Program Implementation
description: Implement comprehensive fall protection requirements for all work at heights exceeding 6 feet in UNIT-012. Install permanent anchor points and rail systems to enable harness attachment. All maintenance staff will complete CNESST-certified ladder safety training and annual refresher courses. Personal protective equipment will include anti-slip gloves rated for wet conditions and hard hats. A pre-work checklist will require visual ladder inspection before each use, with mandatory equipment replacement every 10 years or upon damage.

name: Revise Work Schedule and Implement Fatigue Management Protocol
description: Establish mandatory 15-minute break intervals for every 2 hours of maintenance work on the night shift, with rest areas designated in the maintenance workshop. No maintenance personnel will work more than 5 consecutive hours without a documented break. Work schedules will be reviewed to ensure adequate staffing prevents excessive overtime and fatigue. Night shift supervisors will complete training on recognizing signs of worker fatigue and will have authority to reassign employees to lower-risk tasks if fatigue is detected.

name: Upgrade Ladder Maintenance Workshop Environmental Controls
description: Install improved ventilation and humidity control systems in the Central Maintenance Workshop to reduce moisture accumulation that degrades grip conditions. Add non-slip coating to ladder rungs and install auxiliary lighting at ladder staging areas. Humidity monitoring equipment will track conditions daily, with alerts triggering maintenance protocols when humidity exceeds safe thresholds. Anti-slip foot coverings will be mandatory for all personnel working at heights in high-humidity areas.

name: Implement Preventive Hydraulic System Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic systems on injection molding machines, including pressure relief valve inspections, fluid analysis, and leak detection protocols. Maintenance technicians will inspect all pressure connections, seals, and gauges using ultrasonic leak detection equipment. This addresses the root cause of equipment malfunction by catching deteriorating components before failure. Implementation includes creating a maintenance log system and training all operators to recognize early warning signs of hydraulic system degradation.

name: Upgrade Pressure Gauge Monitoring System
description: Replace analog pressure gauges on all 32 injection molding machines with digital electronic pressure transmitters that provide real-time data logging and audible alerts when parameters drift beyond acceptable ranges. This engineering control eliminates reliance on operator visual inspection of unstable gauges and provides automatic documentation of pressure anomalies. The system will integrate with the machine control interface, enabling operators and maintenance staff to access historical pressure trends via the facility management system.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring in High-Risk Warehouse Areas
description: Apply high-friction anti-slip coatings to all floor surfaces in the Finished Goods Warehouse, particularly around pallet storage areas where plastic film and packaging debris accumulate. The engineering control involves installing textured epoxy flooring that maintains grip even when wet or contaminated with plastic materials. This eliminates the primary slip hazard identified in the incident. The coating will be rated for warehouse conditions and inspected quarterly for wear and reapplication needs.

name: Enforce Two-Person Stacking Protocol and Cross-Training
description: Implement a formal administrative control requiring that all stacking operations above 1 meter height must be performed by at least two trained personnel. Conduct cross-training sessions for all warehouse staff to ensure adequate coverage and reduce instances where single operators continue unsupervised work. Create visual warning signs at pallet storage zones reminding staff of the two-person requirement. Regular audits will verify compliance and identify training gaps.

name: Upgrade to Chemical-Resistant Glove Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a daily glove inspection requirement where all employees handling mold release agents must visually inspect both layers of gloves for tears, punctures, or wear before beginning work. Supervisors will conduct spot-check inspections at shift start. Establish a system where employees can immediately exchange gloves at first sign of damage. Replace standard latex gloves with nitrile or butyl rubber gloves that provide superior chemical resistance to petroleum distillates. Employees will be trained to recognize signs of glove degradation and taught proper glove removal techniques to minimize skin exposure.

name: Implement Closed-Loop Mold Release Application System
description: Replace pressurized spray bottles with an engineered closed-loop applicator system that delivers mold release agent through a controlled tip, significantly reducing spray mist generation. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of chemical mist inhalation and skin contact. The new system will include drip trays to contain any spillage and will be integrated into the mold maintenance workflow. Training will ensure operators understand the reduced risk but maintain other protective measures as backup controls.

name: Install Continuous Temperature Monitoring and Alarm System on Resin Dryers
description: Implement automated temperature monitoring devices on all resin dryers throughout the material drying room with real-time alerts when temperatures exceed safe operating limits. The system will include visual and audible alarms on the equipment and notifications to supervisor tablets. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause (thermostat malfunction) and ensures early detection of hazardous conditions before fumes are released. Expected outcome: elimination of preventable fume exposure events from temperature-related failures.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Material Drying and Preparation Room
description: Conduct engineering assessment and upgrade the local exhaust ventilation system in UNIT-016 to ensure air changes meet or exceed 8-12 per hour. Install additional spot ventilation hoods directly above high-temperature equipment zones. Verify system performance through air velocity testing. This engineering control provides the second line of defense against fume accumulation and improves overall air quality during normal operations and minor equipment malfunctions.

name: Mandatory Quarterly Equipment Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish a formal preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly inspections of all resin dryer temperature control systems and quarterly full calibration of thermostats. Maintenance technicians will document findings in the asset management system. Operators will receive training on daily visual checks and shutdown procedures if fumes are detected. This administrative control ensures equipment reliability and provides multiple touchpoints for catching degradation before critical failure.

name: Implement Pallet Inspection and Certification Program
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection protocol for all wooden pallets used in raw materials storage. Pallets will be visually inspected for cracks, splinters, water damage, and structural degradation. Non-compliant pallets will be immediately removed from service and replaced with certified industrial-grade pallets (plastic or reinforced wood). All compliant pallets will be marked with inspection date labels. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the hazard of load instability by ensuring only sound pallets support crane-lifted loads.

name: Replace Deteriorated Storage Drum Valves and Implement Preventive Maintenance
description: Inspect all storage drums in the Chemical Storage building for valve integrity and leakage. Replace any valves showing corrosion, seepage, or deterioration with new stainless steel or compatible material valves. Implement a quarterly valve inspection and maintenance schedule. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the spill (defective valve) and prevents recurrence of chemical releases in the storage area.

name: Reorganize Chemical Storage Layout with Secondary Containment Zones
description: Redesign the chemical storage room layout to separate frequently-used chemicals from less-accessed materials, reducing reach distances and improper handling. Implement secondary containment trays under all pressurized containers and drum storage racks. Install clear signage indicating hazard zones and proper retrieval procedures. This administrative and engineering control reduces the likelihood of accidental contact with equipment and ensures any minor leaks are contained before spreading.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Heating Elements
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program specifically for injection molding machine heating elements on all production lines. This includes thermographic imaging inspections to detect early thermal anomalies, replacement of heating elements showing signs of degradation, and electrical connection verification. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie will coordinate with the maintenance team to create detailed inspection checklists and schedule maintenance during planned downtime to prevent unexpected failures that trigger false alarms.

name: Upgrade Fire Detection System in Production Area
description: Install advanced multi-sensor fire detection units (combination of smoke and temperature sensors) directly above each injection molding line to provide early warning of equipment malfunctions before fire alarm activation. The new sensors will be integrated with the facility's building management system to alert maintenance personnel automatically. This engineering control reduces false alarms caused by equipment failures while maintaining critical fire safety.

name: Implement Compliant Chemical Storage System
description: Install a dedicated, properly ventilated chemical storage cabinet with secondary containment in the Tool Room. All flammable solvents and cleaning products will be transferred to WHMIS-compliant containers with clear labeling and safety data sheet access. Implement a digital inventory tracking system for all hazardous materials with monthly audits. Establish a 'no storage near electrical outlets' policy with clear floor markings and signage. Provide mandatory training for all staff on proper chemical storage procedures.

name: Upgrade Electrical Infrastructure in Maintenance Workshop
description: Conduct a comprehensive electrical audit of UNIT-013 to identify exposed wiring, outdated outlets, and potential fire hazards. Replace all non-compliant electrical infrastructure with modern, properly grounded outlets featuring ground-fault protection. Install dedicated circuits for high-load equipment away from chemical storage areas. Ensure all electrical work meets current Canadian electrical codes and facility standards.

name: Establish Chemical Handling and Fire Safety Training Program
description: Develop comprehensive training curriculum covering WHMIS regulations, proper chemical storage, fire prevention in manufacturing settings, and correct fire extinguisher use (Class A, B, and C). All maintenance and production staff must complete this training within 30 days with annual refresher courses. Coordinate with Jamal Thompson (Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator) to integrate respiratory safety for potential fume exposure. Require competency certification before employees can handle hazardous materials.

name: Enforce Mandatory Lockout/Tagout Procedures
description: Implement a zero-tolerance policy for LOTO compliance during all equipment maintenance, repair, and jam-clearing activities. Conduct immediate retraining for all packaging line operators on proper LOTO procedures, including verification steps and documentation requirements. Install lockout stations at each packaging machine with clearly labeled LOTO devices and responsibility assignments. Establish a verification checklist that must be completed and signed before any maintenance activity begins. Conduct unannounced audits monthly with disciplinary consequences for non-compliance.

name: Upgrade Machine Guarding and Emergency Stop Accessibility
description: Install large, prominently colored emergency stop (E-Stop) buttons with extended reach capabilities on all sides of the packaging equipment, meeting ANSI B11.19 standards. Add physical guards around the sealing mechanism to prevent hand insertion during normal operation. Install machine interlocks that automatically stop all operations when access panels are opened. These engineering controls will eliminate the hazard of unexpected machine restart during maintenance activities.

name: Provide Advanced First Aid and Burn Prevention Training
description: Ensure all packaging operators and maintenance staff complete advanced first aid certification focusing on burn injury management and severe laceration treatment. Provide specialized training on thermal burn prevention when working with heated equipment. Equip the packaging area with upgraded first aid supplies specifically for burn and laceration management. Conduct quarterly refresher drills for emergency response procedures.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Checklist for Mold Work
description: Establish a comprehensive lockout/tagout verification procedure requiring supervisors to physically inspect and document de-energization of all heating elements before any mold maintenance begins. The checklist will include temperature verification using infrared thermometers, with mandatory 30-minute cooling periods. All operators must complete enhanced LOTO training with annual refresher courses. A laminated reference card will be placed at each mold maintenance station. Non-compliance will result in work stoppage and retraining.

name: Upgrade PPE Requirements and Storage for Mold Operators
description: Issue upgraded aramid fiber heat-resistant gloves rated to 260°C for all Line A personnel, replacing current gloves. Implement a daily pre-shift check requiring operators to inspect PPE integrity. Establish dedicated PPE storage stations with inventory tracking to ensure immediate availability. Provide training on proper donning/doffing of heat-resistant gloves. Include thermal injury scenarios in monthly safety toolbox talks for production teams.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring System on Mold Heating Elements
description: Install electronic temperature monitoring devices on all molds in Line A that provide real-time visual indicators when heating elements exceed safe-touch thresholds (below 50°C). Integrate with the maintenance work order system to prevent tool access until temperature confirmation is received. Train all operators on reading and interpreting temperature displays. Conduct quarterly calibration checks on all monitoring equipment.

name: Install Protective Barriers Around Sprinkler Heads
description: Install protective polycarbonate cage guards around all ceiling-mounted sprinkler heads and thermal elements in the Chemical Storage building to prevent accidental physical contact during maintenance work. The guards will be installed with clear 8-inch clearance indicators and labeled with warning signage. All existing ladder access routes will be re-evaluated and marked as clearance-restricted zones. This engineering control will eliminate the root cause of accidental activation through physical contact.

name: Establish Fire Suppression System Maintenance Safe Work Procedure
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive Safe Work Method Statement for all fire suppression system inspections and maintenance. The procedure will mandate supervisor pre-inspection of all work areas, use of articulating inspection poles to eliminate ladder contact with ceiling elements, and assignment of a dedicated spotter during high-ceiling operations. All facilities personnel will complete mandatory training before performing any fire system work. The procedure will be posted at all access points to chemical storage areas.

name: Implement Job Rotation Schedule in Packaging Department
description: Establish a structured job rotation program rotating assembly personnel between gripping-intensive packaging tasks and lower-demand finishing operations every 2 hours. The rotation will distribute ergonomic stress across different muscle groups and provide recovery periods. Create standardized rotation schedules and train supervisors on proper implementation. Monitor employee feedback and adjust rotation timing based on strain feedback. This administrative control will reduce cumulative trauma risk across the department.

name: Conduct Ergonomic Workstation Assessments and Modifications
description: Perform detailed ergonomic assessments of all packaging workstations, measuring wrist angles, workbench heights, and task repetition rates. Install articulating arm supports and anti-fatigue mats at identified high-risk stations. Adjust workbench heights to optimal ergonomic positions (typically 2-3 inches below elbow height when standing). Provide wrist support splints during high-volume production periods. Document baseline measurements and conduct follow-up assessments monthly. Train all personnel on proper posture and workstation adjustments.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooling Verification Protocol
description: Establish a documented cooling verification checklist that must be completed before each mold removal. Each operator will use infrared temperature guns to confirm mold temperature is below 40°C before handling. This requirement will be integrated into the LOTO procedures and tracked daily by shift supervisors. Training will be mandatory for all injection molding operators, with refresher sessions quarterly. The procedure will be laminated and posted at each injection molding line station.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Mold Handling Gloves
description: Procure and distribute high-performance thermal-resistant gloves rated for continuous contact with surfaces up to 250°C to all injection molding operators. Gloves will be stored at each production line and replaced according to manufacturer recommendations or when showing signs of degradation. Implementation includes a 2-hour training session on proper glove selection, care, and limitations. Budget includes 40 pairs of specialized gloves and initial stock for 6-month supply.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring Sensors on Injection Presses
description: Install digital temperature displays on all 32 injection molding machines showing real-time mold surface temperature. Sensors will trigger visual and audible alarms when temperatures exceed safe handling thresholds (>50°C). This engineering control eliminates guesswork and provides objective data for operators. Integration with existing production management system will allow tracking and reporting of temperature compliance metrics.

name: Implement Pallet Inspection and Rotation Program
description: Establish a weekly inspection protocol for all wooden pallets in the warehouse. Damaged pallets with protruding nails, splinters, or structural degradation will be immediately removed from service and either repaired or disposed of. A color-coded system will identify safe versus damaged pallets. Warehouse staff will complete a 30-minute training session on hazard identification. A monthly audit by warehouse management will ensure compliance and track the number of pallets removed from service.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant and Puncture-Resistant Work Boots
description: Issue all warehouse and materials handling staff with ASTM-rated puncture-resistant work boots featuring steel plates in the sole and cut-resistant uppers. Boots will be provided annually, with replacement as needed. A sizing and fitting session will occur during new employee orientation. Employees will be trained on proper boot inspection and maintenance. This directly addresses the mechanism of injury that allowed splinter penetration.

name: Transition to Latex-Free Glove Supply
description: Replace all latex-containing gloves with hypoallergenic nitrile or synthetic polymer alternatives throughout the facility. Conduct an audit of current glove inventory and establish a procurement policy requiring latex-free gloves for all production areas. All employees will be provided with orientation on the new glove types, ensuring they understand the fit, durability, and chemical resistance properties are equivalent or superior. Stock 20% surplus of various sizes to accommodate last-minute needs. Implementation will be completed within 30 days.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Inspections
description: Establish a comprehensive quarterly inspection protocol for all hydraulic systems on injection molding equipment. Inspections will focus on coupling integrity, hose condition, fluid levels, and pressure readings. All findings will be documented in the maintenance log and tracked through the computerized maintenance management system. Training will be provided to all machine operators on early warning signs of hydraulic system degradation including seepage, hose bulging, and unusual noises. This engineering control combined with administrative oversight will reduce the likelihood of undetected hydraulic failures that could lead to fluid contact or equipment malfunction.

name: Install Hydraulic Fluid Drip Containment Trays
description: Install permanent stainless steel drip containment trays beneath all hydraulic coupling points on Injection Molding Lines A, B, and C. The trays will be rated for 150% of maximum hydraulic fluid volume and will include drain plugs for regular emptying and fluid recycling. Secondary containment is an engineering control that significantly reduces environmental contamination and worker exposure risk should a coupling failure occur. Staff will receive training on proper tray maintenance and fluid disposal procedures. Monthly inspections will verify tray integrity and cleanliness.

name: Relocate Flammable Chemical Storage to Compliant Cabinet
description: Remove all flammable liquid containers from the immediate vicinity of heat-generating equipment in UNIT-025. Install a dedicated, fire-rated chemical storage cabinet at least 20 feet away from all ignition sources including the resin mixing apparatus, space heaters, and electrical panels. The cabinet will meet NFPA 30 standards and include proper ventilation. All chemicals will be transferred to the new cabinet within 3 days of approval. This elimination/substitution control removes the hazard by physically separating incompatible materials and establishing proper storage infrastructure in compliance with all applicable regulations.

name: Conduct Chemical Storage Audit and Staff Retraining
description: Perform a comprehensive audit of all chemical storage locations across the facility to identify other potential violations of CNESST regulations and company policy. Schedule mandatory retraining for all personnel who handle, store, or work near flammable materials. Training will cover proper storage requirements, separation distances from ignition sources, ventilation requirements, spill response procedures, and emergency protocols. Documentation of training completion will be maintained in personnel files. This administrative control ensures systematic compliance across the facility and reinforces the importance of chemical safety protocols to the entire workforce.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring in Material Handling Zones
description: Apply high-traction, anti-slip coating to all concrete flooring in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) and other material handling areas where liquid spills or loose particles create slipping hazards. The coating will meet ASTM D2047 standards for slip resistance and will be reapplied every 24 months or when wear becomes visible. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the incident by reducing slip potential even when spills occur. The improved flooring will benefit all staff working in these high-traffic material handling zones.

name: Implement Spill Response and Material Containment Procedures
description: Develop and distribute standardized procedures for responding to material spills in all facility areas. All material handlers will receive training on immediate containment techniques using designated spill kits containing absorbent materials and collection containers. Work areas will be cordoned off during cleanup to prevent other workers from walking through wet or debris-covered zones. Supervisors will conduct weekly inspections to verify that spill kits are properly stocked and accessible. This administrative control, combined with engineering improvements, will reduce the frequency and severity of slip and fall incidents by ensuring rapid, safe responses to material spills.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Procedures for Hopper Inspections
description: Establish and enforce a written lockout/tagout (LOTO) protocol requiring that all injection molding equipment must be de-energized and locked before any employee manually inspects material levels in hoppers. Provide laminated LOTO checklists at each molding line and conduct mandatory quarterly refresher training for all production operators. Install warning labels on hopper access points reminding workers of LOTO requirements. This eliminates the risk of unexpected material discharge during manual inspections.

name: Install Automated Hopper Level Monitoring System
description: Replace manual hopper level checking procedures with an automated capacitive level sensor that provides real-time feedback on the control panel display. This engineering control eliminates the need for employees to approach or reach into hoppers for visual inspection. The system will trigger an automatic alarm when material levels fall below minimum thresholds, allowing operators to refill from a safe distance using pneumatic controls.

name: Redesign Grinder Jam-Clearing Procedure with Interlock Safety System
description: Install a mechanical interlock system on the regrind grinder that physically prevents rotor operation when the upper access panel is open. Redesign the jam-clearing procedure to require dual-action confirmation: (1) equipment power must be isolated via LOTO, and (2) a maintenance technician must manually verify lock engagement before any internal clearing is attempted. Provide color-coded dowels labeled 'USE ONLY WHEN LOCKED OUT' and conduct hands-on training with all regrind technicians emphasizing that running equipment operation during jam clearing is never permitted.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification and Recertification Program
description: Implement a formal LOTO certification program requiring all production and regrind technicians to pass a written exam and practical skills assessment before operating equipment. Conduct annual recertification with testing focused on scenario-based decision making. Create a compliance tracking system to ensure 100% of equipment operators maintain current certification. Failure to maintain certification will result in removal from operating privileges until retraining is completed.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program with Digital Tracking
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule using CMMS (Computerized Maintenance Management System) software. All drying hoppers and pressure vessels must have their relief valves inspected and calibrated quarterly with electronic work orders and completion confirmations required. Implement pressure sensors on all critical equipment with real-time alerts to the maintenance supervisor when pressures exceed 85% of maximum rated capacity. Create an automated notification system that prevents operators from running equipment if maintenance is overdue.

name: Replace Aging Pressure Relief Valves with Current-Generation Equipment
description: Conduct immediate replacement of all pneumatic pressure relief valves on drying hoppers with modern certified valves featuring integrated redundant pressure monitoring and automatic vent capability. The new valves include fail-safe design elements that prevent seal degradation and feature integrated micro-pressure transducers. All replacements must meet ISO 4414 standards and be certified by an independent pressure equipment testing laboratory.

name: Install Pressure Containment Panels and Improved Equipment Guarding
description: Install reinforced containment panels around all drying hoppers and pressure vessels designed to redirect any discharge safely downward and away from personnel work zones. These engineering controls provide secondary containment in the event of equipment failure. Additionally, install perimeter safety fencing around all material preparation equipment with signage indicating high-pressure equipment hazard zones. Restrict access to these areas to authorized personnel only.

name: Implement Preventive Mold Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish and enforce a strict preventive maintenance schedule for all injection molds, ensuring deburring and edge conditioning occurs every 40 hours of operation or weekly, whichever is sooner. Create a digital tracking system integrated with production scheduling to flag maintenance due dates automatically. Assign dedicated maintenance technicians to handle mold preparation tasks and provide specialized training on edge finishing techniques. This addresses the root cause of delayed maintenance and ensures consistent mold condition standards across all production lines.

name: Upgrade Hand Protection Requirements for Assembly Operations
description: Transition all assembly operators from standard gloves to cut-resistant Level 3 nitrile gloves with reinforced palm protection when handling mold-formed components. Conduct a mandatory training session on proper glove selection, sizing, and usage for all Assembly Department personnel. Stock additional glove sizes and ensure sufficient inventory to prevent workers from reusing worn gloves. Implement a replacement protocol requiring gloves to be changed at the start of each shift and after any visible wear. This engineering and PPE control will reduce laceration severity and frequency.

name: Emergency Warehouse Floor Repair and Safety Marking
description: Conduct immediate inspection of all warehouse and shipping dock floors to identify deteriorated sections, uneven surfaces, and trip hazards. Repair the defective flooring area in UNIT-009 and apply high-visibility yellow-and-black striped hazard tape around any interim areas awaiting repair. Install temporary warning signs at entrance points.
