Establish a monthly floor inspection protocol using standardized checklists and assign responsibility to the Maintenance and Engineering department. This elimination and engineering control removes the root cause of the incident.

name: Implement Enhanced Material Handling Training and Equipment Standards
description: Develop and mandate comprehensive material handling training for all warehouse and materials management personnel, with specific emphasis on manual pallet jack operation, load balancing, speed control, and hazard recognition in confined spaces. Implement a policy requiring all manual pallet jacks to be equipped with load limits clearly marked and weight verification before transport. Establish a buddy system for material movements in areas with limited visibility or challenging terrain. Conduct quarterly refresher training. This administrative control will reduce similar incidents.

name: Implement Enhanced Hydraulic System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive hydraulic line inspection program requiring visual inspection and pressure testing of all main hydraulic lines on injection molding machines every 10 days instead of monthly. This includes thermographic imaging quarterly to detect early stress points. All maintenance technicians will receive certification in hydraulic diagnostics. A maintenance tracking system will be upgraded to flag overdue inspections automatically, preventing missed cycles.

name: Install Hydraulic Containment Systems
description: Install secondary containment trays and drain systems beneath all large injection molding machines to capture hydraulic fluid leaks before they damage equipment or create slip hazards. Add pressure relief valve redundancy to prevent uncontrolled platen descent. Install proximity sensors that automatically trigger emergency stops if descent speed exceeds safe parameters.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Spill Prevention System
description: Install secondary containment trays with 110% capacity under all chemical transfer stations. Implement automated lid verification systems that prevent transfer until containers are properly secured. Add drip trays with absorbent material and place absorbent pads within arm's reach. Install emergency eyewash and shower stations adjacent to mixing areas. Establish color-coded container labeling system to ensure proper matching of lids to containers.

name: Enhance Chemical Handling Training and Certification
description: Require all employees handling chemicals to complete manufacturer-specific training on proper container handling, lid seating procedures, and spill response protocols. Implement quarterly refresher training and monthly toolbox talks focused on chemical safety. Create visual work instruction cards posted at each transfer station. Implement a certification system requiring competency verification before handling any hazardous materials.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance System for Critical HVAC Equipment
description: Deploy vibration monitoring sensors and thermographic cameras on all critical ventilation equipment to detect bearing degradation before failure. Integrate real-time monitoring with the maintenance management system, creating automated alerts when parameters deviate from baseline values. Schedule bearing inspections at 50% of their rated life. Maintain redundant backup sensors on the main system to ensure continuous air quality monitoring. Establish bearing replacement as a scheduled quarterly task for high-use motors.

name: Restore and Redundantly Safeguard Maintenance Records
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all preventive maintenance schedules to ensure they are accurately reflected in the maintenance management system. Create paper-based backup records stored in multiple locations for critical equipment schedules. Implement automated weekly backup of the maintenance database with off-site storage. Require supervisory approval before any maintenance schedule modifications. Implement a quarterly audit verification where maintenance supervisors physically verify that all scheduled tasks are documented and current.

name: Establish Enhanced Emergency Ventilation Response Protocol
description: Upgrade backup ventilation system capacity to 100% to match primary system output. Install manual override switches in accessible locations for rapid backup system activation. Conduct quarterly mock ventilation failure drills with full evacuation procedures. Pre-position portable air filtration units and breathing apparatus kits in three strategic locations throughout the facility. Train all shift supervisors on emergency ventilation response procedures and decision-making criteria for work suspension.

name: Install Redundant Hopper Level Sensors
description: Replace the single-point-of-failure level sensor on Line C hopper with a dual-sensor system featuring independent fail-safe mechanisms. The new system will include a primary electronic sensor and a mechanical backup float switch. Both sensors will independently trigger the feed shut-off at 90% capacity. This engineering control eliminates the risk of overflow due to single sensor failure. The system will also include audible and visual alarms to alert operators to approaching capacity levels, providing additional administrative safeguards.

name: Implement Monthly Hopper System Inspections
description: Establish a formal monthly preventive maintenance schedule for all hopper level detection systems across Lines A through D. Maintenance Planner will create inspection checklists verifying sensor functionality, calibration accuracy, and alarm system operation. Documentation will be maintained in the predictive maintenance software system. Line operators will receive training on recognizing signs of sensor degradation (slow response, intermittent activation). This administrative control ensures early detection of sensor drift before failures occur.

name: Repair and Maintain Material Handling Equipment
description: Immediately repair the pneumatic height adjustment system on all staging carts in Line D production area and implement weekly maintenance checks. Establish a tagging system for defective carts preventing their use until repaired. Substitute manual carts with motorized adjustable-height assist carts designed to maintain ergonomic load positioning at operator waist height. This engineering control eliminates awkward lifting postures that contributed to the herniated disk. Procurement will prioritize acquisition of height-adjustable powered carts for all high-volume material transfer stations.

name: Enhanced Ergonomics Training and Job Rotation Program
description: Require all Line D operators to complete refresher ergonomics training focusing on proper lifting mechanics, load assessment, and use of available mechanical aids. Training will be conducted by the HSE department and include practical demonstrations of correct lifting postures with weighted practice loads. Implement a job rotation schedule limiting consecutive time spent on repetitive lifting tasks to 3-hour intervals. Workers will rotate between Line D molding station, parts inspection, and packaging tasks to distribute physical strain across different muscle groups and reduce cumulative load on the lumbar spine.

name: Install Back Support Exoskeleton Devices
description: Provide passive exoskeleton suits to all Line D operators who perform regular material transfer and lifting tasks. These wearable devices distribute load across larger muscle groups and skeletal structures, reducing stress on the lumbar spine. Operators will receive training on proper fitting, adjustment, and use protocols. This PPE control provides personal protection against future back injuries while longer-term engineering solutions are being implemented. Devices will be rotated between employees daily for hygiene maintenance.

name: Install Pressure Relief Guards on Molding Equipment
description: Engineer and install protective barrier shields around all manual valve access points on Lines A through D injection molding machines. Shields will be constructed from heat-resistant polycarbonate and stainless steel, designed to capture and redirect pressurized releases away from operator hands and body. The shields will include insulated handles and access ports allowing safe tool use while maintaining thermal protection. This engineering control eliminates direct exposure to high-temperature vapor and resin spray, addressing the root cause of Robert's burn injury.

name: Implement Lockout-Tagout Procedures for Valve Maintenance
description: Update and enforce LOTO procedures requiring that molding machines be completely de-energized and cooled to safe handling temperatures (below 120°F) before any manual valve manipulation is permitted. Create color-coded valve access tags indicating equipment status: red for energized/pressurized, yellow for cooling, green for safe to service. Night shift supervisors will verify LOTO compliance before maintenance work begins. This administrative control prevents pressurized equipment incidents by establishing a standardized safety protocol that must be followed before accessing valves.

name: Provide Enhanced PPE for Maintenance Personnel
description: Issue specialized thermal protection gloves (rated to 500°F) and forearm sleeves to all maintenance staff and injection molding setters working on pressurized heated equipment. Include flame-resistant long-sleeve shirts and protective eyewear with thermal shade ratings. Conduct fitting sessions and training on proper donning/doffing procedures. Establish a replacement schedule with quarterly inspections for thermal integrity. While engineering controls are the primary safeguard, this PPE provides backup personal protection against residual thermal hazards.

name: Upgrade to Chemical-Resistant PPE
description: Replace all latex gloves in the Quality Control Laboratory with 8-mil nitrile gloves featuring extended cuffs and superior chemical resistance. Conduct inventory audit to ensure adequate supply. Provide training to all lab personnel on proper glove selection, inspection before use, and replacement protocols. Include visual inspection checklist for PPE integrity at shift start.

name: Implement Chemical Handling Refresher Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory refresher training on proper handling of acetone and isopropanol cleaning solutions, including correct PPE selection, proper donning/doffing procedures, and emergency response for chemical contact. Schedule training quarterly for all QC personnel. Create laminated reference cards for each workstation showing chemical hazards and appropriate PPE combinations.

name: Install Thermal Imaging Monitoring System
description: Implement real-time thermal monitoring systems on all 32 injection molding machines with visual and audible alarms when barrel temperatures exceed safe handling thresholds. Install infrared temperature displays at each workstation. This engineering control prevents operator contact with hazardous temperatures by providing early warning of thermal anomalies and enabling corrective action before manual intervention is necessary.

name: Enforce Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE Protocol
description: Require all injection molding operators to wear certified heat-resistant protective sleeves (rated to 300°C+) and heat-resistant gloves when working within 2 meters of extruder barrels. Conduct daily PPE inspection at shift start. Update lockout/tagout procedures to require equipment shutdown and cool-down period before any manual clearing of material jams. Issue new PPE sets to all 30+ production operators.

name: Implement Material Jam Prevention and Response Procedures
description: Establish new administrative procedures prohibiting manual clearing of material jams while equipment is powered on. Mandate equipment power-down, 30-minute cool-down period, and lockout/tagout compliance before any physical jam clearing. Install mechanical jam-clearing tools at each workstation to eliminate hand contact. Provide monthly competency retraining on these procedures with signed acknowledgment from all operators.

name: Install Automated Material Handling Equipment
description: Deploy pneumatic lifting assists and semi-automated pallet jacks in the Materials Management and Warehouse areas to eliminate manual lifting of bags exceeding 15 kg. Install height-adjustable cart systems to reduce awkward reaching and twisting motions. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard by removing the need for workers to manually handle heavy materials, particularly in high-risk postures.

name: Establish Manual Lifting Restrictions and Training
description: Implement and enforce a maximum manual lifting limit of 15 kg per individual without mechanical assistance. Create administrative procedures requiring team lifting for loads 15-25 kg and mechanical assistance for anything exceeding 25 kg. Conduct mandatory ergonomic training covering proper lifting techniques, load assessment, and identification of hazardous postures. Establish a monthly refresher training schedule and require signed acknowledgment from all material handlers.

name: Provide Back Support and Ergonomic Assessment Program
description: Furnish all material handlers with properly fitted back support belts and lumbar support devices. Conduct individual ergonomic assessments for each handler to identify personal risk factors and provide customized interventions. Establish a preventive health monitoring program with quarterly follow-up assessments. Create an early-intervention protocol for workers reporting minor back discomfort to prevent progression to serious injury.

name: Install Anti-Slip Mold Handling Fixtures
description: Design and procure new mold handling brackets with high-friction rubber grip surfaces and positive locking mechanisms to prevent mold slippage during positioning. Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with these improved fixtures within 14 days. Include redundant safety pins that must be engaged before mold insertion. This engineering control eliminates the primary cause of the incident by ensuring secure mold positioning throughout the changeover process.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Upgrade and Training
description: Issue and require use of high-performance aramid-lined thermal gloves (rated for 250°C contact) to all machine setters and technicians. Conduct mandatory hands-on training on proper donning, inspection for damage, and heat exposure limits. Establish monthly audits to verify 100% compliance during mold changeover operations. Replace gloves every 90 days or when damage is detected. This PPE enhancement provides additional protection during high-temperature mold handling.

name: Implement Mold Changeover Lock-Out Procedure
description: Establish a formal written procedure requiring machine energy isolation (LOTO) before any manual mold positioning. Integrate temperature monitoring into the procedure to verify mold surface temperature below 60°C before manual handling. Require supervisor sign-off on temperature verification tags before changeover begins. Train all production staff on this new administrative control and audit compliance weekly for the first month, then monthly thereafter.

name: Replace Deteriorated Oven Door Insulation
description: Conduct immediate inspection of all industrial ovens in the Post-Processing unit to identify loose or degraded insulation material. Replace all worn insulation with encapsulated fiberglass that is bonded and sealed to prevent fiber shedding. Schedule replacements within 5 days for the incident oven and 30 days for all remaining ovens. This engineering control eliminates the source of airborne fibers by preventing insulation material from becoming loose.

name: Establish Protective Equipment Requirements for Composite Area
description: Implement mandatory use of face shields and safety glasses in the Post-Processing unit when working within 2 meters of active ovens or composite material handling. Place highly visible signage at all oven stations requiring face protection. Conduct toolbox talk with all composite operators on the new requirements and provide proper-fitting protective equipment. Perform weekly compliance audits. This administrative and PPE control provides barrier protection against airborne composite particles.

name: Install Waste Stream Segregation System
description: Design and install a dedicated isolation basin with chemical treatment capability specifically for composite material regrind operations. Implement three-stage filtration and pH neutralization system before any discharge to municipal sewers. Add automated shutoff valve that prevents discharge if VOC concentrations exceed safe thresholds. Install secondary containment around all regrind equipment discharge points. This engineering control prevents hazardous material from entering the municipal waste system by treating it onsite.

name: Develop Hazardous Waste Handling Procedure
description: Create comprehensive written procedures documenting which cleaning solutions and rinse protocols are acceptable for each material type processed in the regrind department. Establish color-coded drain systems with clear labeling indicating which drains connect to treatment versus direct discharge. Require all material handlers to complete certification training on hazardous waste identification and proper disposal routes. Post visual guides at each wash station. Implement daily end-of-shift waste verification logs signed by supervisors.

name: Conduct Environmental Compliance Audit and Notification
description: Notify Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development of the incident with detailed documentation of contamination volume, chemical composition, and corrective actions taken. Conduct facility-wide environmental audit of all discharge points to wastewater system. Establish quarterly third-party environmental monitoring of sump contents and discharge quality. Create environmental incident response protocol that includes immediate supervisor notification, equipment shutdown, and regulatory reporting triggers. This administrative control ensures proper regulatory compliance and prevents recurrence.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Cooling Systems
description: Establish a documented quarterly inspection and replacement program for all cooling water manifold fittings across the 32 injection molding machines. All fittings will be visually inspected for corrosion and replaced if any surface oxidation is detected. A computerized maintenance tracking system will be implemented to ensure no equipment exceeds inspection intervals. Maintenance logs will be reviewed monthly by the Maintenance and Engineering department to identify trending issues. This eliminates the root cause of cooling system failures through systematic preventive maintenance rather than reactive repairs.

name: Install Secondary Electrical Protection and Floor Drainage
description: Install GFCI (Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter) protection on all main injection molding machine circuits and add protective conduit shielding for exposed electrical connections near cooling system manifolds. Additionally, install sloped floor drains and absorbent flooring in the injection molding areas to prevent water accumulation. These engineering controls will prevent electrical faults from cooling leaks and eliminate slip hazards created by leaked coolant water, protecting workers from electrocution and fall injuries.

name: Calibrate and Lock Part Ejection Timing Parameters
description: Recalibrate the automatic part ejection timing on all 32 injection molding machines to ensure minimum 45-second cooling time before parts are transferred to downstream inspection stations. Implement software-level locks on ejection timing parameters so operators cannot adjust settings without supervisor override and documented justification. Install temperature sensors at the inspection conveyor entrance that will halt the line if parts below 30°C are not detected before routing to handlers. Monthly audits will verify system calibration. This administrative and engineering control prevents workers from contacting dangerously hot components.

name: Enhance PPE Requirements and Thermal Awareness Training
description: Mandate heat-resistant gloves (rated to 200°C minimum) for all quality inspectors and downstream material handlers working with post-molding components. Conduct toolbox talks emphasizing thermal burn hazards and safe handling procedures. Install prominent warning labels on all inspection stations indicating 'HOT PLASTIC COMPONENTS - 30 SECOND MINIMUM COOLING REQUIRED.' Provide refresher training quarterly to all staff in the Post-Processing area covering thermal burn first aid response and proper component handling techniques.

name: Install Automatic Temperature Monitoring and Suppression System in Regrind Storage
description: Install thermocouples in all regrind collection hoppers connected to a real-time monitoring system that alerts operators when material temperature exceeds 60°C. Pair this with an automated dry nitrogen injection system that cools and inerts the hopper atmosphere when threshold temperatures are detected, preventing spontaneous combustion. Install Class A/B/C rated automatic suppression sprinkler heads specifically calibrated for polymer material fires above each collection hopper. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of exothermic material ignition through continuous temperature management and appropriate fire suppression design.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System and Implement Heat Dissipation Protocol
description: Increase air exchange rate in the Regrind and Recycling Department from 4 to 8 times per hour through upgraded HVAC ducting and fans. Install temperature-controlled exhaust vents that activate when ambient hopper area temperature exceeds 40°C. Implement an administrative control requiring operators to limit hopper fill levels to 70% maximum capacity and to spread regrind material thinly on cooling trays for 15 minutes before consolidation during high-temperature production periods. Weekly thermographic inspections will verify proper heat dissipation.

name: Establish Fire Prevention Training and Equipment Standardization
description: Conduct mandatory fire safety certification for all material handlers and supervisors in the Regrind Department, including proper fire extinguisher selection and use for polymer fires. Remove all Class D dry powder extinguishers from this area and install only Class A/B/C multi-purpose extinguishers rated for ordinary combustibles and flammable liquids. Post clear signage identifying the fire suppression system specifications. Conduct quarterly fire drills specific to regrind area hazards. Ensure clear emergency exit pathways are maintained and marked with glow-in-the-dark signage.

name: Complete Hydraulic System Inspection and Certification Program
description: Implement a comprehensive quarterly inspection protocol for all hydraulic lines, connections, and support brackets across all injection molding lines. Conduct ultrasonic testing to detect hairline fractures before failure. Replace all hydraulic tubing showing signs of fatigue or corrosion. Establish preventive replacement schedule for critical hydraulic components every 18 months. Train all maintenance staff on early warning signs of hydraulic system degradation. Document all inspections and maintenance in a central database.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Drip Collection System
description: Design and install engineered secondary containment beneath Molding Line C with integrated sloped drainage directing any hydraulic fluid leakage into a collection sump. This prevents fluid from spreading across the production floor and contaminates. Install absorbent pads and spill kits at strategic points. Ensure quick-disconnects are installed on all hydraulic lines to minimize spillage during maintenance. Provide training to all operators on proper spill response procedures.

name: Electrical Equipment Lifecycle Management and Preventive Replacement Program
description: Establish a documented inventory of all critical electrical equipment including capacitor banks, circuit breakers, and disconnect switches with installation dates and manufacturer specifications. Create a preventive replacement schedule ensuring all components are replaced at 80% of design life (7 years for 10-year-rated equipment). Contract with a certified electrical maintenance company to conduct annual thermal imaging surveys of all electrical panels to detect degradation. Implement a tagging system on all electrical equipment showing replacement due dates. Budget €25,000 annually for electrical component replacement.

name: Electrical Panel Safety Zone Implementation and Signage
description: Install permanent barricading around the main 480-volt distribution panel creating a 2-meter safety perimeter. Mount high-visibility warning signs indicating arc flash hazard, required PPE (face shield, arc-rated clothing), and restricted access. Implement a lock-out/tag-out (LOTO) procedure requiring electrical disconnection before any panel maintenance. Provide annual arc flash hazard training to all maintenance staff and supervisors. Issue arc-rated PPE kits to all personnel authorized to work on electrical systems.

name: Enhanced Receiving Inspection Protocol and Checklist Implementation
description: Develop a detailed, laminated pallet inspection checklist requiring documented verification of all four pallet corners, structural integrity, load positioning, and package condition before material acceptance. Require photos of damaged shipments. Implement a mandatory minimum 5-minute inspection window per pallet regardless of shift timing. Train all receiving staff on critical damage indicators and provide escalation procedures for questionable loads. Establish a 'hold' area where suspicious pallets are quarantined for secondary inspection by a supervisor. Make inspection checklist completion a requirement for clock-out.

name: Forklift Load Stability Visual Management System
description: Install colored load stability guide stickers on all 15 forklifts showing acceptable vs. unacceptable load configurations. Create a laminated card that forklift operators must carry showing weight limits per load type and stability warning signs. Implement a policy requiring operators to visually inspect all four fork contact points before moving any load. Establish a peer-review system where operators brief each other on suspicious loads. Conduct quarterly refresher training on load stability and emergency procedures for unstable loads.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance for Drying Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance program for all resin dryers utilizing thermal sensors with real-time monitoring and automated alerts. Replace all existing temperature control systems with upgraded units featuring redundant sensors and automatic shutoff at critical temperature thresholds. Schedule quarterly calibration checks for all thermal monitoring equipment. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of thermal runaway conditions by providing early detection and automatic intervention capabilities, significantly reducing fire risk.

name: Enhanced Fire Safety Training and Dryer Operation Protocol
description: Develop and implement a mandatory training program for all production operators working with drying equipment. Training will include recognition of thermal runaway warning signs, proper emergency shutdown procedures, and evacuation protocols. Create laminated quick-reference guides posted at each dryer station detailing critical temperature parameters and emergency contacts. Conduct quarterly refresher training sessions. This administrative control ensures all personnel can rapidly identify and respond to equipment failures, reducing response time and potential damage.

name: Ergonomic Workstation Redesign and Anti-Fatigue Equipment Installation
description: Install ergonomic arm supports, wrist rests, and anti-fatigue mats at all assembly stations on Injection Molding Line C. Modify workbench height and positioning to reduce wrist extension angles during part removal operations. Install height-adjustable stools with lumbar support to allow alternating between sitting and standing. This engineering control addresses the root cause by reducing biomechanical stress on affected joints and muscles, preventing RSI development. Expected outcome: 60% reduction in ergonomic complaints within 60 days.

name: Mandatory Job Rotation and Scheduled Rest Break Program
description: Implement mandatory job rotation every 90 minutes for assembly operators, rotating between part removal, quality checking, and packaging tasks to distribute repetitive motion across different muscle groups. Establish enforced 10-minute rest breaks every 2 hours with guided stretching exercises. Create a rotation schedule posted at each workstation and tracked in the production management system. Train supervisors on enforcement and operator compliance monitoring. This administrative control redistributes physical demands and provides recovery time, significantly reducing cumulative strain injuries.

name: Operator Ergonomics and RSI Prevention Training Program
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomics training for all production operators focusing on proper wrist positioning, body mechanics, and early recognition of repetitive strain symptoms. Include practical demonstrations at workstations. Distribute ergonomic guidebooks and implement monthly refresher sessions. Create a confidential reporting system for early-stage discomfort to enable preventive intervention. This training control ensures operators understand ergonomic principles and can self-monitor for symptoms before they develop into reportable injuries.

name: Upgrade to Electric Forklifts and Eliminate Propane Combustion Hazard
description: Replace all propane-powered forklifts in UNIT-009 with electric models over the next 180 days. Electric forklifts eliminate internal combustion engines and the associated CO generation hazard completely. This substitution control removes the hazard at the source rather than managing exposure. Conduct operator training on electric forklift operation and charging procedures. Expected outcome: Zero CO exposure risk in receiving dock operations, improved air quality, and reduced fuel costs.

name: Install Permanent Ventilation System and CO Detection Network
description: Install six permanent ventilation exhaust units strategically positioned throughout UNIT-009 to continuously extract vehicle exhaust and maintain air circulation. Install four fixed carbon monoxide detectors at strategic locations (dock entrance, equipment staging area, office area, and emergency exit) with audible alarms set at 25 ppm to provide early warning. Integrate detectors with facility management system for continuous remote monitoring. This engineering control provides continuous hazard monitoring and mechanical extraction of combustion byproducts.

name: Implement Mandatory Rest Break Protocol for Repetitive Tasks
description: Establish a structured break schedule requiring operators on injection molding lines to take a 10-minute rest break every 2 hours during repetitive part removal operations. This administrative control will include job rotation opportunities where operators alternate between part removal tasks and other production duties to reduce cumulative strain on the same muscle groups. Supervisors will enforce compliance through shift checklists and timing systems. Expected outcome: reduction in repetitive strain injuries by rotating task demands and allowing muscle recovery periods throughout the shift.

name: Conduct Ergonomic Assessment and Engineering Redesign of Part Removal Station
description: Commission an occupational ergonomics specialist to conduct a formal assessment of the part removal workstation on Line A. Focus on optimizing fixture height, part orientation, and gripper design to minimize wrist deviation and grip force requirements. Implement engineering modifications such as articulated part holders, power-assisted removal assistance, or improved mold design to reduce manual handling demands. Document baseline metrics and implement post-intervention measurements at 30, 60, and 90 days. Expected outcome: significant reduction in repetitive strain risk through elimination of awkward postures and excessive force requirements at the source.

name: Enhance Regrind Material Quality Control and Contamination Screening
description: Implement a mandatory pre-processing inspection station where all incoming regrind material is visually examined and screened through a mechanical separator to remove metal fragments, mold components, and other hard foreign objects. Establish a training program for regrind technicians on hazard identification. Install signage at the hopper entrance requiring PPE including cut-resistant gloves rated for sharp material handling. Add a metal detection unit to the material stream. Expected outcome: eliminate contaminated material sources that create sharp edges and reduce first aid incidents in the regrind preparation area.

name: Mandatory Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Compliance Verification Program
description: Implement a zero-tolerance LOTO enforcement policy requiring documented lockout/tagout verification before any equipment maintenance. Conduct immediate retraining of all maintenance and setter personnel on LOTO procedures specific to injection molding equipment pressure systems. Introduce a digital verification system using QR codes on equipment that supervisors scan to confirm LOTO compliance before work begins. Conduct unannounced compliance audits twice monthly. Establish disciplinary consequences for LOTO violations. Expected outcome: prevent unauthorized equipment operation and pressure releases during maintenance through systematic verification of proper lockout application.

name: Install Pressure Relief Valve Maintenance Schedule and Upgrade PPE Requirements
description: Establish a quarterly predictive maintenance schedule for pressure relief valves on all injection molding equipment, including pressure testing and functional verification. Assign responsibility to maintenance technicians with certification requirements. Additionally, mandate that all personnel performing nozzle adjustments wear Level 3 flame-resistant aprons, thermal-resistant gloves rated to 300°C, and face shields in addition to standard PPE. Upgrade from standard gloves to Kevlar-reinforced heat-resistant gloves. Expected outcome: prevent pressure relief failures through proactive maintenance and provide enhanced thermal protection for personnel working with high-temperature equipment.

name: Provide Advanced Burn First Aid and Emergency Response Training
description: Conduct immediate hands-on emergency response training for all production supervisors and shift leads focusing on thermal burn management, including proper cooling techniques, blister management, and recognizing signs of shock. Conduct quarterly refresher drills at the emergency eyewash station to ensure all personnel can efficiently access and operate emergency equipment. Establish a direct communication protocol with the nearest burn trauma center and ensure EMS routing is optimized. Stock emergency burn gel and specialized dressings at first aid stations. Expected outcome: minimize burn severity through rapid, effective initial response and reduce time to definitive medical care.

name: Implement Mold Release Agent Application Protocol
description: Establish a standardized operating procedure for mold release agent application that limits accumulation and specifies manual cleaning intervals every 4 hours or after every 500 cycles, whichever comes first. All operators will receive refresher training on proper application techniques to minimize excess buildup. Automated spray systems will be evaluated as a longer-term engineering control to reduce manual handling of the chemical and ensure consistent, controlled application rates.

name: Upgrade PPE Requirements for Mold Release Handling
description: Mandate the use of nitrile gloves (increased thickness, 8-mil minimum) and protective arm sleeves for all operators handling mold release agents. Additional requirements include safety glasses with side shields and a long-sleeve lab coat. Supply quality-tested gloves and sleeves in bulk to ensure compliance. Conduct competency verification training on proper donning and doffing procedures to maximize protection effectiveness.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring in Maintenance and Warehouse Areas
description: Replace or upgrade floor surfaces in all warehouse and maintenance areas with industrial-grade anti-slip coating or textured flooring material rated for wet environments. Priority areas include under crane work zones, near cleaning stations, and high-traffic maintenance pathways. Install drainage or improved water management systems to prevent water accumulation. Implement daily inspections to identify and immediately address wet surfaces with caution signage.

name: Mandatory Fall Protection and Ladder Safety Program
description: Require all work at heights above 6 feet to use properly anchored fall arrest harnesses with 100% tie-off compliance. Conduct comprehensive training for all maintenance personnel on fall protection standards, proper ladder selection, and three-point contact procedures. Implement pre-use ladder inspections and establish a replacement schedule for damaged equipment. Designate a fall protection coordinator to conduct monthly audits of compliance.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule with Floor Preparation
description: Schedule maintenance work during day shifts only when supervisory coverage and emergency response times are optimal. Require that maintenance areas be dried and inspected for hazards before technicians begin work. Implement a checklist system requiring floor surface inspection and sign-off by the maintenance lead before ladder work is authorized. Establish buddy system protocols ensuring at least two workers present during elevated work.

name: Install Automatic Hopper Level Monitoring System
description: Implement a level sensor system on all injection molding hoppers that automatically triggers an alarm when material reaches 85% capacity and begins controlled material diversion to backup hoppers. This engineering control eliminates the risk of manual intervention during overflow conditions. The system will integrate with existing production management software to log events and trigger preventive maintenance alerts. Expected outcome: complete elimination of manual hopper overflow clearing procedures and reduction of overflow incidents by 95%.

name: Revise Hopper Maintenance Procedures and Training
description: Develop comprehensive written procedures for hopper inspection and clearing that explicitly prohibit manual intervention during operating conditions. All production operators will receive mandatory retraining on these procedures with annual refresher courses. Procedures will include proper use of mechanical clearing tools and required PPE (insulated gloves, face shield, heat-resistant apron) when any manual intervention is absolutely necessary. Post visual reminders at each workstation depicting correct and incorrect practices.

name: Redesign Material Storage Rack Stability Configuration
description: Replace existing storage racks with certified heavy-duty racking systems featuring reinforced base plates, secondary bracing, and anti-tip stabilizer bars. All racks will meet ANSI MH16.1 standards and be anchored to the floor to prevent tipping from forklift contact. Implement a clear marking system (red zones) around each rack indicating the no-forklift-contact perimeter. This engineering control eliminates tipping hazard from normal forklift operations.

name: Establish Forklift Operator Recertification and Precision Maneuvering Training
description: All forklift operators will complete refresher certification training emphasizing precision maneuvering, load awareness, and distance management from stored materials. Training will include tabletop scenarios reviewing this specific incident and the financial impact of property damage. Operators will practice controlled approach procedures and rack clearance techniques in a designated training area. Monthly audits will be conducted observing actual operations to ensure compliance.

name: Install Physical Protective Barriers Around High-Value Equipment
description: Install heavy-duty steel bollards and protective cages around quality control testing equipment and sensitive instrumentation areas. Bollards will be placed at minimum 1.5 meters from equipment to prevent forklift or moving equipment contact. This administrative and engineering control creates a buffer zone preventing unintended collisions. Additional benefit: improves equipment security and reduces damage-related downtime.

name: Implement Engineered Resin Container Safety System
description: Replace current resin storage containers with purpose-designed transfer containers featuring improved grip ergonomics, secure locking lids, and integrated spill containment trays. All containers will be mounted on stable pedestal stands or integrated into workstations to prevent tipping and dropping. Implement a secondary containment system beneath all preparation surfaces. These engineering controls eliminate the primary cause of the incident: accidental container drops and resin spillage.

name: Upgrade Composite Materials Operator PPE Requirements
description: Establish mandatory use of heat-resistant composite nitrile gloves specifically rated for epoxy chemical exposure and thermal protection, along with long-sleeve chemical-resistant protective sleeves. Operators will wear ANSI-rated face shields during all resin transfer operations. Provide high-visibility training on proper donning/doffing procedures and importance of full compliance. Update facility signage with required PPE visual reminders. Implement daily pre-shift PPE inspection checklists.

name: Establish Emergency Response and First-Aid Protocol for Chemical Burns
description: Create documented emergency response procedures specifically for epoxy resin thermal and chemical burns, including immediate on-site treatment protocols (copious water rinsing, removal of contaminated clothing, ice/cool pack application timing). Designate and train 3 certified first-aid responders within the composite processing area. Install emergency eyewash and shower stations within 10 seconds walk of all resin work areas. Post clear signage with emergency response flowcharts and hospital contact information. Conduct quarterly drills.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and maintenance program for all injection molding machines focusing on hydraulic connections, fitting tightness, and pressure testing. Technicians will use torque specifications and thread-locking compounds on all critical fittings. Visual inspection logs will be maintained and reviewed by maintenance supervisors. This engineering control will eliminate vibration-induced loosening and detect potential failures before they cause leaks or injuries.

name: Upgrade Mold Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Implement enhanced mold inspection procedures using visual magnification and tactile testing to detect micro-fractures and sharp edges before parts are produced. Establish a mold maintenance log requiring dimensional verification and surface finish checks every 5,000 cycles. Replace damaged molds immediately and archive defective molds for failure analysis. Train all molding operators and QC staff on the new protocols with hands-on demonstrations of mold defect identification.

name: Distribute Cut-Resistant Gloves to Packaging Department
description: Procure and distribute ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant gloves to all packaging and material handling employees. Provide initial training on proper glove selection for different tasks and when to use cut-resistant versus standard gloves. Include glove inspection procedures in daily safety briefings. This PPE upgrade will provide an additional layer of protection while engineering controls address the root mold issues.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Chemical Drums
description: Install engineered secondary containment pallets with 110% capacity under all large chemical storage drums in the Chemical Storage Building. Containment systems will feature sloped floors directing any spills to a central collection sump with a ball valve for controlled drainage. This engineering control will eliminate the risk of floor contamination and environmental release of hazardous chemicals. Staff will be trained on monthly inspection procedures to ensure drains are clear and sump is empty.

name: Establish Chemical Drum Handling Standard Operating Procedure
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive SOP for chemical drum handling, storage, and transfer including: proper bung seating verification using a torque wrench (15-20 ft-lbs), visual inspection before each use, drum rotation system to ensure older stock is used first, and mandatory two-person verification process for all transfers. Create laminated quick-reference guides posted at storage and transfer locations. Conduct mandatory training for all employees handling chemicals within 2 weeks with annual refresher training.

name: Upgrade Emergency Ventilation System Sensors
description: Install VOC (volatile organic compound) sensors in the Chemical Storage Building that automatically trigger emergency ventilation fans when solvent vapor concentrations exceed 25% of the lower explosive limit. Connect sensors to the building alarm system with audible alerts in adjacent areas. Conduct quarterly testing and calibration of sensors. This administrative/engineering control will ensure rapid response to any future chemical releases independent of human detection.

name: Provide Heat-Resistant Gloves and Training
description: Issue Kevlar-lined thermal gloves rated to 200°C for all maintenance personnel working with molds above 60°C. Conduct mandatory 30-minute training session on proper glove selection and application, including demonstration of thermal protection limits. Create visual job hazard analysis cards at each molding line showing required PPE for different mold temperatures. Implementation includes inventory management and quarterly refresher training. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in thermal burns from mold contact within high-risk tasks.

name: Implement Mandatory Material Handling Equipment Use Protocol
description: Establish written policy requiring forklift use for all bags weighing 20 kg or more, with zero exceptions. Install mechanical lift assist devices at truck unloading bays to accommodate difficult positioning situations. Conduct ergonomics training for all material handlers emphasizing proper lifting mechanics, load limits, and equipment alternatives. Create color-coded weight labels on all bulk material bags. Implement weekly audits of material handling practices with supervisor spot-checks. Expected outcome: 80% reduction in back strain incidents within 6 months.

name: Enhanced Ergonomics Assessment and Job Redesign
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomics assessment of all material handling tasks in warehouse and regrind departments. Redesign truck unloading workflow to ensure forklift accessibility from multiple angles. Install height-adjustable palletizing platforms to reduce bending. Provide ergonomic workstation assessments for all handlers. Implement a pain reporting system for early identification of musculoskeletal issues before they become serious injuries. Quarterly follow-up assessments to monitor effectiveness.

name: Establish Mandatory Fall Protection Program for Elevated Work
description: Implement comprehensive fall protection policy requiring harnesses and anchor points for all work above 1.8 meters. Install permanent anchor point systems at the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility and Maintenance Workshop at all elevated work locations. Require a qualified spotter for all ladder work. Conduct fall protection certification training for all maintenance personnel. Provide shock-absorbing lanyards and properly fitted harnesses for each technician. Quarterly audits of fall protection compliance with photographic evidence. Expected outcome: Elimination of elevated fall risks for maintenance operations.

name: Ladder Inspection and Stabilization Program
description: Establish monthly ladder inspection protocol including assessment of rungs, feet, and overall structural integrity. Replace all ladders showing wear or damage. Install self-leveling ladder feet and stabilizer bars on all extension ladders to prevent shifting on uneven surfaces. Assign responsibility for ladder maintenance and storage to designated facilities personnel. Create ladder checklist for all users to complete before use. Implement digital tracking of ladder inspections. Training on proper ladder setup including ground preparation and angle verification (75-degree rule).

name: Ventilation System Maintenance Redesign
description: Evaluate current ventilation maintenance procedures and redesign to eliminate ladder-based work whenever possible. Install platform catwalks with permanent railings in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area to allow safe access to air intakes and ducts. Alternatively, contract with specialized HVAC maintenance services for elevated ductwork cleaning requiring high-altitude work and specialized equipment. Implement preventive maintenance schedule to reduce emergency maintenance requirements. Train facilities staff on new procedures and approved vendors. Expected outcome: Elimination of elevated ladder work for ventilation maintenance.

name: Install Dual-Redundant Mold Position Sensors
description: Replace the single pressure sensor with dual independent proximity sensors that independently verify mold position before cycle initiation. Both sensors must confirm the mold is fully closed and locked before the machine can begin operation. This engineering control eliminates the single point of failure that allowed the machine to cycle with an open mold. The redundant system will be integrated into the safety PLC with fail-safe logic ensuring the machine cannot operate if either sensor fails or provides conflicting signals.

name: Comprehensive LOTO Training and Monthly Verification Audits
description: Implement mandatory lockout/tagout refresher training for all Line A operators focusing on proper procedures before mold cleaning. Establish monthly LOTO compliance audits with documented verification that all energy sources (electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic) are properly isolated and tagged before any maintenance or cleaning work begins. Create a visual checklist posted at each molding station detailing required LOTO steps. This administrative control ensures consistent adherence to energy isolation procedures.

name: Install Machine Startup Warning System with Audible Alarm
description: Install a high-decibel warning alarm and flashing beacon light on each injection molding machine that activates 3 seconds before cycle initiation begins. This provides auditory and visual warning to operators and nearby personnel that machine motion is imminent, allowing time to clear the work area. The alarm will be tied to the machine's safety relay logic and cannot be disabled without authorization.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program with Vibration Analysis
description: Establish a monthly vibration and temperature monitoring program for all HVAC system bearings using handheld vibration analysis equipment. Record baseline measurements and trending data to identify degradation patterns before catastrophic failure occurs. Technicians will perform thermographic imaging to detect overheating zones. This predictive approach will identify failing bearings 3-4 weeks before failure, allowing planned maintenance rather than emergency repairs during production shifts.

name: Upgrade HVAC System with Automatic Bearing Lubrication Units
description: Replace manual lubrication procedures with automatic grease-lubrication cartridges on all HVAC fan bearings. These self-contained units deliver measured amounts of lubricant at regular intervals, eliminating the dependency on technician recalls and ensuring consistent bearing maintenance. The engineering control removes the human error element from a critical maintenance task and extends bearing service life.

name: Install Height-Adjustable Mixing Workstations
description: Replace fixed-height mixing stations with pneumatic height-adjustable workbenches that can be individually calibrated for each operator's anthropometric measurements. Provide height adjustment training so each operator can position their work surface at elbow height (approximately 2 inches below seated elbow level). This engineering control eliminates postural compensation and reduces cumulative strain on wrists and shoulders.

name: Implement Mandatory Task Rotation with Micro-Break Protocol
description: Establish a job rotation schedule requiring composite materials operators to rotate between mixing, container preparation, and quality verification tasks at least every 2 hours. Implement a mandatory 5-minute micro-break every 60 minutes of repetitive gripping work, during which operators must perform standardized hand and wrist stretching exercises. Create a visual posted schedule at each workstation. This administrative control reduces cumulative strain by varying muscle groups used throughout the shift.

name: Provide Ergonomic Wrist Supports and Hand Strengthening Program
description: Issue customized compression wrist braces designed for repetitive strain prevention to all composite materials operators. Provide ergonomic training on proper fit and usage guidelines. Implement an optional employer-sponsored hand strengthening and flexibility program using resistance therapy bands during break periods. While PPE is the lowest-hierarchy control, it serves as a complementary measure alongside engineering and administrative controls to support employee wellness.

name: Install Automated Safety Interlock System
description: Replace the existing mechanical safety interlock on Injection Molding Line D with a redundant automated system that cannot be bypassed without documented supervisory authorization and physical key removal. The new system will include proximity sensors, pressure monitoring, and automated shutdown protocols. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of maintenance overrides creating hazardous conditions. Implementation includes staff training on the new system and regular testing protocols to verify proper function.

name: Enhanced Machine Maintenance Lock-Out Documentation
description: Implement a mandatory digital lock-out/tag-out (LOTO) tracking system for all injection molding machines. Maintenance staff must log all overrides with timestamp, reason, and supervisor approval. System will automatically alert supervisors if locks remain engaged beyond scheduled maintenance windows. Includes weekly audits by Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion to ensure compliance and proper procedures are followed on all shifts.

name: Operator Training on Part Extraction Hazards
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training module focused on safe part removal techniques from injection molding machines, emphasizing hazards of pinch points and proper hand positioning. Training will be mandatory for all operators on lines A through D, with certification required annually. Include practical demonstrations using machine mockups and identification of warning signs of potential entanglement. Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier will lead curriculum development to incorporate best practices.

name: Install Protective Guards Around Sprinkler Heads
description: Install protective cage guards and impact-resistant covers around all sprinkler heads and fire suppression system activators in the Composite Materials Processing Area. These guards will prevent accidental activation from tools or equipment while maintaining proper water coverage patterns. Engineering drawings will be reviewed to ensure accessibility for maintenance and annual inspections. Guards will be fabricated from stainless steel to resist corrosion from process humidity.

name: Establish Exclusion Zones Around Suppression Equipment
description: Develop and post clear signage establishing 3-foot exclusion zones around all fire suppression system components throughout the facility. Maintenance personnel will be required to announce their presence and intended work areas via radio before beginning work on elevated systems. Administrative controls will include updated maintenance procedures requiring spotter assignments for overhead work. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid will develop toolbox talks on suppression system awareness for all shifts.

name: Comprehensive Warehouse Roof Leak Repair and Waterproofing
description: Conduct immediate structural inspection of the warehouse roof by certified contractor and repair all identified leaks. Install additional waterproofing membrane in high-risk areas directly above storage racks. Implement quarterly roof inspections during preventative maintenance schedule. Install humidity monitoring sensors in storage areas to detect moisture accumulation early. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of box degradation and structural failure.

name: Implement Storage Rack Load Capacity Inspection Program
description: Establish mandatory monthly visual inspections of all storage racks focusing on box condition, weight distribution, and moisture damage. Develop a standardized inspection checklist and digital logging system. Any boxes showing damage, moisture, or structural compromise must be removed and contents transferred to new containers. Staff will be trained to identify hazardous storage conditions. Facility manager will assign Warehouse Associate Monique Dion as primary inspector with backup assignment.

name: Install Safety Netting and Barriers on High Storage Racks
description: Install high-strength mesh safety netting and protective barriers on all racks exceeding 8 feet in height to catch and contain any falling materials. Barriers will be installed at intervals to prevent box migration and will include clear warning labels. Engineering design will maintain visibility and accessibility for inventory management. Regular inspections will ensure netting integrity and proper tension. This provides added protection as secondary engineering control.

name: Implement Daily Housekeeping Inspections
description: Establish a daily pre-shift checklist for all production and material handling areas to identify and remove trip hazards including air hoses, cables, and tools. Designate one team member per shift to conduct a 15-minute walkthrough before operations begin. Document findings and remedial actions in a logbook. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate housekeeping by creating accountability and visibility into potential hazards before incidents occur.

name: Install Cable Management and Routing System
description: Install wall-mounted conduit and cable trays along all major walkways in UNIT-016 and adjacent areas to route air hoses and electrical cables overhead or along walls. This engineering control eliminates the hazard entirely by removing cables from floor level. Include color-coded labeling system to identify hose types and destinations. Expected outcome: zero floor-level trip hazards from cables and hoses, improved workplace aesthetics and efficiency.

name: Install Automated Chemical Storage Temperature Control System
description: Install a dedicated climate-controlled storage cabinet for all acetone-based solvents and volatile chemical inventory with automated temperature regulation maintaining 15-25°C year-round. Add pressure relief valves calibrated to 1.5 bar on all pressurized storage tanks. Integrate pressure monitoring sensors with automatic alerts sent to HSE staff when readings exceed 1.0 bar. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of pressure buildup by controlling environmental conditions and providing early warning systems for potential issues.

name: Establish Chemical Storage Safety Zoning and Hazard Isolation
description: Designate a specific chemical storage zone isolated from any heat sources, including portable heaters, electrical equipment, and direct sunlight. Install permanent signage prohibiting portable heating equipment within 10 meters. Implement a management-of-change procedure requiring HSE approval before introducing any maintenance equipment or heat sources near chemical storage areas. Conduct monthly audits of the storage zone. This administrative control prevents future incidents by creating clear, enforced boundaries between hazardous materials and potential ignition sources.

name: Implement Enhanced Operator Chemical Hazard Recognition Training
description: Develop mandatory training for all operators working with volatile solvents covering recognition of pressure buildup indicators (abnormal gauge readings, odors, condensation), emergency response procedures, proper storage verification before shift start, and communication protocols with HSE staff. Include scenario-based training on the November 20 incident. All operators must certify annually. Provide quick-reference laminated cards for all workstations. This administrative control improves operator vigilance and response capabilities to catch hazard escalation early.

name: High-Temperature Protective Glove Distribution
description: Source and distribute silicone-coated heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C) to all injection molding technicians and setters on Line D. Each employee will receive two pairs for rotation and cleaning. Gloves will be stored in a clearly marked bin adjacent to each production station. Training will be provided on proper selection, use, and care of high-temperature PPE. Compliance will be monitored through daily toolbox talks and supervisor spot-checks.

name: Nozzle Insulation Maintenance Program
description: Implement a preventive maintenance schedule for all extruder nozzles on Line D to inspect and replace degraded insulation jackets quarterly rather than reactively. Maintenance technician Andrei Popov will document the condition of each nozzle's insulation during inspections. Any jacket showing signs of wear, cracking, or degradation will be replaced within 5 working days. This engineering control eliminates the source of heat exposure and reduces burn hazards.

name: Chemical Containment Spill Trays Installation
description: Install secondary containment spill trays (capacity: 25 liters) at all material transfer stations in the Raw Materials Warehouse. Each tray will be positioned to catch potential leaks from containers during handling and storage transitions. Trays will be manufactured from chemical-resistant plastic and clearly labeled. Staff will be trained to place any chemical containers on these trays before beginning transfer operations. This engineering control prevents spills from spreading across the warehouse floor.

name: Chemical Container Handling and Spill Response Training
description: Develop and deliver a mandatory 30-minute training module for all warehouse staff on proper chemical container handling, cap securing procedures, and immediate spill response protocols. Training will cover inspection of containers before transfer, use of spill kits, proper use of absorbent materials, and when to call for specialized response. Training will be conducted by Natasha Ivanov (Chemical Inventory Specialist) and will include hands-on demonstration. Completion will be documented and refresher training will occur annually.

name: Spill Kit Accessibility and Documentation
description: Place clearly marked spill response kits at three strategic locations within the Raw Materials Warehouse, each containing absorbent materials, chemical-resistant gloves, respirator masks, and disposal containers. Kits will be labeled with contents and inspection dates. Weekly inspections will be conducted to ensure kits remain stocked and accessible. An inventory log will track all spill kit usage. This administrative control ensures rapid response capability for future incidents.

name: Two-Person Verification LOTO Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a mandatory two-person verification protocol for all equipment lockout/tagout procedures during night shift maintenance activities. After a technician applies LOTO locks, a second qualified technician must independently verify that all locks are in place and that the equipment cannot be re-energized. Both technicians must sign an equipment maintenance log before work begins. This secondary verification system is an administrative control that prevents unauthorized re-energization by ensuring communication between maintenance personnel.

name: LED Task Lighting Installation in Maintenance Areas
description: Install high-intensity LED task lighting (min. 500 lumens) on articulating arms at all maintenance access points for the heat treatment conveyor system. Lighting will be positioned to eliminate shadows and provide clear visibility of mechanical drive components, belts, and pinch points. Motion-activated switches will ensure lights activate when maintenance personnel enter the area. This engineering control removes the hazard of poor visibility that contributed to the near-miss.

name: Night Shift Fatigue Awareness Training
description: Conduct specialized training for all night shift maintenance technicians on fatigue recognition, situational awareness during equipment maintenance, and enhanced safety protocols during low-energy hours. Training will emphasize the increased risk of errors during night operations and establish peer-check procedures. Instructors will highlight this incident as a case study. Training will occur during shift start before maintenance operations commence.

name: Install Automated Hopper Overflow Shut-Off System
description: Replace the malfunctioning mechanical hopper overflow sensor with a modern dual-sensor electronic system featuring redundant level detection and automatic material feed cutoff at 95% capacity. Install stainless steel protective barriers around the hopper to contain any overflow materials. The system will include audible and visual alarms alertable to supervisors via the production control center. Quarterly calibration checks will be documented. This engineering control eliminates the hazard by automating the overflow prevention function.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Program for Hopper Systems
description: Implement a monthly preventive maintenance schedule for all hopper and overflow detection systems in the Regrind and Recycling Department and composite materials areas. Maintenance logs will be maintained in the digital CMMS system with predictive analytics to flag components showing wear patterns. Technicians will receive specialized training on hopper sensor diagnostics. Critical components will be replaced on a fixed schedule regardless of apparent condition. This administrative control prevents equipment failure through proactive maintenance.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Certification and Compressed Air Safety Training
description: Conduct comprehensive Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) and compressed air safety training for all maintenance, engineering, and tool room personnel. Training will include hands-on practice with isolation techniques specific to pneumatic systems, recognition of residual pressure hazards, and proper use of pressure bleed-down procedures. Certification will be required annually with quarterly refresher assessments. Tool room staff will demonstrate competency through written and practical exams. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante will oversee all certifications and maintain records.

name: Install Pressure Isolation Ball Valves on All Pneumatic Work Stations
description: Install manual isolation ball valves immediately upstream of each pneumatic work station and tool connection point, with clear labeling and color-coding. Valves will be positioned at ergonomic height for easy access. Install residual pressure gauge displays at each station showing current pneumatic system pressure. Maintenance procedures will be revised to require valve closure before any tool disassembly. Weekly functional checks of isolation valves will be documented. This engineering control provides positive isolation capability at the point of use.

name: Inspect and Recondition Mold Ejector Pins
description: Conduct immediate inspection of all ejector pins on Molding Line B for sharp edges, burrs, or damage. All affected pins will be removed and either reconditioned using fine sanding and polishing or replaced with new pins meeting dimensional specifications. A preventive maintenance schedule will be established for quarterly ejector pin inspection on all injection molding lines. Documentation of all inspections and maintenance actions will be maintained in the equipment logbook.

name: Enhance PPE Requirements for Part Removal Operations
description: Implement mandatory use of cut-resistant gloves rated for sharp edge contact during part removal operations on all injection molding lines. Update the Line B safety procedure to specify glove type and inspection frequency. Conduct a toolbox talk with all production operators emphasizing proper hand positioning and protective equipment usage when handling freshly ejected parts. Require safety goggles in addition to gloves for enhanced protection.

name: Clear Dust Accumulation and Repair Ventilation System
description: Immediately shut down affected workshop areas and perform comprehensive cleaning to remove all accumulated dust using HEPA-filtered vacuum equipment and wet wiping methods (no compressed air to avoid aerosol creation). Inspect and clear the blocked ductwork section in the dust collection system. Replace air filters in the collection unit. Establish a preventive maintenance schedule with monthly inspections and quarterly filter changes. Install permanent signage indicating fire hazard classification of the area.

name: Implement Enhanced Dust Control and Monitoring Protocol
description: Develop a formal dust control procedure requiring daily cleanup of work areas using approved equipment and methods. Assign responsibility for end-of-shift inspections to each shift team. Install dust monitors in the workshop to track particle levels continuously. Conduct quarterly audits of ventilation system performance. Provide training to all maintenance staff on dust hazard recognition and control measures. Establish a communication protocol to alert HSE office of any ventilation system degradation.

name: Update LOTO Procedure for Equipment with Isolated Power Systems
description: Revise the standard LOTO procedure to include specific requirements for equipment with capacitor banks or isolated power supplies. The revised procedure will mandate: (1) main power de-energization, (2) verification of discharge of all capacitor banks using a multimeter or discharge tool, (3) grounding of charged components, and (4) installation of secondary warning labels on isolated circuits. All maintenance staff will receive retraining within 7 days. The RTX-3000 will have permanent discharge instructions affixed to the equipment.

name: Establish Shift Handover Documentation for Equipment Work
description: Implement a mandatory Equipment Status Log that must be completed at each shift change whenever equipment is in a partially disassembled or serviced state. The log will include equipment name, date/time of work initiation, what was completed, what remains to be done, LOTO status, and specific hazards. The incoming shift supervisor must review and sign this log before work resumes. A digital system will be investigated to automate tracking and ensure accountability.

name: Implement Quarterly Equipment Pressure System Inspections
description: Establish a comprehensive quarterly inspection program for all injection molding equipment pressure systems, focusing on manifold integrity, valve seals, and cartridge conditions. This will include visual inspection for corrosion and stress fractures, pressure testing at 110% of operating parameters, and thermographic scanning to identify hot spots. All findings will be documented in the preventive maintenance system and communicated to production supervisors daily. This proactive approach will catch developing failures before they become safety hazards or cause production downtime.

name: Enhance Operator Equipment Anomaly Recognition Training
description: Develop and deliver specialized training modules for all production operators on recognizing early warning signs of equipment failure including unusual vibrations, temperature fluctuations, pressure gauge abnormalities, and chemical odors. Training will use case studies from TechnoPlast incidents and industry data. Operators will be certified on proper reporting procedures and emergency shutdown protocols. Training will be delivered quarterly to new staff and annually as refresher for existing operators. This ensures consistent recognition and reporting of equipment hazards across all shifts.

name: Install Height-Limited Storage Racks with Load Distribution Guides
description: Replace the existing Equipment Storage mezzanine racks with modern storage systems featuring integrated load distribution guides, weight limit indicators per shelf level, and reduced maximum stacking heights. Install safety stop bars at the top of each shelf to prevent bags from sliding off. All new racks will be rated for the actual load requirements with a 150% safety factor. Physical stops will prevent overloading beyond the rated capacity. Training will be provided on proper weight distribution techniques. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of falling loads.

name: Establish Material Storage Standard Operating Procedures
description: Create and implement detailed SOPs for all material storage operations including maximum stacking heights, load weight limits per section, weight verification requirements, and inspection checkpoints. Procedures will specify that heavier items must be stored at lower levels and lighter items at upper levels. All warehouse personnel will receive certification on these procedures before being authorized to perform material storage tasks. Procedures will be posted at all storage areas and reviewed during shift briefings. Weekly compliance audits will be conducted by supervisors with findings tracked in the safety management system.

name: Implement Daily Pre-Shift Warehouse Rack Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory daily inspection program for all warehouse storage racks to be conducted before the start of each shift. Inspectors will verify load distribution compliance, check for damaged or bent rack components, confirm that load limits are not exceeded, and document findings in a digital inspection log. Any non-compliance will immediately halt operations in that area until corrected. Inspections will be scheduled on a rotation among trained supervisors. This administrative control provides early detection of unsafe conditions before injuries occur.

name: Implement Color-Coded Regrind Material Storage and Tracking System
description: Establish a comprehensive material identification system using color-coded containers, barcodes, and lot tracking for all regrind materials. Each container will display the material grade, purity level, processing date, and approved applications using QR codes linked to a digital inventory database. Premium-grade and contaminated batches will be physically separated in distinct storage zones with restricted access. Only authorized personnel will be permitted to handle regrind materials. This system prevents accidental cross-contamination and ensures full traceability of material batches through production.

name: Establish Pre-Production Batch Verification Protocols
description: Require all composite material operators to perform mandatory visual and olfactory inspections of material batches before introducing them to processing lines. Operators must verify container labeling, check for discoloration or odor inconsistencies, and confirm lot numbers against production schedules. Any material showing signs of contamination or unclear identification must be immediately escalated to the shift supervisor for quality verification. Documentation of each batch inspection will be recorded in the production management system. This administrative control provides multiple opportunities to detect contaminated materials before they enter production.

name: Install Compressed Air Safety Nozzles and Signage
description: Replace all facility air line nozzles with low-pressure blow-off nozzles compliant with OSHA standards (maximum 30 PSI). Install high-visibility warning signs at all compressed air access points prohibiting use for cleaning or material dislodging. Provide training to all operators on proper compressed air handling. This engineering control eliminates the high-pressure air hazard while administrative controls restrict misuse. Expected outcome: elimination of compressed air-related injuries.

name: Implement Hopper Safety Guards and Maintenance Protocol
description: Install perforated steel guards around hopper discharge areas on all injection molding lines to prevent direct contact with ejected fragments. Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for hopper feed systems to prevent jamming. Create a written work instruction requiring lockout/tagout for all hopper maintenance activities. Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf will oversee implementation. This eliminates the hazard of sharp fragments being ejected during clearing operations.

name: Upgrade Chemical Container Labeling and Closure Verification System
description: Implement a color-coded cap system for all chemical containers with different colors for different chemical types. Establish a pre-transfer inspection checklist requiring operators to verify cap tightness before moving containers. Install secondary containment trays under all chemical shelving in the mixing room. Provide refresher training on proper chemical container handling to all mixing room operators. This administrative and engineering control prevents improper cap failures during material handling.

name: Enhance Spill Response Equipment and Positioning
description: Position additional absorbent spill kits and eyewash stations within arm's reach of each chemical work area in the mixing room. Conduct quarterly spill response drills with all chemical handling staff to ensure muscle memory and rapid response capability. Upgrade the chemical storage shelving with integrated drip trays that automatically contain spills. This improves response time and prevents environmental contamination from recurring spills.

name: Install Hydraulic Lift System with Redundant Safety Features
