description: Replace all temporary mechanical jacks with certified hydraulic lift systems equipped with dual pressure relief valves, load cells, and automatic locking mechanisms. Install synchronized support stands that prevent uneven descent. Each lift station must be certified quarterly by an independent hydraulic safety specialist. All maintenance technicians must complete hydraulic safety training before operating new systems. This engineering control eliminates the jack slippage hazard by replacing unreliable temporary supports with engineered systems.

name: Implement Lockout/Tagout Enhancements with Energy Isolation Verification
description: Revise the lockout/tagout procedure to require energy isolation verification and photographic documentation before work begins on suspended loads. Establish a mandatory two-person verification system where a second employee must confirm all energy sources are de-energized and locked before work proceeds. Conduct mandatory annual LOTO recertification for all maintenance staff with competency testing. Install clear warning placards on all mold assembly stations. This administrative control ensures comprehensive energy isolation before maintenance work.

name: Create Maintenance Work Area Environmental Controls
description: Designate dedicated maintenance work zones with reinforced flooring capable of supporting sustained loads. Provide anti-slip matting and eliminate floor obstructions in all maintenance areas. Install overhead warning systems that activate when loads are lifted above ground level. Create a pre-maintenance checklist including floor assessment and environmental safety verification. Train all maintenance personnel on work area setup and hazard identification. This combination of engineering and administrative controls prevents support failures through proper workspace design and preparation.

name: Implement Supplier Quality Verification Protocol for Hazardous Materials
description: Establish mandatory pre-delivery inspection checklist for all incoming bulk containers of regrind and chemical materials. Procurement team will work with suppliers to certify proper sealing procedures and container integrity testing. Documentation will be required for each shipment including integrity photographs and weight verification. Non-compliant shipments will be rejected and returned to sender. Training for receiving personnel on visual inspection of container seals will be mandatory, with quarterly refresher training. This addresses the root cause of the supplier-side container failure.

name: Install Secondary Containment System in Regrind Area
description: Design and install a raised containment floor or curbing system in the primary material staging area of the Regrind Department to contain liquid and particulate spills up to 250 liters. Containment will feature sloped flooring toward a collection sump with integrated absorbent material storage adjacent to the area. Emergency spill kits will be positioned at four strategic locations with clear signage and employee training on rapid deployment. This engineering control will prevent future spills from spreading to adjacent production areas.

name: Establish Material Container Handling Training Program
description: Develop comprehensive training module covering proper techniques for loading, unloading, and positioning bulk material containers using material handling equipment. Training will include recognition of container damage indicators, proper weight distribution assessment, and safe work practices with pallet jacks in warehouse environments. All personnel in Materials Management and Warehousing will complete this training within 30 days, with annual recertification required. Training will be bilingual (French/English) and include hands-on demonstration.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Injection Molding Equipment
description: Deploy vibration monitoring sensors on all six injection molding line primary motors and pump couplings to establish baseline vibration signatures and detect abnormal patterns indicative of wear or misalignment. Monthly trending analysis will be conducted by maintenance planning staff using predictive maintenance software. Alerts will be generated when vibration exceeds thresholds 20% above baseline, triggering preventive inspection scheduling. This engineering control will identify coupling and component failures before critical failure occurs, preventing unplanned shutdowns and hazardous fluid releases.

name: Update and Enforce Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Couplings
description: Establish and document a mandatory preventive maintenance schedule specifying coupling inspection every 12 months and coupling replacement every 36 months for all injection molding line equipment, aligned with manufacturer specifications. Create a digital maintenance tracking system with automatic work order generation 30 days before scheduled maintenance. Maintenance supervisor will conduct monthly compliance audits. Non-compliant equipment will be flagged for immediate attention. Training for all maintenance technicians will emphasize coupling wear recognition and replacement protocols.

name: Replace Hydraulic Solenoid Valves with Higher-Grade Components
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all solenoid valve specifications across production molding lines and replace all current models with ISO-certified industrial-grade solenoids rated for continuous duty at operating pressures. Source components from supplier with documented reliability records and extended warranties. Implement inventory stocking of minimum two replacement units per molding line to enable rapid emergency repairs. This substitution control upgrades equipment reliability by replacing underperforming components with engineered solutions designed for the facility's duty cycle.

name: Install Redundant Proximity Sensor Configuration with Corrosion Protection
description: Replace all single proximity sensors on ejector position detection with dual-sensor redundant configuration to ensure safety interlocks remain functional even if one sensor fails or corrodes. Sensor housing will include stainless steel protective enclosures rated for exposure to machine coolants and hydraulic mist in production environment. Integrate sensors with diagnostic monitoring to alert maintenance of sensor performance degradation or potential failures. This engineering control ensures that machine safety interlocks cannot be defeated by single-point sensor failures.

name: Establish Component Failure Tracking and Root Cause Analysis Protocol
description: Implement mandatory failure documentation and analysis for all hydraulic and electronic control component failures across production equipment. When component failure occurs, maintenance supervisor will document failure mode, probable cause, environmental factors, and component age. Quarterly analysis of failure data will be conducted to identify systemic issues and component design vulnerabilities. Failed components will be sent to supplier for forensic analysis when failure mode indicates quality or design defect. Results will inform procurement specifications and component selection decisions.

name: Implement Cut-Resistant Glove Policy for Mold Maintenance
description: Mandate the use of cut-resistant gloves (ANSI Level 3 or higher) for all mold cleaning, maintenance, and inspection activities. Provide specialized gloves designed for precision work to all technicians on Lines A and B. Include glove selection and proper usage in monthly toolbox talks and update the mold maintenance SOP with specific PPE requirements for different task types. Track compliance through supervisor inspections during daily pre-shift meetings.

name: Conduct Mold Hazard Mapping and Edge Smoothing Project
description: Perform a comprehensive audit of all molds on Lines A and B to identify and document sharp edges, burrs, and pinch points. Work with maintenance technician Fernand Giguère to develop a smoothing and de-burring schedule for identified hazards. Prioritize high-contact areas in mold cavities. Create visual hazard markers on molds that contain unavoidable sharp features. Update mold maintenance documentation with specific cautions for each mold.

name: Establish Warehouse Pallet Height Compliance System
description: Install height-limiting gates on all warehouse racking sections to physically prevent pallets from being stacked above the safe load line. Paint highly visible yellow/black striping at the maximum safe stacking height on all vertical supports. Implement a daily visual inspection checklist that warehouse staff must complete before shift start. Add pallet height verification to the monthly inventory audit. Non-compliant stacks must be corrected immediately. Train all forklift operators on the new height restrictions during their next certification renewal.

name: Enhance Forklift Operator Training with Obstacle Course
description: Develop a mandatory monthly competency refresher for all forklift operators that includes a practical obstacle course simulating warehouse conditions. Include blind spot exercises, pallet interaction scenarios, and speed regulation drills. Require operators to demonstrate awareness of nearby pallets and load stability before operating in the warehouse. Document all training sessions and maintain records. Operators who fail to demonstrate adequate awareness must complete additional training before returning to duty.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Chemical Transfers
description: Design and install a dedicated chemical transfer station with integrated secondary containment trays beneath all chemical storage and transfer points in the Composite Materials area. The containment system must hold 110% of the largest container volume (minimum 25 liters). Install drip pans with drain valves that direct spills to a hazardous waste collection sump. Mark the transfer zone with yellow safety tape and post clear procedural signage. Conduct quarterly maintenance inspections of containment systems and document results.

name: Implement Chemical Transfer Coupling Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-transfer inspection checklist that must be completed before any chemical transfer operation. The checklist must verify: proper coupling connection, hose integrity, valve function, and secondary containment availability. Require two-person verification for all transfers of containers larger than 5 liters. Create laminated checklist cards for posting at each transfer point. Train all personnel who handle chemicals on this protocol and require sign-off on training documentation. Make compliance audits a component of monthly safety committee inspections.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Activation Procedures
description: Reprogram the facility's HVAC control system to allow emergency maximum ventilation activation from multiple locations throughout the production area using clearly marked override switches. Install visual indicators (LED lights) that display current ventilation status. Conduct quarterly ventilation system function tests with staff present. Provide annual training to all production supervisors on ventilation system operation and emergency procedures. Document all ventilation tests and maintenance activities in the building management system.

name: Install Mechanical Lift Assist Equipment
description: Install pneumatic lift tables and material handling carts at the Packaging and Labeling Station to reduce manual lifting of boxes exceeding 15 kg. The equipment will be positioned to allow workers to move materials from shelving to conveyor at waist height, eliminating bending and excessive reaching. All staff will receive 2-hour training on proper use of the equipment. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of repetitive strain on the lumbar spine.

name: Implement Ergonomic Rotation Program for Packaging
description: Establish a job rotation schedule where packaging operators alternate between lifting tasks, labeling tasks, and quality verification every 90 minutes to reduce cumulative strain on any single muscle group. Create written procedures documenting proper lifting techniques with emphasis on back protection. Conduct monthly ergonomic assessments of the packaging workflow and adjust station heights/layouts based on worker feedback.

name: Establish Hopper Sensor Calibration Schedule
description: Implement a monthly calibration and testing protocol for all material hopper level indicators on injection molding lines. Create a preventive maintenance checklist to be performed the first Monday of each month by maintenance personnel. Sensors will be calibrated to trigger alarms at 85% capacity, allowing operators 15 minutes to begin material removal before overflow occurs. Document all calibration activities in the facility's equipment tracking system.

name: Install Secondary Overflow Prevention System
description: Install mechanical overflow gates on all material hoppers that automatically redirect excess resin to secondary containment bins when primary hopper reaches 90% capacity. This engineering control prevents material from spilling directly onto the production floor. Secondary bins will be equipped with quick-disconnect mechanisms for safe emptying. Installation will be prioritized on Line D first, then rolled out to remaining production lines over 60 days.

name: Implement Mandatory Machine Lockout/Tagout Procedures
description: Establish a written policy requiring that all CNC machines must be de-energized and locked out with individual operator locks before any maintenance, cleaning, or inspection activities. Create laminated instruction placards to be mounted on each machine. Conduct mandatory 4-hour LOTO training for all maintenance personnel within 14 days. Non-compliance will result in suspension of maintenance privileges pending retraining. This administrative and engineering control directly prevents accidental machine activation during maintenance.

name: Install Control Panel Protective Guards and Improve Ergonomic Access
description: Install clear polycarbonate guards over all non-essential machine control buttons on CNC equipment to prevent accidental activation from body contact. Redesign the layout of emergency stop buttons to be recessed and larger for easier access. Install a preventive maintenance schedule requiring weekly cleaning of all control panels using specified cleaning cloths to remove plastic dust and coolant residue, preventing buildup that impairs button function.

name: Implement Enhanced Hydraulic System Inspection Schedule
description: Establish a rigorous monthly inspection protocol for all hydraulic hoses on injection molding equipment, including pressure testing, visual inspection for micro-cracks, and documentation in the maintenance management system. Cross-train two maintenance technicians to conduct these inspections independently. Create color-coded inspection tags indicating the last inspection date. This measure directly addresses the root cause of inadequate preventive maintenance by ensuring hoses are assessed before failure occurs.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Hydraulic Systems
description: Install stainless steel drip pans beneath all hydraulic connection points on Lines A and B injection molding machines. These pans will capture leaked hydraulic fluid before it reaches the production floor, preventing environmental contamination and slip hazards. Include absorbent mats as secondary backup. Pans will be emptied into a dedicated waste oil collection container and recycled. This engineering control reduces environmental and safety risks from future hydraulic failures.

name: Implement Mandatory Machine Thermometer Calibration Program
description: Establish a quarterly calibration and verification protocol for all temperature display systems on injection molding machines. Calibrations will be performed by an external certified instrumentation laboratory. Each machine will have calibration certificates maintained on-site and in digital records. Machines with thermometers failing calibration will be immediately tagged out of service pending correction. This engineering control ensures accurate temperature readings and prevents workers from unknowingly handling equipment hotter than expected.

name: Distribute Heat-Resistant Gloves and Require Double-Glove Protocol
description: Provide all machine operators and mold technicians with certified heat-resistant gloves rated for 200°C contact protection. Require the use of double-glove technique when handling molds (cotton inner layer with Kevlar outer layer) to provide redundant protection. Conduct mandatory training on proper glove application and removal. Replace gloves every 90 days or upon visible damage. This administrative and PPE control adds a protective barrier against thermal burns from hot mold surfaces.

name: Install Automated Mold Extraction System with Temperature Verification
description: Retrofit Injection Molding Lines A and B with semi-automated mold extraction equipment that uses sensor-based temperature verification before allowing manual contact. The system will prevent mold removal if surface temperature exceeds a preset safe threshold (150°C). This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard by automating the high-risk mold removal task and adding a safety interlock based on verified temperature data.

name: Mark and Repair Floor Level Transitions in Warehouse
description: Conduct a comprehensive floor survey of the entire Warehouse and Shipping facility to identify all elevation changes exceeding 0.5 inches. Mark all transitions with high-visibility yellow and black striped tape and install beveled ramps to smooth transitions where practical. For unavoidable elevation changes, install permanent tactile warning strips and position additional lighting. Post signage alerting forklift operators to potential hazards. This engineering control eliminates the hidden floor hazard that contributed to forklift instability.

name: Install Protective Cable Conduits and Secure All Floor Utilities
description: Enclose all electrical, heating, and utility cables running across warehouse floors in rigid protective conduits or secure them to wall/ceiling routing systems. Where floor routing is necessary, install heavy-duty cable covers rated for forklift traffic. Implement a monthly inspection schedule to verify all conduits remain secure and undamaged. Add reflective markers to conduit ends and transitions. This engineering control eliminates the trip hazard and prevents pedestrians from catching feet on unsecured cables.

name: Enhance LOTO Enforcement with Real-Time Verification System
description: Install automated LOTO verification system requiring physical key insertion and confirmation before any maintenance mode can be initiated on all injection molding equipment. Integrate machine status display showing LOTO engagement status visible from operator position. Implement daily LOTO competency checks via quick QR-code scanning system with operator confirmation. Establish non-compliance tracking and progressive discipline policy. This engineering control ensures LOTO procedures cannot be bypassed and provides visual confirmation of safe machine state.

name: Mandatory Quarterly LOTO Retraining and Certification Program
description: Implement mandatory quarterly (not annual) LOTO retraining for all production operators covering equipment-specific procedures, emergency protocols, and incident case studies. Require hands-on practical demonstrations with sign-off by HSE director. Create competency matrix tracking individual LOTO proficiency. Include assessment of understanding, not just attendance. Operators failing assessment receive immediate remedial training and supervised operation restriction until competency demonstrated.

name: Restrict Operator Overtime and Implement Fatigue Management Policy
description: Establish maximum 10-hour consecutive shift limit for production operators working with high-hazard equipment. Implement mandatory 15-minute breaks every 2 hours during shift. Create fatigue assessment checklist completed by shift supervisor before operator begins hazardous tasks. Restrict operators from voluntarily extending shifts beyond normal 8-hour day without supervisor risk assessment and approval. Track fatigue-related near-misses and adjust policy accordingly. This administrative control addresses root cause of operator fatigue contributing to LOTO non-compliance.

name: Install Comprehensive Warehouse Traffic Control and Lighting System
description: Install LED motion-sensor lighting throughout all warehouse corridors and high-traffic areas, with minimum 300 lux illumination levels. Paint bright yellow directional floor lines designating pedestrian walkways separate from forklift traffic lanes. Install convex safety mirrors at all blind corners and intersections. Mount audible backup warning systems on all forklifts operating during low-visibility shifts. Install traffic control signs indicating forklift operation zones and pedestrian restrictions. This engineering control eliminates visibility hazards that contributed to collision.

name: Implement Forklift Operation Communication Protocol and Zones
description: Establish mandatory radio communication system where forklift operators broadcast location and intended movement every 2 minutes on dedicated channel. Designate specific forklift operation zones with restricted pedestrian access during active operations. Create role-based communication responsibilities: operators announce movements, pedestrians confirm receipt before crossing paths. Implement visual proximity warning badges for pedestrians in high-traffic areas. Conduct monthly safety huddles reviewing near-misses and collision incidents. This administrative control ensures all personnel know when and where forklifts are operating.

name: Reinstall and Lock Machine Safety Interlocks
description: All 32 injection molding machines will have their safety gate interlocks professionally inspected and certified functional by an external safety engineering firm. Devices will be tested to ensure they cannot be bypassed or propped open. Machine operators will be trained on proper lockout procedures and the critical importance of maintaining active safety systems. A log system will track all bypass incidents and near-misses. Immediate action: Day shift supervisor will physically inspect all machines and remove any objects blocking gates.

name: Implement Machine Guarding Competency Training
description: All production operators will complete a comprehensive 2-hour training program covering machine guarding principles, interlocked safety systems, lockout/tagout procedures, and consequences of bypassing safety devices. Training will include hands-on demonstrations with actual machines in the facility. Certification will be required before operating any injection molding equipment. Annual refresher training will be mandatory. Post-training assessments will verify understanding of proper safety procedures and the prohibition on defeating safety mechanisms.

name: Install Protective Barriers Around Hot Surfaces
description: Heat-resistant polycarbonate guards will be installed around all mold surfaces on high-production machines (20+ cycles per hour) to prevent accidental contact with hot materials during part removal. Guards will be designed to allow part extraction while protecting hands and forearms from thermal exposure. Barrier design will comply with ANSI B11.19 machine guarding standards. This engineering control will reduce burn injury risk concurrent with entanglement prevention.

name: Comprehensive Hydraulic System Inspection and Replacement
description: The failed chemical compounding mixer will be removed from service for complete hydraulic system overhaul by a certified hydraulic equipment technician. All hydraulic lines, fittings, seals, and pressure relief valves will be inspected or replaced. The system will be pressure-tested at 150% operating pressure before returning to service. A predictive maintenance schedule will be established with quarterly pressure tests and annual component inspections. All other identical mixers in the facility will undergo the same inspection proactively. Equipment log will track all maintenance activities.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Upgrade Chemical Storage
description: All flammable solvent storage drums will be relocated to a dedicated secondary containment area with 110% capacity poly containment liners. Each drum will be placed on a stainless steel pallets with drip trays. Storage area ventilation will be upgraded to meet NFPA guidelines with exhaust fans operating continuously and monitored for function via sensor alarms that alert maintenance if airflow drops below minimum threshold. Drum integrity will be inspected quarterly. All staff will receive training on secondary containment purpose and procedures.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Systems
description: A comprehensive preventive maintenance program will be implemented for all facility ventilation systems, including weekly visual inspections and monthly operational tests by dedicated maintenance staff. Specific protocols will address the Chemical Storage Building's exhaust systems with automated sensor verification. Any ventilation failures will be reported to the maintenance supervisor immediately and treated as critical priority repairs (target 4-hour resolution). A maintenance log will track all inspections and repairs. Monthly JHSC reviews will monitor compliance.

name: Implement Drum Integrity Inspection and Leak Detection Protocol
description: All flammable liquid storage drums will be inspected monthly for signs of corrosion, leaks, or damage. Drums showing any deterioration will be immediately transferred to a temporary containment vessel. A color-coded inspection system will track drum condition (green=safe, yellow=monitor, red=transfer immediately). Staff will receive training on recognizing hazardous drum conditions. A centralized log will track all drum inspections and maintenance history. Damaged drums will be decommissioned and properly disposed of through licensed hazmat contractors.

name: Implement Monthly Storage Rack Integrity Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection protocol for all storage racks in the Raw Materials Warehouse and Finished Goods Warehouse. Inspections will focus on structural corrosion, bolt integrity, and load-bearing capacity. Any racks showing signs of corrosion or structural compromise will be immediately removed from service and repaired or replaced. All inspections will be documented with photographs and reports filed with the HSE office. Training will be provided to warehouse supervisors on identifying hazardous rack conditions.

name: Reinforce Storage Protocol Training for Material Handlers
description: Conduct immediate refresher training for all material handlers and warehouse staff on proper stacking procedures, including the 4-bag maximum per-shelf protocol and weight distribution requirements. Training will include visual demonstrations of improper stacking consequences, practical hands-on exercises, and competency verification. A laminated reference guide will be posted at each storage area. Non-compliance will result in retraining and potential disciplinary action.

name: Establish Compressed Air Safety Protocol and Equipment Modification
description: Implement mandatory pressure reduction for compressed air used in hopper cleaning, limiting maximum PSI to 40 PSI via regulator installation. All compressed air lines will be fitted with quick-disconnect safety couplers and pressure gauges. Provide training on proper compressed air handling techniques, including the prohibition of using compressed air for personnel cleaning. Personnel must complete a certified compressed air safety course. Safety alerts will be posted at all compressed air access points. Non-compliance will result in work suspension and retraining.

name: Implement Hopper Maintenance and Cleaning Standard Operating Procedure
description: Develop a detailed SOP for hopper cleaning that includes pre-cleaning visual inspection for blockages, use of non-powered hand tools for blockage removal where possible, and mandatory work isolation procedures. The SOP will specify that all compressed air cleaning must be performed with equipment depressurized and locked out/tagged out (LOTO). Provide laminated reference cards at each molding station. Supervisors will conduct weekly compliance audits. This addresses the root cause of improper compressed air discharge.

name: Install Automated Resin Transfer System with Temperature Control
description: Replace manual pouring procedures with a semi-automated transfer system that uses gravity-fed tubing with flow control valves and insulated piping for hot resin transfer. The system will include temperature sensors and an automated shutoff valve that triggers at temperatures exceeding 65°C. This engineering control eliminates manual contact with hot vessels and reduces burn injury risk significantly. Installation includes staff training on system operation and maintenance. Expected completion: 30 days.

name: Upgrade Chemical Handling PPE and Mandatory Use Protocol
description: Provide all chemical mixing operators with new heat-resistant gloves (rated to 200°C), long-sleeved Kevlar-reinforced aprons, and forearm protection sleeves. Implement a mandatory 100% PPE compliance verification system with photo documentation. All operators must complete a recertification course on chemical handling hazards and thermal protection. Supervisors will conduct daily pre-shift PPE compliance checks. Non-compliance results in immediate work suspension and retraining before resuming duties.

name: Establish Chemical Handling Safe Work Procedures and Ergonomic Assessment
description: Develop comprehensive safe work procedures specific to heated resin transfer operations, including vessel handling techniques, ergonomic positioning, and emergency response protocols. Conduct ergonomic assessment of the chemical mixing workstation to identify postural stress factors. Install non-slip mats and improve task lighting. Implement a buddy system for hot liquid transfer tasks. Document all procedures in a Chemical Handling Manual and require annual recertification. This addresses both the immediate cause (slippery vessel) and underlying risk factors.

name: Install Automatic Hopper Shutoff System with Redundant Sensors
description: Replace the single moisture sensor on the Material Drying and Preparation Room hoppers with a dual-sensor redundant system featuring both capacitive level sensors and mechanical float switches. Install automatic solenoid valves that will immediately halt resin flow when either sensor detects overflow conditions. This engineering control eliminates the need for manual intervention during overflow situations. The system will include visual and audible alarms to alert operators, and integrate with the facility's SCADA monitoring system for real-time tracking. Expected outcome: elimination of manual hopper clearing operations and prevention of operator exposure to active augers.

name: Mandatory Machine Guarding and Lockout/Tagout Refresher Training
description: Conduct immediate safety retraining for all 120 day-shift production personnel focusing on hopper machinery hazards, proper lockout/tagout procedures, and prohibition of manual clearing operations without system shutdown. Training will include hands-on demonstrations using the newly installed shutoff system and documented competency assessments. Implement a monthly audit program where supervisors verify that operators are following protocols, with findings reported to the JHSC. Create visual SOP cards with pictograms showing correct procedures placed directly on all hopper stations.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Program for Hopper Sensors
description: Develop a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule requiring inspection and calibration of all moisture sensors and level detection equipment in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Maintenance technicians will document sensor response times, verify alarm thresholds, and replace aging sensors proactively. Create a tracking log in the maintenance management system with work orders automatically generated 30 days before scheduled maintenance. This administrative control ensures early detection of sensor degradation before failures occur, preventing the cascade of events that led to this incident.

name: Upgrade to Chemical-Resistant Transfer Equipment
description: Replace all 55-gallon drum transfer systems with purpose-designed secondary containment systems featuring integrated peristaltic pump dispensers or sealed gravity-feed transfer carts. These systems eliminate manual pouring and reduce splashing hazards. Install drip trays under all chemical transfer stations with absorbent material for spill containment. Select equipment rated for acetone and other solvents used in the facility. This engineering control substitutes the hazardous manual pouring process with a safer, enclosed system that maintains chemical integrity and prevents thermal stress failures.

name: Complete Warehouse Racking System Structural Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Conduct a comprehensive structural engineering assessment of all storage rack systems in the Warehouse and Shipping facility, including load-bearing calculations, weld integrity testing, and corrosion evaluation. Implement a phased replacement program prioritizing racks over 10 years old or showing any structural compromise. All replacement systems will use modern certified storage solutions with load ratings clearly marked and monitored through a digital inventory management system that prevents overloading. Install redundant load sensors and alarming if weight limits are approached. This engineering control eliminates the cascading failure mechanism and provides structural safety assurance.

name: Establish Quarterly Rack Maintenance and Inspection Protocol
description: Develop and implement a formal quarterly inspection program for all storage racks conducted by certified structural inspectors or qualified maintenance personnel. Inspection checklist will include visual corrosion assessment, bolt and weld integrity verification, beam deflection measurements, and load test documentation. All findings will be recorded in the maintenance management system with automatic work order generation for any deficiencies. Create a warehouse safety zone map showing which racks have been certified and which are restricted pending repairs. Post findings in the JHSC monthly safety meeting.

name: Install Zone Protection and Hazard Barriers Around High-Risk Storage Areas
description: Install heavy-duty steel guardrails and hazard barrier netting around perimeter zones beneath tall storage racks to prevent personnel and equipment from being directly under loaded shelves. Create a restricted access zone during high-activity periods on the dock. Place prominent warning signage with symbols and bilingual text (French/English) at entry points. Establish a traffic pattern on the dock that minimizes personnel time spent in zones below overhead loads. Train all dock personnel on the new safety zones and reinforce that intentional access to restricted areas is grounds for disciplinary action.

name: Implement Real-Time Equipment Status Digital Dashboard
description: Install a networked digital status display system at each injection molding line showing real-time equipment temperatures, maintenance modes, and coolant system status. The dashboard will sync with the maintenance work order system and display bright visual alerts when equipment is in non-standard states. Operators must acknowledge the status before beginning work on any equipment. This engineering control eliminates the communication gap that led to the incident by providing immediate, visible confirmation of equipment safety status.

name: Mandatory Thermal Protective Gloves for Hot Mold Handling
description: Distribute and enforce mandatory use of certified thermal-resistant gloves (minimum 250°C rating) for all personnel handling molds above 100°C. Establish a replacement schedule and require documented training on proper fit and use. Place glove dispensers at all mold changeout stations with visual reminder signage. Conduct monthly compliance audits during shift inspections. This PPE-based control provides immediate hand protection while systematic improvements are implemented.

name: Install Height-Limiting Safety Barriers on Storage Racks
description: Design and install yellow height-limiting bars on all overhead racks in UNIT-007 set 5 cm below the lowest load clearance. These physical barriers will prevent pallet loads from striking structural elements. Conduct a full warehouse survey to identify all at-risk rack configurations. Add reflective striping and install proximity warning sensors on pallet jacks to alert operators when approaching barriers. This engineering control completely eliminates the hazard of loads striking overhead structures.

name: Implement Warehouse Aisle Clearance and Load Securement Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory administrative procedure requiring material handlers to visually confirm overhead clearance before moving any load exceeding 25 kg vertically. Implement a two-person verification system where a spotter confirms clearance for the operator. Create load securement standards requiring bundled materials to be banded with minimum 4 attachment points. Post visual guides at all pallet jack stations. Conduct monthly competency assessments of all material handlers. This administrative control reinforces safe work practices and prevents overloading.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Lighting and Install Safety Mirrors
description: Upgrade LED lighting in warehouse aisles to minimum 200 lux (measured at floor level) with improved fixture placement to eliminate shadow zones. Install convex safety mirrors at aisle intersections and blind corners to improve visibility of approaching equipment and obstacles. This engineering control directly addresses visibility hazards that contributed to the misjudged clearance.

name: Comprehensive Flooring Assessment and Repair Program
description: Conduct a facility-wide assessment of all production and material handling areas to identify uneven flooring, cracks, and surface hazards. Prioritize repairs in UNIT-017 where material transport frequency is highest. Install floor leveling compound in areas with minor irregularities and perform section replacement where damage exceeds 5 mm variation. Establish a monthly floor inspection schedule with photographic documentation. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the cart destabilization.

name: Implement Mandatory Temperature Sensor Calibration Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring all mold temperature sensors and indicators on injection molding lines to be professionally calibrated every 6 months. This will be tracked through a digital maintenance management system with automated alerts. All line supervisors will receive training on recognizing sensor anomalies and halting operations when readings appear inconsistent with physical observations. The corrective measure addresses the root cause of the malfunctioning temperature display that prevented the operator from knowing actual mold surface temperature.

name: Upgrade to Advanced Thermal Gloves with Indicator System
description: Replace standard heat-resistant gloves with advanced thermal-responsive gloves featuring embedded temperature indicators that change color when surface temperature exceeds safe handling levels (160°C). Distribute new gloves to all injection molding operators and machine setters. Provide training on proper glove selection and use. This engineering control provides operators with real-time thermal feedback independent of equipment instrumentation.

name: Establish Mold Contact Safety Procedure
description: Develop and implement a formal written procedure requiring operators to use non-contact infrared thermometers to verify actual mold temperature before attempting component removal. Operators must record readings on a touch-time log. Procedure will include mandatory 2-minute cool-down periods following cycle completion before manual mold contact. All production staff will receive hands-on training and competency assessment. This administrative control creates an independent verification mechanism separate from equipment displays.

name: Install Material Storage Racks with Optimal Height Shelving
description: Replace existing low-height storage pallets in the Material Drying and Preparation Room with adjustable storage racks where material bags can be positioned between knee and shoulder height (optimal ergonomic zone). Install 8 new modular shelving units with maximum bag storage at 36-42 inches above ground. This engineering control eliminates excessive bending and twisting motions required by current storage configuration. Expected outcome: reduction in lower back strain incidents by 60-70% in this area.

name: Mandatory Ergonomic Training and Technique Certification
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic training session for all material handlers on proper lifting techniques, including the 5-step safe lifting method, body mechanics, and load assessment. All material handlers must complete hands-on competency assessment before returning to duty. Provide refresher training quarterly. Distribute laminated ergonomic reference guides at each workstation. This administrative control addresses improper lifting techniques identified as contributing factor.

name: Introduce Mechanical Bag Handling Equipment
description: Procure and deploy 2 manual bag handling assists (ergonomic bag carts with assisted lift mechanisms) for use in material preparation areas. Equipment reduces required lifting force by up to 60%. Train all material handlers on proper equipment operation. Establish procedures requiring use of mechanical assists for bags exceeding 25 kg. This substitution control replaces manual lifting with powered assistance for heavy loads.

name: Implement Automated Deburring Process for Medical Components
description: Integrate a tumble deburring chamber into the post-molding process for all medical-grade polycarbonate components. This equipment uses ceramic media and vibration to remove sharp edges and burrs automatically before parts reach quality inspection stations. The automation eliminates human contact with sharp mold edges entirely. Expected outcome: near-complete elimination of laceration injuries from component handling in quality inspection and packaging operations.

name: Implement Quarterly Hopper Sensor Calibration Program
description: Establish a mandatory preventive maintenance schedule requiring calibration of all hopper level sensors on injection molding lines every 90 days. Create a digital tracking system integrated with the maintenance management software to track calibration dates and alert supervisors when calibration is due. This engineering control removes the root cause of hopper overflow by ensuring sensors accurately detect fill levels. Expected outcome: elimination of hopper overflow incidents related to sensor malfunction.

name: Prohibit Compressed Air Use for Spill Cleanup and Provide Training
description: Establish an administrative control prohibiting the use of compressed air for clearing plastic pellet spills from production floors. Provide all machine operators and setters with mandatory training on safe spill cleanup procedures, including use of soft-bristle brooms, HEPA vacuums, and proper PPE. Create laminated procedure posters at each production line. This administrative control eliminates the practice of using compressed air that caused particle dispersal. All production staff must complete refresher training annually.

name: Upgrade Hopper Containment Shields on All Molding Lines
description: Install engineered containment shields around hopper discharge areas on all injection molding lines to capture and contain overflow material. Shields will be constructed of perforated stainless steel to allow heat dissipation while containing material within a 12-inch radius. Each shield will include a quick-drain valve directing overflow to a designated collection bin below the line. This engineering control prevents airborne dispersion of hot plastic particles. Implementation will be completed across all 8 production lines over 30 days.

name: Install Retaining Straps on All Mezzanine Storage Shelves
description: Install heavy-duty adjustable retaining straps on all storage shelves in the Equipment Storage Room mezzanine. Straps will be rated for minimum 1.5 times the weight capacity of each shelf compartment. Staff will be trained to secure all materials with straps before leaving the area. This engineering control eliminates the potential for objects to fall from elevated storage. All shelves will be retrofitted within 10 days. A verification checklist system will be implemented for daily inspection.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Mezzanine Storage Audit and Reorganization
description: Perform a complete inventory and reorganization of all materials stored on mezzanine shelves. Reorganize items according to weight distribution guidelines, placing heavier items on lower shelves and lighter items on upper shelves. Create and enforce a weight limit marking system for each shelf. Establish a documented storage map showing authorized storage locations for all equipment types. This administrative control ensures materials are stored safely. Zahra Nasri (Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist) will oversee the audit.

name: Implement Mandatory Mold Inspection and Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a preventive maintenance program requiring detailed inspection of all injection molds every 60 days (instead of current 120 days). Inspections will include documentation of parting line condition, ejector pin wear, and cavity edge integrity. Any mold showing wear or sharp edges will be immediately pulled from service and sent to the tool room for reconditioning or replacement. Inspection results will be logged in the maintenance management system. This engineering control removes the hazard of sharp edges on parts by addressing the root cause of mold degradation.

name: Enforce Mandatory Cut-Resistant Gloves for All Part Handling Operations
description: Issue ANSI Level A2 cut-resistant gloves to all production personnel and Machine Setters. Enforce a strict policy requiring gloves during all part removal, handling, and processing activities. Conduct spot inspections during each shift to verify compliance. Replace gloves weekly or immediately if damaged. Post visual reminders at all production lines showing proper PPE usage. This administrative and PPE control ensures workers are protected from hand injuries from sharp edges while the mold maintenance program addresses the root cause.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance for Cooling Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance program for all cooling water systems, including quarterly seal inspections, pressure monitoring, and thermal imaging to detect early failures. Install pressure relief valves with alarm systems on all cooling loops to prevent catastrophic failures. Train maintenance technicians on early warning signs of pump seal degradation and schedule replacements before critical failure occurs. This addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance and prevents future uncontrolled equipment operation.

name: Install Electrical Isolation for Coolant Systems
description: Redesign cooling system layout to physically separate coolant lines from electrical control panels using waterproof barriers and secondary containment. Install automatic shut-off solenoid valves connected to moisture sensors that activate the emergency stop circuit if coolant contacts electrical equipment. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of electrical failure due to coolant contact.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Storage Rack Safety Audit
description: Perform immediate inspection of all storage racks and shelving units throughout the facility, with particular attention to dock areas. Check for corrosion, bent support brackets, loose fasteners, and signs of structural fatigue. Remove any racks showing deterioration and replace with new, galvanized steel systems rated for warehouse environments. Establish a quarterly inspection schedule and document all findings. This eliminates the hazard of structural failure.

name: Implement Load Stacking Height Restrictions
description: Establish and post clear signage limiting storage heights to 5 feet maximum in all warehouse areas, with special restrictions for heavy materials like resin bags. Provide training to all receiving and shipping staff on proper stacking procedures and weight distribution. Use weight limitation labels on racks and implement a checklist system for dock supervisors to verify compliance daily. This administrative control reduces the mass and gravitational energy of potential falling loads.

name: Service and Calibrate Mold Release Application Systems
description: Schedule immediate maintenance on all mold release agent dispensers across the facility. Technicians will clean nozzles, calibrate spray patterns, and replace any worn components to ensure consistent, controlled application. Establish a weekly inspection and testing protocol to verify proper function. Install flow rate gauges on all systems to alert operators when application volumes exceed normal parameters. This engineering control prevents hazardous chemical buildup on equipment surfaces.

name: Implement Automated Deburring Station for Line C
description: Install a dedicated deburring station with pneumatic edge-finishing tools at the end of Injection Molding Line C to remove all sharp edges and burrs from medical-grade components before manual collection. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard at source rather than relying on worker vigilance. Operator training will include the new deburring SOP. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in sharp-edge-related hand injuries on this line within 6 months.

name: Mandatory Cut-Resistant Glove Program for Finishing Operations
description: Issue ANSI A4 cut-resistant gloves to all finishing operators and establish a mandatory-use policy for component handling. Gloves will be provided in two sizes, checked monthly for wear, and replaced as needed. Training sessions will cover proper donning, fit verification, and limitations of PPE. This administrative control combined with PPE provides immediate protection while engineering improvements are implemented.

name: Install Predictive Monitoring System on Industrial Resin Dryers
description: Implement IoT-enabled temperature and humidity sensors on all 12 industrial resin dryers with real-time alerts sent to the maintenance department when parameters fall outside acceptable ranges (±3°C). Integrate with existing CMMS for automated work order generation when anomalies are detected. This engineering control enables early detection of equipment failures before hazardous conditions develop. Expected outcome: 100% detection of temperature excursions within 15 minutes of occurrence.

name: Establish Quarterly Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Resin Dryer Equipment
description: Create and enforce a documented quarterly PM schedule including: thermostat calibration verification, controller battery replacement, condensation drain inspection, and heating element testing. Assign responsibility to maintenance technicians with supervisor sign-off. Document all PM activities in the maintenance log. Training will cover warning signs of controller failure and emergency shutdown procedures. This administrative control prevents recurrence through systematic equipment servicing.

name: Implement Solvent Storage Cabinet with Grounding System
description: Replace all open storage of cleaning solvents with certified flammable liquid storage cabinets installed in designated chemical zones, equipped with grounding straps to prevent static electricity buildup. All cabinets must be positioned minimum 3 meters from electrical panels and equipment. Provide training to all operators on proper solvent handling, storage, and spill response procedures. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard source and reduces ignition risk through proper containment and grounding.

name: Conduct Fire Suppression System Sensitivity Audit and Recalibration
description: Engage certified fire protection engineers to audit all heat detection thresholds on the facility's automated suppression system. Verify that sprinkler activation is calibrated to distinguish between controlled production heat (< 50°C) and actual fire conditions (> 150°C). Recalibrate all 24 zone sensors and document baseline measurements. Implement quarterly verification procedures. Reduce unintended discharge events that cause water damage and production loss.

name: Mandatory Spill Response and Fire Prevention Training for Evening Shift
description: Conduct comprehensive training for all evening shift operators (15 employees) covering: proper solvent handling and storage, spill containment procedures, static electricity prevention, emergency fire suppression equipment operation, and fire alarm procedures. Include hands-on practice with dry chemical extinguishers on a training fire simulator. Require competency assessment and documentation. Training to be completed within 30 days and repeated annually. This administrative control ensures operators have knowledge to prevent and respond to similar incidents.

name: Implement Pre-Transfer Drum Valve Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory checklist for all hazardous material drum transfers requiring verification that outlet valves are secure before any movement. This will include visual inspection, hand-tightness confirmation, and documentation in a logbook. Training will be provided to all inventory and material handling staff within 5 days. The procedure will be posted at all chemical storage and mixing stations. Implementation includes monthly audits of compliance by the HSE team to ensure sustained adherence.

name: Upgrade Spill Containment Infrastructure
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all resin transfer stations with capacity for 150% of the largest drum volume in use. Each tray will include absorbent material stations positioned within 10 meters. Signage will be updated to clearly mark containment zones. Staff will receive hands-on training in spill response procedures using the new infrastructure. This engineering control will prevent future spills from spreading beyond contained areas and reduce cleanup time significantly.

name: Enhanced Respiratory Protection During Resin Operations
description: Provide all personnel working in chemical mixing and transfer areas with certified respirators (N95 minimum, upgraded to P100 for high-exposure periods). Conduct fit-testing for all 15 staff members assigned to this unit within one week. Establish a respiratory protection program coordinator role to conduct quarterly refresher training and maintain equipment. This administrative and PPE control will minimize inhalation exposure during spills and routine operations.

name: Install Edge Protection and Anti-Slip Restraint System on All Mezzanine Shelving
description: Install perimeter guardrails (42 inches high minimum) along all open edges of the storage mezzanine and implement spring-loaded cable or steel bar restraint systems on each shelf to prevent tool boxes and equipment from shifting. All stored items exceeding 25 pounds must be secured with approved restraint straps. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of falling objects. The installation will be completed within 10 days, and staff will receive training on proper use of the restraint system.

name: Establish Mezzanine Storage Management and Inspection Procedures
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive storage management standard for all elevated work areas specifying weight limits per shelf, approved storage locations, and restraint requirements. Conduct monthly safety audits of mezzanine storage using a standardized checklist. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance Supervisor to verify compliance. All equipment stored on mezzanines must be documented in an inventory system. Staff will receive training on the new procedures during the next monthly safety meeting. This administrative control prevents recurrence through clear expectations and regular oversight.

name: Implement Quality Control Edge Inspection Standard for All Molded Parts
description: Establish a mandatory edge deburring and smoothing procedure in the quality control process for all injection-molded components, especially those requiring manual assembly. Parts with sharp edges or burrs exceeding 0.5mm will be rejected and returned for rework. Petra Mueller, Quality Control Lead, will implement visual and tactile inspection standards at the finishing station. Training will be provided to all assembly operators on identifying unsafe part edges. This engineering control at the source eliminates the hazard by preventing defective parts from reaching assembly.

name: Implement Container Integrity Pre-Transfer Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-transfer inspection checklist for all chemical containers before movement. Each container must be visually inspected for lid integrity, seal condition, and structural damage. Inspection must be documented and signed off by the transferring operator. Training will be provided to all composite materials technicians and handlers. Secondary containment trays will be required during all chemical transfers. Implementation includes creation of inspection forms and integration into the daily work procedures.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Composite Materials Area
description: Install additional localized extraction fans and upgrade the existing ventilation system in UNIT-015 to achieve higher air exchange rates during epoxy resin processing. Install fume capture hoods at all chemical transfer points. The upgraded system will include real-time air quality monitoring with alerts when VOC concentrations exceed safe thresholds. This engineering control will reduce employee exposure to harmful vapors and provide early warning of potential chemical releases.

name: Establish Chemical Supplier Quality Audit Program
description: Implement a supplier audit program requiring all chemical container manufacturers to demonstrate quality control procedures for lid sealing mechanisms. Each batch of containers received will be subject to random sampling and pressure testing. Containers failing inspection will be rejected and returned to the supplier. This measure addresses the root cause of defective lids and ensures only high-quality containers enter the facility.

name: Implement Strict Machine Interlock Non-Bypass Protocol
description: Establish a facility-wide policy prohibiting the bypass of safety interlocks under any circumstances without formal authorization and supervision by Plant Manager and HSE leadership. Any machine requiring interlock bypass must be immediately de-energized, locked out, and tagged. Technicians must complete additional lockout/tagout training before working on machines with compromised interlocks. Violations will result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. All machine operators will receive refresher training on this policy within two weeks.

name: Upgrade Injection Molding Machine Safety Systems
description: Replace existing sensor systems on all 32 injection molding machines with redundant pressure monitoring systems and dual interlock mechanisms. Install pressure relief valves that prevent secondary hydraulic pulses during manual part removal. Upgrade the machine guarding to include mechanical barriers that prevent hand entry during cooling periods. Include backup battery systems for safety interlocks to ensure functionality during power anomalies. Conduct full system testing and validation by equipment manufacturer.

name: Establish Machine Maintenance and Sensor Repair Response System
description: Create a rapid response protocol for addressing sensor malfunctions and machine maintenance issues. When a sensor fails or interlock is compromised, the machine must be immediately shut down and clearly marked as out of service with warning tags. A qualified technician must repair the issue within 4 hours or the machine remains offline until repaired. No workarounds or bypasses are permitted. Operators will receive training on reporting procedures and communication with maintenance. Tracking system will monitor all repair requests and response times.

name: Install Automated Deburring and Edge Finishing System
description: Procure and install an automated deburring machine in the finishing area to treat all medical device housings immediately after molding. The equipment will use pneumatic finishing heads to remove sharp edges and molded protrusions before components proceed to assembly. Automated processing will ensure 100% compliance with edge finishing specifications and eliminate dependency on manual process steps. The system will include quality verification sensors to confirm edge smoothness meets specifications before release to assembly.

name: Implement Production Batch Tracking and Quality Gate System
description: Establish a digital tracking system requiring all production batches to pass through mandatory quality gate checkpoints before progressing to the next production stage. Each batch must be verified for completion of all required processes (molding, deburring, cleaning) before release to assembly. Operators will scan batch QR codes at each checkpoint. The system will prevent batches with skipped steps from reaching assembly stations. This administrative control ensures no components bypass critical finishing processes.

name: Implement Mandatory Thermal Equipment Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all heating cylinders, thermocouples, and thermal cutoff devices across production lines. Maintenance technicians will document all inspections, calibrations, and sensor replacements in a centralized digital maintenance log. All equipment will be tagged with inspection dates and next-service-due dates. This addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance intervals and ensures early detection of failing components before incidents occur.

name: Upgrade PPE Requirements for Hot Plastic Material Handling
description: Issue aramid-reinforced thermal protective sleeves and shoulder guards to all machine setters and operators working on injection molding lines. Conduct mandatory training on proper use, inspection, and care of thermal PPE. Update work procedures to require thermal PPE during any operation involving heating cylinders above 200°C. Ensure inventory is maintained with regular replacement cycles. This engineering and administrative control reduces burn risk while maintenance protocols are being strengthened.

name: Install Automatic Temperature Monitoring System
description: Deploy automated thermal monitoring systems with real-time alerts on all injection molding lines. System will trigger automatic shutdown if temperatures exceed safe operating parameters by more than 10°C. Install visual and audible alarms at operator stations. This eliminates the dependency on manual thermocouple readings alone and provides rapid response to equipment malfunctions before hazardous material discharge occurs.

name: Implement Mandatory Container Closure Verification Protocol
description: Establish a two-person verification system for all hazardous chemical transfers. After each transfer operation, a second operator must inspect and physically confirm that container lids are secure, properly seated, and labeled. Create a checklist log maintained at the hazardous waste station. Supervisors will conduct random audits weekly. This administrative control eliminates the most common cause of vapor accumulation and fire risk in the chemical storage area.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Hazardous Waste Management Area
description: Install continuous mechanical ventilation with automated activation based on vapor detection sensors. System will maintain negative pressure in the storage area and exhaust vapors through HEPA filters to atmosphere. Add carbon monoxide and flammable vapor monitors with audible alarms. This engineering control ensures hazardous vapors cannot accumulate regardless of shift activity level or operator oversight.

name: Conduct Hazardous Waste Area Fire Safety Training for All Evening Shift Staff
description: Mandatory quarterly training for all evening and night shift employees covering fire hazards specific to solvent storage, proper container handling, emergency response procedures, and fire suppression system operation. Include practical drills simulating acetone vapor ignition scenarios. Training will emphasize shift-specific risks when hazardous waste area may have reduced supervision. Documented attendance required.

name: Conduct Facility Layout Audit and Update Operational Clearance Documentation
description: Perform comprehensive measurement of all storage corridors and access routes used by forklifts and material handling equipment. Document actual clearances and compare against maximum safe pallet dimensions. Update the facility operations map with new clearance specifications and distribute to all forklift operators and supervisors. Install prominent warning signage at corridors with reduced clearance. This administrative control ensures operators have accurate information for safe material handling operations.

name: Implement Pallet Dimension Compliance Program
description: Establish maximum pallet width limits for each material handling route within the facility based on confirmed clearances. Install load limiters or physical guides at packing stations to prevent oversized loads. Create a visual reference system using colored tape on pallet edges showing maximum allowable width. Conduct monthly audits of packed pallet dimensions before shipment. This engineering and administrative control prevents future load-corridor mismatch incidents.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Procedures for All Mold Operations
description: Establish and enforce strict lockout/tagout protocols for all mold changeout and maintenance activities. All personnel working on injection molding equipment must complete refresher LOTO training and sign acknowledgment forms. Create color-coded lockout stations at each molding line with adequate locks and tags for every operator. Supervisors must verify LOTO compliance before any mold work begins. Non-compliance will result in disciplinary action and mandatory retraining. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of this incident by ensuring equipment cannot be accidentally activated during maintenance.

name: Service and Replace Pressure Relief Valve with Certified Unit
description: Conduct immediate inspection and replacement of the faulty pressure relief valve on Line B's primary injection molding press. Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all pressure relief valves across all injection molding equipment, with documented service records maintained by the Central Maintenance Workshop. Install pressure monitoring gauges visible to operators to detect anomalies. Only certified maintenance technicians from UNIT-012 may perform this work. This engineering control eliminates the mechanical failure that caused the incident by ensuring all safety systems are functioning within design specifications.

name: Enhance Operator Training on Mold Safety Hazards
description: Develop and deliver specialized training module focused on injection molding hazards, including crush and entanglement risks. Training must cover proper mold handling, recognition of equipment malfunction warning signs, and immediate response protocols. All Line B operators must complete this training within 30 days. Include case studies and near-miss scenarios. Conduct quarterly refresher sessions. This administrative control increases operator awareness and preparedness to prevent similar incidents through better hazard recognition and safer work practices.

name: Replace Resin Dryer with Modern Temperature Control System
description: Procure and install a new industrial resin dryer with redundant temperature control systems, dual thermostats, and automatic overheat shutoff mechanisms that trigger at 140°C. Specify equipment with digital temperature monitoring and remote alarm notifications to facility management. The new system must include pressure relief certification and automatic purge cycles. Old equipment will be recycled according to environmental protocols. This engineering control eliminates the specific mechanical failure that caused this incident by replacing the outdated thermostat with modern redundant safety systems.

name: Establish Monthly Preventive Maintenance Schedule for All Thermal Equipment
description: Create documented preventive maintenance schedule for all resin dryers, heat treatment units, and thermal processing equipment. Maintenance tasks include thermostat verification against calibrated reference thermometers, pressure relief valve testing, heating element inspection, and sensor function verification. Schedule maintenance during low-production periods. Maintain detailed records in a centralized database. Train maintenance technicians from Central Maintenance Workshop on all procedures. This administrative control prevents similar overheating incidents by ensuring all safety systems are regularly verified and functioning within design specifications.

name: Implement Hopper Content Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-shift inspection procedure for all material hoppers in the drying room to verify that only raw materials are present and no finished parts, contaminants, or sharp objects have been mixed in. Operators will document their inspection on a daily log. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of commingling of materials and reduces sharp object contact hazards. Training will be provided to all relevant staff within 5 days of implementation.

name: Upgrade to Cut-Resistant Gloves for Material Handling
description: Procure and distribute ANSI A3-rated cut-resistant nitrile gloves to all personnel working in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. These gloves provide protection against sharp objects and cuts while maintaining dexterity for handling small parts. Implementation includes sizing all staff, establishing a replacement schedule, and training workers on proper glove use and care. This engineering/PPE control provides an additional layer of protection against hand lacerations.

name: Install UV Chamber Safety Interlocks and Guards
description: Install physical safety interlocks on all UV testing chambers that automatically shut down the UV light source when the access door is opened or when workers approach within 12 inches of the chamber opening. Add reflective warning guards and expanded polycarbonate shielding around chamber openings to prevent accidental direct exposure. This is an engineering control that eliminates the hazard at the source. Installation will be completed by the Maintenance team within 14 days, with testing and validation required before units return to service.

name: Mandatory UV Safety Training and PPE Requirement
description: Require all personnel working with UV testing equipment to complete a 1-hour training module covering UV exposure hazards, safe operating procedures, and proper use of UV-protective eyewear and arm sleeves. Distribute UV-protective personal protective equipment (PPE) including safety glasses with UV filters and long-sleeved protective garments to all QC lab technicians. Make PPE use mandatory whenever accessing UV chambers. Implement a sign-off system ensuring training completion before any employee works with these units.

name: Install Dedicated Flammable Liquid Storage Cabinet with Secondary Containment
description: Replace the existing general-purpose shelving in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop with a certified flammable liquid storage cabinet (FM-approved, 30-gallon capacity minimum) equipped with built-in secondary containment basin and absorbent pads. The cabinet will feature locking doors, proper ventilation, and grounding connections. Install the cabinet in a location away from ignition sources and with easy access for retrieval and restocking. This engineering control eliminates the spill hazard at the source by providing proper containment. Installation will be completed within 30 days.

name: Implement Flammable Liquid Container Securing Protocol
description: Require all flammable liquid containers over 5 liters to be stored in secondary containment and secured with cable restraints or snap-lock brackets to prevent toppling from vibration, movement, or accidents. Establish a monthly shelf audit procedure to verify that all containers are properly secured and that no containers are stored above shoulder height. Train all staff in the proper securing methods and conduct quarterly refresher training. Post visual reminders at storage locations showing proper securing techniques.

name: Enhanced Chemical Spill Response Training and Equipment Staging
description: Conduct mandatory spill response training for all maintenance and facilities staff covering identification of chemical types, immediate containment procedures, proper use of absorbent materials, safe disposal protocols, and environmental reporting requirements. Stage a dedicated spill response kit in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop containing absorbent pads, containment barriers, disposal containers, and PPE. Conduct tabletop exercises quarterly to maintain readiness. Update the emergency response plan to include specific procedures for flammable liquid spills and designate trained responders on each shift.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance for Robotic Arms
description: Establish a monthly calibration and pressure sensor verification program for all 32 robotic material handling arms used in injection molding lines. This will include digital sensor testing, pneumatic pressure verification, and gripper force testing. Maintenance technicians will use calibrated pressure gauges to ensure gripper sensors remain within specified parameters. Documentation will be maintained in the predictive maintenance system, and any sensor drift exceeding 5% will trigger immediate replacement. This engineering control will prevent similar malfunctions before they create hazardous situations.

name: Install Emergency Stop Buttons at All Injection Molding Stations
description: Install bright red emergency stop (E-stop) buttons within arm's reach of all injection molding operators at Lines B, C, and D. Each button will be positioned 3-4 feet from the operator's work station to ensure accessibility during equipment malfunction events. Operators will receive training on button location and proper activation. Monthly function testing will be documented. This administrative control combined with engineering improvements will give operators immediate control to halt robotic operations during malfunctions.

name: Mandatory Two-Person Lockout Verification Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory two-person verification system for all LOTO procedures on injection molding machines. Before any operator begins maintenance or material clearing work, a designated supervisor or safety monitor must independently verify that the lockout is properly engaged, the tagout cable is fully inserted into the interlock receptacle, and all energy sources are de-energized. Both individuals must sign off on a verification form. This administrative control eliminates single-point failures in lockout procedures. Training will be mandatory for all operators and supervisors, with quarterly refresher sessions.

name: Upgrade Machine Safety Interlocks with Dual-Channel Detection
description: Replace existing single-channel safety interlocks on all 32 injection molding machines with ISO 13849-1 Category 3 dual-channel detection systems. These systems require redundant confirmation of lockout engagement and cannot be bypassed by a single failed component. Installation will be completed in phases over 90 days, beginning with Lines B, C, and D. This engineering control provides fail-safe protection against unexpected machine restart during maintenance operations.

name: Eliminate Production Pressure During Maintenance Operations
description: Establish an administrative policy prohibiting time pressure or productivity incentives that might encourage operators to bypass safety procedures. Production quotas will not be adjusted for machines that require maintenance downtime. Supervisors will be trained to reinforce the principle that safety procedures must never be compromised for production targets. A formal communication will be issued to all production staff explaining this commitment. This addresses the root cause of procedural non-compliance.

name: Upgrade Local Exhaust Ventilation System in Regrind Department
description: Replace the existing capture hood above the solvent-based adhesive application station with a new high-efficiency local exhaust ventilation (LEV) system featuring: (1) dual-stage filtration with activated charcoal filters, (2) variable speed motor maintaining minimum 100 linear feet per minute capture velocity, (3) pressure sensors alerting operators when filter replacement is needed, and (4) weekly maintenance protocol with documented inspections. The new system will be designed to maintain VOC levels below 50% of the exposure limit even during extended operations. Installation will be completed within 30 days.

name: Establish Monthly Air Quality Monitoring Protocol
description: Implement a formalized monthly air quality testing program in all chemical-handling and recycling areas using calibrated VOC meters and real-time data logging. Results will be recorded in a central database, with immediate notification to the HSE committee if any measurement exceeds 70% of exposure limits. Personnel in affected areas will receive training on using personal air sampling equipment and will be informed of results quarterly. This administrative control ensures early detection of ventilation system degradation.

name: Implement Mandatory Rigging Inspection Procedure
description: Develop and enforce a pre-lift checklist requiring visual inspection of all rigging equipment, cables, and attachment points before each mold movement. All operators must document inspection results on a daily log. Monthly audits will verify compliance. This addresses the root cause of inadequate equipment verification and reduces the risk of rigging failure by establishing a formal safety protocol aligned with ANSI B30.20 standards.

name: Install Load Drop Prevention System on Overhead Crane
