description: Retrofit the overhead crane system on Line D with redundant safety brakes and load-holding devices that automatically engage if cable tension is lost. Install proximity sensors to alert operators when loads approach unsafe positions near equipment. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of catastrophic load drops and protects both equipment and personnel.

name: Provide Enhanced Rigging and Load Handling Training
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all injection molding operators and material handlers covering proper mold rigging techniques, load calculation, and emergency procedures. Training will include hands-on practice with proper cable attachment methods and weight distribution. Certification will be renewed annually. This administrative control ensures personnel understand safe practices and can identify rigging hazards.

name: Establish Hydraulic Line Routing Protection Standard
description: Install rigid conduit and cable management systems to physically separate and protect all hydraulic lines from potential damage during maintenance work. Mark protected hydraulic lines with high-visibility color coding. Provide technicians with detailed hydraulic system schematics showing all line locations and routing paths. This engineering control prevents accidental damage to critical lines and clearly communicates system layout.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Maintenance Verification Protocol
description: Require all hydraulic maintenance work to be completed in two stages with a supervisor verification checkpoint between stages. After each maintenance task, a second technician must visually inspect all work and verify that no lines have been kinked, bent, or damaged. Document all verifications on a work order sign-off sheet. This administrative control provides quality assurance and prevents undetected equipment damage.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Monitoring for CNC Equipment
description: Install vibration monitoring sensors on all CNC milling machines that connect to a predictive maintenance system. The system will automatically alert maintenance staff when bearing vibration exceeds threshold values, triggering preemptive bearing replacement before catastrophic failure. Baseline vibration profiles will be established for each machine. This engineering control transitions maintenance from reactive to predictive, preventing unplanned equipment failures and production disruptions.

name: Establish Mandatory Equipment Inspection and Maintenance Schedule
description: Create a formal preventive maintenance schedule requiring weekly inspections of spindle bearings on all CNC equipment. Inspectors will document vibration levels, temperature readings, and visual observations. Any vibration or performance anomalies must be reported immediately, and equipment must be removed from service for bearing replacement if thresholds are exceeded. Maintenance records will be reviewed monthly by the engineering team to identify patterns requiring design improvements.

name: Install Thermal Monitoring System on Injection Molding Lines
description: Install digital thermal monitoring sensors on all injection molding machines to provide real-time mold temperature readings to operators. The system will include audible and visual alerts when molds exceed safe handling temperatures (above 60°C). This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the malfunctioning temperature indicator by providing redundant temperature data. Implementation includes staff training on system operation and interpretation of alerts. Expected outcome: elimination of burn incidents related to unknown mold temperatures and improved operational awareness across all production lines.

name: Mandatory Mold Cooldown Verification Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory checklist procedure requiring operators to verify mold temperature using infrared thermometers before any cleaning or part removal activities. The checklist must be signed by the operator and witnessed by a supervisor. This administrative control enforces disciplined adherence to safe practices regardless of production schedules. All operators must complete refresher training on the procedure. Non-compliance will result in disciplinary action. Expected outcome: consistent application of safety procedures and reduction of thermal contact incidents.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Work Gloves
description: Replace standard cotton work gloves with specialized heat-resistant silicone or aramid-lined gloves rated for continuous contact up to 150°C. While PPE is a lower-tier control, this provides additional protection as a complementary measure to engineering and administrative controls. Gloves will be distributed to all operators on molding lines and proper fitting will be demonstrated during training. Cost includes initial purchase and quarterly replacement program.

name: Implement Chemical Container Labeling and Securing Protocol
description: Establish mandatory procedures for securing all chemical containers with tamper-proof lids and applying highly visible warning labels on all sides of storage pallets containing chemical materials. Labels must include pictograms, hazard statements, and first aid instructions in both French and English per WHMIS 2015 standards. Containers will be stored in designated chemical zones with secondary containment. All material handlers will receive training on proper container handling and storage. Expected outcome: prevention of chemical leaks and improved worker awareness of hazardous materials.

name: Implement Automated Ventilation System Maintenance Schedule
description: Develop and install a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) to track all ventilation system maintenance activities with automated alerts 7 days before scheduled maintenance is due. The system will generate work orders, assign technicians, and document completion with photographs and filter replacement records. This engineering control through better data management ensures no maintenance cycles are missed. All relevant staff will be trained on the system. Expected outcome: consistent ventilation system performance and elimination of respiratory hazard exposure from inadequate air filtration.

name: Establish Daily Ventilation System Visual Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory daily pre-shift visual inspection checklist for all operators in the Composite Materials area to verify ventilation grate cleanliness and system operation. Operators must document findings on a wall-mounted checklist and immediately report any blockages to supervisors. This administrative control provides real-time early warning of system degradation. Training will be provided to all operators during next safety meeting. Expected outcome: early identification of ventilation problems before respiratory exposure occurs.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a mandatory, computerized maintenance tracking system for all hydraulic equipment that automatically flags technicians 2 weeks before scheduled fluid changes and filter replacements. Require documented inspections of hydraulic fluid condition (viscosity, contamination levels, water content) on a bi-weekly basis for Lines A, B, and C. Assign Fernand Giguère as the lead technician responsible for hydraulic system audits. This engineering and administrative control addresses the root cause of deferred maintenance by creating accountability and visibility into maintenance compliance.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic Fluid Filtration System
description: Replace existing 10-micron filters with advanced 3-micron high-efficiency filters on all molding line hydraulic systems. Install automated contamination sensors that trigger alerts when particle counts exceed acceptable thresholds. This engineering control directly eliminates the root cause (contaminated hydraulic fluid) by improving filtration effectiveness and providing real-time warning of system degradation before pump failure occurs.

name: Conduct Equipment Failure Analysis Training for Operators
description: Develop a 2-hour training module for all injection molding operators on recognizing early warning signs of hydraulic system failure (unusual noises, pressure fluctuations, slow cycle times). Train François Gagnon and other Line A operators to report any anomalies immediately to maintenance rather than continuing operations. This administrative control empowers front-line workers to identify problems early, preventing equipment catastrophes through operator vigilance.

name: Eliminate Non-Certified Electrical Equipment from Chemical Storage Areas
description: Immediately remove all non-ATEX certified work lights, power tools, and electrical equipment from Chemical Storage and Mixing areas. Replace with ATEX Category 3 certified equipment rated for Zone 2 hazardous environments (presence of flammable vapors in abnormal conditions). Install permanent LED ceiling lighting with sealed, certified fixtures. This elimination and engineering control removes the primary ignition source and prevents future electrical fire initiation in chemical storage zones.

name: Redesign Chemical Storage Layout and Implement 5-Meter Buffer Zones
description: Reorganize the Chemical Storage area to create minimum 5-meter buffer zones between acetone and other flammable solvents and any potential ignition sources. Move halogen work lights, electrical outlets, and maintenance equipment outside this buffer zone. Install clear floor markings and signage defining the restricted zones. Update Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for chemical handling to include these spatial requirements. This administrative and engineering control reduces the probability of flammable vapor exposure to ignition sources.

name: Mandatory Hazardous Materials Handler Training and Certification
description: Require all material handlers (including Rashid Habib) involved in chemical storage and mixing to complete a certified 4-hour WHMIS and flammable materials handling course. Training must cover: proper ventilation requirements, safe transfer procedures, static electricity prevention, emergency response protocols, and recognition of hazardous conditions. Implement annual refresher training for all chemical handlers. This administrative control ensures personnel understand the risks and proper procedures for working with flammable materials.

name: Install Comprehensive Forklift Safety Visibility System
description: Equip all forklifts with 360-degree camera and monitoring systems (rear view, left/right side cameras with monitor displays in cab). Install backup audible alarms (noise level 88-98 dB) that activate whenever reverse gear is engaged. Apply high-visibility reflective tape to all mast and boom components. Conduct immediate inspection of all lift mirrors and replace any damaged or missing units. This engineering control directly eliminates blind spots and provides operators with full situational awareness, preventing similar collisions.

name: Mark and Remove Floor Obstructions in Warehouse
description: Conduct a comprehensive warehouse audit to identify all floor-level obstructions, electrical conduits, equipment supports, and irregularities. Mark all hazards with bright yellow and black striped tape and install warning signage. Relocate or cover protruding brackets and structural elements identified in the incident. Create a documented floor plan showing all hazard zones. Implement a monthly inspection schedule to verify markings remain visible and in good condition. This administrative and engineering control removes trip hazards and provides visual warnings to forklift operators.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring System on Heating Elements
description: Install automated temperature sensors with alarm thresholds on all heating elements in the Chemical Storage Building. Any temperature exceeding 25°C will trigger an alert to the operations team via email and SMS. The system will include manual override buttons at each station. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of heating element malfunction and will prevent future thermal ignition events. Expected outcome: 100% elimination of temperature-related fire risk in chemical storage areas.

name: Implement FIFO Chemical Inventory Rotation System
description: Establish a strict First-In-First-Out (FIFO) inventory system for all hazardous chemicals with color-coded labels showing receipt dates. Conduct quarterly inventory audits to ensure expired or aged materials are identified and properly disposed of. Train all Material Handlers on the new system through mandatory 2-hour workshops. This administrative control ensures that aged chemicals with compromised containers do not accumulate in storage areas.

name: Upgrade Fire Suppression System with Secondary Detection
description: Install additional heat and smoke detectors in all chemical storage zones, with redundant warning systems independent of the main fire alarm. Upgrade dry chemical powder to advanced Class B foam suppressant suitable for polyurethane materials. Conduct full system testing monthly. This engineering control provides multiple layers of detection and faster response capability.

name: Install Thermal Protective Shielding on Molding Machines
description: Engineer and install high-temperature insulation covers (ceramic or composite material rated to 150°C) on all accessible mold contact points on the 32 injection molding machines. Include removable but secure panels to allow for maintenance access without full removal of insulation. This eliminates the primary hazard by preventing direct contact with hot surfaces.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE Protocol for Molding Line Work
description: Issue heat-resistant Nomex sleeves, gloves rated to 260°C, and heat-reflective aprons to all operators and technicians on injection molding lines. Require 100% compliance through daily sign-out logs. Conduct monthly inspections and replace worn equipment. Supplement engineering controls with personal protective equipment as required by hierarchy of controls.

name: Establish Preventive Mold Maintenance Schedule
description: Convert reactive maintenance approach to preventive maintenance for all 32 molding machines. Schedule monthly inspections of all thermal systems, insulation integrity, and sensor functionality. Log all deficiencies in a tracking system with mandatory resolution timelines (critical issues within 24 hours). Assign Priya Sharma (EMP-00038) as maintenance coordinator. This administrative control prevents equipment defects from remaining unaddressed.

name: Install Motion-Sensor LED Lighting in Material Preparation Room
description: Replace all non-functional overhead fluorescent fixtures with high-efficiency LED fixtures (minimum 500 lux illumination level). Install motion sensors to ensure automatic activation. Add supplementary task lighting above all equipment operation zones. This engineering control eliminates the visibility hazard that was the primary contributing factor to the collision.

name: Paint High-Visibility Aisle Markings and Install Direction Signage
description: Paint bright yellow lane markings (10 cm width) on all main traffic routes in the Material Preparation Room and adjacent areas. Install directional arrows and 'ONE-WAY' signs to establish clear flow patterns. Mark blind corners with convex safety mirrors. Establish designated zones for pallet jacks and motorized carts with separate routes where feasible. This administrative and environmental control provides clear visual guidance to equipment operators.

name: Implement Equipment Operator Communication Protocol
description: Require all operators of motorized equipment to use radio communications before entering the Material Preparation Room during night shift operations. Establish a check-in system: operators must announce their location and intended route every 5 minutes. Conduct mandatory 30-minute training for all equipment operators (15 personnel). This administrative control ensures operators are aware of each other's presence and location.

name: Implement Mandatory Mold Cooling Protocol Enforcement
description: Establish a computerized interlock system on all injection molding equipment that prevents mold removal until surface temperature drops below 80°C. The system will log all bypass attempts and generate alerts to supervisors. Additionally, revise the standard operating procedure to include mandatory 15-minute minimum cooling periods with temperature verification before mold extraction. Conduct immediate supervisor training on hazard communication and production schedule management without compromising safety. Expected outcome: elimination of thermal contact injuries from hot mold handling.

name: Distribute and Enforce Heat-Resistant PPE Requirements
description: Replace all standard work gloves in production areas with certified heat-resistant silicone gloves rated for temperatures up to 250°C. Implement a mandatory glove inspection and replacement protocol every 30 days. Conduct immediate mandatory training for all production operators on proper PPE selection, donning procedures, and signs of PPE degradation. Create visual work instruction cards at each mold changeover station showing correct PPE requirements. Track PPE compliance through daily supervisor inspections with documentation.

name: Establish Production Schedule Safety Review Process
description: Create a formalized process where production schedulers (Wei Liu, EMP-00088) coordinate with HSE team before implementing aggressive production timelines. Develop guidelines that identify when schedule pressure may create safety shortcuts and establish buffer time requirements for critical safety procedures. Institute monthly safety audit meetings with operations, maintenance, and HSE to review incidents and validate that production goals do not compromise required cooling times, lockout procedures, or other critical safety steps.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule Compliance System
description: Establish a computerized maintenance tracking system (CMMS integration) that sends automatic alerts to Luc Girard (EMP-00039) and Gilles Marchand when scheduled maintenance tasks are due. Create monthly maintenance checklists specific to all hopper discharge mechanisms, with mandatory lubrication requirements documented and signed off. Conduct a comprehensive audit of all discharge valves facility-wide to identify similar stuck linkage conditions. Implement a '5-minute safety inspection' requirement at shift start for all discharge equipment where operators will verify smooth valve operation before processing begins.

name: Redesign Hopper Loading Procedure with Secondary Containment
description: Modify the regrind material transfer process to eliminate manual positioning of containers beneath discharge chutes. Install a fixed collection bin with a sealed chute connection that prevents material spillage and reduces operator exposure. Add a manual valve isolation control positioned away from the discharge area, requiring operators to actively open the valve during controlled dispensing rather than relying on automatic mechanisms. Provide secondary containment pallets beneath all hopper discharge points to capture spilled material and prevent floor contamination.

name: Establish Mandatory LOTO Verification Protocol for Night Shift Operations
description: Implement a two-person verification system for all hydraulic equipment work on night shift, where the second person (trained monitor) must independently verify all energy isolation points against the equipment energy diagram before any work begins. Require photographic documentation of each locked isolation point stored in the digital work order system. Revise the LOTO procedure for injection molding presses to mandate a pressure relief verification step: a certified technician must manually actuate pressure gauges at three defined test points to confirm zero residual pressure before hands-on work proceeds. Conduct mandatory LOTO refresher training for all machine setters and maintenance personnel within 30 days.

name: Install Hydraulic Pressure Safety Interlocks on All Injection Presses
description: Retrofit all injection molding equipment with pressure-sensitive interlock switches that prevent mold movement when any LOTO lock is not properly engaged. These interlocks will electronically verify the position of all isolation points and prevent hydraulic pressure buildup when a mold is in an open or semi-open position with workers nearby. Integrate interlock status into the equipment's computerized monitoring system with real-time alerts to operators and supervisors. This engineering control will eliminate the possibility of unexpected mold closure due to incomplete LOTO procedures.

name: Strengthen Night Shift Supervision and Safety Oversight
description: Increase HSE presence during night shift operations by scheduling monthly unannounced safety audits and implementing a dedicated on-call safety contact for night shift employees. Establish a pre-work briefing requirement where any non-routine maintenance must be reviewed with a supervisor before commencing. Create a culture of empowerment where night shift workers can halt operations without production penalty if they identify incomplete LOTO procedures. Document all near-miss events from night shift with root cause analysis and trending to identify systemic gaps in safety systems during low-staffing periods.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring and Cooling System on Injection Lines
description: Implement automatic temperature display systems on all 32 injection molding machines showing real-time barrel and mold temperatures. Install quick-cool shut-down switches that activate a cooling cycle before manual maintenance is permitted. Machines will not allow manual nozzle access unless barrel temperature drops below 150°C, verified by thermal sensors. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of contact with hot surfaces during jam clearing by making high-temperature contact physically impossible.

name: Mandate Heat-Resistant Gloves and Arm Sleeves for All Production Staff
description: Distribute specialized heat-resistant Nomex gloves rated to 350°C and forearm sleeves to all production operators working on injection molding lines. Update the PPE requirements in the employee handbook and conduct mandatory training on proper donning/doffing and care of the equipment. Enforce daily inspection of gloves for damage. This administrative and PPE control provides backup protection while engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Revise Machine Jam Clearing Procedures and Training
description: Update the Standard Operating Procedure for clearing injection line blockages to explicitly require: (1) 20-minute cool-down period minimum before manual intervention, (2) verification of cool-down using thermal imaging gun, (3) lockout/tagout of machine during any manual access, (4) two-person verification system before re-starting. Conduct refresher training for all operators within 14 days. Document training completion and maintain records. This administrative control addresses the root cause of inadequate cooling time procedures.

name: Implement Daily E-Stop Inspection and Accessibility Protocol
description: Establish a daily pre-shift checklist for all machine operators that includes visual inspection and functional testing of all emergency stop buttons. Maintenance staff will physically press each E-stop to verify function and ensure buttons return to neutral position. Any obstruction, damage, or malfunction triggers immediate machine shutdown and tagging. Create laminated checklist cards at each workstation. This administrative control ensures rapid identification of hazards before operation begins.

name: Install Protective Covers and Clear Zones Around Emergency Controls
description: Install clear plastic protective covers around all emergency stop buttons on CNC milling machines that are transparent but prevent dust accumulation and accidental obstruction by tools or materials. Create a 30-centimeter clear zone around all emergency control consoles through use of yellow floor tape and signage. Relocate any storage of maintenance supplies, tape, or materials that could obstruct access. Conduct monthly audits to maintain clear zones.

name: Install Powered Material Handling Equipment for Raw Materials Warehouse
description: Procure and install two electric drum handling trolleys with adjustable width clamps rated for 500-kg drums. These will replace manual hand truck operations for drum repositioning. Equipment will feature automatic brake engagement and ergonomic operation. Train all material handlers on proper operation, maintenance, and safety features. This engineering control eliminates the primary pinch point hazard by removing manual handling as the dominant work method.

name: Reconfigure Warehouse Shelving Layout to Create Safe Work Zones
description: Redesign the raw materials storage area to increase spacing between shelving units from current 1.2 meters to minimum 1.8 meters. Install protective guards or edge rails on shelving to prevent drum rolling or shifting. Mark all pinch points with high-visibility warning labels. Implement a maximum drum stacking height of two drums to reduce instability. This engineering control removes the physical constraint that forced fingers into pinch points.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Pinch Point Hazard Awareness Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training to all warehouse and production staff on identifying and avoiding pinch points in material handling operations. Include case studies, video demonstrations of pinch point injuries, and hands-on practice identifying hazards in the actual warehouse environment. Require annual refresher training. Document training attendance and comprehension. This administrative control ensures workers recognize and avoid pinch point exposures.

name: Install Thermal Safety Interlocks on Injection Molding Lines
description: Engineering control to prevent access to hot mold cavities before temperature drops to safe levels. Install automated mechanical interlocks on mold access doors that prevent opening until cavity temperature sensors confirm cooling to ≤60°C. System will include visual and audible alerts. This addresses the root cause by eliminating the possibility of manual override due to production pressure. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of thermal contact burns from premature mold access.

name: Mandatory Thermal Protection Gloves for All Line Operators
description: Supply all injection molding line operators with rated thermal-resistant gloves (temperature rating 200°C minimum) and mandate their use during all mold handling operations. Conduct quarterly inspections of glove condition and replace as needed. Implement daily toolbox talks emphasizing proper PPE use. While this is a lower-level control, it provides secondary protection if interlocks fail.

name: Replace All Corroded Hazardous Waste Storage Drums
description: Engineering control: conduct comprehensive inspection of all 45 hazardous waste drums stored in UNIT-011. Replace any drum showing corrosion, rust perforation, or compromised integrity with new UN-certified, double-walled stainless steel containers rated for solvent storage. Implement quarterly visual inspections using standardized checklist. Expected outcome: elimination of containment failures due to drum deterioration and prevention of similar environmental releases.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment System and Spill Response Equipment
description: Administrative and engineering control: expand secondary containment basin capacity to 150% of largest stored drum volume (minimum 82.5 liters). Install automated liquid level sensors with continuous monitoring and alarm thresholds at 50%, 75%, and 90% capacity. Position spill kits containing absorbent pads, neutralizers, and disposal bags at three accessible locations around UNIT-011. Conduct monthly spill response drills for all warehouse staff. Expected outcome: improved spill detection, faster response times, and increased containment reliability.

name: Install Pneumatic Tool Safety Guards and Workholding Improvements
description: Engineering control: retrofit all pneumatic die grinders in UNIT-015 with ISO 13857-compliant point-of-operation guards that prevent hand contact with rotating wheels and bits. Replace damaged vise jaw assemblies and install redundant work-holding clamps (minimum two per setup). Implement machine lockout provisions to prevent accidental startup during setup. Expected outcome: physical elimination of hand access to hazardous rotating elements, preventing similar laceration incidents.

name: Implement Drum Bung Cap Verification System
description: Establish a pre-transfer checklist requiring visual and tactile verification of bung cap tightness before any drum movement. All workers transporting hazardous materials must complete a brief verification procedure and initial a transport log. This addresses the root cause of inadequate bung securing. Implementation includes training all Material Handlers and creating laminated checklist cards at each staging area.

name: Upgrade to Secondary Containment Spill Trays
description: Replace open floor-level drum staging with secondary containment trays rated for full 55-gallon drum capacity (65+ gallons). Position trays at all chemical transfer points in the mixing area. This engineering control will contain future spills and prevent floor contamination. Install drain valves with lockable handles to enable controlled disposal during cleanup. Reduces environmental liability and cleanup time significantly.

name: Install Interlocked Mold Access Safety Gates
description: Engineering control: Install mechanical interlocks on all injection molding lines that prevent mold closure when access gates are open. These fail-safe interlocks will automatically disable the remote closure function when a technician opens the mold cavity door for maintenance. Physical barriers combined with electrical interlocks ensure the mold cannot close with personnel inside. This eliminates the hazard entirely at the source.

name: Implement Lockout/Tagout Procedure Enhancement
description: Develop enhanced LOTO procedures specific to mold maintenance requiring mandatory energy isolation before any manual mold access. Create a dual-operator verification system where one person applies locks while a second person confirms isolation before work begins. Monthly audits of LOTO compliance on all production lines. Mandatory retraining for all operators within 30 days. Administrative control addressing communication failures and procedure non-compliance.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Machine Guarding Audit
description: HSE team will audit all injection molding lines for compliance with machine guarding standards. Identify gaps in protective devices, emergency stops, and warning systems. Install additional warning lights and audible alarms on all lines where manual mold access is required during maintenance. Upgrade any non-compliant guarding to current CSA standards. This preventive audit-based approach reduces risk across all equipment.

name: Establish Automated Crane Inspection and Maintenance Log System
description: Implement a digital tracking system for all overhead crane inspections and maintenance activities. Set automated reminders for quarterly cable inspections, annual full equipment certifications, and maintenance intervals. Replace worn cables immediately upon detection. Assign Daniel Kim (Electrical Maintenance) to oversee the compliance system with accountability metrics reported to HSE monthly. This administrative control ensures preventive maintenance reduces equipment failure risk.

name: Upgrade Overhead Crane with Load Limiting and Monitoring
description: Engineering control: Install modern load cells and automatic load-limiting devices on the overhead crane to prevent operation above safe capacity and to alert operators to cable stress conditions. Add real-time monitoring sensors that display cable tension and alert maintenance when cables show degradation patterns. Consider replacing the cable system with higher-quality aircraft-grade cable rated for 5x safety margin. This eliminates cable failure as a failure mode.

name: Implement Area Exclusion During Overhead Lifts
description: Administrative control: Establish a no-personnel-below-loads policy with physical barriers (warning tape, signage, temporary fencing) that prohibits workers from standing directly under any suspended load operations. Require operators to announce lifts via radio and obtain clear zone confirmation before commencing. Conduct quarterly safety drills with all shop personnel. This reduces injury severity even if load drop events occur.

name: Upgrade Cut-Resistant Gloves for Part Removal
description: Implement Level 4 cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rated) for all machine operators performing part removal tasks on Injection Molding Lines C and D. Current standard gloves provide insufficient protection against sharp plastic edges. New gloves will be distributed to all relevant personnel and integrated into daily PPE requirements. Supplier evaluation will ensure gloves maintain dexterity while providing adequate protection. Training will emphasize proper glove usage and inspection for wear.

name: Add Edge Deburring Step to Part Finishing Process
description: Implement automatic edge deburring for all finished parts before they reach the manual removal stage. This engineering control will eliminate the sharp edges at the source rather than relying on PPE. Evaluate and install deburring equipment compatible with existing production lines. This approach follows the hierarchy of controls by eliminating the hazard rather than protecting against it. Projected reduction in hand injuries by 80% based on industry data.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Verification System
description: Implement a dual-verification LOTO procedure requiring two independent personnel sign-offs before any maintenance or cleaning work commences. Install physical lockout stations at each injection molding line with tamper-evident devices. Require photographic documentation of locked-out equipment via mobile app before work begins. Conduct monthly unannounced LOTO audits with corrective training for any lapses. This administrative control ensures consistent application of lockout/tagout procedures and creates accountability.

name: Install Automated Machine Interlock Safety System
description: Engineer and install automated interlock switches that prevent mold closing whenever the machine guard door is open. This engineering control physically prevents sudden machine startup during cleaning operations, eliminating the hazard at its source. System will integrate with existing PLC controls and include redundant safety circuits meeting ISO 13849-1 Category 3 standards. Installation across all injection molding lines will provide comprehensive protection.

name: Comprehensive LOTO Retraining for All Production Staff
description: Conduct mandatory 4-hour LOTO refresher training for all 120 day shift and 60 evening shift production workers. Training will include incident case study, hands-on lockout device practice, recognition of failure modes, and consequences of non-compliance. Assessment and certification required for continued operation of molding equipment. Scheduling will minimize production impact with rotating cohorts.

name: Replace and Upgrade Storage Rack Securing Hardware
description: Conduct complete inspection and replacement of all securing straps, bolts, and fasteners on mezzanine storage racks throughout the facility. Replace corroded carbon steel hardware with stainless steel or zinc-plated alternatives rated for higher tensile strength and corrosion resistance. This engineering control eliminates the root cause (metal fatigue) by using superior materials. Implement quarterly inspections with maintenance documentation. Target completion within 21 days across all storage areas.

name: Install Safety Barriers and Warning Systems on Mezzanine Level
description: Engineer and install physical safety barriers (chain or metal mesh guards) around the perimeter of the storage mezzanine to prevent falling objects from dropping to lower work areas. Add motion-sensor lighting and audible warning systems when material movement occurs near mezzanine edges. Post clear warning signs indicating falling object hazard zone below. This layered approach provides both primary (barriers) and secondary (warnings) protection.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Establish a comprehensive quarterly inspection schedule for all hydraulic lines, couplings, and pressure seals on injection molding equipment. Technicians will perform thermographic imaging to detect stress points, pressure cycling tests, and visual inspections for corrosion or wear. Worn components will be replaced proactively before failure occurs. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of thermal-induced hydraulic failures and extends equipment lifecycle. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in catastrophic hydraulic failures within 12 months.

name: Install Redundant Pressure Relief Valves
description: Upgrade Line D with dual independent pressure relief valves set at 2,400 PSI to provide secondary protection against pressure spikes. This engineering control prevents catastrophic pressure buildup by creating a fail-safe mechanism. Install pressure monitoring sensors that trigger automatic shutdown if pressure exceeds safe thresholds. Additionally, install secondary containment trays beneath all hydraulic connection points to contain spillage during future incidents.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Warehouse Safety Audit and Rack Inspection
description: Immediately conduct Level 2 professional structural inspection of all 34 storage racks in the finished goods warehouse and satellite storage areas. Perform load-bearing calculations, alignment checks, and bolt torque verification. Replace or reinforce any racks showing stress indicators. Implement a monthly visual inspection checklist and quarterly professional certification program. This administrative and engineering control eliminates unstable infrastructure hazards.

name: Implement Post-Collision Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Establish mandatory inspection procedures requiring that any storage rack, forklift, or material handling equipment involved in a collision event must be inspected within 2 hours by a qualified technician before returning to service. Create a 'Collision Incident Report Form' that documents the impact, provides photographic evidence, and certifies structural integrity. Train all warehouse and forklift operators on this procedure. Administrative control ensures no damaged equipment returns to service without verification.

name: Retraining Program on Warehouse Weight Distribution and Load Limits
description: Conduct mandatory retraining for all material handlers and warehouse personnel on proper load distribution principles, weight limit calculations per rack tier, and visual load verification techniques. Provide laminated reference cards for each rack indicating maximum weight per tier and proper distribution patterns. Include monthly toolbox talks during shift briefings. Implement a competency assessment with practical demonstrations. This administrative control ensures proper handling procedures prevent future collapses.

name: Install Heated Component Handling Equipment with Safety Guards
description: Replace open-air heated adhesive trays with enclosed heating chambers equipped with mechanical component extraction mechanisms, thermal shields, and automated cooling staging areas. Install infrared temperature displays so operators can verify component temperature before handling. This engineering control eliminates direct contact with hot materials by removing manual extraction from heated surfaces. Expected outcome: elimination of thermal burn hazards in the adhesive assembly process.

name: Upgrade to High-Temperature Protective Equipment Standards
description: Issue all assembly operators working with heated materials with specialized heat-resistant gloves rated to 250°C (Kevlar-lined, silicone-coated), long-sleeved fire-resistant work shirts (NOMEX or equivalent), and arm guards extending to the elbow. These must pass NFPA 1971 thermal protective performance testing. Establish a PPE replacement schedule every 12 months or upon visible degradation. Conduct fitting and training on proper application and removal techniques. This PPE control provides secondary thermal protection during the interim period before engineering controls are installed.

name: Ergonomic Workstation Redesign for Hot Material Assembly
description: Conduct ergonomic assessment of all assembly stations handling heated materials. Adjust work surface heights, implement angled component trays to reduce reach distance, install automatic cooling fans in work areas, and provide anti-fatigue mats to reduce prolonged standing strain. Install side barriers to prevent accidental contact with heated trays. Redesign tray positioning so operators never reach directly over or across hot surfaces. This engineering control addresses both burn hazard prevention and ergonomic stress reduction.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring System on All Injection Presses
description: Replace mechanical mold temperature indicators with digital temperature monitoring systems equipped with audible alarms. Install redundant sensors on all 12 hydraulic presses in UNIT-015 to ensure operators are continuously aware of mold temperatures. The new system will trigger an alert when mold surfaces exceed 160°C, providing visual and audible warnings. This engineering control eliminates reliance on burnout-prone indicator lights and provides real-time data logging for quality assurance.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Protocol for Mold Operations
description: Issue high-temperature aramid fiber gloves (rated to 250°C) to all operators working with injection presses. Establish a mandatory PPE requirement that gloves must be worn during all mold contact operations. Conduct toolbox talks on proper glove usage and heat protection. Replace worn gloves quarterly. While PPE is a lower-level control, this provides immediate protection while the temperature monitoring system is being installed.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for All Chemical Storage
description: Purchase and install engineered secondary containment trays beneath all flammable liquid storage in UNIT-010. Containment capacity must be minimum 110% of the largest container volume. The containment system will be non-porous, corrosion-resistant polypropylene with drain plugs for cleaning. This engineering control eliminates spill hazards and prevents vapors from reaching ignition sources. Train all personnel on containment use and inspection protocols.

name: Establish Minimum Separation Distances and Fire Safety Zones
description: Create and post facility-wide administrative procedures establishing minimum 3-meter separation between flammable liquid storage and any heat sources or ignition sources. Mark fire safety zones with floor tape and signage. Implement quarterly audits to verify compliance. This administrative control works in conjunction with the secondary containment system to create layered protection against fire hazards.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Propane Heating Equipment
description: Establish a documented maintenance schedule for all propane heaters, requiring professional inspection and servicing every 30 days during winter operation. Include safety valve testing, combustion efficiency checks, and gas leak detection. Maintain records of all maintenance activities. This administrative control reduces the probability of heater malfunction that could create ignition sources near flammable materials.

name: Implement Wet Floor Signage and Communication Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory procedure requiring maintenance staff to place highly visible wet floor warning signs immediately when mopping any facility area. Create a communication log where maintenance staff notify shift supervisors of cleaned areas. Install a whiteboard system in each department listing areas currently being cleaned. Provide training to all maintenance and operations personnel on the protocol. This administrative control ensures workers are aware of temporary hazards.

name: Install Anti-Slip Floor Coating in Break Room
description: Apply high-traction anti-slip coating to the cafeteria and break room floors, particularly in high-traffic areas near beverage stations and exits. The coating will improve grip even when wet. This engineering control reduces the probability of slips regardless of temporary wet conditions. Establish a maintenance schedule to inspect the coating quarterly and reapply as needed.

name: Implement Container Integrity Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a daily pre-shift inspection procedure for all chemical containers entering the mixing room. Operators must visually verify container seals, handles, and integrity before use. Any damaged containers must be immediately removed from service and reported. This administrative control addresses the root cause of the failure (damaged grip handle) by catching defects before they become incidents. All operators will receive updated training on this inspection protocol within 5 days.

name: Install Enhanced Secondary Containment System
description: Upgrade the chemical transfer area with dedicated secondary containment trays designed to capture 150% of the largest container volume (30-liter capacity). These engineered containment systems will be positioned under all chemical transfer stations. Trays will feature sloped floors directing spills to a collection sump with absorbent pads and drain control. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of uncontrolled pool formation on the production floor, directly preventing the 2024 incident scenario from recurring.

name: Update Chemical Supplier Standardization Requirements
description: Work with purchasing to standardize container designs across all chemical suppliers, requiring containers with reinforced ergonomic handles and tamper-evident seals. Current supplier must be evaluated for compliance, or alternate suppliers must be identified. This substitution control ensures all future containers meet TechnoPlast's safety standards, eliminating design-related failures from the supplier base.

name: Retrofit Mold Heating Blocks with Thermal Shielding Guards
description: Engineer and install protective thermal barrier guards around all injection molding heating elements operating above 150°C. Guards will be made from insulating composite material with minimum 50mm spacing from the heat source, reducing surface contact temperature to below 60°C. Installation will be completed on all 12 production lines within 30 days. This engineering control directly eliminates the burn hazard by preventing direct contact with hot surfaces, addressing the primary root cause of the incident.

name: Strengthen Lockout/Tagout Procedures for Maintenance Operations
description: Revise and enforce mandatory LOTO procedures requiring all heating elements to be de-energized and equipment to reach safe temperatures (below 40°C) before any maintenance cleaning is performed. Implement a color-coded tag system and digital lock registry. All operators and maintenance staff must complete refresher LOTO training within 10 days, with competency verification via practical demonstration. This administrative control eliminates the hazard of unexpected equipment activation during maintenance by establishing clear work procedures.

name: Install Heavy-Duty Mezzanine Edge Safety Railing and Nets
description: Engineer and install a reinforced safety railing system along the full perimeter of the mezzanine platform, with secondary safety netting installed beneath to catch any objects that might be inadvertently dislodged. The railing will extend to 1.2 meters height with horizontal cable or mesh infill to prevent items from falling through gaps. Installation will occur within 10 days. This engineering control eliminates the falling object hazard by containing items within the storage platform boundary and providing redundant protection for workers below.

name: Implement Secured Storage Standards and Organizational Protocol
description: Establish mandatory storage standards requiring all items on elevated mezzanines to be secured using industrial-grade strapping systems, securing bags, or lockable storage cages. Weight distribution limits will be clearly marked. All stored items must be positioned minimum 1 meter from platform edges. Weekly inspections will be conducted with documented sign-offs. Staff will receive training on proper securing techniques. This administrative control addresses unsafe stacking practices through clear procedures and accountability.

name: Install Warning Signs and High-Visibility Zone Markings
description: Post large warning signs reading 'Falling Object Hazard - Hard Hat Required Below' at all mezzanine locations. Paint yellow and black hazard stripes on the floor directly below all elevated storage areas. Install reflective floor tape to delineate the restricted zone where items could fall. Ensure emergency exit pathways remain completely clear of all obstructions. This administrative control increases worker awareness and ensures emergency evacuation routes are maintained.

name: Implement Monthly Hopper Sensor Calibration Protocol
description: Establish and document a mandatory monthly calibration and verification schedule for all injection molding machine hopper level sensors. Create a checklist system with digital tracking to ensure technicians verify sensor accuracy, drift, and electrical connections. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance and Engineering department. Include pre-calibration and post-calibration readings in the preventive maintenance log. Non-compliance will be reviewed in monthly JHSC meetings. This engineering/administrative control prevents overflow events caused by sensor drift.

name: Install Secondary Overflow Containment System
description: Design and install a stainless steel collection tray with 100-liter capacity beneath hopper discharge points of all 32 injection molding machines. Tray will channel overflow material into a controlled drain leading to a waste collection bin rather than onto production floor or inventory. Include drainage valve with manual shutoff for safe disposal of hot material. This engineering control provides redundant protection against material spillage and inventory damage.

name: Enhanced Training on Hopper Troubleshooting Procedures
description: Conduct mandatory retraining for all 48 production operators on proper hopper jam clearance procedures, emphasizing never reaching directly into hoppers. Training will include use of pneumatic vibrators, mechanical augers, and extending rods designed for safe material dislodging without hand contact. Operators will be certified annually. This administrative control eliminates unsafe manual intervention and reduces overflow risks during maintenance.

name: Implement Edge Radiusing Standard for Automotive Components
description: Revise injection molding specifications for all automotive trim parts to require minimum 0.5mm edge radius on all exposed edges and handling surfaces. Update CAD design standards and mold manufacturing procedures. Quality control inspection will verify edge radiusing on 100% of parts during post-molding inspection. This engineering control at the source eliminates the sharp edge hazard before parts reach assembly operations, preventing hand injuries.

name: Assembly Operator Hand Protection and Technique Training
description: Conduct hands-on training for all 36 assembly operators on proper gripping techniques for handling parts with potential sharp edges. Distribute upgraded cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 rating) and demonstrate correct personal protective equipment donning/doffing procedures. Include video demonstration of incident scenarios and safe practices. Training to be repeated quarterly during toolbox talks. This administrative and PPE control reduces hand injury risk during assembly operations.

name: Install Automatic Dust Collection System Upgrade
description: Replace existing dust extraction system on the industrial grinding mill with a high-efficiency HEPA-filtered cartridge collector system (ISO Class 8) rated for continuous operation with automatic pulse-jet cleaning cycles. System will include real-time clogging indicator and emergency shutoff valve. Include annual certification and quarterly filter replacement schedule. This engineering control directly addresses dust accumulation by continuously removing fine particles before they accumulate to hazardous levels.

name: Establish Grinding Mill Operating Protocol with Mandatory Rest Cycles
description: Implement administrative control requiring all regrind mills to operate maximum 8 continuous hours followed by mandatory 30-minute cooling and inspection intervals. Operators will conduct visual dust accumulation checks, verify dust collector filter pressure readings, and clean internal housing as needed. This procedure will be documented on daily log sheets and reviewed weekly by the HSE coordinator. Maximum daily operating time limited to 16 hours. This prevents thermal buildup and allows dust extraction system to clear accumulated particles.

name: Combustible Dust Hazard Awareness and Emergency Response Training
description: Conduct facility-wide training on combustible dust hazards including ignition sources, accumulation patterns, and explosion potential in plastic recycling operations. All 200 employees will receive 90-minute classroom instruction covering dust classification, static electricity hazards, and emergency response procedures. Materials warehouse and production personnel will receive advanced 4-hour hands-on training on dust suppression techniques and equipment shutdown procedures. Training to be repeated annually with new hire orientation. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand the fire hazard and appropriate responses.

name: Implement Mandatory Lockout/Tagout Protocol for All Mold Machines
description: Establish a comprehensive lockout/tagout procedure requiring all operators to engage LOTO devices before any manual intervention on injection molding equipment. Install standardized lockout stations at each machine with energy isolation points clearly marked. Conduct mandatory retraining for all production staff within 5 days, with monthly audits of LOTO compliance. Implement a digital checklist system at each machine requiring operator sign-off before manual mold access. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate machine isolation procedures.

name: Install Mold Safety Interlock Guards on All Injection Molding Machines
description: Design and install mechanical interlock safety guards that prevent mold closure when access gates are open. These guards will physically prevent the mold from cycling unless all access points are secured. Work with equipment manufacturer to retrofit existing machines with proximity sensors that halt machine operation if manual access is attempted during active cycles. Expected outcome is complete elimination of crush hazard during routine mold inspection activities.

name: Enhanced Machine Safety Training and Certification Program
description: Develop comprehensive machine safety certification program requiring all production operators to complete hands-on training on emergency stops, energy isolation, and hazard recognition. Create competency assessments with written and practical components. Require annual recertification for all operators. Integrate near-miss reporting into training curriculum so operators understand consequences of unsafe practices. This administrative control ensures all staff understand proper safe procedures.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Chemical Transfer Operations
description: Install engineered secondary containment trays beneath all chemical transfer workstations with capacity to hold 110% of the largest container being transferred. Containment trays will have integrated drain valves that allow controlled recovery of spilled materials into designated recycling containers. This engineering control eliminates environmental discharge to municipal systems by capturing spills at the source. Expected outcome is 100% containment of future transfer incidents.

name: Upgrade Chemical Transfer Equipment and Maintenance Protocol
description: Replace existing manual transfer pump with a certified metering pump equipped with pressure relief valves and automated shutoff mechanisms. Implement preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly inspection and testing of all transfer equipment. Maintain spare pumps on-site to minimize use of faulty equipment. Technician certification required for all transfer equipment operation. This substitution control replaces unreliable equipment with engineered safety features.

name: Enhanced Environmental Spill Response and Reporting Procedures
description: Develop comprehensive spill response protocol including immediate notification procedures, spill containment kits placement, and documentation requirements. Provide spill response training to all chemical handling staff. Install absorbent material dispensers at strategic locations. Create a chemical inventory tracking system to document all transfers and enable rapid response verification. Implement monthly drills to ensure staff competency in spill containment procedures.

name: Replace and Upgrade UV Chamber Interlock Safety Systems
description: Install redundant safety interlock switches on all UV exposure equipment with independent fail-safe mechanisms. Upgrade to electronic interlocks with status indicator lights and audible alarms. Implement automated shutdown sequence that de-energizes UV lamp when door interlock is triggered. This engineering control eliminates the hazard by making it physically impossible to access active UV sources. Equipment will be certified by manufacturer post-installation.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Laboratory Safety Equipment
description: Create monthly inspection protocol for all interlock switches and safety-critical equipment components. Technicians will test interlock functionality, verify electrical connections, and document results. Any failures trigger immediate equipment shutdown until repair is completed. Maintain spare parts inventory for critical interlock components to enable rapid replacement. This administrative control ensures early detection of failures before they create exposure events.

name: Implement Drum Inspection and Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-transport inspection checklist for all chemical drums that includes verification of bung plug tightness, visual inspection for cracks or damage, and confirmation of proper labeling. All Material Handlers will receive training on this protocol, and supervisors will conduct random audits weekly. A laminated checklist will be posted at the storage and loading areas. This eliminates the root cause of improper bung installation and ensures consistent handling practices across all shifts.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System at Loading Dock
description: Install additional exhaust fans and ductwork at the Shipping and Receiving Dock to improve air circulation and reduce chemical fume accumulation during material transfers. The engineering evaluation will determine optimal fan placement to capture vapors at source. System will include emergency shut-off controls and will be integrated with the facility's air quality monitoring system. This engineering control directly addresses inadequate ventilation exposure risk.

name: Provide Enhanced Chemical Handling PPE
description: Issue chemical-resistant gloves, aprons, and face shields to all Material Handlers working with drums of liquid resins or solvents. Conduct mandatory training on proper donning and doffing procedures. Stock additional PPE at the loading dock and establish a replacement schedule. While PPE is a secondary control, it provides immediate protection until engineering and administrative controls are fully implemented.

name: Reinstall and Lock Assembly Jig Guards
description: Immediately reinstall the protective guards on all assembly jigs in the Packaging and Labeling Station. Modify the guard mounting system to use security fasteners that require tools to remove, creating a barrier to accidental or temporary removal. Perform daily visual inspections to ensure guards remain in place. Establish a maintenance tag system that requires supervisor sign-off before any guard removal and mandatory reinstallation documentation. This is an engineering control that directly eliminates the pinch point hazard.

name: Establish Work Order Tracking for Equipment Guard Maintenance
description: Implement a formal work order system in the CMMS (Computerized Maintenance Management System) that tracks all equipment guard removals and creates mandatory alerts for reinstallation. Supervisors must verify and document guard reinstallation before equipment returns to production. Monthly audits will verify compliance. This administrative control ensures accountability and prevents recurrence of untracked maintenance that leaves hazards exposed.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Cooling Systems
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all cooling system components, including quarterly inspection of pump connections, fittings, and seals. Create maintenance cards for each cooling system specifying replacement intervals for hoses and fittings based on manufacturer recommendations. All maintenance will be tracked in the CMMS system with supervisor approval required before equipment returns to service. This eliminates the root cause of corroded fittings by addressing equipment deterioration before failure occurs.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Main Pump
description: Install a secondary containment basin beneath the main recirculation pump with capacity to hold 150% of the system fluid volume. The containment will include a drain valve for controlled disposal and will be integrated with the facility's environmental monitoring system. Signage will clearly identify the containment area. This engineering control prevents environmental contamination and contains future leaks before they reach floor drains or the external environment.

name: Implement Daily Mold Release Agent System Inspection
description: Establish a formal daily inspection protocol for all mold release agent applicator nozzles at the start of each shift. Maintenance technicians will clean nozzles, verify spray patterns, and document findings in the equipment log. This addresses the root cause of poor heat dissipation by ensuring consistent, even application of release agent. Expected outcome: elimination of buildup that causes thermal insulation and reduces burn incidents by 40%.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring Alarms
description: Retrofit Injection Molding Line A with automated temperature monitoring sensors that trigger audible and visual alarms when mold surface temperatures exceed 65°C. Sensors will be calibrated monthly. This engineering control provides early warning of thermal hazards before they become dangerous. Staff will receive training on alarm response procedures.

name: Deburr and Edge-Guard All Sharp Shelf Brackets
description: Inspect all warehouse shelving units and equipment for sharp edges and burrs. All identified hazardous edges will be smoothed with grinding tools and finished with safety edge guards or protective padding. This eliminates the sharp bracket hazard that caused the laceration. Work will be completed in phases across all warehouse areas over 10 days.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Cooling Pumps
description: Install vibration and temperature sensors on all cooling system pumps to monitor bearing health in real-time. Data will be analyzed monthly to identify early signs of bearing degradation before catastrophic failure occurs. This engineering control shifts from reactive repair to preventive maintenance, extending equipment life by 50% and reducing unexpected downtime.

name: Establish Backup Cooling Pump Unit in Inventory
description: Purchase and maintain a fully assembled replacement centrifugal pump identical to the production units. This backup will be stored in the maintenance workshop with quick-connect fittings pre-installed. In the event of future pump failure, replacement time will be reduced from 4.5 hours to 45 minutes, minimizing production loss and reducing pressure on maintenance staff to work hastily.

name: Quarterly Bearing Inspection Schedule
description: Schedule comprehensive bearing inspection and lubrication for all cooling system pumps every 90 days. Maintenance Technicians will document bearing condition, lubrication levels, and any unusual noise or vibration patterns. This administrative control combined with preventive maintenance ensures early detection of wear and maintains optimal pump performance.

name: Implement Ergonomic Workstation Redesign on Line C
description: Complete redesign of injection molding stations to include adjustable height work surfaces, anti-fatigue matting, and mechanical part removal assist devices. Install articulated robotic arms for repetitive extraction tasks to reduce manual handling by 60%. Integrate ergonomic assessment tools into the workstation setup. This addresses the root cause of sustained repetitive motion by eliminating or significantly reducing manual extraction requirements and providing proper postural support.

name: Establish Job Rotation and Mandatory Rest Protocols
description: Implement mandatory 20-minute rest breaks every 2 hours for all production operators, including rotation to different tasks to prevent repetitive strain. Create a job rotation schedule that limits any single operator to no more than 4 hours consecutive work on repetitive extraction tasks. Provide stretching and mobility exercises during break periods. Train supervisors on early warning signs of repetitive strain injuries. This administrative control ensures adequate recovery time and variety in tasks.

name: Conduct Ergonomic Training and Baseline Assessment
description: Hire external ergonomics consultant to conduct baseline assessment of all production operators and workstations. Deliver comprehensive training on proper body mechanics, stretching, and early injury recognition to all Line C personnel. Establish baseline strength and mobility measurements for each operator. Implement quarterly reassessments and follow-up training. This establishes knowledge foundation and tracks worker capability over time to prevent future incidents.

name: Install Redundant Temperature Monitoring and Automatic Shutoff System
description: Replace manual thermostat with redundant digital temperature monitoring system featuring dual independent sensors and automated emergency shutoff at 150°C. Install continuous real-time monitoring display with alarm alerts at 125°C and 135°C to provide early warning. Implement proportional valve system to prevent uncontrolled temperature rise. Annual calibration and testing of all sensors required. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of uncontrolled heating through redundancy and automatic safety intervention.

name: Establish Equipment Preventive Maintenance Program for Dryer Systems
description: Implement quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all resin drying equipment including thermostat inspection, heating element testing, pressure relief valve verification, and thermal imaging analysis. Create maintenance log with documented results. Train maintenance team on early warning signs of sensor failure. Establish critical replacement parts inventory. This administrative/maintenance control prevents equipment degradation that leads to failures.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment and Spill Response Infrastructure
description: Install secondary containment basin beneath all resin storage tanks with capacity equal to 110% of tank volume to contain spills. Install absorbent material station with specialized resin-absorbent materials rated for epoxy compounds. Add emergency eyewash and shower stations. Train all composite operators on spill response procedures and hazmat cleanup protocols. Store spill kit in accessible location with clear labeling. This engineering control limits environmental contamination and enables faster response.

name: Implement Enhanced Personal Protective Equipment Protocol for Cleaning Operations
description: Require all machine operators performing equipment cleaning to wear nitrile gloves rated for quaternary ammonium compounds and cut-resistant finger guards during mold cavity cleaning. Supply hypoallergenic glove option for employees with known contact sensitivities. Store gloves at each cleaning station with clear signage indicating mandatory use. Include glove selection training in equipment cleaning procedures. This PPE control provides immediate protection against both chemical irritation and sharp-edge injuries during routine cleaning.

name: Install Pressure Regulators on All Compressed Air Lines
description: Engineering control to limit compressed air pressure to maximum 30 psi at all workstations where employees use compressed air for cleaning or maintenance. Install pressure gauges and regulator valves on Lines A through D in the Production Operations area. This will significantly reduce the velocity of compressed air discharge, minimizing the kinetic energy of any potential projectiles. The measure addresses the root cause by ensuring all compressed air tools operate within safe parameters per OSHA guidelines (ANSI B15.1). Expected outcome: eliminate risk of high-velocity projectile injuries from compressed air.

name: Compressed Air Safety Refresher Training Program
description: Administrative control requiring all production operators to complete a mandatory 90-minute compressed air safety workshop covering proper pressure settings, nozzle design requirements, PPE requirements, and incident scenarios. Training will emphasize that compressed air should never be used on skin or directed at face level. Sessions will be delivered monthly with attendance tracked. Material will include real incident case studies and demonstrations of compressed air effects at different pressures. Expected outcome: increase operator awareness and compliance with compressed air safety protocols across all shifts.

name: Install Fall Protection Netting and Edge Guards on Mezzanine
description: Engineering control to prevent objects from falling from the Equipment Storage mezzanine (UNIT-025). Install heavy-duty netting with 1-inch mesh aperture along all perimeter edges where materials are stored. Install steel edge protection bumpers and lip guards on all shelf edges to prevent items from sliding off. Add secondary containment trays on shelves holding small components. This directly eliminates the hazard of falling objects from height. Expected outcome: prevent all falling object incidents from mezzanine storage area and protect employees working below.

name: Implement Mezzanine Storage Organization and Inspection Protocol
description: Administrative control establishing a standardized storage system for the Equipment Storage mezzanine. Maximum stack height limits will be set at 5 feet from the shelf surface. All items must be secured with restraint straps or stored in contained bins. A weekly inspection checklist will be completed by warehouse personnel, documenting compliance. Any violations must be corrected within 24 hours. Maintenance Supervisor Mailhot will conduct monthly compliance audits. This addresses the root cause of poor storage practices and creates accountability. Expected outcome: maintain organized, safe storage with no unsecured or unstable stacking.

name: Mandatory Pre-Shift PPE Inspection Protocol
description: Administrative control requiring all employees in the Composite Materials Processing Area to perform and document a visual inspection of their PPE (gloves, arm guards, face protection) before each work shift. Inspection checklist will include checking for tears, punctures, deterioration, and proper fit. Any damaged PPE must be immediately replaced before work begins. Supervisory staff will conduct random spot-checks to ensure compliance. Training Coordinator Roy will deliver 30-minute training sessions to all composite materials handlers on proper PPE inspection techniques. Expected outcome: prevent use of damaged PPE and eliminate skin contact with irritant materials through proper protective equipment.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish quarterly hydraulic system inspections using ultrasonic analysis and thermal imaging to detect seal degradation before failure. Create dedicated inventory of critical hydraulic seals and pumps to eliminate parts availability delays. All maintenance technicians will receive ISO 11159 hydraulic safety certification. Machine HM-847 will be retrofitted with redundant pressure relief valves and automatic shutoff systems. Expected outcome: eliminate hydraulic failures and reduce unplanned downtime by 85%.

name: Install Secondary Containment Under All Hydraulic Equipment
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with hydraulic fluid collection trays sized to capture 120% of system fluid volume. Install absorbent floor mats rated for industrial hydraulic fluids in all production areas. Train all operators on spill response procedures and establish monthly containment system inspections. This engineering control will prevent environmental contamination and eliminate slip hazards from hydraulic leaks.

name: Redesign Conveyor Guard System with Interlock Safety
description: Engineer and install permanent heat-shielding guards around all cooling conveyor discharge points with enclosed packing stations. Integrate interlock switches that automatically stop conveyor movement if guards are removed or opened during operation. Guards will feature quick-disconnect mechanisms for maintenance access while requiring supervisor sign-off before removal. All guards will be color-coded and labeled with thermal hazard warnings. This eliminates direct contact with hot surfaces and prevents recurrence.

name: Mandatory Maintenance Equipment Lockout and Verification Protocol
description: Implement formal LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure requiring documented sign-off when equipment guards or safety devices are removed. Create equipment history log for all machines tracking maintenance activities. Establish supervisor-led daily safety walk-throughs to verify all guards are properly installed before shift starts. All production staff will receive refresher training on this procedure within two weeks. This administrative control ensures safety devices are reinstalled and prevents bypassing of critical safeguards.

name: Install Hand Hygiene Stations at Material Transition Points
description: Install three additional handwashing stations between the Composite Materials Processing Area and Assembly Workstations with antimicrobial soap, paper towels, and posted signage requiring hand washing before assembly work. Install eyewash stations within 10 seconds of all chemical handling areas per ANSI Z358.1 standards. Provide nitrile glove dispensers at each transition point. Training will emphasize that assembly operators must change gloves and wash hands when transitioning from resin handling tasks. This engineering and administrative control eliminates cross-contamination pathways.

name: Ergonomic Assessment of Assembly Workstations
description: Conduct a detailed ergonomic evaluation of all manual assembly stations in the Assembly and Finishing Department, with focus on pinch point hazards at component insertion areas. Install adjustable work height tables to reduce awkward hand positioning. Implement protective barriers or shields at high-risk pinch points where feasible. Provide assembly operators with specialized pinch-resistant gloves designed for precision work. Establish a monthly workstation checklist to identify emerging ergonomic issues before they result in injuries.

name: Mandatory LOTO Retraining and Competency Assessment
description: Implement mandatory LOTO retraining for all production operators and maintenance technicians within 10 days of the incident. Require completion of competency assessment with 100% pass rate before returning to maintenance duties. Training must include real scenario practice on inactive equipment, proper application of lockout devices, and verification procedures. Establish quarterly LOTO refresher training for all personnel. Create a LOTO certification database to track training expiration dates and automatically flag personnel requiring recertification.

name: Pressure Relief Valve Replacement and Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Replace the faulty pressure relief valve on Line D and all identical valves on Lines A, B, and C within 7 days. Implement a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all pressure relief valves, with documented testing and calibration. Assign Marco Rossi (Mechanical Maintenance Technician) as the primary responsible party for this program. Create visual maintenance logs posted on each machine to track completion. Implement a computerized maintenance tracking system that generates automatic work orders based on equipment schedules. Partner with the equipment manufacturer to obtain updated valve specifications and maintenance protocols.

name: Revision of Maintenance Authorization and Supervision Procedures
description: Update the maintenance authorization policy to require written approval and physical LOTO application verification before any maintenance work commences. Establish a rule that production supervisors cannot verbally authorize maintenance—all requests must be documented in the work order system. Implement a buddy system requiring that at least one supervisor be physically present during all mold-related maintenance on injection molding lines. Install visual signage at each production line clearly stating LOTO requirements and supervisor presence rules. Create a maintenance work permit system that must be completed and signed by both the operator and supervisor before proceeding.

name: Installation of Load Capacity Signage and Racking System Inspection
description: Install clearly visible load capacity signage on all storage racks in the Raw Materials Warehouse within 5 days, including maximum weight limits per shelf level and required spacing between pallets. Commission a professional racking inspection to assess structural integrity and identify any damaged uprights or cross-beams.
