Implement a monthly visual inspection checklist for all storage racks to be completed by maintenance staff. Install protective edge rails and anti-slip mats on all shelves to prevent pallet migration. Establish a maximum stacking height limit based on load weight and ensure all personnel are trained on these limits.

name: Load Stability Training and Pre-Lift Verification Procedure
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training to all material handlers on load stability assessment, including how to identify properly wrapped and distributed pallets versus unstable loads. Create a pre-lift verification checklist that operators must complete before lifting any pallet, including visual inspection for cracks in wrapping, uneven weight distribution, and proper corner protection. Implement a policy requiring forklift operators to communicate loading status via radio before each lift. Establish a "pause for safety" protocol where operators must visually confirm load stability for 5 seconds before fully raising the load. Post large visual guides at all forklift operating stations showing examples of stable versus unstable pallet configurations.

name: Install High-Temperature Insulation Guards on All Molding Machines
description: Engineering control to eliminate direct contact with hot mold surfaces. All 32 injection molding machines will be retrofitted with ceramic composite insulation covers that reduce external surface temperatures to below 60°C while maintaining production efficiency. Installation will include quick-release mechanisms for mold access. Covers will be inspected monthly and replaced annually. Expected outcome: elimination of thermal burn hazard from mold contact across all production lines.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Protective Equipment and Training Protocol
description: Administrative control implementing mandatory use of aluminized heat-resistant sleeves (rated to 300°C) and heat-resistant gloves for all operators working on machines above 120°C. Include quarterly refresher training on thermal hazards, proper PPE donning/doffing, and emergency response procedures. Establish a color-coded system on all machines indicating maximum safe operating temperatures for operators.

name: Mold Surface Temperature Monitoring System Installation
description: Install infrared temperature sensors on all high-temperature molding machines with automated alerts when surfaces exceed safe exposure thresholds. System will display real-time temperature on operator interfaces and trigger maintenance alerts when insulation integrity deteriorates. Integrate with machine safety interlocks to disable mold access when surface temperatures exceed 90°C.

name: Complete Electrical System Inspection and Upgrade for Recycling Department
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all electrical systems in the Regrind and Recycling Department with focus on heating elements, thermal controls, and circuit protection. Install dedicated circuit breakers with thermal overload protection on all dryer units. Replace aging wiring identified during inspection and upgrade to modern industrial-grade specifications. Implement monthly preventive maintenance schedules with documented inspections. Expected outcome: elimination of electrical overload risk and prevention of similar thermal incidents.

name: Install Dual-Sensor Fire Detection and Automated Suppression Enhancement
description: Upgrade fire detection in recycling operations with combination heat and smoke sensors that trigger earlier response. Install temperature monitoring devices that provide real-time readouts to operators and alert when equipment approaches thermal limits (85% of maximum safe operating temperature). Implement quarterly testing of fire suppression system and annual recertification by licensed professionals. Establish documented record-keeping for all fire safety inspections.

name: Implement Ergonomic Workstation Redesign for Quality Control Laboratory
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessment by certified specialist (Alain Mercier) of all quality control work stations. Redesign tensile testing and dimensional measurement stations with adjustable height platforms, wrist supports, and optimized equipment positioning to maintain neutral wrist alignment. Install automated specimen handling assists to reduce manual force requirements. Provide each work station with footrests and monitor arms positioned at proper viewing angles. Expected outcome: reduction of repetitive strain risk and elimination of postural stress factors.

name: Establish Mandatory Task Rotation and Microbreak Schedule
description: Administrative control implementing mandatory 10-minute task rotation every 50 minutes for all laboratory personnel performing repetitive testing. Establish microbreak protocol with guided stretching exercises specific to upper extremity occupational health. Rotate employees between tensile testing, dimensional measurement, and specimen preparation tasks throughout shifts. Provide written ergonomic guidelines to all quality control staff and include in annual refresher training. Conduct quarterly ergonomic compliance audits and employee feedback sessions.

name: Implement Preventive Occupational Health Screening Program
description: Establish quarterly ergonomic health screening for quality control employees with focus on early identification of musculoskeletal symptoms. Partner with occupational health clinic for baseline assessments and periodic re-evaluations. Document all findings and identify employees at elevated risk for intervention. Provide access to physiotherapy consultation for employees showing early symptoms. Expected outcome: early detection of developing conditions before progression to lost-time injury status.

name: Ergonomic Workstation Assessment and Redesign
description: Conduct a comprehensive ergonomic evaluation of all Assembly Department workstations, focusing on shelf heights, work surface positioning, and material storage. Implement adjustable work tables and implement proper shelf height guidelines to eliminate awkward lifting postures. Provide ergonomic training to all assembly operators on proper lifting techniques and workstation adjustment. Expected outcome: reduce back-related incidents by 40% within six months.

name: Implement Material Handling Equipment
description: Introduce lightweight mobile carts and lift-assist devices in the Assembly Department to eliminate manual lifting of containers exceeding 10 kg. Train operators on proper use of mechanical assists. Establish maximum manual lift weight limits of 10 kg per company policy. Expected outcome: eliminate heavy lifting injuries and improve productivity.

name: Replace Aging Cooling System Infrastructure
description: Conduct complete inspection and replacement of all corroded cooling lines in injection molding machines, prioritizing equipment over five years old. Replace galvanized steel lines with stainless steel or modern composite materials resistant to corrosion and temperature cycling. Establish preventive maintenance schedule with quarterly pressure testing and visual inspections. Install pressure relief valves and automatic shutoff systems on all high-pressure lines. Expected outcome: eliminate cooling system leak incidents.

name: Enhanced PPE Requirements for Maintenance Operations
description: Mandate use of high-temperature resistant gloves (rated to 100°C), arm sleeves, and face shields for all maintenance work on pressurized cooling systems. Provide flame-resistant long-sleeve shirts as standard maintenance apparel. Implement mandatory PPE inspection before each maintenance shift. Ensure all maintenance technicians complete burn prevention and first aid training annually.

name: Implement Isolation Procedures and Lockout Protocol Enhancement
description: Develop and post comprehensive lockout/tagout procedures specific to cooling system maintenance, requiring dual-lock systems for high-pressure lines. Establish mandatory cool-down period of 30 minutes before any maintenance work begins. Implement pressure release procedures with verification documentation. Train all maintenance staff with certification and quarterly refresher sessions.

name: Comprehensive Storage Rack Structural Assessment and Repair
description: Commission professional structural engineering assessment of all mezzanine and high-shelf storage racks. Replace damaged components, reinforce weak connections, and upgrade cross-bracing systems. Implement monthly load verification inspections. Install secondary containment rails on all elevated shelves to prevent pallet displacement. Maximum load weights must be clearly marked on each shelf with verification against actual stored weights.

name: Implement Restricted Forklift Operating Zones and Enhanced Training
description: Designate low-speed zones (maximum 5 km/h) in warehouse aisles adjacent to high-storage areas. Paint high-visibility warning lines 1.5 meters before structural supports. Implement requirement for spotters when operating in restricted zones and for loads over 500 kg. Mandatory forklift operator certification renewal annually with specific focus on load securing and low-clearance navigation.

name: Install Overhead Falling Object Protection Systems
description: Install protective netting or mesh systems beneath all mezzanine and elevated storage areas where workers operate below. Install impact protection padding on structural columns in high-traffic forklift areas. Implement emergency alert system that activates if movement is detected above work areas. Post warning signage at all entries to overhead work zones.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Systems
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all facility ventilation systems including filter replacement every 6 weeks, fan bearing lubrication monthly, and intake ductwork inspection quarterly. This administrative control will prevent recurring ventilation failures. A maintenance log will be maintained and reviewed by the HSE Director. The program includes training for maintenance staff on early warning signs of system degradation. Annual cost approximately $12,000.

name: Install Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring Sensors
description: Deploy three wireless air quality sensors in the Regrind and Recycling Department connected to a central monitoring dashboard that alerts operators when particulate levels exceed 2.0 mg/m³. This engineering control provides immediate notification of ventilation issues. Sensors will trigger automatic equipment shutdown protocols if levels reach 4.0 mg/m³. System cost is $18,500 including installation and first-year monitoring service.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic Coupling Specifications with Secondary Containment
description: Replace all standard hydraulic couplings on the automated material handling systems with self-sealing quick-disconnect couplings that minimize fluid spray during disconnection. Additionally, install secondary hydraulic fluid collection trays beneath all coupling points. This engineering control eliminates spray hazards and prevents environmental contamination. All four robotic arms on Lines C and D will be retrofitted within 30 days at a cost of $24,000.

name: Implement Hydraulic Maintenance Documentation and Verification Protocol
description: Create a mandatory maintenance checklist for all hydraulic system work including torque specifications, verification by second technician, and photographic documentation of completed connections. All maintenance must be recorded in the digital maintenance management system (CMMS) before equipment restart is authorized. This administrative control ensures proper installation verification. Training will be provided to all maintenance staff. Implementation occurs immediately with zero additional cost beyond existing CMMS licensing.

name: Establish Hydraulic Fluid Spill Response Kit and Training
description: Deploy portable spill kits containing absorbent materials, collection containers, and safety equipment at three strategic locations near hydraulic equipment. Conduct quarterly spill response drills for all production supervisors and maintenance technicians. This ensures rapid containment and proper hazardous waste handling. Kits cost $450 each and spill response training will be integrated into existing monthly safety meetings.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Injection Molding Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule for all 32 injection molding machines requiring daily pre-shift inspections, weekly pressure system checks, and monthly thermal imaging analysis of pump assemblies. Install vibration sensors on high-risk machines to alert operators to developing faults before catastrophic failure. Create a digital maintenance log system that tracks all service intervals and flags machines exceeding maintenance windows. All operators will receive training on early warning signs of hydraulic system failure.

name: Install Secondary Hydraulic Pressure Relief Systems
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with redundant pressure relief valves and secondary containment trays designed to capture and contain hydraulic fluid from line ruptures. Install quick-disconnect safety couplings that automatically close off hydraulic flow when lines separate unexpectedly. This engineering control will prevent pressurized fluid discharge and reduce the risk of hydraulic injection injuries and electrical hazards.

name: Replace Chemical Storage Shelving and Install Inspection Protocol
description: Replace all corroded chemical storage shelving in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility with stainless steel or epoxy-coated units designed for corrosive environments. Install secondary containment trays beneath all solvent containers with capacity equal to 110% of largest container volume. Implement monthly visual inspections of all storage infrastructure with documented reports. Ensure chemical containers have proper secondary sealing caps and are segregated by chemical compatibility. Train all personnel handling chemicals on proper storage procedures.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Chemical Storage Area
description: Install dedicated mechanical ventilation system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility with 15 air changes per hour capacity, exceeding regulatory requirements. Add local exhaust ventilation near chemical handling workstations with capture velocities of at least 100 feet per minute. Install real-time vapor concentration monitoring sensors that provide continuous alerts when solvent vapor levels reach 25% of lower flammable limit. System will automatically increase ventilation fan speed when elevated readings are detected.

name: Replace Safety Relay Module and Establish Critical Components Tracking
description: Immediately replace the faulty safety relay module in CNC Milling Machine #7 with a certified safety-rated unit meeting ISO 13849-1 Category 3 requirements. Perform full safety system functional testing and certification by an independent qualified technician. Create a comprehensive safety-critical components inventory for all CNC equipment with scheduled replacement intervals documented in a centralized maintenance management system. Implement a color-coded tag system for safety components with mandatory replacement dates visible to maintenance personnel.

name: Implement Enhanced Machine Guarding and Emergency Stop Verification
description: Install additional machine guarding around CNC Milling Machine #7's spindle area with access gates that automatically disconnect spindle power when opened. Retrofit the emergency stop system with redundant push-buttons positioned on both sides of the machine and accessible from all operator positions. Perform weekly functional testing of all emergency stop systems across all CNC equipment with documented verification. Establish a mandatory daily pre-shift safety check list that includes emergency stop activation test before any production activity begins.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Lockout/Tagout and Machine Safety Training
description: Conduct refresher training for all maintenance and machine operation staff on proper Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedures, with emphasis on verifying equipment de-energization before manual intervention. Provide hands-on training on recognizing equipment failure symptoms and appropriate responses. Require all personnel to complete the training with competency assessment before resuming work on affected equipment. Establish monthly toolbox talks focused on machine-specific hazards and safety interlock systems.

name: Implement Predictive Cooling System Monitoring
description: Install pressure and temperature sensors on all cooling circuit lines with automated alerts when parameters deviate from baseline. Integrate monitoring system with maintenance database to trigger inspections at predetermined intervals. This engineering control eliminates the gap between inspection cycles and system failures. Expected outcome: detect cooling system anomalies 48-72 hours before failure occurs, reducing emergency shutdowns and environmental incidents by 85%.

name: Replace Corroded Coupling Joints with Stainless Steel Fittings
description: Systematically replace all carbon steel couplings in the cooling system with marine-grade stainless steel fittings rated for 10-year service life in glycol-water mixtures. Perform full system audit to identify all vulnerable connection points. This substitution control addresses the root cause (material corrosion) by using inherently more resistant materials. Expected outcome: eliminate 90% of cooling system leaks related to coupling failure.

name: Establish Quarterly Cooling System Inspections
description: Create standardized quarterly inspection checklist for all cooling lines, couplings, and seals performed by certified maintenance technicians. Document findings in maintenance tracking system with photographic evidence. Implement administrative control through work order system that automatically flags overdue inspections. Expected outcome: catch 95% of developing leaks before environmental release occurs.

name: Install Dual-Redundant Temperature Control System
description: Replace single-point-of-failure thermostat with dual independent temperature monitoring systems—one primary digital controller and one mechanical backup. Install automatic shutdown circuit that triggers if temperature exceeds 60°C for more than 5 minutes. Both systems will feed data to central monitoring dashboard with real-time alerts. This engineering control eliminates the single failure mode that created the near-miss. Expected outcome: reduce thermal runaway incidents to near zero.

name: Enhanced Operator Training on Thermal Hazard Recognition
description: Develop and deliver 2-hour specialized training module on recognizing early warning signs of thermal runaway in composite materials processing. Include case study analysis of this near-miss incident. All operators working with resin batching will complete certification annually. Training will cover proper response protocols, emergency shutdown procedures, and when to escalate to supervision. Expected outcome: ensure all personnel can independently identify and respond to thermal anomalies within 30 seconds of onset.

name: Ergonomic Redesign of Testing Workstations
description: Retrofit all quality testing workstations with adjustable-height tables (electric actuators, 28-46 inches range), ergonomic wrist rests with contoured palm support, and articulating test apparatus arms to reduce reaching and gripping strain. Install anti-fatigue mats and ensure proper lighting at 500-750 lux. These engineering controls directly address the workstation design deficiencies identified in the ergonomic assessment. Expected outcome: reduce wrist strain by 60-70% and prevent progression to clinical carpal tunnel syndrome.

name: Implement Job Rotation Schedule in Quality Control
description: Establish mandatory job rotation that distributes quality technicians across different testing functions every 2 hours—rotating between tensile testing, dimensional measurement, and visual inspection tasks. This administrative control ensures no single employee performs high-repetition wrist-strain activities for extended periods. Expected outcome: distribute cumulative strain across diverse muscle groups and reduce peak strain loading on any single joint.

name: Baseline Occupational Health Surveillance Program
description: Establish baseline occupational health screening for all production and quality personnel performing repetitive tasks. Implement annual ergonomic assessment using validated tools (RULA, Nordic questionnaire). Create early alert system for symptom tracking and trigger interventions at Stage 1 symptoms (pain <2 weeks). Expected outcome: identify RSI risks at earliest stages before occupational illness develops, reducing lost-time injuries by 45%.

name: Implement Secure Chemical Storage Protocol
description: Install secondary containment trays with raised edges (minimum 110% container volume) beneath all chemical storage shelves in the mixing room. Implement mandatory daily visual inspection checklist for all chemical containers to verify cap integrity and proper sealing. Train all chemical handling staff on proper container securing techniques using clips or straps. Establish a 'chemical staging area' away from heat sources with designated secure racks. This engineering and administrative control combination addresses the root cause of inadequate storage practices and eliminates the risk of future spills from improperly sealed containers.

name: Enhanced Ventilation System Upgrade
description: Install an additional dedicated exhaust system in the chemical mixing room with local capture hoods positioned above the mixing workstation and storage area. The system will operate continuously during all shifts and feature activated carbon filtration. Conduct air quality monitoring monthly to ensure compliance with exposure limits. This engineering control directly addresses inadequate ventilation risks and reduces worker exposure to resin fumes, protecting the health of all personnel working in the chemical handling area.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Safety Interlocks
description: Establish a documented weekly inspection program for all safety sensor interlocks on injection molding equipment. Maintenance technician Réjan Simard (EMP-00077) will conduct alignment checks, vibration assessments, and functional testing on each interlock before production shifts. Replace any sensors showing drift or misalignment. Implement a digital tracking system to record all maintenance activities. This administrative control ensures early detection of sensor degradation before it becomes a critical safety hazard, directly preventing potential entanglement incidents.

name: Upgrade Machine Interlock System with Redundant Sensors
description: Replace existing single-point safety sensors on all injection molding lines with dual-channel redundant interlock systems that require both sensors to confirm cavity door closure before machine activation. Install independent circuit monitoring to detect any single sensor failure. This engineering control provides backup protection against any single sensor malfunction and significantly reduces the risk of accidental machine startup during maintenance. Priority installation on Line B within 60 days, followed by other production lines.

name: Replace All Ladders with Anti-Slip Enhanced Models
description: Immediately replace all portable step ladders throughout the facility with models featuring reinforced non-slip feet, self-leveling base technology, and wide-grip side rails. All new ladders must meet CSA B355 standards and feature stability indicators. Inspect and repair all existing ladders or remove them from service. Distribute the new ladders to all maintenance and storage areas. This engineering control directly eliminates ladder slip-related hazards by ensuring stable footing on any floor surface.

name: Establish Mandatory Two-Person Ladder Safety Protocol
description: Implement a company-wide policy requiring two-person teams for all ladder work above 1 meter height. One person must act as a designated spotter/stabilizer positioned at the ladder base, hands ready to support. Create laminated signage for all storage areas and conduct mandatory training for all warehouse and maintenance staff on proper ladder setup and spotting techniques. Document all ladder use activities in a work log. This administrative control significantly reduces instability risks and ensures immediate assistance is available in case of difficulty.

name: Conduct Facility Floor Surface Audit and Remediation
description: Perform comprehensive assessment of all floor surfaces in maintenance and storage areas, identifying uneven sections, gaps, and debris accumulation zones. Repair or level all identified hazards using appropriate materials (epoxy fill, grinding, or replacement). Install clear floor hazard markings in elevated risk areas. Implement daily housekeeping inspections and cleaning schedules to prevent debris accumulation beneath work areas. This engineering and administrative control addresses the underlying floor condition that contributed to ladder instability.

name: Implement Container Integrity Verification Procedure
description: Develop and enforce a mandatory pre-transfer inspection protocol for all chemical containers in the mixing room. All containers must be visually inspected for lid security, cracks, and leaks before being moved. Staff will document each inspection on a daily checklist. Training will be provided to all personnel handling chemicals on proper container handling techniques and lid verification procedures. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate container inspection.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays
description: Install engineered secondary containment trays beneath all chemical storage shelves and work surfaces in the mixing room. These trays will capture any spills and prevent them from spreading across the floor. Trays will have a capacity of at least 110% of the largest container volume. All personnel will receive training on proper placement of containers within the trays. This engineering control prevents future spills from creating widespread hazards.

name: Upgrade Chemical Handling PPE Requirements
description: Establish mandatory PPE standards for all chemical handling activities in the mixing room, including chemical-resistant gloves, safety glasses with side shields, and respiratory protection (half-mask respirators) for operations involving volatile compounds. Stock chemical-specific eyewash and emergency shower stations within 10 seconds of the mixing area. Conduct quarterly refresher training on proper PPE selection and use. Update WHMIS documentation and safety signage accordingly.

name: Enforce Mandatory Mold Cooling Cycle Times
description: Implement automated cycle time controls on all injection molding machines that physically prevent operators from removing parts until the mandatory 45-second cooling period has elapsed. Add visual and audible alerts on each machine to indicate when parts are safe to handle. Reprogram all machine controls to override any manual shortcuts. This engineering control ensures consistent thermal safety regardless of production pressure.

name: Implement Heat-Resistant Glove Compliance Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory PPE checkpoint system where supervisors visually verify that all operators are wearing appropriate heat-resistant gloves before any shift begins. Update production workstations to include a dedicated glove station with multiple size options. Institute a peer-reporting system where operators must confirm their coworker's PPE compliance. Conduct monthly compliance audits. Non-compliance will result in mandatory retraining and disciplinary action.

name: Install Mechanical Pallet Jacks and Lift Assists
description: Purchase and deploy motorized pallet jacks and pneumatic lift-assist devices specifically for handling 50-pound resin bags in the warehouse. Establish designated staging areas where bags must be transferred to mechanical equipment before being moved to storage locations. This eliminates the need for manual lifting of heavy loads and represents a substitution control that removes the primary hazard entirely.

name: Implement Comprehensive Ergonomic Training Program
description: Develop and deliver mandatory ergonomic training to all warehouse and production staff covering proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, load assessment, and back injury prevention. Include practical demonstrations with actual workplace materials and equipment. Conduct refresher training quarterly and for all new hires. Include ergonomic principles in the production planning process to prevent rush situations that encourage unsafe practices. Document training completion and competency assessments.

name: Establish Weight Limit and Two-Person Lift Protocols
description: Implement a policy prohibiting manual lifting of any individual load exceeding 25 pounds in the warehouse. Establish a mandatory two-person lift requirement for items between 25-50 pounds. Create visual signage at all storage locations indicating proper lifting techniques and weight limits. Train supervisors on enforcement procedures and incident reporting protocols. Modify inventory management procedures to ensure sufficient time for safe material handling without production pressure.

name: Install Advanced Temperature Monitoring and Automatic Shutdown System
description: Replace all resin dryer units with models featuring dual redundant temperature sensors connected to automated safety shutdown systems. Implement real-time temperature monitoring software that alerts operators and supervisors if temperatures exceed 240°C, with automatic equipment shutdown at 260°C. Install visual and audible alarm systems at each dryer station. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the incident by preventing equipment from reaching dangerous temperature levels. System will include manual override capabilities for emergency situations and daily calibration verification routines.

name: Implement Pre-Maintenance Equipment Status Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory 15-minute equipment inspection checklist that all operators must complete before beginning any maintenance work. The checklist includes temperature readings from three different measurement points, pressure gauge verification, visual inspection for leaks, and confirmation that equipment has cooled to safe handling levels. All inspections must be documented in the maintenance log with operator signature and timestamp. Supervisors will conduct spot audits of 20% of maintenance activities weekly. This administrative control ensures equipment status is verified before work begins, preventing situations where operators encounter unexpected hazardous conditions.

name: Enhanced Personal Protective Equipment for Equipment Maintenance
description: Issue all production and maintenance staff heat-resistant protective clothing including Kevlar-reinforced gloves rated to 300°C, thermal protective face shields with side protection, and aluminized reflective aprons for all resin dryer maintenance work. Conduct mandatory training on proper donning and doffing procedures and limitations of PPE. Create PPE inspection and replacement schedule every 6 months or after use. While PPE is a lower-priority control, it provides immediate protection while engineering controls are being implemented and serves as backup protection.

name: Implement Mechanical Assist Device for Overhead Material Retrieval
description: Install an overhead vacuum-assisted material handling system in the Regrind and Recycling Department capable of retrieving spools up to 50 pounds from heights up to 3 meters. Alternatively, lower all heavy composite material storage to shoulder height or below (under 1.5 meters). Provide lightweight aluminum rolling carts with adjustable height platforms for easier access to materials. Eliminate the need for workers to reach overhead, which is a high-priority engineering control that removes the primary hazard of falling objects and overexertion injuries.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification and Compliance Audit Program
description: Implement a comprehensive re-certification program requiring all machine operators and setters to complete advanced LOTO training every 12 months with competency testing. Establish a safety audit schedule where a qualified LOTO auditor conducts monthly inspections of 100% of setups and maintenance activities, documenting compliance with photo evidence. Non-compliance results in immediate work stoppage and mandatory retraining. Create a visual LOTO station at each machine with laminated step-by-step procedures, lockout hardware checklist, and verification sign-off sheets. This administrative control ensures consistent application of critical safety procedures.

name: Install Interlocked Safety Guards on Mold Interface Areas
description: Retrofit all injection molding lines with physical safety interlock guards that prevent mold opening during setup and maintenance operations. Install electro-mechanical interlocks connected to the hydraulic system that prevent pressure actuation when access panels are open or when the setup mode is engaged. Additionally, implement a two-operator verification system where no setup activity can proceed without explicit confirmation from both the operator performing the work and a designated supervisor physically present. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of unexpected machine actuation during setup.

name: Enhanced Supervision Protocol for Evening and Night Shift Operations
description: Revise supervision procedures to require that a qualified supervisor conduct visual verification of all LOTO procedures every 15 minutes during setup and maintenance activities on evening (3PM-11:30PM) and night (11PM-7:30AM) shifts when staffing is reduced. Supervisors must sign off on LOTO completion before any work begins. Implement real-time communication system (radio or messaging) between setters and control room operators to prevent unauthorized machine activation. Establish a written protocol requiring control room operators to confirm with the setter before any equipment testing or activation.

name: Implement Ergonomic Workstation Redesign for Line C
description: Redesign workstations on Line C with adjustable-height work surfaces, wrist-neutral positioning guides, and anti-fatigue mats. Install component holders to reduce gripping force requirements. Conduct ergonomic assessments for all assembly operators using standardized RULA methodology. Provide operators with individual workstation adjustments to match anthropometric measurements. This addresses root causes of repetitive strain by reducing forceful exertions and promoting neutral wrist posture throughout the 8-hour shift.

name: Establish Mandatory Job Rotation and Microbreak Protocol
description: Implement a formalized job rotation schedule rotating assembly operators between Line C and packaging operations every 2 hours. Mandate 5-minute microbreaks every 60 minutes for stretching and hand exercises, tracked via shift supervisor logs. Develop standardized stretching routine specific to carpal tunnel prevention, delivered by occupational health specialist during new hire orientation and quarterly refreshers. Train all supervisors on early warning signs of repetitive strain injuries and requirement to refer employees for ergonomic assessment upon first complaint.

name: Install Early Detection Monitoring System
description: Implement a simple self-reporting symptom tracking system where operators log any hand/wrist discomfort in a digital or paper log at shift end. Designate the Assembly Lead to review logs weekly and trigger automatic referral to occupational health if any operator reports symptoms for more than 2 consecutive days. Establish clear protocol requiring occupational health evaluation within 48 hours of threshold being met. This administrative control enables early intervention before conditions progress to lost-time injury status.

name: Replace and Upgrade Hopper Level Control System
description: Install a redundant dual-sensor hopper level monitoring system with independent shut-off valves on Injection Molding Lines A, C, and D. The new system will include both capacitive and mechanical float sensors that trigger cutoff at 95% capacity. Implement automated alerts to the production coordinator's workstation. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of overflow by providing fail-safe level management. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of hopper overflow incidents. System includes automatic email notifications to maintenance staff if any sensor fails.

name: Establish Monthly Hopper Sensor Maintenance Schedule
description: Create and enforce a mandatory monthly preventive maintenance schedule for all hopper level sensors across production lines. Maintenance technicians will clean sensors, verify calibration, and test fail-safe mechanisms. Document all maintenance in the facility maintenance management system. Technicians will record sensor response times and compare against manufacturer specifications. This administrative control ensures early detection of sensor degradation before failures occur.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays for Chemical Storage
description: Install polypropylene secondary containment trays rated for 110% capacity beneath all solvent and chemical containers in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room. These trays will have walls at least 30 cm high and sloped drainage toward collection sumps. All existing chemical containers will be relocated to compliant containment immediately. This engineering control prevents spills from spreading and protects electrical equipment and propane storage. Design capacity will accommodate acetone, isopropanol, hydraulic oils, and adhesive agents. Trays will be inspected monthly and cleaned quarterly.

name: Implement Chemical Container Integrity Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a weekly visual inspection protocol for all stored chemical containers. Inspections will include checking for leaks, corrosion, seal integrity, and proper labeling. Any container showing signs of deterioration will be quarantined in a secondary containment area pending replacement. Inspection results will be logged in a central database. This administrative control identifies failing containers before catastrophic leaks occur. All operators will receive training on identifying container degradation warning signs.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Warehouse Floor Assessment and Repair
description: Hire a structural engineering firm to perform a full assessment of the Finished Goods Warehouse flooring. All cracked and settled areas will be repaired using concrete resurfacing and patching techniques. The floor will be refinished to create a smooth, level surface free of raised edges and trip hazards. After repair, implement a quarterly floor inspection schedule to monitor for new cracking or settlement. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the pallet jack incident. The repair will also reduce equipment strain and improve worker safety across the entire warehouse operation.

name: Implement Mold Insert Replacement Schedule
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule to replace all injection mold inserts showing signs of wear every 6 months or after 500,000 cycles, whichever comes first. The maintenance team will inspect each mold insert for burrs, sharp edges, and material degradation during regular maintenance intervals. A color-coded tagging system will identify molds that require replacement priority. This addresses the root cause of burr formation and eliminates the sharp edge hazard at the source through proactive equipment maintenance rather than reactive part removal.

name: Introduce Edge Finishing and Deburring Station
description: Install a dedicated deburring workstation equipped with pneumatic deburring tools and manual finishing stations between the molding lines and the assembly area. Train all production operators on the safe use of deburring equipment and require all parts with detected burrs to be processed through this station before assembly or packaging. This engineering control removes the hazard of sharp edges by systematically eliminating them before operators handle parts, shifting the burden of edge removal from operators to controlled equipment with proper guarding.

name: Mandatory Cut-Resistant Glove PPE Upgrade
description: Provide all production operators with ANSI Level A3 cut-resistant gloves specifically designed for handling plastic parts with sharp edges. Conduct a 1-hour training session on proper glove selection, sizing, and inspection. Establish a monthly replacement program for damaged or worn gloves. While this is a PPE-level control, it provides immediate protection while engineering solutions are being implemented and serves as a secondary defense layer.

name: Mandatory LOTO Recertification Program
description: Conduct immediate mandatory recertification training for all maintenance and production personnel on lockout/tagout procedures, specifically focusing on hydraulic system isolation. Training will include hands-on practice with actual equipment in the maintenance workshop. All participants must pass a written assessment and a practical demonstration before resuming hydraulic system maintenance work. Refresher training will be required annually and whenever equipment modifications occur. This administrative control ensures that proper energy isolation procedures are understood and consistently followed.

name: Install Pressure Relief Isolation Ball Valve
description: Install manual isolation ball valves on all hydraulic pressure relief lines before the pressure release points. These valves will allow technicians to safely isolate the hydraulic system pressure before beginning any maintenance work on relief mechanisms. Engineering signs and color-coded tags will clearly indicate the required valve closure step in the LOTO procedure. This engineering control provides a physical safeguard that prevents accidental pressure release even if LOTO procedures are not perfectly followed.

name: Establish Wet Waste Storage Containers with Lids
description: Replace all open waste bins in the chemical storage and mixing areas with NFPA-compliant, self-closing, metal waste containers designed specifically for flammable and spontaneously combustible materials. All resin-saturated rags, cotton materials, and absorbent media must be immediately placed into water-filled containers with sealed lids to prevent oxidation. Containers will be labeled with hazard symbols and disposal schedules. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of spontaneous combustion by preventing oxygen exposure to resin-saturated materials.

name: Relocate Resin Dryer Unit Away from Waste Storage
description: Perform a facility layout modification to relocate the heat-generating resin dryer unit to a position at least 5 meters away from all chemical waste storage areas. Install a fireproof barrier between the dryer and any remaining waste storage areas that cannot be relocated. This engineering control removes the heat source that initiated the spontaneous combustion chain reaction and creates physical separation between ignition sources and flammable materials.

name: Implement Enhanced Chemical Waste Management Training
description: Develop and deliver a 2-hour mandatory training program for all employees working in chemical storage, mixing, and waste handling areas. Training will cover spontaneous combustion hazards, proper storage of resin-saturated materials, correct use of sealed waste containers, and emergency response procedures specific to chemical fires. All personnel must complete training within 30 days, with annual refresher training required. This administrative control ensures understanding of hazards and proper procedures for handling reactive materials.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Dryer Equipment
description: Establish a mandatory calibration and maintenance schedule for all resin dryers with calibration required every 10 months instead of 12 months. Integrate this into the computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) with automatic work order generation. Create a checklist that includes thermostat testing, heating element inspection, and safety cutoff verification. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance and Engineering department with monthly compliance audits conducted by the HSE coordinator. This engineering control addresses the root cause by ensuring early detection of equipment degradation before dangerous conditions develop.

name: Install Secondary Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install an independent backup temperature monitoring system with wireless alert capability on all three resin dryers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. This second system will have a lower alarm threshold (5°C below the primary alarm) to provide early warning of dryer malfunction. The system will send alerts to both the equipment operator and the HSE team via SMS and email. Additionally, conduct quarterly testing of all safety cutoff mechanisms and document results. This engineering control provides redundancy and ensures multiple opportunities to detect and respond to overheating conditions.

name: Enhance Fire Safety Training for Chemical Storage Area
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all personnel working in or near the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility focusing on fire response procedures, emergency equipment location and use, and early warning signs of equipment malfunction. Training to include hands-on demonstration of the emergency shutdown procedures for all resin processing equipment. Participants will complete competency assessments and receive certificates. Training will be delivered by the HSE team and repeated quarterly for new hires. This administrative control ensures personnel can quickly identify and respond to fire hazards.

name: Conduct Warehouse Layout Safety Assessment
description: Perform a comprehensive safety audit of the entire warehouse focusing on forklift operating lanes, storage rack clearances, and collision hazards. Measure clearances between all racks and high-traffic areas, ensuring minimum 2-foot clearance on both sides for forklift operation. Implement physical modifications including installation of protective steel guards around rack support beams and clearly marked buffer zones. Install high-visibility edge guards on all low-clearance areas. Create updated warehouse maps showing safe routes and post them at all entry points. This engineering control eliminates the spatial collision hazard.

name: Mandatory Warehouse Layout Training for All Equipment Operators
description: Conduct mandatory training session for all forklift and material handling equipment operators covering the new warehouse layout implemented three weeks prior. Training must include site walk-through identifying high-risk areas, clearance restrictions, and collision hotspots. Operators must pass a practical skills assessment demonstrating safe navigation through tight spaces. Documentation of training completion and competency assessment scores will be maintained. Training to be delivered within 5 business days and repeated for all new operators. This administrative control ensures operators understand spatial constraints and safe procedures.

name: Implement Mandatory Job Rotation and Micro-Break Protocol
description: Establish a structured job rotation system requiring assembly line workers to rotate between different tasks every 90 minutes to vary muscle group usage and reduce repetitive strain. Implement mandatory 10-minute micro-breaks every 2 hours with stretching exercises designed specifically for assembly work. Create a rotation schedule that includes transition to lower-repetition tasks such as quality inspection or material staging. Establish baseline metrics measuring break compliance and worker comfort levels. Train all supervisors on the rotation schedule implementation and break enforcement. This administrative control reduces cumulative strain by distributing physical demands across different tasks and muscle groups.

name: Conduct Ergonomic Workstation Assessment and Modification
description: Hire a certified ergonomic consultant to conduct comprehensive assessment of all workstations in the Packaging and Labeling Station, evaluating desk height, monitor positioning, seating, wrist supports, and tool accessibility. Based on assessment findings, modify workstations including installation of height-adjustable work surfaces, ergonomic chairs with lumbar support, and wrist support devices. Ensure proper lighting at all workstations and eliminate glare. Install document holders at appropriate angles to reduce neck strain. Provide ergonomic training to all workers on proper workstation use and posture. This engineering control eliminates ergonomic stressors through physical workspace modification.

name: Establish Ergonomic Risk Monitoring Program
description: Create a systematic program to monitor and track ergonomic-related injuries and complaints in the Packaging and Labeling Station with monthly reporting to the JHSC. Implement an early reporting system allowing workers to anonymously report discomfort or pain symptoms. Conduct quarterly workstation assessments and update as needed. Establish baseline health metrics and track trends over 12 months. Train supervisors to recognize early signs of repetitive strain injuries and refer affected workers to occupational health services. This administrative control provides continuous monitoring and early intervention for emerging ergonomic issues.

name: Implement Daily Warehouse Rack Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory daily inspection protocol for all storage racks in the Raw Materials Warehouse. Assign a warehouse team member each shift to visually inspect stacking stability, proper load distribution, and compliance with weight limits. Use a standardized checklist and log all findings in the HSE tracking system. This administrative control will catch unstable conditions before they pose risks. Training will be provided to all warehouse staff on proper stacking techniques following CNESST guidelines and load limits per rack design specifications.

name: Install Anti-Slip Pallet Liners
description: Engineer control to reduce pallet movement during stacking. Install anti-slip rubber liners between each pallet layer and mesh netting on exterior-facing surfaces of resin pallet stacks. This engineering solution reduces shifting and sliding of materials during storage and handling. Liners will be certified for use with plastic resin bags and tested for load-bearing capacity. All existing high-risk stacks will be retrofitted within 15 days.

name: Install Protective Sensor Covers and Redesign Fire Detection Layout
description: Install sealed, transparent polycarbonate protective covers over all heat detection sensors in the workshop to prevent accumulation of airborne dust and debris. Additionally, reposition two heat sensors to locations less prone to airborne particulate exposure by relocating them higher on walls away from equipment operations. Use engineering controls to create physical separation between dust-generating activities and detection systems. All modifications will comply with CNESST fire code requirements and will be certified by a professional fire systems engineer.

name: Upgrade Workshop Ventilation and Implement Equipment Cleaning Procedures
description: Enhance the workshop's local exhaust ventilation system with upgraded filtration to capture fine plastic dust before it becomes airborne. Install portable HEPA-filtered air cleaners in high-risk zones. Concurrently, establish new administrative procedures requiring maintenance staff to use vacuum-assisted cleaning (not compressed air) when servicing hydraulic and electrical equipment. Provide training to all technicians on proper cleaning methods and hazards of compressed air dust disturbance. This combination of engineering and administrative controls will reduce sensor false-triggers.

name: Implement Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory two-person verification system for all material feeder equipment before any maintenance or clearing operations. Require that equipment be placed in full lockout status with verified zero energy state before personnel are permitted to access hoppers or augers. Implement physical LOTO devices with multiple lock points on the main power disconnect and emergency stop circuits. All production staff and material handlers must complete recertification training on LOTO procedures and equipment-specific zero-energy verification steps within 10 days.

name: Install Material Feeder Interlock Guards and Signage
description: Engineering control to physically prevent unauthorized access to rotating equipment. Install polycarbonate interlock guards over all material feeder hoppers on Injection Molding Line C that prevent opening unless equipment is powered down. Add visible, multilingual warning signs indicating hazard of rotating equipment and requirement for lockout. Install automated equipment status lights (green=safe, red=active) visible from the operator station and hopper access points. Ensure guards comply with ISO 13485 medical device manufacturing standards.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Inspections
description: Establish a formalized quarterly inspection and maintenance schedule for all injection molding machine cooling water systems. Inspections will include pressure testing, visual examination of all connection joints and hoses for signs of wear or corrosion, and replacement of degraded components before failure occurs. Maintenance technicians will document all findings in the equipment database. This proactive approach will prevent coolant leaks that could create slipping hazards and equipment damage. Expected outcome: reduce cooling system incidents by 85% within 12 months.

name: Install Absorbent Spill Kits at Each Production Line
description: Deploy emergency spill response kits at each of the 8 injection molding lines containing absorbent materials, containment barriers, and disposal bags. Train all production operators on proper spill containment procedures to minimize environmental contamination and slipping hazards. Include clearly visible signage indicating kit locations. This administrative control ensures rapid response capability if leaks occur before maintenance intervention.

name: Replace All Proximity Sensors on Injection Molding Machines
description: Conduct immediate replacement of all proximity sensors on the 32 injection molding machines throughout the facility. Implement a preventive maintenance protocol requiring sensor replacement every 18 months or upon any malfunction detection. Sensors will be sourced from certified suppliers with reliability ratings exceeding 99.9%. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of unexpected mold closures by ensuring reliable cycle interlocks. All operators will receive notification of completion.

name: Mandatory Machine Guarding and Lockout Refresher Training
description: Conduct immediate refresher training for all production operators on machine guarding principles, emergency stop procedures, and lockout/tagout (LOTO) protocols. Training will include hands-on demonstrations at each production line, emphasizing the critical importance of maintaining hand clearance from mold areas during machine operation. All operators must demonstrate competency through written and practical assessments. This administrative control reinforces safe work practices and ensures all personnel understand the hazards associated with injection molding equipment.

name: Install Redundant Environmental Monitoring System for Chemical Storage
description: Install automated temperature and humidity monitoring sensors throughout the Chemical Storage building with real-time alerts to facility management if storage conditions deviate from specifications (temperature range: 15-25°C, humidity: 30-60%). Integrate the system with the building HVAC controls to enable automatic corrective adjustments. Install secondary containment trays beneath all large resin tanks (50+ gallon capacity) to capture any future leaks before environmental release. This engineering control prevents chemical degradation and ensures rapid detection of storage condition failures.

name: Implement Weekly Chemical Storage Facility Inspections
description: Establish a formal weekly inspection protocol for the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility, including visual examination of all storage tanks for cracks, leaks, or corrosion; verification of storage temperature and humidity conditions; confirmation of proper container labeling and inventory rotation (FIFO); and assessment of emergency response equipment functionality. Inspections will be documented and reviewed by the HSE department. This administrative control ensures early detection of storage integrity issues before major spills occur.

name: Upgrade HVAC System Redundancy and Maintenance
description: Implement a predictive maintenance program for the facility HVAC system with quarterly professional inspections and priority replacement of aging components. Install backup HVAC units for the Chemical Storage building to maintain climate control during primary system failures. Establish 24/7 monitoring alerts for HVAC system anomalies on critical areas. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of chemical storage degradation by ensuring consistent environmental conditions throughout the facility.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protective Equipment
description: Replace current heat-resistant gloves with higher-grade silicone aluminized gloves rated for continuous exposure up to 260°C. Distribute new gloves to all operators on injection molding lines within 7 days. Training will be provided on proper donning/doffing procedures and care maintenance. This addresses the root cause of insufficient thermal protection for high-temperature mold handling operations.

name: Implement Mandatory Cool-Down Procedures
description: Establish and enforce a standardized cool-down interval of 90 seconds between part removal and manual handling on Line B and Line A. Coordinate with production supervisors to adjust cycle times accordingly. Post visual timers and procedural signage at each mold station. This administrative control will reduce direct contact with high-temperature mold surfaces during peak production periods.

name: Install Container Integrity Verification System
description: Implement a two-stage lid verification protocol for all chemical containers: visual inspection (integrity and threading) and torque-check with calibrated wrench before storage. Place inspection checklists and torque specifications at all chemical storage shelves. Train all material handlers on proper container closure techniques and consequences of improper sealing. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the root cause of unsealed containers.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Area Ventilation
description: Install continuous air monitoring system with real-time vapor concentration display in the Chemical Storage Room. Upgrade to demand-controlled ventilation system that automatically increases fan speed when VOC concentrations exceed 50% of PEL (permissible exposure limit). Add secondary emergency ventilation switch accessible from outside the room. This engineering control addresses inadequate ventilation exposure risk and prevents vapor accumulation.

name: Establish Chemical Storage Audits and Training
description: Conduct monthly compliance audits of chemical storage procedures performed by Sanaa Rachidi (Fire Safety Coordinator). Audit will include container seal inspections, ventilation system checks, and spill kit accessibility. Implement quarterly refresher training for all material handlers covering proper handling, storage, and emergency response. Document all findings and corrective actions in audit logs maintained by HSE department.

name: Implement Mandatory Electrical Panel De-Energization Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a blanket engineering control requiring all energized control panel maintenance tasks (above 50V) to include de-energization, lockout/tagout (LOTO), and grounding of all bus bars prior to work initiation. Create laminated, waterproof job permits specific to each high-voltage panel location that must be completed and approved by supervisor before work begins. Integrate this protocol into the preventive maintenance scheduling system to prevent bypassing. This eliminates arc flash hazard at the source.

name: Replace and Laminate Arc Flash Labels
description: Replace all electrical panel arc flash hazard labels with permanent, durable labels meeting NFPA 70E standards. Include photoluminescent elements for visibility in low-light night shift conditions. Add QR codes linking to digital maintenance procedures and hazard information. Schedule replacement across all production line panels within 10 days, starting with Line C. This addresses the root cause of inadequate hazard communication that contributed to the near-miss.

name: Conduct Advanced Electrical Safety Training
description: Schedule comprehensive NFPA 70E electrical safety training for all maintenance technicians and electricians within 30 days. Training will cover arc flash hazard recognition, proper PPE selection and use, LOTO procedures, and incident response. Include hands-on scenario drills with de-energization practices. Require annual refresher training and competency assessments. Maintain training records for compliance with regulatory requirements.

name: Upgrade to Chemical-Resistant Gloves for Clean Room Operations
description: Replace standard nitrile gloves with specialized laminated gloves rated for silicone-based mold release agents in Line C operations. Employees will receive training on proper glove selection and donning/doffing procedures. Gloves will be stored in the clean room in designated dispensers to ensure immediate availability. Quarterly audits will verify compliance with new PPE requirements. This addresses the immediate gap in personal protective equipment effectiveness against the specific chemical hazard identified in the incident.

name: Service and Calibrate Automatic Ejector Pin Cleaning System
description: Conduct comprehensive preventive maintenance on the 250-ton injection molding machine's automatic cleaning cycle. Maintenance technician will inspect spray nozzles, verify chemical concentrate levels, test pressure settings, and check sensor functionality. Establish a new maintenance schedule with weekly function tests and monthly detailed inspections. Document all service activities in the equipment maintenance log. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of residual chemical exposure by ensuring the automatic system functions reliably.

name: Implement Enhanced Chemical Safety Training for Production Line C
description: Develop and deliver specialized training module covering chemical hazards specific to mold release agents, including proper handling, symptoms of exposure, and emergency response procedures. All Line C operators will complete the training within 5 working days. Training will include hands-on demonstration of correct glove application, chemical label reading per WHMIS requirements, and first aid response procedures. Refresher training will be conducted quarterly. This administrative control ensures employees understand the risks and proper response protocols.

name: Establish Mandatory Preventive Maintenance Schedule for All Dryer Units
description: Create and implement a formalized preventive maintenance program requiring calibration of temperature sensors and inspection of heating elements every 60 days for all material dryers. A dedicated calendar-based system will be established in the maintenance management software with automatic notifications. Each dryer unit will have a maintenance logbook documenting all service activities. This engineering control prevents sensor drift and equipment degradation that led to the overheating failure.

name: Install Secondary Temperature Monitoring and Automatic Shutdown System
description: Upgrade the resin dryer with an independent secondary temperature sensor and automatic shutdown valve that functions independently from the primary control system. If temperatures exceed the maximum safe threshold (120°C for this unit type), the secondary system will trigger immediate power cutoff and activate visual/audible alarms. Installation will include testing and verification that both systems function correctly. This dual-layer engineering control ensures that a single sensor failure cannot lead to dangerous overheating conditions.

name: Increase Maintenance Department Staffing and Training
description: Hire one additional full-time maintenance technician and cross-train two production supervisors in basic equipment diagnostics and sensor calibration. All maintenance staff will complete specialized training on the XDR-3000 dryer system and thermal management principles. This addresses the root cause of deferred maintenance due to staffing constraints and ensures adequate personnel to maintain all equipment according to schedule.

name: Implement Mechanical Lift-Assist Equipment in Warehouse Operations
description: Install three pneumatic pallet lifting jacks and two electric material handling carts in the warehouse storage areas. All resin pellet pallets weighing over 20 kilograms will be handled exclusively using mechanical assistance. Equipment will be positioned at convenient locations throughout the warehouse. All warehouse staff will receive hands-on training in proper use of the equipment. This engineering control eliminates the need for manual lifting of heavy loads and directly prevents back injuries from occurring.

name: Reorganize Storage Rack Layout to Eliminate High-Reaching Requirements
description: Reconfigure material storage to ensure all frequently-accessed items are stored between waist and shoulder height (0.75-1.5 meters). Heavy resin pellet pallets will be relocated to lower shelves. Implement a clear labeling system indicating recommended handling method for each pallet (manual vs. mechanical lift). Work with the warehouse team to optimize inventory flow and reduce reaching distances. This administrative/engineering control addresses the ergonomic hazard identified in the incident.

name: Conduct Mandatory Ergonomics and Proper Lifting Technique Refresher Training
description: Deliver comprehensive ergonomics training to all 60 warehouse and materials management personnel. Training will include proper lifting mechanics, identifying hazardous postures, using mechanical assistance equipment, and recognizing early signs of strain injuries. Interactive demonstrations using weights and common materials will be conducted. All employees must pass a practical assessment confirming understanding of proper techniques. Training will be repeated annually and for all new hires. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand safe work practices.

name: Enhanced Machine Guard Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a comprehensive daily inspection checklist for all injection molding machine guards, including visual verification that all interlocking safety guards are properly seated and gap-free. Maintenance technicians will perform weekly detailed inspections using precision measurement tools to ensure guard integrity. A new requirement mandates that Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante must personally verify all guard reinstallations before equipment return to service following any maintenance activity. This engineering control, combined with administrative procedures, directly eliminates the gap that created the pinch point hazard.

name: Maintenance Worker LOTO Verification Training
description: Conduct mandatory retraining for all maintenance personnel (12 technicians) on proper lockout/tagout procedures, specifically emphasizing verification steps before removing temporary barriers or completing work. Training will include machine guard specifications, tolerance testing procedures, and sign-off requirements. Technicians will be required to document each guard verification with photographs and measurements. This administrative control ensures procedures match actual safety requirements and prevents improper reinstallation.

name: Warehouse Floor Debris Management System
description: Establish hourly floor inspection schedules with designated zone monitors responsible for removing any debris, spilled materials, or obstacles from warehouse pathways. Install a centralized quick-sweep station in each warehouse section with specialized cleaning equipment for rapid response to spills or dropped items. Implement a color-coded floor marking system highlighting clear traffic lanes for forklift movement, separated from pedestrian walkways by yellow safety lines and physical barriers. This engineering and administrative control directly eliminates the debris hazard that caused the collision.

name: Forklift Operator Refresher Training and Speed Limits
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all 8 active forklift operators on load stability, emergency braking procedures, and proper response to equipment malfunctions. Implement a maximum 5 mph speed limit in warehouse aisles with proximity alerts installed on all forklifts. Require all operators to complete a weekly obstacle course simulation to practice emergency maneuvering in confined spaces. Install convex mirrors at aisle intersections and equip all forklifts with audible backup alarms. These administrative and engineering controls reduce collision risk through operator skill enhancement and environmental modifications.

name: Storage Rack Stability Audit and Reinforcement
description: Conduct a comprehensive engineering assessment of all 24 storage racks in the warehouse facility by a certified structural engineer. All racks will be inspected for proper bolt torque, cross-bracing integrity, and load rating compliance. Any substandard racks will be reinforced with additional lateral bracing or replaced. Implement a quarterly certification program requiring documented inspection of all rack components. Install load capacity placards on each rack level. This engineering control prevents cascading product falls by ensuring structural integrity and proper load distribution.

name: CNC Machine Chip Deflector Verification System
description: Install permanent mounting brackets and visual indicator pins on all 6 CNC machines in the maintenance workshop to ensure chip deflector shields are properly positioned before operation. Implement a mechanical interlock system that prevents spindle operation if the deflector shield is not fully engaged and locked. Add a clear acrylic protective window behind the deflector shield for additional operator protection. Create a daily pre-operation checklist requiring operators to visually verify and physically test deflector shield positioning. This engineering control eliminates the hazard by making the protective device integral to machine function.

name: Upgrade to High-Impact Protective Eyewear Standard
description: Replace all standard safety glasses in the maintenance workshop and production areas with ANSI Z87.1+ certified high-impact polycarbonate protective eyewear rated for flying particle protection at velocities exceeding 400 fps. Conduct a fit-testing program for all 42 maintenance and production operators. Provide each employee with three replacement pairs to ensure continuous availability of properly maintained eyewear. Establish a quarterly inspection and replacement protocol. All employees will receive training on proper wear and maintenance of eyewear. This PPE enhancement provides increased impact resistance as a secondary control.

name: Implement Preventive Ventilation and Dust Cleaning Schedule
description: Establish a mandatory bi-weekly cleaning schedule for all heating equipment ventilation ducts, filters, and heating elements in Post-Processing units. Deploy a dedicated maintenance technician to inspect and clean dust accumulation every 10 operating days. Install pressure gauges on ventilation filters to trigger automatic alerts when dust buildup reaches critical levels. Integrate this schedule into the predictive maintenance program already in place. All maintenance logs will be documented and reviewed monthly by the HSE committee to ensure compliance and early detection of similar hazards.

name: Upgrade Ventilation Filtration System
description: Replace existing ventilation filters with higher-efficiency HEPA-rated filters designed for plastic and composite dust collection. Install secondary filtration cartridges in series to capture finer particles before they reach heating elements. This engineering control will reduce dust accumulation by approximately 85% based on similar manufacturing environments. Install pressure differential indicators on filter housings to provide real-time monitoring of filter status and maintenance needs.

name: Remove Portable Heaters and Improve Environmental Controls
description: Eliminate all portable electric heaters from manufacturing and storage areas. Install insulated pipe wrapping and zone-based heating controls in the maintenance workshop to maintain safe temperatures without portable heating devices. This elimination control removes the primary ignition source. Coordinate with facilities to upgrade the workshop's permanent heating system to maintain temperatures above 15°C during winter months while maintaining fire safety protocols.

name: Reorganize Hazardous Materials Storage and Create Separation Zones
description: Implement strict three-meter separation zones between flammable solvent storage containers and all potential ignition sources in UNIT-025. Relocate solvent containers to a dedicated fire-rated storage cabinet with secondary containment. Install clear floor markings and signage delineating hazardous material zones. Update the facility layout diagram and conduct training with all maintenance personnel on new storage protocols. Establish a weekly compliance inspection schedule to verify separation distances are maintained.

name: Enhance Fire Prevention Training and Emergency Response Drills
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all employees on fire prevention, proper use of fire extinguishers (PASS technique), and evacuation procedures. Emphasize the dangers of portable heaters and flammable solvent storage. Conduct quarterly fire response drills specifically for maintenance and equipment storage personnel. Create a 'fire safety champion' role rotating among shift supervisors to conduct monthly spot-checks of storage areas for compliance with fire codes and proper equipment placement.

name: Implement Mandatory Guard Reinstallation Verification Protocol
description: Establish a formal checklist-based verification procedure that requires a second supervisor to physically inspect and sign off on complete guard reinstallation before any machine is returned to production. Create a 'Machine Safety Clearance Tag' system that must be placed on each machine after maintenance, confirming all guards are in place. This administrative control prevents machines from operating with incomplete safety systems. Integrate this verification into the shift-start safety briefing where supervisors confirm all guards are installed on their production lines.

name: Upgrade Machine Guards with Interlocked Safety Switches
description: Install interlocked safety switches on the removable guards of all 32 injection molding machines. These engineering controls will electronically prevent machine operation whenever guards are not fully seated and latched. Conduct immediate installation on Line A machines as priority, with phased rollout to Lines B and C over 90 days. This eliminates the possibility of operating machinery with incomplete guards, directly addressing the root cause of this incident.

name: Install Secondary Containment Systems for Chemical Storage
description: Implement spill containment trays and drip pans under all hazardous chemical storage shelves in UNIT-010. The containment systems will be rated for 110% of the largest container volume stored above them. This engineering control directly eliminates the risk of large-scale spills reaching the floor and facility infrastructure. Additionally, all shelving will be reinforced with weight-rated capacity labels and load-limiting stop devices to prevent overloading.

name: Establish Chemical Inventory and Shelf Organization Procedures
description: Develop and implement administrative procedures for chemical storage including maximum weight limits per shelf, required spacing between containers, and quarterly inventory audits. Training will be provided to all personnel with access to UNIT-010. The procedures will include a visual inspection checklist and responsibility matrix. This administrative control ensures ongoing compliance and prevents future overloading incidents.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Chemical Storage Area
description: Install a dedicated mechanical ventilation system with enhanced exhaust capacity in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room to rapidly clear vapor clouds in the event of future spills. The system will include vapor detection sensors that automatically trigger exhaust fans when solvent concentrations exceed safe thresholds. This engineering control will prevent respiratory exposure incidents during chemical emergencies.

name: Implement Comprehensive Preventive Maintenance Schedule for All Hydraulic Systems
description: Develop and implement a preventive maintenance program that includes all hydraulic pumps, seals, and coupling components on injection molding lines. Maintenance will follow manufacturer specifications with pump servicing every 500 operating hours, seal inspections every 250 hours, and quarterly full system fluid analysis. A computerized maintenance tracking system will be deployed to ensure no equipment falls through gaps. This engineering/administrative control will prevent future equipment failures from deferred maintenance.

name: Install Pressure Relief and Spill Containment Under Hydraulic Lines
description: All hydraulic pump assemblies on production lines will be retrofitted with secondary pressure relief valves and spill containment trays. This engineering control ensures that if a seal fails, the system automatically depressurizes and any fluid is contained, preventing electrical hazards and equipment damage. Spill kits will be positioned near each line for rapid cleanup response.

name: Conduct Refresher Training on Equipment Failure Response and LOTO Procedures
