description: All production operators and supervisors will receive refresher training on recognizing early warning signs of hydraulic system failure, proper emergency response protocols, and LOTO procedure execution. Training will include case studies of similar failures and their consequences. This administrative control ensures personnel can rapidly and safely respond to future equipment emergencies.

name: Install Specialized Fire Suppression System for Composite Processing Areas
description: Install a Class D fire suppression system specifically designed for composite fiber and resin fires in UNIT-015. This will include automated dry powder suppression with manual backup systems. The system will be integrated with smoke detection sensors for rapid response. Additionally, all electrical equipment will be relocated to sealed, pressurized enclosures that prevent dust infiltration. This engineering control eliminates the conditions necessary for composite dust fires and provides rapid suppression capability.

name: Implement Strict Housekeeping and Dust Control Program for Composite Areas
description: Establish and enforce a comprehensive housekeeping protocol requiring daily vacuum cleaning of all composite work areas using explosion-proof equipment, sealed storage of all composite materials in labeled fireproof cabinets, and prohibition of open bins or uncovered waste containers. A daily pre-shift inspection checklist will verify compliance. Waste composites will be removed from the facility daily. This administrative control directly eliminates accumulated fuel sources for fires.

name: Upgrade Electrical Equipment Sealing and Maintenance Program
description: All electrical junction boxes, breaker enclosures, and conduit entry points in UNIT-015 will be retrofitted with sealed, gasketed covers and dust-tight cable glands. A quarterly inspection and cleaning schedule will be implemented to verify sealed integrity. All electrical installations will comply with hazardous location (Class II) standards for combustible dust environments. This engineering control prevents dust infiltration into electrical equipment.

name: Provide Advanced Fire Suppression and Composite Fire Training
description: All personnel working in UNIT-015 will receive specialized training on composite material fire behavior, proper use of Class D extinguishing agents, and limitations of standard ABC extinguishers on composite fires. Training will include hands-on drills with specialized equipment. Night shift staff will receive priority training due to reduced personnel availability during emergencies. This administrative control ensures appropriate emergency response capability.

name: Implement Drum Inspection and Sealing Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-transfer inspection checklist for all chemical drums that includes verification of bung cap tightness, external cleanliness, and integrity. All material handlers will be required to physically inspect and hand-tighten bung caps before moving drums. A laminated checklist will be posted at each storage location. Inspections must be documented on a daily log. This addresses the root cause of improper bung seating by introducing a systematic verification process before any drum movement.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Monitoring
description: Install real-time VOC concentration monitors in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room with visual and audible alarms set to alert at 50% of exposure limits. The monitoring system will be connected to the facility's alarm network and recorded in the facility management system. This engineering control ensures early detection of vapor release and allows for immediate evacuation or increased ventilation, preventing vapor exposure incidents.

name: Enhanced Spill Response Training for All Staff
description: Conduct comprehensive spill response training for all production and material handling staff, covering identification of different chemical hazards, proper use of spill kits, evacuation procedures, and personal protective equipment requirements. Training will include hands-on practice with absorbent materials and documentation requirements. Training will be delivered quarterly with annual refresher sessions. This administrative control ensures all staff can respond effectively to future spills and minimizes exposure time.

name: Install Mechanical Interlock on Hopper Vibration System
description: Design and install a mechanical interlock that prevents hopper vibration activation when the access port cover is removed or when a worker's hand sensor detects presence in the danger zone. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of unexpected vibration activation during manual intervention. Additionally, install a lockout/tagout point on the vibration system motor to allow complete energy isolation during maintenance and clearing operations. This is the primary control addressing the root cause.

name: Implement Proximity Sensor Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly functional test and calibration schedule for all proximity sensors on injection molding equipment. Create a maintenance log tracking test dates, results, and any sensor replacements. Train maintenance technicians on proper sensor testing procedures. This administrative control ensures sensors function reliably and prevents unexpected equipment activation. Schedule testing for the first Monday of each quarter to ensure consistent compliance.

name: Mandatory Use of Mechanical Clearing Tools with Enforcement
description: Issue individual mechanical clearing tool kits to each injection molding line operator with specific tool designs for each common blockage type. Implement a tool checkout system where operators must check out tools before shift start and return them after use. Post visual standard work instructions at each hopper showing only approved mechanical clearing methods. Supervisors will conduct daily toolbox talks reinforcing never reaching into hoppers manually. Non-compliance results in immediate corrective action. This administrative control through enforcement eliminates reliance on manual intervention.

name: Install IBC Temperature and Environmental Monitoring System
description: Deploy wireless temperature and humidity sensors on all intermediate bulk containers storing reactive chemicals. Sensors will transmit real-time data to the facility management system with automated alerts if temperature exceeds ±5°C from the established storage range. System will log all temperature excursions for trending analysis. This engineering control prevents thermal stress-induced degradation of container integrity by providing early warning of environmental fluctuations, allowing corrective action before container failure occurs.

name: Construct Shaded IBC Storage Shelter with Passive Thermal Control
description: Design and construct a covered storage structure for all IBCs containing temperature-sensitive materials. The shelter will include reflective roofing material, forced ventilation for air circulation, and thermal insulation to maintain temperatures within ±3°C of ambient indoor conditions. Shelving will include secondary containment trays rated to 110% of the largest IBC volume. This engineering control eliminates the primary root cause of direct solar exposure and thermal cycling, preventing container degradation and extending IBC service life.

name: Install Secondary Containment System
description: Implement secondary containment trays beneath all solvent storage containers in the Raw Materials Warehouse. The trays will have a capacity of at least 110% of the largest container volume to prevent spills from spreading across the floor. Containment will include absorbent materials and fire-resistant barriers. This eliminates the risk of spilled solvents reaching electrical equipment and ignition sources.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Ventilation System
description: Install dedicated mechanical ventilation with explosion-proof fans in the solvent storage section of the warehouse to maintain air circulation and prevent vapor accumulation. Ventilation will be upgraded to meet or exceed NFPA 70 standards for hazardous locations. System will include CO2 detection alarms that trigger when flammable vapor concentrations exceed 10% of lower explosive limit.

name: Schedule Preventive Valve Maintenance Program
description: Establish quarterly inspection and maintenance program for all chemical storage container valves and connections. Technicians will check for corrosion, leaks, and proper sealing, with replacement of corroded components every 12 months. Documentation of all inspections will be maintained. This addresses the root cause of the incident—corrosion-induced valve failure.

name: Install Interlocked Safety Guards on All CNC Machines
description: Install fixed perimeter guards with electrical interlocks on all 6 CNC milling machines in the maintenance workshop. Interlocks will automatically stop spindle rotation when guards are opened. Adjustments requiring access to the cutting area will require full machine shutdown and lockout. This engineering control directly prevents hand contact with rotating tools.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Certification Renewal
description: Conduct refresher training on Lockout/Tagout procedures for all personnel operating CNC equipment. Training will emphasize the requirement to fully de-energize and lockout machines before ANY adjustment, regardless of perceived duration. Each technician must pass a competency assessment. Monthly audits will verify compliance through unannounced workplace observations. Certificate renewal required annually.

name: Upgrade CNC Machine PPE Requirements
description: Require all CNC operators to wear cut-resistant gloves rated ANSI A4 or higher, in addition to existing safety glasses and hearing protection. Gloves must be fitted during each shift and inspected for damage. PPE storage and replacement procedures will be clearly posted at each machine station. While not the primary control, enhanced PPE provides supplementary protection.

name: Install Mechanical Lifting Equipment
description: Install two pneumatic lift tables and one mobile articulating arm lift in the Raw Materials Warehouse finishing area. Equipment will be sized to handle loads up to 25 kg and positioned at ergonomic heights (elbow level when standing). All finishing operators will receive training on proper equipment operation. This eliminates the need for manual lifting of heavy composite panels above waist height.

name: Enhance Warehouse Lighting System
description: Upgrade night shift lighting in the finishing and packing area from 100 lux to 500 lux minimum illumination using LED fixtures with motion sensors. Improved lighting will reduce slip/trip hazards and improve visibility for safe material handling. Install task lighting at work stations for detailed inspection work. This addresses the secondary contributing factor of inadequate visibility.

name: Conduct Ergonomic Training and Assessment
description: Bring in an external ergonomics consultant to conduct individual assessments for all warehouse staff. Training will cover proper lifting techniques (load assessment, spine alignment, leg power), load weight limits, and when to request assistance. Ergonomic posters will be installed at all work stations. Workers will be trained to request job rotation after 4 hours of repetitive lifting tasks. Annual refresher training will be required.

name: Implement Quarterly Pressure Regulator Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a formal preventive maintenance program for all compressed air pressure regulators across production lines. Schedule quarterly inspections and annual replacements by qualified maintenance technicians. This will ensure pressure regulators remain within specification and prevent sudden pressure surges. Documentation will be maintained in the predictive maintenance system with alerts generated 2 weeks before service dates. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie will oversee implementation and track compliance through monthly audits.

name: Provide Compressed Air Safety Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training module on safe compressed air practices for all production operators, focusing on pressure regulator inspection, proper tool usage, and recognition of equipment malfunction indicators. Training will include hands-on demonstration of correct pressure settings and safe cleaning procedures. All operators must complete certification before returning to compressed air equipment use. Sessions will be conducted quarterly for new employees and annually as refresher training.

name: Install Automated Spool Transfer System
description: Replace manual spool handling with a semi-automated transfer system featuring pneumatic lifts and ergonomic positioning cradles that adjust to optimal working heights (waist to shoulder level). The new system will eliminate the need for overhead reaching and reduce manual load per operator from 35 kg to maximum 5 kg handling. Installation will include relocating the storage rack to accommodate the new equipment. This engineering control directly eliminates the root cause of back strain injuries.

name: Mandatory Ergonomic Assessment and Training Program
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessments of all material handling tasks in the Regrind and Recycling Department using methodologies from the company's ISO 45001 implementation. Provide individualized training to all operators on proper lifting techniques, load calculation, and recognition of hazardous work postures. Implement a buddy system requiring peer verification of correct techniques. Alain Mercier will lead quarterly reassessments and provide updated training protocols based on incident trends and near-miss reports.

name: Redesign Storage Rack Configuration and Implement Load Limits
description: Reduce maximum stack height from 1.8 m to 1.2 m on fiber spool racks and implement clear weight capacity labeling visible from multiple angles. Install physical stops to prevent overstacking. Add color-coded zone markings to indicate the safe manual reach zone (waist to shoulder height). This administrative control combined with physical redesign will prevent future overhead reaching incidents and enforce compliance through visual management.

name: Upgrade CNC Machine with Proximity Sensor Failsafe System
description: Install redundant safety systems on all CNC milling machines including dual-circuit emergency stop buttons, mechanical spindle brakes, and hardwired proximity sensors that prevent spindle restart when access covers are open or when hand-presence detection devices are triggered. These engineering controls will create a physical barrier preventing inadvertent machine startup regardless of operator action. All 8 CNC machines in the shop will be retrofitted with these systems over 45 days.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Compliance Verification Program
description: Establish a strict verification system requiring a second technician to confirm proper LOTO application before any maintenance begins. Create visual LOTO checklists and place them directly on each machine. Implement a digital log system recording which technicians applied LOTO and when. Conduct unannounced compliance audits weekly for the first month, then monthly thereafter. Any non-compliance results in mandatory re-training before returning to maintenance duties. Serge Lafleur will oversee the audits and maintain compliance documentation.

name: Provide Advanced LOTO and Machine Guarding Certification
description: All maintenance technicians must complete an intensive 16-hour advanced LOTO certification course delivered by an external certified safety professional. Training will include case studies of similar incidents, hands-on practice with various locking mechanisms, and scenario-based decision-making for different equipment types. Certification must be renewed annually. Additional training on CNC-specific hazards and manufacturer-recommended maintenance procedures will be provided within 30 days of incident.

name: Mandatory LOTO Audit and Retraining Program
description: Implement comprehensive lockout/tagout audit across all injection molding lines within 7 days. All operators and maintenance personnel must complete recertification training emphasizing consequences of bypassing interlocks. Establish daily pre-shift verification checklist confirming all interlocks are functional and no bypasses exist. Supervisors will conduct weekly audits with documentation. Non-compliance will result in immediate suspension from equipment operation.

name: Install Redundant Mold Safety Interlocks
description: Upgrade all injection molding machines on Line C with secondary mechanical interlocks that cannot be bypassed without documented authorization and supervisor sign-off. Install pressure relief valves that automatically vent residual pressure when mold opens. Implement electronic monitoring system that logs all interlock status changes and alerts supervisors to any bypass attempts in real-time.

name: Enhanced Machine Guarding and Access Controls
description: Install fixed perimeter guards around mold injection points on all production lines, eliminating direct hand access to mold cavities during operation. Redesign maintenance procedures to require pressure release and cooling cycles before any mold access. Provide specialized extraction tools for retrieving stuck components without hand insertion. Train all personnel on new extraction procedures and conduct quarterly refresher sessions.

name: Enhanced Floor Maintenance and Drainage System
description: Install permanent drainage channels along dock areas to eliminate water pooling. Upgrade flooring to anti-slip composite material rated for wet conditions in high-traffic loading zones. Establish post-cleaning inspection protocol requiring 30-minute dry time before resuming equipment operations. Place additional wet floor signage at all entry points and require cleaning staff to use absorbent materials that eliminate standing water rather than just mopping.

name: Operator Training and Speed Restrictions
description: Implement mandatory refresher training for all powered pallet jack operators focusing on wet surface operation, load stability assessment, and emergency stopping techniques. Reduce maximum speed in dock areas from 8 km/h to 5 km/h and install speed governors on all units. Require operators to visually inspect floor conditions before operation and wait for clearance from floor supervisors after any maintenance activities.

name: Preventive Maintenance Schedule and Temperature Monitoring
description: Implement quarterly preventive maintenance inspections of all resin dryers, including thermostat calibration verification and heating element resistance testing. Install continuous temperature data logging system with automatic alerts if temperatures exceed 285°C. Replace thermostats that exceed 5 years of service or show ±5°C calibration drift. Establish daily log requirement for equipment operators to record temperature readings at start of each shift and any anomalies observed.

name: Upgrade Dryer Control Systems with Redundant Safety Features
description: Replace manual thermostat systems on all resin dryers with PLC-based control systems featuring dual temperature sensors and automatic shutoff at 295°C. Install pressure relief valves and thermal cutoff switches independent of the main control system. Add visual and audible alarms that activate at 280°C to alert operators before critical temperature is reached. Provide backup power to alarm systems to ensure notification even during electrical failures.

name: Install Real-Time Temperature Monitoring System on Molding Lines
description: Implement automated temperature sensors with real-time dashboard monitoring and alert system on all four injection molding lines. System will automatically trigger shutdown and operator alert if temperatures deviate beyond ±2°C from specified parameters. Integrate with existing quality management system for automatic batch flagging and traceability. This eliminates the risk of undetected temperature deviations causing part contamination or non-compliance. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of temperature-related defects and improved first-pass quality rate by 3-5%.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Temperature Control Systems
description: Develop and implement quarterly preventive maintenance protocols for all thermostats, temperature sensors, and cooling systems on injection molding equipment. Create maintenance checklist including sensor calibration verification, thermostat function testing, and cooling line inspection. Assign responsibility to Roland Dostie (Maintenance Planner) with monthly audits by HSE. Training required for all maintenance personnel on new procedures. This administrative control ensures early detection of equipment degradation before failures impact production quality.

name: Enforce Safety Glasses Requirement During All Equipment Cleaning Operations
description: Issue mandatory safety alert requiring ANSI Z87.1 certified safety glasses with side shields for all personnel performing hopper cleaning, compressed air operations, or equipment maintenance. Update SOP to explicitly prohibit directed compressed air use without proper eye protection and machine isolation. Conduct toolbox talks at start of each shift emphasizing the risk of projectile plastic granules. Place visual reminders at all hopper work stations. This engineering and administrative control directly prevents eye injuries from flying particles during routine maintenance tasks.

name: Replace Corroded Safety Guard Fasteners with Stainless Steel Hardware
description: Immediately replace all carbon steel bolts, washers, and fasteners on the regrind shredder safety guard assemblies with 304 stainless steel equivalents to eliminate corrosion-induced failures. Inspect all similar equipment throughout the facility for corroded fastening hardware and implement replacement program. Establish quarterly inspection protocol to verify fastener integrity and corrosion status. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the guard failure by replacing susceptible materials with corrosion-resistant alternatives.

name: Implement Mandatory Guard Reinstallation Verification Procedure
description: Require all maintenance personnel to complete a guard verification checklist following any equipment maintenance or repair involving guard removal. Checklist must include: visual inspection of fasteners, torque testing of bolts to specification, and documented sign-off by supervisor before equipment restart. Provide laminated reference cards at all equipment stations showing proper guard installation and fastener torque specifications. Conduct monthly audits of guard security status on all regrind and processing equipment. This administrative control ensures proper reinstallation procedures are followed consistently.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Pressure Testing
description: Establish a comprehensive quarterly preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic systems on injection molding machines. This includes pressure testing at 110% operational load, inspection of seals and hoses for degradation, and replacement of hydraulic fluid per manufacturer specifications. A certified hydraulics technician will perform audits and maintain detailed logs. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of equipment failure by identifying weakened components before catastrophic rupture. Expected outcome: reduction in hydraulic-related incidents by 95% and extended equipment life by 30%.

name: Install Secondary Fire Containment Barriers Around Hydraulic Equipment
description: Engineer and install removable polycarbonate fire containment barriers (18 inches high, stainless steel frames) around all injection molding machines with high-pressure hydraulic systems. These barriers will contain fluid spray and direct it away from electrical components and material storage. Additionally, install emergency shutoff valves within 18 inches of each operator station. Training will cover manual activation procedures during equipment failure. This engineering control prevents secondary fires and reduces fluid spray dispersion. Expected outcome: containment of 99% of hydraulic fluid in future ruptures.

name: Implement Chemical Container Integrity Management System
description: Establish a comprehensive container inspection and rotation protocol requiring all chemical storage drums to be inspected every 12 months for corrosion, weld integrity, and structural damage. Implement a 'first-in-first-out' (FIFO) inventory system with clear dating labels on all drums. Replace any containers showing signs of degradation immediately. Create a digital database tracking drum age, inspection dates, and storage location. This administrative control ensures containers are maintained in safe condition. Expected outcome: elimination of container-related chemical spills and reduction of environmental contamination incidents by 100%.

name: Install Secondary Containment Sump with Real-Time Monitoring
description: Engineer and install an integrated secondary containment system beneath the chemical storage area with capacity for 110% of the largest single container volume. The containment includes a sloped concrete floor, stainless steel collection trench, and a sump pump system with level sensors and alarm notifications. Install real-time electronic monitoring that alerts staff when fluid levels exceed 20% of sump capacity. Additionally, seal the connection between facility stormwater drains and the sump to prevent chemical release into municipal systems. This engineering control eliminates environmental discharge of chemical spills. Expected outcome: zero environmental contamination incidents from chemical storage.

name: Conduct Chemical Safety Training and VOC Monitoring Procedures
description: Deliver mandatory retraining to all personnel working in chemical storage and adjacent areas on proper chemical handling, spill response, and VOC exposure symptoms. Implement a new procedure requiring portable VOC detection equipment to be used weekly in storage areas and daily following any spill incident. Establish exposure thresholds that trigger evacuation protocols and ventilation system activation. Create quick-reference guides posted at all chemical handling stations. This administrative control ensures early detection and proper response. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in employee exposure to harmful vapors.

name: Upgrade Intermediate Bulk Container (IBC) Storage and Labeling Standards
description: Implement a containerization standard requiring all IBCs to be stored in designated stainless steel drip containment trays with integrated secondary spill capture. Install permanent, laminated multi-language labels on all containers with QR code tracking connected to a real-time inventory management system. Require all containers to be positioned with valves facing accessible areas and protective caps installed when not in active use. Establish a quarterly visual inspection protocol with photographic documentation. This engineering and administrative control eliminates uncertainty about container contents. Expected outcome: 100% container identification accuracy and zero mislabeling-related incidents.

name: Enhance Warehouse Infrastructure with Spill Prevention and Containment
description: Engineer improvements to the warehouse foundation including sealing of cracks and gaps that allow environmental penetration, installation of engineered drainage channels directed to a dedicated spill recovery system rather than natural soil drainage, and placement of absorbent containment mats beneath all chemical container storage areas. Install elevated storage platforms with integrated sumps for all hazardous liquid containers. Add secondary containment barriers in high-traffic forklift areas to separate container storage from movement zones. This engineering control eliminates soil and groundwater contamination pathways. Expected outcome: zero soil and groundwater contamination events.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all hydraulic pump assemblies and pressure relief valves. Conduct monthly inspections of seal integrity, lubrication levels, and pressure readings on all injection molding lines. Create a maintenance log tracking all service intervals. Train all maintenance technicians on early warning signs of hydraulic system degradation including unusual noises, temperature anomalies, and pressure fluctuations. This engineering/administrative control addresses the root cause of inadequate preventive maintenance and seal deterioration.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Pressure Release Safety
description: Install dual redundant pressure relief valves with automatic lockout capability on all injection molding line hydraulic systems. Add pressure monitoring sensors connected to the plant's safety alert system that trigger automatic machine shutdown if pressure exceeds safe operating parameters. Install secondary containment trays beneath all high-pressure hydraulic components to capture any fluid releases. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of catastrophic pressure relief and uncontrolled fluid release.

name: Enhanced Thermal Burn PPE Requirements
description: Require all maintenance technicians working on hydraulic systems to wear specialized heat-resistant sleeves rated for 200°C minimum and aluminized proximity suits during high-pressure system work. Conduct quarterly refresher training on proper donning/doffing of thermal protection equipment. This administrative/PPE control provides additional protection while engineering measures are being implemented.

name: Implement Chemical Container Pressure Relief Engineering
description: Replace all pressurized mold release agent containers with engineered pressure-relief versions featuring dual-stage depressurization mechanisms. Install pressure relief devices calibrated to release internal pressure gradually over 30 seconds minimum. Retrofit existing inventory of concentrate containers with pressure relief caps meeting ISO 1234 standards. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of sudden pressurized liquid spray.

name: Mandatory Chemical Splash Protection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory policy requiring all personnel handling pressurized chemical containers to wear full-face chemical splash shields with integrated goggles, nitrile gloves, and respiratory protection (half-mask cartridge respirator rated for organic vapors). Conduct monthly competency assessments ensuring proper donning/doffing and inspection of PPE. Install larger secondary containment trays (minimum 110% container volume) beneath all chemical mixing and storage areas.

name: Eliminate Solvent Storage in High-Temperature Areas
description: Implement a facility-wide policy prohibiting storage of flammable solvents (acetone, isopropanol) within 5 meters of any equipment operating above 100°C. Relocate all solvent containers to a dedicated, ventilated chemical storage cabinet located in the main warehouse area with proper fire-rating. Establish a controlled checkout system requiring technicians to request only the quantity of solvent needed for immediate tasks. This elimination control removes the primary ignition source hazard.

name: Install Class B Fire Suppression Equipment
description: Replace water-based fire extinguishers in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area with ABC and Class B dry powder extinguishers rated for flammable liquid fires. Install four additional CO2 extinguishers at strategic locations around heat treatment equipment. Conduct mandatory fire extinguisher training for all personnel assigned to this area, including hands-on practice annually. Post large, visible signage identifying correct extinguisher types for different fire classes. Upgrade the automatic Halon suppression system inspection interval from annually to semi-annually.

name: Implement Flammable Material Storage and Handling Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive standard operating procedure for handling, storage, and use of flammable solvents at all workstations. Require all containers to be kept closed when not actively in use. Install secondary containment trays rated for 110% of the maximum volume stored in any location. Mandate training on flammable material hazards and proper storage techniques for all technicians. Conduct monthly audits of solvent storage compliance. Implement a permit-to-work system for any hot work operations involving solvents within 10 meters.

name: Install Temperature Warning Labels on Mold Zones
description: Apply high-visibility warning labels with temperature ranges and cooling time requirements on all injection molding machines in Production Line B. Labels will be positioned at operator eye level and include both French and English text. Additionally, install infrared thermometers at each workstation to allow operators to verify mold temperature before part removal. This engineering control will reduce the likelihood of thermal contact incidents by providing clear visual and measurement-based guidance.

name: Implement Mandatory Cool-Down Interval Enforcement
description: Reprogram the injection molding machine controllers on Line B to enforce a mandatory 2-minute cooling period after each cycle completion. The machine interface will display a countdown timer and prevent the mold from opening until the interval completes. Operators will receive refresher training on the importance of this control and the safety rationale behind it. This administrative/engineering control combination eliminates operator discretion to override safety protocols.

name: Establish Segregated Pedestrian and Vehicle Traffic Zones
description: Implement permanent yellow painted lines throughout the warehouse and shipping areas to create dedicated pedestrian pathways that are physically separated from forklift and vehicle traffic corridors. Install reflective signage at all intersection points with clear directional indicators. Paint crossings at designated zones only, marked with stop signs for vehicle operators. This engineering control eliminates conflicts between equipment and foot traffic by creating clear, segregated movement areas that prevent simultaneous occupancy of high-risk zones.

name: Install Audible Warning Systems on All Material Handling Equipment
description: Retrofit all forklifts and powered material handling equipment with backup alarms, forward motion warning beepers, and proximity sensors that activate horn systems when equipment is within 5 meters of pedestrian zones or obstacles. Test all systems monthly and maintain maintenance logs. Operators will receive training on system functionality and limitations. This engineering control provides acoustic warnings to pedestrians and equipment operators, reducing blind spot incidents by alerting nearby workers to equipment presence and movement.

name: Implement Mandatory Spotter System for High-Risk Materials Transport
description: Establish an administrative control requiring a dedicated spotter for all forklift movements when transporting loads that obstruct the operator's forward or side vision. Spotters will complete a 2-hour training course covering hand signals, positioning requirements, and communication protocols. A laminated reference card will be mounted on each forklift showing approved signals. Supervisors will enforce the spotter requirement through daily pre-shift briefings and shift audits. This administrative control ensures a second set of eyes monitors each high-visibility load movement.

name: Implement Color-Coded Waste Segregation System
description: Establish a comprehensive waste segregation protocol using color-coded containers: red for contaminated solvent waste, blue for inert plastic scrap, yellow for metal waste, and clear for clean recyclable materials. Each container will have large, multilingual labels identifying contents and hazard information. All waste streams will be tracked through a digital logging system. Staff will complete initial training followed by quarterly refresher sessions. This engineering/administrative hybrid control eliminates cross-contamination of waste streams at the source, preventing hazardous mixing and reducing spill risks.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Hazardous Waste Staging
description: Install secondary containment trays with 110% capacity relative to the largest single waste container beneath all temporary hazardous waste staging areas in the Regrind Department. Trays will feature sloped surfaces directing spills to a central sump point. All waste handling will occur within these contained areas. Emergency absorbent material dispensers will be mounted within 3 meters of all staging zones. Staff will receive training on the importance of containment compliance. This engineering control prevents environmental release of hazardous materials by capturing spills at the source.

name: Establish Night Shift Hazardous Waste Handler Certification
description: Require all night shift operators who handle or dispose of waste materials to complete a 4-hour hazardous waste handling certification course covering waste identification, segregation protocols, spill response procedures, and PPE requirements. Certification must be renewed annually. A roster of certified handlers will be posted at all waste staging areas and work assignments will ensure a certified handler is always present. Documentation of training completion will be maintained in employee files. This administrative control ensures night shift personnel have adequate knowledge to handle hazardous materials safely.

name: Implement Drum Transport and Handling Protocol
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive drum handling procedure requiring: (1) pre-transport inspection of all drum closures and seals, (2) use of specialized drum transport carts with secondary containment trays to capture leaks up to 110% of drum volume, (3) designated spill-free transport routes away from storm drains and production areas, (4) training certification for all personnel handling hazardous materials containers. This administrative control will reduce spill incidents by establishing standardized safe practices and accountability.

name: Install Secondary Containment System in Hazardous Waste Area
description: Install a dedicated secondary containment area with impermeable flooring, curbed containment basin with minimum 110% drum capacity, and integrated emergency eyewash/shower station. This engineering control will prevent hazardous materials from reaching soil or water systems and provide immediate first-aid access for chemical exposure incidents. Design to meet Quebec environmental and CNESST requirements.

name: Quarterly Equipment Maintenance and Drum Inspection Audit
description: Establish a quarterly maintenance schedule to inspect and test all drum closure systems, transport equipment, and containment infrastructure. Maintenance records will be logged and reviewed by the Health, Safety and Environment team. Any deteriorated or faulty equipment will be immediately removed from service. This preventive measure ensures equipment reliability and identifies potential failure points before incidents occur.

name: Establish Hazardous Fluid Storage Standards in Maintenance Areas
description: Implement a facility-wide policy requiring all hazardous fluids (coolants, oils, solvents) to be stored in properly sealed, labeled containers with secure lids placed in designated secondary containment cabinets. Restrict quantities of open or partially-sealed containers to minimal working amounts (maximum one shift's supply). All containers must be clearly labeled with contents, hazard warnings, and WHMIS information. This administrative control prevents spills at the source and ensures proper handling protocols are followed.

name: Install Anti-Slip Secondary Containment in Maintenance Workshop
description: Install anti-slip, oil-resistant flooring panels and spill containment trays beneath all workbenches where hazardous fluids are used or stored. Add a centralized absorbent spill kit station with high-visibility signage and quick-access cleanup materials. Train all maintenance personnel on proper spill response procedures. This engineering control minimizes slip hazards and provides rapid response capability to contain spills before they spread to electrical equipment.

name: Replace Emergency Stop Button and Guarding on Machine #7
description: Immediately replace the degraded E-stop button assembly with a new ISO 13850-compliant emergency stop device featuring confirmed tactile feedback and <5ms signal transmission. Simultaneously replace the cracked polycarbonate guarding panels with reinforced, optical-grade materials that meet current injection molding safety standards. This engineering control restores critical safety functionality and eliminates the risk of uncontrolled machine operation or ejection hazards.

name: Implement Quarterly E-Stop Function Testing Program
description: Establish a formal quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all emergency stop systems across the facility. Each injection molding machine E-stop will be tested using an automated testing device that verifies signal transmission time, tactile feedback, and circuit continuity. Results will be logged in the CMMS system with automatic alerts for units approaching maintenance intervals. Maintenance technicians will complete certification training on E-stop testing protocols. This administrative control ensures continuous compliance with safety standards and identifies failing components before they pose operational risk.

name: Conduct Safety Equipment Audit on All Injection Molding Lines
description: Perform a comprehensive facility-wide inspection of emergency stop systems, machine guarding, interlocks, and light curtains on all 32 injection molding machines. Document current condition, testing dates, and maintenance history for each unit. Prioritize remediation based on risk assessment. Schedule equipment replacement and repairs in phases over the next 90 days. This preventive measure identifies systemic maintenance gaps and proactively mitigates machine-related hazards across all production lines.

name: Implement Mandatory Interlock Re-enablement Verification
description: Establish a formal tag-out/tag-in procedure requiring maintenance personnel to physically verify interlock functionality and provide documented confirmation to production supervisors before allowing any equipment operation. Install visual status indicators on all molding machines showing real-time interlock status. Conduct monthly audits of interlock functionality across all production lines. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of unguarded machine access during maintenance by making safety status transparent and verifiable.

name: Enhanced LOTO Training and Accountability Program
description: Develop comprehensive lockout/tagout training module specific to interlock systems with quarterly refresher sessions. Implement a tracking system requiring all maintenance staff to complete annual LOTO certification with practical testing. Assign specific LOTO responsibilities with individual accountability. Create consequence protocols for bypassing safety interlocks. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand proper procedures and consequences.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Upgraded Shelving Systems
description: Replace all chemical storage shelving with heavy-duty secondary containment units designed to hold 110% of largest container volume. Install crash-rated bollards around critical storage areas to prevent forklift impact damage. Use non-flammable shelving materials and ensure all units are grounded to prevent static electricity accumulation. This engineering control eliminates potential spills and reduces fire ignition sources by physically preventing container ruptures.

name: Chemical Segregation and Inventory Management Protocol
description: Implement segregated storage zones using chemical compatibility matrix system. Store solvents separately from oxidizers and other reactive materials. Establish maximum storage quantities for flammable liquids and rotation schedule. Create digital inventory system with real-time tracking and automated low-stock alerts. Conduct quarterly chemical audits for proper labeling and container integrity. This administrative control reduces fire hazard through proper chemical management.

name: Comprehensive Electrical System and Ventilation Maintenance
description: Conduct full electrical system inspection with thermographic imaging to identify overheating junction boxes and faulty relays. Replace deteriorated electrical components with modern units featuring fail-safe designs. Service ventilation system with complete ductwork cleaning and filter replacement. Establish preventive maintenance schedule with monthly inspections during high-risk periods. This engineering control eliminates ignition sources and ensures adequate vapor removal.

name: Transition to Latex-Free PPE Program
description: Eliminate all latex-containing gloves from inventory and transition to nitrile and non-latex alternatives suitable for chemical handling. Conduct workforce survey to identify additional latex sensitivities. Stock multiple glove types (nitrile, vinyl, synthetic rubber) at each workstation. Provide alternative glove options in first aid kits and emergency response areas. This PPE upgrade eliminates latex allergy hazard while maintaining hand protection. Expected outcome: complete elimination of latex-related allergic incidents.

name: Pre-Shift PPE Inspection and Integrity Verification
description: Implement mandatory pre-shift glove inspection protocol requiring operators to visually examine gloves for tears, holes, or degradation before use. Create laminated inspection checklist posted at each workstation. Establish requirement to replace gloves immediately upon detection of damage. Train all employees on proper glove removal and replacement procedures. Implement supervisor spot-checks during first 30 minutes of shift. This administrative control ensures only intact protective equipment is used.

name: Implement Quarterly Chemical Transfer Equipment Inspection Program
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all chemical transfer equipment including hose assemblies, pump connections, and manifolds. Inspections will be conducted every 90 days by maintenance technicians and documented in the CMMS system. All hose connections will be checked for wear, corrosion, and proper tightening. Equipment showing signs of deterioration will be immediately replaced. This addresses the root cause of loose connections and reduces future spill risk by 85%.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment and Install Drip Trays
description: Replace damaged secondary containment tray with a larger capacity unit (25-liter minimum) rated for isopropanol and other solvents. Install individual drip trays under all chemical transfer stations to catch minor leaks before they become larger spills. Add absorbent granule dispensers at each location and train all personnel in their use. This engineering control eliminates the potential for floor-level spills from spreading uncontrollably.

name: Mandatory Chemical Transfer Safety Training
description: Develop and deliver a 90-minute training module covering proper hose connection techniques, equipment inspection, spill response procedures, and emergency protocols. All personnel involved in chemical handling will complete this training within 30 days. Annual refresher training will be mandatory. Training will include practical demonstrations of proper connection procedures and hands-on spill containment practice using non-hazardous materials.

name: Replace Safety Interlocks on All Grinding Equipment
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all regrind machinery safety interlocks across the department. Replace three aging grinding machines with updated models featuring redundant interlock systems that meet current CSA Z432 standards. Install pressure-sensitive mats and electronic proximity sensors on equipment access doors to provide dual-layer protection. All replacements will be completed within 60 days. This engineering control eliminates the single-point-of-failure vulnerability identified in the near-miss.

name: Enhance Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Interlock Systems
description: Develop a monthly inspection protocol specifically for safety interlocks, separate from general equipment maintenance. Maintenance technicians will perform physical function testing, wear assessment, and documentation for all grinding machine doors. A threshold system will flag interlocks requiring replacement before failure occurs. This administrative control ensures early detection of wear patterns and prevents safety system failures.

name: Install Dual-Redundant Proximity Sensor Systems on All Molding Lines
description: Retrofit all 12 injection molding machines with dual-channel safety-rated proximity sensors that monitor operator presence during mold closing cycles. Each sensor will operate independently with automatic shutdown capability. Sensors will be certified to ISO 13849-1 PLd performance level. Installation includes new control logic modules and comprehensive testing. This engineering control provides fail-safe protection by requiring both sensors to confirm mold readiness before closing. Implementation timeline: 45 days. Expected to reduce mold-related injuries by 95%.

name: Establish Monthly Safety Sensor Testing and Calibration Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory monthly testing program for all proximity sensors and timing controls on injection molding equipment. Maintenance technicians will use certified testing equipment to verify sensor response times and accuracy. Any sensor showing drift or degradation will be immediately replaced. A computerized tracking system will log all tests and maintenance actions. This administrative control ensures sensors remain within safe operating parameters and identifies failing sensors before they cause incidents.

name: Mandatory Machine Safeguarding and Mold Operation Retraining
description: Develop and deliver a comprehensive 4-hour training program covering injection molding safety, sensor functionality, proper part removal techniques, and emergency stop procedures. All operators on Lines A, B, and C will complete this training within 21 days. Training includes video demonstrations, equipment walkthroughs, and hands-on practice. Annual refresher training will be required. Special emphasis will be placed on recognizing sensor malfunctions and safe part extraction procedures that minimize hand exposure to closing mechanisms.

name: Install Static Grounding Equipment
description: Install permanent bonding cables and grounding clips on all chemical transfer stations in the mixing room. These will ensure continuous electrical path to ground during liquid transfers, eliminating static charge accumulation. Implement monthly inspection and testing protocols using a multimeter to verify grounding resistance is below 1 megohm. Training will be provided to all chemical handling personnel on proper grounding procedures before any resin or solvent transfer.

name: Enhanced Chemical Storage Segregation
description: Reorganize chemical storage layout to separate flammable solvents (acetone, methylene chloride) into dedicated fireproof storage cabinet with secondary containment. Implement new inventory management system with maximum quantity limits based on daily usage. Install temperature monitoring sensors to alert if storage area exceeds 25°C. This eliminates proximity hazard that allowed fire to spread between incompatible chemicals.

name: Chemical Handling Safety Training Refresh
description: Mandate recertification training for all employees handling chemicals in mixing operations. Training will cover static electricity hazards, proper grounding procedures, incompatible chemical storage, emergency response protocols, and use of fire suppression equipment. Schedule training within 30 days with quarterly refresher sessions. Attendance will be tracked and made a prerequisite for chemical handling assignments.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Procedures for All Mold Work
description: Establish and enforce lockout/tagout protocols requiring that injection molding machines be de-energized, locked, and tagged before any maintenance or cleaning operations. Install mechanical lockout hasps on main power disconnect switches and thermal heater control circuits. Provide laminated LOTO procedure cards at each machine station. Conduct hands-on LOTO certification training for all Line B operators and maintenance technicians. Establish weekly LOTO compliance audits with corrective action for any non-compliance.

name: Install Thermal Insulation Guards on Mold Cavities
description: Design and fabricate protective thermal insulation barriers or guards that can be positioned over mold cavities during cleaning operations. These removable guards will prevent direct contact with hot mold surfaces and reduce heat transfer. Install temperature indicator stickers on all molds to provide visual warning when surface exceeds safe handling temperature (120°C). Train operators on use and proper positioning of these guards.

name: Enhanced Thermal Burn First Aid and PPE Requirements
description: Require all mold maintenance workers to wear cut-resistant thermal gloves rated for 200°C and protective arm sleeves during any mold-contact operations. Stock specialized burn treatment kits at each production line with ice packs, sterile burn dressings, and cooling gel. Conduct quarterly first aid training with emphasis on thermal burn response including proper cooling procedures and emergency transport protocols.

name: Establish Aisle Markings and Storage Protocol
description: Paint yellow and white lane markings on all warehouse and dock floors indicating designated forklift travel paths with 1.5-meter clear zones on both sides. Install wall-mounted signage prohibiting storage of materials or pallets within marked clearance zones. Create and distribute an aisle map to all personnel showing approved storage locations and travel corridors. Conduct monthly audits to verify compliance and address violations with immediate corrective action.

name: Forklift Load Stability Assessment and Load Securing Improvements
description: Implement mandatory load stability checks before any movement, including verification of center of gravity and proper pallet positioning. Upgrade to enhanced load containing straps and corner protectors for high-value composite parts to prevent shifting during transport. Train all forklift operators on load balancing techniques and maximum safe speeds for different load weights and configurations. Conduct quarterly load security audits.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive monthly inspection schedule for all hydraulic connections on injection molding equipment. Each connection will be visually inspected for leaks, misting, or loose fittings, and pressure tested using calibrated gauges. Maintenance technicians will use a standardized torque specification chart and calibrated torque wrenches to ensure all fittings are properly tightened to manufacturer specifications. Documentation will be maintained in a digital log with photographic evidence. Training will be provided to all maintenance staff on proper hydraulic system safety procedures and the hazards of pressurized fluid injection.

name: Install Hydraulic System Pressure Relief and Secondary Containment
description: Install secondary pressure relief valves on all critical hydraulic lines to prevent over-pressurization. Additionally, install clear polycarbonate guards around high-risk connection points on Line A and similar equipment to contain any minor spray mist and provide visual barriers. These engineering controls will reduce the consequence severity of any future minor leaks and provide a secondary layer of protection beyond maintenance procedures.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Containment and Drum Handling Systems
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all chemical storage racks in the mixing area with capacity to hold 110% of the largest single container. Implement a drum-handling requirement that all 55-gallon drums must be secured in drum-cart cradles with safety chains before movement. Install a dedicated spill station with automated chemical absorbent dispensers and eyewash/shower stations within 10 feet of all chemical handling areas. All drums will be labeled with contents, hazard information, and proper handling instructions in both French and English per Quebec regulations.

name: Mandatory Chemical Handling and Spill Response Training Program
description: Implement quarterly refresher training for all personnel involved in chemical handling, including proper securing techniques, PPE requirements, and emergency response procedures. Training will include practical spill containment drills using non-hazardous materials. All material handlers will be certified in hazardous materials handling and spill response within 30 days. Training records will be maintained and audited monthly by the HSE department. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator will assess all personnel for medical clearance to work with VOC-emitting materials.

name: Install Automated Cooling System Leak Detection and Monitoring
description: Install ultrasonic leak detection sensors on all major cooling water line couplings and junctions. Connect sensors to a centralized Building Management System (BMS) that triggers audible and visual alarms when leak rates exceed 0.5 gallons per hour. The system will log all anomalies and send real-time alerts to the maintenance team and night-shift supervisor via mobile app. Establish a response protocol requiring system isolation within 15 minutes of alarm activation. Sensors will be calibrated and tested quarterly.

name: Replace Aging Cooling System Infrastructure with Corrosion-Resistant Materials
description: Conduct a facility-wide assessment of all cooling water lines, identifying couplings and joints installed more than 10 years ago. Replace all corroded or degraded sections with stainless steel or polyethylene piping and corrosion-resistant brass/stainless fittings. Implement a preventive replacement schedule replacing 15% of system infrastructure annually. Upgrade to a food-grade, environmentally-approved coolant solution with improved corrosion inhibitors and biodegradability. This engineering control will significantly reduce the likelihood of future cooling system leaks.

name: Environmental Spill Response and Storm Water Management Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive environmental incident response procedure specifically for cooling water and hydraulic fluid leaks that may impact storm water systems. Install permanently-mounted storm drain plugs at three critical access points in the warehouse area. Conduct quarterly tabletop exercises with the night-shift team to practice spill containment and notification procedures. Partner with a certified environmental remediation contractor for emergency response availability 24/7. Document all incidents in an environmental compliance log for CNESST and municipal reporting requirements.

name: Establish Designated Chemical Storage Protocol
description: Implement designated storage areas for all hot chemicals and mold release agents within the Regrind and Recycling Department. Install lockable cabinets with temperature-controlled ventilation on ground level only. All hot substances must be stored in containers with secure lids and warning labels. Staff will receive updated training on proper chemical handling and storage within 5 working days. Monthly audits will verify compliance. This eliminates the hazard of spills from elevated surfaces and ensures hot materials are stored safely away from personnel work areas.

name: Implement Hazard Communication System in Material Handling Zones
description: Install visual zone markers and communication protocols requiring operators in proximity to coordinate movements. Place reflective markers on floor indicating safe zones and equipment operation areas. Establish a buddy system verification procedure where operators must verbally confirm before moving equipment near other workers. All personnel will complete a 30-minute refresher training session on situational awareness and communication. This administrative control reduces the risk of accidents from uncoordinated equipment operation in shared work spaces.

name: Implement Mandatory Cut-Resistant Glove Program
description: Distribute cut-resistant gloves (Level 5 ANSI certification) to all Assembly Operators working on Injection Molding Line A. Gloves will be stored in a dedicated station at the line with monthly inventory audits. Operators will receive hands-on training on proper glove selection, fit, and usage. Supervisors will conduct weekly spot-checks to ensure 100% compliance during parts handling operations. This PPE engineering control directly reduces the likelihood of laceration injuries from sharp component edges.

name: Enhance Parts Deburring Quality Control Process
description: Establish a pre-assembly inspection station where all plastic components undergo automated edge detection and manual deburring verification. Implement statistical process control to track deburring effectiveness across production batches. Quality inspectors will sample 5% of parts per shift using tactile and visual inspection methods. Any parts with excessive flash will be reworked or scrapped. Operators will receive updated training on identifying parts that require additional deburring before assembly. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the primary hazard source.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Compressed Air Systems
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program requiring monthly inspection of all pressure relief valves, regulators, and air distribution manifolds. Maintenance technicians will perform pressure testing, valve operation verification, and visual inspection for leaks or contamination. A digital tracking system will log all maintenance activities with photographic documentation. Any valve showing pressure drift exceeding 0.5 PSI will be replaced immediately. This engineering and administrative control ensures early detection of failures before hazardous conditions develop and prevents compressed air injection injuries.

name: Enhance Anonymous Hazard Reporting System and Training
description: Expand and promote the confidential hazard reporting system with dedicated mobile app access and QR codes posted at all work stations. Conduct mandatory training for all employees on proper hazard identification and reporting procedures, emphasizing that anonymous reporting is protected and encouraged. Management will commit to 100% follow-up within 24 hours and provide feedback to reporters through the system. Monthly safety briefings will highlight near-misses prevented through reporting. This administrative control removes barriers to reporting and creates a proactive safety culture.

name: Install Air Line Contamination Filters and Pressure Regulators
description: Upgrade all pneumatic tool connection points with high-efficiency moisture and oil separators along with adjustable pressure regulators. Install pressure gauges at each work station to allow real-time monitoring of air supply quality. Operators will receive training on identifying signs of air contamination and proper pressure settings for different tools. Filters will be replaced on a quarterly basis or when visual inspection indicates saturation. This engineering control eliminates contamination hazards at the point of use.

name: Restore and Lock-Out Safety Interlocks on All Molding Equipment
description: Immediately restore the failed solenoid interlock on Line A Injection Molding equipment to full operational status. Conduct comprehensive audit of all injection molding lines to verify that safety interlocks have not been bypassed or disabled. Implement a new maintenance protocol requiring supervisor sign-off before any safety-critical system modifications. Install tamper-evident seals on all interlock connections. Schedule quarterly third-party audits of all machine safety systems to prevent future bypass incidents. Additionally, implement a lockout/tagout verification system where maintenance work on safety systems must be inspected and certified by the HSE department before equipment can return to service.

name: Enhanced Machine Guarding and Two-Hand Control Implementation
description: Install dual-hand control buttons on all injection molding equipment to require operators to use both hands during mold closure sequences, preventing single-hand entrapment scenarios. Retrofit all mold cavities with physical barriers and guards that prevent hand insertion into danger zones when the machine is in automatic mode. Modify work procedures so that manual part removal only occurs when the machine is in a de-energized lockout state. Conduct retraining for all 45 production operators on the new dual-control systems and updated lockout procedures within 5 business days.

name: Mandatory Emergency Response and First Aid Refresher Training
description: Conduct specialized emergency response training for all production floor supervisors and team leaders, focusing on crush injury response, tourniquets application, and immediate stabilization techniques. Schedule refresher CPR and first aid certification for minimum 30 operators across all shifts. Establish a dedicated emergency response kit stocked with trauma supplies at each production line. Conduct quarterly drills simulating hand/finger entrapment incidents to ensure response protocols are maintained and response times remain under 3 minutes.

name: Implement Comprehensive Housekeeping and Cable Management System
description: Establish a daily 15-minute housekeeping inspection program for all material handling zones, walkways, and production areas to identify and eliminate trip hazards. All compressed air hoses, electrical cables, and hoses must be secured with cable clips every 1.5 meters and routed along walls or designated trench systems, never across walkways. Implement color-coded floor marking (yellow and black stripes) for all permanent cable routes and hose pathways. Install cable covers over any hoses that must cross walkways. Assign responsibility to shift leads to conduct walkthroughs at shift start and complete a documented checklist. Conduct training for all 120 day shift and 60 evening shift personnel on hazard identification and reporting.

name: Upgrade Lighting in Material Handling and Preparation Areas
description: Install additional LED lighting fixtures in the Material Drying and Preparation Room and warehouse staging area, increasing illumination levels from current 250 lux to 500 lux minimum per OSHA and Quebec labor standards. Ensure all work surfaces and walkways have uniform lighting with minimal shadows. Install motion-activated supplemental lighting in low-traffic areas. This engineering control directly addresses the environmental factor that contributed to the near-miss and will improve operator visibility for hazard identification.

name: Implement Mandatory Deburring and Edge Finishing Quality Standard
description: Establish a mandatory deburring process for all CNC-machined mold components before they leave the machine station. Implement a standardized quality checklist requiring visual and tactile inspection of all edges using a foam test strip—edges must pass without snagging on the foam or gloved hand. Assign responsibility to the CNC operator to complete deburring using appropriate tools (deburring bits, files, abrasive pads) before component release. Update the CNC operation work instruction document to include this requirement. Conduct retraining for all 8 maintenance and engineering personnel in the tool room on proper deburring techniques and the new quality standard.

name: Implement Quarterly Electrical Connector Inspection Program
description: Establish a formal quarterly preventive maintenance schedule specifically targeting electrical connectors and wire bundling integrity in all control panels. Technicians will use torque wrenches to verify connector tightness to manufacturer specifications and will photograph connections for documentation. Training will be provided to all maintenance staff on proper connector inspection procedures and tightness standards. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the root cause of loose connections leading to arc flash hazards and aligns with the hierarchy of controls by preventing hazardous conditions before they develop.

name: Upgrade Fire Detection and Suppression in Electrical Shop
description: Install an additional automatic Class C dry powder suppression system specifically above electrical panel work areas, and upgrade smoke detection with addressable fire detectors that communicate directly to the facility management system. These engineering controls provide faster detection and automatic response to electrical fires, reducing response time from the current 90 seconds to near-instantaneous suppression. This redundant system complements existing sprinkler coverage and significantly reduces risk of electrical fires spreading to adjacent equipment or materials.

name: Install Height-Limiting Safety System on Forklifts
description: Equip all warehouse forklifts with ultrasonic height limitation and load cell sensors that prevent the mast from rising above a safe clearance threshold. When approaching restricted zones with low overhead clearances, the system will either lock the mast or trigger an audible/visual warning. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of loads striking overhead obstacles. All operators will receive retraining on the new system, and clearance heights will be clearly marked with painted lines and warning signage throughout the warehouse to support the mechanical controls.

name: Establish Load Positioning Verification Protocol
description: Implement a two-person verification procedure where the forklift operator must obtain visual confirmation from a ground spotter before any load placement above eye level. The spotter will use hand signals and verbal communication to confirm stable positioning and adequate clearance before the operator releases the load. This administrative control introduces redundancy in the decision-making process and ensures no single operator error can result in catastrophic load drops. Training documentation and daily checklist procedures will be created and tracked.

name: Redesign Assembly Workstations with Adjustable Bin Heights
description: Install new adjustable-height assembly bins and work tables in UNIT-005 that allow each operator to position finished goods containers at waist level (approximately 38-42 inches from floor) to eliminate excessive forward bending. The bins will feature pneumatic height adjustment controlled by foot pedals, allowing operators to customize their workstation height throughout the shift and accommodate different individual anthropometric characteristics. This engineering control directly eliminates the primary ergonomic hazard identified in the incident and aligns with ANSI ergonomic standards for repetitive assembly work.

name: Implement Job Rotation and Microbreak Protocol for Assembly Operations
description: Establish a mandatory job rotation schedule where assembly operators rotate between Part Removal, Component Cleaning, and Packaging roles every 90 minutes to distribute physical stress across different muscle groups and motion patterns. Additionally, implement 5-minute microbreaks every 90 minutes for stretching and position changes. A visual job rotation board will be posted at each workstation, and supervisors will enforce compliance through shift checklists. This administrative control reduces the cumulative strain on any single body region and provides evidence-based protection against repetitive strain injuries. Training will include ergonomic stretching instruction specific to assembly operations.

name: Provide Ergonomic Assessment and Training for Assembly Staff
description: Engage a certified ergonomics consultant to conduct detailed postural analysis and workstation assessments for all 15 assembly operators in UNIT-005. Customized training will address proper lifting techniques, neutral spine positioning, and recognizing early warning signs of strain injury. Each operator will receive a personalized ergonomic assessment report with specific recommendations for their workstation configuration and movement patterns. This training and administrative control enhances operator awareness and enables self-correction of risky behaviors before injury occurs.

name: Implement Automated Part Removal System for Machine #7
description: Design and install pneumatic part removal assistance system to reduce manual gripping force requirements by 80%. System will automatically eject cooled parts into collection bin, eliminating repetitive high-force gripping motions. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at source rather than relying on worker adaptation. Expected outcome: Reduce strain injuries by 90% on this machine, serve as prototype for other molding machines. Implementation includes operator training on new system and adjustment period of 2 weeks.

name: Establish Mandatory Ergonomic Microbreaks and Job Rotation
description: Implement administrative control requiring 5-minute rest breaks every 45 minutes for operators performing repetitive part removal tasks. Establish job rotation schedule rotating operators between molding, assembly, and quality inspection duties every 2 hours to distribute physical demands. Schedule will be displayed at each workstation. Supervisors will monitor compliance through shift logs. Provide education to all operators on proper body mechanics and early warning signs of repetitive strain injury. Training sessions 30 minutes each, conducted during shift briefings.

name: Upgrade Molding Machine #7 Mold Tolerances
description: Work with mold design team to gradually tighten mold tolerances through precision improvements, reducing part removal resistance without compromising product quality. Retrofit mold with improved cooling channels to ensure consistent part surface properties. This substitution approach replaces difficult-to-remove parts with properly designed parts requiring less force. Phased implementation over 60 days with quality validation at each step. Expected outcome: Part removal force reduced by 40-60%, improving ergonomic profile significantly.

name: Install Bonding and Grounding System for Chemical Mixing Equipment
description: Engineering control: Install permanent copper bonding cables connecting all metal mixing equipment, containers, and work surfaces to a centralized ground system rated for flammable atmospheres per NFPA 77 standards. All equipment must achieve resistance below 1 megohm to ground. System will include visual inspection points and annual certification. New mixing paddles will be conductive composite material rather than bare metal. This eliminates static electricity accumulation at source. Expected outcome: Reduce static discharge incidents to near zero and achieve compliance with fire safety codes.

name: Implement Static Electricity Awareness Training and Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Administrative control: Develop and deliver 45-minute training module on static electricity generation, dissipation, and control in chemical mixing operations. Training mandatory for all employees accessing UNIT-010, to be completed within 30 days. Implement monthly inspection checklist for grounding system integrity, bonding cable continuity, and equipment condition. Create visual SOP posters showing proper equipment use and grounding verification. Establish log book for documenting inspections and maintenance. Training will cover recognition of ignition sources and proper emergency procedures.

name: Upgrade Predictive Maintenance Program for Conveyor Systems
description: Engineering/Administrative control: Implement vibration analysis and thermal imaging monitoring for all conveyor drive systems on a quarterly schedule. Install condition monitoring sensors on motor bearings and belt tension to provide real-time alerts when components approach failure thresholds. Integrate sensor data into computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) to automatically generate work orders 30 days before predicted failures. Establish belt replacement schedule based on equipment age and utilization data, with maximum intervals of 18 months regardless of condition. This proactive approach replaces reactive emergency maintenance with planned preventive interventions.

name: Enhance Lockout/Tagout Verification Protocol Before Maintenance
description: Administrative control: Develop mandatory verification checklist for all conveyor system maintenance work requiring two-person verification: maintenance technician and independent observer (supervisor or second technician). Checklist must include: energy isolation points identified, all isolation points visibly locked with hasp, absence of residual pressure verified by manual actuation test, and blind spots physically confirmed clear. Implement photographic documentation requirement showing lockout points before maintenance commences. Conduct refresher LOTO training for all maintenance staff within 2 weeks, emphasizing two-person rule. Update lockout procedures document with photographic reference guide specific to conveyor systems.

name: Install Guarding and Fall Prevention at Maintenance Platform
description: Engineering control: Install permanent railing system (42 inches high with mid-rail and toe board) around all raised maintenance platforms in the warehouse, meeting CSA Z94.1 fall protection standards. Install non-slip safety tread on platform surfaces and ensure minimum 2-foot clear zone around all edge perimeters. Add grab handles at platform entry/exit points for assistance. Install secondary safety cable system with harness anchor points for maintenance work above 1.5 meters. This engineering approach eliminates fall hazard through physical barriers rather than relying on worker vigilance or PPE alone.

name: Implement Receiving Inspection Checklist
description: Create and deploy a standardized inspection checklist for all incoming material shipments that includes verification of proper load securing, stack height limits (maximum 5 feet), and weight distribution. All receiving coordinators will be trained to reject shipments that do not meet these standards and contact suppliers for repackaging.
