Checklist will be posted at receiving dock and electronic version integrated into warehouse management system. Implementation will occur within 14 days with quarterly audits.

name: Conduct Supplier Communication Update
description: Send formal notification to all material suppliers detailing TechnoPlast's load securing and stacking requirements. Include diagrams showing proper pallet configuration, maximum heights, and tie-down specifications. Establish monthly compliance review with top 5 suppliers. Non-compliant shipments will incur restocking fees to incentivize proper preparation.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Implement ultrasonic leak detection and thermal imaging inspection of all 32 injection molding machines' hydraulic systems on a bi-weekly schedule. Create maintenance alert system that flags machines with pressure anomalies or temperature increases exceeding 5% from baseline. All maintenance technicians will be certified in hydraulic system inspection within 30 days. Program will include documentation of all findings with corrective action tracking.

name: Upgrade Operator PPE Requirements for Hydraulic Operations
description: Mandate high-temperature resistant gloves (rated to 200°F minimum) and arm sleeves for all operators working on lines with pressurized hydraulic systems. Conduct training session on recognizing hydraulic fluid spray hazards and proper emergency response. Provide new PPE inventory with quarterly replacement schedule. Cost includes 60 sets of upgraded protective equipment.

name: Install Automated Material Handling System for Post-Processing
description: Replace manual tray handling with automated conveyor system and pneumatic lifting devices in the post-processing area. This engineering control eliminates direct contact with hot materials by automating transfer from oven to cooling stations. System will include temperature monitoring sensors that prevent tray removal until internal temperature drops below 110°F. Installation timeline is 60 days with $185,000 budget. This addresses the root cause by eliminating the hazard entirely.

name: Implement Heat-Protective PPE and Cooling Station Requirements
description: Provide all material handlers with Level 5 heat-resistant gloves rated to 500°F, long-sleeve Kevlar protective shirts, and forearm guards for interim period before automated system installation. Install three cooling stations with ice water baths, first aid supplies, and thermal relief packs within 10 feet of all ovens. Conduct mandatory training on thermal hazard recognition and emergency response procedures. Create signage indicating mandatory cooling time before manual handling.

name: Revise Standard Operating Procedures for Post-Processing
description: Update SOPs to mandate 45-minute cooling period for all composite material trays after oven discharge before any manual handling is permitted. Implement color-coded tray system: red = hot (oven discharge), yellow = cooling (10-45 minutes), green = safe to handle. Require two-person verification before handling any tray. Add temperature measurement requirement using infrared thermometer to confirm material temperature below 110°F. Procedure will be posted at all work stations and reviewed during monthly safety meetings.

name: Implement Chemical Storage Zone Reorganization
description: Establish designated flammable materials storage area with proper grounding systems, away from electrical outlets. Install static-dissipative flooring, ensure all containers are properly grounded during transfers, and establish minimum 3-meter distance from electrical equipment. Install secondary containment trays rated for 110% of largest container volume. Implement daily inspection checklist for chemical storage areas focusing on proper labeling and containment integrity.

name: Conduct Emergency Response Drill and Update Procedures
description: Execute full-facility fire evacuation drill with special focus on warehouse personnel. Update emergency response procedures to include chemical fire protocols. Provide refresher training to all materials management staff on flammable liquid handling, static electricity prevention, and safe solvent transfer procedures using grounded equipment only. Document training completion and schedule quarterly refresher sessions.

name: Install Continuous Gas Detection System
description: Install fixed-location combustible gas detectors in raw materials warehouse with audible and visual alarms triggering at 20% LEL (lower explosive limit). Connect detectors to facility monitoring system with automatic alerts to HSE department. Detector placement will cover chemical storage zones, transfer areas, and equipment staging areas. Monthly calibration and maintenance program to be established.

name: Establish Compressed Air Safety Program
description: Implement facility-wide compressed air safety procedures prohibiting direct hand contact with pressurized air streams. Install pressure regulators limiting output to maximum 30 PSI for cleaning operations. Provide all maintenance technicians with certified training on pneumatic tool safety, including hazards of compressed air injection injuries. Require use of protective shields on air hoses in maintenance areas and establish monthly compliance audits.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Mold Work
description: Provide all mold maintenance technicians with cut-resistant gloves (rated ANSI A4 or higher), safety glasses with side shields, and nitrile-coated precision handling gloves for detailed mold inspection work. Establish mandatory PPE usage before any mold handling activity. Update job safety analysis for all mold maintenance tasks to specify required PPE based on hazard assessment. Track PPE compliance during weekly safety inspections.

name: Implement Comprehensive Crane Safety Program
description: Establish mandatory daily pre-operation inspections for all overhead cranes including sling, eyelet, and hook condition verification. Create color-coded sling system with weight ratings clearly marked and laminated labels. Require all crane operators to complete CNESST-certified training with practical load test demonstrations. Implement maximum safe load weight postings at each crane station. Schedule quarterly third-party crane inspections with certification documentation.

name: Establish No-Drop Zone Safety Protocol
description: Designate and clearly mark no-personnel zones directly beneath all overhead crane paths using floor markings, overhead signage, and automated warning systems. Implement mandatory hand signals training for material handlers and ground personnel. Require two-way radio communication between crane operator and ground personnel during all lift operations. Install video monitoring system at shipping dock with operator visibility to ground level. Update work procedures to prohibit personnel from entering crane drop zones during active lift operations.

name: Implement Load Securement and Rigging Audit
description: Conduct immediate audit of all lifting equipment, slings, and rigging hardware in use at shipping dock. Remove and destroy any substandard equipment. Establish monthly equipment inspection schedule with documented results maintained for regulatory compliance. Create laminated quick-reference guides showing proper load centering, sling angling, and weight distribution for common pallet configurations. Train all dock personnel on proper rigging fundamentals.

name: Implement Container Handling Safety Protocol
description: Develop and enforce mandatory standard operating procedures for handling all chemical containers, including use of secondary containment trays, securing lids with torque wrenches to specified tightness, and requiring two-person verification for transfers of containers larger than 10 liters. All personnel involved in chemical handling will complete refresher training within 14 days. Signage will be installed at the Material Drying and Preparation Room entrance detailing proper container handling steps.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System with Spillage Detection
description: Install automated volatile organic compound (VOC) sensors in the Material Drying and Preparation Room that trigger enhanced ventilation and alert building management when chemical concentrations exceed 50% of occupational exposure limits. Add dedicated emergency ventilation exhaust route separate from main HVAC to prevent cross-contamination of other facility areas during chemical incidents.

name: Establish Spill Response Kits and Monthly Audits
description: Place certified chemical spill response kits at strategic locations near all chemical storage and handling areas. Include absorbent materials rated for VOC compounds, pH indicators, disposal containers, and personal protective equipment. Conduct monthly audits of kit completeness and employee knowledge of kit locations and proper use procedures.

name: Adjust Injection Molding Line B Part Ejection Height
description: Reconfigure the part ejection mechanism on Line B to position finished parts at elbow height (40-42 inches) to maintain neutral wrist position during part removal. This engineering control will reduce repetitive strain by keeping the operator's wrists in a neutral, non-flexed posture. Work with equipment manufacturer to determine optimal height range that accommodates 95th percentile of operator population. Test adjustment with multiple operators of different heights.

name: Implement Mandatory Job Rotation and Micro-Break Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory 30-minute job rotation schedule for all operators on Injection Molding Line B, requiring them to rotate to lower-repetition tasks (e.g., quality inspection, material staging, documentation) every 2 hours. Additionally, implement 5-minute paid micro-breaks every 60 minutes of repetitive work. Train all supervisors on proper enforcement. Track rotation compliance through production log timestamps.

name: Replace Corroded Mezzanine Safety Railing with Stainless Steel Components
description: Complete replacement of all mezzanine perimeter safety railings and fasteners with stainless steel 304-grade components rated for humid, chemically-aggressive industrial environments. Install bolts with locking washers and apply anti-seize compound to prevent future corrosion. Railings must meet or exceed CSA Z271.1 standards with 200-pound outward force resistance. Completion required within 14 days; mezzanine remains restricted to authorized personnel only until replacement is complete.

name: Establish Quarterly Fall Protection Equipment Inspection Program
description: Implement a formal quarterly inspection schedule for all elevated work areas, mezzanines, catwalks, and associated fall protection equipment. Inspections will include visual assessment for corrosion, fastener integrity, railing damage, and load capacity verification. Assign André Bellavance (Confined Space Entry Supervisor) to lead these inspections and document findings in a centralized maintenance log. Any deficiencies must be remediated within 72 hours or the area restricted from use.

name: Install Thermal Safety Interlocks on Mold Assemblies
description: Engineering control: Install thermal interlock systems on all injection molding machines (Lines B, C, and D) that prevent pressure valve access until the mold assembly temperature drops below 80°C. The system will include audible and visual alerts when mold cooling is incomplete. This eliminates the hazard of contact with hot equipment surfaces during routine maintenance. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of thermal burn incidents during mold inspection procedures.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE for Mold Maintenance
description: Administrative and PPE control: Establish mandatory requirement for all personnel performing mold maintenance to wear specialized silicone-coated heat-resistant gloves (rated to 200°C) and forearm protection. Create a color-coded storage rack in the maintenance area with replacement schedules. Implement monthly inspection of PPE integrity. While this is a lower-priority control, it provides essential backup protection for mold work.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooling Period Verification Procedure
description: Administrative control: Develop and enforce a mandatory 30-minute cooling verification checklist for all mold maintenance operations. Operators must document temperature readings using infrared thermometers before any valve or assembly access is permitted. Integrate this into the digital maintenance log system. Train all production and maintenance staff on the new protocol during the next monthly safety meeting.

name: Implement Weight Distribution Load Limits for Storage Racks
description: Engineering and administrative control: Conduct structural engineering assessment of all storage racks in the warehouse and packaging areas. Install permanent weight limit signs on each shelf indicating maximum safe load capacity. Create and distribute new material handling procedures specifying weight distribution requirements. For high-capacity racks, implement secondary safety features such as adjustable shelf straps or mesh backing. Train all material handlers and warehouse staff on proper load distribution during the next safety orientation cycle.

name: Establish Monthly Rack Safety Inspection Protocol
description: Administrative control: Develop a comprehensive monthly inspection checklist for all storage racks, to be conducted by designated material handlers and warehouse supervisors. Include visual assessment for signs of stress, bolt tightness verification, and load distribution verification. Document findings in a digital log system with photos of any deficiencies. Establish a corrective action timeline for any identified issues. This ensures early detection of potential failures before incidents occur.

name: Implement Drum Inspection and Locking Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-transfer inspection checklist for all liquid chemical containers that includes verification of locking rings, seals, and structural integrity. Each shift supervisor will conduct visual inspections before any forklift movement, and inspections will be documented in a new digital tracking system. Materials Supervisor Valérie Pelletier will oversee protocol development and training rollout to all warehouse personnel. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause: inadequate verification of container security before transport.

name: Upgrade Spill Response Equipment and Training
description: Install additional spill containment kits with absorbent materials and secondary containment trays throughout UNIT-007 at strategic storage locations. Conduct mandatory training for all warehouse and materials handling employees on proper spill response, chemical hazard identification, and emergency procedures. Training will be delivered by Safety Training Coordinator Amélie Roy and documented for compliance. Secondary containment trays will prevent spills from reaching drains and spreading contamination. This engineering control combined with administrative training reduces incident severity and environmental impact.

name: Implement Forklift Operator Certification Refresh Program
description: Require all forklift operators to complete a refresher certification course focusing on safe handling of liquid chemical containers, load balance assessment, and emergency procedures. Operators will demonstrate competency in laboratory settings before resuming drum handling duties. Training will be coordinated with Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux who will oversee equipment-specific operator training protocols. This administrative control ensures operators understand specialized handling requirements for hazardous materials and recognize warning signs of container damage.

name: Overhaul Preventive Maintenance Scheduling System
description: Implement a new computerized Computerized Maintenance Management System (CMMS) with automated alerts and enforcement protocols for preventive maintenance intervals on all critical equipment. The system will flag overdue maintenance tasks, prevent equipment operation when maintenance is overdue without supervisor authorization, and generate automatic work orders. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux will oversee system configuration and train maintenance personnel. This engineering/administrative control eliminates the scheduling errors that led to spindle failure and ensures predictive maintenance is performed on schedule.

name: Install Real-Time Equipment Vibration Monitoring System
description: Deploy wireless vibration sensors on all CNC milling machines that provide real-time monitoring of spindle bearing health. The system will generate alerts when vibration levels exceed safe thresholds, allowing maintenance teams to perform preventive replacement before catastrophic failure occurs. Historical data and trending analysis will inform maintenance scheduling. This engineering control provides early warning of bearing degradation and prevents future critical failures, protecting equipment investment and production schedules.

name: Install Redundant Emergency Stop System with Independent Safety Controller
description: Replace the single-point-of-failure emergency stop architecture with a dual-channel safety-rated emergency stop system utilizing independent safety-grade programmable logic controllers (SIL 2 rated). Install hardwired emergency stop buttons with mechanical latching and redundant hydraulic isolation valves. The new system will be physically independent from production control electronics, eliminating firmware corruption as a failure mode. This engineering control achieves high integrity protection against safety-critical failures and exceeds ISO 13849-1 safety standards for machinery control systems.

name: Implement PLC Firmware Integrity Verification and Backup System
description: Install automated firmware integrity checking on all control system PLCs with automatic boot validation and rollback to last verified firmware image if corruption is detected. Establish redundant backup of all PLC programs on secure network storage with version control. Implement quarterly firmware validation tests and annual PLC replacement schedule for aging controllers. This administrative and engineering control prevents firmware corruption from causing safety system failures and ensures continuity of critical control functions.

name: Establish Pressure Safety Relief Valve Audit and Maintenance Program
description: Conduct full pressure relief valve audit on all hydraulic equipment to verify operation and calibration within design specifications. Establish monthly functional testing protocol and annual professional calibration and certification by qualified hydraulic technicians. Maintain detailed documentation of all relief valve inspections and adjustments. This administrative control ensures pressure relief systems function correctly to prevent over-pressurization and related equipment damage or operator injury.

name: Implement Monthly Temperature Sensor Calibration Program
description: Establish a mandatory monthly calibration and verification protocol for all injection molding machine temperature sensors across all production lines. Maintenance staff will use calibrated temperature instruments to verify sensor accuracy before and after each shift on critical equipment. This will prevent sensor drift that could mask dangerously high mold temperatures. Documentation will be maintained in the predictive maintenance system with alerts triggered if any sensor exceeds acceptable variance thresholds.

name: Install Temperature Display Warning System
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with real-time mold temperature display screens visible to operators at the point of part removal. Install high-temperature warning lights that activate when mold surface temperatures exceed 80°C, requiring mandatory hand protection and waiting period before part handling. Include tactile feedback warnings through the machine interface to reinforce cooling status.

name: Mandatory Mold Contact Awareness Training
description: Conduct immediate refresher training for all production operators on mold surface hazards, proper cooling verification procedures, and mandatory use of insulated handling tools when removing parts. Include simulation of temperature sensor failures and proper response protocols. Training will be documented and completed within 5 working days for all line C operators, with annual recertification required.

name: Comprehensive Powered Equipment Maintenance Program
description: Implement a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all powered material handling equipment including hydraulic system inspections, steering component verification, and brake functionality testing. Maintenance records will be entered into the predictive maintenance system with automated alerts before due dates. Any equipment showing steering irregularities will be immediately removed from service pending repairs. Daily pre-shift inspections by equipment operators will be formalized with a standardized checklist.

name: Install Racking Protective Barriers
description: Install protective bollards and guardrails around critical racking support columns throughout the warehouse. These barriers will be positioned 5 feet from column bases to prevent equipment collision damage. Aisle width will be adjusted where necessary to ensure safe equipment operation. High-visibility paint will be applied to all barriers and column edges. This engineering control eliminates the direct impact hazard from equipment failure events.

name: Enhanced Chemical Storage Ventilation Upgrade
description: Install advanced mechanical ventilation system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area with continuous air exchange rate of 12 air changes per hour, exceeding OSHA standards. Add spark-resistant ductwork and install flammable vapor sensors with automatic alarm thresholds set at 25% of lower explosive limit. Ventilation system will operate 24/7 with backup generator support. Monthly air quality testing will verify effectiveness and document compliance in the safety management system.

name: Implement Electrical Hazard Mitigation in Chemical Areas
description: Install Class I, Division 2 compliant electrical equipment in the chemical storage enclosure, including intrinsically safe heating elements and grounded power distribution systems. All electrical connections will be verified for proper grounding with quarterly testing. Install static dissipative flooring to prevent electrical charge accumulation. Remove all non-essential electrical equipment from the chemical storage zone, relocating the heating panel to an adjacent non-hazardous area.

name: Chemical Container Quality Verification Protocol
description: Establish incoming inspection procedure for all hazardous material containers, including visual and pressure testing for seam integrity before storage acceptance. All drums will be pressure-tested at 50% of maximum working pressure and documented with batch tracking. Implement vendor quality audit program with quarterly reviews of supplier manufacturing standards. Any defective containers will be immediately segregated, documented, and returned or safely disposed of.

name: Fire Safety Training and Response Drills
description: Conduct comprehensive fire safety training for all shift teams with emphasis on chemical fire hazards, suppression system operation, and evacuation procedures. Monthly tabletop drills and quarterly full-facility evacuation exercises will be conducted with documentation of participant performance. Night shift team will receive additional specialized training on early hazard detection and emergency response protocols when supervisory staff may be limited.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Pressure Testing
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly pressure test protocol for all injection molding machine cooling systems to detect hairline cracks and weak junctions before catastrophic failure. Each test will document baseline pressure readings and compare against historical data. A certified technician will inspect all copper tubing junctions, fittings, and manifolds under controlled pressure conditions. Results will be logged in a maintenance database and reviewed by the Maintenance and Engineering Lead. This proactive measure addresses the root cause of inadequate preventive maintenance and provides early warning of developing equipment failures before coolant sprays onto the production floor.

name: Install High-Temperature Coolant Splash Guards
description: Install polycarbonate splash guards and deflection shields around all coolant circulation points on injection molding lines. These engineering controls will contain spray patterns and redirect hot liquid away from worker zones. Guards will be positioned at 45-degree angles to channel any leaking coolant safely into collection trays positioned below vulnerable equipment sections. All guards will be removable for maintenance access and clearly labeled with warning signage. This engineering control eliminates the direct exposure hazard by creating a physical barrier between the high-temperature fluid and workers.

name: Upgrade LED Lighting in Finished Goods Warehouse
description: Replace all existing fluorescent lighting fixtures in the Finished Goods Warehouse with high-output LED panels that provide minimum 500 lux illumination at all workstations, with particular focus on part removal and packaging areas. Install task lighting directly above bulk storage bins to eliminate shadow zones where sharp gate runners and sprue become invisible. Ensure color temperature of 4000-5000K for optimal visibility of plastic part details and defects. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of insufficient visibility that prevented detection of the hazardous sharp edge.

name: Implement Gate Runner Removal Station with Safety Equipment
description: Establish a dedicated gate runner removal and de-burring station at the entrance to the packaging area, equipped with grinding tools, cutting jigs, and disposal containers. Operators will remove all sharp sprue before parts enter the packaging workflow. Provide heavy-duty cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rating) and training on proper handling techniques. This administrative/engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source by removing sharp edges before parts reach packaging staff, preventing future lacerations.

name: Enhanced LOTO Verification Protocol with Visual Confirmation
description: Implement a mandatory two-step LOTO verification system requiring operators to visually confirm all indicator lights are OFF and mechanically test for any residual motion before leaving equipment unattended. Install large, illuminated status indicators on all 32 injection molding machines showing real-time energization state. Require operators to photograph the lockout configuration on mobile devices and upload to a tracking system. Conduct immediate retraining for all 45 production staff on medical components line with competency testing. Schedule monthly audits of LOTO compliance.

name: Install Proximity Warning System on High-Risk Molding Equipment
description: Add ultrasonic proximity sensors to the 12 largest injection molding machines (200+ tons) used in medical component production to detect workers within 1.5 meters of mold closing areas. System will trigger audible and visual alarms and halt all automated cycles if human presence is detected. Integration with existing machine control systems to create a secondary safety layer beyond LOTO procedures.

name: Implement Computerized Preventive Maintenance Management System
description: Deploy a cloud-based maintenance tracking system across all 32 injection molding machines, 8 material handling conveyors, and 12 auxiliary equipment units. System will automatically generate work orders at manufacturer-recommended intervals, track lubrication schedules, monitor operating hours, and send alerts 48 hours before maintenance is due. Integrate with production scheduling to allow planned downtime during low-demand periods. Assign Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux as system administrator with weekly compliance reporting to operations management.

name: Replace Failed Motor with Heavy-Duty Industrial Unit and Install Redundant Backup Conveyor
description: Install a new 15 HP motor with premium bearing cartridges designed for 2000+ hour service intervals on the primary material drying conveyor. Additionally, install a secondary backup conveyor system that can be manually activated within 2 minutes to maintain material supply to critical production lines during primary equipment failure. Includes automatic switchover controls and integration with production line sensors.

name: Establish Monthly Lubrication Audit Program
description: Create a scheduled monthly inspection program where Maintenance Technicians verify lubrication levels, oil condition, and bearing temperatures on all conveyor motors using thermographic imaging. Document findings in maintenance log. Replace all bearing lubricant every 12 months regardless of hours accumulated. Train Fernand Giguère and secondary technician to use ultrasonic bearing analysis equipment for early detection of bearing degradation.

name: Implement Enhanced Quality Control Inspection for Mold Defects and Sharp Edges
description: Establish a dedicated post-molding inspection station where 100% of medical device housing components are visually inspected and physically examined with a tactile edge-detection protocol using calibrated edge guides. Any components with detected defects, micro-fractures, or sharp edges exceeding 0.15 mm are segregated and returned to quality assurance for root cause analysis. Implement automated vision system using high-resolution cameras to detect surface defects on 60% of production volume. Train Quality Auditor Indira Singh and two assembly lead staff on edge classification standards.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Assembly Operations
description: Transition all assembly operators on medical components line from standard nitrile gloves to specialized cut-resistant gloves rated ANSI A4 with enhanced dexterity for precision assembly tasks. Distribute cut-resistant finger cots for high-risk assembly operations. Provide training to all 12 assembly line operators on proper glove selection, fit verification, and inspection. Establish quarterly glove replacement schedule and maintain inventory buffer of 20% above minimum usage projections.

name: Mandatory LOTO Interlock Verification Program
description: Implement a daily machine interlock inspection protocol for all 32 injection molding machines. Each technician must verify that LOTO interlocks are functioning before starting shift work. Establish a checklist system with photographic documentation stored in the maintenance management system. Train all production operators and maintenance personnel on proper LOTO procedures with certification required annually. Install audible and visual alerts on machines that detect incomplete LOTO sequences.

name: Production Quota Pressure Review and Adjustment
description: Conduct a review of production schedules and quotas in consultation with production planning and the JHSC. Adjust scheduling to eliminate time-pressure situations that incentivize workers to skip safety procedures. Implement a 'safety first' policy where production targets are only achievable with full compliance to all safety protocols. Communicate revised expectations to all production supervisors and operators. Monitor adherence and adjust workload allocation if pressure-related incidents continue.

name: Enhanced Machine Guarding on Line A Molding Machines
description: Install additional physical guards around barrel-housing pinch points on all machines in Line A. Upgrade to proximity sensors that detect hand approach and trigger automatic shutdown. Install transparent polycarbonate guards to maintain visibility while preventing contact. Conduct engineering review of all 32 machines to identify similar hazards and prioritize retrofitting across all molding lines within 90 days.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Chemical Storage
description: Install a secondary containment tray system beneath all chemical storage areas in the Composite Materials Processing Area. The containment system must have capacity equal to 110% of the largest single container. Install appropriate drip pans on all mixing equipment. Mark containment areas clearly with warning labels and establish a daily inspection checklist. Train all staff on proper use and maintenance of containment systems. Establish procedures for regular inspection and cleaning of trays to maintain functionality.

name: Implement Segregated Storage for Raw Materials and Chemicals
description: Reorganize the Composite Materials Processing Area to physically separate raw composite fiber materials from chemical storage and staging areas. Install elevated shelving units with drip containment for all fiber materials to protect them from potential spills. Establish clear delineation zones with colored floor markings and signage. Restrict access to chemical staging areas to trained materials personnel only. Update facility layout diagrams and communicate new procedures to all affected staff.

name: Establish Scheduled Interlock Cleaning and Maintenance Protocol
description: Implement a weekly preventive maintenance schedule for all safety interlocks on the 32 injection molding machines. Maintenance technicians will clean all interlock switches, remove dust and debris, and test functionality with documented results. Create a maintenance checklist specific to interlock mechanisms and establish a tracking system to ensure no machines are missed. Train all maintenance personnel on proper cleaning techniques that do not damage sensitive electrical components. Establish quarterly professional inspections by an external safety equipment specialist.

name: Enhance Night Shift Inspection Procedures and Lighting
description: Upgrade lighting in the production areas to enhance visibility for night shift inspections, particularly around machine interlock mechanisms. Install task lighting at each machine station focused on interlock areas. Formalize the night shift inspection procedure as a documented protocol with specific checkpoints, including interlock verification. Provide night shift operators with portable inspection tools (LED flashlights, magnifying glasses) to aid in identifying accumulated residue and wear. Conduct training with night shift staff on what to look for during inspections and when to escalate findings.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all hydraulic pressure relief valves across Lines B and D, with inspection intervals reduced from 18 months to 12 months as per manufacturer specifications. Implement pressure monitoring sensors that alert maintenance staff when pressure exceeds safe thresholds. Create a digital tracking system to log all maintenance activities and ensure no valve exceeds service intervals. Train all maintenance technicians on proper relief valve inspection and calibration procedures.

name: Upgrade Machine Guarding on Injection Molding Lines
description: Install additional engineering controls including transparent polycarbonate guards around mold opening areas to prevent ejection of hot material and fragments from reaching operators. Design guards to allow visibility for process monitoring while maintaining physical barriers. Ensure guards meet ISO 13849-1 safety standards. Retrofit Lines B and D as priority, with expansion to other lines within 60 days.

name: Enhanced PPE Requirements and Heat-Resistant Gear
description: Issue all injection molding operators with upgraded heat-resistant sleeve covers rated for 300°C exposure and reinforced leather aprons. Require mandatory use of face shields with thermal protection during all mold operations. Conduct training on proper donning and care of new PPE. Update standard operating procedures to mandate this PPE as non-negotiable requirement before machine operation.

name: Install Overhead Cable and Hose Routing System
description: Route all compressed air hoses and electrical cables through overhead cable trays and conduit systems mounted at minimum 7 feet height. Install clips and supports every 3 feet to prevent sagging or dropping into walkways. Use color-coded hoses and cables for easy identification. Install warning signage at all transition points. This engineering control eliminates trip hazards at ground level and improves overall facility safety in the Composite Materials area.

name: Establish Hose and Cable Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Create a monthly inspection checklist for all hoses and cables in high-traffic production areas. Assign responsibility to maintenance technicians to identify damage, wear, improper routing, or hazardous placement. Document findings and corrective actions in a centralized database. Replace any damaged hoses or cables immediately. Train all production supervisors to report hazards observed during shifts. This administrative control ensures ongoing monitoring and rapid response to emerging hazards.

name: Redesign Chemical Storage Shelving with Anti-Tip Features
description: Replace existing storage shelving in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility with industrial-grade racking systems featuring integrated drum cradles, stabilizing bars, and height-limited stacking (maximum 2 drums per shelf). Install secondary containment trays beneath all solvent storage to capture 110% of the largest container volume. Implement clear labeling of weight limits and proper stacking procedures. This engineering control prevents future drum tipping incidents and limits potential spill volume.

name: Install Automated Chemical Spill Detection and Response System
description: Deploy floor-level chemical sensors in the storage area that detect acetone and isopropanol vapors and trigger automatic alarm systems. Install emergency eyewash and shower stations within 10 seconds travel distance. Establish an emergency spill kit station with absorbent materials, neutralizing agents, and disposal containers. Post emergency contact information and spill response procedures prominently. Conduct quarterly drills for all staff who work in or pass through the chemical storage area.

name: Implement Chemical Inventory and Storage Best Practices Training
description: Conduct mandatory training for all personnel involved in chemical handling, storage, or inventory on proper drum and container handling, stacking procedures, and spill response. Training must cover weight distribution, use of secondary containment, and inspection of container integrity before storage. Implement a sign-off system where each shift supervisor confirms compliance with storage protocols at end of shift. Update SOPs to require helmet use and slip-resistant footwear in chemical storage areas.

name: Install Comprehensive Water Line Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Implement a quarterly inspection schedule for all water lines in production areas, with particular focus on cooling water systems in humid environments. Replace all corroded or deteriorated sections with stainless steel piping resistant to corrosion. Install secondary containment trays under high-value equipment to capture any future leaks before they damage machinery or inventory. Install automatic shut-off valves at critical junctions to isolate failures quickly. All inspections and replacements to be completed within 90 days.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Infrastructure
description: Create and implement a documented preventive maintenance calendar for all facility infrastructure including water lines, compressed air systems, electrical conduits, and HVAC systems. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance Planning department with quarterly audits by HSE. Track all inspections in the maintenance management system with photographic documentation. Non-compliance with the schedule will be escalated immediately to facility management.

name: Deploy Rapid-Dry Floor Treatment and Slip Prevention Equipment
description: Purchase and station absorbent granules and wet floor signage at strategic locations throughout the production area. Train all employees on immediate spill response procedures. Install permanent drainage channels in the Material Drying Room to direct spilled water to a collection sump. Post laminated emergency response cards at each workstation outlining water shutdown procedures and evacuation routes in case of major spills.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification and Refresher Training for All Maintenance Personnel
description: All maintenance technicians and machine operators involved in equipment troubleshooting must complete OSHA-compliant Lockout/Tagout training within 30 days. Training must include hands-on practice with actual machines at TechnoPlast, scenario-based problem solving, and a written certification test. Refresher training is required annually, with compliance tracked by the HSE office. Employees who fail to maintain current certification will be restricted from performing maintenance work until retrained.

name: Install Automatic Sensor Diagnostic and Corrosion Prevention System
description: Replace all corrosion-prone electrical connectors on injection molding machines with marine-grade sealed connectors. Implement quarterly inspection of all sensor connectors with cleaning and application of dielectric grease. Install diagnostic monitoring that alerts maintenance staff to abnormal sensor readings before they cause equipment failures. Integrate this monitoring into the preventive maintenance schedule with automatic work order generation when sensor anomalies are detected.

name: Restore and Secure UV Equipment Safety Interlocks
description: Within 5 days, all ultraviolet light testing equipment in the Quality Control Laboratory must have safety interlocks restored to factory specifications and tested to ensure they function correctly. Install tamper-evident seals on interlocks to prevent unauthorized disabling. Any future modifications to safety systems must be approved in writing by the HSE department and documented with engineering drawings. Non-compliance will result in immediate equipment shutdown until interlocks are restored.

name: Implement Mandatory UV Safety Training and Exposure Monitoring Program
description: All laboratory staff must complete UV light hazard training within 10 days, covering eye protection requirements, exposure limits per CSA Z1007, and recognition of overexposure symptoms. Provide UV-protective eyewear meeting CSA standards to all laboratory personnel at no cost. Implement an exposure time log using dosimeters for all staff working with UV equipment. Conduct monthly audits of eyewear compliance with photographic documentation. Exposures exceeding 15 minutes per shift require approval from the HSE coordinator.

name: Establish Monthly Safety Equipment Audit Program with Enforcement
description: The HSE department will conduct comprehensive monthly inspections of all safety interlocks, shielding, and protective devices on equipment in all production and testing areas. Findings will be documented in a compliance register with photographic evidence. Any disabled or non-compliant equipment will be immediately removed from service with a red tagged lockout. Supervisors will be held accountable for equipment compliance in their departments with performance metrics reviewed quarterly.

name: Implement Mandatory Edge De-flashing Protocol
description: Establish a 100% inspection and de-flashing procedure for all composite and polycarbonate parts before assembly operations. All parts must pass a tactile edge inspection using standardized test gloves. Quality inspectors will use dedicated deburring tools to remove all sharp edges and burrs. Documentation of de-flashing will be recorded in the QMS. Training will be provided to all assembly and quality personnel on proper techniques and required PPE including cut-resistant gloves.

name: Upgrade PPE Requirements for Assembly Operations
description: Issue ANSI A3 cut-resistant gloves to all assembly operators working with sharp-edged components. Provide training on proper glove selection and limitations. Implement visual signage at Line C indicating mandatory cut-resistant glove use. Conduct monthly audits of glove compliance and condition. Establish a glove replacement program with a 6-week replacement cycle.

name: Upgrade Injection Molding Connection Couplings
description: Replace all injection line couplings on Line C and all other molding machines with vibration-resistant, redundant-lock designs rated for 250°C+ applications. Install secondary safety clips on all quick-disconnect couplings to prevent accidental disconnection during operation. Retrofit all existing machines with upgraded coupling hardware and conduct pressure testing to confirm integrity. Establish a quarterly maintenance schedule to verify coupling tightness and inspect for wear. Document all coupling replacements and maintenance in equipment logs.

name: Install Thermal Containment Guards Around Injection Points
description: Design and fabricate custom stainless steel thermal shields around all injection connection points on Line C. Shields will include insulation layers and will redirect any leaked material away from operator zones. All molding machines will be retrofitted with these guards within 60 days. Guards will have hinged access panels for maintenance with interlock switches that pause operation during maintenance mode. All operators will receive training on proper use and maintenance of the guards.

name: Issue Advanced Thermal Protection Gloves and Training
description: Distribute ANSI A4 rated thermal-resistant gloves with silicone palm coating to all injection molding operators. Gloves must be rated for temperatures up to 300°C contact protection. Implement mandatory training on proper glove use, limitations, and inspection procedures. Establish a glove replacement cycle of 8 weeks or upon visible damage. Conduct monthly audits of glove use and condition. Post visual reminders at all molding stations regarding proper PPE requirements.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive monthly inspection and testing protocol for all hydraulic pump assemblies and seals across production lines. Install pressure monitoring sensors with alarm thresholds to detect anomalies before fluid leakage occurs. Technicians will document all findings in a centralized database for trend analysis. This engineering control will prevent catastrophic hydraulic failures and operator exposure to pressurized fluids. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in unexpected hydraulic system failures within 6 months.

name: Conduct Hydraulic System Hazard Awareness Training
description: Develop and deliver specialized training for all production operators on recognizing early warning signs of hydraulic system failures (vibration patterns, unusual sounds, fluid leaks). Include proper lockout/tagout procedures specific to hydraulic equipment and emergency response protocols. Training will be conducted quarterly with attendance tracking. This administrative control ensures operators can quickly identify and report issues before they escalate to dangerous situations.

name: Enhanced Edge Finishing and Quality Control Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory secondary inspection step for all composite parts exiting the finishing line, focusing specifically on edge quality and fiber deburring. Assign dedicated quality assurance staff to conduct 100% visual inspection of high-risk batches using standardized edge smoothness gauges. Parts failing inspection will be reworked immediately. Establish clear acceptance criteria documentation. This engineering/administrative hybrid control eliminates the hazard at the source by ensuring no sharp edges reach storage or assembly areas, significantly reducing laceration risks.

name: Relocate Chemical Storage and Install Secondary Containment System
description: Immediately relocate all acetone-based solvent drums to a designated chemical storage area with proper 10-foot clearance from propane tanks and other ignition sources. Install secondary containment trays designed to hold 110% of the largest container volume beneath all stored drums. Implement spill kits and absorbent materials in the storage area. Install proper ventilation and fire suppression equipment (ABC dry powder extinguishers). This engineering control eliminates the critical fire/explosion hazard by separating incompatible materials and providing containment for potential spills.

name: Implement Monthly Chemical Storage Area Audits with Documentation
description: Establish a formal monthly inspection program for all hazardous chemical storage areas with standardized checklists covering: clearance distances, secondary containment integrity, drum condition, ventilation function, and fire suppression equipment accessibility. Assign responsibility to the Chemical Safety Officer with documented findings logged in a centralized tracking system. Non-conformances must be corrected within 48 hours with follow-up verification. This administrative control ensures sustained compliance and early detection of emerging hazards through systematic, recurring surveillance.

name: Provide Hazardous Materials Storage Certification Training
description: Require all warehouse staff and supervisors to complete CNESST-compliant hazardous materials storage and handling certification training. Training will cover proper segregation of incompatible materials, secondary containment requirements, emergency response procedures, and documentation responsibilities. Training documentation and completion certificates will be maintained on file. Annual refresher training will be mandatory. This administrative control ensures personnel understand the critical importance of proper chemical storage and can identify storage violations.

name: Implement Ergonomic Job Rotation Program for Assembly Operations
description: Establish a mandatory job rotation schedule requiring assembly operators to alternate between high-repetition part removal tasks and lower-strain activities every 2 hours. This includes rotation to packaging, quality inspection, and material staging positions. Conduct ergonomic assessments for each assembly station to identify micro-break opportunities. Train all assembly staff on proper wrist positioning, stretching techniques, and early symptom recognition. Introduce anti-fatigue mats and wrist support equipment at stations. Expected outcome: 40% reduction in repetitive strain complaints within 90 days.

name: Install Ergonomic Assist Devices on Assembly Line C
description: Design and install mechanical part extraction assists and powered jigs to reduce manual gripping force required during automotive component removal. Equipment will utilize pneumatic actuators to support part positioning and extraction, reducing operator hand strain by 60%. Conduct training on proper device usage and maintenance. Implement a feedback system for operators to report device improvements. Expected outcome: Significant reduction in wrist and hand strain injuries among assembly line workers.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO and Pressure Relief Procedures for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish comprehensive lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures specifically for all hydraulic equipment maintenance. Require technicians to: (1) de-energize equipment, (2) manually release all pressure through designated relief valves, (3) bleed all residual pressure from lines, and (4) tag equipment with LOTO placards. Create visual checklists at each maintenance station. Conduct mandatory re-training for all maintenance staff on hydraulic hazards and pressure relief techniques. Inspection of LOTO compliance will occur during weekly maintenance supervisor rounds. Expected outcome: Elimination of pressure-related burn injuries on hydraulic systems.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic Line Fittings and Install Automatic Pressure Bleed Valves
description: Replace all aging hydraulic connections on injection mold equipment with improved quick-disconnect fittings designed to prevent fluid release during disconnection. Install automatic pilot-operated bleed valves on the discharge side of all hydraulic pumps serving maintenance-accessed systems. These valves will automatically relieve pressure when pump pressure exceeds safe operating range. Install pressure gauges at all service points to verify pressure relief before work begins. Conduct quarterly inspections of all hydraulic fittings for wear and deterioration. Expected outcome: Elimination of unexpected pressure releases during routine maintenance.

name: Establish Mandatory Chemical Spill Response and Floor Safety Protocol
description: Implement immediate action protocol requiring: (1) any solvent or chemical spill must be contained and marked with visible warning cones within 5 minutes, (2) affected floor areas must be cleaned using approved absorbent material and floor stripper within 30 minutes, (3) areas must be inspected and certified dry before heavy equipment operation resumes, (4) all spills must be logged in the chemical incident tracking system. Assign Material Management personnel to conduct hourly floor inspections during all shifts, with particular focus on high-traffic material handling zones. Place absorbent kits and warning equipment at 12 strategic locations throughout warehouse. Training will be mandatory for all warehouse and material handling staff with quarterly refresher training. Expected outcome: Elimination of slip hazards caused by chemical spills.

name: Install Anti-Skid Floor Treatment in High-Traffic Warehouse Zones
description: Apply permanent anti-skid coating to all warehouse floor areas where material handling equipment regularly operates, particularly areas within 50 feet of chemical storage and mixing stations. The epoxy-based coating will provide sustained friction even when exposed to oils, solvents, and moisture. Install tactile warning strips at transitions between treated and untreated surfaces. Conduct quarterly inspections of coating integrity and reapply as needed. Complementary measure: implement a preventive maintenance schedule for forklift tires, ensuring proper tread depth and pressure. Expected outcome: Significant reduction in equipment skidding and tip-over incidents.

name: Implement Mandatory Forklift Operator Retraining and Load Stability Assessment
description: Require all forklift operators to complete advanced operator certification including emergency maneuver training, load stability assessment, and hazard recognition in challenging floor conditions. Operators must successfully complete a practical skills test demonstrating ability to maintain control in slippery conditions, including simulated chemical spill scenarios. Implement a supervisor ride-along program where operations supervisors observe and assess operator techniques monthly. Establish maximum forklift speed limits of 5 mph in warehouse areas with documented spill history. All operators must complete annual retraining. Expected outcome: Enhanced operator capability to recognize and avoid hazardous conditions.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE for All Maintenance Operations
description: Implement requirement for employees performing any maintenance on injection molding equipment to wear ANSI-rated heat-resistant gloves (minimum 500°C rating) and flame-resistant long sleeves. Establish inspection protocol ensuring all PPE is in good condition before use. Conduct training for all production and maintenance staff on proper selection and use of thermal protection equipment. Supply locked storage for heat-resistant PPE at each production line. Cost includes bulk procurement of compliant equipment and storage fixtures.

name: Enhanced Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Verification System
description: Implement a two-person verification protocol for all equipment maintenance requiring energy isolation. Develop standardized LOTO checklists specific to each machine type, including verification that heating elements have cooled to safe temperatures (below 60°C) before maintenance begins. Install temperature monitoring labels on critical equipment. Conduct mandatory retraining on LOTO procedures for all maintenance technicians. Establish daily audits during first 60 days, then weekly spot-checks. Non-compliance will result in immediate suspension of maintenance privileges until retraining is completed.

name: Installation of Temperature Warning Systems on Injection Equipment
description: Install visual and audible temperature alert systems on all injection molding machines to alert operators and maintenance staff when heating elements exceed 100°C. These systems will prevent unauthorized access to hot zones when temperatures are elevated. Integrate alerts into the machine lockout sequence so equipment cannot be accessed for maintenance until temperature falls below safe threshold. Retrofit all 24 production line machines. Include quarterly calibration and maintenance contract.

name: Complete Warehouse Racking System Safety Audit and Retrofit
description: Hire certified structural engineer to conduct comprehensive safety assessment of all 47 storage racking units in Raw Materials Warehouse and Finished Goods Storage. Identify all units not meeting load weight specifications or showing signs of damage. Install proper load-bearing plates on all shelving units and reinforce base footings where needed. Reduce weight limits on existing shelving by 25% to provide safety margin and mark maximum weight capacity clearly on each shelf. Install anti-slip mats on all shelves. Implement quarterly inspection schedule with documented log maintained by Warehouse Lead. Estimated cost includes engineering assessment, materials, and installation labor.

name: Implement Automated Racking Monitoring System
description: Install load sensors on each storage rack to provide real-time alerts when weight exceeds safe limits. Integrate system with warehouse management software to prevent operators from scanning/storing items on racks that have reached capacity. Include daily automated alerts to Warehouse Lead summarizing all weight status across the facility. Provide training to all warehouse staff on reading and responding to system alerts. System will include backup battery power to maintain monitoring during power interruptions.

name: Complete Cooling System Infrastructure Replacement
description: Replace all copper piping in the cooling water circulation system (estimated 340 meters) with modern stainless steel piping resistant to corrosion from acidic additives. Upgrade to closed-loop cooling system with automated chemical monitoring and inhibitor injection system that maintains pH between 8.5-9.5. Install expansion tanks and pressure relief valves meeting current ASME standards. Include installation of isolation ball valves at all major junction points to allow partial system shutdown without full production line stoppage. Upgrade all connections to vibration-dampening fittings to reduce stress failures. Project requires 2-week production shutdown but eliminates corrosion-related failure risk for 20+ years.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Cooling Systems
description: Install ultrasonic pipe wall thickness monitoring sensors at 12 critical junction points throughout the cooling system. Establish monthly automated data collection and trend analysis to identify corrosion progression. When any sensor detects 10% reduction from baseline thickness, automatic alert triggers preventive replacement scheduling. Integrate with predictive maintenance software to forecast equipment failures 90 days in advance. Conduct quarterly training for maintenance technicians on sensor data interpretation. Maintain inventory of replacement pipe segments ready for immediate deployment. This engineering control prevents future failures by detecting degradation before rupture occurs.

name: Enhanced Cooling System Inhibitor Replacement Protocol
description: Establish mandatory inhibitor testing and replacement schedule every 6 months (currently no schedule existed). Procure and maintain inventory of inhibitor concentrate sufficient for quarterly top-ups. Install pH test kit stations at Facilities Technician workbench and near production control panels. Require weekly pH testing with results logged and reported. When pH falls below 8.0, initiate immediate inhibitor correction procedure. Conduct training for both facilities staff and production operators on inhibitor function and early warning signs of system degradation. Implement administrative controls to prevent system chemistry degradation.

name: Install Thermal Safety Interlocks on Injection Molds
description: Implement pressure relief safety interlocks on all 250+ ton injection molding machines that automatically vent internal mold cooling passages before manual access is permitted. These interlocks will be mechanically linked to mold ejection systems, ensuring complete pressure dissipation before operator contact. The system will include visual and audible indicators confirming safe conditions. Installation will prioritize high-temperature mold operations first.

name: Enhanced Mold Handling Training Program
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive mold handling training module specifically addressing pressure release hazards, residual heat assessment, and safe cooling verification procedures. All operators will complete hands-on training with simulator demonstrations. Training will be mandatory annually with refresher sessions after any equipment modifications. Documentation will be maintained in personnel files.

name: Provide Specialized Heat-Resistant Protective Equipment
description: Issue specialized heat-resistant gloves and forearm protectors (rated for 500°F+) to all operators working with injection molding equipment. Equipment will be stored at each production line and mandatory during mold maintenance activities. Gloves will be inspected monthly and replaced quarterly. Staff will receive fitting and usage training.

name: Implement Real-Time Waste Stream Tracking System
description: Deploy an automated digital waste tracking system using RFID tags and barcode scanning for all hazardous material batches. Every composite and epoxy-containing production run will generate a digital waste manifest that tracks material from generation through final disposal. System will integrate with quality control data to automatically flag non-compliant batches. Regular audits will be conducted against physical inventory.

name: Establish Composite Material Segregation Protocol
description: Create physical separation areas in the regrind facility specifically designated for composite waste versus standard plastic waste. Each area will have color-coded bins, warning signage in English and French, and dedicated containment equipment. Staff will receive training on material identification and proper segregation. Weekly audits by the Materials Supervisor will verify compliance.

name: Quarterly Environmental Compliance Training
description: Implement mandatory quarterly training for all Warehouse, Materials, and Regrind staff covering waste disposal regulations, environmental compliance requirements, and identification of hazardous versus standard waste streams. Training will include case studies of improper disposal incidents and their environmental consequences. Attendance tracking will be maintained in personnel records.

name: Install Independent Temperature Verification System
description: Install a redundant, independent digital thermometer with both display and audible alarm system on each industrial curing oven. This system will be mechanically separate from the main oven controls and will require two-step verification: operator visual confirmation on both displays AND contact temperature verification using calibrated infrared thermometer. An interlock will prevent oven door opening until both readings confirm safe entry conditions. All devices will be calibrated monthly.

name: Implement Pre-Entry Safety Checklist with Supervisor Sign-Off
description: Create and post a laminated pre-entry safety checklist at each oven station requiring operators to verify: (1) oven has cooled 30+ minutes, (2) infrared thermometer reading below 60°C, (3) main display reading below 60°C, (4) no steam visible, and (5) Supervisor or HSE staff visual approval. The checklist must be signed and dated. Non-compliance will result in retraining before resuming oven access duties.

name: Install Protective Guards Around Manual Fire Pull Stations
description: Install clear polycarbonate protective covers with hinged design around all 8 manual fire pull stations throughout the facility. The covers will require intentional lifting before activation, preventing accidental triggers during maintenance operations. Covers will be labeled with high-visibility warning tape and include clear activation instructions. This engineering control eliminates unintended discharge while maintaining emergency accessibility.

name: Conduct Fire Suppression System Sensitivity Audit
description: Commission a third-party inspection of all fire suppression systems to verify proper calibration and sensor sensitivity settings. Adjust threshold parameters to reduce false alarms while maintaining rapid response to genuine fire conditions. Install backup manual shutoff stations with training for supervisory staff. Document all adjustments and create a 12-month recalibration schedule.

name: Implement Mold Temperature Monitoring and Cool-Down Protocol
description: Install infrared temperature sensors on all injection molding machines to display real-time mold surface temperatures at operator workstations. Establish a mandatory 15-minute cool-down period with visual confirmation before manual mold handling. Create a color-coded status system (red/yellow/green) on each machine indicating thermal safety status. Integrate this protocol into the pre-shift machine setup checklist and train all operators on new requirements.

name: Upgrade Heat-Resistant PPE Requirements
description: Replace current cut-resistant gloves with rated heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C) for all personnel working in mold handling areas. Issue silicone-coated sleeve protectors for forearm protection during mold transfer operations. Conduct PPE fit and comfort training to ensure consistent use. Update PPE specification sheet and store replacement supplies in accessible locations at each production line.

name: Establish Automated Mold Transfer System Feasibility Study
description: Commission engineering assessment for partial automation of hot mold transfer using robotic arms or conveyor-based cooling stages. Evaluate feasibility for Lines A and B within 60-day timeline. This engineering control would eliminate direct operator contact with hot surfaces during peak thermal periods, addressing the root cause through substitution of manual handling.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Equipment
description: Implement comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all material handling hydraulic systems with inspections every 90 days maximum (more frequent than manufacturer requirement). Create digital tracking system to monitor service history, component wear indicators, and safety mechanism testing. Assign responsibility to Central Maintenance Workshop with quarterly reporting to HSE. Include hydraulic latch mechanism load testing and certification before each use cycle.

name: Install Secondary Safety Interlock System on Automated Racks
description: Engineering control: Install redundant mechanical safety pins that automatically engage when personnel approach elevated platforms using proximity sensors. These pins will lock the hydraulic mechanism independent of electronic controls, preventing any uncontrolled descent regardless of primary system failure. Retrofit all 12 automated storage racks in the warehouse. Include backup manual engagement handles accessible to all staff.

name: Provide Hands-On Equipment Safety Training for Material Handlers
description: Conduct mandatory 4-hour training session for all 8 material handlers covering hydraulic system failure modes, emergency release procedures, and recognition of mechanical wear indicators. Hands-on practice with equipment emergency stops and manual release valves. Annual refresher training requirement with competency testing. Create visual reference cards at each workstation.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Regrind Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all regrind mill bearings with inspections every 2 weeks, including vibration analysis and temperature monitoring. Maintenance technicians will be trained to recognize early warning signs of bearing failure. This measure directly addresses the root cause of equipment malfunction that generated the friction heat leading to the fire. Expected outcome: reduce unplanned equipment failures by 85% and eliminate friction-related fire risks.

name: Install Enhanced Dust Collection and Ventilation System
description: Retrofit the Regrind and Recycling Department with upgraded dust collection ducting and HEPA filtration to maintain air velocity above 4000 feet per minute, ensuring combustible dust does not accumulate above 1/32-inch thickness per NFPA 654. Install continuous air quality monitors to alert operators when dust levels approach critical thresholds. This engineering control eliminates the combustible dust accumulation hazard.

name: Conduct Combustible Dust Hazard Training
description: Deliver mandatory training to all personnel in regrind operations on the NFPA 654 combustible dust standard, ignition sources, and proper housekeeping protocols. Include quarterly refresher training and competency assessments. This administrative control ensures employees understand the hazard and their role in prevention through proper cleaning and equipment maintenance protocols.

name: Mandatory PPE Compliance Verification System
description: Implement a daily PPE checklist system where the machine operator and their supervisor jointly verify that all required thermal-resistant sleeves, gloves, and face shields are worn before barrel maintenance begins. Introduce visual compliance tracking with photos taken at shift start. This administrative control directly addresses the behavioral factor of non-compliance with existing PPE requirements and creates accountability through peer and supervisory oversight.

name: Refresh Machine Hazard Labeling and Remove Obstructing Labels
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all injection molding machines to ensure temperature warning labels are clearly visible, unobstructed, and legible. Remove or relocate production labels that cover or obscure critical safety warnings. Replace faded or damaged labels with high-visibility alternatives. Install additional temperature display indicators at operator eye level showing real-time barrel temperatures. This engineering control ensures hazard communication is not compromised.

name: Install Reinforced Shelving System with Load Distribution Improvements
description: Replace the existing warehouse shelving in Section A with industrial-grade racking rated for 2,000 kg per shelf with improved load distribution. Install load-limiting devices to prevent overloading and add diagonal bracing to eliminate sagging. Conduct a full load capacity recalculation considering the actual density of stored materials. This engineering control eliminates the structural deficiency and prevents future shelf failure incidents.

name: Implement Quarterly Shelving Inspection and Load Verification Program
description: Establish a quarterly inspection schedule where warehouse supervisors perform visual assessments of all shelving, measuring sag and checking for signs of structural distress. Cross-reference actual material loads against design specifications in a tracking database. Provide workers with training on proper load placement principles to distribute weight evenly across shelf surfaces. Document all findings and remediate issues within 48 hours.

name: Implement Enhanced Pre-Operational Hydraulic System Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory daily visual inspection protocol for all hydraulic fittings and connectors on injection molding lines. Operators will use a standardized checklist to identify hairline cracks, weeping connections, and pressure anomalies before each shift begins. All identified defects trigger automatic machine lockout and work order submission. Training will be provided to all production staff on proper inspection techniques and hazard recognition. Implementation includes adding visual inspection stations with magnifying equipment and pressure test logs at each molding line.

name: Retrofit Hydraulic Lines with Safety Couplings
description: Replace all existing quick-disconnect hydraulic couplings with flat-face, shutoff-style couplings on Injection Molding Lines B, C, and D. These couplings minimize fluid spray by automatically closing when disconnected. Additionally, install secondary containment trays beneath all pressure-bearing hydraulic fittings to capture any leaked fluid. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the near-miss by preventing pressurized fluid release.

name: Enhance Operator Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Training for Hydraulic Systems
description: Develop specialized LOTO training module focusing on hydraulic system isolation procedures. All operators will learn proper lockout points, energy isolation verification, and zero-energy confirmation for hydraulic circuits. The training will include case studies of similar incidents and the specific consequences of hydraulic fluid injection injuries. Competency assessments will be required with 100% passing score before independent operation on hydraulic equipment.

name: Implement Incompatible Chemical Segregation System
description: Redesign the hazardous waste storage area with clearly demarcated zones for incompatible chemical classes. Install physical barriers (bollards and safety rails) to separate oxidizers, flammable solvents, and reactive materials at least 3 meters apart. Color-coded storage locations and SDS reference stations will be placed in each zone. A new waste manifest system will require dual-signature verification that materials are compatible before consolidation. Staff will complete hazard communication training specific to chemical incompatibilities.

name: Establish No-Operate Zones During Waste Consolidation
description: Create administrative controls restricting forklift and equipment operation within 20 meters of the waste consolidation work area during active chemical transfer operations. Install motion-sensor warning lights at zone boundaries. Personnel consolidating waste materials must use two-way radio communication with equipment operators for real-time coordination. A spotter will be posted during all waste transfer activities to maintain visual oversight of equipment movement. Weekly safety meetings will review incident scenarios and near-miss reports.

name: Upgrade Emergency Response and Containment Equipment
description: Install secondary containment berms with 110% capacity around all hazardous chemical storage areas. Deploy hazmat-certified spill kits at three strategic locations within and adjacent to the waste management facility. These kits will contain absorbent materials compatible with multiple chemical classes, personal protective equipment (respirators, chemical-resistant suits), and emergency response guides. Conduct quarterly drills simulating chemical spill scenarios to maintain responder competency and validate equipment functionality.

name: Implement Mandatory Rest Break Protocol for Repetitive Tasks
description: Establish a formal work-rest schedule for all employees performing repetitive assembly and finishing tasks. For every 50 minutes of continuous work, a 10-minute break is mandatory. Electronic timers at each workstation will alert supervisors when break time is due. Cross-training will enable job rotation every 2 hours to vary muscle groups used. Compliance will be monitored through supervisor checklists and included in performance evaluations. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause by preventing cumulative strain.

name: Install Ergonomic Workstation Modifications and Part Handling Assistance
description: Redesign assembly workstations with adjustable-height tables, ergonomic hand supports, and wrist angle guides to minimize repetitive strain during part removal. Install pneumatic assist grippers (vacuum-based or mechanical) to reduce manual gripping force required for part removal by 60-70%. Provide ergonomic wrist braces and compression sleeves as PPE for high-risk tasks. Conduct individual ergonomic assessments for all employees performing these tasks and customize workstation setups accordingly.

name: Revise Production Quotas Based on Ergonomic Capacity Studies
description: Conduct time-motion studies to determine sustainable daily part removal quotas that allow for proper technique and mandated rest breaks without productivity loss. Current quotas (200+ parts/shift) were established without ergonomic input. Engineering analysis will establish a revised quota of 140-150 parts/shift that maintains reasonable production while preventing overuse injuries. This quota will be communicated to all supervisors and factored into performance management systems to remove pressure for excessive speed.

name: Establish Predictive Cooling System Maintenance Program
description: Implement a comprehensive maintenance schedule for all cooling water systems using CMMS (Computerized Maintenance Management System) to track inspection dates and replacement cycles. All cooling lines, pumps, and connections will be inspected every 6 months for corrosion, mineral buildup, and integrity. Preventive replacement of cooling lines will occur every 5 years per manufacturer specifications. Weekly visual inspections will be assigned to production coordinators. This eliminates the root cause of delayed maintenance and prevents future environmental contamination incidents.

name: Deploy Secondary Containment System for All Heat Treatment Equipment
description: Engineering control requiring installation of drip pans and secondary containment trays beneath all cooling water lines and equipment in the Post-Processing area. Each machine will have a collection system with capacity for 1.5x the fluid volume in the lines. Trays will be inspected daily and emptied according to protocol. Absorbent spill kits will be stationed at 3 locations. This contains any future leaks immediately, preventing environmental release and facilitating recovery of cooling fluid for proper disposal.

name: Implement Chemical Container Inspection and Replacement Protocol
