description: Administrative control requiring daily visual inspection of all chemical containers used in production areas. Any container showing damage to threads, seals, caps, or structural integrity must be immediately removed from service and labeled as defective. Damaged containers will be transferred to secondary containment and scheduled for proper disposal. A database will track container condition, age, and replacement dates. All operators will receive training on identifying defective containers during the daily pre-shift safety meeting. This prevents future chemical splashes from container failure.

name: Upgrade Emergency Response Infrastructure and Training
description: Engineering and administrative controls to improve response capability. Relocate eyewash station to within 30 feet of all chemical handling areas (currently 45 feet away). Install additional emergency shower station in north production zone. Conduct mandatory refresher training for all night shift personnel on chemical burn response procedures, proper eyewash station use (15+ minutes minimum), and when to activate emergency medical services. Train personnel on proper positioning to prevent chemical from entering eyes. Post clear signage with emergency numbers and station locations.

name: Require Facial Protective Equipment for Epoxy Resin Handling
description: PPE control as secondary measure. Mandate use of full face shield (impact-resistant, with chemical splash rating) and chemical-resistant safety glasses for all personnel handling epoxy resin and hardener. Require nitrile gloves rated for epoxy exposure. Ensure adequate inventory of replacement shields and glasses. Include PPE inspection in daily toolbox talks. While not eliminating the hazard, this reduces severity of chemical contact injuries and prevents eye exposure.

name: Enhanced PPE Protocol for Mold Release Agent Handling
description: Implement mandatory nitrile glove replacement every 30 minutes during production shifts, with visual PPE compliance audits at production lines. Install laminated instruction cards at each molding station displaying required PPE and chemical contact emergency procedures. Conduct toolbox talks every Monday morning emphasizing proper hand protection and mold surface hazards. Establish a non-negotiable requirement that operators must wear safety glasses and chemical-resistant gloves when handling any mold surfaces or release agents.

name: Shift Changeover Safety Communication Protocol
description: Develop and implement a standardized 5-minute safety briefing template for all shift changes, specifically covering chemical hazards, PPE requirements, and recent incidents. Create a digital handover log where outgoing shift leads document any chemical spills, equipment issues, or hazard alerts. Ensure all incoming shift supervisors review this log before authorizing production restart. This will ensure critical safety information is not lost during shift transitions and creates accountability for hazard communication.

name: Material Storage Rack Safety Overhaul
description: Install weight-rated signage on all material storage racks clearly indicating maximum load limits per shelf. Implement new stacking protocol limiting height to 5 feet maximum and requiring pyramid-style stacking with heavier materials on lower shelves. Install anti-slip shelf liners and load-stop barriers on all racks to prevent bag migration. Conduct structural engineering assessment of all racks to ensure OSHA compliance. Train all Material Handling personnel on proper stacking procedures with certification requirement before independent rack use.

name: Mandatory Mechanical Assist for Material Handling
description: Procure and deploy 3 additional powered material handling assists and pneumatic bag lifters to reduce manual lifting of materials over 25 pounds. Establish policy requiring mechanical assistance for all bags stored above shoulder height. Schedule 2-hour hands-on training for all operators on proper use of lift-assist equipment. Station equipment prominently with easy access in the drying room. Implement monthly equipment maintenance checks to ensure reliability and safety.

name: Material Handling Competency Certification Program
description: Develop and implement a formal material handling certification program with written test and practical demonstration. Cover topics including proper lifting mechanics, load assessment, rack capacity limits, emergency procedures, and incident reporting. Require annual recertification for all personnel handling materials. Create laminated competency cards displayed at each workstation. Track certification status and enforce policy that only certified workers may independently handle materials in storage areas.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Audit and Training
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all shift changeover LOTO procedures across all production lines. Implement electronic LOTO verification system requiring photographic documentation of locked/tagged equipment before shift end. Provide mandatory recertification training for all shift leads and equipment operators on LOTO requirements with emphasis on heating elements and electrical equipment. Create laminated LOTO checklist posted at each equipment station. Establish policy of 10-minute overlap between shifts specifically for LOTO verification and sign-off by both incoming and outgoing shift leads.

name: Solvent Storage and Usage Protocol Revision
description: Establish dedicated solvent handling zone minimum 15 feet from all heat sources, electrical elements, and ignition sources. Install clearly marked 'NO HOT WORK' zones around all chemical storage and use areas. Replace acetone with non-flammable alternative solvent (isopropanol-based cleaner) for routine maintenance cleaning tasks. Provide only small quantities of solvent (maximum 500ml) per shift in spill-proof containers. Mandate that all containers be capped and stored in flammable cabinet when not actively in use. Implement daily safety huddle specifically addressing solvent hazards and fire prevention.

name: Night Shift Equipment Integrity Inspection Protocol
description: Implement mandatory 15-minute pre-shift equipment walkthrough for night shift supervisor focusing on powered equipment status, heating elements, and electrical connections. Create shift-specific inspection checklist with photo documentation requirements. Establish rule that no maintenance cleaning begins until heating equipment integrity is verified and confirmed OFF by supervisor. Conduct targeted training for night shift operators emphasizing heightened vigilance during reduced staffing periods. Schedule quarterly deep maintenance inspections of all heating elements and electrical connections by qualified technician.

name: Enhanced PPE and Protective Equipment for Molding Operators
description: Implement upgraded personal protective equipment for all injection molding operators, including heat-resistant sleeves rated for 300°C+ exposure and reinforced gloves with improved insulation. Require all operators on Lines B, C, and D to wear this upgraded PPE during all mold-related tasks. Conduct a 30-minute training session for all 45 production operators covering proper donning, doffing, and maintenance of new equipment. Inspect and replace PPE weekly rather than monthly.

name: Implement Interlock Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory two-person verification system where the operator must verbally confirm safety interlock engagement before any mold access. The second person (supervisor or safety-trained operator) must physically verify the interlock status using a checklist. Document all verifications in a daily log. Provide laminated verification cards at each molding station. This engineering/administrative hybrid control directly addresses the root cause of premature machine cycling.

name: Implement Daily Forklift Safety Inspection and Alarm Testing Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily pre-shift forklift inspection checklist that includes testing the backup alarm at full volume. All 12 forklifts in the facility (electric and propane) must be checked by operators before use. Any forklift with a non-functioning alarm is immediately removed from service and tagged with a red 'OUT OF SERVICE' label. A maintenance technician must certify repairs before the forklift returns to service. Inspections are recorded in a digital log reviewed weekly by the facility coordinator. This engineering control ensures critical safety systems remain functional.

name: Install Advanced Proximity Warning System on High-Risk Forklifts
description: Retrofitting the 4 most-used forklifts (those operating in high-traffic areas like the dock and warehouse) with electronic proximity detection systems that alert both the operator and surrounding workers via audible and visual signals when vehicles come within 2 meters of each other. These systems provide redundancy beyond mechanical alarms and are particularly valuable during reverse operations. Training will be provided to all forklift operators on system interpretation and response procedures.

name: Replace and Upgrade Ventilation System with Predictive Monitoring
description: Replace the failed 15-year-old centrifugal fan unit with a new high-efficiency model rated for continuous composite processing operations. Integrate a real-time vibration and temperature monitoring system that automatically alerts maintenance staff when bearing temperatures exceed safe thresholds or vibration patterns indicate early degradation. Install backup portable ventilation units that can be rapidly deployed in case of primary system failure. The predictive monitoring system will provide email and SMS alerts to facility coordinators and EHS staff, enabling intervention before catastrophic failure occurs.

name: Establish Quarterly Ventilation System Maintenance and Inspection Program
description: Implement a formal quarterly maintenance schedule for all ventilation systems, conducted by certified HVAC technicians rather than relying solely on predictive algorithms. Inspections will include bearing condition assessment, filter replacement, ductwork cleanliness, and motor performance testing. Documentation will be maintained in a centralized database. Additionally, conduct annual air quality testing in the composite processing area to verify solvent vapor concentrations remain below occupational exposure limits. This engineering and administrative control provides layered protection against ventilation failure.

name: Install Backup Emergency Ventilation with Manual Override
description: Install an independent backup ventilation unit in the Composite Materials Processing Area that can operate on standby power and be manually activated by any staff member in case of primary system failure. Mount clear signage indicating the location and operation of this emergency system. Include quarterly testing and maintenance of the backup unit to ensure reliability. This engineering control ensures continuous air circulation even if the primary system fails, preventing hazardous vapor accumulation.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Protocol
description: Establish a dual-verification system for all lockout/tagout procedures where a second trained technician must independently verify energy isolation before maintenance begins. All isolation points must be clearly labeled with permanent identification markers. Weekly audits of LOTO compliance will be conducted by the Maintenance and Engineering department using a standardized checklist. All employees performing maintenance must complete refresher LOTO training within 30 days, with certification renewal required annually.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Safety Equipment
description: Install pilot-operated check valves on all hydraulic line disconnect points to prevent sudden pressure release. Replace all standard hydraulic hoses with high-pressure rated, color-coded hoses meeting ISO 1402 standards. Install pressure relief valves on the manifold to limit system pressure. Equip the maintenance workshop with portable hydraulic testing equipment to verify pressure is zero before disconnection. Purchase and distribute high-grade cut-resistant gloves rated for hydraulic fluid exposure to all maintenance personnel.

name: Establish Hydraulic Safety Training Program
description: Develop and deliver specialized training on hydraulic fluid injection injury recognition, prevention, and emergency response. Training must include hands-on demonstrations of proper hose disconnection techniques, pressure bleeding procedures, and immediate first aid for injection injuries. All maintenance staff and equipment operators must complete this certification program. Documentation will be maintained in employee training files with annual refresher sessions required.

name: Install Cable and Hose Management System
description: Install overhead cable trays and hose routing systems in the Assembly and Finishing Department to eliminate floor-level air hoses. All pneumatic lines will be routed through secure overhead channels suspended from the ceiling structure. Existing floor-level hoses will be consolidated and secured using cable clips rated for pneumatic hose pressure, spaced every 1.5 meters maximum. All hose routing changes must be completed within 30 days, with inspection and certification by Facilities Management.

name: Establish Daily Workstation Safety Inspection Checklist
description: Create and implement a standardized daily safety checklist for all assembly stations that includes verification of clear floor space, proper hose routing, and removal of trip hazards. Each shift supervisor must complete the inspection at shift start and document findings. The checklist will be posted at each workstation and stored digitally for trend analysis. Assembly operators will be trained to identify and report potential trip hazards immediately to their supervisor.

name: Implement Drum Storage Rack Safety Standards
description: Replace all existing drum storage racks with certified industrial-grade racks designed for hazardous material storage. Racks must have maximum weight-rated capacity clearly marked and include anti-slip pallet platforms. All drums will be secured with chain or strap restraints on each tier. Racks will be anchored to the floor to prevent tipping. A maximum stacking height of 2 drums per position will be enforced with clear markings. The storage layout will be redesigned to separate incompatible chemicals with appropriate spacing.

name: Establish Chemical Inventory and Storage Procedures
description: Develop and document comprehensive standard operating procedures (SOPs) for chemical inventory management including proper stacking limits, segregation requirements, and handling protocols. All personnel working in chemical storage areas must complete training on these procedures and sign acknowledgment forms. A laminated SOP card will be posted at eye level in the storage area. Monthly audits will verify compliance with stacking and segregation standards. Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov will coordinate with all storage personnel to ensure understanding of new procedures.

name: Upgrade Spill Response Equipment and Training
description: Install permanent spill containment stations at all chemical storage areas with absorbent material dispensers, portable containment berms, personal protective equipment (respirators, nitrile gloves, eye protection), and first aid stations. All employees working in chemical areas must complete spill response training with quarterly refresher drills. Emergency response procedures will be posted visibly and emergency contact information will be programmed into facility communication systems.

name: Implement Monthly Forklift Charging Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory monthly preventive maintenance schedule for all electric forklift charging stations, including visual inspection of cables for corrosion, battery terminal cleanliness, and charging system functionality. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie will coordinate with equipment vendors to develop a comprehensive inspection checklist and ensure all maintenance staff are trained on proper inspection procedures. This engineering and administrative control will prevent battery acid exposure incidents and extend equipment lifespan.

name: Install Ventilation Upgrades in Material Storage Area
description: Install additional exhaust ventilation ports near all battery charging stations in the Raw Materials Warehouse to prevent accumulation of battery acid fumes and chemical vapors. The enhanced ventilation system will include automated sensors that detect chemical odors and trigger increased airflow. This engineering control addresses the root cause by eliminating vapor exposure at the source and will protect all employees working in the warehouse.

name: Establish Mandatory Thermostat Calibration Schedule
description: Implement a quarterly calibration and certification program for all injection molding machine thermostats, reducing the maintenance interval from 18 months to 3 months. Production Engineer Sébastien Carrier will coordinate with external calibration specialists to establish baseline measurements and create a digital tracking system. Temperature sensors will be replaced annually regardless of performance to ensure accuracy. This engineering control will prevent thermal burns by maintaining equipment safety parameters.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Thermal Protection
description: Replace all standard heat-resistant gloves with advanced aramid-composite gloves rated for continuous exposure up to 250°C in the injection molding line. Additionally, provide all technicians with thermal alert bracelets that change color at 80°C to provide immediate visual warning of elevated temperatures. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert will ensure all evening and day shift technicians receive fitting and training on the new PPE.

name: Implement Pre-Shift Equipment Temperature Verification
description: Require all production technicians to perform a 5-minute pre-shift temperature verification using infrared thermometers at each injection molding machine, documenting readings in a digital logbook. Any temperature variance exceeding ±5°C from established baseline will trigger immediate maintenance alerts. This administrative control ensures early detection of thermostat failures and prevents employees from working with malfunctioning equipment.

name: Repair Roof Leak and Restore Wall Structural Integrity
description: Engage licensed contractors to repair the roof leak that caused water infiltration damage to the maintenance workshop wall. Once the wall moisture is remediated and dried, structural reinforcement will be installed, including installation of new wall anchors rated for 1000-pound static loads. The workshop wall will be re-inspected by structural engineers before ladder storage equipment is reinstalled. This elimination and engineering control addresses the root cause by removing the water damage hazard and restoring safe mounting surfaces.

name: Relocate Ladder Storage to Secure Wall-Mounted System
description: Install a new commercial-grade ladder storage system on the reinforced wall with individual ladder cradles that distribute weight evenly and prevent shifting. The new system will be mounted on structural studs with Grade 8 bolts and will feature adjustable cradles to accommodate ladders of various sizes. All ladders will be individually secured to prevent accidental dislodging. This engineering control eliminates the risk of falling ladders by providing secure, properly engineered storage.

name: Conduct Workshop Hazard Communication Training
description: Provide all maintenance staff with mandatory training on identifying and reporting structural hazards, water damage, and equipment instability risks. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante will lead a 2-hour workshop session covering near-miss reporting procedures, communication protocols, and the importance of not using equipment that appears compromised. Documentation of training attendance will be maintained in employee records.

name: Implement Static Discharge Prevention Protocol
description: Install ground straps and conductive flooring in the chemical storage room to eliminate static discharge hazards. Require all personnel handling volatile solvents to wear anti-static wrist straps connected to grounded work surfaces. Provide training on proper grounding procedures and conduct monthly inspections of all grounding equipment. This engineering control will directly address the root cause of the fire by preventing the static discharge that ignited the acetone vapors.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Ventilation System
description: Install a dedicated mechanical ventilation system with increased air exchanges per hour (minimum 8 ACH) in the chemical storage room to rapidly disperse solvent vapors. Ensure the system includes explosion-proof components rated for Class I Division 2 hazardous locations. Add vapor detection sensors that trigger increased ventilation automatically when solvent concentrations exceed 25% of the lower explosive limit. This will reduce vapor accumulation and minimize ignition risk.

name: Establish Chemical Handling and Fire Safety Training Program
description: Develop a comprehensive training module covering proper static discharge prevention, safe solvent handling procedures, and emergency response protocols. All employees working in or near the chemical storage area must complete this training quarterly. Include practical demonstrations of grounding procedures, proper container handling, and fire extinguisher operation. Document training completion and maintain records for compliance purposes.

name: Implement Automated Equipment Maintenance Scheduling System
description: Deploy a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) that tracks all preventive maintenance tasks for chemical dispensing equipment across all production lines. Set automatic alerts for overdue inspections and require sign-off documentation from maintenance technicians. The system will ensure that routine equipment checks on mold release agent dispensers, chemical pumps, and related equipment occur on a strict schedule regardless of shift changes or staffing variations. This administrative control will prevent future maintenance gaps.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment Requirements
description: Mandate that all assembly operators working with injection molding equipment use chemical-resistant safety glasses with side shields, not just standard safety glasses. Provide operators with respiratory protection (P100 particulate masks) to be worn when working near mold release agent dispensers. Conduct fit-testing for all respiratory equipment and maintain certification records. Update the assembly workstation procedures to require PPE inspection at the start of each shift.

name: Install Interlock Safety Guards on All CNC Equipment
description: Replace all removable machine guards on CNC milling machines with permanently affixed guards that include mechanical interlocks. These interlocks will prevent the cutting tool from operating when guards are open or partially removed. Install secondary sensing systems that halt machine operation if any portion of a guard is disturbed during operation. This engineering control eliminates the ability of operators to bypass safety features to access workpieces, preventing a repeat of this incident.

name: Implement Comprehensive Lockout/Tagout Program with Enforcement
description: Establish mandatory LOTO procedures requiring that all CNC machines be completely de-energized and locked out before any maintenance or guard removal occurs. Conduct quarterly audits of LOTO compliance with discipline for violations. Require each technician to carry an individual lock and key, ensuring only they can remove their lock. Provide advanced LOTO training to all maintenance personnel covering proper procedures, energy source identification, and emergency procedures. Establish a verification checklist that must be signed off before each maintenance task begins.

name: Upgrade Emergency Stop System and Preventive Maintenance
description: Perform immediate inspection and testing of all emergency stop buttons across all CNC equipment to ensure proper function. Replace any E-stop buttons with non-functioning electrical connections and upgrade to redundant E-stop systems that operate independently. Implement daily visual inspections of E-stop button responsiveness by operators before beginning work. Add emergency stop system testing to the monthly preventive maintenance schedule with documented proof of function testing.

name: Mandate Heavy-Duty Cut-Resistant Gloves and Hand Protection
description: Require all maintenance technicians working with rotating equipment and sharp tools to wear ANSI cut-level A7 or higher cut-resistant gloves rated for protection against machinery hazards. Provide technicians with specialized hand armor or kevlar sleeves for extended milling operations. Conduct monthly safety briefings emphasizing the risks of partial guard removal and the importance of proper PPE usage. Maintain an incident tracking system to monitor hand injuries and identify patterns.

name: Electrical Infrastructure Audit and Upgrade
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all electrical outlets and circuits in chemical storage areas with particular focus on high-demand zones. Install dedicated circuits with appropriate amperage for each piece of equipment used in solvent handling areas. Replace all overloaded outlet boxes with higher capacity electrical distribution panels. Install individual circuit breakers with lower trip thresholds (20A maximum) on all solvent handling equipment. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of overloaded circuits and prevents electrical fires.

name: Chemical Storage Area Fire Prevention Training
description: Implement mandatory quarterly training for all personnel working in or accessing chemical storage areas. Training will cover: electrical fire hazards, proper equipment load management, fire alarm response procedures, evacuation routes, and safe solvent handling. Include hands-on demonstration of fire extinguisher use and location mapping of all alarm stations and emergency exits. Document training completion for all employees with refresher sessions scheduled every 90 days.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic systems on injection molding equipment. All high-pressure hoses must be inspected monthly for signs of corrosion, wear, or deformation and replaced every 36 months maximum (per manufacturer specifications). Create a tracked maintenance log for each line with digital alerts when hoses approach replacement dates. Train all operators to recognize early warning signs of hose degradation. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the root cause of the rupture and prevents future failures.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Hydraulic Lines
description: Install drip containment trays and secondary catch systems under all high-pressure hydraulic hose assemblies on production lines to capture any fluid leaks before they contaminate materials or equipment. Line the containment areas with absorbent material rated for hydraulic fluid. Install visual indicators (float switches) that trigger alerts when fluid accumulates. This engineering control prevents secondary damage and contamination.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Rack Systems with Safety Features
description: Replace existing chemical storage shelving with commercial-grade industrial racks featuring: anti-slip surfaces, secondary containment basins on each shelf level, and side rails to prevent container rolloff. Implement a maximum storage height limit of 1.2 meters for containers over 5 kilograms. Install shelf dividers to prevent container movement during normal handling. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of container falls.

name: Chemical Handling and Spill Response Training Program
description: Develop and implement mandatory training for all personnel handling chemicals covering: proper lifting techniques, container inspection procedures, spill response protocols, respiratory protection requirements, and confined space awareness. Include quarterly drills using simulated spill scenarios to ensure competency. Establish a 'buddy system' for chemical handling where no single person works alone in chemical storage. Create laminated quick-reference cards at all spill response stations.

name: Implement Quarterly Thermostat Calibration Program
description: Establish a formalized preventive maintenance schedule specifically for all material drying equipment thermostats across Lines A-D. Schedule monthly visual inspections and quarterly calibration checks using certified equipment. Assign responsibility to Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux with backup coverage. Create digital tracking system integrated with maintenance software to flag overdue calibrations. This directly addresses the root cause of the near-miss by ensuring temperature control devices remain within acceptable tolerances, preventing dangerous overheating incidents.

name: Conduct Operator Training on Temperature Anomaly Recognition
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training module for all injection molding operators covering recognition of visual and operational indicators of temperature control failures. Training will include safe response procedures, proper lockout-tagout protocol before any investigation, and escalation procedures. Include case studies of similar incidents. All production operators on day and evening shifts must complete training within 14 days. This engineering-level administrative control ensures operators can quickly identify hazardous conditions before attempting intervention.

name: Implement 100% Burr Inspection Protocol
description: Establish mandatory 100% visual and tactile inspection of all composite and molded parts before they enter assembly operations. Create standardized burr-detection stations with specialized magnification equipment and tactile-checking gloves. Each part must pass inspection before advancing to assembly. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source by preventing defective parts from reaching assembly workers. Expected outcome: zero hand laceration incidents from sharp edge contact within 90 days.

name: Revise Production Scheduling to Prioritize Safety
description: Modify production scheduling protocols to explicitly prevent quality assurance shortcuts during high-demand periods. Establish a hierarchy where safety compliance is non-negotiable and cannot be overridden by production quotas. Implement a process where production planners and QC managers meet weekly to balance throughput with quality requirements. Train all supervisory staff on this new policy. Document this in the employee handbook and production guidelines. This administrative control ensures that pressure to meet deadlines does not result in safety protocol violations.

name: Develop Forklift Wheel and Tire Inspection Checklist
description: Create a detailed pre-shift inspection checklist specifically addressing forklift wheels, tires, and structural integrity. Checklist must include visual inspection for cracks, bulges, separations, and metallurgical defects; measurement of tire tread depth; verification of rim integrity; and load capacity verification. Provide checklist in both English and French. Train all equipment operators and shift supervisors on proper use. Implement the checklist as part of the daily pre-shift maintenance protocol. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause by establishing systematic inspection procedures that catch defects before equipment operation.

name: Implement Quarterly Forklift Wheel Assembly Replacement Program
description: Establish a proactive equipment maintenance schedule that replaces all forklift wheel assemblies every 18 months or after 2,000 operational hours, whichever comes first. Partner with Toyota forklift service provider to source genuine replacement components and ensure proper installation by certified technicians. Maintain inventory of spare wheel assemblies to minimize downtime. This substitution control replaces potentially defective wheels with known-good components before critical failure occurs, preventing future tip-over incidents and equipment damage.

name: Mandatory Forklift Operations Refresher Training
description: Require all forklift operators and equipment maintenance personnel to complete a 4-hour refresher training on safety procedures, load securing techniques, and emergency response protocols. Training must be delivered by a certified CNESST instructor. Emphasize the critical importance of pre-shift inspections and proper escalation procedures when equipment defects are suspected. Conduct training for all three shifts within 14 days. This administrative control reinforces safety culture and ensures operators understand their responsibility in identifying and reporting equipment hazards.

name: Install Localized Spill Response Stations
description: Install three strategically positioned emergency spill kits within the Material Drying and Preparation Room, with one kit located directly adjacent to the chemical transfer station. Each kit will contain absorbent materials specific to acetone and other solvents used in the facility. All personnel working in UNIT-016 will receive quarterly training on kit location and proper spill containment procedures. Signage indicating kit locations and emergency procedures will be prominently displayed.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Transfer Equipment
description: Establish a monthly inspection and maintenance program for all chemical transfer pumps and pressure valves throughout the facility. All transfer equipment will be inspected by maintenance personnel, pressure relief valves will be tested for proper function, and worn components will be replaced before failure occurs. Inspection records will be maintained and reviewed quarterly. Operators will receive training on visual inspection procedures to identify equipment degradation between formal maintenance cycles.

name: Upgrade Ventilation Monitoring in Chemical Handling Areas
description: Install real-time air quality monitors in the Material Drying and Preparation Room that display acetone vapor concentrations and automatically activate enhanced ventilation when concentrations exceed 75% of the regulatory threshold. Install audible alarms that alert personnel to activate backup ventilation systems. Quarterly calibration of monitoring equipment will be scheduled with preventive maintenance records maintained.

name: Replace Corroded Cabinet Door Latches on All Molding Lines
description: Conduct comprehensive inspection of all electrical cabinets on injection molding lines A through D. Replace all corroded, damaged, or worn door latches with stainless steel self-locking latches that provide positive mechanical engagement. Upgrade all cabinet doors to include secondary safety catches that prevent accidental opening. This engineering control eliminates the potential for unintended cabinet access to energized components during equipment operation.

name: Establish Quarterly Electrical Cabinet Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a formal quarterly inspection program for all electrical cabinets, focusing on door latch mechanisms, seal integrity, and corrosion signs. Maintenance personnel will document findings on standardized inspection forms. Any deficiencies will be corrected within 48 hours. Training will be provided to maintenance and production supervisors on proper inspection procedures and criteria for immediate shutdown of equipment if cabinet integrity is compromised.

name: Implement Post-Maintenance Equipment Verification Checklist
description: Develop and implement a mandatory equipment status verification checklist for all maintenance work involving critical environmental control systems, including cooling water collection tanks and overflow valves. After any maintenance activity, maintenance personnel must complete the checklist documenting that all safety-critical components are returned to proper operational status. Supervisory sign-off is required before equipment is returned to operation. Checklists will be retained as compliance records and reviewed monthly.

name: Install Secondary Overflow Alarm on Cooling Water Collection System
description: Install a low-level sensor and audible alarm on the collection tank that alerts operators when water levels rise toward the normal overflow point. Install a high-level alarm that automatically triggers system shutdown if water approaches tank capacity. This engineering control provides multiple layers of protection against overflow conditions. Operators will receive training on alarm responses and emergency procedures.

name: Install Secondary Containment Systems
description: Implement dedicated secondary containment tubs and spill kits in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Each chemical transfer station will have a containment tub with at least 110% capacity of the largest container being handled. Absorbent materials, drain covers, and spill kits will be stored in accessible locations. Staff will receive training on proper use of containment systems and spill response procedures. This engineering control eliminates the risk of uncontained spills reaching facility floors and drainage systems.

name: Enhance Chemical Handling Training
description: Develop and implement comprehensive training module for all personnel handling chemicals, focusing on proper drum positioning, bung plug inspection, pallet jack operation with pressurized containers, and spill response procedures. Training will include hands-on demonstration with dummy drums and monthly refresher sessions. All material handlers will be certified before handling hazardous materials. This administrative control ensures consistent safe practices across all shifts.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protection PPE
description: Replace all heat-resistant work gloves with high-temperature aramid-lined gloves rated for continuous exposure up to 250°C. Establish a replacement schedule requiring inspection every 30 days and replacement every 90 days regardless of visible wear. Provide three pairs per operator per shift. Conduct fit testing and comfort trials to ensure compliance. This engineering/PPE control directly addresses the inadequate thermal protection that contributed to the burn injury.

name: Implement Mandatory Mold Cooling Protocol
description: Establish written standard operating procedure requiring all molds to cool to maximum 50°C before any manual maintenance or residue removal. Install temperature monitoring stickers on all mold surfaces. Create a 15-minute minimum waiting period after mold shutdown before operator contact. This procedure will be posted at each molding station and reinforced in monthly toolbox talks. Add this requirement to the pre-shift safety checklist. This administrative control ensures operators never contact dangerously hot mold surfaces.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Program for Ventilation Systems
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all facility ventilation systems using computerized maintenance management software (CMMS). Schedule quarterly lubrication of all fan bearings, semi-annual filter replacement, and annual motor inspection. Assign responsibility to Maintenance and Engineering department with monthly compliance audits. Create redundant alerts system to prevent schedule lapses. This engineering/administrative control ensures ventilation equipment remains operational and prevents catastrophic failures that expose workers to hazardous airborne contaminants.

name: Install Backup Ventilation System
description: Install a secondary portable ventilation unit in UNIT-015 that can be rapidly deployed if primary ventilation fails. Unit will be equipped with HEPA and activated carbon filters appropriate for glass fiber and VOC removal. Conduct monthly operational tests and staff training. Establish clear protocols for activation and deployment. This engineering control provides redundancy and reduces the duration of exposure during equipment failures, protecting worker health during maintenance transitions.

name: Enhance Ventilation Monitoring and Alerts
description: Install real-time air quality sensors and ventilation system monitors in UNIT-015 with automated alerts when airflow falls below safe operating parameters or when particulate levels exceed thresholds. Connect sensors to facility emergency alert system. Train all operators on interpreting alert signals and emergency evacuation procedures. Conduct quarterly drills. This administrative/engineering control provides early warning of ventilation system degradation, enabling rapid response before worker exposure becomes critical.

name: Replace All High-Pressure Hydraulic Hoses
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all hydraulic hose systems across the 32 injection molding machines. Replace any hoses over 15 years old with new certified hoses rated for current operating pressures. Implement a preventive maintenance schedule requiring hose replacement every 10 years or upon visual inspection indicating degradation. All replacement hoses will be ISO 4414 compliant and tested to 1.5x rated pressure before installation. This addresses the root cause of equipment age and lack of preventive maintenance.

name: Install Secondary Containment Under Hydraulic Equipment
description: Install drip pans and secondary containment systems beneath all high-pressure hydraulic manifolds and connection points on injection molding machines. Containment capacity must meet or exceed 150% of system fluid volume. This engineering control will prevent hydraulic spills from reaching the production floor and creating slip hazards. Pans will be inspected weekly and emptied as needed. This reduces environmental exposure and improves worker safety.

name: Enhanced Hydraulic System Training Program
description: Develop and deliver mandatory quarterly training for all machine setters and maintenance staff on hydraulic system safety, including hose inspection procedures, pressure relief protocols, and emergency response. Training will include hands-on identification of hose degradation signs (cracking, bulging, leaks) and proper lockout/tagout procedures before maintenance. Include scenario-based training on responding to hydraulic ruptures. This administrative control improves worker awareness and response capability.

name: Implement Automated Edge Deburring System
description: Install a robotic edge deburring station downstream of the injection molding process where all composite parts are automatically processed to remove sharp edges and micro-burrs before manual handling. System will use abrasive finishing and tumbling technology to produce smooth edges meeting ISO 4287 surface roughness standards. This eliminates the hazard at the source rather than relying on PPE, following the hierarchy of controls. Expected to reduce sharp edge injuries by 95% and improve part quality consistency.

name: Supply Cut-Resistant Gloves and Hand Protection
description: Procure and distribute ANSI A3 or higher cut-resistant gloves to all operators handling unfinished composite parts. Gloves must provide adequate tactile sensitivity for part inspection while protecting against laceration hazards. Establish a mandatory PPE policy requiring use when handling rough-edged components. Gloves will be available in multiple sizes and replaced as needed. Include training on proper glove selection and limitations. While this is a PPE control (lowest in hierarchy), it serves as interim protection until automated deburring is installed.

name: Install Secondary Containment for All Flammable Liquids
description: Install purpose-built secondary containment systems for all flammable liquid storage in the hazardous waste management area and chemical storage building. Each containment must meet or exceed 110% of the largest container volume and be constructed from compatible, impermeable materials. Implement labeling and inventory control systems to track all flammable materials. Conduct monthly inspections of containment integrity. This engineering control prevents future environmental releases and meets regulatory requirements under CAA and water protection regulations.

name: Environmental Compliance Training and Chemical Handling Certification
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training for all personnel handling hazardous materials covering proper storage, secondary containment requirements, spill response procedures, and regulatory compliance. Include competency-based certification requiring employees to demonstrate proper container handling, storage location selection, and emergency response. Training must cover WHMIS requirements and facility-specific protocols. Require annual recertification. Administrative control that ensures personnel understand their responsibilities and regulatory requirements.

name: Install Automated Floor Drain Isolation and Monitoring System
description: Install automated drain isolation valves with flow detection sensors in the hazardous waste management area. System will automatically close drains when contaminated liquid approaches and alert facility management via the SCADA system. Install absorbent containment barriers around all floor drains. This secondary containment measure prevents environmental contamination from reaching municipal water systems. Include quarterly system testing and maintenance procedures.

name: Install Interlock System Guard Redundancy
description: Engineer and install a secondary mechanical interlock that prevents robotic arm activation when the emergency stop button circuit is compromised. This dual-redundancy system will ensure that even if one safety mechanism fails, the robotic arm cannot operate. Additionally, implement a fail-safe design where loss of signal defaults to a safe state. This engineering control addresses the root cause by eliminating the possibility of unexpected robot activation during maintenance operations.

name: Implement Robotic Equipment Lockout Certification Program
description: Develop and mandate a specialized LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) certification program specifically for robotic equipment maintenance. All personnel working on or near automated machinery must complete this training and demonstrate competency in properly isolating energy sources before any maintenance work begins. Include quarterly refresher training and compliance audits. This administrative control ensures consistent safe work practices and accountability.

name: Install Permanent Cable and Hose Management System
description: Replace temporary air hose fastening with a permanent overhead cable tray system and floor-mounted conduit channels in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Route all compressed air lines, electrical cables, and utility hoses through these enclosed pathways, elevated at least 8 inches above floor level or installed flush with the floor in protective channels. Install directional signage and clear zone markings. This engineering control eliminates the primary trip hazard by removing hoses and cables from walking surfaces.

name: Conduct Workplace Layout and Ergonomics Assessment
description: Commission a comprehensive assessment of the Composite Materials Processing Area to identify all potential trip hazards, poor ergonomic layouts, and material handling inefficiencies. Work with production staff to redesign workflow paths and equipment placement. Implement yellow floor markings for safe walkways and identify clear zones for material staging. Provide staff training on the new layout and safe material handling techniques. This administrative and engineering control creates a safer, more organized workspace.

name: Implement Quarterly Mold Release Equipment Inspections
description: Establish a formal quarterly inspection program for all mold release agent dispensing systems across the 32 injection molding machines. Inspections will include visual checks for cracks, leaks, and proper nozzle function. Maintenance technicians will document findings and schedule repairs during planned maintenance windows. This engineering control prioritizes early detection of equipment degradation before hazardous exposures occur, reducing reliance on operator vigilance alone.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays Under Dispensers
description: Retrofit all mold release agent dispensers with secondary containment trays to capture leaked or misted aerosols. This engineering control will reduce airborne exposure and prevent floor contamination. Trays will be made of chemically resistant material with drain valves for controlled disposal. Implementation includes training operators on tray maintenance and replacement procedures.

name: Replace Gravity-Feed Transfer System with Pressurized Pump System
description: Engineering control eliminating the gravity-feed transfer method by installing a pressurized pump system with redundant safety valves and automated shut-off mechanisms. The new system will include pressure relief valves set below coupling failure thresholds, regular pressure testing protocols, and quick-disconnect couplings designed to prevent accidental separation. This substitution reduces chemical spill risk by 85% compared to gravity-feed systems and provides better control over transfer rates.

name: Install Automated Chemical Spill Detection and Response System
description: Deploy an automated system with moisture and chemical sensors that detect spills larger than 5 liters and trigger immediate alarms, ventilation system activation, and optional foam suppression in chemical storage areas. The system integrates with facility management software for real-time alerts to safety coordinators and emergency responders. This engineering control provides rapid response capability independent of operator awareness.

name: Implement Monthly Chemical Transfer Procedure Audits
description: Administrative control establishing monthly observational audits of chemical transfer operations by safety personnel. Audits will verify proper coupling inspection, equipment testing, containment preparation, and adherence to transfer procedures. Operators will receive immediate corrective feedback, and findings will inform training updates. This control leverages administrative procedures to maintain consistent safe practices.

name: Install Automatic Deburring Station for Composite Parts
description: Engineering control implementing an automated deburring workstation positioned at the warehouse receiving area where all composite parts are deburred immediately upon arrival before transfer to packaging. This eliminates the hazard at the source rather than relying on operator awareness. The station includes rotary sanding equipment with dust collection and operator guards. All parts processed through the station before reaching assembly areas.

name: Implement Cut-Resistant Glove Requirement for Part Handling
description: Administrative control requiring all assembly and packaging personnel to wear ANSI A4 cut-resistant gloves when handling newly received composite parts, molded components with unfinished edges, or any parts not yet certified as deburred. Training will emphasize proper glove selection, fit, and limitations. Gloves will be provided at no cost to employees. While PPE is a lower-level control, this provides immediate protection while engineering controls are implemented.

name: Implement Enhanced Powered Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily inspection checklist for all powered material handling equipment, including visual inspection of hydraulic hoses, coupling nuts, and steering mechanisms. Maintenance supervisor will mark up inspection forms with specific tightening torque specifications. All operators must complete the checklist before each shift and report any anomalies immediately. Inspections will be logged in the maintenance management system for trending and historical tracking. This addresses the root cause of inadequate preventive maintenance that allowed the hydraulic coupling to loosen over time.

name: Install Speed-Limiting Governors on Pallet Jacks
description: Retrofit all powered pallet jacks with mechanical speed-limiting governors that cap maximum velocity to 3 mph in warehouse areas. This engineering control reduces the potential for high-impact collisions if steering fails. The governors will be calibrated by the equipment manufacturer and tested quarterly. Additionally, install reflective warning strips on all jacks to increase visibility in low-light warehouse conditions.

name: Calibrate and Replace Temperature Control Systems
description: All heated mixing tanks will undergo immediate calibration verification by an external instrument calibration service. Any tank with temperature deviation exceeding ±2°C will have its control module replaced. Install redundant high-temperature alarm systems that trigger at 70°C and alert operators via audible alarm and visual indicator. Temperature dataloggers will be installed on all critical heating equipment to provide automatic historical documentation of temperature excursions. Equipment logs will be reviewed monthly.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment and Work Procedures
description: All chemical mixing operators will be issued flame-resistant sleeves (Nomex) that extend from wrist to mid-shoulder, rated for 200°C contact temperature. Operators must wear long sleeves at all times in the mixing area. Implement a new procedure requiring operators to use remote temperature probes rather than manual contact assessment. All equipment in the mixing area will be fitted with protective shrouds around protruding valves and handles to prevent sleeve entanglement. Quarterly refresher training will be conducted on burn prevention and first aid response.

name: Establish Heat Source Segregation and Clearance Standards
description: Implement mandatory 48-inch clearance distances between all heat-generating equipment (heat lamps, shredders, dryers) and scrap/waste storage bins. Install physical barriers (perforated steel fencing with 6-inch base elevation) around all heat sources to prevent accidental contact with stored materials. Mark all heat source areas with high-visibility yellow and red striping. Conduct monthly inspections using thermal imaging to identify any equipment operating outside normal temperature ranges. All heat lamp fixtures will be upgraded to models with automatic shut-off if proximity sensors detect obstruction.

name: Install Automatic Fire Suppression System in Recycling Area
description: Install a wet chemical fire suppression system specifically designed for Class D fires (plastic and polymeric materials) above the regrind and recycling work areas. System will include automated detection via temperature-sensitive heads that trigger at 155°C, supplemented by manual pull-station controls. The system will be maintained by a certified fire protection company with quarterly inspections. Install additional Class D dry powder extinguishers (15-pound capacity) at 4 strategic locations around the recycling department, with operators receiving annual training on proper deployment technique.

name: Implement Plastic Waste Heat Management and Ventilation Upgrade
description: Install a dedicated ventilation system with 6 air changes per hour in the regrind area to dissipate heat and moisture that can contribute to spontaneous ignition in compacted waste. Scrap bins will be fitted with perforated bottoms and elevated on racks to allow air circulation underneath. All bins will be limited to 60% capacity to prevent material compaction. Implement a policy requiring scrap bins to be emptied every 4 hours during operations. Install temperature monitoring sensors in bins that alert operators when material temperature exceeds 55°C, indicating potential heat generation.

name: Implement Dull-Edge Part Removal Tools
description: Procure and distribute specialized plastic part removal tools with rounded, dulled edges designed specifically for injection molding operations. These tools will replace the current manual hand removal method for high-volume parts. Train all Line C operators on proper tool usage during their next shift toolbox talk. Expected outcome: reduce sharp edge contact incidents by 85% while maintaining production efficiency. Implementation will include tool storage at each workstation.

name: Enhanced Cut-Resistant Glove Program
description: Upgrade from standard latex gloves to reinforced cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 rating) for all Line C operators performing part removal. Establish a glove replacement schedule every 15 days or upon visible wear. Conduct a 30-minute training session on proper glove fit and care. Maintain an inventory of replacement gloves at the workstation. This addresses both the repetitive strain and laceration hazards in the finishing department.

name: Install Automated Spill Containment System
description: Install stainless steel secondary containment trays beneath all chemical transfer stations in the mixing room with capacity exceeding 110% of the largest container volume. Add absorbent mat stations and spill kit placement within 2 meters of each transfer point. This engineering control will capture any liquid spills before they contact skin. Training will be provided on proper containment procedures. Expected reduction in chemical contact incidents by 90%.

name: Mandatory Chemical Protective Equipment Upgrade
description: Establish requirement that all personnel in the chemical storage and mixing room wear face shields (over regular safety glasses), chemical-resistant long-sleeved aprons, and nitrile-backed gloves rated for organic solvents. Create a pre-shift PPE checklist that supervisors must verify. Stock replacement PPE at the room entrance. Conduct monthly refresher training on proper PPE donning and doffing procedures. This administrative and PPE control provides immediate protection while engineering controls are implemented.

name: Implement Container Integrity Verification Protocol
description: Establish a daily visual inspection checklist for all chemical containers focusing on lid security, container integrity, and proper labeling. Use color-coded stickers to indicate inspection completion (green for passed, red for failed). Any container with visible damage or unsecured lid must be flagged and reported to the Maintenance department. Conduct this inspection at shift change. This administrative control prevents improper container closure from recurring.

name: Implement Enhanced Lockout/Tagout Protocol for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a mandatory dual-authorization LOTO procedure for all hydraulic equipment maintenance. Install pressure relief bypass valves on all injection molding machines to safely vent pressure before maintenance. Conduct comprehensive retraining of all production supervisors and equipment operators on LOTO procedures with competency assessments. Install pressure gauges that display real-time system pressure in operator view. Require written work permits for any equipment adjustments with documented pressure venting confirmation.

name: Upgrade Thermal Burn Prevention Equipment
description: Install automatic pressure release monitoring systems on all 32 injection molding machines that alert operators when pressure exceeds safe thresholds. Provide heat-resistant gloves rated for 300°C to all production operators and setters. Install signage at each machine station clearly indicating hydraulic pressure zones and prohibition on manual adjustments during operation. Implement quarterly safety drills focused on pressure release scenarios.

name: Install Secondary Containment System in Material Preparation Area
description: Design and install secondary containment bunds for all chemical storage areas capable of holding 110% of the largest single container volume. Containment must be lined with chemical-resistant materials appropriate for acetone and other solvents used. Install absorbent material dispensers and spill kits at strategic locations throughout the preparation room. Mark all spill zones with yellow tape and signage indicating secondary containment capacity and chemical types stored. Conduct monthly inspections of containment systems and document maintenance records.

name: Establish Preventive Drum Inspection and Maintenance Program
description: Implement quarterly inspection protocol for all chemical drums focusing on valve integrity, corrosion, and seal condition. Create detailed inspection checklists and require photographic documentation. Train all personnel handling chemical drums on proper inspection procedures and rejection criteria for compromised containers. Establish a drum replacement schedule with manufacturer specifications. Maintain a chemical inventory database with inspection dates and results. Assign responsibility to Maintenance and Engineering department for oversight.

name: Enhance Chemical Spill Response Training and Equipment
description: Conduct comprehensive refresher training for all evening and night shift personnel on chemical spill response procedures, emphasizing evacuation protocols and communication procedures. Install additional emergency eyewash and safety shower stations within 10 meters of chemical storage and handling areas. Upgrade the ventilation system with manual override capability and install real-time air quality monitoring. Establish quarterly spill response drills with documented participation. Create laminated emergency contact cards for all personnel with CNESST reporting procedures and emergency numbers.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Lighting and Visibility Systems
description: Install high-intensity LED lighting throughout the Raw Materials Warehouse, particularly in Section A-7 and all narrow corridors, meeting minimum 500 lux illumination standards for material handling areas. Add motion-sensor lighting in low-traffic zones to ensure immediate illumination. Install convex safety mirrors at blind intersections and overhead clearance indicators on all overhead structures. Paint hazard zones with high-visibility yellow and black striping. Conduct quarterly lighting audits and maintenance to ensure optimal visibility conditions.

name: Implement Storage Rack Stabilization and Inspection Program
description: Conduct comprehensive structural inspection of all 47 storage racks in Warehouse Section A and C, documenting load-bearing capacity, bolt integrity, and lateral stability. Install reinforced diagonal bracing and anti-tip devices on all multi-tier racks. Establish a maximum load capacity labeling system with weight limits clearly visible. Implement a monthly rack inspection protocol with photographic documentation and maintenance log. Require immediate re-securing of any shifted or misaligned loads. Train all materials management personnel on proper load distribution and securing procedures.

name: Establish Forklift Safety Corridor Management System
description: Designate clear forklift pathways with painted lane markings (minimum 3.5 meters wide) throughout warehouse sections. Install forklift speed limit signs (8 km/h maximum in narrow corridors) and conduct speed enforcement through monthly audits. Implement a system for reporting near-misses and hazardous conditions with documented tracking. Require all forklift operators to complete quarterly refresher training with emphasis on restricted visibility zones. Install proximity warning sensors on all forklifts that alert operators to obstacles and personnel. Establish a one-way traffic flow in Section A to minimize collision risks.

name: Reinstall and Lock Hopper Safety Interlocks
description: Immediately reinstall all hopper overflow prevention interlocks on Injection Molding Lines C and D that were removed during maintenance. Implement a new maintenance procedure requiring supervisory verification and sign-off before any safety device bypass. All interlocks will be equipped with tamper-proof fasteners and documented in the equipment maintenance log. A weekly audit schedule will verify all interlocks are functional. This engineering control directly eliminates the root cause of the hopper overflow hazard.

name: Implement Mandatory Hopper Level Visual Inspection Protocol
description: Replace manual hopper checking procedures with remote visual inspection using safety mirrors positioned at safe distances from the hopper rim. Provide operators with laser level indicators to assess material levels without approaching the hopper edge. Update the shift checklist to require documentation of level checks using these remote methods. Train all production staff on the new procedure during the next safety briefing. This administrative control prevents workers from positioning themselves in hazardous locations near overflow zones.

name: Complete Hydraulic System Pressure Isolation Audit and Procedure Update
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all hydraulic systems to identify all pressure storage components (accumulators, intensifiers, servo cylinders). Engage the equipment manufacturer to create complete depressurization procedures for each system. Update the LOTO procedure manual with detailed, illustrated step-by-step depressurization instructions including accumulator bleed valve location and operation sequence. Implement a mandatory secondary verification step where a second technician confirms zero pressure using a digital pressure gauge before work begins. This engineering and administrative control eliminates residual pressure hazards.

name: Provide Enhanced Thermal Protection Aprons and Gloves for Hydraulic Maintenance
description: Issue all maintenance technicians specialized high-temperature resistant aprons and insulated leather gloves rated for thermal protection up to 120°C. Store protective equipment sets in the maintenance workshop with clear labeling indicating they must be worn during any hydraulic system work. Conduct a 1-hour training session demonstrating proper donning and limitations of the equipment. While PPE is a lower-order control, this measure provides critical protection given the inherent risks of pressurized hydraulic systems containing hot fluid.

name: Establish Quarterly Hydraulic System Safety Certifications
description: Implement a mandatory quarterly retraining and certification program for all maintenance technicians involved in hydraulic system work. Each session will cover system components, hazard identification, updated LOTO procedures, emergency response, and pressure isolation verification. Technicians must pass a practical competency assessment and sign a certification document. Maintain training records and restrict uncertified personnel from hydraulic maintenance work. This administrative control ensures ongoing competency and awareness of system hazards.

name: Implement Compliant Chemical Waste Segregation and Storage System
description: Establish a new secondary containment area within the Chemical Storage Building specifically designed for temporary storage of contaminated materials awaiting disposal. Install metal, ventilated storage cabinets rated for flammable material storage that meet CSA/NFPA standards. All acetone-contaminated materials must be placed in sealed metal cans with self-closing lids and stored in these cabinets with continuous ventilation. Implement a 72-hour maximum holding period before disposal contractor pickup. Remove all cardboard and non-compliant containers from the chemical storage area. This engineering control eliminates the fire hazard at its source.

name: Update Chemical Storage Standard Operating Procedures
description: Conduct a complete revision of the Chemical Storage SOP (last updated 2019) in collaboration with the HSE department and the Hazardous Waste Management Coordinator. New procedures must include: specific storage requirements for all solvent-contaminated materials, maximum holding times, compliant container specifications, ventilation requirements, static electricity prevention measures, and emergency contact protocols. Include photographic examples of compliant vs. non-compliant storage. Distribute updated SOP to all relevant personnel and conduct mandatory training. Post laminated copies in the chemical storage area. This administrative control ensures clear guidance for all staff.

name: Install Monthly Chemical Storage Compliance Audit Program
description: Establish a formal monthly inspection schedule where the HSE department or Confined Space Entry Supervisor conducts a comprehensive audit of the Chemical Storage and Mixing Building. The audit will verify: proper container labeling and segregation, compliance with storage temperature conditions, verification of ventilation system operation, inspection of fire suppression equipment functionality, and confirmation that no non-compliant materials are stored. Results will be documented and shared with facility management. Any non-compliances must be corrected within 48 hours with photographic verification. This administrative control creates ongoing accountability and early detection.

name: Install Enhanced Thermal Barrier Guards on All Injection Molding Lines
description: Replace existing thermal barrier guards on all 12 injection molding lines with upgraded stainless steel guards featuring improved mounting systems with self-locking fasteners. Guards will have zero gaps at operational temperatures and include quick-release access panels for maintenance. Installation will include vibration-dampening spacers to prevent loosening. This engineering control eliminates the gap hazard and reduces burn injury potential from hot plastic contact during normal operations and minor jam clearing activities.

name: Implement Monthly Thermal Guard Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish a documented monthly inspection schedule for all injection molding machine thermal barriers, conducted by Production Coordinators. Inspections will check for gaps, loose fasteners, deterioration, and proper alignment. All findings will be logged in the maintenance tracking system with immediate work orders for any defects. Training will be provided to all production staff on the inspection checklist and procedures for reporting guard deterioration. This administrative control ensures early detection of guard degradation before incidents occur.

name: Enhance Heat-Resistant PPE and Provide Advanced Burn Treatment Training
description: Upgrade all production line operators to Class 4 insulated heat-resistant gloves with extended cuff protection covering the wrist. Conduct refresher training for all production staff on proper thermal burn first aid, including immediate cooling protocols, wound coverage, and when to seek emergency care. Ensure all production areas have clearly marked emergency eyewash stations and safety showers with monthly functionality checks. This multi-level approach strengthens the last line of defense while improving emergency response capability.

name: Complete Structural Inspection and Replacement of Raw Materials Storage Racks
description: Conduct comprehensive structural engineering assessment of all 8 storage rack systems in the Raw Materials Warehouse by a certified structural engineer. Replace all corroded, fractured, or fatigued support brackets with new stainless steel components rated for 25% safety factor above current loads. Inspect all welds, connections, and attachment points. Reduce load ratings on racks to 80% of original capacity to account for age and environmental exposure. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of potential rack failure and falling material hazards.

name: Implement Quarterly Rack Safety Audits and Load Management System
description: Establish a quarterly comprehensive inspection program for all storage racks conducted by Facilities Coordinators with training in structural assessment. Implement a weight tracking system where all materials are documented at receipt with verification that loads do not exceed rated capacity. Create clear weight limit signs on all racks visible from multiple angles. Establish a no-storage zone of 3 meters around any racks showing any signs of stress or damage. Train all warehouse staff on proper load distribution and stacking procedures.

name: Replace All High-Pressure Solvent Distribution Couplings and Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Replace all high-pressure distribution line couplings in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room with newly designed stainless steel couplings rated for current system pressures plus 30% safety margin. Implement a preventive maintenance schedule calling for inspection of all couplings every 6 months, with replacement at 5-year intervals or upon any sign of corrosion or micro-leakage. Install pressure relief valves set at 10% below maximum system pressure on all distribution lines to prevent catastrophic pressure buildup. This engineering control eliminates the failure mode and reduces future spill risk through scheduled replacement before degradation occurs.

name: Install Real-Time Chemical Spill Detection and Automated Isolation System
description: Install moisture/chemical detection sensors in the secondary containment system floor that automatically trigger isolation valves on the solvent distribution line when liquids are detected. Sensors will also activate alarm systems alerting staff to potential spills. Install redundant shutoff valves at the main solvent tank supply point and at critical junction points. Connect all sensors to the facility's environmental monitoring system with 24/7 alert capability. This administrative and engineering control combination enables rapid response to minimize spill volume and contamination spread.

name: Enhance Hazardous Material Spill Response Training and Drill Program
description: Develop and implement mandatory quarterly hazardous material spill response training for all night shift staff and maintenance personnel working in or near the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Training will include hands-on practice with spill containment equipment, proper use of neutralization materials, personal protective equipment protocols, and emergency communication procedures. Conduct full-scale spill response drills twice annually simulating various failure scenarios. Provide certification cards to all trained personnel. Update the facility's Chemical Emergency Response Plan with current inventory of all hazardous materials and updated response procedures.

name: Implement Drum Handling Safety Procedures
description: Develop and enforce standardized procedures for all 55-gallon drum transfers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Procedures will require use of mechanical drum handling equipment (drum dollies or forklifts) for all transfers weighing more than 20 pounds. Manual handling will be restricted to containers under 20 pounds. All chemical mixing operators will receive updated training on proper equipment use within 5 business days. The procedure will be posted at all transfer stations with visual aids in both English and French. Monthly audits will verify compliance.

name: Enhance Chemical Storage Area Secondary Containment
description: Install secondary containment systems (drip trays and containment berms) under all chemical storage racks and transfer stations. These systems will be rated to contain 110% of the largest single container volume in each storage zone. The containment system will feature improved drainage that routes spills to a collection basin with automatic shutoff valves rather than direct floor drains. This engineering control eliminates the primary pathway for chemical environmental release. Implementation will be completed within 30 days.

name: Implement Spindle Full-Stop Verification Protocol
description: Revise LOTO procedures to require verification that all spindle rotation has completely ceased before beginning any work on CNC machines. A new requirement will mandate that maintenance technicians use a calibrated tachometer to confirm spindle speed is exactly 0 RPM before beginning tool removal or internal maintenance. A visual checklist will be posted at each CNC machine detailing the spindle verification steps. All maintenance staff will receive retraining on the revised procedures within 3 business days. Monthly audits will be conducted to ensure compliance, with results reported to the Health, Safety and Environment committee.

name: Establish Load Parking and Communication Protocol
description: Implement a new standard operating procedure that prohibits elevated forks in parking areas and requires all loads to be lowered to ground level before operators leave the forklift unattended. A secondary administrative control will establish a daily load staging schedule that is communicated to all shift supervisors and forklift operators by 6:00 AM and 3:00 PM each day via email and whiteboard postings. All forks must be lowered to ground level within 10 minutes of completing a load transfer. Training will be provided to all forklift operators within 5 business days, with annual refresher training required. Supervisors will conduct random spot checks weekly.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Pressure Testing
description: Establish a preventive maintenance program with quarterly high-pressure testing of all cooling circuit hoses at 150% operational pressure to identify micro-fractures before they develop into leaks. Each line will be visually inspected and pressure-tested using calibrated gauges. Documentation will be maintained for all tests. This addresses the root cause of unplanned cooling system failures by catching deterioration early. Expected outcome: elimination of unexpected cooling line failures and associated slip/electrical hazards.

name: Install Drip Containment Trays Under Cooling Lines
description: Install stainless steel drip trays with 5-liter capacity beneath all injection molding machine cooling circuit connections in Production Lines A and B. Trays will be fitted with drain valves and absorbent liners to contain any leaks immediately, preventing floor contamination and electrical hazard exposure. Automatic leak detection float switches will trigger facility alerts when fluid levels reach 70% capacity. This engineering control eliminates the propagation of cooling fluid onto electrical equipment and floor areas.

name: Replace Wooden Pallets with Plastic Composite Pallets
description: Eliminate the use of all wooden pallets in raw materials warehouse within 60 days. Replace with FDA-approved plastic composite pallets rated for 250 kg loads that eliminate wood splinter hazards and provide superior load distribution. Plastic pallets are recyclable, non-absorbent, and resistant to moisture damage and cracking. This substitution-level control removes the root cause (wood deck failure) completely.
