All 340 pallets in warehouse inventory will be replaced over 8 weeks to maintain operations.

name: Establish Daily Pallet Inspection Program
description: Implement mandatory daily visual inspection of all pallets in use before material stacking begins each shift. Inspectors will check for visible cracks, warping, moisture damage, and structural integrity using a standardized checklist. Defective pallets will be immediately removed from service and tagged for repair or disposal. This administrative control ensures damaged pallets never enter the materials handling workflow. Training will be provided to all material handlers on inspection criteria.

name: Reduce Maximum Stack Height to 4 Bags (100 kg)
description: Establish a new procedural maximum stack height limit of 4 bags (100 kg) per pallet instead of the current 5-6 bags, reducing concentrated load stress and fall consequences. This administrative control reduces the energy of potential collapse events. Material handlers will be trained on the new stacking procedure and visual height markers will be painted on all shelving units to indicate maximum safe stack height.

name: Install Machine Guarding with Interlock System on All CNC Equipment
description: Retrofit all six CNC milling machines in the maintenance workshop with full polycarbonate guards and dual-channel safety interlocks that cannot be manually bypassed or disabled without supervisor override codes. Guards will automatically stop machine spindle rotation if opened during operation. This engineering control eliminates access to rotating cutting tools during normal operation. Interlock systems will log all access attempts for auditing. Installation will occur over 4 weeks during scheduled maintenance windows.

name: Prohibit In-Process Dimensional Checking on Running Machines
description: Implement strict administrative procedure that requires operators to stop the spindle and allow tool rotation to cease completely (minimum 30-second wait after stop command) before any dimensional checking with calipers or measurement tools. Procedure will be prominently posted at each machine and reinforced in monthly toolbox talks. Supervisors will conduct random compliance audits. This eliminates the hazardous practice of hand-tool measurement on running equipment.

name: Mandatory CNC Machine Safety Retraining for All Users
description: Conduct intensive 4-hour retraining for all 12 employees authorized to operate CNC equipment in the maintenance workshop. Training will cover: machine guarding requirements, prohibited practices (hand measurement on running machines), lockout/tagout procedures, and emergency stop protocols. All trainees must pass a written competency exam (minimum 85%) before resuming machine operation. Retraining will be completed within 30 days and repeated annually.

name: Implement Chemical Supplier Notification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory notification system requiring suppliers to alert TechnoPlast at least 7 days before any formulation changes to adhesives, resins, or cleaning products. Create a cross-functional team including Purchasing, HSE, and Production to review all notifications and assess potential hazards. Update Safety Data Sheets (SDS) immediately and communicate changes to all affected personnel through toolbox talks. Maintain a central log of all product formulation changes for traceability.

name: Expand Skin Sensitization Testing for Assembly Products
description: Conduct skin patch testing on all new batches of adhesives and epoxy products before deployment on production lines. Work with occupational health services to perform standardized patch tests on a representative sample of assembly workers. Document baseline skin sensitivity profiles for employees handling chemical products. Implement quarterly re-testing for sensitive individuals. Store results in employee health files with appropriate confidentiality measures.

name: Implement Hose and Fitting Replacement Program
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all pressurized hose systems in production areas, with special focus on cooling water lines. Replace all hoses and fittings manufactured before 2019 regardless of apparent condition, as corrosion risk increases exponentially after 5 years in industrial environments. Establish a preventive replacement schedule: every 5 years for standard fittings, every 3 years for critical cooling systems. Use stainless steel fittings instead of standard steel to extend service life. Document all replacements with dates and part numbers for maintenance tracking.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Deflection Barriers
description: Install polycarbonate deflection shields around all pressurized hose connection points on Molding Lines A and B to redirect any spray away from worker positions. Add secondary containment drip trays beneath cooling system components to capture leaking water and prevent slip hazards. Improve floor drainage in the maintenance access areas to ensure water does not pool. Paint high-visibility warning zones around high-pressure equipment with appropriate hazard labeling.

name: Mandatory Thermal Burn Prevention Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive thermal burn prevention training to all production and maintenance staff working with high-temperature equipment and pressurized systems. Training will cover: recognition of high-pressure hose hazards, proper PPE selection for thermal protection, first aid response for thermal injuries, emergency shower station location and operation, and proper reporting procedures. Conduct training within 30 days and repeat annually. Document attendance and competency verification for all participants.

name: Overhaul Pneumatic Transfer System with Redundant Safety Valves
description: Immediately replace all pressure relief valves in the pneumatic transfer system with dual-redundant certified units that meet or exceed ASME standards. Install primary and secondary pressure regulators with independent monitoring to prevent pressure buildup. Implement automated shutdown protocols that trigger when pressure exceeds safe thresholds. Add pressure gauges at critical junctures with visual alarms. Conduct hydrostatic testing of all hoses and connections quarterly. Maintenance technicians must document all inspections with photos and performance data.

name: Eliminate Manual Troubleshooting of Pressurized Systems
description: Establish a strict policy prohibiting manual intervention on pressurized transfer systems. All blockages or flow problems must be reported to maintenance staff who will depressurize the system completely before investigation. Install isolation ball valves at both ends of every transfer line segment to allow safe lockout-tagout procedures. Create a laminated troubleshooting guide posted at each system showing proper depressurization sequence. Include this requirement in all employee training and make it part of the formal LOTO procedures.

name: Upgrade Respiratory and Eye Protection in Chemical Areas
description: Issue all personnel working in chemical storage and mixing areas with full-face protective shields and certified NIOSH respirators rated for fine particulate and organic vapors. Upgrade from basic safety glasses to chemical splash goggles for all staff. Establish a respirator fit-testing program with baseline and annual retesting for all designated personnel. Create designated donning/doffing stations with posted instructions and trained monitors. Maintain current cartridge inventory with quarterly replacement cycles.

name: Implement Continuous Night Shift HSE Monitoring
description: Assign a dedicated HSE resource to conduct hourly safety rounds during night shift operations, focusing on chemical handling areas and equipment maintenance activities. This person will verify proper PPE usage, check for equipment anomalies, and ensure emergency response protocols are accessible. Night shift supervisors will receive advanced first aid and hazmat response training. Establish direct communication line to on-call medical personnel and emergency services coordination.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedure Retraining and Certification
description: Implement a comprehensive retraining program for all maintenance staff on LOTO procedures with specific emphasis on the chemical mixing area hazards. All maintenance technicians will be required to achieve 100% compliance certification including written exams and practical demonstrations. Refresher training will be mandatory quarterly. This administrative control ensures proper understanding and application of energy isolation protocols. Documentation will be maintained in employee files with tracking by supervisor. Expected outcome: Zero LOTO violations within 90 days.

name: Upgrade Proximity Sensors and Install Redundant Safety Systems
description: Replace all defective limit switch sensors with dual-redundant proximity sensors capable of detecting presence in the hazard zone within milliseconds. Install secondary mechanical interlocks that physically prevent auger rotation unless specifically enabled via a separate control panel located outside the hopper zone. This engineering control provides multiple layers of protection against unexpected equipment activation. All hopper systems will be upgraded within 30 days. Expected outcome: Complete prevention of unexpected auger activation incidents.

name: Implement Mandatory Safety Interlock Verification Protocol
description: Establish a formal checklist procedure that must be completed and signed off by both maintenance technicians and production supervisors after any maintenance work on injection molding machines. The checklist will include testing all safety interlocks, proximity sensors, and emergency stops. A physical lock-box system will be installed requiring dual-key access before mold closing can be manually overridden. All operators will receive refresher training on the new verification protocol within 5 working days. This eliminates the possibility of machines operating with disabled safety systems.

name: Install Additional Proximity Sensors on All 500-Ton Class Machines
description: All injection molding machines rated at 250 tons or higher will be retrofitted with redundant proximity sensors and an independent monitoring system. This engineering control provides multiple layers of detection to prevent mold closure if objects or hands are detected in the cavity. The system will include backup sensors that operate on a different frequency to ensure reliability. Installation will be completed over 60 days with priority given to Lines B and C where medical-grade components are produced. Expected outcome is elimination of similar crushing incidents.

name: Enhanced Post-Maintenance Equipment Inspection
description: Maintenance and Engineering department will develop a comprehensive post-maintenance inspection protocol with photographic documentation. All maintenance work must be followed by a supervised test cycle where the machine runs through a complete cycle with safety systems engaged. Quality Control will perform a secondary verification before production resumes. Training will be provided to all maintenance staff and supervisors on the new protocol. This administrative control ensures no equipment returns to production with compromised safety systems.

name: Install Mezzanine Safety Edge Guards and Lip Restraints
description: All mezzanine shelving in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room will be retrofitted with 12-inch perimeter safety guards and adjustable lip restraints on all shelf edges. The guards will be constructed of galvanized steel and installed at all four edges of each storage section. Each shelf will be labeled with maximum load capacity and weight distribution requirements. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of falling objects from height by physically preventing items from sliding or being pushed off edges.

name: Establish Mezzanine Storage Safety Procedures and Audits
description: A comprehensive mezzanine storage procedure will be documented specifying weight limits per shelf, required spacing between items, prohibition of stacking above guardrail height, and quarterly safety audits. All warehouse staff will receive training on the new procedures within one week. André Bellavance from Confined Space Entry will conduct monthly spot audits of compliance. Any storage modifications must receive HSE approval before implementation. This administrative control ensures sustained awareness of storage hazards and prevents future unauthorized changes to storage configurations.

name: Install Pressure-Limiting Regulators on All Compressed Air Service Points
description: All compressed air service ports in the Maintenance Workshop will be retrofitted with automatic pressure-limiting regulators set to 60 PSI maximum output for maintenance tasks. Secondary regulators will be installed at each workstation with clear labeling of maximum safe pressures for different tasks. The regulators will include tamper-evident seals that must be signed off by a supervisor if adjustment is necessary. Additionally, all personnel will receive training on proper compressed air pressure settings and the dangers of high-pressure air streams. This engineering control prevents accidental over-pressurization and makes it physically difficult to exceed safe pressure limits.

name: Implement Predictive Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install digital temperature monitoring sensors with real-time alerts on all injection molding lines. System will automatically alert operators and maintenance staff when temperatures deviate from normal operating ranges. Sensors will be integrated with the existing predictive maintenance program to flag anomalies before they create hazardous conditions. Weekly sensor calibration checks will be added to maintenance schedules. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of unexpected mold temperature variations.

name: Enhanced Thermal Hazard Training for Operators
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all production operators on thermal burn hazards and proper procedures for checking mold temperatures remotely using non-contact infrared thermometers. Training will include case studies of near-miss incidents and emphasis on never manually approaching hot molds. Certification will be required annually. This administrative control ensures operators understand safe work practices around high-temperature equipment.

name: Install Automated Edge Deburring Equipment
description: Procure and install an automated edge deburring machine in the finishing department to remove sharp edges from all molded parts before they enter the packaging line. This engineering control will eliminate the source of the hazard by removing sharp edges at the production stage rather than exposing workers to the risk during assembly. Equipment will be integrated into the production workflow between molding and packaging. Implementation includes operator training on equipment operation and maintenance.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Work Gloves
description: Issue ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant gloves to all assembly and packaging operators working with finished parts. Gloves will be available in multiple sizes and replaced every 90 days or as needed. This PPE control provides personal protection while engineering solutions are being implemented. Training will emphasize proper glove fit and care.

name: Replace Hose Couplings with Quick-Disconnect Leak-Free Connectors
description: Replace all standard hose couplings on resin storage and mixing equipment with ISO 16028 flat-face quick-disconnect couplers that have zero-spill, zero-drip design. These engineering controls eliminate hazardous leaks during connection/disconnection operations. All tanks will be retrofitted within 60 days. Technicians will receive certification training on proper use and maintenance of new connectors. This substitution control prevents future chemical releases.

name: Establish Enhanced Preventive Inspection Schedule
description: Implement a bi-weekly visual inspection protocol for all resin tank couplings, hoses, and connections in the chemical storage area. Inspections will be documented and any signs of wear, weeping, or cracking will trigger immediate repair or replacement. A dedicated maintenance technician will be assigned this task. This administrative control ensures early detection of potential failures before they result in spills.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System with Automated Sensors
description: Install chemical vapor detection sensors in the chemical storage area that automatically trigger maximum ventilation and alert personnel when acetone or other volatile solvent vapors exceed 50% of the ACGIH TLV threshold. System will provide real-time monitoring and documented records of air quality. This engineering control ensures rapid response to airborne chemical hazards and prevents worker exposure.

name: Implement Pre-Use PPE Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-use inspection protocol for all chemical handling PPE. Employees will conduct visual inspections of gloves, aprons, and face shields before beginning work with chemical materials. A laminated inspection checklist will be posted at all chemical handling stations. Any PPE with visible tears, punctures, or degradation must be immediately discarded and replaced. Supervisors will verify compliance during the first two weeks of implementation through observation and sign-off sheets.

name: Upgrade to Double Glove System for Chemical Transfer
description: Replace single-layer nitrile gloves with a dual-layer system consisting of inner nitrile gloves covered by outer latex-free synthetic gloves for all chemical transfer operations. The outer glove can be quickly removed if contamination occurs, providing an additional protective barrier. New gloves will be procured in bulk. All employees performing chemical handling will receive training on proper donning/doffing procedures for the double-glove system. Inventory will be maintained at 150% of normal usage levels to ensure availability.

name: Implement Mandatory Dual-Authorization LOTO System
description: Install a dual-authorization lockout/tagout system requiring sign-off from both the machine operator and the maintenance technician before any work begins on injection molding equipment. A physical lockout checklist board will be installed at each machine requiring documented completion and acknowledgment by both parties. The board will display current maintenance status in real-time. All employees must complete refresher LOTO training before implementation. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the risk of unexpected machine startup during maintenance operations.

name: Enhance Night Shift Staffing and Communication
description: Increase night shift supervision to ensure at least one dedicated LOTO-certified supervisor is present at all times. Implement a digital communication system (digital display boards and text alerts) to broadcast maintenance schedules to all night shift personnel at shift start. Conduct daily toolbox talks during night shift to review any scheduled maintenance activities. A backup communication protocol will ensure that if primary systems fail, verbal confirmation occurs between shift lead and maintenance personnel before any work begins.

name: Quarterly LOTO Competency Audits and Refresher Training
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly competency audit program for all personnel involved in LOTO procedures. Audits will include practical demonstrations, written tests, and scenario-based assessments. Any employee scoring below 90% will immediately receive refresher training before returning to LOTO-related duties. Night shift personnel will receive additional emphasis due to staffing challenges. Training will be documented and tracked in the safety management system. Annual comprehensive LOTO training will also be required for all applicable personnel.

name: Implement Drum Transport Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory protocol for transporting large chemical drums including: use of designated spill-proof transport carts with secondary containment, reduced speed limits in production corridors, two-person verification system, and scheduled transport windows during low-traffic periods. All material handlers will receive refresher training on proper drum handling, center-of-gravity positioning, and emergency response procedures. Secondary containment trays will be positioned at transfer stations.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Area Drainage
description: Install a dedicated sump system in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) with sloped flooring and drain lines that direct any spilled materials to a containment tank equipped with absorbent media. This engineering control will eliminate the risk of chemical spreading toward electrical systems and will facilitate faster cleanup. The system will include spill containment berms rated for 110% of the largest single container volume.

name: Deploy Spill Response Kits and Training
description: Place emergency spill response kits containing absorbent materials, neutralizing agents, and containment barriers at 5 strategic locations throughout the facility including production lines B and C, the warehouse, and the chemical storage building. Conduct mandatory 2-hour training for all production and material handling staff on spill response procedures, hazard identification, and equipment use. Quarterly refresher sessions will be scheduled.

name: Install Automatic Hopper Jam Detection System
description: Engineer and install an automated monitoring system on Injection Molding Lines A, B, and C that detects resin flow interruptions and automatically triggers machine shutdown alerts. This eliminates the need for manual hopper clearing during operation. The system will include pressure sensors, flow meters, and audible/visual alarm systems that alert operators to notify maintenance. Installation will include safety interlocks preventing manual access while the hopper is heated above 60°C.

name: Reinforce Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Compliance Training
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all injection molding operators on LOTO procedures, emphasizing that ANY maintenance task requires complete machine shutdown and energy isolation, regardless of perceived urgency. Implement a new verification checkpoint where operators must obtain supervisor approval before attempting any troubleshooting. Violators will receive counseling and progressive discipline. Monthly audit inspections will verify LOTO compliance with feedback provided to supervisors.

name: Implement Quarterly Equipment Interlock Inspection Program
description: Establish a formal quarterly maintenance schedule for all UV testing equipment and interlocks in the Quality Control Laboratory. Maintenance technician will verify proper alignment and function of door interlocks, seals, and warning indicators. Documentation will be maintained in a logbook. Any equipment failing inspection will be immediately removed from service until repairs are completed. This preventive maintenance approach addresses the root cause of deteriorating interlock functionality.

name: Issue Cut-Resistant Gloves to Finishing Department
description: Procure and distribute ANSI A4 cut-resistant gloves to all finishing operators in Assembly and Finishing Department. These gloves provide superior protection against sharp plastic edges compared to standard nitrile gloves. Conduct mandatory training session for all operators on proper glove selection, fitting, and care. Update work instructions to specify cut-resistant gloves as required PPE for all deburring and finishing operations. Implement weekly PPE audits to ensure compliance.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooling System Depressurization Protocol
description: Develop and distribute a detailed work instruction requiring all maintenance personnel to completely depressurize the cooling system using the isolation valve before attempting any repairs or adjustments to fittings. Add visual reminder stickers at all cooling system connection points. Conduct mandatory retraining on LOTO procedures with emphasis on pressurized systems for all maintenance staff. Schedule quarterly refresher training sessions. Install a pressure gauge at the main coolant supply to help operators verify depressurization status.

name: Inspect and Replace Deteriorated Cooling System Fittings
description: Conduct comprehensive inspection of all cooling water system fittings on Injection Molding Lines A, C, and D to identify cracked or corroded fittings before they fail. Replace all fittings showing signs of wear or damage with high-quality stainless steel fittings rated for the system pressure. Implement a preventive maintenance schedule with bimonthly inspections of all cooling connections. Document all inspections and replacements in the maintenance log system.

name: Establish Mandatory Temperature Monitoring and Cool-Down Protocol
description: Install digital temperature displays at all injection molding stations showing real-time mold surface temperatures. Implement a strict protocol requiring molds to cool to 60°C or below before manual intervention is permitted. Add automated interlocks that prevent manual mold access until safe temperature is reached. Update all work procedures and training materials to emphasize waiting periods and temperature verification. Conduct refresher training for all production operators emphasizing the severity of thermal burns and proper procedures.

name: Issue Heat-Resistant Protective Gloves and Sleeves
description: Procure and distribute kevlar-lined heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C) and forearm sleeves to all injection molding operators. Gloves must meet ANSI specifications for thermal protection. Conduct mandatory fitting and training on proper donning/doffing procedures. Establish a replacement schedule with monthly inspections. Require glove use during all mold adjustments, maintenance, or jam clearing activities. Place prominent signage at all molding stations reminding operators of thermal hazard and required PPE.

name: Implement Engineering Control for Jam Clearing
description: Design and install remote-operated mechanical tools for clearing material jams on injection presses, eliminating the need for operators to approach hot molds manually. The system should use hydraulic-powered rods to clear blockages from a safe distance (minimum 1.5 meters from mold surfaces). Provide training on new equipment operation to all relevant staff. Establish procedure requiring use of mechanical jam-clearing method as first response, with manual intervention only as last resort after all automated methods attempted and equipment cooled to safe temperature.

name: Install Secondary Containment Bunding for Chemical Storage
description: Implement secondary containment systems beneath all epoxy resin and chemical storage areas in the Chemical Storage and Mixing unit. Secondary containment should have a capacity of 110% of the largest container stored. This engineering control will prevent spills from spreading across the facility floor and contain volatile fumes more effectively. Install absorbent material dispensers at strategic locations within 10 meters of all chemical storage areas. This eliminates the primary hazard by providing immediate environmental protection and reduces cleanup time from hours to minutes.

name: Implement Forklift Operator Training on Chemical Storage Awareness
description: Develop and deliver a mandatory 2-hour training module for all forklift operators (including propane and electric operators) focusing on hazardous material storage areas, vibration awareness, and no-operation zones near chemical storage. Training will include identification of chemical storage hazards, proper speeds near sensitive areas, and emergency response procedures. All operators must pass a written assessment before operating in restricted zones. This administrative control reduces the probability of vibration-induced accidents through operator knowledge and awareness.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Drum Securing Hardware
description: Replace all existing drum storage racks with certified heavy-duty racks featuring improved bung retention mechanisms and anti-vibration padding. Install safety straps rated for 500 pounds across each drum at the center of gravity point. Add visual inspection labels requiring weekly verification of strap integrity. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause by preventing bung plug loosening from vibration. All maintenance staff will be trained on proper drum placement and securing procedures during the next quarterly training cycle.

name: Implement Ergonomic Workstation Redesign and Adjustment Program
description: Conduct full ergonomic assessments of all 32 injection molding workstations using ISO 11228 principles and anthropometric data. Install height-adjustable work tables on 12 high-risk stations (Identified through REBA scoring analysis). Relocate material bins to waist-height accessible zones within 12 inches of operator centerline. Install adjustable footrests at all stations and provide operator training on proper positioning. Implement a monthly ergonomics checklist system requiring operators to self-assess and report workstation issues. This engineering control addresses postural risk by eliminating awkward reach requirements and compensatory movements.

name: Establish Preventive Ergonomics Training and Microbreak Protocol
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive ergonomics training program for all production operators covering proper workstation setup, stretch routines, and symptom recognition for early-stage cumulative trauma. Establish a mandatory 5-minute microbreak protocol every 2 hours requiring operators to perform specific stretching exercises targeting shoulders, wrists, and lower back. Create a digital tracking system for ergonomics near-miss reports and early symptom complaints. This administrative control reduces incidence probability through knowledge transfer and active break intervention.

name: Replace Thermostat and Install Redundant Safety Systems on All Dryers
description: Replace the failed thermostat on the XR-500 unit with a modern digital controller featuring independent dual-sensor input (primary thermocouple and redundant RTD probe with independent alarm circuit). Install a mechanical pressure relief valve set at 2.5 bar above normal operating pressure on all 8 industrial dryers in the facility. Implement a hard-wired emergency shutdown button accessible from outside the dryer unit perimeter. This engineering control eliminates the single-point-of-failure vulnerability by providing redundant safety mechanisms and immediate emergency response capability.

name: Restore and Enforce Preventive Maintenance Schedule with Quarterly RTD Probe Inspections
description: Immediately restore the 6-month preventive maintenance interval for all heating equipment (previously extended to 12 months). Implement a specific quarterly checklist item requiring visual inspection and functional testing of all RTD temperature sensor connections and probes using a calibrated multimeter. Create a digital maintenance log with automatic email alerts to maintenance planners 30 days before each service interval. Conduct a full calibration audit of all temperature measurement equipment. This administrative control ensures that equipment degradation is detected before critical failure occurs.

name: Install Continuous Emissions Monitoring and Alarm System for Dryer Area
description: Install a continuous four-gas monitor (CO, O2, LEL, H2S) in the Material Drying and Preparation Room with audible and visual alarms set at 25 ppm for CO and automatic area evacuation alarm at 50 ppm. Connect the system to the facility's emergency notification system. Establish a weekly sensor calibration routine and install a fixed detector at 1.5 meters height near the dryer unit exhaust. Train all personnel working in this area on alarm response procedures during the next monthly safety briefing. This engineering control provides real-time hazard detection and early warning capability.

name: Implement Mandatory PLC Reset Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory verification checklist requiring maintenance technicians to confirm PLC software reset completion with a secondary witness signature before resuming production. Create a digital tracking log in the maintenance management system documenting all PLC resets with timestamp and technician ID. This engineering and administrative control addresses the root cause of unintended robotic arm activation by ensuring the control system is fully cleared between maintenance cycles. All maintenance staff will receive refresher training on proper shutdown and reset procedures within 5 days.

name: Install Secondary Safety Interlock on Robotic Arms
description: Engineer and install a redundant safety interlock system on all 32 robotic arms across production lines that requires dual-channel confirmation before arm movement can resume after any maintenance activity. This hardware-based engineering control prevents unintended machine activation by adding a physical and electronic barrier. Work with the equipment supplier to integrate the interlock with existing emergency stop systems. Installation will be completed in phases over 60 days, starting with Lines B and C. This addresses the critical MEDIUM-HIGH probability risk of robotic arm malfunction.

name: Establish Lockout/Tagout Enforcement Audit Program
description: Implement a monthly LOTO compliance audit program led by the HSE team to verify that all robotic and molding equipment is properly locked and tagged during maintenance activities. Audits will include random inspections of maintenance work in progress and post-maintenance verification before equipment restart. Create a database to track audit findings and assign corrective actions with defined timelines. This administrative control strengthens procedural compliance and creates accountability. Training on updated LOTO procedures will be mandatory for all maintenance personnel within 10 days of implementation.

name: Overhaul and Clean Composite Area Ventilation System
description: Engage a certified HVAC contractor to perform complete inspection, cleaning, and repair of the ventilation ductwork and exhaust fans in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Remove all accumulated resin residue, dust, and blockages from intake and exhaust lines. Replace air filters and inspect dampers for proper operation. Verify airflow rates meet or exceed the designed 100-150 linear feet per minute specification at all mixing workstations. This engineering control directly restores the ventilation system to design specifications and eliminates the chemical exposure hazard. Post-cleaning verification will include airflow measurements at 6 points across the area.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Systems
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all ventilation systems across the facility with documented inspections and cleaning. Create a maintenance calendar tracked in the computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) with automatic work order generation. Designate responsibility to the Maintenance and Engineering department to inspect ductwork, replace filters, and test airflow rates every 13 weeks. This administrative control prevents future system degradation by establishing routine upkeep procedures. All maintenance personnel will receive training on proper ventilation system inspection and cleaning techniques within 7 days.

name: Repair Overhead Crane Hydraulic System Leak
description: Hydraulic systems technician Andrei Popov will inspect the overhead crane system in the Materials Management and Warehousing area to locate the source of the hydraulic fluid leak. Replace damaged hoses, seals, or fittings as needed and refill the hydraulic reservoir to proper operating level. Test the system under load to confirm the leak has been eliminated. This engineering control removes the source of the wet floor hazard by eliminating the hydraulic fluid discharge. The repair will be completed within 24 hours, and the dock area will be cordoned off until repairs are verified complete.

name: Install Slip-Resistant Flooring in High-Traffic Dock Areas
description: Apply high-grip anti-slip coating to all loading dock entrance transitions and high-moisture areas where condensation accumulates. Select a coating product rated for industrial environments and moisture exposure. This engineering control directly reduces slip hazards in areas prone to condensation from overhead equipment. The coating will be applied during the next scheduled maintenance window (within 14 days). Additionally, install absorbent floor mats in areas subject to seasonal condensation during winter months (November-March). Post warning signage about wet floor conditions during high-humidity periods.

name: Install Redundant Temperature Monitoring System
description: Replace single thermostat with dual-sensor temperature control system featuring independent safety cutoffs at 85°C. Install real-time monitoring dashboard in control room with audible alarm at 80°C. Integrate automatic shutoff valve to halt material feed if temperature exceeds threshold. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of uncontrolled heating by providing multiple layers of thermal protection. Expected outcome: 99.5% prevention of similar thermal runaway incidents.

name: Enhanced Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Drying Equipment
description: Implement monthly thermistor testing and quarterly sensor calibration procedures for all desiccant dryers. Create maintenance checklist identifying thermal sensor inspection as critical control point. Schedule equipment inspections every 60 operating days instead of existing 120-day cycle. Assign Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie as primary owner for this equipment class. Administrative control that reduces component degradation and detection failures through structured preventive action.

name: Implement Ergonomic Trimming Station with Safety Fixtures
description: Install specialized plastic component trimming jig with integrated work-holding device and ergonomic handle positions. Replace standard utility knives with safety knives featuring automatic blade retraction (1.5mm maximum extension). Add non-slip silicone work mat (30x40 cm) to all trimming stations. Provide cut-resistant gloves (ANSI Level A3) as mandatory PPE for all assembly operators. This combination of engineering controls (work fixtures), tool design, and PPE creates multiple protective layers against hand laceration incidents.

name: Hydraulic Fluid Compatibility Audit and Component Standardization
description: Conduct full inventory assessment of all hydraulic seals, hoses, and components across 3 injection molding lines to verify material compatibility with ISO 32 synthetic fluid. Replace all elastomer seals with fluorocarbon (Viton) components rated for synthetic formulations. Update maintenance procedures to specify only approved fluid types and prohibit mixing of mineral and synthetic hydraulics. Create compatibility chart for maintenance team reference. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the root cause of seal degradation and prevents recurrence across all equipment.

name: Secondary Containment System Upgrade and Maintenance Protocol
description: Repair crushed drain line in secondary containment basin and install secondary backup drain with check valve. Increase containment capacity from current 50 liters to 150-liter minimum (125% of maximum fluid volume). Install monthly inspection schedule for containment system integrity. Add visual capacity markers to tank. Conduct quarterly drain testing to verify proper function. Administrative and engineering controls that ensure environmental compliance and rapid response capability for future spill events.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Compliance Verification
description: Install electronic lockout verification system that prevents machine startup unless all LOTO pins are physically inserted and registered in the safety system. Implement daily audits of all machines to verify proper lockout compliance. Conduct mandatory retraining for all operators on LOTO procedures with emphasis on never bypassing safety protocols. Establish disciplinary procedures for LOTO violations. This administrative and engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the incident—failure to follow proper lockout procedures.

name: Production Quota Review and Adjustment
description: Review current production quotas and cycle times on all injection molding lines to ensure operators have sufficient time to perform required maintenance and safety procedures without pressure. Implement a policy that explicitly protects time for proper machine lockout and verification. Meet with production scheduling and management to eliminate quota-driven shortcuts. This administrative control addresses the underlying pressure that led the operator to bypass safety procedures.

name: Install Machine Guard Enhancements on Production Lines
description: Install additional mechanical guards on mold closing mechanisms across all injection molding machines to prevent hand access to pinch points during operation. Add light curtain sensors that detect hand proximity and trigger automatic machine stoppage. This engineering control provides a secondary barrier to prevent similar crush injuries even if lockout procedures are not properly followed.

name: Install Material Handling Lift-Assist Equipment
description: Purchase and install pneumatic lift tables and powered lift-assist devices in the finished goods warehouse to reduce manual lifting of heavy material bags. Position lift-assist equipment at key workstations where material transfers occur most frequently. Train all material handlers on proper use of the equipment. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of manual lifting of heavy loads, directly addressing the root cause of the incident.

name: Ergonomics Training and Workstation Assessment
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomics training for all warehouse and material handling staff, focusing on proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, and use of available equipment. Perform detailed ergonomic assessment of all material handling workstations and implement modifications to shelf heights, spacing, and layout to minimize awkward postures. Establish a reporting system for ergonomic concerns and schedule quarterly refresher training. This administrative control and workstation redesign will prevent future back injuries.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring and Cooling System
description: Install automated temperature sensors and display panels at the composite parts handling station that clearly show both oven temperature and part surface temperature in real-time. Implement a conveyor-based cooling zone with forced air circulation before the manual handling area to ensure all parts reach safe handling temperature (below 50°C) before operator contact. Add audible and visual alarms that prevent parts from being removed from the oven until they are below the safe handling threshold. This engineering control eliminates the burn hazard.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring System with Redundant Sensors
description: Replace the single thermostat with a dual-sensor temperature control system featuring redundant digital sensors and an automated alert system that triggers at 150°C. The new system will include weatherproof sensor housings with silicone seals to prevent moisture ingress. Install a secondary mechanical pressure relief valve set at 160°C as a fail-safe backup. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of sensor failure and prevents future overheating incidents. Expected outcome: 99.8% prevention of similar dryer overheating events.

name: Implement Monthly Resin Dryer Maintenance Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a standardized monthly preventive maintenance checklist for all resin dryers, including visual inspection of sensor port seals, thermostat calibration verification, and moisture intrusion testing. Assign Claude Rioux as the maintenance lead responsible for scheduling and documenting all inspections. Create a digital tracking system accessible to the maintenance team and HSE department. Training sessions will be conducted for all maintenance staff on proper sensor installation and seal replacement techniques. This administrative control ensures early detection of potential failures before they escalate.

name: Upgrade Resin Storage Area Environmental Controls
description: Install a dehumidification system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area to maintain relative humidity below 40%, preventing moisture accumulation that leads to sensor corrosion. Add ventilation ducting to direct heat and steam away from electrical components. Install silica gel desiccant canisters in storage cabinets containing temperature sensors and control modules. These engineering controls create an environment hostile to corrosion and moisture-related failures, directly supporting the reliability of all resin processing equipment.

name: Install Mechanical Lift Assist Equipment in Finished Goods Warehouse
description: Purchase and install 3 pneumatic lift tables (750 kg capacity each) positioned throughout the Finished Goods Warehouse to eliminate manual lifting of cartons exceeding 15 kg. These engineering controls directly substitute mechanical assistance for human physical effort. Technicians will be trained on proper operation, and signage will indicate maximum manual lifting weights (15 kg) and lift table locations. This eliminates the primary hazard causing the incident and is expected to reduce back injuries by 85% in the warehouse.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Ergonomics Training and Assessment
description: Engage a certified ergonomics specialist to conduct on-site training for all warehouse and material handling personnel. Training will cover proper lifting mechanics, load assessment techniques, and safe workstation arrangement. Specialist will perform individual ergonomic assessments for each material handler, identifying personal risk factors and recommending modifications. Create a refresher training schedule (quarterly) to reinforce proper techniques. Provide pocket-sized laminated ergonomics guides for each employee. This administrative control targets the human behavior component of the incident and builds long-term safer work practices.

name: Implement Mandatory Energy Isolation Verification System
description: Install independent voltage verification stations (3 locations in maintenance workshop) featuring calibrated digital multimeters mounted on articulating arms with clear signage requiring dual verification before any maintenance begins. Implement a mandatory 'three-point verification' procedure: (1) technician verifies circuit de-energized with personal meter, (2) second technician independently verifies with station meter, (3) supervisor signs off on verification log. Purchase 12 portable arc flash detection devices to be worn during all high-voltage work. Create laminated verification checklist cards for every technician. This engineering and administrative control directly prevents the root cause of energized circuits being accessed during LOTO procedures.

name: Overhaul Lockout/Tagout Program with Bypass Contactor Elimination
description: Conduct full audit of all 460-volt distribution panels and eliminate bypass contactors that allow partial circuit energization. Replace with solid-state disconnects that provide complete isolation. Implement cascading LOTO procedures requiring lockout at the main panel AND the machine disconnect simultaneously. Retrain all 28 maintenance technicians on the new procedures with written certification. Establish a penalty system where equipment cannot be re-energized without documented verification and supervisor approval. Create an electronic LOTO log system accessible in real-time to all maintenance staff. This eliminates the technical flaw that enabled the incident.

name: Mandate Arc Flash PPE for All High-Voltage Maintenance Work
description: Issue complete arc flash personal protective equipment kits to all 12 technicians performing electrical maintenance, including arc-rated long-sleeve shirts (rating: 8+ cal/cm²), face shields with arc-rated lenses, leather gloves, and arc-rated pants. Establish a requirement that this PPE must be worn before opening any panel containing circuits over 240 volts. Conduct quarterly re-certification training on proper PPE usage and maintenance. Create designated high-voltage work zones marked with yellow/black striping and warning signage. While not eliminating the hazard, this PPE layer provides critical backup protection if electrical contact occurs.

name: Implement Cut-Resistant Glove Program for Part Finishing
description: Deploy nitrile-coated cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 or higher rating) to all Production Operators performing manual flash removal and part finishing tasks. Establish a mandatory personal protective equipment policy requiring gloves during these operations, with weekly glove replacement to maintain effectiveness. Conduct toolbox talks during each shift to reinforce proper glove usage and hand positioning techniques. Track compliance through supervisor observations and incident reports.

name: Redesign Manual Flash Removal Tools and Techniques
description: Procure ergonomic, rounded-edge plastic flash removal tools with integrated finger guards to replace existing sharp scrapers. Conduct tool trial testing with Production Operators to ensure usability. Develop standard work instructions with photographic guides demonstrating proper hand positioning, tool angle, and safe removal techniques. Include these instructions in the operator training curriculum and reinforce during monthly safety meetings.

name: Install Pneumatic Lift Assist Equipment at Bin Loading Stations
description: Procure and install three pneumatic lift-assist units at the primary bin loading stations in the Finished Goods Warehouse to reduce manual lifting from 12 kg to approximately 2 kg perceived load. These ceiling-mounted systems with adjustable height will enable operators to load bins without bending or straining. Conduct operator training on proper equipment usage, adjustment procedures, and maintenance requirements. Establish preventive maintenance schedule to ensure optimal functioning. Expected outcome: 60-70% reduction in lower back strain during bin stacking operations.

name: Implement Mandatory Task Rotation and Microbreak Schedule
description: Develop and implement a structured task rotation system requiring warehouse associates to alternate between bin stacking, order picking, and labeling tasks every 90 minutes. Establish mandatory 10-minute microbreaks every 2 hours in a heated break area (minimum 18°C) with gentle stretching exercises. Create a visual schedule posted at each work station showing rotation assignments. Train supervisors to enforce rotation compliance and document adherence. Include task rotation guidelines in warehouse standard operating procedures.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Climate Control for Operator Comfort
description: Increase warehouse ambient temperature setpoint from 12-15°C to 16-18°C in work zones while maintaining material storage requirements (coordinating with Quality Control). Install localized infrared heating elements at break areas and work stations where operators spend extended periods. Provide cold-weather work clothing (insulated vests and gloves) to all warehouse staff. Monitor temperature compliance weekly and document in maintenance logs.

name: Implement Comprehensive Hazardous Waste Drum Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly drum inspection program for all hazardous waste storage containers, documenting structural integrity, corrosion status, and remaining useful life. Create a drum replacement schedule requiring all drums older than 7 years to be replaced proactively, regardless of apparent condition. Conduct visual inspections for cracks, leaks, rust, and seal degradation during routine safety audits. Maintain digital inventory with photos and inspection dates. Budget for quarterly drum replacement cycles. Train all maintenance and warehouse staff on inspection criteria.

name: Expand Secondary Containment Capacity and Upgrade Drain System
description: Install additional polypropylene spill containment pallets around hazardous waste storage area, expanding capacity from current 120 liters to 180 liters to accommodate larger single-drum spill scenarios. Install a manual shutoff valve on the stormwater drain line within the waste management area, positioned for rapid activation during spill events. Create clear signage indicating drain valve location and operation procedures. Install secondary collection sumps to capture any overflow before environmental discharge. Conduct quarterly drain system inspections and maintenance.

name: Enhance Environmental Incident Response Training and Documentation
description: Develop comprehensive environmental incident response procedures including spill response flowcharts, regulatory notification templates, and remediation checklists. Conduct quarterly environmental incident response drills involving maintenance staff, chemical handlers, and EHS personnel simulating various spill scenarios. Create laminated quick-reference guides posted at hazardous waste area and maintenance workshop. Establish incident documentation system requiring photo evidence, volume quantification, environmental impact assessment, and corrective action tracking. Include training requirements in employee onboarding.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Inspections
description: Establish a formal preventive maintenance program for all cooling water circulation systems across injection molding lines. Technicians will inspect hose clamps, couplings, and connections every 90 days, documenting pressure ratings and wear. Replace any components showing signs of deterioration before failure occurs. This engineering and administrative control will reduce the probability of unexpected system failures from HIGH to LOW by catching issues before they present hazards.

name: Operator Training on Equipment Auditory Signals
description: Develop and deliver training to all production operators on recognizing abnormal sounds from injection molding equipment as early warning indicators of system problems. Include specific audio samples of normal vs. problematic hydraulic system noises. Operators will be trained to immediately stop production and notify maintenance when unusual sounds are detected. This administrative control reinforces the existing safety culture and empowers workers to prevent incidents.

name: Upgrade to Chemical-Resistant PPE for Composite Operations
description: Replace standard nitrile gloves with nitrile gloves rated specifically for epoxy and mold release agent contact in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Require all personnel working with these materials to wear long-sleeve chemical-resistant sleeves and aprons in addition to gloves. Update WHMIS postings with allergen warnings specific to the epoxy batch being used. This PPE enhancement, while a last-resort control, addresses the frequency of skin contact incidents and provides multiple barriers to chemical exposure.

name: Implement Mandatory Rigging Certification Program
description: Require all maintenance technicians and supervisors to complete formal rigging and load control certification through an accredited third-party training provider. Certification must include proper cable selection, load calculations, securing methods, and safety factor documentation. All rigging equipment will be tagged with maximum load ratings and inspection dates. Personnel will be re-certified annually. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the root cause by ensuring only properly trained individuals conduct overhead lifting operations and that equipment is properly rated.

name: Install Load-Limiting Overhead Crane Safety System
description: Upgrade all overhead cranes in the Maintenance Workshop and Material Drying Room to include load-limiting devices that prevent lifting when weight exceeds rated capacity by more than 10%. Install warning lights and audible alarms that activate during crane operation. Conduct monthly maintenance and testing of safety systems. This engineering control provides a mechanical safeguard against overload conditions that could cause rigging failure, reducing severity potential from CRITICAL to LOW.

name: Establish Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Procedures for Equipment Maintenance
description: Develop and implement comprehensive LOTO procedures for all conveyor systems and powered equipment in the Material Drying area. Require that all equipment be de-energized, locked, and tagged before any maintenance or repair work begins. Post clear signage at all energy isolation points. Conduct LOTO training for all maintenance staff and supervisors within 14 days. This administrative control ensures equipment cannot restart unexpectedly during maintenance, preventing struck-by and caught-between hazards.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a rigorous monthly inspection protocol for all hydraulic pump systems on injection molding equipment, including pressure relief valve cleaning and function testing. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance and Engineering department with documented checklists and sign-off procedures. Create visual inspection tags on equipment showing last service date. Train all maintenance technicians on proper relief valve operation and blockage indicators. This measure addresses the root cause of internal pressure buildup and introduces engineering controls through systematic monitoring.

name: Install Equipment Pressure Relief Guards
description: Design and fabricate protective metal mesh guards around all hydraulic pump casings on injection molding lines to contain potential fragment ejection. Guards will allow visual inspection while preventing direct contact with pressurized components. Install on all 32 molding machines over a two-week period. This engineering control directly mitigates the consequence of a future pressure release event.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protection PPE Requirements
description: Mandate use of heat-resistant forearm guards (minimum rating 200°C) for all personnel working with post-processing ovens. Current PPE includes gloves only. Procure and distribute aluminum-backed aramid sleeve guards to all production staff. Update equipment safety signage to clearly indicate surface temperature warnings. Include thermal PPE inspection in pre-shift briefing procedures for equipment operators.

name: Implement Load Securing and Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory two-person verification system for all pallet loads stored on overhead systems. Before load placement, both the operator and a spotter must inspect and confirm proper strap tension using a calibrated load indicator. Create a load identification tag system that documents securing technician, date/time, and certification. Conduct retraining for all warehouse staff on proper pallet securing techniques with emphasis on strap tension uniformity. Implement random audits twice weekly.

name: Install Secondary Load-Holding Safety Devices
description: Retrofit all overhead crane hoists with redundant mechanical load-holding brakes that automatically engage if primary brake pressure drops. These secondary safety blocks will prevent load descent even if primary systems fail. Additionally, install load cell sensors on all hoist cables that trigger audible alarms when load exceeds rated capacity by 10%. Engineering contractor to complete installation within 30 days. This addresses the critical gap in load-holding failure prevention.

name: Establish Overhead Work Safe Work Method Statement
description: Create a comprehensive Safe Work Method Statement (SWMS) specific to all overhead crane operations and manual maintenance on suspended load systems. The SWMS will include hazard identification, control measures, emergency procedures, and competency requirements. Mandate that all personnel working on overhead systems complete a 4-hour certification course covering load dynamics, failure modes, rescue procedures, and lockout/tagout protocols. Require annual refresher training. Document all competency records.

name: Implement Secondary Containment System for Chemical Storage
description: Install containment trays with 110% capacity of the largest container under all bulk chemical storage areas in the Assembly and Finishing Department. Trays will feature sloped surfaces directing spills toward a collection sump with absorbent cartridges. This engineering control eliminates the risk of chemical spread to floor drains and minimizes spill volume reaching the floor. Expected outcome: containment of future spills within secondary containers, reducing environmental exposure and cleanup time.

name: Establish Chemical Container Handling Training Program
description: Develop mandatory training for all personnel handling containers larger than 5 liters, covering proper grip techniques, load assessment, container inspection before transport, and appropriate use of transport equipment (carts, forklifts). Training will include hands-on practice with dummy containers and spill simulation scenarios. Personnel will be certified quarterly. This administrative control addresses the human error component and ensures consistent safe practices.

name: Install Real-Time Environmental Monitoring and Alert System
description: Deploy continuous differential pressure monitoring with immediate electronic notification to maintenance and production supervisors when pressure drops below threshold. Implement redundant sensors at three locations in the clean room. System will send SMS and email alerts simultaneously to at least two personnel. This engineering control ensures rapid response to future ventilation anomalies, reducing contamination exposure time. Expected outcome: detection within 5 minutes of system degradation versus the current 65+ minute delay.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for HVAC Critical Components
description: Implement quarterly inspections and semi-annual replacement of damper motors, filter assemblies, and sensor calibration in the clean room HVAC system. Create a detailed maintenance log with predictive indicators for component degradation. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance Planner who will coordinate with shift supervisors. This administrative control addresses preventive maintenance gaps and ensures critical equipment reliability. Expected outcome: elimination of unexpected failures through early detection and planned maintenance cycles.

name: Conduct Full Warehouse Rack Structural Inspection and Certification
description: Engage a third-party structural engineer to perform comprehensive inspection of all 24 high-density storage rack systems in the warehouse. Assessment will include ultrasonic testing of all welds, load-bearing capacity verification, and structural integrity evaluation. Any racks rated below 85% structural integrity will be decommissioned. All remaining racks will be certified and marked with inspection date and load capacity. This engineering control eliminates catastrophic failure risk through structural verification and remediation.

name: Implement Equipment Load Verification and Weight Monitoring System
description: Install weight verification scale stations at all forklift loading points in the warehouse. Operators must weigh pallets before loading and cannot exceed 100% of rated capacity (electronic interlock system will prevent operation if exceeded). Establish training requirement for all Material Handlers on proper load centering, weight distribution, and capacity calculations. Create a daily pre-operation checklist for all forklifts including fork condition assessment. This combination of engineering and administrative controls prevents overloading.

name: Establish Annual Rack Inspection and Maintenance Program
description: Create a documented annual inspection schedule for all storage racks, conducted by manufacturer-certified inspectors. Inspections will occur during scheduled maintenance windows every January. Results will be documented and filed with facility maintenance records. Any recommended repairs or weld reinforcements will be prioritized in the maintenance budget. This administrative control ensures compliance with manufacturer requirements and establishes preventive maintenance protocols.

name: Implement Quarterly Safety Interlock Calibration Program
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly calibration and testing schedule for all machine safety interlocks and proximity sensors across all 32 injection molding machines. Each machine will receive documented certification following ANSI B11.19 standards. A preventive maintenance tracking system will be implemented using barcode scanning to ensure no machine exceeds the 90-day service interval. Training will be provided to the maintenance team on proper testing procedures and documentation requirements. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the incident by ensuring safety systems remain reliable.

name: Install Enhanced Machine Guarding and Light Curtains
description: Install dual-channel safety-rated light curtains at the mold entry points of all high-tonnage molding machines (150+ tons) to provide an additional layer of protection. These systems will trigger an immediate mold-hold function if any object enters the hazard zone during the molding cycle. Additionally, upgrade physical guards around mold cavities with clear polycarbonate barriers that allow operators to monitor parts while preventing hand access. This redundant safety system provides engineering control and significantly reduces the likelihood of hand entrapment.

name: Mandatory Retraining on Machine Safety Procedures
description: Conduct immediate retraining for all injection molding operators on the proper lockout/tagout procedures and the prohibition of reaching into mold cavities during machine operation. All operators will be required to pass a written certification test and practical demonstration. Refresher training will be scheduled quarterly. New signage with pictorial warnings will be installed at each machine station emphasizing the dangers of cavity interference. This administrative control reinforces safe work practices and ensures all operators understand the consequences of bypassing safety interlocks.

name: Implement Warehouse Rack Safety and Load Rating System
description: Conduct a complete structural assessment of all metal storage racks in the warehouse and install permanent load-capacity signage on each rack tier. Implement a color-coded system: green for full capacity, yellow for 75%, red for restricted access. All hydraulic oil drums will be relocated to dedicated secondary containment storage with bunding capability rated for 110% of maximum volume. Forklift operating lanes will be clearly marked with floor paint to maintain minimum 4-foot clearance from all rack systems. Staff will receive training on proper load distribution and inspection protocols before each shift.

name: Install Secondary Spill Containment Infrastructure
description: Establish dedicated storage areas with integrated spill containment systems (bunds) for all hazardous liquids including hydraulic oils, solvents, and cleaning chemicals. Each containment area will be rated to hold 110% of the maximum volume stored in that section. Install oil-absorbent pads and spill kits at strategic warehouse locations, with staff training on proper spill response procedures. This engineering control prevents environmental contamination and protects inventory from chemical damage.

name: Enforce Mandatory Lockout/Tagout Procedures for All Equipment Maintenance
description: Implement a zero-tolerance policy requiring that ALL machines be placed in lockout/tagout status before any maintenance or cleaning work begins, regardless of the scope of work. Provide universal LOTO kits for the Material Drying and Preparation Room with clear labeling and storage. Conduct immediate certification training for all maintenance and tool-making staff on proper LOTO procedures according to CNESST requirements. Monthly LOTO audits will be performed by the HSE department to verify compliance. Violators will receive disciplinary counseling. This administrative control is fundamental to preventing machinery-related injuries.

name: Supply Cut-Resistant Gloves and Enforce PPE Requirements
description: Issue ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant gloves to all maintenance technicians and tool makers, with replacement stock maintained in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Create a required equipment checklist that must be completed before any maintenance work begins, including verification that proper PPE is being worn. Post visual reminders at machine stations showing required PPE for each task. Conduct spot inspections during shifts to verify compliance. While PPE is the lowest level in the hierarchy of controls, it provides immediate protection while engineering and administrative controls are implemented.

name: Implement Quarterly Oven Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a formalized preventive maintenance program requiring monthly inspection and cleaning of all industrial oven heating elements, exhaust vents, and surrounding areas. Maintenance tasks will be tracked in the CMMS system with automatic work order generation. All heating equipment will undergo professional inspection quarterly by certified technicians. This addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance scheduling and reduces fire risk from dust accumulation.

name: Install Automatic Fire Detection System in Post-Processing Area
description: Install aspirating smoke detection with fire suppression integration in the Post-Processing unit. System will include ceiling-mounted smoke detectors connected to an automated sprinkler system with manual override capability. All personnel will receive training on system operation. Additionally, establish a 10-foot perimeter around all heat-generating equipment as a material-free zone to eliminate fuel sources near ignition sources.

name: Conduct Facility-Wide Fire Safety Refresher Training
description: Mandate all production and maintenance staff to complete updated fire safety certification including proper use of different extinguisher types (Class B and C for plastic/electrical fires), evacuation procedures, and emergency response protocols. Training will be delivered within 2 weeks and documented for each employee. Annual refresher training will be scheduled every January.

name: Install Real-Time Hydraulic System Monitoring
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with digital pressure and temperature sensors connected to a central monitoring dashboard. System will generate automated alerts when pressure drops below critical thresholds or when seal degradation patterns are detected. Alerts will trigger immediate work orders in the maintenance system. This engineering control enables early detection of component failures before catastrophic breakdown, reducing unplanned downtime and equipment damage.

name: Enforce Preventive Maintenance Compliance Program
description: Create an automated maintenance scheduling system that locks out equipment for use if scheduled PM is overdue by more than 3 days. Maintenance technician Réjan Simard will conduct weekly audits of PM schedules versus actual completion. Accountability measures include supervisor reviews for missed maintenance windows. All maintenance work will be logged with photographic evidence of seal replacement and component inspection to ensure quality completion.

name: Upgrade CNC Machine Guarding and Emergency Stop System
description: Install enhanced polycarbonate guards around all CNC cutting zones and add redundant emergency stop buttons (at workpiece level and operator position). Upgrade to magnetic quick-release tool holders that automatically release if excessive resistance is detected. Install automated coolant line pressure monitoring with machine shutdown if blockages form. These engineering controls directly prevent hand contact with rotating cutters and mitigate tool seizure incidents.

name: Implement Daily Coolant System Inspection Protocol
description: Require daily visual inspection and weekly analytical testing of CNC coolant systems before operations begin. Inspection checklist will include flow rate verification, concentration testing, and filter condition assessment. Any blockages detected will immediately halt machine use until cleared. Mold Maintenance Technician Réjan Simard will oversee implementation and train all CNC operators on the inspection procedure.

name: Conduct Mandatory CNC Safety Certification Training
description: All CNC operators must complete comprehensive retraining covering emergency response to tool seizure, proper hand positioning, use of workholding devices, and machine guarding. Training will include hands-on simulation of tool seizure scenarios and emergency stop procedures. Documentation will be maintained for all employees. Training will be completed within 10 days of this incident, with annual refresher training thereafter.

name: Resurface and Mark Chemical Transfer Zone
description: Repave the Composite Materials Processing Area entry floor with anti-slip epoxy coating. Install yellow and black floor markings to designate the chemical transfer zone. Add 3 secondary containment berms (30-liter capacity each) at transfer points. Install directional flow signs to guide operators away from high-risk areas. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the spill by preventing cart tipping through improved floor conditions and providing secondary containment.

name: Implement Chemical Transfer Standard Operating Procedure
description: Develop a comprehensive SOP for all chemical drum transfers requiring: two-person teams for drums over 30 liters, mandatory pre-transfer equipment inspection, designated transfer pathways, and spill kit availability within 5 meters of all transfer zones. Conduct mandatory training for all operators handling chemicals. Include quarterly refresher training and monthly audits of chemical handling practices. This administrative control establishes clear procedures to prevent future incidents.

name: Install Interlock Safety System on Injection Line D
description: Install a dual-interlock system on Line D that prevents machine auto-cycle activation when maintenance mode is active or when the hydraulic pressure panel reads below operating threshold. Add mandatory electronic notification alerts to the facility management system and text alerts to shift supervisors when hydraulic pressure drops below 80% of normal operating range. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of sudden machine startup during vulnerable maintenance activities.

name: Establish Shift-to-Shift Equipment Handover Protocol
description: Create a mandatory digital logbook system where outgoing shift supervisors document all equipment status, maintenance work completed, and any ongoing issues. Incoming shift leads must review and acknowledge this report before beginning operations. Implement a 15-minute overlap period between shifts for verbal briefing on equipment conditions. Conduct monthly audits of shift handover compliance. This administrative control ensures critical equipment information is communicated across shifts, preventing hazardous conditions from being overlooked.

name: Replace and Upgrade Adhesive Application Guards
description: Replace the worn safety guard on the labeling equipment with a new polycarbonate guard featuring enhanced coverage and ergonomic design. Install proximity sensors that automatically pause adhesive application when hands enter the application zone. Add high-visibility yellow and black warning striping around the application area. Conduct visual inspection of all similar equipment in the facility and replace guards showing 20% or greater wear. This engineering control prevents direct contact with hazardous adhesives.

name: Enhance Personal Protective Equipment Requirements
description: Mandate nitrile gloves (minimum 0.15mm thickness) and safety glasses for all personnel working with labeled products during the first 2 hours after adhesive application. Provide silicone gloves as an alternative for those with latex sensitivities. Stock extra gloves at 5 convenient locations throughout UNIT-019. Conduct monthly audits to verify 100% compliance with PPE requirements during labeling operations. Update the facility safety induction training to include specific adhesive contact hazards and first-aid response procedures.

name: Implement Preventive Hydraulic System Maintenance Program
description: Establish a quarterly hydraulic system inspection and maintenance schedule with documented pressure tests, hose integrity assessments, and connection torque verification. All hydraulic lines will be visually inspected weekly for signs of leakage or wear. A predictive maintenance log will be created to track system performance trends. Maintenance technicians will receive specialized training on hydraulic safety and environmental compliance. This program will include secondary containment trays under all high-risk connections and automatic shutoff valves to minimize spill volume if leaks occur.

name: Upgrade Spill Response and Environmental Containment Protocols
description: Install permanent spill containment systems including absorbent floor mats and collection trays in high-risk areas around all hydraulic equipment. Establish dedicated spill response kits at strategic locations with clear labeling and access instructions. Train all production staff on proper spill containment, hazardous waste classification, and proper disposal procedures. Update emergency response procedures to include notification timelines to environmental compliance and waste management vendors. Conduct monthly drills to ensure staff competency in spill response.

name: Mandatory Thermal Protective Equipment for Mold Changeovers
description: Establish mandatory use of high-temperature resistant gloves and arm sleeves rated for 200°C+ contact during all mold changeover and maintenance activities. All operators will be required to wear approved thermal PPE before beginning any mold work. Supervisors will conduct visual inspections at the start of each shift. Non-compliance will result in immediate work stoppage and retraining. Equipment will be provided in multiple sizes to ensure comfort and proper fit. Monthly audits will track compliance rates and identify barriers to adoption.

name: Install Automated Temperature Monitoring and Lockout System
