description: Implement digital temperature sensors on all injection molding lines that display real-time mold surface temperatures on visible display panels. Integrate with the machine control system to automatically prevent mold access until surface temperature drops below 60°C. Operators will receive alerts when approaching safe temperature thresholds. This engineering control removes the reliance on operator judgment and provides objective data. System installation includes operator training on interpretation of temperature displays and emergency override procedures.

name: Enhanced Mold Changeover Training Program
description: Develop comprehensive training module covering thermal hazard recognition, proper use of thermal protective equipment, correct changeover sequencing, and emergency response procedures. All operators will complete this training within 30 days and annually thereafter. Training will include practical demonstrations on mold temperature verification using non-contact thermometers. Case studies will highlight burn injuries from similar incidents. Competency assessments will be documented with signatures. New operators will complete training before being allowed to perform mold work independently.

name: Install Protective Bollards and Collision Prevention Systems
description: Install heavy-duty steel bollards around all storage rack support columns in the warehouse. Position bollards at least 1.5 meters from column bases to create impact buffers. Additionally, install proximity warning sensors on all electric forklifts that alert operators when approaching storage structures. These sensors will emit audible and visual alarms within 2 meters of obstacles. All forklifts will receive motion limiters to reduce maximum speed to 6 km/h in high-density storage areas. Impact-absorbing corner guards will be installed on all forklift frames to absorb minor collisions.

name: Enhanced Forklift Operator Certification and Aisle Management Program
description: Implement mandatory recertification program for all forklift operators with practical testing in confined warehouse spaces, depth perception assessment, and load stability evaluation. Operators must demonstrate competency in high-density aisles using standardized route courses. Establish maximum aisle width requirements and install mirrors at all intersections. Paint clear floor markings defining pedestrian zones and equipment zones. Implement a speed governor limiting forklift speeds in storage areas. Supervisors will conduct monthly audits of operator technique and adherence to safe practices.

name: Implement Weekly Ductwork Cleaning Schedule
description: Engineering/administrative control: Establish a mandatory weekly cleaning protocol for all ducting systems in the material handling areas. Install access ports at regular intervals to facilitate inspection and cleaning. Use vacuum systems with HEPA filters to prevent dust re-suspension. Document all cleaning activities in a maintenance log and post cleaning schedules visibly at work stations. Assign responsibility to the maintenance team with supervisor verification.

name: Install Static Grounding on Material Transfer Equipment
description: Engineering control: Install continuous static grounding cables on all material transfer hoppers, mixing vessels, and transfer chutes. Ensure all equipment is bonded to a proper ground system. Install grounding connection points at material loading stations with visual indicators. Train all operators on proper grounding procedures before any material transfer. Conduct quarterly inspections of all grounding connections for continuity.

name: Upgrade Fire Detection and Suppression in Ductwork
description: Engineering control: Install tube-based detection systems throughout the composite fiber ducting network to provide early warning of fire development. Upgrade the existing suppression system with improved nozzles in critical ducting segments. Install fire dampers in the ductwork to prevent fire spread. Conduct annual inspections and testing of all fire protection systems. Train night shift staff on fire emergency procedures specific to ductwork fires.

name: Install Absorbent Spill Stations at Dock Area
description: Engineering control: Install permanent spill containment and absorbent stations at the Shipping and Receiving Dock and near all equipment parking areas. Stock spill kits with absorbent materials, biohazard bags, and cleanup supplies. Place spill response instructions on signage at each station. Train all dock workers on immediate spill response procedures. Designate staff to check spill stations daily for adequate supplies and report maintenance needs of parked equipment.

name: Increase Anti-Slip Matting and Surface Treatments
description: Engineering control: Install durable anti-slip rubber matting in the Shipping and Receiving Dock, particularly in high-traffic pathways and areas where equipment is parked. Apply anti-slip coating to concrete surfaces that are subject to moisture exposure. Ensure drainage systems are clear and functioning properly. Conduct monthly inspections to verify matting integrity and address any worn or damaged sections immediately.

name: Implement Mandatory Hydraulic System Inspection Schedule
description: Establish a preventive maintenance protocol requiring daily visual inspections of all hydraulic lines for leaks, cracks, or deterioration, with documented weekly pressure testing of all high-pressure circuits. All injection molding machines will be limited to 16-hour continuous operation cycles, with mandatory 4-hour maintenance windows. Maintenance staff will receive specialized hydraulic system training. This administrative control directly addresses the deferred maintenance root cause and ensures early detection of seal degradation before catastrophic failure occurs.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for High-Pressure Hydraulic Equipment
description: Design and install stainless steel drip trays beneath all hydraulic manifolds and high-pressure connection points on the 32 injection molding machines. Install secondary catch basins with volume capacity of 110% of the maximum hydraulic fluid inventory per machine. Integrate drain valves connected to hazardous waste collection system. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of hydraulic fluid spreading across the facility floor and potential ignition when contacting hot equipment surfaces.

name: Upgrade Fire Detection and Suppression Near Production Equipment
description: Install dedicated automatic fire suppression systems using inert gas (nitrogen) for hydraulic equipment areas, supplementing existing dry chemical systems. Add temperature-sensitive optical flame detectors adjacent to all high-pressure hydraulic connection points. Integrate alert system with facility-wide alarm and notification system. Train all production operators on system activation and emergency procedures. This engineering control provides rapid fire suppression capability before equipment damage becomes catastrophic and protects against the specific hazard of hydraulic fluid ignition.

name: Complete Overhead Rack Structural Assessment and Hardware Replacement
description: Conduct comprehensive structural engineering assessment of all overhead storage racks in the Composite Materials Processing Area and Production Operations zones. Inspect 100% of fastening hardware (bolts, brackets, welds) for corrosion, fatigue, or damage. Replace all corroded fasteners with stainless steel hardware rated for high-humidity composite manufacturing environments. Install protective coatings on all iron/steel brackets. Establish quarterly reinspection schedule documented in maintenance logs. This engineering control eliminates the immediate hazard of container failure while establishing preventive monitoring.

name: Implement Environmental Humidity Control and Protective Equipment Maintenance
description: Install industrial dehumidification system in Composite Materials Processing Area to maintain humidity below 60% RH, reducing moisture-based corrosion of overhead equipment. Apply moisture-barrier protective coating to all exposed fastening hardware quarterly. Place desiccant packets in storage racks to control localized moisture. Train all personnel on early warning signs of corrosion and mandate monthly visual inspections with documented reporting. This administrative and environmental control addresses the root cause of corrosion formation.

name: Install Automated Component Specification Verification System
description: Implement vision-based quality verification system at the Packaging and Labeling Station that automatically checks component cavity dimensions against specification tolerance band before allowing pneumatic press operation. System will use industrial camera with image analysis software to verify inner cavity width, depth, and roundness. If any dimension exceeds ±2mm tolerance, the component will be ejected to a quarantine bin and press operation will be blocked. This engineering control (elimination of the hazard source) prevents non-conforming components from ever reaching the press, eliminating the root cause of misalignment and operator hand injuries.

name: Enhance Pneumatic Press Safety Interlocks and Emergency Controls
description: Retrofit all pneumatic presses with dual safety features: (1) pressure-sensitive mats around the press cavity that immediately cut pneumatic pressure if weight is detected, and (2) integrated hand detection sensors that trigger emergency stop if foreign objects enter the press chamber during operation. Replace existing foot pedal with deadman switch requiring continuous operator pressure to maintain cycle, combined with emergency palm button accessible from any position. Conduct 4-hour safety training for all operators on new controls. This engineering control provides automatic protection against finger/hand entrapment regardless of operator attention.

name: Implement Mandatory Component Handoff Verification Protocol
description: Establish written procedure requiring Materials Management personnel to attach specification verification tags (indicating cavity dimensions, part number, and batch number) to every pallet delivered to production stations. Assembly Operators must physically inspect the tag and verify against the work order before beginning processing. Institute weekly meetings between Materials Management (Warehouse Associate) and Production Supervisors to communicate any tooling drifts, material discrepancies, or production anomalies immediately. Add this handoff procedure to the New Employee Orientation training. This administrative control ensures critical specification information is communicated and acknowledged before work begins, preventing upstream production errors from reaching operators.

name: Establish Preventive Sensor Maintenance Schedule for Composite Areas
description: Develop a formalized maintenance schedule requiring monthly sensor cleaning and inspection in all composite processing equipment, documented in the computerized maintenance management system (CMMS). Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie will assign this task to maintenance technicians with specific cleaning procedures using approved solvents to prevent sensor damage. Work orders will include photographic documentation before and after cleaning. This administrative control prevents sensor degradation and ensures early detection of blockages before they cause equipment malfunction.

name: Implement Waste Storage Area Relocation and HVAC Clearance Zones
description: Establish a minimum 1.5-meter clearance zone around all HVAC inlet and outlet vents in composite processing areas. Relocate all waste bins containing composite scraps to designated storage areas outside recirculation zones with proper ventilation. Install stainless steel bins with ventilation holes and secure lids to prevent material accumulation and airflow concentration. Mark clearance zones with high-visibility floor tape and signage. This engineering control eliminates the fire initiation pathway by separating combustible materials from heat sources.

name: Upgrade Fire Detection System Sensitivity in Composite Processing
description: Install additional heat and smoke detection sensors with lower activation thresholds specifically calibrated for composite material fire risk (lowering thermal threshold from 150°C to 95°C in this area). Add optical smoke detectors in addition to existing thermal sensors. Integrate all sensors into the facility's integrated fire management system with immediate facility-wide alert capability and automatic notification to the Laval Fire Department. This engineering control ensures earlier detection and faster emergency response.

name: Conduct Facility-Wide Fire Safety and Hot Work Prevention Training
description: Provide mandatory training to all production and maintenance staff on fire prevention specific to composite materials, including spontaneous heating risks, proper waste disposal, and hot surface awareness. Include hands-on demonstration of fire suppression system activation using training simulators. Document competency verification for all personnel in the composite processing area. This administrative control ensures all staff understand fire prevention principles and their role in maintaining safe conditions.

name: Implement Mandatory Interlock Bypass Reporting System
description: Establish a daily equipment condition checklist where operators must report any malfunctioning interlocks or slow cycle times to maintenance before shift end. Create a quick-response maintenance protocol with 4-hour maximum response time for reported issues. All bypasses must be logged with timestamp, operator name, and reason. Any interlock found bypassed during audit will trigger immediate investigation and corrective training for the operator. This eliminates the pressure operators feel to disable safety devices due to production delays.

name: Enhanced LOTO Audit Program
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all injection molding lines to identify any existing interlock bypasses or LOTO violations. Implement monthly compliance audits with photographic documentation. Add LOTO verification to daily startup checklist. Require all operators to complete refresher training on lockout/tagout procedures within 30 days. Track audit results and share findings with JHSC monthly.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Facility Lighting and Inspection Protocol
description: Install LED high-bay lighting system in Chemical Storage and Mixing building to provide minimum 500 lux illumination throughout storage areas, enabling detection of container damage during inspections. Implement daily visual inspection checklist requiring staff to document container condition, integrity, and any signs of damage or leakage. Create standardized damage report form that triggers immediate container replacement or repair. Replace all storage containers older than 5 years proactively, regardless of apparent condition.

name: Staff Training on Chemical Hazard Identification and Reporting
description: Conduct mandatory training for all personnel who handle or move hazardous materials on recognizing signs of container deterioration, proper damage reporting procedures, and environmental incident response protocols. Include specific focus on VOC spill response and stormwater protection. Training must be completed within 30 days with documentation. Add annual refresher training requirement to safety calendar.

name: Install Spill Prevention and Containment Infrastructure
description: Design and install secondary containment bunding for all large VOC-containing resin storage containers, capable of holding 110% of the largest container volume. Install segregated sump area with automatic shutoff valve to prevent accidental discharge to stormwater system. Add emergency response kit (absorbent materials, spill kit, cleanup supplies) within 10 meters of chemical storage with clear labeling and access instructions.

name: Implement Mechanical Material Handling Equipment
description: Procure and install electric pallet jacks and hand trucks in the Warehouse and Shipping building to eliminate manual lifting of bags over 30 kg. Train all warehouse staff on proper equipment operation within 7 days. Establish clear guidelines that bags over 30 kg must be moved via mechanical equipment only. This engineering control removes the hazard entirely rather than relying on proper technique alone.

name: Restore Two-Person Lift Protocol and Ergonomics Training
description: Immediately reverse the two-week-old delivery protocol change. Reinstate mandatory two-person lift requirement for all loads exceeding 25 kg (not 40 kg as previously). Conduct comprehensive ergonomics and proper lifting technique training for all warehouse and material handling staff within 5 days. Include assessment of current workstation design and adjustment recommendations. Schedule quarterly ergonomics refresher training going forward.

name: Ergonomic Workstation Assessment and Modification
description: Conduct formal ergonomic assessment of the Warehouse and Shipping building loading dock area, including truck bed height, pallet positioning, and floor conditions. Make necessary modifications such as adjustable loading dock height, improved floor surface to reduce strain, and strategic placement of mechanical handling equipment to minimize manual lifting distances. Install anti-fatigue mats in high-standing-time areas.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling Water System Inspections
description: Establish a formal preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly visual inspections and quarterly pressure tests of all cooling water system piping in the facility. Inspections will include examination for mineral deposits, corrosion indicators, and moisture accumulation as early warning signs of developing leaks. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie (EMP-00199) will create inspection checklists and assign responsibility to maintenance technicians. Documentation will be retained for trend analysis. This engineering control combined with administrative procedures will detect leaks before they become critical failures.

name: Install Secondary Containment Under Cooling Water Lines
description: Engineering control to prevent water system leaks from creating slip hazards and equipment damage. Install shallow containment trays under the most critical cooling water piping sections that run over warehouse storage areas and production floors. Trays will capture any leakage and include drainage to collection sumps for monitoring. This eliminates the slip hazard from leaked cooling water and provides early detection through visual inspection of collected water volume and quality. Implementation includes pipe insulation replacement and tray installation by maintenance team.

name: Establish Mandatory Equipment Post-Maintenance Verification Protocol
description: Administrative control requiring comprehensive verification testing after any deburring machine maintenance or repair. Protocol mandates that at least 50 sample parts must be processed and 100% inspected for burr removal before production resumes. All defects must be documented and equipment must be recalibrated before approval. A checklist sign-off by both maintenance technician and production supervisor is required. This procedure directly addresses the root cause by preventing equipment from returning to production without proven effectiveness. Training will be provided to all relevant staff on the new protocol.

name: Upgrade Manual Part Handling PPE Requirements
description: Implement enhanced personal protective equipment for assembly operators handling composite parts. All operators will be required to wear cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 rated) when removing parts from fixtures. Provide ergonomic grab tools and part handling fixtures that reduce direct hand contact with part edges. Conduct training on proper tool use and hazard recognition for sharp edges on composite parts. While PPE is the lowest hierarchy control, it provides immediate protection while engineering and administrative controls are developed for the automated deburring process.

name: Implement Comprehensive Ladder Safety and Maintenance Program
description: Engineering and administrative control combining equipment inspection with work procedures. All facility ladders will be inspected monthly for structural integrity, rung cleanliness, and slip-resistance. Ladders in chemical storage areas will receive priority attention due to contamination risk. A color-coded inspection tag system will indicate last inspection date and next due date. Cleaning protocols will specify that all ladders in chemical areas must be wiped down after each shift using appropriate solvents to remove resin residue. Maintenance staff will receive annual ladder safety training. This eliminates the slip hazard while ensuring equipment integrity.

name: Install Anti-Slip Ladder Treads in Chemical Storage Area
description: Engineering control to reduce slip risk on all ladders in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Install adhesive-backed anti-slip tape on all ladder rungs, with particular emphasis on the bottom 6 feet where slip incidents are most common. Replace tape annually. Additionally, install permanent fixed stairways with handrails as primary access to elevated work areas where feasible, eliminating reliance on portable ladders for routine maintenance tasks. This substitution control removes the ladder hazard entirely for regularly-accessed areas.

name: Establish Pre-Shift Hazard Inspection for Night Operations
description: Administrative control requiring night shift supervisors to conduct documented pre-shift walkthroughs of all work areas, specifically checking for slip hazards, ladder condition, and chemical spill contamination. Inspection checklist will be posted and signed off by supervisor each shift. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie will create standardized inspection forms and provide training to supervisors. This procedure ensures early detection of environmental hazards before they contribute to incidents during the night shift when support personnel are limited.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Thermal Equipment
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all resin dryers and heating units including thermostat sensor replacement and calibration verification. Maintenance technician Luc Girard will develop a standardized checklist covering thermal sensor functionality testing, electrical connections, and temperature logging. This will be integrated into the predictive maintenance system already in place. Expected outcome: reduction of thermal equipment failures by 85% and earlier detection of sensor drift before critical temperatures are reached.

name: Operator Training Enhancement on Equipment Anomaly Recognition
description: Develop and deliver a 2-hour supplementary training module for all injection molding operators focusing on identification of early warning signs of equipment malfunction including unusual vibrations, odors, temperature anomalies, and sound changes. Training will include case studies and practical demonstrations. Alain Mercier will coordinate with production supervisors to schedule sessions during shift changes. All operators must complete certification before solo operation on Lines A, B, and C.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Chemical Storage
description: Design and install engineered secondary containment trays with 110% capacity of the largest container for all solvent storage areas in Regrind and Recycling Department. Install stainless steel drip pans with drain valves leading to collection sump. Implement color-coded containment zones: red for acetone/flammables, yellow for general chemicals. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of uncontained spills reaching the floor. Expected outcome: complete prevention of environmental release to floor areas and adjacent spaces.

name: Chemical Inventory Management and Labeling Protocol
description: Implement a comprehensive digital chemical inventory system requiring RFID tags and QR codes on all containers. All containers must display hazard pictograms, product name, hazard classification, first aid measures, and storage requirements. Conduct a facility-wide chemical audit to identify all stored materials. Establish monthly inventory verification with Hana Al-Rashid. Create no-contact zones for chemical storage preventing stacking and requiring minimum clearance. Establish proper storage locations based on chemical compatibility charts.

name: Enhanced Ventilation System Upgrade and Air Quality Monitoring
description: Upgrade existing ventilation in Regrind and Recycling Department with dedicated exhaust lines for solvent areas, real-time VOC sensors, and automated damper systems. Install continuous air quality monitoring displays showing real-time ppm levels. System will automatically increase exhaust capacity when VOC levels exceed 25 ppm. Monthly calibration of sensors required. This ensures airborne solvent concentrations remain well below occupational exposure limits (100 ppm OSHA TWA for acetone).

name: Mandatory Mechanical Assist Equipment Usage Policy
description: Implement a facility-wide administrative control requiring documented use of mechanical assistance (pallet jacks, forklifts, hoists) for all loads exceeding 20 kg. Supervisors must conduct pre-shift briefings highlighting this requirement. Electronic work permits will not be issued for manual lifting tasks without documented supervisor approval for exceptional circumstances. Install prominent signage at all loading areas showing proper lift techniques and mechanical equipment availability. This administrative control addresses the root cause of non-compliance with existing safety protocols.

name: Ergonomic Assessment and Redesign of Loading Dock Operations
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessment of Shipping and Receiving Dock workflow with ergonomics specialist Alain Mercier. Implement height-adjustable work platforms to eliminate bending, install conveyor rollers on dock to reduce manual manipulation, and reorganize storage to place frequently-moved items between waist and shoulder height. Redesign shift rotation to limit consecutive night shifts to maximum 3 nights followed by 2 days rest. Expected outcome: reduction of manual handling injuries by 70% and decreased fatigue-related incidents.

name: Refresher Training on Proper Lifting Techniques and Fatigue Management
description: Develop and deliver mandatory 90-minute training module covering proper lifting biomechanics, fatigue recognition, and fatigue mitigation strategies for night shift workers. Training will include practical demonstrations, micro-break scheduling, and hydration protocols. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid will assess individual fitness and modify recommendations based on personal risk factors. All personnel involved in manual material handling must recertify annually. Include specific guidance on when to request assistance and how to refuse unsafe work tasks.

name: Implement Automated Temperature Monitoring System for Resin Dryers
description: Install real-time temperature monitoring sensors with automated alerts on all 12 resin dryers across production lines. System will trigger visual and auditory alarms if temperatures exceed safe thresholds and log all temperature data for trend analysis. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause by providing continuous oversight of critical equipment. Expected outcome: Prevention of undetected temperature excursions and early identification of failing thermostats before critical conditions develop.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for All Thermal Equipment
description: Create and implement a documented preventive maintenance schedule requiring thermostat calibration and resin dryer inspection every 250 operating hours (approximately every 2 weeks). Assign responsibility to the Maintenance team with tracking in the facility's CMMS system. Maintenance checks will include temperature sensor verification, heating element inspection, and thermal cutoff testing. This administrative control ensures systematic monitoring and early detection of equipment degradation.

name: Install Automated Deburring Station for Medical Component Molds
description: Install an automated tumble deburring system specifically configured for the medical-grade polycarbonate connectors produced on Line A. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source by automating the sharp edge removal process, making manual contact with unfinished parts unnecessary. The system will be integrated into the production flow between molding and quality inspection. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of flash edges on finished parts and elimination of hand laceration risk during part handling.

name: Mandate Cut-Resistant Gloves for All Part Handling Operations
description: Distribute ANSI A4-rated cut-resistant gloves to all production and quality personnel handling injection-molded components. Integrate glove requirements into the production work instructions and implement daily compliance checks by shift supervisors. This PPE control serves as an interim protective measure while the automated deburring system is being procured and installed. Training will emphasize proper glove selection, fit, and limitations.

name: Revise Production Scheduling to Eliminate Deburring Bypass
description: Modify the production scheduling system to never permit bypass of critical quality control and finishing operations such as deburring, regardless of time pressures. Establish communication protocol between production planning and operations to address scheduling conflicts without compromising safety. Include explicit language in production orders that quality processes cannot be abbreviated. This administrative control addresses the systemic root cause of the incident.

name: Install Mechanical Drum Handling Equipment in Chemical Storage Area
description: Procure and install two drum lifters/handling devices (pneumatic or electric) in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room to mechanically lift, position, and secure resin drums up to 55 kg onto storage racks without manual handling. This engineering control eliminates the heavy lifting hazard at the source. Equipment will include safety stops, secure grip mechanisms, and operator training protocols. Expected outcome: Elimination of manual heavy lifting for drum storage and significant reduction in back injury risk for all personnel handling chemical materials.

name: Mandatory Ergonomics and Manual Lifting Refresher Training
description: Conduct mandatory 2-hour ergonomics and safe lifting training for all warehouse, materials management, and production personnel. Training will cover proper lifting mechanics, load assessment, two-person lift requirements for loads exceeding 25 kg, use of mechanical handling equipment, and recognition of ergonomic risk factors. Training will include video demonstrations, practical exercises, and competency assessment. Documentation will be maintained for regulatory compliance. Schedule training during regular work hours with attendance tracked.

name: Enforce Two-Person Lift Policy for Heavy Materials
description: Implement and enforce a facility-wide administrative control requiring two-person manual lifting for any load exceeding 25 kg. Post signage at all storage areas identifying loads requiring two-person lifts. Train supervisors on enforcement procedures and include this requirement in job task analysis and work instructions for all relevant positions. Supervisors will verify compliance during shift inspections. This administrative control provides immediate protection while mechanical equipment is being installed.

name: Install Automated Temperature Monitoring and Alarm System
description: Implement real-time temperature monitoring sensors on all material drying and heating systems with automated alerts when temperatures exceed safe operating parameters by more than 5%. The system will trigger both visual and audible warnings at operator stations and alert maintenance staff via SMS. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of undetected equipment malfunction that led to material decomposition and fume generation.

name: Mandatory Pre-Shift Equipment Inspection Training
description: Develop and implement a 2-hour training module for all production operators on recognizing early warning signs of equipment malfunction including unusual vibrations, temperature anomalies, and abnormal odors. Include procedural requirement that operators must conduct visual and auditory inspections of their assigned machines every 90 minutes and document findings on a checklist. Emphasize immediate reporting and emergency stop activation without attempting to diagnose or troubleshoot. Training will be completed within 30 days for all existing operators and incorporated into new employee onboarding.

name: Implement Mandatory Ladder Safety and Fall Protection Protocol
description: All ladders in the maintenance workshop must now be equipped with self-locking feet and top-stabilizing bars. Establish a new procedure requiring two-point contact at all times (both hands or both feet plus one hand). Install guardrails or safety harness anchor points for any maintenance work above 6 feet. Conduct immediate ladder safety inspection audit of all 24 ladders in the facility. Implement a monthly ladder maintenance and inspection log. This engineering control directly prevents future falls from ladder slippage and ensures adequate hand/foot support.

name: Establish Shift-End Workplace Cleaning and Debris Management
description: Institute a mandatory 15-minute shift-end cleaning protocol for the Mold Shop and Central Maintenance areas. Assign specific responsibilities for sweeping, clearing metal shavings, wiping coolant spills, and securing equipment. Implement a daily checklist reviewed by the shift supervisor before shift change. Ensure adequate PPE (safety glasses, cut-resistant gloves) is available for cleanup crew. This administrative control reduces the risk of slip hazards and the severity of injuries from falls by eliminating sharp debris from landing zones.

name: Mandatory Maintenance Worker Fall Protection and Rescue Training
description: Require all maintenance technicians to complete an 8-hour advanced fall protection certification course including proper harness fitting, anchor point identification, rescue techniques, and emergency protocols. Training must be completed within 60 days and renewed annually. Include competency assessment and practical demonstrations. This administrative/training control ensures that maintenance staff understand fall risks and can respond appropriately to emergency situations.

name: Implement Mandatory Load Inspection and Securing Protocol
description: Establish a new procedure requiring all palletized materials to be inspected for stability and properly secured with industrial-grade shrink wrap before being stored or moved. Implement a three-point verification system: (1) visual stability check before wrapping, (2) shrink wrap application verification, and (3) 100% inspection before movement. Create a checklist form that forklift operators must complete and sign off on. This administrative control ensures loads are stable and prevents shifting hazards. Include photographic documentation of loads exceeding 40 pounds to verify stability.

name: Implement Mandatory Machine Interlock Testing Protocol
description: Establish a monthly verification schedule for all CNC milling machine interlock systems, including spindle brake responsiveness and emergency stop button activation testing. All test results must be documented and reviewed by the Maintenance Supervisor. Testing must be performed before any production shifts resume. This addresses the root cause of the unexpected spindle restart and ensures machines meet ANSI B11.19 standards for emergency stop systems. Expected outcome: Elimination of interlock-related machine restart incidents.

name: Upgrade Emergency Stop Button Responsiveness
description: Replace all existing emergency stop buttons on CNC milling machines with Category 3 safety-rated emergency stop systems that meet IEC 60204-1 standards. These new systems will have faster response times (less than 100ms) compared to current systems (currently 300-400ms). Engineering firm will be contracted for installation and certification. This engineering control eliminates the delay that allowed the incident to develop further.

name: Mandatory CNC Machine Safety Refresher Training
description: Conduct immediate refresher training for all Tool and Die Makers and CNC operators on machine-specific hazards, proper lockout/tagout procedures, and emergency stop procedures. Training will include hands-on demonstration of the new emergency stop systems and interlock verification procedures. All employees must pass a competency assessment before returning to CNC operations. This administrative control ensures workers understand the hazards and proper response protocols.

name: Establish Hydraulic Equipment Inspection and Maintenance Schedule
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic equipment, including monthly visual inspections for corrosion, leaks, and hose integrity. All hydraulic hoses must be replaced every 5 years or immediately if signs of external corrosion or leaking are detected. A digital maintenance tracking system will log all inspections and repairs. Supervisors must authorize and document all maintenance work. This eliminates the root cause of the fire alarm trigger by preventing corroded hoses from leaking.

name: Install Automated Hydraulic Fluid Leak Detection System
description: Install absorbent containment pads and drip collection trays under all hydraulic equipment in the Shipping and Receiving Dock. Integrate moisture sensors in collection trays that trigger audible alarms when fluid accumulation exceeds safe levels. This engineering control prevents hydraulic fluid from reaching ignition sources and provides early warning of equipment failures.

name: Implement Monthly Chemical Storage Container Integrity Inspection
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection protocol for all chemical storage containers and cabinet seals. Inspections must include verification of cap tightness, assessment of crystallization or residue on container exteriors, and integrity of container labeling. Any containers showing signs of leakage or seal degradation must be transferred to new containers or marked for disposal. All inspections must be logged in the chemical inventory management system with date, inspector name, and findings. This administrative control ensures early detection of chemical storage issues before they create exposure hazards.

name: Clean and Verify Chemical Storage Ventilation System
description: Perform immediate professional cleaning of the chemical storage cabinet ventilation ports and ducting to remove accumulated dust and fibers. Verify that ventilation system is operating at designed flow rates using airflow measurement instruments. Schedule quarterly ventilation system inspections and cleanings going forward. Document all ventilation maintenance in facilities logs. This engineering control ensures proper air circulation to prevent hazardous solvent vapor accumulation.

name: Replace Compromised Acetone Containers and Implement Supplier Quality Controls
description: Immediately replace the three compromised acetone containers with new inventory from suppliers who provide containers with certified seal integrity. Establish a receiving inspection protocol that includes verification of container seal integrity before acceptance of chemical deliveries. Update supplier contracts to include performance requirements for container quality and seal integrity. This addresses both the immediate contamination issue and prevents future occurrences through supply chain controls.

name: Implement Compressed Air Safety Training and PPE Requirements
description: Mandatory refresher training for all production operators on safe compressed air handling practices, with emphasis on maximum PSI limits and PPE requirements. All operators will be required to wear safety glasses and face shield when using compressed air near material hoppers. A new procedure will designate approved high-pressure air usage zones and require supervisor authorization. Training will be completed within 7 days and documented for all affected staff.

name: Install Compressed Air Regulator Control Devices
description: Engineer and install pressure-limiting regulators on all compressed air lines in production areas to cap maximum PSI at 30 psi for non-industrial applications, eliminating the potential for high-velocity projectile incidents. Regulators will include clear pressure gauge indicators. Installation will be completed on all 12 injection molding lines within 14 days of incident declaration.

name: Establish Waste Container Level Monitoring and Replacement Schedule
description: Implement a daily visual inspection checklist for all chemical waste containers with mandatory capacity limits set at 80% maximum. Containers will be replaced before reaching this threshold. A digital tracking system will be installed to monitor container usage and automatically generate replacement requests. All operators will receive training on proper container handling and the new inspection protocol within 5 days.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Drain Protection System
description: Engineer and install secondary containment trays beneath all chemical mixing workstations with sufficient capacity to contain 150% of the largest single container volume. Drain system will be retrofitted with removable screens and emergency shut-off valves to prevent spills from entering the facility drainage system. Chemical waste will be segregated into separate containers by type. Installation will be completed within 21 days.

name: Conduct Environmental Compliance Audit and Staff Training
description: Comprehensive audit of all chemical storage, handling, and waste disposal procedures to ensure CNESST and environmental protection regulation compliance. All staff involved in chemical operations will attend refresher training on spill response, waste segregation, and emergency procedures. Documentation of the audit and training completion will be maintained for regulatory review. Audit to be completed within 14 days.

name: Implement Mandatory Pre-Shift Hydraulic System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a daily checklist that requires operators to visually inspect all hydraulic system components, including pressure gauges, hoses, and relief valves before beginning operations. Any damaged or non-functioning gauges must be reported immediately and the line must be marked with lockout tags. No production can proceed until repairs are verified and documented. All operators will receive training on this protocol within 3 days. Daily inspection logs will be maintained and reviewed weekly by maintenance leads.

name: Install Automated Pressure Monitoring and Alert System
description: Engineer and install real-time pressure monitoring sensors on all injection molding line hydraulic systems with automated alerts when pressure exceeds 1,900 psi. The system will trigger an audible alarm and illuminated warning on the operator control panel. Secondary pressure relief valves will be installed as backup safety devices set at 1,950 psi. All sensors will communicate to a centralized monitoring station. Installation completion target is 30 days.

name: Enforce Lockout/Tagout Procedures for All Hydraulic Maintenance
description: Implement mandatory LOTO procedures for any maintenance work involving hydraulic systems, pressure release valves, or high-temperature equipment. All maintenance personnel will receive comprehensive LOTO training and certification within 10 days. A certified LOTO technician must be present for any hydraulic system maintenance. Written LOTO procedures will be posted at each workstation. Monthly LOTO audits will be conducted by the HSE team with findings reported to management.

name: Upgrade Operator Protective Equipment for Thermal and Hydraulic Hazards
description: Issue all injection molding operators specialized thermal-resistant protective equipment including reinforced sleeves rated for 200°C contact and high-pressure hydraulic fluid resistant gloves rated for 3,000 psi impact resistance. Equipment will be distributed within 7 days and fit testing will be conducted. Usage will be mandatory during all mold maintenance activities. Equipment replacement schedule will be established every 12 months or upon damage.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE Requirement for Mold Inspection
description: Implement a mandatory requirement that all personnel performing mold temperature checks or cavity inspections must wear heat-resistant sleeves rated for 100°C+ and heat-resistant gloves. Update the standard operating procedures (SOPs) for all injection molding lines to explicitly require this PPE configuration. Conduct a toolbox talk with all production operators (within 48 hours) and add this requirement to the monthly safety briefing checklist. Procure additional heat-resistant sleeves and gloves to ensure availability at each workstation.

name: Install Mold Temperature Remote Monitoring System
description: Evaluate and implement non-contact infrared thermometers or thermal imaging cameras for mold temperature monitoring to eliminate direct mold contact during inspection. This engineering control removes the hazard entirely by allowing operators to safely read mold temperatures from a safe distance (minimum 12 inches). Conduct training sessions for operators on proper use of thermal monitoring equipment. This addresses the root cause by providing an alternative to manual contact-based inspection methods.

name: Mandatory Lockout/Tagout Enforcement and Certification Program
description: Implement a comprehensive LOTO enforcement program with immediate mandatory re-certification for all 200 employees within 15 days. Establish that NO production troubleshooting shall occur without LOTO compliance. Install lockout stations at each molding machine with required LOTO equipment. Establish a two-operator verification rule: one operator performs LOTO while a second operator independently verifies all energy sources are isolated before ANY manual intervention on machines. Conduct audits monthly. Update all SOPs to explicitly state that bypassing LOTO results in immediate disciplinary action up to termination.

name: Install Automated Part Ejection Jam Detection System
description: Engineer and install pressure-relief systems and jam detection sensors on all 32 injection molding machines. These sensors will automatically halt the molding cycle and trigger an alarm if a part jam is detected during ejection, preventing the need for manual intervention. This eliminates the root hazard by making manual part removal unnecessary. Coordinate with equipment manufacturers for sensor integration and calibration. Test all systems before returning machines to full production.

name: Restricted Entry Training for Night Shift Operations
description: Implement mandatory additional training specifically for night shift operations (20 employees) on incident response, machine safety, and hazard recognition. Assign a dedicated safety supervisor to the night shift (stagger assignment with existing EHS staff) to provide direct oversight of all machine interventions. Establish a protocol requiring phone contact to day-shift supervisor before any unscheduled machine troubleshooting is performed.

name: Electrical System Preventive Maintenance Schedule Implementation
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance (PM) schedule for all electrical fixtures, particularly those in hazardous areas (chemical storage, solvent mixing rooms). Schedule quarterly inspection of all light fixtures, ballasts, and electrical connections in chemical storage and mixing areas. Contract with a certified electrical contractor to perform detailed inspections every 6 months for fixtures located within 5 meters of flammable chemical storage. Replace any ballasts showing signs of age or degradation immediately upon discovery. Document all inspections in the predictive maintenance system.

name: Enhanced Ventilation and Vapor Monitoring in Chemical Areas
description: Upgrade the ventilation system in the Regrind and Recycling Department to achieve continuous air changes at 12+ per hour (current estimate: 8 per hour). Install permanent mounted acetone/isopropanol vapor detectors with audible/visual alarms set at 600 ppm (80% of PEL) to provide early warning of vapor buildup. Ensure exhaust air is directed to safe location outside the facility. Test ventilation monthly and document readings. This control prevents vapor accumulation that could reach explosive concentrations near ignition sources.

name: Relocation of Chemical Solvents Away from Electrical Equipment
description: Evaluate the physical layout of the chemical mixing room and implement a distance barrier of minimum 3 meters between all solvent storage cabinets and electrical fixtures (including lighting, junction boxes, outlets). If adequate distance cannot be achieved, relocate the solvent storage cabinet to a designated hazardous materials storage building or external storage shed. Install explosion-proof lighting fixtures (Class I Division 1 rated) in any areas where this 3-meter distance cannot be maintained. This engineering control reduces fire risk by minimizing proximity of flammable materials to ignition sources.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Enforcement
description: Implement mandatory lockout/tagout procedures for all equipment maintenance and pressure relief operations. All production operators must complete LOTO certification within 30 days with quarterly refresher training. Create checklist system requiring supervisor sign-off before any manual equipment adjustments. Install visible LOTO stations at each injection molding line with pre-configured lockout kits and documented procedures in French and English. Conduct weekly audits of LOTO compliance with disciplinary measures for non-compliance.

name: Hydraulic System Maintenance Schedule Overhaul
description: Establish preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic systems with monthly inspections, quarterly pressure relief valve testing, and semi-annual system audits. Create digital maintenance log system tracking all service dates, technician notes, and component replacements. Replace all pressure relief valves on Lines C and D within 14 days. Train maintenance technicians on proper pressure system diagnostics and install pressure gauges on all lines for real-time monitoring.

name: Enhanced Chemical Burn First Aid Training
description: All production staff must complete emergency chemical/thermal burn response training with hands-on demonstration of on-site treatment protocols. Install eyewash stations and emergency showers within 10 meters of all injection molding lines. Stock first aid kits with specialized burn dressings and cooling agents. Conduct quarterly drills simulating hydraulic fluid exposure incidents with response time tracking.

name: Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish quarterly thermographic and ultrasonic inspections of all hydraulic hoses in the tool room to detect age-related degradation before failure. Create inventory system tracking hose installation dates and pressure ratings. Replace hoses every 5 years or upon first sign of degradation. Document all inspections with photographic evidence stored in digital system. Provide technicians with portable ultrasonic testing equipment and training to identify failing components early.

name: Install Hopper Thermal Insulation and Warning Labels
description: All material drying hoppers in UNIT-016 will be retrofitted with high-temperature silicone foam insulation (minimum R-4 rating) to reduce exterior surface temperature to below 45°C. Yellow and black warning labels with bilingual text will be affixed to all heated equipment indicating temperature hazards. This engineering control directly eliminates the thermal contact hazard. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in hopper-related thermal burns.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE Compliance Program
description: Implement a structured administrative control requiring all operators in UNIT-016 to wear assigned Kevlar-lined forearm sleeves during all shifts. Monthly audits will be conducted by the shift supervisor. The HSE office will provide re-training on proper PPE fit and heat management strategies. Improved sleeve comfort (cooling gel inserts) will be provided to address previous non-compliance issues.

name: Immediate Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Enforcement and Re-Certification
description: All maintenance personnel will be required to complete comprehensive LOTO re-certification training within 5 days. A zero-tolerance policy will be implemented: any maintenance work without proper lockout will result in immediate suspension of work privileges and disciplinary action. Supervisors will conduct daily pre-shift LOTO audits. Installation of tamper-evident lockout hasps and comprehensive LOTO checklist postings at every injection molding machine will provide visual reminders.

name: Replace Faulty Sensor and Install Machine Guard Barriers
description: The faulty sensor override on Machine #18 will be replaced immediately with a dual-redundant safety sensor system that prevents hopper cycling during maintenance mode. All 32 injection molding machines will be retrofitted with physical perimeter guards around hopper and feeder areas, reducing access to pinch points. These engineering controls directly eliminate the entanglement hazard by preventing both unexpected machine cycling and direct contact with rotating components.

name: Predictive Maintenance Program Acceleration for Sensor Systems
description: Implement accelerated preventive maintenance protocols for all sensor systems and safety interlocks across production equipment. Faulty sensors will be replaced within 24 hours of identification rather than waiting for scheduled maintenance. A dedicated maintenance technician will be assigned to perform daily sensor functionality checks. This administrative/engineering hybrid control ensures equipment reliability and prevents future component-related incidents.

name: Chemical Storage Segregation and Compatibility Assessment
description: A comprehensive chemical inventory audit will be conducted to identify all incompatible chemical pairs in UNIT-018. Incompatible chemicals will be physically separated by minimum 3-meter distances and stored in separate secondary containment zones with color-coded labeling systems. A Chemical Compatibility Matrix will be posted at all storage locations. All staff will receive training on the matrix within 10 days. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the root cause (incompatible storage) that led to corrosion and rupture.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment and Spill Response Infrastructure
description: All chemical storage areas will be upgraded with 110% volume capacity secondary containment (drain-equipped polymer basins). Additional spill kits containing absorbent pads, neutralizing agents, and disposal containers will be strategically positioned throughout UNIT-018 (minimum 2 kits per 500 sq meters). Enhanced ventilation capacity will be installed with real-time VOC monitoring sensors that trigger automatic alerts when VOC levels exceed 50 ppm. Staff will receive quarterly spill response drills.

name: Implement Automated Drum Condition Monitoring System
description: Inspection protocols will transition from monthly visual checks to weekly inspections using corrosion-detection technology (ultrasonic thickness measurement for all chemical drums). Drums showing corrosion thinning >10% will be immediately transferred to new containers. Staff will be trained on ultrasonic inspection equipment operation. A tracking log will be maintained for all drum conditions and maintenance history.

name: Install Redundant Safety Interlocks on All Injection Molding Lines
description: Install dual-channel safety interlocks on Lines A, B, and C injection molding equipment to prevent unexpected machine startup. These interlocks will include door sensors, two-hand control stations, and mold position sensors with independent verification circuits. The system will be certified to ISO 13849-1 PLd standards. Implementation includes full system testing, operator training, and monthly verification audits. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of unexpected machine activation.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Protocol for Part Removal
description: Establish and enforce a lockout/tagout procedure specifically for routine part removal operations on all injection molding equipment. Operators must de-energize machines, apply locks, and verify zero energy state before inserting hands into mold cavities. Training will be mandatory for all production operators. Compliance will be verified through daily equipment inspections by the LOTO Coordinator. Weekly audits will track compliance rates and identify training gaps.

name: Establish Daily Equipment Maintenance and Status Log
description: Implement a digital equipment status tracking system where maintenance issues must be logged immediately and flagged for priority repair. Operators will perform pre-shift equipment inspections and report any anomalies. Faulty sensors, sluggish responses, or irregular cycles must be escalated to maintenance within 2 hours. A daily huddle will review equipment status. Maintenance Supervisor will conduct weekly reviews of recurring issues to identify equipment requiring replacement or upgrade.

name: Implement Mandatory Equipment Checkout and Test Protocol
description: Create a standardized post-maintenance equipment release procedure requiring tool makers and maintenance personnel to conduct comprehensive safety system tests before returning equipment to production. All pressure relief systems, interlocks, sensors, and emergency stops must be independently verified and documented. Operations supervisor must sign off on test results before equipment returns to service. This procedure will be posted at all equipment stations and integrated into the maintenance tracking system. Quarterly audits will verify compliance.

name: Upgrade PPE Requirements for Pressure System Operations
description: Require operators working with pressurized resin systems to wear full face shields, fire-resistant sleeves, and heat-resistant gloves certified to handle 200°C contact. Inspect and replace PPE annually. Conduct mandatory training on proper donning/doffing procedures and inspection for damage before each shift. Store PPE at convenient access points near all heated tank stations to encourage consistent use.

name: Implement Color-Coded and RFID-Tagged Container System
description: Replace all hazardous waste collection and storage drums with color-coded, clearly labeled containers marked with RFID tags indicating contents, volume status, and last inspection date. Implement an electronic inventory system that tracks container fill levels and prevents overfilling. Operators must scan containers before transfer operations using handheld readers that verify container contents match the material being transferred. System will display warnings if incompatible materials are being combined.

name: Establish Mandatory Pre-Transfer Container Verification Protocol
description: Create a written checklist procedure requiring material handlers to visually inspect and confirm receiving container status (empty/fill level) before beginning any liquid transfer. Supervisor sign-off or electronic verification is mandatory. All operators, including evening and night shift staff, must complete hands-on training with competency verification. Monthly compliance audits will track adherence. This administrative control prevents overfill scenarios.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Evening Shift Hazardous Materials Training
description: Develop and deliver specialized training for all evening and night shift material handlers on hazardous chemical properties, transfer procedures, spill response, and emergency protocols. Include specific focus on isopropyl alcohol characteristics and flammability risks. Training will include demonstration with simulated transfer operations and written competency assessment. Refresher training will occur quarterly. Ensure evening shift staff have equivalent knowledge to day shift personnel.

name: Implement Daily Floor Inspection and Drying Protocol
description: Establish a daily inspection checklist for the Materials Management area to identify and immediately dry wet spots created by cleaning operations. Designate specific times for floor cleaning to avoid overlap with material handling operations. Install absorbent floor mats in high-traffic areas and provide staff with microfiber mops for rapid drying. Train all material handlers on pre-operation inspection procedures to identify slip hazards before moving equipment. Post wet floor signs immediately after cleaning and maintain a 30-minute buffer between cleaning and forklift operations.

name: Upgrade Storage Rack Load Capacity Assessment
description: Conduct a comprehensive engineering review of all storage racks in the Materials Management area to verify load ratings and structural integrity. Replace any racks showing signs of metal fatigue or inadequate design for the current material storage loads. Implement a color-coded system on all racks indicating maximum weight capacity and prohibited stacking heights. Install secondary safety restraints (e.g., cable mesh) on upper shelves to prevent cascading failures if a lower level is impacted. Schedule quarterly inspections by a qualified structural engineer.

name: Enhanced Forklift Operator Stability Training
description: Mandate refresher training for all propane forklift operators focusing on stability, load distribution, and emergency maneuvers. Include practical exercises on wet surface handling, tire traction assessment, and proper braking techniques. Implement a certification program requiring operators to demonstrate competency quarterly. Introduce telemetry systems on forklifts to monitor speed and tilt angle, with alerts when operating parameters approach unsafe levels. Require operators to reduce speed by 50% in areas with known wet floor hazards.

name: Establish Preventive Ventilation Maintenance Schedule
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all ventilation systems in chemical handling areas. Schedule monthly inspections to measure airflow rates and identify particulate accumulation. Require quarterly professional ductwork cleaning and biannual filter replacements on all intake systems. Document all inspections in a maintenance log and establish alert thresholds that trigger immediate corrective action when airflow drops below 80% of design specifications. Assign responsibility to a dedicated maintenance technician with quarterly competency assessments.

name: Install Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring System
description: Deploy continuous VOC monitoring sensors in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room with digital displays and automated alerts when concentrations exceed 75 ppm. Integrate the system with the facility's fire alarm network to trigger enhanced ventilation fan activation if thresholds are breached. Provide operators with wearable personal exposure monitors that alert when individual exposure levels approach limits. Establish a protocol requiring immediate work stoppage and area evacuation if readings exceed 100 ppm, with mandatory incident reporting to HSE leadership.

name: Mandatory Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Protocol Enforcement
description: Implement a zero-tolerance LOTO policy requiring that all CNC equipment be de-energized, locked, and tagged before any maintenance or setup operations. Install mechanical lockout hasps on all machine power supplies with multiple anchor points to prevent unauthorized restart. Conduct mandatory LOTO retraining for all maintenance personnel and machine setters within 5 days, with certification testing. Establish a non-negotiable 15-minute minimum buffer before production deadlines to allow proper LOTO procedures without time pressure. Audit compliance weekly through random inspections and include LOTO adherence in employee performance evaluations.

name: Proximity Sensor Replacement and Predictive Maintenance Program
description: Replace the faulty proximity sensor on the CNC machine with a redundant dual-sensor system that requires both sensors to confirm a valid signal before servo motor activation. Implement a predictive maintenance program using vibration analysis and sensor diagnostics to identify failing components before they cause incidents. Establish a centralized maintenance alert system that automatically flags equipment showing intermittent sensor readings. Schedule quarterly inspections of all proximity sensors across the facility, and require immediate replacement if any anomalies are detected. Document all sensor replacements and anomalies in a database accessible to all maintenance personnel.

name: Production Planning Communication Protocol Revision
description: Establish a formal communication protocol between Production Engineering and Maintenance departments requiring that all setup deadlines be submitted 24 hours in advance with built-in safety buffers. Implement a shared digital calendar showing equipment availability and maintenance windows to prevent last-minute scheduling conflicts. Require that production planners consult with maintenance supervisors before assigning machine-specific deadlines. Conduct quarterly cross-departmental meetings to review scheduling efficiency and identify recurring time pressure issues. Train production planning staff on OSHA regulations and TechnoPlast's safety policies regarding maintenance timelines.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Cooling Systems
description: Establish a quarterly inspection protocol for all cooling water system couplings and joints across both molding lines. Install pressure sensors and temperature monitors with automated alerts set to trigger at pre-failure thresholds. Replace all couplings older than 5 years with corrosion-resistant stainless steel alternatives. Create a digital maintenance log accessible to all maintenance staff tracking inspection dates, findings, and replacement parts. Train Andrei Popov and other maintenance technicians on early warning signs of cooling system degradation.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Water Drainage System
description: Design and install a containment tray beneath the cooling water circuit sections of both Injection Molding Lines A and B to capture any future leaks and prevent water from reaching electrical systems or creating slip hazards. Include integrated drainage that routes water to the facility's wastewater treatment system. Install additional non-slip surface coating in high-risk areas around the molding lines.

name: Update Equipment Failure Response Procedures
description: Revise the emergency response documentation to include specific protocols for cooling system failures, including immediate electrical hazard assessment, leak containment procedures, and communication sequences. Conduct a mandatory 2-hour training session for all production operators and maintenance staff covering these procedures, to be completed within 60 days. Include hands-on practice with the emergency stop procedures and manual valve isolation techniques.

name: Establish Material Handling Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Create a weekly inspection checklist for all material handling scoops, trowels, and transfer tools used in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Inspect for sharp edges, burrs, cracks, or corrosion. Any tool showing damage will be immediately removed from service and replaced or repaired by maintenance staff. Assign responsibility to the Receiving Clerk to conduct these inspections every Monday morning. Document all inspections in a logbook maintained in UNIT-016.

name: Issue Cut-Resistant Gloves for Material Handling Operations
description: Procure ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant gloves in multiple sizes for all personnel working in material handling and preparation areas. Stock gloves at both material preparation stations and in the first aid area. Mandate glove use during all material transfer operations. Conduct a 30-minute training session for all affected staff on proper glove selection, fitting, and care to ensure consistent PPE compliance.

name: Mandatory Safety Eyewear Requirements for Composite Material Inspection
description: Update all standard operating procedures for quality inspection work to mandate ANSI Z87.1 rated safety glasses with polycarbonate lenses for all personnel handling or inspecting composite materials and finished parts. Establish designated eyewear stations at each inspection point in the Central Maintenance Workshop and Material Drying areas. Conduct immediate training for all quality control staff on the hazards associated with the new reinforcement fiber formulation and the importance of consistent PPE use. Include this requirement in the next quarterly safety briefing for all affected departments.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Protocol
description: Establish a dual-verification lockout/tagout system requiring two authorized personnel to physically confirm energy isolation before any maintenance activity. Install mechanical locks on all injection molding machines with assigned lock boxes per operator. Implement daily pre-shift LOTO audits with documented sign-offs. All maintenance personnel must complete recertification training within 30 days, with quarterly refresher training thereafter. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the root cause of this incident—inadequate LOTO enforcement—and aligns with CNESST regulations for energy-isolating devices.

name: Install Emergency Stop Buttons on All Production Lines
description: Retrofit all 12 injection molding lines in the production facility with easily accessible emergency stop (E-stop) buttons positioned at multiple points around each machine. Ensure buttons are bright red, clearly labeled, and located within arm's reach of typical work positions. Conduct safety training for all production staff on proper E-stop activation. This engineering control provides an additional safeguard to prevent equipment from continuing operation during unexpected situations, reducing injury severity when incidents occur.

name: Enhance Machine Guarding on Mold Interfaces
description: Install interlocked safety guards on all injection molding machines that physically prevent mold access when clamps are pressurized. Guards must be designed to prevent hand insertion into the hazard zone. Conduct a full machine hazard assessment by an external certified safety engineer to identify and eliminate pinch points. Implement quarterly guard inspections to ensure mechanical functionality. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at its source by making physical contact with the danger zone impossible during normal machine operation.

name: Reinstate Mandatory Safety Guard Inspections
description: Implement a comprehensive tracking system for all machine safety guards requiring documented re-installation verification after any removal. Create a log sheet for each CNC machine noting guard removal date, reason, and reinstatement date with supervisor sign-off. Conduct monthly audits to verify guard integrity. Establish a policy prohibiting equipment operation without all original safety guards in place. Non-compliance results in immediate work stoppage and equipment lockout. This administrative control ensures safety devices remain functional and prevents unauthorized removal.

name: Enforce PPE Compliance Program with Progressive Discipline
description: Implement a three-tier PPE enforcement system: (1) First violation results in mandatory retraining and documentation; (2) Second violation results in written warning; (3) Third violation results in suspension from that duty. Conduct weekly visual audits of workshop personnel. Provide alternative cut-resistant glove options to accommodate worker preferences while maintaining protection standards. Conduct a survey to identify which glove styles maximize compliance. Make PPE compliance part of performance evaluations. This administrative control addresses non-compliance behavior while maintaining protective standards.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Scheduling System
description: Implement a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) with automated work order generation for all equipment requiring preventive maintenance. All maintenance activities must be scheduled outside normal warehouse operating hours or cordoned off with engineering controls. Establish a 72-hour advance notice requirement for any maintenance activity in operational areas. Create a weekly maintenance schedule review meeting to identify potential conflicts with production and warehouse operations. This administrative control ensures maintenance activities are properly coordinated and don't create hazardous conditions for warehouse personnel.

name: Install Spill Containment Trays and Secondary Containment
description: Install drip pans beneath all forklifts and equipment undergoing maintenance in the warehouse area. Implement secondary containment trays with absorbent material capacity rated for 110% of the largest potential hydraulic fluid volume. Place warning signs and caution tape around any active maintenance areas. Establish an immediate cleanup protocol requiring spill absorbent materials and a designated cleanup crew response within 15 minutes of spill detection. Train all warehouse staff on spill reporting procedures. This engineering control prevents hazardous fluid from spreading across warehouse floors.

name: Emergency Ventilation Duct Cleaning and Deep Cleaning
description: Professional cleaning service contracted to perform immediate deep cleaning of all ventilation ducts, exhaust systems, and overhead surfaces in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Cleaning will include removal of all dust accumulation, coating surfaces with anti-static treatment where appropriate, and documentation of completion. Post-cleaning inspection will verify compliance with fire safety standards. This engineering control eliminates the primary fire hazard.

name: Establish Monthly Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Dust Control
description: Implementation of a monthly preventive maintenance schedule specifically for dust accumulation monitoring and cleaning in high-risk areas. Maintenance personnel will inspect ventilation systems, ductwork, and accumulation points using a standardized checklist. Monthly cleaning will be performed with documentation maintained in the facility management system. This administrative control prevents future accumulation of combustible dust.

name: Update and Distribute Fire Safety Procedures
description: Review and update facility fire safety procedures with specific attention to combustible dust hazards in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. All staff will receive updated procedures during the next mandatory safety meeting. Signage will be posted near the drying room entrance identifying fire hazard precautions. The HSE team will conduct quarterly audits to ensure compliance with the updated procedures.

name: Install Safety Barriers and Load-Limiting Devices on Storage Racks
description: Engineering modification of all elevated storage racks in the Raw Materials Warehouse to include: (1) physical safety barriers or guard rails to prevent materials from cascading, (2) load-limiting devices with weight sensors to alert when racks are overloaded, and (3) anti-slip matting on all shelf surfaces. Racks will be inspected and, if necessary, reinforced or replaced to meet current load specifications. This engineering control directly addresses the falling materials hazard.

name: Implement Material Storage Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish and document a weekly inspection protocol for all storage racks, including visual checks for proper load distribution, structural integrity, and compliance with weight ratings. Maintenance technicians will photograph and document any issues. A no-retrieval zone (1.5 meters minimum) will be marked beneath all elevated storage areas. Staff will be trained to report any observed hazards immediately. This administrative control includes enhanced supervision and hazard reporting.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Handover Verification Protocol
description: Establish a formalized shift handover checklist requiring both outgoing and incoming operators to jointly verify all LOTO locks and tags are properly placed before any equipment operation resumes. Create a sign-off sheet that documents the time, employee names, and equipment status. This will be posted at each injection molding line and enforced through daily supervision audits. Training will be provided to all production staff within 7 days of implementation.

name: Upgrade Feed Throat Guard Design on Line C
description: Install an enhanced mechanical guard with pressure-sensitive interlocks on the injection molding feed throat that prevents machine operation if hands are detected in the danger zone. This engineering control will provide redundant protection beyond LOTO procedures. The guard will be designed to allow normal material loading while preventing access to the rotating screw mechanism. Installation and testing is scheduled for the next maintenance window with certification required.

name: Establish Pump Replacement Schedule with Accountability Framework
description: Implement a mandatory equipment replacement schedule based on manufacturer specifications and predictive maintenance data. Pumps at or exceeding 80% of service life must be scheduled for replacement within 60 days, with written approvals required from operations management and finance. A tracking dashboard will be created to monitor all critical pumps across the facility. Maintenance Planner will provide quarterly reports to the HSE committee showing compliance status and any deferred replacements with documented justification.

name: Install Automated Cooling System Monitoring with Alert System
description: Deploy a continuous pressure and flow monitoring system on all cooling water circuits with real-time alerts to the SCADA system and operator stations. The system will trigger automatic equipment shutdown if coolant pressure drops below 45 PSI for more than 30 seconds, preventing thermal damage. This engineering control provides redundant protection against cooling system failures and human error in manual monitoring. Installation will be completed within 45 days with full testing and operator training.
