name: Implement Quarterly Overhead Crane Preventive Maintenance and Lubrication Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule requiring quarterly inspections and lubrication of all overhead crane components including load pins, spreader bars, hoist mechanisms, and wire ropes. A certified crane technician will perform detailed visual and functional inspections per CSA B167 standards. Maintenance logs will be posted on each crane with next service date clearly visible. All maintenance will be completed before the next certification cycle, with documentation provided to the HSE committee.

name: Replace Load Pin Assembly with High-Performance Corrosion-Resistant Components
description: Upgrade all crane load pins and spreader bar hardware to stainless steel or coated alloy specifications designed for warehouse humidity and chemical exposure environments. The new design includes secondary mechanical locking features that provide redundancy if primary pins disengage. All personnel involved in material handling will receive training on the new load verification procedures. Installation will be completed during the next scheduled crane downtime.

name: Implement Preventive Hydraulic System Maintenance Program
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all hydraulic systems that includes quarterly inspection and replacement of ferrule connectors on all high-pressure connections. Develop detailed maintenance checklists aligned with manufacturer specifications, integrate into CMMS system with automatic work order generation, and provide specialized training to all maintenance personnel on hydraulic system safety and inspection procedures. This addresses the root cause of connector corrosion and establishes proactive replacement before failure occurs.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Hydraulic Equipment
description: Design and install secondary containment trays beneath all injection molding machines and their associated hydraulic systems to capture potential leaks or spills. Containment capacity must be minimum 110% of largest connected reservoir volume. Include drain valves, absorbent material storage, and clear labeling. Implement weekly inspection checklist and spill response procedures. This engineering control prevents contamination of raw materials and reduces environmental impact while providing additional worker protection.

name: Upgrade Temperature Control Equipment with Automatic Safety Shutoffs
description: Replace all manual hot plates and temperature-controlled heating equipment in chemical mixing areas with modern units featuring automatic temperature limiting, overheat shutoffs at 200°C maximum, and digital readout displays. Ensure all equipment meets NFPA standards and is rated for the specific chemistry in use. Implement monthly calibration verification using external thermometers. This engineering control eliminates the ability to exceed safe temperature limits regardless of operator error or equipment failure.

name: Establish Equipment Change Control and Documentation System
description: Implement a mandatory equipment change control process requiring that any equipment repair, replacement, or modification be documented in a centralized equipment registry with photos, dates, technician signatures, and functional specifications. Create laminated equipment ID cards attached to each device listing current configuration and safety parameters. Conduct quarterly audits comparing registry records to actual equipment. Train all maintenance personnel and supervisors on the new system with emphasis on preventing unauthorized modifications.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Chemical Drums in Storage
description: Install containment pallets with integrated drain plugs and capacity of 150% of largest drum volume (approximately 85 gallons) in all chemical storage areas. Clearly mark containment zones with yellow lines and signage. Mandate that all chemical drums 5 gallons or larger must be stored within containment. Implement daily visual inspection checklist by shift supervisors. This engineering control prevents spills from reaching floor drains and stormwater systems while maintaining regulatory compliance.

name: Revise Material Handler Training Program with Drum Securing Procedures
description: Develop comprehensive training module specifically addressing proper drum handling, secure bunging procedures, and verification protocols before transport. Require all material handlers to complete hands-on practical assessment demonstrating correct drum securement including checking bung tightness with calibrated torque wrench (25-30 ft-lbs for standard bungs). Implement monthly refresher training and document completion. Emphasize that all drums must be verified secure before cart movement and that verification is a non-delegable responsibility.

name: Upgrade Stormwater System with Isolation Capability
description: Install manual isolation valves and quick-closing caps on all floor drains in chemical storage and manufacturing areas, allowing immediate containment of spills. Implement a color-coded drain cap system: blue caps for isolated drains, clear caps for connected stormwater. Conduct quarterly inspections to verify valve functionality. Provide immediate access to drain isolation valve location maps in all work areas and include drain isolation as first step in spill response procedure. This prevents environmental release and demonstrates environmental responsibility.

name: Enhanced Mold Insert Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a daily visual inspection checklist for all mold inserts focusing on burr detection and sharp edge identification. Maintenance staff will use tactile inspection gloves and magnification tools to identify micro-defects. Any burrs will be immediately dressed with fine-grit emery cloth or replaced if damage is extensive. Supervisors will sign off on inspection logs daily. This engineering and administrative control will reduce repeat incidents by catching hazards before they cause injury.

name: Upgraded Cut-Resistant Gloves for Mold Handling
description: Replace standard nitrile gloves with ANSI A3-rated cut-resistant gloves for all personnel handling mold inserts and finished parts. The new gloves feature reinforced knit construction with polyurethane coating, providing superior protection against sharp edges while maintaining dexterity for precision tasks. Gloves will be available in multiple sizes and restocked weekly. Training will ensure proper fitting and correct use.

name: Automated Hopper Maintenance Scheduling System
description: Install a digital maintenance management system with automated alerts for hopper discharge valve lubrication and inspection. The system will trigger notifications at 25-day intervals to maintenance staff via email and dashboard alerts. A physical inspection tag with the last service date will be affixed to each hopper. Maintenance logs will be tracked in the system with supervisor sign-off required. This administrative control ensures preventive maintenance is never missed and reduces mechanical failures.

name: Local Exhaust Ventilation Installation at Hopper Discharge
description: Install a flexible capture hood with local exhaust ventilation directly above the hopper discharge point, ducting material dust to the facility's central filtration system. The hood will feature adjustable positioning to accommodate different container heights. Ventilation will be interlocked so the discharge valve cannot be manually opened unless the exhaust system is operating. This engineering control eliminates airborne dust exposure at the source and prevents inhalation hazards.

name: Automated Dust Collection and Enclosure Sealing for CNC Equipment
description: Install sealed enclosures around all CNC milling machines with automated dust collection systems that activate whenever the machine is running. Enclosures will be equipped with HEPA filtration and automated dampers that prevent dust accumulation in blind cavities. Weekly vacuum collection of residual dust will be mandatory with documented checklists. This engineering control eliminates the primary fuel source for fire and prevents dust accumulation hazards.

name: Bearing Test Procedure Revision and Pre-Operation Clearance Protocol
description: Revise all bearing wear test procedures to include mandatory pre-operation enclosure inspection and dust removal steps. Add a 'clearance verification form' that must be completed and signed by two personnel before any bearing test is initiated. The form will confirm that the machine interior has been cleaned, dust collection systems are operational, and no combustible material is present. Create laminated reference cards posted at each CNC machine. This administrative control prevents future ignition events by ensuring safe conditions before testing begins.

name: Night Shift Supervision Enhancement and Dust Protocol Audits
description: Assign an additional maintenance supervisor to the night shift (11 PM to 7:30 AM) with explicit responsibility for enforcing dust collection and housekeeping protocols. Implement hourly spot-check audits of equipment enclosures and waste management areas. Supervisors will document findings in a digital log with photographic evidence. Monthly compliance reports will be reviewed by the plant manager. This administrative control ensures protocols are enforced consistently regardless of shift, reducing human error and negligence.

name: Implement Mandatory Bypass Flag System
description: Install a bright red flag and logbook system at all injection molding lines requiring maintenance technicians to physically log and sign all safety overrides. Overrides must be documented with time, reason, and when cleared. A supervisor must verify clearance before resuming normal operations. Electronic notification to shift supervisors will alert them to active bypasses. Training on the system will be mandatory for all maintenance and operations staff within 5 days.

name: Upgrade Mold Safety Interlocks to Dual-Channel Design
description: Replace single-channel safety interlocks on Lines B and D with redundant dual-channel systems that cannot be bypassed during operation. Install mechanical position sensors that physically prevent mold closure unless the interlock is actively engaged. Conduct full validation testing on each line. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of bypass-related injuries through design rather than procedure.

name: Mandatory Hand Safety Training and Equipment
description: Provide all injection molding operators with certified hand and finger protection training including proper positioning and recognition of jam conditions. Issue cut-resistant gloves with impact padding to all operators. Conduct quarterly refresher training with emphasis on never removing hands from safe zones during machine operation. Create a visual standard work guide posted at each operator station showing proper hand placement.

name: Install Mechanical Drum Handling Equipment
description: Procure and install 3 drum rotators and 2 pallet jacks equipped with drum handlers in the Materials Management area. These engineering controls eliminate manual lifting of heavy drums by allowing handlers to roll and position drums safely. Provide hands-on training to all material handlers on proper equipment use. This substitution of mechanical assistance for manual lifting directly addresses the root cause and significantly reduces strain injury risk across the entire materials handling operation.

name: Comprehensive Ergonomics and Lifting Training Program
description: Develop and deliver mandatory 2-hour ergonomics training covering proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, load assessment, and risk recognition. All material handlers and assembly operators must complete training within 10 days, with annual refresher required. Include practical demonstrations using actual materials. Create laminated ergonomic posters for all high-risk areas. This administrative control establishes proper work practices and ensures all personnel understand safe lifting principles before handling heavy materials.

name: Install Vibration Isolation Mounts on Laboratory Equipment
description: Install elastomeric vibration isolation mounts on all heavy testing equipment and machinery in UNIT-006 and adjacent areas. Conduct a vibration baseline assessment to determine proper isolation specifications. This engineering control eliminates vibration transmission that triggered the accidental discharge. Equipment will be relocated according to manufacturer specifications maintaining minimum 12-inch clearance from all fire suppression sensor heads.

name: Implement Fire Suppression System Equipment Exclusion Zone
description: Mark all fire suppression heads and piping with high-visibility red zones on floor and walls extending 3 feet in all directions. Install protective cages around sensor heads in high-vibration areas. Create administrative procedure requiring equipment repositioning requests to be reviewed by safety department before execution. All equipment moves must be approved and supervised to maintain clearances from fire suppression infrastructure.

name: Fire Suppression System Annual Inspection and Maintenance
description: Establish formal quarterly inspection program for all fire suppression systems with documentation of sensitivity settings, pressure readings, and sensor conditions. Contract with certified fire suppression service provider to perform comprehensive annual testing and recalibration of all pre-action heads. Maintain detailed maintenance log accessible to all facility personnel and emergency responders. This administrative control ensures the fire suppression system remains properly calibrated and functioning as intended.

name: Install Redundant Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Replace existing single-point temperature monitoring system with dual redundant digital thermometers on all injection molding lines. Implement automatic alarm system that triggers at 270°C and physically stops mold operation at 285°C. This engineering control eliminates reliance on visual warning lights and prevents operator contact with dangerously hot surfaces through automated safety interlocks.

name: Issue Heat-Resistant PPE to All Molding Operators
description: Procure and distribute Kevlar heat-resistant sleeves, silicone-coated gloves rated to 300°C, and full-arm protection gear to all 45 operators working on injection molding lines. Provide training on proper donning and use. Establish monthly replacement schedule for worn PPE. While PPE is a lower-hierarchy control, it provides essential interim protection during mold maintenance operations.

name: Implement Daily Mold Temperature Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Create mandatory daily checklist requiring operators to verify both primary and backup temperature monitoring systems are functioning before shift start. Document all maintenance on temperature monitoring equipment. Any malfunctioning equipment must be reported immediately and mold must not operate until repaired. This administrative control ensures early detection of equipment failures.

name: Implement Monthly Ventilation System Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish mandatory preventive maintenance program for all facility ventilation systems with inspections and filter changes every 30 days, documented in maintenance log. Install visual filter condition indicators on intake vents. Assign responsibility to Facilities Technician with supervisor sign-off required. Designate backup technician for coverage continuity. This engineering control ensures proper air quality and chemical vapor removal during all composite material operations.

name: Mandate Closed-Container Storage for All Solvents and Establish Locked Container Protocol
description: Issue regulations requiring all acetone, isopropanol, and other volatile organic solvents be stored in sealed, labeled containers with caps fastened immediately after each use. Install three sealable solvent storage cabinets in the shop with secondary containment. Implement electronic access logging to track solvent usage. Remove all open containers from work areas. Conduct monthly audits. This eliminates a primary vapor emission source.

name: Update WHMIS and Respiratory Protection Training for All Composite Material Workers
description: Conduct mandatory recertification training for all 18 personnel working with composite materials and solvents, covering chemical hazard identification, proper respiratory protection selection, and emergency response procedures. Provide competency assessment and documentation. Require annual refresher training. Issue properly fitted respirators (P100 or combination cartridge) rated for organic vapors and particulates.

name: Implement Automated Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install real-time thermal sensors and a computerized alert system on all 32 injection molding machines to continuously monitor mold temperatures. The system will prevent mold removal until surface temperatures drop below safe contact levels (40°C). Operators will receive visual and audible alerts on their workstations when molds are safe to handle. This engineering control eliminates the reliance on manual monitoring and removes the primary hazard by ensuring equipment cannot be accessed while still dangerously hot. Expected outcome: 100% elimination of heat-related contact burns from premature mold removal.

name: Enhance Operator Training on Thermal Hazards
description: Develop and deliver a comprehensive training module specifically addressing thermal burn prevention in injection molding operations. Training will include recognition of mold temperature zones, proper use of infrared thermometers for manual verification, correct PPE selection (heat-resistant gloves), and emergency response procedures. All current operators and new hires will complete this training annually with hands-on practical exercises. This administrative control ensures operators understand the thermal hazard landscape and can make informed decisions about equipment access timing.

name: Provide High-Temperature Resistant Work Gloves
description: Issue all Injection Molding Operators with certified heat-resistant gloves rated for sustained contact up to 120°C for a duration of 3-5 seconds. These gloves will feature aramid fiber construction with silicone grip coating. Gloves will be replaced every 6 months or when damaged. While PPE is a lower-tier control, these gloves provide critical protection as a secondary measure until all engineering controls are fully operational. Each operator will receive 2 pairs and training on proper use and inspection.

name: Implement Plastic Pallet Replacement Program
description: Replace all wooden pallets in the Warehouse and Shipping area with high-density polyethylene (HDPE) plastic pallets within 60 days. Plastic pallets eliminate splinter hazards entirely, are easier to sanitize for medical device components, and have superior durability for repeated use. This substitution control removes the primary hazard at its source. Remaining wooden pallets will be retained only for external supplier deliveries and marked with hazard warnings. Estimated replacement: 120 pallets across the facility.

name: Establish Wooden Pallet Maintenance Schedule
description: Until plastic pallet replacement is complete, implement a preventive maintenance program for all wooden pallets. Establish a weekly inspection and surface sanding schedule to identify and smooth splinter-prone areas. Damaged pallets will be repaired or decommissioned immediately. A maintenance log will be maintained and reviewed by the Warehouse Supervisor. This administrative control extends the useful life of existing pallets while reducing worker exposure to splinter hazards during the transition period.

name: Install Secondary Containment Systems in Chemical Storage
description: Install engineered secondary containment trays beneath all chemical storage shelving units in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. Trays will have a capacity of at least 110% of the largest container volume and feature sloped surfaces for drainage to collection sumps. Materials will include polyethylene construction rated for polyester resin compatibility. All resin containers will be transferred to compliant storage immediately. This engineering control prevents chemical spills from reaching the floor or groundwater by containing any leaks at the source. Installation will be completed within 21 days.

name: Conduct Chemical Storage Compliance Audit Training
description: Develop and deliver a mandatory 2-hour training program for all production supervisors, warehouse staff, and new employees on CNESST chemical storage regulations, secondary containment requirements, container integrity inspection, and proper WHMIS labeling. Training will include practical demonstrations of correct vs. incorrect storage configurations, spill response procedures, and documentation requirements. All supervisors will be trained to conduct self-inspections using a standardized checklist. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand legal requirements and can identify compliance gaps independently.

name: Implement Monthly Chemical Storage Compliance Audits
description: Establish a formal monthly audit program conducted by the Environmental Compliance Specialist using a standardized checklist covering container integrity, lid security, secondary containment functionality, labeling accuracy, inventory records, and staff compliance. Audit results will be documented and reviewed at the monthly JHSC meetings. Non-conformances will trigger immediate corrective actions with documented resolution timelines. This administrative control ensures sustained compliance and provides early detection of emerging hazards.

name: Implement Quarterly Ventilation System Audits
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all ventilation systems in chemical storage and processing areas. Technicians will conduct full system inspections, filter replacements, airflow velocity measurements, and temperature monitoring. Documentation will be maintained in a central maintenance database. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate ventilation that allowed solvent vapor accumulation. Expected outcome: Prevent future temperature buildup and vapor concentration hazards in chemical areas.

name: Install Heat Source Separation Protocol and Storage Redesign
description: Redesign the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility to physically separate all heat sources (work lamps, equipment, electrical fixtures) from flammable chemical storage areas by minimum 5 meters. Install dedicated storage racks with anti-static properties and flame-resistant liners for acetone and other Class B solvents. Implement administrative controls requiring all temporary heat sources to be pre-approved and logged. Label all storage areas with warning signage. Train all personnel on heat source distances before access approval. This engineering control eliminates proximity hazards while administrative controls ensure compliance.

name: Enhanced Fire Safety Training Program
description: Develop and deliver mandatory fire safety retraining to all personnel working in or near chemical storage areas, with emphasis on Class B (flammable liquid) fire response. Training will include: hazard identification for common TechnoPlast solvents, proper extinguisher selection and use (hands-on practice with Class B extinguishers), emergency evacuation procedures specific to chemical storage areas, and first responder protocols. Sessions will be conducted quarterly with documentation maintained for compliance audits. Administrative control addressing knowledge gaps that contributed to the incident.

name: Establish Mandatory Preventive Maintenance Schedule for All Injection Molding Equipment
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all 47 injection molding machines at TechnoPlast, with quarterly hydraulic system servicing aligned with OEM specifications. Create a centralized digital maintenance tracking system with automatic alerts for service due dates. Hydraulic fluid analysis will be conducted every 6 months to monitor fluid degradation. All maintenance work will be documented with completion sign-offs. This engineering control addresses the root cause (overdue maintenance and seal deterioration) by ensuring equipment operates within safe parameters. Expected outcome: Elimination of preventable hydraulic system failures and associated fire risks.

name: Install Continuous Hydraulic Temperature and Pressure Monitoring System
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with real-time hydraulic system monitoring sensors that track pressure, temperature, and flow rates. System will trigger automatic machine shutdown if parameters exceed safe operating limits (pressure >250 bar, fluid temperature >60°C). Integration with facility SCADA system will enable remote monitoring from the control room. Technicians will receive alerts 30 minutes before predicted seal failure based on trending data. This engineering control provides early warning and automatic protection against catastrophic failures. Expected outcome: Prevention of uncontrolled pressure release incidents.

name: Upgrade Local Exhaust Ventilation in Post-Processing Area
description: Install high-efficiency local exhaust ventilation (LEV) systems at all grinding and sanding workstations in UNIT-017. Systems will feature HEPA filtration capable of capturing particles as small as 0.3 microns, essential for composite fiber dust containment. Ducting will be designed to prevent air re-circulation into breathing zones. Capture velocity will be optimized for each workstation type. Monthly filter replacement schedules will be mandatory with electronic tracking. This engineering control directly eliminates the source of exposure by containing dust at generation point. Expected outcome: Reduction of airborne fiber concentration below occupational exposure limits.

name: Implement Respiratory Protection Program with Fit Testing
description: Establish a comprehensive respiratory protection program for all employees working with composite materials. Program will include: NIOSH-approved respirators (P100 cartridge minimum) for all composite fiber grinding operations, initial fit-testing for all participants, annual refit testing, cartridge replacement schedule, and storage protocols. Employees will receive training on proper donning/doffing procedures and maintenance. A designated respirator storage cabinet with humidity monitoring will be established. Administrative records will track all fit-testing and training completion. This administrative control combined with appropriate PPE ensures respiratory protection until engineering controls are fully operational.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for All Exhaust Systems
description: Create a facility-wide preventive maintenance protocol for all ventilation and local exhaust systems with monthly inspections, quarterly filter replacement (or sooner if needed), and bi-annual professional HVAC audits. Each workstation will have a visible maintenance checklist posted nearby. Digital tracking system will alert maintenance staff of upcoming service dates. This administrative control prevents future ventilation failures through systematic monitoring. Expected outcome: Continuous operation of exhaust systems at design specifications.

name: Implement Automated Hopper Level Sensor Maintenance Program
description: Establish a bi-weekly preventive maintenance schedule for all material hopper level sensors across production lines. This includes sensor calibration, cleaning of sensor windows to prevent false readings, and functional testing with simulated material loads. Maintenance records will be logged in the CMMS system. All operators will receive training on recognizing sensor malfunction warning signs (inconsistent cutoff behavior, unusual beeping patterns). The corrective action addresses the root cause of sensor failure that led to hopper overflow.

name: Install Secondary Overflow Containment Tray
description: Engineering team will design and install a secondary containment tray beneath hopper discharge points with a capacity of 150% of maximum hopper volume. The tray will route any overflow back into the hopper or into a collection bin, preventing material from spilling onto the production floor. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of material spills reaching critical areas and blocking emergency exits. Installation will include drain plugs for easy emptying and will be integrated with the hopper alarm system.

name: Develop Emergency Exit Protection Protocol
description: Create a facility-wide standard operating procedure requiring that emergency exit routes be kept clear at all times during material handling operations. Implement physical barriers (orange cones and warning tape) positioned 2 meters from all emergency exits. Train all production staff during monthly safety meetings on alternative exit routes and the importance of maintaining clear egress. Post emergency exit maps and ensure backup exits are clearly marked. This administrative control prevents future incident severity escalation if evacuation becomes necessary.

name: Upgrade Safety Eyewear to Impact-Resistant Polycarbonate with Side Shields
description: Replace all standard safety glasses in the quality control and packaging areas with ANSI Z87.1 rated impact-resistant polycarbonate eyewear featuring full side shields and anti-scratch coatings. The enhanced eyewear provides superior protection against flying particles and chips from all angles. All 25 quality control and packaging personnel will be issued new eyewear and trained on proper fitting and maintenance. Old eyewear will be recycled through the company waste program. This engineering control directly addresses the gap in protection that allowed the plastic chip to strike the employee.

name: Establish Quarterly E-Stop Testing and Documentation System
description: Implement a mandatory quarterly testing schedule for all emergency stop buttons on production and heating equipment facility-wide. Testing will include visual inspection for corrosion, mechanical activation testing to verify immediate cutoff, and documentation in the CMMS system with photos. All maintenance technicians will receive training on proper E-stop testing procedures. A centralized calendar reminder system will alert supervisors 5 days before each testing is due. Failure to complete testing will escalate to the Safety Director. This administrative control ensures critical safety devices remain functional and prevents catastrophic equipment failure scenarios.

name: Perform Comprehensive E-Stop Maintenance and Reinforcement
description: Send Industrial Oven #3 to certified service provider for complete E-stop circuit refurbishment, including replacement of corroded components, cleaning of all contacts, and re-calibration of response time. Reinforce all LOTO hasp attachment points by installing vibration-damping washers and welded reinforcement gussets. Perform static testing under load to verify no further shifting occurs. Upon return, conduct full functionality testing including simultaneous activation with all safety interlocks. This engineering control directly addresses the mechanical degradation that threatened LOTO system integrity.

name: Expand LOTO Coordinator Audit Frequency in High-Risk Areas
description: Increase preventive inspections of Post-Processing and Heat Treatment equipment from semi-annual to quarterly intervals. LOTO Coordinator will perform detailed walkthroughs checking for corrosion, mechanical degradation, proper hasp positioning, and emergency control functionality. All findings will be documented with photographs and trended to identify patterns. Equipment found with deficiencies will be immediately flagged for remediation before maintenance access is permitted. This administrative control creates ongoing verification that critical safety systems remain functional and catches degradation before failures occur.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Pressure Relief Inspection
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly inspection schedule for all hydraulic systems across production lines, focusing on pressure relief valve functionality, hose integrity, and connection security. This administrative control will be integrated into the preventive maintenance program with documented inspection logs. Each inspection will be performed by François-Xavier Mailhot's maintenance team using a standardized checklist. Implementation includes training all maintenance staff on pressure relief testing procedures and hazard identification for hydraulic systems. This measure directly addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance scheduling.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Drain System for Hydraulic Equipment
description: Engineer and install secondary containment trays beneath all high-pressure hydraulic components on Injection Molding Line B, with integrated drain systems that safely channel fluid to a collection tank. This engineering control will prevent hydraulic fluid from spreading across the production floor and contaminating electrical systems. Additionally, install absorbent spill kits at strategic locations with clearly labeled signage and provide staff training on spill response procedures. This addresses both the immediate property damage and creates a safer work environment by reducing slip hazards.

name: Replace Hazardous Waste Storage Shelving System with Stainless Steel Units
description: Remove the existing corroded carbon steel shelving system in the Hazardous Waste Management Area and replace it with marine-grade stainless steel units designed specifically for chemical storage environments. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of corrosion-induced structural failure by using materials resistant to chemical exposure and moisture. All shelves will have reinforced brackets, secondary containment trays, and clearly labeled capacity ratings. Installation includes spill containment drains and a system designed to accommodate proper segregation of incompatible chemicals. This directly addresses the root cause of material degradation.

name: Install Permanent Thermal Guards on Packaging Line Sealing Stations
description: Engineer and install permanent perforated metal guards around all heated press plates on the packaging line sealing stations. These guards will allow thermal imaging for quality control while preventing accidental contact with surfaces exceeding 65°C. The guards will be powder-coated for durability and designed for easy cleaning. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of direct contact with heated equipment. Installation includes warning labels and heat-resistant indicators. This measure prioritizes eliminating the hazard rather than relying on procedural compliance alone.

name: Enforce Mandatory Maintenance Access Panel Closure Checklist
description: Implement an administrative control requiring all maintenance personnel to complete a signed checklist confirming closure of all access panels before leaving their workstation. This checklist will be posted at each maintenance location and reviewed daily by the maintenance supervisor. Include a 15-minute pre-shift verification walk-through by the operations supervisor to identify any open panels requiring attention. Additionally, provide refresher training to all maintenance staff on thermal hazard awareness and the critical importance of securing access panels. This addresses the immediate cause of the incident and reinforces safety culture.

name: Install Fixed Machine Guards on Label Applicators
description: Design and install permanent fixed guards around all label applicator nozzles and protruding mechanisms at the Packaging and Labeling Station to prevent hand/arm contact during normal operation. Guards will be fabricated from powder-coated steel mesh with apertures no larger than 6mm to prevent insertion of fingers or objects. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the near-miss by making the hazard physically inaccessible during routine work. Installation will include updated equipment documentation and operator training.

name: Implement Monthly Machine Safety Audits
description: Establish a monthly inspection protocol requiring the Maintenance team to audit all equipment guarding at the Packaging and Labeling Station and other production areas. Inspections will specifically check for inadequate guards, missing covers, and wear on existing protective equipment. Findings will be documented in a tracking system with priority-based corrective action timelines. This administrative control ensures hazards like the one identified in this near-miss are caught before they result in injury.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Program for Motor Equipment
description: Implement a comprehensive predictive maintenance program utilizing bearing temperature monitoring and vibration analysis for all motors in the Regrind and Recycling Department and related production areas. Equipment will be monitored monthly with replacements scheduled when bearing temperatures exceed safe thresholds (typically 75°C for this motor type). This engineering/administrative control directly addresses the root cause of overheating that triggered the fire alarm. Maintenance logs will be centralized and reviewed quarterly by the maintenance lead to identify patterns.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring Sensors with Automatic Shutoff
description: Install thermal sensors on the recycling conveyor motor that automatically trigger equipment shutdown if bearing temperature exceeds 80°C, preventing progression to smoke generation and fire risk. Sensors will include audible alarm notifications to alert operators 5 degrees below the shutoff threshold, providing early warning. This engineering control provides redundant protection against thermal escalation and allows for graceful equipment shutdown rather than alarm activation.

name: Replace Cooling Water Lines with Pressure-Rated Hoses
description: Replace all existing cooling water lines on Injection Molding Line D and similar production lines with high-pressure, high-temperature rated hoses rated for 80°C+ and burst pressures exceeding system operating pressures by 300%. Use crimped connections with certification rather than threaded connections to eliminate failure points. This engineering control directly eliminates the root cause of the line fracture by upgrading to equipment specifically designed to handle the operating conditions without degradation.

name: Implement Weekly Cooling System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a documented weekly inspection routine for all cooling water systems including visual checks for leaks, weeping connections, and line degradation. Inspections will be performed by trained maintenance technicians and recorded in a centralized maintenance log. Any identified issues will be categorized as immediate (shutdown equipment), urgent (repair within 48 hours), or routine (repair within one week) based on severity. This administrative control provides early detection of deteriorating lines before catastrophic failure occurs.

name: Install High-Temperature Warning Labels and Shields
description: Install bright yellow/red warning labels on all exposed cooling water lines indicating 'HOT WATER - CAUTION 65°C+' at 30-centimeter intervals. Additionally, install semi-rigid plastic guards around accessible line segments to create physical separation from operator contact zones during normal work activities. This provides both administrative notification and a barrier control, giving operators visual warning and reducing accidental contact probability.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Enforcement for Cooling System Maintenance
description: Establish a strict lockout/tagout protocol for all hydraulic cooling system work that includes: (1) mandatory electrical and pressure relief isolation before any system access, (2) physical lockout devices installed at all power sources, (3) a sign-off checklist that must be completed by both the operator and a supervisor. Weekly audits will verify compliance during the first month, then monthly thereafter. Operators who bypass LOTO procedures will receive immediate retraining and disciplinary action. This engineering and administrative control combination directly addresses the root cause of pressure system failure and ensures no energized system is accessed without proper safeguards.

name: Replace Deteriorated Pressure Relief Valve on Cooling System
description: The cooling system's pressure relief valve has exceeded its operational lifespan and is no longer functioning within specification. A new industrial-grade pressure relief valve rated for 85°C fluids will be installed immediately by the Central Maintenance Workshop. The old valve will be disposed of properly, and the new valve will be tested under full system pressure to ensure proper operation. A preventive maintenance schedule will be established to replace this component every 18 months. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the pressurized spray incident and prevents future cooling system failures.

name: Replace Emergency Stop Braking System on Regrind Equipment
description: The existing mechanical emergency stop system on the regrind machine has response time delays exceeding safety standards (7-10 seconds vs. required 3-second maximum). A new pneumatic rapid-stop braking system will be installed that achieves full blade cessation within 1.5 seconds of activation. This system includes redundant brake pads and a pressure accumulator to ensure consistent performance. Installation will be completed by an authorized equipment service technician, followed by third-party certification testing. This engineering control eliminates the mechanical jam hazard escalation pathway and meets all CNESST equipment safety requirements.

name: Mandate Safety Glasses and Face Shield Use During Regrind Operations
description: All personnel operating or working within 5 meters of the regrind system must wear ANSI Z87.1 certified safety glasses with polycarbonate lenses and an additional clear polycarbonate face shield. Failure to wear required PPE will result in immediate removal from the work area. Supervisors will conduct daily visual inspections at the start of each shift. Additional PPE kits will be stored at three convenient locations near the regrind station. While PPE is a lower-tier control, it provides essential backup protection when engineering controls fail, and will be implemented immediately to protect other employees until the emergency stop system replacement is complete.

name: Install Automated Temperature Cutoff and Over-Temperature Safety System
description: Replace the existing manual temperature control system on the resin dryer with an industrial-grade PLC (programmable logic controller) system featuring: (1) dual independent temperature sensors with cross-validation logic, (2) automatic power cutoff if any sensor detects temperature exceeding 185°C, (3) audible and visual alarm system activating at 175°C, and (4) fail-safe design that defaults to OFF if sensor malfunction is detected. The system will include lockable manual override that requires supervisor authorization and documented justification. This engineering control eliminates the catastrophic failure mode of uncontrolled temperature escalation. Third-party certification will verify system compliance with CSA B139 industrial thermal equipment standards.

name: Establish Mandatory Annual Thermal Hazard Refresher Training and Competency Certification
description: All personnel working with equipment exceeding 100°C must complete annual thermal hazard awareness training covering: (1) recognition of thermal equipment hazards, (2) proper lockout/tagout procedures, (3) emergency response protocols, and (4) correct use of thermal monitoring equipment. Training will include hands-on demonstrations with thermal imaging cameras to visualize hidden heat hazards. Employees who fail competency assessments will be removed from thermal equipment operations until retraining is completed. Records will be maintained by HSE department and reviewed during safety audits. This administrative control ensures all operators possess current knowledge of thermal risks specific to TechnoPlast's equipment.

name: Issue and Enforce Use of Advanced Thermal-Resistant Protective Equipment for Dryer Operations
description: All personnel working within 2 meters of active resin dryers must wear specialized thermal-resistant PPE including: (1) aluminized proximity suit jacket rated to 300°C, (2) thermal-resistant gloves with 15-second contact tolerance at 200°C, (3) face shield with thermal coating, and (4) high-temperature work boots. Equipment will be inspected weekly and replaced annually or after any thermal incident contact. While PPE is a reactive control, thermal-resistant equipment provides critical backup protection while engineering controls are being implemented. Compliance will be verified during each shift by supervisors using a mandatory check-in system.

name: Replace Faded Thermal Warning Labels on All Molds
description: Replace all worn, faded, or illegible thermal hazard warning labels on injection molding machines with high-visibility, durable labels that clearly indicate mold surface temperatures. Labels will be replaced quarterly during preventive maintenance. This addresses the inadequate hazard communication that contributed to the burn incident. Expected outcome: improved hazard recognition and reduction in thermal burn incidents by 40%.

name: Implement Mandatory Mold Cooling Verification Checklist
description: Develop and implement a standardized pre-removal checklist requiring operators to verify mold temperatures using infrared thermometers before manual part extraction. Operators must document cooling confirmation on a log sheet. Include training on proper thermometer use. This engineering and administrative control ensures molds reach safe handling temperatures. Expected outcome: elimination of thermal contact burns through verification of temperature thresholds below 45°C before handling.

name: Establish Quarterly Crane and Rigging Equipment Inspection Program
description: Implement a comprehensive quarterly inspection program for all overhead cranes, cable systems, brackets, and rigging equipment. Inspections will be conducted by a certified equipment technician with full documentation and photographic evidence. Any corroded, cracked, or deteriorated components will be immediately removed from service. A color-coded tagging system will track inspection dates and next due dates. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of equipment failure through proactive identification and replacement before catastrophic failure.

name: Replace Corroded Support Brackets with Stainless Steel Components
description: Replace all corroded steel brackets and fasteners in the overhead crane system with marine-grade stainless steel equivalents that resist corrosion. This substitution control eliminates the root cause of bracket failure. Additionally, implement protective coatings on remaining steel components and establish a corrosion monitoring protocol. All work will be completed within 10 days by external crane certification specialists.

name: Implement Maintenance Scheduling System with Automated Alerts
description: Implement a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) that tracks all equipment maintenance intervals, generates automatic alerts 2 weeks prior to due dates, and prevents overdue maintenance from being deferred. The system will integrate with the JHSC reporting system and generate monthly compliance reports for management review. Training will be provided to all maintenance staff and supervisors.

name: Install Secondary Containment Systems for All Chemical Drums
description: Install engineered secondary containment trays beneath all chemical storage locations capable of containing 110% of the largest single container volume. Containment trays will be constructed from polypropylene or stainless steel with drain plugs and absorbent material storage. This engineering control prevents chemical spills from reaching drains or facility surfaces. All chemical storage shelves will be relocated to containment areas within 5 days.

name: Upgrade Storage Rack Stability and Seismic Restraint
description: Inspect all chemical storage racks for structural integrity and load capacity. Replace any racks showing signs of instability or corrosion with heavy-duty industrial racks rated for 1000+ pound capacity. Install seismic restraint straps and load limiters to prevent drums from falling during shelf removal operations. Conduct load distribution training for all staff handling chemical storage.

name: Implement Chemical Storage Area Labeling and Access Control
description: Install large, visible signage identifying the chemical storage area with hazard pictograms, emergency contact information, and spill response procedures. Create a restricted access zone with limited entry to trained personnel only. Install a check-in/check-out log system for anyone entering the chemical mixing area. Conduct mandatory quarterly training on chemical handling and spill response for all maintenance personnel.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooling Protocol for Mold Handling
description: Establish a strict 5-minute minimum cooling period after every mold opening cycle before any manual part removal is permitted. Install visual countdown timers on all 32 injection molding machines. Require operators to don heat-resistant gloves rated to 200°C minimum before approaching any mold. Create laminated quick-reference cards at each workstation outlining safe cooling protocols. Train all production staff on the thermodynamic properties of molten plastic and residual heat retention in molds.

name: Upgrade to Auto-Detection Glove Sensors
description: Install proximity sensors on all injection molding machines that prevent mold opening until appropriate heat-resistant gloves are detected on the operator's hands. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of unprotected hand contact with hot molds. Partner with equipment manufacturer to retrofit existing machines with this safety technology.

name: Replace Corroded Resin Drum Couplings
description: Conduct immediate inspection of all 47 polyester resin storage drums currently in inventory. Replace all lug caps and threaded couplings with stainless steel hardware rated for chemical compatibility. Implement a quarterly inspection schedule to monitor for corrosion. Maintain spare coupling kits in the Chemical Storage facility for rapid replacement. This engineering control prevents drum failures that lead to chemical spills.

name: Upgrade Chemical Transfer Protocol and Secondary Containment
description: Install permanent secondary containment trays under all chemical transfer points in the Regrind department, sized to contain 110% of the largest container volume. Mandate the use of spill kits and absorbent materials before any drum transfer. Require all personnel handling chemicals to complete annual hazmat certification. Install additional VOC sensors with real-time monitoring linked to the HVAC system for automatic activation. Implement a chemical transfer checklist system with supervisor sign-off.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Industrial Ovens
description: Deploy thermal imaging cameras and vibration sensors on all four industrial ovens to detect anomalies before failure. Schedule quarterly comprehensive inspections by certified equipment engineers, including heating element support structure assessment. Create digital maintenance logs tracking all service history. Establish preventive replacement schedule for heating elements at 80% of manufacturer-recommended service life. Train all production supervisors on early warning signs of equipment degradation.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Chemical Storage
description: Install secondary containment trays and bermed floor sections in the Hazardous Waste Management Area designed to hold 110% of the largest single container volume. This engineering control eliminates the risk of spills reaching floor drains or spreading across the facility. Containment areas will have sloped bottoms directing liquids to collection sumps, with regular inspections scheduled weekly to ensure integrity and cleanliness.

name: Implement Quarterly Chemical Container Inspection Program
description: Establish a formal quarterly inspection program for all chemical storage containers, with special attention to metal container seams, base integrity, and signs of corrosion. Inspections will be documented using a standardized checklist, with corroded or compromised containers flagged for replacement within 48 hours. Training will be provided to warehouse staff on identifying corrosion indicators, and containers showing damage will be immediately transferred to secondary containment.

name: Install Enhanced Ventilation in Chemical Storage Building
description: Upgrade the ventilation system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building to include dedicated extraction fans with moisture controls, reducing humidity levels that accelerate container corrosion. The system will maintain air exchange rates of at least 6 complete changes per hour and include desiccant-based dehumidification to maintain relative humidity below 60%. Sensors will trigger automatic alerts if humidity rises above threshold levels.

name: Install Mechanical Lifting Assists on Production Line D
description: Procure and install pneumatic lift tables and ergonomic material handling equipment at all component transfer stations on Injection Molding Line D. These assist-devices will reduce manual lifting by approximately 80%, limiting individual lift weight to 5 kg or less. Installation will include operator training on proper use of equipment and safety interlocks. Implementation will be coordinated with Production Engineering to minimize line downtime.

name: Mandatory Ergonomic Training and Work Rotation Schedule
description: Implement mandatory annual ergonomic and manual handling training for all production operators, with emphasis on proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, and load limits. Establish a work rotation schedule rotating operators between different tasks every 2 hours to reduce repetitive strain. Training will be delivered by an external ergonomics specialist and documented in employee training records. Refresher training will occur semi-annually.

name: Implement Chemical Container Integrity Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a daily pre-shift inspection protocol for all chemical storage containers, requiring operators to visually inspect for lid integrity, corrosion, and seal degradation before any handling or transfer. Create a standardized inspection checklist and log system. Containers showing any signs of compromise will be immediately flagged and transferred to quarantine storage. Training will be provided to all shift supervisors and materials handlers, with spot-check audits conducted monthly by HSE personnel.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Environmental Controls
description: Install temperature and humidity monitoring sensors in the Material Drying and Preparation Room to maintain optimal storage conditions (18-25°C, 40-60% humidity) that minimize container corrosion. Upgrade ventilation capacity in the room to provide 12 air changes per hour minimum. Install secondary containment systems under all chemical storage shelving with 110% capacity of stored volumes. These engineering controls will prevent degradation of container integrity and contain any future spills.

name: Enhanced Spill Response Training and Equipment Staging
description: Conduct comprehensive spill response training for all evening and night shift personnel, including proper use of absorbent materials, neutralization agents, and personal protective equipment specific to various chemicals used in the facility. Pre-stage fully equipped spill response kits at four strategic locations throughout the production building. Conduct quarterly spill response drills to ensure rapid response capabilities. Update the spill response SOP to include container integrity checks before transfer operations.

name: Implement Automated Predictive Maintenance Monitoring System
description: Deploy an Internet-of-Things (IoT) based predictive maintenance system on all injection molding machines that continuously monitors cooling system pressure, temperature, and flow rates. System will generate automated alerts when parameters approach critical thresholds or maintenance is due. Integration with existing maintenance scheduling software will ensure no maintenance intervals are skipped. System will provide real-time dashboard visibility to maintenance supervisors and generate monthly predictive analytics reports. This engineering control eliminates human scheduling errors.

name: Establish Redundant Cooling System Backup and Secondary Containment
description: Install secondary coolant collection trays beneath all manifold connection points on machines #7, #8, and #9 with 110% capacity of maximum fluid volume. Install check valves and automatic shutoff mechanisms that activate if pressure exceeds safe limits. For Machine #8 specifically, install a backup cooling loop with auxiliary pump that can maintain minimal coolant circulation if primary system fails, providing 30 minutes of emergency cooling to prevent machine damage.

name: Staffing Adjustment and Maintenance Scheduling Audit
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of maintenance staffing levels and scheduling practices to ensure no maintenance tasks are deferred due to understaffing. Add one full-time maintenance technician to day shift to provide adequate coverage for routine checks and preventive maintenance. Establish a formal procedure requiring supervisor approval and documented exception handling for any skipped maintenance tasks, with escalation to HSE leadership if intervals exceed tolerance.

name: Install Blind Corner Mirrors and Audible Warning Systems
description: Install convex safety mirrors at all blind corners in the warehouse and production transition areas where forklifts and pedestrians interact. Additionally, retrofit all forklifts with audible backup warning systems that activate automatically when the vehicle is in reverse. These engineering controls will eliminate the line-of-sight hazard and provide audio warnings. A third measure includes clear lane markings on floors to separate pedestrian walkways from forklift traffic zones, painted in high-visibility yellow and black.

name: Establish Dedicated Pedestrian and Forklift Traffic Zones
description: Implement a facility-wide traffic management plan that designates specific pathways for forklift operation and separate pedestrian walkways throughout the warehouse and production areas. Mark all zones with high-visibility tape and signage. Conduct mandatory training for all forklift operators and production staff on the new traffic protocol. Supervisors will monitor compliance and enforce the system. This administrative control will physically separate hazardous equipment from employee pedestrian movement.

name: Implement Enhanced Forklift Operator Certification Program
description: Require all current and new forklift operators to complete a refresher certification course that includes advanced situational awareness training, blind spot management, and near-miss reporting procedures. The 8-hour course will be conducted by an external certified trainer and will be mandatory every 24 months. Operators will be tested on knowledge and practical skills. This training program will reinforce safe operating procedures and heighten awareness of pedestrian hazards in shared spaces.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification System with Two-Person Rule
description: Establish a two-person rule for all lockout/tagout operations where a trained LOTO coordinator must independently verify all energy isolation points before any maintenance work begins. Create a standardized verification checklist specific to each machine type that must be signed off by both the technician and the coordinator. Implement physical lockout devices with color-coded tags that cannot be removed without proper authorization. Install mechanical stop-blocks on mold closures as backup fail-safes. This engineering and administrative control will eliminate unauthorized machine startup during maintenance.

name: Install Interlock Safety Systems on All Injection Molding Machines
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with mechanical and electronic interlocks that prevent any mold closure or machine startup when maintenance access doors are open or when LOTO devices are in place. These safety interlocks will provide a physical barrier to unauthorized operation regardless of human oversight. Each interlock system will be integrated with the facility's industrial control system and will log all attempts to bypass or override the safety features. This engineering control addresses the root cause by eliminating the possibility of accidental startup.

name: Conduct Facility-Wide LOTO Competency Assessment and Retraining
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all employees with LOTO responsibilities to assess current knowledge and competency. Identify gaps and provide targeted retraining using CNESST-approved curriculum. Implement annual recertification requirements and create a centralized LOTO competency database. Develop a mentorship program pairing experienced technicians with newer staff. Create visual aids and laminated reference cards posted at each machine location. This administrative control will ensure all personnel understand proper procedures and the critical importance of compliance.

name: Implement Preventive Electrical Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a comprehensive monthly preventive maintenance program specifically for all injection molding machine electrical connections and heating element control panels. This will include visual inspection for corrosion, connection integrity verification, and thermal imaging scans to detect overheating in electrical components. Claude Rioux will lead training sessions for all maintenance personnel on proper connection inspection techniques and corrosion prevention. Documentation will be maintained in a centralized log accessible to the HSE department for trend analysis and risk assessment.

name: Install Temperature Alert and Shutdown Systems
description: Upgrade all injection molding machines on Line B with redundant temperature monitoring systems that automatically alert operators at threshold temperatures and trigger controlled shutdowns if critical temperatures are exceeded. This engineering control eliminates the risk of thermal runaway conditions. The system will integrate with the existing plant alarm system and send alerts to both the production supervisor and maintenance team. Implementation includes sensor calibration and operator training on interpreting new alert signals.

name: Upgrade Hazardous Chemical Storage and Containment
description: Install secondary containment systems for all drums of epoxy resin and similar hazardous liquids in UNIT-015. Each storage location will feature a stainless steel containment tray with capacity of 110% of the largest container stored. Drums will be stored on stable pallets within the containment areas. Quarterly inspections will verify integrity of drums and containment systems. All storage areas will display proper labeling and hazard signage. This engineering control prevents future spills from contaminating the facility floor and surrounding areas.

name: Enhance Ventilation System in Composite Processing Area
description: Conduct an air quality assessment in UNIT-015 and upgrade the ventilation system to handle potential epoxy resin vapors more effectively. Install local exhaust ventilation hoods at chemical preparation and material handling zones. Ensure minimum air changes per hour meet or exceed CNESST requirements for areas with volatile organic compound emissions. Install air quality monitoring sensors to provide real-time feedback on vapor concentration levels. Maintenance staff will perform monthly filter changes and system performance verification to maintain optimal ventilation effectiveness.

name: Implement Chemical Spill Response Training and Drills
description: Develop a comprehensive chemical spill response training program for all personnel working in UNIT-015 and adjacent areas. Training will cover hazard identification, spill containment procedures, personal protective equipment requirements, and emergency notification protocols. Quarterly spill response drills will be conducted to ensure employee competency. Materials Supervisor Valérie Pelletier will coordinate training delivery and maintain records of attendance. This administrative control ensures rapid and effective response to any future spill incidents.

name: Replace Damaged Crane Components and Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Immediately replace all damaged or worn brackets and load hook assemblies on the overhead crane system. Conduct a full inspection of all crane components to identify any other potential sharp edges or wear hazards. Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule that includes detailed inspection of hooks, brackets, and rigging hardware. All components showing signs of wear or damage will be removed from service and replaced immediately. This engineering control eliminates the sharp edge hazard that caused the incident.

name: Mandate Cut-Resistant Gloves for Crane Maintenance Operations
description: Issue ANSI Level 4 cut-resistant gloves to all crane operators and maintenance personnel who perform routine cleaning or inspection of crane components. Establish a policy requiring use of these gloves during all operations involving contact with metal surfaces, rigging components, or load hooks. Include glove inspection and replacement in the routine work preparation checklist. Training will emphasize that cut-resistant gloves must be worn even during seemingly routine cleaning tasks where workers may encounter unexpected sharp edges or burrs.

name: Implement Enhanced LOTO and Temperature Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory lockout/tagout procedure with mandatory temperature verification using infrared thermometers before any mold access. Implement a two-operator confirmation system where a second supervisor must independently verify mold temperature is below 50°C before releasing the lockout. All injection molding operators will receive retraining on this protocol within 5 business days. Install visual temperature indicators on mold cavities. This eliminates the hazard of unexpected thermal exposure by ensuring equipment is definitively safe before access.

name: Provide Enhanced Personal Protective Equipment for Mold Operations
description: Issue specialized heat-resistant gloves (rated to 300°C) and arm sleeves to all injection molding operators. Conduct fitting and training on proper PPE use. Establish a monthly inspection and replacement schedule for damaged protective gear. Position PPE stations at each molding line with clear signage. While engineering controls are primary, this additional PPE layer provides backup protection during transition period.

name: Install Automated Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Implement IoT-based temperature sensors on all 32 injection molding machines that automatically log and display real-time mold temperatures. System will trigger visual and audible alarms if mold temperature exceeds safe access threshold (60°C). Data will be logged for compliance verification. This engineering control eliminates human error in temperature assessment and provides continuous monitoring.

name: Reorganize and Secure Compressed Gas Storage Area
description: Conduct immediate audit of compressed gas storage capacity and implement proper organization system. Install wall-mounted racks with spring-loaded retainers and chain securing systems that meet CSA standards for compressed gas cylinder storage. Ensure all cylinders are upright, secured with dual-point restraints, and separated by gas type. Remove all temporary storage solutions and establish a formal request process for temporary storage needs that requires HSE approval.

name: Implement Chemical Storage Area Inspection and Certification Program
description: Establish weekly inspection checklist for UNIT-010 covering cylinder storage, chemical segregation, PPE availability, and emergency equipment. Designate Normand Bergeron as the inspection lead with monthly verification by HSE team. Document all inspections and maintain records for regulatory compliance. Any non-conformance triggers immediate corrective action. Train all employees accessing this area on proper storage and handling procedures.

name: Install Mechanical Lifting Assists for Composite Materials Handling
description: Procure and install pneumatic lift tables and vacuum-assist lifting systems in UNIT-015 designed specifically for CFRP materials. Position equipment at standard work heights (28-32 inches) to eliminate bending and twisting. Train all material handlers on proper use of mechanical assists, making them mandatory for any load over 15 kg. Establish a culture where using assists is the default practice rather than an exception. This engineering control eliminates the biomechanical stress.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Ergonomics Assessment and Training Program
description: Hire external ergonomics consultant to conduct detailed assessment of all material handling tasks in composite processing areas. Identify high-risk tasks and redesign work processes. Develop task-specific training modules for proper lifting techniques for different material types. Implement refresher training annually and whenever procedures change. Focus on night shift staff given the incident. Provide one-on-one coaching for at-risk employees.

name: Increase Material Handler Staffing on Night Shift
description: Review night shift staffing levels and workload. Current assignment of 4 material handlers for entire facility creates pressure to work quickly and bypass safety procedures. Recommend increasing to minimum 6 handlers, or implementing a job rotation system to prevent fatigue. Ensure adequate supervision and HSE oversight during night hours when fewer managers are present. This administrative control reduces time pressure and fatigue-related errors.

name: Implement Quarterly Storage Rack Inspection Program
description: Establish a formal quarterly inspection schedule for all storage racks throughout the warehouse and shipping area. Inspections will include visual assessment of anchor bolts, welds, frame integrity, and load capacity verification. A certified maintenance technician will document all findings using a standardized inspection checklist. Any corroded, bent, or damaged components will be repaired or replaced immediately. This administrative control ensures early detection of structural degradation before catastrophic failures occur.

name: Replace Corroded Anchor Bolts with Stainless Steel Hardware
description: Replace all existing mild steel anchor bolts on warehouse storage racks with hot-dipped galvanized or stainless steel equivalents that resist corrosion in the warehouse environment. Priority replacement will target the identified problem racks, followed by systematic replacement across all warehouse infrastructure over the next 90 days. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of corrosion-related failures and extends equipment service life significantly.

name: Upgrade Temperature Control Systems with Redundant Safety Features
description: Replace the existing single-point-of-failure temperature control modules on all injection molding lines with dual-channel systems that include independent high-temperature shutdown mechanisms and continuous monitoring. Install temperature sensors at multiple points on each mold with automatic alarm activation if temperatures exceed safe parameters by more than 15°C. This engineering control eliminates the risk of undetected thermal runaway conditions. Implementation across Molding Lines C and D within 21 days, with full facility completion within 60 days.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Sleeve PPE for All Molding Operations
description: Require all production operators on injection molding lines to wear ANSI-certified heat-resistant sleeves (minimum 500°F protection) during all mold handling procedures. Sleeves must be inspected weekly for damage and replaced every 6 months. Operators will receive 15-minute training on proper donning and fit verification. While this is a PPE control (lower in the hierarchy), it provides critical protection during the transition to improved equipment controls.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule with Warning Light Response Protocol
description: Implement a computerized preventive maintenance tracking system requiring that all equipment warning signals and diagnostic alerts trigger immediate work orders with 24-hour maximum response time for non-emergency issues and 4-hour response for high-risk systems like temperature controls. Train supervisors and maintenance leads on the new protocol. This administrative control ensures that warning signs are not deferred and that maintenance is performed proactively.

name: Replace Overhead Crane Hook Assembly with Load-Tested Components
description: Immediately remove and replace all overhead crane hook assemblies throughout the facility with new components that have undergone certified load testing to 200% of rated capacity. All replacement hooks must have permanent identification plates with load ratings, inspection dates, and certification numbers. This engineering control eliminates the immediate risk of hook failure caused by undetected fatigue cracks.

name: Implement Mandatory Annual Crane Inspection Program with Third-Party Certification
description: Establish a contract with an accredited crane inspection service to perform comprehensive annual inspections of all overhead cranes, including non-destructive testing (ultrasonic and magnetic particle inspection) to detect internal fatigue cracks in load-bearing components. Inspection reports will be maintained in a central database with corrective action tracking. Cranes showing defects will be immediately taken out of service until repairs are certified. This engineering and administrative control detects failures before they become critical.

name: Install Safety Zone Barriers and Exclusion Signs Around Crane Operating Areas
description: Install physical barriers (safety railings) and painted floor markings in all areas directly beneath overhead crane paths, with signage indicating active load zones and restricting pedestrian access during crane operations. Install warning lights on the crane that activate whenever loads are being moved. Operators must sound an audible alarm before each load movement. This administrative and engineering control reduces personnel exposure to falling load hazards.

name: Mandatory High-Visibility Vests and Hard Hats in Composite Materials Area
description: Require all personnel in the Composite Materials Processing Area and Chemical Storage zones to wear ANSI-certified hard hats and high-visibility Class 2 vests during all shifts. Implement daily helmet inspections for cracks or damage. This PPE control provides direct protection against head injuries from falling objects. While a lower-level control, it provides essential protection during transition to engineering improvements.

name: Implement Quarterly Electrical Connector Inspection Program
description: Establish a documented preventive maintenance schedule requiring inspection of all electrical connectors on injection molding machines every 90 days. Maintenance technicians will use thermal imaging cameras to identify connectors showing elevated temperatures indicating resistance buildup. Any connectors showing signs of loose connections, corrosion, or thermal stress will be replaced immediately. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the root cause of this incident by detecting failing connectors before they generate sufficient heat to cause fires.

name: Relocate Flammable Materials Storage Away from Electrical Equipment
description: Move plastic resin storage bins at least 6 feet away from all electrical enclosures and control panels in the injection molding area. Install metal protective barriers between electrical equipment and any remaining combustible material storage. This engineering control eliminates the opportunity for small electrical fires to rapidly propagate to flammable materials, reducing potential fire severity.

name: Install Secondary Containment System in Chemical Storage Room
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all acetone-based mold release agent storage containers with capacity equal to 110% of the largest single container. Ensure containment trays are chemically compatible with acetone and have drain plugs directed to an approved hazardous waste collection system. This engineering control prevents spilled volatile chemicals from contacting hot equipment surfaces and eliminates the immediate fire ignition pathway.

name: Physically Separate Hot Equipment from Volatile Chemical Storage
description: Relocate the chemical heating unit to the opposite side of the storage room, ensuring minimum 8-foot separation from all volatile compound storage. Install a fire-rated partition wall between the heating unit and chemical storage areas. This engineering control eliminates the direct hazard pathway by removing the source of ignition from the vicinity of flammable materials.

name: Enhance Chemical Transfer Training and Procedures
description: Develop and implement a mandatory refresher training program for all personnel handling volatile chemicals, focusing on proper spill prevention techniques, correct transfer procedures using funnel systems, and immediate emergency response protocols. Training will be documented and completed by all staff within 30 days. This administrative control ensures personnel understand proper handling procedures to prevent spills at the source.

name: Repair and Upgrade Hazardous Waste Containment Infrastructure
description: Repair all concrete cracks in the secondary containment area using epoxy injection, reseal the containment floor with chemical-resistant polyurethane coating, and replace corroded steel containment walls with new stainless steel barriers. This engineering control restores the structural integrity of containment systems and prevents environmental contamination. Work must be completed within 45 days and verified by independent environmental consultant.

name: Implement Comprehensive Waste Labeling and Tracking System
