Connect monitoring data to building management system to track trends and maintain historical records for regulatory compliance.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System with Redundancy and Maintenance Schedule
description: Replace existing single-stage ventilation with dual-stage system providing redundant capacity. Install heated duct sections to prevent condensation formation during cold weather. Implement weekly maintenance inspections of dampers, filters, and ductwork during winter months. Establish quarterly professional HVAC service with documented airflow verification. Maintain replacement parts inventory for critical components.

name: Establish Chemical Area Exposure Control Program
description: Develop comprehensive administrative controls including work rotation policies to limit individual exposure duration, mandatory respiratory protection requirements when ventilation drops below 80% capacity, and daily briefings on chemical hazards. Conduct baseline and annual health monitoring for employees regularly working with solvents and resins. Train all chemical area workers on early symptoms of solvent exposure including headaches, eye irritation, and dizziness.

name: Replace High-Pressure Resin Supply Lines with Schedule 80 Steel Tubing
description: Engineering control measure to eliminate resin line rupture hazard. All existing polyethylene resin supply lines in the Material Drying and Preparation Room will be replaced with heavy-duty Schedule 80 steel tubing rated for 1200 PSI continuous operation. Installation includes installation of pressure relief valves set at 900 PSI maximum and inline particulate filters to prevent blockages that increase back-pressure. Work will be completed by contracted hydraulic systems specialists with full system pressure testing following installation. This measure directly addresses the root cause of thermal stress failure in the previous line.

name: Implement Monthly Pressure Line Inspection Program
description: Administrative control establishing a formal monthly inspection schedule for all resin supply lines, pressure hoses, and hydraulic connections in the material preparation area. Inspections will document line age, visible damage, pressure test readings, and temperature cycling patterns. Results will be recorded in a centralized log reviewed by the Facilities Manager and HSE Director. Lines showing signs of wear, discoloration, or pressure fluctuation will be flagged for replacement immediately. All operators will receive brief training on early warning signs of line stress during monthly safety toolbox talks.

name: Install Mold Cleaning Station with Controlled Compressed Air System
description: Engineering control to reduce chemical splash hazard during mold cleaning operations. A dedicated mold cleaning station will be installed adjacent to Line A equipped with a pressurized spray chamber equipped with manual controls and pressure regulation limiting compressed air delivery to maximum 40 PSI. The chamber will include side shields and a clear acrylic front panel to contain splatter and aerosol generation. All epoxy residue removal work must be performed within this contained environment rather than at the press itself. Installation and safety training on proper operation will be completed by the Maintenance and Engineering department within 30 days.

name: Replace All Overhead Crane Safety Cables with Non-Corrosive Stainless Steel Wire Rope
description: Immediate elimination control measure addressing the root cause of cable failure. All four overhead crane systems throughout the facility will have their existing galvanized steel safety cables replaced with marine-grade 316 stainless steel wire rope of equivalent load rating. Stainless steel resists corrosion and fatigue failure significantly better than galvanized steel in the humid, chemical-rich production environment. Replacement will be performed by certified crane service technicians with full load testing and documentation. A spare set of cables will be maintained on-site for rapid replacement if needed.

name: Implement Quarterly Crane Cable Inspection and Pressure Testing Program
description: Administrative control establishing mandatory quarterly inspections of all overhead crane safety cables by certified third-party inspectors. Each cable will be visually examined for corrosion, fraying, and micro-fractures, and pressure tested to 125% of rated load. Inspection reports will be maintained in a centralized database accessible to the HSE director and production schedulers. Any cable showing signs of degradation will immediately be taken out of service and replaced before resumption of operations. All crane operators will complete annual recertification training emphasizing load assessment and hazard recognition.

name: Establish No-Stand-Under-Load Policy with Enforcement Signage and Training
description: Administrative and engineering control establishing absolute prohibition on personnel standing or working directly beneath suspended loads. Large warning signs will be installed at all four overhead crane locations showing the international no-standing symbol with French and English text. All operators will receive mandatory retraining emphasizing the hazard and alternatives such as using remote load verification cameras. Supervisors will conduct spot audits during production shifts to verify compliance. Non-compliance will result in immediate operator recertification requirement.

name: Implement Mandatory Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install digital temperature indicators on all 32 injection molding machines displaying real-time mold surface temperatures. Operators must document temperature readings before beginning maintenance tasks and wait for molds to cool to below 60°C before manual cleaning. This engineering control eliminates contact with dangerously hot surfaces. Training will be provided on proper use of the monitoring system and cooling procedures. Expected outcome: Reduce heat-related burns by 95% on production lines.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Protective Gloves
description: Procure and distribute Kevlar-reinforced, silicone-coated heat-resistant gloves rated for 250°C contact to all injection molding operators. Gloves must be inspected weekly and replaced every 6 months. Implement mandatory glove-wearing policy during all mold maintenance tasks, enforced through visual inspection and daily safety briefings. While PPE is a lower-priority control, this provides interim protection while engineering controls are implemented.

name: Redesign Chemical Storage Layout with Segregation Zones
description: Implement a complete reorganization of the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room establishing separate, clearly marked storage zones: flammable solvents in fire-rated cabinets minimum 3 meters from electrical equipment, with dedicated explosion-proof ventilation. Install secondary containment trays under all solvent containers rated for 110% of container volume. Remove all standard electrical fixtures from the room and replace with explosion-proof lighting and equipment certified for Class I, Division 2 hazardous locations. This engineering control eliminates the primary fire hazard source.

name: Establish Chemical Inventory Management System with Automated Alerts
description: Deploy a barcode-based inventory tracking system that enforces maximum storage limits for flammable materials in the chemical storage building. The system will generate automatic alerts when solvent quantities approach unsafe levels and prevent further inventory additions until items are relocated. Monthly audits will verify physical inventory matches digital records. Integrate this with the facility's existing ISO 14001 environmental management system to ensure compliance.

name: Upgrade Fire Suppression System and Emergency Response Procedures
description: Install an automatic fire detection system with sprinkler heads specifically rated for chemical storage facilities throughout Building 5. Conduct comprehensive employee training on fire extinguisher operation (Type ABC and D) with quarterly refresher drills. Establish a 5-person Chemical Storage Emergency Response Team with monthly scenario-based training. Create laminated emergency procedure cards posted at all exits and work stations detailing chemical fire response protocols.

name: Install Permanent Cable and Hose Management System
description: Install overhead cable trays and hose routing systems along all production equipment in the Main Production Building, keeping air hoses and electrical cables elevated and secured away from walkways and work areas. All cables passing through work zones must be routed through protective conduit or channeling rated for foot traffic. Color-code hoses by function (air, hydraulic, electrical) to improve identification and maintenance efficiency. This engineering control eliminates trip hazards by removing obstacles from floor level.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Workplace Ergonomics and Trip Hazard Audit
description: Engage an external ergonomics consultant to conduct a complete audit of the Main Production Building and Maintenance Workshop, identifying all trip hazards, cable management issues, and ergonomic risk factors. Develop a prioritized remediation plan addressing high-risk areas. Conduct employee training on hazard identification and reporting procedures. Implement a monthly workplace inspection program with rotating employee participation to maintain compliance and identify emerging hazards.

name: Implement Pallet Stacking and Load Verification Procedure
description: Establish a standardized pallet stacking protocol requiring all material handlers to verify load balance and weight distribution before moving pallets. Create visual inspection checklists and conduct weekly audits of warehouse stacking practices. Train all material handlers on proper stacking techniques using the FIFO method and balanced weight distribution. Documentation will be maintained showing shift-by-shift compliance.

name: Clear Warehouse Aisles and Install Floor Markings
description: Conduct a complete warehouse layout review to identify and remove all obstructions from primary and secondary aisles. Install high-visibility floor markings (yellow tape) to define clear pathways for pallet jack operations. Remove packaging debris and scrap materials that accumulate during shifts. Implement a daily end-of-shift cleanup checklist to maintain aisle clearance.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Program for Cooling Systems
description: Establish a monthly preventive maintenance schedule for all injection molding machine cooling circuits. Inspect all hose clamps, connections, and manifold seals for tightness and signs of wear. Replace hose clamps every 18 months as part of routine maintenance. Create a maintenance log tracking all cooling system inspections and repairs. Train maintenance technicians on proper torque specifications for all cooling line connections.

name: Upgrade to Self-Sealing Quick Disconnects on Cooling Lines
description: Replace all standard hose clamp connections on cooling water circuits with spring-loaded self-sealing quick-disconnect couplers. These couplers automatically stop flow when disconnected and prevent leakage from minor clamp loosening. Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines over a 90-day period. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of pressure leaks during normal operation.

name: Mandatory Two-Person Verification Protocol for Machine Setup
description: Implement a new operational procedure requiring two qualified personnel to confirm all machine setup steps before transitioning from manual to automatic mode. Both operators must verbally confirm readiness and visually inspect work areas for personnel. Introduce color-coded flags (red for active setup, green for ready) that must be physically placed and removed at each setup station. Train all machine setters and operators on the new protocol with competency assessments before returning to independent work.

name: Install Machine Interlock Safety System Upgrade
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with enhanced safety interlocks that require active manual disengagement to switch from manual to automatic mode. Install proximity sensors around mold work areas that trigger automatic machine shutdown if personnel are detected within the danger zone during automatic cycles. Conduct third-party safety certification of all installations. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of unexpected machine activation.

name: Enhanced LOTO Procedures and Weekly Audits
description: Revise all Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedures to include mandatory interlock verification as a standalone step before any manual mode operations. Implement weekly LOTO compliance audits conducted by HSE personnel, with documented findings reported to shift supervisors. Conduct monthly refresher training on LOTO procedures for all production and maintenance personnel. Create a compliance tracking dashboard visible to all shift teams.

name: Enforce Mandatory LOTO Protocol for All Maintenance Tasks
description: Implement a mandatory lockout/tagout protocol requiring all maintenance personnel to physically lock and tag the machine power source before any internal work. Install clearly visible LOTO stations at each injection molding line with assigned personnel as LOTO coordinators. All technicians must complete LOTO recertification training within 30 days. A daily pre-shift checklist will confirm LOTO compliance. Random audits will be conducted weekly to ensure adherence, with disciplinary action for non-compliance.

name: Install Mold Safety Interlock System
description: Replace the current mold closing system on Injection Molding Line B with an advanced safety interlock that prevents machine operation when any protective gates are open or when foreign objects are detected in the mold cavity. This engineering control eliminates the risk of unexpected startup during maintenance. The new system will include pressure sensors and proximity detectors that automatically halt the injection cycle if manual intervention is detected.

name: Establish Machine Maintenance Buddy System
description: Create a mandatory two-person verification system where one technician performs maintenance while a second trained observer verifies LOTO compliance and monitors for hazards. This administrative control ensures accountability and provides immediate assistance in case of emergency. All production operators will receive training on their role as observers, and a sign-off sheet must be completed for each maintenance activity.

name: Enhanced Local Exhaust Ventilation in Fiber Preparation Area
description: Install dedicated local exhaust ventilation (LEV) systems directly above fiber material transfer stations with capture hoods positioned to intercept dust at the source. The system will include HEPA filtration and real-time particle monitoring with visual alerts when capture efficiency drops below 95%. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of respiratory hazard exposure by preventing fiber dust from entering the breathing zone.

name: Mandatory Composite Materials Safety Training for All Production Staff
description: Conduct comprehensive training on composite fiber hazards, proper PPE selection and fit-testing, and correct material handling procedures. Focus on respiratory protection, including when N95 masks are required versus when P100 cartridge respirators are necessary based on dust concentration. Training will be provided to all 45 production and material handling employees, with certification required before solo work in fiber preparation areas. Annual refresher training will be mandatory.

name: Install Perimeter Safety Guardrails and Toe Boards on Mezzanine
description: Install standard 42-inch height guardrails with 4-inch toe boards on all open edges of the mezzanine level storage area, meeting CSA Z195-14 standards for fall protection. Material will be galvanized steel with high-visibility yellow paint. Installation includes removal of existing hazardous conditions and securing of all storage items. This engineering control eliminates the falling objects hazard by containing materials within the guarded perimeter.

name: Install High-Intensity LED Lighting on Mezzanine Level
description: Install motion-activated high-intensity LED lighting fixtures providing minimum 500 lux illumination throughout the mezzanine storage area, with backup battery systems for night shift operations. Lighting will eliminate shadows and dark corners that currently obscure hazards. All fixtures will be vandal-resistant and rated for industrial environments.

name: Implement Secure Storage System with Load Limits and Restraint Straps
description: Reorganize mezzanine storage using dedicated industrial shelving with maximum weight limits clearly labeled and enforced. Install load-securing straps on all shelving units to prevent items from shifting or falling. Establish a inventory management system limiting items stored near edges. Conduct staff training on proper storage practices and load distribution. Post weight capacity signage in multiple languages.

name: Install Secondary Containment System
description: Design and install a complete secondary containment system for all chemical transfer operations in UNIT-010. This will include a 110% capacity containment basin beneath all drum and tank transfer areas with integrated drain valves and sump pump systems. All transfer hoses will be replaced with reinforced, quick-disconnect couplings rated for organic solvents. This engineering control directly eliminates the root cause of uncontained spills and prevents future environmental releases. Expected outcome: 100% containment of spills up to maximum single-container capacity.

name: Enhanced Chemical Transfer Procedures and Training
description: Develop and implement comprehensive standard operating procedures (SOPs) for all chemical transfer operations with mandatory quarterly refresher training for all mixing operators. SOPs will include pre-transfer equipment inspection checklist, pressure equalization protocols, and spill response procedures. All operators will receive hands-on training on proper coupling attachment, hose integrity verification, and emergency ventilation activation. Additionally, implement a log system for all chemical transfers to track compliance and identify patterns.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Sensors
description: Install real-time continuous air quality monitoring system in the Chemical Storage Building with VOC sensors placed at multiple heights and locations. The system will provide immediate alerts when VOC levels reach 50% of the OSHA action level (600 ppm), giving operators advance warning before hazardous conditions develop. Connect monitoring system to automated ventilation controls that increase air exchange rates when elevated VOC concentrations are detected. This administrative control ensures early detection and rapid response to chemical vapors.

name: Mandatory Lockout/Tagout System Upgrade and Compliance Audit
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all 32 injection molding machines to verify LOTO compliance and install mandatory mechanical lockout devices that cannot be bypassed. Implement electronic interlock monitoring system that records all lock/unlock events with timestamps and operator identification. All production operators must complete recertification training on LOTO procedures within 14 days, with competency verification assessments. Establish zero-tolerance disciplinary policy for LOTO bypass violations. This engineering and administrative control directly prevents unauthorized machine startup during maintenance operations.

name: Comprehensive Ventilation System Redesign and Installation
description: Engage certified HVAC engineering firm to redesign the ventilation system in UNIT-015 with focus on capturing composite fiber dust at the source. Install local exhaust ventilation (LEV) systems above all composite curing ovens and processing equipment with high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filtration rated for composite fibers. Establish minimum air exchange rate of 12 changes per hour in processing areas. Install permanent airflow measurement devices with alarms that trigger when ventilation falls below minimum thresholds. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at its source before employees can be exposed.

name: Respiratory Protection Program Implementation
description: Establish comprehensive respiratory protection program including fit-testing for all employees working in UNIT-015, quarterly re-testing, and mandatory use of NIOSH-approved particulate respirators (N100 rating minimum) during all composite processing and curing operations. Maintain inventory of replacement cartridges and conduct monthly inspections of all respirators. Provide employee training on proper donning/doffing procedures and care protocols. This administrative and PPE control provides interim protection while engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Storage and Equipment Placement Protocol
description: Establish and enforce facility-wide protocol that restricts placement of storage equipment, materials, and temporary installations in designated 3-meter clearance zones around all ventilation intake and exhaust points. Create visual floor markings and signage in UNIT-015 identifying these protected zones. Implement weekly inspection checklist to verify compliance and immediately remove any obstructive items. Train all staff on the importance of maintaining clear ventilation pathways during facility orientation.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Double-Verification Procedure
description: Establish a two-person LOTO verification system where one operator performs the lockout procedure while a second trained observer independently verifies all LOTO steps before any maintenance begins. This engineering/administrative control will eliminate opportunities for single-point failures. All maintenance personnel will receive recertification training on LOTO procedures with emphasis on verification protocols. A laminated checklist will be mounted at each machine requiring the observer's signature. Monthly audits will be conducted by the Electrical Maintenance Lead to ensure compliance.

name: Install Visual LOTO Status Indicators on All Injection Molding Machines
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with electronic LOTO status indicators that display red/green LED lights visible from multiple angles. These high-visibility indicators will show real-time LOTO engagement status, making it immediately obvious to any personnel whether machines are safely locked out. Integration with the facility's maintenance management system will log all LOTO/unlock events for audit trails. This engineering control provides a fail-safe visual confirmation system reducing human error in verification.

name: Production Scheduling Review and Operator Relief Protocol
description: Conduct a comprehensive review of production scheduling targets to ensure realistic timelines that do not create pressure to skip safety procedures. Implement a mandatory relief rotation system where operators on high-risk machines take 15-minute breaks every 2 hours, with temporary coverage provided by cross-trained staff. This administrative control addresses the root cause of time pressure driving unsafe shortcuts. The Production Supervisor will monitor compliance and adjust schedules if pressures resurface.

name: Transition to Latex-Free Glove Program
description: Replace all latex gloves in the facility with high-quality nitrile alternatives, which provide equivalent chemical protection without latex allergen exposure. Coordinate with the supply chain to ensure all material handlers receive nitrile glove kits (multiple sizes) with training on proper fit and inspection. Eliminate any remaining latex products from first aid kits and safety inventory. This substitution control removes the latex allergen hazard entirely. Post signage indicating the facility is now a latex-free workplace and document employee sensitivities for medical file records.

name: Install Secondary Containment System in Chemical Mixing Area
description: Implement a dedicated secondary containment platform in the mixing room designed to hold 110% of the largest single container volume (minimum 60-liter capacity). This engineering control will prevent spills from spreading across the floor and contaminating large areas. The containment area will be equipped with integrated drainage to a collection sump with manual valve control, allowing controlled disposal of accidental spills. All chemical containers will be stored exclusively within this containment area during mixing operations. Signage and training will reinforce this requirement.

name: Upgrade Chemical Mixing Area Ventilation to Automatic Sensing
description: Replace the manual ventilation system with an automated air quality monitoring system that activates exhaust fans when volatile organic compound (VOC) concentrations exceed predetermined thresholds. Install VOC sensors at multiple heights in the mixing room with automatic damper adjustment to increase air exchange rates proportionally to detected chemical vapor levels. This engineering control ensures rapid ventilation response to spills without relying on manual operator intervention. Quarterly calibration of sensors will be scheduled and documented by the Environmental Compliance Specialist.

name: Implement Spill Response Training and Equipment Staging
description: Conduct comprehensive spill response training for all night shift personnel covering hazard identification, safe evacuation, equipment deployment, and when to contact emergency services. Stage spill response kits (absorbent granules, neutralizers, personal protective equipment, waste containers) at three strategic locations in the chemical storage area with laminated instruction cards. Conduct quarterly drills simulating small spills to maintain readiness. This administrative control ensures rapid, safe response to future incidents and minimizes vapor exposure time.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling Water System Flush and Treatment
description: Establish a formal quarterly maintenance schedule to flush all cooling water lines in injection molding machines and treat water with scale inhibitor to prevent mineral buildup. Train maintenance technicians on proper flushing procedures and water treatment protocols. Install inline water filters on all molding machines to capture particulates before they accumulate in cooling systems. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of blockages and will prevent future pressure buildup incidents that could lead to equipment failure or operator injury.

name: Add Pressure Relief Monitoring to Preventive Maintenance Checklist
description: Update the daily operator checklist to include visual inspection and verbal confirmation of normal hydraulic system sounds and vibration levels. Create a pressure monitoring log where operators record baseline system pressures at shift start. Any deviation of more than 5% triggers immediate work order for maintenance investigation. This administrative control ensures early detection of emerging hydraulic system problems before they escalate to equipment failure.

name: Replace Damaged Pallets and Inspect All Storage Pallets Weekly
description: Conduct immediate inspection of all resin storage pallets in the warehouse to identify any cracked, splintered, or otherwise damaged units. Remove damaged pallets from service and replace with new ones. Establish a weekly visual inspection routine where warehouse staff systematically check all pallets for damage and segregate defective ones for disposal. This engineering control eliminates the sharp edge hazard by removing damaged equipment from the warehouse environment before injuries occur.

name: Install Self-Cleaning Sensor Guards on All Regrind Machine Interlocks
description: Retrofit all regrind machines with stainless steel self-cleaning sensor guards that prevent plastic dust and debris accumulation around safety interlock sensors. These guards will feature periodic air purge cycles that automatically clear dust buildup. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause—sensor blockage from dust accumulation—ensuring safety interlocks function reliably and preventing dangerous situations where operators might bypass LOTO procedures due to non-functioning warning systems.

name: Reinforce LOTO and Lockout Verification Training for Night Shift Staff
description: Conduct mandatory retraining on Lockout/Tagout procedures with emphasis on verification steps before performing any maintenance or clearance work on guarded equipment. Include scenario-based training where operators must verbally confirm interlock status and warning lights before proceeding with any blocking removal. Emphasize that lack of warning light indication is NOT confirmation of de-energization; physical LOTO verification is required. This administrative control ensures all operators, particularly night shift staff with minimal supervision, understand and consistently follow proper lockout procedures.

name: Install Mold Temperature Monitoring System with Redundant Sensors
description: Replace single-point thermostats on all 32 injection molding machines with dual-sensor temperature monitoring systems that display actual mold surface temperature in real-time. Sensors will trigger automatic alarms if temperature exceeds safe-to-touch threshold (60°C) before maintenance personnel can access the mold. System will include visual and audible warnings on the machine console and send alerts to the production control system. This engineering control eliminates reliance on faulty single sensors and provides real-time verification of mold temperature before human contact.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Gloves for Mold Maintenance
description: Issue silicone-based, rated to 250°C heat-resistant gloves to all operators and maintenance personnel who work on injection molding equipment. Establish mandatory use policy requiring gloves for all external mold contact tasks. Conduct training on proper glove selection, inspection, and replacement procedures. Store gloves in designated containers at each molding line for easy access. This administrative control combined with PPE provides temporary protection until all molds are equipped with functional temperature monitoring.

name: Implement Mandatory Load Testing and Mold Inspection Program
description: Establish quarterly (every 3 months) non-destructive load testing protocol for all overhead cranes, chain hoists, and rigging equipment using certified third-party testing services. Conduct 110% rated load proof tests on all mold lifting lugs prior to each use. Maintain detailed inspection logs with photographic documentation. Remove any equipment failing inspection from service immediately and tag with 'Do Not Use' warning. This engineering control ensures equipment integrity and prevents catastrophic load drops. Responsibility assigned to Maintenance and Engineering department with monthly audits by HSE.

name: Establish Exclusion Zone Policy for Suspended Load Operations
description: Define and mark all areas beneath storage mezzanine shelves and overhead rigging paths as restricted zones during material handling operations. Install high-visibility yellow and black striped warning tape, permanent floor markings, and signage indicating 'Suspended Load Zone - Keep Clear.' Require all personnel to wear high-visibility vests and hard hats when working in or near these zones. Implement a two-person verification system where the crane operator verifies that the exclusion zone is clear before hoisting any load. Train all personnel on radio communication protocols to announce load movements.

name: Implement Automated CNC Work-Clamp Verification System
description: Install pressure transducers and load sensors on all CNC milling machine work-holding clamps to continuously monitor clamping force. Program the machine control system to prevent spindle startup if clamping pressure falls below 90% of specified minimum. Add visual and audible alarms if pressure degradation is detected. Create automatic log files recording clamp pressure readings at 5-minute intervals. This engineering control removes dependency on manual checklist compliance and provides continuous, objective verification of clamp integrity, preventing workpiece shifting during high-speed operations.

name: Complete Hydraulic System Overhaul and Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Implement a comprehensive hydraulic system inspection and replacement program for all shredding equipment. All hoses will be replaced with reinforced high-pressure variants rated 25% above maximum operating pressure. Install pressure relief valves on secondary circuits and upgrade the control panel with redundant electrical systems. Establish quarterly inspections by certified hydraulic technicians. Maintain a spare control panel on-site for emergency replacement. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of hose failure and ensures system reliability.

name: Sensor Line Protection and Contamination Prevention
description: Install stainless steel mesh guards around all hydraulic sensor lines and emergency stop sensor connections in the Regrind Department. Implement weekly flushing of sensor lines using filtered hydraulic fluid to prevent contamination buildup. Upgrade the emergency stop system with mechanical-only activation independent of electronic sensors. Train operators on recognizing warning signs of hydraulic contamination including discoloration, foaming, or viscosity changes.

name: Implement Heat-Resistant Glove Requirement and Upgrade PPE Standards
description: Replace all standard cotton work gloves with certified heat-resistant gloves rated for contact temperatures up to 250°C in the Post-Processing Department. All gloves must meet ANSI/ISEA standards for thermal protection. Distribute new gloves to all 45 operators on Lines A, B, and C. Conduct mandatory training on proper glove selection, inspection, and replacement protocols. Establish a monthly glove replacement schedule and implement an inspection system to identify worn or damaged gloves before use.

name: Install Remote Part Removal Tools and Engineering Barriers
description: Engineer and install mechanical part removal systems using long-handled extraction tools (18-24 inches minimum) to create physical distance between operators and hot mold surfaces. Install thermal barriers around exposed mold cavities using stainless steel guards with 15mm gaps for part removal. The guards will reduce radiant heat exposure by approximately 60%. Retrofit Line C first as a pilot project, then expand to Lines A and B upon validation. This engineering control eliminates direct contact hazard.

name: Enhanced Operator Training and Temperature Awareness Program
description: Develop and implement mandatory training module covering thermal hazards, proper PPE selection, and emergency first aid for burn injuries. Include hands-on demonstration of safe part removal techniques and recognition of equipment temperature indicators. Conduct quarterly refresher training with all Post-Processing operators. Implement color-coded temperature warning labels on all mold equipment showing danger zones and safe approach distances.

name: Install Automatic Door Closure Enforcement System
description: Replace the manual emergency exit door with a self-closing model featuring an electromagnetic hold mechanism that requires authorized personnel to use a key card or manual override to keep the door open. The door will automatically close after 30 seconds of being held open, preventing indefinite propping. Install visible signage stating 'Emergency Exit - Do Not Block' with pictographic warnings. This engineering control eliminates the ability to permanently wedge the door open while maintaining emergency accessibility.

name: Secure Mezzanine Storage and Implement Load Capacity Labels
description: Install stainless steel mesh netting along all mezzanine edges in the Shipping and Receiving area to prevent objects from falling. Conduct inventory audit of mezzanine stored items and remove any items exceeding the designated 5 kg per linear meter limit for edge storage. Install permanent weight capacity and storage limitation signs. Implement a monthly mezzanine inspection checklist to be completed by the Warehouse Lead, documenting edge security and stored item conditions.

name: Cooling System Maintenance and Contingency Planning
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule for the dock cooling system with quarterly inspections and component replacement. Create a contingency procedure that specifies authorized personnel may use temporary ventilation methods (portable fans, external vents) rather than blocking emergency exits during maintenance. Train all night shift supervisors on this protocol and communicate it via shift briefings and posted procedures.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all 32 injection molding machines with quarterly inspections of hydraulic systems, pressure relief valves, and sensor calibration. This includes pressure testing, fluid analysis for degradation, and replacement of worn components according to manufacturer specifications. All maintenance work will be documented in the equipment management system and tracked by the Maintenance and Engineering department.

name: Install Pressure Relief Override Safety Device
description: Engineer and install dual-redundant pressure relief override systems on all high-tonnage injection molding machines (250+ tons). This engineering control ensures that if the primary relief valve malfunctions, a secondary system automatically engages to prevent catastrophic pressure buildup. The system will include alarm notification to the machine operator when the secondary relief activates, prompting immediate shutdown and inspection procedures.

name: Install Ergonomic Component Extraction Assist Devices
description: Engineer and install pneumatic-assisted component removal devices at all assembly stations on Line B and C in the Assembly Department. These devices reduce repetitive gripping force required by operators by 60-70%, significantly lowering carpal tunnel risk. The system will be calibrated to match component weight and extraction force requirements, with adjustable settings for different product types. Training will be provided to all assembly operators on proper use and maintenance.

name: Mandatory Job Rotation and Micro-Break Protocol
description: Implement mandatory 15-minute job rotation every 2 hours for all assembly operators performing repetitive extraction tasks, combined with structured 5-minute micro-breaks every 30 minutes. Operators will rotate between assembly stations, quality inspection, and material staging roles to vary muscle group usage. This administrative control will be enforced through shift supervisor oversight and will be incorporated into the Assembly Department standard operating procedures. Expected outcome is 40% reduction in repetitive strain incidents.

name: Provide Custom Wrist Support PPE
description: Issue medical-grade wrist stabilization braces to all assembly operators performing high-repetition extraction work. Braces will be individually fitted and selected based on task demands and operator hand size. Operators will receive training on proper application, wearing duration, and care. PPE inventory will be maintained with quarterly replacement cycles. This provides additional personal protection while engineering and administrative controls are implemented.

name: Replace Hopper Level Sensor with Redundant System
description: Install dual-level ultrasonic sensors on the regrind machine hopper with independent alarm circuits. If the primary sensor fails or detects overflow conditions, the secondary sensor automatically triggers machine shutdown and audible/visual alarm to alert operators. The new system will include preventive maintenance intervals of 30 days for sensor calibration and cleaning. This engineering control eliminates the single point of failure that caused the spill.

name: Establish Preventive Sensor Maintenance Schedule
description: Create and implement a monthly preventive maintenance checklist for all material handling equipment sensors, including the regrind hopper level sensor, compounding station sensors, and feed rate sensors. Maintenance will include sensor cleaning, electrical connection verification, calibration testing against known standards, and replacement of sensors exceeding acceptable drift parameters. Records will be maintained in the equipment management system with tracking of any sensor anomalies or recalibration events.

name: Enhance Quality Inspection Procedures for Edge Defects
description: Implement enhanced visual inspection protocol specifically targeting stress fractures and sharp edges on all plastic components before packaging. Quality Control will add a tactile inspection step using gloved hands to detect sharp edges and stress weaknesses. Training will be provided to all quality inspectors on identifying stress fracture indicators. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the manufacturing defect that caused the injury by catching defects before they reach the packaging stage. Expected outcome: 99.5% defect detection rate improvement.

name: Upgrade Cooling System Parameters in Injection Molding
description: Work with Process Engineer Raj Patel to adjust cooling parameters on injection molding machines to eliminate internal stress concentrations. This involves optimizing cooling time, temperature gradients, and mold circulation rates. Engineering controls will be implemented through updated machine settings and monitoring procedures. All affected machines will be calibrated and baseline data collected. This addresses the root cause by preventing stress fracture formation during production rather than catching defects after the fact.

name: Implement Chemical Segregation Storage System
description: Install fire-rated steel cabinet dividers and secondary containment systems in the Hazardous Waste Management Area to physically segregate incompatible chemical categories. Oxidizers, flammables, and solvents will be stored in separate compartments with clear labeling and updated inventory tracking system. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard by preventing contact between incompatible substances. All staff will receive updated WHMIS training on the new storage protocols. Regular monthly audits will verify compliance and placement accuracy.

name: Establish Proper Rag and Solvent Disposal Protocol
description: Create and enforce a new administrative control requiring all solvent-saturated rags to be stored in NFPA-compliant flammable waste containers with self-closing lids and proper ventilation holes. Install five compliant waste containers throughout the facility at solvent-use locations. Implement weekly disposal schedule with certified hazardous waste contractor. All employees will receive training on proper rag disposal during next safety meeting. This procedure change directly prevents the ignition source by ensuring contaminated materials cannot accumulate near heat or incompatible substances.

name: Upgrade Fire Suppression and Detection Systems
description: Install automatic fire detection system with heat and smoke sensors in the chemical storage building exterior zone, tied to facility alarm system. Upgrade extinguisher inventory to include Class C and foam units appropriate for chemical fires. Inspect and recharge all extinguishers and maintain updated inventory chart. Conduct quarterly fire drill with focus on chemical storage area evacuation procedures. This engineering control provides rapid detection and response capability to minimize fire spread and worker exposure to hazardous conditions.

name: Replace and Upgrade Resin Dryer Temperature Control System
description: Replace the corroded thermal sensor with redundant dual-sensor system featuring independent monitoring channels and automatic alert thresholds set at 95°C and automatic shutdown at 105°C. Install a secondary mechanical temperature gauge for manual verification. This engineering control eliminates the root cause by providing fail-safe temperature monitoring. The redundant system ensures that even if one sensor fails, the second sensor provides backup protection. All maintenance staff will be trained on the new system during mandatory training session.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Dryer Equipment
description: Implement quarterly preventive maintenance for all resin dryers including sensor cleaning, electrical contact inspection, and complete system calibration. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard will coordinate with all dryer operators to schedule maintenance during shift transitions. Documentation will be maintained in centralized maintenance log. Corroded sensors will be inspected and replaced before failure occurs, following manufacturer specifications. This administrative control prevents sensor degradation through regular inspection and replacement before corrosion becomes critical.

name: Implement Mandatory Micro-Break Schedule for Repetitive Tasks
description: Establish a formal micro-break policy requiring 5-minute breaks every 45 minutes for all assembly and part removal operations. Workers will rotate through lighter tasks during breaks to reduce repetitive strain. Supervisors will monitor compliance using shift logs. Training will be provided to all production staff on proper ergonomic techniques and early warning signs of repetitive strain injuries. This administrative control addresses the root cause of inadequate rest periods during high-repetition tasks.

name: Install Ergonomic Part Extraction Fixtures
description: Design and fabricate mechanical part extraction devices that reduce manual gripping force required during mold cavity extraction. These engineering controls will replace repetitive hand squeezing with lever-operated mechanisms, significantly reducing pinching and gripping motions. Fixtures will be customized for each mold cavity size and installed on all 32 molding machines over 60 days. This engineering control directly eliminates the primary hazard of excessive repetitive strain.

name: Complete Overhead Crane System Replacement and Certification
description: Replace all cable support brackets and suspension hardware on the overhead crane system in the Materials Storage area. Implement a certified engineering inspection protocol requiring professional third-party certification of all load-bearing components. Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring annual inspections and load testing. All work will be performed by a certified crane service provider. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of structural failure due to fatigue and corrosion in load-bearing equipment.

name: Install Redundant Bin Stabilization System
description: Engineer and install secondary mechanical stabilization devices on all storage bins to prevent shifting during crane transport. Implement automated bin securing clamps that engage when the crane engages, providing triple-redundancy in load containment. This engineering control will prevent any bin movement even if primary cable support fails, protecting employees and equipment below.

name: Upgrade Temperature Display Systems with Redundant Monitoring
description: Replace all temperature display monitors on injection molding machines with dual-sensor systems that provide continuous cross-verification. Install audible alarms that trigger if temperature readings diverge between sensors or exceed safe maintenance thresholds. Implement automatic nozzle cooling shutdown if any anomaly is detected. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of false temperature readings that led to unsafe maintenance practices.

name: Install Automated Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Implement real-time temperature monitoring sensors on all injection molding lines that automatically lock the part extraction mechanism until the mold reaches safe handling temperature (below 60°C). The system will provide visual and auditory alerts to operators when safe extraction is possible. This engineering control directly eliminates the risk of contact with excessively hot mold surfaces by making manual temperature assessment unnecessary. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of heat-related mold contact incidents.

name: Mandatory Heat Hazard Retraining for All Operators
description: Develop and deliver a comprehensive 2-hour training module on thermal hazards in injection molding operations. Training will cover: proper cooling cycle protocols, burn severity classifications, appropriate PPE requirements, and decision-making under production pressure. All production operators will complete this training within 14 days, with annual refresher training thereafter. Include scenario-based learning using near-miss and incident case studies. Documentation will be maintained for CNESST compliance.

name: Establish Production Scheduling Buffer Protocols
description: Work with production scheduling to implement minimum 10% time buffer in daily production targets to reduce pressure for operators to bypass safety procedures like full cooling cycles. Communicate to all line leads and supervisors that safety compliance takes precedence over schedule targets. Implement weekly safety performance metrics that are tracked alongside production metrics in management reviews.

name: Implement Chemical Storage Management System with Visual Audits
description: Develop and implement a digital chemical inventory management system integrated with the warehouse management software that includes: mandatory chemical compatibility checks before any storage location assignment, weekly automated email alerts to shift supervisors listing all chemicals in high-risk proximity, color-coded shelf labeling indicating chemical hazard classifications, and monthly physical audits with photographic documentation. Create laminated reference cards showing proper storage zones for all 47 chemicals used at TechnoPlast, posted at each storage location.

name: Conduct Chemical Storage Refresher Training for All Warehouse and Maintenance Staff
description: Deliver a mandatory 90-minute training session covering: WHMIS chemical classification system, TechnoPlast's Chemical Compatibility Matrix, emergency response procedures for chemical spills or fires, proper handling of pressurized containers, and identification of incompatible storage combinations. Training will be delivered to all warehouse associates, maintenance technicians, and supervisors within 14 days. Include scenario-based drills simulating chemical spill response. Maintain training records for regulatory compliance and annual refresher requirement.

name: Install Temperature-Monitoring Indicators on Molding Lines
description: Implement thermal color-change adhesive strips on all injection molding machines to provide real-time visual indication of mold surface temperatures. These indicators will change color when molds exceed safe handling temperatures, alerting operators to wait before removal. This engineering control directly eliminates the guesswork in determining safe contact times and reduces thermal contact injuries by providing immediate feedback.

name: Enhance Heat-Resistant PPE for Assembly Operations
description: Upgrade all Assembly Operator gloves to rated heat-resistant materials (silicone-lined leather) capable of withstanding 120°C contact for 5+ seconds. Conduct training session on proper donning and inspection of PPE. Replace all existing cotton/synthetic gloves with heat-rated alternatives across Injection Molding Line D and similar high-heat zones.

name: Establish Hot Work Exclusion Zones and Containment Protocol
description: Implement a facility-wide hot work permit system requiring minimum 10-meter spatial separation between active welding/cutting operations and all flammable solvent storage. Install demarcated exclusion zones with high-visibility tape and signage around all active hot work areas. Conduct pre-work inspections to verify no flammable materials within the exclusion radius. This administrative and engineering control eliminates the primary ignition pathway by preventing spark propagation to flammable vapor sources.

name: Transition to Closed-Container Solvent Storage and Dispensing
description: Replace open-top solvent containers with sealed containers equipped with dispenser pumps and spill containment trays. Install secondary containment for all flammable liquid storage areas rated for 110% of maximum container volume. This engineering control eliminates vapor release from open containers, directly addressing the fire fuel source. Include training on proper dispenser operation for all maintenance and production personnel.

name: Install Fire Extinguisher Network with Operator Training
description: Deploy Class B fire extinguishers (suitable for flammable liquids) at 4 strategic locations within the maintenance workshop, each within 15 meters of potential ignition sources. Conduct mandatory hands-on fire extinguisher training for all maintenance personnel on PASS technique (Pull, Aim, Squeeze, Sweep) and when to evacuate vs. attempt suppression. This administrative control ensures rapid manual response capability before automatic suppression system activation.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule with Thermal Inspection
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all industrial drying ovens including thermal imaging analysis of heating elements and electrical connections to detect early degradation patterns. Document all maintenance activities and create predictive maintenance thresholds based on age and usage hours. This administrative control will identify equipment degradation before catastrophic failure and establish baseline operational parameters that minimize risk of explosive malfunction.

name: Upgrade Oven Electrical Systems with Surge Protection and Isolation
description: Install industrial-grade surge protectors and electrical isolation relays on all heating elements to prevent uncontrolled power fluctuations that caused the internal fault. Upgrade electrical panel to include thermal overload sensors with automatic shutdown capability. Replace aging electrical wiring in the oven circuit with heavier-gauge, properly insulated cabling. This engineering control eliminates the electrical fault condition that triggered the explosion.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Explosion Venting System
description: Install a reinforced stainless steel secondary containment shroud around the material drying oven equipped with controlled pressure relief vents designed to safely direct explosive discharge upward through the facility's roof exhaust system rather than laterally into the work area. This engineering control redirects any future explosive energy away from personnel and equipment.

name: Establish Equipment Safety Exclusion Zone and Signage
description: Mark a 5-meter exclusion zone around all industrial drying ovens with high-visibility floor tape and post warning signage indicating explosion hazard and restricted access requirements. Conduct training for all personnel in UNIT-016 on hazard recognition and emergency evacuation procedures specific to thermal equipment failures. This administrative control increases situational awareness and ensures rapid evacuation capability.

name: Install Automated Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Replace manual temperature sensors on all 32 injection molding machines with automated digital monitoring systems that trigger immediate alerts when mold surface temperatures exceed safe working thresholds. Integrate with machine control systems to automatically initiate cooling cycles and prevent operator access to hot surfaces. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard by preventing unsafe temperatures from occurring. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of heat-related incidents from mold surface contact through automation rather than reliance on operator awareness.

name: Require Heat-Resistant Gloves for All Molding Operations
description: Implement mandatory use of certified heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C) for all personnel working within 2 meters of injection molding machines during operation. Update PPE requirements in the employee handbook and conduct mandatory training during next shift meetings. Maintain inventory of various sizes to ensure proper fit for all employees. While this is PPE-level control, it serves as interim protection while engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Install High-Level Hopper Overflow Detection and Auto-Shutoff System
description: Retrofit all drying room hoppers with ultrasonic level sensors connected to automated shutoff valves that halt material flow when capacity reaches 95% threshold. This engineering control prevents overflow conditions by eliminating manual monitoring failures. System will include visual and audible alarms in UNIT-016 to alert personnel of impending overflow situations, allowing for intervention before spills occur. Integration with existing SCADA system enables real-time monitoring from control room.

name: Establish Material Spill Emergency Response Protocol and Training
description: Develop and document comprehensive spill response procedures specific to plastic resin materials, including containment techniques, proper cleanup materials (absorbent compounds rated for polymer pellets), safe storage of contaminated waste pending disposal, and reporting requirements. Conduct mandatory training for all warehouse and materials handling personnel on spill recognition, immediate containment using spill kits stationed strategically throughout UNIT-016, and notification procedures. Maintain accessible spill kits with absorbent materials, collection containers, and PPE.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Leak Detection and Containment Infrastructure
description: Install continuous monitoring sensors on all hydraulic systems in UNIT-012 with automated alerts when pressure loss exceeds 2% per hour, indicating potential leaks. Retrofit all high-pressure hydraulic components with secondary containment trays designed to capture 110% of maximum fluid volume for each system section. Upgrade floor drainage system with oil-water separator technology that prevents hydraulic fluid and other industrial fluids from entering stormwater systems. These engineering controls intercept leaks before environmental release occurs.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Components
description: Develop and implement quarterly inspection protocol for all hydraulic system pressure relief valves, seals, and connection points in UNIT-012, with documented assessment of wear patterns, fluid discoloration, and micro-fracture indicators. Establish replacement intervals of 3 years for all relief valves regardless of apparent condition to prevent age-related failures. Maintain detailed maintenance logs to identify patterns and assess equipment reliability. This administrative control prevents similar leaks through proactive component replacement before failure occurs.

name: Establish Environmental Incident Notification and Reporting Protocol
description: Create standardized procedure for rapid CNESST notification in accordance with Quebec environmental regulations for any fluid discharge to external systems, including documentation requirements, communication chains, and follow-up investigation timelines. Ensure all supervisory personnel (including Michel Laflamme and night shift leads) receive training on identification of regulated environmental incidents, notification thresholds, and documentation procedures. Post reference materials in break rooms and maintenance areas.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooling Verification Protocol
description: Establish a written procedure requiring operators to verify barrel temperature below 150°C using infrared thermometers before any manual clearing of jams. Install temperature indicator labels on machines showing safe handling zones. Require documentation of cooling verification on shift logs. Train all production operators on the new protocol within 5 working days. This eliminates unnecessary exposure to residual heat and reinforces administrative controls through verification procedures.

name: Issue Heat-Resistant Gloves to All Production Lines
description: Procure and distribute silicone-based heat-resistant gloves rated to 260°C for all operators working with hot plastic material. Require glove use during any clearing or maintenance activities near heated equipment. Include glove inspection and replacement in monthly PPE audits. While PPE is a lower-level control, this provides immediate protection while procedural changes are being embedded.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Pressure Testing
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly pressure testing and inspection program for all high-pressure hydraulic lines on injection molding equipment. Create a detailed work instruction requiring certified hydraulic technicians to perform non-destructive testing on all lines showing signs of corrosion or age greater than 5 years. Document all test results in a centralized maintenance database. Schedule first testing cycle within 15 days. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the hidden hazard of undetected line degradation.

name: Install Hydraulic Fluid Containment Barriers
description: Design and install polycarbonate barriers or shields around all high-pressure hydraulic connection points on Lines D and subsequent lines C, B, and A over the following month. These barriers will deflect any pressurized fluid spray away from operator positions while remaining transparent for visibility. Barriers will be engineered to withstand 3000 PSI directional forces. This is an engineering control that significantly reduces the severity of potential hydraulic release incidents.

name: Implement Mandatory Pre-Operation Equipment Inspection System
description: Create a digital pre-operation checklist system requiring all forklift and material handling equipment operators to perform and document daily brake, steering, and hydraulic system checks before operating equipment. Integrate this into the daily shift startup routine using QR-code scanning to timestamp inspections. Any equipment flagged as requiring maintenance must be immediately removed from service and locked out. This administrative control ensures early detection of brake system degradation before it creates collision hazards.

name: Establish Priority Maintenance Schedule with Zero-Tolerance Enforcement
description: Revise maintenance scheduling procedures to eliminate deferral of brake and hydraulic system repairs. Implement a 48-hour maximum completion window for any flagged equipment requiring brake maintenance before the equipment becomes unavailable for operation. Create a rotating spare forklift pool to ensure operational continuity. All flagged items must receive written supervisor approval to defer, with documented business justification submitted to the Plant Manager. This ensures critical safety defects are addressed promptly.

name: Install Automated Braking System Retrofit on Fleet
description: Upgrade all propane-powered forklifts with redundant brake systems including secondary hydraulic pressure accumulators and pressure gauges visible to operators. This engineering control provides fail-safe braking capability even in the event of primary hydraulic system failure. Retrofit will be phased across the 8-unit fleet over 60 days, starting with equipment in highest-utilization service areas.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Resin Dryers
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program requiring quarterly inspection and annual full service of all resin dryer temperature controllers, pressure relief valves, and heating elements. Create a maintenance log tracking all service activities. Cross-reference manufacturer specifications for all equipment. Train maintenance personnel on early warning signs of controller malfunction. This addresses the root cause of deferred maintenance by establishing mandatory service intervals.

name: Install Backup Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install a redundant, independent temperature monitoring system with visual and audible alarms set at 150°C and 180°C on the resin dryer. This secondary system will operate independently from the primary thermostat and provide real-time temperature data to the control room display. Include an automatic emergency shutdown function if temperatures exceed 200°C. This engineering control ensures equipment temperature remains within safe operating parameters.

name: Enhanced Operator Training on Equipment Limits
description: Conduct mandatory training for all regrind operators and supervisors covering resin dryer operating parameters, early warning signs of malfunction, proper shutdown procedures, and emergency response protocols. Training will include review of temperature and pressure gauges, recognition of unusual sounds or odors, and immediate notification procedures. Document attendance and competency verification for all personnel.

name: Mandatory Cut-Resistant Gloves During Maintenance
description: Issue cut-resistant gloves (rated ANSI A4 or higher) to all maintenance and molding technicians for use during any mold cleaning or maintenance activity. Update the maintenance procedure checklist to require documented glove use before beginning work. Conduct a toolbox talk emphasizing that protective gloves must be worn regardless of perceived risk level. Stock multiple sizes of gloves in the maintenance area and track usage through monthly inventory checks.

name: Mold Deburring and Surface Finishing Inspection
description: Implement a comprehensive inspection protocol for all molds entering service, specifically checking for sharp edges, burrs, and improperly finished internal surfaces. Any mold showing rough or sharp edges will be sent to the maintenance workshop for deburring and polishing before deployment to production lines. Create a mold inspection checklist and document all inspections. This eliminates the hazard at the source by ensuring molds meet surface finish standards before use.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Ventilation in Warehouse
description: Install a dedicated exhaust ventilation system in the Raw Materials Warehouse chemical storage section with a minimum air exchange rate of 6 complete changes per hour. Include spot extraction hoods positioned above high-volatility chemical storage areas. Install permanently mounted CO/VOC sensors with remote alarms that trigger automatic ventilation boost mode when threshold concentrations are exceeded (500 ppm for VOCs). This engineering control removes accumulated fumes and provides early warning of chemical leaks.

name: Implement Mandatory Secondary Containment for All Chemical Containers
description: Establish a requirement that all chemical containers larger than 5 liters must be stored in secondary containment trays with a capacity of at least 110% of the container volume. Inspect containment trays weekly for cleanliness and integrity. Label all containment areas with contents and hazard information. Train all warehouse personnel on proper placement and inspection procedures. Update the chemical storage procedure manual to include these requirements.

name: Respiratory Protection Training and Equipment Availability
description: Provide all warehouse and regrind operation personnel with training in respiratory hazards, proper use of respirators, and fit-testing for assigned respirators. Ensure a supply of NIOSH-approved half-mask respirators with organic vapor cartridges is immediately available at the warehouse entrance. Conduct quarterly refresher training on respiratory protection and update all personnel on symptoms of chemical exposure and emergency response procedures.

name: Install Temperature Warning Systems on All Molding Machines
description: Implement redundant temperature monitoring systems with audible and visual alarms on all 32 injection molding machines. Each system will include dual-channel temperature sensors with independent circuitry to detect mold temperatures above 80°C. Alarms will sound continuously until mold temperature drops to safe operating range. System will be integrated with machine lockout mechanisms to prevent part removal when temperatures exceed safe thresholds. Monthly calibration checks will be conducted.

name: Mandatory Thermal Burns Prevention Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive thermal hazard training to all 120 day-shift production operators and 60 evening-shift operators. Training will include recognition of high-temperature equipment, safe cooling procedures, proper PPE selection (heat-resistant gloves, protective sleeves), and emergency response protocols. All operators must pass a competency assessment. Training will be refreshed annually and provided to new hires during orientation.

name: Implement Equipment Temperature Log System
description: Establish a digital temperature monitoring log for each molding machine with mandatory operator check-ins before part removal. Operators must confirm mold temperature is below 65°C using infrared thermometer guns before proceeding. Records will be maintained for 2 years for audit purposes. Non-compliance will trigger immediate equipment shutdown and supervisor notification.

name: Comprehensive Overhead Crane Inspection and Maintenance Program
description: Implement quarterly (rather than annual) comprehensive inspections of all overhead cranes and lifting equipment. Inspections will include wire rope ultrasonic testing to detect internal fatigue and corrosion, load pin verification, hook condition assessment, and brake system functionality testing. All equipment must be certified by a third-party lift equipment specialist. Any equipment failing inspection will be immediately decommissioned until repairs are certified.

name: Install Load Capacity Monitoring Systems
description: Equip all overhead cranes with electronic load monitoring systems that display real-time load weight and alert operators when loads exceed safe working limits. Systems will include automatic emergency brakes that engage if load indicators show abnormal conditions. Operator training on interpreting load data and responding to alerts will be mandatory.

name: Implement Automated Part Removal and Stacking System on Line C
description: Replace manual part removal and stacking with semi-automated robotic arms equipped with pneumatic grippers. The new system will reduce operator repetitive gripping motions by 85%, with operators only performing quality inspection and occasional manual adjustments. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard at its source rather than relying on operator behavior modification.

name: Comprehensive Ergonomic Assessment and Job Rotation Program
description: Conduct detailed ergonomic assessments on all remaining manual production tasks using RULA and REBA methodologies. Identify high-risk jobs and implement job rotation schedules to limit repetitive strain. Operators will rotate between Line C manual tasks and other production duties every 90 minutes. Ergonomic workstations will be optimized with adjustable height surfaces, wrist supports, and anti-fatigue matting.

name: Establish Ergonomic Training and Early Symptom Reporting System
description: Implement quarterly ergonomic training for all production operators focusing on proper body mechanics, stretch exercises, and early symptom recognition. Create an anonymous symptom reporting system allowing workers to report early signs of repetitive strain (tingling, numbness, pain) without fear of retaliation. Reported symptoms trigger immediate ergonomic assessment and possible temporary task modifications.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a condition monitoring program using vibration analysis and thermal imaging to detect hydraulic component degradation before failure. All injection molding machines will receive quarterly inspections using portable ultrasonic and thermography equipment. High-risk components identified as exceeding wear thresholds will be scheduled for immediate replacement. This engineering control eliminates catastrophic failures through early detection and planned maintenance rather than reactive emergency repairs. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in unexpected hydraulic system failures and associated property damage.

name: Replace All Hydraulic Couplings Exceeding Service Life
description: Conduct comprehensive inventory audit of all hydraulic system couplings across the production facility. Replace any component that has exceeded manufacturer's recommended service life of 10 years, regardless of apparent condition. Implement replacement schedule with 5-year renewal intervals going forward. Stock adequate spare couplings to prevent production delays. This substitution control removes aged components before they reach critical failure thresholds, ensuring system reliability and worker safety.

name: Implement Chemical Container Damage Assessment and Quarantine Protocol
description: Establish mandatory inspection procedure requiring all chemical containers involved in material handling incidents to be immediately isolated and inspected for structural integrity before return to storage. Develop a quarantine area within the chemical storage building for damaged containers pending disposal or safe transfer. Train all material handlers on visual damage indicators (cracks, dents, corrosion) that warrant immediate reporting. This administrative control ensures damaged containers are identified and managed before vapor or spillage occurs, preventing exposure hazards.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System with Real-Time Vapor Monitoring
description: Install continuous air quality monitors in the chemical storage and mixing area that detect solvent vapor concentrations and trigger automated ventilation system increases when levels approach 50% of PEL. The system will log all vapor events for trend analysis. Additionally, upgrade existing ventilation fans to higher capacity units capable of 12 complete air changes per hour (current: 8 changes/hour). This engineering control provides both active hazard detection and enhanced air handling capacity to prevent dangerous vapor accumulation.

name: Install Non-Slip Matting and Improve Beverage Station Design
description: Install permanent anti-slip rubber matting in front of and around the beverage preparation station in the cafeteria. Redesign the beverage station layout to incorporate a lower-profile counter section (reduced reach distance) and place hot beverage dispensers at least 30 centimeters from the counter edge to reduce spill consequences. Add edge guards to contain spillage within the beverage preparation zone. These engineering controls reduce both the probability of spills through improved footing and the severity of any spill that does occur by limiting contact area.

name: Implement Automated Chemical Container Sealing Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory automated seal-verification system for all volatile chemical containers before storage. Every container must pass through a visual and mechanical verification station at the end of each shift. Containers failing verification are isolated and re-sealed by trained chemical handlers only. This engineering control eliminates the human error element of improper sealing. All chemical storage staff will receive certification in the new verification process within 14 days.

name: Relocate All Heat Sources from Chemical Storage Areas
description: Engineering control to physically eliminate the hazard by relocating all curing lamps, heat equipment, and ignition sources to a separate, dedicated non-chemical workspace minimum 50 meters from the Chemical Storage Building. Install clear demarcation zones with signage. All electrical outlets in UNIT-010 will be converted to explosion-proof fixtures rated for Class I, Division 2 hazardous locations per NFPA 70. Implementation requires coordination with maintenance and facility management.

name: Enhance Fire Detection and Suppression System Monitoring
description: Install real-time IoT-enabled fire detection sensors with continuous monitoring dashboard in the Chemical Storage Building. Upgrade suppression system to include rapid-response pre-action sprinklers and add foam-type suppression capability for flammable liquid fires. Establish daily system checks logged electronically. Train all chemical handlers on new system operation and emergency procedures. Monthly maintenance audits will verify system readiness.

name: Reinstall and Upgrade Dock Visibility Systems
description: Engineering control to permanently reinstall spotting mirrors at all forklift operation zones in the dock. Upgrade to wide-angle convex mirrors (180-degree view) and supplement with additional mirrors at blind corners. Install three motion-activated overhead warning lights at dock entry points to alert all personnel during loading operations. Establish a preventive maintenance schedule with monthly inspections logged electronically to ensure mirrors remain clean and properly positioned.

name: Implement Mandatory Forklift Operator Certification Renewal Program
description: Administrative control requiring all forklift operators to complete comprehensive recertification training every 12 months, with emphasis on blind-spot protocols, load stability, and speed control in restricted areas. Create online training modules with practical testing. Operators failing certification cannot operate equipment until retraining is completed and re-certification achieved. Maintain digital records of all certifications and schedule renewal reminders 60 days prior to expiration.

name: Install Protective Guards Around All Sprinkler Heads
description: Engineering control to install protective wire cages around all sprinkler heads in UNIT-017 and other production areas where equipment adjustments occur. Guards will prevent accidental head contact while maintaining water discharge capability. Cages will be stainless steel, rated for high-temperature environments, and installed 5cm from each head. This engineering solution eliminates the direct contact hazard without requiring behavioral changes. Inspect all guards quarterly for integrity and cleanliness.

name: Establish Emergency Suppression System Shutdown Training for All Night Shift Staff
description: Administrative control requiring all night shift employees (permanent and temporary) to complete quarterly hands-on training in emergency suppression system shutdown procedures. Create laminated quick-reference guides posted at three locations in each production zone.
