This provides a physical barrier to reduce consequences if a leak does occur, complementing the inspection program.

name: Replace All Overhead Crane Hoist Cables
description: Complete replacement of all hoist cables on the three overhead cranes in the facility. All cables will be replaced with new wire rope meeting ASME B30.16 standards, with certificates of compliance from the manufacturer. New cables will be installed on all cranes regardless of current age to standardize equipment lifecycle. Installation will be performed by certified riggers. This elimination of aging infrastructure removes the root cause of sudden cable failure and prevents recurrence of this equipment failure mode.

name: Establish Crane and Rigging Equipment Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all material handling equipment including overhead cranes, hoists, and rigging hardware. Inspections will occur monthly for visual defects and annually for certified load testing. A tracking database will record all maintenance activities, inspection results, and replacement dates for all components. Equipment exceeding manufacturer service life limits will be automatically scheduled for replacement. This administrative control ensures regular monitoring and prevents deferred maintenance issues.

name: Install Load Drop Protection Netting in Warehouse Area
description: Engineering control to minimize consequences if future overhead load drops occur. Install high-strength nylon netting beneath the primary load paths of the overhead cranes in the warehouse. The netting will be suspended at an appropriate height to catch dropped loads and reduce velocity of falling objects. This provides secondary protection while primary controls (cable replacement and maintenance programs) eliminate the root cause. Netting will be inspected quarterly for wear and damage.

name: Implement Multi-Point LOTO Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory two-person verification system for all LOTO procedures on injection molding equipment. Before any maintenance work begins, both the technician performing the work and a designated LOTO verifier must independently confirm all energy isolation points are locked out and tagged out. Both workers must sign the LOTO log verifying compliance. Additionally, install bright red warning lights on each machine that illuminate when LOTO is active, providing visual confirmation visible from 10 meters away. This administrative control with visual feedback prevents unauthorized machine restart during maintenance.

name: Mandatory LOTO Retraining and Competency Assessment
description: Conduct mandatory retraining of all production and maintenance personnel on LOTO procedures within 5 days of incident. Training will include case study review of this specific incident, emphasizing consequences of incomplete LOTO procedures. All personnel will complete a written assessment and practical demonstration. Only those achieving 100% will be cleared to perform or participate in maintenance activities. Additional training will occur quarterly. This addresses the human factors component and reinforces safety culture.

name: Install Mechanical Machine Guard on Injection Molding Hopper Access Point
description: Engineering control to prevent hand entry into the auger mechanism. Install a fixed safety guard over the hopper access point that prevents insertion of hands or arms into the auger zone while still allowing material loading operations. The guard will be designed to meet ISO 13857 requirements for openings that prevent hazardous access. This eliminates the primary entanglement hazard by making it physically impossible to reach the moving auger during normal operation, serving as the highest-level control in the hierarchy.

name: Install Thermal Insulation Barriers on Mold Ejection Points
description: Engineering control to reduce burn hazard: Install silicone-based thermal insulation sleeves and removable guards on all injection molding machine mold ejection points on Lines A, B, and C. These barriers will reduce surface temperatures at operator contact points by 40-60°C, significantly reducing burn severity if contact occurs. Implementation includes modifications to machine guards and daily inspection protocols for barrier integrity. Expected outcome: Reduce burn-related incidents by 70% within 6 months.

name: Implement Enhanced Cooling Time Protocol and Machine Monitoring
description: Administrative control: Establish mandatory minimum cooling time verification system with audible alarms on all injection molding machines before allowing part removal. Operators must confirm cool-down completion before proceeding. Include weekly refresher training on thermal hazard recognition and proper part removal techniques. Add documented cooling verification logs to production records.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Work Gloves and Sleeves
description: PPE enhancement: Distribute nitrile-coated heat-resistant gloves rated to 300°C and forearm-length protective sleeves to all injection molding operators. Conduct fitting and training session on proper donning/doffing. Include glove inspection procedures in daily equipment checks and establish replacement schedule quarterly.

name: Implement Drum Storage and Containment System Upgrade
description: Engineering control: Install secondary containment berms with 110% capacity in the Raw Materials Warehouse Section A for all drums containing volatile release agents and solvents. Add locking drum holders with auto-latch bung caps that require two-handed confirmation to open. Install drip trays under elevated storage racks. Include weekly inspection checklist and monthly certification of berm integrity. Expected outcome: Eliminate large-volume spills from drum tipping incidents.

name: Chemical Spill Response Training and Procedure Enhancement
description: Administrative control: Conduct mandatory 4-hour hazmat response certification training for all warehouse and production staff. Establish clear written procedures for chemical spill response with laminated quick-reference cards posted at 8 locations in the warehouse. Implement quarterly spill response drills with documentation. Update SDS (Safety Data Sheet) accessibility with digital kiosks and printed copies at three warehouse stations.

name: Enhance Ventilation System Monitoring and Capacity
description: Engineering control: Install real-time VOC monitoring sensors in the warehouse with alarm thresholds set at 150 ppm (pre-alert) and 180 ppm (full activation). Upgrade HVAC system with variable-speed controls to increase air changes per hour from 4 to 6 ACH during chemical handling. Add carbon filtration cartridges rated for siloxane compounds. Maintenance staff to perform quarterly filter inspection and biannual replacement.

name: Implement Equipment Guard Restoration Tracking System
description: Administrative control: Establish a digital tracking system for all temporarily removed equipment guards, heat shields, and safety devices. Each removal requires work order entry with justification, location, removal date, and scheduled restoration date. Implement automated email alerts 2 days before scheduled restoration date. Conduct weekly audits comparing active work orders to physical equipment inspection. Generate monthly compliance reports to maintenance supervisor. This addresses the specific root cause of this incident—guard removal without tracking or accountability.

name: Implement Part Protection and Storage Protocol
description: Establish mandatory use of protective separators (foam inserts or cardboard layers) between stacked polycarbonate and composite parts. Create visual work instructions at all finishing and packaging stations showing proper stacking techniques. Conduct toolbox talks with all finishing operators on part handling procedures. Provide nitrile cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rating) to all personnel handling sharp-edged components. Verify compliance through weekly HSE audits of packaging station during first month, then monthly thereafter.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Finishing Operations
description: Procure and distribute high-performance cut-resistant gloves rated ANSI A4 or higher to all 15 finishing operators and packaging staff. Conduct training on proper glove selection, donning/doffing, and inspection for defects. Create a replacement schedule ensuring gloves are changed when damaged. Stock gloves in multiple sizes and locations for easy access. Document distribution and training in employee records.

name: Implement Preventive Cooling System Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a bi-weekly inspection protocol for all cooling water circulation lines on Injection Molding Lines B and C, focusing on hose clamps, connection points, and pressure gauges. Maintenance staff will document inspections using a standardized checklist. Replace all hose clamps on cooling lines with locking-style clamps (quick-lock mechanism) to prevent gradual loosening. Install pressure gauges with alarm thresholds at each line to alert operators to leaks. Train all evening and night shift operators on visual inspection of cooling lines during pre-shift equipment checks.

name: Enhance Thermal Burn Prevention Training for Production Staff
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training on thermal hazard recognition, proper cooling system operation, and emergency response procedures specific to Injection Molding Lines. Training will include hands-on demonstration of safe distances from hot surfaces, use of thermal sensors to identify leak locations, and proper use of first aid resources (eyewash, cool water immersion). Include training on the importance of immediately reporting cooling system anomalies. Conduct training for all 30 production operators across all shifts within 21 days, with annual refresher training thereafter.

name: Enforce Mandatory Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Procedures on All CNC Equipment
description: Implement a zero-tolerance policy requiring physical lockout of the main power disconnect and activation of the E-stop button on ALL CNC machines before ANY maintenance or adjustment work begins. Create laminated LOTO checklist cards to be posted at each CNC station in both French and English. Require documented verification by a second qualified person before work begins. Conduct competency assessments for all maintenance staff on proper LOTO procedures. Remove access to machines from staff who have not completed LOTO certification within 30 days. Implement daily electronic logging of LOTO activities for audit trails.

name: Upgrade CNC Machine Safety Systems with Programmable Logic Controllers
description: Install safety-rated Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) on the three primary CNC milling machines in the tool room that will automatically clear all residual program commands and disable the spindle when the machine is placed in maintenance mode. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of unexpected spindle engagement. Each machine will require a separate enable/disable switch that must be physically secured in the 'off' position during maintenance. Conduct factory training for maintenance staff on the new system. Budget includes hardware, installation, programming, and validation testing.

name: Implement Mandatory CNC Maintenance Competency Certification Program
description: Establish a formal certification program for all personnel performing CNC machine maintenance and adjustments. The program will include classroom instruction on LOTO procedures, emergency response protocols, machine-specific hazards, and hands-on supervised practice. Require annual recertification with practical assessment. Create a centralized database tracking certification status for all 12 maintenance and setup personnel. Prohibit uncertified personnel from working on CNC equipment. Partner with local vocational training institution to deliver training if capacity is insufficient in-house.

name: Implement Chemical Container Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a receiving inspection checklist for all chemical containers that verifies cap integrity, container condition, and label accuracy before acceptance. This will be performed by inventory control staff at delivery. Include documentation requirements and authorization signatures. Training will be provided to all personnel involved in chemical receiving and storage.

name: Install Lower-Level Chemical Storage Racks
description: Replace existing high-level storage shelving in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room with lower-profile racking systems designed for hazardous chemical storage. Shelves will be positioned no higher than 1.5 meters to eliminate overhead lifting and reduce fall hazards. All racks will have integrated spill containment trays beneath each shelf level to capture leaks before they reach the floor.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Monitoring
description: Install continuous monitoring of exhaust ventilation systems in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room with alarm notification when airflow drops below minimum thresholds. This addresses inadequate ventilation exposure risks by providing real-time alerts to maintenance staff. Monthly maintenance logs will be cross-referenced with ventilation data to prevent degradation.

name: Replace All Machine Interlock Safety Systems
description: Conduct comprehensive replacement of all interlock safety gate systems on the 32 injection molding machines. Upgrade to newer sensor technology with redundant sensing capabilities and thermal compensation features. New systems will include continuous self-diagnostic monitoring that alerts maintenance staff to potential failures before they compromise safety. Installation will be staggered across production lines to maintain operational capacity.

name: Implement Quarterly Safety System Audits
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly audit schedule for all machine safety systems including interlocks, emergency stops, and pressure relief valves. Audits will be performed by certified maintenance technicians and documented in a centralized database. Any findings will be corrected within 48 hours. Training will be provided to ensure consistency and thoroughness of audit procedures.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Create and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic systems across the facility. Schedule pressure relief valve replacement every 5 years as per manufacturer specifications, with automatic tracking through the maintenance management system. Include hydraulic fluid analysis quarterly to detect degradation. All maintenance activities will be documented in a centralized database accessible to both day and night shift supervisors.

name: Replace All Critical Hydraulic System Components
description: Audit all CNC milling machines and production equipment for hydraulic systems requiring component replacement due to age. Replace all pressure relief valves, seals, hoses, and filters that have exceeded their service life recommendations. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of hydraulic system failures. Establish staggered replacement schedule to minimize production interruption.

name: Install Hydraulic Spill Containment Kit and Training
description: Deploy hydraulic spill containment kits in the workshop areas containing absorbent pads, drain pans, and disposal containers. Train night shift maintenance staff on proper spill response procedures including isolation, containment, and safe cleanup. This provides secondary containment while maintenance systems are upgraded and ensures environmental compliance.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program Enhancement
description: Establish a real-time monitoring system for all critical injection molding machines to track hydraulic pressure, temperature, and system performance. Integrate IoT sensors with the existing maintenance scheduling software to generate automated alerts when equipment approaches service intervals or shows anomalous pressure readings. Train maintenance technicians on the new system and establish mandatory equipment inspections every 45 days regardless of production demand. This engineering control eliminates the risk of deferred maintenance causing catastrophic failures.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Relief Valve Specifications
description: Replace all pressure relief valves on injection molding machines with upgraded models rated for 30% higher pressure tolerance and featuring redundant safety mechanisms. Conduct a complete audit of all 32 injection molding machines to identify valves operating near end-of-service life. Implement a staggered replacement program over 90 days with priority given to machines running continuous production. This substitution control reduces the likelihood of sudden valve failure by employing more robust components with enhanced safety features.

name: Establish Production Demand vs. Maintenance Planning Committee
description: Create a cross-functional committee including Production Operations, Maintenance, and HSE to review equipment maintenance schedules quarterly and ensure production demands do not compromise scheduled preventive maintenance. Develop documented procedures for identifying when maintenance must be prioritized over production targets, and establish escalation protocols to senior management when conflicts arise. Implement administrative controls through policy that establish maintenance as a non-negotiable safety priority.

name: Install Automated Secondary Containment System
description: Design and install an engineered secondary containment system with 110% capacity for the largest drum used in the facility (55 gallons). Install permanent, raised containment pallets with integrated drip trays at all chemical storage locations. Implement barriers and guardrails to prevent forklift access to chemical staging areas except during authorized transfer operations. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of uncontained chemical spills by providing physical infrastructure to capture and contain accidental releases.

name: Implement Restricted Chemical Handling Zone with Access Controls
description: Designate the Chemical Storage and Mixing area as a restricted zone with controlled forklift access limited to certified operators only. Install electronic gate access that requires badge verification and training certification. Establish a material transfer log requiring chemical inventory specialists to authorize all drum movements. Require spotters for all forklift operations within 50 feet of chemical storage areas. Conduct mandatory hazmat training for all forklifts operators with annual recertification. These administrative controls reduce the probability of unauthorized or careless handling of hazardous materials.

name: Implement Automated Deburring Process for Medical-Grade Components
description: Install a dedicated automated vibratory deburring system for all medical device housings and composite components before they reach final assembly stations. Configure the system to process parts for a minimum cycle time that ensures complete edge finishing to ISO 13485 specifications. Establish protocol requiring 100% visual inspection of components after deburring using enhanced lighting and magnification. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of sharp edges by transferring the deburring responsibility from manual assembly workers to automated equipment designed for precision finishing.

name: Implement Enhanced LOTO Procedures for Resin Dryer Systems
description: Establish mandatory lockout/tagout protocols for all resin dryer maintenance activities, including pressure relief valve inspection and hopper clearing. Create visual signage at each injection molding line indicating specific LOTO steps. Conduct immediate retraining of all machine setters on proper pressure system isolation procedures. Install pressure gauges with visual relief confirmation on all dryer systems. Maintenance personnel must complete LOTO certification renewal within 30 days. Implement daily pre-shift checklists that specifically verify all pressure systems are properly isolated before any troubleshooting work begins.

name: Install Automatic Pressure Relief Isolation Valves
description: Retrofit all six injection molding lines with automatic isolation ball valves on hopper discharge chutes that must be manually opened after LOTO verification. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of unexpected pressure release during maintenance. Valves will be installed between the pressure system and the work area. All setters will receive hands-on training on the new valve operation during the installation process. This eliminates the hazard at the source rather than relying on procedure compliance alone.

name: Install Load Restraint Systems on All Storage Racks
description: Retrofit all material storage racks in the Materials Preparation Room and Composite Processing Area with load restraint chains, bungee cords, or engineered containment nets on each tier. These systems will prevent materials from falling regardless of vibration or improper stacking. Establish load weight limits per tier with visible signage. Conduct monthly inspections of restraint systems. This engineering control eliminates the struck-by hazard at the source by physically preventing material displacement.

name: Enhance Mold Release Agent Removal Protocol
description: Implement mandatory air-drying station with heated air blowers for all cleaned trays before they are transferred to packaging. Trays will remain in the drying zone for minimum 3 minutes to ensure complete removal of residual mold release agents. Provide workers with cotton towels and designated drying racks to prevent manual handling of wet, slippery surfaces. Add non-slip gripping gloves specifically designed for handling oily plastic components at the packaging stations. Update the cleaning procedures documentation with this requirement and train all warehouse and packaging staff within one week.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Gloves at Packaging Workstations
description: Supply workers with cut-resistant gloves rated for handling sharp-edged plastic components. These gloves will provide a protective barrier during transfer of trays and other components. Ensure proper sizing and fit for all packaging personnel. Conduct training on proper glove selection and use. Store extra pairs at each workstation for immediate replacement when worn. This PPE control provides additional protection while other preventive measures are being implemented.

name: Install Temperature Safety Interlocks on All Mold Cooling Stations
description: Implement automated temperature monitoring systems on all 24 mold cooling stations with electronic interlocks that physically prevent part removal until mold surface temperature drops below 50°C. System will include audible and visual alarms at 60°C to alert operators. This engineering control eliminates the reliance on individual operator judgment and malfunctioning indicator lights. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of mold-contact thermal burns across all production areas.

name: Enhanced Thermal Burn First Aid Training Protocol
description: Develop and deploy comprehensive thermal burn response training for all production operators and supervisors, covering immediate cold water immersion techniques, burn classification assessment, and emergency escalation procedures. Training will include hands-on practice with simulation models and quarterly refresher sessions. Include specific guidance on when to seek medical attention versus on-site first aid.

name: Implement Automated Preventive Maintenance Scheduling System
description: Deploy computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) that tracks all forklift and material handling equipment service schedules with automatic work order generation at defined intervals. System will send supervisor alerts 5 days before service deadline and flag any equipment exceeding maintenance window. Integrate barcode scanning at maintenance completion to create audit trail. This administrative control ensures no equipment falls outside preventive maintenance protocols.

name: Replace Corroded Hydraulic Fittings on All Material Handling Fleet
description: Conduct comprehensive inspection of all 12 forklifts and 8 pallet jacks in the fleet. Replace all hydraulic fittings showing corrosion or age-related degradation with stainless steel or zinc-coated alternatives rated for 10-year service life. Establish quarterly hydraulic system pressure checks and visual inspections. This engineering control substitutes vulnerable components with more durable alternatives resistant to environmental corrosion.

name: Mandatory Forklift Pre-Shift Safety Inspection Protocol
description: Require all forklift operators to conduct 5-minute pre-shift equipment inspection checklist focusing on hydraulic leaks, tire conditions, and brake responsiveness before any material movement. Operators must sign inspection log daily. Supervisors will review logs weekly and flag any repeated issues for immediate maintenance escalation. Implement spot audits by HSE team to verify compliance.

name: Upgrade Chemical Container Closure and Transport System
description: Replace all non-locking container caps on mold release agent dispensers with child-proof, locking pour spouts that require two-handed operation to prevent accidental spillage during movement and elevated work. Implement color-coded secondary containment trays for all chemical containers during transport or temporary placement. Train all personnel on proper container sealing before any elevation or repositioning work.

name: Install Chemical Splash Barriers and Emergency Containment at Inspection Platforms
description: Install fixed plastic splash guards and absorbent containment mats on all elevated inspection platforms where chemicals are handled or stored. Add clearly marked secondary containment areas with drain-into-absorbent pads. This engineering control provides physical barriers and containment to prevent spills from spreading and reduces skin exposure potential.

name: Implement Quarterly Air Line Coupling Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a formalized quarterly inspection program for all compressed air hose couplings across production lines, with particular focus on high-pressure lines used in maintenance operations. Inspections will document thread condition, corrosion levels, and coupling integrity. Replace any couplings showing signs of corrosion or wear. Integrate into the existing preventive maintenance schedule with documented checklists and sign-offs. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the root cause of the coupling failure.

name: Provide Refresher Training on Equipment Lockout During Material Jams
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all production and maintenance staff on proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures before attempting to clear equipment jams. Training will emphasize that all energy sources, including compressed air, must be isolated and safely dissipated before any maintenance work begins. Include hands-on demonstration of proper hose disconnection techniques using disconnect blocks to control pressure release. Update work instructions with photographic aids showing correct procedures.

name: Establish Separate Operational Zones for Chemical Handling and Forklift Traffic
description: Redesign the layout of the Chemical Storage and Mixing Building to physically separate active chemical transfer operations from forklift traffic routes. Install permanent safety barriers, floor markings, and signage to create dedicated zones. Chemical transfer operations will be relocated to a dedicated workstation with secondary containment systems rated for 110% of the largest container volume. Forklift pathways will be clearly marked with yellow line striping and directional signage. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of concurrent high-risk activities in the same space.

name: Implement Interlock Communication System Between Operations
description: Deploy a two-way radio communication system requiring forklift operators and chemical handlers to confirm all movements before proceeding. Chemical handlers must declare when transfer operations are active; forklift operators must request clearance before entering designated zones. Establish protocol that chemical transfer operations halt immediately when any forklift enters the building. Conduct training on new communication procedures for all affected staff. This administrative control ensures awareness and coordination between concurrent operations.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment and Spill Response Equipment
description: Install expanded secondary containment trays with 120% capacity rating for all epoxy resin storage and transfer areas. Upgrade absorbent pad storage with clearly labeled, easily accessible spill kits positioned within 15 meters of all chemical handling stations. Include eye wash station and safety shower upgrades. Ensure absorbent materials are rated for epoxy resin specifically. This engineering control increases response capability and prevents environmental contamination.

name: Replace UV Spectrophotometer Protective Shields
description: Immediately order and install manufacturer-approved replacement UV-absorbing protective shields for the spectrophotometer unit. Verify all replacement components meet current safety specifications and provide equivalent protection to original design standards. Conduct post-installation verification testing to confirm UV radiation levels are within acceptable limits before returning equipment to service. Document the replacement with serial numbers and dates in the equipment maintenance log. This engineering control directly eliminates the identified UV exposure hazard.

name: Establish UV Equipment Inspection and Maintenance Schedule
description: Create a formal preventive maintenance schedule for all UV equipment in the QC lab with annual inspections by qualified technicians. Incorporate manufacturer recall tracking into the maintenance management system to flag equipment needing component updates. Provide all QC staff with training on UV equipment safety protocols, including proper operation distances and visual monitoring for signs of shield degradation. Maintain documentation of all inspections and maintenance performed. This administrative control ensures ongoing compliance and early detection of future equipment safety issues.

name: Implement Chemical Container Securing Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory requirement that all chemical containers over 5 liters must be secured in transport carts with locking mechanisms before movement. Containers must be inspected for proper cap sealing before transfer. All personnel handling chemicals must complete a competency check before working with hazardous materials. Supply dedicated chemical transport carts with anti-slip surfaces and spill containment trays. Post visual reminders at all chemical storage locations.

name: Enhanced Spill Response Training and Equipment Placement
description: Conduct mandatory spill response training for all warehouse and materials handling personnel, with quarterly refresher sessions. Install spill kits at four strategic locations within the warehouse, each containing absorbent materials, chemical neutralizers, and personal protective equipment. Mark spill kit locations with high-visibility signage. Establish a documented spill response procedure and assign specific roles to trained responders during each shift.

name: Establish Predictive Temperature Sensor Maintenance Program
description: Implement a quarterly calibration schedule for all temperature sensors on injection molding machines, integrated into the existing predictive maintenance program. Install digital monitoring systems that alert supervisors when sensor accuracy drifts beyond acceptable thresholds. Cross-reference sensor readings with infrared thermal cameras during each calibration cycle. Create maintenance logs tracking all calibrations and anomalies. Assign responsibility to Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux for oversight and quarterly audits.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Mold Handling
description: Issue all personnel working with injection molding machines new high-temperature resistant gloves rated for surfaces up to 100°C, replacing standard heat-resistant gloves. Provide training on proper glove selection and inspection before each shift. Require personnel to wear face shields when removing parts from molds, in addition to existing safety glasses. Conduct fit-testing and comfort assessments to ensure compliance. Make PPE availability visible and easily accessible at each workstation.

name: Implement Real-Time LOTO Communication System
description: Install a digital LOTO status dashboard visible in the maintenance workshop and accessible to all shift supervisors via mobile application, displaying current lockouts, tagged-out equipment, and personnel responsible for each energy isolation. Require all shift transitions to include a mandatory 15-minute safety briefing where LOTO status is reviewed. Establish a requirement that any work on equipment with multiple energy sources must have a complete energy isolation verification performed by both the technician and a designated shift supervisor before work commences. Train all supervisory personnel on comprehensive LOTO requirements quarterly.

name: Expand LOTO Training for All Shift Supervisors
description: Conduct comprehensive LOTO certification training for all three shift supervisors, emphasizing multi-source energy isolation procedures specific to hydraulic systems used at TechnoPlast. Implement a competency assessment with annual refresher training. Require supervisors to maintain current knowledge of all equipment energy sources in their areas of responsibility. Establish a mentorship pairing where experienced maintenance technicians shadow supervisors during critical shift transitions to verify LOTO compliance understanding.

name: Implement Mold Temperature Monitoring and Cooldown Procedures
description: Establish a standardized protocol requiring operators to verify mold temperature using non-contact infrared thermometers before performing any maintenance or ejection procedures. All molding machines will be equipped with visual temperature indicators visible from the operator station. A mandatory 5-minute cooldown verification checklist will be implemented before each maintenance task. Operators will document temperature readings in a daily log. This engineering and administrative control combination directly addresses the root cause of insufficient temperature awareness and will prevent similar thermal injuries by ensuring molds reach safe handling temperatures (below 50°C) before contact.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Thermally Insulated Gloves
description: Replace current standard production gloves with specialized heat-resistant gloves rated for sustained contact with surfaces up to 250°C. These gloves will feature advanced insulation materials and improved grip characteristics suitable for molding line operations. All operators on injection molding lines will be fitted and trained on proper glove use. Inventory will be maintained with quarterly replacement cycles. This PPE enhancement provides an additional layer of protection while administrative and engineering controls are reinforced.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification and Quarterly Audits
description: Implement a comprehensive lockout/tagout training program with mandatory certification for all maintenance and setup personnel. A new LOTO audit schedule will require monthly inspections of all equipment with quarterly third-party verification. Audit checklists will specifically verify hasp engagement, electrical isolation confirmation, and energy dissipation procedures. Non-compliance will result in immediate suspension of maintenance privileges until retraining is completed. This administrative control eliminates the root cause of incomplete LOTO procedures and ensures consistent application of critical safety protocols across all production equipment.

name: Install Dual-Channel Safety Interlocks on Chemical Processing Equipment
description: Replace existing single-point electrical lockout systems with redundant dual-channel safety interlocks that require positive confirmation of equipment isolation before startup capability is restored. Install mechanical hasp verification sensors that prevent hopper access unless dual interlocks are engaged. All pneumatic and electrical energy sources will feed through independent control circuits. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of equipment startup during maintenance by creating a physical and electronic barrier that cannot be bypassed by single-point failures.

name: Redesign Hopper Access and Clearing Procedures
description: Engineer a new hopper design with external clearing access ports that eliminate the need for operators to work in proximity to internal rotating equipment. Implement a pneumatic pulsing system for material dislodgement that operates from outside the hazard zone. Develop new standard operating procedures that prohibit manual tools inside hoppers. Provide alternative mechanical jam-clearing methods including vibrating plates and flushing systems. This elimination and substitution strategy removes the operator from the hazard area entirely, providing the highest level of control.

name: Implement Pre-Lift Rigging Inspection and Sign-Off Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory two-person verification process for all loads exceeding 1,000 pounds. Before any lift, both the crane operator and a designated safety spotter must physically inspect all sling connections, anchor points, and load distribution. A pre-lift checklist will be completed and signed by both parties, documented in a daily rigging log. Visual inspection markers will indicate proper sling tension. Weekly training will ensure consistent application. This administrative control addresses the root cause of improper rigging by creating accountability and redundant verification before any load is suspended.

name: Upgrade to Self-Locking Sling System with Tension Indicators
description: Replace standard four-point slings with advanced self-locking sling systems featuring built-in tension indicators that prevent lifting until proper tension is achieved. Install load cells on the crane system that provide real-time feedback to the operator regarding load balance and sling tension. Equipment will include audible and visual alarms if tension drops below safe thresholds during lifting operations. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of loads being lifted with improper rigging by making safe rigging a prerequisite for crane operation.

name: Install Thermal Protective Gloves at All Molding Lines
description: Procure and distribute high-temperature resistant gloves (rated to 250°C) to all injection molding operators at Lines A, B, and D. Conduct mandatory training on proper glove usage and when to inspect for wear. Place glove inspection checklists at each work station. This PPE upgrade will provide immediate protection against accidental contact with hot mold surfaces during normal operations and maintenance activities. Expected outcome: eliminate hand burn incidents from thermal contact.

name: Implement Automated Cooling Verification System
description: Install temperature sensors on injection molding equipment that prevent part removal until mold temperature drops below 80°C. Integrate sensors with machine interlocks so that ejector pins cannot activate until safety threshold is reached. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of operator error in assessing mold readiness. Requires coordination with equipment maintenance and programming support. Expected outcome: prevent all thermally-induced burn incidents from premature part extraction.

name: Conduct Structural Safety Audit of All Storage Systems
description: Engage external structural engineer to inspect all shelving units, wall-mounted racks, and storage systems throughout the facility, particularly the mezzanine storage areas. Identify all units showing signs of metal fatigue, corrosion, or stress fracturing. Document load ratings and compare to actual stored weights. Replace all non-compliant shelving units with new ones rated for 150% of actual load capacity. This engineering control addresses the root cause of the near-miss by eliminating defective infrastructure before failure occurs. Expected outcome: prevent equipment failure incidents.

name: Implement Hopper Handling Procedure and Training
description: Develop written procedure requiring that all hoppers weighing over 25 pounds must be moved using mechanical handling equipment (forklifts or pallet jacks) rather than manual lifting. Create visual signage at storage areas clearly indicating hopper weights and mechanical handling requirements. Conduct mandatory training for all materials handlers and forklift operators. Establish monthly refresher training during safety meetings. This administrative control eliminates manual overload incidents through standardized safe work practices. Expected outcome: reduce shoulder and back injuries from heavy hopper handling.

name: Upgrade Oven Temperature Control Systems with Redundant Safety
description: Replace the existing single-element heating control system on all composite processing ovens with dual-element systems featuring independent thermostats and automatic cutoff at maximum safe temperature. Install real-time digital temperature monitoring with audible and visual alarms when setpoint is exceeded by 5 degrees. This engineering control prevents oven temperature excursions that cause hazardous fume generation. Requires coordination with equipment vendors and a 2-week installation window. Expected outcome: eliminate chemical exposure incidents from equipment malfunction.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Heating Equipment
description: Develop and implement quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all ovens and heating elements. Technicians will perform visual inspection of heating elements, verify thermostat accuracy using calibrated instruments, check electrical connections, and document all findings. Establish replacement schedule for heating elements at 80% of manufacturer-rated lifespan. Create maintenance log visible at each equipment location. This administrative control through preventive maintenance will extend equipment life and prevent sudden failures. Expected outcome: reduce unplanned equipment failures by 90%.

name: Enhance VOC Monitoring and Ventilation Interlocks
description: Install upgraded VOC sensors in the composite processing area with alarm setpoints at 100 ppm, 150 ppm, and 200 ppm. Integrate the 100 ppm alarm with automatic ventilation system increases. At 150 ppm, system triggers automatic oven shutdown and evacuation alarm. Train all operators on alarm responses and establish protocol for stopping work and exiting area when alarms sound. This layered administrative and engineering control approach creates multiple barriers to chemical exposure. Expected outcome: prevent any employee chemical inhalation exposure.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Chemical Storage
description: Implement a secondary containment system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building capable of holding 110% of the largest container volume stored. This engineered control will eliminate the risk of chemical spread to adjacent areas in case of container rupture or spillage. The system will include sloped floors directing spills toward collection points, sealed drain systems, and absorbent material storage stations. Installation will include staff training on containment procedures and monthly inspection protocols to ensure system integrity and compliance with CNESST regulations.

name: Implement Enhanced Chemical Handling Training Program
description: Develop and deliver a mandatory chemical handling competency program focusing on safe transfer procedures, proper grip techniques for containers, awareness of environmental hazards, and emergency response protocols. Training will include hands-on practice with transfer equipment and use of mechanical lifting aids for containers over 10 liters. All personnel working in chemical storage areas must complete certification before handling hazardous materials. Refresher training will be conducted annually and whenever new chemical types are introduced.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Shelving with Safety Features
description: Replace existing storage shelving with commercial-grade chemical storage racks featuring integrated spill containment trays, anti-slip surface coatings, and secondary locking mechanisms on shelf edges. Implement a maximum container stacking height policy and install edge guards to prevent containers from sliding off. All shelves must be secured to walls and floor to prevent tipping during seismic events or accidental impacts. Shelves will be labeled with weight limits and chemical compatibility information.

name: Implement Lockout/Tagout Enforcement for All Electrical Maintenance
description: Establish mandatory LOTO procedures for all equipment maintenance involving electrical systems above 48 volts. All maintenance technicians must de-energize, lock, tag, and verify absence of energy before beginning work. Implement a verification checklist system requiring supervisor sign-off before work begins. Conduct monthly LOTO compliance audits and provide refresher training quarterly. Install prominent LOTO procedure placards on all machine control panels and electrical cabinets with specific hazard voltage warnings. Non-compliance will result in work suspension and additional training requirements.

name: Upgrade Electrical Panel Safety Enclosures and Insulation
description: Replace exposed electrical terminals and wiring in all machine control panels with fully enclosed, arc-rated enclosures meeting or exceeding NFPA 70E standards. Install arc flash warning labels indicating hazard levels and required personal protective equipment (arc-rated clothing, face shields, gloves). Upgrade internal wiring insulation to flame-retardant materials and install thermal monitoring systems to detect overheating conditions. All electrical work will be performed by licensed electricians and verified by independent inspection.

name: Establish Load Securing and Pallet Stacking Standard Operating Procedures
description: Develop comprehensive written procedures for pallet loading, stacking height limits, shrink-wrap application requirements, and load securing specifications for all shift teams. All personnel involved in warehouse operations must receive hands-on training with competency verification before working independently. Implement a pre-shift load inspection checklist that forklift operators must complete before moving any pallet. Include photographic examples of correct and incorrect pallet configurations. Post these procedures at all warehouse stations and in break rooms. Non-compliance will trigger retraining and follow-up verification.

name: Implement Shift Handoff Communication System for Warehouse Operations
description: Create a formal shift-to-shift handoff process requiring the outgoing shift supervisor to document any non-standard load configurations, ongoing projects, or equipment issues on a digital or physical log reviewed by the incoming shift supervisor before operations begin. Include visual inspection walks of all loaded pallets and equipment status verification. Establish communication protocols between warehouse supervisors across shifts via daily briefing meetings or recorded log reviews. This administrative control will ensure continuity of safety practices and prevent knowledge gaps that lead to improper loading.

name: Implement Monthly Pressure Tank Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive monthly inspection program for all pressurized resin storage tanks, focusing on valve assemblies, pressure gauges, and structural integrity. Inspections will be documented in a maintenance log with photographs. Maintenance and Engineering personnel will be trained to identify early signs of valve deterioration. Any tanks showing stress or corrosion will be immediately scheduled for professional maintenance or replacement. This addresses the root cause of inadequate preventive maintenance monitoring.

name: Install Continuous Gas Detection Monitors in Chemical Storage Area
description: Install two wall-mounted continuous air quality monitoring systems in the Materials Management and Warehousing area that detect resin fumes at concentrations below OSHA permissible exposure limits. Monitors will be equipped with audible and visual alarms that trigger at 50% and 100% of action levels. Staff will receive training on alarm response procedures. This engineering control provides real-time detection of hazardous vapor release before personnel can be exposed.

name: Implement Automated Part Deburring Station
description: Install an automated deburring machine specifically designed for the Consumer Packaging line products. This eliminates the manual part removal hazard by removing sharp edges immediately after part ejection while parts are still in the controlled automated system. The engineering solution reduces human contact with hazardous edges by 95%. Training will be provided to operators on the new equipment, and manual deburring will be eliminated for these product lines.

name: Mandatory Cut-Resistant Gloves for Part Removal
description: Issue Level 5 cut-resistant gloves (nitrile-coated nylon with steel reinforcement) to all machine operators and material handlers working on Injection Molding Lines. Gloves must be worn during all part removal and handling operations. Conduct monthly PPE inspections to ensure proper use and condition. Replace damaged gloves immediately. Include glove usage in toolbox talks and annual safety training.

name: Enhanced Part Quality Inspection Process
description: Establish a quality checkpoint immediately after part ejection where a dedicated quality inspector uses tactile and visual assessment to verify edge finish meets specifications. Parts with sharp edges or inadequate deburring will be quarantined for additional processing or scrap. Implement a feedback loop to production control to identify mold wear patterns early. This administrative control ensures defective parts never reach operators.

name: Complete Overhead Crane System Replacement and Certification
description: Replace the entire overhead bridge crane system with a modern unit incorporating redundant brake systems, load limiters, and real-time load monitoring. Install a new emergency descent system that operates independently from primary brakes. All equipment will be certified by a third-party mechanical engineer per ASME B30.2 standards. Conduct full load testing to 125% of rated capacity before returning to service. This eliminates the root cause of brake failure by providing dual fail-safe mechanisms.

name: Implement Crane Maintenance and Inspection Schedule
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all material handling equipment including cranes, forklifts, and lifts. Inspections will follow manufacturer specifications and ASME standards. A certified equipment technician will perform detailed brake assessments, load testing, and structural inspection. Any equipment showing wear or defects will be immediately removed from service until repaired. Maintenance logs will be maintained and reviewed monthly during HSE committee meetings.

name: Establish No-Work-Beneath-Suspended-Loads Policy
description: Implement a facility-wide administrative control prohibiting all personnel from working, standing, or passing beneath any suspended loads, including during maintenance operations. Install yellow and black floor markings in a 20-foot radius beneath all overhead crane paths. Conduct training for all warehouse and maintenance personnel on suspended load hazards and designated safe zones. Include this requirement in daily toolbox talks and annual safety refresher training.

name: Implement Container Sealing and Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory two-person verification system for all chemical container transfers. Each container must be inspected for proper lid sealing by both the operator and a supervisor before transfer. Implement a visual checklist system with color-coded tags (green=verified, red=do not use) placed on each container. Conduct immediate training for all personnel handling chemical containers on proper sealing techniques and inspection procedures. This addresses the root cause of inadequate lid sealing and ensures accountability.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Area Ventilation
description: Install additional mechanical ventilation fans in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room with automatic activation when styrene vapor levels exceed safe thresholds. Add real-time air quality monitoring sensors that trigger alerts at 50% of permissible exposure limits (PEL). Ensure ventilation system maintenance schedule is documented and performed quarterly. This engineering control will minimize vapor accumulation and protect workers from respiratory irritation during normal operations and minor spill events.

name: Establish Spill Response Training Program
description: Develop and deliver mandatory quarterly spill response training for all personnel working in or near the Chemical Storage Building. Training will cover identification of hazardous materials, proper use of absorbent materials, ventilation activation, evacuation procedures, and reporting protocols. Maintain training records and ensure 100% completion. Establish spill response drills conducted bi-annually. This administrative control ensures all personnel are prepared to respond quickly and safely to chemical incidents.

name: Reinstate and Lock Thermal Safety Guards on All Molding Lines
description: Immediately inspect all injection molding machines and ensure all thermal guards are installed and functioning properly. Implement a permanent locking mechanism that requires supervisor authorization and a work order to remove any thermal guard. Create a maintenance log documenting when guards are removed, by whom, and when reinstalled. Conduct a facility-wide audit of all machines on Lines A, B, C, and D. Train maintenance personnel on proper guard removal protocols. This engineering control directly eliminates contact with hot barrel surfaces during routine operations.

name: Mandatory Machine-Specific Burn Prevention Training for All Production Staff
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training to all injection molding operators and technicians covering thermal burn hazards, proper PPE selection (heat-resistant gloves rated to 250°C+), safe maintenance procedures, machine lockout/tagout protocols, and emergency response. Training must be completed before return to work on molding lines. Document completion and provide refresher training quarterly. Include scenarios specific to Lines A, B, C, and D operations. This administrative control ensures workers understand burn hazards and proper prevention methods.

name: Install Continuous Protective Railings on Shipping Dock
description: Complete installation of 42-inch-high protective railings along the entire perimeter of the elevated loading dock, eliminating all gaps. Use welded steel construction with 4-inch maximum opening to prevent accidental falls. Install mid-rails and toe boards for maximum protection. Ensure railings are certified to industry standards and can withstand 200-pound impact force. This engineering control eliminates the fall hazard by providing continuous barrier protection.

name: Apply Anti-Slip Surface Coating to Dock Edge
description: Apply industrial-grade anti-slip coating to all dock edge surfaces and high-traffic areas. The coating must be suitable for wet conditions and maintain traction even when damp. Perform surface preparation to ensure proper adhesion. Reapply coating annually or when wear is observed. This engineering control prevents slips by increasing friction between shoes and the dock surface.

name: Implement Wet Floor Protocols and Signage
description: Establish mandatory wet floor signage protocol requiring prominent yellow warning signs to be placed immediately after cleaning operations in the Shipping Dock area. Require cleaning personnel to notify dock supervisors before beginning cleaning and to complete operations during off-peak hours when feasible. Train all dock personnel to recognize wet surfaces and use additional caution. Provide slip-resistant footwear recommendations or requirements for dock staff. This administrative control ensures workers are aware of hazardous wet conditions.

name: Implement Predictive Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install real-time digital temperature monitoring with automated alerts and manual shutdown capabilities on all industrial ovens. The system will display continuous temperature readings on control panels and alert operators via audible and visual signals if temperatures exceed safe thresholds by 10°C. Integration with the SCADA system will enable remote monitoring from the control room. This engineering control eliminates the risk of undetected temperature spikes by providing continuous supervision and immediate notification to operators and maintenance staff.

name: Establish Quarterly Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Thermal Equipment
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all industrial ovens and curing equipment. Schedule quarterly inspections including calibration of temperature controllers, replacement of thermocouples, and testing of safety interlocks. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance and Engineering team to maintain detailed records. This administrative control addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance by establishing systematic inspection protocols that will detect controller degradation before failures occur.

name: Expand Fire Safety Training for Production Staff
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all production operators on fire emergency procedures, including recognition of fire hazards specific to composite materials, proper use of fire suppression equipment, and evacuation procedures. Training will include practical drills using the facility's suppression systems. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand the specific fire risks in the composite processing area and can respond quickly to prevent escalation.

name: Implement Drum Integrity Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily inspection procedure for all chemical storage drums before transport. Inspections will check for dents, corrosion, rust, and structural integrity. Drums showing any defects will be segregated and replaced. All drums must pass inspection before being moved within the facility. This engineering/administrative control ensures that only safe, intact containers are used for chemical transfers, eliminating the hazard of container failure during handling.

name: Upgrade Chemical Transport Equipment with Secondary Containment
description: Replace existing hand pump transfer systems with mobile chemical transfer carts equipped with integrated secondary containment trays rated for 110% of typical drum volumes. The carts will feature spill-proof sealing mechanisms and absorbent material holders. All personnel will be trained on proper equipment operation. This engineering control provides physical containment capability that will capture any spills during transport before they reach facility floors or drainage systems.

name: Mandate Drum Cap Verification and Tamper-Evident Seals
description: Require all personnel transferring chemicals to verify drum caps are fully tightened and apply tamper-evident seals. Train staff on cap tightening procedures and implement a sign-off checklist. This administrative control adds a verification step to prevent caps from coming loose during transport and provides documentation that proper procedures were followed.

name: Implement LOTO Verification Checklist and Visual Indicators
description: Create a mandatory LOTO verification checklist that must be completed and signed before any maintenance work begins. All machines will have visual indicator tags color-coded by shift: green for day shift, yellow for evening shift, red for night shift. Each shift supervisor must verify and initial the LOTO checklist, and cameras will be installed at key LOTO points on critical machines to provide documentation. This administrative control ensures multiple verification steps and accountability, preventing shortcuts or oversights in LOTO procedures.

name: Mandatory LOTO Retraining for All Production and Maintenance Staff
description: Conduct immediate retraining for all employees who work with injection molding machines, emphasizing the critical importance of LOTO compliance and consequences of non-compliance. Include practical exercises on proper lockout procedures and testing of energy isolation. Implement a certification system where employees must pass a written and practical exam. This administrative control addresses the behavioral root cause by ensuring all personnel understand LOTO requirements and the life-threatening risks of circumventing safety protocols.

name: Install Automatic LOTO Reset Prevention System
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with electromechanical LOTO reset prevention devices that require manual key removal from lockout points before the machine can be powered down. These devices prevent operators from simply pressing emergency stop without properly engaging LOTO. The system will be tested monthly. This engineering control physically prevents the type of circumvention discovered in this incident by making proper LOTO engagement a prerequisite for machine shutdown.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Chemical Storage Areas
description: Install dedicated mechanical ventilation with continuous air exchange rate of minimum 12 air changes per hour in Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Add makeup air system with HEPA filtration to maintain negative pressure and prevent vapor accumulation. Install real-time atmospheric monitoring with automatic exhaust fan activation when solvent vapor concentrations exceed 25% of lower explosive limit. Cost includes ductwork, fans, sensors, and controls integration.

name: Implement Static Electricity Grounding Protocol
description: Install grounding equipment at all resin transfer stations including conductive hoses, grounding straps, and bonding cables to container racks. Conduct training for all personnel handling flammable materials on proper grounding procedures before any transfer operation. Conduct weekly equipment inspections to verify grounding integrity. Add warning signage at all transfer stations indicating static electricity hazards and required grounding procedures.

name: Establish Flammable Material Separation and Storage Standards
description: Reorganize chemical storage layout to maintain minimum 15-foot separation between reactive resin materials and composite material stock. Install fire-rated storage cabinets for high-volatility solvents (segregated from general storage). Implement inventory rotation system (FIFO) and quarterly audit of all stored materials. Update chemical inventory database with volatility ratings and minimum separation requirements for each material type.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Regrind Operations
description: Design and install secondary containment berm around all liquid chemical transfer points in the Regrind and Recycling Department with capacity to contain 150% of largest single container volume. Install drain plugs and collection sumps with manual isolation capability. Implement sloped flooring (minimum 2% grade) directing all potential spills toward contained collection area rather than facility drains. Add absorbent drain filters rated for organic solvents upstream of wastewater system.

name: Establish Spill Response Kit and Emergency Procedures
description: Deploy pre-positioned spill response kits at 4 strategic locations in Regrind Department containing: absorbent pads (500 units), containment barriers, PPE, waste disposal bags, and rapid-response guides. Conduct monthly inspection and replenishment of kits. Implement clear signage identifying kit locations and emergency response procedures in French and English. Train all production personnel on immediate containment actions within first 5 minutes of spill discovery.

name: Upgrade Material Hopper Feedgate Maintenance Program
description: Implement predictive maintenance schedule for all hopper feedgate mechanisms with monthly lubrication, quarterly mechanical testing, and annual replacement of seals and gaskets. Install pressure relief valve on hopper to prevent overfilling. Add visual level indicators to prevent operator overfilling errors. Conduct root cause analysis of feedgate failure and implement design improvements to prevent future malfunction.

name: Replace Resin Hopper with Pressure-Monitored System
description: Replace all existing non-instrumented resin hoppers on Injection Molding Lines with new generation hoppers featuring integrated pressure relief valves, real-time pressure sensors, and automatic shutdown triggers. Install fail-safe mechanisms preventing hopper pressurization above safe operational limits. Add audible and visual alarms when pressure exceeds 80% of safety threshold. Implement quarterly pressure testing certification for all hoppers to ensure relief valve functionality.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protective Equipment (PPE) Standard
description: Issue all production operators working with injection molding equipment with advanced thermal-resistant gloves (rated for 300°C+ exposure) and long-sleeved thermal-barrier shirts made from Nomex or equivalent material. Replace standard work gloves with specialized aluminized gloves providing superior heat insulation. Conduct fit testing and comfort assessment for all personnel. Establish mandatory use policy and weekly inspection protocol to ensure PPE integrity and replacement when damaged.

name: Implement Mandatory Safety Training and Proximity Protocols
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training module on thermal hazards and pressure release risks in injection molding operations. Implement minimum safe working distance (0.5 meters) from active hopper zones during operation and quality checks. Establish buddy system requiring second operator confirmation before any hopper inspection or maintenance. Conduct biannual refresher training for all production staff with emphasis on pressure hazard recognition and emergency response procedures.

name: Install Automated Blockage Detection and Mechanical Shutoff System
description: Install proximity sensors and mechanical interlocks on the regrind machine hopper to detect blockages and automatically shut down the auger before manual intervention is needed. This engineering control eliminates the need for workers to reach into active machinery. Add a remote-operated mechanical auger cleaner that allows clearing blockages from a safe distance. System should prevent operation when maintenance access doors are open.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Gloves and Implement Mandatory Thermal PPE
description: Replace existing gloves with high-temperature rated Nomex or silicone-coated gloves rated for 200°C+ exposure. Mandate use of long-sleeved thermal-resistant shirts for all regrind technicians. Conduct quarterly training on proper PPE selection, fit, and limitations. Establish a documented fit-testing and replacement schedule for all heat-protective equipment. Include thermal burn first aid training for all production and warehouse staff.

name: Establish Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Procedure for Hopper Maintenance
description: Develop and implement a formal LOTO procedure specifically for regrind machine maintenance and blockage clearing. Require all personnel to de-energize, lockout, and tag the equipment before any manual hopper access. Provide annual LOTO certification training. Install energy isolation points and lockout stations adjacent to the regrind area. Create a verification checklist that must be completed before equipment restart.

name: Install Segregated Fire-Rated Waste Storage Containers
description: Replace all existing waste disposal bins in maintenance areas with UL-approved fire-rated metal containers specifically designed for flammable solvent-contaminated rags and materials. Install separate containers for organic solvent waste, oil-based waste, and non-hazardous materials with clear labeling in French and English. Position containers a minimum of 5 meters away from any hot work areas and maintain a 2-meter clearance on all sides. Implement a weekly inspection and disposal schedule to prevent overfilling.

name: Develop and Implement Chemical Waste Segregation Protocol
description: Create a comprehensive waste segregation matrix identifying which materials can be co-stored and which require separate containment based on chemical compatibility (flash point, reactivity, volatility). Train all maintenance and production personnel on proper waste disposal procedures. Establish a monthly audit of waste storage areas by HSE staff. Post visual guides at all waste disposal stations. Include quarterly refresher training focused on common disposal errors.

name: Enhance Hot Work Safety Zone and Fire Watch Procedures
description: Establish a mandatory 10-meter fire-free zone around all hot work operations (grinding, cutting, welding) with clear floor markings and signage. Require a dedicated fire watch observer with direct communication to emergency services during all hot work operations. Install temporary or portable fire extinguishers (ABC and Class D rated) specifically staged within the hot work zone. Implement a sign-in/sign-out log for hot work permits. Conduct quarterly fire watch and emergency response drills.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hopper Systems
description: Establish a quarterly calibration schedule for all hopper level sensors with documented proof of completion. Install backup mechanical floats on critical hoppers to provide redundant overflow protection. Integrate hopper monitoring into the existing CMMS system with automatic work order generation when sensors are due for calibration. This addresses the root cause of sensor failure through engineering controls and administrative procedures. Expected outcome: Zero unplanned hopper overflows and reduced equipment damage.

name: Install Secondary Containment Barriers Around Heat Treatment Equipment
description: Design and install stainless steel drip trays beneath hopper discharge points and main processing units to contain material spills within a confined area. The containment system will be equipped with drain valves for easy cleanup and prevent contamination of adjacent clean room areas. Install absorbent mats in high-risk zones to address slip hazards created by spilled materials. This engineering control will prevent future spills from causing secondary damage and safety hazards.

name: Mandatory Annual Burns Awareness and Prevention Training Audit
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all production staff burn safety training completion records. Implement a mandatory refresher training module covering thermal hazards, safe cool-down procedures, and proper use of thermal protection equipment (insulated gloves, heat-resistant sleeves). Training will be delivered monthly in mandatory 1-hour sessions for all equipment operators. Create a tracking system requiring digital sign-off that feeds into the performance management system. Non-compliance will result in operator certification suspension until training is completed.

name: Install Automatic Thermal Shutdown and Cool-Down Verification System
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with automated cool-down indicator systems that prevent mold access until surfaces reach safe handling temperature (below 60°C). Install infrared temperature sensors on each machine's control panel that display real-time mold temperature and lock the machine access doors until safe conditions are confirmed. Implement a 15-minute mandatory cool-down hold period that cannot be bypassed. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of contact with hot surfaces during normal operations.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protection Equipment (PPE) Requirements
description: Upgrade all production operator heat-resistant gloves to extended wrist protection (minimum 10 inches). Issue new high-temperature rated protective sleeves to all operators working on injection molding lines. Conduct a mandatory fit and comfort assessment during the next safety meeting to ensure compliance and proper usage. Establish a monthly PPE replacement schedule with no-cost replacement to operators. While PPE is the last hierarchy of control, it provides immediate interim protection pending engineering control implementation.

name: Upgrade All Compressed Air Hose Connections and Install Pressure Regulators
description: Replace all compressed air quick-disconnect couplings at dock outlets and production areas with secondary locking mechanisms (ball-lock couplers) that prevent accidental detachment. Install pressure regulators set to maximum 60 PSI at each dock workstation, reducing injury risk from high-pressure discharge. Install whip-check cables on all pressurized hoses over 3 meters in length to prevent uncontrolled movement if connections fail. Conduct a system-wide pressure test to verify safe operating parameters. This engineering control directly eliminates the hazard source.

name: Mandate Compressed Air Safety Training and Certifications for All Night Shift Personnel
description: Develop and deliver a mandatory 2-hour compressed air safety course covering proper hose handling, pressure relief principles, personal protective equipment requirements, and emergency response procedures. Training must be completed by all night shift operators before returning to compressed air-adjacent work. Document completion in the personnel training database and establish an annual refresher requirement. Ensure training content addresses CNESST guidelines and includes hands-on demonstration of safe connection and disconnection procedures.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance for Temperature Controllers
description: Establish a quarterly calibration and functional testing program for all injection molding temperature control systems. Install digital thermometers at each station to cross-verify controller readings. Replace temperature controllers showing drift of more than 5°C from baseline. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause by ensuring early detection of controller malfunction before hazardous conditions develop. Expected outcome: Prevent future temperature-related relief valve activations and reduce risk of chemical exposure incidents.

name: Conduct Resin Vapor Hazard Awareness Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training to all production operators on the hazards of pressurized resin vapor, including symptoms of chemical exposure and proper response procedures. Training will include hands-on demonstration of emergency stop procedures and evacuation protocols. This administrative control ensures operators understand the serious nature of the hazard and can respond appropriately. Expected outcome: Improve operator awareness and response times to potential chemical exposure incidents.

name: Establish Pallet Inspection and Rotation Program
description: Implement a formal daily visual inspection protocol for all pallets in the warehouse, with particular attention to structural integrity and signs of damage. Develop a color-coded tagging system to identify damaged, repaired, or approved pallets. Establish a rotation schedule replacing old pallets quarterly. Provide forklift operators with training on proper load placement to minimize impact stress on pallets. This engineering/administrative control eliminates the risk of pallet failure by ensuring only structurally sound pallets are used. Expected outcome: Prevent material handling incidents related to pallet failure and reduce injury risk in warehouse operations.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Components
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all hydraulic relief valves with quarterly inspection intervals, semi-annual cleaning, and annual replacement of susceptible components. Apply protective marine-grade coatings to all exposed metal surfaces of hydraulic components. Install desiccant breathers on hydraulic fluid reservoirs to reduce moisture ingress and mineral contamination. Maintain detailed maintenance logs for each valve. This engineering control directly addresses the corrosion failure mechanism by implementing proactive replacement before failure occurs. Expected outcome: Eliminate unplanned equipment failures from corrosion, reduce production downtime, and improve system reliability.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Environmental Controls
description: Install dedicated dehumidification units in the Main Production Building hydraulic areas to maintain relative humidity below 50%, reducing moisture-related corrosion of metal components. Add protective shrouds or enclosures around exposed hydraulic lines and fittings in high-humidity zones. Improve ventilation air circulation to prevent localized moisture accumulation. Conduct facility environmental survey to identify other areas with similar humidity problems. This engineering control modifies the environment to be less corrosive, preventing future corrosion-related failures. Expected outcome: Reduce corrosion damage to hydraulic and electrical components throughout the facility.

name: Implement Quarterly HVAC Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a rigorous preventive maintenance program for all ventilation systems with quarterly inspections, motor testing, damper valve functionality checks, and filter replacements. Maintenance logs will be tracked in the facility management system with alerts for upcoming service dates. This addresses the root cause of deferred maintenance contributing to system failure. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in unplanned ventilation failures.

name: Install Automatic Backup Ventilation System with Redundant Controls
description: Replace the existing manual damper valve with an automatic dual-controller backup activation system that independently monitors primary and secondary ventilation units. Install real-time air quality sensors (VOC and particulate monitors) with audible alarms at 50% and 75% of exposure limits. System will automatically engage backup ventilation and alert facility control room. Engineering control will eliminate cascade failures and provide early warning for future issues.

name: Conduct Emergency Response Training and Drill Program
