description: Design and install a redundant ventilation system for critical production areas (Regrind/Recycling and chemical mixing) capable of maintaining minimum air exchange rates during primary system failure. System should include independent power supply and automated switchover capability. Install real-time monitoring with audible alarms at workstations when air quality degrades. Conduct full system testing monthly. Expected outcome: ensure continuous safe working conditions even during primary system maintenance or emergency failure.

name: Emergency Response Training for Ventilation Failures
description: Develop and implement specialized training for all evening and night shift supervisors covering emergency procedures for ventilation system failures. Training includes rapid evacuation protocols, respiratory protection requirements, emergency shutdown procedures, and communication protocols. Conduct drills quarterly. Ensure all personnel understand respiratory irritation warning signs and medical response procedures. Expected outcome: reduce confusion and response time during future equipment emergencies.

name: Install Backup Warning Systems on All Material Handling Equipment
description: Equip all forklifts and powered material handling equipment with audible backup alarms (minimum 97 dB), visual flashing warning lights, and side-proximity sensors. Ensure alarms are functioning daily and documented in pre-operation checklists. Install backup cameras on forklifts as secondary visual aids. Require all operators to complete annual recertification including backup procedures and blind spot management. Expected outcome: prevent pedestrian-equipment near-misses and collisions by 90%.

name: Establish Dock Safety Zones and Communication Protocol
description: Paint and mark clear pedestrian pathways, equipment zones, and safe standing areas on the dock floor using high-visibility floor markings (yellow/black striping). Install traffic control mirrors at blind corners and intersections. Implement a mandatory communication protocol: dock personnel must use radio communication to confirm equipment movement before forklifts approach loading areas. Establish dedicated receiving personnel positions at safe distances from equipment paths. Conduct briefing meetings at shift start covering dock traffic patterns. Expected outcome: eliminate confusion about right-of-way and create predictable, controlled dock operations.

name: Implement Dock Safety Training and Competency Certification
description: Develop comprehensive dock safety training covering pedestrian and equipment operator responsibilities, blind spot awareness, communication protocols, and emergency procedures. Require all dock personnel to complete training and pass practical assessment. Require all forklift operators to participate in specialized dock operation training with focus on equipment visibility limitations and pedestrian awareness. Establish annual recertification requirement. Expected outcome: create consistent, safety-aware behavior among all dock personnel and equipment operators.

name: Implement Daily CNC Deburring Machine Calibration Checks
description: Establish a mandatory daily calibration verification protocol for the CNC deburring equipment to detect drift before it affects part quality. The Tool Room Supervisor will conduct daily checks at the start of each shift using precision gauges. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate edge finishing. Maintenance logs will track all calibrations, and any deviation exceeding 0.5mm will trigger immediate machine servicing before production resumes.

name: Upgrade to Cut-Resistant Gloves for Part Handling
description: Replace standard nitrile gloves with ANSI Level A3 cut-resistant gloves for all production operators handling parts with machined edges. These gloves provide superior protection against sharp plastic edges while maintaining dexterity for precision work. All production staff will receive fitting and proper usage training. This engineering/PPE control provides an additional layer of protection while the deburring process is optimized.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Lighting to Code-Compliant Levels
description: Install additional LED lighting fixtures in the southeast section of Raw Materials Warehouse to achieve minimum 200 lux illumination throughout all work areas. This includes 8 new 150W LED panels positioned to eliminate shadows and dark corners. The engineering control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate visibility that contributed to the near-miss. Lighting will be installed within two weeks, and illumination levels will be verified with a light meter. This is a primary control from the hierarchy of controls.

name: Implement Monthly Equipment Inspection for Hose and Cable Security
description: Establish a monthly preventive maintenance routine specifically targeting air hoses, electrical cables, and their mounting brackets throughout the warehouse and production areas. Maintenance staff will inspect all fasteners, brackets, and connections for signs of loosening or wear. A checklist will be maintained and filed. This administrative control, combined with preventive maintenance, ensures that trip hazards are identified and corrected before they create incidents. Loose fasteners will be immediately re-secured or brackets replaced as needed.

name: Develop and Implement Mandatory Pre-Lift Safety Checklist
description: Create a standardized, laminated pre-lift inspection checklist that must be completed and signed off by the crane operator before any load exceeding 500 kg is lifted. The checklist will include: rigging strap seating verification, load weight confirmation, personnel clearance confirmation, and equipment condition assessment. All crane operators and rigging personnel will acknowledge receipt of the checklist procedure. This administrative control creates a systematic verification process that ensures human error in rigging setup is caught before loads are elevated. The checklist will be posted at the crane control station.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Rigging and Load Security Training
description: Arrange certified training for all crane operators, rigging coordinators, and maintenance personnel involved in material handling. Training will cover proper rigging strap installation, load weight calculations, rigging hardware inspection, and pre-lift verification procedures. Each participant will complete hands-on practice with supervision. Training certification will be valid for 24 months. This administrative/training control addresses the root cause of inadequate knowledge and ensures that all personnel understand the critical importance of proper rigging setup in preventing falling load incidents.

name: Implement Strict Thermostat Calibration Schedule
description: Establish a mandatory monthly thermostat calibration and inspection protocol for all resin dryers, with documented verification records. Assign Maintenance Technician Luc Girard to conduct calibrations on the first Monday of each month, with a backup technician assigned to ensure continuity. Create alert system in preventive maintenance software to flag any gaps in scheduling. Calibration records will be reviewed quarterly by the HSE Coordinator to ensure compliance.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring Alert System
description: Install automated temperature monitoring sensors on all resin dryers with real-time alerts to the production supervisor's mobile device when temperatures exceed safe ranges. System will integrate with existing production management software and create automatic email notifications to the HSE office. This engineering control will provide continuous oversight and enable rapid response to equipment malfunctions without reliance on operator observation alone.

name: Enhanced Operator Training on Equipment Malfunction Recognition
description: Develop comprehensive training module for all production operators focusing on recognizing early warning signs of dryer malfunctions including temperature anomalies, unusual sounds, and odors. Include quarterly refresher training and competency assessments. Training materials will be bilingual (French/English) and include visual aids specific to each production line. Operators will be certified to recognize hazards and immediately notify supervisors, following strict procedures to never attempt independent repairs.

name: Supply Cut-Resistant Gloves at All Part Handling Stations
description: Procure and distribute ANSI Level 4 cut-resistant gloves (nitrile-coated) to all workstations where composite parts are manually handled, especially shipping and receiving areas. Ensure gloves are readily available in multiple sizes and that workers are trained on proper selection and use. PPE inventory will be tracked monthly by the Chemical Inventory Specialist to maintain adequate stock levels at all locations.

name: Implement Part Burr Removal and Quality Control Process
description: Establish mandatory deburring and finishing inspection protocol before parts are released from production lines. Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le will conduct visual and tactile inspections of all finished components, particularly those destined for manual assembly or shipping. Parts with sharp edges or burrs will be routed to a designated finishing station where Tool Maker René Caron will remove rough edges using appropriate equipment. This engineering control eliminates the source hazard before parts reach handlers.

name: Comprehensive Storage Rack Inspection and Releveling Program
description: Conduct immediate professional inspection of all storage racks in the warehouse and materials management areas by a certified structural engineer. Identify racks with settling, misalignment, or structural defects. All racks will be releveled, anchored to floor, and inspected quarterly thereafter. Documentation will include load ratings, inspection dates, and corrective actions taken. Any racks found unsafe will be immediately removed from service.

name: Implement Monthly Storage Rack Safety Audit Protocol
description: Establish formal monthly inspection checklist for all storage systems covering level alignment, anchor bolts, structural integrity, weight distribution, and load capacity compliance. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance will lead monthly audits with participation from Maintenance staff. Audit results will be documented in the ISO 45001 management system and reviewed at monthly JHSC meetings. Any deficiencies will trigger immediate corrective action and work orders.

name: Install Load-Limiting Devices and Height Restriction Signage
description: Install weight limit indicators on each storage rack shelf clearly showing maximum load capacity. Add warning signage at 5-foot height indicating maximum manual stacking height to prevent workers from overloading upper shelves. Install load-limiting stops on lower shelves to prevent bag shifting. These engineering and administrative controls will reduce settling pressure and create visual cues to prevent unsafe stacking practices.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic systems on injection molding lines, with quarterly inspections and seal replacement every 12 months. This will include detailed documentation of maintenance activities, pressure tests, and fluid analysis. The program will be coordinated with the Maintenance and Engineering department to ensure timely identification of worn components before failure occurs. Expected outcome: Reduce unplanned equipment shutdowns by 85% and extend pump service life.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Drip Trays
description: Install secondary containment systems beneath all hydraulic pump assemblies in the production area to capture leaked fluid and prevent floor contamination. Drip trays will have 150% capacity of the largest system reservoir. This engineering control will minimize environmental impact, reduce cleanup time, and prevent slipping hazards from spilled hydraulic oil. Include absorbent material stations nearby for immediate spill response.

name: Upgrade Control Panel Emergency Response Logic
description: Reprogram the Line D control panel to include independent mechanical emergency stop circuits that do not rely on hydraulic pressure. Install a backup pressure relief system that automatically activates if primary pressure control fails. This will ensure emergency shutdown capability remains functional even during hydraulic system failures, protecting equipment integrity and personnel safety.

name: Conduct Structural Inspection and Certification of Storage Racks
description: Engage a qualified structural engineer to conduct a comprehensive inspection of all storage racks throughout the facility, including load-bearing capacity assessment, bolt tightness verification, and corrosion evaluation. Replace all corroded bolts and welds with stainless steel fasteners rated for warehouse applications. Provide certification for continued use and establish annual inspection protocol. This engineering control will eliminate the risk of structural failure and prevent future collapse incidents.

name: Install Load Capacity Signage and Weight Limits
description: Install permanent, visible signage on each storage rack section clearly indicating maximum load capacity per level and overall rack load limits. Develop and distribute a visual work instruction guide to all forklift operators and warehouse staff showing proper loading procedures and weight distribution requirements. Conduct mandatory refresher training for all warehouse personnel within 30 days. This administrative control ensures operators understand and respect equipment limitations.

name: Enhance Burr Detection and Removal Procedures
description: Implement mandatory secondary inspection protocol for all injection-molded parts before packaging. Train all production technicians on identifying sharp edges and burrs using tactile and visual inspection methods. Establish quality checkpoints at each molding station with specialized burr removal tools (files, deburring machines). Create a daily inspection log requiring technicians to sign off on parts meeting burr-free standards. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in sharp edge injuries within 60 days.

name: Mandatory Pressure Gauge Calibration Program
description: Establish a comprehensive pressure gauge calibration and replacement schedule for all hydraulic equipment. Implement quarterly calibration by certified technicians using NIST-traceable equipment. Install pressure gauges with clear visual indicators and alarm thresholds. Maintain a digital log of all calibrations with automatic alerts 30 days before recalibration dates. All technicians must verify gauge readings match actual system pressure before beginning maintenance work.

name: Enhanced LOTO Verification Procedure
description: Implement a two-person verification system for lockout/tagout procedures on all high-pressure hydraulic equipment. Require a second qualified technician to independently verify system depressurization using backup pressure measurement devices before maintenance begins. Introduce redundant safety lockout devices on critical equipment. Conduct monthly LOTO audits with random spot-checks of active maintenance work. Provide recertification training to all maintenance personnel within 30 days.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Hazardous Materials Storage
description: Install certified secondary containment tray systems with minimum 110% capacity for all chemical drums (polyester resin, epoxy, solvents) stored in UNIT-018. Containment trays must be non-absorbent, chemically resistant polypropylene with sloped floors for drainage into collection sumps. All drums must be stored on stable metal pallet racks (not wooden pallets) secured to prevent tipping. Clearly label all containment areas with hazmat signage and safety data sheet (SDS) information. Provide quarterly inspections to ensure tray integrity and drain valve functionality.

name: Enhanced Chemical Handling and Spill Response Training
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all warehouse and production staff on proper chemical handling procedures, spill containment techniques, and emergency response protocols. Training must include hands-on practice with absorbent materials, proper PPE selection (chemical-resistant gloves, splash goggles, respiratory protection), and use of eye wash stations. Establish spill response kits at strategic locations with clearly marked absorbent materials, spill pillows, and collection containers. Implement a monthly testing protocol to verify employee knowledge through written assessments.

name: Upgrade Material Transfer Equipment and Procedures
description: Replace all manual hand truck-based material transfer methods with motorized electric pallet jacks for hazardous chemical drums. Eliminate wooden pallets completely from hazmat storage areas, substituting with metal pallet racks that have load-rated capacity plates. Implement a controlled transfer protocol requiring two-person teams, with designated pathways and reduced speed limits (maximum 3 mph) in warehouse areas. Install spill prevention containment mats on all material transfer routes.

name: Replace and Upgrade Heat Shielding on Line D Molding Machines
description: Install new high-temperature composite heat shields rated for continuous exposure to 300°C+ on all injection molding barrels in the Consumer Packaging line. Shields will completely encircle the heated barrels and extend to cover the material hopper interface. Thermal testing will be conducted post-installation to verify adequate protection. This engineering control eliminates direct contact with hot surfaces during normal operations and material changeover.

name: Implement Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a daily inspection procedure where operators check their heat-resistant gloves for damage, deterioration, or reduced protective capability before each shift. Damaged gloves must be immediately replaced from inventory. Supervisors will conduct weekly compliance audits. All operators will receive refresher training on proper glove selection, donning, and inspection. This administrative control ensures workers always have appropriate PPE protection.

name: Implement Daily Floor Inspection and Spill Management Protocol
description: Establish mandatory daily floor inspections in the warehouse and shipping dock areas to identify and immediately address spills, debris, and slip hazards. Create a spill response procedure requiring immediate containment, cleanup, and documentation. All maintenance work must be performed in designated areas with secondary containment systems. Maintenance personnel will be held accountable for cleanup before departing. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of the tip-over incident.

name: Install Traction Control Floor Matting in High-Traffic Warehouse Areas
description: Install anti-slip adhesive-backed floor matting in the warehouse aisles, dock approach zones, and turning areas where equipment is regularly operated. Matting will be rated for forklift tire traction and regular replacement schedule will be established. This engineering control provides an additional protective barrier against slipping incidents even if minor spills occur.

name: Provide Advanced Forklift Operation Training with Emphasis on Surface Conditions
description: Conduct comprehensive refresher training for all forklift operators focusing on hazard recognition, surface condition assessment, speed adjustment for wet/slippery conditions, and proper maneuvering techniques in confined warehouse spaces. Training will include scenario-based decision-making exercises. All operators will be recertified before returning to duty. This training-based administrative control enhances operator capability to recognize and respond to environmental hazards.

name: Install Automated Resin Transfer System with Pump Dispensers
description: Replace manual siphon pump and gravity transfer methods with automated dispenser pumps mounted on resin storage tanks. These systems will eliminate the need for manual container handling during transfer operations. Operators will simply position the receiving vessel beneath the dispenser and activate the controlled pump. This engineering control eliminates the grip-and-slip hazard while also improving accuracy and safety of chemical transfers.

name: Implement Enhanced Chemical Container Labeling and Replacement Program
description: Establish a quarterly container inspection and relabeling program to ensure all chemical containers maintain clear, legible labeling with product name, hazard warnings, and handling instructions in English and French. Any container with faded, damaged, or illegible labels will be immediately removed from service. New high-visibility weatherproof labels will be applied. A barcode tracking system will also be implemented to monitor container status.

name: Implement Cable and Hose Management System
description: Install cable trays and hose routing clips along all production lines to organize and elevate air hoses, hydraulic lines, and electrical cables off the floor. This engineering control will eliminate trip hazards by creating defined pathways for all utilities. Conduct a complete audit of cable routing in the main production building and retrofit non-compliant areas with properly installed cable management infrastructure. Training will be provided to all operators on the new system. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in trip hazards from floor-level cables and hoses.

name: Establish Daily Hose and Cable Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a daily pre-shift inspection checklist for all machine operators that includes verification of pneumatic hose connections, electrical cable integrity, and floor clearance. Machine Setters will document findings on a checklist posted at each line and report any issues immediately to the Production Supervisor. This administrative control establishes accountability and early detection of hazards. Training on proper hose connection techniques will be included in the monthly machine operator refresher sessions.

name: Install Ergonomic Assist Device for Part Removal
description: Procure and install a pneumatic-assisted component extraction system (degating assist tool) at the assembly station to reduce manual gripping force required during part removal. This engineering control eliminates the root cause by replacing manual twisting and pulling with mechanized assist. The device will reduce repetitive strain on wrist and forearm by 85-90%. Installation will include operator training on proper use and maintenance. Alain Mercier, the Ergonomics Specialist, will oversee selection and installation to ensure optimal positioning and accessibility for operators of varying heights.

name: Implement Job Rotation and Micro-Break Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory job rotation schedule rotating assembly operators between part removal and quality inspection tasks every 90 minutes to distribute physical demands across different muscle groups. Implement mandatory 5-minute micro-breaks every 2 hours involving stretching exercises targeting wrists, forearms, and shoulders. Alain Mercier will develop customized ergonomic stretching guides and train all production staff. This administrative control reduces cumulative strain by varying work tasks and allowing muscle recovery periods. Supervisors will track compliance using a daily log.

name: Provide Wrist Support PPE and Ergonomic Training
description: Distribute high-quality neoprene wrist braces to all assembly operators and train them on proper fitting and use during high-repetition tasks. Conduct comprehensive ergonomic training for all line operators covering proper posture, wrist positioning, tool handling techniques, and early warning signs of RSI. Training will include practical demonstrations and video resources in both English and French. This PPE control provides supplementary support while administrative and engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Install Flexible Duct Guards and Strain Relief
description: Install protective guards and strain relief clamps around all flexible air ducts in the Material Drying room and material handling areas to prevent mechanical disconnection from equipment movement. These engineering controls will protect critical connections from accidental impact while allowing flexibility for necessary adjustments. Guards will be constructed from impact-resistant polymer and installed at heights vulnerable to pallet and hand truck contact. This eliminates the root cause of duct disconnection.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring and Alert System
description: Install wireless temperature sensors in the Material Drying room and adjacent material handling area with automated alerts triggered when temperatures exceed safe operating thresholds (>35°C). The system will alert operators via audible alarm and mobile notifications to facility management. This administrative/engineering control provides early detection of thermal hazards and enables rapid response. Integrate monitoring data into the facility's SCADA system for real-time oversight.

name: Implement Machine Adjustment Documentation and Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory work order system for all equipment adjustments that includes pre- and post-adjustment speed/pressure verification. All maintenance personnel must document baseline settings, adjustment rationale, and verification results. A supervisor must sign off on each adjustment before the equipment returns to production. This engineering and administrative control addresses the root cause of inadequate communication between maintenance and operations. Expected outcome: Elimination of unauthorized or unverified equipment parameter changes within 30 days.

name: Enhanced Emergency Stop Button Training and Monthly Drills
description: Conduct comprehensive training on proper emergency stop procedures for all production line operators, emphasizing response protocols and equipment safeguards. Institute monthly practice drills where operators must demonstrate correct emergency stop usage and notification procedures. Include training on recognizing equipment anomalies and safe shutdown sequences. This administrative control reinforces proper response capabilities and builds institutional knowledge of emergency procedures.

name: Develop Formal Regrind Material Quality Assurance Procedure
description: Create comprehensive written procedure for regrind material inspection that includes visual inspection criteria, batch documentation requirements, and traceability protocols. Procedure must specify acceptance/rejection criteria, storage requirements, and maximum shelf life for regrind materials. Implement batch labeling system with date received and inspection results. For medical device lines, maintain separate regrind batches with documented testing. This administrative control ensures consistent quality verification and compliance with ISO 13485 requirements.

name: Install Enhanced Lighting in Regrind Inspection Area
description: Upgrade lighting in the regrind material inspection station to minimum 500 lux intensity, with color-corrected LED fixtures to enable accurate detection of foreign particles and material discoloration. Install task lighting directly over inspection workstations. This engineering control directly addresses vision-related hazards and improves accuracy of visual inspection procedures, reducing reliance on operator vigilance alone.

name: Implement Monthly Overhead Crane Inspection Protocol with Documented Tracking
description: Establish formal monthly inspection schedule for all overhead cranes, including detailed visual and tactile examination of cables, hooks, pulleys, and electrical components. Inspections must be performed by certified crane technicians and documented in a centralized maintenance log. Any defects must generate immediate work orders with automatic equipment tagging. Create visual inspection checklist specific to fraying, kinks, and corrosion. This engineering and administrative control prevents catastrophic failures through early detection.

name: Mandatory Crane Operation and Hazard Recognition Training Refresh
description: Conduct comprehensive refresher training for all personnel operating or working near overhead cranes, with emphasis on visual inspection protocols before load lifting, recognition of cable and equipment defects, and proper tagging procedures. Include case studies of crane-related incidents in manufacturing environments. Document training attendance and competency verification. This administrative control reinforces vigilance and builds a safety culture of proactive equipment inspection.

name: Upgrade Chemical Transfer Equipment with Secondary Containment
description: Install secondary containment trays (stainless steel, 15-gallon capacity) beneath all acetone transfer stations in Material Drying and Preparation Room. Upgrade pump coupling connections to quick-disconnect fittings with integrated backflow preventers and drip trays. Implement mandatory monthly inspection and pressure testing of all transfer equipment. Training will be provided to all material handlers on proper connection procedures and spill response. This engineering control eliminates the risk of uncontained spills and reduces environmental contamination.

name: Chemical Spill Response Training and Drills
description: Develop and implement quarterly chemical spill response training for all production and material handling staff. Training will cover identification of hazardous materials, proper use of absorbent materials, containment procedures, evacuation protocols, and emergency reporting. Conduct monthly tabletop drills and semi-annual full-scale spill simulation exercises. Create laminated quick-reference guides posted at all chemical storage and transfer areas. Documentation of training completion will be maintained in employee files.

name: Install Real-Time Vapor Detection System
description: Install continuous air quality monitors with audible alarms in the Material Drying and Preparation Room to detect acetone vapor concentrations exceeding 500 ppm (10% of OSHA PEL). Alarms will automatically trigger local ventilation boost and notify facility management. Integration with building management system will enable remote monitoring. Monthly calibration will be performed by certified technician. This administrative control provides early warning of chemical vapor hazards.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Filters
description: Establish monthly pre-filter inspection and quarterly replacement schedule for all air handling systems in Composite Materials Processing Area. Maintenance logs will be maintained digitally with automatic reminders to maintenance team. Pressure differential gauges will be installed on all filter banks to provide visual indication of filter saturation. HVAC system performance will be tested monthly using aerosol photometer to confirm dust removal efficiency remains above 95%. This administrative control ensures consistent air quality and prevents accumulation of hazardous fiber dust.

name: Replace All Mixing Tank Discharge Valves with Redundant Safety Design
description: Replace all existing discharge valves on resin mixing tanks in Regrind and Recycling Department with dual-ball valve assemblies featuring integral check valves and accessible isolation points. Install pressure relief valves set at 110% of system operating pressure. Implement torque wrench specifications (displayed on valve assembly in foot-pounds) for all connections with color-coded wrench indicators. Conduct training for all maintenance personnel on proper valve assembly and torque specifications. This engineering control eliminates discharge valve failures as a spill source.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Program for Fluid Systems
description: Implement quarterly ultrasonic testing and vibration analysis of all resin mixing tanks, discharge piping, and valve assemblies to detect early signs of mechanical degradation or misalignment. Establish maintenance tracking database with automatic work order generation when condition indicators exceed threshold values. Train maintenance technicians on ultrasonic inspection techniques. Generate monthly predictive maintenance reports for review by HSE department. This administrative control prevents catastrophic valve failures through early detection.

name: Implement Daily Emergency Stop Button Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a formal daily inspection checklist requiring shift leads to verify all emergency stop buttons are fully accessible and free of obstructions before production start. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause—obstructed emergency controls preventing rapid machine shutdown. Inspections will be logged in the maintenance system and reviewed during monthly JHSC meetings. Expected outcome: 100% accessibility of emergency controls and documented compliance.

name: Install Additional Machine Guard Sensing System on Line D
description: Install proximity sensors on the output tray area of the injection molding machine that will automatically halt the ejection cycle if an operator's hand is detected in the pinch point zone. This engineering control adds a mechanical safeguard independent of operator awareness. The system will include redundant sensors and emergency reset capability. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of pinch point injuries at this machine through automated protection.

name: Conduct Refresher Training on Pinch Point Hazards
description: Mandatory 2-hour retraining session for all production operators on Line D focusing on pinch point identification, proper hand positioning during part ejection, and emergency response procedures. Include case study analysis of this incident. Training will be delivered by the HSE team with attendance tracking and competency assessment. Expected outcome: Increased operator awareness and consistent safe work practices across all shifts.

name: Establish Wet Floor Management and Drainage Procedures
description: Create a comprehensive written procedure for post-cleaning operations in hazardous waste areas specifying: minimum drying time (2 hours), placement of wet-floor warning signs in high-traffic zones, use of non-slip mats during cleaning, and verification of dry conditions before resuming normal operations. All cleaning staff will receive training on this procedure. Implement a daily checklist for area supervisors to confirm floors are safe. Expected outcome: Elimination of slip hazards caused by wet surfaces.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring in Chemical Storage Zones
description: Replace the existing smooth concrete flooring in the hazardous waste management area with commercial-grade anti-slip epoxy coating designed for chemical environments. This engineering control provides permanent slip resistance even when wet. The coating meets industrial safety standards and is compatible with the chemical substances stored in this zone. Installation will occur during a scheduled facility closure. Expected outcome: Substantially reduced slip risk across the entire chemical storage zone.

name: Implement Mandatory Bin Stacking and Restraint System
description: Install heavy-duty metal shelf restraint brackets and implement a revised stacking protocol limiting warehouse bins to maximum 3 units per vertical stack with mandatory lateral safety clips connecting stacks to shelf frames. All personnel will receive hands-on training demonstrating proper installation and verification procedures. Implement a weekly inspection schedule with photographic documentation. Non-compliance will result in immediate corrective action. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of falling material hazards from storage racks.

name: Redesign Warehouse Storage Layout with Safety Zones
description: Reorganize the finished goods warehouse to implement exclusion zones directly beneath high shelving where no personnel are permitted during inventory operations. Relocate frequently accessed items to lower shelf heights (below 1.2 meters). Install overhead protective mesh netting in high-traffic areas as secondary containment. Create separate inventory station at ground level with organized staging area. Expected outcome: Reduced exposure to falling materials through elimination of work beneath elevated storage.

name: Mandatory Competency Assessment for Warehouse Staff
description: Develop and administer comprehensive training program on materials handling, load stability, and shelf management for all warehouse personnel. Include certification requirement with annual recertification. Program includes hazard recognition, proper stacking techniques, load capacity calculations, and emergency response. Supervisors will conduct monthly spot-checks during shifts to verify compliance. Expected outcome: Enhanced worker competency and consistent adherence to safe storage practices.

name: Implement Mandatory Hydraulic System Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all injection molding machines' hydraulic systems, including the relief valve inspection and replacement every 500 operating hours. Create a digital tracking system integrated with the production scheduling software to prevent maintenance scheduling oversights. Train all operators and maintenance personnel on the critical importance of pressure relief valve functionality. Implement weekly visual inspections of hydraulic components and monthly full system diagnostics.

name: Install Automated Mold Position Sensors and Interlocks
description: Install advanced position sensors on all injection molding machines to detect when a mold is closing unexpectedly or at an incorrect pressure threshold. These sensors will automatically trigger an emergency stop if operator hands are detected in the cavity during the closing cycle. Retrofit existing machines with mechanical interlocks that prevent mold closure if the safety gate is open or if hands are in the work zone. This engineering control eliminates the reliance on operator vigilance alone.

name: Enhance Machine Guarding Training and Safety Procedures
description: Conduct immediate retraining for all production operators on injection molding machine hazards, focusing on the dangers of hydraulic system failures. Implement a 'two-person verification' procedure where operators must confirm all pressure systems are stable before beginning the part removal process. Create visual warning labels on each machine displaying pressure relief valve inspection dates. Establish a near-miss reporting system where operators report any unusual machine behavior.

name: Install Mechanical Pallet Jacks and Material Handling Equipment
description: Provide all material handlers with access to electric pallet jacks and ergonomic lifting carts in the Finished Goods Warehouse. These mechanical aids will eliminate the need for manual lifting of loads exceeding 25 pounds. Implement a strict policy prohibiting manual lifting of pallets over 30 pounds. Install height-adjustable workstations to reduce reaching and bending. This engineering control removes the hazard at its source by eliminating heavy manual lifting.

name: Implement Mandatory Ergonomics Training and Assessments
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomics training for all warehouse personnel, covering proper lifting techniques, load limits, and body mechanics. Include hands-on demonstrations and video resources in both French and English. Perform individual ergonomic assessments for each material handler to identify personal risk factors. Establish a system where workers report any pain or discomfort immediately. Include ergonomic refresher training quarterly and document all training sessions.

name: Establish Chemical Storage and Labeling Compliance Program
description: Implement a comprehensive WHMIS compliance audit of all chemical storage areas in the Composite Materials Processing unit. Create clear, color-coded labeling for all chemical containers and storage cabinets. Establish designated zones for chemical storage with clear signage in French and English. Conduct immediate retraining for all workers on chemical hazard identification and proper PPE selection. Implement a monthly compliance audit and assign responsibility for maintaining proper labeling and organization. Create a checklist system for supervisors to verify compliance weekly.

name: Install Secondary Containment Protection and Emergency Access Clearance Protocol
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all secondary containment systems for resin and chemical tanks. Remove all obstructions and establish a 2-meter clearance zone around all emergency equipment including pressure relief valves, emergency stop buttons, and spill response kits. Install clear floor markings and warning signs indicating emergency equipment zones. Implement a monthly inspection schedule documented on a facility-wide checklist. Assign specific responsibility to the Maintenance team to verify clearance weekly.

name: Strengthen Night Shift Safety Culture and Supervision
description: Implement enhanced safety supervision protocols for the night shift, including mandatory safety briefings at shift start and a designated safety compliance officer present during all night operations. Provide safety glasses and ensure 100% compliance through regular spot-checks with non-compliance consequences. Create a night-shift specific safety communication board with highlighted hazards for that shift. Conduct weekly safety meetings specific to night shift operations. Implement a peer observation program where workers report unsafe acts to supervisors confidentially.

name: Implement Production Status Communication System
description: Establish a daily production status log that is shared between Production Operations, Quality Control, and Post-Processing teams. This log will track equipment status, maintenance schedules, and any deviations from standard processing procedures. A morning briefing will be conducted at shift change to communicate all relevant status updates. Electronic notifications will alert QC staff when parts bypass standard processing steps, ensuring proper inspection protocols are adjusted accordingly. This administrative control will prevent similar incidents by ensuring all teams have real-time visibility into production process changes.

name: Enhance Personal Protective Equipment Requirements in QC Lab
description: Upgrade QC lab PPE requirements to include reinforced nitrile gloves (cut-resistant Level 3) and safety glasses with side shields for all personnel handling freshly molded components. Provide training on proper donning and inspection of PPE. Establish a replacement schedule for damaged gloves and eye protection. Create visual signage in the QC lab identifying high-risk component types that require enhanced PPE. This engineering and PPE control will reduce the severity of potential laceration incidents involving plastic part burrs and sharp edges.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for E-Stop Systems
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program specifically for all emergency stop systems facility-wide. Schedule quarterly inspections and testing of all E-stop buttons, mechanisms, and electrical contacts. Create a standardized checklist that includes visual inspection for corrosion, functional testing, and electrical continuity verification. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance and Engineering department. Document all inspections in the maintenance management system with photographic evidence. Replace any corroded or non-functional E-stop components immediately. This administrative and engineering control will prevent future failures of critical safety systems and ensure compliance with occupational safety standards.

name: Install Protective Enclosures for E-Stop Buttons
description: Install weatherproof, UV-resistant protective enclosures around all emergency stop buttons throughout the facility, particularly in high-moisture areas like the Material Drying Room and Post-Processing and Heat Treatment zones. These enclosures will include ventilation to prevent moisture accumulation while protecting components from direct water spray and chemical exposure. Ensure enclosures are transparent or feature clear indicator windows so the red E-stop button remains visible and accessible. Provide training to all operators on proper use of enclosures while maintaining E-stop accessibility. This engineering control will reduce corrosion and extend the service life of critical safety equipment.

name: Implement Equipment-Specific Lockout/Tagout Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive LOTO training specifically tailored to the regrind and recycling equipment in UNIT-018. Training will cover: identification of all energy sources (electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic), proper lock application procedures, verification of energy isolation, and communication protocols. Include hands-on practice with the actual equipment using de-energized mockups. Require all regrind technicians and maintenance personnel to complete certification before operating or performing any maintenance on this equipment. Conduct refresher training annually and whenever equipment modifications are made. This administrative control will ensure workers understand and follow proper energy isolation procedures, preventing caught-in-running-equipment incidents.

name: Install Physical Guards and Warning Systems on Regrind Equipment
description: Install protective guards around all rotating shafts and drive mechanisms on the regrind equipment. Add transparent polycarbonate shields that allow visibility while preventing hand contact with rotating components. Install warning lights and audible alarms that activate when the equipment is running and cannot be easily disabled. Mount large, high-visibility warning labels (ISO 7010 standards) on the equipment indicating hazards, required LOTO procedures, and the prohibition of hand-clearing while equipment is energized. Include pictograms showing the consequences of failure to follow procedures. These engineering controls will provide multiple layers of protection against accidental contact with rotating hazards.

name: Establish Jam-Clearing Procedure with Automatic Equipment Shutdown
description: Modify the regrind equipment to include an automatic shutdown feature that activates when material flow stops for more than 30 seconds, allowing workers time to safely clear jams using LOTO procedures. Establish a written standard operating procedure (SOP) that requires: (1) operator activation of LOTO before any manual clearing attempt, (2) verification of energy isolation, (3) removal of lockout devices only after confirming material is cleared and equipment is functioning normally, and (4) documentation of each jam-clearing event. Post the SOP prominently at the equipment and include it in monthly toolbox talks. This administrative and engineering control will eliminate the incentive to clear equipment while energized by making the process safer and more efficient.

name: Implement Drum Stacking Compliance Audit
description: Establish a weekly visual inspection protocol for all chemical storage areas to verify compliance with two-drum-high maximum stacking limits. Create laminated signage with photographic examples of correct and incorrect stacking displayed at all storage locations. Conduct mandatory retraining for all warehouse staff on material handling procedures with documented sign-off. Implement a digital tracking system to log inspection results and any non-conformances found during audits.

name: Activate Secondary Containment Protocols
description: Restore and permanently commission all secondary containment berms in the warehouse. Establish a daily checklist ensuring berms are clear of obstructions and in operational status at shift start. Train all warehouse personnel on proper spill response procedures and the location of spill kits. Conduct quarterly mock spill drills involving actual activation of containment systems and deployment of absorbent materials to ensure readiness.

name: Enhanced Resin Storage Engineering Control
description: Install stainless steel drum cradles and racks designed specifically for a maximum two-drum configuration with fail-safe locking mechanisms. These engineered solutions eliminate the possibility of improper stacking through physical design constraints. Simultaneously, upgrade the ventilation system in the warehouse with additional make-up air capacity and targeted extraction near high-risk chemical storage zones to reduce fume concentrations in the event of future spills.

name: Implement Daily Machine Housekeeping Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory end-of-shift cleaning procedure for all injection molding machines requiring operators to wipe down cooling oil and debris from ejector assemblies and mold surfaces using lint-free cloths and appropriate degreasing solutions. Create a laminated checklist at each workstation detailing the cleaning steps with photographic guidance. Assign rotating accountability for checklist completion with supervisor spot-checks recorded weekly. This eliminates the slippery surface hazard that contributed to the incident.

name: Provide Ergonomic Gloves and Mold Edge Guards
description: Supply all production operators with cut-resistant nitrile gloves rated for sharp edge protection (ANSI A3 rating) to be worn during all part removal operations. Additionally, install protective edge guards or tape on known sharp mold parting lines that pose laceration risks. Conduct training on proper glove selection and application techniques. This PPE-level control provides immediate protection against future laceration events from the same hazard.

name: Establish Mechanized Lifting Equipment Accessibility
description: Relocate mobile hoist equipment to permanently station one mechanical lift device within 15 feet of each active injection molding machine requiring mold changeovers. Install wall-mounted hoists directly at stations where heavy molds (>50 lbs) are regularly handled. Ensure all operators complete orientation training on proper hoist operation before beginning work. This engineering control eliminates the manual lifting hazard completely by making mechanical assistance the default, easiest option.

name: Implement Mandatory Staffing Levels and Time-Pressure Protocol
description: Establish minimum staffing thresholds that prevent night shift operations below two fully-staffed operators per production line. Create a protocol requiring shift supervisors to immediately halt non-critical time-sensitive activities if staffing drops below safe levels due to illness or emergency. Institute a "safety pause" rule that prevents operators from bypassing mechanical lifting equipment due to production pressure. Communicate clearly that production schedules must be adjusted rather than compromising worker safety.

name: Reinforce Safe Lifting Training and Ergonomic Assessment
description: Conduct mandatory annual ergonomic training for all production and maintenance staff, with special focus on proper lifting mechanics for loads over 25 pounds. Implement a risk assessment identifying all tasks involving manual lifting of molds or components, with documented recommendations for mechanical assistance. Establish a report system allowing workers to self-report ergonomic concerns without penalty, and commit to addressing identified risks within 30 days. Monitor lifting incidents monthly and provide corrective feedback during safety meetings.

name: Implement Lockout/Tagout Enforcement During Cleaning Operations
description: Establish mandatory LOTO procedures for all cleaning and maintenance work on injection molding machines. Install lockable electrical disconnect switches on all 32 machines in the facility, requiring operators to physically lock out the main power supply during any non-operational maintenance. Conduct refresher training for all production and maintenance staff on LOTO compliance. Include verification checkpoints in daily pre-shift meetings. Violators will be subject to disciplinary action. This engineering and administrative control will eliminate the risk of unexpected machine activation during cleaning.

name: Establish Cleaning Work Safety Protocol and Signage
description: Develop and post large, visible warning signs on all injection molding machines indicating 'DO NOT OPERATE - CLEANING IN PROGRESS' during maintenance shifts. Implement a buddy system requiring two employees present during cleaning operations—one performing cleaning and one stationed at the control panel to prevent unauthorized activation. Provide reflective armbands to cleaning personnel and establish a check-in/check-out log at each machine. Update the machine operation manual to include explicit warnings about never activating equipment while cleaning is underway.

name: Install Protective Equipment around Chemical Storage Fixtures
description: Install steel protective cages around all overhead lighting fixtures, pipe supports, and electrical equipment in the chemical storage and warehouse areas to prevent forklift impact damage. Reinforce all structural supports with high-visibility yellow and black striping. Install additional bollards around high-value chemical storage zones. These engineering controls will physically separate forklifts from critical infrastructure that could cause dangerous chemical spills.

name: Implement Forklift Speed Restrictions and Driver Certification Program
description: Reduce maximum forklift speeds in warehouse zones from 12 mph to 6 mph through electronic speed governors. Require all forklift operators to complete advanced certification through an external training provider, including hazard recognition and emergency response protocols. Establish a mandatory quarterly recertification program with skills assessment. Install mirrors and backup warning systems on all powered equipment. Implement a disciplinary system for unsafe operation violations.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Containment and Ventilation Systems
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all large chemical drums and containers, capable of holding 110% of the largest container volume. Upgrade the ventilation system in the chemical storage area to achieve 15 air changes per hour (exceeding the current 10 changes per hour standard). Install additional explosion-proof fume extraction units and ensure all electrical equipment is ATEX-certified for flammable atmospheres. This eliminates the risk of widespread contamination and mitigates fire hazard from vapor accumulation.

name: Mandatory LOTO Completion and Verification Protocol
description: Establish an absolute requirement that all LOTO procedures must be completed and verified before ANY maintenance work begins. Implement a dual-verification system where two authorized personnel must independently confirm that all power sources (electrical, pneumatic, hydraulic) are disconnected and locked. Create laminated LOTO checklists at each equipment station. Require supervisors to conduct pre-work inspections signing off on safety compliance. Establish consequences for incomplete LOTO procedures including immediate work stoppage and disciplinary action. This eliminates the primary root cause of unexpected equipment activation.

name: Install Physical LOTO Stations and Automated Lockdown Systems
description: Install dedicated LOTO stations at each piece of equipment with clearly labeled disconnect points and lockout hasps for all power sources. Add automated interlocks that physically prevent equipment operation when maintenance access panels are opened. Implement a centralized LOTO tracking system using RFID tags to record which technicians have locked out which equipment and when. This engineering control provides redundancy to human procedures and ensures lockout integrity.

name: Comprehensive LOTO Training and Certification Program
description: Conduct mandatory recertification training for all maintenance personnel on LOTO procedures, focusing on the composite materials area equipment. Include hands-on practice with the facility's specific equipment configurations. Require annual refresher training for all authorized personnel. Document training completion and competency assessments. Implement a knowledge test requirement with minimum 95% passing score. Create a culture of safety accountability where LOTO compliance is a non-negotiable requirement monitored in performance reviews.

name: Replace and Upgrade Mold Temperature Warning Labels
description: Install high-visibility, UV-resistant warning labels on all injection molding machines with explicit temperature warnings and requirement for PPE. Labels will display current mold temperature digitally and include thermal burn hazard symbols. All Line B equipment will be inspected and updated within 5 days. Replacement labels will meet CSA Z535 standards and be positioned at operator eye level. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of faded labeling that contributed to the incident.

name: Implement Lockout/Tagout for Mold Maintenance Tasks
description: Establish and enforce a formal LOTO procedure for all routine mold maintenance activities including temperature controller adjustments. Procedure will require electrical isolation and thermal shutdown verification before any manual contact with mold surfaces. All injection molding operators will receive mandatory retraining on LOTO procedures specific to mold maintenance. Monthly compliance audits will be conducted. This administrative control ensures machines cannot cycle unexpectedly during maintenance.

name: Provide Heat-Resistant Protective Gloves
description: Distribute aramid-lined, silicone-coated thermal gloves (rated to 260°C) to all injection molding operators working on high-temperature molds. Gloves will be inspected monthly for wear and replaced as needed. Training will be provided on proper donning and inspection procedures. While this is a PPE control (lower priority), it provides an additional layer of protection for high-temperature environments when engineering controls cannot fully eliminate the hazard.

name: Install Ventilation System Upgrade in High-Heat Zone
description: Install three additional industrial-grade exhaust fans with 12,000 CFM capacity in the post-curing oven zone to reduce ambient temperature from 38°C to below 28°C. Add intake vents to promote cross-ventilation. This engineering control directly eliminates the root cause of heat accumulation. Expected implementation will require 30 days including equipment procurement and installation, with professional HVAC contractors. Post-installation monitoring will track temperature reduction and employee comfort.

name: Repair and Mark Floor Hazards in Production Area
description: Conduct inspection of all concrete floors in production zones to identify and repair gaps, cracks, and uneven surfaces that could catch equipment wheels. Mark any permanent hazardous areas with high-visibility yellow and black striping and post warning signs. This preventive engineering control will reduce trip hazards and equipment tipping incidents. All repairs will be completed within 10 days.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Compliance Protocol with Physical Verification
description: Establish a mandatory two-person verification system for all LOTO procedures on automated systems. Implement physical lockout devices with key storage in the maintenance supervisor's office. Require photographic documentation of locked equipment before work begins, with timestamp and employee identification. Conduct monthly LOTO compliance audits with random spot checks. All personnel must complete refresher LOTO training within 7 days. This administrative control ensures proper hazard isolation and prevents unexpected machine startup.

name: Install Remote Control Safety Disable Switch
description: Retrofit the automated material handling system with an emergency disable switch that physically locks out remote control functionality during maintenance operations. Switch will be mounted in the maintenance area and activate a red beacon light visible across the production zone. This engineering control prevents inadvertent remote activation by restricting control access during maintenance windows.

name: Establish Maintenance Communication Protocol
description: Implement a communication board system where technicians must post notices indicating which equipment is under maintenance and designate a specific maintenance zone. Require radio check-ins between maintenance teams working on interconnected systems. Conduct daily briefings before shift start to review all active maintenance work. This administrative control improves coordination between maintenance personnel and reduces accidental activation risks.

name: Immediate Replacement of Faulty Proximity Sensors
description: All proximity sensors on injection molding lines A through D will be replaced within 48 hours, with priority given to Line D. Engineering will source replacement sensors that meet ISO 13849-1 safety standards. A comprehensive audit of all remaining sensors will be conducted to identify additional units at risk of failure. All replacements will be documented in the equipment maintenance log and tracked for warranty purposes.

name: Establish Mandatory Predictive Maintenance Schedule
description: TechnoPlast will implement a non-negotiable monthly maintenance schedule for all critical safety-related sensors and components. Production schedules will be adjusted to accommodate this maintenance window. The JHSC will review and approve the maintenance calendar quarterly. Any flagged components in the predictive maintenance log must be addressed within 30 days or equipment must be taken offline. This administrative control ensures that production pressure does not override safety requirements.

name: Enhanced Lockout/Tagout Training for Operators
description: All injection molding operators will receive updated LOTO training emphasizing the importance of NOT attempting manual clearance operations without confirmed equipment lockout and verification. Training will include case studies of similar incidents and emphasize the chain of command for reporting equipment malfunctions. Training will be conducted by Gaétan Laplante (LOTO Coordinator) and documented for compliance records. Training will be repeated annually and during onboarding for new operators.

name: Install Safety Lip Guards on Storage Racks
description: All storage racks in the warehouse and receiving dock areas will be fitted with adjustable lip guards or restraint systems designed to prevent cylindrical materials such as resin spools from rolling or falling. Guards will be installed on shelves at heights above 4 feet. Engineering will specify guards that meet industrial warehouse standards and can accommodate various spool diameters. Installation will be completed within 14 days. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at its source.

name: Mandatory Training on Safe Material Storage and Retrieval
description: All warehouse personnel will receive comprehensive training on proper stacking and securing of cylindrical materials, with emphasis on weight distribution, securing straps, and awareness of high-shelf retrieval hazards. Training will include demonstration of proper pallet jack usage at height and when to request mechanical assistance via forklift or overhead crane. Training sessions will be conducted by the HSE coordinator and documented. Refresher training will be required annually and for all new warehouse hires.

name: Implement High-Shelf Retrieval Protocol Requiring Mechanical Equipment
description: An administrative control will mandate that all retrieval of materials stored at heights above 5 feet must be performed using overhead cranes or forklifts with cage attachment, never manual pallet jacks or ladders. A visual signage system will clearly mark restricted zones and provide instructions. The procedure will be posted at all warehouse access points. Supervisors will conduct weekly audits to ensure compliance. This removes the hazard of employees working at heights with unstable equipment.

name: Comprehensive Revision of Hydraulic System LOTO Procedures
description: All hydraulic system lockout/tagout procedures will be completely revised and validated by a certified safety engineer in consultation with equipment manufacturers. The procedure will include a mandatory multi-step pressure relief sequence: main system pump isolation, gradual pressure bleed through primary relief valve, secondary accumulator isolation and complete pressure bleed, and tertiary line verification. A color-coded checklist card will be laminated and affixed to each machine showing exact sequence and verification points. All maintenance technicians must initial each step on a work log before and after maintenance. This eliminates the hazard of residual pressure through improved engineering of the procedure.

name: Installation of Automated Pressure Monitoring and Alert Systems
description: All 32 injection molding machines will be equipped with real-time pressure sensors and indicator lights on control panels that display residual pressure in all hydraulic circuits. A secondary mechanical gauge will be installed at each maintenance access point showing current system pressure, requiring visual verification before work begins. Sensors will trigger an audible alarm if pressure exceeds safe thresholds during maintenance. This engineering control provides continuous verification of safe system state and prevents reliance on memory or incomplete procedures.

name: Mandatory Hydraulic Safety Certification Training for All Maintenance Staff
description: All electrical and maintenance technicians will complete an intensive two-day certified course on hydraulic systems safety, specifically covering high-pressure release hazards, proper depressurization procedures, and the physics of stored energy. The course will include hands-on training with pressure gauges and demonstration of hydraulic fluid burn injuries using simulated scenarios. Training will be provided by a certified hydraulic safety instructor. Technicians will be required to pass a written and practical examination. Refresher training will be required every 24 months. This administrative control ensures deep understanding of the hazard.

name: Implement Maintenance Work Authorization System with Peer Verification
description: A new work authorization procedure will require that all hydraulic system maintenance be performed by a minimum of two trained technicians, with one serving as an independent safety verifier. The verifier's sole responsibility during the task is to confirm that all LOTO and pressure relief steps are completed correctly before the primary technician proceeds. The verifier cannot perform other tasks simultaneously. Work permits will be issued only when both technicians have verified understanding of the procedure. This administrative control provides a human backup system to catch procedure deviations.

name: Implement Preventive Cooling System Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and maintenance protocol for all cooling water circuits on injection molding machines. Technicians will perform visual inspections for cracks, weeping connections, and corrosion; conduct pressure tests at rated operating pressure; and replace all couplings and seals showing signs of degradation. This engineering/administrative hybrid control directly addresses the root cause of premature coupling failure by detecting and replacing components before catastrophic failure occurs. Expected outcome: 90% reduction in cooling system failures within 12 months.

name: Install Pressure Relief and Isolation Valve Signage
description: Mount color-coded emergency placards on all injection molding machines identifying the location of manual isolation valves for cooling water systems. Include QR codes linking to quick-reference maintenance procedures. Train all operators on proper valve operation during equipment anomalies. This administrative control ensures rapid circuit isolation in future incidents and reduces response time during emergencies.

name: Replace Standard Gloves with Heat-Resistant Insulated Gloves
description: Procure and distribute NFPA 1977-compliant high-temperature resistant gloves (rated to 260°C) to all personnel working with curing ovens and hot composite processing equipment. The new gloves will be made from aramid fiber materials with reinforced palms and extended cuffs covering the forearm. Each operator will receive two pairs for rotation and cleaning. This engineering/PPE control directly eliminates the inadequate protection gap that led to the burn injury. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of heat-related burn injuries from oven contact.

name: Install Oven Guard Rails and Heat Shields
description: Design and install stainless steel guard rails around the perimeter of all composite curing ovens, positioned 15 cm from the oven exterior wall. Add removable insulated heat shields on interior walls where operators frequently reach. This engineering control creates a physical barrier reducing accidental contact with hot surfaces. Additionally, implement a mandatory cooling period protocol: all ovens must reach 60°C before unloading operations begin, monitored via temperature displays at the loading station.

name: Conduct Heat Stress and Burn Prevention Training
description: Develop a mandatory 45-minute training module covering thermal hazard identification, proper PPE selection and use, safe loading/unloading procedures for hot equipment, and first aid response for thermal burns. Training will include hands-on demonstration with dummy ovens at reduced temperatures. All composite area operators must complete this training within 10 days, with refresher training annually. This administrative control ensures workers understand the hazard and proper mitigation strategies.

name: Establish Cold Exposure Work Protocols and Temperature Monitoring
description: Implement mandatory temperature monitoring in the Raw Materials Warehouse with automated alerts when ambient temperatures fall below 12°C (54°F). Establish work rotation protocols limiting continuous exposure to cold environments to 2 hours maximum, with mandatory 30-minute warm-up breaks in heated rest areas. Install wall-mounted thermometers at key warehouse zones with visible warning placards. Distribute cold-weather PPE kits (thermal underlayers, insulated vests, gloves) to all night shift warehouse personnel. This administrative and PPE control directly addresses the cold stress hazard that contributed to reduced grip strength and the resulting drop incident.

name: Prioritize HVAC System Maintenance and Install Heaters
description: Schedule critical HVAC maintenance during daylight hours only to prevent prolonged cold exposure during night shift operations. Install auxiliary electric radiant heaters in the Raw Materials Warehouse ambient storage sections, targeting a minimum maintained temperature of 15°C (59°F). Heaters will be controlled via programmable thermostat with redundant temperature sensors. This engineering control eliminates the cold stress hazard at its source rather than relying on worker adaptation.

name: Implement Container Handling Restrictions and Ergonomic Training
description: Establish a maximum single-container weight limit of 10 kg for manual handling in warehouse operations, with heavier containers requiring two-person lifts or mechanical assistance equipment. Provide refresher ergonomic training focusing on proper grip techniques, load stabilization, and the dangers of manual material handling when experiencing fatigue or cold stress. Install grab handles and non-slip surfaces on all frequently handled material containers. This administrative and engineering control reduces injury severity from dropped loads.

name: Implement Drum Integrity Verification Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a mandatory pre-transfer inspection checklist for all chemical drums, including visual inspection of bung plugs, sealing tape integrity, and drum exterior condition. Train all Material Handlers on proper verification procedures and require sign-off documentation. Implement weekly audits of storage areas to verify compliance. This engineering and administrative control addresses the root cause of improper bung plug seating and prevents future spills of hazardous materials.

name: Upgrade Spill Containment and Secondary Containment
description: Install permanent secondary containment systems (drip trays, berms) under all chemical storage racks and mixing equipment with capacity of 110% of the largest container stored. Install redundant absorbent material storage stations in the Chemical Storage area with clear labeling and accessibility. This engineering control ensures that spills are contained on-site and prevents environmental contamination of storm drains and soil, addressing the environmental impact observed in this incident.

name: Enhanced Ventilation System Maintenance and Monitoring
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule for the Chemical Storage facility's ventilation system with monthly filter replacements and quarterly duct cleaning. Install continuous air quality monitoring with VOC sensors that trigger automatic alerts when concentrations exceed safe thresholds. Provide quarterly refresher training to all personnel on ventilation system operation and emergency protocols. This addresses the VOC exposure hazard and ensures adequate air quality control during normal operations and incidents.

name: Implement Mandatory Preventive Maintenance Schedule with No Deferral Policy
description: Establish a non-negotiable preventive maintenance (PM) schedule for all injection molding machines with quarterly relief valve inspections and annual replacements. Create a tracking system that alerts supervisors 30 days before PM is due and prevents production scheduling during PM windows. Any deferral requires approval from the Plant Manager and HSE Director with documented justification. This administrative and engineering control eliminates deferred maintenance as a root cause of equipment failures and ensures all safety-critical components remain within specification.

name: Install Automatic Pressure Monitoring and Alert System
description: Replace manual pressure gauges with digital pressure monitoring systems that continuously transmit data to a central dashboard. Configure automatic alerts to notify operators and supervisors when pressure exceeds 105% of design parameters, and implement automatic shutdown triggers at 115%. Provide daily operator training on reading digital displays and responding to alerts. This engineering control provides real-time visibility into machine status and prevents unsafe pressure conditions from being missed during routine checks.

name: Enhance Machine Guarding and Mold Ejection Safety Interlocks
description: Install interlocked safety guards on all 250+ ton molding machines that physically prevent mold opening when pressure exceeds safe thresholds. Add redundant pressure relief systems as fail-safes. Retrofit existing machines with hydraulic line rupture detection that triggers automatic shutdown. Conduct quarterly inspections of all interlock systems. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of mold ejection injuries by preventing dangerous pressure release scenarios.

name: Replace Deteriorated Cooling Lines with Stainless Steel Tubing
description: Complete replacement of the copper tubing cooling circuits on all three industrial dryers with corrosion-resistant stainless steel 316L tubing rated for 150 PSI. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of premature failure due to corrosion and material degradation. All joints will use welded connections rather than compression fittings to minimize future leak points. Implementation includes pressure testing to 1.5x operating pressure and installation of secondary containment trays under each dryer. Expected outcome: zero cooling line failures for minimum 10 years.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Inspections
description: Establish formal quarterly preventive maintenance protocol for all cooling water systems with documented inspection checklists. Maintenance planners will conduct visual inspections for corrosion, leaks, and fitting integrity; measure system pressure and flow rates; and test water chemistry (pH, conductivity) monthly. All findings will be logged in the predictive maintenance database to identify deterioration trends. Training will be provided to maintenance staff on early warning signs of cooling system failure.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant PPE for Molding Operations
description: Replace standard nitrile gloves with rated heat-protective gloves (Kevlar-lined, minimum 150°C rating) for all operators working in proximity to injection mold equipment. Establish new PPE requirement stating that operators must wear appropriate hand protection rated for equipment operating temperatures plus 20°C safety margin. Conduct inventory audit and provide all 35 production operators with new gloves. Include PPE upgrade in new employee orientation and quarterly safety briefings.

name: Install Automatic Temperature Control System Failsafe
description: Engineering control: Install redundant temperature sensors and proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controllers on all 12 injection molding lines with automatic alarm and power cutoff if mold temperature exceeds preset safe limits by more than 5°C. Implement real-time temperature monitoring dashboard in control room. Establish maintenance protocol requiring calibration and testing of all thermostats monthly. Any thermostat showing drift of more than 2°C will be replaced immediately.

name: Mandatory Thermal Safety Certification Training
description: Develop and implement mandatory thermal hazard recognition training for all production operators covering: identification of hot surfaces, safe temperatures for contact, proper PPE selection and maintenance, emergency response to thermal injuries, and use of thermal cameras to verify equipment temperatures. Training will include hands-on demonstration with calibrated hot plates at various temperatures. Competency assessment required with 90% passing score. Training to be completed within 30 days and refreshed annually.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Lighting to LED High-Bay System
description: Engineering control: Replace existing fluorescent high-bay lighting throughout Raw Materials Warehouse with LED fixtures providing minimum 400 lux illumination in all material handling and pedestrian zones, with particular focus on inventory counting and forklift traffic areas. Install motion-sensor controls to ensure lights activate in warehouse sections during active work periods.
