All staff will be trained to maintain clear ventilation pathways. Update facility SOPs to prohibit storage of materials near HVAC components. This administrative control ensures existing ventilation systems operate at design capacity.

name: Solvent Handling and Respiratory Protection Training
description: Deliver comprehensive training to all maintenance personnel on safe solvent handling procedures, proper use of closed-container cleaning methods where feasible, and respiratory protection requirements. Training will include recognition of solvent vapor symptoms, emergency response procedures, and proper donning/doffing of respirators. Provide each night shift maintenance technician with NIOSH-approved organic vapor respirators and fit-testing. This multi-level administrative and PPE control reduces inhalation hazard exposure.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Thermal Equipment
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all industrial ovens and thermal processing equipment. This includes thermostat calibration checks, heating element inspection, insulation integrity assessment, and thermal fluid condition analysis. A certified technician will conduct these inspections and maintain detailed logs. Root cause analysis identified that the thermostat had not been calibrated in 18 months, leading to temperature reading inaccuracy. Implementation of this schedule will prevent similar overheating incidents and extend equipment life by 40%.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring and Alert System
description: Deploy a continuous digital temperature monitoring system with automatic alerts set at 95% of maximum safe operating temperature for all Post-Processing ovens. The system will trigger audible and visual alarms, notify supervisors via text/email, and automatically reduce heating if temperature exceeds thresholds. This engineering control provides real-time oversight and prevents manual monitoring gaps during shift changes. Integration with the facility's SCADA system enables remote monitoring from the central control room.

name: Enhanced Operator Training on Thermal Equipment
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training to all operators on proper oven operation, recognizing early warning signs of malfunction, emergency shutdown procedures, and thermal fluid spill response. Training will include hands-on simulator exercises and quarterly refresher sessions. Operators will be certified competent before operating post-processing equipment. This administrative control ensures personnel can identify and respond appropriately to equipment anomalies.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification and Audit Program
description: Implement a comprehensive Lockout/Tagout compliance program requiring all maintenance personnel and machine operators to complete CNESST-certified LOTO training and pass competency assessments. Conduct weekly audits of LOTO compliance during maintenance activities, with photographic documentation. Establish a system where maintenance work cannot proceed without physical lockout devices applied and verified by a second trained person. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the root cause of this incident by enforcing proper energy isolation procedures.

name: Install Machine Start Inhibitor Locks
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with mechanical start inhibitor locks that physically prevent machine startup when a LOTO device is installed. This engineering control provides a fail-safe mechanism ensuring machines cannot be remotely started during maintenance. Each lock integrates with the existing control systems and requires authorized removal of both the LOTO device and the start inhibitor before normal operation can resume.

name: Implement Maintenance Work Permit System
description: Establish a formal maintenance work permit system where no maintenance can begin without a signed permit indicating: equipment to be serviced, maintenance work scope, LOTO devices applied, authorized personnel involved, and supervisor sign-off. Permits remain displayed on the machine during maintenance and must be removed by the maintenance supervisor upon completion. This administrative control ensures clear communication and accountability for all maintenance activities.

name: Supply High-Performance Cut-Resistant Gloves for Maintenance Work
description: Distribute ANSI level A4 or A5 cut-resistant gloves to all maintenance personnel for use during hydraulic system work and other high-puncture-risk tasks. These gloves provide superior protection against sharp edges and puncture wounds while maintaining dexterity for detailed maintenance work. Gloves will be stored in the maintenance workshop and replaced monthly or when damaged. This PPE control significantly reduces puncture wound risk during routine maintenance activities.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Corrosion Inspection Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly visual inspection of all hydraulic hose connectors, fittings, and connections for corrosion, brittleness, and degradation. Document findings and replace any components showing signs of corrosion damage before they fail. This addresses the root cause of the incident by preventing brittle connector failures that create sharp puncture hazards.

name: Comprehensive LOTO Energy Audit and Documentation Update
description: Conduct a complete audit of all CNC milling machines and automated equipment to verify proper lockout/tagout procedures. Document all energy sources including hydraulic, pneumatic, electrical, and mechanical systems. Update the LOTO procedure manual with detailed energy isolation diagrams specific to each machine model. Require secondary verification by an independent technician before maintenance begins. Implement monthly LOTO compliance inspections with documented checklist validation. Training will be mandatory for all maintenance staff within 15 days.

name: Install Machine Safety Interlocks and Residual Energy Discharge Systems
description: Engineering modification to all CNC milling machines to include automatic residual energy discharge upon power cutoff. Install safety interlocks on machine access panels that prevent spindle rotation when maintenance covers are open. Add pressure relief valves with visual/audible confirmation when hydraulic systems are depressurized. Implement software-based machine state verification that displays hydraulic and pneumatic pressure readings on a local control panel. This engineering control eliminates the risk of unexpected machine movement during maintenance operations.

name: Enhanced Maintenance Training Program with Competency Assessment
description: Develop a comprehensive maintenance technician certification program focusing on energy isolation, hazard recognition, and incident investigation. Require all maintenance staff to complete 40-hour initial training covering LOTO principles, equipment-specific energy sources, and hands-on verification procedures. Implement annual recertification with practical competency testing. Include case study analysis of similar incidents. Create a peer review system where experienced technicians validate procedures before new staff perform independent maintenance work.

name: Installation of Mechanical Lifting Equipment for Material Handling
description: Eliminate manual lifting hazard by installing pneumatic lift-assist devices and motorized pallet jacks in the Raw Materials Warehouse. Implement vacuum lift systems for handling cylindrical pellet containers. Reduce maximum manual lift requirement to 15 kg with mechanical assistance for anything heavier. Establish loading docks with adjustable height platforms to minimize awkward reaching and bending. This engineering control directly removes the biomechanical stress that caused Yvon's injury. All equipment will be ergonomically certified and require operator training.

name: Comprehensive Ergonomic Assessment and Job Redesign Program
description: Conduct formal ergonomic risk assessments for all warehouse and material handling positions using OSHA guidelines. Analyze workstation heights, container weights, frequency of lifts, and distance of carries. Redesign warehouse layout to minimize carrying distances and optimize container storage heights. Create standardized work procedures with photographic guidance for proper lifting mechanics. Implement job rotation to reduce repetitive strain on any single employee. Establish baseline measurements and quarterly monitoring of employee ergonomic complaints. Document all findings in an ergonomic improvement plan with prioritized interventions.

name: Upgrade to Impact-Rated Safety Eyewear with Side Shield Protection
description: Replace all standard safety glasses in production areas with high-impact rated safety glasses featuring full-coverage side shields and polycarbonate lenses rated ANSI Z87.1 level 3. Provide additional wraparound eyewear options for quality control personnel working in close proximity to molded parts. Establish a mandatory eyewear inspection and replacement schedule every 6 months or upon visible damage. Conduct fit testing for all employees to ensure proper seal and coverage. This engineering control upgrade will significantly reduce eye injury risk from flying particles and material fragments.

name: Implement Enhanced Cooling Protocol and Part Quality Control Procedures
description: Establish mandatory extended cooling time for all plastic injection molded parts before removal from molds, with documented temperature verification. Install infrared temperature sensors on the automated part removal system to ensure parts reach minimum safe handling temperature before extraction. Modify the quality control inspection procedure to include fracture-resistance visual screening before close-proximity examination. Train all QC technicians to identify brittle or insufficiently cooled material characteristics. Document part cooling logs and track material batch quality metrics to identify systematic cooling failures.

name: Install Humidity Monitoring System in Warehouse
description: Install automated humidity sensors and monitoring equipment in the Finished Goods Warehouse with real-time alerts when humidity exceeds 65% relative humidity. System will include data logging to track environmental conditions continuously. This addresses the root cause of mold growth by ensuring proper storage conditions are maintained year-round. Expected outcome is complete elimination of mold contamination risk in stored parts.

name: Establish Warehouse Climate Maintenance Schedule
description: Develop and implement a documented preventive maintenance schedule for all HVAC and humidity control systems in the warehouse, performed quarterly by Maintenance staff. Include pre-maintenance humidity baseline testing and post-maintenance verification. Train all warehouse personnel on new protocols for environmental monitoring and reporting. This administrative control ensures equipment failures are caught before they impact product quality.

name: Implement Two-Person LOTO Verification Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a mandatory two-person verification procedure for all lockout/tagout operations on injection molding equipment. Before any maintenance or cleaning work, a second qualified technician must independently verify that all energy sources are properly isolated and tagged. Both technicians must sign the LOTO documentation. This engineering/administrative control ensures that single-point failures in LOTO procedures are caught before they result in injuries.

name: Conduct Mandatory LOTO Refresher Training - Night Shift
description: Deliver comprehensive lockout/tagout refresher training to all night shift personnel within 14 days. Training will include updated LOTO procedures, common failure points, emergency response protocols, and practical demonstrations on machinery. All participants must pass a competency assessment. Include specific emphasis on mold closing hazards and proper machine energy isolation verification. This administrative control addresses the knowledge gap identified in the near-miss.

name: Install Physical LOTO Override Prevention Device
description: Install a mechanical override prevention guard on the emergency stop button of all injection molding machines that prevents accidental activation or reset during active LOTO procedures. The device will require intentional two-step disengagement to reset. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of accidental reset that occurred in this near-miss event.

name: Reinstall and Secure All Machine Guards
description: Immediately reinstall all shaft coupling guards on the assembly conveyor system in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Verify that all guards meet ANSI B29.1 standards and are properly secured with tamper-evident fasteners. Conduct comprehensive inspection of all equipment in UNIT-015 to identify any other missing or inadequate guards. This engineering control directly eliminates the entanglement hazard identified in the near-miss.

name: Install Redundant Hopper Level Sensing System
description: Implement a dual-sensor hopper level monitoring system with independent alarm triggers and automatic material feed cutoff. The new system will include both capacitive and ultrasonic sensors to detect material levels, with a secondary backup alarm that alerts operators if sensor malfunction is detected. This engineering control eliminates the single-point-of-failure risk and provides real-time monitoring. Installation will include new control panel integration and daily automated self-test procedures to ensure sensor functionality. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of hopper overflow incidents on all production lines.

name: Establish Weekly Hopper Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Create and implement a standardized weekly inspection checklist for all hopper systems, including sensor calibration verification, manual level verification, and alarm function testing. Assign responsibility to Production Operators on each shift, with Quality Control oversight. Document all inspections in a maintenance log to track sensor performance trends. Training will be provided to all operators and technicians on proper inspection procedures and how to recognize early warning signs of sensor degradation.

name: Implement Enhanced Material Pre-Sorting Inspection System
description: Establish a mandatory pre-grinding inspection station where all recycled plastic is visually examined and hand-sorted to remove composite materials, cured resin pieces, and other foreign objects. Staff will use specialized magnifying equipment and tactile inspection gloves to identify sharp edges or protruding features. Only approved, fully pre-sorted material will be fed into grinding equipment. This administrative and physical control measure eliminates the source of the hazard before it enters the grinding chamber. Implement a quality tracking system to monitor contaminated batches and identify upstream process improvements.

name: Upgrade Regrind Mill Guard Design and PPE Requirements
description: Replace existing regrind mill guards with enhanced polycarbonate shields that provide additional containment of ejected fragments while maintaining visibility for operator monitoring. Integrate perforated metal backing to capture smaller particles. Mandate that all regrind operators wear reinforced cut-resistant sleeves (ANSI A4 rating) and high-impact safety glasses during all grinding operations. Provide operators with hand-held inspection tools to reduce exposure to grinding chamber hazards. Update standard operating procedures to require arm protection as non-negotiable PPE.

name: Establish Electrical Equipment Calibration and Maintenance Program
description: Implement a comprehensive electrical test equipment management system that tracks calibration dates, maintenance records, and retirement schedules. All multimeters, megohmeters, ground resistance testers, and other electrical diagnostic equipment must be calibrated annually by a certified external laboratory. All extension cords and power distribution equipment will be inspected monthly using a standardized checklist, with damaged items immediately removed from service and replaced. Create a centralized equipment tracking log maintained by maintenance personnel, with alerts sent 30 days before calibration expiration. All equipment must have visible calibration labels and be stored in dedicated, climate-controlled cabinets.

name: Implement Grounding Strap Inspection and Replacement Protocol
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and maintenance program for all personal grounding straps and ESD (electrostatic discharge) protection equipment. All straps must be tested for continuity and proper contact resistance (not exceeding 1 Megohm per technical standards). Non-compliant or oxidized straps will be immediately removed from inventory and replaced with new certified equipment. Technicians will be trained on proper strap care, including removal of corrosion using designated cleaning methods and proper storage techniques. Implement a color-coded system to identify inspection dates and track usage history for each strap.

name: Conduct Electrical Safety Certification and Retraining Program
description: Arrange for all maintenance technicians and engineers to complete refresher training on electrical safety, including LOTO procedures, safe working practices near energized equipment, and emergency response protocols. Ensure all technicians hold current electrical safety certifications (NFPA 70E or equivalent Canadian standard). Implement annual recertification requirements with assessment testing to verify competency. Training will be provided by an external certified electrical safety instructor and documented for compliance purposes. Establish a sign-off system requiring technicians to acknowledge electrical safety protocols before accessing the shop.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays
description: Implement secondary containment trays for all chemical transfer operations in UNIT-016. Each tray will have a capacity of at least 110% of the largest container being transferred. Trays will be positioned under all transfer points and chemical storage shelves. This engineering control directly eliminates the risk of chemical spread during container handling. Expected outcome: Zero chemical releases reaching the floor during normal operations.

name: Enhanced Chemical Transfer Training Program
description: Develop and implement mandatory training for all personnel handling polyol resins and similar viscous chemicals. Training will cover proper container securing techniques, lid verification procedures, two-person transfer protocols for containers over 15 liters, and emergency response procedures. All material handlers and technicians will complete certification within 30 days. Refresher training will occur quarterly. This administrative control addresses the human error component of the incident.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Monitoring
description: Install real-time air quality monitoring sensors in UNIT-016 that trigger alerts when solvent vapor concentrations exceed 50% of exposure limits. System will automatically increase ventilation speed and alert supervisors via SMS and control room display. Sensors will be calibrated monthly and tested quarterly. This provides early warning capability to prevent worker exposure and enables rapid response to ventilation changes.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Scheduling System
description: Deploy a computerized preventive maintenance management system that locks production schedules when maintenance tasks are overdue. System will generate escalating alerts at 1 week, 3 days, and 24 hours before maintenance is due. All production supervisors and plant management must approve any maintenance deferrals, with documented business justification. This administrative control prevents maintenance avoidance by creating accountability and visibility. Expected outcome: 100% on-time completion of hydraulic system maintenance.

name: Replace Hydraulic Pump with Sealed Design
description: Upgrade the hydraulic pump assembly on Machine Line C with a newer sealed design unit that incorporates redundant seals and internal pressure relief features. The new pump has an extended service interval of 2000 hours versus the current 1500 hours, and provides better failure warnings through pressure monitoring. Installation will occur during next scheduled maintenance window. This engineering control reduces failure probability and extends intervals between maintenance events.

name: Install Vibration-Damping Mounts for Load Cell Sensors
description: Replace all standard load cell sensor mounting hardware with vibration-isolating mounts specifically designed for industrial environments. These mounts reduce transmission of vibration from adjacent equipment by 85%, preventing connector loosening. Additionally, apply thread-locking compound (removable strength) to all electrical connections on load cells and enable periodic inspection. This engineering control addresses the root cause of sensor connection failure.

name: Establish Quarterly Crane Inspection and Calibration Program
description: Implement a mandatory quarterly inspection and calibration program for all overhead cranes, including complete electrical system verification. A certified third-party inspector will conduct these audits. Between inspections, dock supervisors will perform monthly visual checks of all visible connections and connectors. Any anomalies such as flickering displays or inconsistent readings will trigger immediate equipment lockout and investigation before return to service. Documentation will be maintained in the preventive maintenance system.

name: Install Automated Part Ejection System on Line B
description: Engineering control to eliminate repetitive manual part removal. Install pneumatic part ejectors on the injection mold cavity to automatically eject finished components into collection trays, reducing operator hand/wrist strain by 85%. This substitutes manual extraction with mechanical automation. Implementation includes calibration for different part geometries and integration with existing conveyor system. Expected outcome: Reduction in carpal tunnel syndrome incidents and improved production efficiency.

name: Implement Mandatory Stretch Break Protocol
description: Administrative control establishing mandatory 5-minute ergonomic stretch breaks every 60 minutes for all molding line operators. Develop illustrated ergonomic guide targeting wrist, forearm, and shoulder flexibility. Train all operators on proper stretching techniques. Supervisor will document break compliance. Include job rotation to alternate between high-repetition tasks and lower-repetition monitoring duties. Expected outcome: Reduce repetitive strain injuries by 40% and improve employee comfort and productivity.

name: Provide Ergonomic Wrist Support PPE
description: Distribute medical-grade compression wrist braces and anti-vibration gloves to all operators performing high-repetition tasks. Ensure proper fit and wear instructions. Establish PPE replacement schedule (every 6 months). While PPE is lowest in the hierarchy of controls, it provides immediate protection while engineering controls are being implemented. Document distribution and usage compliance.

name: Implement Daily Hydraulic Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Administrative control requiring daily pre-shift inspection of all hydraulic equipment and fluid storage containers. Create checklist documenting pressure seals, hose conditions, and leak history. Assign responsibility to maintenance team lead. Any leaks must be repaired immediately before equipment operation. Establish spill containment procedure with absorbent pads deployed near all hydraulic storage. Expected outcome: Eliminate hydraulic fluid hazards in material handling corridors and prevent equipment-related slip incidents.

name: Install Slip-Resistant Flooring in Material Corridors
description: Engineering control to reduce slip hazards in high-traffic material handling areas. Replace smooth concrete in warehouse corridors with anti-slip surface treatment or textured flooring. Focus on areas near chemical storage and material drying rooms where spills are most likely. Apply chemical-resistant coating. This engineering solution eliminates the root cause of forklift traction loss. Expected outcome: Reduce material handling accidents by 60% and improve overall warehouse safety.

name: Replace All Storage Tank Valve Seals with Corrosion-Resistant Materials
description: Engineering control eliminating the root cause of the chemical release. Conduct complete audit of all chemical storage tanks and replace corroded valve seals with PTFE-lined corrosion-resistant seals rated for isopropanol and other solvents used in facility. Implement preventive maintenance schedule replacing seals every 12 months. Document all replacements. This substitution of materials with superior corrosion resistance prevents future leaks. Expected outcome: Eliminate solvent vapor release incidents and ensure regulatory compliance.

name: Install Continuous Air Quality Monitoring System
description: Engineering control providing real-time detection of solvent vapor concentrations. Install four fixed air quality sensors in the chemical storage room configured to trigger alerts at 75% of OSHA PEL (300 ppm for isopropanol). Connect sensors to centralized alarm system with audible and visual alerts at the facility control center and night shift supervisor station. Enable automatic ventilation boost when levels approach threshold. This provides early warning system to prevent exposure incidents.

name: Implement Enhanced Night Shift Inspection Protocol
description: Administrative control addressing detection gap. Establish mandatory night shift supervisor rounds every 2 hours including chemical storage room visual inspection and odor assessment. Create inspection checklist for valve operation, seal integrity, and ventilation function. Provide night shift staff with calibrated portable air quality meters for spot checks. Document all inspections. Train night supervisor on chemical hazard recognition. Expected outcome: Early detection of equipment malfunctions and chemical releases before reaching dangerous concentrations.

name: Implement Supplier Container Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory incoming inspection procedure for all chemical containers and pressurized supply vessels. Each container must be visually inspected for seal integrity, structural defects, and pressure indicators before being placed into production areas. A checklist-based system will be implemented at the receiving dock. All staff handling chemical containers will receive training on identifying defective seals and proper rejection procedures. Supplier performance will be tracked quarterly with defect rates reported to procurement.

name: Upgrade Eyewash Station Accessibility and Signage
description: Install an additional emergency eyewash station closer to the hopper feeder system on Line B to reduce response time. Upgrade signage with reflective materials and high-visibility markers. Conduct staff training on eyewash station operation and ensure all operators know the nearest station locations. Monthly testing of all eyewash stations will be documented with results posted visibly.

name: Procure Mobile Lift Assist Equipment for Warehouse
description: Purchase two powered lift assist devices (lift tables) rated for 100+ pounds and capable of reaching 6-foot heights. Equipment will be positioned in high-traffic material handling areas. All warehouse staff will receive training on proper operation, load capacity limits, and maintenance procedures. Staff will be required to use mechanical assists for all loads exceeding 40 pounds or requiring overhead placement. Implementation will include written procedures posted at each station and monthly equipment maintenance checks.

name: Conduct Ergonomics Assessment and Workstation Redesign
description: Perform a comprehensive ergonomic assessment of all material handling tasks in the warehouse. Redesign storage rack heights and shelf spacing to minimize lifting above shoulder height or below waist height. Implement lower shelving (30-48 inches) for frequently accessed heavy items. Provide step stools with handrails for safe access to elevated items. Introduce a job rotation program to vary physical demands throughout shifts.

name: Implement Mold Repair Isolation and Safety Protocol
description: Establish a formal mold repair procedure requiring isolation of the mold on a designated work bench with containment barriers. All mold repairs involving pry-bar or lever-based removal must be performed with secondary containment (plexiglass shields or guards) protecting operator hands. Require the use of precision tools rated for the specific task rather than general-purpose pry bars. Implement a pre-repair hazard checklist identifying stuck components and appropriate removal techniques. All technicians must complete a certified mold repair safety course within 60 days.

name: Upgrade Hand and Finger Protection Equipment
description: Issue specialized cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rated) to all maintenance technicians and mold repair staff. Gloves must be worn during all mold repair operations involving sharp edges or tools. Implement a replacement protocol with inspections monthly. Additionally, provide custom-fitted impact-resistant work gloves for technicians working with heavy tools. Conduct training on proper glove selection, sizing, and care to ensure effectiveness.

name: Establish Emergency Mold Outsourcing Protocol
description: Create a formal agreement with external mold repair specialists for complex or time-sensitive mold repairs. This eliminates the need for in-house technicians to perform emergency repairs under time pressure. Establish cost parameters and turnaround time expectations. Train supervisors on when to trigger external repair services. Maintain an emergency vendor contact list and payment authorization procedures. This measure reduces injury risk by eliminating expedited, unsafe repair attempts.

name: Implement Compressed Air Safety Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a facility-wide compressed air safety standard limiting pressure to 30 PSI for cleaning operations and prohibiting direct air application to face, ears, or body cavities. Require all personnel using compressed air to wear appropriate PPE including safety glasses and ear protection. Install pressure regulators with visible gauges at all compressed air stations. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the root cause of improper compressed air use and reduces risk of serious injuries from pneumatic hazards.

name: Conduct Compressed Air Safety Training
description: Mandatory refresher training for all production and maintenance staff on proper compressed air handling techniques, maximum safe pressure limits, and PPE requirements. Training to include demonstration of hazards, case studies of compressed air injuries, and hands-on practice with approved cleaning methods. Training records to be maintained and annual recertification required. This administrative control ensures all employees understand the risks and safe practices.

name: Clear and Secure Emergency Exit Routes
description: Immediately relocate all stored pallets and materials from within 36 inches of all emergency exit doors in the Shipping and Receiving Dock. Establish permanent no-storage zones around all emergency exits with clear floor markings and signage. Conduct facility-wide audit of all exit routes to ensure compliance with CNESST minimum clearance standards of 28 inches for single doors and 44 inches for double doors. Install protective barriers or guardrails where necessary to prevent future obstruction. This elimination control removes the hazard at its source.

name: Reinstall and Verify Emergency Exit Signage
description: Conduct immediate inspection and reinstallation of all emergency exit signage throughout the facility to ensure visibility and illumination standards are met. Remove any obstructions blocking signage lines of sight. Verify exit lighting is functional and backup battery systems are operational. Establish monthly inspection schedule to maintain compliance. Document all inspections and corrective actions taken. This administrative control ensures emergency routes are clearly marked and identifiable in all conditions.

name: Implement Predictive Hydraulic Maintenance Program
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance program for all hydraulic systems using thermal imaging and vibration analysis to detect metal fatigue in hose fittings before failure occurs. Schedule monthly inspections of all high-pressure hydraulic connections with documented torque verification and pressure testing. Replace hydraulic hoses on a 5-year cycle regardless of apparent condition to eliminate age-related failure. Install secondary containment trays beneath all hydraulic equipment to capture leaks and prevent environmental spread. This engineering control eliminates the root cause through early detection and systematic replacement.

name: Upgrade Electrical Panel Redundancy and Protection
description: Install secondary isolation valves and hydraulic fluid deflectors around all electrical control panels in the injection molding area. Upgrade critical control panels with secondary weather/fluid-resistant housings and install automatic shutoff systems that isolate hydraulic pressure when fluid pressure exceeds safe operating limits by 10%. Implement real-time monitoring alerts for pressure anomalies. This engineering control provides multiple layers of protection to prevent future contamination of critical electrical systems.

name: Establish Mold Storage Hazard Prevention
description: Relocate all precision molds to a secondary, dedicated storage area outside the immediate vicinity of hydraulic equipment. Install protective barriers between hydraulic systems and mold storage zones. Implement hourly inspection protocols for any signs of hydraulic seepage during operation. Store backup molds for critical medical device production to minimize lost production time during equipment failures. This administrative and elimination control reduces exposure of valuable assets to hydraulic hazards.

name: Implement Mandatory Quarterly Overhead Crane Inspections
description: Establish a formal quarterly inspection protocol for all overhead cranes with documented checklist and photographic evidence. Inspections will specifically focus on cable integrity, load-bearing capacity verification, and mechanical wear indicators. All findings will be logged in a centralized maintenance management system with alerts generated automatically when inspection dates approach. Training will be provided to all operators on pre-shift visual inspections and immediate reporting of any anomalies.

name: Install Load Drop Warning System with Automatic Shutdown
description: Retrofit all overhead cranes with cable tension monitoring sensors that automatically halt load movement if tension drops below safe thresholds. Install audible and visual warning systems that activate when abnormal cable wear patterns are detected. Add weight limiters to prevent overloading and integrate with the facility's incident reporting dashboard to track all near-miss events.

name: Establish Overhead Crane Operator Certification Program
description: Require all personnel operating overhead cranes to complete a certified training program covering equipment operation, pre-shift inspection procedures, emergency protocols, and load calculation. Operators must pass a written and practical examination annually. Certifications will be posted at each crane station with expiration dates clearly visible. Only certified operators will be authorized to use equipment.

name: Install Insulated Handling Tools and Cooling Pads at Part Removal Stations
description: Provide all machine operators with heat-resistant gloves rated for 100°C contact and insulated tongs specifically designed for removing hot composite parts. Install cooling pads with temperature monitoring near cooling chambers to allow parts to reach safer handling temperatures. Operators must allow minimum cooling time before manual handling. Temperature-tracking labels on parts will indicate when they are safe to handle without protective equipment.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Pressure Monitoring with Automated Alerts
description: Install real-time pressure monitoring sensors on all hydraulic systems with automated email and SMS alerts when pressures deviate more than ±5 PSI from setpoint. Integrate with the facility's preventive maintenance scheduling system to automatically flag systems for inspection when anomalies are detected. Install secondary backup relief valves on critical systems to provide redundancy in case primary valve failure occurs.

name: Establish Monthly Hydraulic System Deep Inspection Protocol
description: Mandate monthly visual and auditory inspections of all hydraulic system components, including pressure relief valves, hoses, and fittings. Inspectors will document valve response times, listen for unusual sounds, and photograph any visible corrosion or degradation. Findings will be recorded in a detailed database. Any system showing three or more warning signs will be scheduled for immediate component replacement regardless of age.

name: Install Secondary Containment Systems
description: Install spill containment trays beneath all large chemical containers in the Chemical Storage facility. Each tray must have capacity for at least 110% of the largest container volume. Trays will be made of chemical-resistant materials and positioned to allow easy inspection and cleaning. Implementation includes labeling all containers with chemical name, hazard classification, and emergency contact information using standardized WHMIS labels. A maintenance schedule will be established for monthly inspections.

name: Clean and Maintain Ventilation System
description: Schedule comprehensive cleaning of all intake and exhaust valves in the Chemical Storage facility. Replace or clean air filters and conduct full system inspection by qualified HVAC technician. Establish quarterly maintenance schedule with documented inspections. Install visual airflow indicators to verify adequate ventilation during operations. Train staff on recognizing signs of ventilation failure and proper reporting procedures.

name: Implement Cooling Rack with Temperature Monitoring
description: Install a dedicated cooling rack with integrated temperature monitoring sensors at the Packaging and Labeling Station. Components must cool to below 50°C before handling without protective equipment. Establish clear color-coded zones: red (>70°C - no touch), yellow (50-70°C - heavy gloves required), green (<50°C - safe). Train all personnel on zone system. Establish handling protocol requiring verification of component temperature before transfer operations.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Implement comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all 32 injection molding machines with focus on hydraulic systems. Schedule pump inspections and lubrication every 250 operating hours or weekly, whichever is sooner. Create detailed maintenance logs with signature verification. Establish hydraulic fluid analysis program to detect early signs of contamination or degradation. Train maintenance technicians on early warning signs of pump failure including unusual noises, pressure drops, and temperature increases. Stock replacement pump assemblies for critical machines to minimize downtime.

name: Install Hydraulic System Monitoring and Alert System
description: Install real-time pressure and temperature monitoring sensors on all injection molding machine hydraulic systems. Sensors will transmit data to central monitoring station with automatic alerts when pressure drops below 90% of normal operating range or temperature exceeds safe limits. System will log all anomalies for trend analysis. Integrate with production scheduling system to prevent machine operation when alerts are active. Technicians will receive automated notifications via email and SMS for critical conditions.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Industrial Ovens
description: Establish a comprehensive quarterly preventive maintenance program for all industrial ovens in the Post-Processing unit. This includes thermal cycling stress analysis, hinge assembly inspection, weld integrity testing, and replacement of corroded components before failure. The program will utilize thermal imaging to detect stress points and schedule maintenance during planned downtime. Implementation includes purchasing specialized inspection equipment ($8,500), technician training ($3,200), and scheduling software ($2,100). Expected outcome: 95% reduction in unplanned equipment failures and extended equipment lifespan by 40%.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Protective Barriers
description: Design and install secondary containment systems beneath oven units to capture leaking hydraulic fluid and prevent spills from reaching production areas. Install adjustable protective barriers around high-risk equipment zones to contain debris from potential equipment failures. Barriers will use modular polycarbonate panels rated for impact resistance. This engineering control eliminates the need for rapid manual intervention during failure events and reduces property damage risk by 70%. Installation includes materials ($6,200), structural reinforcement ($4,100), and safety signage ($800).

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance and Interlock System Upgrade
description: Implement an integrated electronic LOTO system that automatically prevents machine startup whenever maintenance mode is activated. All 32 injection molding machines will be retrofitted with dual-stage safety interlocks requiring both LOTO engagement AND remote-only startup capability during maintenance. The system will log all maintenance activities and generate alerts if standard procedures are bypassed. Training certification will be mandatory quarterly for all night shift operators. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the ability to bypass LOTO procedures through human error. System cost includes hardware ($24,000), software integration ($8,500), installation labor ($6,200), and quarterly training ($3,500 annually).

name: Implement Night Shift Production Scheduling Buffer Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory 30-minute buffer period between production completion and maintenance start on all shifts, with specific emphasis on night shift operations where supervision is reduced. This administrative control removes time pressure from maintenance decisions. Supervisors must approve and document all expedited maintenance requests. Create a secondary verification system requiring two operators to confirm LOTO engagement before any maintenance begins. Production scheduling software will be updated to enforce buffer periods automatically. Expected outcome: elimination of schedule-driven safety shortcuts and reduced risk of LOTO violations by 85%.

name: Enhanced Competency-Based LOTO Certification Program
description: Develop a rigorous competency-based certification program for all personnel working with injection molding equipment. Include practical skill assessments, scenario-based decision making, and consequences training. Certifications will be renewed every 12 months with refresher sessions every 6 months. Establish a mentor system pairing experienced technicians with newer staff for the first 90 days of assignment to UNIT-012. Create visual LOTO reminder signage at each machine and maintenance workstation. Documentation will track individual compliance rates and identify at-risk employees for targeted coaching.

name: Implement Advanced Humidity Control in Warehouse Zones
description: Install commercial-grade dehumidification and climate control systems throughout the Finished Goods Warehouse and Shipping areas to maintain optimal humidity levels between 45-55% relative humidity. This engineering control directly eliminates the root cause of cable corrosion by preventing salt air condensation on metal components. System includes eight industrial dehumidifiers ($12,000), moisture monitoring sensors with alerts ($3,200), and HVAC system integration ($4,800). Monthly humidity checks will be documented and tracked. Expected outcome: complete elimination of environment-induced metal corrosion, extended cable lifespan from 8 years to 15+ years, and reduced maintenance costs by 60%.

name: Enhanced Overhead Crane Inspection and Certification Protocol
description: Establish a rigorous quarterly inspection program for all overhead crane systems including certified third-party cable analysis. Each cable will undergo tensile strength testing using non-destructive ultrasonic technology to detect internal fatigue. Load-bearing capacity will be documented and reduced capacity thresholds will trigger automatic cable replacement. Protective coatings will be reapplied annually with corrosion-resistant marine-grade products. Create a visual load-capacity rating system visible at all crane control stations. Training for all crane operators will include hazard recognition and load limitation procedures.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for All Hydraulic Equipment
description: Establish a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) tracking all hydraulic press service intervals with automatic alerts 30 days before due dates. Include quarterly pressure relief valve inspection and annual full valve replacement across all 8 hydraulic presses. Train maintenance technicians on early warning signs of valve degradation. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of component failure and eliminates the risk of similar catastrophic releases.

name: Install Secondary Pressure Containment System
description: Add redundant pressure relief valves and containment bunding around all hydraulic presses to capture fluid spray in the event of primary valve failure. Install pressure monitoring sensors with automated shutdown triggers if pressure exceeds safe thresholds. This engineering control provides a secondary barrier to prevent uncontrolled fluid release and associated ignition risks.

name: Conduct Mandatory LOTO and Hydraulic Safety Retraining
description: Deliver refresher training to all operators and maintenance staff on proper lockout/tagout procedures specific to hydraulic equipment, emphasizing residual pressure hazards. Include practical scenarios involving pressure release and energy dissipation techniques. Audit compliance through tagged-equipment inspections and near-miss reporting. This administrative control reinforces proper procedures and ensures all personnel understand the critical importance of energy isolation before equipment servicing.

name: Establish Contractor Safety Orientation and Materials Handling Certification
description: Develop mandatory 2-hour contractor induction program covering TechnoPlast-specific hazards, materials handling procedures, and equipment operation protocols. Require all temporary workers to complete refresher training on load securing and stacking procedures before starting work. Implement a sign-off verification system where supervisors confirm contractor understanding before assigning duties. This administrative control ensures all personnel, regardless of employment status, follow consistent safety procedures.

name: Install Load Weight Verification Signage and Weight Limit Markers
description: Place clearly visible weight capacity labels on all warehouse shelving and pallet storage areas, indicating maximum stacking heights and load limits. Install bright yellow floor markings delineating safe load-stacking zones away from dock edges. Implement a color-coded pallet identification system (green for compliant stacks, red for non-compliant) to provide visual feedback. This engineering/administrative hybrid control makes hazards visually obvious and prevents improper stacking through environmental design.

name: Replace All Resin Transfer Hoses and Quick-Couplings with Redundant Safety Systems
description: Immediately replace all transfer hoses showing signs of age or corrosion (visual inspection completed within 48 hours). Install redundant quick-coupling safety mechanisms that prevent accidental disconnection under pressure. Replace all flexible hoses with braided steel-reinforced versions rated for temperatures up to 120°C. Implement a quarterly hose inspection and replacement schedule regardless of visible condition. This engineering control eliminates the direct cause of the spray incident by improving equipment reliability and preventing unintended releases.

name: Mandate Protective Equipment and Implement Compliance Verification
description: Enforce strict PPE requirements for all hot resin handling: chemical-resistant aprons with integral sleeve covers, insulated gloves rated to 150°C, and safety glasses with side shields. Conduct daily visual inspections by shift supervisors to verify compliant PPE before personnel enter chemical processing areas. Implement a non-compliance disciplinary procedure with first offense resulting in mandatory retraining. Store all required PPE at strategic points near resin handling stations to eliminate access barriers.

name: Develop and Implement Daily Equipment Inspection Protocol with Documentation
description: Create a detailed pre-shift checklist requiring visual inspection of all resin transfer hoses, quick-couplings, and kettle connections for signs of wear, corrosion, or improper seating. Each shift supervisor must document inspection completion and note any defects found. Establish a 24-hour repair/replacement requirement for defective components before equipment can return to service. Train night shift supervisors specifically on identifying early-stage coupling degradation. This administrative control ensures regular monitoring prevents aged equipment failures.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Inspections
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program requiring quarterly inspections of all hydraulic systems on injection molding machines. Inspections will include pressure gauge verification, visual hose assessment for cracks or weeping, coupling integrity checks, and fluid condition analysis. Training will be provided to maintenance technicians on early failure indicators. This proactive approach addresses the root cause of inadequate preventive maintenance and reduces the likelihood of sudden hydraulic failures that could cause injection injuries.

name: Install Hydraulic Rupture Containment Shields
description: Engineering control to install transparent polycarbonate containment shields around high-pressure coupling areas on all 32 injection molding machines. These shields will contain hydraulic spray in the event of a rupture, protecting operators from direct fluid injection while still allowing visual inspection. Shields will be removable for maintenance access and certified to withstand 300+ PSI fluid spray. This engineering control directly mitigates the risk of hydraulic fluid injection injuries by eliminating direct operator exposure to high-pressure spray.

name: Upgrade to Cut-Resistant Finishing Gloves
description: Replace standard work gloves with specialized cut-resistant gloves featuring reinforced palm material and extended cuff coverage rated for abrasion and laceration resistance. Gloves will be ANSI/ISEA Level 3 rated and made from nitrile-coated nylon blend to prevent slipping during wet work. All 15 finishing operators will be fitted with properly sized gloves and trained on proper donning and care. This PPE upgrade directly addresses the inadequate hand protection that contributed to the laceration incident.

name: Install Machine Guards on Die Grinders
description: Install protective guards on all 8 handheld die grinders used in the finishing department. Guards will have adjustable shields that protect the operator's hand and fingers while allowing adequate visibility and work access. All guards will be OSHA-compliant for rotating disc tools. Maintenance will perform daily visual checks to ensure guards remain secure and effective. This engineering control reduces the risk of hand/finger contact with rotating discs.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Robotic Arms
description: Establish a quarterly vibration analysis program for all 32 injection molding machines with robotic arms. Install accelerometers on each servo motor coupling to monitor vibration patterns in real-time. This will allow early detection of loosening or misalignment before operational hazards develop. Technicians will review vibration data weekly and perform preemptive maintenance when thresholds are exceeded. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in robotic arm-related near-misses within 6 months.

name: Enhanced Operator Awareness Training
description: Develop a mandatory 2-hour training module for all production operators focusing on equipment abnormality recognition and early intervention procedures. Training will include case studies of near-misses, video demonstrations of typical equipment failure indicators, and hands-on practice with stop/lockout procedures. Operators will be certified quarterly. This builds on existing operator vigilance and formalizes the early detection culture.

name: Complete Electrical Infrastructure Audit and Upgrade
description: Conduct a comprehensive inspection of all electrical systems in the Chemical Storage building by a certified electrical engineer. Replace all junction boxes over 10 years old and install arc-fault circuit interrupters (AFCIs) on all circuits in high-dust areas. Install weatherproof covers on all electrical connections. Expected completion within 60 days. This eliminates the ignition source entirely by replacing obsolete equipment and adding protective devices.

name: Enhanced Housekeeping and Dust Control Protocol
description: Implement daily vacuum cleaning using HEPA-filtered equipment in all chemical storage areas, targeting dust accumulation on shelves, ledges, and equipment. Establish weekly inspections by supervisors with documented checklists. Install dust collection hoods above material transfer points to capture airborne particles before they settle. Restrict food and personal items from storage areas. Training mandatory for all personnel working in these zones.

name: Install Advanced Fire Detection and Suppression System
description: Install dual-sensor smoke detectors (ionization and photoelectric) throughout the Chemical Storage building and add an automated dry chemical suppression system above material handling and heating stations. System will automatically discharge when fire is detected, with manual override capability. Monthly inspections and annual certification will be performed. This provides both early warning and rapid suppression capability.

name: Implement Quarterly Pallet Rack Structural Inspections
description: Establish a formal inspection schedule requiring a qualified individual to inspect all pallet racks quarterly for structural integrity, load-bearing capacity, damage, and corrosion. Inspections will include verification that load limits are clearly marked and not exceeded. A checklist will be developed and documented for each rack, with results reported to the warehouse supervisor and stored in the safety management system. Any deficiencies will trigger immediate corrective action or rack removal from service.

name: Install Warehouse Load Limit Signage
description: Install permanent signage on all pallet racks in the Finished Goods Warehouse clearly indicating maximum load weight limits per shelf level. Signs will be in English and French per company standards. Additionally, paint yellow and black striping on all racks at the maximum safe stacking height to provide visual cues to material handlers. Conduct a refresher training session for all warehouse personnel on load limits and safe stacking procedures.

name: Upgrade Hopper Overflow Sensor Preventive Maintenance Protocol
description: Revise the preventive maintenance schedule for all injection molding machines to mandate hopper overflow sensor testing and replacement every two weeks instead of the current six-week cycle. Integrate sensor replacement verification into the electronic maintenance management system, with automatic alerts 48 hours before each scheduled replacement. Technicians will document replacement date and sensor serial numbers for traceability. This more aggressive schedule accounts for the thermal stress and contamination exposure these sensors experience in the production environment.

name: Install Real-Time Air Quality Monitors at Injection Lines
description: Install continuous ambient air quality monitoring sensors near Injection Molding Lines A and B that measure volatile organic compound (VOC) levels and styrene concentrations. Sensors will be configured to trigger audible and visual alarms in the production area and in the HSE office if readings exceed 80% of the occupational exposure limit. Data will be logged hourly for trend analysis and compliance documentation. This engineering control provides immediate detection of chemical exposure risks before operator detection via odor.

name: Replace All Hazardous Waste Storage Containers with Compliant Units
description: Procure and install six new fire-rated, secondary-containment hazardous waste storage bins approved for flammable and corrosive chemical waste. Each bin will be certified to hold 110% of the largest single container volume and will feature built-in drip trays, proper ventilation, and temperature monitoring. All bins will be installed in the designated Hazardous Waste Management Area with concrete dikes to prevent lateral spill migration. Existing non-compliant containers will be removed from service. A detailed inventory and labeling system will track all waste containers.

name: Comprehensive Hazardous Waste Storage Area Compliance Audit
description: Conduct a complete facility-wide audit of all chemical and hazardous waste storage areas to identify potential non-compliance with CNESST regulations and company safety policies. Audit scope includes container integrity, secondary containment adequacy, proper labeling, signage visibility, proximity to ignition sources, ventilation sufficiency, and spill response kit availability. All findings will be documented and categorized by priority. Areas of non-compliance will receive corrective action plans with defined timelines, and a compliance tracking dashboard will be established for ongoing monitoring and management.

name: Install Permanent Hazardous Waste Storage Signage and Visual Markers
description: Install permanent, weather-resistant bilingual (French/English) signage at all external access points to the Hazardous Waste Management Area, clearly identifying flammable and chemical storage hazards. Add reflective yellow and black striping on container storage racks and floor-painted boundaries around storage zones. Establish a 3-meter safety perimeter marked with floor striping around all flammable waste containers. Display QR codes linking to digital material safety data sheets (SDS) for each waste stream stored in the area.

name: Install Automated Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Implement real-time thermal sensors on all injection molding machines that display mold surface temperature on individual operator panels and trigger audible/visual alerts when safe-to-touch threshold is reached. The system will integrate with production logs to prevent cycle advancement until minimum cooling time is achieved. This engineering control eliminates the human error element by automating temperature verification and creating physical constraints on the manual handling process.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Requirement for Mold Contact Operations
description: Require all production operators and maintenance technicians to wear certified heat-resistant gloves rated for temperatures up to 200°C whenever handling molds or components post-injection. Provide training on proper glove selection, donning procedures, and care. Conduct monthly audits of glove compliance and condition. This PPE-based control provides secondary protection while primary engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Implement Automated Racking System with Load Limiters
description: Replace manual storage racks in the warehouse with automated or semi-automated racking systems equipped with load cell sensors and mechanical stops that prevent overloading beyond safe limits. Install racking pins on all racks and require their use before and after each shift. Implement digital inventory management that physically restricts stacking if weight distribution is unsafe. This engineering control eliminates human error in load management and creates physical barriers against dangerous stacking practices.

name: Shift-to-Shift Warehouse Handover Checklist and Verification Protocol
description: Develop and implement a mandatory handover checklist where the outgoing shift supervisor and incoming shift supervisor jointly inspect all storage racks, verify racking pin placement, confirm weight distribution compliance, and document findings. This checklist becomes a quality gate preventing shift changes from occurring without verification. Implement weekly audits by warehouse supervisors with photographic documentation. Non-compliance results in corrective action. This administrative control ensures accountability and visibility of storage conditions across all shifts.

name: Warehouse Safety Training and Racking Competency Certification
description: Require all warehouse personnel to complete formal training on proper load stacking, weight distribution principles, racking pin usage, and risk recognition. Implement annual competency certification with practical assessment where employees must demonstrate correct stacking procedures on actual racks with weighted loads. Failed assessments result in restricted warehouse duties pending remediation. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand the consequences and technical requirements of safe stacking.

name: Replace All Aged Resin Dryer Thermostats and Install Dual Thermal Cutoff System
description: Immediately replace all thermostats on resin dryer units regardless of age with new components meeting current manufacturing standards. Install redundant independent thermal cutoff systems on each dryer so that if the primary thermostat fails, the secondary system activates to prevent overheating. Upgrade the control circuit boards to include automatic shutdown protocols triggered by temperature sensor anomalies. This engineering control adds system redundancy and eliminates single points of failure in critical safety systems.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Compliance Tracking and Accountability System
description: Establish a computerized preventive maintenance tracking system that prevents maintenance technicians from closing out maintenance work orders until all required component replacements and inspections are physically verified and documented. Implement monthly compliance audits where a supervisor reviews the maintenance log against the scheduled checklist. Non-completion of scheduled maintenance results in formal escalation. Create a dashboard showing deferred maintenance items in real-time. This administrative control ensures scheduled maintenance is actually completed and creates visibility of maintenance backlog.

name: Install Cooling Chambers and Handling Tools for Hot Parts
description: Engineering control to reduce burn risk: Install passive cooling chambers at each injection molding machine where operators remove parts. Provide silicone-coated handling tongs and thermal gloves (rated for 100°C+) to all production operators. These tools will prevent direct contact with hot materials and allow operators to safely handle parts above 50°C. Expected outcome: Eliminate hand contact with hot plastic parts during normal operations, reducing thermal burn incidents by 95% within the production area.

name: Enhance Operator Training on Heat Hazard Recognition
description: Administrative control: Develop and deliver targeted training module on thermal injury prevention for all injection molding operators. Training will include part temperature estimation techniques, safe handling procedures, and proper use of thermal protection equipment. Implement monthly toolbox talks during shift briefings to reinforce hazard awareness. Create visual signage around high-temperature zones highlighting part temperature ranges and safe handling distances.

name: Replace Storage Bin Support Brackets with High-Grade Stainless Steel
description: Engineering control addressing root cause of equipment failure: Replace all 12 bulk storage bins in the Regrind and Recycling Department with heavy-duty stainless steel support brackets rated for 1.5x maximum load capacity. Implement quarterly inspection protocol with load testing to prevent bracket fatigue and structural failure. Specify Grade 316L stainless steel to resist corrosion from moisture and recycled material contaminants. This eliminates the primary failure mode that caused the incident.

name: Install LED Task Lighting in Regrind and Recycling Department
description: Engineering control to improve visibility during evening/night shift operations: Install 16 LED high-bay lights with motion sensors and dimming capability throughout the recycling department, focusing on storage and transfer areas. Ensure minimum 300 lux illumination at all work surfaces. Improved lighting will reduce operator errors related to visual obstruction and help identify equipment damage before failure. Expected outcome: Reduce shift-related visibility incidents by 80% and enable early detection of structural problems.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Storage Infrastructure
description: Administrative control: Create and implement a formalized preventive maintenance program for all bulk storage bins and support structures. Schedule monthly visual inspections, quarterly detailed inspections with load-deflection testing, and annual ultrasonic thickness testing on brackets. Document all findings in a maintenance tracking system. Train maintenance staff on early signs of metal fatigue and corrosion. This proactive approach prevents future equipment failures and identifies hazards before incidents occur.

name: Replace Resin Dryer Thermostat with Redundant Dual-Control System
description: Engineering control to prevent catastrophic overheating: Replace the single-point thermostat with a redundant dual-controller system featuring independent temperature sensors and microprocessor-based logic. Install a secondary thermal cutoff switch rated 10°C below the maximum safe temperature. Add real-time temperature monitoring with automated alerts sent to maintenance staff when temperature approaches limits. Implement automatic shutdown if both controllers detect simultaneous malfunction. This eliminates the single-failure vulnerability that caused the incident.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Calendar for Resin Processing Equipment
description: Administrative control: Develop comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all 8 resin dryers in the facility. Specify monthly thermostat calibration verification, quarterly full system inspections, and annual replacement of thermal cutoff switches and heating elements regardless of operational status. Create detailed maintenance logs and track all component replacements. Train maintenance technicians on early warning signs of thermostat drift and thermal system degradation. Implement predictive temperature monitoring to catch anomalies before failure.

name: Install Continuous Emission Monitoring and Emergency Ventilation
description: Engineering control to mitigate volatile organic compound exposure during equipment failures: Install VOC sensors in the maintenance workshop connected to emergency ventilation systems that automatically activate when chemical vapor levels exceed safe thresholds. Add dedicated exhaust ductwork to vent decomposition byproducts safely to the exterior. Install visual and audible alarms to alert maintenance technicians of hazardous conditions. This protects staff from inhalation hazards during equipment malfunctions and provides early warning of thermal failures.

name: Implement Overhead Storage Safety Protocol
description: Install anti-slip shelf liners and implement a maximum stack height of three bags per shelf in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Establish a 2-meter clearance zone beneath all overhead storage areas with floor markings and warning signage. Train all material handlers on proper stacking techniques and require the use of mechanical lifting equipment for items stored above shoulder height. Conduct weekly inspections of overhead storage integrity.

name: Install Protective Netting on Overhead Storage
description: Install horizontal safety netting suspended 1.5 meters below all overhead storage shelves in the Regrind and Recycling Department to catch any falling materials before they reach floor level. This engineering control provides secondary protection and prevents materials from traveling unpredictably across work areas.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System for Line C
description: Install additional exhaust hood captures directly above injection molding machine Line C to remove mold release agent aerosols at the source before they settle on equipment and floors. Increase air exchange rate from 4 to 8 times per hour in the South Zone. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of chemical accumulation and improves overall air quality in the production area.

name: Increase Floor Cleaning Frequency and PPE Requirements
description: Establish a mandatory hourly floor cleaning protocol for all high-chemical-use areas during shift operations. Equip all production operators with slip-resistant safety footwear (provided by company) and require the use of anti-slip shoe covers when working in spray application zones. Schedule interim floor wipe-downs using chemical-absorbent pads every 2 hours during evening shift.

name: Implement Mold Release Agent Application Training
description: Conduct mandatory retraining for all operators on proper mold release agent application techniques, including spray distance, duration, and environmental conditions. Establish a spraying protocol that minimizes overspray and includes wind-down periods. Require operators to report excessive agent accumulation immediately so maintenance can clean surfaces before hazardous conditions develop.

name: Replace All Cooling Hoses on Heat Treatment Equipment
description: Conduct a comprehensive inspection of all cooling water hoses on injection molding machines and post-processing equipment throughout the facility. Replace all hoses showing any visible degradation, cracks, or age-related wear. Implement a preventive replacement schedule: hoses rated for 5-year service life will be replaced every 4 years. Use hoses with burst-containment sleeves designed to capture fluid in case of hose rupture, directing flow into a collection tray rather than across the work area.

name: Install Automatic Shutoff Valves on Cooling Circuits
description: Install pressure-relief and automatic shutoff valves on all cooling water supply lines to injection molding machines. These devices will automatically isolate circuits if pressure spikes or flow anomalies occur, preventing large-volume coolant discharge from hose failures. Configure valves to activate at 15% above normal operating pressure, eliminating accidental large spills.

name: Implement Quarterly Hopper Sensor Calibration Program
description: Establish and document a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all hopper level sensors across the 32 injection molding machines. The program will include sensor calibration, cleaning, and functional testing. Maintenance technicians will verify calibration using certified equipment and maintain records in the CMMS system. This addresses the root cause of inadequate preventive maintenance and will prevent future overflow incidents by ensuring early detection of material level anomalies.

name: Install Anti-Slip Matting Around High-Risk Spill Areas
description: Install industrial-grade anti-slip matting at the base of all injection molding machines, particularly around hopper areas where material spillage is common. The matting will be UV-resistant and rated for wet conditions. Staff will clean and inspect matting monthly. This engineering control directly reduces slip hazard by improving traction in areas prone to material accumulation.

name: Enhance Post-Processing Deburring Inspection Protocol
description: Revise the post-processing quality inspection checklist to include mandatory burr and sharp edge inspection for all medical device components before packaging. Train all quality inspectors on proper edge assessment techniques using tactile and visual methods. Implement 100% inspection of high-risk product lines (medical devices) for sharp edges. Any component with unacceptable edges will be routed for rework. This administrative control ensures defective parts do not reach quality testing areas.

name: Distribute Cut-Resistant Gloves to Quality Control Staff
description: Issue ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant gloves to all quality control and inspection personnel for use when handling finished components. Gloves will be nitrile-coated nylon with high dexterity ratings suitable for detailed inspection work. Staff will be trained on proper glove usage and maintenance. While PPE is the last line of defense, this protects staff handling components with potential sharp edges until process improvements eliminate the defects.

name: Establish Quarterly Crane and Rigging Equipment Inspection Program
description: Implement a comprehensive quarterly inspection and maintenance program for all overhead cranes, ratchet straps, slings, and load-bearing equipment. All straps and rigging components will be visually inspected for corrosion, fraying, and wear. Any equipment showing signs of deterioration will be immediately removed from service and replaced. A certified rigger will conduct detailed inspections semi-annually. All equipment will be tagged with inspection dates. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of equipment failure and prevents future incidents.

name: Implement Load Verification and Documentation System
description: Develop a standardized load verification checklist that crane operators must complete before moving suspended loads. The checklist will include load weight verification, strap inspection, attachment point assessment, and destination clearance review. All verifications must be documented on a signed form retained in the warehouse records. Operators will receive training on the new procedure. This administrative control creates accountability and ensures systematic verification of rigging integrity before each load movement.

name: Install Load Control Zone Barriers and Warning Signage
description: Install permanent protective barriers and signage in the warehouse aisle beneath the primary crane loading path. Yellow and black warning tape will mark the no-entry zone during overhead operations. Additional proximity warnings will be posted at entry points. All personnel will receive training on restricted zones. This engineering control prevents personnel from being in the path of falling loads and provides visual reinforcement of hazard areas.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all injection molding machine hydraulic systems, including monthly pressure testing, quarterly hose inspections, and fluid analysis. Implement a tracking system to monitor equipment degradation patterns and schedule maintenance before catastrophic failure occurs. Train all operators to recognize warning signs such as unusual vibrations, pressure fluctuations, and temperature changes, with clear protocols to report issues immediately without deferring maintenance due to production schedules.

name: Install Hydraulic Fluid Containment Barriers
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with secondary containment trays beneath hydraulic pump assemblies and high-pressure hose routing areas. These barriers will capture any sprayed or leaking hydraulic fluid, preventing contact with operators and equipment. Install protective deflector shields around pressurized hose connections to redirect any fluid discharge away from the operator station during potential ruptures.

name: Repair Dehumidification System and Establish Floor Maintenance Protocol
description: Service the malfunctioning dehumidifier in the Material Drying and Preparation Room to restore proper humidity control and prevent condensation accumulation on floor surfaces. Establish a twice-daily floor inspection and drying schedule, with designated staff responsible for identifying and treating wet or slippery surfaces. Install moisture-sensing alarms to alert when humidity levels exceed safe thresholds and schedule preventive maintenance for HVAC/dehumidification equipment every 90 days.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring in Material Handling Areas
description: Replace the polished concrete flooring in the Material Drying and Preparation Room with high-traction anti-slip epoxy coating. This coating maintains durability for heavy material handling while significantly reducing slip hazards even when surfaces become wet. The coating is easy to clean and maintain, meeting ISO standards for slip resistance in industrial environments.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Warehouse Storage Audit and Racking Inspection
description: Perform a complete inspection of all storage racks in the Finished Goods Warehouse to identify weight-bearing capacity issues, structural damage, and improper load distribution. Engage a structural engineer to assess racking integrity and provide remediation recommendations. Implement load weight limit labels on all racks and establish a maximum stack height policy. All staff responsible for warehouse operations must receive retraining on proper pallet placement, weight distribution, and stability verification before resuming material stacking duties.

name: Install Hopper Level Sensors and Alarm System
description: Implement electronic level sensing devices on all injection molding machine hoppers to automatically prevent overfilling and alert operators when material levels reach 85% capacity. The sensors will integrate with machine control systems to pause material feed and trigger audible/visual alarms. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of unplanned hopper overflows by preventing operators from manually loading hoppers beyond safe capacity. Expected outcome: zero hopper overflow incidents within 6 months of implementation.
