name: Quarterly Hopper Cover Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring quarterly inspection of all hopper covers, hinges, and locking mechanisms by maintenance technicians. Create a detailed checklist to verify proper seating, fastener integrity, and mechanical function. Maintenance logs will be recorded in the CMMS system and reviewed during monthly JHSC meetings. This administrative control ensures early detection of cover defects before they contribute to spillage incidents.

name: Replace Wooden Pallets with Plastic Pallets in High-Risk Areas
description: Procure and deploy 200 reusable plastic pallets to replace damaged wooden pallets in the Finished Goods Warehouse and Material Drying areas. Plastic pallets eliminate the splinter hazard entirely through substitution and offer additional benefits including longer service life, improved hygiene, and easier cleaning. Establish a pallet inspection protocol to identify and remove damaged units from circulation before they pose injury risks. This elimination-level control directly addresses the root cause of splinter injuries.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Spill Kits in Chemical Storage Areas
description: Install engineered secondary containment systems (poly-lined concrete basins with minimum 110% capacity of largest container) beneath all solvent storage and transfer areas in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Deploy clearly marked spill kits containing absorbent materials, disposal containers, neutralizing agents, and PPE at strategic locations within 5 meters of chemical handling zones. Conduct staff training on proper use of containment and spill response equipment. This engineering control prevents environmental release and enables rapid response to future incidents.

name: Implement Chemical Hose Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring quarterly inspection of all solvent transfer hoses for cracks, deterioration, and connection integrity. Replace hoses that show signs of wear or have exceeded 5-year service life. Document all inspections and replacements in the maintenance management system. Upgrade all connections to ISO 1219-compliant fittings with secondary containment threads to prevent connection failures. This administrative control addresses the root cause of the spill by ensuring equipment reliability.

name: Enhanced Ventilation System Upgrade and Monitoring
description: Upgrade ventilation systems in the Composite Materials Processing Area with additional exhaust capacity and install continuous air quality monitoring stations with alarms set at 50% of the acetone PEL (125 ppm). Establish a maintenance schedule requiring monthly testing of all ventilation dampers and fan functionality. Train all personnel on ventilation system operation and alarm response procedures. This engineering control ensures adequate air quality management for future chemical handling activities.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Procedures for All Drying Equipment
description: Establish and enforce lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures for all material drying and preparation equipment. All operators must physically lock equipment with personal padlocks and complete LOTO checklist forms before any internal maintenance or jam clearing. Conduct mandatory retraining on LOTO procedures for all relevant personnel within 5 days. Install clear warning signage and pictograms on all drying chamber access points indicating high-temperature hazard and LOTO requirements. Implement daily audits for 30 days to verify compliance, then monthly thereafter.

name: Install Thermal Protective Gloves and Heat-Resistant Sleeves
description: Provide specialized heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C) and protective arm sleeves to all operators working with heated drying chambers and mold equipment. Ensure gloves are stored in designated, clearly marked locations at each workstation. Conduct fitting and training sessions to ensure proper usage and care. Include thermal PPE requirements in equipment-specific standard operating procedures and daily pre-work safety briefings.

name: Upgrade Material Drying Equipment with Automatic Cutoff Sensors
description: Install proximity sensors and automatic material flow shutoff systems on all drying hoppers to prevent unexpected equipment cycling when internal maintenance is being performed. Retrofit existing drying equipment with secondary safety interlocks that disable the heating elements and feed mechanisms when access panels are opened. Conduct equipment modifications within 15 days and verify functionality through manufacturer-certified testing.

name: Implement Daily Floor Cleaning and Material Spill Protocols
description: Establish mandatory daily warehouse floor cleaning schedule with spill response procedures. Deploy absorbent materials at all material handling zones and implement immediate cleanup protocols for plastic pellet spills. Assign responsibility to warehouse staff to conduct hourly visual inspections of high-traffic areas, especially around loading docks and storage racks. Create spill kits stationed at strategic locations with clear usage instructions. Document all cleaning and spill incidents in a log to track problem areas.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring and Improve Warehouse Lighting
description: Apply high-traction anti-slip coatings to all high-traffic warehouse areas, particularly around loading docks, material staging zones, and forklift pathways. Upgrade warehouse lighting to meet OSHA standards of minimum 50 foot-candles in material handling areas. Install additional LED fixtures in previously dim corners and shadowed areas. Conduct lighting audit to ensure uniform illumination. These engineering controls will reduce both slip hazards and visibility-related incidents.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Quarterly Inspection Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a comprehensive quarterly inspection schedule for all hydraulic cooling systems on injection molding machines. Create digital work order checklist requiring documented inspection of all hose connectors, manifold seals, and pressure relief valves. Assign Andrei Popov as lead technician responsible for training all maintenance staff on proper inspection techniques and pressure testing procedures. Implement automated reminder system in maintenance management software to prevent missed inspections. Expected outcome: prevent future cooling system failures and equipment damage through predictive maintenance.

name: Install Secondary Containment Barriers Around Hydraulic Equipment
description: Design and install stainless steel drip containment trays beneath all primary hydraulic manifolds and connection points on the 32 injection molding machines. Each containment system will capture up to 250 liters of fluid to prevent floor contamination and environmental release. Include sloped flooring to direct leaks toward collection sumps with manual shut-off valves. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of large-scale coolant spills reaching the production floor and electrical systems. Maintenance staff will perform weekly visual inspections of containment integrity.

name: Upgrade Electrical Panel Protection in Production Areas
description: Install waterproof enclosure covers and splash shields on all electrical control panels located within 3 meters of hydraulic equipment or cooling systems. Relocate critical electrical components to elevated mounting locations where feasible. Implement redundant electrical shut-off systems that are hardwired independently from main control panels to prevent total system failure during electrical shorts. This measure reduces the risk of cascading equipment failure when cooling system leaks occur.

name: Implement Mandatory Part Quality Inspection Before Assembly
description: Establish a mandatory visual inspection station positioned before all assembly operations where trained Quality Control staff verify that all edges and surfaces meet deburring standards. Create a checklist system with photographic examples of acceptable versus unacceptable edge finish. Any parts failing inspection will be immediately removed from the production line and re-processed through the deburring station. This administrative control ensures no sharp-edged components reach assembly operators. Training will be provided to all relevant staff on quality standards and inspection procedures.

name: Upgrade Glove Specification for Assembly Operations
description: Replace standard latex assembly gloves with specialized cut-resistant gloves rated for composite material handling (ANSI A4 cut level). Distribute new gloves to all assembly operators and provide training on proper fit and use. The upgraded gloves will provide superior protection against sharp edges and fiberglass splinters while maintaining dexterity for precision assembly tasks. Establish monthly glove replacement schedule to ensure PPE effectiveness.

name: Install Automated Deburring Equipment for Mold Cavities
description: Procure and install a CNC deburring machine in the Tool Room equipped with automated edge finishing tools for standard mold cavity geometries. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of manual sharp edge contact during deburring operations. Operator will load the mold, set parameters, and allow the machine to complete deburring automatically. This technology upgrade reduces dependency on manual hand operations around sharp surfaces, improving both safety and consistency of mold quality.

name: Implement Secondary Containment System in Composite Materials Area
description: Install drip trays and secondary containment basins beneath all resin mixing vessels in UNIT-015. Containment systems must have capacity for 150% of largest vessel volume. All containers will be fitted with locking lids and tamper-evident seals. Staff will receive training on proper vessel securing procedures, including three-point locking mechanism verification before any mixing operations commence. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of large-scale spills and chemical exposure.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Composite Materials Processing
description: Install dedicated local exhaust ventilation (LEV) system at all mixing stations in UNIT-015 with minimum 200 CFM capture velocity. System will include carbon filtration and HEPA stage to reduce VOC and particulate emissions by 95%. Engineering controls will reduce inhalation hazard and create safer working environment. Monthly inspection and quarterly filter replacement protocol will be established.

name: Mandatory Refresher Training on Chemical Handling and WHMIS
description: Conduct comprehensive 4-hour training session for all composite materials operators covering updated WHMIS 2015 requirements, SDS interpretation, proper PPE selection and use, emergency response procedures, and thermal hazard awareness. Training will be delivered within 10 days and documented. All composite area staff must achieve 90% on knowledge assessment. Administrative control ensures workers understand chemical hazards and proper containment protocols.

name: Install Permanent Cable and Hose Management System
description: Install cable trays, conduit systems, and hose routing brackets along loading dock stairs and high-traffic pathways to eliminate floor-level hazards. All pneumatic hoses will be routed overhead using P-clips rated for compressed air use. Equipment will be labeled with bright yellow and black chevron tape. This engineering control permanently removes the trip hazard by eliminating hose/cable contact with walkways.

name: Establish Maintenance-Warehouse Coordination Protocol
description: Create formal work coordination procedure requiring maintenance to schedule equipment checks 24 hours in advance and notify warehouse staff. Maintenance personnel must clearly mark any temporary hoses/cables with high-visibility warning flags and maintain clear pathways. Daily housekeeping inspection checklist will be implemented with responsibility assigned to warehouse lead. Administrative control prevents future coordination failures.

name: Implement Compressed Air Safety Program with Regulator Controls
description: Install pressure regulators on all compressed air lines in production areas, limiting maximum PSI to 40 PSI for cleaning operations. Install pressure gauges at each workstation for easy operator verification. All compressed air hoses will have clearly marked PSI rating labels. Engineering controls reduce hazard by limiting projectile velocity. Training component will establish operator awareness of safe air pressure thresholds.

name: Provide Compressed Air Safety Training to All Production Operators
description: Conduct mandatory 1-hour training module covering compressed air hazards, safe pressure limits, proper use of safety barriers, PPE requirements, and alternative cleaning methods (vacuum systems, soft brushes). Training will be delivered to all 45 production operators within 14 days with documented sign-off. Assessment quiz will verify understanding. Administrative control ensures operators understand compressed air risks and safe handling procedures.

name: Implement Enhanced Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Enforcement Program
description: Establish mandatory LOTO verification checkpoints on all injection molding equipment with documented sign-offs by two personnel before maintenance begins. Install mechanical lockout stations at each machine with color-coded, serialized locks and personal tagout devices. Conduct monthly LOTO audits with photographic documentation. Require recertification training for all operators and maintenance personnel within 30 days, with quarterly refresher sessions. Deploy LOTO compliance checklist posters at each workstation. Create disciplinary policy with consequences for LOTO violations, up to and including suspension.

name: Install Hydraulic Pressure Relief and Machine Interlock Safety System
description: Upgrade all injection molding machines on Line B with automatic hydraulic pressure relief systems that vent to safe levels when mold cavity access doors are opened. Install mechanical and electronic interlocks on mold access gates that prevent machine cycle initiation when doors are unlatched or when mold halves are positioned beyond safety parameters. Integrate these interlocks with the PLC control system to provide audible and visual warnings. Conduct FAT (Factory Acceptance Testing) with third-party engineering firm and implement preventive maintenance schedule for interlock inspection every 30 days.

name: Establish Confined-Space-Like Protocol for Mold Cavity Maintenance
description: Designate mold cavity work as a controlled maintenance procedure requiring the same protocols as confined space entry, including atmospheric verification, trained entry supervisor (Confined Space Entry Supervisor), permit-to-work system, and buddy system requirements. Create standardized maintenance permit forms specific to mold cavity work. Train all relevant personnel on the new protocol. Implement a digital permit management system to track compliance. Review and update the procedure annually with input from operators and maintenance staff.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program with Condition Monitoring
description: Deploy vibration analysis and thermal imaging equipment to monitor all critical conveyor systems on a monthly basis. Establish baseline vibration signatures for all belt-driven equipment. Integrate IoT-enabled bearing temperature sensors on motors and gearboxes with real-time alerting when thresholds are exceeded. Create a digital maintenance management system (CMMS) to track all lubrication intervals, part replacements, and inspection dates. Schedule automatic alerts 2 weeks before each service interval. Train maintenance staff on condition monitoring interpretation. Conduct monthly reviews of collected data to identify trending issues before failure occurs.

name: Replace End-of-Life Conveyor Equipment with Modern System
description: Replace the 25-year-old conveyor belt system with a new heavy-duty modular conveyor featuring sealed bearing cartridges (requiring lubrication only every 12 months), integrated safety guarding, emergency stop stations every 10 feet, and built-in variable frequency drive (VFD) for controlled acceleration/deceleration. Select equipment with predictive maintenance capabilities and remote diagnostics. Ensure new system meets current ISO safety standards (ISO 13857, ISO 14120). Install safety signage and machine guarding per ANSI/ASABE standards. Provide comprehensive training to all operators and maintenance personnel on the new system.

name: Mandatory PPE and Safe Cutting Tool Implementation
description: Issue all warehouse and materials handling personnel with polycarbonate safety glasses (ANSI Z87.1 rated) and require their use whenever handling glass-fiber composite materials. Establish a no-utility-knife policy for material handling; replace all utility knives with retractable box cutters featuring automatic blade retraction and thumb guards (Stanley 10-180 or equivalent). Implement a tool inspection and blade replacement protocol: all box cutters must be inspected weekly, dull blades replaced immediately, and damaged tools removed from service. Place safety glasses and box cutters in a locked storage cabinet with sign-out logs. Conduct a 15-minute safety toolbox talk at start of each shift emphasizing proper cutting techniques and hand positioning.

name: Establish Glass-Fiber Material Handling and Respiratory Protection Protocol
description: Create a specific work procedure for receiving and handling glass-fiber reinforced materials, including requirements for respiratory protection (N95 masks minimum, P100 respirators recommended), eye protection, long sleeves, and gloves. Establish a designated unloading zone with localized dust capture or ventilation improvements. Provide annual respiratory protection fit-testing and training for all materials handlers. Implement signage on all glass-fiber shipments indicating respiratory hazard. Store these materials in a separate, dedicated area away from general warehouse traffic to minimize fiber dust exposure to other employees. Conduct quarterly air quality monitoring in the receiving area.

name: Establish Mandatory Preventive Maintenance Schedule with Priority Override Authority
description: Create a non-negotiable preventive maintenance (PM) calendar for all critical equipment including cooling systems, with lockdown dates that cannot be deferred for production schedules. Implement a maintenance tracking software that alerts supervisors 7 days before each PM is due. Establish a policy requiring maintenance completion before high-priority orders are scheduled on that equipment. Train production supervisors on the long-term cost of skipped maintenance versus short-term delays. This administrative control ensures critical equipment receives proper care independent of immediate production pressures.

name: Upgrade Cooling System Components with Corrosion-Resistant Materials
description: Replace all copper tubing in injection molding lines with stainless steel tubing rated for higher pressures and resistant to corrosion from prolonged moisture exposure. Install redundant pressure relief valves and rupture detection sensors on cooling circuits. Add secondary containment trays beneath connection points to capture any leaks immediately, preventing floor hazards. Upgrade pump bearings to sealed, pre-lubricated units requiring service only every 3 years. These engineering controls eliminate the cooling water leak hazard at its source.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Ergonomic Assessments for All Assembly Stations
description: Hire a certified ergonomics consultant to perform formal workstation assessments for all 15 assembly operator positions within 14 days. Each assessment will evaluate desk height, monitor positioning, reach distances, chair adjustment, and repetitive motion patterns. Document findings and create individualized adjustment plans. Purchase adjustable work tables, monitor arms, and ergonomic chairs for stations requiring modifications. Establish a policy requiring annual ergonomic reassessments and immediate action on employee complaints. This administrative and engineering control prioritizes injury prevention and addresses the root cause of Tatiana's injury.

name: Implement Mandatory Rest Break and Rotation Program for Assembly Operators
description: Establish a policy requiring all assembly operators to take a 10-minute break every 2 hours from repetitive tasks, with mandatory rotation to different task types if available. Create a visual break schedule posted at each station. Train supervisors to enforce breaks and track compliance. Provide stretching guides and ergonomic micro-break exercises at each workstation. Rotate operators between high-repetition tasks and lower-repetition quality inspection duties throughout the day to reduce cumulative strain. These administrative controls reduce the physical stress on wrists and upper extremities.

name: Implement Mandatory Deburring Quality Checkpoint
description: Establish a dedicated quality control checkpoint at the post-processing line where all composite and plastic parts undergo mandatory inspection for sharp edges, burrs, and protrusions before warehouse transfer. Train Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) and all quality staff on proper detection techniques using tactile and visual methods. Implement a 100% inspection protocol for parts with known edge hazards, including polycarbonate and nylon components. Documentation of inspections will be tracked daily in the quality management system.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Glove PPE to Warehouse Staff
description: Issue cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 rating) to all assembly operators and warehouse staff who handle finished goods or semi-finished components. Conduct toolbox talk training on proper glove selection, fit, and inspection. Ensure gloves are available in multiple sizes and replaced monthly or when damaged. While this is a PPE control and lower on the hierarchy, it provides immediate protection while process improvements are implemented.

name: Mandatory Machine Shutdown Procedure Training
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive lockout/tagout (LOTO) training program specifically for injection molding equipment, emphasizing proper cooldown procedures. All operators on Lines A, B, and C will receive recertification training conducted by Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105). Training will include classroom instruction, hands-on demonstration with cold equipment, and competency testing. A laminated step-by-step procedure card will be posted at each machine. Training completion will be tracked in employee records and refreshed annually or when equipment is modified.

name: Install Thermal Pressure Relief Guard on Machine Access Ports
description: Engineer a protective guard or deflector shield over the access port on Line A's injection molding machine that redirects or contains expelled material during pressure release events. Work with equipment manufacturer to source compatible guards that maintain proper air circulation. Installation will be completed by maintenance technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) within 10 days. This engineering control eliminates direct contact with expelled molten material.

name: Replace Faulty Electrical Heating System with Thermostat-Controlled Unit
description: Engage an electrical engineer to inspect and certify all heating systems in the Chemical Storage Building. Replace the faulty heating element on the affected TPE resin drum with a UL-certified heating jacket featuring automatic thermostat cutoff (set to 5°C below material ignition temperature). Install temperature monitoring sensors with alarm capability that alert HSE personnel when temperature exceeds safe limits. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) will oversee installation and documentation. This engineering control eliminates the ignition source.

name: Implement Chemical Storage Area Reorganization and Segregation
description: Reconfigure the Chemical Storage Room to ensure minimum 6-foot separation between heat-generating equipment and flammable material storage. Create designated zones with clearly marked boundaries: heating zone, volatile solvent storage zone, and non-flammable material zone. Install fire-rated shelving in the flammable materials storage area. Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron will work with HSE to implement labeling and signage. Fire suppression capability will be enhanced with addition of two emergency eyewash stations and accessible fire extinguishers in each zone.

name: Conduct Facility-Wide Fire Prevention and Emergency Response Drills
description: Training Coordinator Amélie Roy (EMP-00028) will organize and conduct facility-wide fire prevention training and full-scale emergency evacuation drills within 60 days of the incident. All 200 employees will participate in classroom training covering fire prevention, proper use of fire extinguishers (PASS technique), evacuation procedures, and assembly point accountability. Specialized training for HSE committee and shift supervisors on chemical fire hazards and advanced suppression techniques. Drills will be conducted quarterly thereafter and documented with corrective actions recorded.

name: Mandatory LOTO Protocol Enforcement at Molding Lines
description: Implement mandatory lockout/tagout procedures for all maintenance and troubleshooting activities at injection molding lines. Install visible LOTO stations at Lines A and B with energy isolation requirements clearly posted. Conduct refresher training for all machine setters on LOTO procedures and consequences. Require supervisor sign-off before any non-standard operations. Establish a culture where stopping production is prioritized over productivity to address jams safely.

name: Install Pressure-Sensitive Safety Guards on Mold Closing Mechanisms
description: Retrofit injection molding lines A and B with proximity sensors and pressure-sensitive safety guards that prevent mold closing when hands are detected in the hazard zone. These engineering controls will provide a fail-safe backup to administrative controls. Include automatic alert system that notifies operators when guards are bypassed or disabled. Test all systems monthly to ensure proper functioning.

name: Enhanced Machine Safety Training for Setters and Operators
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training on machine guarding, hazard recognition, and safe work procedures specific to injection molding equipment. Include case studies of crush injuries and near-misses. Require annual certification with practical competency assessment. Training to cover emergency stops, lockout procedures, and when to call maintenance versus attempting self-repair.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Spill Prevention System
description: Install drip trays and secondary containment systems beneath all chemical transfer stations in the Chemical Storage building. Containment capacity must be at least 110% of the largest container volume. Install absorbent spill kits at each transfer station with clear labeling and monthly inspections to ensure kit completeness. Mark secondary containment areas clearly on the floor with non-slip paint.

name: Enhanced Chemical Safety Training and PPE Requirements
description: Mandate chemical safety goggles, face shield, and chemical-resistant long sleeves for all personnel working in chemical transfer areas. Conduct hands-on WHMIS training focusing on mold release agent hazards, proper transfer procedures, and emergency response protocols. Establish a buddy system for all chemical handling tasks. Post emergency contact numbers and first aid procedures visibly at all transfer stations.

name: Install Mechanical Lifting Assistance at Packaging Station
description: Purchase and install an adjustable pneumatic lift table (capacity 25 kg, height range 60-100 cm) at the Packaging and Labeling Station. This engineering control will eliminate the need for employees to manually lift boxes from ground level to waist height. The lift table will reduce strain on the lower back by 70-80% and improve ergonomic positioning. Staff will receive 2-hour training on proper use. Implementation includes installation of safety guards and emergency stop buttons. Expected outcome: reduction in back-related injuries by 60% in packaging operations within 12 months.

name: Implement Ergonomic Training Program for Packaging Staff
description: Develop and deliver a mandatory 4-hour ergonomics training module covering proper lifting techniques, load assessment, use of mechanical aids, and recognition of early strain symptoms. Training will be conducted by occupational health consultant for all 12 packaging and labeling employees. Modules will include video demonstrations of correct lifting posture for various box sizes and weights common in operations. Annual refresher training will be mandated. This administrative control establishes safe work practices and builds employee awareness of ergonomic hazards.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Monitoring System
description: Install vibration and temperature sensors on all three hydraulic pump motors and central compressor units. Connect sensors to cloud-based predictive maintenance platform (e.g., Mobius or similar CMMS integration). System will automatically alert maintenance team when bearing vibration or temperature thresholds are exceeded, enabling intervention before catastrophic failure. Data will be reviewed weekly by maintenance planner. This engineering control transforms reactive maintenance into proactive prevention. Expected outcome: 85% reduction in unexpected equipment failures, improved system uptime to 99%+, reduced emergency replacement costs.

name: Establish Mandatory Preventive Maintenance Schedule with Backup Resources
description: Revise preventive maintenance schedule with clear responsibility assignments for all critical equipment. Schedule hydraulic motor lubrication checks every 500 operating hours (approximately monthly). Cross-train two additional technicians as backup to ensure schedule adherence during staffing gaps. Create color-coded maintenance calendar visible in workshop. Maintenance planner will track compliance monthly and report to HSE committee. This administrative control ensures consistent maintenance execution. Include quarterly bearing inspections and oil analysis testing to catch degradation early.

name: Establish Safety-Critical Maintenance Priority System
description: Implement a three-tier maintenance prioritization system where any reported software glitches or hardware faults affecting machine safety systems are classified as Tier 1 (immediate resolution within 24 hours). Current system treated all maintenance requests equally, resulting in safety-critical issues being deprioritized. New process requires: (1) documented hazard assessment for any flagged issue, (2) supervisor sign-off for any delay beyond 24 hours, (3) weekly safety committee review of Tier 1 backlog. Production engineering and maintenance leadership will jointly own this system. Expected outcome: elimination of known safety hazards from backlog, prevention of near-miss recurrence.

name: Repair Injection Mold Pressure Release Software Glitch
description: Engage equipment manufacturer's technical support to debug and patch the mold clamp hydraulic pressure release algorithm in the injection molding controller software. The glitch causes intermittent failure to fully de-pressurize hydraulic lines when emergency stop is activated. Schedule maintenance window for 6 hours (likely overnight). Install updated firmware on all 32 molding machines. Conduct full system validation testing post-installation with pressure sensors and manual verification. This engineering control eliminates the root hazard. Document all software versions post-patch to prevent regression.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protective Gloves for All Molding Operators
description: Replace standard cotton work gloves with heat-resistant Kevlar-lined gloves rated for temperatures up to 350°C across all injection molding lines. Distribute to all operators on Lines A, B, and C by shift. Implement mandatory glove inspection weekly to ensure proper condition. Train all operators during next safety meeting on proper glove usage and storage. Expected outcome: Eliminate thermal burns from hot plastic contact and drips.

name: Repair and Preventive Maintenance of Automatic Ejector Systems
description: Conduct immediate inspection and repair of the Line C automatic part ejector that malfunctioned. Schedule comprehensive preventive maintenance for all 32 injection molding machines on a bi-weekly basis to identify worn ejector pins, sensors, and hydraulic components before failure. Maintenance team to document all findings in equipment log. This engineering control eliminates the need for manual part removal in emergency situations. Expected outcome: Reduce manual handling of hot components by 95% and prevent future burn incidents.

name: Mandatory Heat-Related Safety Training for Production Staff
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training on thermal hazards, proper PPE selection, first aid for burns, and emergency response procedures. Training to be completed by all production operators within 10 days. Include hands-on demonstration of proper glove fit and usage. Documentation of training completion to be maintained by HSE office. Expected outcome: Increase operator awareness of thermal hazards and proper use of protective equipment.

name: Implement Automated Flash Removal Station
description: Install a dedicated flash-removal workstation with pneumatic deburring equipment to automatically remove sharp edges from molded components before they reach assembly operations. This engineering control eliminates the manual contact with sharp edges. Equipment to be installed in the post-processing area adjacent to Line B within 20 days. Training provided to operators on proper use and safety protocols. Expected outcome: Eliminate 90% of hand lacerations from sharp component edges.

name: Comprehensive Forklift Fleet Maintenance and Inspection Program
description: Immediately inspect all eight propane-powered forklifts and six electric forklifts for hydraulic system integrity, steering responsiveness, brake function, and tire condition. Schedule quarterly preventive maintenance for all units with certified technician. Implement mandatory daily pre-operation inspections by operators with documented checklist. Any vehicle failing inspection must be removed from service until repaired. Expected outcome: Eliminate hydraulic failures and steering defects that cause uncontrolled vehicle movement.

name: Redesign and Reinforce Storage Rack Configuration
description: Replace three damaged storage racks with heavy-duty commercial-grade racks featuring reinforced cross-bracing, higher load ratings (3,500 kg minimum), and improved stability. Install protective bumpers along the outer edges of the storage area perimeter. Implement clear floor marking and yellow/black warning lines around all storage zones. Add secondary containment barriers to prevent racks from overturning into adjacent areas. Expected outcome: Increase rack durability and prevent inventory loss from collision impacts.

name: Implement Forklift Operator Certification and Refresher Training
description: Require all 12 personnel with forklift operation responsibilities to complete certified forklift operator training (CNESST-compliant) within 30 days. Conduct annual refresher training emphasizing emergency steering failure response, load securing, speed reduction in congested areas, and backup procedures. Implement written competency assessments with minimum 85% passing score. Non-certified operators prohibited from operating forklifts. Expected outcome: Improve operator awareness and response capabilities during equipment failures.

name: Implement Mandatory Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a non-negotiable preventive maintenance program for all material handling equipment with weekly inspections, monthly component checks, and quarterly full system audits. Create a tracking system that locks out equipment if maintenance dates are missed. Maintenance scheduling will be protected in production planning and cannot be deferred. All motor drives, bearings, and transmission systems will be inspected on a fixed 4-week cycle with documented sign-off by maintenance supervisors.

name: Install Protective Barriers Around Compressed Air Manifolds
description: Design and install reinforced polycarbonate guards around all high-pressure air distribution manifolds in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. These barriers will contain fragments in case of line rupture and prevent equipment contact. Install redundant pressure relief valves on all manifold banks to reduce pressure-spike risks. Add visible high-pressure warning signage and update equipment layout diagrams.

name: Upgrade Mold Insulation Materials with High-Temperature Specification
description: Replace all mold release mechanism insulation on injection molding lines with industrial-grade ceramic fiber composite rated for continuous exposure at 300°C+. Conduct a complete audit of all 32 molding machines to identify and replace substandard insulation. Establish a quarterly inspection protocol to assess insulation integrity and schedule replacement every 18 months or when degradation is detected. Maintain inventory of replacement materials to prevent operational delays.

name: Mandatory Heat Exposure Protection and Retraining Program
description: Implement mandatory training for all production operators on thermal hazard recognition, proper use of high-temperature resistant gloves (Kevlar-rated to 500°C minimum), and safe mold changeout procedures. Require operators to wear thermal-protective aprons during all mold work. Establish a certification requirement renewed annually. Conduct supervised drills monthly on the evening and night shifts where thermal burn injury rates are highest.

name: Install Remote Mold Release Extraction System
description: Engineer and install an automated remote-controlled mold release system for high-temperature zones that eliminates manual contact with heated components during part extraction. Retrofit existing molding lines with pneumatic or robotic part-extraction attachments. This eliminates the primary hazard source through engineering control rather than relying on PPE alone.

name: Install Advanced Temperature Monitoring and Automated Ventilation System
description: Install continuous real-time temperature sensors throughout the recycling bin with automatic alerts when internal temperatures exceed 65°C. Integrate with an upgraded mechanical ventilation system that increases airflow automatically when temperatures rise, preventing thermal accumulation. Install thermal imaging cameras to detect hotspots before they become critical. Add humidity control to reduce static electricity risk in the dusty environment.

name: Implement Material Compatibility Segregation and Processing Protocol
description: Establish a rigorous waste material sorting procedure that segregates different thermoplastic types before they enter the grinding system. Create separate processing streams for incompatible materials to prevent exothermic reactions. Implement a color-coded bin system and train all operators on material identification. Limit batch sizes to reduce thermal load during processing. Document all material batches processed with date, type, and temperature records.

name: Upgrade Fire Suppression and Emergency Response Capability
description: Replace existing dry powder extinguishers with specialized Class D foam suppressants designed for thermoplastic fires. Install an automated pre-action sprinkler system in the recycling department that triggers at 70°C. Conduct quarterly fire drills specific to plastics fires. Maintain clearance zones around all recycling equipment and establish a no-smoking, no-hot-work zone with 50-foot perimeter. Install visible fire exit signage and ensure all personnel complete annual fire safety certification.

name: Repair Emergency Stop Button Circuit on Line D
description: Complete electrical diagnostic and replacement of the non-functional emergency stop button circuit on Injection Molding Line D. This is a critical safety device that must respond immediately to operator commands. The repair will include testing of all interlocked safety circuits and verification that the button reliably de-energizes the hopper feed motor when activated. This addresses the root cause of the incident where the emergency stop failed to function, requiring manual intervention at a remote panel.

name: Install Hopper Level Sensor with Automatic Cutoff
description: Install an electronic hopper level sensor with integrated automatic shutoff capability on all injection molding lines to prevent overflow incidents. When material reaches a safe maximum level, the sensor will automatically stop the material feeder. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of operator override during emergency situations and prevents the creation of slip hazards from material spillage. Implementation includes sensor calibration and integration with existing hopper control systems across UNIT-004.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hopper Systems
description: Develop and implement a documented preventive maintenance schedule for all hopper feed systems with quarterly inspections of control modules, electrical connections, and emergency stop circuits. All reported equipment issues will be tracked in a centralized maintenance log and prioritized based on safety impact. Outstanding maintenance requests will be escalated to management if not completed within 14 days. This administrative control ensures systematic identification and correction of equipment defects before they contribute to incidents.

name: Implement Drum Integrity Inspection and Rotation Program
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection program for all flammable solvent storage drums to identify corrosion, leaks, and structural degradation before failure occurs. Drums showing any signs of corrosion or damage will be immediately isolated and transferred to secondary containment for safe disposal. Implement a FIFO (First In, First Out) inventory rotation system to ensure older drums are used first, reducing the likelihood of long-term corrosion issues. All inspections will be documented in a centralized log maintained by the Chemical Safety Officer.

name: Install Enhanced Fire Detection and Suppression System
description: Upgrade the Chemical Storage room with dual-stage fire detection including both traditional smoke detectors and advanced vapor detection sensors capable of identifying flammable vapor concentrations before ignition. Install a dedicated dry chemical suppression system in addition to the existing sprinkler system, specifically designed for class B fires (flammable liquids). The system will include manual pull stations and automatic activation at 25% LEL (Lower Explosive Limit) detection. This engineering control provides redundant layers of protection against fire propagation.

name: Establish Solvent Vapor Management and Dust Control Protocol
description: Implement a comprehensive dust control program in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building, including weekly vacuuming of composite fiber dust with HEPA-equipped equipment (not air sweeping which disperses particles). Install permanent ventilation upgrades to maintain negative air pressure in the storage room and establish a minimum air exchange rate of 6 changes per hour. Designate UNIT-010 as a restricted dust zone and require all personnel handling dry materials to use grounding straps during activities that generate static electricity. Prohibit spark-generating equipment in the solvent storage area.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment Infrastructure
description: Replace all existing solvent storage racks with containment systems featuring integrated drip pans designed to capture 110% of the volume of the largest single container plus 10% of aggregate capacity. All secondary containment will have sealed, sloped floors directing any leakage to a central collection sump monitored with low-level leak detection sensors. Install absorbent pads rated for flammable liquids in all storage areas and establish a formal spill response kit location with monthly inventory checks. This eliminates the accumulation of solvent pools on facility floors.

name: Implement Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory requirement for all mold cleaning operations to utilize ANSI-rated heat-resistant gloves rated for temperatures up to 150°C. Conduct a procurement review to ensure gloves are available in all sizes and stored at each injection molding station. Include visual reminder signage at all mold stations depicting proper glove usage. Implement a monthly glove inventory audit to ensure compliance and replacement of worn equipment. Train all Production Operations staff on proper glove selection, donning, and doffing procedures during the next quarterly safety meeting.

name: Establish Mold Cooling Verification Procedure
description: Develop a written standard operating procedure requiring operators to verify mold temperature below 50°C using infrared thermometers before initiating any manual cleaning or maintenance work. Create a logbook at each molding station where operators must record mold temperature readings before cleaning tasks. Supervisors will conduct daily audits of these logs during shift transitions. Include this verification step in the machine lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures to ensure systematic compliance and prevent similar incidents.

name: Install Cable Conduit Protection System
description: Install protective cable conduit along all pneumatic and electrical supply lines in the maintenance workshop, particularly in the Equipment Storage mezzanine area. The conduit will be rated for industrial environments and provide abrasion resistance against sharp surfaces. Secure conduit runs using appropriate clips and supports every 3 feet to prevent sagging and contact with equipment edges. This engineering control will eliminate the root cause of cable damage by substituting the unprotected cable design with a protected system. All future installations will adhere to this standard.

name: Establish Monthly Electrical Cable Inspection Program
description: Create a formal monthly inspection schedule for all electrical cables throughout the Maintenance Workshop and Equipment Storage areas. Assign responsibility to the Instrumentation Technician to conduct systematic visual inspections using a checklist that documents cable condition, routing, support adequacy, and any signs of damage or deterioration. Document findings in a maintenance logbook and establish a protocol requiring immediate de-energization and repair of any defective cables. Integrate these inspections into the predictive maintenance program currently in implementation.

name: Conduct Electrical Safety Refresher Training
description: Develop and deliver a focused electrical safety training module for all Maintenance and Engineering personnel covering hazards associated with damaged cables, proper grounding procedures, lockout/tagout requirements for electrical equipment, and identification of unsafe electrical conditions. Training will include recognition of insulation damage, exposed wiring, and improper cable routing. All personnel in the maintenance workshop will complete this training within 30 days of incident declaration. Training records will be maintained as part of the CNESST compliance documentation.

name: Implement Comprehensive Hydraulic System Lockout Procedure
description: Develop and enforce a mandatory lockout/tagout procedure specifically for injection molding equipment hydraulic systems that requires all hydraulic pressure to be relieved and the system to be de-energized before any maintenance, adjustment, or component retrieval beneath the machine. The procedure will include pressure gauge verification, accumulator discharge procedures, and mechanical isolation of hydraulic lines. Create visual quick-reference cards at each molding station showing the required LOTO sequence. Assign responsibility to Maintenance supervisors to conduct weekly audits of LOTO compliance with documented evidence. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of pressurized fluid contact.

name: Schedule Preventive Maintenance for Hydraulic Fittings
description: Initiate a comprehensive inspection and preventive replacement program for all hydraulic fittings on injection molding equipment. Establish a maintenance schedule requiring hydraulic fitting inspections quarterly with visual documentation of fitting condition, pressure ratings, and connection integrity. Replace fittings showing wear, corrosion, or pressure rating concerns according to manufacturer specifications. Implement a tracking system that records fitting maintenance history for each machine. This substitution and engineering control addresses the root cause of fitting failure by ensuring equipment is maintained according to design specifications.

name: Conduct Mandatory LOTO and Hydraulic Safety Training
description: Deliver comprehensive lockout/tagout training for all Production Operations staff focusing on injection molding equipment, with specific emphasis on hydraulic system hazards, proper pressure isolation procedures, and consequences of non-compliance. Include training on recognizing signs of hydraulic system failure such as leaks, unusual noises, or pressure anomalies. Require all operators to complete a practical demonstration of the LOTO procedure on their assigned equipment under supervisor observation. Implement annual refresher training with documented competency assessments. This administrative control ensures operators understand the critical importance of proper procedure compliance.

name: Install Protective Covers on Fire Alarm Stations
description: Install clear polycarbonate protective covers with hinged access doors on all 12 manual fire alarm pull stations throughout the facility. The covers will require deliberate lifting action before the alarm can be pulled, preventing accidental activation while maintaining immediate accessibility during genuine emergencies. All personnel will receive updated training on cover operation. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of unintended contact with the alarm mechanism.

name: Relocate Fire Alarm Stations Away from High-Traffic Areas
description: Conduct a facility layout review to identify and relocate five fire alarm pull stations currently positioned in high-traffic maintenance and production zones. New locations will be selected to maintain code-compliant accessibility while minimizing incidental contact risk. Stations will be placed in visible locations but away from equipment and walkway contact points. Signage will clearly mark new locations to ensure emergency awareness.

name: Implement Equipment Damage Recovery Plan and Insurance Review
description: Establish rapid equipment inspection and damage recovery protocols following accidental fire suppression discharge. Coordinate with equipment manufacturers for emergency service support. Review facility insurance coverage to ensure adequate protection against accidental activation events. Develop supplier contacts for expedited replacement of water-damaged sensitive equipment. Document all damage and costs to support insurance claims and operational recovery timelines.

name: Install Secondary Containment Systems in Chemical Storage Area
description: Design and install secondary containment trays and barriers beneath all chemical storage shelving in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Containment capacity must hold 110% of the largest container volume (22 liters minimum). Trays will be constructed from chemical-resistant materials compatible with all stored substances. This engineering control ensures that any future spills will be immediately contained and prevented from spreading across the facility floor, significantly reducing cleanup scope and environmental exposure risk.

name: Implement Container Cap Inspection and Sealing Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-transfer inspection procedure requiring visual verification and manual testing of all chemical container caps before movement. Implement a checklist system where personnel must confirm cap tightness and integrity before transporting containers. Provide training to all staff handling chemicals on proper cap sealing techniques. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of improper cap sealing during the previous shift.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Chemical Handlers
description: Replace existing nitrile gloves with Viton gloves rated for extended chemical contact with mold release agents and silicone compounds. Issue chemical-resistant aprons and footwear to all personnel working in the mixing area. Provide face shields and respirators (cartridge-type for organic vapors) to be worn during all chemical transfer operations. Update WHMIS labeling and safety data sheet information at the mixing station for immediate reference.

name: Establish Mandatory Load Securing Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a pre-shipment load inspection checklist requiring verification that all palletized loads meet minimum securing standards: minimum four corner straps, cross-bracing on stacks exceeding 1.8 meters, and weight distribution verification. All loads must be visually inspected and signed off by the packaging supervisor before forklift transport. This administrative control ensures consistent application of load securing procedures and creates accountability through documented inspection records.

name: Conduct Forklift Operator Refresher Training on Load Assessment
description: Deliver focused training to all 12 forklift operators on recognizing unstable loads, proper response procedures, and when to reject improperly secured pallets. Training will include scenario-based exercises demonstrating load shift indicators and safe response techniques. Operators will be empowered to refuse transport of questionable loads without penalty. This administrative control reinforces the critical role operators play in preventing material handling incidents.

name: Install Air Hose Safety Retaining Clips and Routing Guides
description: All compressed air hose couplings throughout the facility will be upgraded with industry-standard safety retaining clips to prevent accidental disconnection. Additionally, all air hoses will be rerouted using cable trays and secured guides to eliminate trip hazards across walkways and work areas. New hose management standards will require hoses to be positioned against walls or overhead when possible. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the near-miss by eliminating the potential for whip hazards.

name: Implement Air Hose Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: A monthly inspection schedule will be established for all compressed air systems. Maintenance technicians will document the condition of couplings, hose routing, and retaining mechanisms. Training will be provided to all operators on proper hose handling and the critical importance of reporting any loose or damaged couplings immediately. This administrative control ensures ongoing prevention of similar incidents.

name: Retrofit All Mobile Storage Racks with Locking Mechanisms
description: All mobile cooling racks and storage units in the Assembly and Finishing Department will be equipped with redundant locking casters and securing cables. Each unit will be assigned a permanent location with marked floor anchors. A visual labeling system will indicate whether the rack is secured or mobile. Staff will receive toolbox training on proper securing procedures before moving any equipment. This engineering control prevents equipment from shifting and eliminates the hazard at its source.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Enforcement and Automated Machine Lockout System
description: All injection molding machines will be retrofitted with automated LOTO enforcement systems that prevent operation when a safety interlock is not engaged and verified. Additionally, LOTO procedures will be made mandatory with no exceptions, and production incentives will be restructured to eliminate time pressure conflicts with safety procedures. Supervisors will conduct weekly audits of LOTO compliance with documented verification. All operators will receive immediate refresher training on the critical importance of LOTO procedures, with certification required before returning to production work.

name: Repair or Replace Faulty Auto-Cycle Timer and Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: The intermittent auto-cycle timer fault on Line B Machine 7 will be permanently resolved through component replacement. A comprehensive preventive maintenance program will be established with quarterly inspections of all timer mechanisms, safety interlocks, and pressure release valves. A maintenance tracking system will ensure that all reported equipment faults are resolved within 72 hours. This eliminates the root cause that contributed to the unexpected machine cycle during the incident.

name: Implement Production Scheduling and Safety-First Culture Initiative
description: Production quotas will be adjusted to prevent time pressure situations that create incentives to bypass safety procedures. A company-wide safety culture initiative will communicate that no production target justifies bypassing mandatory safety procedures. Management will implement positive reinforcement for safe work practices and will hold daily safety huddles. Employee safety committees will be empowered to halt production if safety concerns arise without penalty.

name: Implement Composite Panel Edge Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory inspection procedure for all composite panels after trimming and finishing operations to identify and eliminate sharp edges before assembly. Quality inspectors will use specialized edge detection tools and perform tactile verification at each station. Training will be provided to all assembly operators on identifying hazardous edges and reporting concerns. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause by ensuring no sharp edges enter the assembly process, reducing laceration and cut risks from composite materials.

name: Upgrade Protective Glove Requirements
description: Replace standard nitrile gloves with cut-resistant composite-handling gloves rated for sharp edge protection. Conduct fitting sessions for all assembly operators and maintain an inventory of properly sized gloves. Include glove selection and inspection in the daily safety briefing. While this is a PPE-level control, it provides immediate protection pending completion of the edge inspection protocol and serves as a secondary safeguard for composite material handling.

name: Emergency Ventilation System Restoration
description: Immediately replace all clogged air intake filters in the chemical mixing room ventilation system and conduct a complete system performance test to verify 100% airflow restoration. Perform baseline air quality monitoring before and after corrective action to document hazard elimination. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause by restoring the primary hazard control mechanism designed to protect workers from chemical vapor exposure.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Filters
description: Create and implement a documented preventive maintenance program specifying that all ventilation system intake filters in UNIT-010 must be inspected monthly and replaced every 60 days or when visual inspection indicates 50% clogging. Assign specific maintenance staff responsibility for tracking and execution. Integrate filter replacement dates into the facility's maintenance management system with automatic reminders. This administrative control prevents recurrence by institutionalizing routine maintenance and creating accountability.

name: Install Real-Time Ventilation Monitoring System
description: Deploy continuous air quality and ventilation performance monitoring equipment in the chemical mixing room that will alert operators and supervisors when airflow drops below 90% of design capacity. System should trigger an automatic shutdown protocol for high-risk mixing operations and alert maintenance staff via mobile notification. This engineering control provides real-time detection of future ventilation degradation, enabling rapid corrective response before worker exposure risk materializes.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedure Verification System
description: Implement a dual-verification lockout/tagout system where no injection molding machine maintenance or cleaning work can commence without documented evidence that: (1) the machine has been powered down via main disconnect switch, (2) all residual heat has been dissipated (verified by temperature probe to confirm <50°C), and (3) a second trained operator has independently verified proper LOTO status by signing off on a physical checklist posted at the equipment. This engineering and administrative control prevents unauthorized operation and ensures thermal hazards are eliminated before worker exposure.

name: Comprehensive LOTO Refresher Training for All Molding Line Operators
description: Conduct mandatory recertification training for all 24 injection molding operators on proper LOTO procedures, thermal hazard recognition, and emergency response protocols. Training must include hands-on verification of LOTO procedures at each assigned machine line. Require annual refresher training going forward with documented competency assessment. This administrative control ensures all operators understand proper hazard elimination procedures and can perform verification independently, preventing future incidents from procedural non-compliance.

name: Install Automatic Machine Cooling Shutdown System
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with automated thermal shutdown systems that prevent operators from performing maintenance until the heating barrel has cooled to safe operating temperatures (<50°C). The system will physically lock the maintenance access covers until temperature parameters are met, creating an engineering control that eliminates thermal hazard exposure even if LOTO procedures are not followed. This is a primary control that removes the hazard source rather than relying on operator compliance.

name: Implement Chemical Container Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a daily pre-transfer inspection checklist for all chemical containers, requiring visual verification of lid integrity, seal condition, and expiration dates. Train all personnel handling chemicals to perform these inspections and document findings in a logbook. This administrative control will prevent degraded containers from being moved, reducing spill risk. Containers showing wear will be transferred to secondary containment or replaced immediately.

name: Upgrade Spill Response Equipment and Training
description: Install additional spill containment kits with absorbent materials at three strategic locations in the composite materials area. Conduct monthly spill response drills for all shift supervisors and production staff. Provide hands-on training on proper use of absorbent materials, secondary containment procedures, and emergency ventilation activation. This will ensure faster response times and minimize vapor exposure during future incidents.

name: Implement Mandatory Part Deburring Station
description: Install an automated deburring and edge polishing station on Injection Molding Line A immediately following the ejection point. All parts will pass through this station before being transferred to quality control or packaging. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of sharp edges by removing burrs at the source, before parts enter inspection areas. Expected outcome: elimination of burr-related hand injuries in quality control and assembly operations.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Gloves for Quality Control Staff
description: Issue ANSI A3-rated cut-resistant gloves to all quality control and inspection personnel. These gloves will be required PPE during all part inspection activities. Conduct training on proper glove selection, fit, and care. This provides an immediate layer of protection while the deburring station is being installed, and serves as a secondary control after the engineering solution is implemented.

name: Reinstall and Secure Machine Thermal Guards
description: Immediately reinstall thermal guards on all injection molding lines, using tamper-evident fasteners that require supervisor authorization to remove. Establish a maintenance log tracking all guard removals, reasons, and reinstallation dates. Conduct a facility-wide audit of all machines to ensure all thermal guards are in place and functional. This engineering control eliminates direct contact with hot barrel surfaces during routine operations and maintenance tasks.

name: Mandatory High-Temperature PPE for Line Maintenance
description: Issue flame-resistant and high-temperature-resistant sleeves and gloves to all production operators and maintenance staff. Require use of this PPE during any machine maintenance, hopper clearing, or barrel work. Conduct mandatory training on proper donning, use, and care of high-temperature protective equipment. Include this requirement in the LOTO procedures and pre-work safety briefings. Post visual reminders at each machine station.

name: Implement Machine Guard Removal Control and Certification
description: Establish a formal procedure requiring written authorization from the HSE manager before any machine guard can be removed. All removed guards must be tagged with removal date, reason, and reinstallation date. Maintenance personnel must re-certify all guards upon reinstallation before the machine can return to production. Conduct monthly audits of all guard status. This administrative control ensures accountability and prevents guards from remaining off machines indefinitely.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays at All Drum Storage Stations
description: Implement 65-gallon secondary containment trays beneath all resin and chemical drums in UNIT-010. These trays will capture 110% of the largest container volume, preventing floor spills from spreading. Position trays to integrate with existing material handling paths. Train all material handlers on proper drum placement and inspection procedures. Conduct monthly audits to ensure trays remain empty and functional. Expected outcome: elimination of large-scale floor spills and reduced environmental and personal exposure incidents.

name: Implement Drum Inspection and Threading Protocol
description: Develop and enforce a standard operating procedure requiring visual inspection of all drum bungs before transfer and mixing operations. Create laminated inspection checklists posted at each drum staging area. Require operators to verify bung tightness using a calibrated torque wrench set to manufacturer specifications (45-55 ft-lbs for polyester resin drums). Include this inspection as a daily pre-shift checklist item. Conduct refresher training for all material handlers and production operators on proper drum handling. Expected outcome: elimination of improperly sealed drums and associated spill incidents.

name: Relocate Chemical Spill Response Kit to Central Location
description: Install additional spill response stations within 15 feet of all chemical storage and mixing areas. Each station will contain absorbent pads (minimum 50 sheets per station), spill containment booms, chemical neutralizers, disposal bags, and PPE (nitrile gloves, eye wash bottles). Mark stations with high-visibility signage and ensure monthly inventory checks. Conduct quarterly drills with production staff to maintain response competency. Expected outcome: response time reduced from 8 minutes to under 2 minutes, minimizing spill spread and employee exposure.

name: Implement Mandatory Nitrogen Accumulator Pressure Gauge Certification Program
description: Establish a quarterly calibration and certification schedule for all pressure relief gauges on injection molding equipment. Contract with certified hydraulic/pneumatic service provider to verify accuracy and functionality. Maintain calibration records on equipment log sheets. Install color-coded tags (green/yellow/red) on gauges indicating last calibration date and next required service. Replace all gauges that cannot be verified within 12 months. Cross-reference this maintenance schedule with LOTO procedures to prevent operations if gauges are uncalibrated. Expected outcome: elimination of false pressure readings and reliable confirmation of safe lockout states during maintenance operations.

name: Enhance LOTO Verification Procedures with Multi-Point Confirmation
description: Revise LOTO procedures to require verification of pressure relief at two independent points: (1) pressure gauge reading AND (2) manual pressure test using calibrated test gauge performed by authorized technician. Require documented sign-off from both LOTO coordinator and production supervisor before cavity access is permitted. Implement digital LOTO log system with mandatory photo documentation of pressure gauge status and test gauge readings. Train all operators and maintenance staff on enhanced verification procedures. Conduct monthly audits of LOTO compliance. Expected outcome: elimination of false lockout confirmations and improved operator confidence in safe work conditions.

name: Redesign Maintenance Workshop Workbench with Anti-Slip Surfaces and Edge Guards
description: Replace existing sloped workbenches with flat, anti-slip work surfaces featuring integrated edge guards and part containment lips. Install positive mechanical stops at all workbench edges to prevent parts from rolling beyond the surface. Implement angled trays with 6-inch high walls for positioning small to medium components. Install under-bench storage racks to eliminate floor clutter. Train all machinists on proper part positioning within the new workbench design. Expected outcome: elimination of sliding part incidents and improved ergonomic workspace organization.

name: Establish CNC Safety Interlock Re-Enablement Verification Checklist
description: Create a mandatory maintenance completion checklist requiring verification that all safety interlocks (spindle guard interlocks, emergency stops, load-sensing limits) are functional before equipment is returned to service. Require electrical maintenance technician sign-off AND independent verification by production supervisor. Implement digital tag-out system preventing equipment restart until all interlocks are re-tested and documented. Add quarterly testing of all interlocks as preventive maintenance task. Expected outcome: elimination of disabled safety features and prevention of near-miss and injury incidents.

name: Conduct Behavior-Based Safety Training for CNC Work Zone Awareness
description: Implement specialized training module focusing on situational awareness in CNC work zones, including recognition of active spindles, understanding emergency stop locations and functions, and maintaining safe positioning relative to rotating equipment. Include scenario-based training with video demonstrations of near-miss incidents. Require all machinists and maintenance technicians to complete training and pass competency assessment. Conduct refresher training semi-annually. Expected outcome: improved operator awareness of machinery status and enhanced emergency response capability.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification and Quarterly Audits
description: Implement a rigorous Lockout/Tagout certification program requiring all maintenance and production personnel to complete hands-on LOTO training with practical assessments quarterly. Establish a schedule of unannounced LOTO audits across all equipment during maintenance activities, with audits conducted by HSE personnel and maintenance supervisors. Non-compliance will result in immediate suspension from equipment maintenance duties. Additionally, implement a digital LOTO tracking system to log all lockout/tagout events with timestamped photographic evidence.

name: Install Pressure Relief and Isolation Valves
description: Install secondary pressure relief valves and manual isolation ball valves on all injection molding equipment hoppers to eliminate residual pressure risks. Engineer secondary mechanical interlocks that prevent hopper access when injection screws are in motion. All hoppers will be retrofitted with clear warning labels and tactile barriers. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of residual pressure activation and provides multiple layers of protection independent of human compliance.

name: Enhanced PPE Requirements for Hopper Work
description: Require all personnel performing hopper maintenance to wear specialized cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rated) and reinforced work sleeves as mandatory PPE. Establish a PPE inspection protocol to ensure gloves meet performance standards and are replaced monthly. Update the standard operating procedures to document that hopper work is prohibited without proper PPE and full LOTO compliance. Conduct monthly refresher training on PPE requirements specific to injection molding operations.

name: Install Real-Time Environmental Monitoring System
description: Replace the existing passive humidity monitoring with a fully integrated real-time digital system featuring continuous sensor arrays throughout the Finished Goods Warehouse. The system will trigger automatic alerts when temperature or humidity deviates from tolerance bands, with notifications sent to warehouse supervisors, HSE, and maintenance via SMS and email. Install backup dehumidification units with automatic activation if primary HVAC humidity control fails. Implement weekly calibration checks of all sensors with documented records maintained in the facility database.

name: Establish Environmental Monitoring Daily Checklist
description: Create a standardized daily environmental quality checklist for all warehouse shifts, requiring confirmation of HVAC functionality, visual inspection of stored materials for contamination, and manual recording of temperature/humidity readings. Assign specific accountability to each shift supervisor for completing and signing the checklist. Implement a shift handover log where off-going shifts must document any equipment anomalies or concerns for incoming shifts to address. Conduct monthly audits of checklist compliance with corrective retraining for non-compliance.

name: Secure All Wall-Mounted Storage and Utility Equipment
description: Conduct a comprehensive facility audit to identify all utility carts, storage racks, and equipment positioned against walls or in high-traffic corridors. Implement permanent mechanical anchoring for all wall-mounted storage using L-brackets, cable systems, and vibration-resistant fasteners rated for the weight of stored materials. Specifically, secure the metal utility cart in the Material Drying Room corridor with anti-slip flooring underneath and cable restraints at multiple points. All modifications will be completed to CNESST standards with certification.

name: Implement Pathway Width and Clearance Standards
description: Establish and mark all vehicle traffic corridors with minimum 4.5-meter clearances for forklift operations, exceeding the current 3.5-meter narrow corridor. Paint high-visibility yellow warning lines 60 centimeters from walls and fixed structures to indicate forklift exclusion zones. Install convex safety mirrors at all blind corners and intersections. Create a detailed facility traffic map showing designated forklift routes, pedestrian zones, and no-equipment areas. Conduct refresher training for all equipment operators on these new routing requirements.

name: Install Thermal Protective Barriers on Mold Surfaces
description: Install silicone-based thermal guard covers on all exposed mold surfaces in Injection Molding Line A that regularly exceed 60°C during operation. These barriers will provide tactile and thermal protection while allowing visual inspection through transparent sections. Barriers will be removable for maintenance and replaced quarterly. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate thermal protection and reduces burn risk significantly. Installation will occur during the next scheduled maintenance window.

name: Enhanced Heat Awareness Training for Production Operators
description: Develop and deliver a focused 30-minute training module on thermal hazard recognition and mold surface temperature management for all injection molding operators. Training will include demonstration of proper handling techniques, identification of visual cues for hot surfaces, and mandatory use of thermal imaging devices before manual mold contact. All operators will complete this training within 30 days and demonstrate competency through practical assessment.

name: Implement Automated Load Restraint Systems in Warehouse
description: Install load-locking automated restraint systems on all pallet jacks and material handling equipment in the packaging and warehousing area. These systems will prevent unintended load disengagement through redundant mechanical and electronic monitoring. All material handlers will receive certification training on proper use. Additionally, implement height limitation markers on all storage racks to prevent stacking beyond safe thresholds. This engineering control eliminates the primary failure mode that caused the incident.

name: Mandatory Daily Equipment Safety Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a documented daily pre-shift inspection checklist for all material handling equipment, including pallet jacks, forklifts, and load restraint systems. All equipment must be visually and functionally tested before use each shift. Any equipment failing inspection will be removed from service immediately and tagged for repair. A trained safety monitor will conduct spot checks daily. This administrative control ensures equipment reliability and identifies maintenance issues before they cause incidents.

name: Material Handling Safety Certification Program
description: Require all material handlers to complete formal CNESST-aligned material handling and load securing certification within 60 days. Training will cover proper load assessment, center-of-gravity identification, safe stacking practices, and emergency response procedures. Only certified personnel will be permitted to operate material handling equipment. Refresher training will occur annually. This administrative and training control addresses the knowledge gap that contributed to the incident.

name: Install Dual-Channel Safety Monitoring on Hydraulic Presses
