description: Create a structured job rotation program that alternates assembly operators between different task types every 2 hours to minimize repetitive strain exposure. Tasks will be grouped by movement patterns (fine motor, gross motor, standing vs. seated). Train all assembly operators on at least three different station configurations to enable seamless rotation. Update production scheduling software to track and enforce rotation patterns automatically.

name: Reinforce Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Compliance Training
description: Conduct immediate LOTO refresher training for all CNC machinists and maintenance personnel, emphasizing that machine disengagement is mandatory before any manual material handling or cleaning operations. Implement a visual checklist system at each milling station showing required LOTO steps. Require supervisors to verify LOTO compliance through documented spot-checks twice weekly. Update all work instructions with photographic LOTO requirements at key steps.

name: Install Machine Interlock Safety Switches
description: Install mechanical interlock switches on the CNC milling machines in UNIT-013 that automatically stop spindle rotation when access covers are opened or hands enter the cutting zone. These engineering controls will prevent accidental contact even if operator bypasses LOTO procedures. Conduct maintenance checks monthly to ensure interlock functionality. Document all interlock tests in equipment maintenance logs.

name: Install High-Friction Anti-Slip Flooring in High-Risk Areas
description: Replace polished concrete flooring in UNIT-016 (Material Drying and Preparation Room) with industrial-grade anti-slip epoxy coating with minimum coefficient of friction (COF) of 0.60. Focus on areas around material transfer stations, storage hoppers, and near hydraulic equipment. The coating will be resistant to oil contamination and chemical exposure. Install the flooring within 4 weeks and conduct quarterly inspections to maintain slip-resistant properties.

name: Implement Daily Floor Inspection and Cleaning Protocol
description: Establish mandatory documented floor inspection checklist for all shifts, requiring supervisors to perform visual inspections every 2 hours, specifically checking for oil, water, and debris. Implement immediate cleanup procedures with spill kit stationed in UNIT-016. Assign cleaning responsibility with clear accountability. Create a digital logbook system to track inspections and corrective actions taken. Train all night shift staff on hazard recognition and reporting procedures, with emphasis on communicating floor hazards when supervision is limited.

name: Repair Hydraulic Equipment Leak and Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Immediately repair the hydraulic press oil leak in the adjacent system that contributed to floor contamination. Establish preventive maintenance schedule with weekly inspections of all hydraulic connections, seals, and hoses. Install secondary containment trays under hydraulic equipment to capture any future leaks before they reach the floor. Maintain detailed maintenance records and conduct quarterly review of equipment condition. Train maintenance staff on early leak detection techniques.

name: Implement Monthly Chemical Container Inspection Program
description: Establish a documented monthly inspection schedule for all chemical storage containers, focusing on valve connections, seal integrity, and corrosion indicators. Inspections will be performed by trained maintenance personnel using a standardized checklist. Any container showing signs of corrosion or valve degradation will be immediately removed from service and replaced. This eliminates the root cause of container failures and prevents future spills. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in spill incidents caused by container valve failure.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Container Quality Standards
description: Replace all existing chemical containers in UNIT-010 with stainless steel or polymer containers rated for 10+ year service life with integrated pressure relief valves and secondary containment bases. Current containers are carbon steel and susceptible to corrosion. New containers will feature anti-corrosion coatings and quarterly replacement cycles. This engineering control removes the hazard of container failure at the source rather than relying on inspection procedures alone.

name: Enhanced Spill Response Training for Material Handlers
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive spill response training to all material handlers, warehouse staff, and supervisors covering identification of hazardous chemical properties, proper use of absorbent materials, ventilation system activation, and emergency notification procedures. Training will include hands-on drills quarterly. Emphasis will be placed on recognizing early warning signs of container degradation and proper PPE selection for different chemical categories.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Program for Dryer Equipment
description: Implement a condition-monitoring program using vibration analysis sensors on all resin dryer motors to detect bearing wear before failure occurs. Real-time monitoring data will trigger automatic maintenance alerts when vibration exceeds threshold parameters. This replaces reactive time-interval maintenance with predictive maintenance based on actual equipment condition. Maintenance technicians will receive training on sensor interpretation and threshold setting. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in unplanned dryer downtime due to bearing failure.

name: Mandatory Bearing Lubrication Schedule with Digital Tracking
description: Create a digital maintenance tracking system (integrated into existing CMMS software) that generates automatic work orders for bearing re-greasing on the 12-month manufacturer-recommended cycle. Each maintenance action will be logged with photographic evidence and logged by the technician. Maintenance supervisor will receive weekly alerts showing upcoming due maintenance. This administrative control ensures lubrication intervals are never exceeded and creates accountability.

name: Ergonomic Redesign of Part Extraction Tools
description: Commission industrial ergonomics consultant to redesign the part extraction tooling in UNIT-005, focusing on reducing required gripping force and wrist twisting motions. Current manual extraction requires force estimates of 15-20 pounds per part. New ergonomic tools will incorporate mechanical advantage principles and angled handles to reduce force requirements to less than 8 pounds per extraction. Tools will be tested with production workers before full implementation. Expected outcome: 70% reduction in wrist strain injuries in part removal operations.

name: Implement Mandatory Work Rotation and Micro-Break Protocol
description: Establish a job rotation schedule requiring assembly workers performing repetitive tasks to rotate to different workstations every 90 minutes, with 10-minute rest breaks every 2 hours of repetitive work. Supervisors will use timers and visible schedule boards to enforce compliance. Workers will receive stretching instruction focused on wrist and forearm muscle groups. An administrative control procedure will be documented and included in employee work procedures. Supervisors will monitor compliance during daily safety stand-ups.

name: Provide Preventive Wrist Support PPE and Training
description: Distribute ergonomic wrist support braces (compression sleeves with rigid stays) to all workers in repetitive assembly roles. Workers will receive instruction on proper donning/doffing procedures and when to use the supports. Supports will be provided in multiple sizes and will be replaced annually. While PPE is a lower-hierarchy control, it provides immediate harm reduction while longer-term engineering solutions are implemented.

name: Implement Heat-Resistant Glove Inventory Management System
description: Establish a mandatory daily inventory check system for heat-resistant gloves at the start of each shift on all injection molding lines. Create a dedicated storage location with visual inventory indicators showing minimum stock levels. Assign responsibility to the shift lead to verify adequate supplies before operations begin. Integrate this check into the daily production log. All operators will be trained on the specific glove types required for each mold temperature range and will sign off on receipt of proper PPE at shift start.

name: Conduct Mandatory PPE Retraining for All Molding Line Operators
description: Schedule mandatory 2-hour refresher training sessions for all 45 production operators working on injection molding lines. Training will cover: identification of temperature hazards specific to each mold station, selection of appropriate PPE based on mold temperature (nitrile vs. heat-resistant vs. composite gloves), proper donning and doffing techniques, and inspection procedures for damaged gloves. Training will include hands-on demonstration of glove performance under heat exposure. Completion must be documented and tracked. This training must be completed within 30 days.

name: Install Temperature Warning Labels on High-Temperature Molds
description: Apply high-visibility thermal hazard warning labels on all injection molds operating above 150°C. Labels will clearly indicate the mold temperature range and required PPE. These will be installed on all accessible surfaces of each mold. Additionally, implement color-coded glove storage bins at each workstation: red bins for molds >170°C (heat-resistant gloves required), yellow bins for 130-170°C (composite gloves), and blue bins for <130°C (standard nitrile acceptable). This visual system provides immediate guidance without requiring operators to consult reference materials.

name: Establish Equipment Coupling Inspection and Maintenance Program
description: Implement a preventive maintenance schedule requiring inspection and re-torquing of all material transfer hose couplings every 400 operating hours (reduced from 500 to provide additional safety margin). Create a checklist-based inspection process that includes: visual crack/corrosion assessment, thread integrity verification, coupling torque measurement using calibrated wrenches, and documentation in the maintenance log. Assign maintenance technician responsibility and track completion using the predictive maintenance software. All couplings will be tagged with last inspection date. This measure directly addresses the root cause of premature coupling failure.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Material Drying Room
description: Install enhanced local exhaust ventilation (LEV) hood directly above the material transfer station in the Drying and Preparation Room. The hood will capture dust and vapor emissions at source before they disperse into the breathing zone. Ventilation will be interlocked with material transfer operations such that the system automatically activates when the hopper is opened. Install visual indicators showing ventilation status. Conduct airflow velocity testing to confirm capture efficiency of >95% for polymer particulates. This engineering control reduces respiratory exposure risk during normal operations and spill situations.

name: Mandatory Chemical Splash Goggles Policy Implementation
description: Establish and communicate a mandatory policy requiring all personnel working in chemical handling areas to wear ANSI Z87.1 certified chemical splash goggles (in addition to safety glasses) whenever handling liquids or volatile chemicals. Place prominent signage at all chemical workstations showing the required PPE. Conduct an immediate audit of all chemical mixing workstations to ensure splash goggles are available, properly maintained, and in good condition. Train all chemical handling staff on correct fitting and inspection procedures. Non-compliance will be addressed through progressive discipline. This represents a simple administrative and PPE control that significantly reduces eye injury risk.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Chemical Liquid Measurement
description: Provide secondary containment trays (chemical-resistant polypropylene, 15L capacity minimum) at all chemical measuring and dispensing stations. These trays will contain any accidental spills and prevent liquid spread across work surfaces. Ensure graduated cylinders, beakers, and other measuring equipment are always placed within the containment tray during use. Include absorbent pads in the tray for rapid spill cleanup. Establish a daily inspection routine to verify tray integrity and cleanliness. This engineering control reduces both personnel exposure and environmental release risks.

name: Replace Faded Thermal Hazard Labels on All Molds
description: Conduct immediate inspection of all injection molding equipment in Lines C and D to identify faded or illegible warning labels. Replace all thermal hazard labels with high-visibility alternatives that clearly indicate mold surface temperature and required cool-down periods. This eliminates reliance on worker memory and creates visual reminders at the point of hazard. Labels will use pictograms and bilingual text (French/English) for clarity across the workforce.

name: Implement Mandatory Cool-Down Verification System
description: Install temperature sensors on injection molding lines that prevent mold cavity access until the surface temperature drops below 50°C. A green indicator light will illuminate only when safe to handle parts. This engineering control removes the reliance on operator adherence to timing procedures. All operators will receive training on the new system during the next scheduled shift briefing.

name: Install Material Storage Racks with Load Capacity Indicators
description: Replace existing ad-hoc shelving in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility with industrial-grade storage racks specifically designed for bulk resin storage. Each shelf will have permanently installed load capacity nameplates indicating maximum weight limits and proper orientation (vertical vs. horizontal). This engineering control eliminates ambiguity about proper material placement and creates physical barriers to overloading.

name: Implement Monthly Chemical Storage Audits
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection program for the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility led by the Warehouse Supervisor. Audits will verify correct material orientation, load limits compliance, and shelf condition. Results will be documented and reviewed during monthly JHSC meetings. Training will be provided to all warehouse associates on proper stacking procedures during the next shift rotation.

name: Install Automatic Pressure Regulation on Compressed Air System
description: Implement pressure regulators set to maximum 6 bar on all compressed air supply lines feeding the production areas. This engineering control prevents pressures exceeding safe limits regardless of operator actions. Regulators will include visual gauge indicators for pressure verification. All operators will receive training on the new system during mandatory safety briefings.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification System
description: Install a physical LOTO verification checkpoint system where technicians must obtain supervisor sign-off before any maintenance work begins. All LOTO procedures will be laminated and posted at each machine with photographic guides. A monthly audit will be conducted by the HSE department to verify compliance. Training will be mandatory for all maintenance staff within 2 weeks, with competency assessments required before returning to solo maintenance duties.

name: Install Machine Guarding and Proximity Sensors
description: Install electronic proximity sensors on all 50-ton and larger injection molding machines to detect hand presence near pinch points. These sensors will integrate with the LOTO system to prevent machine cycling if a hazard is detected. Additionally, perimeter guarding will be installed around the nozzle area. Engineering controls upgrade will reduce reliance on procedural compliance alone and provide passive protection during maintenance operations.

name: Establish Production Pressure Relief Protocol
description: Create a documented shift handover procedure that explicitly permits maintenance-induced production delays without penalty. Supervisors will be trained to recognize and mitigate time pressure that leads to safety shortcuts. A near-miss reporting system will track any future LOTO bypass attempts, with root cause analysis focusing on scheduling and workload issues rather than individual blame.

name: Upgrade Deburring Equipment and Maintenance Schedule
description: Conduct preventive maintenance on the automated deburring equipment to ensure consistent operation without schedule delays. Install a backup deburring station to provide redundancy during maintenance periods. Establish a predictive maintenance schedule based on equipment runtime rather than reactive repairs. This engineering control will eliminate the root cause of inadequate deburring that led to sharp edges on parts.

name: Install Cable Management and Overhead Routing System
description: Replace floor-level cable and hose routing with overhead cable trays and wall-mounted conduit throughout UNIT-015. All air hoses will be suspended from the ceiling or routed along walls using cable management clips rated for the hose pressure. This engineering control eliminates the trip hazard completely by removing the hazard source from the walking surface.

name: Upgrade Composite Area Lighting to LED with Motion Sensors
description: Replace existing fluorescent lighting with LED high-efficiency fixtures providing minimum 500 lux illumination throughout UNIT-015, with motion-activated supplemental lighting in storage areas. Night shift workers will have clear visibility of all floor hazards, reducing trips and falls. Improved lighting also enhances quality control during night shift composite material processing.

name: Establish Daily Safety Walk and Housekeeping Audit
description: Implement a mandatory 15-minute beginning-of-shift safety walk in UNIT-015 where the shift supervisor inspects for trip hazards, cable management compliance, and storage rack stability. A daily checklist will be completed and posted. Night shift staff will receive additional hazard awareness training specific to low-light conditions. This administrative control ensures hazards are identified and corrected before workers begin production activities.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Program
description: Establish a formalized Lockout/Tagout verification system where a second trained employee must independently confirm that all energy sources are isolated before any maintenance begins. Create a standardized checklist and verification log for each machine on all production lines. Conduct immediate retraining for all maintenance and production staff on LOTO procedures with emphasis on never bypassing lockout protocols. Include monthly audits of LOTO compliance with corrective action for any violations. This administrative control will prevent similar incidents by ensuring dual verification of machine de-energization.

name: Install Machine Interlocks on Hopper Maintenance Access Points
description: Engineer and install mechanical interlocks on hopper access panels for all 32 injection molding machines that prevent screw rotation when panels are opened or partially opened. Retrofit existing machines with proximity sensors that automatically trigger emergency stops if hands approach rotating components during active cycles. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source by making it physically impossible to access the screw while it is rotating. Expected outcome is complete prevention of hand entanglement incidents during routine hopper clearing operations.

name: Upgrade Injection Molding Technician Training Program
description: Develop comprehensive refresher training module specifically addressing high-risk maintenance tasks on injection molding lines. Include scenario-based training with equipment simulators showing consequences of improper maintenance procedures. Require annual certification and monthly toolbox talks focused on rotating equipment hazards. Implement a mentorship program pairing experienced technicians with newer staff for first 50 hours of independent maintenance work. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand hazard recognition and proper procedures for routine maintenance tasks.

name: Replace Chemical Storage Containers and Install Secondary Containment
description: Immediately replace all deteriorating or defective chemical containers in the Hazardous Waste Management Area with new sealed containers using automated sealing systems. Install individual secondary containment trays under all chemical storage shelves capable of containing 150% of stored liquid volume. Implement a monthly inspection protocol for container integrity with documented sign-off by warehouse supervisor. Engineer storage racks to include dividers preventing containers from shifting or falling if one container fails. This eliminates the root cause of chemical exposure and falling material hazards.

name: Require Chemical-Resistant PPE for Hazardous Waste Area
description: Mandate that all personnel entering the Hazardous Waste Management Area wear full chemical-resistant aprons, arm guards, and closed-toe shoes with chemical-resistant coating. Provide nitrile gloves rated for organic solvents and safety glasses with side protection. Establish a dedicated PPE station at the area entrance with inspection and replacement protocols. Conduct training on proper donning and doffing of chemical-resistant equipment. While this is a PPE control (lower hierarchy), it provides necessary protection given the chemical hazard nature of the area.

name: Install Aisle Traffic Management and Forklift Routing System
description: Engineer dedicated one-way traffic lanes in the Regrind and Recycling Department with painted floor markings, directional arrows, and mirror installations at blind intersections to eliminate head-on collision risk. Implement a radio-based communication system requiring operators to announce their position and direction before entering narrow aisles. Install convex mirrors at high-risk intersection points and create designated forklift staging areas where operators must yield and wait for opposing traffic to clear. Establish maximum load height restrictions in narrow aisles to improve operator sightlines. These engineering controls will prevent vehicle-to-vehicle collisions in confined warehouse spaces.

name: Mandate Powered Industrial Truck (PIT) Operator Recertification
description: Require immediate recertification of all forklift and powered industrial truck operators across the facility, with emphasis on blind-spot awareness, load visibility limitations, and communication protocols in confined spaces. Implement refresher training every 12 months for all operators rather than the current 3-year certification cycle. Include practical scenarios simulating narrow aisle operations and accident reconstruction videos showing consequences of operator errors. Create a three-strike incident policy where operators involved in near-miss or actual collision incidents must complete additional supervised training before returning to independent operation. This administrative control ensures operators maintain current knowledge of safety practices.

name: Implement Ergonomic Assessment and Workstation Redesign
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessment of all assembly stations by certified ergonomist. Redesign Station 5 including adjustable height work surface, anti-fatigue matting, and optimized tool grip designs to reduce repetitive stress. Install adjustable task lighting and wrist supports. Develop job rotation schedule requiring position changes every 90 minutes. Establish 5-minute stretching breaks every 2 hours with guided exercises specific to hand and wrist strain prevention.

name: Establish Mandatory Ergonomics and RSI Prevention Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training for all assembly line staff on repetitive strain injury prevention, early warning signs, and proper ergonomic techniques. Include hands-on demonstration of correct posture, tool handling, and break exercises. Train supervisors on identifying at-risk workers and implementing preventive measures. Schedule quarterly refresher training and create visual ergonomics reminders at each assembly station.

name: Install Hopper Level Monitoring and Automatic Shut-off System
description: Install ultrasonic level sensors on all injection molding hoppers to detect material accumulation and pressure buildup. Integrate sensors with machine control systems to automatically activate alert systems and reduce feed rates when levels exceed safe thresholds. Implement automatic shut-off valves if critical levels are reached. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of unexpected overflow by preventing dangerous conditions from developing.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hopper Systems
description: Develop and implement formal preventive maintenance schedule requiring inspection and cleaning of hopper outlet valves every 12 operating hours. Train maintenance staff on proper inspection procedures and early warning signs of clogging. Document all maintenance activities and identify patterns of valve failure. Rotate responsibility among maintenance team members to ensure consistent execution.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedures and Machine Inspection Protocol
description: Reinforce lockout/tagout procedures requiring all machines to be de-energized and locked before any inspection or adjustment. Prohibit reaching into hoppers without proper guards and personal protective equipment. Issue thermal-resistant aprons and arm guards rated for temperatures up to 200°C to all machine operators. Conduct mandatory retraining on machine safety procedures within 5 days.

name: Implement Secondary Containment for All Chemical Storage
description: Install secondary containment systems (drip pans with 110% capacity of largest container) beneath all hazardous chemical storage on elevated racking. Replace current incompatible storage practices with designated hazmat storage area with epoxy-coated flooring and curbed containment. Clearly label all storage locations and ensure chemical compatibility. This engineering control prevents chemical releases from contaminating inventory and spreading throughout the warehouse.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Ventilation System in Section B
description: Install dedicated extraction ventilation system in warehouse Section B with minimum 6 air changes per hour capacity. Install carbon filtration to capture chemical vapors and implement continuous monitoring with low-level alarms. This addresses inadequate ventilation identified during incident and reduces employee respiratory exposure to chemical odors during future incidents.

name: Establish Chemical Inventory Management and Inspection Protocol
description: Implement daily visual inspection procedures for all stored chemicals, with focus on container integrity and proper placement. Create inventory tracking system with barcode labels tied to chemical type, storage location, and storage date. Train all warehouse staff on proper handling and inspection procedures. Establish rule prohibiting chemical storage directly above finished goods inventory. Conduct monthly audits of chemical storage compliance.

name: Implement Equipment Cooling Cycle Calibration Program
description: Establish a monthly calibration and maintenance schedule for all injection molding machine cooling cycle timers. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard will verify timer accuracy against documented baseline parameters for each Line (A, B, and C). Any deviations greater than 10% will trigger immediate equipment servicing. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of premature part removal attempts. Documentation will be maintained on a shared database accessible to all Production Supervisors, ensuring visibility of equipment status and compliance.

name: Reinforce Part Removal Safety Training
description: Conduct a 30-minute refresher training session for all production operators covering safe part extraction procedures, including visual and tactile checks for adequate cooling before removal. This administrative control will be delivered by EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury to all shifts within two weeks. Training will include review of first aid procedures and when to escalate injuries. Attendance records and competency assessments will be maintained.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Industrial Ovens
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all six industrial ovens, including monthly bracket tightness inspections, vibration analysis, and bearing condition checks. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher will coordinate with Maintenance Technician Luc Girard to create detailed maintenance checklists and establish a tracking system using the company database. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of equipment degradation. All maintenance activities will be documented, and any abnormalities will trigger immediate corrective action and hazard investigation to prevent recurrence.

name: Enhance Operator Hazard Recognition Training
description: Develop and deliver a specialized 45-minute training module for all production and composite material operators on recognizing equipment failure indicators including unusual sounds, vibrations, and performance changes. Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri will create training materials with video demonstrations of common warning signs. This administrative control reinforces the near-miss detection capability demonstrated by Lina Sokolova. Training will be mandatory for all production staff and completed within three weeks. A recognition program will incentivize continued hazard reporting.

name: Install Anti-Tip Safety Devices on All Chemical Storage Racks
description: Retrofit all 12 chemical storage racks in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility with secondary restraint systems including cable stabilization, load-limiting devices, and automatic lock mechanisms. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher will contract with a professional equipment installer to complete work within 30 days. This engineering control eliminates the risk of container displacement and falling objects. All racks will be certified by a qualified inspector before being returned to service. Maximum load capacities will be clearly marked on each shelf, and shelving will include intermediate dividers rated for the maximum load per shelf.

name: Implement Mandatory Receiving and Shelving Protocol with Verification
description: Establish and enforce a detailed written procedure for chemical receiving, storage, and inventory placement that includes: (1) mandatory three-point verification checklist, (2) photographic documentation of shelf arrangements, (3) supervisor sign-off before materials are considered 'in storage', and (4) weekly shelf condition audits. Materials Manager Nicole Proulx and Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne will conduct quarterly refresher training for all receiving personnel. This administrative control ensures consistent adherence to safety practices. Non-compliance will result in suspension of receiving privileges pending retraining.

name: Provide Specialized PPE for Material Handlers and Receiving Staff
description: Issue certified bump caps, impact-resistant gloves, and steel-toed boots to all material handlers and receiving personnel engaged in chemical storage operations. Director of HSE Marie-Claude Beaumont will procure equipment meeting CSA standards and maintain replacement inventory. All staff will receive fitting and proper-use training. This PPE control provides a secondary layer of protection while engineering controls are implemented. Cost per employee is approximately $250 for complete protective set.

name: Implement Mandatory PPE Checkpoints for Chemical Handling
description: Establish visual PPE requirement signage at all injection molding stations and implement a pre-shift checklist that operators must complete before handling mold release agents or cleaning equipment. Train all production staff on the specific hazards of mold release agents and proper donning/doffing procedures for nitrile gloves. Conduct monthly audits of PPE compliance during chemical handling tasks. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate work practices and will reduce skin contact incidents.

name: Install Secondary Containment on Equipment Feed Hoppers
description: Install removable plastic drip trays beneath all injection molding machine feed hoppers to catch mold release agent residue and prevent pooling in corner areas. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of concentrated chemical accumulation that contributed to the contact exposure. Trays should be inspected and emptied daily as part of preventive maintenance. Material compatibility with mold release agents must be verified during selection.

name: Install Non-Slip Flooring in Chemical Storage Area
description: Replace existing concrete flooring in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room with anti-slip epoxy coating or rubber matting designed for wet chemical environments. This engineering control eliminates the slip hazard that caused the drum to tip. The new flooring must meet ANSI standards for chemical resistance and provide adequate traction even when wet from cleaning operations. Installation should be completed during scheduled facility maintenance.

name: Implement Drum Transfer Safety Protocol with Mechanical Equipment
description: Require all personnel transferring drums larger than 30 gallons to use drum handling equipment (drum trucks or mechanical lifts) rather than manual transfer. Establish a new administrative procedure that prohibits manual carrying of large chemical drums. All staff performing drum transfers must complete certification training on proper mechanical equipment operation. This substitution control eliminates the manual handling hazard and reduces the likelihood of drum slippage and spillage.

name: Relocate Electrical Equipment Away from Spill Zones
description: Conduct a facility assessment to identify electrical panels and control systems located within potential chemical spill zones. Relocate critical electrical equipment to elevated platforms or separate control rooms where possible. For equipment that cannot be relocated, install protective enclosures and secondary containment barriers. This engineering control protects valuable equipment from chemical damage and reduces downtime from equipment failure.

name: Install Redundant Temperature Control and Monitoring System
description: Upgrade the resin dryer with a dual-channel temperature control system featuring independent thermostats and a supervisory PLC (programmable logic controller) that continuously monitors both channels. Install a wireless temperature alert system that sends real-time notifications to maintenance personnel if temperatures exceed 270°C. This engineering control provides multiple layers of protection against thermal runaway conditions and enables early intervention before alarms are triggered.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Thermal Equipment
description: Implement a mandatory preventive maintenance program for all dryers and high-temperature equipment with quarterly inspections that include thermostat functionality testing, thermal imaging verification, and control circuit diagnostics. Maintenance records must be logged in the facility management system with automatic alerts when inspections are due. Create a rotating schedule ensuring no inspection is skipped. This administrative control ensures early detection of temperature control malfunctions before they result in safety incidents.

name: Install Automatic Pressure Relief and Thermal Cutoff Valve
description: Install an automatic thermal cutoff valve on the dryer exhaust line that triggers at 280°C, venting excess pressure and preventing internal temperature from reaching critical levels where thermal degradation occurs rapidly. Additionally install a secondary mechanical pressure relief valve as a safety backup. These engineering controls eliminate the condition where smoke-generating temperatures are maintained within the chamber.

name: Implement Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE Requirement
description: Issue heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C minimum) and arm protectors to all Machine Setters and operators working on injection molding lines. Establish a signed acknowledgment protocol requiring workers to confirm they are wearing appropriate PPE before beginning machine adjustments. Store replacement PPE at three strategic locations near high-temperature equipment. Conduct a 30-minute training session for all line operators on proper donning and care of heat-resistant equipment within 5 days.

name: Establish Coupling Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Create a daily pre-shift inspection checklist for all hose couplings on injection molding machines, to be completed by the Machine Setter before production begins. Implement a color-coded tag system (green=safe, yellow=inspect, red=do not use) for all couplings. Require maintenance personnel to perform a secondary verification inspection within 4 hours of completing any hose maintenance work. Train all maintenance staff on proper coupling tightening procedures and torque specifications. Audit compliance weekly for 8 weeks.

name: Upgrade Machine Hose Safety Design
description: Replace all standard hose couplings on the 12 most frequently used injection molding machines with quick-disconnect couplings featuring integrated shut-off valves that automatically stop plastic flow when disconnected. This engineering control eliminates the risk of material spillage during coupling maintenance. Schedule replacement during regular maintenance windows over the next 60 days, starting with machines in Line A. Provide 2-hour training to all maintenance and setter staff on the new coupling system.

name: Warehouse Aisle Width Assessment and Reconfiguration
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all warehouse aisles used for forklift traffic, measuring actual working width against manufacturer specifications for the electric forklifts in use (minimum 3.5 meters for safe two-way traffic). Reconfigure the Finished Goods Warehouse layout to ensure all primary aisles meet or exceed safe width standards by relocating 8 secondary pallet racks to alternative storage areas. Install high-visibility yellow and black striping along all aisle edges and position directional floor markers for one-way traffic in narrow sections. Expected outcome: elimination of collision risk in constrained spaces.

name: Forklift Tire Maintenance and Replacement Program
description: Establish a preventive tire maintenance schedule requiring tire inspection every 40 operating hours and immediate replacement if tread depth falls below 4mm or any visible damage is present. Purchase a set of 8 replacement tires for the electric forklift fleet. Assign Luc Girard as maintenance coordinator for tire tracking. Implement a tire log system with digital records of inspection dates, tread measurements, and replacement dates. Conduct a one-time inspection of all 6 operational forklifts within 48 hours and replace any tires not meeting standards.

name: Mandatory Confined Space Entry Certification and Retraining
description: Require all maintenance technicians and equipment specialists who may access tanks, mixing vessels, or enclosed equipment spaces to complete formal confined space entry training through an accredited external provider within 30 days. Establish that recertification is required every 24 months. Create a visible roster of certified confined space workers posted at the Chemical Storage area entrance. Implement a sign-off log requiring Confined Space Entry Supervisor approval before ANY work on enclosed vessels. Alain Gravel must complete retraining before returning to maintenance duties on chemical equipment.

name: Install Automated Ventilation Interlock System
description: Install an automated ventilation interlock system on the Chemical Storage and Mixing area that requires mechanical fans to run for a minimum of 15 minutes before any tank is opened or entered. Install CO and solvent vapor sensors that display real-time air quality on a visible monitor at the tank work station. Establish a requirement that air quality must reach 'safe' status (visual green indicator) before confined space work begins. Add an emergency shut-off button for immediate system override. This engineering control ensures adequate atmospheric conditions before human exposure.

name: Implement Buddy System and Documented Confined Space Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory buddy system where no one enters a confined space without a trained spotter present outside the space at all times. Develop a detailed confined space entry permit system requiring completion of a checklist including: hazard assessment, atmospheric testing, ventilation activation confirmation, rescue equipment positioning, and emergency contact notification. Create a log book at the Chemical Storage entrance where entry persons must sign in/out with time stamps. Conduct quarterly safety drills simulating confined space rescue scenarios with Alain Gravel and other team members.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all 32 injection molding machines with quarterly inspections of pressure relief valves, seal integrity checks, and hydraulic fluid analysis. Create a digital tracking system to monitor maintenance compliance. Train maintenance technicians on early warning signs of valve degradation. All machines will receive baseline inspections within 30 days. This addresses the root cause of delayed maintenance and ensures critical safety components are monitored before failure.

name: Install Hydraulic Fluid Containment and Cooling System
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all injection molding machines to capture leaking hydraulic fluid and reduce burn hazard exposure. Add thermal shielding around high-pressure lines and install emergency pressure relief bypass systems that safely redirect excess pressure away from operator stations. This engineering control will prevent hot fluid spray injuries during equipment failure scenarios.

name: Mandatory Heat Injury Prevention and Response Training
description: Require all production operators and technicians to complete updated training on recognizing thermal burn hazards, proper PPE selection for thermal protection, and emergency response procedures. Training to include hands-on demonstration of emergency eyewash/shower stations. Conduct refresher training annually and after any thermal incident. Ensure all operators understand when to halt operations if equipment feels abnormally warm.

name: Install Fireproof Storage Cabinets and Improve Ventilation
description: Replace all open chemical storage areas with FM-approved fireproof storage cabinets rated for flammable liquids (Class 4). Install mechanical ventilation system with explosion-proof fans in the waste management area to prevent accumulation of solvent vapors. Remove all non-explosion-proof heaters and replace with intrinsically safe heating systems. Ensure cabinets have self-closing doors and proper grounding to prevent static discharge. This eliminates the ignition sources and containment failures that caused the fire.

name: Implement Solvent Waste Segregation and Daily Removal Protocol
description: Establish a strict protocol requiring all solvent-contaminated materials to be placed in sealed, labeled containers immediately after use. Implement daily removal of waste containers to approved external storage locations away from ignition sources. Create a tracking log for waste disposal with operator sign-offs. Train all staff on proper waste segregation to prevent mixing of incompatible chemicals. This administrative control ensures hazardous materials are not left in open containers.

name: Upgrade Fire Detection and Suppression System
description: Install advanced flame detection sensors with automatic dry chemical suppression system in the chemical storage and waste management areas. System will trigger at first sign of ignition to suppress flames before they spread. Upgrade the facility's main fire suppression system to include chemical-compatible extinguishing agents. Conduct quarterly fire safety drills with all staff to ensure rapid evacuation. This provides rapid response to minimize damage and prevents injury.

name: Strengthen LOTO Protocol and Eliminate Bypass Mechanisms
description: Remove all unauthorized bypass pins and access keys from equipment areas immediately. Redesign LOTO systems to use tamper-evident locks that cannot be physically bypassed. Implement a centralized LOTO tracking log visible to all shifts documenting which machines are locked, by whom, and for what purpose. Require photo documentation of LOTO locks with timestamp. Conduct mandatory LOTO certification renewal for all 200 employees within 60 days. This eliminates the bypass vulnerability and ensures proper lockout procedures.

name: Implement Shift-to-Shift Handoff Communication System
description: Establish mandatory 15-minute overlap period between shifts with structured handoff meeting covering equipment status, active maintenance work orders, LOTO status, and any anomalies observed. Create a digital logbook (accessible to all shifts) documenting machine status, active work, and communication notes. Require supervisor sign-off on equipment release before new shift can operate machines. Hold weekly safety meetings to review any LOTO-related near-misses or issues. This ensures transparent communication across shifts.

name: Install Machine Interlocks and Warning Systems
description: Install electronic interlocks on all 32 injection molding machines that prevent startup unless all access panels are closed and LOTO locks are verified by the system's magnetic sensor. Add audible and visual alarm that sounds for 10 seconds before carousel startup to alert nearby personnel. Install presence-sensing safety gates at all pinch points that halt equipment if operator's hand is detected. These engineering controls provide redundant protection against sudden startup incidents.

name: Enhance Operator Training on Hazard Recognition and LOTO Compliance
description: Develop comprehensive training module specifically addressing consequences of LOTO violations and pinch point hazards. Include case studies of similar incidents and fatalities in the plastics industry. Require all operators to complete hands-on competency assessment demonstrating proper LOTO application and verification procedures before returning to production work. Implement annual refresher training with competency reassessment. Create incentive program for departments maintaining perfect LOTO compliance for 6 consecutive months. This strengthens safety culture and operator awareness.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification System
description: Install a mechanical lock-out verification board at each injection molding line requiring photographic evidence and shift supervisor sign-off before any maintenance or clearing operations. All operators must complete a refresher LOTO training module within 7 days, with monthly audits of LOTO compliance conducted by maintenance supervisors. Production scheduling will be adjusted to eliminate time-pressure justifications for bypassing safety procedures. Non-compliance will result in immediate suspension of machine operation privileges.

name: Upgrade Machine Safety Interlocks and Testing Protocol
description: Conduct immediate inspection and functional testing of all safety interlocks on injection molding lines by certified third-party technician. Replace any interlocks showing degraded response times. Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all interlock systems with documentation maintained in the equipment database. Install proximity sensors on all hopper access points to automatically de-energize machines when opened. Maintenance Manager will ensure all equipment certifications are current.

name: Enhanced Burn Prevention and First Aid Training
description: Develop specialized training module on thermal burn recognition, prevention, and immediate field treatment for all production operators. Training will include hands-on practice with emergency response procedures and proper application of cooling techniques. Distribute burn prevention posters in all production areas highlighting the dangers of hot plastic contact and safe handling procedures. Stock all first aid stations with specialized burn treatment kits including sterile gauze and cooling packs rated for thermal injuries.

name: Comprehensive Electrical System Audit and Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Conduct a complete electrical safety audit of all production equipment including conduit integrity, motor housings, control panels, and grounding systems. Engage a certified electrical safety professional to inspect all circuits and connections. Establish a monthly preventive maintenance inspection checklist requiring documented visual inspection of electrical systems. Maintenance technicians will receive specialized training on electrical hazard recognition. All findings will be logged in the computerized maintenance management system with priority flagging for any deterioration.

name: Equipment Inspection Reporting and Communication Protocol
description: Develop a standardized equipment hazard reporting system requiring all operators and technicians to document and immediately report any equipment abnormalities through a digital portal accessible from all workstations. Implement a response time requirement of 4 hours for initial assessment of reported hazards. Conduct weekly safety briefings at shift changes to discuss identified hazards and corrective actions. Reward proactive hazard reporting through the company safety recognition program to encourage early identification.

name: Install Improved Mezzanine Ladder Safety Features
description: Replace all access ladders to elevated storage areas with heavy-duty climbing equipment featuring anti-slip tread surfaces treated with permanent grip coating. Install handrails on both sides of ladder sections. Add multiple strategically positioned LED lighting fixtures to illuminate ladder access points during all shifts, particularly at night. Apply high-visibility paint markings to all ladder rungs and handholds. Implement a daily pre-shift inspection of all ladder surfaces with sign-off documentation to ensure tread integrity.

name: Implement Spill Prevention and Cleanup Protocol in Maintenance Areas
description: Establish designated maintenance zones with secondary containment systems to capture hydraulic leaks immediately. Train all maintenance personnel on proper spill containment and cleanup procedures with focus on preventing spills from spreading to adjacent work areas. Provide absorbent material stations at maintenance locations for immediate spill response. Conduct daily visual inspections of high-traffic areas to identify and clean any spills immediately. Post warning signs in areas with recent spills to alert workers of hazard conditions.

name: Implement Secondary Containment System
description: Install drip trays and secondary containment basins beneath all chemical storage and handling areas in the Quality Control Laboratory. These containment systems will capture 110% of the largest container's volume. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of chemical spill propagation by preventing floor contamination and environmental exposure. Training will be provided to all lab personnel on proper placement and monitoring of containment vessels. Expected outcome: elimination of floor-level chemical spread in future incidents, reducing cleanup costs and personnel exposure risks.

name: Upgrade Chemical Container Handling Procedures
description: Develop and implement new handling protocols requiring the use of container gripping devices (bottle carriers, hand-safe handles) for all acetone and solvent transfers. Establish a mandatory safety briefing for all lab personnel on proper grip techniques, environmental condition assessment (wet/dry surfaces), and two-person verification for containers larger than 2 liters. Integrate this training into the monthly safety meeting schedule and track completion rates. This administrative control reduces human error factors that contributed to the spill.

name: Install Thermal Barrier Guards and Insulation
description: Engineering solution: Install removable thermal barrier guards (silicone composite guards rated for 300°C) around all accessible high-temperature mold surfaces on Lines A, B, C, and D. Additionally, apply high-temperature insulating tape to all hot surface areas. These guards will prevent unintended skin contact while maintaining accessibility for necessary temperature checks. The barriers will be rated for continuous exposure and replaced quarterly or when visibly degraded. This eliminates direct contact opportunities, moving from reliance on PPE to structural hazard elimination.

name: Implement Automatic Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install non-contact infrared temperature monitoring sensors with automatic alert systems on all injection molding lines. These sensors will continuously track mold surface temperatures and trigger visual/audible alarms if temperatures exceed safe operating parameters (280°C threshold). Data will be logged to the production management system for trend analysis. Operators will receive training on interpreting sensor outputs and responding to temperature anomalies. This administrative and engineering control prevents operators from needing to manually verify temperatures, reducing burn risk.

name: Enhance Heat Exposure PPE Requirements
description: Mandate the use of heat-resistant arm sleeves (rated minimum 300°C) and reinforced thermal-protective gloves for all operators working on molding lines. Update the PPE inspection checklist to include weekly heat protection equipment assessment. Ensure adequate supply of replacement PPE maintains a 2-week inventory minimum. Conduct fit-testing and comfort training for all personnel. While PPE is a lower-level control, this immediately protects personnel while engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Cooling Systems
description: Establish a data-driven predictive maintenance schedule for all cooling water circulation systems using vibration analysis and thermal monitoring. Install vibration sensors on pump bearings to detect anomalies 30-60 days before failure. Conduct quarterly water quality analysis to monitor mineral content and implement a descaling protocol when deposits exceed 2mm accumulation. Reduce maintenance intervals from annual to quarterly for critical pumps. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses root cause (mineral deposit accumulation) and prevents future failures through early detection.

name: Upgrade Piping Infrastructure and Corrosion Prevention
description: Replace all corroded carbon steel cooling lines (estimated 400 linear feet) with stainless steel piping rated for the facility's water chemistry. Install isolation check valves at critical junction points to prevent backpressure surge propagation. Apply protective polymer coating to remaining carbon steel fittings. Implement annual corrosion inspection protocol with photographic documentation. This engineering control eliminates the structural failure mode and adds redundancy through isolation valves.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Emergency Shutdown System
description: Construct a secondary containment basin (minimum 250 gallon capacity) beneath the cooling system pump and primary piping junction. Install automatic shutoff valves triggered by water level sensors in the containment area. Connect the containment drain to the facility's industrial wastewater treatment system. Add emergency shutdown buttons within 10 meters of the cooling system at multiple locations, with clear labeling and operator training. This administrative and engineering control limits spill propagation and enables rapid response.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly inspection and testing schedule for all high-pressure hydraulic couplings and hoses across all injection molding lines. This includes pressure testing, visual inspection for corrosion, and replacement of components showing any signs of degradation. All technicians will be certified in hydraulic system maintenance. Documentation will be maintained in the facility's computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) with automated alerts for due maintenance. Expected outcome: Elimination of preventable hydraulic system failures and extension of equipment service life.

name: Upgrade Coolant Filtration System
description: Replace existing basic filtration system with advanced multi-stage filtration capable of removing particles down to 10 microns. This will significantly reduce internal corrosion of hydraulic components caused by contaminated coolant. The new system will include automatic bypass valves and real-time contamination monitoring with pressure gauges. Installation will be completed on all six injection molding lines. Expected outcome: Substantial reduction in coolant-related corrosion, extended component lifespan, and improved operator safety through reduced failure incidents.

name: Install Heat-Resistant Protective Barriers
description: Install removable polycarbonate heat shields around high-temperature hydraulic coupling zones on all molding lines to contain spray patterns and redirect escaping fluid away from operator work areas. Shields will be rated for temperatures up to 120°C and will feature quick-release mechanisms for maintenance access. Additionally, upgrade all operator protective aprons to Kevlar-reinforced thermal-resistant material. Expected outcome: Reduced burn exposure severity and improved containment of hydraulic fluid spray incidents.

name: Install Mechanical Material Handling Assist System
description: Deploy pneumatic-powered vacuum lift systems at each injection molding line capable of safely handling containers up to 50 pounds. These systems eliminate manual lifting hazards associated with resin container transfers and reduce operator strain. Training will be provided to all operators on proper use and safety protocols. The system will include emergency release mechanisms and load cell indicators. Expected outcome: Elimination of manual lifting injuries related to resin container transfers and improved ergonomic conditions for operators.

name: Reorganize Chemical Transfer Station Layout
description: Redesign the chemical transfer station to include protective bollards, wider spacing between work stations, and flex hose routing guidelines that prevent accidental displacement. Install secondary containment trays under all transfer operations to capture any spills immediately. Add clear floor markings indicating personnel zones and hose pathways. This administrative and engineering control combination will reduce the likelihood of accidental contact with hazardous materials. Expected outcome: Reduction in chemical splash incidents and improved safety awareness through better facility design.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule for all 32 injection molding machines, with particular focus on hydraulic pressure relief valves. Install pressure monitoring sensors on critical machines to detect anomalies before failure. Schedule quarterly inspections and annual replacement of relief valves regardless of apparent condition. Create a digital maintenance log system integrated with production scheduling to ensure no machine exceeds maintenance intervals. Train all maintenance technicians on early warning signs of hydraulic system degradation.

name: Install Hydraulic Pressure Safety Interlocks
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with dual-channel safety interlocks that prevent manual mold opening if internal pressure exceeds safe thresholds. These interlocks will automatically vent pressure to safe levels before allowing operator access to the mold area. Conduct safety validation testing on each installation. Develop operator procedures that require confirmation that pressure has been safely vented before any manual mold intervention.

name: Enhanced Safety Training on Machine Hazards
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training on hydraulic system hazards specific to injection molding equipment. All operators and maintenance technicians must complete this training within 30 days. Training will include recognition of warning signs (unusual noises, pressure gauge anomalies), proper lockout/tagout procedures, and emergency response protocols. Include video demonstrations of past incidents and near-misses to reinforce learning.

name: Mandatory PPE Compliance and Accountability Program
description: Implement a stricter PPE compliance program with daily tool kit inspections before shift start. Supervisors must verify that all required PPE is worn correctly for each task. Create a photo-based task matrix showing exactly which PPE is required for each job in the mold shop. Establish consequences for PPE non-compliance including documented warnings and mandatory retraining. Introduce peer accountability where team members remind each other of PPE requirements. Monthly audits will be conducted with findings reported to management.

name: Upgrade to Cut-Resistant Gloves with Enhanced Grip
description: Transition from standard work gloves to premium cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rated) that maintain superior grip even when wet or when handling metal components. Procure gloves specifically designed for precision grinding work that don't compromise dexterity. Provide samples for all mold shop technicians to test and provide feedback. Conduct a 2-week trial period to ensure acceptance before full rollout. The improved design should eliminate the excuse that PPE compromises work quality.

name: Implement Automated Material Stacking and Racking System
description: Install industrial racking system specifically designed for composite material storage, with height limits set to 1.5 meters and load capacity clearly marked. The racking will use lateral bracing to prevent stack collapse from minor disturbances. Establish designated storage zones with clear floor markings and signage indicating maximum stack heights. Train all warehouse personnel on proper placement techniques using the new racking system. Conduct weekly inspections of all stored materials to ensure compliance. This eliminates manual stacking hazards associated with unstable pyramid configurations.

name: Enforce Material Stacking Procedures with Shift Handover Inspections
description: Revise Material Management SOP to include explicit height restrictions (1.5 meters maximum) for composite material stacking and require that all stacks be secured with anti-slip mats and lateral stabilization devices. Mandate a formal shift handover inspection where the outgoing shift lead signs off on all stacked materials being within compliance limits, and the incoming lead verifies and countersigns. Create a digital checklist system accessible via mobile devices. Non-compliance will result in immediate stack remediation and documented corrective action.

name: Implement Forklift Load Securing Protocol
description: Develop and enforce mandatory load securing procedures requiring all forklifts to use load straps, load stabilizers, and weight distribution verification before transport. Conduct refresher training for all forklift operators on load balance assessment and safe speeds on uneven surfaces. Implement pre-shift checklist verification signed by operators and supervisors. Training will be delivered within 14 days to all 12 active forklift operators.

name: Repair and Resurface Loading Dock Transition Area
description: Engage a concrete contractor to repair the uneven floor surface at the warehouse-to-production building transition point where the incident occurred. Fill and level the 2-3 inch depression that contributed to the load shift. Install yellow warning tape and signage at the transition zone. Apply anti-slip coating to the transition surface to improve traction during wet conditions.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Area Ventilation System
description: Install a high-capacity industrial extraction system with ducting to the exterior of the Chemical Storage Building, capable of achieving 8-10 air changes per hour in the mixing area. Add make-up air supply balanced with extraction. Install real-time VOC and combustible gas monitoring with alarms at 50% LEL and 75% exposure limits. Conduct air quality baseline testing before and after system installation to verify compliance with ACGIH guidelines.

name: Implement Preventive Hose Maintenance and Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a quarterly hose and connection inspection schedule for all chemical transfer lines using a certified technician. Document all inspections in a maintenance log. Replace hoses showing any signs of deterioration, cracking, or age (replace all hoses every 5 years regardless of condition). Mark hoses with installation dates using permanent markers. Require inspection sign-off before each chemical transfer operation. Train Elena and all chemical operators on visual hose inspection procedures.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Grounding System
description: Install a secondary containment system beneath all chemical transfer points with a minimum 110% capacity of the largest container volume being transferred. Ensure the containment area has proper sloped drainage to a collection tank. Install bonding and grounding equipment for all metal containers and transfer equipment to eliminate static electricity risk. Provide visual training to all chemical handlers on proper use of secondary containment and grounding procedures.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program with Hydraulic Fluid Analysis
description: Establish a quarterly hydraulic fluid sampling and analysis program for all major injection molding machines to detect wear metals, contamination, and fluid degradation before component failure. Install particle counters in the hydraulic circuits of 8 production machines to provide real-time monitoring of system cleanliness. Set alert thresholds at ISO 19/17/14 cleanliness levels. Engage a hydraulics specialist to conduct training for maintenance staff on fluid analysis interpretation and component wear prevention. Budget $18,000 for first-year implementation including laboratory contracts and equipment.

name: Enforce Strict Equipment Maintenance Schedule Compliance
description: Review and update the preventive maintenance schedule for all 32 injection molding machines based on manufacturer specifications and actual operating hours. Machine #14 should have had a hydraulic system overhaul at 15,000 operating hours; establish computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) to automatically generate work orders before critical intervals are exceeded. Implement an escalation protocol requiring manager sign-off if any scheduled maintenance is deferred beyond 30 days. Conduct quarterly audits of maintenance completion rates. Assign Priya Sharma as CMMS administrator with responsibility for schedule oversight.

name: Implement Mandatory Thermal Insulation Inspection Program
description: Establish a monthly preventive maintenance schedule specifically for thermal insulation systems on all 32 injection molding machines. Maintenance technicians will conduct visual inspections for degradation, cracks, or exposed metal surfaces and replace damaged insulation immediately. All findings will be documented in the maintenance management system with photographic evidence. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the incident and will be integrated into the existing predictive maintenance program. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in thermal exposure incidents from damaged insulation within 6 months.

name: Upgrade Operator PPE Requirements for Production Floor
description: Mandatory provision of heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C minimum) and heat-protective sleeves for all production operators working with temperatures above 150°C. Training on proper donning and inspection of PPE will be provided during the next quarterly safety training cycle. All operators will be required to wear this PPE during mold temperature checks and hot surface handling tasks. Inventory will be maintained in UNIT-008 with monthly replenishment checks.

name: Develop Hot Surface Awareness Training Module
description: Create a site-specific training module focused on thermal burn prevention in injection molding environments. The module will include machine-specific hazard identification, proper use of thermal measurement devices, safe work procedures near hot surfaces, and emergency response protocols. All production operators will complete this training within 30 days and annually thereafter. The training will include hands-on demonstrations of PPE use and thermal measurement techniques to ensure competency.

name: Install Mechanical Material Handling Equipment
description: Procure and install three heavy-duty electric pallet jacks equipped with lifting tables (capacity 30+ kg) in the Finished Goods Warehouse to eliminate manual lifting of resin bags. Position equipment at strategic locations to reduce walking distances. Provide comprehensive operator training on equipment use, maintenance, and emergency procedures. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at its source by reducing manual handling to near zero. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in back strain incidents from material handling within 3 months.

name: Comprehensive Ergonomics and Manual Handling Training Program
description: Develop and deliver site-specific ergonomics training for all warehouse and material handling staff, emphasizing proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, and load assessment. Include practical demonstrations using actual materials and equipment found in the facility. Implement a peer mentoring system where trained operators observe and provide feedback to colleagues. Conduct annual refresher training and competency assessments. Distribute ergonomic reminder posters throughout the warehouse.

name: Implement Load Limit Labels and Weight Management System
description: Apply standardized weight identification labels to all resin bags indicating weight and recommended handling method (mechanical vs. manual). Establish maximum manual lift limits (no more than 15 kg per item) and ensure all bags exceed this are managed via mechanical equipment. Train staff to visually identify bags requiring assisted handling. Implement a monthly audit of compliance with weight management procedures.

name: Implement Composite Material Edge Protection Standards
description: Establish mandatory procedures for all glass fiber composite materials in the Tool Room to be deburred, sanded smooth, or wrapped with protective edge guards before storage. All incoming materials will be inspected upon receipt and processed according to the new standard before being placed on storage shelves. Create a tool kit specifically designed for material edge finishing and provide staff training. Include monthly audits to verify compliance with the new edge protection standards.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a comprehensive hydraulic hose inspection and replacement program with maximum service life of 5 years instead of 7. All hoses will be tagged with installation dates and scheduled for replacement during planned maintenance windows. Quarterly visual inspections will be conducted to identify early signs of degradation including surface cracks, leaks, or discoloration. This engineering control will eliminate premature failures by replacing components before failure occurs. The predictive maintenance software system will be updated to automatically generate work orders 6 months before hoses reach their replacement interval.

name: Install Secondary Spill Containment Barriers
description: Install permanent secondary containment systems beneath all hydraulic equipment on production lines, including drip pans with capacity to hold 110% of largest connected hose volume. This engineering control will prevent hydraulic fluid from spreading across production areas and contaminating materials or creating slip hazards. Pans will be fitted with drain plugs for proper fluid disposal and weekly inspection checklists will be implemented. Training will be provided to all production operators on proper containment procedures and fluid disposal protocols.

name: Implement Automated Racking Restraint System
description: Install engineering-controlled load retention barriers on all storage racks exceeding 8 feet height. Each shelf will be equipped with adjustable safety stops that prevent boxes from sliding or shifting during normal facility vibrations or forklift operations. All boxes will be marked with maximum allowable shelf positions and load weight limits. This eliminates the primary hazard source by ensuring loads cannot accidentally fall regardless of operator error in securing items. The system will include quarterly load testing and certification by qualified personnel.

name: Mandatory Racking Safety Training and Certification
description: Develop comprehensive administrative control program requiring all warehouse personnel to complete CNESST-aligned training on proper load securing, rack weight limits, and load distribution. All personnel who place items on racks above 6 feet will obtain certification before performing those tasks. Training will include recognition of unstable load conditions, proper use of strapping materials, and communication protocols with equipment operators. Refresher training will occur annually and whenever equipment changes are made. This administrative control ensures consistent safe practices across all shifts and reduces human error in load placement.

name: Establish Mobile Ladder Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Audit and replace all mobile ladders currently in use, replacing models that do not meet modern stability standards with new equipment featuring wider bases and three-point contact safety features. All ladders will be inspected monthly for structural integrity and fit with non-slip feet. Operators will be trained on proper ladder positioning and usage techniques through administrative controls. Yellow warning tape will mark restricted zones beneath elevated storage to prevent personnel from working directly under loads during access operations. This multi-level approach addresses both engineering and administrative hazard control.

name: Install Automated Deburring System Verification Check
description: Implement an engineering control by installing a pneumatic edge detection sensor system that automatically verifies burr removal compliance on all medical-grade parts before they advance from the deburring station. Parts failing verification will be automatically diverted for manual rework. This eliminates the hazard at its source by ensuring no non-conforming parts reach quality inspection. The system will integrate with production monitoring software to alert operators of calibration drift before parts escape quality control. Monthly calibration certification will be required.

name: Relocate Heat Sensor Array and Install Protective Barriers
description: Engineering control to install protective barriers around ceiling-mounted heat sensors in the Composite Materials Processing Area to prevent direct exposure to compressed air streams and thermal fluctuations. Sensors will be repositioned 18 inches higher and angled to detect genuine fire conditions while filtering false triggers from maintenance activities. Installation of perforated polycarbonate deflection shields will be completed within 14 days. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in false alarm incidents from maintenance activities.

name: Implement Equipment Maintenance Safety Training Module
description: Administrative control establishing a mandatory 2-hour training module for all operators and technicians performing oven maintenance, focusing on fire detection system awareness and compressed air safety protocols. Training will cover sensor locations, maintenance exclusion zones, and proper tool usage near safety systems. To be delivered quarterly with initial completion required within 7 days. Documentation will track attendance and competency assessment.

name: Install Waterproof Electrical Junction Box Covers
description: Engineering control to install weatherproof polycarbonate covers with drain ports over all electrical junction boxes and terminal strips in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. Covers will be rated for high-pressure water spray exposure and designed to allow ventilation while preventing liquid ingress. Installation includes reconfiguring spray access patterns to maintain equipment inspection capability. Work to be completed within 21 days, affecting four primary work stations.

name: Establish Restricted Spray Zones and Maintenance Protocols
description: Administrative control establishing designated spray-free zones in the tool room with clear painted floor markings and signage indicating electrical infrastructure protection areas. Maintenance procedures will be revised to require water spray maintenance activities to be scheduled and coordinated with electrical systems verification. Monthly audits of compliance will be conducted by the Safety Officer with corrective training for non-compliance.

name: Replace Chemical Storage Racks with Certified Structural Systems
description: Engineering control to completely replace all chemical storage racks in the hazardous materials building with new industrial-grade steel racks manufactured to CSA standards and certified for chemical storage. New racks will feature redundant anchor points (minimum 8 bolts per rack), stainless steel fasteners, and integrated secondary containment trays with drain valves and sump pumps. Installation will include floor leveling assessment and correction. All new racks will undergo load testing at 150% of rated capacity before receipt of inventory. Completion target: 45 days. This eliminates the risk of structural failure from drum storage.

name: Implement Quarterly Rack Inspection and Maintenance Program
description: Administrative control establishing a formal quarterly inspection schedule for all chemical storage infrastructure, conducted by the Maintenance and Engineering department.
