Inspections will document bolt torque verification (using calibrated tools), corrosion assessment, floor surface condition, and load stability testing. Results will be recorded in a centralized database with automated alerts for maintenance items exceeding threshold values. Non-compliance with inspection schedules will trigger management escalation. Training for inspectors to be completed within 10 days.

name: Install Enhanced Containment and Vapor Recovery System
description: Engineering control to install a secondary containment sump system with automatic vapor extraction beneath all volatile chemical storage areas. The system includes a 500-liter capacity collection basin with drain valve, automated pump activation on liquid detection, and a vapor recovery unit with activated carbon filtration capable of handling 300 cubic meters per hour. Integration with the facility HVAC system will ensure captured vapors are safely processed. System will include continuous monitoring with alarm alerts to the control room. Installation: 30 days.

name: Establish Chemical Material Handling Certification Program
description: Administrative control requiring all personnel handling hazardous materials to complete a comprehensive 4-hour certification program covering proper drum handling, spill response procedures, PPE selection, and emergency protocols specific to styrene, epoxy, and polyester resins. Program will include hands-on training with spill containment equipment and vapor monitoring instruments. Certification valid for 24 months with annual refresher requirements. Implement within 15 days with mandatory completion for all current handlers within 30 days.

name: Implement Mandatory Edge Deburring Process
description: Establish a mandatory quality control checkpoint requiring all injection molded parts to undergo edge finishing and deburring before packaging. This will be integrated into the production workflow between the molding machine and quality inspection station. Training will be provided to all production and quality staff on proper deburring techniques and inspection standards. The process will include documentation and batch traceability to ensure no parts bypass this critical safety step, addressing the root cause of bypassing this step due to schedule pressure.

name: Upgrade PPE for Part Handling Operations
description: Replace standard nitrile gloves with cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rating) for all production operators handling molded parts with potential sharp edges. Conduct fit and comfort testing with current staff and provide training on proper glove selection and use. Supply personal hand protection that maintains dexterity while providing superior cut protection. Include guidance on when to replace damaged gloves to maintain protection integrity throughout shifts.

name: Redesign Machine Guards for Better Functionality
description: Conduct engineering review of all CNC milling machine guards in the tool room to identify designs that can accommodate common part dimensions without removal. Work with equipment manufacturers to design modular or adjustable guards that maintain safety while allowing operational flexibility. Install permanent machine guards that cannot be easily bypassed. Establish a policy requiring management approval and documentation of any temporary guard removal, with mandatory reinstatement upon task completion. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the bypass.

name: Mandate Cut-Resistant Gloves with Enhanced Tactile Sensitivity
description: Procure and distribute premium-grade cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A5 rating) specifically designed for precision work that maintain tactile sensitivity for detailed machining tasks. Conduct fit testing with tool room technicians to ensure comfort and functionality. Implement a mandatory glove-wearing policy for all CNC machine operation with no exceptions. Include documentation in work procedures stating that removing safety equipment is grounds for disciplinary action. Pair this with training on proper glove use and the occupational health risks of amputation.

name: Implement Machine Guard Inspection and Lockout Protocol
description: Establish a daily pre-operation inspection checklist for all CNC machines that specifically verifies the presence and proper installation of all safety guards. Implement a LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure that requires guards to be inspected and verified before any machine is energized. Create a permit system for temporary guard removal that requires supervisor authorization, safety review, and mandatory reinstatement. Assign the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator to conduct monthly audits of compliance. Train all technicians on the procedure with documented sign-off.

name: Mandatory Mechanical Assist Device Implementation
description: Install permanent mechanical lift-assist hoists at all Injection Molding Line A workstations with capacity for 30+ kg loads. Conduct immediate maintenance repair of existing hoist and establish backup equipment protocol. Require all operators to use mechanical assistance for parts exceeding 15 kg. Implement daily pre-shift equipment inspection checklist and maintain spare hoist units in maintenance workshop. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in manual lifting-related back injuries.

name: Enhanced Ergonomics Training and Fatigue Management
description: Conduct mandatory refresher ergonomics training for all production operators focusing on proper lifting techniques and recognition of fatigue-related risks. Implement mandatory 15-minute breaks every 2 hours for repetitive lifting tasks. Establish rotation schedule to vary job tasks. Train supervisors to monitor for signs of excessive fatigue and enforce break policies. Create job rotation matrix to reduce repetitive strain. Expected outcome: Reduced cumulative strain injuries and improved operator awareness of physical limits.

name: Equipment Maintenance Communication Protocol
description: Establish formal communication system requiring HSE department notification when any lifting or material handling equipment is taken out of service. Create alternate workstation assignments or provide temporary portable assist devices. Implement daily maintenance logs displayed at each production line. Require supervisor sign-off confirming availability of all safety-critical equipment before shift commencement. Expected outcome: Elimination of unsafe workarounds and gaps in equipment availability.

name: Upgrade to Chemical-Resistant PPE and Eyewash Stations
description: Issue all personnel working with epoxy resins chemical-resistant full-face shields in addition to existing safety glasses, meeting ANSI Z87.1 standards for splash protection. Install secondary eyewash station in composite materials laboratory with monthly inspection log. Establish quarterly eyewash station function testing protocol with documented results. Provide all quality control staff with protective lab coats and nitrile gloves rated for epoxy exposure. Expected outcome: Elimination of chemical splash injuries to eyes and improved emergency response capability.

name: Chemical Container Storage and Handling Standards
description: Establish and enforce standardized chemical container closure procedures requiring double-check verification before storage. Implement color-coded container caps to indicate seal status (green=sealed, red=unsealed). Conduct training for all laboratory and production staff on proper chemical container handling. Create laminated procedure sheets for high-risk chemicals posted at storage and work areas. Establish monthly audit of chemical storage areas with supervisory sign-off. Expected outcome: Prevention of loose container incidents and consistent chemical handling practices.

name: Comprehensive Lockout/Tagout Enforcement and Hopper Safety Redesign
description: Implement mandatory LOTO procedure requiring complete electrical disconnect and lockout of all hoppers during maintenance operations. Install removable hopper covers with quick-disconnect latches to eliminate hand access to dangerous internal mechanisms. Disable all automatic timer overrides or require explicit maintenance department approval for timer activation. Conduct immediate audit of all hopper equipment for similar restart hazards. Mandate re-certification of all maintenance technicians in LOTO procedures within 30 days. Expected outcome: Elimination of unexpected machine restart incidents and finger entrapment hazards.

name: Machine Restart Hazard Communication and Control Panel Modifications
description: Install prominent warning labels on all hopper control panels identifying automatic timer functions and restart sequences. Implement visual alarm system (flashing lights and audible warning) that activates 10 seconds before any automatic restart. Modify control logic to require manual confirmation before hopper restart after maintenance mode. Create laminated quick-reference guides for each hopper type posted in the maintenance workshop and on equipment. Establish daily communication logs between maintenance and operations teams regarding equipment status and timer settings.

name: Enhanced PPE and Emergency Response for Maintenance Operations
description: Issue all maintenance technicians reinforced leather work gloves with anti-puncture properties for hopper maintenance tasks. Provide cut-resistant gloves rated ANSI A4 level. Establish first-aid kit in maintenance workshop stocked specifically for laceration and amputation emergencies including sterile dressings and finger preservation protocol documentation. Conduct annual training with local emergency room on finger reattachment procedures. Implement rapid-response drill quarterly to ensure technicians know emergency procedures. Expected outcome: Improved personal protection and faster emergency response.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Checklist
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive lockout/tagout verification checklist that requires visual confirmation of all energy isolation points before any maintenance work begins. The checklist will include a photo documentation requirement showing locked-out energy sources. All technicians will receive refresher training on LOTO procedures with emphasis on the consequences of incomplete lockouts. This administrative control addresses the root cause of the incomplete motor contactor isolation by creating a mandatory verification step.

name: Install Dual-Point Lockout Stations on Molding Lines
description: Install engineering controls consisting of dual-point lockout stations at each injection molding line, with physical locks that must be engaged simultaneously before any maintenance access. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of partial lockouts by requiring redundant isolation of the motor power source. Training will be provided to all production and maintenance staff on the new dual-point system.

name: Install Physical Barriers and Warning Signs Around Hot Equipment
description: Install durable perimeter barriers (yellow caution fencing) around all heat treatment equipment and curing stations that operate above 100°C. Mount high-visibility warning signs at 3-foot intervals indicating temperature hazards and required PPE. Install reflective temperature indicator tape on equipment surfaces showing temperature zones. These engineering controls eliminate accidental contact by creating physical separation between workers and hazardous equipment, reducing thermal burn risk by establishing a protected buffer zone.

name: Implement Automated Cycle Parameter Monitoring System
description: Install real-time monitoring software on all 32 injection molding machines to track temperature sensors, cycle times, and cooling durations. The system will alert operators immediately if parameters drift outside acceptable ranges and automatically reduce cycle speed if cooling time drops below thresholds. This engineering control eliminates the gap between actual and intended machine behavior. Expected outcome: prevention of premature mold openings due to parameter drift, reducing thermal burn incidents by approximately 85%.

name: Enhance Operator Training on Machine Cycle Verification
description: Develop mandatory training module for all injection molding operators covering proper cycle monitoring, sensor drift identification, and safe part removal procedures. Training will include hands-on practice with thermal imaging to visualize cooling times and decision-making scenarios. Operators will be required to verify cycle completion on display panels before opening mold guards. This administrative control ensures operators understand the equipment behavior and risk factors. Training will be delivered quarterly with competency assessments.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Temperature Sensors
description: Create and implement a quarterly calibration and replacement schedule for all temperature sensors on injection molding machines. Maintenance planner Roland Dostie will coordinate with the maintenance team to document baseline readings and replace sensors showing drift patterns. This preventive maintenance control addresses the root cause of the incident by ensuring sensors remain accurate. Maintenance records will be tracked in the CMMS system with alerts for overdue calibrations.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System with Enhanced Dust Collection
description: Design and install upgraded ventilation system in Chemical Storage and Mixing building with capacity matched to increased production volume. New system will include HEPA filtration, enhanced intake filtering to prevent dust escape, and automated dust collection bins with overflow monitoring. Ducting will be redesigned to eliminate horizontal runs where dust accumulates, using downward slopes toward collection points. This engineering control directly eliminates the dust accumulation hazard by removing the source and capturing particles before settling. System design will meet or exceed NFPA 654 combustible dust standards.

name: Implement Daily Dust Housekeeping Protocol and Monitoring Schedule
description: Establish mandatory daily cleaning schedule for all resin processing areas with documented inspections. Cleaning teams will use HEPA-filtered vacuum equipment and damp-wipe methods to prevent dust resuspension. A visual inspection checklist will track dust accumulation on all elevated surfaces, with photo documentation. Any area exceeding 1mm dust depth triggers immediate enhanced cleaning. Chemical Storage area will be inspected twice daily during evening shift. This administrative control maintains continuous dust suppression while the ventilation upgrade is being completed.

name: Install Fixed Combustible Dust Monitoring and Detection Equipment
description: Install continuous combustible dust concentration monitors in Chemical Storage and Mixing building with audible and visual alarms set at 50% of lower flammable limit (LFL). Place sensors at multiple heights and locations to detect dust clouds before they reach hazardous concentrations. Integrate alerts with facility emergency response system to automatically shut down ignition sources in affected areas. This engineering control provides real-time detection capability as a temporary measure while ventilation upgrades proceed.

name: Conduct Complete Electrical Circuit Audit of All Crane Systems
description: Commission independent electrical engineering firm to perform comprehensive audit of all 12 overhead crane systems at TechnoPlast. Audit will map all power sources, backup circuits, and interconnections, identifying any undocumented or secondary circuits. Results will be documented in detailed schematic drawings with clear labeling of all circuit breakers, switches, and isolation points. This engineering control eliminates the information gap that caused the near-miss. Updated schematics will be posted at each crane and distributed to all maintenance personnel.

name: Revise and Enhance LOTO Procedures for Crane Equipment
description: Rewrite LOTO procedures for all overhead cranes to specifically address multiple power sources and backup circuits. New procedures will require technicians to verify de-energization at ALL identified circuit breaker panels before beginning work. Procedure will include a two-person verification checkpoint where a second technician independently confirms all isolation points. All circuit breaker locations must be physically visited and documented on a LOTO checklist prior to work beginning. This administrative control prevents recurrence by building in redundant verification steps.

name: Install Additional Signage and Labeling on Secondary Power Circuits
description: Install high-visibility warning labels at all secondary power circuit breaker locations for crane systems, clearly indicating they are backup/redundant circuits that must also be isolated during LOTO procedures. Labels will reference the associated equipment and LOTO procedure number. Additionally, install a bright yellow warning placard on each crane stating 'MULTIPLE POWER SOURCES - VERIFY ALL CIRCUITS BEFORE MAINTENANCE.' This engineering control ensures visibility of the hazard to all personnel.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all 32 injection molding machines with mandatory hydraulic hose replacement every 5 years and quarterly inspections for micro-fractures. Create a digital tracking system in the maintenance management software to flag machines approaching replacement intervals. Assign Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) as owner of compliance verification. All hoses will be visually inspected for swelling, cracks, and leaks. Include pressure test validation at 110% of operating pressure annually. Document all findings in equipment logs accessible to all operators via QR code at each machine station.

name: Install Automatic Pressure Relief Guards on Hydraulic Lines
description: Engineer and install protective polycarbonate guards on all exposed hydraulic lines carrying pressurized fluid above 100 PSI. Guards will be angled to deflect any pressurized spray away from operator stations and include quick-disconnect safety couplers that reduce pressure to safe levels when hoses are separated. This engineering control eliminates the ability for high-pressure fluid to contact workers directly. Implementation includes modification of 32 machines with estimated labor of 40 hours per machine. Testing will verify spray deflection angles and pressure reduction effectiveness.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Upgrade and Training
description: Replace all standard latex gloves in production areas with cut and heat-resistant nitrile gloves rated to 200°C minimum. All operators on Lines B, C, and D will receive hands-on training on proper glove donning, doffing, and inspection procedures. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) will conduct initial training sessions and quarterly refresher training. Gloves will be inspected daily and replaced at end of shift. Emergency replacement gloves will be staged at every control station with clear signage indicating correct storage and use.

name: Comprehensive Ergonomic Workstation Redesign
description: Conduct full ergonomic assessment of all 24 assembly workstations in the Finishing Department using certified ergonomist protocols. Redesign workbench heights to ISO 11228-1 standards with adjustable-height stations (28-36 inches) allowing employees to maintain neutral wrist posture. Install anti-fatigue matting and ergonomic seating with lumbar support. Replace high-grip-force assembly tools with pneumatic and electric alternatives reducing required grip strength by 60%. Implement individual workstation customization based on anthropometric measurements for each of 8 assembly operators. Include monitor arms and document holders positioned at eye level to reduce neck strain.

name: Implement Mandatory Micro-Break Schedule and Job Rotation
description: Establish an administrative control requiring all assembly operators to take 5-minute micro-breaks every 30 minutes of repetitive work, with mandatory 30-minute lunch breaks. Implement a 4-hour job rotation schedule rotating operators between assembly finishing and quality control inspection tasks to reduce cumulative strain on any single muscle group. Assembly Lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070) will oversee compliance through a digital work schedule system with alerts. All operators will receive training on proper break techniques including stretching exercises targeting wrist, shoulder, and back muscle groups. Track break adherence and monitor for early warning signs of repetitive strain injuries through monthly assessments.

name: Quarterly Ergonomic Assessment and Injury Prevention Training
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly ergonomic assessment program for all production and assembly personnel. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) will conduct individual workstation evaluations documenting posture, tool use, and early strain indicators. Each employee will receive personalized feedback and corrective guidance. Implement annual ergonomics training focused on proper body mechanics, early symptom recognition, and reporting procedures. Create an employee-managed ergonomic concern log allowing workers to report discomfort before injuries develop. Monthly 15-minute toolbox talks will reinforce proper technique and celebrate ergonomic compliance milestones.

name: Install Floor Hazard Identification and Maintenance Work Permits
description: Implement a mandatory floor inspection system requiring daily documented walkthroughs of all warehouse and production areas by designated safety officers. All floor drains, recessed areas, and structural hazards will be marked with high-visibility yellow and black striping and reflective signage. Establish a 'Maintenance Work Permit' system requiring maintenance personnel to complete a hazard communication form before any floor-level work, specifying exact locations and required warning indicators. Uncovered drains must have temporary protective covers or barriers visible from 20 feet away. Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) will audit compliance weekly and maintain records. All drains will receive protective grating or permanent covers where feasible.

name: Forklift and Material Handler Safety Training Enhancement
description: Implement mandatory quarterly certified forklift operator refresher training focusing on hazard recognition, obstacle navigation, and emergency response procedures. All material handlers including Elif Yilmaz will receive hands-on training on navigating around floor hazards, proper speed control, and load securing techniques. Create a laminated 'Daily Hazard Assessment' checklist that operators must complete before beginning shifts, requiring notation of any floor obstacles, drain covers, or structural hazards. Implement a 'Near-Miss' reporting system specifically for material handlers to identify hazards before equipment damage occurs. Training records will be maintained and reviewed quarterly by EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003).

name: Preventive Hydraulic Inspection Program for All Material Handling Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all electric forklifts (12 units) and material handling equipment requiring monthly hydraulic system inspections by certified technicians. All hydraulic hoses will be pressure-tested annually at 125% of operational pressure and replaced every 5 years regardless of condition. Hydraulic fluid will be analyzed quarterly for contamination, viscosity degradation, and early warning indicators of system stress. Any hose showing signs of wear, cracking, or leakage will trigger immediate replacement. Maintain a digital maintenance tracking system with predictive alerts. Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) will oversee program administration and compliance verification.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Material Handling Equipment
description: Establish a quarterly vibration analysis and bearing condition monitoring program for all drying and hopper equipment. This will include baseline measurements, thermal imaging during operation, and oil analysis for wear particles. Maintenance technician Andrei Popov will coordinate with equipment suppliers to establish early warning thresholds. Documentation will be maintained in the CMMS system with automated alerts 30 days before predicted maintenance needs. This proactive approach will prevent catastrophic failures and unplanned downtime.

name: Enhance Operator Observation and Reporting Training
description: Develop and deliver targeted training module for all material handlers on recognizing equipment distress signals including unusual vibrations, sounds, temperature changes, and odors. Create a simplified visual checklist for daily pre-operation inspections. Implement a near-miss reporting incentive program recognizing employees who identify potential hazards before incidents occur. Train all shift supervisors to conduct immediate equipment assessment when abnormal conditions are reported.

name: Establish Hydraulic Component Lifecycle Management System
description: Implement a comprehensive tracking system for all critical hydraulic components including pressure relief valves, seals, and hoses with documented service intervals. All components will be tagged with installation dates and maximum service life. Andrei Popov (Hydraulic Systems Technician) will develop replacement schedules based on manufacturer specifications and historical failure data. Relief valves on all injection presses will be replaced immediately if exceeding 6 years of service. A automated alert system will notify maintenance personnel 60 days before component replacement is due.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Monitoring and Shutdown Protocols
description: Install pressure monitoring sensors on all injection molding lines with real-time alerts when pressure exceeds 95% of relief valve setpoint. Integrate monitoring system with production control software to automatically reduce injection speed and clamp force when anomalies detected. Implement fail-safe shutdown that vents all hydraulic pressure if sensor malfunction detected. Train all operators on new alert signals and manual override procedures. This adds redundancy to the relief valve safety function.

name: Conduct Root Cause Analysis and Preventive Maintenance Audit
description: Commission external hydraulic systems expert to conduct comprehensive audit of all press equipment to identify similar aging components at risk of failure. Perform ultrasonic and thermographic inspection on all relief valves, pressure regulators, and proportional valves. Develop detailed preventive maintenance plan with prioritized replacement schedule. Document findings in incident report and present to Joint Health and Safety Committee to prevent recurrence.

name: Upgrade Chemical Transfer Equipment and Secondary Containment
description: Replace all manual pump couplings with quick-disconnect safety couplings that prevent accidental disconnection. Inspect and upgrade secondary containment basins to ensure 110% capacity of largest stored container. Install drain plugs with lockable valves to prevent debris accumulation. Establish monthly inspection and maintenance schedule for all transfer equipment. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of improper coupling failure and inadequate containment verification.

name: Implement Enhanced Chemical Transfer Training and Procedures
description: Develop comprehensive training module for all personnel involved in chemical transfer operations, covering proper coupling verification, secondary containment inspection, spill response protocols, and emergency ventilation procedures. Require annual recertification and document all training completion. Create visual job aids at transfer stations showing proper connection sequences. Establish supervisor checklist for pre-transfer inspections. This administrative control ensures all employees understand proper procedures and hazard recognition.

name: Establish Rigorous Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Implement computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) to track all hydraulic component service intervals. Ensure relief valves receive service every 12 months maximum, with calibrated pressure gauges checked every 6 months. Create pre-production checklists requiring verification of maintenance status. Assign Maintenance Workshop Lead responsibility for monthly compliance audits. Establish parts inventory for critical spares to prevent production delays when replacements are needed. This engineering and administrative control prevents future pressure system failures.

name: Install Enhanced Pressure Monitoring and Automated Shutdown System
description: Retrofit Injection Molding Line C with real-time pressure monitoring sensors connected to the programmable logic controller (PLC). Configure automated shutdown protocols to trigger emergency stop if pressure drops below critical thresholds, preventing unexpected mold opening. Install visual and audible alarms to alert operators before critical conditions develop. Extend monitoring to all six injection molding lines. This engineering control provides automatic hazard mitigation independent of human intervention.

name: Implement Mandatory Mold Cooling and Waiting Periods
description: Establish engineering control through automated cycle time interlocks that prevent operator access to mold surfaces until temperature drops below 60°C (verified by thermal sensors). Install visible countdown timers at each machine showing mandatory cooling periods before manual intervention is permitted. Reprogram production schedule targets to incorporate realistic cooling intervals. This eliminates the hazard of hot surface contact through engineering controls rather than relying on operator compliance.

name: Upgrade PPE Requirements and Provide Heat-Resistant Gloves
description: Mandate use of high-temperature-rated gloves (rated to 250°C minimum) for all mold cleaning activities, replacing standard nitrile gloves. Issue specialized gloves to all production operators and establish monthly replacement schedule. Add heat-resistant sleeves and aprons to PPE kits for high-temperature operations. Conduct training on proper donning/doffing and care of heat-protective equipment. Store PPE at workstations for convenient access. While PPE is the lowest hierarchy level, this measure protects against residual risk.

name: Establish Production Scheduling Review and Safety Culture Initiative
description: Review current production targets with operations management to ensure they do not incentivize unsafe shortcuts. Implement policy that explicitly states safety cannot be compromised for schedule adherence. Conduct management training on creating psychologically safe workplaces where employees feel empowered to report safety concerns without fear of discipline. Introduce anonymous safety suggestion system. Establish monthly safety culture audits. This administrative control addresses the systemic issue of production pressure overriding safety procedures.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Pre-Work Briefing Protocol
description: Establish a formal requirement that all maintenance personnel must receive a brief safety huddle before beginning any work on injection molding equipment. The briefing will include: verification of lockout/tagout status, review of all automated cycles and timers, identification of all energy sources (hydraulic, pneumatic, electrical), and confirmation that locks are in place and verified by a second person. This administrative control will be documented on a pre-work checklist that must be signed by both the technician and supervisor before work begins. Expected outcome: 100% compliance with LOTO procedures and elimination of unauthorized equipment activation during maintenance.

name: Install Automatic Pump Shutdown on Equipment Standby
description: Modify the hydraulic pump control system on Injection Molding Line D to completely de-energize the pump when the machine enters maintenance mode, rather than relying on timer-based cycles. This engineering control will include installation of a solenoid valve that physically isolates hydraulic pressure when maintenance mode is selected via a dedicated switch. The system will include confirmation lights and audible alarms to indicate when full pressure isolation has been achieved. A tertiary mechanical lock will prevent accidental mode switching during maintenance. This eliminates the hazard of unexpected equipment movement during maintenance activities.

name: Distribute Cut-Resistant Gloves for Document Handling
description: Issue cut-resistant gloves (Level 3 protection per EN 388) to all Quality Documentation Specialists and warehouse personnel who handle cardboard boxes and sharp-edged materials. The gloves will be provided in multiple sizes and stored at convenient locations near work stations. Training will be conducted on proper use and inspection of gloves. This PPE control will reduce the risk of lacerations from paper edges and cardboard handling. Staff will be required to wear gloves when handling boxes containing sharp materials, with compliance monitored during safety audits.

name: Establish Designated Equipment Staging Areas with Cable Management
description: Create clearly marked staging zones in the warehouse where maintenance equipment, hoses, and cables must be stored when not actively in use. These areas will be located outside of forklift traffic lanes and clearly indicated with yellow and black safety markings. All air hoses and electrical cables will be routed through cable trays mounted at 6 feet height, eliminating floor-level hazards. A new work procedure will require maintenance personnel to coil and secure hoses in designated holders at the end of each shift or work session. Compliance will be verified during daily pre-shift safety walks by the Production Supervisor.

name: Implement Mandatory Forklift Operator Spotter Training and System
description: Establish a requirement that all forklift operations in confined warehouse aisles must include a trained spotter positioned to guide the operator and identify hazards. All forklift operators will receive updated training on spotting techniques, communication protocols, and hazard recognition. A system of hand signals and two-way radio communication will be standardized across the facility. Administrative controls will include a log system documenting when spotters were used. This reduces collision risk by providing a second set of eyes to identify obstacles, personnel, and hazardous conditions that the operator cannot see from the forklift cab.

name: Install Physical Barriers Between Pedestrian Zones and Material Handling Routes
description: Install permanent yellow bollards and safety railings to create clear physical separation between high-traffic pedestrian areas and forklift operating lanes in the warehouse. These engineering controls will be positioned to prevent personnel from entering forklift zones while allowing clear equipment movement. Access points will be controlled with traffic control signs and mirrors to enhance visibility at blind corners. The barriers will be reinforced to withstand accidental forklift contact without damaging the equipment or creating secondary hazards.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Protocol
description: Establish a rigorous Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) verification system requiring two-person verification before any machine startup. Install physical lockout stations at each injection molding line with color-coded tags and locks. Require all operators to complete a refresher LOTO certification training module within 30 days, with quarterly competency assessments. Implement digital LOTO logging to track who locked/unlocked equipment and when. Any deviation from the protocol will result in immediate disciplinary action up to and including suspension.

name: Upgrade Machine Guarding on Mold Closing Mechanism
description: Install physical guards and interlock devices on all injection molding lines to prevent manual access to mold closing areas during operation. Add redundant pressure-relief systems that prevent mold closure if any obstruction is detected. Install proximity sensors that detect hand/object entry and trigger automatic machine shutdown. Replace manual safety interlocks with electronic interlocks that cannot be bypassed without management override and documentation. Expected to reduce crushing injuries by 95%.

name: Enhance Production Line Lighting and Machine Status Indicators
description: Install additional LED lighting in the machine operation zones to improve visibility of mold engagement status and operator positions. Add large, illuminated status indicators (green/red/yellow) visible from all angles showing machine state (powered down/ready/running). Implement audible warning signals that sound during all startup sequences. Ensure all lighting meets ANSI standards for industrial environments. This prevents confusion about machine status and reduces visibility-related errors.

name: Install Pinch Point Guards on Material Handling Equipment
description: Design and install physical guards around all material cart and hopper junction points to prevent fingers from entering pinch zones. Use adjustable protective barriers that allow material transfer while blocking hand access to dangerous areas. Ensure guards are positioned at all likely contact points and are made of impact-resistant material. Conduct a full hazard assessment of all material handling stations and retrofit with appropriate guards within 21 days.

name: Provide Material Handler Hand Protection and Awareness Training
description: Issue cut-resistant gloves rated for material handling to all warehouse personnel, with replacement gloves provided quarterly. Conduct a focused 30-minute training session on pinch point hazards specific to hopper and cart operations. Include demonstration of proper hand positioning during material transfer and identification of high-risk situations. Require all material handlers to sign acknowledgment of training completion and discuss at next team safety meeting.

name: Upgrade Hazardous Waste Storage Area Flooring
description: Replace existing concrete flooring in Unit-011 with chemical-resistant, non-slip epoxy coating designed for hazardous material environments. The new flooring will have anti-slip properties even when wet with resin or solvents, and drain channels that direct spilled materials safely away from personnel work areas. Installation will include perimeter containment berms to prevent spills from spreading. Secondary containment pallets will be required for all large resin containers. Implementation within 45 days.

name: Implement Automated Resin Container Handling System
description: Install a mechanical lift system (pneumatic or hydraulic) for transferring large resin containers to eliminate manual handling of containers weighing more than 10 kg. Operators will use foot pedal or hand controls to raise/lower/position containers, reducing risk of spillage from dropped or tipped containers. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the spill and significantly reduces injury potential. Train all operators on new system within one week of installation.

name: Establish Spill Response and Floor Cleanup Protocol
description: Create a detailed spill response procedure specific to resin and solvent materials. All night shift staff will be trained on rapid containment techniques using absorbent materials, safe perimeter establishment, and proper cleanup using non-slip precautions. Install spill kits at three stations in Unit-011. Require no personnel to work within 3 meters of an active spill without spill barrier protection. Designate a spill response leader for each shift who has received advanced training.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Inspections
description: Establish a formal preventive maintenance schedule requiring quarterly visual and pressure inspections of all cooling water lines on injection molding machines. Maintenance technicians will use thermal imaging cameras to detect early stress points and potential crack formation. Documentation will be maintained in the CMMS system with alerts generated 30 days before scheduled inspections. This proactive approach will catch developing issues before they result in leaks or system failures that could cause chemical exposure or equipment damage.

name: Operator Hazard Recognition Training Reinforcement
description: Conduct focused 30-minute training sessions for all production operators emphasizing early detection of equipment anomalies (unusual vibrations, odors, sounds, temperature changes). Training will include case studies of near-misses like this incident. Operators will be empowered to immediately stop operations and notify supervisors without concern for production delays. Quarterly refresher sessions will reinforce this culture of proactive hazard reporting and early intervention.

name: Install Ergonomic Component Dispensing System
description: Replace floor-level component storage with adjustable-height shelving units that position boxes at waist level, eliminating the need for repetitive bending. Implement mechanical lift-assist devices or light pneumatic hoists for boxes exceeding 15 kg. This engineering control removes the root cause of the injury by reducing awkward postures and excessive load handling at floor level. The system will be configured for both day and evening shift operators at all four production lines within 90 days.

name: Mandatory Ergonomic Assessment and Training Program
description: Conduct individual ergonomic assessments for all assembly and packaging operators, identifying personal risk factors and optimizing workstation setup. Provide 60-minute hands-on training sessions teaching proper lifting techniques, use of mechanical assists, and recognition of early warning signs of musculoskeletal strain. Monthly toolbox talks will reinforce best practices. Operators will be encouraged to report discomfort early without fear of retaliation. Track and trend reporting of minor aches and pains to identify emerging patterns.

name: Implement Job Rotation and Micro-break Protocol
description: Establish a job rotation schedule requiring assembly operators to change tasks every 90 minutes to reduce cumulative strain on specific muscle groups. Implement 5-minute active recovery breaks every 2 hours where operators perform guided stretching and mobility exercises. Document rotation schedules in the production planning system. This administrative control will distribute physical demands across different body regions and allow recovery time, reducing the risk of overuse injuries.

name: Install Automatic Dust Collection and Suppression System
description: Engineer and install a comprehensive automated dust collection system in UNIT-016 using industrial-grade HEPA filters with self-cleaning mechanisms that activate every 4 hours. Add spark detection and automatic powder suppression nozzles above drying ovens and ventilation points. Install explosion-proof electrical equipment to eliminate ignition sources. This elimination and engineering control approach removes the primary hazard (accumulated combustible dust) and prevents ignition. System will be operational within 120 days and will reduce dust accumulation to less than 0.5 mm depth at all times.

name: Establish Daily Dust Control and Cleaning Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory daily cleaning schedule requiring operators to vacuum and wipe down all horizontal surfaces in UNIT-016 during each shift. Use anti-static vacuum equipment to prevent electrostatic ignition. Establish visual standards (maximum visible dust depth of 1 mm) and conduct daily inspections with photographic documentation. Create an automated scheduling system with operator sign-offs. This administrative control ensures immediate removal of accumulated dust and prevents accumulation that can fuel fires.

name: Upgrade Oven Temperature Control and Monitoring Systems
description: Replace aging thermostats on all industrial ovens in UNIT-016 with modern PLC-based systems featuring redundant temperature sensors, automatic shutdown at 250°C setpoint limit, and remote monitoring with alerts sent to maintenance and supervisory staff. Implement a preventive maintenance schedule for heating elements with replacement every 18 months or upon performance degradation. This engineering control prevents the specific ignition source (overheating element) that initiated this fire and provides real-time visibility into equipment conditions.

name: Comprehensive Fire Safety Training and Incident Response Drills
description: Conduct facility-wide fire safety training emphasizing dust explosion hazards, early detection, and rapid evacuation protocols. Schedule quarterly fire evacuation drills with full accountability procedures. Provide specialized training to night shift staff on identifying dust accumulation and reporting hazards. Create job aids and laminated reference cards for each work area showing emergency procedures and suppression system locations. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand their roles and respond effectively to fire emergencies.

name: Implement Mandatory Equipment Shutdown Protocol for Fume Detection
description: Establish a non-negotiable procedure requiring immediate equipment shutdown and LOTO compliance when operators detect unusual fumes or vapor emissions. All Production Operations staff will receive retraining on this protocol within 5 days. Signage will be posted at all injection molding stations emphasizing that continued operation with visible fumes constitutes a safety violation. Additionally, mobile gas detection equipment will be positioned at high-risk lines for real-time monitoring. This addresses the root cause of operator hesitation to stop production and ensures early hazard detection.

name: Accelerate Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Material Drying Systems
description: Establish a firm maintenance calendar for all material drying and preparation equipment that cannot be delayed due to production demands. Schedule preventive maintenance at 50% capacity utilization triggers rather than fixed dates. Assign dedicated maintenance technician responsibility to ensure drying systems are inspected bi-weekly rather than the current monthly schedule. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of equipment malfunction and prevents similar incidents.

name: Install High-Grip Safety Flooring in High-Traffic Warehouse Zones
description: Replace deteriorated slip-resistant floor coating in the Finished Goods Warehouse with industrial-grade high-grip safety flooring rated for wet conditions and forklift traffic. Focus on high-traffic routes between storage areas and loading docks. This engineering control directly eliminates the slip hazard that caused the near-miss. Installation will be completed in phases during low-volume periods to minimize operational disruption. Expected completion within 30 days.

name: Revise Warehouse Cleaning and Drying Protocols
description: Update cleaning procedures to include enhanced drying times during high-humidity seasons (May-October in Quebec). Specify use of water-absorbent materials and air circulation equipment following wet cleaning. All evening and night shift warehouse staff will receive updated training on the modified protocol. Additionally, establish daily visual inspections of warehouse floors before shift changes to identify wet spots or residue. Post warning signs in wet areas during cleaning operations.

name: Implement Mandatory Physical LOTO Compliance with Electronic Verification System
description: Establish a non-negotiable policy requiring physical lockout-tagout (LOTO) application on ALL CNC equipment breakers before maintenance begins—not software-only disabling. Install a new electronic verification system that prevents any remote equipment activation when a physical LOTO device is detected. This system will use RFID tags on locks to communicate with the central control system. Train all maintenance technicians and day shift supervisors on the updated protocol within 48 hours. This engineering control directly prevents accidental equipment startup during maintenance activities.

name: Establish Shift Handover LOTO Communication Protocol
description: Create a mandatory written communication log for all active LOTO situations that must be verbally confirmed between shift supervisors before each shift change. Implement a physical whiteboard system in each maintenance area displaying active lockouts, affected equipment, responsible technician, and expected completion time. Day shift personnel must review and acknowledge the board before commencing any equipment operations. This administrative control ensures all personnel are aware of active maintenance work and reduces communication failures that could lead to equipment startup during maintenance.

name: Implement Secondary Containment System for Chemical Storage
description: Install plastic secondary containment trays beneath all chemical storage shelves in UNIT-010. All mold release agents and similar liquid chemicals must be stored in clearly labeled containers within these trays to contain any spills. Chemical handlers must complete a refresher training on proper storage protocols and the importance of securing container lids. Monthly inspections will verify compliance and identify any leaking containers before incidents occur.

name: Mandatory Chemical Handling PPE Upgrade
description: Require all personnel handling mold release agents to wear nitrile gloves and protective sleeves rated for chemical exposure. Update the WHMIS station to include visual reminders and implement mandatory PPE checks at shift start. Conduct training for all production and materials management staff on proper donning and doffing of chemical-resistant gloves to prevent skin contact incidents.

name: Enhanced Lighting and Wet Floor Management Protocol
description: Install additional LED lighting fixtures in the materials handling aisle connecting UNIT-011 and storage areas to achieve minimum 300 lux illumination levels. Implement a mandatory dry-down procedure following any cleaning operations, with designated wet floor signage and traffic control. Create a cleaning schedule that avoids overlap with material handling activities. Require all cleaning staff to use absorbent materials and complete floor inspection before allowing forklift traffic to resume.

name: Quarterly Forklift Operator Recertification and Equipment Inspection
description: Establish a quarterly recertification program for all forklift operators focusing on hazard recognition, emergency maneuvering, and load stability management. Implement pre-shift equipment inspections to verify tire tread, brake function, and visibility features. Conduct monthly equipment maintenance audits. All operators must complete a written hazard assessment test demonstrating understanding of wet floor and spill hazards before being cleared to operate equipment.

name: Implement Mechanical LOTO Interlock System on Line D
description: Install a physical mechanical interlock system on the Line D injection machine that prevents machine startup when the hopper access panel is opened or LOTO hasp is engaged. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of accidental pressure release during maintenance. The system must include visual indicators confirming safe state and integration with the remote control system to prevent override attempts. All operators must receive hands-on training on the new interlock before resuming operations.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedure Verification and Buddy System
description: Revise the LOTO procedure to require two-person verification before any maintenance work on heated equipment. A designated supervisor must physically verify and document that all lockout devices are engaged, heating elements have cooled below 60°C (verified with thermal imaging), and pressure has been fully relieved before maintenance begins. Implement a daily toolbox talk during shift changes specifically addressing LOTO compliance. Conduct unannounced LOTO audits weekly, with non-compliance resulting in immediate retraining.

name: Enhanced PPE and Thermal Protection for Heat-Exposed Work
description: Upgrade PPE requirements for all personnel working on heated injection molding equipment to include flame-resistant shirts, heat-resistant gloves rated to 200°C, and face shields. Store specialized thermal protection equipment in easily accessible kits at each production line. Conduct quarterly training on proper donning, inspection, and care of thermal protective equipment. Maintain inventory logs to ensure PPE availability and functionality.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification System
description: Establish a two-person lockout/tagout verification protocol where a supervisor must physically inspect and confirm all energy isolation points before any maintenance begins. Install lockout stations at each injection molding line with standardized LOTO equipment and energy source diagrams. Conduct monthly audits of LOTO compliance with documentation. All operators must complete refresher LOTO training within 30 days, with emphasis on disabling automatic cycle timers and confirming zero-energy state before hand placement near molds.

name: Install Proximity Sensors on Mold Closing Mechanisms
description: Install safety proximity sensors on all injection molding machines to detect human hand presence in the mold closing zone. Configure sensors to interrupt the closing cycle and trigger an audible alarm if hands are detected. This engineering control provides an additional layer of protection regardless of LOTO status. Sensors will be integrated with existing machine control systems and tested weekly. This addresses the root cause by creating a mechanical barrier to the hazard.

name: Enhanced Machine Guarding and Signage
description: Retrofit injection molding Line A and Line B with enhanced guards around mold closing areas with high-visibility warning labels in French and English. Install red emergency stop buttons within arm's reach of all operator positions. Add pictorial warnings showing crush injury hazards. Ensure all guards meet CSA standards for industrial machinery. This provides immediate visual and physical reminders of hazards to all workers.

name: Establish Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Implement a comprehensive hydraulic system inspection and maintenance program for all gantry cranes, injection molding machines, and material handling equipment. Schedule hose inspections every 12 months and mandatory replacement every 24 months regardless of visible condition. Maintain detailed logs of all replacements and inspections. Train maintenance technicians on early signs of hydraulic hose degradation including micro-fractures, bulging, and fluid weeping. This eliminates the root cause of equipment failure.

name: Install Secondary Containment Under Overhead Equipment
description: Install drip pans and secondary containment systems directly beneath the gantry crane and all overhead lifting equipment. Design containment to capture 150% of maximum hydraulic fluid capacity. Connect containment systems to the facility's hazmat collection protocol. This engineering control prevents environmental contamination and material loss in case of future leaks.

name: Install Automatic Temperature Shutoff and Alarm System
description: Replace the existing manual thermostat on the resin dryer with a redundant dual-sensor automatic temperature control system with high-limit shutoff at 150°C. Install an audible alarm that activates at 145°C to alert operators of temperature deviation. Integrate the system with the facility's building management system to send automated alerts to maintenance staff and supervisors via email and SMS. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of uncontrolled dryer heating.

name: Implement Shift Handover Temperature Check Protocol
description: Create a mandatory shift handover checklist that includes verification of all equipment temperatures, particularly the resin dryer. Require incoming shift supervisor to physically sign off on the equipment status report before previous shift can leave. Post large laminated checklist at the dryer location. Conduct monthly spot audits to ensure compliance. Train all production supervisors on the hazards of unmonitored dryer operation.

name: Increase Clearance and Fire Prevention Around Dryer
description: Remove all combustible materials (resin pellets, absorbent materials, packaging) from storage racks within 2 meters of the resin dryer. Install metal mesh guards around dryer exhaust vents to prevent fiber accumulation. Schedule weekly cleaning of dryer exterior and vent areas. Install a Class D dry powder fire extinguisher specifically rated for plastic material fires adjacent to the dryer. This reduces the potential consequences if overheating occurs.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Audits
description: Implement weekly audits of lockout/tagout compliance across all production lines, with mandatory retraining for all operators and maintenance staff. Create a digital verification system requiring photographic evidence of LOTO implementation before any maintenance work begins. Assign Gaétan Laplante as LOTO Coordinator to conduct unannounced spot checks and maintain compliance documentation. Non-compliance will result in immediate work stoppage and additional training requirements.

name: Replace Faulty Pressure Relief Valves
description: Immediately replace all pressure relief valves on Injection Molding Line B and conduct a preventive maintenance audit of identical equipment across the facility. Establish a predictive maintenance schedule using pressure monitoring sensors to detect valve degradation before failure. Schedule quarterly replacement of all relief valves as standard maintenance protocol to prevent unexpected machine cycling.

name: Enhanced Machine Guarding and Interlock Systems
description: Install mechanical interlocks on all hopper access points that prevent auger rotation when hopper covers are open or maintenance panels are accessed. Add proximity sensors to detect unauthorized hand entry into hazard zones. Upgrade to Type-4 emergency stop stations with dual-channel safety monitoring that cannot be bypassed by equipment malfunctions.

name: Comprehensive Chemical Storage Facility Redesign
description: Relocate all flammable solvents to a dedicated, purpose-built storage room with Class IV fire suppression, segregated electrical systems rated for hazardous locations, and secondary containment for all containers. Install redundant ventilation systems with real-time monitoring and automatic alerts if airflow drops below threshold. Implement a chemical inventory management system with barcode tracking and automated reorder points to prevent overstocking. All stored chemicals must meet container integrity standards with monthly inspections.

name: Ventilation System Upgrade and Preventive Maintenance
description: Replace all ventilation equipment in chemical storage areas with industrial-grade systems designed for solvent vapor extraction. Establish a mandatory maintenance schedule with quarterly professional inspections and monthly staff checks. Install continuous air quality monitoring with sensors that detect solvent vapor concentrations and automatically increase ventilation when thresholds are exceeded. Maintain detailed logs of all maintenance activities.

name: Electrical Safety Certification in Hazardous Zones
description: Install certified Class I, Division 2 electrical equipment throughout chemical storage and mixing areas in compliance with NEC standards. Remove all non-rated components and upgrade panel systems to intrinsically safe designs with emergency disconnect capabilities. Hire a licensed electrical contractor to certify all modifications and establish annual re-certification requirements. Train all maintenance staff on electrical safety in hazardous locations.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring and Drainage System
description: Replace the dock area flooring with high-friction, chemical-resistant anti-slip coating rated for wet environments and solvent exposure. Install a proper drainage system with collection trays beneath cleaning and transfer stations to prevent liquid accumulation. Mark all wet zones with permanent slip hazard signage and implement daily inspection protocols to identify and document any slippery surfaces before shift start.

name: Enhanced Cleaning Protocols and Spill Management
description: Implement a mandatory cleaning schedule with assigned responsibility for each shift to clean and dry dock areas immediately after any chemical use. Provide absorbent spill kits stationed at strategic locations with clear usage instructions. Require documentation of all cleaning activities on a daily log reviewed by supervisors. Train all personnel on proper spill cleanup procedures emphasizing immediate containment and notification.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification System
description: Establish a two-person verification protocol requiring both the maintenance technician and a supervisor to physically verify that all lockout/tagout devices are properly engaged before any machine startup is authorized. Install visual verification tags on each machine's startup panel that must be physically removed by the second person. Conduct immediate refresher training for all production supervisors and machine setters on LOTO procedures, with competency certification required. Create daily LOTO audit checklists to be completed before each shift by supervisory staff.

name: Install Automated Machine Interlock System
description: Engineer and install an advanced electronic interlock system that prevents machine startup unless all LOTO pins are physically detected in their secured positions. The system will integrate with the existing PLC controls and cannot be bypassed manually. Additionally, install proximity sensors near maintenance access points that automatically trigger a machine shutdown if any object enters the hazard zone while the machine is running. This engineering control eliminates reliance on human memory and procedures alone.

name: Establish Machine Maintenance SOPs with Photographic Documentation
description: Develop comprehensive standard operating procedures with step-by-step photographs showing correct LOTO positioning, verification points, and sign-off locations for each machine type at TechnoPlast. Create laminated quick-reference guides posted at each machine. Require digital photo documentation of proper LOTO setup before maintenance work begins, with automatic timestamped submission to the HSE system. This creates a verifiable record and reinforces proper procedures.

name: Implement Material Receiving and Pre-processing Protocol
description: Establish a new procedure requiring all incoming composite material shipments to be visually inspected and moisture-conditioned before opening. Materials must be sprayed with light water mist while still in sealed containers for 30 minutes to suppress airborne dust. All material unpacking must occur in the composite material preparation room with local exhaust ventilation running at maximum capacity. Create a receiving checklist that specifies fiber type, moisture content, and batch composition verification before materials are released for processing. Train all materials management personnel on this protocol.

name: Upgrade Laboratory Ventilation and Install Real-time Air Quality Monitoring
description: Install portable real-time air quality monitors (IAQ sensors) in the Quality Control Laboratory that track particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10) and provide audible alerts when composite fiber dust levels exceed 5 mg/m³. Upgrade the laboratory's local exhaust ventilation hood with HEPA filtration and increased capture velocity. Install a secondary ceiling-mounted supply ventilation system to create positive air pressure and backup evacuation. Mount visual monitors at workstations so workers can see real-time air quality data and self-regulate exposure.

name: Repair and Upgrade Material Handling Equipment
description: Immediately repair the mechanical hoist in the Regrind and Recycling Department and conduct full functionality testing. Additionally, procure and install a second backup hoist to provide redundancy and ensure material transfer operations can continue during maintenance. Install heavy-duty carrying handles or grip loops on all regrind rolls to provide safe manual grip points for situations requiring hand manipulation. Ensure all material handling equipment is included in the preventive maintenance schedule with monthly inspections.

name: Conduct Mandatory Ergonomics and Lifting Technique Refresher Training
description: Organize immediate refresher training for all materials management and warehousing personnel covering proper lifting techniques, load assessment, use of mechanical assists, and recognition of ergonomic risk factors. Training will be delivered by the company's occupational health nurse and include practical demonstrations using actual materials handled at TechnoPlast. Emphasize the prohibition on manual lifting of loads exceeding 23 kg without mechanical assistance. Require all participants to demonstrate competency through practical assessment, with training records maintained.

name: Implement Post-Maintenance Safety Interlock Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory checklist requiring all safety interlocks, guards, and emergency stop systems to be tested and verified after any maintenance work on injection molding equipment. Maintenance Lead will verify each system functions correctly before the machine returns to production. A supervisor must sign off on verification documentation. This addresses the root cause of incomplete safety system inspection by creating an administrative control and documentation requirement.

name: Install Enhanced Mold Guarding with Presence Sensing Devices
description: Replace standard guards on Injection Molding Lines with presence-sensing safety devices that detect operator proximity to pinch points and prevent mold closure. These electro-optical sensors will provide an engineering control that eliminates the crush hazard by creating a protective safety zone around the mold. Training will be provided to all operators on proper use and testing of the new guards.

name: Conduct Mandatory Machine Guarding Refresher Training
description: Deliver targeted training to all production operators on Line D regarding proper lockout/tagout procedures, identification of pinch points, and correct mold removal techniques. Training will include case study review of this incident and emphasis on never bypassing safety interlocks. Training records will be maintained and refresher sessions scheduled quarterly.

name: Establish Strict Chemical Storage and Container Management Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory requirement that all flammable solvent containers must be sealed immediately after use and stored in dedicated flammable cabinets that meet CSA standards. All containers must be logged in a digital inventory system with location tracking. Chemical Storage area will be inspected daily at shift changes. This administrative control eliminates the root cause of open solvent containers creating vapor hazards.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Spill Prevention Equipment
description: Install high-capacity secondary containment trays under all chemical storage shelves to capture potential spills and prevent liquids from spreading. Add absorbent spill kits at two strategic locations in the storage room. Install automatic spill shutoff valves on dispensing stations. These engineering controls provide physical containment of hazardous materials and reduce fire risk from spreading spilled chemicals.

name: Prohibit Open Flame and Hot Surface Equipment in Chemical Storage Areas
description: Eliminate all hot plates, heating elements, and potential ignition sources from the Chemical Storage Room and Mixing Room. Relocate any required heating operations to a separate, properly ventilated area distant from solvent storage with proper fire separation. This substitution control removes the ignition source that initiated the fire.

name: Implement Mandatory Annual Certified Crane Inspection Program
description: Establish a documented schedule requiring all overhead cranes to undergo professional certified inspections by a qualified engineer at least annually, with documented records maintained for compliance verification. Create a digital tracking system to alert HSE staff 60 days before each inspection due date. All inspection reports will be reviewed by Maintenance Lead and corrective actions implemented before crane return to service. This administrative control ensures equipment is properly maintained and inspected per regulatory requirements.

name: Replace Overhead Crane Hook Assemblies with Load Monitoring Systems
description: Replace all aging hook assemblies on warehouse cranes with newer models incorporating integrated load cells and automatic cutoff systems that prevent overload conditions. Install wireless load monitoring displays visible to operators showing real-time load weight and safe working limits. This engineering control detects and prevents overload conditions that could cause equipment failure.

name: Install Drum Secondary Containment System
description: Install a dedicated secondary containment berm in UNIT-010 capable of holding 110% of the largest container volume. The berm will feature sloped surfaces for drainage, absorbent pads for spill response, and clearly marked storage zones. All solvent drums will be stored exclusively within this containment area. Quarterly inspections will verify berm integrity and absorbent material stock levels.

name: Enhanced Ventilation System Upgrade
description: Upgrade the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room ventilation system to achieve 12 air changes per hour with dedicated exhaust. Install real-time VOC monitoring sensors that trigger emergency alerts at 250 ppm. Implement automatic activation of secondary exhaust fans and emergency shutdown procedures for high-risk equipment when thresholds are exceeded. Annual certification of ventilation performance will be required.

name: Chemical Handling Procedure Revision and Training
description: Revise chemical transfer procedures to mandate valve inspection before each transfer, use of barrel dollies rather than manual handling, and reduction of transfer heights. Require all personnel handling hazardous materials to complete refresher WHMIS training within 30 days. Implement a pre-transfer checklist system with supervisor sign-off. Monthly competency assessments for all chemical handlers will be conducted.

name: Implement Temperature Verification Protocol
description: Require all Injection Molding Operators to use infrared thermometers to verify mold surface temperatures before manual part removal. Establish a written procedure mandating that operators wait until component surface temperatures drop below 150°C or use mechanical extraction tools for hotter parts. Install visual temperature gauges on each molding line. Operators must document temperature readings on shift logs daily.

name: Upgrade to Advanced Heat-Resistant Gloves
description: Replace standard heat-resistant gloves with Kevlar-lined silicone gloves rated for 260°C continuous contact. All 40 assembly and finishing staff will receive new gloves. Implement quarterly replacement schedule and conduct fit/comfort testing. Store backup gloves at each workstation to ensure no delay when replacement is needed.

name: Install Mechanical Part Extraction Assists
description: Procure and install mechanical vacuum-assisted part extractors on all four injection molding lines to eliminate direct hand contact with hot components. Train operators on proper extraction tool use. Establish mandatory use policy for all parts hotter than 180°C. Monthly tool maintenance inspections will be performed by maintenance staff.

name: Establish Mezzanine No-Equipment Zone
description: Designate the mezzanine level as a restricted area for motorized equipment including pallet jacks and forklifts. All material movement on the mezzanine must use manual carts or hand trucks only. Install physical barriers and warning signage at all mezzanine access points. Implement daily safety briefings for warehouse staff emphasizing this policy. Violators will be subject to disciplinary action.

name: Install Load Securing and Anti-Slip Systems
description: Install anti-slip matting and containment rails on all warehouse shelving and pallet positions, particularly on elevated surfaces. Implement mandatory load wrapping protocols using stretch film on all stacked cartons. Install load stabilization bars on mezzanine racks. Conduct training for all warehouse personnel on proper load securing techniques and documentation of load verification before and after shifts.

name: Implement Safety Canopy Protection and Barrier System
description: Install protective ceiling nets and deflection canopies above all work areas beneath mezzanine levels to safely redirect and absorb falling objects. Add impact-absorbing foam bumpers to equipment parked below storage areas. Paint high-visibility hazard zones on the floor beneath mezzanines. Post permanent warning signage and conduct quarterly safety audits of the warehouse layout.

name: Implement Shift-End Machine Cleaning Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory end-of-shift cleaning checklist for all injection molding lines requiring operators to wipe down all horizontal surfaces with specialized solvent and lint-free cloths before shift changeover. Create laminated reference cards at each station detailing specific areas requiring attention. Include mold release agent residue removal as a critical step. This addresses the root cause of inadequate surface cleaning between shifts and reduces direct skin contact hazards.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment Requirements
description: Mandate the use of nitrile gloves (double-layer) and long-sleeve protective sleeves for all operators working with mold release agents on Lines C and D. Distribute new PPE to all affected staff and conduct mandatory 30-minute training on proper application and removal to minimize contamination. Stock additional glove sizes and sleeve lengths to ensure proper fit and comfort compliance.

name: Establish Daily Forklift Pre-Operation Inspection Program
description: Implement a mandatory pre-shift inspection checklist for all forklift operators covering tire condition, hydraulic fluid levels, brake responsiveness, and warning light functionality. Operators must document findings on a daily logsheet before operating equipment. Any vehicle with defects must be immediately removed from service and tagged. Provide training to all 8 forklift operators and establish a supervisor sign-off requirement. This engineering and administrative control prevents equipment failure incidents before they occur.

name: Install Ground-Level Warehouse Debris Collection Stations
description: Place 6 additional designated debris collection bins throughout the warehouse in high-traffic areas where sharp objects (pallet fragments, nails, metal bands) accumulate. Assign housekeeping responsibilities during shift handovers to sweep warehouse aisles and remove floor debris. This reduces the probability of tire damage from sharp objects and eliminates a root cause of the near-miss event.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification and Audit System
description: Establish a two-person verification protocol requiring maintenance supervisors to inspect all LOTO procedures before equipment maintenance begins. Create a digital LOTO verification checklist requiring photographic evidence of energy isolation and equipment de-energization. Conduct monthly surprise audits of LOTO compliance across all production areas. Non-compliance results in mandatory retraining. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the root cause of Stéphane's incident by creating accountability and verification checkpoints.

name: Install Pressure-Sensitive Safety Interlocks on Composite Press Equipment
description: Retrofit all three high-pressure composite forming presses with dual-channel pressure-sensitive safety interlock systems that prevent press closure and cycle initiation when mold area is occupied. Install tactile pressure mats covering the maintenance access zone. These engineering controls eliminate the possibility of unexpected press actuation during maintenance by making physical interruption impossible. Expected outcome is complete elimination of crush injury risk during mold maintenance operations.

name: Revise Work Scheduling to Eliminate Time-Pressure Maintenance
description: Modify shift schedules to allocate dedicated maintenance windows at the beginning of each shift rather than end-of-shift, eliminating time pressure to complete procedures quickly. Ensure maintenance tasks are completed during normal working hours with supervisor oversight readily available. This administrative control removes a significant contributing factor (schedule pressure) that led to LOTO procedure circumvention.

name: Implement Secondary Containment System for Hazardous Waste
description: Install engineered secondary containment pallets with integrated spill trays beneath all hazardous waste storage drums in the exterior zone. Capacity must be at least 110% of the largest single container. Containment will include sloped surfaces for drainage to collection sumps with absorbent materials. All drums will be relocated onto these systems, with documentation of placement date and inspection schedule. This engineering control eliminates ground-level environmental contamination risk and prevents seepage into storm drains. Expected outcome: 100% compliance with environmental regulations and reduced worker exposure to chemical vapors from degraded containers.

name: Establish Weekly Hazardous Waste Storage Inspection Protocol
description: Create and implement a standardized weekly inspection checklist for all hazardous waste areas, including secondary containment integrity, proper WHMIS labeling verification, drum condition assessment, and documentation review. Inspections will be conducted every Monday at 08:00 by the Materials Management team with results logged in the HSE database. Any deficiencies trigger immediate corrective action. This administrative control ensures consistent monitoring and early detection of storage violations. Expected outcome: Zero instances of improperly stored hazardous waste and documented compliance with environmental regulations.

name: Implement Dual-Authentication LOTO Clearance System
