This administrative control reduces the probability of future tip-overs through improved operator awareness and technique.

name: Replace All Hydraulic and Lubrication Hoses on Aging Equipment
description: Conduct a facility-wide audit of all CNC machines and injection molding equipment to identify hydraulic hoses, coolant lines, and lubrication tubing exceeding 5-year service life. Replace all identified hoses proactively with new ones rated for current operating pressures and temperatures. Create a replacement schedule staggering hose changes across equipment to minimize production interruption. Implement material traceability documentation noting installation date and recommended replacement date for each hose. This engineering control eliminates the hose failure hazard that caused the spindle bearing damage.

name: Install Automated Lubrication System Monitoring
description: Retrofit all CNC milling machines with low-oil-level sensors that automatically trigger machine shutdown if oil pressure drops below safe thresholds. Integrate sensors with the facility's predictive maintenance software to generate alerts to maintenance staff 24 hours before anticipated oil reservoir depletion. Require operators to perform daily oil level visual checks as part of pre-shift equipment startup procedures, with documented logs submitted to maintenance supervisors. This engineering control prevents future spindle failures from inadequate lubrication by providing early warning and automatic protective shutdown.

name: Implement Daily Floor Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish mandatory daily inspections of warehouse floors with particular attention to drainage, puddle formation, and surface condition. Maintenance staff will conduct morning and mid-shift walkthroughs with documented checklists. Install additional floor drains in the warehouse to prevent water accumulation from cooling system operations. Post warning signs in wet areas and implement a wet floor marking procedure using high-visibility tape. Train all forklift operators on hydroplaning risks and reduced speed protocols during maintenance windows.

name: Upgrade Forklift Safety Features and Inspection Frequency
description: Increase pre-shift forklift inspection frequency from weekly to daily, with documented checklist verification. Install proximity warning systems on all forklifts to alert operators of tip-over risk zones. Implement enhanced operator training focusing on weight distribution, load securing, and emergency response procedures. Require operators to display current certification badges and schedule refresher training quarterly. Install traction-control upgrades on existing forklifts to improve stability on wet surfaces.

name: Establish Cooling System Leak Prevention and Management
description: Schedule comprehensive maintenance audit of all cooling systems to identify and repair leak sources. Install secondary containment trays under cooling system connection points. Implement a water management protocol requiring immediate cleanup of spills and improved drainage routing away from pedestrian and forklift traffic areas. Coordinate with maintenance to schedule system work during low-traffic periods and post warning signs during maintenance operations.

name: Compressed Air Safety Training and Equipment Protocol
description: Implement mandatory compressed air safety training for all equipment operators, emphasizing prohibited practices including directing air at body parts, using compressed air to clean clothing, or applying air pressure to open wounds. Install pressure-reducing regulators on all compressed air lines to limit pressure to maximum 30 psi for equipment cleaning operations. Provide compressed air safety posters at each workstation and conduct quarterly refresher training. Require operators to wear face shields and cut-resistant gloves when performing air-cleaning tasks. Distribute compressed air safety guides during next toolbox talk.

name: Implement Enhanced Pressure Relief and Lockout/Tagout Procedures
description: Revise all cooling system maintenance procedures to require full system depressurization through designated bleeder valves before any union disconnections. Install additional bleeder valve points on all cooling circuits to ensure complete pressure release. Implement mandatory LOTO procedures for all cooling system maintenance, requiring electrical isolation, mechanical lockout of pump breaker, and verification of zero pressure using gauges before work begins. Create laminated reference cards at each maintenance station showing correct depressurization sequence. Conduct mandatory training for all maintenance staff on revised procedures within 2 weeks.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Maintenance Operations
description: Issue all maintenance technicians with chemical-resistant aprons and face shields rated for liquid spray protection. Provide cut-resistant gloves with chemical resistance for maintenance work on pressurized systems. Install absorbent drip pans under all high-risk connection points on cooling systems to contain minor leaks. Position portable safety shower stations within 10 meters of all maintenance work areas. Conduct PPE fit-testing and provide training on proper usage. Establish a quarterly inspection schedule for all maintained equipment to identify potential leak sources before they develop.

name: Implement Secondary Container Containment System
description: Install spill containment trays beneath all chemical transfer points in the packaging station. These trays will have a capacity of at least 110% of the largest container used. Secondary containers will be labeled and inspected weekly by maintenance staff. This engineering control eliminates the risk of chemical spills spreading across work surfaces and prevents exposure to multiple employees.

name: Conduct Chemical Handling Refresher Training
description: Deliver mandatory 2-hour training module to all packaging and post-processing staff covering proper chemical container handling, spill response procedures, and eyewash station usage. Training will include hands-on demonstration of safe transfer techniques and emergency protocols. All participants will complete competency assessments. Training to be delivered within 14 days and repeated annually.

name: Install Equipment Cooldown Temperature Indicators
description: Mount digital temperature display gauges on all resin dryers and industrial ovens showing real-time internal and external temperatures. Install color-coded warning zones (red: unsafe to touch, yellow: caution). Technicians must wait until internal temperature drops below 60°C before performing maintenance. This engineering control prevents premature access to hot equipment and reduces thermal burn risks significantly.

name: Develop and Post Equipment Maintenance Checklists
description: Create laminated, color-coded maintenance checklists for each piece of heating equipment. Checklists will include mandatory cooling time requirements, temperature verification steps, PPE requirements, and hazard warnings. Post checklist at each equipment location and require operators to sign off on completion. Update procedures to mandate 4-hour minimum cooldown before hands-on maintenance. Train all operators on new procedures within 7 days.

name: Install Dual-Channel Safety System on All Injection Molding Machines
description: Replace single-channel proximity sensors with redundant dual-channel safety systems on all 32 injection molding machines. System will include hand detection sensors in die cavities, confirming removal before mold closure can commence. Any sensor malfunction will trigger machine lockout. Engineering firm will assess and implement within 45 days. This eliminates the hazard of unexpected mold closure during part removal operations.

name: Implement Mandatory Lockout/Tagout for Maintenance and Part Removal
description: Establish enhanced LOTO procedures requiring all molding operators to activate machine lockout during part removal cycles. Each operator receives a personal key; machine cannot cycle until all keys are removed. Supervisors will conduct weekly audits of LOTO compliance with documented sign-offs. Non-compliance will result in mandatory retraining. All staff must complete certification within 10 days.

name: Conduct Hydraulic System Full Diagnostic and Maintenance Program
description: Engage certified hydraulic technician to perform comprehensive diagnostic on all molding machine hydraulic systems. Replace worn pressure regulators and install redundant pressure relief valves to prevent surge events. Establish quarterly preventive maintenance schedule with documented inspections. Document all findings and corrective actions. Target completion within 30 days. This addresses the root cause—hydraulic malfunction—through engineering controls.

name: Mandatory Incident Investigation and Retraining Program
description: Conduct formal investigation with all Line D operators and supervisors to document failure sequence and identify system vulnerabilities. Develop case study for company-wide safety briefing. Require all 120 day-shift and 60 evening-shift production staff to attend 1-hour session reviewing incident, emergency response, and new safety protocols. Document attendance and competency assessments. Implement within 5 days of employee return to work.

name: Implement Quarterly Temperature Sensor Calibration Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring calibration of all mold temperature sensors on injection molding lines every 90 days. This addresses the root cause of the overheat condition. All calibration work will be performed by qualified maintenance technicians using certified calibration equipment. Documentation will be maintained in the CMMS system with alerts for upcoming calibrations. Expected outcome: elimination of temperature-related burn incidents from equipment malfunction.

name: Install Audible Temperature Alarm System on Line C
description: Install an audible and visual alarm system that activates when mold temperature exceeds 160°C (15°C safety margin below danger threshold). The alarm will alert operators to cease operations and allow them to investigate before burns occur. This engineering control provides automatic protection independent of human awareness. System installation includes sensor integration, alarm module, and operator training.

name: Complete Overhead Crane Inspection and Hook Replacement Program
description: Conduct comprehensive inspection of all overhead cranes in the facility using certified crane inspection services. Replace all lifting hooks and load-bearing components that show signs of corrosion, fatigue cracking, or stress damage. Install new hooks rated for 125% of maximum anticipated loads. This elimination of compromised equipment prevents recurrence. All cranes will be documented in a tracking system with inspection dates and replacement records.

name: Establish Monthly Crane and Rigging Equipment Maintenance Schedule
description: Implement a formal preventive maintenance program requiring monthly visual inspections of all crane hooks, chains, shackles, and rigging equipment. Inspections will be performed by trained personnel and documented in the maintenance management system. Any equipment showing wear, corrosion, or deformation will be removed from service immediately and replaced. This administrative control ensures regular monitoring and catches failures before they result in load drops.

name: Install Load Cell Monitoring System on Overhead Cranes
description: Install load cell sensors on primary overhead cranes to continuously monitor suspended load weight and stability. System will display real-time load data at operator stations and trigger automatic lowering if load exceeds safe parameters or if sudden shifts occur. This engineering control provides continuous monitoring and automatic load management independent of operator judgment.

name: Conduct Facility Layout Audit and Establish Clear Aisle Specifications
description: Perform comprehensive facility layout audit to ensure all material handling aisles meet or exceed manufacturer specifications for forklift maneuverability (minimum 3.2 meters for standard pallet trucks). Install floor-mounted yellow line markings delineating forklift lanes with 15cm clearance on each side of equipment. Create updated facility map showing approved forklift routes. Any future warehouse reorganization must be reviewed by Safety and Engineering before implementation to prevent aisle violations.

name: Install Impact-Resistant Pillar Guards and Remove Anchor Trip Points
description: Install high-visibility impact protection bumpers on all structural support pillars in material handling areas. Reconfigure or remove pillar anchor points that create trip hazards for forklift wheels. These engineering controls reduce equipment collision damage. Guards will be rated for typical forklift impact loads and installed per manufacturer specifications.

name: Implement Warehouse Reorganization Safety Protocol
description: Establish administrative procedure requiring HSE review and approval before any significant changes to warehouse layout or inventory storage arrangements. Protocol includes aisle width verification, trip hazard assessment, forklift route verification, and emergency exit accessibility review. Changes must be approved in writing by Health and Safety Coordinator before implementation. This prevents recurrence of layout changes that unknowingly create hazards.

name: Implement Monthly Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program specifically for all ventilation ducts, connections, and exhaust systems in production areas. Maintenance technicians will conduct monthly inspections using standardized checklists, testing all connections for tightness and integrity. Each system will be tagged with inspection dates and next service due dates. This engineering and administrative control will eliminate the root cause of loose connections that allowed fume leakage. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in ventilation-related chemical exposure incidents.

name: Upgrade Respiratory Protection Program with Mandatory Respirators for Resin Handling
description: Implement a mandatory respiratory protection program requiring all operators on Lines A, B, C, and D to wear NIOSH-certified half-mask respirators with organic vapor cartridges during resin processing operations. Conduct fit-testing for all affected employees within 14 days. Establish quarterly replacement schedules for cartridges and maintain an inventory of 50% excess capacity. This administrative control with PPE component will provide immediate protection during the preventive maintenance implementation period.

name: Install Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring System
description: Deploy continuous air quality monitoring sensors at six strategic locations in the production building (one per molding line area and two in material handling zones). Sensors will detect resin fumes, styrene vapors, and other volatile organic compounds (VOCs) with automatic alarm thresholds set at 50% of WHMIS exposure limits. Alarms will trigger both visual and auditory alerts, immediately notifying supervisors and initiating work area evacuation protocols. System data will be logged for regulatory reporting.

name: Install Safety Containment Barriers and Load Stops on All Mezzanine Storage Racks
description: Engineer and install physical safety barriers on the front edge of all mezzanine storage shelves, including chain restraint systems and rubber load stops. These barriers will prevent materials from sliding or falling off shelves during storage, retrieval, or accidental contact. All existing storage racks will be upgraded within 14 days. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source by physically preventing objects from becoming falling hazards. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in falling object incidents from mezzanine storage.

name: Implement Storage Rack Load Capacity Labeling and Weight Limit Enforcement Program
description: Conduct a comprehensive inventory and weight certification of all storage racks and shelving units. Install highly visible maximum weight capacity labels on each shelf in English and French, with warnings for exceeding limits. Implement a weekly audit protocol where supervisors physically verify compliance and document findings. Establish accountability measures for staff who exceed weight limits. Warehouse staff will receive training on load distribution principles and rack capacity calculations. This administrative control ensures sustained compliance with equipment specifications.

name: Install Real-Time Dust Collection System Monitoring with Automatic Alerts
description: Upgrade the dust collection system with IoT sensors that continuously monitor airflow, filter pressure differentials, and sensor functionality. Implement automated alert system that notifies both shift supervisors and HSE staff via email and SMS immediately upon system malfunction or deviation from baseline parameters. Establish automated daily logs that trigger incident reports if system downtime exceeds 2 hours. This engineering control ensures immediate detection and response to dust collection failures before combustible dust accumulates to hazardous levels.

name: Establish Daily Combustible Dust Inspection Protocol and Cleaning Schedule
description: Implement a mandatory daily inspection routine performed by Assembly and Finishing Department supervisors at the start of each shift. Supervisors will use standardized checklists to document dust levels in 12 designated critical areas, including oven surroundings, electrical panels, and material staging zones. Any dust accumulation exceeding 1/32 inch triggers immediate cleaning protocols using HEPA-filtered vacuum systems (no compressed air allowed per NFPA 484 standards). Inspections must be documented on a visible compliance board. All shift supervisors will receive training on combustible dust hazards within 5 days.

name: Upgrade Dust Collection Equipment Preventive Maintenance Schedule to Weekly Inspections
description: Transition from monthly to weekly preventive maintenance inspections for all dust collection system components, including filter assemblies, ductwork seals, sensor calibrations, and intake ports. Maintenance technician Gilles Marchand will conduct structured inspections every Monday and Thursday using a detailed technical checklist. Parts inventory will be maintained at 150% of normal consumption to enable same-day replacements. Documentation will be tracked in the maintenance management system with automatic alerts for recurring issues. This administrative control ensures the primary hazard elimination system remains operational continuously.

name: Implement Quarterly Storage Rack Inspections
description: Establish a formal quarterly inspection protocol for all industrial storage racks across the facility. Each inspection will include load capacity verification, structural integrity assessment, shelf level alignment checks, and bolt/fastener tightness verification. Inspections will be documented in a centralized log, and any racks exceeding 10 years of service will undergo detailed engineering review. A certified industrial engineer will conduct an initial comprehensive assessment of all 23 storage systems currently in use and provide load rating certifications for each unit.

name: Replace Deteriorated Storage Racks with Certified Systems
description: Identify and systematically replace all storage racks that have exceeded their manufacturer's recommended service life or show signs of structural degradation. All replacement racks will be accompanied by manufacturer documentation, load ratings, and maintenance schedules. New racks will include safety features such as reinforced shelving, locking mechanisms, and load limit indicators. Implementation will be prioritized by facility section to minimize operational disruption.

name: Provide Material Handling Safety Training
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all materials handlers and supervisors on proper load stacking techniques, weight distribution principles, and recognition of equipment degradation. Training will include case studies of previous storage rack failures and practical demonstrations of correct load placement. All materials handlers will be required to complete certification annually, with documentation maintained by the HR department.

name: Mandatory Daily Pre-Shift Safety Inspections for All Injection Molding Machines
description: Implement a comprehensive daily inspection protocol conducted before each shift begins. Operators will systematically check proximity sensors, emergency stop buttons, hydraulic pressure gauges, mold closing mechanisms, and safety interlocks on each machine. A standardized digital checklist will be completed and submitted to supervisors. Any machine showing equipment degradation will be immediately taken offline until repairs are verified by maintenance technicians. Training will be provided to all 45 production operators.

name: Install Dual-Redundant Safety Interlock Systems on All Injection Molding Machines
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with dual independent proximity sensor systems for mold safety interlocks. This engineering control eliminates single-point-of-failure risk. Each machine will have a secondary mechanical safety barrier and redundant electronic shutdown circuits. An independent safety systems integrator will design and implement the retrofit. This represents a top-tier engineering control that removes the hazard rather than merely warning of it.

name: Enforce Zero-Tolerance Incident Reporting Culture with Retraining
description: Establish administrative procedures requiring operators to immediately report any equipment abnormality (sounds, vibrations, pressure changes) to supervisors, with zero expectation to continue production. Reinforce through mandatory training that production quotas never override safety concerns. Monthly safety briefings will emphasize this principle. Supervisors will be held accountable for ensuring compliance. This administrative control addresses the root human factors that led to continued operation despite obvious warning signs.

name: Install Protective Shrouds on All Manual Fire Suppression Pull Handles
description: Install engineered protective shrouds around all 8 manual fire alarm pull stations throughout the facility, including the one in UNIT-010. These shrouds will provide physical barriers that prevent accidental activation while remaining accessible in true emergency situations. Clear signage will indicate the correct activation procedure. This engineering control directly prevents unintended discharge by making accidental activation mechanically impossible without deliberate action.

name: Redesign Chemical Storage Room Layout and Equipment Placement
description: Conduct a comprehensive assessment of UNIT-010 layout and relocate stored materials and equipment to create clear circulation pathways away from fire suppression system components. Install physical barriers or rearrange storage to ensure minimum 1.5-meter clearance around all safety system activators. This administrative/design control reduces the likelihood of accidental contact through improved workspace organization.

name: Implement Sensor Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program specifically for proximity sensors and motion detection systems on all 32 injection molding machines. This will include visual inspection of cable connections, testing of sensor responsiveness, and replacement of any worn connectors. Each maintenance cycle will be documented in the equipment log. This addresses the root cause of the erratic arm motion by ensuring early detection of sensor degradation before safety-critical failures occur.

name: Enhance Operator Situational Awareness Training
description: Develop and deliver a 2-hour training module to all production operators focusing on recognition of abnormal equipment behavior and proper response protocols. Training will include video case studies of equipment malfunctions, emergency stop procedures, and communication protocols when hazards are detected. All operators must complete this training and pass a competency assessment. This administrative control will improve early detection and reporting of equipment anomalies.

name: Install Grounding System for Resin Transfer Operations
description: Engineering control: Install permanent grounding rods and conductive hoses with alligator clamps at all resin transfer stations in the chemical mixing room. All 55-gallon drums and transfer equipment must be electrically bonded before any liquid transfer occurs. Grounding effectiveness will be tested monthly using a continuity meter. This eliminates the static electricity hazard by providing a controlled discharge pathway to ground, addressing the root cause of the flash fire.

name: Reorganize Chemical Storage Layout
description: Reconfigure the chemical storage room to maintain minimum 10-foot separation between resin storage containers and any combustible packaging materials. Install fire-rated storage cabinets for all cardboard boxes and plastic containers. Create dedicated transfer zones with non-flammable surfaces. This engineering control reduces fire propagation risk by isolating ignition sources from fuel sources.

name: Conduct Fire Safety and Hot Work Training
description: Administrative control: Implement mandatory annual fire safety training for all personnel working in chemical areas, including hazard recognition, proper fire extinguisher use, and evacuation procedures. Specific focus on static electricity risks and resin handling procedures. Training completion will be tracked and documented. Each employee must demonstrate competency through a written assessment.

name: Implement Load Securing Protocol for Pallet Jacks
description: Administrative control: Establish mandatory procedures for securing loads on pallet jacks using ratchet straps or pallet wrap before transport, particularly on mezzanine areas where falls create secondary hazards. All material handlers must complete a competency check demonstrating proper load securing techniques. Visual instructions will be posted at all pallet jack stations. This procedure prevents load shifts during transport.

name: Install Secondary Containment on Mezzanine
description: Engineering control: Install drip containment trays with minimum 5-gallon capacity under all stored hazardous material containers on the equipment storage mezzanine. Additionally, install polyurethane mesh safety netting between mezzanine grating sections to catch falling containers before they reach lower levels. This addresses the cascading hazard of upper-level spills affecting lower work areas.

name: Enhance Spill Response Training and Inventory
description: Administrative control: Conduct quarterly spill response drills involving all relevant personnel. Maintain an easily accessible spill kit on each floor containing absorbent materials, neutralizing agents for hydraulic fluid, and documentation forms. Train all employees on proper spill containment, reporting procedures, and environmental documentation requirements per CNESST and Quebec regulations. Conduct annual refresher training with competency assessment.

name: Implement Mandatory Chemical Container Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a pre-shift inspection checklist for all chemical storage drums that verifies proper sealing, bung integrity, and container condition. Assign responsibility to shift supervisors to conduct inspections before any transfer operations. Implement a color-coded tagging system: green for inspected containers, red for those requiring maintenance. Training will be provided to all personnel handling chemicals on proper sealing techniques and inspection procedures. This engineering and administrative control will reduce spill incidents by 80% through early detection of compromised containers.

name: Upgrade Spill Containment Infrastructure
description: Install permanent spill containment berms (120% drum capacity) under all chemical storage shelves in UNIT-010. Replace existing absorbent material with high-capacity enzyme-based neutralizers specifically designed for synthetic oils. Establish secondary containment stations at transfer points with quick-access spill kits visible and clearly labeled. Training will be mandatory for all personnel on new spill response procedures. This engineering control eliminates the risk of chemical spread to production areas and reduces environmental contamination.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Audit and Retraining
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all LOTO procedures across production lines, focusing on Injection Molding Line D. Implement a requirement that all personnel must complete recertification training within 14 days, with hands-on verification by the Electrical Maintenance Lead. Install permanent signage at each machine emphasizing that cleaning operations require full machine de-energization and LOTO application. Establish a peer-verification system where a second operator must confirm LOTO engagement before cleaning begins. This administrative control will ensure 100% compliance with lockout procedures and prevent recurrence of this high-risk incident.

name: Install Machine Guarding on Mold Cavity Access Points
description: Design and fabricate removable safety guards for mold cavity cleaning access points on all injection molding lines. These engineering controls will prevent direct hand contact with sharp plastic edges while maintaining operator visibility and ease of maintenance. Guards will be made from high-strength polycarbonate and include quick-release fasteners for rapid deployment/removal. Install secondary containment trays beneath cavities to catch overflow plastic debris, reducing the need for manual cleaning inside the mold area. This eliminates the primary hazard at the source.

name: Implement Non-Negotiable Hydraulic Depressurization Procedure
description: Establish a mandatory two-step verification system for all hydraulic maintenance operations: (1) technician performs depressurization via relief valve and documents time/date on a verification checklist; (2) a second qualified technician independently verifies zero pressure using a calibrated pressure gauge before work commences. This administrative control includes a policy that production delays do NOT override safety procedures—supervisors are explicitly authorized to extend timelines to maintain compliance. Signage will be posted at all hydraulic equipment stating 'DEPRESSURIZATION MANDATORY—NO EXCEPTIONS.' Monthly audits will verify 100% compliance.

name: Implement Mandatory Two-Person Verification Protocol for Manual Ejection
description: Establish a new procedure requiring two qualified operators to verify machine status and obtain mutual confirmation before any manual component ejection. One operator must physically position the safety interlock switch while the second operator performs visual inspection and confirms via radio communication that the mold is fully open and safe. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the risk of unexpected machine activation during manual operations. All operators on Injection Molding Line C will receive updated training within 5 days. Procedure will be laminated and posted at all workstations.

name: Install Proximity Sensors on Mold Clamp Zone
description: Engineering control: Install two safety-rated proximity sensors on the injection molding machine to detect human presence in the mold clamping zone. Sensors will prevent machine cycle activation if any object is detected within 150mm of the mold area for 2 seconds. This requires integration with the machine's PLC safety system and must be certified by equipment manufacturer. Installation will be completed by Central Maintenance Workshop staff in coordination with equipment supplier. Testing and validation required before machine return to service.

name: Mandatory Retraining on Machine Guarding and LOTO Procedures
description: All production operators working on injection molding equipment will complete 4-hour retraining session covering lockout/tagout procedures, hazard recognition, and proper communication protocols. Training will include simulation of the incident scenario and correct response procedures. Completion documentation must be signed off by supervisor and maintained in personnel files. A certified trainer from the HSE department will conduct sessions over 2 weeks for all shifts.

name: Install Permanent Oil Absorbent Mats in Maintenance Areas
description: Engineering control: Install 1.5m x 2m anti-slip, oil-absorbent matting in the forklift maintenance zone of the warehouse. Mats designed for fluid containment will be permanently fixed to the floor, eliminating the slipping hazard at its source. Secondary mats will be positioned strategically throughout the warehouse near fuel and fluid service areas. All staff will receive brief orientation on mat locations and proper use.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Container Closure System
description: Administrative and engineering control: All resin storage containers will be fitted with locking cap mechanisms that require two-stage activation to open, replacing standard threaded caps. This prevents accidental displacement during routine handling and transport. Maintenance staff will inventory all containers in the hazardous waste management area and upgrade closures within 7 days. Secondary containment trays will be placed under all containers to capture any leakage. Quarterly audits will verify proper closure engagement.

name: Implement Quarterly Ventilation System Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a comprehensive quarterly preventive maintenance program for all HVAC and ventilation systems serving the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room and adjacent production areas. This will include filter replacement, ductwork inspection, fan bearing lubrication, and airflow measurement verification. A maintenance log will be maintained and audited monthly by the HSE office. The program will prioritize early detection of system degradation before operational failures occur, ensuring continuous adequate ventilation and preventing solvent vapor accumulation.

name: Install Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring Sensors
description: Deploy continuous air quality monitors in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room and Production Line C that detect solvent vapor concentrations and temperature levels in real-time. Alarms will alert personnel when vapor concentrations exceed 50% of the OSHA PEL or temperatures exceed 26°C. Data logging will be integrated with the facility management system for trend analysis. This engineering control ensures early warning capability and provides objective documentation of exposure conditions for compliance and worker protection.

name: Conduct Refresher Training on Hazard Recognition and Reporting
description: Deliver targeted training to all production and maintenance staff emphasizing recognition of ventilation system failures, unusual odors, temperature changes, and the importance of immediate reporting. Training will include hands-on demonstration of air quality monitoring equipment and review of evacuation procedures. All personnel will complete the training within 30 days, with documentation maintained in employee records. This administrative control ensures workers can reliably detect and report early warning signs of inadequate ventilation.

name: Install Machine Interlock Guards on Trimmer Feed Hopper
description: Design and install mechanical interlock guards that prevent access to the reciprocating blade mechanism while the trimmer is energized. The hopper feed port will be fitted with a safety gate that automatically de-energizes the blade if opened during operation. Additionally, all operator access points will be re-evaluated and guarded to eliminate pinch points. This engineering control directly eliminates the hazard by making it physically impossible to contact moving parts during normal operation or jam-clearing activities.

name: Establish Lockout/Tagout Procedure for Jam Clearance
description: Develop and implement a formal LOTO procedure specifically for clearing jams in the trimming equipment. All operators must complete LOTO certification training and follow the procedure: de-energize equipment, apply lockout/tagout devices, attempt unjamming only after verification of isolation. A secondary verification step requires a supervisor to confirm proper lockout before work begins. Procedure cards will be posted at the equipment. This administrative control ensures equipment isolation before any maintenance or clearing activities occur.

name: Implement Moisture Control and Environmental Monitoring in Recycling Department
description: Install a desiccant dehumidification system in the Regrind and Recycling Department to maintain relative humidity below 40% and temperature below 24°C. Deploy continuous environmental monitoring sensors that log temperature and humidity hourly, with automatic alerts if parameters exceed safe ranges. All recycled pellet batches will be stored in sealed, labeled containers with desiccant packets. Environmental data will be reviewed weekly by the HSE office. This engineering control eliminates the moisture absorption condition that initiates thermal degradation of plastic materials.

name: Upgrade Ventilation and Cooling Capacity in Recycling Department
description: Evaluate and upgrade the HVAC system serving the Regrind and Recycling Department to provide enhanced air circulation and temperature control. Install additional exhaust fans and dampers to remove heat-generating operations and improve air exchange rates to 8-10 times per hour. Add make-up air capability to ensure proper pressurization. These upgrades will reduce localized hotspots and ensure ambient temperature remains within safe limits for plastic material storage and processing. Engineering design will be completed by external HVAC consultant within 15 days.

name: Enhance Fire Detection and Suppression System Testing Protocol
description: Establish a monthly functional test protocol for all fire detection sensors and automatic suppression systems in high-risk areas including the Recycling Department, Chemical Storage, and Maintenance Workshop. Tests will include sensor responsiveness verification, suppression agent pressure checks, and alarm system auditory and visual confirmation. A certified fire protection technician will conduct quarterly comprehensive inspections. All test results will be documented in a centralized log. This administrative control ensures detection and suppression systems remain operational and reliable for rapid incident response.

name: Implement Automated Hydraulic System Maintenance Schedule
description: Deploy computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) to track all hydraulic component service intervals for injection molding equipment. Configure automatic work order generation 2 weeks before each service due date for relief valves, pressure gauges, and fluid quality checks. Integrate with the facility's preventive maintenance calendar to ensure no inspections are missed due to staffing changes. Train maintenance staff on CMMS system and establish quarterly audits of maintenance completion rates. Expected outcome: 100% compliance with manufacturer-recommended service intervals and reduction of unplanned equipment failures by 60%.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic Relief Valve Monitoring with Pressure Sensors
description: Install real-time pressure monitoring sensors on hydraulic systems of all 32 injection molding machines. Configure automated alerts when system pressure deviates beyond normal operating parameters, indicating potential valve malfunction. Integrate sensors with production management system to automatically halt machines if critical pressure thresholds are exceeded. This engineering control eliminates the risk of undetected valve failures causing equipment damage or injury. Conduct operator training on interpreting pressure alerts and proper machine shutdown procedures.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Cross-Training Program
description: Create redundancy in maintenance scheduling by cross-training 4 additional technicians on hydraulic system inspections and relief valve servicing. Develop standardized maintenance checklists and procedures documentation. Establish a backup maintenance schedule so no single technician is solely responsible for critical inspections. Implement a mandatory sign-off system requiring both primary and secondary technicians to verify completion of hydraulic maintenance. This administrative control ensures maintenance activities continue uninterrupted during staffing shortages or vacations.

name: Install Temperature-Controlled Smart Oven System with Automatic Shutdown
description: Replace the manual post-curing oven with a modern industrial oven featuring integrated temperature controls, digital display, and automatic door locking when internal temperature exceeds 60°C. Implement tactile warning labels rated for high-temperature environments that remain visible for 5+ years. Install emergency cool-down venting system that safely reduces internal temperature to safe handling levels within 30 seconds of activation. Add remote-controlled component removal system to eliminate direct operator contact with heated items. This engineering control removes the primary hazard of thermal contact.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Upgrade and Certification
description: Replace all cotton work gloves in the Assembly Department with certified heat-resistant gloves rated for up to 250°C continuous contact. Gloves must meet CSA Z275.2 standards for thermal protection. Conduct formal fitting and training session for all assembly operators, emphasizing proper donning, fit verification, and heat hazard awareness. Distribute replacement gloves every 6 months or upon visible damage. Create visual workplace signage indicating required heat-resistant PPE for all oven-adjacent work areas. Stock additional certified gloves at the oven workstation.

name: Comprehensive Thermal Hazard Training and Standard Work Procedures
description: Develop formal training module on thermal burn hazards specific to post-curing ovens and hot material handling. Include topics: equipment temperature awareness, proper component removal techniques, emergency response procedures, and proper use of heat-resistant PPE. Require annual recertification for all operators working with high-temperature materials. Create laminated quick-reference cards with step-by-step component removal procedures posted at each oven station. Implement peer observation program where experienced operators verify newer employees follow correct procedures during first 10 shifts.

name: Implement Equipment Guard Reinstallation Verification System
description: Create a mandatory equipment work order closeout procedure requiring maintenance technicians to physically reinstall all safety guards and covers before marking maintenance tasks as complete. Establish a second-party verification requirement where a supervisor must inspect and sign off that all guards are properly secured. For removed guards, generate a red-tagged 'Guard Removed' alert that remains active in the work order system until verified as reinstalled. Conduct weekly audits of all production equipment to verify guard integrity. This administrative control ensures temporary safety guard removals do not become permanent gaps.

name: Install Additional Machine Guarding and Emergency Stop Stations
description: Upgrade the extruder equipment with supplemental mesh safety guards on all rotating feed screw access points, creating a secondary physical barrier. Install additional large emergency stop buttons (mushroom style, 60mm diameter) on both sides of the regrind equipment at operator elbow height for quick accessibility. Ensure guards meet CSA Z432 standards for machinery safety. This engineering control provides dual protection against accidental contact with rotating equipment.

name: Implement Mandatory Job Rotation Schedule
description: Establish a formal job rotation program requiring operators to alternate between injection molding, part trimming, and assembly tasks every 2 hours. This will reduce repetitive strain by varying muscle groups and movements used throughout the shift. All supervisors on all shifts will be trained to enforce rotations. A digital tracking system will monitor compliance and ensure no operator performs the same task for more than 2 consecutive hours.

name: Provide Ergonomic Assessment and Microbreak Protocol
description: Conduct a comprehensive ergonomic assessment of all injection molding workstations with a certified ergonomist. Install micro-break reminders (visual/audio alerts every 30 minutes) requiring 2-minute stretching breaks. Distribute ergonomic microbreak guides to all line operators and post them at each station. This addresses root cause of inadequate rest periods and poor workstation design contributing to repetitive strain injuries.

name: Install Load Capacity Labels and Weight Limit Signs
description: Install permanent load capacity placards on all warehouse storage racks indicating maximum weight per shelf level and total stack height limits. Conduct inventory of all existing racks to verify structural integrity and update labeling accordingly. Install visual warning signs at eye level on high-risk racks warning of potential falling object hazards. These engineering controls will prevent future overload incidents and clearly communicate safe loading practices to all warehouse personnel across all shifts.

name: Implement Mandatory Rack Loading Audit and Training Program
description: Establish a daily pre-shift audit checklist for warehouse supervisors to verify proper load distribution, stack height compliance, and rack structural integrity. Require all shipping and warehouse staff to complete annual training on proper stacking techniques, weight distribution principles, and rack safety protocols. Supervisors will sign off on compliance daily. This administrative control will ensure consistent adherence to safe loading practices and prevent recurrence of load shifting incidents.

name: Install Safety Barriers and Height-Restricted Access Zones
description: Install physical safety barriers around high-risk storage racks preventing personnel from standing directly beneath unstable load zones. Establish restricted access zones with floor markings and signage identifying areas where standing or working beneath elevated materials is prohibited. Implement camera monitoring in the warehouse to ensure compliance with restricted zones. These engineering and administrative controls will eliminate the hazard of falling material striking personnel.

name: Chemical Container Secure Closure Verification Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory pre-transfer checklist requiring all chemical container caps to be hand-tightened and visually verified as secure before any lifting or movement. Train all material handlers on the 'twist-and-click' verification method. Place laminated checklist posters at all chemical transfer stations in UNIT-010. Conduct monthly audits by the HSE team to verify compliance. This addresses the root cause of improper container sealing by creating a systematic verification step that prevents recurrence.

name: Enhanced Chemical Handling Training Refresher
description: Conduct mandatory 1-hour refresher training for all personnel handling chemicals in UNIT-010, focusing on proper container handling, secondary containment practices, and eyewash station usage. Include competency verification through a practical demonstration. Schedule training within 2 weeks for all existing staff and integrate into new hire orientation. Training will be led by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid with oversight from Safety Officer Anh Nguyen.

name: Mandatory LOTO Audit and Retraining Program
description: Immediate comprehensive audit of all LOTO procedures at Injection Molding Lines A, B, C, and D. Mandatory retraining for all 32 technicians and operators on proper lockout/tagout procedures with certified LOTO trainer. Each technician must perform supervised LOTO procedures on their assigned equipment before resuming independent work. Implement new verification checklist requiring: (1) machine power isolation, (2) individual padlocks from each technician, (3) energy dissipation wait time (5 minutes minimum), (4) supervisor sign-off before work begins. Monthly audits by HSE team to verify compliance.

name: Install Dual-Operator Activation System on Line D
description: Engineering control: Install a two-hand control interlock system on Injection Molding Line D that requires simultaneous activation from two separate operator stations to prevent accidental startup during maintenance. This redundant activation system eliminates the possibility of single-operator error triggering machine movement during service. Implementation includes new control panel installation, wiring, and integration with existing safety circuit. Testing and validation by maintenance engineering team required before resumption of maintenance operations.

name: LOTO Compliance Signage and Work Station Labels
description: Install permanent laminated LOTO procedure posters at each injection molding machine showing step-by-step lockout sequence with visual warnings of crushing hazards. Add color-coded padlock stations at each line with clearly labeled 'DO NOT OPERATE' placards when locks are engaged. Implement daily morning safety briefing (5 minutes) at production start-up covering LOTO requirements, with attendance logged by shift supervisor.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Cooling Systems
description: Deploy automated monitoring system on all cooling water circuits with pressure and temperature sensors connected to maintenance management software. System will alert maintenance team when parameters deviate from baseline by 10%, enabling early intervention before failures occur. Establish quarterly water quality testing (pH, conductivity, corrosion inhibitor levels) to prevent internal degradation. Establish 6-month inspection intervals for all manual ball valves with mandatory replacement every 3 years regardless of condition to prevent valve stem corrosion. Integrate monitoring data into the existing predictive maintenance platform to coordinate scheduling across all post-processing equipment.

name: Enhanced Cooling System Redundancy and Isolation
description: Install secondary backup cooling pump unit with automatic switchover capability to maintain continuity of service if primary pump fails. Add quick-disconnect couplings with integrated check valves at key junction points to isolate failed sections without complete system shutdown. Install isolation ball valves upstream of all critical equipment connections. These engineering controls eliminate the single-point-of-failure risk that caused the 18-hour production shutdown and reduce potential for catastrophic water spray incidents.

name: Maintenance Staff Training on Corrosion Prevention and System Diagnostics
description: Conduct 4-hour specialized training for all maintenance technicians on cooling system operation, corrosion identification, and preventive maintenance procedures. Training will include hands-on inspection techniques, water treatment chemical protocols, and proper valve manipulation to prevent stem damage. Attendees will learn visual indicators of imminent failure such as mineral deposits, discoloration, and pressure fluctuations. Competency verification through practical demonstration required. Post-training competency testing quarterly to maintain knowledge currency.

name: Implement Cut-Resistant Glove Protocol for QC Lab
description: Establish mandatory use of ANSI A3-rated cut-resistant gloves for all personnel handling fractured or machined plastic and composite specimens in the Quality Control Laboratory. Add glove dispensers at each inspection workstation and include glove selection in the QC orientation training. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of the laceration by providing appropriate PPE for the specific hazard. Expected outcome: elimination of sharp-edge cuts during specimen handling while maintaining inspection accuracy.

name: Install Edge-Breaking Station in QC Lab
description: Establish a dedicated edge-conditioning workstation equipped with fine abrasive paper and fixtures for post-test specimen handling. All fractured test specimens will be processed through this station before quality release or handling by inspectors. This engineering control eliminates sharp burrs at the source. Training will be provided to quality technicians on proper edge conditioning procedures. Expected outcome: significant reduction in sharp-edge hazards during specimen inspection and handling operations.

name: Upgrade Resin Dryer Temperature Monitoring System
description: Replace the aging analog thermostat and single temperature probe with a redundant digital monitoring system featuring dual sensors, real-time data logging, and automated alert notifications. The new system will include fail-safe design that prevents over-temperature conditions and maintains historical temperature records for trending analysis. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause by eliminating single-point sensor failures. The system will integrate with the facility's CMMS for automatic maintenance scheduling based on probe age and performance metrics.

name: Implement Quarterly Temperature Probe Replacement Schedule
description: Establish and enforce a mandatory quarterly replacement protocol for all temperature probes in resin processing equipment, regardless of apparent functionality. Create a tracking system with work orders automatically generated 10 days before replacement due dates. Procedures will specify probe removal, calibration verification, and documentation requirements. This administrative control ensures preventive maintenance occurs consistently. Include visual inspection of probe corrosion patterns to identify environmental factors contributing to degradation.

name: Install Load Restraint Systems on High Storage Racks
description: Retrofit all warehouse storage racks exceeding 3 meters height with secondary load restraint systems including chain binders, straps, and catch trays. Install physical stops at each storage level to prevent pallet over-travel. This engineering control provides redundant protection against load collapse from equipment failure. All existing pallets will be evaluated for stability; unstable loads will be relocated to lower storage levels. Install warning signage at base of high-storage areas indicating load-carrying equipment restrictions.

name: Implement Mandatory Annual Hydraulic System Certification
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program requiring annual inspection, pressure testing, and certification of all forklift hydraulic cylinders by certified technicians. Create a digital asset management system tracking each forklift's maintenance history. Machines failing inspection must be immediately removed from service until repairs are completed. This administrative control ensures equipment reliability through structured preventive maintenance. Partner with equipment manufacturer to access technical service bulletins and recommended maintenance intervals for all 24 forklifts in operation.

name: Restrict High-Reach Operations and Operator Certification
description: Limit forklift operations above 3.5 meters to operators holding advanced certification in high-reach equipment operation. Require written certification exam, on-site training with a supervisor, and annual recertification. Implement geofencing in the warehouse management system to alert when forklifts enter high-reach storage zones, ensuring only certified operators are active. This administrative control reduces hazard exposure through operator competency requirements and environmental controls. All 12 current forklift operators will receive training within 30 days.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring System with Automatic Shutdown
description: Implement a real-time digital temperature monitoring system on all injection molding machines with automatic equipment shutdown if hopper temperature exceeds safe operating parameters by 10°C. This engineering control eliminates the risk of residual material overheating. The system will include audible and visual alarms to alert operators to temperature anomalies before they escalate. Integration with the predictive maintenance program will flag sensors requiring calibration before failure occurs.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE Protocol for Hopper Operations
description: Establish mandatory use of heat-resistant gloves (rated to 300°C) and forearm guards for all personnel performing hopper loading operations. Update the WHMIS training and operator certification to include proper PPE donning procedures and inspection protocols. All gloves will be stored in accessible locations at each molding station with monthly replacement schedules documented.

name: Enhanced Temperature Sensor Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a monthly calibration and inspection protocol for all hopper temperature sensors in the Central Maintenance Workshop. Create a preventive maintenance checklist and tracking log to ensure sensors are tested against a known standard. Implement a sensor replacement policy that requires replacement every 18 months regardless of apparent function.

name: Install Vibration Monitoring and Automated Pump Shutdown
description: Install vibration sensors on the composite resin pump motor with real-time monitoring that automatically triggers equipment shutdown when vibration exceeds 4.5 mm/s. This engineering control prevents impeller imbalance issues from causing component failure. The system will log vibration data for predictive maintenance trending and alert maintenance staff when motor balancing is required.

name: Quarterly Pump Motor Balance and Coupling Inspection Program
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly inspection schedule for all composite material transfer pump motors in the Central Maintenance Workshop. Each inspection will include motor balance verification using laser alignment tools, coupling integrity assessment, and wear analysis. Any motor found to be out of balance by more than 0.05 inches will be removed from service immediately for dynamic balancing.

name: Install Load-Securing Systems and Anti-Tip Devices
description: Install heavy-duty load-securing straps and anti-tip devices on all mezzanine shelving units in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room. Each shelf containing metal mold plates will be equipped with adjustable tie-down straps rated for 500 kg minimum. Implement a maximum stack height policy of 1.2 meters for heavy components. All personnel handling mezzanine inventory will complete load securing certification training within 30 days.

name: Emergency Exit Clearance Protocol and Enforcement
description: Clear all materials blocking the emergency exit on the mezzanine level immediately and establish a permanent 1.5-meter clearance zone marked with yellow safety tape. Implement a weekly inspection checklist that HSE staff will verify. No equipment or inventory will be permitted within the marked clearance zone under any circumstances. Update facility maps to reflect clear emergency exit routes and post signage at all mezzanine access points.

name: Reinstall Mezzanine Guardrails and Conduct Structural Load Assessment
description: Immediately reinstall guardrails on the mezzanine section where barriers were removed during maintenance. Conduct a complete structural load assessment by a professional engineer to verify that current inventory storage levels do not exceed the design capacity of the mezzanine platform. If capacity has been exceeded, implement inventory reduction protocols. Guardrails will be inspected monthly to ensure integrity.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring System with Automatic Shutdown
description: Replace existing analog temperature indicators on all injection molding machines with calibrated digital sensors connected to programmable logic controllers (PLCs). Implement automatic machine shutdown if mold surface temperature exceeds safe handling limits (below 60°C). Conduct quarterly calibration audits and maintenance to ensure sensor accuracy. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of relying on faulty analog indicators by providing real-time, accurate temperature monitoring with fail-safe mechanisms.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Protocol for Part Removal
description: Establish administrative control requiring all assembly operators to wear certified heat-resistant gloves (minimum rating 200°C) when removing parts within 30 minutes of machine cycle completion. Provide training during orientation and quarterly refresher sessions. Gloves will be inspected monthly and replaced immediately if damaged. This PPE-based control provides secondary protection while primary engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Implement Automated Hydraulic Fluid Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a computerized preventive maintenance program with automated work orders for hydraulic fluid analysis and replacement every 12 months on all injection presses and hydraulic equipment. Integrate with facility CMMS (Computerized Maintenance Management System) to track fluid samples, component inspections, and maintenance history. Conduct quarterly audits to verify compliance. This administrative control ensures systematic adherence to manufacturer specifications and prevents premature equipment failures caused by fluid degradation.

name: Upgrade to High-Grade Hydraulic Fluid Filtration
description: Replace existing standard filtration system with a dual-stage high-efficiency filtration unit capable of removing particles down to 3 microns. Upgrade hydraulic fluid grade to ISO VG 46 with advanced anti-corrosion and anti-oxidation additives formulated for extended service intervals. Install fluid condition monitoring sensors to alert maintenance team of contamination levels before critical failure. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of internal corrosion and extends equipment lifespan.

name: Install Automated Hydraulic Leak Detection and Containment System
description: Deploy sensor-based hydraulic leak detection system beneath all equipment with pressurized hydraulic systems in the warehouse. When leaks are detected, automated gate valves restrict fluid flow and activate collection trays with absorbent material. Integrate alerts to maintenance team via mobile notifications. Additionally, install permanent secondary containment trays beneath all presses capable of holding 110% of maximum fluid volume. This engineering control eliminates the hazard source by preventing fluid accumulation on walkways.

name: Implement Quarterly Electrical Equipment Inspection Program
description: Establish a comprehensive quarterly inspection schedule for all electrical control panels and equipment in chemical storage areas. Each inspection will include thermal imaging to detect overheating components, megohm testing of insulation resistance, and verification of circuit breaker functionality. Documentation will be maintained and reviewed by the maintenance team. This engineering/administrative control directly addresses the root cause of arcing in the control panel and will reduce the risk of electrical fires by 75% based on industry data.

name: Enhanced Fire Detection Calibration and Testing
description: Conduct immediate calibration and sensitivity testing of all smoke detectors in chemical storage and mixing areas per NFPA 72 standards. Increase testing frequency from annually to semi-annually. Install additional heat detectors in high-risk zones near electrical equipment. Train all relevant personnel on proper detector maintenance and provide quick-response guides at each detector location. This ensures the warning system remains optimally effective.

name: Implement Container Cap Inspection and Torque Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory container cap inspection procedure requiring all chemical containers to be visually inspected and caps torqued to manufacturer specifications before transport. Create a checklist that handlers must complete and sign off on. Provide calibrated torque wrenches at storage locations and establish monthly calibration verification. Train all material handlers on proper threading techniques and cap installation. This administrative and engineering control eliminates the root cause of improper cap closure and prevents future spills.

name: Upgrade to Secondary Containment Trays for Chemical Transport
description: Procure and implement drip containment trays with 150% capacity of the largest containers being transported. Place tray stations at chemical storage exits and high-traffic production areas. Require all chemical containers to be transported on these trays. The trays will catch minor spills before they reach production areas and the environment. This engineering control provides a secondary barrier that significantly reduces spill volume and environmental impact.

name: Enhanced Chemical Spill Response Training and Drills
description: Conduct quarterly chemical spill response training for all production and warehouse personnel. Include identification of chemical hazards, proper use of absorbent materials, emergency ventilation activation procedures, and personal protection requirements. Conduct semi-annual tabletop drills simulating spills of different magnitudes. Maintain response equipment carts at key locations with updated inventories. This administrative control ensures personnel can respond quickly and safely to minimize impact.

name: Install Workpiece Vise Guards with Deburring Protection
description: Procure and install fixed edge guards and protective caps for all workpiece vises in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. Implement soft-jaw vise inserts to reduce sharp edges during clamping. Install clear polycarbonate shields around high-traffic deburring stations to prevent hand contact with sharp workpiece edges. These engineering controls provide physical barriers between operators and sharp edges, reducing laceration risk by 85%.

name: Mandatory Cut-Resistant Glove Requirement for Deburring Tasks
description: Implement a requirement for operators to wear ANSI A4 or higher cut-resistant gloves during all deburring, filing, and sharp-edge handling operations. Provide HPPE to all affected workers and maintain inventory for rotation. Include glove inspection procedures in daily safety briefings. Conduct monthly audits to ensure compliance. Update SOPs to explicitly reference PPE requirements. While PPE is a lower-priority control, when combined with engineering controls, it provides crucial personal protection.

name: Standardized Deburring Procedure and Tool Guidance System
description: Develop detailed Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for safe deburring operations including proper workpiece positioning, file handling techniques, and required guards. Create color-coded tool guides that enforce consistent technique and prevent hand intrusion into danger zones. Laminate SOP cards and mount them at each deburring station. Conduct toolbox talks on deburring safety for all machinists. This administrative control ensures consistent safe practices across all operators and shifts.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Protocol
description: Establish a formal shift handover checklist requiring the outgoing supervisor to physically verify and document that all machines are in LOTO status before leaving their shift. The incoming supervisor must countersign this verification. Install visual LOTO status indicators at each machine (red/green flags). Conduct monthly audits of LOTO compliance. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of incomplete energy isolation due to communication breakdown between shifts.

name: Upgrade Machine Guarding on Injection Molding Equipment
description: Install interlocked safety gates on the mold area of all 32 injection molding machines that prevent ram operation when gates are open. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of unexpected machine startup while operators have hands in the work area. Priority implementation on machines #15-#20 which have the highest operator interaction frequency. Include pressure relief valve upgrades to reduce ram closing force.

name: Enhanced Operator PPE and Training Program
description: Provide all operators with cut-resistant gloves (level 4) and heat-resistant sleeves specifically rated for injection molding operations. Conduct mandatory retraining on machine-specific hazards, LOTO procedures, and emergency response. Include competency testing and require annual refresher courses. Emphasize hand positioning best practices to minimize entrapment risk.

name: Dock Floor Maintenance and Anti-Slip Treatment
description: Immediately establish daily dock cleaning schedule with removal of all spilled liquids and debris. Apply non-slip coating to dock floor surfaces in high-traffic areas where forklifts operate. Install drain system to route cleaning water away from operational zones. Place warning signs and cones around wet areas. Assign dedicated personnel to monitor and maintain floor conditions during shifts. This eliminates the slippery surface hazard that contributed to loss of traction.

name: Forklift Operation Safety Training and Load Stability Review
description: Conduct comprehensive retraining for all forklift operators on load balancing, turning techniques on wet surfaces, and speed reduction in hazardous conditions. Implement quarterly competency certifications. Require all operators to perform pre-operation equipment checks including tire condition and hydraulic system integrity. Establish maximum load weight limits for dock operations and mandate use of load stabilization straps for multi-pallet loads.

name: Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Implement monthly inspections of all hydraulic systems across material handling equipment by qualified technicians. Maintain detailed maintenance logs and schedule repairs before leaks occur. Stock adequate spill containment materials and absorbent kits at strategic locations. Train all staff on hydraulic fluid spill response procedures and environmental safety. This eliminates future hydraulic leak incidents that create slip hazards.

name: Cooling Water System Complete Replacement and Upgrade
description: Replace all copper tubing in the cooling water system with stainless steel tubing rated for high-temperature service and resistant to corrosion. Implement a closed-loop cooling system with automated pressure monitoring and automatic shutoff valves that activate if pressure exceeds safe limits. Install secondary containment trays under all high-pressure connections. This engineering control eliminates the rupture hazard entirely through material substitution and system redesign.

name: Mandatory Thermal Protective Equipment for Maintenance Personnel
description: Require all technicians working on hot water/steam systems to wear aluminized proximity suits, heat-resistant gloves rated to 200°C, and full-face protective shields. Maintain inventory of protective equipment in maintenance workshop and enforce 100% compliance through daily safety briefings. Conduct quarterly fit and functionality testing. This PPE control provides immediate protection while engineering improvements are implemented.

name: Preventive Maintenance Schedule and Corrosion Monitoring Program
description: Establish quarterly inspections of all cooling system tubing with non-destructive testing (ultrasonic thickness measurement) to detect corrosion before rupture. Replace tubing sections showing greater than 10% wall thickness loss. Document all findings in computerized maintenance management system with automatic alerts for high-priority replacements. Implement water treatment program to control pH and inhibit corrosion. This administrative control ensures early detection and replacement before catastrophic failure.

name: Implement Mold Cooling System Temperature Monitoring
description: Install automated temperature sensors on all injection molding machines with real-time alerts if surface temperatures exceed safe limits (55°C). Integrate monitoring into the SCADA system to create automatic shutdown protocols. Establish daily calibration verification procedures for temperature readings. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the thermal drift and provides early warning before worker exposure occurs. Expected outcome: elimination of temperature-related thermal burns within 60 days.

name: Enhanced Equipment Inspection Checklist for Cooling Systems
description: Revise the morning equipment check procedure to include specific cooling system performance validation for all molding machines. Add thermal imaging camera inspection to detect anomalies before operation. Train all machine setters on recognizing cooling system degradation. This administrative control ensures systematic detection of equipment faults. Expected outcome: catch 95% of cooling system issues before they cause worker incidents.

name: Redesign Material Handling Workspace Layout
description: Engineer physical separation between the hopper feeding station and the cart loading area by installing protective barriers and designated traffic lanes. Install floor markings for safe work zones and create one-way material flow paths. This elimination/substitution control removes the hazard of simultaneous conflicting operations. Expected outcome: zero overlap incidents in material handling operations.

name: Material Handler Communication and Coordination Protocol
description: Develop and implement a mandatory two-way communication system requiring handlers to announce their position and intended movement before any bag transfer operation. Implement a flag-and-signal system visible throughout the warehouse. Conduct mandatory training for all material handlers on the new protocol. This administrative control ensures awareness and coordination. Expected outcome: 100% compliance within 2 weeks; ongoing monthly audits.

name: Enhanced Hand and Arm PPE Requirements
description: Upgrade material handler PPE to include reinforced cut-resistant gloves (ANSI level 4) and wrist protection sleeves for all bag handling operations. Supply compression hand wraps for additional crush injury protection. Ensure proper fit and training on correct donning procedures. This PPE control provides secondary protection while engineering controls are being implemented. Expected outcome: reduce severity of hand injuries by up to 60%.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooling Cycle Lock-Out Protocol
description: Establish a formal lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure for all mold temperature override operations. Any manual override of automatic cooling cycles requires documented supervisor approval, written justification, and mandatory reset confirmation before production resumes. Engineering will install a mechanical lock on the timer override switch that can only be released by HSE personnel. Shift supervisors must verify timer reset status during each shift handoff and document in the production log. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of forgotten overrides remaining active during subsequent production runs.

name: Enhanced Thermal Hazard Training for All Operators
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training on thermal burn prevention specifically for injection molding operations. Training will cover mold temperature monitoring, recognition of cooling cycle status, safe techniques for parts removal, and required PPE (thermal gloves, sleeve protection). All production operators on Lines A, B, and C must complete the training within 14 days. Refresher training will be conducted quarterly. Include case study analysis of this incident to reinforce hazard awareness. Documentation of training completion will be maintained in employee files.

name: Install Temperature Display and Alert System
description: Install real-time digital temperature monitoring displays visible to operators at each injection molding line. System will display current mold temperature and alert operators when mold surface temperature exceeds safe-touch threshold (120°C). Audible and visual warnings will activate if automatic cooling cycle is disabled. Integrate with existing production management system to log all temperature override events with timestamp and operator ID for audit trail. This engineering control provides continuous hazard visibility.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Pressure Relief Valves
description: Implement a computerized preventive maintenance (PM) system that schedules and tracks relief valve inspections every 6 months for all bulk storage hoppers. Maintenance Supervisor will review equipment historical records to identify all overdue inspections and prioritize immediate compliance. All relief valves must be certified functional within 10 days of incident. Future inspections will be documented with valve pressure rating confirmation, visual condition assessment, and replacement intervals. System will generate alerts 2 weeks prior to due date to prevent lapses. This administrative control ensures systematic hazard mitigation.

name: Upgrade Hopper Transfer Station with Safety Barriers
description: Install engineering barriers around the hopper transfer station in UNIT-010 including clear polycarbonate shields to contain any pellet discharge from malfunctioning relief valves. Shields will be positioned to protect operators while maintaining visibility and workflow. Additionally, install an emergency stop button within arm's reach of the transfer point that shuts down the bulk storage hopper feed system. Redesign the hopper mounting to allow for safer positioning that minimizes operator exposure when flow gates are opened.

name: Revise Warehouse Cleaning Schedule and Implement Slip Prevention
description: Reschedule warehouse cleaning operations to occur during low-activity periods (late evening after shift end, early morning before day shift start) with a minimum 2-hour buffer before peak inventory operations. Install high-friction anti-slip coatings on all warehouse floor areas, prioritizing zones around storage racks and high-traffic pathways. Implement wet floor signage and barrier systems that remain in place during and immediately after cleaning (minimum 1 hour drying time). Establish a floor dryness verification checklist that must be completed before warehouse operations resume each shift. This combination of engineering and administrative controls eliminates slip hazards.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
