description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program with quarterly inspections of all hydraulic pressure relief valves on the 32 injection molding machines. Create a digital tracking system with automated alerts for maintenance due dates. Maintenance Technicians will perform visual inspections, pressure testing, and valve replacement according to manufacturer specifications. This addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance intervals and ensures equipment reliability. Expected outcome: elimination of pressure release incidents caused by valve degradation and extension of equipment operational life.

name: Install Pressure Relief Valve Guards and Deflection Shields
description: Install protective steel mesh guards and deflection shields around all hydraulic pressure points on injection molding machines to redirect any unintended fluid spray away from operators. Guards will be mounted at a safe distance to allow maintenance access while protecting personnel from direct contact. This engineering control provides a secondary barrier to protect operators during unexpected pressure releases. Expected outcome: significant reduction in thermal burn injuries from pressurized fluid contact.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE Training and Upgrade
description: Conduct mandatory training for all production operators on proper selection and use of heat-resistant protective equipment including flame-resistant sleeves, protective aprons, and heat-resistant gloves rated for 300°C+ exposure. Upgrade existing PPE inventory to include Kevlar-reinforced sleeves and aluminized heat-protective clothing. Establish requirement that operators working near heated injection points must wear full heat-resistant ensemble. Training will emphasize inspection of PPE before each shift and replacement of damaged equipment.

name: Redesign Warehouse Layout with Clear Aisle Marking
description: Implement comprehensive warehouse reorganization with permanent floor markings for forklift travel aisles using high-visibility yellow and black striping. Establish one-way traffic patterns and reduce storage heights in high-traffic zones. Install reflective edge guards on all support columns and remove or relocate protruding bolts. Install mirrors at blind intersections to improve sightlines. This engineering control eliminates congestion-related hazards by creating dedicated, clearly marked safe pathways. Expected outcome: 85% reduction in forklift collision incidents and improved inventory damage prevention.

name: Implement Forklift Operating Speed Limits and Electronic Monitoring
description: Install speed-limiting governors on all forklifts restricting maximum speed to 8 km/h in warehouse areas. Deploy telematics monitoring systems to track forklift movements, speeds, and harsh maneuvers in real-time, with automated alerts for violations. Establish a performance dashboard accessible to supervisors. Operators exceeding speed limits will receive retraining. This administrative control combined with technology ensures compliance with safe operating practices. Expected outcome: prevention of high-speed collisions and associated property damage.

name: Implement Automated Deburring and Edge Finishing Process
description: Install automated deburring equipment in the post-molding production line to eliminate manual edge finishing work. All parts will pass through vibratory deburring or thermal deburring systems to remove sharp edges, flash, and burrs before quality control inspection. Establish 100% inspection checkpoints with tactile and visual verification of edge quality. This engineering control eliminates the hazard source by automating the deburring process and ensuring no sharp edges reach QC personnel. Expected outcome: elimination of laceration injuries from sharp part edges.

name: Enhance Cut-Resistant PPE Requirements for QC Personnel
description: Require all Quality Control and Inspection personnel to wear ANSI A4 cut-resistant gloves (rated for sharp edges and glass) during part handling and inspection activities. Conduct training on proper glove selection, fit, and inspection procedures. Establish glove replacement schedule with monthly inventory audits. While PPE is a secondary control, cut-resistant gloves will provide protection during the transition to automated deburring. Expected outcome: reduction in severity of laceration injuries if sharp edges are encountered.

name: Implement Pallet Load Securing Protocol
description: Develop and deploy mandatory pallet securing procedures requiring all material handlers to use stretch wrap, straps, or edge protectors when stacking bags over 5 feet high. Provide training to all warehouse staff on proper load balancing and securing techniques. Create visual work instructions at key material handling stations. Expected outcome: reduce material spillage incidents by 85% and prevent drainage contamination.

name: Upgrade Dock Drainage System Filtration
description: Install secondary filtration screens and collection traps in the loading dock drainage system to prevent plastic granules from entering the main wastewater line. Include quarterly maintenance schedule and documentation. This engineering control directly addresses environmental contamination risk from material spills.

name: Replace Chemical Storage Tank with Redundant Safety System
description: Procure and install a new 200-liter acetone storage tank with integrated secondary containment, double-wall construction, and automatic leak detection sensors. The new system will include pressure relief valves, corrosion-resistant fittings rated for acetone compatibility, and built-in tertiary drain collection. Complete replacement eliminates valve failure hazard through engineering control.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Room Ventilation System
description: Install a dedicated, purpose-built ventilation system with continuous air exchange rate of 12 air changes per hour, specifically calibrated for solvent vapor removal in the chemical storage building. Add real-time air quality monitoring with audible/visual alarms when acetone vapor concentrations exceed 500 ppm (well below PEL). Include automated system that triggers emergency exhaust fans and alerts operations team.

name: Implement Weekly Chemical Storage Integrity Inspections
description: Create a standardized weekly inspection checklist for all chemical storage containers focusing on valve connections, tank integrity, and corrosion indicators. All inspections must be documented and reviewed by the Chemical Inventory Specialist. Include quarterly third-party tank integrity testing. This administrative control ensures early detection of equipment degradation before failures occur.

name: Install Perforated Safety Guards on Shaft Couplings
description: Engineering control to eliminate pinch point hazard. Install ANSI-compliant perforated metal guards around all exposed shaft couplings on Injection Molding Line B. Guards will allow visual inspection while preventing contact with rotating parts. Implementation includes removal of old guards, fabrication of new custom-fitted guards in the Tool Room, and installation by Maintenance personnel. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of coupling-related entanglement incidents on this line.

name: Conduct Refresher Training on Machine Hazard Recognition
description: Administrative control through enhanced training. Training Coordinator Amélie Roy will develop and deliver a 2-hour refresher session for all production operators on Line B covering identification of pinch points, rotating hazards, and proper lockout procedures. Training will include hands-on inspection of the specific machinery, identification of blind spots, and emergency stop procedures. All Line B operators will complete this training within 10 days. Expected outcome: increased awareness and faster incident response.

name: Provide Ergonomic Inspection Equipment and Training
description: Engineering and administrative control to prevent repetitive strain. Procure adjustable inspection magnification stands, work positioning assists, and articulating task lights for the Tool Room. These tools eliminate the need for technicians to bend and twist into awkward positions during detailed mold inspections. Conduct ergonomics training session for all maintenance and tool room personnel covering proper workstation setup, use of new equipment, and recognition of strain indicators. Expected outcome: significant reduction in back and neck strain incidents during inspection tasks.

name: Implement Aisle Marking and Pinch Point Identification
description: All material handling pathways in the Material Drying and Preparation Room will be clearly marked with high-visibility yellow and black floor tape, indicating safe travel zones and equipment exclusion areas. Pinch points between equipment and pallets will be labeled with warning decals. Minimum aisle width requirements will be enforced at 4 feet. This eliminates the immediate environmental hazard that contributed to the foot entrapment and provides clear visual guidance for material handlers.

name: Mandatory Pallet Jack Safety Training and Certification
description: All material handlers will complete a comprehensive pallet jack operation and safety course delivered by an external certification provider. Training will include hazard recognition in confined spaces, proper positioning techniques, load capacity awareness, and emergency response procedures. Certification must be renewed annually. Material handlers without current certification will not be permitted to operate equipment in restricted areas, ensuring compliance with safe work practices.

name: Redesign Material Storage Layout
description: The Material Drying and Preparation Room will be redesigned to increase aisle width from 3 feet to 5 feet minimum, relocate the drying oven to provide better clearance around its base, and install bollards to prevent accidental equipment contact. Engineering will evaluate potential relocation of some drying equipment or procurement of more compact units. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of confined-space hazards and provides safer working conditions for all material handlers.

name: Upgrade PPE for Assembly Operations
description: All assembly operators working with thermoplastic component trimming will be issued new safety glasses featuring wraparound design with side shields and polycarbonate lenses rated for high-velocity particle impact (ANSI Z87.1 D3 rating). Existing glasses with inadequate lateral coverage will be replaced. Training will be provided on proper fit and daily inspection of PPE. This engineering control through improved personal protective equipment reduces the risk of eye injuries from airborne particles during routine assembly operations.

name: Replace Aging Backup Power Supply Unit
description: The existing 7-year-old backup power supply and battery system in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop will be replaced with a new UPS unit meeting current UL standards and equipped with thermal monitoring. The replacement will be completed by a certified electrician within 10 days. New unit will include automatic alerts for battery degradation. This eliminates the arc flash and fire risk posed by the deteriorated equipment and restores safe operational status to the electrical infrastructure.

name: Establish Equipment Replacement Schedule
description: An equipment maintenance and replacement schedule will be developed for all critical electrical and power management systems. Schedule will be based on manufacturer recommendations and will include battery backup units, voltage regulators, and surge protection systems. Annual reviews will be conducted by maintenance staff to identify aging equipment approaching end-of-service life. This administrative control ensures proactive replacement of equipment before failure, preventing future arc flash and electrical hazards.

name: Implement Predictive Hydraulic System Maintenance Program
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance program for all hydraulic systems using vibration analysis and fluid sampling. Schedule quarterly hydraulic fluid analysis to detect contamination and seal degradation early. Replace pressure relief valves on all molding lines with upgraded models featuring redundant safety mechanisms. Train maintenance staff on early warning signs of hydraulic system failure. This engineering control will eliminate equipment failure incidents by identifying degradation before catastrophic rupture occurs.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Maintenance Operations
description: Issue all maintenance technicians with full-body protective suits made of heat-resistant aramid material, chemical-resistant gloves rated for hydraulic fluid exposure, and face shields with high-temperature protection. Conduct mandatory PPE fitting and training sessions. Ensure replacement PPE is readily available at maintenance workstations. While this is a PPE-level control, it provides critical protection during the implementation of higher-level engineering controls.

name: Implement Warehouse Floor Assessment and Remediation Program
description: Conduct comprehensive evaluation of all warehouse flooring to identify uneven surfaces, damage, and drainage issues. Repair or resurface compromised areas to ensure level, stable foundation for all work activities. Establish daily housekeeping protocols requiring immediate water removal and floor inspection before each shift. Install anti-slip coating in high-traffic areas and implement a moisture control system to prevent water pooling. This engineering control eliminates the environmental hazard that caused the near-miss event.

name: Establish Ladder Safety and Housekeeping Inspection Protocol
description: Create a pre-use inspection checklist for all ladders including stability verification on level surfaces. Require workers to inspect work areas for hazards (water, debris, uneven surfaces) before positioning ladders. Provide anti-slip ladder feet pads for all extension ladders. Implement mandatory daily warehouse housekeeping inspections documented by shift supervisors. Include ladder safety in monthly toolbox talks.

name: Design and Implement Ergonomic Part Extraction Tools
description: Develop specialized extraction devices with spring-loaded grippers and long handles to reduce repetitive hand/wrist strain during autoclave part removal. Partner with ergonomics consultant to design tools that minimize repetitive grasping motions and wrist deviation. Conduct worker feedback sessions to ensure tool usability. Pilot test new tools on the composite material line for 2 weeks before full implementation. This engineering control will reduce the repetitive stress by replacing manual extraction with mechanically-assisted removal.

name: Establish Job Rotation and Ergonomic Work Practice Protocol
description: Implement mandatory job rotation policy requiring composite material operators to alternate between extraction tasks and other production duties every 90 minutes to reduce cumulative strain. Provide ergonomic training covering proper body mechanics, wrist positioning, and rest break protocols. Install height-adjustable workstations at extraction areas. Conduct monthly ergonomic assessments of high-risk tasks. Educate workers to report early signs of repetitive strain for immediate intervention.

name: Mandatory Machine Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Enforcement Program
description: Implement a zero-tolerance LOTO policy for all equipment maintenance and jam clearance operations. Install standardized lockout stations at each production line with clearly labeled energy isolation points. Conduct mandatory LOTO recertification for all production and maintenance personnel within 7 days. Implement daily audits of LOTO compliance using a checklist system. Any equipment jam requiring intervention must trigger an automatic work stoppage requiring supervisor verification before restart. Gaétan Laplante will coordinate monthly LOTO drills and audits.

name: Installation of Mechanical Interlocks and Guard Barriers
description: Install mechanical interlock switches on all regrind equipment hopper access points that automatically de-energize equipment when the hopper cover is opened. Add physical guard barriers around rotating shafts and augers with bright yellow warning signage. Retrofit regrind hoppers with wider opening designs to allow jam clearance without hand insertion. Install emergency stop buttons at multiple accessible locations around each unit. These engineering controls will physically prevent access to hazardous moving parts during operation.

name: Enhanced Safety Training and Hazard Communication
description: Develop and deliver specialized training on machine entanglement hazards specific to regrind equipment. Create visual job safety analysis (JSA) posters for the Material Drying and Preparation Room showing correct jam-clearing procedures. Include real incident case studies in training to reinforce consequences. Require all personnel working with regrind equipment to complete competency assessment before independent operation. Karine Cloutier will coordinate quarterly refresher training on machine guarding and safe jam clearance procedures.

name: Installation of Protective Barriers Around Sprinkler Heads
description: Install protective cage barriers around all sprinkler heads in the Chemical Storage Building at heights and locations susceptible to contact with moving materials and equipment. Implement overhead clearance markings to designate maximum safe material stacking heights. Mark fire suppression system components with high-visibility paint and warning labels. These physical barriers will prevent accidental contact with sprinkler heads during normal material handling operations while maintaining system effectiveness.

name: Revise Material Handling Procedures and Safe Work Practices
description: Develop and implement new standard operating procedures for material movement in UNIT-010 that mandate designated aisles, speed restrictions, and equipment operation protocols. Establish maximum container carrying heights and weights for manual handling. Require clear overhead visibility zones during all material movement operations. Conduct job safety analysis (JSA) training with all material handlers on proper load securing and cart operation. Create visual floor markings indicating safe travel routes that avoid sprinkler system components.

name: Implementation of Grounding and Static Dissipation Controls
description: Install permanent grounding equipment and conductive flooring in UNIT-010 chemical transfer areas to eliminate static electricity accumulation. Install bonding cables on all solvent containers during transfer operations. Implement conductive anti-static mats at all chemical preparation workstations. Require use of grounded metal transfer equipment exclusively. Install signage prohibiting plastic containers and synthetic materials in solvent transfer areas. Conduct training on static electricity hazards for all personnel involved in chemical handling. These engineering controls will physically eliminate the ignition source.

name: Comprehensive Chemical Storage and Handling Reorganization
description: Redesign UNIT-010 to segregate incompatible chemical classes into separate fireproof storage cabinets. Implement a maximum inventory policy limiting flammable solvents to immediate operational needs only. Establish designated solvent-only transfer areas with proper ventilation (minimum 12 air changes per hour), Class B fire suppression systems, and eyewash/shower stations. Replace open storage bins with covered, labeled containers. Create a detailed chemical inventory management system with daily audits. Implement a 'dispense only what is needed' policy requiring written authorization for bulk transfers.

name: Enhanced Personnel Training and Emergency Response Preparedness
description: Develop specialized training module on flammable solvent handling hazards, fire prevention, and emergency response specific to UNIT-010. Mandate that all personnel authorized to handle flammable chemicals complete WHMIS training, fire safety certification, and competency assessment before independent work. Conduct quarterly fire extinguisher training and drills for all night shift personnel. Install quick-access Class B fire extinguisher stations with clear signage. Establish monthly safety briefings reviewing fire incident case studies and prevention strategies.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Cooling Circuits
description: Establish quarterly thermographic inspections and pressure testing of all cooling water couplings and circuits across production equipment. Integrate thermal imaging cameras into the preventive maintenance schedule to detect early signs of coupling corrosion and metal degradation before catastrophic failure occurs. This engineering control combined with administrative procedures will identify at-risk components, extend equipment lifecycle, and prevent costly water damage incidents. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in cooling system failures within 12 months.

name: Upgrade Coupling Materials and Installation Standards
description: Replace all existing brass couplings with stainless steel or titanium-reinforced alternatives rated for 150 PSI minimum. Implement new coupling installation standards requiring torque specifications and periodic re-tightening verification every 6 months. Develop detailed equipment maintenance log procedures for all operators to document coupling condition during daily shift startup inspections. This substitution and administrative control addresses root cause of corrosion and poor coupling maintenance.

name: Enhanced Component Edge Finishing Process
description: Implement mandatory deburring and edge finishing for all injected plastic components before assembly operations. Install automated deburring equipment in the Material Drying and Preparation Room to process all medical-grade components through tumble finishing with fine abrasive media. This engineering control eliminates sharp edges at the source. Establish quality inspection checkpoints requiring visual and tactile verification of component edge smoothness before release to assembly. Training for assembly staff will emphasize safe handling techniques and recognition of improperly finished components.

name: Implement Cut-Resistant Glove Requirements
description: Provide all assembly operators with ANSI A4 cut-resistant nitrile gloves rated for sharp plastic edges during component insertion tasks. Establish a glove replacement program with quarterly audits to ensure proper fit and integrity. Include glove selection training in the assembly operator orientation program. This PPE control provides personal protection during the transition to full engineering controls and serves as a secondary safeguard.

name: Mandatory Forklift Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all powered material handling equipment, with hydraulic system inspections every 500 operating hours or quarterly, whichever comes first. Implement visual brake line inspections for signs of corrosion, abrasion, or metal fatigue at each service interval. Require replacement of brake lines showing any signs of degradation, not merely at failure. Maintain detailed maintenance logs for each forklift unit. This engineering and administrative control prevents equipment failure through systematic inspection and early replacement of worn components.

name: Install Automatic Brake Safety Systems
description: Retrofit all forklifts with secondary hydraulic brake systems or modern electronic brake assist technology that automatically engages in case of primary system failure. Install load-sensing technology to limit vehicle speed proportionally to load weight, reducing impact force in collision scenarios. This engineering control provides redundant safety barriers. Upgrade all operators with refresher training on new brake system operation within 2 weeks of installation.

name: Implement Operator Refresher Training and Load Securing Requirements
description: Mandate annual forklift operator certification renewal with emphasis on emergency braking procedures and load securing techniques. Require all loads to be secured with banding or strapping when stacked higher than 6 feet. Establish speed limits of 5 mph in the loading dock area and require horn use before each direction change. Install warning mirrors and backup cameras on all forklifts. This administrative and engineering control reduces accident severity and frequency through operator competency and equipment visibility improvements.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Establish a strict preventive maintenance schedule for all hydraulic systems with mandatory relief valve inspections every 12 months. Create a digital maintenance tracking system integrated with equipment monitoring to alert maintenance staff when service intervals approach. All hydraulic presses will undergo comprehensive pressure testing and valve calibration before returning to operation. Maintenance logs will be audited quarterly by the HSE department to ensure compliance. This measure directly addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance scheduling.

name: Install Secondary Pressure Relief Backup Systems
description: Engineer and install dual redundant pressure relief valves on all hydraulic presses, with the secondary valve set 10% below the primary valve threshold. This engineering control ensures that even if the primary valve fails, the secondary system will activate to prevent catastrophic pressure buildup. Additionally, install pressure monitoring sensors with automatic equipment shutdown functionality when pressure exceeds safe thresholds. This provides both mechanical and electronic backup protection.

name: Enhance Hydraulic Fluid Containment and Spill Response
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all hydraulic press units to capture any fluid leaks or ruptures. Train all operators on proper spill response procedures including immediate equipment shutdown and area evacuation. Place absorbent materials and spill kits within 10 feet of each press. Post warning signs regarding hydraulic fluid hazards and skin contact risks. Conduct quarterly spill response drills to ensure staff readiness.

name: Install Mechanical Lifting Assistance Equipment
description: Procure and install pneumatic lift tables and articulating material handling hoists in the Finished Goods Warehouse to eliminate manual lifting of boxes exceeding 25 pounds. Position equipment at workstations where heavy composite material components are routinely staged. Provide comprehensive operator training on proper use of lift equipment. Establish a policy requiring use of mechanical assistance for any load over 25 pounds. This engineering control directly eliminates the hazard by removing the need for manual lifting of heavy objects.

name: Mandatory Ergonomics and Safe Lifting Training Program
description: Implement a comprehensive ergonomics training program for all warehouse personnel covering proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, load assessment, and recognition of early strain symptoms. Training will include hands-on demonstrations with actual workplace tasks and loads. Refresher training will occur annually and whenever new equipment is introduced. The training will specifically address the materials handling tasks in the Finished Goods Warehouse. Supervisors will monitor compliance with proper techniques during daily operations.

name: Implement Two-Person Lifting Protocol for Heavy Items
description: Establish and enforce a procedure requiring two-person manual lifting for any boxes or components weighing between 20-35 pounds, with mechanical assistance mandatory for items over 35 pounds. Post clear signage indicating weight thresholds and lift requirements at all material staging areas. Adjust work assignment and scheduling to ensure two operators are available when tasks require team lifting. Supervisor spot-checks will verify compliance weekly.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Verification System
description: Implement a rigorous LOTO compliance verification program where no employee may access rotating equipment without first obtaining sign-off from the LOTO Coordinator. Install mechanical lockout points on all composite processing equipment with color-coded locks assigned to each authorized employee. Conduct monthly LOTO audits with photographic documentation. Establish consequences for LOTO violations including immediate retraining and potential disciplinary action. All night shift operations will include LOTO verification checklist sign-offs by supervisors at shift start.

name: Install Machine Guarding on All Rotating Shafts
description: Engineer and install fixed perforated metal guards around all rotating augers, feed screws, and shaft mechanisms in the composite materials processing area. Guards must prevent access to moving parts while allowing visual inspection of equipment operation. Install interlocked access gates that disable equipment automatically when opened. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source by making contact with rotating parts physically impossible.

name: Comprehensive Machine Safety Retraining Program
description: Conduct mandatory retraining for all operators on composite processing equipment emphasizing lockout/tagout procedures, hazard recognition, and proper maintenance protocols. Include night shift specific training addressing fatigue-related errors and communication challenges. Require certification testing with 100% passing score before return to equipment operation. Schedule quarterly refresher training for all operators. Create laminated LOTO procedure cards posted at each piece of equipment as visual reminders.

name: Install Emergency Stop Buttons with Enhanced Visibility
description: Install bright red emergency stop (E-stop) buttons on all composite processing equipment at waist height and accessible from multiple angles. Buttons must be larger (80mm diameter minimum) and highly visible with yellow and black warning striping. Conduct training on proper E-stop activation and ensure all employees understand that pressing the button will immediately cease all equipment operations without penalties or reporting requirements for legitimate safety emergencies.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooling Time Verification System
description: Install audible timer alarms on all injection molding lines that activate when the mold has cooled to safe handling temperature (below 60°C). Operators must verify the alarm before any part removal is permitted. Additionally, implement a visual indicator system with color-coded heat-sensitive strips on each mold cavity to provide immediate confirmation of safe handling temperature. Train all production operators on the new system during the next scheduled safety briefing.

name: Enforce Heat-Resistant Glove Usage Policy
description: Establish and enforce a mandatory requirement that all operators working with mold removal must wear rated heat-resistant gloves rated for 200°C+ exposure. Place clearly visible signage at each molding station stating glove requirements. Conduct weekly spot checks by supervisors to ensure compliance. Include this requirement in the daily pre-shift safety briefing and make non-compliance grounds for immediate work suspension until proper PPE is donned.

name: Provide Advanced Thermal Burn First Aid Training
description: Conduct certified advanced thermal burn first aid training for all production supervisors and the occupational health nurse. Training will cover immediate cooling protocols, assessment of burn severity, proper dressing application, and when to escalate to emergency medical services. Ensure all first aid kits are stocked with specialized burn treatment supplies and sterile non-adherent dressings. Document training completion and schedule refresher training annually.

name: Replace Critical Cooling System Couplings with Redundant Shut-off System
description: Replace all fractured and aging coupling connections in the main cooling loop with high-grade stainless steel couplings rated for continuous 80°C operation at 6 bar pressure. Install redundant automatic shut-off valves at key junction points that trigger when pressure drops below 5.5 bar, preventing massive fluid loss in case of coupling failure. Include vibration-damping mounts under all heat exchange equipment to reduce coupling stress. This engineering control eliminates the primary failure mode.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Cooling Systems
description: Implement a quarterly ultrasonic inspection program to detect early signs of coupling degradation, stress fractures, and pressure anomalies in all cooling loops. Schedule proactive coupling replacement on a 5-year cycle regardless of visible wear. Create a maintenance log tracking all inspections, replacements, and pressure readings. Train maintenance staff to recognize early warning signs of coupling failure such as unusual vibration or audible hissing.

name: Install Load Securement and Containment Barriers
description: Install adjustable side barriers and mesh containment netting on all forklifts used in the warehouse to prevent load shifting during turns and transport. Implement mandatory load height restrictions with clearly marked maximum stacking limits on all storage racks. Add diagonal load bracing requirements for all palletized loads exceeding 800 kg. This engineering control prevents load instability and cascade failures.

name: Reinforce Storage Rack Structural Capacity and Inspection Protocol
description: Conduct structural engineering assessment of all storage racks to verify load capacity ratings and identify any compromised units. Replace or reinforce racks that cannot safely support maximum loaded weight limits. Install load capacity placards on every rack section clearly indicating maximum weight per shelf level. Implement monthly visual inspections with documented sign-offs by warehouse supervisors to identify bent frames, damaged beams, or load-bearing issues before failures occur.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a quarterly thermographic inspection program to identify pressure anomalies and fluid degradation before failures occur. All injection molding lines will be monitored using thermal imaging to detect hot spots indicating imminent ruptures. Additionally, hydraulic fluid samples will be analyzed monthly for viscosity and contamination levels. Equipment readings will be logged in a predictive maintenance database to track degradation trends and schedule preventive replacements before critical failures.

name: Upgrade Operator PPE Requirements for Hydraulic Work
description: All operators working with hydraulic systems will be required to wear heat-resistant arm sleeves rated for 100°C contact and splash-resistant gloves during shift operations. Existing PPE inventory will be upgraded to include flame-resistant materials. All operators will receive training on proper donning/doffing procedures and heat-resistant gear limitations. A compliance audit will be conducted weekly for the first month.

name: Replace Storage Racks with Load-Rated Industrial Systems
description: All existing storage racks in UNIT-018 will be replaced with certified industrial-grade shelving rated for the specific loads of recycled plastic materials. New racks will include secondary retention brackets, load limiters with warning indicators, and anti-tip mechanisms. A structural engineer will certify all new installations. Old racks will be salvaged. Implementation includes comprehensive worker training on new load charts and weight distribution requirements.

name: Establish Rack Inspection and Weight Distribution Audits
description: Weekly visual inspections will be conducted by Materials Supervisor Valérie Pelletier to verify load distribution, bolt integrity, and shelf alignment. Monthly load audits will ensure no single shelf exceeds rated capacity. Workers will be trained to report any visible rack movement or damage immediately. A color-coded warning system will mark maximum load lines on each shelf. All incidents involving falling objects from height will trigger immediate re-certification of affected racks.

name: Implement Overhead Netting and Containment Systems
description: Install protective overhead netting and containment barriers above high-traffic zones where falling object risk is highest in the recycling area. Workers below these zones will wear hard hats at all times. Emergency exit routes and staging areas will remain clear of overhead storage. Quarterly safety drills will be conducted to practice emergency response procedures.

name: Comprehensive Electrical Panel Inspection and Remediation Program
description: All electrical panels throughout the facility will undergo professional thermographic and visual inspection within 30 days to identify loose connections, corrosion, and thermal hotspots before they become hazards. A certified industrial electrician will tighten all connections, replace corroded terminals, and verify torque specifications on all breaker clamps. A detailed report with photographic documentation will be maintained. High-risk panels will be inspected monthly thereafter, with all findings recorded in a centralized maintenance database.

name: Enhance Electrical Safety Training and LOTO Procedures
description: All maintenance technicians and electricians will complete advanced electrical safety certification within 60 days, including arc flash recognition, hazard assessment, and emergency response. LOTO procedures will be updated to require a witness verification step for any work involving panels exceeding 240V. A laminated quick-reference guide showing arc flash hazard zones will be posted at each panel location. Monthly toolbox talks will focus on electrical hazards and near-miss reporting.

name: Install Automated Hopper Level Cutoff Systems
description: Engineer and install redundant hopper level sensors with independent cutoff mechanisms on all material drying and preparation equipment. This engineering control will eliminate overflow incidents by providing automated backup systems that stop material feed when hopper capacity is reached. The system will include visual and audible alarms to notify operators of high-level conditions. Implementation includes calibration, testing, and operator training on the new systems.

name: Implement Monthly Hopper Sensor Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a preventive maintenance program requiring monthly inspection, cleaning, and calibration of all hopper level sensors and moisture detection equipment. Maintenance logs will be tracked in the computerized maintenance management system with alerts for technicians. This administrative control addresses the root cause of sensor malfunction by ensuring equipment is regularly serviced and calibrated to specification.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Predictive Monitoring
description: Install condition monitoring sensors on all injection molding machine hydraulic systems to track pump vibration, fluid temperature, and pressure fluctuations in real-time. Sensors will send data to the maintenance management system, triggering automatic alerts when readings approach failure thresholds. This engineering control will enable technicians to schedule preventive maintenance before catastrophic failure occurs, eliminating unexpected equipment failure events and production stoppages.

name: Establish Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Protocol
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive hydraulic maintenance schedule requiring fluid analysis every 500 operating hours, pump bearing inspection every 2000 hours, and complete seal kit replacement every 4000 hours. All work will be documented in the computerized maintenance management system. Technicians will receive training on hydraulic system diagnostics and the early warning signs of pump degradation. This administrative control ensures that hydraulic components are systematically serviced according to manufacturer specifications.

name: Install Dual-Channel Temperature Control and Safety Shutdown System
description: Replace single-channel temperature controllers with dual-channel redundant systems featuring independent thermostats and emergency cutoff valves. Install backup heating element shutdown relays that automatically de-energize the heating elements if any channel fails or reads above safe operating parameters. This engineering control eliminates the risk of heating element overtemperature failures by providing independent safety systems that cannot simultaneously fail. All new controls will have manual override capability and audible alarm notification.

name: Install Redundant Hopper Level Monitoring System
description: Implement a dual-sensor hopper level detection system with independent alarm circuits to prevent overflow conditions. The primary sensor will trigger material feed cutoff at 85% capacity, while a secondary backup sensor provides redundancy. Install an audible alarm and visual indicator light on the production line to alert operators of high hopper levels. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the overflow incident and provides layered protection against hopper malfunctions.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hopper Sensors
description: Create a monthly inspection and calibration routine for all hopper level sensors across the 32 injection molding machines. Maintenance technician Luc Girard will lead the program, documenting sensor performance and replacing units that show drift or degradation. Train all shift supervisors to perform basic troubleshooting and reset procedures. This administrative control ensures early detection of sensor failures before they create safety hazards and production disruptions.

name: Mandatory LOTO Audit and Enforcement Program
description: Implement a 100% LOTO compliance verification system for all maintenance activities on CNC and injection molding equipment. Prior to any maintenance work, equipment must be locked out, tagged, and photographed. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury will conduct weekly spot-checks on maintenance activities and issue compliance reports. Any violation will trigger retraining and disciplinary action. This administrative control strengthens enforcement of existing LOTO procedures and creates accountability for adherence.

name: Install Fixed Guards on CNC Machine Spindle Couplings
description: Design and fabricate perforated steel guards around all rotating spindle couplings on the five CNC milling machines in the workshop. Guards will allow visibility for inspections while preventing hand contact with rotating components. Install quick-release mechanisms to allow maintenance access without compromising safety during non-maintenance periods. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of hand-spindle entanglement and complements LOTO procedures.

name: Upgrade Maintenance Worker PPE Requirements
description: Specify nitrile-coated cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rating) for all maintenance personnel working on CNC and injection molding equipment. Replace standard cloth work gloves with high-visibility, cut-resistant alternatives. Provide training on proper donning and inspection of PPE. While not a primary control, improved PPE reduces severity of laceration injuries. Maintenance technicians will be issued new glove kits immediately.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring and Alarm System
description: Retrofit all six resin drying hoppers with digital temperature sensors connected to a centralized monitoring dashboard in the production control room. Set temperature thresholds that trigger audible and visual alarms if heating elements exceed 150°C. Configure automated email alerts to maintenance staff and shift supervisors. Install backup thermostat devices with independent shutoff capability to prevent runaway heating. This engineering control provides real-time protection against thermal runaway conditions.

name: Establish Quarterly Thermostat Calibration Program
description: Reduce the preventive maintenance interval from six months to every three months for all resin dryer thermostats and heating elements. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard will perform calibration checks, replace worn thermostats, and document findings in the equipment maintenance log. Implement a digital scheduling system that automatically notifies maintenance staff when calibrations are due. This administrative control ensures timely detection and correction of thermostat drift before dangerous overheating occurs.

name: Implement Secondary Containment Protocol for Chemical Transfers
description: Install permanent secondary containment pallets with 15-gallon capacity under all chemical transfer operations in the mixing room. Require all drum transfers to occur within these containment units. Train all material handlers on proper placement and inspection procedures. Conduct monthly verification audits to ensure compliance. This engineering control will prevent future spills from spreading across the facility floor, protecting groundwater and enabling rapid containment.

name: Upgrade Chemical Transfer Hose Specifications
description: Replace all existing transfer hoses with certified stainless steel quick-disconnect couplings rated for chemical transfer applications. Implement a quarterly inspection and recrimping schedule conducted by maintenance technicians. Document all hose inspections in the preventive maintenance system. Provide training to material handlers on proper hose connection procedures and visual inspection checklist before each transfer operation.

name: Enhanced Ventilation System Verification
description: Conduct a full HVAC system performance audit in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room, including flow rate measurements and air quality testing. Install permanent CO2 and VOC monitoring sensors with real-time dashboard alerts set at 75% of exposure limits. Establish daily pre-shift ventilation system startup verification procedures with sign-off requirements. Schedule quarterly professional ductwork cleaning and system maintenance to ensure optimal operation.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification System
description: Install mechanical LOTO verification stations at each injection molding machine requiring operators to physically verify lockout device placement before any maintenance or cleaning work begins. Implement a digital checklist system with photographic documentation that must be completed and approved by a supervisor before work commences. Conduct comprehensive LOTO refresher training for all production operators and technicians within 5 business days, with quarterly verification audits by the HSE team.

name: Install Emergency Stop Button Guards and Clear Access Zones
description: Install protective guards around all emergency stop buttons on injection molding machines to prevent accidental obstruction by tools or equipment. Clear a minimum 18-inch zone around each emergency stop button and mark with high-visibility tape. Remove or relocate tooling storage areas that were blocking emergency access. Conduct daily pre-shift safety inspections with documented sign-offs to ensure compliance.

name: Establish Two-Person Safety Protocol for Mold Cavity Work
description: Implement a mandatory two-person rule for all work involving mold cavities or confined access areas. Designate one operator to perform maintenance work and one designated observer whose sole responsibility is monitoring equipment status and maintaining communication. The observer must have a clear line of sight to all emergency controls and equipment status indicators. Provide training and certification for all assigned observers, with quarterly competency verification.

name: Implement Pre-Lift Load Inspection Checklist
description: Develop and laminate a required pre-lift inspection checklist for all overhead crane operations. The checklist must include: strap condition assessment, load weight verification, center-of-gravity confirmation, and proper securing point identification. All crane operators must complete the checklist and obtain supervisor sign-off before initiating any lift. Store checklists at each crane station and maintain documentation for monthly audit by the HSE team.

name: Replace Crane Strapping Harnesses with Certified Load-Rated Systems
description: Replace all existing tie-down straps with certified synthetic nylon straps rated for 1200-pound minimum load capacity with inspection intervals clearly marked. Implement a monthly inspection schedule conducted by maintenance technicians with documented results. Retire any straps showing signs of wear, UV degradation, or load-bearing compromise. Maintain a spare strap inventory equal to 25% of operational straps for immediate replacement.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Drying Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all material drying equipment in UNIT-016, including quarterly thermostatic control inspections, annual calibration of temperature sensors, and weekly visual inspections for signs of malfunction. This will be documented in a maintenance log and tracked through the facility's CMMS system. Training will be provided to all operators on recognizing warning signs of equipment failure, including unusual vibrations, temperature fluctuations, and grinding sounds. Expected outcome: Reduce equipment-related incidents by 80% and extend equipment lifespan by implementing early detection protocols.

name: Enhanced Operator Awareness Training on Fire Hazard Recognition
description: Develop and deliver a targeted training module for all Production Operators focusing on early warning signs of potential fire hazards in drying and heating equipment, including abnormal sounds, temperature irregularities, and material discoloration. Training will include case studies of similar incidents in the plastics industry and will emphasize the importance of immediate reporting and shutdown procedures. All operators will complete the training within 30 days and competency will be assessed through a written quiz.

name: Install Ergonomic Part Removal Workstation with Mechanical Assists
description: Design and install a new ergonomic workstation at Injection Molding Line D featuring mechanical part removal assistance including pneumatic ejectors, rotating work surfaces at optimal height, and anti-fatigue matting. The station will include adjustable work surfaces (25-45 inches height) to accommodate different operator body dimensions. Additionally, install a split-pad gripper tool that reduces hand force requirements by 60%. This engineering control will eliminate excessive wrist bending and gripping strain. Expected outcome: Reduce repetitive strain injuries in part removal operations by 85% and improve production efficiency by 12%.

name: Implement Mandatory Micro-Break and Job Rotation Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory work schedule requiring 5-minute micro-breaks every 60 minutes during production operations, during which employees must perform guided stretching exercises targeting wrists, forearms, and shoulders. Implement job rotation where operators switch between part removal, quality inspection, and packaging tasks every 90 minutes to vary muscle group usage. Create visual stretch guides at each workstation and train all supervisors on monitoring compliance. Breaks will be tracked in the shift management system.

name: Comprehensive Ergonomics Assessment and Individual Fit Program
description: Conduct detailed ergonomic assessments for all 45 operators in injection molding using biomechanical analysis and video analysis of work tasks. Develop individualized ergonomic modification plans based on each operator's anthropometric data and work style. Provide custom wrist supports, hand tools adjusted to individual preferences, and personalized exercises. Establish a baseline measurement of grip strength and range of motion, with quarterly reassessments to detect early signs of cumulative trauma. Include ergonomic awareness training specific to each operator's identified risk factors.

name: Replace All Pressure Relief Valves with Redundant Safety System
description: Replace all existing pressure relief valves on chemical storage tanks with high-grade stainless steel units rated for corrosive chemical environments. Install a dual-valve redundant system so that if one valve fails, a secondary valve maintains safety. Add pressure gauges upstream and downstream of each valve pair to enable early detection of valve degradation. Implement a quarterly pressure relief valve integrity testing protocol using calibrated equipment. Install secondary containment basins under all tanks with capacity for 150% of the largest tank volume. Cost includes materials, installation, and first year testing.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance and Inspection Schedule for Chemical Tanks
description: Create a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all chemical storage and handling equipment including monthly visual inspections for corrosion, quarterly valve functionality tests, semi-annual pressure tests, and annual professional inspection by certified technicians. Maintain detailed inspection records in the facility CMMS. Assign rotating responsibility among maintenance team members and track completion on a facility dashboard. This systematic approach will identify emerging problems before catastrophic failure occurs. Include staff training on recognizing signs of valve degradation such as micro-leaks or abnormal hissing sounds.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Facility Secondary Containment Infrastructure
description: Install epoxy-sealed concrete containment basins under all chemical storage tanks with sloped floors directing any spills toward a centralized collection sump. Add absorbent booms and containment kits in strategic locations throughout UNIT-010. Install spill response signage with emergency procedure flowcharts. Create a chemical spill emergency response plan detailing immediate actions, equipment shutdown sequences, area evacuation procedures, and external agency notification protocols. Train all night shift operators on spill response procedures through monthly tabletop exercises. Ensure spill kit replacement after any use.

name: Replace Cooling System Couplings with High-Pressure Rated Components
description: Engineering control: Replace all standard couplings on the primary cooling lines with rated high-pressure quick-disconnect couplings that include automatic shutoff valves. This eliminates the risk of catastrophic water discharge if a coupling fails. All 32 molding machines will be retrofitted within 60 days. Upgrade the secondary containment basin by clearing drain blockages and installing a secondary pump to ensure 100% capture capacity. The new couplings cost approximately $8,000 total installation.

name: Implement Monthly Cooling System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Administrative control: Establish a documented monthly inspection and maintenance protocol for all cooling system components including visual inspection of couplings for wear, pressure testing, and coupling tightness verification. Maintenance staff will use a standardized checklist and record all findings in the equipment maintenance database. This will identify deteriorating components before failure occurs. Training will be provided to all maintenance personnel on proper inspection techniques and documentation requirements.

name: Install Automatic Leak Detection and Alarm System
description: Engineering control: Install moisture sensors in the secondary containment area of each molding machine station that trigger an audible alarm and automatic machine shutdown when water accumulation is detected. This provides real-time notification to operators before significant spillage occurs. Additionally, install drain valve position indicators visible from the production floor so operators can verify containment basin readiness. System cost is approximately $12,500 for all 32 machines.

name: Upgrade Electrical Cabinet Environmental Protection
description: Engineering control: Relocate all hydraulic press electrical control cabinets to a dedicated, climate-controlled equipment room with sealed construction and positive air pressure to prevent coolant vapor and moisture intrusion. Install NEMA 4X stainless steel protective enclosures around remaining electrical connections. Add desiccant-based moisture control systems inside all cabinets. Upgrade all control relays to solid-state versions that are less susceptible to moisture damage. This comprehensive upgrade costs approximately $22,000 and eliminates the root cause of electrical failures.

name: Install Redundant Safety Interlock Monitoring System
description: Engineering control: Install a secondary, independent safety interlock monitoring system that continuously verifies the primary interlock status and automatically triggers emergency shutdown if any discrepancy is detected. Add visual and audible indicators on the machine control panel showing the status of all safety interlocks in real-time. Technicians will receive training to interpret these indicators before operating the press. This dual-verification system ensures the machine cannot operate with compromised safety systems.

name: Implement Enhanced LOTO and Equipment Certification Program
description: Administrative control: Establish a quarterly equipment certification program where all LOTO procedures and safety interlock systems are formally tested by qualified technicians. Create a database tracking all maintenance performed on each machine, including dates, actions, and certification status. Require signoff by both maintenance personnel and supervisors confirming LOTO compliance. Additionally, conduct monthly refresher training on LOTO procedures for all maintenance staff with competency verification. Non-compliant equipment will be immediately removed from service.

name: Install Aisle Racking Guards and Load Capacity Monitoring
description: Engineering control: Install protective barriers (steel angle guards) on all storage racks in the warehouse to absorb impact from forklift collisions and prevent load spills. Install load capacity limit signs on each rack tier with visual weight indicators. Additionally, upgrade to racking systems with load cells that trigger an alarm if weight limits are exceeded. Install wide-angle convex mirrors at all aisle intersections to improve visibility. These measures prevent future collisions from causing structural failure and cascading damage.

name: Establish Warehouse Layout Change Control and Traffic Flow Management
description: Administrative control: Create a formal change control process requiring that any warehouse layout modifications must be reviewed by the Safety Committee and Production Planning team before implementation. Update the forklift traffic flow map, install clearly marked traffic lanes with painted floor markings, and place directional signage at all intersections. Conduct a mandatory warehouse layout familiarization briefing for all forklift operators and materials handlers within 24 hours of any layout changes. Post updated maps at all operator stations and the main entrance.

name: Implement Advanced Forklift Operator Training and Certification Program
description: Administrative control: Establish a comprehensive forklift operation certification program requiring all operators to complete formal training, pass both written and practical competency assessments, and demonstrate proficiency in load visibility management, load securing, and collision avoidance techniques. Require recertification annually and additional training whenever warehouse layouts change. Implement a "load too high to see" protocol requiring a spotter for any load obscuring forward visibility. Track all forklift incidents per operator and provide targeted retraining for operators involved in collisions.

name: Implement Quarterly Drum Valve Inspection Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule for all chemical storage drums, focusing on valve couplings, seals, and pressure relief systems. Maintenance Technicians will inspect all drums every 90 days using a standardized checklist. Any worn or degraded components will be immediately replaced before drums are returned to service. This engineering and administrative control addresses the root cause of the coupling failure and ensures early detection of potential leaks.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Room Ventilation System
description: Install an enhanced mechanical ventilation system with real-time vapor monitoring sensors in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The system will automatically activate at elevated acetone vapor concentrations (>250 ppm) and alert personnel. This engineering control provides continuous protection against solvent vapor accumulation and enables rapid response to future spills. Installation includes backup battery system for emergency operation.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring and Alarm System on Resin Dryers
description: Install automatic temperature monitoring systems with audible and visual alarms on all three composite material resin dryers. System will alert operators when temperatures exceed safe thresholds (set at 5°C below maximum operating temperature). Alarms will also trigger automatic shutdown sequences to prevent equipment damage and thermal hazards. This engineering control eliminates the need for manual investigation of overheating conditions.

name: Mandatory LOTO Training and Enforcement for Night Shift
description: Conduct mandatory lockout/tagout retraining for all night shift personnel with emphasis on non-negotiable compliance. Implement supervisory accountability measures where shift leads must verify LOTO compliance before any equipment maintenance. Create production schedules that allocate adequate time for proper lockout procedures without pressure to bypass safety steps. All supervisors will receive training on recognizing and correcting LOTO violations.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Dryer Equipment
description: Develop and implement a preventive maintenance program for resin dryers including thermostat calibration, sensor testing, and thermal relief valve inspection every 60 days. This will be performed during scheduled maintenance windows to prevent operational emergencies. Maintenance records will be tracked and reviewed monthly by the HSE department to identify patterns and ensure consistent application across all shifts.

name: Implement Incoming Scrap Material Inspection System
description: Establish a mandatory pre-shredding inspection station where all composite scrap material is hand-sorted and visually inspected for foreign objects, metal fragments, and contaminants before entering the shredder hopper. Personnel will use handheld metal detectors and visual checklists to identify hazardous items. This material will be segregated and disposed of separately. This engineering and administrative control eliminates metal fragments from reaching processing equipment.

name: Enhanced Housekeeping and Dust Management Program
description: Implement daily housekeeping protocol in the Regrind and Recycling Department with focus on removing plastic dust and debris accumulation. Install HEPA-filtered vacuum equipment for dry dust collection inside the shredder housing area. Establish weekly deep cleaning cycles where equipment is safely powered down and internal chambers are professionally cleaned. This administrative and engineering control reduces fire risk from dust accumulation.

name: Install Fire Suppression System in Shredder Equipment
description: Install an automatic dry powder fire suppression system with heat-activated triggers inside the shredder chamber and housing. This will provide immediate fire suppression capability for incipient fires resulting from foreign objects or dust accumulation. System will include automatic shutdown integration to halt rotor operation when suppression is triggered. This engineering control provides redundant protection against fire incidents.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule for all hydraulic pump assemblies across the 32 injection molding machines. Schedule quarterly inspections with vibration analysis to detect seal degradation early. Replace seals proactively every 12 months regardless of visible wear. Implement condition monitoring software that alerts maintenance staff when vibration signatures deviate from baseline parameters. This engineering control approach will prevent catastrophic failures before they occur.

name: Update Maintenance Documentation and Training
description: Create detailed maintenance logs for all critical equipment with clear intervals for seal replacement, fluid analysis, and inspection procedures. Conduct training sessions for all production operators and maintenance technicians on recognizing early warning signs of hydraulic system failure (vibrations, noise, fluid temperature, leaks). Distribute laminated reference cards at each machine showing maintenance schedules and escalation procedures. This administrative control ensures consistent adherence to maintenance protocols.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Gloves for Composite Trimming Operations
description: Distribute ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant gloves (nitrile-coated nylon) to all personnel working in composite materials processing who handle sharp-edged parts. Gloves must be sized individually and replaced when showing signs of wear. Ensure gloves are readily available at each workstation and stored in designated containers. Include information about proper glove selection and usage in toolbox talks. This PPE control will significantly reduce laceration injuries from hand contact with sharp edges.

name: Implement Safe Trimming Tool Standards and Training
description: Replace manual utility knives with specialized plastic trimming tools featuring ergonomic handles and retractable blades that reduce slip risk. Provide hands-on training to all composite area operators on proper cutting techniques, including hand positioning and work surface stabilization. Establish a tool inspection and replacement schedule to ensure blades remain sharp (dull blades increase slip risk). Create visual job aids showing correct grip and cutting angles. This substitution control replaces ineffective tools with safer alternatives.

name: Install Secure Shelving with Containment Systems
description: Replace all open shelving in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room with enclosed industrial shelving units featuring solid backs, sides, and safety rails. Install containment trays with raised edges on each shelf to prevent containers from sliding or falling. Implement weight distribution protocols limiting loads on upper shelves (max 10 kg per shelf above 1.5 meters). Add clear labeling indicating maximum weight capacity per shelf and proper stacking procedures. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of falling objects.

name: Mandate Safety Footwear and Implement Ergonomic Storage Procedures
description: Require all material handlers and warehouse personnel to wear ANSI-approved steel-toed safety boots with metatarsal protection guards. Conduct fit testing and provide individual sizing. Implement administrative controls restricting access to mezzanine storage to authorized personnel only. Establish work procedures requiring two-person retrieval for any items above 1.5 meters height and limiting individual lifting of containers over 10 kg. Provide training on proper lifting mechanics and storage organization. This hierarchical approach combines PPE protection with administrative safeguards.

name: Conduct Mezzanine Level Safety Audit and Signage Enhancement
description: Perform comprehensive inspection of the mezzanine storage area by qualified safety personnel. Install high-visibility warning signs at all mezzanine edges indicating falling object hazard and required PPE. Paint floor markings showing exclusion zones directly beneath elevated storage. Add motion-sensor lighting to improve visibility during night shift operations. Install a protective canopy over work areas below the mezzanine to intercept falling items. Establish monthly inspections to verify containment system integrity and product stability.

name: Implement Automated Part Extraction System for Molding Lines
description: Install pneumatic extraction arms on the three most heavily-used injection molding machines (Units #5, #7, #9) to eliminate manual gripping and twisting forces during part removal. This engineering control will reduce repetitive strain injuries and hand lacerations. The system will incorporate soft gripper pads to prevent part damage and allow for consistent cooling time. Implementation includes operator training on system controls and emergency manual override procedures. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in hand-related extraction injuries within 6 months.

name: Establish Part Cooling and Removal SOP with Mandatory Training
description: Develop and distribute a standardized operating procedure (SOP) for part extraction that includes mandatory cooling time intervals (minimum 90 seconds), proper hand positioning techniques, and required PPE (cut-resistant gloves, wrist supports). Conduct mandatory training for all assembly operators with competency testing. Include photographic guides and video demonstrations. Implement monthly refresher training and include extraction technique assessment in quarterly safety audits. Expected outcome: Improved operator awareness and 60% reduction in extraction-related injuries within 3 months.

name: Upgrade Part Removal PPE Requirements
description: Distribute ANSI Level 4 cut-resistant gloves (Kevlar-lined, rated for sharp plastic edges) and ergonomic wrist support braces to all assembly operators. Implement mandatory use policy during all part extraction activities. Conduct fit-testing and training on proper donning/doffing. Establish monthly inventory checks to ensure replacement gloves are available. While PPE is a lower-level control, it provides immediate protection during transition to engineering controls.

name: Replace All Resin Tank Pressure Couplings and Valves
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all pressurized resin tanks and identify all coupling and valve assemblies that are more than 10 years old. Replace with modern, pressure-rated stainless steel fittings rated for 150% of operating pressure. This engineering control eliminates the equipment failure mechanism. Work with equipment supplier to obtain certified pressure test certificates for all new components. Establish baseline for future replacement schedules every 8 years.

name: Implement Quarterly Pressurized Equipment Inspection Program
description: Establish mandatory quarterly inspection of all pressurized resin tanks, couplings, valves, and relief mechanisms. Create detailed inspection checklist including visual crack assessment, pressure gauge calibration verification, and thermal imaging for temperature verification. Document findings in maintenance management system. Assign responsibility to Maintenance Technician supervisor. Any couplings or valves showing wear marks, discoloration, or stress corrosion patterns trigger immediate replacement. Expected outcome: Early detection of equipment degradation before catastrophic failure.

name: Foundation Waterproofing and Exterior Drainage System Upgrade
description: Engage licensed waterproofing contractor to repair the warehouse foundation exterior wall, install continuous drainage system around the perimeter of the Raw Materials Warehouse section, and implement interior sump pump system if needed. This engineering control eliminates moisture infiltration. Install French drain system to divert water away from building foundation. Conduct post-project testing with moisture measurement during simulated rain conditions. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of water intrusion and associated mold/contamination risks.

name: Install Continuous Environmental Monitoring System in Raw Materials Warehouse
description: Install 6 wireless humidity and temperature sensors throughout the Raw Materials Warehouse with real-time monitoring dashboard accessible to warehouse staff and HSE team. Set alert thresholds at 65% relative humidity. Data logging system will maintain 90-day history for audit trail. Sensors will provide early warning of moisture intrusion issues before materials are affected. Integrate monitoring data into daily shift reports. Expected outcome: Real-time visibility into warehouse environmental conditions and early detection of HVAC or moisture issues.

name: Establish Raw Materials Receiving Inspection and Storage Protocol
description: Develop SOP requiring visual inspection of all incoming raw material shipments for moisture damage or contamination before warehouse storage. Relocate sensitive materials (medical-grade resins, sterile-critical components) to climate-controlled core warehouse section away from exterior walls. Implement FIFO (First-In-First-Out) rotation for affected materials. Train all warehouse staff on proper material segregation and environmental sensitivity. Include inspection findings in weekly HSE reports. Expected outcome: Prevention of contaminated materials entering production and improved traceability.

name: Install Predictive Temperature Monitoring System on Resin Dryers
description: Implement automated temperature monitoring and alarm system on all six resin dryers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. System will include thermostat redundancy and real-time alerts to maintenance personnel when temperatures exceed safe ranges. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of undetected overheating events. All maintenance staff will receive training on the new monitoring dashboard and alert protocols.

name: Establish Monthly Resin Dryer Maintenance Schedule
description: Create and enforce a documented preventive maintenance schedule for all resin dryers, including thermostat testing, heating element inspection, and complete thermal system verification. Schedule will be tracked in the facility's maintenance management system with mandatory sign-offs by the maintenance supervisor. This administrative control ensures early detection of potential failures before they can escalate to alarm situations.

name: Install Permanent Cable Management and Floor Routing System
description: Engineer and install a permanent overhead cable tray system running through all main corridors and work areas, eliminating floor-level hose and cable hazards. All pneumatic hoses and electrical cables will be routed through the trays with proper supports and labeling. This engineering control removes the trip hazard entirely from floor surfaces. The system will be installed across the warehouse and production areas within 30 days, with temporary hoses prohibited on floor surfaces until completion.

name: Implement Temporary Equipment Installation Safety Protocol
description: Develop and distribute a mandatory safety protocol for all temporary equipment installations, requiring maintenance staff to document hose and cable routing, secure all lines per ANSI standards, mark hazard zones, and notify affected departments. All temporary installations must be reviewed and approved by HSE before activation. This administrative control ensures immediate hazard mitigation for future installations and establishes accountability for compliance.

name: Conduct Facility-Wide Hazard Walkthrough and Remediation
description: Perform comprehensive inspection of all production and warehouse areas to identify remaining unsecured hoses, cables, and trip hazards. All identified hazards will be corrected immediately using cable ties, floor covers, or temporary routing solutions while permanent cable tray system is being installed. Results will be documented and communicated to all employees. This administrative control addresses the seven known hazards and prevents similar incidents.

name: Replace All Injection Molding Cooling Lines with Reinforced High-Pressure Hoses
description: Execute facility-wide replacement of aging cooling water lines on all 14 injection molding machines with modern reinforced high-pressure rated hoses rated for 120% of maximum system pressure. All connections will be upgraded to quick-disconnect couplings with automatic shut-off valves. This engineering control eliminates the risk of catastrophic hose rupture. Work will be completed during planned maintenance shutdowns over a 3-week period, with priority given to Line C and Line D machines.

name: Mandate High-Temperature Protective Equipment for Cooling System Maintenance
description: Issue all operators performing mold cleaning and cooling system maintenance with enhanced PPE including heat-resistant sleeves, thermal gloves rated to 150°C, and protective aprons. Establish a requirement that this PPE be worn whenever working within 50 cm of pressurized cooling systems. All affected staff will receive one-hour training on proper fitting and use of equipment.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Pressure Line Inspection Program
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly inspection and documentation program for all pressure lines, couplings, and hose assemblies on all injection molding machines. Inspections will be conducted by certified maintenance technicians using visual assessment and pressure testing. Any hoses showing signs of degradation, corrosion, or age exceeding 10 years will be immediately replaced. Inspection records will be maintained in the facility's maintenance management system with mandatory supervisor sign-off.

name: Conduct Emergency Response and Burn Treatment Training for All Line Operators
description: Organize comprehensive first aid training focused specifically on burn injury response and initial care procedures for all 24 injection molding line operators. Training will cover immediate water immersion protocols, appropriate wound dressing, pain management, and when to escalate to emergency medical services. Training will be delivered in two sessions to maintain production coverage and will be documented with attendance records.

name: Implement Weekly Safety Interlock Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory preventive maintenance schedule requiring all machine safety interlocks on injection molding equipment to be inspected weekly by maintenance technicians. Inspection will include visual assessment, functional testing, and solenoid continuity checks. Results will be documented in the CMMS system with alerts generated for any devices showing degradation. This proactive approach addresses the root cause of worn solenoids and prevents future failures that could expose operators to entanglement hazards.

name: Enhance Operator Pre-Shift Equipment Verification
