description: Develop and distribute a standardized pre-shift checklist for all injection molding operators that specifically includes testing machine safety interlocks before production begins. Training will be provided to all 45+ operators working on Lines B through D. The checklist will be posted at each machine and completed daily, with sign-off required. This administrative control empowers operators to catch interlock issues early and reinforces a culture of equipment accountability.

name: Install Physical Thermal Barriers in Chemical Storage
description: Install insulated thermal barriers around all heating elements in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility to prevent direct heat exposure to flammable materials. Barriers will be constructed from non-combustible materials (ceramic fiber blankets rated for 600°C+) and will maintain minimum 30 cm clearance between heat source and any stored chemicals. All heating elements will be equipped with thermostat cutoffs set to maximum safe temperature of 35°C. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the hazard.

name: Revise Chemical Storage Layout and Standard Operating Procedures
description: Develop and implement a new facility layout diagram for chemical storage that establishes mandatory exclusion zones around all heat-generating equipment. Update SOPs to require monthly verification inspections by HSE staff and quarterly re-training for all personnel with access to the chemical storage area. Include specific guidance on segregation of incompatible materials, proper ventilation requirements, and emergency response procedures.

name: Relocate Forklift Battery Charging Station Away from Flammable Materials
description: Relocate the forklift battery charging station to a dedicated, isolated area in the Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-025) with proper fire suppression systems, ventilation, and thermal management. The new charging station will be equipped with individual battery temperature monitoring devices set to alarm at 55°C and auto-shutoff at 65°C. Maintain minimum 50-meter separation between charging area and solvent/flammable material storage. This engineering control eliminates the primary ignition source from proximity to flammable materials.

name: Implement Hazardous Material Segregation Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a mandatory segregation protocol requiring acetone-based solvents and other Class B flammables to be stored in a dedicated, climate-controlled cabinet located in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-019) separate from raw material warehousing. Install absorbent mat dispenser stations at the warehouse and update signage. Conduct mandatory training for all warehouse staff and forklift operators on proper material segregation, with refresher training quarterly.

name: Upgrade Fire Detection and Suppression Systems
description: Install additional thermal detection sensors in warehouse storage areas and upgrade the automated sprinkler system with pre-action capabilities that will activate earlier in thermal events. Add portable fire extinguishers (ABC-rated, 20 lbs minimum) at 10-meter intervals throughout the warehouse and ensure all personnel receive WHMIS-compliant fire extinguisher training. Conduct annual system testing and maintenance.

name: Install Temperature Warning Labels and Cool-Down Indicators
description: Apply high-visibility thermal warning labels on all injection molding equipment indicating safe-touch temperatures and cool-down times. Install LED temperature indicators on critical mold surfaces that change color when equipment reaches safe handling temperatures (below 40°C). This engineering control will provide immediate visual feedback to operators about equipment temperature status, reducing burn hazards. Expected outcome: 85% reduction in thermal contact injuries within 6 months.

name: Enhance Thermal Burn Prevention Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive thermal safety training module for all production operators covering mold temperature management, proper cool-down procedures, and personal protective equipment requirements. Include hands-on demonstrations using infrared thermometers to help operators understand actual temperature ranges of equipment. Conduct quarterly refresher training sessions. This administrative control ensures all staff understand thermal hazards and proper mitigation strategies.

name: Implement Mandatory Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Protocol Enhancement
description: Establish strict lockout/tagout procedures requiring ALL equipment to be de-energized and locked out before any manual hopper clearing or maintenance operations begin. Install energy isolation locks on all injection molding lines with clear LOTO point identification. Require dual-operator confirmation and LOTO checklist sign-off before any maintenance work. Conduct immediate retraining of all maintenance staff on LOTO procedures per CNESST standards. This eliminates the root cause of unexpected equipment restart during maintenance.

name: Install Hopper Guard Safety Interlock System
description: Engineer and install mechanical safety interlocks on all material hoppers that prevent auger rotation when hopper access panels are opened. Add emergency stop buttons within arm's reach of hopper areas with high-visibility red covers. Install perimeter guarding around hopper feed mechanisms with restricted access points. This engineering control eliminates pinch point exposure during hopper maintenance.

name: Establish Communication Protocol for Night Shift Maintenance
description: Create formalized maintenance communication log system requiring maintenance planners to document all ongoing work to night shift supervisors via shift handoff meetings. Implement color-coded equipment status tags (Green=Ready to Operate, Red=Under Maintenance, Yellow=Caution). Conduct daily 15-minute safety huddles at shift transitions with equipment status review. This administrative control ensures maintenance awareness across all shifts and prevents unexpected equipment operation during maintenance.

name: Enforce Mandatory PPE Compliance in Chemical Storage Area
description: Conduct immediate audit of chemical storage area PPE compliance and issue formal reminder to all personnel requiring long sleeves, gloves, and eye protection when handling solvents and cleaning agents. Install PPE vending station at storage mezzanine entrance with mandatory sign-off checklist. Implement weekly compliance inspections with photographic documentation. Deploy supervisory reminders during toolbox talks. This administrative control ensures consistent protective equipment use during chemical handling.

name: Implement Mandatory Lockout/Tagout Enforcement
description: Establish a strict lockout/tagout protocol requiring equipment de-energization before any maintenance or clearing operations on injection molding lines. Install conspicuous warning tags at all equipment access points and conduct monthly LOTO compliance audits. All supervisors must sign off on LOTO compliance before operations resume. Create a disciplinary policy for LOTO violations. Expected outcome: elimination of equipment-related crush and amputation incidents through verified de-energization.

name: Design and Install Hopper Safety Guards
description: Engineering redesign of injection molding line hoppers to include protective barriers that prevent hand access to rotating auger mechanisms while still allowing material loading and jam removal using only provided tools. Install mechanical interlocks that prevent auger rotation when access panels are opened. Replace all wooden clearing rods with industry-standard non-conductive polymer tools with length restrictions.

name: Enhanced Machine Operator Training Program
description: Develop comprehensive, scenario-based training for all injection molding operators covering emergency hopper clearing procedures using only approved methods with equipment de-energized. Include hands-on demonstrations with mock equipment and regular refresher training every 6 months. Document training completion and competency assessment for all personnel. Add specific instruction on recognizing time-pressure situations and when to request assistance.

name: Reorganize Chemical Storage and Material Flow Layout
description: Complete redesign of the warehouse layout to physically separate raw material pathways from chemical storage areas using permanent barriers or designated buffer zones. Install clear floor markings, directional signage, and one-way traffic patterns for material handling equipment. Ensure minimum 10-foot clearance around all chemical storage areas. Install convex mirrors at sharp turns and add reflective edge protection to all fixed obstacles.

name: Material Handler Safety Training and Certification
description: Implement mandatory forklift and pallet jack operator certification including load stability, speed management on turns, blind spot awareness, and emergency procedures. Require initial certification plus annual recertification with practical driving assessment. Include scenario training for handling loads near chemical storage. All material handlers must pass written and practical exams before operating equipment.

name: Implement Chemical Container Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a weekly inspection routine for all chemical storage containers to identify defective caps, cracks, or leaks before they cause spills. Personnel will use a standardized checklist and document findings in a maintenance log. Containers showing signs of damage will be immediately replaced or relocated to secondary containment. This engineering and administrative control will prevent similar incidents by catching problems early before they result in environmental or health hazards.

name: Upgrade Mezzanine Ventilation System
description: Install additional exhaust fans and improve air circulation on the storage mezzanine to better manage solvent vapors and prevent vapor accumulation. The current ventilation system is inadequate for the volume of chemical storage in that space. Enhanced ventilation will reduce exposure risk and provide better air quality for personnel working in the area. Installation includes ductwork, fans, and damper controls with a target air exchange rate of 8-10 times per hour.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring Locks on Mold Equipment
description: Implement automated temperature monitoring systems on all injection molding equipment that prevent operation until molds cool to safe handling temperatures (below 50°C). Visual indicators and audible alerts will notify operators when molds reach safe touch temperature. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of accidental contact with hot mold surfaces by preventing maintenance work during active heating cycles and ensuring adequate cooling verification before work begins.

name: Enhance Burn Prevention Training and PPE Upgrades
description: Conduct comprehensive retraining on mold maintenance safety procedures with emphasis on thermal hazard recognition and safe work practices. Upgrade all operator work gloves to high-temperature resistant gloves rated for 150°C contact. Provide additional training on first aid response for thermal burns including proper cooling techniques and wound care. This combines administrative controls (training) with PPE improvements to reduce incident severity and improve immediate response.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays for Chemical Dispensers
description: Engineering control to prevent chemical splashes during maintenance and normal operations. Secondary containment trays will be installed beneath all mold release agent dispensers on Lines A through D. These trays will capture any spills or overspray before they contact skin. Trays will be emptied daily and inspected for cracks. This directly addresses the root cause of inadequate containment infrastructure during the incident.

name: Mandatory PPE Protocol for Mold Release Agent Handling
description: Administrative control establishing that all personnel working with mold release agents must wear nitrile gloves and arm protection sleeves rated for chemical splash. Training will be conducted for all machine setters and operators on proper PPE donning/doffing procedures. A laminated poster will be installed at each machine station. Monthly compliance audits will be performed by the HSE team. This creates an additional barrier while engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification and Audit Program
description: Administrative and training control to ensure strict adherence to lockout/tagout procedures. All production and regrind operators will complete formal CNESST-compliant LOTO certification with hands-on practical assessment. Monthly audits will be conducted on all equipment with rotating mechanical hazards. Supervisors will verify LOTO compliance before any maintenance activity begins. Non-compliance will result in immediate retraining. A new LOTO policy will clarify that equipment modifications must be submitted to maintenance through work orders only.

name: Install Mechanical Guard Barriers on Regrind System
description: Engineering control through permanent installation of protective guards around all accessible rotating components of the granulation system. Full-enclosure guards will be fitted to the conveyor screws, with access panels that require tool removal to open. Emergency stop buttons will be installed at multiple points around the equipment. This eliminates direct contact possibility with hazardous rotating parts.

name: Establish Equipment Maintenance Work Order System
description: Administrative control requiring all equipment maintenance requests to be submitted through a formal system to the Central Maintenance Workshop. No unauthorized maintenance will be permitted on production equipment. Operators will be trained to recognize mechanical issues and document them. Maintenance priority levels will ensure prompt response. Daily shift briefings will review pending maintenance items. This ensures trained technicians handle all equipment modifications.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Procedures for All Machine Maintenance
description: Establish and enforce a comprehensive lockout/tagout (LOTO) protocol requiring all personnel to isolate energy sources before performing any maintenance, cleaning, or adjustment activities on injection molding equipment. All operators and maintenance technicians will receive hands-on LOTO certification training within 14 days. A visual LOTO station will be established at each production line with clearly marked energy isolation points and lockout devices. Supervisors will conduct daily pre-shift LOTO audits to verify compliance. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the hazard of unexpected machine startup during maintenance.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Safety Sensors
description: Develop and implement a rigorous preventive maintenance program requiring all proximity sensors and safety interlocks on injection molding machines to be inspected, tested, and calibrated every 6 months by qualified maintenance personnel. A digital tracking system will log all maintenance activities and generate automatic alerts when calibrations are due. Maintenance logs will be reviewed monthly during JHSC meetings. This engineering control ensures that all safety-critical sensors function reliably to prevent accidental machine activation during maintenance operations.

name: Upgrade Machine Guarding on Injection Molding Lines
description: Install additional physical guards and barriers around all hydraulic injection platens and mold frame interfaces on Lines A, B, C, and D to create a secondary containment layer that prevents worker access to pinch points during operation. Guards will include polycarbonate shields with proper ventilation to maintain production visibility while providing physical isolation. This engineering control provides a fail-safe protective barrier independent of electronic interlocks and human compliance with procedures.

name: Replace All Corroded Hose Connections with Stainless Steel Fittings
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all chemical transfer hoses and connection points in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Replace all corroded, damaged, or standard steel fittings with corrosion-resistant stainless steel fittings rated for the specific chemical compatibility of each system. Establish a quarterly inspection protocol for all connections with photographic documentation. Technicians will use calibrated torque wrenches to ensure all fittings are properly tightened to manufacturer specifications. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the hose failure and prevents future spills from equipment degradation.

name: Install Secondary Containment System in Chemical Storage Area
description: Design and install a comprehensive secondary containment system beneath all bulk chemical storage drums and transfer stations in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The system will include impermeable polyethylene-lined containment trays with a capacity of at least 110% of the largest storage container. All transfer operations will be conducted within the containment area. Emergency spill kits will be stationed at each transfer point with absorbent materials, neutralizing agents, and personal protective equipment. This engineering control provides a protective barrier to prevent releases from reaching environmental receptors.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Temperature Controllers
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection and calibration protocol for all injection molding machine temperature controllers. Create a priority tracking system that prevents deferral of safety-critical maintenance items due to production demands. Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux will coordinate with Operations Manager Guillaume Deschamps to ensure maintenance windows are protected in the production schedule. All temperature controllers will be tested within 30 days to establish baseline conditions. Expected outcome: elimination of temperature-related burn hazards through proactive equipment maintenance.

name: Enhance Thermal PPE Requirements for Mold Handling
description: Issue updated high-temperature resistant gloves rated to 250°C for all operators handling injection molds. Current gloves are only rated to 150°C. Conduct mandatory training on proper PPE selection, inspection, and replacement procedures. Supply inventory will be maintained in UNIT-002 with quarterly rotation. All Line D operators will be fitted and trained within 7 days. Expected outcome: additional thermal protection while preventive maintenance measures take effect.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Ventilation System
description: Install secondary exhaust ventilation with localized capture hoods directly above chemical storage shelving in UNIT-010. Current ventilation is general room-level only. New system will include activated carbon filters rated for epoxy fumes and include real-time monitoring of vapor concentration with automatic alarm activation. Installation will be completed by external HVAC specialist. System will be tested and certified within compliance standards before operational use. Expected outcome: reduction of chemical vapor exposure to safe levels during normal operations and minor spills.

name: Implement Secondary Containment for Large Chemical Containers
description: Install spill containment trays beneath all shelving units holding containers larger than 10 liters in UNIT-010. Trays will have minimum 110% capacity of the largest container stored above. Additionally, implement retaining straps and securing brackets for all containers on elevated storage. Conduct training for all personnel accessing chemical storage on proper container handling, securing procedures, and spill response protocols. Expected outcome: containment of spills at point of origin, prevention of floor-level spreading and vapor concentration.

name: Establish Chemical Storage Inspection and Compliance Protocol
description: Create weekly inspection checklist for UNIT-010 chemical storage areas to verify container caps are secure, shelving is organized per safety standards, and no expired materials are stored. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois will lead training for Materials Management staff on proper inspection procedures. Results will be logged and reviewed monthly by HSE Director. Any non-compliance findings will be corrected within 48 hours. Expected outcome: systematic prevention of storage-related chemical incidents through routine oversight.

name: Establish Material Weight Handling Limits and Mechanical Assist Requirements
description: Issue facility-wide procedure requiring that any material exceeding 20 kilograms must be moved using mechanical assistance (overhead cranes, forklifts, or material handling equipment). Implement clear labeling on all molds and assemblies indicating weight and required handling method. Conduct mandatory training for all production and maintenance personnel on proper body mechanics, weight limitations, and available equipment. Training will be delivered by occupational health consultant and documented. Expected outcome: elimination of manual handling of heavy materials through engineering and administrative controls.

name: Optimize Night Shift Staffing and Equipment Availability
description: Review night shift operations to ensure sufficient personnel and equipment availability to support production schedules without creating unsafe workarounds. Establish protocol that production scheduling must coordinate with maintenance department for equipment (crane) availability and staffing levels. Operations Manager Guillaume Deschamps will work with night shift supervisors to identify resource constraints and implement solutions such as scheduling adjustments or temporary staffing increases during peak periods. Expected outcome: elimination of time-pressure driven unsafe practices through proper resource allocation.

name: Implement Ergonomic Assessment and Workstation Redesign for UNIT-013
description: Conduct professional ergonomic assessment of all material handling tasks in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. Identify opportunities for workstation redesign, equipment repositioning, or process modification to reduce manual handling demands. Install mechanical assist devices (portable hoists, pneumatic lifts) at key workstations to support safe material movement. Prioritize tasks currently performed by night shift operations due to limited staffing and supervision. Expected outcome: systematic reduction of back injury risk through engineering-based ergonomic improvements.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly inspection program for all hydraulic systems across production lines using thermographic imaging and visual inspection protocols. This will identify deteriorating hoses and connections before failure occurs. Inspections will be documented in the maintenance management system and tracked by the Maintenance and Engineering department. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in hydraulic leaks within 12 months.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays Under High-Risk Equipment
description: Design and install stainless steel drip trays beneath all injection molding equipment with hydraulic systems operating above 150°C. Trays will have 110% capacity of maximum fluid volume in connected systems. This engineering control will prevent hydraulic fluid from reaching electrical components and production floor surfaces. Installation will occur during scheduled maintenance windows on each production line.

name: Mandatory Refresher Training on Load Handling and Equipment Updates
description: Implement mandatory quarterly training sessions for all material handlers covering current load specifications, weight categories, and proper pallet jack operation techniques. Training will be delivered by the Training Coordinator and documented in employee files. All materials handlers will complete the training within 30 days. Sessions will include practical demonstrations and testing to ensure competency. Expected outcome: Increased awareness of hazards and proper handling procedures.

name: Replace and Maintain Pallet Jack Fleet
description: Conduct immediate inspection of all 15 pallet jacks in the warehouse. Replace worn or damaged units with new hydraulic models featuring enhanced load stability and braking systems. Implement a preventive maintenance schedule with monthly inspections and documentation. Assign responsibility to Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher. All pallet jacks will be tagged with inspection dates and maintenance history. This engineering control will reduce equipment failure and associated injuries.

name: Install Mechanical Lift Assist Equipment in Warehouse
description: Procure and install two powered pallet lift trucks in high-volume resin staging areas to eliminate manual handling of loads exceeding 500 kg. This substitution control will remove the primary hazard. Operators will receive certified training. Installation will be completed in the Raw Materials Warehouse Section A within 45 days. Expected outcome: 80% reduction in manual heavy lifting incidents.

name: Install Interlocked Safety Guard at Conveyor Jam-Clearing Access
description: Design and fabricate a hinged, interlocked safety guard for the shrink-wrap sealing station that prevents conveyor operation when the access panel is opened. The guard will feature an electromechanical interlock connected to the conveyor control system. Installation will be completed by the Maintenance Workshop within 21 days. This engineering control eliminates the pinch point hazard during maintenance operations. The interlock will require supervisor override authentication to bypass, ensuring intentional activation only.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Inspections
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule for all injection molding machines' cooling water systems to be inspected every 90 days. Inspections will include visual assessment for cracks, proper connection torque verification, and coolant integrity testing. Maintenance technicians will document findings in the predictive maintenance database. This proactive approach will identify developing issues before they create safety hazards or operational failures.

name: Install Drip Trays Under All Injection Machines
description: Install secondary containment drip trays beneath all 32 injection molding machines to capture cooling water and hydraulic fluid leaks before they reach the production floor. Each tray will have a capacity of 5 gallons and drain plugs for easy disposal. This engineering control will prevent slip hazards and environmental contamination while allowing operators to continue work safely during minor leaks until maintenance can address the source.

name: Establish Mandatory Forklift Pre-Operation Inspection Protocol
description: Implement daily pre-operation checklists for all forklifts (electric and propane) to be completed by operators at the start of each shift. Checklists will include hydraulic fluid level verification, visual inspection of hoses and connections for leaks or damage, test of lift and lower functions, and brake responsiveness. Any deficiencies will immediately remove the equipment from service. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante will maintain a log of all inspections and failed equipment, with monthly reviews to identify patterns.

name: Replace Hydraulic Systems on All Forklifts
description: Conduct complete hydraulic system overhauls on all warehouse forklifts within 60 days. Replace worn hoses, seals, and valves proactively rather than waiting for failure. Upgrade lift mechanisms to newer models with redundant safety systems that prevent sudden load drops. All work will be performed by certified hydraulic technicians. This engineering control eliminates the specific failure mode that caused this incident and reduces overall equipment failure risk.

name: Install Load-Catching Safety Nets Under Storage Racks
description: Install secondary containment safety nets beneath elevated storage racks in the warehouse to catch dropped materials before they reach ground level. These engineered nets will be rated for 1,000-pound loads and will prevent materials from striking personnel or equipment below. This mitigation will reduce injury risk even if a second equipment failure occurs.

name: Implement Equipment-Specific Maintenance Log System
description: Transition from manual maintenance schedules to a digital predictive maintenance system that tracks service history for all CNC machines, injection molders, and material handling equipment. The system will automatically generate maintenance alerts based on equipment runtime hours and historical failure patterns. Maintenance Manager Carlos Rodriguez will oversee implementation. Each piece of equipment will have a unique identifier and maintenance record stored in the system, ensuring no critical maintenance intervals are missed.

name: Replace All Spindle Belts on CNC Machines
description: Conduct immediate replacement of spindle drive belts on all CNC milling machines in the workshop as an emergency preventive measure. Establish a new replacement schedule: belts will be replaced every 6 months or 1,000 operating hours, whichever comes first. Stock a dedicated inventory of replacement belts to minimize downtime. Maintenance technicians will document all replacements with dates and serial numbers to track performance and identify any supplier quality issues.

name: Provide Personal Protective Equipment Upgrade for Maintenance Staff
description: Issue comprehensive PPE packages to all maintenance personnel working with machinery, including reinforced work vests and shoulder guards to protect against whipping belt and high-velocity object hazards. Conduct training on proper PPE selection for different machine maintenance tasks. PPE will be stored at each maintenance workstation for immediate availability during emergency repairs.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protection Equipment
description: Implement heat-resistant gloves rated for 250°C continuous contact to replace standard production gloves. Gloves will be made from aramid fiber with silicone coating, providing superior thermal insulation. All Line A and Line B operators will be trained on proper donning/doffing procedures and glove inspection protocols. A 6-month replacement schedule will be established based on visible wear. Expected outcome: Reduce thermal burn incidents by 85% and provide employees with adequate protection against mold-related burns during routine operations.

name: Install Mold Temperature Warning System
description: Install digital temperature sensors and visual warning lights on both injection molding lines to display real-time mold surface temperatures. Warning lights will activate when mold temperature exceeds 170°C, alerting operators to exercise caution and use appropriate protective equipment. System will be integrated into existing production monitoring displays. Maintenance procedures will be documented for weekly sensor calibration checks. This engineering control will provide continuous hazard awareness without relying solely on employee memory or training compliance.

name: Mandatory Heat Safety Refresher Training
description: Conduct immediate refresher training for all Production Operators covering thermal hazard recognition, proper use of thermal protection equipment, and first aid for thermal burns. Training will include hands-on demonstration of glove effectiveness and practice scenarios. Documentation will be maintained in employee training files. All operators will complete assessment quiz to verify comprehension. Additional signage will be posted at each molding line displaying burn prevention procedures and emergency contact numbers for medical assistance.

name: Implement Mandatory Hydraulic Line Replacement Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring replacement of all hydraulic coupling fittings every 5 years maximum, with interim inspection at 3-year mark. Create a computerized tracking system to flag equipment requiring replacement based on installation date. Maintenance supervisors will receive training on hydraulic system risks and importance of adherence to replacement schedule. All existing fittings will be inventoried and flagged for replacement if exceeding 5-year mark. Expected outcome: Eliminate coupling failures due to material degradation and reduce chemical burns/spill incidents from hydraulic line failures by 90%.

name: Install Pressure Relief Barriers and Secondary Containment
description: Install polycarbonate shields around all high-pressure hydraulic coupling points to contain spray in event of rupture. Position secondary containment trays beneath all maintenance work areas where pressurized hydraulic lines are serviced. Shields will allow visibility while providing worker protection. Containment trays will capture spilled fluid for proper disposal per environmental regulations. Maintenance technicians will complete training on new barrier systems and spill response procedures. System will be inspected monthly for cracks or degradation.

name: Enhance Lockout/Tagout Procedures for Hydraulic Maintenance
description: Revise LOTO procedures to mandate complete pressure relief and line purging before any maintenance on hydraulic systems. Add requirement for two-person verification that pressure has been relieved using pressure gauges. Implement checklist system where maintenance technician and supervisor both sign off on pressure relief completion. Add annual LOTO certification training with emphasis on hydraulic system hazards. Create quick-reference guide cards for posting at all maintenance stations. This administrative control ensures hydraulic energy is fully dissipated before workers contact pressurized lines.

name: Establish Comprehensive Equipment Inspection and Certification Program
description: Implement a mandatory annual inspection and certification program for all overhead cranes, gantry systems, and lifting equipment. Inspections will be performed by certified third-party inspectors qualified to CAN/CSA standard B167. Create a centralized tracking system with inspection dates, certification expiry, and required maintenance. Email reminders will be sent 60 days before certification expiry. All equipment will be tagged with visible certification labels. Non-certified equipment will be immediately removed from service. Expected outcome: Eliminate equipment failures due to deferred maintenance and reduce near-miss incidents by 95%.

name: Install Load Monitoring and Emergency Load Drop Systems
description: Retrofit overhead cranes with modern load monitoring systems including load cells that detect abnormal weight distribution or cable stress conditions. Install emergency load-lowering mechanisms that automatically engage if cable tension anomalies are detected. Add visual and audible alarms to alert operators to equipment malfunctions before failure occurs. Install secondary safety cables as backup load support on all critical lifting points. Operators will receive training on new monitoring system indicators and emergency procedures.

name: Implement Exclusion Zones and Load Path Management
description: Mark all overhead crane paths with floor tape and signage establishing exclusion zones directly beneath lifting operations. Reorganize warehouse layout to ensure no employee work areas fall directly under crane operation paths. Install height-adjustable warning barriers that activate when loads are suspended above warehouse floor. Create standard operating procedures requiring all personnel to vacate exclusion zones before crane operation begins. Conduct daily pre-shift briefings where warehouse supervisor reviews that day's material movement schedule and identifies personnel and exclusion zones.

name: Implement Mandatory Deburring Verification Process
description: Establish a documented quality control checkpoint requiring visual and tactile inspection of all molded components before assembly operations. Assembly operators will be trained to use standardized inspection templates and touch-safe test strips to verify edge finish compliance. All parts failing inspection will be quarantined and routed back to the finishing department. This administrative control will be integrated into the shift startup procedures and monitored daily by quality supervisors to ensure 100% compliance before components reach assembly stations.

name: Schedule Preventive Maintenance for Edge Finishing System
description: Conduct comprehensive preventive maintenance on the automated edge finishing equipment to restore full operational capacity and eliminate the backlog that caused the incident. Maintenance technician will perform bearing inspection, brush replacement, and calibration. Schedule regular weekly inspections going forward to prevent similar equipment downtime. Parts will be processed through the system continuously during operations to eliminate manual handling of unfinished components with sharp edges.

name: Replace Resin Dryer Thermostat Control System
description: Install a new digital thermostat controller with dual-redundant temperature sensors and an alarm threshold set at 165°C. The replacement system will include automatic shutoff capability if temperature exceeds the setpoint by more than 5 degrees. Technician will also perform calibration verification and document all settings in the equipment maintenance log. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of temperature overshooting and prevents future thermal runaway scenarios that could trigger fires or create burn hazards for operators working nearby.

name: Establish Monthly Thermal Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Create and document a mandatory monthly inspection schedule for all high-temperature processing equipment including the resin dryer, industrial ovens, and mixing vessel heaters. Inspections will include visual assessment for visible damage, infrared thermography to detect hot spots, and functional testing of all temperature control systems. Results will be logged in a centralized equipment maintenance database. Maintenance Planner will review logs quarterly and flag any equipment showing degradation trends for preventive component replacement before failures occur. This administrative control provides early warning of potential thermal runaway incidents.

name: Install Accumulator Isolation Valves on All Hydraulic Systems
description: Engineering control: Install ball valve isolation points on all high-pressure hydraulic lines serving injection molding equipment to allow technicians to isolate sections for maintenance without de-pressurizing entire systems. Additionally, install pressure relief accumulators downstream of isolation points to safely bleed residual pressure. All technicians will be trained on the new isolation procedures. This engineering control eliminates the high-pressure injection hazard by ensuring technicians can work on isolated, depressurized sections only. Implementation will address hydraulic lines on all 32 molding machines within 60 days.

name: Implement Enhanced LOTO Procedures for Hydraulic Systems
description: Revise and document comprehensive Lockout/Tagout procedures specific to hydraulic systems, requiring mandatory pressure gauge verification at three points during lockout sequence. Create a color-coded LOTO station in the maintenance workshop with clearly labeled hydraulic line isolation tags. Require all maintenance personnel to complete refresher training on the new procedures within 30 days. Add audit checkpoints to verify proper lockout execution before any maintenance work begins. This administrative control strengthens the procedural layer of protection against pressurized system exposure.

name: Provide Specialized Puncture-Resistant Protective Equipment
description: Issue specialized cut-resistant and puncture-resistant gloves (Level 5 cut protection, rated for impact and pressure hazards) to all maintenance technicians working on hydraulic systems. These gloves provide enhanced protection against injection injury from high-pressure fluid streams. Establish a replacement protocol so gloves are replaced every 30 days or immediately if damaged. While PPE is the lowest-order control, it provides an additional layer of defense while engineering and administrative controls are being implemented.

name: Ergonomic Workstation Redesign for Line A
description: Implement comprehensive ergonomic assessment and redesign of Injection Molding Line A workstations. Install height-adjustable work platforms to accommodate proper wrist alignment, reducing deviation during part extraction. Add padded grip handles and part removal tools to minimize repetitive gripping force. Introduce job rotation schedule requiring operators to switch tasks every 2 hours between part removal, quality inspection, and packaging duties. This multi-control approach addresses root causes: inadequate workstation design, repetitive strain, and lack of activity variation.

name: Implement Mandatory Break and Rotation Program
description: Establish formal program requiring 10-minute break every 90 minutes for Line A operators, during which employees perform hand and wrist stretching exercises guided by physical therapist-approved protocols. Institute mandatory 2-hour job rotation between high-repetition tasks and lower-strain activities. Track participation through shift logs and monitor for early signs of cumulative strain injuries through quarterly health screening questionnaires.

name: Ergonomics Training and Awareness Campaign
description: Develop and deliver specialized ergonomics training for all injection molding operators covering proper wrist positioning, early warning signs of repetitive strain injuries, correct use of mechanical assists and tools, and self-care techniques. Include monthly toolbox talks focusing on specific ergonomic challenges for each production line. Distribute illustrated guides in French and English at each workstation.

name: Install Enhanced Dust Collection and Ventilation System
description: Replace existing ventilation system with upgraded industrial-grade dust collection equipment specifically designed for composite material processing. Install HEPA filtration with automatic pulse-jet cleaning cycles and real-time particulate monitoring sensors. Add dedicated exhaust ducting from all high-dust-generation areas directly to exterior vents. Include backup power supply for critical ventilation components. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard (dust accumulation) through source capture and removal.

name: Implement Daily Housekeeping and Dust Control Protocol
description: Establish mandatory daily cleaning procedures for the Composite Materials Processing Area, including: dry sweeping at shift start/end using non-sparking tools, wet mopping of all work surfaces to suppress airborne dust, and disposal of composite waste in sealed, non-combustible containers. Assign responsibility rotation among technicians with documented daily sign-off. Include weekly deep cleaning of ventilation ducts and equipment surfaces. Deploy portable HEPA vacuum units equipped with explosion-proof motors for fine dust collection.

name: Upgrade Fire Detection and Suppression Systems
description: Install advanced multi-sensor fire detection system (combination thermal and optical detectors) with response time under 60 seconds. Upgrade to Class D fire suppression system suitable for metal and composite material fires. Install additional ABC-rated fire extinguishers rated for composite material fires at strategic locations. Conduct quarterly fire suppression system inspections and monthly fire drills specific to composite processing hazards. Establish dedicated fire watch protocols during oven operations.

name: Install Non-Slip Countertop Surfaces in Break Room
description: Replace existing cafeteria countertops with commercial-grade non-slip laminate surfaces with textured finish to reduce likelihood of slipping when wet. Install drain channels in beverage preparation zones to direct spilled liquids away from work surfaces. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the incident (wet surface leading to kettle tip-over) through environmental modification.

name: Implement Flammable Materials Storage Protocol
description: Establish designated storage areas for all flammable liquids (mold release agents, solvents, adhesives) with secondary containment systems rated for 150% of container volume. Install clearly marked signage and implement a chemical inventory management system requiring daily inspection of storage areas. All flammable materials must be stored minimum 15 meters from heat sources, open flames, and high-temperature equipment. Conduct mandatory training for all production staff on proper handling, storage, and emergency procedures for flammable materials.

name: Upgrade Fire Suppression Equipment in Composite Area
description: Install three additional Class B fire extinguishers positioned strategically around the composite processing area, ensuring every work zone is within 10 meters of an extinguisher. Mount extinguishers at easily accessible height (1.2-1.5 meters) with clear signage. Install an automatic fire suppression system (wet chemical) above the high-temperature curing ovens. Conduct quarterly fire safety drills specific to composite materials hazards with all personnel working in UNIT-015.

name: Establish Secondary Containment System in Material Prep Area
description: Install secondary containment basins beneath all hydraulic lines, pumps, and connections in UNIT-016. Containment capacity must equal 150% of the largest single container volume on-site. Ensure containment areas slope toward a collection sump with manual valve control. Install absorbent pads and spill kits in clearly marked locations. Implement daily visual inspections of all hydraulic connections with a log maintained by the shift supervisor. Train all personnel on proper spill response procedures and disposal requirements.

name: Accelerate Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Review all pending hydraulic maintenance work orders and prioritize completion within 30 days. Replace all hydraulic line couplings identified as corroded or beyond service life specifications. Implement a quarterly hydraulic system inspection schedule with documented findings. Establish an automated notification system that alerts maintenance supervisors when work orders remain pending beyond 14 days. Integrate hydraulic system inspections into the facility's predictive maintenance monitoring system to identify degradation before failures occur.

name: Upgrade Machine Safety Interlocks with Dual-Verification System
description: Install supplementary pressure verification sensors on all injection molding machines that provide independent confirmation of zero-pressure status. The safety interlock must require both electrical confirmation (microswitch) AND hydraulic pressure sensor reading below 5 PSI before allowing personnel access. Install a secondary visual indicator (red light) that remains active until actual pressure reaches safe levels. This dual-verification approach prevents reliance on any single sensor that could malfunction. Retrofit Injection Molding Line B immediately, with completion of all 32 molding machines within 60 days.

name: Implement Enhanced LOTO Verification Procedure and Training
description: Revise LOTO procedures to require manual pressure gauge verification by two personnel before any maintenance work begins. Create a pre-maintenance checklist that must be completed and signed by both the technician and supervisor. Add a mandatory 5-minute observation period after pressure relief is applied to confirm stable zero pressure readings. Conduct refresher LOTO training for all production and maintenance staff within 14 days, with emphasis on pressure relief valve function and failure modes. Establish monthly LOTO audits with documented findings shared at safety committee meetings.

name: Schedule Preventive Maintenance for All Pressure Relief Valves
description: Conduct immediate inspection and testing of pressure relief valves on all 32 injection molding machines and ancillary hydraulic systems. Replace any valves showing signs of wear, corrosion, or response delay greater than 2 seconds. Establish a quarterly testing protocol where pressure relief valves are inspected under load to ensure proper poppet function and response timing. Create a maintenance log documenting all valve servicing with dates and test results. Assign responsibility to maintenance technicians with oversight by Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance for Industrial Ovens
description: Install temperature monitoring sensors with automated alert systems on all 8 industrial ovens in the facility. Implement a preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly calibration checks and quarterly sensor replacements. Establish a protocol requiring immediate shutdown and inspection if any sensor reading deviates more than 5°C from expected setpoint. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of sensor failure leading to temperature excursion. Expected outcome: early detection of equipment anomalies before critical failures occur.

name: Establish Equipment Status Escalation Protocol
description: Create a documented procedure requiring operators to report any equipment readings outside normal range to their supervisor within 30 minutes. Supervisors must escalate findings to Maintenance within 2 hours if readings persist. Implement a daily equipment check log that must be signed off by shift supervisors. Train all production and materials staff on the new escalation procedure during next scheduled safety meeting. This administrative control ensures early identification and response to equipment malfunctions.

name: Upgrade Fire Suppression System Signage and Training
description: Install high-visibility emergency signage around the Material Drying and Preparation Room indicating location of fire suppression system manual override and emergency shutoff controls. Conduct refresher training for all day shift employees (120 personnel) on fire response procedures, evacuation routes, and system operation. Specifically train Materials Management and Warehousing staff on rapid evacuation procedures and assembly point locations. This ensures all personnel can effectively respond to future fire incidents.

name: Upgrade Machine Labeling and Hazard Identification
description: Install weatherproof hazard warning labels on all 32 injection molding machines indicating 'MOLD RELEASE AGENT PRESENT' and 'CHEMICAL SKIN IRRITANT' in both English and French. Include pictograms showing required PPE (nitrile gloves) and first aid response procedures. Ensure labels are placed at operator eye level on all high-contact surfaces including cooling jackets, mold clamps, and material feed areas. This engineering control provides immediate hazard communication to all operators.

name: Implement Mandatory PPE Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Establish a daily pre-shift PPE inspection requirement for all production operators. Operators must inspect gloves for tears, punctures, or chemical degradation before putting them on. Any damaged gloves must be immediately replaced from the supply station. Supervisors will conduct random weekly spot-checks of glove condition during shift. Upgrade to heavy-duty nitrile gloves (0.15mm thickness) specifically rated for mold release agent exposure. Track replacement frequency to identify problem areas.

name: Mandatory Full LOTO Compliance with Zero-Energy State Verification
description: Implement enhanced LOTO procedures requiring complete isolation of ALL energy sources (electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic, and thermal) before any maintenance work begins. Establish a three-point verification system: (1) operator performs zero-energy test on all systems, (2) supervisor independently verifies zero-energy state, (3) LOTO coordinator documents and affixes lockout tags. Install pressure gauges on all hydraulic systems to visually confirm zero pressure before work begins. This engineering and administrative control eliminates residual energy hazards.

name: Daily Pre-Shift LOTO Equipment Verification Program
description: Establish a mandatory daily pre-shift verification requirement where the LOTO coordinator must physically inspect all 32 injection molding machines to confirm proper lockout tag placement and integrity. Create a daily verification checklist with photographic documentation of each machine's lockout status. Implement a digital tracking system where supervisors must electronically confirm their shift machines are in proper LOTO status before production begins. Any discrepancies must be immediately reported to plant management.

name: Intensive LOTO Retraining and Certification Program
description: Conduct mandatory full-day retraining for all 120 day shift and 60 evening shift maintenance staff and machine operators on LOTO procedures, focusing on hydraulic system hazards and zero-energy verification. Include hands-on demonstration on each machine type with actual lockout and tag placement. Implement written certification exam with 90% minimum passing score. Require annual recertification and quarterly refresher sessions for all personnel. Track attendance and competency metrics.

name: Install Automatic Hydraulic Pressure Bleed-Down System
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with automatic pressure relief valves that bleed residual hydraulic pressure to atmosphere within 30 seconds of main power shutdown. This engineering control eliminates the root cause by ensuring zero hydraulic pressure state is automatically achieved. Install pressure indication lights on each machine that illuminate only when hydraulic system is pressurized, providing visual confirmation of energy state.

name: Implement Automated Spill Containment System
description: Install secondary containment trays with built-in spill barriers beneath all epoxy resin storage shelves in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. This engineering control will prevent large-volume spills from spreading across the floor and potentially contaminating multiple work areas. The system includes drip trays with 110% container capacity and collection sumps for rapid disposal. Installation will be completed within 45 days by the Maintenance department.

name: Mandatory Chemical Handling and Spill Response Retraining
description: Conduct comprehensive retraining for all personnel handling hazardous materials, focusing on proper grip techniques, container inspection procedures, and personal protective equipment requirements. This administrative control will ensure all composite materials technicians and chemical handlers understand the risks and proper protocols. Training will include hands-on demonstration of safe transfer techniques and spill containment procedures. All involved personnel must complete certification within 14 days.

name: Establish Monthly Chemical Storage Audit Program
description: Create a formal monthly inspection program for all chemical storage areas, including verification of shelf integrity, container condition assessment, and verification of PPE availability and condition. This administrative control will identify potential hazards before incidents occur. Audits will be documented and tracked by the HSE department, with corrective actions implemented within 48 hours of discovery.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Safety Interlocks
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule for all safety interlocks on injection molding equipment, including quarterly inspections instead of the previous 18-month interval. Implement IoT sensors on critical interlocks to provide real-time monitoring and alert maintenance staff to potential failures before they occur. This engineering control will eliminate the likelihood of safety system failures that could lead to unexpected machine activation. The system will be integrated with the existing maintenance management software.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification and Refresher Training
description: Require all production operators and maintenance personnel to complete comprehensive LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) certification within 14 days, with emphasis on proper procedures for emergency situations and the dangers of bypassing safety interlocks. This administrative control will ensure all personnel understand the critical importance of proper lockout procedures and the risks of equipment with compromised safety systems. Training will be documented and tracked.

name: Install Emergency Stop Button Upgrade on Line B
description: Upgrade the emergency stop (E-stop) button system on Injection Molding Line B with redundant safety circuits and improved tactile feedback to ensure immediate equipment shutdown in emergency situations. This engineering control provides an additional layer of protection against unintended machine operation. The upgrade will include installation of wireless E-stop capability for improved accessibility.

name: Establish Emergency Exit Zone Management Protocol
description: Implement a formal protocol requiring all warehouse personnel to maintain a minimum 1.8-meter clearance from all emergency exits and fire doors at all times. Install yellow floor markings delineating the required clearance zones and place warning signs in English and French. Create a weekly inspection checklist that must be completed and documented by the warehouse supervisor. This administrative control ensures sustained compliance with fire safety regulations and facility evacuation requirements.

name: Install Automated Emergency Exit Monitoring System
description: Install motion-sensor cameras and pressure-sensitive floor mats at all emergency exit routes to detect and alert facility management when clearance zones are violated. This engineering control provides real-time monitoring and prevention of exit obstruction. The system will integrate with the facility management system and send alerts to supervisory personnel when violations occur.

name: Implement Predictive Cooling System Maintenance Program
description: Establish a quarterly thermographic inspection protocol to identify stress points and potential fractures in all cooling water lines before failure occurs. Install ultrasonic flow rate monitors on critical circuits to detect pressure drops and leaks early. Replace high-risk copper tubing sections with reinforced stainless steel lines rated for thermal cycling stress. Train all operators on early warning signs of cooling system issues including unusual sounds, temperature fluctuations, and visual moisture accumulation. Document all findings in a centralized maintenance management system to track recurring issues by line.

name: Upgrade Clean Room Flooring with Slip-Resistant, Drainage-Ready Surface
description: Replace current smooth epoxy flooring in the medical components production area with high-grip, textured anti-slip flooring specifically designed for wet environments. Install strategically placed floor drains with check valves to prevent backflow contamination. The new surface will reduce water pooling and maintain slip resistance even when wet, directly addressing the dual hazard of contamination and fall risk. Material selection will maintain cleanroom certification standards while enhancing safety. Implementation will occur during a scheduled production shutdown.

name: Install Automated Deburring and Edge Breaking System
description: Procure and install a dedicated vibratory deburring machine equipped with ceramic media and polishing compounds to process all molded components before they reach quality control inspection. The automated system will remove burrs, sharp edges, and micro-defects that manual finishing processes miss. Integrate the system into the production workflow immediately after cooling. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source rather than relying on worker awareness. Train operators on proper batch size selection and cycle time parameters to ensure consistent edge quality for all component types.

name: Enhance Quality Control Workstation Lighting and Ergonomics
description: Upgrade inspection workstations with LED task lighting providing minimum 1000 lux illumination directly on component surfaces to enable detection of sharp edges and burrs before hand contact. Install adjustable magnifying lamps for detailed inspection work. Provide anti-cut protective finger cots and cut-resistant inspection gloves (level 3) to all quality control staff. Implement a daily tool rotation policy requiring workers to switch inspection stations every 2 hours to reduce fatigue from sustained focus. Conduct ergonomic assessment of all QC workstations to optimize workspace layout.

name: Install Load-Stabilizing Safety Equipment on All Storage Racks
description: Install heavy-duty load retention bars on every shelf of all material storage racks in the warehouse and material preparation areas. Apply high-friction anti-slip mats to all shelf surfaces to prevent box shifting. Install protective edge guards and safety bumpers at the perimeter of each rack to contain falling items. Paint weight capacity limits clearly on all shelves in large, visible lettering. Install overhead protective wire mesh screens above high-traffic areas beneath upper shelves to catch any items that do escape. These engineering controls directly prevent struck-by incidents from falling storage.

name: Implement Material Storage Procedures and Audits
description: Develop and deploy a comprehensive written material storage SOP specifying weight distribution requirements, maximum box heights per shelf, proper stacking orientation, and mandatory stability checks before personnel work near shelves. Conduct mandatory training for all warehouse and material handling staff on correct stacking procedures and the rationale behind weight distribution rules. Establish a daily storage audit checklist to be completed by warehouse leads, with spot audits by Safety team on a weekly basis. Create a reporting system for staff to flag questionable rack configurations immediately without fear of reprisal. Display visual diagrams showing correct vs. incorrect loading at each rack location.

name: Establish Zone Exclusion and Administrative Controls
description: Mark high-risk shelf zones (above 1.8 meters) with yellow and black hazard tape and prominent warning signage stating 'Caution: Falling Object Zone - Do Not Reach Above Head Height.' Implement a two-person material retrieval rule for items on upper shelves requiring one person to stabilize the rack while the other retrieves items. Create designated retrieval tools including grabbing poles with adjustable reach for accessing upper shelf items without overreaching. Rotate warehouse staff responsibilities quarterly to ensure no individual bears continuous repetitive exposure to high-reaching tasks. Document all changes in the facility safety manual.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Compliance Audit Program
description: Establish a comprehensive lockout/tagout compliance verification system with weekly audits of all injection molding machines conducted by the maintenance team. Create a production scheduling buffer to eliminate pressure to bypass LOTO procedures. Train all machine operators and supervisors on the legal and safety consequences of LOTO violations. Implement disciplinary procedures for non-compliance and reward compliance through safety incentive programs.

name: Install Presence-Sensing Safety Systems on High-Risk Injection Molding Machines
description: Retrofit injection molding machines #15-#20 with advanced presence-sensing safety devices and light curtains that prevent machine cycling when hands or objects are detected in danger zones. This engineering control will eliminate the possibility of unexpected mold clamp cycling during manual mold extraction operations. Conduct full safety validation testing post-installation.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule with Predictive Monitoring
description: Implement a comprehensive predictive maintenance program for all material drying equipment including monthly bearing inspections, lubrication audits, and quarterly thermography scans to detect early failure signs. Install IoT-enabled temperature sensors with real-time monitoring and automated alerts set at 130°C to provide advance warning. Maintain a critical parts inventory (motors, sensors, bearings) to eliminate supply chain delays.

name: Replace All Dryer Temperature Control Systems with Dual-Redundancy Design
description: Upgrade the Material Drying and Preparation Room dryers with redundant temperature sensor systems and backup automatic shutoff mechanisms. This engineering control ensures that if one sensor fails, the backup system provides continuous protection against overheating. All dryers will have independent over-temperature protection that cannot be disabled.

name: Replace All Chemical Transfer Hoses with FDA-Approved Chemical-Resistant Tubing
description: Eliminate all degraded hoses in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room and replace with high-grade PTFE-lined hoses rated for isocyanate and polyurethane resin compatibility. Implement a quarterly hose inspection and replacement program with documentation. All transfer systems will be upgraded to quick-disconnect couplings with secondary containment drip trays to capture any minor leaks before they escalate.

name: Implement Enhanced PPE Requirements and Fitting Protocol
description: Establish mandatory use of full-face shield chemical splash guards (in addition to safety glasses) for all chemical transfer operations. Conduct annual PPE fit testing for all employees in chemical handling roles to ensure proper sizing and comfort. Provide adjustable head straps and secure retention systems to prevent PPE slippage during operations. Store all PPE in designated lockers with replacement schedules to ensure integrity.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Automated Spill Response System
description: Engineer the chemical transfer station with comprehensive secondary containment (110% of largest container capacity) with sloped flooring directing any spills to a collection basin equipped with automated shutoff valves. Install an overhead emergency rinse system with foot-activated controls positioned within 2 meters of all transfer points, exceeding the current eyewash-only protocol.

name: Implement Pre-Maintenance Mold Inspection Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a mandatory checklist for all mold maintenance work that includes verification of mold temperature, complete residue removal, and PPE requirements. This will be reviewed daily by shift supervisors before any mold work begins. Training will be provided to all operators on Line B within 5 days, with monthly refresher sessions. The checklist will be posted at each mold maintenance station and digitally tracked in the production system to ensure compliance and create accountability records.

name: Upgrade Mold Maintenance Tool Kit with Safety Features
description: Replace all manual metal scrapers with ergonomic tools featuring guards and rounded edges to reduce laceration risk. Provide cut-resistant gloves (Level 4 protection) to all operators performing mold maintenance. Conduct a tool inventory audit across all production lines and ensure proper tool storage in designated kits. This upgrade addresses the engineering control hierarchy by providing safer equipment design and appropriate PPE for high-risk tasks.

name: Establish Latex-Free PPE Inventory System
description: Implement a comprehensive audit of all PPE inventory with a mandatory transition to 100% latex-free gloves (nitrile, vinyl, or synthetic alternatives) across all warehouse and production areas. Establish a par-level inventory system that triggers automatic reordering when nitrile glove stock drops below 30% of capacity. Create a database linking employee health profiles to required PPE types and ensure supervisors have real-time access to this information. Monthly inventory audits will verify compliance. This administrative and substitution control eliminates the latex hazard for sensitive employees.

name: Conduct Health Sensitivity Training for Supervisors
description: Provide mandatory training for all shift supervisors on recognizing allergic reactions, maintaining awareness of employee health profiles, and ensuring appropriate PPE availability. Training will include emergency response procedures for allergic reactions and documentation requirements. All supervisors will receive updated employee health sensitivity lists before each shift and acknowledge receipt. This administrative control ensures proactive identification and prevention of allergen exposures in the workplace.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Critical Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule for all drying ovens and critical processing equipment using thermal imaging, vibration analysis, and control system diagnostics. Schedule preventive maintenance at manufacturer-recommended intervals (quarterly for DVS-3000 models) regardless of production demands. Integrate maintenance scheduling into production planning software to ensure compliance. Install condition monitoring sensors on the Mocon DVS-3000 and similar equipment to provide early warning of component degradation. This engineering and administrative control prevents equipment failure by identifying issues before catastrophic breakdown occurs.

name: Replace Aged Drying Equipment with Modern Units
description: Procure and install two new Mocon DVS-4500 drying ovens with integrated redundancy and real-time remote monitoring capabilities. The new units feature dual heating elements, automatic failover systems, and cloud-based monitoring that alerts maintenance staff of anomalies 48 hours before potential failure. Equipment will be installed in parallel with existing units to maintain production capability during transition. This eliminates the aging equipment hazard through equipment substitution with modern, reliable technology featuring advanced safety and monitoring features.

name: Create Night Shift Equipment Monitoring Checklist
description: Develop a documented hourly equipment monitoring checklist for night shift operators to verify drying oven display responses, temperature stability, alarm system functionality, and visual indicators of normal operation. Checklist will be printed and posted at the equipment station with digital backup in the production tracking system. Night shift operators will initial checklist entries hourly and report any anomalies immediately to on-call maintenance. This administrative control ensures early detection of equipment problems and empowers night shift staff with clear procedures for equipment verification.

name: Mandatory LOTO Certification Renewal and Competency Assessment
description: Implement a comprehensive LOTO re-certification program for all machine setters and maintenance technicians. This will include hands-on competency testing, system-specific lockout procedures for each injection molding line, and emphasis on depressurization protocols for hydraulic systems. The program will be conducted by an external safety consultant and tracked in the employee development management system. All staff working on Lines A-D must complete certification within 30 days.

name: Install Automatic Pressure Relief Signage and Quick-Depressurization Stations
description: Install high-visibility warning signage at all hydraulic access points on injection molding equipment indicating pressure release procedures. Add accessible manual depressurization valves with clear labeling at each line. Implement a color-coded tagging system (yellow for pressurized, green for safe access). Conduct toolbox talks with all production staff on the new signage and procedures. This engineering and administrative control combination will reduce likelihood of residual pressure incidents.

name: Quarterly LOTO Audit Program with Enforcement Protocol
description: Establish a formal quarterly audit program where the HSE team will observe and document LOTO compliance on all production lines during scheduled maintenance windows. Non-compliance will result in immediate work stoppage, retraining, and potential disciplinary action. Create a digital checklist using mobile devices for real-time audit recording and trend analysis. Results will be reviewed at monthly JHSC meetings.

name: Implement Secondary Containment and Chemical Storage Reorganization
description: Install certified secondary containment trays under all volatile chemical storage areas with capacity equal to 110% of the largest container volume. Relocate all polyurethane resins and solvents to elevated shelving (minimum 18 inches above floor level) with drip containment. Implement color-coded labeling system and verify all container seals weekly. Create a chemical storage audit checklist and assign responsibility to the day shift supervisor. This engineering control will prevent spills and chemical releases.

name: Calibrate Air Quality Monitoring Equipment and Establish Monthly Maintenance Schedule
description: Immediately schedule calibration of solvent vapor monitoring equipment with an accredited third-party lab (target: within 5 days). Establish a monthly calibration and maintenance schedule to be tracked in the facility management system. Document baseline vapor concentration readings in mixing areas and establish action thresholds. Cross-reference with OSHA PELs and TLVs for polyurethane solvents. Assign responsibility to the facility maintenance coordinator.

name: Emergency Eyewash Station Inspection and Flushing Protocol
description: Conduct immediate inspection of emergency eyewash station and flush the entire system to remove any stale water. Replace any degraded components. Implement a bi-weekly flushing schedule with digital logging (QR code system). Train all chemical area staff on proper eyewash station use and location during next toolbox meeting. Verify water temperature and flow rate meets ANSI Z535.1 standards (0.4 GPM minimum). Post laminated instructions adjacent to station.

name: Emergency Roof Leak Repair and Facility Water Management
description: Engage certified roofing contractor to identify and repair roof leak in Warehouse Section B within 48 hours. Implement a comprehensive facility inspection to identify other potential water ingress points, especially in warehouse and storage areas prone to moisture. Install temporary drainage barriers and absorbent mats in high-risk areas pending repairs. Establish a monthly roof inspection schedule with documented checklist. Assign facility manager responsibility for coordinating repairs and prevention measures.

name: Install Anti-Slip Floor Treatment and Enhanced Drainage in Warehouse
description: Apply industrial-grade anti-slip coating to all warehouse floor surfaces, particularly areas around perimeter walls and under roof drainage points. Install sloped micro-drainage channels to direct water away from pedestrian walkways. Mark all wet areas with high-visibility wet floor signs and establish a 30-minute inspection and drying protocol during night shifts. Provide absorbent floor treatment materials and training to night shift staff on proper floor maintenance.

name: Shelving Load Assessment and Storage Rack Safety Inspection Program
description: Conduct comprehensive load rating assessment of all storage racks in Sections A and B, comparing actual stored weights to manufacturer load limits. Redistribute inventory to ensure loads do not exceed 80% of rated capacity per shelf. Install safety labels indicating maximum weight limits on each shelf. Implement annual rack inspections with certified third-party inspector. Install safety chains or containment bars on upper shelves to prevent box dislodgement. Train all warehouse staff on proper stacking procedures and load limits.

name: Implement Weekly Pallet Inspection Program
description: Establish a standardized weekly inspection protocol for all wooden pallets used in the Packaging and Labeling Station and Finished Goods Warehouse. Safety Officer will conduct inspections every Monday morning, documenting pallet condition and immediately removing damaged pallets from service. Develop a pallet maintenance schedule that includes sanding and repair of worn surfaces. This engineering and administrative control will prevent splinter hazards before they become incidents. Expected outcome: elimination of splinter-related injuries and near-misses within 90 days.

name: Enhance Hazard Awareness Training for Packaging Staff
description: Develop targeted training module for all Packaging and Labeling Station workers focusing on wooden pallet hazards, splinter identification, and early reporting protocols. Include photos of common pallet defects and demonstrate proper PPE usage (cut-resistant gloves). Training to be delivered within 2 weeks to day, evening, and night shift workers. Create laminated hazard identification posters for station walls. This administrative control reinforces Aaliyah Jackson's positive behavior and ensures all staff can recognize similar hazards.

name: Implement Controlled Exhaust Cleaning Protocol
description: Replace compressed air cleaning method with specialized industrial vacuum system equipped with HEPA filtration and static-dissipative hoses for all exhaust vent maintenance. Require use of anti-static grounding equipment during cleaning procedures. Develop written procedure specifying maximum vacuum pressure settings and proper grounding techniques. This engineering control eliminates the dust dispersal and static discharge hazard by removing particulates through controlled suction rather than pressurized air displacement. Train all maintenance staff on new protocol before implementation.

name: Upgrade Ductwork Cleaning Schedule and Inspections
description: Establish monthly ductwork inspections with documented particulate removal schedule to prevent accumulation. Install cleanout ports at strategic locations throughout exhaust system to allow safer access for maintenance. Implement preventive maintenance schedule that includes quarterly professional ductwork cleaning using approved methods. Administrative controls will reduce dust buildup that triggered the false alarm. Expected outcome: elimination of fire alarm false activations related to duct maintenance within 6 months.

name: Establish Mandatory Electrical Repair Quality Inspection Procedure
description: Implement a two-technician verification protocol for all electrical repairs in the maintenance workshop. All electrical work must be inspected by a second qualified technician before equipment testing. Create electrical repair checklist including wire insulation verification, connection torque confirmation, and continuity testing. Require photographic documentation of all repairs.
