This administrative control prevents improper repairs that could cause electrical hazards and false fire alarms. Assign responsibility to Central Maintenance Workshop supervisor for oversight and compliance tracking.

name: Install Electrical Test Safety Enclosure
description: Install a dedicated electrical testing enclosure in the Central Maintenance Workshop equipped with fire suppression capability, insulated walls, and dedicated exhaust ventilation. This engineering control isolates equipment testing from main facility, containing any electrical failures. All equipment testing must occur within this enclosure with proper fire suppression equipment and first aid kit nearby. Reduces risk of false alarms affecting entire facility operations and protects adjacent areas from electrical hazards.

name: Implement Electrical Safety Certification Program
description: Require all maintenance technicians performing electrical work to complete formal electrical safety certification through accredited provider. Include modules on proper wire insulation, connection techniques, testing protocols, and emergency procedures. Establish annual refresher training requirement. Maintain records of all certifications. This training control ensures staff possess proper knowledge and skills for electrical repairs, reducing risk of human error.

name: Implement Mandatory Post-Changeover Guard Inspection Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a documented checklist that must be completed immediately after every mold changeover on all injection molding lines. The checklist will include verification of thermal guard positioning, integrity checks, and certification by the operator and a supervisor. This will be incorporated into the production scheduling system with electronic sign-offs. Training will be provided to all production staff and refresher training will occur quarterly. Non-compliance will result in production suspension until completed.

name: Install Thermal Barrier Improvements on Injection Molding Lines
description: Replace existing thermal guards on all 32 injection molding machines with enhanced guard systems featuring improved fastening mechanisms and visibility indicators that show guard integrity status. The new guards will include pressure-sensitive switches that trigger alerts if guards are not properly seated. Installation will be performed by the Maintenance and Engineering team over a 6-week period starting immediately, with 4-5 machines serviced per week to maintain production capacity. Total system cost includes materials and labor.

name: Comprehensive E-Stop System Audit and Certification
description: Conduct immediate inspection and testing of all emergency stop systems across all 12 CNC machines in the Tool Room by certified electrical technicians. Replace all defective relays, circuit components, and wiring. Perform load testing to verify E-stop response time meets requirements (immediate shutdown within 100ms). Document all findings and corrective actions. Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly E-stop functional testing with documented results. All CNC machines will be offline until certified safe, with priority given to machines that had not been recently tested.

name: Implement Mandatory CNC Machine Lockout Procedures Training
description: Develop and deliver specialized lockout/tagout (LOTO) training specific to CNC milling operations, emphasizing energy isolation procedures before any maintenance or troubleshooting. All Tool and Die Makers and Maintenance Technicians must complete this training within 7 days. Training will include hands-on practice with the actual LOTO equipment used on CNC machines, review of energy hazards (electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic), and documentation requirements. Assessment will be conducted for each participant with certification. Training will be repeated annually and for all new hires in this role.

name: Install Height-Restricted Material Storage Racks with Load Limits
description: Replace existing storage racks in the Maintenance Workshop with heavy-duty racks featuring maximum height limits of 1.2 meters for items over 100 kilograms. Install load limit signs on each shelf section clearly indicating maximum weight capacity. Implement color-coded shelf markers (green for safe load levels, yellow for caution, red for maximum). All storage locations will be reorganized to comply with new height restrictions, with heavier items stored at or below waist height. Provide training to all maintenance staff on proper mold handling and storage procedures.

name: Replace and Upgrade Warehouse Shelving System
description: Install new heavy-duty industrial shelving units rated for 1000+ lbs per shelf with reinforced diagonal bracing. The new system will include load capacity signage, maximum weight limits per shelf level, and integrated safety pins to prevent pallet shifting. All units will be anchored to floor and wall structures to prevent toppling. Installation includes employee training on proper pallet placement procedures and quarterly load verification inspections.

name: Implement Monthly Shelving Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a documented monthly inspection procedure for all warehouse shelving units. Inspections will assess structural integrity, rust development, load distribution, and signage visibility. Receiving staff will document findings using a standardized checklist and report any deterioration immediately to maintenance. This administrative control ensures early detection of hazards before critical failures occur.

name: Upgrade LOTO Procedure for Hydraulic Accumulator Release
description: Revise the lockout/tagout procedure to include an additional mandatory step: manual release of hydraulic accumulator pressure through the bleed valve, with documented verification using a pressure gauge showing zero PSI before any personnel approach the mold. Install a secondary pressure relief valve as an engineering backup. All LOTO coordinators and machine operators must complete recertification training on the updated procedure within 14 days.

name: Install Hydraulic Accumulator Safety Signage and Guards
description: Install high-visibility warning signage on all injection molding machines indicating accumulator locations and residual pressure hazards. Add physical guards or barriers around accumulator access points to prevent accidental contact. Implement daily pre-shift checks of accumulator condition with documentation on the machine logsheet.

name: Replace Colorant Injection Metering Valve with Redundant System
description: Install a new dual-solenoid metering valve system with automatic shutdown capability on the colorant injection line. The upgraded system includes a pressure relief valve that automatically triggers closure if pressure exceeds safe limits, and a secondary mechanical lock that prevents uncontrolled flow. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of valve failure. Requires calibration and testing before restart.

name: Implement Enhanced Chemical Storage Segregation and Secondary Containment
description: Designate separate storage zones for volatile solvents with dedicated secondary containment trays (holding 110% of largest container volume). Install absorbent spill kits at 3 strategic locations within the Chemical Storage Room with clear signage and employee training. Upgrade floor drainage system to include chemical-resistant sump with dedicated separator tank for hazardous liquid recovery.

name: Mandatory Chemical Spill Response and Confined Space Awareness Training
description: Conduct comprehensive training for all night shift operators on chemical spill containment procedures, proper use of PPE during vapor exposure, and emergency response protocols. Include confined space hazard recognition for the Chemical Storage Room. Training documentation will be maintained in employee files and recertification completed annually. This administrative control ensures personnel can respond immediately to future incidents.

name: Install Hopper Maintenance Alert System
description: Implement a visual warning label and maintenance checklist at all bulk storage hoppers indicating when hopper gate valves require lubrication and inspection. Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly inspection of all hopper discharge mechanisms. Coordinate with Maintenance and Engineering department to perform baseline inspections of all 12 hoppers in the facility within 15 days. Train all Material Handlers and Production Supervisors to recognize signs of hopper valve sticking (resistance, grinding sounds) and immediately halt operations pending maintenance evaluation rather than attempting manual correction.

name: Enhance Hot Material Handling Training
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all Material Handlers on safe handling procedures for heated plastic pellets, including proper PPE requirements (insulated gloves, face shield availability), emergency response protocols, and the hazard hierarchy principle (report before attempting self-correction). Include scenarios specific to hopper discharge incidents and first aid response for thermal burns. Update the Material Handling Standard Operating Procedure document to explicitly prohibit striking or forcing hopper components and require supervisor notification for any equipment irregularities.

name: Implement Formal Shift Change LOTO Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory written Shift Change Lockout/Tagout Communication Procedure requiring outgoing and incoming supervisors to physically walk the production floor together during every shift transition, specifically identifying and documenting all machines currently under LOTO. Create a centralized LOTO Status Board in the production area displaying active locks by machine number, technician name, and lock-in time. Require both supervisors to sign off on a Shift Handoff Checklist confirming LOTO status verification. Train all production supervisors and shift leads on this protocol within 5 days, with monthly refresher training and quarterly audits by the LOTO Coordinator.

name: Upgrade Mold Press Interlock System
description: Conduct an engineering assessment of all 14 injection molding machines to evaluate the effectiveness of existing safety interlocks preventing remote operation during maintenance access. Coordinate with equipment manufacturer to verify current interlock functionality meets industry standards. If deficiencies are identified, implement hardware upgrades including dual-channel safety monitoring systems and motion inhibit devices that prevent any mold movement when access covers are open or when human presence is detected via pressure sensors. Complete assessment within 20 days and implement upgrades within 60 days.

name: Enhance LOTO Training with Scenario-Based Drills
description: Develop and conduct mandatory LOTO scenario-based training for all Production Supervisors, Maintenance Technicians, and Injection Molding Technicians. Include specific scenarios addressing the consequences of incomplete communication during shift changes, unauthorized restart attempts, and proper verification procedures. Conduct quarterly drills simulating shift handoff situations with LOTO scenarios to reinforce compliance and identify knowledge gaps. Document all training and drills for regulatory compliance purposes.

name: Implement Quarterly Fastener Inspection Program
description: Establish a comprehensive quarterly inspection schedule for all coupling fasteners and rotating equipment connections on injection molding lines. Maintenance technicians will use calibrated torque wrenches to verify tightness according to manufacturer specifications and document findings in the maintenance management system. This addresses the root cause of vibration-induced loosening that led to the guard separation. Weekly visual inspections will also be conducted during shift start-ups by line operators using a standardized checklist.

name: Upgrade Machine Guarding on Line B
description: Replace existing frame guards on Injection Molding Line B with enhanced containment guards that feature sealed edges and captive fastening systems to prevent accidental separation. The new guards will include interlocked access doors that automatically stop machine operation when opened, providing additional protection against entanglement hazards. Installation will be completed during the scheduled maintenance window with training provided to all line operators.

name: Conduct Refresher Training on Lockout/Tagout Procedures
description: Deliver mandatory refresher training to all Production Operations staff on proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures, specifically focusing on coupling maintenance and guard removal protocols. Training will emphasize the importance of de-energizing equipment before performing any adjustments or inspections. All operators and maintenance staff will be required to complete the training within two weeks and sign attestation forms confirming understanding.

name: Conduct Warehouse Racking System Audit and Reinforcement
description: Engage a certified warehouse equipment inspector to perform a comprehensive assessment of all storage racks throughout the warehouse and shipping facility. Racks will be evaluated for load capacity, structural integrity, proper anchoring, and weight distribution. Any identified deficiencies will be remediated immediately, including reinforcement of unstable units, installation of additional cross-bracing, and proper reanchoring to floor structures. Weight distribution protocols will be clearly labeled on each rack with maximum load capacities.

name: Establish Warehouse Traffic Management Protocol
description: Implement a formal traffic management plan that designates specific pathways for forklift operations separate from pedestrian areas and material storage zones. Install warning signage, floor markings with yellow tape, and physical barriers to prevent vibration transfer to storage infrastructure. Require operators to reduce speed in storage areas and conduct spotting observations to prevent future incidents. Monthly safety briefings will review the protocol with all warehouse staff.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hopper Sensors
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and maintenance protocol for all material hopper level sensors across the 32 injection molding machines. This will include visual inspection for loose connections, electrical continuity testing, and sensor calibration verification. A maintenance log will be maintained for each machine. This engineering and administrative control addresses the root cause of sensor degradation and ensures early detection of potential failures before they create hazardous conditions.

name: Install Secondary Hopper Overflow Containment System
description: Design and install secondary containment trays beneath material hoppers on all injection molding lines. These engineered containment systems will catch overflow material, preventing it from spilling directly onto the production floor. The trays will be equipped with manual drain valves for safe material recovery and disposal. This engineering control eliminates the slip hazard at the source and reduces waste.

name: Repair and Upgrade Secondary Containment System
description: Engage a specialized contractor to conduct a detailed assessment of the secondary containment floor and walls in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Repair all micro-cracks and surface damage using epoxy-resistant coating materials. Install additional protective barriers around high-use areas where chemical drips are most frequent. This engineering control restores containment system integrity and prevents potential environmental and safety failures.

name: Mandatory Updated WHMIS Training for Chemical Room Staff
description: Conduct comprehensive WHMIS 2015 training sessions for all personnel working in or near the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room, with specific focus on new epoxy resin formulations and their hazard classifications. Include practical demonstrations of proper handling, storage, emergency response procedures, and PPE requirements. Training will be documented and tracked for compliance. This administrative control ensures all staff understand current chemical hazards and proper safety protocols.

name: Install Protective Caging and Thermostat Controls on Heat Lamps
description: Replace all unprotected heat lamps in the Hazardous Waste Management Area and other chemical storage locations with new lamps equipped with: (1) protective wire mesh cages to prevent direct contact with flammable vapors, (2) built-in thermostat controls to maintain safe temperatures below 60°C, and (3) mounting brackets that position lamps at least 2 meters above floor level. This engineering control eliminates the ignition source hazard and prevents vapor accumulation near heat sources.

name: Redesign Flammable Waste Storage Area Layout
description: Implement a new storage layout in the Hazardous Waste Management Area that creates a minimum 5-meter separation buffer between flammable waste containers and all potential ignition sources, including heat lamps, electrical equipment, and loading dock areas. Install clear floor markings and signage indicating the restricted zone. Add ventilation ducting to direct vapors away from ignition sources. This engineering control addresses the spatial hazard and improves overall waste management safety.

name: Enhanced Fire Safety Training and Hazard Awareness Program
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive fire safety training to all personnel who work with or near hazardous waste, including identification of flammable materials, recognition of ignition sources, proper storage procedures, and emergency response protocols. Include hands-on fire extinguisher training and evacuation drills. Create laminated reference guides for the waste management area. This administrative control ensures staff understand fire hazards and can respond appropriately.

name: Implement Daily Warehouse Floor Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily morning inspection checklist for all warehouse sections, focusing on debris accumulation, spill cleanup, and aisle obstruction. Assign rotating responsibility among material handlers on each shift. Inspection results will be logged in a digital system accessible to supervisors. This directly addresses the root cause of the incident—debris on the floor creating trip hazards for equipment. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in floor-related material handling incidents within 60 days.

name: Install Anti-Slip Floor Marking and Edge Guards
description: Install yellow and black anti-slip tape on all high-traffic warehouse aisles, particularly around narrow passages between storage racks. Add rubber edge guards to protruding rack supports to create buffer zones. This engineering control will reduce contact between equipment and fixed objects. Expected outcome: Enhanced visibility and physical protection will prevent similar pinch-point incidents.

name: Replace Hopper Level Indicators with Digital Sensors
description: Install digital capacitive-level sensors on all resin hoppers in the production lines to provide remote, real-time monitoring without manual verification. Integrate sensors with the machine control interface so operators can check levels from a safe distance at their workstation. This eliminates the hazard entirely by removing the need for operators to lean over hoppers. Expected outcome: Hazard elimination; zero incidents related to hopper visual inspection.

name: Mandatory Safety Briefing on Hopper Hazards
description: Conduct a refresher training session for all production operators on the specific hazards of resin hoppers, including material cascade risks and the prohibition on leaning over or reaching into hoppers. Use incident photos and near-miss examples to illustrate consequences. Require signed acknowledgment from each operator. Implement as part of quarterly safety retraining. Expected outcome: Increased hazard awareness and adherence to safe work practices.

name: Deburr and Smooth All Exposed Duct Seams
description: Conduct a comprehensive inspection of all ventilation ductwork in UNIT-015 to identify sharp burrs, rough edges, and poorly finished seams. Hire a specialized HVAC contractor to deburr and smooth all identified hazardous areas using appropriate tools and techniques. Apply protective coating where necessary to prevent future corrosion-induced burr formation. This engineering control directly eliminates the hazard that caused the laceration. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of sharp-edge hazards on ductwork.

name: Issue Cut-Resistant Work Gloves for Maintenance Personnel
description: Provide ANSI A3 cut-resistant gloves to all electrical and HVAC maintenance technicians working on ventilation systems. Require gloves to be worn whenever working with ductwork, seams, or other potentially sharp surfaces. Store gloves in readily accessible locations at maintenance work stations. Conduct training on proper glove selection and use. This PPE measure provides personal protection while the engineering correction is being implemented. Expected outcome: Reduced severity of any sharp-edge contact injuries.

name: Install Temperature Warning Systems on Molding Lines
description: Implement proximity-based temperature alert systems on all injection molding equipment that trigger visual and audible warnings when mold surfaces exceed 160°C. The sensors will be positioned at accessible points where operators commonly interact with molds during setup and maintenance. This engineering control eliminates the need for direct hand contact assessment. Training will be provided to all molding operators on interpreting and responding to temperature alerts. The system will be integrated with the predictive maintenance program to identify cooling system failures before they create hazardous conditions.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooling System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a daily inspection checklist for all molding line cooling water systems to be completed before start of each shift. Operators will verify water flow rates, check for visible leaks, and confirm proper temperature readings. Weekly deep cleaning of cooling lines will be scheduled to prevent debris accumulation. All findings will be logged in the maintenance tracking system. This administrative control ensures early detection of cooling issues before they create burn hazards. Training will be conducted for all operators on proper inspection techniques and documentation.

name: Install Pressure Relief and Secondary Containment Systems
description: Retrofit all chemical storage drums with pressure relief valves calibrated to 0.5 PSI above normal operating pressure. Install secondary containment trays beneath all mixing room drums with capacity for 150% of the largest drum volume. This dual engineering control eliminates uncontrolled spill hazards and contains leaks before floor contamination. Containment trays will have drain plugs connected to a dedicated hazardous waste collection system. All chemically-compatible containment materials will be selected based on the specific chemicals stored. Staff training will cover proper installation, maintenance, and drainage procedures.

name: Establish Ventilation Maintenance and Monitoring Program
description: Implement a bi-weekly ventilation system inspection schedule with documented airflow testing. Install permanent air velocity monitors in the mixing room that display real-time airflow rates at accessible locations. Establish automatic alerts when ventilation drops below 85% of design capacity. Replace all mixing room air filters on a fixed monthly schedule regardless of visual appearance. Maintain spare filter inventory on-site for emergency replacement. This preventive maintenance approach ensures adequate fume removal capacity at all times.

name: Implement Chemical Drum Fill Level Control and Training
description: Establish a maximum fill level policy of 90% drum capacity for all pressurized chemical containers. Install fill level indicator labels on all drums showing safe fill zone. Implement a mandatory training module for all personnel involved in chemical handling covering proper filling procedures, pressure monitoring, and spill response. Create a chemical handling checklist to be completed before and after each filling operation. This administrative control prevents over-pressurization and ensures consistent safe practices. Training will be conducted immediately and refreshed annually.

name: Repair and Standardize Warehouse Floor Transitions
description: Conduct a comprehensive inspection of all floor transitions, ramps, and elevation changes throughout the warehouse and shipping areas. All transitions with elevation differences greater than 0.5 inches will be corrected using proper ramping materials or beveled edges to create smooth angles no greater than 1:12 slope. Install high-visibility yellow and black striping and tactile warning strips at all remaining minor transitions. All floor surfaces will be sealed to prevent further deterioration. This engineering control eliminates the catch points that cause forklift instability and operator compensation maneuvers.

name: Implement Forklift Safety Harness and Positioning Verification
description: Conduct mandatory retraining for all forklift operators emphasizing proper seat belt usage as a non-negotiable safety requirement. Install tamper-evident indicators on all forklift seat belts that show if the belt has been routed improperly. Implement a pre-operation inspection checklist that explicitly requires verification of proper seat belt routing and engagement before engine start. Supervisors will conduct random observations of forklift operations weekly to verify compliance. This administrative control ensures operators remain secure and prevent self-ejection during vehicle instability events.

name: Install Warehouse Equipment Handling Protocols and Communication Systems
description: Establish a written protocol prohibiting solo forklift operation when vehicle is wedged or stuck. Require operators to exit the vehicle and assess the situation, then summon supervisory assistance for repositioning decisions. Install additional high-visibility mirrors and camera systems at the packaging station to provide better sightlines for stuck equipment situations. Implement mandatory radio communication procedures when equipment requires repositioning. These administrative and engineering controls prevent operators from attempting high-risk corrective maneuvers without proper supervision and support.

name: Install Insulated Hot Water Dispensers with Spill Guards
description: Replace the existing open heating kettle with commercial-grade insulated hot water dispensers equipped with automatic spill containment trays and adjustable temperature controls. Install dispensers at safe locations away from primary work paths in the Packaging Station. Units will maintain water at 70°C maximum and feature child-lock style triggers to prevent accidental dispensing. Training will be provided on proper use and emergency response procedures.

name: Ergonomic Workstation Redesign at Packaging Station
description: Conduct ergonomic assessment of the labeling workstation to improve workflow and reduce reaching across hot equipment. Reposition all heating equipment to the rear of the workstation and install a logical flow pattern for label application. Add anti-fatigue matting and adjust work surface height to reduce strain. Install additional task lighting to improve visibility and reduce worker fatigue-related errors.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Safety Interlocks
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program specifically targeting all safety interlock systems on injection molding equipment. Schedule monthly inspections and realignment checks for all proximity sensors and safety switches across production lines. Create a detailed checklist covering sensor calibration, electrical connections, mechanical alignment, and response time verification. Maintenance logs will be digitally tracked with alerts for overdue inspections. Technicians will be trained on proper sensor adjustment procedures and troubleshooting protocols.

name: Upgrade to Advanced Dual-Redundant Safety Systems
description: Replace single-point-of-failure proximity sensors with dual-redundant safety systems on all injection molding presses. Install redundant sensors that must both confirm safe conditions before press operation can proceed. Implement real-time diagnostic software that continuously monitors sensor functionality and immediately alerts operators to any degradation. Add visual and audible warnings on the equipment when safety systems are in diagnostic mode or require attention.

name: Enhanced Operator Training on Safety System Verification
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training for all operators and setters on proper pre-production safety verification procedures. Training will include recognition of safety interlock warning signs, step-by-step verification protocols before each production run, proper use of emergency stop systems, and incident reporting procedures. All production staff will participate in quarterly refresher training with competency assessments. Training materials will be provided in both English and French.

name: Implement Equipment Guard Completion and Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory verification checklist that must be completed before any equipment is returned to service after maintenance work. This checklist will specifically include verification that all safety guards, shields, and protective barriers are properly installed and secured. Create a digital work order system that requires photographic documentation of guard reinstallation before maintenance can be marked complete. Implement a two-person verification requirement for all grinder and shredder equipment before night shift operation.

name: Install Interlocked Safety Guards on All Grinder Equipment
description: Replace existing removable guards on all regrind and recycling equipment with permanently mounted, interlocked guards that prevent equipment operation when any access panel is open. Install proximity sensors that immediately halt equipment operation if guards are opened during active cycling. Add tamper-evident fasteners to prevent unauthorized removal. Ensure guards are designed to allow necessary maintenance access while preventing direct hand contact with hazardous areas.

name: Implement Daily Hydraulic Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a daily pre-shift inspection checklist for all material handling carts and hydraulic lifting mechanisms in the production areas. Inspections will focus on locking mechanism functionality, hydraulic fluid levels, and any signs of wear or corrosion. Training will be provided to all production operators on the new checklist. Any equipment failing inspection will be tagged out of service and sent to the Central Maintenance Workshop for repair. This addresses the root cause of the cart's locking mechanism failure and prevents similar incidents.

name: Install Automatic Cart Positioning Guards on Injection Molding Lines
description: Engineering modification to install mechanical stops and guide rails on the material intake area of Injection Molding Line C and all similar lines. These guards will physically prevent carts from moving more than 2 inches beyond the loading position, eliminating the pinch point hazard between carts and machine support columns. Installation will be performed by the Maintenance team using existing capital equipment budget.

name: Establish Dock Cable and Hose Management Standard Operating Procedure
description: Create and distribute a new SOP requiring all pneumatic hoses and electrical cables in the Shipping and Receiving Dock to be managed using permanent cable management systems including wall-mounted conduits, clips, and floor channels. All existing cables will be rerouted away from equipment traffic paths and pedestrian walkways. Evening and night shift supervisors will conduct visual inspections at shift start and end to verify compliance. Training will be provided to all dock personnel at the next safety meeting. This eliminates the recurring hazard and establishes accountability.

name: Replace Hydraulic System Fittings with Corrosion-Resistant Components
description: All hydraulic cooling system fittings on the three industrial ovens will be replaced with stainless steel (316 grade) fittings rated for the system's operating pressure and temperature ranges. The old galvanized carbon steel fittings will be completely removed and properly disposed of per hazardous materials protocols. All connections will be installed with proper torque specifications and angles to prevent stress corrosion. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the failure and extends the service life of the cooling systems.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule with Hydraulic System Inspections
description: Establish a preventive maintenance program with quarterly visual inspections of all hydraulic systems in the Post-Processing zone, specifically targeting connection fittings, seals, and fluid levels. Inspections will be conducted by certified maintenance technicians and documented in the maintenance management system. Any fittings showing signs of corrosion, weeping, or discoloration will be immediately replaced. This administrative control ensures early detection of potential failures before spills occur.

name: Enhance Secondary Containment and Spill Response Equipment in Heat Treatment Area
description: Install permanent secondary containment trays beneath all three industrial ovens with a capacity of at least 110% of the maximum hydraulic fluid volume in each system. Additionally, establish a spill response kit station in the Post-Processing area containing absorbent pads, collection containers, and neutralizing agents. All night shift personnel will receive training on spill response procedures, and the location of emergency spill containment materials will be clearly marked with signage.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule for all 32 injection molding machines, with quarterly inspections of pressure relief valves, semiannual hydraulic fluid analysis and replacement, and monthly pressure monitoring. Install condition-monitoring sensors on high-risk equipment to detect anomalies before failure. Create a digital maintenance tracking system integrated with production schedules to ensure no equipment exceeds maintenance intervals. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of seal degradation and contamination-related failures.

name: Enhanced PPE and Thermal Protection Training
description: Require all machine setters and maintenance personnel working on hydraulic equipment to wear aluminized proximity suits and heat-resistant gloves during pressure valve maintenance. Conduct mandatory quarterly training on recognizing early signs of equipment failure, proper lockout/tagout procedures, and emergency response protocols. Distribute updated safety bulletins highlighting the specific thermal hazard associated with pressurized hydraulic fluid release.

name: Install Pressure Release Containment Shields
description: Engineer and install stainless steel containment shields around pressure relief valves on all 32 injection molding machines to redirect sudden fluid release away from operators. Shields will be designed to safely channel hydraulic fluid into collection trays for disposal. This engineering control provides an additional layer of protection while maintenance improvements are being implemented.

name: Complete Crane Safety System Overhaul and Certification
description: Conduct a comprehensive inspection and recertification of the overhead crane system by a third-party certified crane engineer. Replace the load limit switch assembly, inspect and replace the hoist cable, and perform load testing at 125% of rated capacity. Establish a documented maintenance schedule requiring monthly functional tests of all safety interlocks and annual full inspections. All repairs must be completed before the crane returns to service. This engineering control ensures the crane meets or exceeds all safety standards.

name: Create Equipment Maintenance Backlog Resolution Protocol
description: Implement an administrative control requiring that all flagged maintenance items identified during inspections must be resolved within 30 days or equipment must be removed from service. Establish a centralized maintenance tracking dashboard visible to supervisors and maintenance personnel. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance Engineering team to provide weekly status reports on outstanding maintenance items. Create an escalation process for items exceeding 20-day resolution targets.

name: Comprehensive Dust Control and Housekeeping Program
description: Install additional vacuum collection systems with HEPA filtration directly at regrind processing equipment to capture plastic dust at the source. Implement a mandatory daily housekeeping schedule requiring all horizontal surfaces in UNIT-018 to be cleaned of accumulated plastic debris. Install electrostatic discharge flooring in the regrind area to eliminate friction-generated sparks. Create a weekly audit checklist for supervisors with documentation and accountability measures. Establish a 'zero tolerance' policy for plastic dust accumulation exceeding 2mm depth on any surface. This engineering and administrative control directly eliminates the primary fuel source for fire propagation.

name: Emergency Communication and Staffing Enhancement During Peak Operations
description: Provide all night shift supervisors with dual-channel communication devices (radio and mobile phones) to enable rapid emergency coordination. Establish a minimum staffing requirement of at least two trained personnel in the warehouse area during all operational hours, even during off-peak periods. Implement a 'night shift safety protocol' requiring periodic walk-throughs of high-risk areas every two hours, with documented sign-offs. Create an emergency response team roster specifically trained in fire suppression equipment operation and evacuation procedures.

name: HVAC System Preventive Maintenance and Temperature Monitoring
description: Conduct immediate inspection and repair of the HVAC system in the warehouse area. Install temperature monitoring sensors with automated alerts if ambient temperature exceeds 24°C (75°F) in fire-sensitive areas. Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all HVAC equipment with documented compliance. Create a work order system requiring HVAC maintenance items to be completed within 7 days of identification to prevent heat-related hazard accumulation.

name: Replace Deteriorated Storage Rack System
description: Complete replacement of the mezzanine storage racking system with new industrial-grade shelving units rated for the current load capacity and future expansion. New racks will utilize stainless steel construction to prevent corrosion and will include load-rated capacity labels and secondary safety restraint systems. Installation will include verification of floor anchoring and structural integrity verification by a qualified engineer. All components will be sourced from certified manufacturers meeting CNESST industrial storage standards.

name: Implement Monthly Storage Rack Inspection Program
description: Establish a formal monthly inspection schedule for all storage racks and elevated storage systems throughout the facility. Inspections will focus on weld integrity, corrosion indicators, bolt tightness, and load distribution. Results will be documented in a centralized database with photographic evidence. Any rack scoring below acceptable standards will be immediately taken out of service. All supervisory staff will receive training on inspection procedures and hazard identification.

name: Enforce Mandatory Machine LOTO Procedures with Digital Verification
description: Implement a mandatory electronic lock-out/tag-out system where machines cannot be powered without supervisor authorization via QR code scanning and operator verification. All maintenance work must be preceded by documented LOTO verification checklist visible to all personnel. Operators must physically inspect and document the LOTO status before any work begins. Non-compliance will result in immediate retraining and corrective action. A second operator must witness and verify lockout procedures for all high-risk equipment modifications.

name: Intensive LOTO Retraining for All Production and Maintenance Staff
description: Conduct mandatory full-day retraining on lockout-tagout procedures for all 120+ day shift personnel, with separate sessions for evening and night shifts. Training will include video case studies of real injury incidents, hands-on practice with actual equipment, and competency verification testing. Emphasis will be placed on the consequences of bypassing procedures and the legal/personal liability of non-compliance. Refresher training will be scheduled quarterly for all operators and bi-annually for maintenance personnel.

name: Install Machine Guard Enhancement with Interlock Safety Switches
description: Install additional interlock safety switches on the injection mold access points that physically prevent machine operation if guard panels are removed or if hands enter the danger zone. Guards will be retrofitted with pressure-sensitive mats that immediately stop operation upon contact. All emergency stops will be repositioned for easier access from the mold cavity work area. Testing of all interlock systems will be performed weekly.

name: Implement Quarterly Equipment Coupling Inspection Schedule
description: Establish and document a preventive maintenance schedule requiring quarterly visual inspection of all injection molding machine feed tube couplings and fasteners across all production lines. Inspections will include tightness testing and vibration assessment. Maintenance technicians will use a standardized checklist and record findings in the CMMS system. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of vibration-induced loosening and ensures early detection of coupling degradation before failures occur.

name: Install Vibration Damping Pads Under Line C Machine Base
description: Install elastomer-based vibration damping pads under the Line C injection molding machine base to reduce vibration transmission to adjacent equipment. This engineering control will minimize lateral vibration transfer to Line D and other nearby machines. The pads will be professionally installed and baseline vibration measurements will be taken before and after installation to verify effectiveness. Expected reduction in coupling stress-induced failures by 75%.

name: Replace and Upgrade Surge Protection System Infrastructure
description: Install a new multi-stage surge protection system including upgraded surge arrestors at the main electrical panel, secondary protection devices at critical equipment circuits, and modern whole-facility transient voltage surge suppression (TVSS). Replace the failed UPS battery backup system with a newer model with extended capacity. Include installation of remote monitoring capability to send alerts when surge events occur. This engineering control will protect all equipment from voltage surges and provide real-time visibility into electrical health.

name: Establish Annual Electrical Infrastructure Maintenance Protocol
description: Implement a comprehensive annual preventive maintenance program for all surge protection equipment, UPS systems, and electrical distribution infrastructure. Contract with a certified electrical maintenance firm to perform thermographic scans, surge arrestor testing, and UPS battery load testing. Schedule maintenance during planned downtime periods. Document all findings and corrective actions in the maintenance management system. This administrative control ensures aging electrical protection equipment is regularly inspected and maintained before failures occur.

name: Install Secondary Electrical Isolation and Emergency Shutdown
description: Install automated isolation switches and emergency shutdown capabilities that can be triggered remotely or manually to disconnect critical machinery during electrical emergencies. This will prevent cascading damage to multiple pieces of equipment during surge events. Training will be provided to all shift supervisors on activation procedures. Secondary benefit: allows rapid shutdown during electrical fires or other emergencies.

name: Implement Mandatory Annual Oven Temperature Sensor Calibration and Replacement
description: Establish a preventive maintenance program requiring all industrial ovens to have temperature sensors professionally calibrated and replaced annually, regardless of apparent functionality. Create a tracking system with color-coded equipment tags indicating last service date. Sensors will be replaced with calibrated units certified to ±1°C accuracy. This administrative control directly prevents sensor drift and failure by enforcing regular replacement cycles rather than reactive maintenance.

name: Install Redundant Temperature Monitoring System with Automatic Shutoff
description: Install a secondary independent temperature monitoring system with an automatic thermal cutoff valve that activates if oven temperature exceeds 255°C. This backup system will function independently of the primary control system and will use a redundant sensor. If the primary sensor fails and temperature exceeds the safety threshold, the secondary system automatically shuts off fuel supply or heating elements, preventing runaway temperature conditions. This engineering control provides failsafe protection against sensor failure.

name: Install Automated Pressure Monitoring System
description: Implement real-time pressure monitoring sensors on all injection molding lines with automatic alerts when pressure exceeds safe thresholds. The system will trigger an audible alarm and email notification to the shift supervisor when pressure reaches 2,350 PSI, allowing operators time to investigate before critical failure. This engineering control eliminates the reliance on manual gauge reading and provides early warning. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in undetected hydraulic pressure anomalies on monitored equipment.

name: Implement Daily Hydraulic System Pre-Shift Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory 10-minute daily pre-shift inspection protocol for all operators on injection molding lines. Inspection checklist includes visual examination of all hydraulic lines for leaks, confirmation that pressure gauges are functioning, and verification of relief valve settings. Operators document findings on a laminated checklist posted at each machine. This administrative control creates consistency in hazard identification. Supervisor Michael Chen will conduct weekly audits of compliance. Expected outcome: Early detection of developing hydraulic issues before they escalate to critical failures.

name: Conduct Hydraulic Safety Refresher Training
description: Provide all production operators with a one-hour refresher training session on hydraulic system hazards, pressure relief procedures, and emergency response protocols. Training will include hands-on demonstration of emergency stop buttons, pressure relief manual overrides, and safe techniques for isolating hydraulic equipment. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos will facilitate the training, incorporating photos and video from this incident as a real-world case study. All operators must pass a brief competency assessment. Expected outcome: Improved operator awareness and faster response times to pressure-related anomalies.

name: Replace Heat Shrink Tunnel with Advanced Model
description: Replace the defective heat shrink tunnel with a newer industrial-grade model featuring dual redundant thermostats, automatic temperature cutoff at 330°F, and integrated real-time temperature monitoring with remote alerts. The new equipment will include a safety shutdown mechanism that activates if any sensor detects malfunction. This engineering control eliminates the specific hazard of thermostat failure that triggered this incident. The new equipment will be installed by the manufacturer with full training provided to all shift operators. Expected outcome: Prevention of future overheating incidents through redundant safety systems.

name: Establish Equipment Temperature Monitoring Protocol
description: Until equipment replacement is complete, implement a manual temperature monitoring protocol requiring operators to verify heat shrink tunnel temperature every 30 minutes using an infrared thermometer. Readings must be logged on a posted sheet with date, time, and operator initials. Any reading above 340°F triggers an immediate shutdown and maintenance notification. Additionally, assign one evening shift employee to conduct a dedicated 15-minute daily inspection of all heating equipment before production starts. This administrative control provides interim protection while engineering modifications are finalized.

name: Install Equipment De-Energization and Lockout Signage
description: Install prominent high-visibility lockout/tagout (LOTO) signs and placards on all maintenance work stations in UNIT-025. Ensure that all equipment awaiting maintenance has a clearly visible tag indicating the de-energization status, date of removal from service, and maintenance technician identity. Implement a policy requiring all maintenance personnel to physically verify de-energization before beginning work on any equipment. Create color-coded work trays (red for active work, yellow for staged components) to prevent accidental contact with sharp edges. This engineering control and administrative procedure prevents confusion about equipment status.

name: Mandate Cut-Resistant Gloves for Hand-Intensive Maintenance
description: Require all maintenance technicians performing equipment maintenance involving sharp edges, metal burrs, or spindle assemblies to wear ANSI A4 cut-resistant gloves rated for abrasion and laceration protection. Provide a selection of properly-fitted gloves in sizes XS through XXL at the maintenance workshop. Establish a monthly inspection and replacement protocol to ensure gloves remain functional. Include cut-resistant glove selection and proper fit in the maintenance safety training curriculum. While this is a PPE control and thus lower on the hierarchy, it provides essential protection given the inherent hazards in this work environment.

name: Implement Maintenance Tool Safety Protocol
description: Develop and distribute a laminated tool safety reference card specific to maintenance work on spindle assemblies and CNC equipment. The card will include proper wrench sizing, slip prevention techniques, hand positioning guidelines, and emergency response procedures. Conduct a 90-minute hands-on training session for all maintenance staff covering proper use of adjustable wrenches, socket wrench techniques, and identification of slip-hazard scenarios. Create a checklist requiring sign-off that must be posted before any technician begins spindle or bearing maintenance work. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury will lead the training and maintain records of completion.

name: Implement Quarterly Temperature Sensor Calibration Program
description: Establish mandatory quarterly calibration of all injection molding temperature sensors with documented verification records. Implement automated alert system that triggers when sensor readings deviate more than 5% from actual surface temperatures. Assign Sylvain Jodoin (Automation Engineer) to oversee calibration schedule and maintain calibration database. All temperature sensor equipment will be serviced by external certified technician to ensure accuracy. Expected outcome: eliminate temperature sensor drift incidents and ensure operator receives accurate equipment status information.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Operator Gloves
description: Replace all standard work gloves with high-temperature rated gloves (rated to 500°C) in all production areas handling injection molding equipment. Gloves will be provided to all 120 day shift operators, 60 evening shift operators, and 20 night shift operators. Gloves will be distributed with written instructions on proper use and temperature limitations. Implement monthly inventory checks to ensure compliance and replace worn gloves quarterly. Expected outcome: provide adequate hand protection when contacting heated equipment surfaces.

name: Conduct Annual Hot Surface Hazard Awareness Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory annual training for all production operators covering: proper nozzle clearing procedures, recognition of malfunctioning temperature indicators, safe clearance distances from heated equipment, appropriate PPE for heat exposure tasks, and emergency response protocols. Training will include practical demonstrations with non-operational equipment and include competency assessments. Brigitte Mathieu (Incident Investigation Specialist) will coordinate curriculum development with production supervisors. Expected outcome: ensure all operators understand thermal hazards and proper safe work procedures before working with heated injection molding equipment.

name: Install Protective Shielding Around Tensile Test Equipment
description: Design and install clear polycarbonate shielding enclosure around all three tensile testing machines in the QC laboratory. Enclosure will feature reinforced design with 6mm polycarbonate panel resistant to high-velocity projectiles from composite material fragments. Access doors will be interlocked to prevent operation when open. Enclosure will allow full visibility for monitoring test progress while containing fragment ejection. Mario Bélisle (Tool and Die Maker) will fabricate custom mounting brackets. Expected outcome: eliminate fragment ejection hazard to operators performing tensile testing on composite materials.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Inspections
description: Establish a preventive maintenance protocol requiring comprehensive hydraulic system inspections every 90 days across all injection molding lines. Inspections will include hose pressure tests, connection integrity checks, and fluid condition analysis. All high-pressure hoses will be photographed and documented with manufacturing dates to identify components approaching end-of-life. This will replace the current ad-hoc inspection practice and ensure early detection of defects before failure occurs.

name: Install Secondary Containment Guards on High-Pressure Lines
description: Engineer and install transparent polycarbonate guards around all high-pressure hydraulic hose connections on injection molding lines. These guards will redirect pressurized fluid spray downward and away from worker zones in the event of a rupture. The guards will be positioned to maintain visibility for monitoring while providing passive protection. Installation will be completed on all 12 production molding lines during the next scheduled maintenance window.

name: Redesign Chemical Mixing Procedures with Incompatibility Matrix
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive chemical incompatibility matrix for all materials used in the mixing facility. Create color-coded storage zones and modify the mixing procedure checklist to require operators to consult the matrix before combining any chemicals. Implement a buddy-verification system where a second operator must verbally confirm chemical compatibility before any mixing begins. Conduct mandatory retraining for all mixing room personnel within 14 days, with competency assessment before return to unsupervised operations.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment and Drainage Systems
description: Install improved secondary containment berms with sealed connection to on-site waste treatment system rather than municipal drains. Upgrade containment capacity from current 50-gallon to 200-gallon system to accommodate larger potential spills. Install absorbent material dispensers and spill kit stations at four strategic locations in the mixing area. Conduct quarterly inspections of drain seals and containment integrity. This engineering control will prevent environmental release to municipal systems and groundwater.

name: Install Real-Time VOC Monitoring System
description: Install continuous VOC monitoring sensors with audible alarms at 175 ppm threshold (below OSHA PEL) in the mixing room. Integrate system with facility ventilation controls to automatically increase air exchange rates when VOC levels approach alert threshold. Display real-time readings on control panel. This will provide early warning of VOC release before reaching regulatory limits, enabling rapid response to spill situations.

name: Install Height-Limiting Load Stops on All Pallet Racks
description: Install mechanical height limiters (load stops) on all warehouse racking systems that physically prevent pallets from being positioned above the 1.4-meter safe stacking height. These will be welded to the upright frames at the designated maximum level. Limiters will include clear visual markers and height measurement guides. This eliminates the possibility of operator error in height judgment and provides passive safety without relying on human compliance. All 18 racking units in Finished Goods Warehouse will be retrofitted within 10 days.

name: Implement Mandatory Load Securing Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a pre-shift inspection procedure requiring all warehouse personnel to visually inspect and manually test all pallet loads for security using standardized holding straps before the shift commences. Create a laminated checklist posted at each racking section. Implement a sign-off log where personnel document completion. Supervisors will conduct spot checks twice weekly. This administrative control ensures consistent application of securing procedures and builds awareness of load stability risks among all warehouse staff.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Racking Systems with Anti-Sway Bracing
description: Install diagonal anti-sway bracing on all warehouse racking units to reduce movement from nearby forklift vibrations and equipment operation. Add secondary containment bumpers at the base of racks to prevent forklift contact damage to uprights. Enhance structural integrity by adding intermediate horizontal tie-beams between racking units. These engineering modifications will prevent the vibration-induced pallet shifts that triggered this incident and reduce vulnerability to equipment contact damage.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Overhead Crane Systems
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all overhead crane systems requiring monthly visual inspections, quarterly load cell recalibrations, semi-annual cable tension testing, and annual third-party certification inspections. Create a digital tracking system using maintenance software to log all service activities and alert supervisors when maintenance is due. This administrative control will ensure all critical components are regularly serviced before failure, eliminating the root cause of this incident.

name: Upgrade Crane Load Monitoring System with Real-Time Alerts
description: Replace the existing load cell sensor with a newer generation system that includes redundant load measurement capabilities and real-time wireless alerts to the operator and control room when load parameters exceed safe limits. Install a secondary independent overload cutoff mechanism that triggers an automatic emergency stop if the primary system fails. This engineering control provides multiple layers of protection against overload conditions and equipment failure.

name: Implement Mandatory Ventilation System Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish a formal preventive maintenance schedule for all ventilation systems in chemical handling and material recycling areas, requiring weekly filter inspections, bi-weekly filter cleaning, and monthly full system performance testing with documentation. Install pressure differential gauges on intake filters to alert staff when filter replacement is needed. This administrative control ensures ventilation systems remain fully operational to prevent accumulation of harmful fumes and vapors in enclosed spaces.

name: Install Real-Time VOC Monitoring System with Automated Shutoff
description: Deploy continuous air quality monitoring sensors throughout the Regrind and Recycling Department that measure VOC concentrations in real-time. Configure the system to trigger audible alarms when VOC levels reach 50% of the OSHA Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) and automatically shut down compounding equipment and activate emergency ventilation when levels reach 80% of PEL. Display real-time air quality readings on dashboard screens visible to all operators. This engineering control provides early warning and automatic protection before dangerous exposures occur.

name: Conduct Respiratory Protection and Chemical Safety Training
description: Provide comprehensive training to all regrind and recycling department staff on recognizing signs of chemical exposure (dizziness, respiratory irritation, eye burning), proper use of supplied air respirators, emergency evacuation procedures, and hazard communication. Include practical sessions on donning and doffing respiratory protection equipment. Require annual refresher training for all personnel in this department. This administrative control ensures workers understand chemical hazards and know how to respond appropriately to exposure situations.

name: Install Explosion-Proof Vacuum System with HEPA Filtration
description: Procure and install an explosion-proof, HEPA-filtered vacuum system specifically rated for composite fiber dust collection in UNIT-016. The system will be permanently mounted near high-accumulation areas and connected to a centralized dust collection system with automatic shutdown if dust levels exceed safe thresholds. This engineering control eliminates the use of unsafe standard vacuums and reduces dust re-suspension. Implementation includes installation of permanent collection points at material dryer exhaust areas and behind equipment where dust typically accumulates.

name: Implement Daily Housekeeping Schedule with Documented Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory daily housekeeping protocol for UNIT-016 requiring cleaning of all horizontal surfaces, equipment ledges, and overhead areas before end of shift. Create a checklist-based inspection log that materials handlers must complete and sign. Designate Georges Plante as the unit housekeeping coordinator responsible for weekly audits and monthly deep cleaning events. Training will emphasize fire hazards and proper dust handling procedures. This administrative control ensures consistent dust management and creates accountability.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Material Drying Room
description: Engineering assessment and upgrade of the local exhaust ventilation (LEV) system in UNIT-016 to increase air changes per hour and improve capture efficiency at dust generation points. Install additional exhaust ducting at material dryer discharge points and consider adding a bag filtration system to the existing ventilation. This engineering control at the source will dramatically reduce dust accumulation rates and maintain air quality below OSHA PEL for composite fiber dust.

name: Implement Scheduled Mold Maintenance and Inspection Program
description: Establish a preventive maintenance schedule for all injection molds with documented inspections every 500 production cycles or weekly, whichever comes first. Mold designer Philippe Houle will develop an inspection checklist identifying edge defects, burrs, cracks, and wear patterns. Any mold with sharp edges or burrs will be immediately removed from service and sent to the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013) for restoration. This eliminates the hazard at the source by preventing sharp edges from developing in the first place.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Gloves for Mold Cleaning Operations
description: Distribute ANSI A4-rated cut-resistant gloves to all machine operators and machine setters who perform mold cleaning and maintenance tasks. The gloves will be made of high-strength synthetic fiber with enhanced grip for handling wet cloths and solvents. Include in employee training the proper use and care of the gloves, and ensure adequate supply is maintained. This PPE-based control provides a personal protective layer while engineering and administrative controls are being implemented.

name: Replace All Chemical Transfer Couplings with Stainless Steel Quick-Disconnects
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all chemical transfer equipment in UNIT-010 and replace all aluminum couplings with corrosion-resistant stainless steel quick-disconnect couplings rated for isopropanol and other solvents in use. Develop a preventive maintenance schedule requiring quarterly inspection of all couplings for corrosion, wear, or damage. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the spill by using materials that resist corrosion in the chemical environment.

name: Install Secondary Containment with Absorbent Inventory
description: Expand secondary containment capacity in UNIT-010 by installing removable containment trays under all bulk chemical storage and transfer areas. Ensure containment volume is at least 110% of the largest container in use. Maintain minimum inventory of 500 pounds of absorbent material (composite absorbent rated for organic solvents) in the unit at all times. Mark containment areas with hazard signage and include containment instructions in employee training. This engineering control prevents spilled chemicals from spreading beyond designated areas.

name: Mandatory Chemical Transfer Standard Operating Procedure with Training
description: Develop detailed SOP for all chemical transfer operations in UNIT-010, including pre-transfer coupling inspection requirements, transfer rate limits, and continuous monitoring protocols. Require all personnel performing chemical transfers to complete competency-based training and pass a written exam. Implement monthly refresher training and quarterly competency assessments. Designate André Bellavance as the chemical safety coordinator responsible for training delivery and documentation. Include spill response procedures and emergency contacts in the SOP.

name: Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Implement a comprehensive monthly inspection and maintenance schedule for all hydraulic systems on injection molding machines, including pressure relief valve testing, fluid analysis, and seal integrity checks. This engineering control will prevent future pressure anomalies by identifying degraded components before failure. All maintenance technicians will receive specialized training on hydraulic diagnostics. Target implementation includes pressure monitoring sensors with alarm thresholds set at 90% of maximum safe operating pressure.

name: Enhanced Machine Guarding for Hopper Assembly
description: Install reinforced polycarbonate safety shields around the hopper assembly on all 32 injection molding machines to contain ejected material and prevent operator exposure. Shields will be designed to redirect resin safely downward into containment trays rather than across the production floor. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause by physically preventing hazardous material dispersal. Installation will be completed progressively with priority given to Line D and Line B.

name: Solvent Container Labeling and Storage Protocol
description: Implement a standardized container management system requiring tamper-evident seals and daily inspection checklists for all chemical containers. All acetone and solvent bottles must be stored in designated secondary containment trays with clear labeling indicating hazard level and required PPE. Administrative controls will include a sign-off log requiring the operator to verify container lid security before storage. Training will be conducted for all personnel handling chemical transfers.

name: Enhanced Eye Protection Requirements for Chemical Areas
description: Mandate chemical splash goggles and face shields (meeting ANSI Z87.1 standards) for all personnel working within 2 meters of open chemical containers. Current safety glasses will be replaced with dual-lens protection equipment. All employees in Materials Management will receive fit-testing and training on proper donning and care. This PPE upgrade represents the most practical immediate control given the nature of solvent handling tasks.

name: Coolant System Secondary Containment Upgrade
description: Install rigid secondary containment trays with 110% sump capacity beneath all coolant recirculation lines in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop. Existing compression fittings will be replaced with vibration-resistant swaged fittings and monthly pressure testing will be conducted. All lines will be relocated to eliminate direct proximity to storm drains. Stainless steel drain pan systems will include automatic level sensors with alarm notification to the maintenance control station. This engineering control prevents environmental release by containing leaks at source.

name: Environmental Incident Response Training and Procedures
description: Develop a comprehensive emergency response protocol specific to coolant spills, including absorbent material placement, drain isolation procedures, and regulatory notification workflows. All night shift personnel (approximately 20 employees) will receive annual certification training with tabletop drills conducted quarterly. A dedicated spill kit containing absorbent booms, containment materials, and drain plugs will be positioned at three strategic locations with laminated quick-reference guides. This administrative control ensures faster response and minimizes environmental migration.

name: Monthly Floor Drain Inspection and Maintenance
description: Implement a formalized monthly inspection schedule for all floor drains, storm system connections, and containment barriers in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop and adjacent production areas. Maintenance technician Carlos Rodriguez will document any cracks, degradation, or debris blockage. Preventive sealing of floor cracks identified during inspection will be scheduled within 48 hours. This administrative control identifies infrastructure vulnerabilities before they allow environmental release.

name: Enhanced Chemical Handling Training Program
description: Implement mandatory quarterly refresher training for all production staff on proper chemical container handling, storage, and transfer procedures. Training will include hands-on demonstrations of correct container closure techniques, proper use of PPE (gloves, aprons, safety glasses), and emergency response protocols. Training materials will be available in both French and English. All operators on injection molding lines will be required to complete this training within 14 days of incident notification. Competency assessments will be conducted and documented.

name: Upgrade Chemical Transfer Equipment with Spill Prevention Devices
description: Replace all mold release agent transfer containers with closed-loop transfer systems featuring self-closing valves and drip trays to prevent spillage during transfer operations. Install additional eyewash and chemical shower stations within 5 meters of all chemical application points on Lines C and D. Ensure containers are clearly labeled with content, hazards, and first aid instructions in both English and French. Stock extra supplies of sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment at each production line station.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program with Vibration Monitoring
description: Install real-time vibration monitoring sensors on all CNC milling machines in the tool room. Integrate sensor data with a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) that automatically alerts maintenance staff when vibration patterns indicate bearing wear or spindle degradation. Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring spindle bearing inspection and replacement every 12 months for production machines. Train maintenance staff on proper sensor calibration and data interpretation. Conduct baseline vibration measurements on all equipment before system activation.

name: Spindle Bearing Replacement and Electrical System Restoration
description: Replace the damaged spindle bearing assembly with a new OEM-specification bearing and conduct full spindle performance testing before returning the machine to service. Conduct a comprehensive electrical audit of all CNC machines, with particular focus on safety-related wiring including vibration sensor connections. Repair or replace any disconnected, damaged, or corroded electrical connections. Install protective conduit over sensor and control wiring to prevent future disconnection. Document all electrical repairs and create laminated reference cards showing correct sensor connection diagrams for each machine model.

name: Maintenance Documentation and Training for Night Shift Staff
description: Create comprehensive maintenance logs for all CNC equipment documenting service dates, components replaced, and performance metrics. Make these logs accessible to night shift maintenance personnel. Conduct specialized training for the night shift maintenance team (currently understaffed at only 2 personnel) on advanced troubleshooting of CNC spindle systems, sensor interpretation, and emergency procedures. Establish a mandatory pre-shift equipment inspection checklist for night shift supervisors. Cross-train at least one day shift technician to support night shift operations during critical maintenance windows.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Audits and Re-certification
description: Conduct comprehensive audits of all lockout/tagout procedures at TechnoPlast within 48 hours of incident. Every operator and maintenance technician currently authorized to perform LOTO must complete re-certification training within 7 days. Implementation includes: (1) physical verification that all LOTO equipment is functional and accessible, (2) review of LOTO procedures specific to each injection molding machine model, (3) practical demonstrations of proper energy isolation techniques, (4) consequences documentation for non-compliance. Establish a zero-tolerance policy for operating machines without proper LOTO implementation. Supervisors must witness and sign off on all LOTO certifications.

name: Installation of Automatic Thermal Cutoff Safety Systems
description: Install automatic thermal cutoff switches on all injection molding machine hoppers set to activate emergency shutdown when hopper temperature exceeds 290°C for more than 5 seconds. These switches will be independent of the primary temperature control system to ensure redundancy. Additionally, install mechanical guard barriers around hopper access points that prevent hand insertion while machine is energized. The barriers will be removable only when the machine is in full lockout status (electrical and thermal energy isolated). Install temperature warning decals on all hoppers stating safe/danger temperature thresholds.

name: Enhanced Hazard Communication and Machine Jamming Protocols
description: Implement a new standard operating procedure (SOP) for handling material jams in injection molding equipment that explicitly prohibits manual clearance of internal cavities while machines are energized. All jamming situations must be reported to the supervisor, who will initiate proper LOTO procedures before any internal access is attempted. Develop illustrated job aids in French and English showing proper jam clearance techniques. Install prominently visible warning signs on all injection molders stating 'DO NOT REACH INTO HOPPER - EXTREME HEAT HAZARD.' Establish a daily pre-shift safety briefing on Line D that includes hazard identification and specific focus on thermal burn prevention.

name: Thermal Injury Prevention Training and PPE Upgrade
description: Conduct mandatory thermal burn prevention training for all production staff on Lines C and D, covering: (1) recognition of thermal hazards on injection molding equipment, (2) first aid response for thermal burns, (3) proper use of heat-resistant PPE including Kevlar gloves rated for 300°C+ contact, (4) emergency communication procedures. Upgrade all operator PPE kits to include aluminized proximity suits for high-temperature tasks, thermal-rated safety glasses, and heat-resistant sleeves. Issue new PPE to all 18 operators on Lines C and D within 5 days. Establish a monthly thermal hazard awareness reminder session.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Checklist
description: All injection molding operators will be required to complete a printed LOTO checklist before any mold adjustment or clearing work, with signatures from both the primary operator and a designated observer. The checklist will include verification that all energy sources are isolated, locks are in place, and the restart button is tested. Supervisors will conduct daily audits of completed checklists during the first 60 days, then weekly thereafter. This administrative control will ensure consistent adherence to lockout procedures and create accountability for safety compliance.

name: Install Interlock Safety Gate on Line C Molding Machine
description: Engineering control: Install a mechanical interlock safety gate on the injection molding machine that prevents mold closure when the guard is open. This device will make it physically impossible to operate the machine with hands in the mold cavity, eliminating the primary hazard. The interlock will be integrated with the machine's control system. Installation will be performed by qualified maintenance technicians and certified by an independent equipment auditor.

name: Conduct Refresher Training on Equipment Hazards
description: All production operators on Line C will attend a 2-hour refresher training session focused on injection molding machine hazards, crush injury prevention, and proper LOTO procedures. Training will include video demonstration of an actual crush injury incident in a similar machine, discussion of the recent incident, and hands-on practice with the new interlock gate system. Training will be repeated quarterly for all shift operators. Attendance will be tracked and documented.

name: Replace All Storage Rack Restraint Cables
description: Engineering control: All storage rack restraint cables throughout the Finished Goods Warehouse will be replaced with stainless steel cables rated for chemical corrosion resistance. Installation will occur during a scheduled weekend shutdown. Each rack will have a manufacturer inspection label with replacement date.
