A quarterly inspection schedule will be established where all cables are visually examined for signs of corrosion, fraying, or damage. Any cable showing 20% or more corrosion will be immediately replaced.

name: Improve Warehouse Moisture Control and Ventilation
description: Engineering control: Install additional dehumidification units and improve air circulation in the Finished Goods Warehouse to reduce moisture accumulation on metal components. Target humidity level is 55-65%. Monthly humidity monitoring will be conducted and logged. A maintenance schedule will establish weekly checks of dehumidifier filters and quarterly replacement. This addresses the root cause of cable corrosion by controlling the warehouse environment.

name: Establish Monthly Rack Safety Audit Program
description: Administrative control: Warehouse supervisors will conduct monthly comprehensive inspections of all storage racks, documenting the condition of restraint cables, shelf fasteners, load stability, and aisle clearance. A standardized audit checklist will be used and results submitted to the HSE department. Any deficiencies will be corrected within 24-72 hours depending on severity. All warehouse staff will receive training on the audit procedures and hazard recognition.

name: Upgrade Fire Safety Signage and Equipment Positioning
description: Engineering/Administrative control: Install prominently visible hazard warning signs on the resin mixing tank with bilingual French/English labeling indicating "Flammable Solvent - Fire Hazard" and emergency procedures. Relocate four additional Class B fire extinguishers (suitable for solvent fires) to positions within 10 meters of the mixing station, with clear floor markings and signage. Create a no-storage zone (1.5m radius) around all fire extinguishers. Conduct staff training on fire extinguisher locations and proper use. This control combines engineering improvements with administrative procedures.

name: Clear and Secure All Emergency Exit Pathways
description: Administrative control: Immediately remove all cardboard boxes and materials from emergency exit areas in the chemical storage building. Establish a permanent storage protocol prohibiting any materials within 2 meters of exit doors. Install floor markings (yellow/red striped tape) delineating the no-storage zones. Conduct a facility-wide audit of all emergency exits and document compliance. Implement monthly walk-throughs by the HSE team to ensure exits remain clear. Provide staff training on the importance of maintaining clear egress routes.

name: Implement Quarterly Preventive Safety Inspections
description: Administrative control: Establish a formal quarterly preventive safety inspection program led by the Confined Space Entry Supervisor in collaboration with the Industrial Hygienist. Each chemical storage area will be systematically evaluated for hazard signs, equipment positioning, ventilation function, emergency equipment visibility, and exit accessibility. Findings will be documented in a centralized safety database with photographic evidence. Priority issues will be corrected within 10 days. This proactive approach will prevent issues from escalating to incident status.

name: Implement Automated Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install real-time thermostat monitoring devices on all injection molding machines with automated alerts when mold temperatures exceed safe operating ranges. Integrate data logging to track temperature drift patterns and generate daily compliance reports. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of unexpectedly hot mold surfaces by preventing out-of-range conditions from occurring. Expected outcome: reduction in thermal burn incidents by 90% through early detection and automatic shutdown protocols.

name: Enhance Daily Equipment Pre-Shift Inspection Procedures
description: Revise the daily pre-shift equipment checklist to include mold temperature verification using infrared thermometers before each shift begins. Require operators to document readings and sign off on the inspection. Add specific calibration checks for thermostats monthly. Train all production operators on the expanded procedure during toolbox talks. This administrative control ensures temperature anomalies are caught before production starts.

name: Replace All Storage Rack Securing Systems with Heavy-Duty Redundant Straps
description: Conduct a complete audit of all high-storage racks and replace all deteriorated straps with new heavy-duty industrial securing systems rated for 1.5x maximum load capacity. Implement a redundant dual-strap system where pallets are secured with two independent straps from different anchor points. This engineering control eliminates load failure as a failure mode. Additionally, install load cells on racks to monitor shifting. Expected outcome: complete elimination of falling load incidents from strap failure.

name: Establish Quarterly Strap and Rack Inspection Program
description: Create a detailed quarterly inspection protocol requiring material handlers and supervisors to visually assess all storage racks and securing straps for signs of wear, chemical degradation, or damage. Develop a color-coded tagging system (green/yellow/red) to indicate inspection status and required maintenance. Document findings in a centralized log. Remove any equipment rated red from service immediately. This administrative control ensures deterioration is detected before failure occurs.

name: Install Safety Nets and Guardrails Below High-Storage Racks
description: Install heavy-duty safety nets beneath all high-storage racks (3+ meters) and erect protective guardrails to prevent access directly under loaded racks. Implement a 'no pedestrian zone' policy in areas directly beneath elevated storage with clear floor markings and signage. This engineering control provides secondary protection if loads do fall, reducing injury severity. Expected outcome: reduction of critical injuries from falling objects by establishing protected zones.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Spill Prevention Systems
description: Install engineered secondary containment trays beneath all chemical transfer stations with capacity for 125% of the largest container being handled. The trays feature sloped floors to direct spills toward a central drain connected to hazardous waste collection. Additionally, install adjustable container stabilization frames that prevent tipping during pouring operations. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of spills from container instability and overflow.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment and Engineering Controls for Chemical Handling
description: Provide all chemical operators with enhanced PPE including chemical-resistant gloves rated for acetone (nitrile-coated neoprene), long-sleeved chemical-resistant aprons, and face shields with integrated respirators for operations involving volatile solvents. Install local exhaust ventilation hoods directly above chemical transfer work stations with capture velocity of 0.5 m/s to remove vapors at source. Expected outcome: reduction of chemical exposure incidents through improved protection and vapor control.

name: Implement Mandatory Chemical Handling Training and Safe Transfer Procedures
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive chemical safety training covering hazard communication, proper pouring techniques, spill response protocols, and emergency procedures. Require annual recertification and monthly toolbox talks on chemical handling. Create visual standard work instructions at each chemical transfer station showing correct container positioning, pouring angles, and PPE requirements. This administrative control ensures operators understand safe procedures and hazard awareness.

name: Install Automatic Shut-off Transfer Pump System
description: Replace the current manual transfer pump with an automatic pump equipped with fail-safe shut-off mechanisms and level sensors. This engineering control will prevent overflow incidents by stopping the pump when containers reach capacity. The new system will include backup shutoff valves and be serviced monthly. This addresses the root cause of uncontrolled chemical dispensing and reduces reliance on operator vigilance.

name: Establish Chemical Spill Response Protocol and Training
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive spill response procedure specific to acetone and other solvents used in the tool room. All staff in UNIT-013 will receive hands-on training on spill containment, emergency ventilation activation, and evacuation procedures. Training will be documented and repeated annually. Secondary containment kits will be positioned strategically, and emergency eyewash stations will be installed. This administrative control ensures rapid, coordinated response to future incidents.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System with Sensor-Activated Controls
description: Install VOC (volatile organic compound) sensors in the tool room that automatically trigger enhanced ventilation when chemical vapors exceed safe threshold levels. This engineering control will provide real-time response to chemical exposure risks without manual intervention. The system will include manual override capabilities and maintenance alerts.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and replacement schedule for all hydraulic hoses and connectors throughout the facility. Implement thermographic imaging and vibration analysis to detect early signs of equipment degradation. Each hose will be pressure-tested annually, and connectors will be replaced on a 3-year cycle regardless of condition. Create a maintenance log database to track all servicing. This administrative control combined with engineering oversight will prevent future leaks.

name: Install Secondary Containment Under All Hydraulic Equipment
description: Place removable drip pans and absorbent mat systems under the material compactor and other hydraulic equipment in UNIT-018. These engineered containment barriers will capture any leaking fluid before it reaches floor drains or spreads across work areas. The systems will be inspected daily during shift changes, with used materials properly disposed of. This engineering control protects both worker safety and environmental integrity.

name: Replace and Reinforce All Storage Racks with Load Capacity Systems
description: Replace deteriorated warehouse racks in UNIT-008 with new industrial-grade racks rated for 50% above current maximum anticipated loads. Install permanent load capacity placards on each rack and implement a color-coded load limit system using safety tape. Conduct structural engineering assessment of all existing racks, reinforcing supports and replacing corroded bolts with stainless steel fasteners. Hire quarterly third-party inspections to verify structural integrity. This comprehensive engineering control eliminates the root cause of the collapse.

name: Establish Warehouse Inventory Control and Load Limits Policy
description: Create detailed inventory management procedures specifying maximum loads per rack location, weight distribution requirements, and material stacking heights. Train all warehouse staff on proper load placement and verification procedures. Implement a digital inventory tracking system that flags when storage areas approach capacity limits. Designate a warehouse supervisor responsible for weekly load verification audits. Post visual guides showing correct and incorrect loading patterns. This administrative control ensures personnel compliance with safety requirements.

name: Install Dust Collection and Air Quality Monitoring System
description: Install upgraded HEPA filtration and dust collection system in the warehouse capable of capturing and filtering fine polycarbonate particulates. Add air quality sensors that monitor particulate levels in real-time and alert operators when concentrations exceed safe thresholds. Position filtration units strategically to provide coverage of all storage areas. Implement daily filter inspections and monthly replacements. This engineering control protects air quality and worker health.

name: Install Redundant Temperature Monitoring System with Automatic Shutdown
description: Upgrade all heat shrink packaging machines with dual temperature sensors that operate independently. Install a backup thermostat control system that automatically initiates equipment shutdown if primary sensor fails or readings exceed safe parameters by more than 15 degrees Celsius. Integrate the system with building management software to send real-time alerts to maintenance staff and shift supervisors when temperature anomalies are detected. Program automatic alerts to trigger at 80% of maximum safe temperature to allow for preventive intervention before hazardous conditions develop.

name: Establish Preventive Temperature Sensor Replacement Schedule
description: Implement a mandatory quarterly replacement schedule for all temperature sensors on heat-sensitive equipment. Create a maintenance calendar tracking sensor replacement dates and calibration verification. Conduct sensor calibration testing before reinstallation to ensure accuracy within ±1 degree Celsius specification. Establish a spare parts inventory of temperature sensors to prevent delays in replacement. Train maintenance technicians on proper sensor installation procedures and verification protocols to eliminate installation errors that could compromise sensor accuracy.

name: Conduct Facility-Wide Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Compliance Audit and Remediation
description: Perform a comprehensive audit of all equipment to verify that all interlock switches, lockout points, and tagout stations are properly functional and accessible. Create a detailed inventory of every equipment item with energy sources requiring LOTO compliance. Replace all disabled, missing, or malfunctioning interlock switches with certified safety devices. Establish a permanent tracking system to log any LOTO device maintenance or modifications. Implement a monthly verification protocol where maintenance supervisors physically test all interlock switches to ensure operational integrity. Any discovered failures must be corrected within 24 hours.

name: Mandatory Refresher Training on LOTO Procedures and Interlock Switch Operation
description: Require all maintenance staff, regrind technicians, and equipment operators to complete 4-hour LOTO refresher training within 2 weeks. Include specific modules on interlock switch function, inspection procedures, and failure recognition. Conduct hands-on demonstrations of proper lockout device application and verification procedures. Include assessment quizzes with 100% pass requirement; staff achieving less than 80% must complete remedial training. Document all training completion with attendance records. Establish quarterly mini-training sessions to reinforce procedures and address identified knowledge gaps.

name: Install Machine Access Safety Guarding with Integrated Lockout Points
description: Design and install physical access guards around all rotating screw feeder mechanisms that prevent operator hands from reaching moving components during normal operation. Install redundant lockout/tagout attachment points that are clearly marked and easily accessible. Ensure all guards can only be removed by authorized maintenance personnel using required LOTO procedures. Install warning labels and hazard indicators on all guard access points. Test all guard functionality and LOTO integration with full equipment startup verification before returning equipment to service.

name: Implement Comprehensive Crane Maintenance and Load Testing Program
description: Establish a rigorous preventive maintenance schedule for all overhead crane systems with documented monthly inspections and load testing. Hire a certified crane inspection service to perform detailed quarterly audits of mechanical and electrical systems. Require that all load testing results be documented and maintained in a digital maintenance management system. Set maximum load limits for each crane section and install visible weight limit placards. Cross-train backup operators to provide redundancy and implement a peer review system for all crane operations exceeding 50% of rated capacity.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Racking System and Install Safety Barriers
description: Replace damaged racking with modern warehouse storage systems that include anti-collapse features and load-rated identification. Install protective barriers and guard rails around high-value material storage areas to contain potential spillage. Implement a color-coded racking system to indicate load limits and material types. Add impact protection columns at critical racking intersections. Train all warehouse personnel on proper load distribution and maximum stacking heights for different material types.

name: Establish Mandatory Pre-Use Container Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a formal visual inspection procedure for all incoming hazardous material containers before they are placed into storage or used in operations. Create an inspection checklist that includes examination of handle rings, seams, caps, and structural integrity. Train all materials handlers and operators to conduct these inspections and reject any containers with visible defects. Establish a vendor accountability system whereby suppliers are notified of defective containers and required to implement corrective actions. Document all inspections and defects in a digital tracking system.

name: Upgrade Chemical Handling Equipment and Establish Safe Lifting Zones
description: Procure mechanical lifting aids and drum handlers to eliminate manual lifting of heavy chemical containers. Designate a specific chemical staging area with proper ergonomic workstations and mechanical handling equipment. Provide training on the use of all mechanical lifting devices and prohibit manual lifting of drums exceeding 25 pounds. Install secondary containment systems to capture potential spills from damaged containers. Create clear signage indicating proper handling procedures and emergency response contacts for chemical incidents.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedure Enforcement on All Injection Lines
description: Implement comprehensive mandatory lockout/tagout procedures on all 32 injection molding machines. Every operator must shut down the machine, lock the main electrical panel with personal locks, and allow minimum 45-minute cooling time before any barrel access. Install laminated LOTO checklists at each machine station with mandatory supervisor sign-off. Conduct retraining for all production staff on LOTO protocols within 5 days. Implement daily audits for 30 days, then weekly audits ongoing.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring Sensors on Barrel Systems
description: Install digital temperature sensors on all injection molding machine barrels that display real-time temperature on external control panels. Sensors will automatically display RED when temperature exceeds 100°C, preventing operator access. Integrate with LOTO system so machine cannot be manually accessed until sensor confirms barrel temperature below 50°C. This engineering control eliminates guesswork regarding barrel cooling.

name: Heat-Resistant Protective Equipment Upgrade
description: Provide all injection molding operators with flame-resistant protective sleeves rated to 400°C and updated first aid training specific to thermal burns. Establish requirement that sleeves must be worn whenever approaching active molding equipment, regardless of task. Store emergency cold water stations with ice within 10 feet of each molding line. Train all operators on proper cold water immersion procedures for burn incidents.

name: Regrind Equipment Two-Person Verification System
description: Implement mandatory two-person verification system for regrind equipment operation. Operator feeding material must verbally confirm 'Clear to activate' and receiver must visually confirm all hands clear of auger area before activation. Install interlock switch requiring both operators to press separate activation buttons within 2 seconds. Post large warning signs at hopper access points. This administrative control with engineering reinforcement eliminates single-operator activation errors.

name: Implement Chemical Drum Inventory Management System
description: Establish FIFO (First-In-First-Out) chemical inventory system with maximum storage duration limits of 12 months for reactive resin compounds. Create digital tracking system requiring monthly visual inspection of all stored drums for corrosion, seepage, or damage. Drums showing any signs of deterioration must be immediately segregated and scheduled for professional disposal. Install secondary containment trays under all hazardous chemical storage. Training required for all material handlers on inspection protocols and reporting procedures.

name: Enhanced Spill Response Equipment and Training
description: Install spill response kits at four strategic locations within composite materials area, each containing absorbent materials rated for chemical spills, chemical neutralizers, PPE, and spill containment barriers. Conduct quarterly spill response drills with all production and material handling staff. Designate backup spill response coordinator trained to incident command level. Update emergency response procedures to include specific protocols for polyester resin compounds and required ventilation procedures.

name: Implement Edge Deburring Station in Post-Processing
description: Install a dedicated deburring workstation in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment department with pneumatic deburring tools and edge finishing fixtures. All polycarbonate and ABS components will undergo mandatory edge inspection and deburring before assembly. Training will be provided to all operators on proper deburring techniques and inspection standards. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source by removing sharp edges before components reach assembly, preventing hand injuries during part removal.

name: Revise Quality Control Checklist for Edge Finishing
description: Update the quality control inspection checklist to include mandatory edge smoothness verification for all medical device components using tactile inspection methods and edge measurement gauges. Quality inspectors will perform 100% edge verification before components proceed to assembly. Non-conforming parts will be reworked or scrapped. Monthly audits will verify compliance with the updated checklist.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Program for Pneumatic Lift Equipment
description: Establish a bi-weekly preventive maintenance schedule for all pneumatic lift carts and material handling equipment. Maintenance includes hydraulic fluid level checks, cylinder inspection, seal replacement when seepage is detected, and pressure testing. A dedicated log will be maintained for each piece of equipment. Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand will coordinate with equipment supplier for annual professional inspections and certification. This engineering control prevents equipment failure that could cause dropped loads and crush injuries.

name: Install Load Cell Safety Switches on Material Handling Equipment
description: Retrofit all pneumatic lift carts with load cell safety switches that prevent lowering if maximum load is exceeded or if hydraulic pressure drops below safe operating range. The system will include audible warning alarms and emergency stop mechanisms. Training will be provided to all operators on the new safety system functionality and response procedures. This adds a secondary engineering control to prevent catastrophic failures.

name: Mandatory Manual Lifting Assessment and Ergonomic Training
description: Conduct ergonomic assessments of all manual material handling tasks in the regrind department. Implement administrative controls including weight limits (maximum 25kg per lift), use of mechanical assists for loads exceeding limits, and proper lifting technique training. Create job rotation schedules to minimize repetitive strain. Workers will be trained on recognizing early signs of strain injuries and reporting procedures.

name: Establish Supplier Qualification Protocol for Chemical Additives
description: Develop and implement a mandatory supplier qualification process for all plastic resin additives, masterbatches, and colorants. All new suppliers must provide certified material safety data sheets (SDS) with VOC content analysis and toxicological testing results. Chemical Safety Officer will review all documentation before materials are approved for use. This process includes inspection of supplier facilities and third-party verification of manufacturing controls. Non-compliant suppliers will be rejected, eliminating hazardous materials at the source.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System on Injection Molding Lines A-D
description: Install enhanced local exhaust ventilation systems on all four injection molding production lines, including the medical device clean room area. New systems will include real-time air quality monitoring with CO2 and VOC sensors that trigger increased extraction rates when chemical levels exceed safe thresholds. Exhaust will be directed through activated carbon filters and HEPA filtration before external discharge. The medical device line will maintain ISO 8 clean room standards while safely removing chemical vapors.

name: Implement Chemical Batch Testing and Documentation System
description: Require laboratory analysis of every new batch of colorants and additives before production use, including VOC profiling and thermal stability testing. Environmental Compliance Specialist will maintain a chemical inventory database with test results, SDS documents, and safe handling procedures for each material. Production supervisors must verify batch documentation matches received materials. Non-compliant batches will be quarantined and returned to suppliers. Monthly audits will verify compliance.

name: Implement Mold Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for injection molding equipment with inspections every 500 production cycles to identify and address mold wear before sharp burrs develop. Conduct detailed dimensional checks and surface inspections of mold cavities and cores. Create a maintenance log tracking all mold repairs and replacements. This engineering control will eliminate the root cause of burr formation at the source, reducing repeat incidents and improving product quality. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in deburring-related injuries within 6 months.

name: Provide Protective Finger Guards for Manual Part Extraction
description: Issue cut-resistant finger guards (ANSI A4 rated) to all assembly and finishing operators who perform manual part removal operations. The guards provide protection against sharp edges and burrs while maintaining dexterity for precision handling. Conduct training on proper selection and usage of protective equipment. This PPE-based control serves as an interim measure while mold maintenance improvements are implemented. Expected outcome: Eliminate finger laceration incidents during part extraction operations.

name: Revise Quality Control Deburring Standards
description: Restore full deburring cycle times that were previously shortened to meet production schedules. Implement a no-compromise quality control policy where deburring operations cannot be expedited regardless of production demands. Establish a training refresher for quality assurance specialists on critical burr detection methods. Document all deburring inspections with photographic evidence. This administrative control ensures that production pressure does not compromise worker safety. Expected outcome: 100% elimination of internal burr defects on medical device components.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Predictive Maintenance Program
description: Establish a predictive maintenance protocol for all hydraulic systems utilizing pressure monitoring sensors and scheduled fluid analysis every 6 months. Create a work order system that triggers automatic maintenance alerts at 12-month intervals with mandatory completion before continuing equipment operation. Track all hydraulic component replacements and fluid condition tests in a centralized database. Partner with hydraulic equipment supplier for quarterly inspections of high-pressure coupling connections. This engineering control will detect degradation before catastrophic failure occurs. Expected outcome: Eliminate hydraulic system failures and associated production disruptions.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Corrosion Protection
description: Replace existing hydraulic hose assemblies with corrosion-resistant stainless steel alternatives rated for high-humidity warehouse environments. Apply protective coating to all exposed hydraulic fittings and couplings. Install desiccant breathers on hydraulic reservoirs to prevent moisture ingress. Increase the frequency of visual inspections from quarterly to monthly, with documented photo evidence of coupling conditions. This substitution control replaces vulnerable carbon steel components with inherently more durable materials designed for warehouse conditions. Expected outcome: Extend service life of hydraulic components by 300% and eliminate corrosion-related failures.

name: Install Damage Detection System for Chemical Containers
description: Implement a visual damage inspection protocol requiring all chemical storage drums to be checked for physical integrity before and after repositioning in the warehouse. Install pressure-sensitive tamper indicators on all resin storage containers that visually confirm seal integrity. Establish a quarantine zone for any containers showing signs of damage, impact, or seal compromise. Create a photographic documentation system for any container drops or impacts. Train all material handlers on proper handling techniques for pressurized and sealed containers. This engineering and administrative control ensures damaged containers are identified and segregated before leakage occurs. Expected outcome: Prevent 100% of chemical spills caused by container damage.

name: Upgrade Secondary Containment and Floor Drain Protection
description: Expand secondary containment berm capacity in the chemical storage area from current 25% to 110% of the largest container volume. Install high-flow emergency shut-off valves on all floor drains in the chemical storage and mixing area with manual and automatic triggers. Apply epoxy-resistant sealant coating to concrete floor surfaces and create sloped surfaces directing spills toward contained collection sump rather than drains. Install VOC monitoring sensors that alert staff when vapor levels exceed 50% of exposure limits. This engineering control prevents environmental release and provides early warning of volatile emissions. Expected outcome: Eliminate environmental contamination pathways and provide real-time monitoring of chemical hazards.

name: Implement Mandatory Chemical Handling Training and Incident Reporting
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive chemical handling training to all warehouse and production staff with emphasis on container damage reporting procedures. Establish a no-penalty incident reporting system where any container impact or seal damage must be reported immediately to supervisory staff. Create a daily inspection checklist for chemical storage areas completed by shift supervisors. Implement a reward system recognizing employees who report hazards before incidents occur. Track all reported near-misses and container integrity issues in a centralized database. This administrative control ensures rapid response to damage before environmental release occurs. Expected outcome: Achieve 100% incident reporting rate with average response time of less than 2 hours for reported container damage.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Pressure Testing
description: Establish a formal quarterly inspection program for all hydraulic couplings and pressure-bearing components in the production lines. This will involve using calibrated pressure gauges and ultrasonic flaw detection to identify developing fractures before catastrophic failure. The program will document all findings in a centralized maintenance database and trigger immediate component replacement if pressure-bearing integrity is compromised. Expected outcome: Prevent 90% of potential hydraulic system failures through early detection.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays Under All Cooling Systems
description: Design and install stainless steel secondary containment trays beneath all injection molding machines with active cooling systems. These trays will capture 125% of the volume of hydraulic fluid in each system's circuits. The trays will have drain valves for safe disposal of contained fluid and will prevent environmental contamination and worker exposure. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of pressurized fluid contact with operators.

name: Enhance Operator Emergency Response Training
description: Develop a specialized 4-hour training module focused on immediate response procedures for hydraulic system failures. All production operators will receive annual certification covering: proper emergency shutdown protocols, safe evacuation from pressurized zones, first aid for thermal burns, and communication procedures. Stéphane's correct response will be used as a case study for exemplary emergency behavior. Training will include hands-on drills with shutdown systems and simulated emergency scenarios.

name: Replace All Corroded Storage Rack Binding Straps
description: Conduct a complete inventory of all metal binding straps and fasteners on warehouse storage racks. Replace all corroded, fractured, or compromised straps with marine-grade stainless steel hardware rated for 2000 kg load capacity. All fasteners will be torqued to specification using calibrated torque wrenches. This eliminates the root cause of pallet shifting and falling materials hazard. A maintenance log will document all replacements with date, location, and inspector signature.

name: Install Load Safety Certification Labels and Upgrade Rack Load Ratings
description: Install permanent safety labels on all warehouse racks indicating maximum load capacity, pallet weight limits, and the date of last structural inspection. Hire a professional structural engineer to certify the load-bearing capacity of existing racks and recommend upgrades if needed. Implement monthly visual inspections by trained personnel with a standardized checklist. Create a digital tracking system to ensure no overloading occurs.

name: Install Grounded Static Dissipative Transfer Equipment
description: Replace all manual acetone transfer operations with closed-loop, grounded transfer systems featuring bonded hoses, grounding clips rated for 1 megohm resistance, and static-dissipative drums certified for flammable liquid transfer. Install equipment at the Chemical Mixing Room transfer station with pressure regulators and over-fill protection devices. All personnel will receive certification training on the new equipment. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of static ignition and reduces fire initiation probability from MEDIUM to VERY_LOW.

name: Upgrade Fire Suppression System and Implement Vapor Monitoring
description: Install an advanced foam suppression system with dual nozzles and upgraded capacity to cover 6000 cubic feet of chemical storage space. Install real-time volatile organic compound (VOC) vapor monitoring sensors that trigger automatic ventilation system activation when acetone vapor concentration exceeds 500 ppm. Integrate sensor data with facility alarm system to alert operators before fire-risk thresholds are reached. Conduct quarterly fire suppression system inspections and annual professional inspections by certified technicians.

name: Implement Chemical Storage Area Administrative Controls and Training
description: Establish a formal Chemical Storage Procedure Manual requiring: only grounded personnel in the chemical mixing zone, mandatory 15-minute ventilation purge before chemical operations begin, no non-essential equipment or ignition sources within 20 feet of storage areas, and daily pre-shift vapor level verification. Require all personnel with chemical handling duties to complete annual hazardous materials certification including static electricity prevention. Conduct monthly refresher toolbox talks on chemical fire hazards.

name: Install Heat-Resistant Covers on Mold Release Applicators
description: Install silicone-based thermal insulation sleeves on all mold release agent applicator units throughout Line B and adjacent lines. This engineering control will prevent skin contact with heated surfaces by creating a physical barrier. The sleeves will be rated for temperatures up to 80°C and replaced quarterly. This directly eliminates the root cause of the incident by removing the hazard at its source, reducing reliance on personal behavior and PPE compliance.

name: Mandatory PPE Compliance Training for Production Lines
description: Implement mandatory monthly refresher training for all injection molding technicians on proper PPE usage, specifically emphasizing the requirement to wear nitrile gloves during all mold-related operations. Training will include case studies from similar incidents and will be tracked via attendance records. Supervisors will conduct daily pre-shift briefings reinforcing PPE requirements, with non-compliance resulting in work stoppage and retraining.

name: Implement Enhanced Mold Design Review Process
description: Establish a formal mold design review checklist that requires all new and modified molds to undergo documented inspection for sharp edges, burrs, and pinch points before they enter production or maintenance use. A designated quality engineer will sign off on each mold, certifying all edges are deburred to ISO 13715 standards. This engineering control eliminates the hazard by removing sharp edges at the source, preventing incidents during maintenance operations.

name: Install Protective Edge Guards on High-Risk Mold Cavities
description: Fabricate and install removable polycarbonate safety guards on all mold cavities identified as having sharp or difficult-to-access edges. These guards will prevent hand contact with hazardous surfaces during cleaning operations. Guards will be clearly labeled and integrated into the mold maintenance procedure documentation. This provides a physical engineering barrier between workers and the hazard.

name: Mandatory Mold Maintenance Safety Certification
description: Require all maintenance technicians and production operators performing mold cleaning to complete a certified mold maintenance safety course covering hazard identification, proper tool usage, safe cleaning techniques, and personal protective equipment requirements. Certification must be renewed annually. This administrative control ensures workers understand the risks and proper work practices for mold maintenance activities.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Hazardous Waste Management Area
description: Install a dedicated, continuously-operating local exhaust ventilation system in the Hazardous Waste Management Area with capture hoods positioned directly above all waste disposal drums. The system will be rated for solvent vapor extraction and monitored daily. This engineering control ensures that any vapor emissions are captured at the source and safely evacuated, eliminating inhalation hazards regardless of procedural compliance.

name: Implement Double-Lock Waste Drum Closure Procedure
description: Redesign waste drum closure protocol to require all waste disposal drums to be sealed with both a primary threaded lid AND a secondary tamper-evident safety clip. All employees handling hazardous waste will be trained to verify both closure points are secure. Create a simple laminated checklist posted at each waste station. This administrative control ensures that vent caps remain properly sealed throughout all handling operations, preventing vapor release.

name: Mandate Supplied-Air Respirator Use During Waste Transfer Operations
description: Require all employees involved in hazardous waste transfer operations to wear NIOSH-approved supplied-air respirators during the transfer process, regardless of visible vapor presence. Establish a refit testing and maintenance schedule. This PPE-level control provides respiratory protection in case of unexpected vapor exposure, serving as a backup to engineering controls.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Program for Cooling Systems
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and maintenance schedule for all cooling water circuits across injection molding lines. This includes visual inspection for corrosion, pressure testing, and replacement of couplings showing signs of wear. Maintenance logs will be tracked in the facility's computerized maintenance management system (CMMS). Training will be provided to all maintenance technicians on identifying early-stage corrosion and coupling failure indicators. This addresses the root cause of inadequate maintenance intervals by creating a systematic, documented approach to equipment monitoring. Expected outcome: reduction in unplanned cooling system failures by 85% within 12 months.

name: Upgrade Cooling System Couplings to Corrosion-Resistant Materials
description: Replace standard carbon steel couplings on all 32 injection molding machines with stainless steel or duplex steel couplings that offer superior corrosion resistance in acidic cooling environments. This engineering control eliminates the susceptibility to stress corrosion cracking that affected the Line B machine. Couplings will be sourced from OEM-approved suppliers and installation will be completed during scheduled maintenance windows. A phased approach will replace 8 machines per month to avoid extended downtime. This substitution control directly prevents future coupling failures caused by mineral deposits and coolant chemistry imbalances.

name: Implement Mold Edge Deburring and Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory deburring and edge smoothing procedure for all injection molds after each production run. Quality Control Inspector Lidia Fernandes will lead implementation of a visual inspection checklist that identifies any sharp burrs, cracks, or defects on mold surfaces before molds are returned to storage or used in subsequent runs. All technicians performing mold maintenance will use fine-grit abrasive pads to smooth rough edges. A photographic database will be created documenting acceptable vs. unacceptable mold conditions. This administrative control eliminates the hazardous sharp edges by preventing their occurrence in the first place. Expected outcome: reduction in mold-related hand injuries by 90% within 3 months.

name: Upgrade to Cut-Resistant Work Gloves for Mold Maintenance
description: Procure and distribute Level 4 cut-resistant work gloves (ANSI A4 rated) to all technicians performing mold maintenance and part extraction tasks. Current work gloves provide insufficient protection against sharp mold edges. New gloves feature high-performance polyethylene fiber liners that resist cuts while maintaining dexterity for precision work. All technicians will be trained on proper glove selection and fit during the next monthly JHSC meeting. While PPE is a lower-level control, it serves as an interim protection measure until all molds are retrofitted with edge protection. Gloves will be replaced quarterly or when visible damage occurs.

name: Install Edge Guards on High-Risk Mold Components
description: Engineer and install protective edge guards or protective tape on all identified sharp edges within molds that cannot be physically smoothed. This will include adding silicone protective strips or aluminum edge guards to mold cavities where technicians commonly insert hands during part extraction. Guards will be designed to not interfere with mold function or part quality. All 32 injection molding machines will be assessed to identify mold components requiring guards. Installation will be completed over 6 weeks in coordination with scheduled maintenance. This engineering control provides passive protection by making hazardous edges physically inaccessible during normal maintenance operations.

name: Restore and Upgrade Local Exhaust Ventilation at Mixing Stations
description: Conduct a comprehensive assessment of the local exhaust ventilation (LEV) system serving the material hopper and mixing operations. This includes cleaning/replacing all intake filters, repairing ductwork, and increasing extraction capacity to achieve minimum 2000 CFM at the breathing zone. Install supplementary extraction hoods directly over hopper loading points to capture fibers at the source. All ductwork will be sealed to prevent dust bypass. A qualified HVAC contractor will perform the work and provide performance testing documentation. Ventilation will be monitored quarterly thereafter. This engineering control directly eliminates airborne fiber exposure by removing contaminants at the source before they reach the worker's breathing zone.

name: Implement Mandatory Respiratory Protection Program for Fiber-Reinforced Material Handling
description: Establish a comprehensive respiratory protection program compliant with CNESST regulations for all employees handling glass-filled or carbon-filled composite materials. This includes medical evaluations for all affected workers, fit-testing for P100 respirator masks, and quarterly re-fit testing. Workers will be trained on proper donning/doffing procedures, mask maintenance, and cartridge replacement. All material handlers will be required to wear appropriate respiratory PPE when working with fiber-reinforced resins until engineering controls are fully validated. A designated area will be established for secure storage of respirators. Training will be provided by the Training Coordinator within 2 weeks of incident.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Systems
description: Create a documented preventive maintenance program for all local exhaust ventilation systems, dust collectors, and intake air filters throughout the facility. Maintenance tasks will include monthly visual inspections, quarterly filter replacements, and semi-annual ductwork cleaning. A computerized tracking system will monitor all maintenance activities and alert supervisors when maintenance is due. Responsibility for oversight will be assigned to the Maintenance Coordinator. This administrative control ensures ventilation systems remain effective and prevents the 9-month gap in filter replacement that contributed to the incident. Expected outcome: consistent reduction in airborne contaminant levels.

name: Implement Load Securing and Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-operation checklist for all forklift operators requiring visual inspection of load banding and securing straps before transport. Replace all deteriorated plastic banding with reinforced metal or synthetic strapping rated for 200+ kg loads. Conduct a facility-wide audit of all stored materials to identify inadequately secured items. Implement monthly banding replacement schedule and provide operator training on proper load stabilization techniques. This addresses the root cause of improper load securing.

name: Install Load Restraint Systems on Storage Racks
description: Install additional containment barriers and load stops on storage racks in the warehouse to prevent materials from falling into work areas below. Add 60 cm high perimeter railings around the quality control work station. Install impact-resistant protective barriers around all active workstations near storage areas. This engineering control will prevent future falling object incidents and protect personnel and equipment.

name: Establish Mandatory Chemical Vessel Cleaning Procedure
description: Implement a strict shift-end cleaning protocol requiring all mixing vessels to be thoroughly cleaned and documented before the end of each shift. Introduce a log sheet at each mixing station where operators must sign off on cleaning completion, with photos of clean vessels required. Create color-coded tags indicating vessel status (clean/in-use/awaiting cleaning). Train all personnel on incompatible chemical reactions and cross-contamination risks. Conduct quarterly audits of cleaning compliance and provide refresher training biannually.

name: Install Real-Time Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install automated temperature sensors and alarm systems on all mixing vessels in the chemical storage area that alert operators immediately when temperatures exceed safe thresholds (35°C threshold with audio/visual alarm). Integrate sensors with the facility management system for remote monitoring. Install emergency shut-off switches within arm's reach of all mixing stations. This engineering control provides early warning of exothermic reactions and prevents escalation.

name: Enhance Shift Handover Communication Protocol
description: Develop and implement a formal shift handover checklist that must be completed by outgoing and incoming shift leads at the start of each shift. The checklist must specifically address the status of all active chemical processes, vessel conditions, and any potential hazards. Require supervisory sign-off on the handover log. Conduct daily toolbox talks (5 minutes) focusing on chemical handling awareness. Review all chemical safety procedures during new employee orientation.

name: Install Automatic Temperature Monitoring and Shut-Off System
description: Install automated temperature sensors on all 12 injection molding machines with real-time display and alert functionality. Program the system to automatically reduce power and halt the molding cycle if temperatures exceed 160°C (5°C safety margin above standard operating temperature). Integrate the system with the facility's predictive maintenance program to log temperature anomalies for trend analysis. This eliminates the hazard of uncontrolled temperature increases.

name: Implement Mandatory Equipment Inspection and Shift Handover Log
description: Require operators to conduct a detailed equipment inspection at the start of each shift, specifically checking temperature control units, pressure gauges, and safety interlocks. Establish a signed shift handover log where operators must document any anomalies or concerns with equipment. Empower operators to remove equipment from service immediately if temperature anomalies are detected. Conduct monthly safety audits of the logs and provide operators with immediate feedback on reporting compliance.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment and Training
description: Issue all injection molding operators with heat-resistant aluminized gloves rated for up to 250°C and long-sleeved fire-resistant sleeves as standard PPE for mold opening operations. Conduct mandatory training on proper PPE donning/doffing procedures and burn first aid. Install additional emergency eyewash and full-body shower stations within 3 meters of each molding line. Provide annual refresher training on thermal hazard recognition and response procedures for all production personnel.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule for all injection molding machine hydraulic ejector systems using vibration analysis and thermal imaging. Monthly inspections will be conducted by certified maintenance technicians to detect hydraulic fluid leaks, pressure anomalies, and thermal signatures indicating system degradation. Maintenance logs will be tracked in the facility's CMMS system with automatic work order generation when thresholds are exceeded. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the mold engagement failure by ensuring optimal hydraulic system performance.

name: Install Automated Mold Extraction Safety System
description: Design and install an automated mold extraction mechanism on Line A that utilizes pneumatic ejection with integrated proximity sensors to prevent manual contact with hot mold surfaces. The system will feature automatic shutdown interlocks that prevent operator manual intervention when mold temperatures exceed 120°C. Operators will be trained on the new system with competency assessments before returning to full production duties. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of direct contact with hot surfaces during routine operations.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment Standards
description: Replace current cotton work gloves with specialized heat-resistant Kevlar-lined gloves rated for 200°C contact and extended exposure. All operators on injection molding lines will receive new gloves with proper fit testing and training on correct donning/doffing procedures. Gloves will be inspected weekly and replaced immediately upon any visible damage. While this is a PPE control (lower hierarchy priority), it serves as interim protection pending full system automation implementation.

name: Install Static Dissipation Bonding System in Chemical Storage
description: Implement a comprehensive grounding and bonding system in UNIT-010 including conductive flooring, bonding cables for all storage drums and transfer containers, and static dissipation work benches rated for solvent handling. All transfer operations will require connection to the grounding system before any liquid movement occurs. Monthly continuity testing will verify system integrity. This engineering control eliminates the static electricity hazard through physical infrastructure modifications.

name: Upgrade Fire Suppression System for Flammable Liquids
description: Replace or augment the existing water-based sprinkler system in the chemical storage area with a combination suppression system including automatic dry chemical foam discharge and Class B fire extinguishers strategically positioned every 10 meters. Install foam-compatible drainage systems to manage residual suppressant. Conduct quarterly inspections of all suppression equipment with annual full system pressure testing. This engineering control provides appropriate fire suppression methods specific to flammable liquid fires.

name: Enhance Ventilation System with Solvent Vapor Removal
description: Install a dedicated solvent vapor extraction system above all transfer work areas with minimum 12 air changes per hour capacity and continuous operation during all solvent handling activities. Add carbon filtration to the exhaust stream to capture volatile organic compounds. Implement real-time vapor concentration monitoring with audible alarms when vapor levels exceed 25% of lower explosive limit. This engineering control reduces accumulated vapors that could provide fuel for ignition sources.

name: Implement Enhanced Chemical Transfer Procedures and Training
description: Develop new standard operating procedures for solvent transfer that mandate: grounding continuity verification before any transfer initiation, use of conductive transfer equipment only, limitation of container sizes to 5-gallon volumes maximum, and 100% compliance with bonding protocols verified by supervisor sign-off. Conduct comprehensive retraining of all chemical handling staff with competency assessments and monthly refresher sessions. Establish audit program with 10% daily observation of transfer operations by supervisors. This administrative control ensures proper procedures are followed consistently.

name: Implement Cable and Hose Management Infrastructure
description: Install permanent cable tray systems and flexible conduit routing throughout the clean room production area with dedicated channels for compressed air hoses, electrical cables, and hydraulic lines. All maintenance activities will require post-work restoration of hoses to secured positions within the management infrastructure. Maintenance technicians will complete a facility checklist verifying all hoses are properly routed before clocking out. This engineering control eliminates trip hazards through proper infrastructure design.

name: Establish Post-Maintenance Inspection and Sign-Off Protocol
description: Develop a mandatory post-maintenance inspection procedure requiring maintenance personnel and a supervisor to jointly verify that all work areas are restored to safe operational status before the work order is closed. A photographic record will be taken for high-hazard areas. Maintenance work must not be considered complete until the facility area is inspected and approved by Quality/Production supervision. This administrative control ensures housekeeping issues are caught immediately after maintenance.

name: Install Thermal Barrier Guards on All Injection Molding Machines
description: All 32 injection molding machines will be retrofitted with thermal barrier guards around heated mold surfaces, reducing direct contact exposure. Guards will be designed to permit normal equipment operation while maintaining a minimum 50mm standoff distance from heat sources exceeding 200°C. Installation will follow ISO 13852 standards for guard design. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard rather than relying on operator awareness. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in heat contact burn incidents.

name: Implement Temperature Display Verification Procedure
description: Establish a mandatory pre-shift verification protocol where operators must visually confirm barrel and mold temperature displays match expected setpoints using calibrated infrared thermometers. Display discrepancies must be reported to maintenance immediately. Monthly equipment audits will verify display accuracy against actual temperatures. Training will be provided to all production operators on the new protocol.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Equipment
description: Implement a monthly preventive maintenance program for all forklifts and material handling equipment with documented hydraulic fluid level checks and leak inspections. All equipment showing fluid loss exceeding 100ml will be immediately removed from service pending repair. Maintenance logs will be reviewed weekly. This eliminates the root cause—unaddressed hydraulic leaks creating slip hazards—through systematic oversight.

name: Install Edge Guards on Resin Storage Drums
description: All resin storage drums in the Raw Materials Warehouse will have smooth rounded edge guards installed to minimize sharp edge injury potential. Additionally, all drums will be organized with safe spacing to prevent accidental hand contact during material handling. Staff will receive retraining on proper stacking techniques and awareness of sharp edge hazards.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System with Real-Time Monitoring
description: Install automated ventilation monitoring system with real-time airflow sensors and audible alarms that trigger when capacity falls below 85%. Implement quarterly filter replacement schedule instead of reactive maintenance. All chemical storage areas will maintain minimum 10 air changes per hour. This engineering control directly addresses inadequate ventilation, the root cause of chemical vapor exposure.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Protocol Enforcement
description: Establish a zero-tolerance lockout/tagout procedure for all injection molding operations with mandatory enforcement. Every operator must complete LOTO verification with their supervisor before any manual intervention on equipment. Install visible LOTO checkpoints at each molding line with required electronic sign-off via QR code scanning. Conduct monthly LOTO audits with penalties for non-compliance. All supervisors must complete LOTO certification renewal training within 30 days.

name: Install Automatic Mold Extraction System
description: Replace manual mold extraction procedures with an automated pneumatic extraction system on all injection molding lines. This engineering control eliminates the need for operators to manually reach into active mold areas. The new system will automatically detect and safely remove adhered components using controlled air pressure. This substitutes the hazardous manual process with an engineered control, aligning with hierarchy of controls principles.

name: Enhanced Safety Training for Production Operators
description: Develop and deliver targeted safety training covering machine entanglement hazards, proper use of emergency stops, and real-world incident scenarios. Include mandatory hands-on training using simulator equipment where operators practice LOTO procedures and emergency response. Training must be completed by all production staff within 14 days, with quarterly refresher sessions. Incorporate this incident as a case study to reinforce hazard awareness.

name: Upgrade Chemical Container Transport System
description: Replace all standard carrying straps with certified secondary containment transport carts designed for hazardous chemical containers. Each cart must have integrated spill trays with minimum 110% capacity of transported containers, mechanical braking systems, and anti-tip guards. All Material Handlers must complete new transport procedure training. This engineering control eliminates the risk of container rupture during transport by providing engineered containment and stability.

name: Install Automated Floor Drain Shut-Off System
description: Install solenoid-controlled emergency shut-off valves on all floor drains in chemical handling areas with manual override switches positioned at multiple locations. Connect system to motion sensors and chemical spill detection pads that automatically trigger drain closure within 5 seconds of a spill. This prevents chemical migration to the retention basin during emergency situations and provides a layer of environmental protection.

name: Chemical Spill Response and Environmental Awareness Training
description: Conduct comprehensive training for all personnel working in chemical storage and mixing areas covering spill prevention, immediate response procedures, environmental protection measures, and regulatory reporting requirements. Include practical drills quarterly using simulated spills. Update chemical inventory management procedures to include container condition inspections and secure securing protocols. Distribute updated emergency contact procedures and spill response kits to all relevant areas.

name: Install Automated Coolant Mist Collection System
description: Install a centralized coolant mist collection and chip evacuation system on all CNC milling machines in the workshop. This system will automatically remove metal shavings and coolant mist during machine operation, eliminating the need for manual shaving removal while equipment is running. The engineering control reduces the hazard by removing the requirement for hand contact near active cutting tools.

name: CNC Machine Safety Refresher Training
description: Conduct immediate safety refresher training for all CNC operators emphasizing the critical importance of stopping equipment before performing any manual maintenance or cleanup tasks. Include hands-on demonstration of proper emergency stop procedures, machine lockout, and safe cleaning techniques. Distribute laminated quick-reference guides at each workstation showing prohibited activities near active cutting tools. Implement weekly tool-box talks covering machine safety topics.

name: Implement Automated Deburring for Injection Molded Parts
description: Install pneumatic deburring station between the injection molding machine and manual assembly area. This engineering control will eliminate manual contact with sharp edges on freshly molded parts by automating the initial edge removal process. A compressed air-powered tumbling chamber with ceramic media will be programmed to run for 2-3 minutes on all parts before they reach the manual inspection station. This substitution of the manual deburring process addresses the root cause of the incident and reduces repetitive strain injuries. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in sharp edge injuries within this operation.

name: Enhanced Quality Control Protocol for Burr Detection
description: Establish mandatory quality checkpoint immediately after injection molding and before part removal. Implement tactile inspection procedure using gloved hand to verify all edges meet smoothness standards. Train all QC technicians on this new protocol with monthly refresher training. Add visual markers on each part bin to indicate deburring status. This administrative control ensures defective parts do not advance to the next production stage, preventing potential injuries at downstream operations.

name: Segregated Chemical Storage Area for Maintenance Workshop
description: Designate and construct a dedicated chemical storage cabinet 15+ meters away from all overhead crane equipment in the Maintenance Workshop. This engineering control eliminates the opportunity for chemical vapors or spills to contact crane cable systems. Install secondary containment in the storage cabinet rated for all solvents currently used in the facility. Install clear signage with '25-Meter Equipment Exclusion Zone' around the storage area. This eliminates the root cause of cable corrosion and prevents similar near-miss incidents.

name: Enhanced Overhead Crane Inspection Schedule
description: Implement monthly detailed cable inspection protocol instead of quarterly inspections. Create standardized inspection checklist including visual assessment, surface corrosion detection, and stress point evaluation. All inspections must be documented on a new Crane Maintenance Log maintained by the Maintenance Supervisor. Any signs of corrosion, fraying, or mechanical stress must trigger immediate cable replacement. Train all maintenance technicians on early detection of corrosion patterns. This administrative control reduces inspection intervals and catches cable degradation before critical failure occurs.

name: Installation of Mechanical Jam-Clearing Device with Hydraulic Ejection
description: Replace manual jam-clearing procedure with automated mechanical ejection system. Install a hydraulic ram-actuated clearing probe on the regrind grinder hopper that safely removes stuck material without hand insertion. The system will be activated via remote pendant from a safe distance (minimum 3 meters from the hopper). Add interlocked emergency stop buttons around the hopper perimeter that cut power to the auger. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard by removing the need for hand insertion into the feed mechanism.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedure Enforcement with Electronic Lockout System
description: Install electronic lockout/tagout (LOTO) management system on all regrind equipment requiring wireless verification that all LOTO procedures have been completed before machine restart is permitted. Every jam-clearing procedure must now include: (1) Power isolation with electronic verification, (2) Manual energy bleed-down, (3) Physical lockout device installation with 10-minute waiting period, (4) Mandatory second-person verification checklist. Implement weekly LOTO compliance audits with documented results. Any violations result in mandatory retraining before equipment operation. This administrative control ensures strict adherence to lockout procedures.

name: Comprehensive Regrind Operations Safety Training Program
description: Develop and deliver mandatory 4-hour certification course for all regrind operators covering: (1) Hazard identification specific to regrind equipment, (2) LOTO procedures with hands-on practice, (3) Prohibited activities and workarounds, (4) Emergency response procedures, (5) Pre-sizing requirements for incoming material. Include scenario-based training on responding to equipment jams using only approved methods. Require annual recertification for all operators. Implement competency assessment before allowing solo operation. This training ensures all operators understand the critical importance of proper procedures and know safe alternatives to manual jam clearing.

name: Pallet Stacking and Load Securing Standards
description: Establish and post standardized pallet stacking height limits (maximum 6 feet) and load distribution guidelines for the warehouse. Implement mandatory use of safety straps for loads exceeding 20 kilograms or stacked above 4 feet height. Provide training to all material handlers and forklift operators on proper load securing techniques. Include photo examples of compliant and non-compliant stacking at each storage area.

name: Forklift Operator Refresher Training
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all forklift operators focusing on load stability awareness and proper maneuvering in congested warehouse environments. Include assessment of pre-operation checklist compliance and load capacity verification. Implement quarterly competency assessments and identify operators requiring additional training or reassignment.

name: Ventilation System Maintenance and Filter Replacement
description: Immediately replace all intake and exhaust filters in the chemical mixing hood with new HEPA-grade filters rated for organic solvents. Schedule professional HVAC technician evaluation to verify airflow restoration to specification (minimum 150 cubic feet per minute at the work surface). Establish biweekly filter inspection protocol and implement monthly airflow verification using calibrated anemometer. Document all maintenance activities and airflow measurements.

name: Enhanced Ventilation System Monitoring Program
description: Install permanent airflow monitoring system with visual and audible alarm triggers if ventilation drops below minimum threshold. Integrate monitoring into the facility's SCADA system for remote monitoring and historical data logging. Train all chemical handling staff to recognize alarm conditions and required response procedures. Implement daily visual inspection checklist and weekly quantitative airflow measurements by trained personnel.

name: Preventive Maintenance Schedule Expansion
description: Extend the facility's preventive maintenance program to include all chemical handling area ventilation systems on a quarterly basis rather than annual. Add ventilation hood filter inspections to the monthly safety inspection checklist. Document all maintenance performed and maintain records for CNESST compliance audits. Schedule professional HVAC system evaluation annually to identify emerging issues before they affect worker safety.

name: Implement Monthly Dryer Equipment Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all resin dryer units, including monthly inspections of temperature sensor connections, cleaning of cooling vents, and calibration verification of monitoring displays. Maintenance technicians will document all inspections in the equipment log. This addresses the root cause of loose connections and restricted airflow by ensuring regular equipment servicing before failures occur. Expected outcome: 90% reduction in dryer-related equipment malfunctions and improved early detection of potential thermal hazards.

name: Install Temperature Alarm System on Primary Dryer
description: Install an independent high-temperature alarm system that triggers at 130°C on the primary resin dryer unit, providing audible and visual alerts to operators when temperatures approach unsafe levels. This engineering control ensures automatic detection and notification of temperature anomalies regardless of sensor malfunction. The alarm will be integrated with the facility's emergency management system. Expected outcome: Immediate detection of thermal runaway conditions and prevention of equipment damage or thermal incidents.

name: Mandatory Pre-Lift Load Inspection Checklist
description: Implement a standardized pre-lift inspection checklist that must be completed and signed off by both the crane operator and ground supervisor before any overhead lift operation. The checklist will include verification of strap tension, pallet integrity, weight distribution, and sling configuration. Inspections will be recorded in the daily operations log and reviewed during weekly safety meetings. This administrative control ensures systematic verification of load security before any movement. Expected outcome: Elimination of unsecured load incidents and 100% compliance with load verification procedures.

name: Install Load Monitoring Sensors on Overhead Cranes
description: Install load monitoring sensors on all overhead crane systems that provide real-time weight and stability feedback to the operator through a visual display in the crane cabin. Sensors will alert operators if load weight exceeds safe parameters or if weight distribution becomes unbalanced during lifting. This engineering control provides objective data on load status independent of visual assessment. Expected outcome: Automatic detection of unstable loads and prevention of load drop incidents through operator notification.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant PPE with Extended Coverage
description: Replace standard work gloves with specialized heat-resistant gloves featuring silicone-coated palm surfaces and extended cuff coverage (minimum 6 inches) designed for mold handling operations. Provide long-sleeved flame-resistant shirts as mandatory PPE for all molding line operators. Conduct mandatory training on proper PPE application and care. This control reduces skin exposure to hot surfaces and provides thermal protection for high-risk contact points. Expected outcome: Elimination of thermal contact injuries through improved barrier protection for operators working with temperatures above 80°C.

name: Install Automatic Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install thermocouple-based temperature monitoring sensors on all injection molding machines with digital display dashboards visible to operators and automatic alerts when mold temperature exceeds 88°C. Integrate system with production management software to log temperature data continuously and flag anomalies. This engineering control provides continuous temperature verification and eliminates reliance on equipment thermostats that may malfunction. Expected outcome: Early detection of temperature anomalies and prevention of operator contact with excessively hot mold surfaces.

name: Enhanced Equipment Maintenance and Thermostat Inspection Protocol
description: Implement daily thermostat verification procedures for all molding equipment as part of shift start-up inspection protocol. Maintenance technicians will conduct monthly calibration testing of all temperature control devices. Any thermostat reading variance exceeding ±3°C from calibration baseline will trigger immediate equipment removal from service and replacement. This administrative control ensures detection of malfunctioning temperature controls before they create hazardous conditions. Expected outcome: 100% detection of thermostat malfunctions and prevention of temperature-related incidents through proactive equipment maintenance verification.

name: Install Interlock Safety Verification System
description: Implement a dual-verification system requiring both electronic and manual confirmation that all safety interlocks are re-enabled after maintenance work. Maintenance personnel must complete a sign-off checklist, and production supervisors must verify interlock functionality before any machine restart. Install visual indicators (red/green lights) on each injection molding machine clearly displaying interlock status. Training for all relevant personnel will be mandatory before system activation.

name: Mandatory Machine Guarding and Lockout/Tagout Audit
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all 32 injection molding machines to ensure all guards are properly installed and interlocks are functioning. Implement monthly verification audits led by EHS Coordinator. Require certification from maintenance personnel before each LOTO procedure, with documentation retained for 24 months. Establish consequences for bypassing safety interlocks including retraining and disciplinary measures.

name: Enhanced Operator Training on Machine Safety Procedures
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training module specifically addressing manual part extraction procedures and when NOT to reach into mold cavities. Training will cover alternative methods for dislodged parts, emergency stop procedures, and the absolute prohibition on reaching into equipment with active safety interlocks. All operators will be required to pass competency assessment before returning to production. Refresher training will occur quarterly.

name: Install Static Electricity Grounding System in Waste Management Area
description: Install grounding mats and bonding cables throughout the Hazardous Waste Management Area to prevent static electricity accumulation. All waste containers and regrind storage areas must be grounded to a central grounding point. Personnel handling flammable materials must wear anti-static wrist straps connected to grounding points. Monthly inspection and testing of grounding system will be conducted by maintenance personnel. All relevant staff will receive training on proper grounding procedures.

name: Implement Solvent Storage and Secondary Containment Protocol
description: Relocate all solvent containers to a dedicated chemical storage cabinet with integrated secondary containment and proper ventilation. Install spill containment kits at strategic locations and establish a 2-meter exclusion zone around solvent storage areas. Require proper labeling of all containers and implement a digital inventory system tracking solvent usage. Establish weekly inspections of storage areas by EHS staff to ensure compliance and identify potential hazards before incidents occur.

name: Reorganize Regrind Material Storage and Implement 72-Hour Clearance Protocol
description: Establish clear designated storage zones for regrind materials with maximum accumulation limits. Implement a 72-hour maximum storage period before material must be either reprocessed or safely disposed of. Install metal shelving units away from electrical outlets and flammable material sources. Conduct weekly audits to ensure compliance with storage protocols. Provide training to all staff on proper regrind material handling and storage procedures to prevent accumulation and reduce fire risk.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program with Vibration Monitoring
description: Install vibration sensors on all CNC milling machines to continuously monitor spindle performance and detect early signs of bearing wear or misalignment. Integrate sensor data with computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) to automatically schedule preventive maintenance when vibration thresholds are exceeded. Train maintenance personnel to interpret vibration data and respond appropriately. This will enable detection of failures before catastrophic equipment damage occurs, reducing unplanned downtime and safety risks.

name: Establish Strict Preventive Maintenance Schedule with Compliance Verification
