description: Create a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all CNC equipment with specific intervals for spindle bearing inspection (every 6 months), hydraulic hose replacement (every 12 months), and emergency stop system testing (every 3 months). Implement a digital tracking system requiring maintenance personnel to document completion of all scheduled tasks. Assign accountability by requiring supervisor sign-off on completed maintenance. Conduct quarterly audits to ensure 100% compliance with the schedule and identify any missed or delayed maintenance.

name: Upgrade Emergency Stop System with Dual-Channel Safety Relay
description: Replace the existing single-channel emergency stop relay system with a redundant dual-channel safety-rated system (Category 3, PLd per ISO 13849-1) on all CNC milling machines. This ensures that failure of a single component does not prevent the emergency stop function. Conduct monthly functional tests of all emergency stop buttons and relay systems. Provide comprehensive training to all machine operators on proper emergency stop procedures and the importance of reporting any malfunctions immediately.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Automated Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule for all robotic arms and automated material handling systems, including weekly pneumatic system inspections, quarterly gripper force calibration tests, and real-time sensor monitoring for early failure detection. This will replace the current reactive maintenance approach. The program will include technician training on diagnostic equipment and integration with the existing maintenance management software system.

name: Install Containment Barriers Around Automated Workstations
description: Install transparent polycarbonate safety barriers and deflection guards around Injection Molding Lines B and C where robotic arms operate. These barriers will contain any ejected components and protect workers from flying debris. Barriers will be positioned to allow visual monitoring while maintaining safe distance from equipment. Implementation includes modification to existing workstation layouts and coordination with production scheduling.

name: Establish Quarterly Deep Cleaning and Ventilation Filter Replacement Schedule
description: Implement a mandatory quarterly deep cleaning program for all maintenance workshops and production areas where composite fiber dust accumulates. Establish a rotating schedule for ventilation filter replacement with backup inventory to prevent supply chain delays. Designate cleaning responsibilities by shift and create checklist procedures for supervisors to verify completion. Integrate schedule into the facility management system with automated alerts for maintenance personnel and management approval requirements.

name: Upgrade Electrical Equipment Thermal Monitoring Systems
description: Install infrared temperature sensors and automated shutdown systems on aging CNC equipment to detect overheating conditions before fire risk escalates. Equipment will automatically power down if thermal thresholds are exceeded, alerting maintenance staff via email and dashboard notifications. This engineering control will complement the existing fire alarm system and provide early warning for maintenance needs. Training will be provided to all maintenance technicians on system operation and response protocols.

name: Conduct Fire Safety Drill and Update Emergency Procedures
description: Facilitate a full-facility fire safety drill involving all shifts to practice evacuation procedures and review assembly point protocols. Update emergency procedures documentation to reflect current equipment locations and new control systems. Provide refresher training to all supervisors on fire response procedures, including how to properly shut down equipment in emergency situations. Document drill results and identify any gaps in employee understanding or facility preparedness.

name: Implement Mandatory Daily Pre-Operation Forklift Inspection Program
description: Establish a comprehensive daily pre-operation checklist for all forklifts and material handling equipment, with mandatory operator sign-off before each shift. Checklist will specifically include brake pad thickness verification using calibrated depth gauges, with replacement thresholds established at 70% wear rather than 100%. Inspections will be logged electronically in the maintenance management system. Any equipment showing brake wear exceeding threshold will be immediately removed from service and tagged with maintenance lock-out procedures.

name: Install Automated Rack Safety Load Limiters
description: Retrofit all storage racks in the Finished Goods Warehouse with automated load-limiting stops and collision detection sensors that prevent forklift penetration beyond safe depths. Install overhead mirrors and proximity warning systems to enhance visibility in high-density storage areas. Paint high-visibility floor markings indicating safe driving lanes and rack approach zones. This multi-layered engineering control approach will prevent future collision damage.

name: Implement Preventive Hydraulic System Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all hydraulic systems on injection molding machines, including monthly pressure relief valve inspections and annual replacement of relief valve cartridges regardless of performance status. All maintenance activities will be documented in the equipment tracking system. Maintenance technicians will receive specialized training on hydraulic system diagnostics and failure modes. This proactive approach will eliminate premature valve failures caused by accumulated wear and contaminants. Expected outcome: reduce hydraulic system failures by 85% within 12 months.

name: Install Hydraulic Fluid Containment Barriers
description: Design and install secondary containment barriers around all high-pressure hydraulic components on the 32 injection molding machines. These engineering controls will include drip pans with capacity for 125% of system fluid volume and sealed collection systems that route spillage to designated recovery tanks. The barriers will be fabricated from corrosion-resistant stainless steel and include inspection ports for routine monitoring. Installation will occur during scheduled maintenance windows over 8 weeks. This eliminates the hazard of uncontrolled hydraulic fluid dispersal across production floors.

name: Upgrade Emergency Response Procedures for Fluid Spills
description: Revise and enhance the emergency response protocol for hydraulic fluid spills, including immediate machine shutdown procedures, designated spill zones with marked safety perimeters, and rapid-deployment absorbent material stations. All production personnel will receive quarterly refresher training on spill containment and personal protective equipment requirements. The updated procedure will be posted at each injection molding line and included in the daily pre-shift safety briefing. Response time targets will be established: containment within 10 minutes, area secured within 15 minutes.

name: Establish Mandatory HVAC Maintenance Program
description: Implement a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all warehouse and production facility ventilation systems. This will include replacement of HVAC filter cartridges every 60 days, bearing lubrication and inspection every quarter, and complete system performance testing semi-annually. A dedicated HVAC maintenance contractor will be retained under a service agreement with guaranteed response times of 4 hours for emergency calls. All maintenance activities will be logged in the facility management system. This eliminates the root cause of ventilation failures caused by deferred maintenance.

name: Install Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring System
description: Deploy continuous VOC and particulate matter monitoring sensors throughout the warehouse and production areas, with digital displays and automated alarm systems that trigger at 50% of permissible exposure limits. The system will be integrated with the facility's building management system and configured to automatically activate supplemental ventilation when thresholds are approached. Personnel will receive training on interpreting air quality readings and responding to alerts. This engineering control provides early warning of ventilation inadequacy before employee exposure becomes hazardous.

name: Implement Burr Removal Quality Control Step
description: Add a mandatory deburring and edge-finishing step to the post-molding quality control process for all medical device housings. Establish a dedicated workstation equipped with pneumatic finishing tools, deburring compounds, and protective barriers. Quality inspectors will be trained to identify and eliminate sharp edges and burrs before parts are packaged. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source by removing the sharp edges that caused the laceration. Expected outcome: eliminate laceration incidents related to plastic flashing within one production cycle.

name: Implement Heat-Resistant PPE Requirements for Line C
description: Immediately mandate the use of Kevlar-reinforced thermal gloves (rated to 200°C) and long-sleeved protective jackets for all personnel working with injection molding equipment on Line C. Conduct a comprehensive PPE audit across all production lines to ensure operators have appropriate protection for their assigned tasks. Update the equipment procedures manual to specify required PPE by station and temperature exposure level. Conduct mandatory training for all Line C personnel on proper donning, doffing, and maintenance of heat-resistant equipment.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring and Alert System on Injection Molds
description: Install wireless temperature sensors on all injection molds in the facility with real-time monitoring displays at each workstation. Configure automated alerts to notify operators when mold surface temperatures exceed safe thresholds (>70°C). Integrate the system with the facility SCADA platform for centralized monitoring. This engineering control will provide continuous feedback to operators and prevent accidental contact with dangerously hot surfaces by alerting them to maintain safe distance during cooling cycles.

name: Revise Mold Handling Procedures and Implement Mandatory Cooling Time
description: Update standard operating procedures to mandate a minimum 10-minute cooling period between production cycles before manual part removal. Implement an automatic mold release system (when feasible) to eliminate direct hand contact with mold surfaces. Create visual work instruction cards at each station showing safe handling zones and required cooling times. Conduct refresher training with all production operators on the new procedures, emphasizing the hazards of thermal contact and the importance of adhering to cooling time requirements.

name: Establish Chemical Spill Response and Prevention Protocol
description: Implement a facility-wide chemical spill containment and response protocol. All mold release agent containers must be stored in designated secondary containment trays with absorbent pads. Staff shall receive training on proper storage, handling, and immediate spill response procedures. Establish a daily inspection checklist for chemical storage areas to identify leaks before they create slip hazards. Install absorbent mats at high-traffic areas adjacent to chemical storage. Designate 'spill response kits' throughout the facility with appropriate absorbent materials, signage, and disposal containers.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Lifting Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all overhead cranes and lifting apparatus, with quarterly inspections of cables, connections, and mechanical components. Implement a detailed inspection checklist that includes wire rope condition assessment, connection integrity testing, and load capacity verification. Maintenance records shall be maintained in a centralized database with automated alerts for equipment due for inspection. All maintenance shall be performed by certified technicians and documented with photographic evidence before equipment returns to service. This administrative control will detect equipment degradation before incidents occur.

name: Install Deburring Station with Safety Guards
description: Implement a dedicated deburring workstation equipped with mechanical deburring tools and transparent polycarbonate safety shields to eliminate hand contact with sharp edges. The station will be positioned between the molding lines and packaging area, with all operators required to deburr parts before removal from molds. Training will be provided to all Line B operators within 5 days. This engineering control directly eliminates the sharp edge hazard at the source, reducing likelihood of similar injuries from 'HIGH' to 'LOW'.

name: Mandatory Cut-Resistant Glove Protocol
description: Establish mandatory use of ANSI Level 4 cut-resistant nitrile gloves for all injection molding operators during part removal operations. Gloves will be provided at each production station with weekly inventory audits. All operators will be fitted and trained on proper glove selection and replacement procedures. This administrative control combined with PPE will provide secondary protection while engineering controls are implemented.

name: Implement Secondary Containment System for Chemical Transport
description: Install secondary containment pallets and modified forklift baskets designed to hold 55-gallon drums securely with integrated spill collection trays capable of retaining 110% of drum volume. All forklifts transporting hazardous chemicals will be retrofitted within 30 days. Operators will receive re-certification training on proper drum securing procedures and equipment inspection before each shift. This engineering control prevents spills from reaching the floor while administrative controls ensure consistent proper usage.

name: Enhanced Chemical Transport Protocol and Spill Kit Deployment
description: Develop and implement a detailed written procedure for transporting all hazardous chemicals, including specific drum inspection requirements, securing methods, and designated routes. Deploy emergency spill response kits at three strategic locations including the loading dock, and ensure all operators are trained quarterly on spill response procedures. Conduct monthly audits of forklift equipment and securing practices. This administrative control combines procedure reinforcement with increased monitoring to prevent future incidents.

name: Install Perimeter Machine Guards on Labeling Equipment
description: Install fixed polycarbonate safety guards around all pinch points on the packaging labeling machine, including the conveyor feed mechanism and guide plate area. Guards will have openings sized to prevent finger access while allowing normal part loading operations. All guards will meet OSHA machine guarding requirements. Installation will be completed within 10 days by qualified maintenance personnel. This engineering control eliminates the pinch point hazard at the source.

name: Enhanced Lockout/Tagout System Implementation
description: Implement a dual-verification LOTO protocol requiring two trained technicians to independently verify all energy isolation points before maintenance begins. Install pressure gauge monitors on all hydraulic systems to confirm zero residual pressure before work commences. Conduct monthly LOTO audits with documented photographic evidence of all isolation points. All maintenance personnel will complete recertification training within 30 days, with quarterly refresher sessions mandatory.

name: Hydraulic System Pressure Relief Upgrade
description: Replace all mechanical pressure relief valves on injection molding machines with electronically controlled relief systems that automatically bleed residual pressure when the main pump is shut down. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of unexpected pressure release during maintenance. Schedule replacements on all 32 machines over 90 days, beginning with high-risk equipment. Include pressure testing certification after each installation.

name: Emergency Ventilation System Rehabilitation
description: Replace the failing exhaust fan motor with a new industrial-grade unit meeting or exceeding current airflow specifications. Install variable frequency drive (VFD) controllers to maintain consistent 80+ CFM/linear foot extraction velocity at all workstations. Add real-time ventilation monitoring sensors that trigger automated alerts if airflow drops below 90% of design capacity. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of vapor accumulation and protects worker respiratory health.

name: Preventive Ventilation Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a formal quarterly preventive maintenance program for all HVAC systems with documented inspections, bearing lubrication, motor performance testing, and airflow verification. Maintenance logs will be maintained in the facility management system with trending analysis to predict component failures before they impact air quality. Training will be provided to maintenance staff on airflow measurement techniques and alarm system operation.

name: Thermal Control System Upgrade on All Molding Machines
description: Install redundant temperature monitoring systems on all 32 injection molding machines with independent primary and backup thermal sensors. Implement automated alerts and machine shutdown protocols when temperatures exceed safe parameters by more than 5°C. Add secondary pressure relief valves calibrated to activate at system overpressure conditions. This engineering control prevents future thermal runaway scenarios through engineered redundancy and automatic safety interventions.

name: Predictive Maintenance Program for Thermal Systems
description: Expand the existing predictive maintenance program to include quarterly thermal imaging analysis of all barrel heating elements and temperature sensor assemblies. Implement baseline thermal signatures for each machine and establish trending protocols to identify sensor degradation patterns early. Staff training will enable early identification of sensor reliability issues before equipment failure occurs, supporting the company's recent predictive maintenance initiative.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Protocol for Injection Units
description: Establish a quarterly calibration and inspection program for all injection molding machine thermostats and temperature display systems. Install real-time temperature monitoring sensors with automated alert systems that notify operators and maintenance staff if temperatures exceed setpoints by more than 5 degrees Celsius. Conduct immediate recalibration of all Line A equipment and implement daily pre-shift verification checks. This engineering control will eliminate the root cause of equipment malfunction and provide early warning of future issues.

name: Enhanced Burn Prevention Training and PPE Protocol
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all production operators on thermal hazard recognition and proper handling of high-temperature equipment. Require all operators on injection lines to wear heat-resistant arm sleeves and reinforced gloves rated for 200+ degree Celsius contact. Implement a color-coded system where molds are tagged as 'HOT' for the first 5 minutes after cycle completion. Review and update SOP documentation to include explicit temperature verification procedures before part removal.

name: Ventilation System Inspection and Lock-Out Protocol
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all ventilation dampers and HVAC controls throughout the facility within 48 hours. Install permanent position indicators and labels on all dampers showing the correct operational position. Implement a work permit system requiring HSE sign-off before any HVAC maintenance, with mandatory restoration verification before equipment is returned to service. Create a weekly ventilation system checklist that must be completed by maintenance staff and verified by the HSE team.

name: Enhanced Chemical Handling and PPE Compliance
description: Require all personnel working with solvents in the post-processing area to wear ANSI-approved chemical splash goggles and respiratory protection (N95 minimum, or organic vapor cartridge respirators in higher-exposure scenarios). Conduct immediate refresher training on WHMIS requirements for acetone and isopropanol. Install permanent signage indicating chemical hazard zones and required PPE. Distribute laminated quick-reference cards for all employees detailing emergency response procedures for chemical exposure.

name: Implement Plastic Pallet System for Chemical Storage
description: Replace all deteriorating wooden pallets in the Hazardous Waste Management Area with industrial-grade plastic pallets rated for 2000+ kg loads and resistant to moisture and chemical degradation. Establish a quarterly inspection schedule for all pallets to identify cracks, warping, or subsidence. Install level monitoring sensors under all hazardous material storage areas to detect equipment settling. Ensure all pallets maintain slope toward the secondary containment basin.

name: Enhanced Drum Integrity Monitoring Program
description: Establish a weekly visual inspection protocol for all stored hazardous waste drums, documenting observations in a dedicated logbook. Train all relevant personnel on early indicators of drum failure including seam cracks, rust, bulging, and corrosion. Implement immediate quarantine procedures for any drum showing signs of structural compromise. Procure a handheld ultrasonic thickness gauge to verify drum wall integrity during inspections. Conduct quarterly training for all staff in the waste management area on spill response procedures.

name: Install Redundant Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install a dual-channel thermostat system with independent sensors and a high-temperature alarm that triggers at 260°C. Add a secondary temperature display visible from the operator station and integrate it with the building's SCADA system to enable remote monitoring. Include a thermal cutoff device that automatically shuts off heating if temperature exceeds 280°C. This engineering control eliminates the single point of failure in temperature regulation and provides real-time alerts to prevent future overheating incidents.

name: Implement Monthly Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Dryer Equipment
description: Establish a formal preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly inspection of all dryer units, including thermostat calibration, heating element resistance testing, and ventilation system verification. Create a maintenance log and assign responsibility to Sylvain Jodoin (Automation Engineer) with backup coverage. Include quarterly replacement of thermostat batteries and annual heating element stress testing. This administrative control ensures equipment degradation is detected before failures occur and establishes accountability for equipment integrity.

name: Conduct Equipment Operator Refresher Training
description: Deliver mandatory refresher training to all material handling staff on recognizing early warning signs of equipment malfunction, including unusual vibrations, odors, temperature gauge anomalies, and appropriate emergency shutdown procedures. Training will include hands-on practice with manual shutdown procedures and proper use of emergency ventilation controls. Document attendance and competency verification. This administrative control ensures operators can identify and respond to equipment failure indicators before catastrophic damage occurs.

name: Implement Mandatory Lifting Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a detailed pre-operation inspection checklist for all lifting equipment (chains, slings, clevis pins, shackles) to be completed before each use. Inspection must include verification of locking wire integrity, pin retention, and SWL (Safe Working Load) compliance. All inspections must be logged daily with date, equipment ID, inspector name, and sign-off. Any defective equipment must be immediately removed from service and tagged for repair. This administrative control ensures equipment defects are identified before they cause failures and establish clear accountability for equipment safety.

name: Install Load Containment Barriers Around Maintenance Work Zones
description: Install steel mesh or polycarbonate containment barriers around all elevated work zones in the maintenance workshop where loads are being transferred or positioned. Barriers must be rated for the maximum load weights handled in the area. This engineering control prevents falling or shifting objects from striking personnel or equipment in adjacent work areas and limits property damage by containing impact zones.

name: Pressure Release Hazard Elimination Through System Redesign
description: Re-engineer the injection molding Line C hydraulic system to include enclosed pressure relief pathways that route high-pressure releases into sealed return lines rather than open atmosphere discharge points. Install secondary pressure containment shrouds around all maintenance ports and pressure relief vents. Replace the open maintenance port covers with sealed quick-disconnect couplers that automatically block flow when disconnected. This engineering control eliminates the uncontrolled pressurized spray hazard by preventing direct atmospheric release of pressurized hydraulic fluid.

name: Mandatory Equipment Shutdown Protocol for Anomalies
description: Implement a strict written procedure requiring immediate shutdown of equipment when any anomaly is detected (leaks, pressure fluctuations, unusual sounds, temperature changes). The procedure must explicitly prohibit continued operation for 'monitoring' purposes. Operators must report anomalies to maintenance supervision before resuming production. Include disciplinary measures for non-compliance. Display large procedure posters at operator stations. This administrative control ensures early detection prevents catastrophic failures and establishes clear expectations for operator responsibility.

name: Enhanced Personal Protective Equipment for Hydraulic Work
description: Require all operators performing hydraulic system maintenance or work near pressurized equipment to wear chemical-resistant aprons, face shields rated for hydraulic spray, and nitrile gloves. Provide training on proper PPE donning and demonstrate spray hazards using video simulation. Station PPE at the Line C control area with monthly inspections for damage. This PPE-level control provides personal protection against pressurized fluid contact until engineering controls are fully implemented.

name: Install Automated Part Removal System with Robotic Gripper
description: Replace manual part removal process on Injection Molding Line C with an automated robotic arm equipped with precision grippers. The system will handle 80% of repetitive part extraction tasks, reducing operator exposure to cumulative strain injuries. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard by removing the manual repetitive motion requirement. Expected outcome: 90% reduction in RSI complaints within 6 months. System will be integrated with existing conveyor system and PLC controls.

name: Implement Mandatory Ergonomic Breaks and Job Rotation Schedule
description: Establish 10-minute rest breaks every 90 minutes for operators on high-repetition tasks, with mandatory job rotation every 2 hours between part removal, inspection, and packaging duties. Create laminated job rotation cards and train all shift supervisors on implementation. This administrative control reduces continuous strain exposure and promotes muscle recovery. Include stretching exercises developed by occupational therapist during breaks. Track compliance through supervisor logs and monitor for reduced RSI incidents.

name: Paint High-Visibility Emergency Exit Perimeter and Install Warning Signs
description: Mark a 1.5-meter exclusion zone around all emergency exits with yellow and black striped floor paint. Install illuminated warning signs stating 'Emergency Exit - Keep Clear' and attach magnetic warning placards to nearby forklift charging stations. This engineering/administrative control creates visual barriers reminding staff to avoid blockage. Include emergency exit zones in the facility map posted at all workstations.

name: Establish Daily Emergency Exit Audit Checklist for All Shifts
description: Implement a documented daily checklist requiring shift supervisors to inspect all emergency exits at the start and end of each shift. Checklist must verify exits are fully operable, unobstructed, and properly illuminated. Use a digital log system accessible to HSE coordinator for compliance tracking. Non-compliance results in immediate escalation. Train all supervisors including night shift lead Laflamme on checklist procedures.

name: Conduct Quarterly Fire Safety and Emergency Procedures Training
description: Develop and deliver quarterly 1-hour training covering emergency egress, evacuation routes, assembly points, and exit blockage prevention. Make training mandatory for all warehouse and production staff. Include specific scenarios relevant to TechnoPlast operations and local fire code requirements. Document attendance and test comprehension with brief quiz. First session within 2 weeks.

name: Implement Mandatory Temperature Monitoring for Mold Cooldown
description: Install temperature-sensitive labels on all injection molds that indicate safe-to-touch status. Operators must verify mold temperature using infrared thermometer before beginning cleaning procedures. Implement a cooling time checklist (minimum 20 minutes post-cycle) that must be completed before maintenance work begins. Training will be mandatory for all Line A and Line B operators within 10 days. This eliminates the guesswork regarding mold temperature and creates a clear, documented procedure to prevent thermal contact injuries.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Work Gloves
description: Replace current general-purpose cotton gloves with certified heat-resistant gloves rated for up to 150°C. Distribute new gloves to all operators on Lines A, B, and C. Include glove inspection and replacement procedures in the weekly safety check. Cost includes initial purchase and quarterly replacement stock. While PPE is a lower-priority control, heat-resistant gloves provide an additional layer of protection during the transition period while engineering controls are being fully implemented.

name: Install Automated Material Handling Equipment
description: Procure and install two pneumatic lifting assists rated for 50 kg loads in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. These devices will reduce manual lifting requirements by 80%. Equipment will be mounted at ergonomic heights to eliminate bending and twisting motions. All operators will receive training on proper use within 5 days of installation. This engineering control directly eliminates the hazard by removing the need for manual lifting of heavy materials, addressing the root cause of the incident.

name: Implement Mandatory Mechanical Lifting Procedure and Training
description: Establish a facility-wide policy requiring mechanical lifting assistance for any load exceeding 23 kg. Create visual work instructions posted at all material handling stations showing proper mechanical lift usage. Conduct mandatory training for all production staff on ergonomic lifting principles and mechanical equipment operation. Include a requirement that team members must never lift heavy materials alone. Implement a 'Lift Buddy' system where two operators must verify safe lifting practices. Monthly toolbox talks will reinforce these procedures.

name: Conduct Ergonomic Assessment and Workplace Redesign
description: Hire a certified ergonomics consultant to assess all material handling areas and identify design improvements. Recommendations will include optimal hopper heights, material staging locations, and workflow optimization. Implement recommendations within 60 days. This administrative/engineering hybrid approach will systematically eliminate ergonomic stressors in the drying room, preventing future injuries similar to this incident.

name: Establish Warehouse Storage Load Limit Enforcement System
description: Paint weight capacity clearly on each pallet rack section. Implement a digital inventory management system that prevents storage of additional items once rack weight capacity is reached. Create a daily pre-shift inspection checklist for warehouse staff that includes verification of rack loading compliance. All warehouse associates will complete a 30-minute training session on proper load distribution and capacity limits. Weekly audits will be conducted by the supervisor. This combination of administrative controls and system design prevents exceeding rack capacity in the future.

name: Implement Daily Emergency Exit Verification Protocol
description: Create a daily checklist that designates a specific warehouse employee to verify that all three emergency exits in the warehouse are completely clear and accessible. This verification must occur at the beginning of each shift and be documented on a posted log. Install reflective tape on all emergency exit doors and install motion-activated lighting above each exit. Include emergency exit checks as part of monthly safety committee inspections. This administrative control ensures continuous compliance with fire code and emergency preparedness requirements.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Lighting System with Preventive Maintenance
description: Conduct a comprehensive lighting audit and replace all non-functional fixtures. Install LED lighting fixtures with 50% higher luminosity than current standards to improve visibility throughout the warehouse. Establish a monthly preventive maintenance schedule where all light fixtures are inspected and replaced if dimming is detected. Implement a 'light failure reporting' system where employees can quickly notify maintenance of outages. This engineering control improves workplace safety visibility and reduces trip/fall hazards related to poor lighting.

name: Implement Quarterly High-Surface Dust Cleaning Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly deep-cleaning procedure for all elevated surfaces, roof infrastructure, electrical conduits, and equipment in production areas where plastic dust accumulates. This will be added to the maintenance management system with assigned responsibility to the Maintenance and Engineering department. Cleaning will use HEPA-filtered vacuums and non-sparking tools to prevent ignition sources. All supervisors will receive training on dust fire hazards. Expected outcome: eliminate 95% of combustible dust accumulation.

name: Replace Faulty Thermostat and Implement Predictive Maintenance for Heating Elements
description: Immediately replace the failed thermostat on all resin mixers with redundant temperature control systems featuring automatic shutoff at 5 degrees below maximum safe operating temperature. Integrate all heating elements into the existing predictive maintenance program with monthly calibration checks. Install temperature alert systems that notify operators when elements approach unsafe ranges. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the fire.

name: Enhance Fire Detection and Suppression in Composite Processing Area
description: Install additional early-warning smoke detectors specifically calibrated for plastic dust fires at six locations throughout the West Wing ceiling infrastructure. Upgrade the existing sprinkler system coverage to include previously unprotected overhead spaces where dust accumulates. Conduct quarterly fire system inspections rather than semi-annually. Provide all production staff with annual fire safety refresher training focused on composite material fire behavior.

name: Relocate Hazardous Waste Storage to Shaded, Temperature-Controlled Area
description: Redesignate the hazardous waste management staging area to a shaded location within the Chemical Storage Building interior (maintaining exterior access for safety). Install temperature monitoring and maintain ambient conditions below 20°C year-round using upgraded HVAC. This eliminates the root cause of vapor generation from sun exposure. All chemical storage containers will be re-inventoried and transferred to the new location within 7 days. Expected outcome: eliminate vapor-triggered false alarms and reduce chemical degradation.

name: Implement Real-Time RFID Inventory Tracking for Hazardous Materials
description: Deploy RFID tag system for all hazardous waste containers to provide automated location tracking and storage duration monitoring. System will alert personnel when containers exceed recommended storage time (30 days for solvents) or when items are moved to non-approved storage areas. Integrate with the maintenance management system to trigger automated notifications to supervisors. Training will be provided to all warehouse and chemical handling staff.

name: Upgrade to Cut-Resistant Gloves for Metal Debris Handling
description: Replace standard cloth work gloves with ANSI Level 4 cut-resistant gloves (nitrile-coated with synthetic fiber reinforcement) for all personnel working in the Tool Room and Mold Manufacturing areas where sharp metal chips and aluminum shavings are present. New gloves will be assigned to each employee and replaced monthly or when damaged. Training will emphasize proper fit and inspection procedures. Cost per pair is $18, with estimated 12 replacements per employee annually.

name: Install Chip Collection Guards and Hazard Barriers at Milling Stations
description: Install transparent polycarbonate guards and chip deflection barriers around all precision milling machines to contain sharp metal debris within designated collection zones. These engineering controls will prevent chips from reaching work surfaces or employee skin during cleanup operations. Guards will feature quick-release mechanisms for maintenance access. Expected outcome: reduce laceration incidents by 85% in the Tool Room.

name: Upgrade Cooling Water System Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a monthly preventive maintenance schedule for all cooling water circuits in injection molding lines, including pressure testing and visual inspection of connection points. Technicians will document findings in the maintenance management system and flag any components showing signs of wear for replacement. This engineering-level control substitutes reactive repairs with proactive identification, eliminating the hazard before system failure occurs.

name: Install Water Detection Sensors on Line C
description: Install automated moisture detection sensors beneath the cooling water connections on Injection Molding Line C. Sensors will trigger visual and audible alarms at the operator station when water accumulation exceeds normal operational thresholds. This engineering control provides real-time hazard detection and enables immediate shutdown procedures, protecting both personnel and equipment from water-related incidents.

name: Enhanced LOTO Procedure with Pressure Isolation Verification
description: Revise and strengthen the LOTO procedures for all injection molding lines to include mandatory pressure bleed-down steps before equipment access. Technicians must use pressure gauge verification to confirm zero pressure in all hydraulic circuits before removal of covers or components. Create a standardized pressure bleed checklist that must be signed off by both the technician and a supervisor. This administrative control ensures all stored energy is safely released before maintenance begins.

name: Install Secondary Pressure Relief Markers and Guards
description: Install bright yellow safety markers and clear protective guards around all secondary pressure relief valves on injection molding lines. Add warning labels in French and English identifying these as pressurized components. This engineering control makes hazardous components more visible and physically protected, reducing accidental contact during maintenance operations.

name: Mandatory LOTO Competency Recertification Training
description: Require all maintenance technicians to complete advanced LOTO recertification training within 60 days, with emphasis on pressure system isolation, energy assessment, and real-world failure scenarios. Include case study analysis of the April 2 incident and similar near-miss events. Document all training completion and require annual refresher training. This administrative control ensures personnel maintain high competency in critical safety procedures.

name: Install Motion-Activated LED Lighting in Warehouse Aisles
description: Install high-intensity motion-activated LED lighting throughout all warehouse aisles, particularly in the materials storage sections. Lighting will activate when movement is detected and provide illumination levels of at least 500 lux in work areas. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of poor visibility during night shift operations, significantly improving hazard recognition for forklift operators and material handling personnel.

name: Upgrade Storage Rack Load Capacity and Stability
description: Conduct a comprehensive structural audit of all warehouse storage racks, particularly those in high-traffic areas near material handling routes. Reinforce racks that show signs of wear or instability. Install load-limiting devices and secondary restraint systems on all upper shelves to prevent bin migration. Add anti-tip brackets to connect rack units vertically. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of falling loads by improving structural integrity and load containment.

name: Implement Forklift Path Management and Speed Restrictions
description: Establish dedicated forklift traffic lanes marked with floor tape and signage in the warehouse. Install speed-limiting markers and require operators to reduce speed to 5 km/h in aisles between storage racks. Implement a mandatory pre-shift equipment inspection that includes brake testing and load securement verification. Create an administrative protocol requiring load spotters when operating in confined spaces during low-visibility shifts. This administrative control reduces collision risk through operational discipline and procedural safeguards.

name: Forklift Operator Safety Retraining and Recertification
description: Require all forklift operators to complete comprehensive recertification training with focus on night shift hazards, load stability, visibility limitations, and emergency procedures. Include practical driving assessments in low-light conditions and operation around storage racks. Implement annual recertification requirement with documented competency verification. This administrative control ensures operators maintain awareness of environmental hazards and safe operational practices.

name: Implement Enhanced Deburring Protocol for Complex Parts
description: Establish a secondary quality checkpoint specifically for deburring verification on automotive components with complex geometry. All parts will be inspected using touch-safe gloves before being released to the molding line. Train all finishing personnel on identifying and properly removing sharp edges and flash. Implement a tagging system for parts requiring additional finishing attention. This addresses the root cause by ensuring no sharp edges reach production operators during part removal.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Gloves to Line C Operators
description: Issue ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant gloves to all operators on Injection Molding Line A and C as PPE for part removal activities. Conduct fitting and training on proper glove usage. Establish a replacement schedule and storage system for gloves at each workstation. While engineering controls should prevent sharp edges, PPE provides additional protection during the transition period.

name: Implement Mandatory Shift Handover Safety Checklist
description: Develop and deploy a standardized shift handover checklist that must be completed and signed off by both outgoing and incoming shift supervisors. The checklist will specifically document LOTO status, machine safety conditions, and any equipment in maintenance mode. Require verbal confirmation of each safety-critical item. This administrative control ensures consistent communication of hazardous machine states across all shifts and prevents assumptions about machine readiness.

name: Conduct Comprehensive LOTO Refresher Training for All Shifts
description: Schedule mandatory LOTO recertification training for all production operators, led by Gaétan Laplante and the HSE team. Include scenario-based training on communication failures and near-miss prevention. Emphasize that operators must never assume a machine is safe and must verify LOTO status independently before any manual intervention. Track training attendance and comprehension with post-training assessments. This reinforces the critical importance of lockout/tagout procedures.

name: Install Visual LOTO Status Indicators on Line B Machines
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines on Line B with high-visibility lockout status indicator boards that clearly display whether machines are in LOTO compliance. These will be positioned at operator eye level and must be updated by whoever performs LOTO. Indicators will use color coding: Red = LOTO Active, Yellow = Maintenance In Progress, Green = Machine Operational. This engineering control provides immediate visual confirmation of machine safety status.

name: Install Secondary Containment for All Flammable Chemical Storage
description: Install compliant secondary containment pallets with integrated spill catch basins for all drums of flammable solvents, resins, and reactive chemicals in the Hazardous Waste Management Area. These containment systems will have capacity for 110% of the largest single container. Conduct staff training on proper drum placement within containment systems. This engineering control prevents chemical leaks from reaching the floor and creating fire hazards.

name: Establish Monthly Hazardous Waste Storage Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a monthly inspection program where Natasha Ivanov and the chemical inventory team conduct detailed visual inspections of all stored chemical drums for signs of damage, leakage, corrosion, or improper storage conditions. Document all findings in an inspection log and photograph any issues. Any damaged drums must be immediately transferred to properly contained and labeled interim storage. Inspect storage area walls and surfaces to ensure no rough edges contact drum bodies.

name: Improve Ventilation and Add Thermal Monitoring in Chemical Storage Zone
description: Upgrade the ventilation system in the Hazardous Waste Management Area to meet NFPA requirements for flammable vapor dispersion. Install additional exhaust fans and intake louvers to ensure continuous air exchange and prevent accumulation of volatile organic compounds. Add continuous thermal monitoring sensors that will alert if temperatures in waste disposal bins exceed safe thresholds. This addresses the oxidation hazard identified in the incident.

name: Implement Quarterly Hydraulic System Inspections
description: Establish a preventive maintenance protocol requiring quarterly inspection of all hydraulic pressure relief valves, high-pressure lines, and fittings on injection molding equipment. Maintenance personnel will conduct pressure testing at 110% of normal operating pressure and replace any components showing signs of wear or corrosion. This addresses the root cause of the relief valve malfunction by catching deterioration before catastrophic failure. Expected outcome: eliminate pressure-related equipment failures and reduce unplanned downtime by 40%.

name: Install Secondary Containment Around High-Pressure Equipment
description: Engineer and install steel-reinforced polycarbonate blast shields around all high-pressure mold release points on injection molding lines. These engineering controls will contain flying debris and hydraulic fluid spray within a defined perimeter, protecting workers in adjacent areas. Shields will be positioned to maintain operator visibility and workflow efficiency. Implementation includes installation of additional spill containment drip trays beneath hydraulic connection points to capture any fluid releases before they contaminate the production floor.

name: Conduct Hazard Recognition Training for Production Staff
description: Training Coordinator Amélie Roy will develop and deliver a 2-hour specialized training module on equipment failure warning signs, including pressure gauge anomalies, unusual sounds, vibration patterns, and fluid leaks. All production operators and material handlers will complete this training within 30 days, with annual refresher sessions. The training will emphasize immediate evacuation protocols and include hands-on identification of actual worn hydraulic components. This administrative control ensures workers can recognize early failure indicators and report concerns before catastrophic failures occur.

name: Establish Chemical Inventory Control and Segregation System
description: Implement a color-coded storage system where all chemical additives and intermediate materials are stored in clearly designated zones separate from production equipment, with individual lockable cabinets assigned to specific material types. Every container will receive a permanent WHMIS label with QR code linking to digital safety data sheets in both French and English. A daily inventory verification log will be maintained by shift supervisors. This elimination/substitution control prevents mixing of incompatible materials by creating physical and administrative barriers. Expected outcome: zero chemical incompatibility incidents within 12 months.

name: Upgrade Vapor Capture System with Real-Time Monitoring
description: Replace the existing fixed vent system with a state-of-the-art vapor capture hood equipped with active sensors that detect temperature spikes and unusual gas composition. When anomalies are detected, the system automatically increases extraction capacity and triggers audible/visual alarms at workstations. The new system includes a 10-stage filtration process with activated carbon and HEPA filters. Engineering controls will include ducting direct to outdoor exhaust with secondary containment on spent filter cartridges. This addresses root cause by capturing hazardous vapors before they reach workers.

name: Implement Enhanced Pre-Assembly Part Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory two-stage quality verification process where all composite parts undergo visual inspection under LED magnification (minimum 5x magnification) for surface defects including delamination, micro-cracks, and contamination before being released to assembly workstations. Quality Control personnel will use standardized defect classification charts and reject any parts with visible edge delamination. This administrative control at the source prevents defective parts from reaching assembly. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in assembly-related cuts and contamination incidents within 90 days.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Assembly Gloves and Hand Protection
description: Issue nitrile-coated cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rating minimum) to all assembly operators working with composite materials. The gloves provide protection against minor lacerations from sharp composite edges while maintaining dexterity for precise assembly work. Gloves will be replaced monthly or immediately upon any visible damage. As a secondary PPE control, this measure provides personal protection for workers handling materials with sharp edges while the primary control (enhanced inspection) prevents defective parts from reaching workstations.

name: Warehouse Storage Procedure Audit and Revision
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all warehouse storage racks and implement revised load distribution guidelines based on maximum weight capacity calculations per shelf tier. Establish clear visual markings on racks indicating maximum load limits and prohibited stacking zones. Create laminated reference guides for all material handlers showing correct stacking patterns. This addresses the root cause of improper manual stacking decisions by providing clear, visual guidance accessible at all times.

name: Mandatory Refresher Training on Material Storage
description: Develop and deliver 30-minute hands-on training module for all warehouse personnel covering load stability principles, proper pallet positioning, center-of-gravity concepts, and rack capacity limits. Include practical exercises with load simulators. Schedule training sessions for all shifts over a two-week period with documented attendance and competency verification. Training will be repeated annually and integrated into new hire orientation.

name: Temperature Sensor Replacement and Calibration Program
description: Replace faulty temperature sensor on Injection Molding Line D and implement quarterly calibration and replacement schedule for all temperature sensors across the 32 injection molding machines. Establish preventive maintenance documentation system that tracks sensor testing dates and results. Sensors will be replaced every 18 months regardless of apparent function. This engineering control directly eliminates the mechanical failure that caused the injury by ensuring sensors remain reliable.

name: Enhanced Heat Protection PPE Requirement
description: Issue specialized thermal-resistant gloves (Kevlar-lined, rated to 200°C) to all operators on injection molding lines. Gloves will be mandatory when performing any maintenance or adjustment tasks on molds or heating elements. Establish a glove inspection and replacement protocol, with damaged gloves replaced immediately. Post visual reminders at all workstations showing proper PPE usage for heat tasks. Include thermal PPE requirement in revised standard operating procedures.

name: Pre-Shift Equipment Checklist Enhancement
description: Expand pre-shift equipment checklist to include specific temperature sensor function test requiring operators to verify sensor response by triggering a cooling cycle test. Provide operators with written checklist in both French and English. Implement digital tracking system where operators photograph sensor readings and upload to central database before starting production. This administrative control ensures equipment status verification occurs consistently before operations begin.

name: Electrical Connection Safety Retrofit
description: Install vibration-resistant lock washers and nylon-insert lock nuts on all electrical panel connections across the CNC milling machines and other high-vibration equipment in the Maintenance Workshop. Replace standard electrical connectors with locking-type connectors that resist loosening from machine vibration. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of the loose connection by preventing vibration-induced loosening of electrical fasteners.

name: Enhanced Electrical Equipment Inspection Protocol
description: Revise the monthly electrical equipment inspection checklist to include tactile verification (tightness testing) of all panel connections using a calibrated torque wrench in addition to visual inspection. Develop a digital inspection form requiring technicians to photograph connection conditions and record torque readings. Implement a two-inspector verification system where a second qualified technician independently verifies findings before equipment is cleared for operation. Include specific focus on high-vibration equipment. This administrative control strengthens the inspection process.

name: Electrical Hazard Awareness Training for Night Shift
description: Conduct specialized 45-minute training session for all night shift personnel focusing on electrical hazard recognition, safe isolation procedures, and proper emergency response protocols for electrical faults. Include practical demonstration of warning sign placement and area cordoning procedures. Emphasize the importance of immediate reporting and area isolation when electrical faults are detected. Ensure all participants understand that electrical hazards require no direct contact to be dangerous.

name: Install Mechanical Lifting Assists at Packing Stations
description: Procure and install pneumatic lifting tables with adjustable height at all three packing stations in the Finished Goods Warehouse. These devices will reduce manual lifting to heights between waist and shoulder, minimizing back strain. Training will be provided to all warehouse staff on proper use of the equipment. The lifting tables will accommodate bundles up to 20 kg and will be integrated into standard packing procedures.

name: Implement Ergonomic Assessment and Training Program
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessment of all packing and assembly tasks. Develop and deliver mandatory training for all warehouse and assembly staff on proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, and recognition of early strain symptoms. Training sessions (30 minutes) will be scheduled monthly during shift changes. Refresher training will occur annually. Assessment will identify high-risk tasks and prioritize engineering controls.

name: Replace Pressure Relief Valves on Molding Machines
description: Immediately replace the faulty pressure relief valve on Machine Line D with an OEM-approved replacement unit rated for 2500 PSI. Implement preventive replacement of pressure relief valves on all eight injection molding lines following manufacturer recommendations (every 18 months or 8000 operating hours). Establish a maintenance schedule tracking replacement dates and pressure test results to prevent recurrence of system pressurization incidents.

name: Establish Pressure Bleed Protocol for Hydraulic Maintenance
description: Develop and implement a mandatory pressure bleed procedure for all hydraulic system maintenance. Before any component disconnection, technicians must engage the manual bleed valve and verify zero pressure on the digital gauge. Procedure will be laminated and posted at each machine. All maintenance technicians must complete certification on the procedure. Monthly audits will verify compliance. This engineering/administrative control eliminates pressure buildup as a hazard source.

name: Implement Mandatory Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Verification System
description: Establish a two-person verification protocol for all equipment maintenance and troubleshooting. Before any manual intervention on rotating equipment, the primary technician must power down the equipment, engage the lockout hasp, and place a danger tag. A second trained employee must physically verify that the lockout is engaged and confirm zero rotation of critical components before work begins. Weekly LOTO audits will be conducted by HSE staff. All technicians will receive refresher training quarterly.

name: Install Physical Guards on Regrind Mill Feed Section
description: Design and install expanded metal guards extending over the auger feed hopper opening, reducing manual access to rotating components. Guards will maintain 90% visibility for monitoring but prevent hand insertion. Installation will be performed by the maintenance engineering team to OEM specifications. The retrofit will be completed within 30 days and verified through safety inspection before return to full production.

name: Upgrade Thermal-Resistant PPE for Injection Molding Operators
description: Procure and distribute heat-resistant gloves rated to 120°C minimum and long-sleeved protective garments with thermal insulation. Conduct mandatory training on proper glove selection, donning/doffing procedures, and inspection for wear. Implement a quarterly replacement schedule for thermal PPE. This engineering control upgrade will reduce the severity of thermal contact injuries by providing superior barrier protection during high-temperature part removal tasks on injection molding lines.

name: Install Ergonomic Part Extraction Tools on Molding Lines C and D
description: Design and fabricate vacuum-assisted part extractors and mechanical handling aids to eliminate direct hand contact with hot mold cavities. Tools will be mounted on retractable arms at each workstation. Train all operators on proper tool use and maintenance. This substitution/engineering control directly eliminates the hazard of thermal contact by removing the need for manual hand insertion into mold cavities, addressing the root cause of the incident.

name: Install Machine Guarding and Interlock Systems on Compression Presses
description: Design and install fixed guard barriers around all compression mold presses in the Composite Materials Processing Area to prevent hand entry into mold cavities. Integrate mold cavity sensors with automated press interlocks that halt operation if obstruction is detected. Add mechanical presence-sensing safety devices at operating positions. Conduct comprehensive machinery safety audit and certification. These engineering controls will eliminate the critical hazard of operator hand entry into press working areas, preventing repeat incidents.

name: Implement Enhanced LOTO Procedures and Confined Space Safety Training
description: Develop detailed lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures specific to each hydraulic press model with monthly compliance audits. Provide mandatory refresher training to all press operators and maintenance personnel on proper equipment isolation, testing, and verification. Create visual LOTO instruction cards at each machine station. This administrative control ensures equipment is properly de-energized during maintenance and cleaning operations, preventing unexpected startup injuries.

name: Redesign Press Operator Workstations with Ergonomic Emergency Access
description: Relocate emergency stop buttons to positions within 30 centimeters of normal operator hand position during all operating modes. Install additional emergency stop stations on both sides of each press. Reconfigure material positioning procedures to eliminate requirement for manual hand placement in mold cavities. Add anti-fatigue mats and adjustable operator platforms to improve posture and reduce strain during monitoring activities. This combined engineering and administrative control reduces operator fatigue and improves emergency response capability.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Ventilation Systems
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all exhaust fan motors including bearing inspection, lubrication, and vibration analysis. Install bearing temperature sensors on critical fan motors with real-time monitoring linked to facility SCADA system. Create maintenance logs and trending analysis to identify degradation patterns before failure occurs. Contract with qualified HVAC technician for professional inspection and servicing. This engineering control eliminates unpredictable equipment failures by detecting issues during early stages before safety-critical system loss.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Monitoring with Automated Alarm Integration
description: Retrofit the existing air quality monitoring system with automated alerts that trigger when VOC levels exceed 150 ppm or when ventilation fan performance drops below 85% of design specifications. Install redundant backup sensors in the chemical room. Integrate alarm signals to both facility management system and direct SMS/email notifications to maintenance personnel and the HSE office. Display real-time air quality metrics on digital boards visible to all room occupants. This engineering/administrative control ensures rapid detection and response to ventilation failures, preventing worker exposure to hazardous fume concentrations.

name: Establish Emergency Ventilation System and Backup Power Supply
description: Install a secondary exhaust fan system with independent power supply and automatic switchover capability that activates within 30 seconds of primary system failure detection. Equip the backup system with a dedicated UPS (uninterruptible power supply) and battery backup for minimum 2 hours of operation. Create operational testing procedures and conduct quarterly backup system activation drills. This substitution/engineering control ensures continuous ventilation capability even during primary system failures, eliminating the hazard of fume accumulation.

name: Implement Chemical Waste Storage Protocol and Ventilation Upgrades
description: Install dedicated, properly ventilated chemical waste storage cabinets in the Composite Materials Processing Area with automatic temperature monitoring systems. Implement a maximum 48-hour storage policy for exothermic waste materials with daily segregation audits. Install secondary containment systems and upgrade HVAC specifications to ensure minimum 15 air changes per hour in chemical storage areas. Conduct staff retraining on proper waste classification and segregation procedures following WHMIS guidelines.

name: Enhanced Fire Detection and Suppression System Installation
description: Install advanced thermal imaging fire detection sensors in all chemical storage and processing areas to provide early warning of temperature anomalies. Upgrade the existing sprinkler system with specialized dry chemical suppression capabilities for solvent-based fires. Establish quarterly fire suppression system inspections and employee fire safety drills specific to composite material fire scenarios.

name: Implement Automated Deburring Verification System and Enhanced PPE
description: Install automated vision inspection system on Injection Molding Line D to detect and flag any parts with burrs or sharp edges before they reach the assembly/packaging stage. Issue upgraded cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rating) to all assembly operators and make their use mandatory during part handling. Establish a daily pre-shift equipment check to ensure deburring equipment is operational and schedule maintenance only during planned downtime windows to prevent production batches from bypassing critical finishing steps.

name: Mezzanine Storage System Redesign and Load Securing Implementation
description: Replace wooden pallets in the mezzanine storage area with purpose-designed metal racking systems featuring integrated load locks and safety straps. Install secondary containment barriers at the mezzanine edge to prevent any material from shifting toward the front edge. Implement a maximum weight limit of 100 pounds per storage unit on elevated surfaces and install weight-sensitive warning systems. Conduct a complete inventory audit and reorganize components by weight distribution principles.

name: Mandatory Safety Training and Mezzanine Access Controls
description: Implement restricted-access protocols for the mezzanine storage area, requiring all personnel to receive specialized training before accessing elevated storage. Establish a two-person rule for any material retrieval from mezzanine level. Install high-visibility signage identifying mezzanine load limits and hazard zones. Conduct quarterly refresher training for all staff on proper material handling procedures in elevated storage environments and emergency response protocols.

name: Personal Protective Equipment Enhancement for Warehouse Operations
description: Issue enhanced hand and wrist protection (Level 5 cut/crush resistant gloves with rigid wrist supports) to all personnel working in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room. Provide additional forearm protection and require their use during all material handling operations on mezzanine areas. Conduct fit testing and training on proper donning procedures to ensure effectiveness.

name: Install Mandatory Cool-Down Timer System on All Injection Molding Machines
description: Implement automated timer locks on all 32 injection molding machines that prevent mold access until the mandatory 30-minute cool-down period has elapsed. The system will display a countdown timer visible to operators and supervisors. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of premature mold contact regardless of production pressure. Integration with the existing SCADA system will log all cool-down cycles and alert maintenance staff to any timer bypasses. Expected outcome: 100% elimination of heat-related mold contact incidents.

name: Enhanced Thermal Hazard Labeling and Work Instructions
description: Install high-visibility thermal hazard warning labels at all mold access points, clearly indicating current surface temperatures and cool-down requirements. Replace existing maintenance work instructions with laminated, color-coded procedure cards showing temperature profiles and mandatory waiting times. Conduct mandatory retraining for all production operators and maintenance staff on heat hazard recognition and proper cool-down procedures. This administrative control reinforces safe work practices through environmental cues and standardized procedures.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Mold Maintenance Tasks
description: Supply all operators performing mold cleaning with cut-resistant, heat-resistant gloves rated for 150°C contact (5-second contact tolerance) and thermal protective sleeves. Gloves will be made from nitrile-coated aramid fabric with silicone backing. Store gloves in designated locations near each molding line with replacement stock maintained by supervisors. This PPE enhancement provides additional protection as a final barrier while other controls are implemented. Monthly inspection and replacement will ensure effectiveness.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Resin Drying Equipment
description: Establish a quarterly calibration and maintenance schedule for all drying chamber thermostats and temperature sensors. Integrate thermometers with the predictive maintenance software already deployed for other equipment. Maintenance technicians will conduct thermal imaging scans to verify internal heating element performance. Replace failing thermostats with digital sensors featuring real-time monitoring and automatic alert capabilities when temperatures deviate ±5°C from setpoint. This engineering control prevents equipment failures before they impact material quality or create hazardous conditions.

name: Install Automated Drying Chamber Monitoring and Alert System
description: Deploy continuous monitoring system with automated alerts sent to supervisors via email/SMS when dryer temperature exceeds 85°C or falls below 55°C. System will include a visual alarm panel in the Material Drying Room and integration with the facility's central monitoring system. Include 30-minute automatic shutdown protocol if temperature continues to rise unchecked. This administrative control ensures rapid response to equipment malfunction and prevents material degradation.

name: Install Automated Resin Container Handling System
description: Replace manual lifting of 45 kg resin containers with a semi-automated handling system featuring a lift-assist device rated for loads up to 60 kg. The system will utilize pneumatic or mechanical assistance to reduce actual lifting force required to approximately 5-8 kg. Position the system to eliminate asymmetric loads and maintain neutral spine posture during transfers. This engineering control eliminates the manual lifting hazard completely by reducing required force below safe thresholds. Implementation will be completed on the primary Material Drying Room line with expansion to secondary lines within 6 months.

name: Comprehensive Ergonomics Training and Certification Program
description: Conduct ergonomic assessment of all material handling stations and redesign workstations to maintain neutral spine posture. Implement mandatory, certified ergonomics training for all production and material handling staff (40 employees minimum). Training will include proper lifting mechanics, load assessment, and equipment utilization. Provide laminated ergonomic reference cards at each workstation. Conduct quarterly refresher training and individual assessments. This administrative control builds worker awareness and standardizes safe practices across all shifts.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Certification and Audit Program
description: Establish a comprehensive lockout/tagout (LOTO) certification program requiring all maintenance personnel and production operators to complete CNESST-approved training within 30 days. Conduct weekly LOTO compliance audits using a checklist system to verify proper procedures are followed before any equipment maintenance. All maintenance work orders must include LOTO sign-off by a certified supervisor. Non-compliance will result in immediate retraining and disciplinary measures. This engineering and administrative control directly addresses the root cause of this incident: inadequate LOTO procedures.

name: Install Hydraulic System Pressure Relief Valve Maintenance Schedule
description: Develop and implement a preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly inspection and cleaning of all pressure relief valves on injection molding machines. Technicians will inspect for debris accumulation, verify calibration against manufacturer specifications, and document findings in the maintenance management system. Replace any valve showing signs of wear or deviation from specifications. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of pressure valve failure by ensuring valves function reliably within design parameters.

name: Upgrade Machine Guards and Thermal Protective Equipment
description: Install secondary protective barriers around hydraulic fluid lines and relief valves on all injection molding machines to contain any fluid spray. Provide all production and maintenance staff with thermal-resistant protective sleeves and heat-resistant gloves rated for 200°C contact. Conduct training on proper PPE selection and use during equipment operation and maintenance. While PPE is a lower-level control, this provides immediate protection during the transition to engineering improvements.

name: Establish Emergency Exit Protection Zone Policy
description: Implement a facility-wide policy designating 36-inch buffer zones around all emergency exits and evacuation routes. Mark these zones with yellow floor paint and signage indicating no storage is permitted. Install electronic alerts on emergency exit doors that trigger alarm notifications if doors are blocked for more than 5 minutes. Conduct monthly audits of all evacuation routes. This engineering and administrative control prevents future blockage of critical life-safety exits.

name: Upgrade Emergency Exit Lighting System
description: Replace all standard exit lights with LED emergency lighting units featuring battery backup capability (minimum 90-minute duration). Conduct quarterly testing of all emergency lighting to verify functionality and battery charge status. Install a maintenance alert system that notifies the facilities team when fixtures fall below acceptable brightness levels. All bulbs will be replaced on a 3-year cycle regardless of appearance. This engineering control ensures exits remain visible during emergencies.

name: Implement Mandatory Ventilation System Pre-Shift Verification
description: Establish a daily equipment checklist for night shift requiring verification of exhaust ventilation system status before any solvent or resin work begins. Technicians must confirm airflow with visual indicators and log confirmation in the shift maintenance log. If ventilation is below operational standards, work must be postponed until repairs are completed. Additionally, install real-time CO₂ and vapor monitors in the tool room that alert when concentrations exceed safe levels. This administrative and engineering control prevents future chemical exposure incidents.

name: Provide Respiratory Protection and Training for Night Shift
description: Issue all night-shift workers in the tool room with properly-fitted P95 particulate respirators and organic vapor cartridges for use during solvent-based cleaning operations. Conduct fit-testing and training on proper donning, use, and maintenance of respirators. Establish a respiratory protection program compliant with CNESST regulations. While PPE is not the primary control, this provides immediate protection for night-shift operations when ventilation supervision is reduced.

name: Implement Quarterly Pneumatic System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish and execute a formal preventive maintenance program for all pneumatic systems, including solenoid valves, actuators, and compressed air lines. Schedule maintenance quarterly in accordance with manufacturer specifications. Create a maintenance log accessible to all operators showing completion dates and any components replaced or adjusted. Assign responsibility to the Maintenance and Engineering department to track compliance and report status monthly to the HSE committee. This engineering control eliminates the root cause by ensuring equipment functions as designed.

name: Install Pneumatic System Interlock Safety Upgrade
description: Retrofit the semi-automated trimming station with a dual-channel safety interlock system that physically prevents pneumatic clamp re-engagement during the parts removal phase. Install emergency stop buttons within 18 inches of operator hand position. Add redundant pressure relief valves to prevent unexpected clamp actuation. Test and verify the system functions correctly before returning the equipment to production. This engineering control provides physical safeguards independent of operator action.

name: Enhance Operator Training on Equipment Hazards and Safe Procedures
description: Develop comprehensive training module covering pneumatic system hazards, identifying signs of equipment malfunction, proper lockout/tagout procedures before manual extraction, and emergency response protocols. Conduct mandatory retraining for all Assembly and Finishing Department operators within two weeks. Include hands-on practice with the new interlock system. Document training completion and maintain records. This administrative control ensures operators understand risks and proper procedures.

name: Replace Forklift Load Capacity Indicator System
description: Retrofit all electric forklifts with functional load capacity indicator lights and audible alarm systems that activate when loads exceed safe parameters. Verify all equipment has current certification and calibration certificates. Establish a monthly inspection protocol to test indicator functionality. This engineering control ensures operators have real-time feedback on load safety status, preventing overloading situations.

name: Implement Mandatory Forklift Load Verification Procedure
description: Establish a written procedure requiring all forklift operators to visually verify load stability, weight distribution, and stacking height before lifting.
