Create a checklist posted at each forklift station with required verification steps. Conduct refresher training for all operators on proper load assessment. Document compliance through shift logs. This administrative control establishes clear expectations and procedures.

name: Install Automated De-Flashing Equipment with Redundant Backup System
description: Procure and install a secondary automated de-flashing station to provide backup capability when the primary unit is offline for maintenance. Establish a maintenance schedule ensuring at least one de-flashing station remains operational at all times. Prohibit manual handling of components with visible flash without protective equipment and tools. This engineering control eliminates the hazard by ensuring parts are processed safely before manual handling.

name: Implement Mandatory Cut-Resistant Gloves and Hand Protection Protocol
description: Issue cut-resistant gloves rated ANSI A4 or higher to all composite materials operators and make them mandatory PPE during manual part handling. Provide training on proper glove selection and wear. Conduct monthly audits to ensure compliance. Store gloves at all workstations and replace worn pairs immediately. Additionally, implement a visual inspection requirement before handling any component to identify and flag sharp edges. This PPE control provides personal protection while procedural changes reduce exposure.

name: Revise Maintenance Planning to Prevent Single-Point Equipment Failures
description: Develop a maintenance schedule that staggers de-flashing station servicing to ensure continuous operational capacity. Document equipment downtime requirements and coordinate with production planning to avoid processing untreated components during maintenance windows. Create emergency protocols for manual part handling procedures when equipment is offline, including mandatory use of de-flashing hand tools and protective equipment. This administrative control ensures system reliability and establishes fallback procedures.

name: Reinstall and Lock Machine Heat Shrouds
description: Immediately reinstall heat shrouds on all 32 injection molding machines and install tamper-evident locks requiring supervisor authorization to remove. Engineering will conduct a full audit of all machine guarding on molding lines to ensure compliance with ISO safety standards. Maintenance personnel will document all shroud installations with photographic evidence. A monthly inspection schedule will be implemented to verify shrouds remain in place and locked. This engineering control directly eliminates the burn hazard by eliminating direct contact exposure to heating elements.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Upgrade and Training
description: Replace all current work gloves with certified heat-resistant gloves rated for 250°C+ temperatures. Conduct mandatory 2-hour training session for all production operators on proper glove selection, inspection, and use. Training will include demonstration of thermal protection capabilities and practical application scenarios. All operators must pass a competency assessment before returning to independent line operation. Supervisors will conduct monthly spot-checks of glove condition and correct usage.

name: Implement Machine Maintenance Lock-out and Documentation System
description: Establish a computerized maintenance work order system requiring sign-off when machine guards and safety components are removed or modified. Any removal of heat shrouds, guards, or safety devices must trigger an automatic notification requiring supervisory approval and re-installation verification within 24 hours. Non-compliance will result in machine shutdown until compliant. Training will be provided to all maintenance staff on proper documentation procedures and accountability requirements.

name: Install Solvent Drum Containment and Securing System
description: Install 4 industrial-grade drum containment stations in UNIT-018 with integrated secondary containment trays (rated for 110% drum volume capacity) and heavy-duty cable tie-down systems that require positive mechanical locking. Each station will include integrated drip pans and absorbent materials. All 55-gallon solvent drums must be secured in these stations when not in active transfer. No drums shall be left unsecured on mobile carts. This engineering control eliminates the source of splash incidents by preventing drum movement from vibration or impact.

name: Expand PPE Requirements and Issue Chemical-Resistant Face Shields
description: Require all personnel in UNIT-018 to wear ANSI Z87.1-rated chemical splash goggles and full-face protective shields during any solvent transfer activities. Issue new face shields to all regrind staff and provide replacement schedule. Conduct training on proper donning, doffing, and inspection of chemical PPE. Implement 100% compliance monitoring with daily supervisor checks. Establish consequence protocols for non-compliance including retraining and temporary work restrictions.

name: Install Secondary Restraint System for Cylindrical Materials
description: Install horizontal tie-down straps and polymer cradles on all pallet racks in UNIT-007 specifically designed to secure cylindrical spools and reels. Each rack tier will be retrofitted with adjustable cable restraint systems that can accommodate various spool diameters. Spools must be secured with minimum two-point positive restraints before work on adjacent tiers can commence. Engineering will design and install these restraints to meet or exceed ANSI guidelines for storage rack safety. This eliminates the rolling/falling hazard through engineered physical restraints.

name: Replace Faulty Proximity Sensors on All Hoppers
description: All 32 injection molding machines will undergo immediate proximity sensor replacement and calibration by maintenance staff. New sensors with redundant fail-safe mechanisms will be installed to prevent accidental hopper activation during idle or maintenance modes. A comprehensive testing protocol will verify sensor functionality before machines return to production. This addresses the root cause of unexpected auger engagement and prevents similar incidents.

name: Implement Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Enforcement During Hopper Maintenance
description: Mandatory LOTO procedure will be enforced for all hopper clearing and maintenance activities. Machine operators must receive refresher training on proper LOTO sequencing, including verification that all energy sources are isolated before manual intervention. Supervisors will conduct daily spot-checks to ensure compliance. All machines will have updated LOTO procedure placards posted at operator stations with clear step-by-step instructions.

name: Install Machine Guarding Around Hopper Access Points
description: Physical barriers and expanded machine guards will be installed around all hopper access areas on Injection Molding Line A to restrict hand access to moving components. Guards will be designed to allow material loading while preventing contact with the auger mechanism. Installation will follow ISO 12100 machinery safety standards and will be completed by certified machine safety engineers.

name: Improve Component Curing and Handling Procedures
description: Implement a clear curing protocol requiring all resin-coated components to remain in designated curing racks for a minimum of 24 hours before warehouse transfer. Cured components will be labeled with cure-date tags and segregated from handling areas until fully set. Material handlers will receive training on identifying fully cured versus partially cured components to avoid unnecessary skin contact with residual uncured materials.

name: Install Anti-Slip Flooring in Maintenance Workshop
description: High-friction anti-slip coating will be applied to all floor areas in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop, with special emphasis on the washout station and adjacent walkways where water and cleaning agents create slip hazards. The coating will be industrial-grade, designed for wet environments and frequent cleaning. Installation will be completed during a scheduled maintenance shutdown to minimize production disruption.

name: Implement Wet Floor Procedures and Signage
description: Mandatory wet floor signage protocol will be established requiring warning signs to be placed immediately whenever cleaning operations begin in the workshop. Staff will be trained to use designated drainage areas and squeegees to minimize water spread. A daily inspection checklist will verify that walking surfaces are dry before workers begin scheduled maintenance tasks. Supervisors will conduct weekly audits of floor conditions.

name: Implement Monthly Dryer Maintenance and Calibration Schedule
description: Establish a preventive maintenance program requiring monthly inspection and recalibration of all resin dryer thermostats. A calibrated thermostat tester will be purchased for $800. Maintenance logs will be kept and reviewed by the HSE Coordinator. This engineering control, combined with administrative procedures, will ensure heating elements remain within safe operating parameters and reduce the risk of thermal runaway events.

name: Install Dust Collection System Around Resin Dryers
description: Purchase and install a localized dust collection system with HEPA filtration around the resin dryer area, targeting airborne plastic dust before it accumulates near heating elements. The system will include ducting, a dedicated 5 HP vacuum unit, and automatic shutoff controls. This engineering control eliminates the fire hazard at its source by removing the fuel load. Expected cost is approximately $18,000.

name: Establish Weekly Dust Cleaning Protocol for Chemical Storage Area
description: Create and enforce a documented weekly cleaning schedule for all dust-prone areas in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. Assign responsibility to Material Handlers on a rotating basis. Use explosion-proof vacuum equipment and anti-static brushes. Workers will document completion on a checklist posted at the area. This administrative control bridges the gap until the dust collection system is installed, reducing accumulation to safe levels.

name: Install Protective Guards on Mold Cavity Sharp Edges
description: Design and fabricate protective plastic or rubber guards that cover sharp internal edges on all injection mold cavities used on Lines A and B. These removable guards will be installed during routine maintenance to eliminate the cutting hazard. Implementation will include a training session for all Injection Molding Operators on proper guard installation and removal. This engineering control directly eliminates the hazard source.

name: Enhance Mold Securing Procedures and Implement Jig Inspection Protocol
description: Develop detailed work procedures requiring operators to visually inspect and confirm that molds are properly seated and secured in cooling jigs before any maintenance work begins. Implement a checklist system where operators initial each verification step. Add training content to the monthly safety toolbox talks covering proper mold positioning. This administrative control ensures molds remain stable during maintenance, preventing the slip-and-contact scenario.

name: Distribute Cut-Resistant Gloves and Reinforce PPE Requirements
description: Issue ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant nitrile gloves to all personnel performing mold maintenance or handling sharp-edged components. Update the Line A safety procedures to require these gloves for any work involving mold cavities or internal metal components. Conduct a refresher training on proper glove selection, fit, and limitations. While PPE is a lower control priority, this provides an additional layer of protection pending implementation of engineering controls.

name: Upgrade to Automated Pallet Handling Equipment
description: Procure and install two additional electric pallet jacks with load-monitoring displays that alert operators when loads exceed 800 lbs. These devices will replace manual lifting for moves between production and warehouse areas. Implement a facility policy requiring all pallet transfers exceeding 300 lbs to use powered equipment rather than manual handling. This substitution control removes the manual lifting hazard by replacing the unsafe work method with a safer alternative.

name: Implement Weight Labeling and Material Handler Training Program
description: Establish a standardized pallet weight labeling system using adhesive labels that must be applied and verified before any pallet leaves production. Labels will include the weight and a warning if over 500 lbs. Conduct mandatory training for all Material Handlers and Forklift Operators on proper lifting mechanics, load assessment, and the importance of reading labels. Include training on when to request assistance or equipment. Monthly refresher training will be conducted. This administrative control prevents labeling errors and ensures operators make informed decisions.

name: Provide Ergonomic Back Support and Injury Prevention PPE
description: Issue high-quality lumbar support belts (rated for warehouse use) to all Material Handlers, Forklift Operators, and production staff involved in manual material handling. Conduct fitting and proper-use training. While PPE is a lower-tier control, this provides acute support for employees during the transition to powered equipment. Costs include 30 belts at $45 each plus training materials.

name: Implement Daily PPE Inspection and Compliance Audit
description: Establish a mandatory daily pre-shift PPE inspection at each production line where line leads verify that all operators have intact, appropriate personal protective equipment. Create a digital checklist system that tracks PPE condition daily. Any torn, damaged, or missing PPE must be immediately replaced. Supervisors will conduct spot checks every 2 hours during shifts. This addresses the root cause of inadequate PPE compliance and ensures workers have functioning protection against mold release agents and thermal hazards.

name: Install Temperature Warning Labels and Thermal Hazard Signage
description: Install high-visibility warning labels on all injection molding lines indicating mold temperatures, ejection zones, and required PPE. Labels will display current mold temperature using thermal sensors. Add color-coded warning tape around hot zones. Conduct a facility-wide signage audit and standardize thermal hazard communication. This engineering and administrative control reduces incidents from unexpected contact with hot components by increasing worker awareness of thermal hazards at each step of the production process.

name: Conduct Refresher Training on Chemical Hazards and Mold Release Agents
description: Develop and deliver a 90-minute refresher training session for all production operators covering mold release agent hazards, proper application, temperature risks, and first aid response. Include practical demonstrations of correct PPE donning and doffing. Training will be mandatory quarterly and logged in the employee development system. This addresses the knowledge gap regarding specific chemical hazards and reinforces the importance of consistent PPE use for skin protection.

name: Reinforce and Audit Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Procedures
description: Conduct immediate audit of all LOTO compliance at maintenance workstations. Require written LOTO procedures to be posted at each machine requiring maintenance. Implement a mandatory two-person verification system where a second trained employee must physically verify that all energy sources are locked, tagged, and de-energized before any maintenance begins. The verifying employee must sign off on the LOTO checklist. Monthly surprise LOTO audits will be conducted by the HSE team with corrective action for non-compliance. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the primary hazard of unexpected machine restart.

name: Mandate Supervisor Presence During After-Hours Maintenance
description: Establish a policy requiring supervisor or designated lead presence for all maintenance activities conducted during evening and night shifts. Create a maintenance scheduling system that ensures adequate coverage and supervision. Maintenance personnel working alone on complex equipment will be prohibited. This administrative control ensures immediate response capability in case of emergency and promotes accountability for safety procedures. Management will track compliance monthly.

name: Implement Comprehensive Hazardous Waste Segregation and Labeling System
description: Redesign the hazardous waste management protocol to strictly segregate incompatible waste streams into clearly labeled, properly ventilated containers. All containers must be color-coded and labeled with contents, date received, and hazard classification per WHMIS standards. Implement a digital tracking system for waste inventory with mandatory weekly audits. Containers will have sealed, flame-arrestor lids designed for solvent vapors. Staff will receive comprehensive hazmat waste certification training. This eliminates the root cause of reactive materials accumulating and creating spontaneous ignition conditions.

name: Install Dust Collection and Ventilation System in Waste Management Area
description: Install a dedicated industrial dust collection system in the Hazardous Waste Management Area with HEPA filtration and anti-static components suitable for composite material dust. Upgrade ventilation to maintain negative pressure and continuous air exchange. Install spark detection and automatic suppression in the ductwork. Conduct monthly system inspections and filter replacements. This engineering control directly addresses the dust accumulation fire hazard by removing accumulated composite particles that contributed to ignition conditions.

name: Install Exterior Fire Suppression System Coverage for Chemical Storage Areas
description: Extend the facility fire suppression system to include the exterior Hazardous Waste Management Area currently not covered by sprinkler heads. Install foam-type suppression heads rated for solvent fires and connect to the building's main suppression line. Add automatic fire detection sensors specifically configured for early flame detection in this high-risk zone. Conduct quarterly system testing and maintenance. This engineering control ensures rapid fire suppression response in exterior storage areas vulnerable to flammable solvent fires.

name: Implement Composite Material Handling PPE Protocol
description: Establish mandatory use of specialized cut-resistant gloves (minimum ANSI A3 rating) for all personnel handling fiber-reinforced composite materials. Conduct training session for all composite area workers on proper glove selection, donning/doffing procedures, and limitations. Procure high-visibility cut-resistant gloves in various sizes and store them in accessible dispensers at workstations in UNIT-017. Include glove inspection checklist in daily pre-shift routines. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in laceration injuries from composite material edges.

name: Enhance Edge Finishing Quality Control for Composite Parts
description: Modify the post-processing inspection procedure to include mandatory edge deburring and finishing verification before parts proceed to handling areas. Train Tool Room Supervisor Richard Beaulieu and his team on edge finishing standards and tolerances. Implement a 100% visual inspection checkpoint with tactile verification (gloved hand assessment) of all composite part edges. Document findings on quality control forms. Schedule monthly audits to verify compliance. This engineering control will eliminate the hazard at the source before parts reach assembly areas.

name: Implement Mandatory Hydraulic System Pressure Purge Procedure
description: Develop and document a comprehensive lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure specifically for hydraulic systems that includes mandatory pressure purging requirements before any maintenance work. Install pressure relief check valves on all high-pressure hydraulic lines with visual pressure indicators. Train all maintenance technicians on the new procedure with practical demonstrations. Create laminated quick-reference cards for posting on each hydraulic system. Require technicians to verify zero pressure using calibrated gauges before beginning work. Implement a sign-off checklist that must be completed and verified by a second technician. Expected outcome: Elimination of unexpected pressure release incidents.

name: Establish Shift-to-Shift Communication Protocol for Equipment Status
description: Create a formal equipment status handoff procedure where the outgoing shift coordinator and incoming shift coordinator physically verify equipment lockout status together before shift transition. Implement a digital equipment status log accessible to all shifts that records which machines are in maintenance mode, who authorized the work, and expected completion time. Conduct daily toolbox talks in the production area reviewing any ongoing maintenance work. Assign accountability by requiring both coordinators to sign-off on the handoff. Include this protocol in the revised LOTO training curriculum for all supervisors and coordinators.

name: Install Thermal Protective Equipment for Hydraulic Work
description: Procure and issue specialized thermal-resistant work gloves (rated to 75°C minimum), arm guards, and face shields to all maintenance technicians who work on pressurized hydraulic systems. Establish mandatory PPE requirements in the revised maintenance procedures. Conduct fit and comfort testing with all technicians to ensure proper usage. Stock replacement PPE items in the maintenance workshop (UNIT-014). Update the maintenance department's daily briefing to reinforce thermal protection requirements. While this is a PPE control (lowest priority in hierarchy), it serves as critical secondary protection given the hazard severity.

name: Implement Mold Transport Safety System
description: Replace manual cart transport with a dedicated powered cart system equipped with secure clamping brackets designed for large injection molds. Implement mandatory use of load-securing straps and bungee cords for all mold transportation. Create clearly marked pathways on the facility floor with smooth transitions and identify all depressions or uneven surfaces for repair. Establish a two-person verification rule: one person operates the cart while a second person guides and monitors the load. Conduct training on proper load distribution and securing techniques. Expected outcome: Elimination of unstable load incidents during mold transport.

name: Mandatory LOTO Pre-Work Verification Protocol
description: Implement a new pre-maintenance checklist requiring all operators and maintenance personnel to physically verify emergency stop activation and energy isolation before beginning any work on molding equipment. Install laminated checklist posters at each molding line with a mandatory sign-off sheet. Conduct immediate retraining for all 45 production staff on LOTO procedures with competency testing. Establish a 'no exceptions' policy with consequences for bypassing LOTO procedures. Track compliance through daily supervisor audits for 90 days.

name: Installation of Interlocked Safety Gates on Molding Lines
description: Engineer and install mechanical interlock systems on mold cavity access points that prevent machine operation when gates are open. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of mold closure during maintenance access. Work with equipment suppliers to source compatible systems for all four injection molding lines. Installation will occur during scheduled maintenance windows over a 30-day period. This addresses the root cause by removing the hazard of unexpected machine activation.

name: Enhanced Container Cleaning and Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a standardized container cleaning procedure requiring all chemical containers to be wiped down with lint-free cloths and verified as dry before storage. Implement a visual inspection checklist at the hazardous waste area with photo examples of acceptable versus unacceptable container conditions. Assign Michel Laflamme, the warehouse lead, to conduct weekly audits of all stored containers. Provide additional PPE (nitrile gloves, safety glasses) specifically for inventory and cleaning tasks. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of residual chemical contact.

name: Solvent Storage Relocation and Ventilation Enhancement
description: Relocate all flammable solvent storage to a dedicated cabinet located at least 15 feet from any heat-generating equipment. Install secondary containment trays beneath all solvent containers. Upgrade ventilation in the Packaging and Labeling Station with additional extraction fans to reduce vapor accumulation. Install signage prohibiting solvent storage near the heat-shrink tunnel. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard source by physically separating incompatible materials and conditions.

name: Static Electricity Grounding Protocol Implementation
description: Install permanent anti-static grounding mats at all labeling and packaging workstations. Require all operators to wear anti-static wrist straps while handling materials near electrical equipment. Conduct electrical conductivity testing of all grounding systems monthly. Provide training to all night shift personnel on static electricity hazards specific to solvent-rich environments. Add static electricity awareness to the WHMIS training module. This multi-layered administrative and engineering control addresses the ignition source hazard.

name: Install Automatic Part Ejection Sensor Replacement Program
description: Replace all thermal sensors on injection molding machines with redundant sensor systems that trigger immediate shutdown if ejection delays exceed 2 seconds. Implement quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all ejection mechanisms across the 32 injection molding machines. Sensors will be calibrated monthly. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of manual intervention need by ensuring equipment automatically cycles properly, preventing employee contact with hot components.

name: Reinforce Hot Surface Handling Training and Lockout Procedures
description: Conduct mandatory retraining for all 48 production operators on LOTO procedures specific to injection molding equipment, with emphasis on never manually intervening during cooling cycles. Create visual warning labels at all ejection points showing temperature hazard zones. Implement a competency verification system requiring operators to demonstrate safe handling procedures before resuming duties. Training will include simulation of sensor malfunction scenarios and correct response protocols.

name: Install Physical Guards Around Part Ejection Points
description: Design and install stainless steel mesh guards around all part ejection and cooling stations that prevent hand access to pinch points while allowing part visibility and airflow. Guards will be removable only with special tool access to prevent bypassing. This physical engineering control creates a barrier that makes manual part extraction impossible, addressing the gap in current machine design.

name: Implement Secondary Containment System for Large Chemical Containers
description: Install stainless steel spill containment trays beneath all containers larger than 100 liters in the Chemical Storage facility. Trays will be sized to contain 110% of the largest container volume. All containers will be permanently anchored with chains to fixed anchor points. This engineering control prevents liquid from spreading and reaching drain systems. Monthly inspections will verify tray integrity and anchor security.

name: Establish Chemical Storage Organization and Labeling Standards
description: Reorganize chemical storage using the NFPA diamond classification system with visible color-coded zone assignments. Implement a database tracking system for all hazardous materials with automated inventory alerts. Establish a policy requiring all personnel handling chemicals over 50 liters to complete hazmat certification. Create standard operating procedures for safe repositioning of storage equipment that requires minimum two-person teams and administrative approval.

name: Upgrade Emergency Response Equipment and Training
description: Install three additional emergency spill kits positioned strategically throughout the chemical facility, each containing neutralizing agents, absorbent materials, and PPE appropriate for the stored chemicals. Conduct quarterly emergency response drills for all personnel who may work in or near chemical storage areas. Create laminated emergency response flowcharts posted at all exits showing evacuation procedures, spill response protocols, and emergency contact information.

name: Compressed Air System Replacement and Pressure Management Upgrade
description: Replace the aged pressure relief valve assembly with a modern dual-redundant system featuring independent pressure regulators and safety shutoff mechanisms. Install digital pressure monitoring with automated alerts sent to maintenance when pressure deviates beyond safe parameters. Implement monthly pressure gauge calibration and annual certification program. This engineering control eliminates air discharge hazard through redundant safety mechanisms, addressing the root cause of erratic gauge readings and potential explosive release.

name: Install Complete Machine Guarding on Regrind Mill Equipment
description: Design and fabricate custom stainless steel guards covering all rotating parts and material feed openings on the regrind mill. Guards will include interlocked access gates that automatically shut down equipment when opened. Implement through-bolted installation preventing removal without specialized tools. This engineering control directly addresses the identified missing guards from the 2022 assessment and eliminates entanglement hazard.

name: Enhance Regrind Area Ventilation System and Respiratory Protection Program
description: Install upgraded HEPA-filtration ventilation system with extraction points positioned at the primary dust generation areas within the regrind mill. System will achieve minimum 12 air changes per hour. Install fixed dust collection containers with visual fill-level indicators requiring replacement at 75% capacity. All regrind workers will receive fit-tested respirator masks for situations when ventilation maintenance is required. Implement weekly dust accumulation inspections and cleanup procedures.

name: Implement Mandatory Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) for All Hopper Operations
description: Develop and enforce a comprehensive LOTO procedure specific to hopper clearing and maintenance tasks. All machine setters and operators must complete recertification training on LOTO protocols within 14 days. Install proximity-activated warning labels and sensor switches on all hopper loading stations that trigger an audible alarm when the hopper access door is opened while the system is energized. Conduct weekly LOTO compliance audits on all injection molding lines to verify proper lock engagement before any manual hopper interventions. This engineering and administrative control will eliminate the primary hazard of unexpected equipment cycling during maintenance activities.

name: Upgrade Hopper Design with Mechanical Anti-Jam System
description: Replace current hopper feed mechanisms on all 32 injection molding machines with newer models featuring integrated mechanical jam-detection and automatic feed reversal systems. These devices automatically sense resistance in the auger and reverse feed direction before material compaction occurs. Installation will be completed in phases over 60 days, starting with high-risk lines A and D. This engineering control substitutes the manual intervention hazard with automatic safety systems, significantly reducing the likelihood of entanglement incidents during normal operations.

name: Provide Enhanced PPE for Material Handling Operations
description: Issue reinforced cut-resistant gloves (Level 5 protection rating) and mesh steel-backed hand guards to all machine setters and material handlers working on injection molding lines. Gloves will be distributed within 3 days and integrated into the standard PPE kit. While primarily a PPE control (lowest hierarchy), this serves as an interim protective measure until engineering upgrades are completed. All personnel must attend a 30-minute training session on proper glove fit and care to ensure effectiveness.

name: Install Drum Containment and Spill Prevention System
description: Implement secondary containment trays rated for 110% volume capacity beneath all chemical drum storage and transfer stations in Unit 015. Install 12 modular spill containment pallets with integrated drip trays capable of holding 200+ liters. Additionally, retrofit all motorized pallet jacks used in chemical areas with automatic load-securing clamps and tilt-detection sensors that trigger audible warnings if the load shifts during transport. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the incident (unsecured drum) and provides multiple layers of containment if a spill occurs.

name: Establish Mandatory Chemical Transport and Verification Procedure
description: Create a detailed standard operating procedure (SOP) for chemical drum transport requiring pre-movement inspection of all securing mechanisms and load stability verification. All material handlers transporting hazardous chemicals must complete a 45-minute certification course covering proper strapping techniques, weight distribution, and emergency response. Implement a sign-off checklist system where the handler and a supervisor must verify drum condition before transport begins. This administrative control reduces human error through systematic verification and training.

name: Replace All Production Floor Ladders with Anti-Slip, Self-Leveling Models
description: Conduct immediate audit of all 28 ladders currently in use throughout the facility. Replace all standard aluminum ladders with industrial-grade fiberglass models featuring wide, textured anti-slip rungs, automatic stabilizing feet that compensate for uneven flooring, and integrated safety rails. Prioritize replacement in areas with documented moisture, oil, or chemical residue exposure (Units 015, 017, 009). All new ladders must meet or exceed CSA B354.2-16 standards for portable ladders. Complete replacement within 30 days. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of ladder slippage and reduces fall risk significantly.

name: Implement Daily Floor Cleaning and Maintenance Protocol for Production Areas
description: Establish a mandatory daily cleaning schedule for all production floors, targeting removal of hydraulic oil residue, plastic pellets, and other slip hazards. Assign cleaning responsibilities to specific shifts with documented daily verification sign-offs. Use industrial degreasers rated for concrete floors to remove accumulated hydraulic oils. Conduct weekly inspections of all floor surfaces adjacent to equipment requiring elevated work. Facilities Technician Georges Plante will supervise implementation and monitor compliance. This administrative control eliminates the environmental factor (slippery floor) that directly contributed to the ladder instability.

name: Mandate Fall Protection System Use for Elevated Work Above 1.5 Meters
description: Require all maintenance personnel performing work from ladders at heights exceeding 1.5 meters to utilize personal fall protection systems, including a properly fitted harness secured to an engineered anchor point. Retrofit all equipment requiring elevated maintenance access with rated tie-off anchor points meeting CSA Z94.1-17 standards. Conduct mandatory 2-hour fall protection training and harness fit verification for all 14 maintenance technicians within 14 days. This engineering control provides active fall prevention if ladder slippage or other instability occurs, serving as a critical backup safety system.

name: Install Enhanced Thermal Barriers on Injection Nozzles
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with reinforced, interlocking thermal shields that extend coverage around discharge nozzles. These barriers will reduce exposed hot surfaces and prevent accidental contact. Include quick-release mechanisms for maintenance access. Expected outcome: eliminate direct contact burns from normal operation. Implementation includes training for all machine operators on barrier inspection procedures.

name: Mandatory Pre-Shift Equipment Inspection Checklist
description: Develop a standardized daily equipment inspection checklist specifically for thermal shield integrity, barrier alignment, and discharge area safety. Make it mandatory for all operators before starting each shift, with digital logging in the production management system. Supervisors must spot-check compliance twice weekly. Include specific verification steps for shield position, fastener tightness, and visual condition assessment.

name: Enhanced PPE Requirements for Line Operators
description: Require all injection molding line operators to wear heat-resistant arm sleeves rated for minimum 300°C contact, in addition to existing PPE. Update the dress code policy and provide properly fitting sleeves to all personnel. Conduct fitting sessions and training on proper application and care of protective equipment.

name: Replace Corroded Tank Fittings with Corrosion-Resistant Materials
description: Replace all standard steel fittings on chemical storage tanks with stainless steel or other corrosion-resistant materials rated for epoxy and resin compatibility. Implement a preventive replacement schedule for all fittings every 3 years regardless of visible condition. Conduct material compatibility assessment for all chemicals stored and select appropriate fitting materials accordingly.

name: Establish Daily Tank Inspection Protocol with Mandatory Logging
description: Implement a daily inspection requirement for all chemical storage tanks, focusing on fitting integrity, seals, and containment tray levels. Create digital inspection logs with photos and automated alerts when inspections are missed. Train all maintenance and inventory staff on inspection procedures. Add this task to the night shift duties with backup day shift verification to ensure 24/7 coverage.

name: Upgrade Wastewater Treatment System Pre-filtration
description: Install an enhanced pre-filtration and separation system specifically designed to capture epoxy and resin compounds before they reach the main treatment tank. Include dual-stage filtration with chemical neutralization capacity. Install overflow detection sensors with automated shutdown and alert systems.

name: Hire Additional Chemical Handling Technician
description: Recruit and onboard an additional full-time Chemical Handling Technician to ensure adequate staffing for daily inspections, maintenance, and documentation. This position will focus exclusively on tank management and environmental compliance, eliminating the staffing gaps that contributed to missed inspections.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance program for all hydraulic pump assemblies and motor bearings on injection molding equipment. Schedule quarterly inspections with bearing vibration analysis and hydraulic fluid quality testing. Create automated alerts in the maintenance management system when equipment approaches replacement thresholds. Train all machine setters to recognize early warning signs of pump degradation including unusual noise, vibration, and fluid leakage. Document all observations in real-time monitoring logs to identify failure trends before catastrophic breakdown occurs.

name: Enhance Equipment Pre-Shift Inspection Protocol
description: Revise and formalize the pre-shift equipment inspection checklist to include specific criteria for hydraulic system integrity, bearing condition assessment, and seal examination. Implement a digital inspection log system requiring machine setters to photograph anomalies and submit reports directly to the maintenance supervisor. Provide training to all operators and setters on the updated inspection protocol with emphasis on early hazard detection. Establish a rapid-response protocol where equipment flagged during pre-shift inspection is immediately assessed by maintenance before production startup.

name: Replace Temperature Sensor and Implement Calibration Protocol
description: Immediately replace the drifted temperature sensor on Resin Dryer Unit #3 with a new calibrated sensor meeting ISO 1593 standards. Implement a monthly calibration verification schedule using a precision reference thermometer to ensure all temperature sensors remain within ±0.5°C accuracy. Create a calibration log maintained by maintenance personnel with documentation of all readings and any corrective adjustments made. Establish an automatic alert system that flags sensors exceeding acceptable drift parameters, triggering immediate replacement before production use.

name: Upgrade Dryer Control System with Redundant Safety Controls
description: Install a redundant high-temperature limit controller (independent of the primary temperature sensor) on all resin dryer units, set to trigger emergency shutdown at 110°C to provide safety margin below damaging thresholds. Add a secondary thermocouple sensor with independent signal conditioning to provide real-time verification of primary sensor readings. Implement automated alerts sent to Maintenance Supervisor and Evening Shift Supervisor when temperature differential between primary and secondary sensors exceeds 5°C, indicating sensor malfunction. Train all operators on interpreting dual sensor displays and emergency response procedures.

name: Implement Container Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Conduct immediate inventory inspection of all 55-liter chemical storage drums in the Raw Materials Warehouse, identifying containers showing signs of corrosion, seam deterioration, or rust. Replace all compromised containers with new HDPE or stainless steel containers meeting CNESST chemical storage standards. Establish a quarterly container inspection schedule with documented assessment of all chemical storage vessels for integrity. Implement a chemical container shelf-life and rotation system ensuring older containers are used first and containers in storage for over 24 months are replaced regardless of apparent condition. Train warehouse staff on recognizing container degradation signs.

name: Enhance Chemical Storage Environmental Controls
description: Install dedicated dehumidification equipment in the Raw Materials Warehouse to maintain relative humidity below 60%, reducing moisture-driven corrosion of metal containers. Upgrade shelving storage racks to epoxy-coated stainless steel systems resistant to chemical corrosion and moisture degradation. Install secondary containment trays beneath all chemical storage areas with capacity to contain 110% of the largest single container (61 liters minimum). Improve warehouse ventilation with dedicated exhaust ducting and upgraded HVAC filtration to remove solvent vapors. Implement vapor monitoring sensors with automated alarm alerts if volatile organic compound concentrations exceed 50 ppm in warehouse areas.

name: Establish Chemical Spill Response and Worker Training Program
description: Develop comprehensive chemical spill response procedures specific to solvent-based release agents and volatile compounds stored at TechnoPlast facility. Create detailed Emergency Response Guide with sections covering: hazard identification, evacuation procedures, containment techniques, ventilation protocols, and cleanup procedures. Conduct quarterly training drills for warehouse staff and night shift personnel covering spill scenario simulation, emergency equipment operation (absorbent booms, ventilation activation), and proper reporting procedures. Ensure all employees can access emergency contacts and hazardous material safety data sheets (SDS) through mobile devices. Establish clear communication protocols for notifying HSE and Environmental Compliance teams immediately upon spill detection.

name: Install Finger Guards on Ejector Pin Assemblies
description: Design and install protective sleeves over all ejector pin assemblies on Injection Molding Lines C and D to eliminate sharp edge contact during part removal. These guards will be fabricated from flexible silicone tubing bonded to the pins, reducing lacerations while maintaining ejection functionality. Operators will receive updated training on the new guard maintenance procedures. This engineering control addresses the root cause by removing the sharp edge hazard entirely rather than relying on gloves or technique changes.

name: Implement Part Cooling Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory cooling period chart for each composite part type, posted at each molding line. Operators will not remove parts until the specified cooling time has elapsed, reducing thermal stress and the temptation to rush removal. Supervisors will conduct daily compliance audits for the first 30 days, then weekly thereafter. This administrative control reduces the pressure-driven unsafe behavior that contributed to the incident.

name: Remove Damaged Ladder and Implement Mobile Access Equipment
description: Immediately remove and retire the damaged 6-foot aluminum ladder from service. Replace with two mobile access stairs (rated for overhead maintenance tasks) that will be stored in the Equipment Storage room with clear signage indicating they must be used for any mezzanine access. Staff will inspect stairs weekly and document inspection dates on attached tags. This eliminates the hazard of ladder misuse and improves the reliability of access equipment.

name: Establish Mezzanine Safety Protocol and Training
description: Develop and implement a written mezzanine access procedure requiring all workers to use approved access equipment, conduct a risk assessment before work, and use harness-based fall protection systems rated for the 7-foot height. All maintenance staff will complete mandatory retraining within 5 business days. Night shift supervisor will perform daily compliance checks during the first 60 days. A visible procedural poster will be mounted at the mezzanine entrance.

name: Conduct Facility-Wide Ladder Inspection and Retirement Program
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all ladders and elevated access equipment throughout the TechnoPlast facility. Retire any equipment showing damage, improper repair, or wear. Replace with ANSI-compliant equipment and establish a quarterly inspection schedule with documented results. Train all supervisors on ladder safety standards and inspection criteria. This proactive engineering and administrative control prevents similar incidents across the entire facility.

name: Replace and Upgrade Dust Collection Filter System
description: Replace the clogged primary filter in the fiberglass trimming dust collection system and install a new secondary HEPA filter with a maintenance schedule alarm. Install differential pressure gauges on both stages to alert operators when filter efficiency drops below acceptable thresholds. Establish a preventive maintenance schedule requiring filter inspection every 7 days and replacement every 30 days or when pressure differential reaches 5 inches of water. This engineering control ensures adequate dust capture before particles become airborne.

name: Implement Dust Accumulation Monitoring and Cleaning Protocol
description: Establish a daily visual inspection checklist for all horizontal surfaces in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Operators will document dust accumulation levels and notify maintenance when accumulation exceeds 1mm. Implement a weekly wet-cleaning protocol (using HEPA-filtered vacuum equipment) to prevent dust buildup. Create a laminated visual guide showing acceptable vs. unacceptable dust levels posted at the work area entrance. This administrative control ensures early detection of ventilation system degradation.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Monitoring and Automated Alerts
description: Install differential pressure sensors on the main dust collection system connected to a networked alert system that notifies maintenance via email and text when filter efficiency degrades. Integrate the sensor data into the facility's predictive maintenance dashboard. Reconfigure the secondary HEPA stage to automatically isolate when pressure differential exceeds safe operating parameters, triggering immediate maintenance response. Train all production supervisors on reading the system alerts and emergency shutdown procedures.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance for HVAC Systems
description: Establish a quarterly bearing inspection and lubrication schedule for all exhaust fan motors in chemical processing areas. Install vibration sensors on primary ventilation equipment to provide early warning of mechanical degradation. Create a maintenance log with required inspections every 90 days. Train maintenance technicians on bearing assessment protocols. This engineering control will prevent future failures by identifying problems before critical breakdown occurs.

name: Install Redundant Secondary Ventilation System with Auto-Switchover
description: Deploy a secondary exhaust system with automatic switchover capability activated by CO2/VOC sensors. System will activate within 30 seconds of primary system failure, maintaining air quality standards. Install real-time air quality monitoring dashboards in the regrind area with audible alerts at 75% of exposure limits. This eliminates gaps in ventilation protection during equipment failures.

name: Enhanced Environmental Monitoring and Evacuation Protocol
description: Establish mandatory air quality monitoring every 4 hours in high-risk chemical processing zones with documented readings. Develop and post evacuation procedures specific to ventilation failure scenarios. Conduct quarterly drills simulating ventilation emergencies. Train all regrind department personnel on early warning signs of inadequate ventilation including headaches, dizziness, and respiratory symptoms. Administrative control reducing response time and worker awareness.

name: Mandatory Lockout/Tagout Enforcement with Physical Energy Isolation
description: Implement strict LOTO procedures requiring dual operator verification before any equipment cleaning or maintenance. Install electrical disconnect switches at each molding line's control panel with physical locks requiring supervisor authorization. Establish written permits for all cleaning operations identifying who is working and what equipment state is required. All operators must complete LOTO recertification training within 30 days. This engineering and administrative control eliminates accidental startup hazards during maintenance.

name: Three-Person Communication Protocol for Equipment Maintenance
description: Establish mandatory communication system where one operator performs work, one serves as safety spotter at equipment controls, and one maintains external line-of-sight. Use two-way communication devices and visual signals. Post laminated procedure cards at each molding line. Conduct monthly drills. Training for all production personnel on new protocol required before return to duty. Administrative control ensuring awareness and communication during high-risk operations.

name: Install Machine Guarding on Hopper Auger Access Points
description: Design and install physical guards that prevent hand access to rotating auger components during cleaning operations. Guards must allow material inspection without exposing moving parts. Installation of emergency stop buttons within arm's reach of hopper work area. Engineering control providing passive protection against entanglement regardless of operator behavior.

name: Replace Thermostat and Install Dual Redundant Temperature Control Systems
description: Replace the failed analog thermostat with a digital PLC-controlled temperature management system featuring dual independent sensors. Install a secondary mechanical thermal cut-off as backup that activates at 135°C. Both systems must independently power down the heating element if temperature exceeds safe limits. Engineering control providing multiple layers of failure prevention to eliminate overheating scenarios.

name: Implement Quarterly Temperature Sensor Calibration Program
description: Establish mandatory calibration schedule for all temperature sensors and thermostats on resin dryers and material processing equipment. Use certified calibration standards and maintain detailed logs. Schedule calibrations quarterly with documented before/after readings. Create automated alerts in maintenance software when calibrations are due. This administrative control ensures early detection of sensor drift before failures occur.

name: Install Real-Time Equipment Monitoring with Predictive Alerts
description: Deploy IoT-based temperature monitoring system on all resin dryers that logs continuous data and sends alerts to maintenance personnel when temperatures approach 110°C. System will flag anomalies indicating sensor drift or heating element degradation before critical failure. Maintenance team receives daily summary reports. Engineering control providing early warning capability for all thermal equipment.

name: Implement Monthly Hopper Interlock Inspection and Cleaning Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly inspection and cleaning of all hopper safety interlocks across production lines. This will include removal of resin dust and debris accumulation, lubrication of moving components, and functional testing. Create a checklist-based inspection form to be completed by maintenance staff and signed off by the Maintenance Lead. Documented inspections will be retained in a centralized log to track hopper performance and identify patterns. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of interlock failure due to material buildup, reducing the probability of future overflow incidents.

name: Install High-Level Material Sensors on All Hoppers
description: Engineering control: Install automated high-level sensors with audible and visual alarms on all 12 injection molding hoppers. These sensors will trigger an alert when material reaches 75% capacity, providing a redundant safety system independent of mechanical interlocks. Sensors will be integrated with the production line PLC system and include data logging capabilities for predictive maintenance. Operators will receive immediate notification to halt refilling, preventing overflow regardless of interlock status. This engineering control eliminates the dependency on a single mechanical safeguard.

name: Replace All Warehouse Ladders and Implement Tool Inspection System
description: Eliminate use of damaged equipment: Remove all existing aluminum ladders from warehouse use and replace with new, certified ANSI-compliant fiberglass ladders rated for industrial use. Each ladder will be assigned an identification number and include a pre-use inspection tag. Establish a mandatory tool inspection protocol requiring daily visual checks and monthly detailed inspections by designated personnel. All findings will be recorded in a digital asset management system. Non-compliant tools will be immediately quarantined and repaired or discarded. This engineering and administrative control prevents recurrence of equipment failure as a root cause.

name: Install Mechanical Aisle Lifts and Eliminate Ladder Access to High Shelves
description: Engineering control: Replace manual ladder-based material retrieval from upper shelves (tiers 4-6) with motorized vertical aisle lifts operating at maximum 1.5 meters per second. Install two scissor lift units with integrated safety rails, emergency stop buttons, and load-bearing capacity of 500 kg. Redesignate upper shelf inventory to contain lower-use items, reserving frequently accessed materials on lower tiers (1-3) for manual access. This eliminates the need for ladder work at heights exceeding 2 meters and reduces fall risk from elevated surfaces.

name: Conduct Mandatory Fall Prevention and Height Safety Training
description: Administrative control: Implement a 2-hour fall prevention training module for all warehouse and material handling personnel covering: proper ladder selection and inspection, three-point contact technique, identification of hazardous storage practices, and emergency response protocols. Training will include practical demonstrations using properly maintained equipment and will be recorded with attendance tracking. Annual refresher training will be mandatory. Content aligns with CNESST requirements and will be delivered by Karine Cloutier, Safety Trainer.

name: Install Thermal Insulation Barriers and Shielding on All Mold Manifolds
description: Engineering control: Apply high-temperature silicone foam insulation (rated to 200°C) to all exposed heated mold manifold surfaces in both production lines. Cover areas with thickness of 25mm and secure with high-temperature adhesive and stainless steel retaining straps. Insulation will be color-coded yellow/black for hazard identification and inspected quarterly for degradation. Additionally, install removable polycarbonate guards around mold changeover work zones during active operations. This eliminates direct skin contact with surfaces above 60°C during normal setup operations.

name: Require Heat-Resistant Gloves for All Mold Handling and Setup Operations
description: PPE and administrative control: Procure Kevlar-lined thermal protective gloves (rated to 260°C) for all machine setters and maintenance personnel. Gloves will be stored in designated bins at each production line and include size-specific pairs. Implement a mandatory glove-wearing requirement during all mold changeover procedures, documented through a sign-off checklist completed by operators and supervisors. Gloves will be inspected monthly for degradation and replaced if damaged. Reinforce glove compliance through toolbox talks and safety signage at each workstation.

name: Implement Scheduled Cooldown Protocol Before Mold Changeover
description: Administrative control: Establish a standardized mold changeover procedure requiring a 10-minute cooldown period at 60°C before any manual hose disconnection work begins. Operators will use calibrated infrared thermometers to verify temperature thresholds before proceeding. This waiting period will be incorporated into production scheduling to prevent time-pressure rushing. The procedure will be documented in a laminated reference card at each production line and reinforced during monthly safety toolbox talks. Training will emphasize that cooldown time is non-negotiable and contributes to both worker safety and mold longevity.

name: Implement Lockout/Tagout Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory sign-off procedure requiring maintenance personnel to physically verify and document all machine interlocks before returning equipment to production. This includes creation of a LOTO checklist for each machine type, daily verification logs, and photography documentation of locked/tagged equipment. Production supervisors must confirm interlock status with maintenance before resuming operations. Training will be provided to all operators and maintenance staff on the new protocol.

name: Install Dual-Channel Safety Monitoring System
description: Upgrade all injection molding machines with dual-channel safety controllers that cannot be bypassed or disabled without documented approval from the HSE Coordinator. This engineering control ensures that safety interlocks function independently of maintenance status. The system will include automatic alerts if both channels are not functioning. Implementation will be phased starting with Lines C and D (highest risk operations).

name: Conduct Machine Guarding and LOTO Retraining
description: Mandatory retraining for all 45 production operators and 12 maintenance technicians covering lockout/tagout procedures, hazard recognition on injection molding equipment, and emergency response protocols. Include hands-on demonstrations using the specific machine models at TechnoPlast. Assessment tests required for all participants with minimum 90% passing score. Retraining to be completed within 2 weeks of incident.

name: Establish PPE Assignment and Accountability System
description: Implement a personal PPE locker system where each operator receives assigned heat-resistant sleeves, gloves, and aprons with their employee ID embroidered. PPE must remain at their workstation and be tracked via inventory audit every Friday. Replacement PPE is available on-demand from HSE office. Operators sign acknowledgment of their assigned equipment upon receipt. Supervisors conduct weekly spot-checks to ensure PPE is being worn correctly during all mold handling activities.

name: Install Thermal Indicators on All Mold Surfaces
description: Apply high-visibility thermal warning labels on all injection mold surfaces that exceed 50°C. Labels will change color when surface temperature reaches critical levels, providing visual confirmation of hazard. This engineering control supplements PPE requirements and serves as a reminder of hot surface hazards. Labels will be replaced quarterly or as needed.

name: Install Enhanced Spill Containment System
description: Upgrade the Chemical Storage area with a comprehensive secondary containment system including: reinforced concrete bunded area with 150% capacity of largest single container, automatic shut-off sump pump with secondary backup, and absorbent barriers at all drainage points. Containment capacity will be increased from current 60 gallons to 200 gallons. This engineering control prevents environmental release and significantly reduces cleanup costs.

name: Enforce Material Handling Load Securing Protocol
description: Implement mandatory load-securing requirements for all drum transfers: minimum two heavy-duty straps per drum, diagonal cross-bracing for multi-drum loads, and weight limit verification before movement. Create laminated instruction cards at all forklift stations showing proper drum stacking and securing methods. All forklift operators must complete recertification training including load stability assessment. Weekly audits of stored materials to ensure compliance.

name: Upgrade Storage Rack Load Rating and Placement
description: Replace undersized storage racks in Chemical Storage area with industrial-grade racks rated for 5,000 lbs per shelf. Clearly mark load capacity on each rack. Reposition racks to maintain minimum 3-foot clearance from equipment and walls. Implement a spacing standard of 18 inches between drum rows. Conduct a facility-wide audit of all storage racks to identify other areas with inadequate capacity ratings.

name: Mandatory LOTO Recertification and Compliance Program
description: Implement a mandatory annual LOTO recertification program for all production and maintenance personnel with quarterly audits of lockout/tagout procedures at all 32 injection molding machines. Install permanent LOTO warning placards at all machine access points with color-coded tags. Create a digital LOTO compliance tracking system requiring sign-off before machine activation. Establish role-based responsibilities: operators cannot activate machines during maintenance windows marked with active LOTO tags. This engineering-administrative hybrid control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate hazard isolation and employee knowledge gaps.

name: Install Thermal Insulation Barriers and Cool-Down Zones
description: Install transparent polycarbonate thermal barriers around injection points of all molding machines to reduce direct contact exposure to 290°C+ plastic material. Create designated cool-down zones with emergency ice water stations adjacent to each molding station. Install temperature monitoring sensors that automatically alert operators when material exceeds safe handling thresholds. Provide all production staff with improved thermal-resistant work gloves (rated to 400°C) and reinforced sleeves. These engineering controls reduce burn severity even if exposure occurs, and administrative controls ensure proper PPE availability.

name: Interlock System on Remote Machine Activation
description: Install electronic interlock system that prevents remote machine activation when physical LOTO devices are engaged. The system will integrate with existing LOTO tags via RFID technology, requiring manual override with supervisor approval and real-time notification to both the operator and maintenance personnel. Add audible and visual warnings (alarm + flashing lights) at machine control panels when maintenance mode is active. This engineering control creates a physical barrier to accidental machine activation regardless of human error or communication failures.

name: Relocate and Guard Emergency Pull-Stations
description: Relocate all emergency fire suppression pull-stations to wall-mounted positions at least 2.5 meters away from high-traffic storage areas and frequently-accessed shelves. Install protective shrouds around pull-stations with transparent polycarbonate guards to prevent accidental activation while maintaining emergency access capability. Add a clear 1-meter buffer zone around all pull-stations marked with yellow-and-black floor striping. Provide staff training on proper pull-station location and operation. These engineering controls directly prevent the contact that triggered the incident.

name: Install Improved Fire Suppression System Signage and Training
description: Install high-visibility signage above all emergency pull-stations with pictographs and bilingual (French/English) warnings indicating hazards of accidental discharge. Conduct mandatory quarterly refresher training for all employees on fire suppression system operation, including consequences of accidental discharge and proper response procedures. Create visual floor markings indicating 'No Storage' zones around emergency equipment. Update the employee handbook with detailed fire suppression safety protocols. This administrative control ensures employees understand the risks and proper use of emergency equipment.

name: Install Overhead Cable and Hose Routing System
description: Install ceiling-mounted cable trays and hose carriers along the entire length of the main warehouse aisle to route all compressed air lines and electrical cables overhead at 2.4 meters height, removing them from floor level. Use color-coded conduit (blue for compressed air, black for electrical) for easy identification. Install cable guides at 2-meter intervals to prevent sag. Where overhead routing is not feasible, install yellow-and-black floor-mounted protective conduit channels with beveled edges to create a smooth, trip-free surface. This primary engineering control eliminates the trip hazard entirely.

name: Upgrade Warehouse Lighting to LED High-Efficiency System
description: Replace all fluorescent lighting fixtures in the Raw Materials Warehouse with LED high-efficiency fixtures capable of 400+ lux illumination. Install motion-activated supplemental lighting in low-traffic zones to maintain minimum 300 lux standards throughout the facility. Add emergency backup lighting on critical pathways to ensure visibility during power events. Improved lighting reduces fatigue-related errors and enables operators to better identify floor-level hazards. Install light level monitoring sensors that alert maintenance if illumination drops below safe thresholds.

name: Enhanced Forklift Operator Training and Warehouse Traffic Control
description: Implement mandatory refresher training for all 8 active forklift/reach truck operators focusing on hazard avoidance, reduced speed protocols in constrained aisles, and communication procedures. Establish a 'slow traffic zone' (max 5 km/h) designation in the main aisle with painted floor markings. Install convex mirrors at aisle intersections to improve sightlines. Require spotters during high-congestion periods (peak material movement windows). Conduct weekly 'near-miss' review meetings with operators to identify developing hazards. These administrative controls provide multiple layers of protection while engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Install Storage Rack Safety Dividers and Load Limiters
description: Install adjustable plastic dividers and weight-rated load limiters on all material storage racks in UNIT-016 and similar areas. Dividers will prevent bag shifting and collapse, with clear maximum stack height markings at 4 feet. Load limiters will alert staff when weight capacity is approached. Engineering control addresses root cause by physically preventing unsafe stacking configurations. Expected outcome: elimination of falling material incidents from storage racks.

name: Implement Material Handling Training and Bag Stacking Protocol
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive retraining on proper material handling techniques, including maximum stack heights, use of PPE, and safe reaching practices. Create laminated stacking protocol posters for all storage areas showing maximum 4-foot stacking height and proper bag orientation. Conduct quarterly refresher sessions with all material handlers and supervisors. Administrative control establishes clear procedures and competency standards.

name: Install Mobile Reaching Equipment and Reduce Manual Lifting
description: Procure and deploy 3 mobile reach assist units (step stools with grab handles and safety rails) for Material Drying and Preparation Room. Train material handlers on proper use of reach assist equipment to eliminate overreaching and unstable positions. Equipment will reduce manual lifting above shoulder height by 80%. Engineering control substitutes unsafe manual reaching with stable, supported access methods.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Crane Controls
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program specifically for all overhead crane electrical controls, emergency stop buttons, and load brakes. Maintenance will include contact cleaning, button travel testing, load brake pressure verification, and electrical circuit continuity checks. Technician Luc Girard will conduct inspections on the first week of each quarter. Administrative control ensures systematic detection of wear before critical failure occurs.

name: Replace Emergency Stop Button with Redundant Safety System
description: Replace the current single emergency stop button with a dual-channel safety-rated emergency stop system compliant with ISO 13850. New system will feature redundant contact mechanisms and load holding brake that engages within 0.5 seconds of activation. Engineering control eliminates the single point of failure that caused this incident by adding system redundancy and automatic load holding.

name: Relocate Chemical Storage Cabinet and Separate Utility Lines
description: Immediately relocate the mold release agent and solvent storage cabinet to a location minimum 15 feet away from natural gas supply line entry points and electrical distribution panels. Install secondary containment tray beneath the cabinet with capacity of 110% of largest container volume. Ensure cabinet is in a designated chemical storage zone with dedicated spill response kit and fire suppression coverage. Engineering control eliminates the primary hazard by creating physical separation between flammable materials and ignition sources.

name: Implement Chemical Storage Container Securing and Inventory Control
description: Install anti-tip corner braces on all chemical storage shelving and implement mandatory container securing with bungee straps rated for 50 lbs minimum. Conduct inventory reduction to eliminate redundant containers, reducing storage density by 30%. Establish weekly chemical storage audits by HSE staff to verify proper containment, securing, and cabinet organization. Administrative control prevents container tipping through physical restraints and reduces overall hazard through inventory management.

name: Install Automatic Fire Suppression System in Chemical Storage Area
description: Install Class D dry chemical fire suppression system specifically designed for flammable liquid storage areas, with automatic heat-activated discharge capability and manual override switches. System will complement existing sprinkler coverage and provide rapid suppression of solvent-based fires before they can propagate. Install clearly marked emergency alarm pull stations at the entry/exit of chemical storage zone and conduct quarterly system inspections. Engineering control adds automatic hazard suppression capability to prevent fire escalation.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Chemical Spill Response Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory 2-hour training on hazardous chemical spill response, with emphasis on solvent-related hazards, electrical safety around spills, and proper use of spill containment equipment. Training will include live demonstration of spill response kit usage and emergency communication protocols. All production and maintenance staff will complete training within 30 days. Conduct annual refresher training. Administrative control ensures workforce competency in spill response and emergency procedures.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring System on Line C
description: Implement an automated mold temperature monitoring system with visual and audible alarms that alert operators when mold surface temperatures exceed safe handling thresholds (above 60°C). The system will integrate with the injection cycle controls to prevent part removal until mold temperature drops to safe levels. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of thermal burns by preventing operator contact with hot surfaces. Expected outcome: Zero thermal burn incidents on Line C within 90 days.

name: Enhanced Heat Safety Training for Assembly Staff
description: Conduct comprehensive training on thermal hazard recognition and response for all assembly operators, covering mold temperature cycles, safe cooling procedures, and first aid for thermal burns. Include hands-on demonstration of proper cooling techniques and PPE requirements. Training will be mandatory for all operators on Lines A, C, and D. Documentation will track completion and competency assessments.

name: Establish Post-Maintenance Equipment Staging Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory post-maintenance checklist requiring maintenance staff to return all work areas to pre-maintenance conditions before shift changeover. This includes securing all hoses, cables, and tools in designated storage areas or elevated cable trays. The Electrical Maintenance Lead will verify compliance before signing off on maintenance work orders. This administrative control prevents trip hazards from accumulating during shift transitions and establishes clear ownership of housekeeping responsibilities. Expected outcome: Zero trip hazard incidents in production areas within 60 days.

name: Install Permanent Cable Management Systems
description: Install cable trays and hose routing systems along production area walls to provide designated pathways for all air lines, electrical cables, and hydraulic hoses. This engineering control eliminates the root cause by providing permanent infrastructure for cable management rather than relying on maintenance staff to secure cables after each job. Cable trays will be installed at 2.5 meters height to keep pathways clear. Expected installation completion within 45 days.

name: Implement Mandatory Overhead Crane Inspection and Certification Program
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all overhead cranes requiring quarterly inspections by certified technicians, with detailed documentation of cable condition, hoist mechanism integrity, and load testing. All cranes must obtain current certification from an independent third party. Any crane showing signs of cable fraying, corrosion, or wear exceeding manufacturer specifications will be immediately removed from service. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of cable failure by ensuring systematic detection and replacement of worn components before catastrophic failure occurs.

name: Replace Overhead Crane Lifting Cable
description: Complete immediate replacement of the failed lifting cable on the warehouse overhead crane with new cable meeting or exceeding ASME B30.20 standards. The old cable will be inspected by the maintenance team to determine cause of failure (fatigue, corrosion, overload). Installation must be performed by certified personnel with full load testing to 150% of rated capacity before returning crane to service. Post-installation documentation will be maintained in the equipment file for compliance tracking.

name: Enhance Load Exclusion Zone Procedures
description: Formalize and post clearly marked load exclusion zones (minimum 5-meter radius) under all overhead lifting equipment in warehouse and production areas. Install warning signage and use floor marking tape to delineate zones. Conduct mandatory training for all personnel on exclusion zone protocols and consequences of unauthorized entry. Warehouse supervisors will conduct monthly audits to verify compliance. This administrative control ensures that even if equipment failure occurs, personnel remain protected from falling objects.

name: Install Protective Enclosure Over Fire Alarm Sensors
description: Install clear polycarbonate protective shields around all fire alarm sensors in the Raw Materials Warehouse to prevent accidental contact from cleaning materials or inventory handling. The shields will be designed to allow smoke passage while protecting sensors from liquid splash. Installation will be completed by a certified fire protection specialist, and all staff will receive updated briefing on sensor locations and the new protective measures to ensure they understand the system has been secured.

name: Implement Segregated Chemical Storage Protocol
description: Establish a dedicated chemical storage zone physically separated from the fire alarm control panel and sensitive electronic equipment. All cleaning supplies and solvents will be stored in sealed chemical cabinets located at least 15 feet from fire suppression system components. Staff will receive training on proper chemical handling, storage locations, and the importance of containing spills immediately. A monthly audit will verify compliance with this new protocol.

name: Conduct Fire Suppression System Sensitivity Review
description: Engage a certified fire protection engineer to conduct a comprehensive review of all fire alarm sensor sensitivity settings in the facility. Sensors will be calibrated to respond only to actual smoke/heat conditions while being resistant to accidental liquid contact or minor environmental fluctuations.
