Documentation of all sensor calibrations will be maintained and reviewed quarterly. This engineering control prioritizes elimination of false alarms that can desensitize staff to actual emergencies.

name: Implement Automatic Component Temperature Verification System
description: Install infrared temperature sensors at the conveyor discharge point to automatically verify that all components meet minimum cooling requirements before reaching the assembly station. Components above the safe handling threshold (>60°C) will trigger automatic conveyor rejection, preventing assembly operators from contact with dangerous materials. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at its source by ensuring components are safely cooled before human handling. System will be integrated with production tracking software.

name: Establish Change Control Procedure for Production Parameters
description: Create a formal change control procedure requiring approval from both Production Engineering and HSE departments before any modifications to cooling cycles, temperature settings, or conveyor timing. All production parameter changes must be documented, assessed for safety impact, and communicated to all affected departments before implementation. Assembly line supervisors will receive mandatory training on this procedure and will have authority to halt production if they observe undocumented parameter changes.

name: Distribute Heat-Resistant Handling Gloves to Assembly Personnel
description: Issue certified heat-resistant gloves (rated to 200°C) to all Assembly and Finishing Department personnel. Gloves will meet ANSI standards for thermal protection and be replaced every 6 months or upon damage. While PPE is the last-resort control, this interim measure provides protection during the implementation period of the temperature verification system. All staff will receive fitting and proper use training to ensure correct sizing and application.

name: Replace All Substitute LOTO Pins with Certified Lock Hardware
description: Immediately remove all temporary or substitute lock pins from injection molding equipment and replace with manufacturer-specified, certified LOTO locking devices. Each lock will be uniquely keyed and color-coded by machine line. All equipment will be retrofitted with lock point identification tags clearly marking where locks must be placed. Inventory control will track all locks to prevent substitutions. This engineering control eliminates the root cause by ensuring only proper locking mechanisms can be used.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Certification and Quarterly Audits
description: Establish a mandatory LOTO certification program requiring all maintenance technicians and operators to complete formal training and pass written examination on lockout/tagout procedures specific to TechnoPlast equipment. Recertification will be required every 12 months. Quarterly unannounced LOTO audits will be conducted by the HSE department, and audit results will be reviewed in monthly safety committee meetings. Any observed LOTO violations will result in immediate equipment removal from service until corrected.

name: Install Hopper Gate Electronic Interlock Safety System
description: Install an electronic interlock system that physically prevents hopper gate operation whenever the maintenance access hatch is open or whenever lockout devices are engaged. This redundant engineering control provides protection even if operators fail to follow LOTO procedures. The interlock will also send alert signals to the supervisory control system, creating an auditable record of maintenance activities. Installation will be completed by equipment manufacturer technicians and fully tested before returning equipment to service.

name: Establish LOTO Responsibility Assignment and Accountability Protocol
description: Create a clear procedure assigning LOTO lock responsibility to specific named individuals for each maintenance task. Only the assigned technician or authorized supervisor can remove locks. A handwritten LOTO log will be maintained at each station documenting who locked/unlocked equipment, time of action, and signature. Supervisors will verify lock status before allowing any equipment operation. Training will emphasize that material handlers cannot perform lock/unlock duties, reducing exposure from untrained personnel.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Cooling Systems
description: Establish quarterly ultrasonic thickness testing and annual thermal imaging inspections of all cooling system couplings and pipe sections. Install vibration sensors on high-risk connections to monitor stress patterns. Create a replacement schedule for components reaching 80% of expected service life. Maintenance team will maintain a digital asset registry with inspection history. This addresses the root cause of age-related coupling failure and deferred maintenance practices.

name: Upgrade Mezzanine Spill Containment Infrastructure
description: Install secondary containment trays under all mezzanine-mounted cooling equipment with capacity for 125% of system fluid volume. Add slip-resistant coating to mezzanine floor and install improved drainage system with oil-water separator. Mark spill kit locations with high-visibility signage and train all maintenance staff on spill response procedures. This prevents future coolant migration to lower levels and reduces cleanup time.

name: Mandatory LOTO Enforcement for All Grinding Equipment
description: Install electrical interlock switches on all regrind equipment that prevent operation without lockout engagement. Conduct mandatory retraining for all 18 regrind department operators on LOTO procedures with emphasis on composite material processing hazards. Implement weekly audits of equipment setup compliance using a standardized checklist. Supervisors must witness and sign off on all jam-clearing procedures for one month. This eliminates operator discretion and enforces engineering control over behavioral hazard.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Gloves for Regrind Operations
description: Distribute ANSI A4 rated cut-resistant gloves (nitrile-coated nylon) to all regrind operators for use during jam clearing and maintenance tasks. Select gloves compatible with grip requirements and material handling. Establish replacement schedule and include in monthly PPE audits. While PPE is a lower-tier control, this provides necessary hand protection during the equipment modification transition period.

name: Install Mechanical Deburring Station with Guard System
description: Replace manual hand burring process with semi-automated deburring station featuring pneumatic tool holder with adjustable guard rails and emergency palm-button stop. Design allows only controlled tool access to mold edges, eliminating slip-catch incidents. Integrate dial calipers for edge quality verification without hand contact. Expected to reduce mold finish time by 25% while eliminating this high-risk manual operation. Implementation includes operator retraining on new equipment protocols.

name: Implement Night Shift Fatigue Mitigation and Mandatory Breaks
description: Establish 15-minute mandatory break every 2 hours for night shift precision work (02:00-06:00 period highest risk). Provide well-lit break room with ergonomic seating and caffeine-free beverages. Rotate night shift assignments to maximum 3 consecutive nights per employee before 2-night break. Conduct baseline fatigue assessment using validated screening tools. Supervisor check-ins at 02:30 and 04:30 to observe operator alertness and work quality. This administrative control addresses circadian rhythm disruption and reduced vigilance during overnight operations.

name: Provide Enhanced Cut-Resistant Gloves with Finger Reinforcement
description: Upgrade to ANSI A5 rated gloves (highest cut resistance) with reinforced fingertip and web area padding for all mold finishing operations. Select gloves maintaining dexterity for precision work (tested with calipers and burring tools). Issue two pairs per employee weekly. Include glove inspection in daily safety briefing. Complement engineering control during implementation phase.

name: Mandatory LOTO Enforcement for All Molding Line Maintenance
description: Implement strict lockout/tagout protocol verification before any maintenance begins on injection molding equipment. Install visual compliance checkpoints and require supervisor sign-off on all LOTO procedures. Deploy colored lockout tags specifically for thermal hazards on nozzles and heating elements. Conduct refresher training for all operators on proper LOTO sequence and emergency stop button relocation study. This directly addresses the root cause of inadequate hazard isolation during maintenance work.

name: Upgrade to Heat-Resistant Thermal Protection Gloves
description: Replace all standard cotton work gloves with certified heat-resistant aramid-based gloves rated for temperatures up to 260°C in production and maintenance areas. Distribute to all 30 operators and maintenance staff on molding lines. Train staff on proper use and care of new gloves. Include quarterly replacement schedule in inventory management. While this is a PPE measure, it provides critical protection given the high thermal exposure risk in injection molding operations.

name: Install Temperature-Cut Safety Shutoff Valves on Nozzle Heaters
description: Engineer and install automated thermal cutoff valves on all injection nozzle heating systems that halt heat delivery if temperature exceeds safe maintenance limits (>150°C). This engineering control prevents accidental hot plastic discharge during maintenance activities. Retrofit all 4 molding lines within 60 days. This eliminates the hazard at the source rather than relying on PPE alone.

name: Clear Emergency Stop Button Access Zones
description: Immediately establish and maintain 3-foot clear zones around all emergency stop buttons in packaging and labeling stations. Relocate all storage boxes, material racks, and equipment that currently obstruct operator access to these controls. Install yellow floor markings and signage indicating the protected zone. Conduct weekly audits to verify compliance. This administrative control ensures operators can quickly engage emergency stops during equipment malfunctions or jams.

name: Implement Shift Handover Chemical Container Inspection Protocol
description: Establish mandatory shift-to-shift inspection and documented handover procedure specifically for chemical storage containers. At the end of each shift, the departing supervisor must visually inspect all resin and composite material containers, checking for cracks, leaks, discoloration, and proper sealing. Findings must be logged in a physical inspection register and electronically communicated to the incoming shift supervisor. Any defective containers must be immediately flagged with red tape and replaced or moved to quarantine storage. This administrative control ensures no damaged containers remain in service due to communication gaps.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Container Quality and Add Secondary Containment
description: Replace all existing polyester resin storage containers with industrial-grade polypropylene or steel drums rated for chemical storage and equipped with pressure relief valves. Install secondary containment trays beneath all chemical storage shelving in the Composite Materials Processing Area with capacity for 110% of the largest single container. The secondary containment will capture any leaks before they reach the floor or drainage systems. This engineering control eliminates the source hazard by providing superior containment and prevents environmental contamination.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a quarterly hydraulic system inspection protocol for all injection molding machines, including pressure testing, fluid level monitoring, and hose clamp verification. Maintenance technician Fernand Giguère will coordinate with Gilles Marchand to conduct these inspections on a rotating basis. Fluid samples will be analyzed for contamination. All operators will receive training on recognizing early warning signs of hydraulic leaks. Work orders will be generated automatically in the maintenance system every 90 days.

name: Install Hydraulic Leak Detection System with Automatic Shutoff
description: Replace existing manual pressure relief valves with smart pressure monitoring sensors that trigger automatic machine shutdown if pressure drops more than 15% from baseline. This engineering control eliminates the risk of personnel discovering leaks through equipment malfunction or burns. The system will generate alerts to maintenance staff and log all pressure anomalies for predictive maintenance analysis.

name: Mandatory Operator Training on Equipment Abnormality Recognition
description: All production operators on Lines A, B, and C will complete a 2-hour hands-on training session covering identification of abnormal sounds, odors, vibrations, and leaks in injection molding equipment. Training will include immediate response procedures, machine shutdown protocols, and emergency contact procedures. Operators will be tested monthly during safety briefings on their ability to recognize at least 5 common equipment malfunction indicators.

name: Implement Mandatory Load Securing Verification Checklist
description: All forklift operators must complete a visual load-securing checklist before moving any pallet. The checklist requires verification of all four corner straps, assessment of load stability, and confirmation that no bags protrude beyond pallet edges. A laminated checklist will be affixed to each forklift. Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme will conduct weekly audits to ensure compliance. Any operator found moving unsecured loads will receive immediate retraining and a safety violation will be recorded.

name: Upgrade Forklift Training Program with Load Dynamics Module
description: Expand the existing forklift certification program to include a section on load behavior during turns, acceleration, and deceleration. The training will use video demonstrations and case studies of load shifts similar to this incident. All current operators must recertify within 60 days. New operators will complete this enhanced training before receiving their license. The training will be delivered by Jamal Thompson from the Respiratory Protection Program office in collaboration with HSE.

name: Replace All Wooden Stirring Equipment with Food-Grade Stainless Steel Alternatives
description: Eliminate all wooden paddles, stirrers, and mixing equipment from the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-008). Replace with FDA-approved stainless steel or plastic-coated stirrers that are non-porous, autoclavable, and resistant to chemical degradation. This engineering control removes the splinter hazard completely. Inventory of existing wooden equipment will be completed within 5 days, with replacement ordered immediately. All wooden mixing tools currently in storage will be disposed of following hazardous waste protocols.

name: Establish Equipment Condition Inspection and Replacement Program
description: Implement a monthly inspection protocol for all mixing equipment, stirrers, paddles, and contact tools used in chemical preparation areas. Any equipment showing signs of wear, splintering, cracking, or chemical damage will be immediately removed from service and replaced. Normand Bergeron, Regrind Supervisor, will maintain an equipment condition log. All composite materials operators will receive training on identifying equipment degradation and will be empowered to report unsafe tools. Replacement budget will be allocated quarterly.

name: Mandate Enhanced PPE for Chemical Area Operations
description: All personnel working in Chemical Storage and Mixing areas must now wear cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 rating minimum) in addition to standard nitrile chemical gloves through a double-gloving system. Safety glasses with side shields are now mandatory. Operators will receive training on proper double-glove application and removal to prevent chemical exposure while maintaining dexterity. Glove inventory will be increased to support weekly changes. Monthly safety audits will verify compliance.

name: Mandatory Cut-Resistant Glove Policy for Finishing Operations
description: Implement a mandatory requirement for all Finishing Operators to wear ANSI A3-rated cut-resistant gloves when handling cooled composite parts with exposed edges. Gloves will be stored in the work area and inspected daily. Add laminated signage at all finishing stations reminding workers of PPE requirements. Conduct a 15-minute toolbox talk with all finishing personnel within 2 days of the incident to reinforce the policy and demonstrate proper glove fit and inspection.

name: Design Review of Part Edge Finishing Specifications
description: Coordinate with Raj Patel (Process Engineer) to review and revise the edge finishing specifications for all polycarbonate medical device housings currently in production. Establish minimum edge radius requirements to eliminate sharp edges before parts reach the finishing operator stage. Update CAD specifications and mold designs to incorporate beveled edges as a standard feature. This engineering control will reduce the root cause of cut hazards by eliminating sharp edges at the source during manufacturing.

name: Implement Mandatory Pre-Shift PPE Inspection Checklist
description: Develop and implement a daily pre-shift PPE inspection checklist for all operators in Production Operations handling materials above 80°C. Each operator must physically inspect gloves, sleeves, and aprons for tears, holes, and seal integrity before clocking in. A supervisor or safety representative must sign off on completed inspections. Place laminated checklist cards at each workstation and conduct a mandatory 30-minute training session with all production staff covering proper glove inspection techniques, identifying damage, and replacement procedures. Track compliance weekly with discipline for non-compliance.

name: Upgrade to Thermal-Resistant Gloves with Double-Layer Construction
description: Replace current single-layer thermal gloves with dual-layer aluminized thermal gloves that provide enhanced insulation and puncture resistance. Conduct a trial period with 3 operators to verify comfort and dexterity before full rollout. The new gloves meet ANSI Z535.4 standards for high-temperature protection. Issue new gloves to all 32 molding machine operators and establish a replacement schedule every 6 months or upon inspection failure. Cost includes procurement and training on proper use.

name: Conduct Mandatory Burn Prevention and First Aid Refresher Training
description: Schedule a 1-hour mandatory training session for all Production Operations personnel covering thermal burn prevention, recognition of burn severity, and proper first aid response. Include practical demonstration of cooling techniques, appropriate dressing materials, and when to seek medical attention. Emphasize the importance of immediate action and cooling for at least 10 minutes. Training will be delivered by Karine Cloutier and completed within 30 days of the incident. Document attendance and comprehension via short written quiz.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule Management System
description: Deploy a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) to track and schedule all preventive maintenance tasks for the 32 injection molding machines and associated hydraulic systems. Program the system with manufacturer-recommended intervals for all major components, including the 2,000-hour hydraulic pump seal inspection and replacement. Generate automated alerts 100 hours before due maintenance. Assign François-Xavier Mailhot as system administrator responsible for reviewing alerts and assigning work orders. Conduct training for all maintenance staff on the new system within 5 days. Monthly audit of compliance will be conducted by the JHSC.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Monitoring with Redundant Pressure Gauges
description: Install dual pressure gauges on all 32 injection molding machines, with the second gauge positioned as a backup that will alert maintenance to discrepancies when primary gauge readings differ significantly. Additionally, upgrade to smart pressure sensors that trigger automatic machine shutdown if pressure drops below safe operating levels rather than relying solely on operator observation of gauges. This engineering control provides real-time monitoring and prevents catastrophic failures from going undetected. All machines will be retrofitted within 60 days.

name: Establish Secondary Containment and Spill Response Protocol
description: Install secondary containment drip pans beneath all injection molding machines to capture hydraulic fluid in the event of seal failure. Pans must have a capacity of at least 150% of the hydraulic system volume for each machine. Place absorbent spill kits at strategic locations throughout the production area. Designate containment/spill cleanup as a specific role in the maintenance job responsibilities and include in the JHSC inspection checklist. Establish procedures for waste hydraulic fluid collection and recycling through licensed disposal contractor. Training on containment and spill response will be provided to all maintenance personnel.

name: Install Advanced Dust Collection System in Heat Treatment Area
description: Replace the existing partial-collection oven dust system with a high-efficiency cyclone separator and bag filter system rated for plastic composite dust. Install real-time dust accumulation sensors that trigger alerts when thickness exceeds 2 mm. The new system will include automatic purge cycles every 4 hours during production. This engineering control eliminates the primary ignition source by preventing dust accumulation at dangerous levels. Installation will include new ductwork, sensors, and control logic integration with the facility's PLC system.

name: Implement Daily Compressed Air Dust Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily 15-minute inspection and compressed air cleaning routine for all oven heating chambers and adjacent surfaces. Operators will use anti-static grounding straps connected to equipment during all dust removal activities. Inspections will be logged in a digital maintenance tracker with photo documentation. Supervisors will review logs weekly. This administrative control ensures dust levels never accumulate beyond safe thresholds and institutionalizes proper grounding procedures during maintenance activities.

name: Conduct Facility-Wide Static Electricity Awareness Training
description: Deliver mandatory 2-hour training to all production and maintenance personnel on static electricity generation, dissipation, and fire risks in composite material environments. Include demonstration of proper grounding techniques, identification of static hazards specific to plastic dust, and emergency response procedures. Training will be delivered within 14 days and repeated annually. All staff will sign competency attestations. This administrative control addresses the human behavior component of the incident and ensures staff understand the connection between static discharge and dust fires.

name: Install Real-Time Ventilation System Monitoring with Automated Alerts
description: Install digital airflow sensors on all chemical mixing ventilation hoods that continuously monitor extraction rates and display real-time readings on control panels. Configure automated alerts (visual and audible) when airflow drops below 90% of design capacity. Integrate sensors with the facility's predictive maintenance system to generate work orders when thresholds are exceeded. System will include daily calibration checks and monthly verification testing. This engineering control ensures ventilation failures are detected immediately rather than allowing prolonged exposure periods.

name: Implement Mandatory Pre-Shift Ventilation System Verification Protocol
description: Require all operators beginning work in the chemical mixing area to perform a 5-minute pre-shift ventilation verification using a handheld airflow meter. Results will be recorded on a laminated checklist and submitted to the shift supervisor. If airflow is below 90% of specification, the operator must not begin chemical mixing and must immediately notify maintenance. Supervisors will review logs daily and escalate any issues within 30 minutes. This administrative control creates accountability and ensures no chemical work begins without confirmed adequate ventilation.

name: Expedite Repair of All Disabled Equipment Monitoring Systems
description: Conduct immediate facility audit to identify all disabled or non-functional monitoring systems, alarms, or safety indicators. Prioritize repair of the chemical area hood airflow indicator (currently disabled for 6 weeks). Establish policy that no safety monitoring system can remain disabled for more than 24 hours. Create a 'disabled equipment' log that is reviewed daily in safety meetings until clearance is achieved. This administrative control prevents situations where broken safety systems create blind spots in hazard detection.

name: Implement Preventive Drum Replacement Program
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and replacement schedule for all 55-gallon chemical drums stored in the Chemical Storage Building. Drums showing signs of corrosion, dents, or structural compromise will be replaced immediately. All drums will be elevated on pallets with secondary containment trays to catch potential leaks before they reach the floor. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the spill by removing degraded containers from service before failure occurs. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in drum-related chemical spills.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Ventilation System
description: Install an automated continuous ventilation monitoring system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room with real-time sensors for chemical vapor concentration. The system will trigger mechanical exhaust fans when vapor levels exceed safe thresholds and alert facility management via email and audible alarm. This addresses the inadequate ventilation hazard and ensures rapid response to fume accumulation. Installation includes ducting modifications and integration with the facility's emergency alert system.

name: Conduct Chemical Spill Response Training
description: Mandatory training for all production and warehouse staff on proper chemical spill containment, use of absorbent materials, and ventilation protocols. Training will include hands-on practice with spill response kits and decision trees for escalation. All personnel working near chemical storage areas will complete this training within 30 days, with annual refresher training thereafter. This administrative control ensures all employees can respond effectively to spills.

name: Enforce Mandatory LOTO Procedure Compliance
description: Implement a zero-tolerance policy for lockout/tagout violations during all maintenance activities on injection molding machines. All machine setters and maintenance technicians must complete recertification training on LOTO procedures within 7 days. A LOTO checklist will be physically affixed to each of the 32 machines requiring completion before any maintenance work begins. Supervisors will conduct random audits of LOTO compliance twice weekly. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of Tomas's injury by ensuring energy isolation before equipment access.

name: Install Dual-Confirmation Safety Interlock System
description: Retrofit Injection Molding Machines #1-#16 (including the incident machine) with dual-confirmation safety interlocks that prevent machine operation when maintenance or access compartments are open. The system requires both supervisor authorization and operator confirmation before any cycle can begin. This engineering control provides a secondary safeguard that prevents accidental machine activation during maintenance. Implementation will occur over 45 days in phases to minimize production disruption.

name: Establish Maintenance-Operations Communication Protocol
description: Create a formal handoff procedure requiring written and verbal confirmation between maintenance personnel and machine operators before and after any maintenance work. All diagnostics and troubleshooting must be documented in a log posted on each machine. Operations staff must wait for explicit clearance from maintenance before resuming machine operation. This administrative control prevents miscommunication between shifts and departments.

name: Replace Wheeled Ladders with Stable Access Equipment
description: Remove all wheeled ladders from the Finished Goods Warehouse and replace with fixed stairway access systems or stable A-frame ladders with wider bases and non-slip feet. All bin retrieval heights above 5 feet will be redesigned using mechanical material lifts or lower-level storage reorganization. This engineering control eliminates the unstable ladder hazard that directly contributed to Salma's fall.

name: Implement Ergonomic Assessment and Workplace Redesign
description: Conduct a comprehensive ergonomic assessment of all material handling tasks in the warehouse, focusing on reaching heights and awkward postures. Redesign bin storage layout to keep frequently accessed items between waist and shoulder height. Provide ergonomic training to all warehouse staff emphasizing proper lifting techniques, the dangers of reaching above shoulder height, and when to request assistance. This administrative and ergonomic control addresses the root cause of the awkward reaching posture.

name: Implement Preventive Mold Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish a formal preventive maintenance schedule for all injection mold injection molds, with bi-weekly alignment checks and tolerance verification using calibrated equipment. This will prevent the temperature drift that contributed to this incident. Maintenance technician Fernand Giguère will oversee implementation in the Central Maintenance Workshop, documenting all adjustments in the equipment log. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in temperature-related ejection anomalies within 60 days.

name: Enhanced Heat-Resistant PPE Trial Program
description: Upgrade to premium silicone-based heat-resistant gloves rated to 150°C for all Line A operators, replacing current standard gloves. Conduct fit and comfort trials with affected employees over two weeks to ensure compliance. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator will oversee procurement and training. Expected outcome: Improved protection margin against thermal injuries with better operator comfort and compliance.

name: Implement Daily Pre-Operation Forklift Inspection Protocol
description: Develop and deploy a standardized daily pre-operation inspection checklist for all electric and propane forklifts, including mandatory hydraulic fluid level verification using calibrated dipsticks. Operators must complete the checklist before shift start and document results on laminated cards attached to each vehicle. Maintenance technician Fernand Giguère will review all inspection records weekly. Any fluid level below minimum triggers immediate removal from service. Expected outcome: 100% detection of hydraulic fluid anomalies before operational use, eliminating recurring maintenance-related load shift events.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Monitoring Technology
description: Install automated hydraulic pressure sensors on all forklifts with real-time feedback displays in the operator cabin. Sensors will alert operators to pressure drops exceeding 5% of nominal operating pressure. This engineering control provides early warning before critical load failures occur. The system includes automatic data logging for predictive maintenance analysis. Implementation to be completed by the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop. Expected outcome: Real-time detection of all hydraulic system degradation before operational failure.

name: Mandatory Hydraulic System Pressure Relief Tool Deployment
description: Require all maintenance personnel working on hydraulic systems to use calibrated, computer-controlled pressure relief tools rather than manual depression of relief valves. Three new hydraulic diagnostic stations will be installed in the Central Maintenance Workshop, each equipped with certified pressure relief equipment and digital readout displays. All technicians must complete 4-hour certification training before using any hydraulic system. Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère will assist with training development. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of residual pressure hazards during hydraulic maintenance, with documented zero-pressure verification before any cartridge removal.

name: Comprehensive LOTO Procedure Audit and Retraining
description: Conduct a complete audit of all LOTO procedures across the maintenance department, with particular focus on hydraulic system isolation protocols. Develop detailed step-by-step visual work instructions with photographic documentation of each LOTO checkpoint. Implement a mandatory 8-hour retraining program for all 18 maintenance staff members, with competency testing and documented sign-off. Repeat retraining quarterly. Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri will lead procedure development and audit compliance. Expected outcome: 100% adherence to LOTO procedures with documented verification at each maintenance task.

name: Install Pressure Relief Interlock Safety System
description: Engineering modification to Machine #18 and all similar 250+ ton molding machines: Install automatic mechanical interlocks that physically prevent cartridge access until digital pressure sensors confirm zero residual pressure in the hydraulic system. The interlock will be controlled by the machine's programmable logic controller (PLC) and will only release when confirmed pressure readings remain at zero for 60 consecutive seconds. Electrical and Instrumentation Shop will oversee design and implementation. Expected outcome: Physical elimination of pressurized hydraulic release hazard during maintenance operations through engineering control.

name: Install High-Temperature Warning Labels and Heat-Resistant Signage
description: Install permanent, high-visibility warning labels on all exposed mold heating elements and hot surfaces throughout the injection molding lines, identifying them as hot surfaces with operating temperatures. Labels will use ISO-compliant hazard symbols and be placed at eye level and on approach routes. Additionally, implement reflective warning tape around high-temperature zones. This engineering control directly addresses the lack of visual hazard communication and will serve as a persistent reminder to workers.

name: Provide Heat-Resistant Work Gloves at All Molding Workstations
description: Procure and distribute high-quality Kevlar and silicone-blend heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C) to all injection molding operators and setters. Mount glove dispensers at four strategic locations on each molding line for immediate accessibility. Ensure gloves are included in the daily PPE inspection checklist. This control provides a last-line defense against thermal burns and ensures workers have proper protective equipment immediately available when performing temperature-sensitive adjustments.

name: Implement Mandatory Quarterly Spreader Bar and Rigging Equipment Inspection Program
description: Establish a formal, documented inspection protocol for all rigging equipment including spreader bars, slings, and attachment hardware. Inspections will be conducted quarterly (every 3 months) by certified rigging inspectors and maintenance technicians. Each piece of equipment will be tagged with inspection dates and removed from service immediately upon discovery of any defects. A centralized tracking system will be implemented to ensure no inspection schedule is missed. Non-compliant equipment will be segregated and repaired or replaced. This administrative control ensures systematic hazard identification and prevents equipment failures.

name: Install Automated Load Monitoring and Warning System on Overhead Cranes
description: Retrofit all overhead cranes in the warehouse with load cells and wireless monitoring systems that continuously transmit load weight and spreader bar status to the operator's control pendant and a centralized dashboard. The system will audibly and visually alert operators if load approaches maximum capacity or if spreader bar attachment integrity is compromised. Install automatic load-stopping mechanisms that prevent crane operation if dangerous conditions are detected. This engineering control provides real-time hazard detection and prevents unsafe lifting operations.

name: Establish No-Load-Under-HEAD Zone and Enhanced Dock Safety Protocol
description: Paint and mark a clearly defined 5-meter-wide exclusion zone directly beneath all overhead crane paths. No personnel will be permitted in this zone during any lifting operations. Implement a communication protocol where crane operators must confirm "area clear" before commencing any lift. Install red warning lights above crane paths that activate when loads are being moved. Conduct mandatory monthly toolbox talks specifically covering overhead crane safety and load-under-head hazards. This administrative control eliminates worker exposure to falling object hazards.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for All Chemical Storage Equipment
description: Create and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program specifically for all chemical storage tanks, pressure relief valves, and associated equipment. Schedule annual inspections and maintenance for all pressure relief valves, replacing seals and cleaning crystallized residue. Utilize a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) to track all service dates and generate automatic alerts when maintenance is due. Assign responsibility to the maintenance planning team to execute this schedule without exception. This administrative control prevents equipment failures that could lead to unexpected chemical releases.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Area with Enhanced Eye Wash and Shower Stations
description: Install two additional emergency eyewash stations and one emergency shower station in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room, positioning them within 10 seconds of all primary work areas. Ensure all stations meet ANSI Z358.1 standards and are regularly inspected and flushed monthly. Install highly visible signage and directional markers indicating the locations of all emergency wash stations. This engineering control ensures rapid access to emergency decontamination in the event of chemical exposure.

name: Restore and Lock Mold Temperature Alarm System
description: Central Maintenance Workshop will immediately restore the cooling timer alarm functionality on Injection Molding Line A and implement a lockout procedure requiring management approval before any alarm can be disabled. A daily alarm function test will be added to the morning shift checklist. Maintenance will document all future troubleshooting activities involving critical safety systems and require re-verification before equipment return to service. This engineering control eliminates the hazard by ensuring operators cannot bypass temperature verification procedures.

name: Mandatory Cooling Protocol Refresher Training
description: All production operators will receive immediate retraining on mold cooling procedures, emphasizing the critical 15-minute cooling requirement and prohibition on manual mold contact. Training will include review of thermal burn hazards and will be documented in individual training records. Supervisory staff will conduct daily toolbox talks for two weeks following the incident to reinforce safe practices. This administrative control ensures operators understand and comply with established procedures.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Protocol for All Machine Maintenance
description: Establish formal Lockout/Tagout procedures for all CNC finishing equipment in UNIT-005 that must be followed before any clearing of cutting areas or maintenance work. Install prominent LOTO signage and provide dedicated lock boxes at each machine station. All operators will receive certified LOTO training within 5 business days. A checklist system will document LOTO compliance for each shift. This engineering and administrative control prevents unintended machine startup during maintenance activities.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Calendar for Proximity Sensors
description: Central Maintenance Workshop will create and implement a preventive maintenance schedule requiring calibration of all proximity sensors on CNC equipment every 6 months per manufacturer specifications. A digital tracking system will issue alerts 2 weeks prior to each scheduled maintenance date. All calibrations will be documented with date, technician name, and results. Non-compliance will trigger escalation to maintenance supervisor. This administrative control ensures critical safety components function reliably.

name: Install Machine Guarding on CNC Finishing Equipment
description: Evaluate and upgrade physical machine guarding on all CNC equipment in UNIT-005 to prevent hand contact with rotating cutting tools. Consult with equipment manufacturer regarding guard retrofit options that maintain operator access for material loading while preventing incidental contact. Install transparent polycarbonate guards if feasible to allow operator visibility. This primary engineering control reduces severity of potential injuries even if LOTO procedures are not followed.

name: Install Overhead Cable and Hose Management System
description: Design and install a comprehensive overhead cable/hose routing system in the Shipping and Receiving Dock that elevates all pneumatic lines, electrical cables, and compressed air hoses above the active forklift traffic pathway. Install cable trays mounted to ceiling structure with minimum 8-foot clearance. All pneumatic connections will be reconfigured to feed from overhead routes to individual tool stations. This engineering control eliminates the trip hazard and removes obstacles from material handling areas.

name: Establish Dock Area Housekeeping and Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a daily shift start inspection checklist for UNIT-009 requiring verification that all hoses, cables, and equipment are secured and routed properly. Material handlers will conduct a 10-minute walkthrough before beginning operations to identify hazards. Any non-compliant routing will be corrected immediately or the dock area will be restricted from use until corrected. Document all inspections and corrective actions. This administrative control maintains safe conditions between permanent infrastructure upgrades.

name: Mandatory PPE Compliance Program for Resin Handling
description: Implement a mandatory personal protective equipment (PPE) compliance program specifically for all employees working with uncured epoxy resins and composite materials. The program will include: mandatory use of nitrile gloves (minimum 8-mil thickness), long-sleeved protective clothing, and face shields during all resin handling operations. Weekly visual inspections will be conducted by supervisors to verify compliance. Non-compliance will result in immediate work stoppage and retraining. All staff in UNIT-015 will receive refresher training on proper PPE usage and skin contact protocols within 5 business days.

name: Enhanced Eyewash Station Accessibility and Training
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all eyewash and safety shower stations in the Composite Materials Processing Area to ensure accessibility and proper function. Establish monthly testing and maintenance protocols. Provide hands-on training to all UNIT-015 employees on proper use of emergency eyewash equipment, including correct rinsing duration (minimum 15 minutes for chemical exposure) and immediate notification procedures. Post clear signage and provide laminated quick-reference guides at each workstation showing eyewash station locations and proper procedures.

name: Install Automated Part Removal System with Manual Override Safety
description: Engineer and install an automated robotic arm with vacuum-grip technology on Injection Molding Line A to eliminate manual part removal from the mold cavity. The system will include pressure-sensitive safety interlocks that prevent mold closure until the robot has successfully removed all parts or signaled completion. Include a manual override button that requires two-hand concurrent activation to prevent accidental triggering. Additionally, retrofit the machine with proximity sensors that detect hand presence within 12 inches of the mold cavity and automatically halt the cycle. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source rather than relying on operator compliance.

name: Mandatory Machine Guarding and Lockout/Tagout Reinforcement Training
description: Conduct immediate retraining for all injection molding operators on proper Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedures and the prohibition against reaching into active mold cavities. Require all operators to complete a hands-on certification course that includes machine-specific hazard identification and safe work practices. Implement a buddy-check system where operators must verbally confirm with a partner that they will allow automatic ejection systems to operate before each cycle. Post visual warning placards at each machine showing the consequences of reaching into live mold areas. Testing and recertification will occur quarterly for all production staff.

name: Upgrade to Cut-Resistant Gloves and Hand Protection Equipment
description: Distribute high-grade cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rating) to all injection molding operators and provide training on proper selection and usage. These gloves feature puncture-resistant materials and are rated to resist cuts from sharp mold edges and ejected plastic components. Include proper donning/doffing procedures in the training. Establish a supply management system to ensure gloves are replaced when damaged or worn. Make glove replacement a daily pre-shift requirement monitored by shift supervisors. This provides an additional layer of protection while engineering controls are being implemented.

name: Install Fixed Access Stairway to Mezzanine Level
description: Design and install a permanent fixed industrial stairway with handrails and anti-slip treads leading to the mezzanine level in the Maintenance Workshop, eliminating the need for ladder access to the elevated work areas. The stairway will meet all applicable building codes and OSHA requirements including 30-degree slope, minimum 36-inch width, and 42-inch handrails with 1.5-inch graspability. Install intermediate landings as required by code. This engineering control provides a safe, stable access solution and removes the ladder hazard entirely. Estimated timeline: 60 days for design and installation.

name: Implement Mandatory Fall Protection Equipment and Harness System
description: Establish a comprehensive fall protection program requiring all personnel working at heights greater than 6 feet to use certified full-body harnesses rated for 100% anchorage. Install fixed anchor points and certified cable systems throughout the Maintenance Workshop mezzanine area at intervals no greater than 12 feet. All staff who work at heights must complete OSHA 30-hour training focused on fall protection, proper harness fitting, and rescue procedures. Conduct quarterly harness inspections and replace any equipment showing signs of wear or damage. Designate François-Xavier Mailhot as the Fall Protection Program Manager responsible for oversight and compliance monitoring.

name: Floor Maintenance and Contamination Control Protocol
description: Implement a comprehensive floor maintenance and contamination control protocol for the Maintenance Workshop. Establish designated areas for oil spill cleanup with absorbent mat stations and clearly marked contamination zones. Require immediate cleanup of any spills using absorbent materials, with secondary absorbent treatment of affected areas. Implement daily floor inspections at the start of each shift, with documentation in a maintenance log. Install additional slip-resistant floor coatings in high-traffic work areas. Provide all maintenance staff with non-slip shoe requirements and allow company-subsidized purchase of appropriate footwear. Establish a 'wet floor' sign protocol requiring immediate closure of affected areas until cleaned.

name: Ladder Inspection and Safety Procedures Audit
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all ladders in the facility, including the 16-foot aluminum extension ladder involved in this incident. Replace or repair any ladders showing signs of damage, corrosion, or instability. Implement a monthly ladder inspection checklist to be completed by maintenance supervisors, with documentation maintained in a central log. Establish clear procedures requiring ladder stabilization on level ground with anti-slip feet, placement at proper angle (75-degree angle), and securing to prevent slipping. Prohibit use of ladders on uneven, slippery, or contaminated surfaces - require ground leveling or alternative access methods. Include ladder safety in the quarterly toolbox talks.

name: Remove Unauthorized Heating Equipment from Chemical Storage
description: All portable space heaters and unauthorized electrical heating devices must be permanently removed from the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. Implement a formal equipment authorization process requiring HSE approval for any heating or electrical devices in hazardous material areas. Install centralized, ATEX-compliant heating system designed for explosive atmospheres. Conduct immediate inspection of all storage areas to identify and remove any unauthorized equipment.

name: Implement Flammable Solvent Storage Best Practices
description: Redesign the chemical storage area layout to isolate flammable solvents in an approved flammable cabinet with proper ventilation and grounding. Ensure all solvent containers are stored minimum 10 feet away from electrical outlets, heat sources, and ignition sources. Establish a strict no-heat protocol in the chemical storage zone. Conduct training for all personnel handling flammable materials on proper storage procedures, spill containment, and fire response within 5 days of this incident.

name: Conduct Fire Safety Audit and Equipment Inspection
description: Perform comprehensive fire safety audit of all production and storage areas. Inspect all fire suppression systems, extinguishers, and emergency response equipment. Verify proper maintenance records and certification dates. Replace any expired or damaged extinguishers. Conduct refresher training on proper extinguisher use (PASS technique) for all employees, with particular focus on production and maintenance staff who work near flammable materials.

name: Install Real-Time Ventilation Monitoring System
description: Install automated airflow monitoring sensors at critical points in the ventilation system with real-time alerting capabilities. Configure system to trigger automatic line shutdown if airflow drops below 85% of design specifications. Implement dashboard display in production areas showing current ventilation status. Sensors should be checked and calibrated monthly by certified technician. This engineering control will provide early warning of system failures before worker exposure reaches unsafe levels.

name: Structural Reinforcement of Ventilation Ductwork
description: Conduct comprehensive structural engineering assessment of all ventilation ductwork in production areas. Install permanent support brackets and reinforcement at all junction points and unsupported spans exceeding 6 feet. Replace any deteriorated sections of ductwork. Implement quarterly visual inspection protocol with documented findings. This elimination/substitution approach removes the root cause of system failure by ensuring structural integrity of the ventilation infrastructure.

name: Establish Ventilation System Maintenance Schedule and Training
description: Create comprehensive preventive maintenance plan for all ventilation systems with quarterly inspections by certified HVAC technician. Document all maintenance activities and system performance metrics. Provide training to maintenance technicians and shift supervisors on identifying signs of ventilation degradation (unusual noise, reduced airflow sensation, odor changes). Establish emergency response procedures requiring immediate line shutdown if ventilation issues are suspected. Conduct annual HVAC system efficiency audit.

name: Replace Temperature Control System with Redundant Monitoring
description: Replace the single-point thermostat control on the resin dryer with a dual-sensor, redundant temperature monitoring system. Install primary thermostat with secondary independent high-temperature alarm that triggers equipment shutdown at 175°C. Implement automated shutdown protocol if temperature exceeds setpoint by more than 8°C for more than 90 seconds. This engineering control eliminates the risk of single-point thermostat failure causing dangerous overheating.

name: Implement Equipment Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Establish quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all resin preparation equipment including thermostat inspection, cleaning, and contact verification. Create maintenance log with required sign-off by qualified technician. Include thermostat contact cleaning every 2 months to prevent corrosion. All maintenance must be documented with dates and findings. This administrative control ensures early detection of thermostat degradation before failure occurs.

name: Improve Environmental Controls in Equipment Storage Area
description: Install dedicated dehumidification system in the Material Drying and Preparation Room to maintain relative humidity below 50%, preventing condensation accumulation on electrical components. Install air filtration unit to reduce dust contamination of sensitive equipment. Ensure proper ventilation with air changes every 4 hours in this area. Conduct monthly humidity and dust monitoring to verify environmental control effectiveness.

name: Replace Faded Equipment Warning Labels
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all 32 injection molding machines to identify and replace faded, illegible, or damaged hazard warning labels. Priority focus on mold temperature indicators and hot surface warnings. Implement quarterly inspection schedule to ensure label visibility and legibility. Use high-visibility, UV-resistant label stock rated for industrial environments with temperatures up to 100°C. Expected outcome: 100% compliance with CNESST labeling requirements and improved hazard awareness among operators.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE Compliance Program
description: Implement daily pre-shift PPE verification checklist for all Line B operators, to be signed by both operator and line supervisor. Replace existing heat-resistant sleeves with ergonomic cooling-insert variants designed for comfort in warm environments. Conduct training session emphasizing the relationship between comfort-compromised PPE compliance and burn injury risk. Establish discipline protocol for non-compliance. Supply additional PPE sets to reduce frequency of laundering gaps. Expected outcome: 100% PPE compliance rate during hot mold operations.

name: Install Automated Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Retrofit Line B injection molding machine with real-time mold temperature display and audible alarm system that alerts operators when surface temperatures exceed 75°C. System will provide continuous digital readout at operator workstation and log temperature data for compliance records. Installation includes automatic shutdown safety feature if temperature exceeds 95°C. Training will be provided to all Line B operators on system operation and alarm response procedures. Expected outcome: Operators maintain awareness of actual mold temperatures, reducing inadvertent contact risk.

name: Implement Dual-Verification Lockout/Tagout Protocol
description: Establish mandatory two-person verification system for all LOTO procedures in the Regrind Department. Outgoing shift operator must physically demonstrate locked-out state to incoming operator, who must verify lock engagement and document on handoff checklist. Install lockout verification checklist posted at each equipment station. Conduct refresher LOTO training for all Regrind Department staff emphasizing consequences of incomplete lockout. Implement monthly audits of LOTO compliance. Expected outcome: Elimination of equipment activation during material clearing operations.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Procedures for All Maintenance Tasks
description: Establish and enforce strict lockout/tagout protocols for all machine adjustments and jam clearance activities. Install visible LOTO stations at each injection molding line with properly labeled locks and tags. Conduct mandatory retraining for all operators on LOTO procedures with written certification required. Implement daily pre-shift LOTO checklist verification. Non-compliance will result in immediate suspension of machine operation privileges.

name: Install Cooling Water Leak Detection and Monitoring System
description: Replace manual cooling water inspections with automated sensor-based leak detection on all injection molding lines. Install pressure monitors and flow rate sensors that trigger automatic machine shutdown if anomalies are detected. Implement predictive maintenance alerts to notify maintenance technicians before critical leaks occur. This engineering control eliminates the need for operators to manually inspect active cooling systems.

name: Enforce Mandatory PPE Compliance Program for Glass Fiber Handling
description: Implement daily visual PPE compliance audits at warehouse entry points with supervisor sign-offs. Establish clear consequences for non-compliance including mandatory retraining and suspension of material handling duties. Provide all warehouse staff with fitted long-sleeve Nomex work shirts and nitrile gloves specifically for glass fiber work. Update WHMIS documentation with photographic examples of proper PPE. Schedule monthly refresher training focused on why each PPE item is required.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Belt Tension Mechanisms
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule that includes quarterly inspection and semi-annual replacement of all belt tension springs and mechanisms on pumping equipment. Create a database tracking component age and replacement history. Install vibration sensors on critical pumps to detect belt degradation before failure. Replace all existing tension springs immediately as an interim safety measure. Maintenance technicians will receive training on early warning signs of spring corrosion.

name: Install Protective Shields on Belt Drive Systems
description: Design and install engineered protective guards around all belt tensioner release mechanisms to contain ejected belts and prevent projectile injuries. The guards will redirect released belts downward and prevent contact with personnel. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source rather than relying on worker behavior. All guards will be fabricated from steel mesh meeting industrial safety standards and installed within 30 days.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Pressure Systems
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all mold cooling systems, pressure relief valves, and associated regulators. Create a tracking system with work orders and inspection checklists. Train maintenance staff on proper testing and calibration procedures. Install pressure monitoring gauges on all molding lines with visual alarm thresholds. This eliminates the root cause of unscheduled pressure releases and ensures early detection of system degradation.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment Requirements
description: Mandate the use of Kevlar-lined thermal protection sleeves and heat-resistant aprons for all operators working with heated molds above 80°C. Provide face shields with thermal coating and insulated gloves rated for 200°C. Conduct mandatory PPE fitting and training for all production staff. Update safety procedures to require full PPE before any mold opening activities. Stock replacement PPE items in accessible stations throughout the production floor.

name: Deliver Comprehensive Pressure System Hazard Training
description: Conduct mandatory training for all production and maintenance personnel on pressure system hazards, emergency response procedures, and equipment shutdown protocols. Include hands-on demonstrations of pressure relief mechanisms and emergency eyewash/shower station locations. Create laminated quick-reference guides posted at each molding line. Require annual refresher training and competency assessments. Document all training completion.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Stabilization Systems
description: Retrofit all solvent storage shelving with secondary containment trays capable of holding 110% of the largest container volume. Install anti-slip mat liners and container restraint straps on all shelving units. Ensure all chemical storage containers remain secured at all times, even during brief transfers. Implement a new shelving system with lower center of gravity and wider base for improved stability. Conduct quarterly inspections of all containment systems and restraints.

name: Establish Solvent Transfer Protocols and Safe Handling Procedures
description: Create detailed written procedures for transferring and handling acetone and other volatile solvents, including requirements for two-person operations on containers larger than 10 liters. Mandate use of approved transfer pumps and grounding cables to prevent static discharge. Require all operators to complete competency certification before handling volatile chemicals. Implement a checklist system for every transfer operation. Update the facility's chemical inventory management system to track container location and secure storage compliance daily.

name: Upgrade Ventilation and Vapor Detection Systems
description: Install additional exhaust ventilation ducting throughout the chemical storage room to achieve 12 air changes per hour and maintain negative pressure relative to adjacent areas. Upgrade the vapor detection system with additional sensors in high-risk zones and connect to building management system for real-time monitoring. Install emergency shutdown switches that automatically isolate the chemical storage area and activate supplemental ventilation. Perform annual ventilation system inspections and cleaning.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Audit and Compliance Program
description: Establish a monthly audit schedule where the LOTO Coordinator inspects all machinery for proper lockout device installation, functional emergency stops, and safety interlock integrity. Create a compliance scoring system with corrective action timeframes. Any bypassed or disabled safety devices trigger immediate machine shutdown and work suspension. Develop a database tracking all LOTO violations, root causes, and remediation. Ensure maintenance supervisors conduct pre-job safety briefs requiring verbalization of LOTO requirements before any equipment work begins.

name: Provide Intensive LOTO Retraining and Accountability Framework
description: Conduct mandatory retraining for all maintenance and production staff on LOTO procedures, with special emphasis on why shortcuts are never acceptable and what constitutes a serious compliance violation. Use the discovered bypass incident as a case study in training materials. Implement a sign-off procedure where each technician acknowledges LOTO requirements before starting maintenance work. Create performance metrics linking LOTO compliance to performance evaluations. Establish consequences for unauthorized bypasses, including retraining requirements and disciplinary measures.

name: Repair Emergency Stop and Safety Interlock Devices
description: Immediately replace the unresponsive emergency stop button on the CNC machine with a new certified device meeting ANSI E-Stop standards. Replace the compromised safety interlock mechanism with a modern electronic safety gate switch that cannot be mechanically bypassed. Install tamper-evident seals on all future safety devices. Conduct a facility-wide audit of all machinery emergency stops and interlocks to identify similar deficiencies. Establish a preventive replacement schedule for safety devices every 5 years or upon first failure.

name: Replace Hydraulic Interlock Systems on All Molding Machines
description: Complete replacement of mechanical safety interlocks on all 32 injection molding machines with dual-channel electronic safety systems that independently verify gate closure position before mold engagement. System includes redundant pressure relief valves and automatic cycle abort if gate position cannot be confirmed. Retrofit will be conducted over 6 weeks with staggered machine downtime to maintain production capacity. Manufacturer certification and third-party validation required.

name: Implement Mandatory Machine Guarding Audit Program
description: Establish monthly comprehensive safety audit of all injection molding equipment conducted jointly by Electrical Maintenance Lead and Incident Investigation Specialist. Audits will include verification of all interlocks, guards, emergency stops, and pressure relief systems. Any deficiencies must be corrected within 48 hours. Results documented and reviewed with line supervisors. Audit checklist to be uploaded to safety management system.

name: Enhanced Operator Training on Machine Safety Procedures
description: Develop and deliver mandatory 4-hour retraining module for all injection molding operators focusing on: proper equipment operation, recognition of malfunction indicators, correct emergency procedures, and prohibition on manual intervention during mold cycles. Include hands-on simulation using deactivated machine. All operators must pass written and practical assessment. Annual recertification required. Training to be documented in personnel files.

name: Install Semi-Automated Component Handling System
description: Replace manual stacking operations at Post-Processing area with semi-automated robotic arm system that picks cooled components from conveyor and places them in organized pallets. System includes adjustable gripper for different part geometries and integrates with existing quality control equipment. Reduces repetitive motion by approximately 85%. Training required for 12 packaging operators. Payback period estimated at 18 months through reduced injury costs and increased throughput.

name: Ergonomic Workstation Redesign and Job Rotation
description: Implement ergonomic assessment of all packaging workstations using certified ergonomist. Adjust work surface heights, implement anti-fatigue mats, and install component presentation systems at optimal reach heights (between elbow and shoulder). Establish mandatory 15-minute job rotation every 90 minutes where operators alternate between different tasks. Reduces cumulative strain on any single joint group. All staff required to complete updated ergonomics training.

name: Replace All Aging Hazardous Waste Storage Tanks
description: Complete replacement of 8 storage tanks that are over 12 years old with new double-walled polyethylene tanks featuring integrated electronic leak detection systems. All tanks equipped with secondary containment systems sized for 110% of maximum tank volume. Tanks fitted with locked access ports and emergency shut-off mechanisms. Installation of automated monitoring system that alerts maintenance staff if moisture is detected in inter-wall space. All tanks certified to CSA standards and equipped with proper grounding.

name: Implement Hazardous Waste Storage Inspection Protocol
description: Establish bi-weekly visual inspection of all hazardous waste storage tanks and containment systems conducted by Maintenance Manager. Inspection checklist includes verification of drain valve position (always locked closed), secondary containment integrity, tank exterior condition, and electronic monitoring system functionality. All findings documented and maintained for regulatory compliance. Monthly review meeting with HSE department. Any deficiencies corrected within 24 hours. Inspection training provided to backup personnel for coverage during vacations.

name: Contaminated Soil Remediation and Site Restoration
description: Engage certified environmental remediation contractor to excavate and properly dispose of approximately 2.5 cubic meters of TCE-contaminated soil. Soil will be transported to licensed hazardous waste treatment facility for thermal remediation. Replacement topsoil from approved source will be installed. Post-remediation soil testing conducted to verify contaminant levels below regulatory thresholds. Final documentation filed with Quebec Ministry of Environment. Estimated completion within 30 days.

name: Upgrade Glove Specifications for Mold Release Handling
description: Replace standard nitrile gloves with double-layer nitrile or butyl rubber gloves that provide enhanced resistance to mold release agents (petroleum-based compounds). Distribute new glove specifications to all production operators working with molding lines. Conduct training on proper glove selection, inspection, and replacement protocols. This engineering/administrative control addresses the root cause of inadequate PPE protection against specific chemical agents used in the molding process.

name: Install Chemical Exposure Signage and Safety Stations
description: Install laminated warning signs at molding line stations indicating hazards of mold release agents and required PPE. Install eyewash and safety shower stations within 10 seconds of all injection molding workstations. Ensure stations are inspected monthly per CNESST requirements. This provides engineering controls and environmental awareness to prevent future skin contact incidents.

name: Implement Enhanced Hydraulic System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish quarterly third-party non-destructive testing (ultrasonic and magnetic particle inspection) of all hydraulic pressure valves and fittings on injection molding lines. Document all test results in a centralized maintenance tracking system. Replace any components showing signs of material degradation immediately. This engineering control and administrative procedure directly addresses equipment fatigue and material defects that caused the valve failure.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic System Pressure Relief Redundancy
description: Install secondary mechanical pressure relief valves on all major hydraulic circuits to provide fail-safe protection. These backup systems will activate if primary valves fail, preventing catastrophic pressure release. Install pressure monitoring sensors with real-time alerts on the production control system. This layered engineering control ensures that single-point equipment failures cannot cause system-wide damage.

name: Transition to Premium Valve Supplier with Quality Certification
description: Replace all standard-grade hydraulic valves with ISO 9001 and ISO 14001 certified suppliers who provide material certifications and heat-treat documentation. Require suppliers to provide traceability documentation for all critical components. Establish quarterly vendor performance reviews. This substitution control ensures higher-quality equipment with documented manufacturing standards and eliminates defective materials.

name: Install Permanent Fixed Ladders and Access Platforms
description: Replace all makeshift stepping solutions (crates, boxes, unstable platforms) with permanent, CNESST-compliant fixed ladders and access platforms integrated into high-storage rack systems. Ensure all platforms have anti-slip surfaces, railings, and weight-rating signs. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of using unsuitable materials as step stools, providing safe and stable access to elevated storage.

name: Implement Warehouse Safety Audit and Rack Inspection Schedule
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all storage rack systems to identify stability issues, load capacity concerns, and improper loading patterns. Establish monthly visual inspections documented by warehouse staff. Require load capacity placards on all shelves in multiple languages (French/English). Train warehouse associates on proper loading procedures, weight distribution, and prohibited access methods.

name: Implement Quarterly Cooling System Inspections
description: Establish a documented quarterly inspection and maintenance protocol for all cooling water systems, including pressure testing, corrosion assessment, and line replacement scheduling. This administrative control will address the root cause of gradual pipe degradation by detecting problems before they escalate into environmental incidents. Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot will oversee implementation and create inspection checklists. Expected outcome: elimination of preventable cooling system failures and associated environmental risks.

name: Replace Corroded Copper Piping with Stainless Steel Lines
description: Engineering control to substitute the existing copper cooling lines (susceptible to corrosion) with corrosion-resistant stainless steel piping throughout the Post-Processing unit. This substitution control eliminates the root cause of recurring leaks in hard water environments. Installation will include improved drainage slopes to prevent water pooling and easier access points for future maintenance. This represents a permanent solution that significantly reduces environmental incident risk.

name: Install Dual-Redundant Hydraulic Safety Valves
description: Engineering control implementing dual independent pressure relief systems on all injection press mold clamps, ensuring that single sensor failure cannot result in uncontrolled mold descent. Each valve will be rated for independent operation and calibrated to fail-safe, holding the mold in position. This eliminates the root cause of the incident by providing mechanical backup independent of electronic sensors. All 32 injection molding machines will be retrofitted with this enhanced safety system within 60 days.

name: Establish Mandatory Preventative Maintenance Completion Before Operation
description: Administrative control creating a lockout procedure requiring that all flagged maintenance items must be completed within 48 hours or the equipment is taken offline. A digital maintenance tracking system will be implemented to flag any deferred maintenance, and supervisors will receive alerts. Training will be provided to all operators on recognizing deferred maintenance status. This addresses the human/organizational error that led to deferring the sensor replacement.

name: Conduct Enhanced Mold Handling Safety Training
description: Mandatory retraining for all injection molding operators on proper mold changeover procedures, hazard recognition, and emergency response. Training will include hands-on practice with new emergency stop procedures and emphasis on two-person verification during critical equipment operations. All operators will be certified within 30 days. This administrative control reinforces safe work practices and ensures awareness of dual-redundant safety systems.

name: Install Automated Tank Cooldown System
description: Engineering control implementing programmable cooling cycles that automatically reduce tank temperature to 40°C at the end of each heating cycle, preventing resin crystallization on pressure relief valves. The system will include temperature sensors, automated valve sequencing, and operator interface displays. This substitution control replaces manual cooldown procedures with a mechanical system immune to human error, directly addressing the root cause of recurring valve failures.

name: Establish Monthly Relief Valve Preventative Replacement Program
description: Administrative control scheduling quarterly replacement of all pressure relief valves on resin storage tanks on a calendar basis rather than waiting for failure. A documented maintenance schedule will track valve age and replacement dates. This administrative control ensures degraded valves are removed before they can leak, maintaining continuous safety margins. All night shift staff will receive training on identifying valve condition during routine visual inspections.

name: Upgrade Motor Control Center with Predictive Maintenance Sensors
description: Install thermal monitoring sensors on all motor control center contactors and relay assemblies to detect abnormal temperature increases before failure occurs. The system will send real-time alerts when temperature exceeds safe thresholds and log data for trend analysis. Additionally, replace all corroded electrical connections throughout the distribution system with properly rated, corrosion-resistant connectors. Implement quarterly infrared thermography surveys of all high-amperage circuits. This engineering control prevents electrical overheating failures before they escalate to fire risk.

name: Establish Preventive Electrical Maintenance Schedule
description: Create and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all electrical infrastructure including monthly visual inspections, quarterly thermal imaging, semi-annual contact resistance measurements, and annual load analysis. Designate Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie as the responsible party for coordinating these inspections. All findings will be documented in a tracking system with corrective action follow-up. This administrative control ensures early detection of electrical degradation and prevents catastrophic failures.

name: Replace Storage Tank with Double-Walled Containment System
description: Replace the single-wall 500-liter epoxy resin storage tank with a new double-walled tank featuring integrated secondary containment with capacity for 110% of primary tank volume. The new tank will include level sensors, pressure relief valves, and an automated leak detection system that alerts operators when any fluid is detected in the secondary containment chamber. Install the system with concrete drip pans beneath all connection points. This engineering control prevents future spills from reaching the facility floor.

name: Implement Enhanced Tank Inspection and Stress Analysis Program
description: Conduct comprehensive non-destructive testing (NDT) ultrasonic inspection of all resin storage tanks to identify existing stress points and material degradation. Perform finite element stress analysis on the tank design to identify high-risk areas. Establish a quarterly visual inspection protocol with documentation of any signs of cracking, corrosion, or deformation. All tanks will receive external protective coating to resist thermal cycling stress.
