Facilities Technician Georges Plante will maintain an inspection log and report findings to Environmental Compliance.

name: Upgrade Spill Response Equipment and Training
description: Install additional spill response stations throughout the Chemical Storage and Mixing area with enhanced absorbent materials, containment booms, and personal protective equipment. Conduct refresher training for all operators on spill response procedures, including proper material disposal, hazardous waste documentation, and environmental reporting requirements. Ensure absorbent granule inventory is maintained at 200% of typical usage. This administrative and PPE control improves response capability and minimizes environmental impact of any future incidents.

name: Implement Mandatory Job Rotation Schedule
description: Establish a structured job rotation program requiring assembly operators to switch between part removal, finishing, and packaging tasks every 2 hours. Create a rotation matrix posted at each station showing which operators rotate and when. This will reduce repetitive strain by varying muscle usage patterns. Training will be provided to all assembly staff on proper body mechanics during transitions. Expected outcome: 60% reduction in repetitive strain incidents within 90 days.

name: Install Ergonomic Hand Tools and Extraction Aids
description: Replace manual part extraction methods with pneumatic-assisted removal tools featuring ergonomic handles and reduced grip force requirements. Install adjustable extraction fixtures at each molding station to minimize wrist torque and repetitive gripping. Conduct ergonomic assessment of workstations and adjust heights to neutral wrist positions. These engineering controls will directly address the root cause of strain by reducing force and frequency of repetitive motions.

name: Implement Cable Management and Floor Safety Standards
description: Establish and enforce a facility-wide cable management protocol requiring all temporary electrical cables in production areas to be routed through elevated conduit systems at least 8 inches above floor level. Install cable guards at all floor-level crossings where conduit routing is not possible. Mark all cable routes with yellow and black safety tape and high-visibility signage. Conduct a facility-wide audit of all temporary installations and remediate non-compliant areas within 14 days. This administrative and engineering control will eliminate the tripping and entanglement hazard.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Containers and Implement Secondary Containment
description: Replace all aging 55-gallon drums in the chemical storage area with new, UN-certified polyethylene drums featuring reinforced seams and integral drip trays. Install dedicated secondary containment systems capable of holding 110% of the largest container volume beneath all chemical storage locations. Implement quarterly drum integrity inspections with documented visual examination for cracks, corrosion, and seam degradation. Train all maintenance staff on inspection protocols and defective container reporting procedures. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of drum failure and prevents future environmental releases.

name: Establish Chemical Spill Response Drills and Enhanced Monitoring
description: Conduct mandatory quarterly spill response drills for all production and maintenance staff, simulating mold release agent and other common chemical releases. Install continuous low-level air quality monitors in the chemical storage area with automated alerts when contaminant thresholds are exceeded. Create a laminated spill response flowchart posted at all chemical storage locations detailing immediate response steps, emergency contact numbers, and disposal procedures. Maintain spill response kits in three accessible locations throughout the facility. Document all drills and environmental monitoring results in the HSE database.

name: Implement Daily Dust Removal Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily cleaning schedule for all composite processing work areas with dedicated staff assigned to remove accumulated dust at shift start, midday, and end-of-shift. Implement HEPA filter vacuums for all dust collection and prohibit compressed air for dust dispersal. Install signage and update work instructions to include dust removal checkpoints. Monitor compliance through daily shift supervisor inspections and document on equipment maintenance logs.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Maintenance
description: Schedule quarterly professional inspection and cleaning of the ventilation system in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Install inline spark detection equipment to automatically shut down the system if sparks are detected. Replace existing dust collection filters with high-efficiency particulate filters rated for composite materials. Document all maintenance activities and create a predictive maintenance schedule based on equipment manufacturer specifications.

name: Fire Safety Training for Composite Area Staff
description: Conduct mandatory refresher training for all personnel working in UNIT-015 focusing on fire prevention specific to composite dust hazards. Training will cover proper grinding spark management, approved cleaning methods, emergency evacuation procedures, and suppression system operation. Include practical demonstration of the dry powder system and dust ignition risks. Require completion of competency assessment and document attendance. Repeat training annually and when new staff are assigned to the area.

name: Implement Cooling System Water Treatment Program
description: Establish a comprehensive water treatment protocol for all cooling system manifolds including monthly chemical analysis, pH adjustment, and inhibitor replenishment. Install water treatment monitoring equipment with automatic alert notifications. Partner with a qualified water treatment vendor to provide quarterly system inspections and cleaning. Document all treatment activities in the equipment maintenance management system. Train maintenance staff on proper water quality standards and treatment procedures. Replace all manifolds showing corrosion damage within 30 days.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Program for Injection Molding Machines
description: Implement a quarterly inspection schedule for all cooling manifolds and high-pressure hydraulic components on the 32 injection molding machines. Utilize ultrasonic thickness measurement to detect corrosion before rupture occurs. Create a risk assessment matrix ranking manifolds by age and inspection history. Schedule proactive replacement of high-risk manifolds based on corrosion rate trends. Document all measurements and trends in maintenance database with automatic work order generation when thickness falls below safe thresholds.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Cooling Systems
description: Install secondary containment trays or bunding around high-pressure cooling manifolds on all injection molding machines to capture leaked fluid and prevent spread across production floors. Containment systems must have capacity equal to 110% of system volume. Position drains to direct fluids to appropriate collection sumps with absorbent materials staged nearby. Install absorbent mats in high-risk areas and train operators on spill response procedures. Inspect containment integrity monthly.

name: Implement Mandatory Load Securing Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training on proper pallet stacking, load securing, and use of strapping/wrapping materials for all material handlers. Training will include proper height limits (maximum 5 feet), weight distribution, and pallet jack operation. Sessions will be conducted monthly for new hires and quarterly refreshers for existing staff. Training materials will include visual aids and hands-on demonstrations in the warehouse.

name: Install Load Strapping and Wrapping Equipment
description: Procure and install automated pallet wrapping equipment and high-quality strapping materials in the warehouse receiving area. This engineering control will ensure all incoming material pallets are securely wrapped before storage or movement. Establish a standard operating procedure requiring all loads over 300 lbs to be wrapped and strapped. Designate trained personnel to operate the wrapping equipment.

name: Establish Warehouse Racking Height Limits Signage
description: Install clear, visible signage at all warehouse storage locations indicating maximum stacking heights (5 feet), weight limits per pallet, and required securing methods. Paint visual height markers on warehouse walls and posts. Conduct a full warehouse audit to identify non-compliant stacks and redistribute materials. Include these limits in all material handler job procedures and during new employee orientation.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a quarterly predictive maintenance schedule using ultrasonic and pressure monitoring equipment to detect early signs of hydraulic system degradation. This will include regular sampling and analysis of hydraulic fluid for contamination, pressure testing of relief valves, and thermal imaging to identify unusual heating patterns. Assign trained technicians to conduct these inspections and maintain detailed records. This engineering control will identify issues before they become critical failures.

name: Upgrade Hydraulic Fluid Filtration System
description: Replace existing hydraulic filters with higher-efficiency (3-micron) filters on all 32 injection molding machines to reduce resin contamination entering hydraulic systems. Install differential pressure gauges on filter housings to provide visual indicators when filters require replacement. This substitution control will prevent contamination buildup in pressure relief valves and other precision hydraulic components, reducing equipment failures and associated safety hazards.

name: Install Digital Temperature Monitoring System with Redundant Sensors
description: Replace the aging analog thermostat controller with a modern PLC-based digital temperature management system featuring dual temperature sensors and automatic redundancy switching. Install sealed, stainless-steel sensor probes with moisture-resistant connectors to prevent corrosion. Implement real-time alarming that alerts operators and sends alerts to maintenance personnel if temperature deviates more than 5°C from setpoint. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of temperature measurement failure and provides immediate detection of overheating conditions.

name: Establish Daily Resin Dryer Inspection Checklist
description: Create and implement a mandatory daily inspection checklist for all resin dryers, to be completed during each shift change. The checklist will include visual inspection of temperature display readings, checking for unusual sounds or odors, verifying alarm system functionality, and documenting all observations in a maintenance log. Train all production operators and maintenance staff on the checklist. This administrative control ensures regular human verification of equipment status and provides early warning of sensor or controller issues.

name: Schedule Quarterly Sensor Probe Replacement Program
description: Implement a preventive replacement schedule for all temperature sensor probes on resin dryers every 12 months, regardless of apparent condition. This addresses the root cause of sensor corrosion by replacing components before moisture ingress becomes problematic. Maintain an inventory of spare sealed sensor assemblies and train technicians on proper installation techniques to ensure moisture-tight connections. This substitution/preventive measure will eliminate temperature measurement failures before they lead to equipment overheating.

name: Install Flexible Vibration-Damping Connectors on Hopper Ventilation System
description: Replace rigid ductwork connections between the regrind hopper and main ventilation system with flexible, vibration-damping connectors rated for industrial plastic processing environments. This engineering control will prevent future dislodgement due to machine vibrations. Additionally, install secondary support brackets every 2 meters along the duct run. Install vibration isolation mounts under the injection molding machine that was recently repositioned. Conduct monthly visual inspections of all hopper ventilation connections as part of the preventive maintenance schedule.

name: Implement Hopper Ventilation Inspection Training Program
description: Develop and deliver a 2-hour training module for all production operators and maintenance staff on identifying signs of ventilation system failure, including unusual odors, vibration changes, and temperature anomalies. Training will include proper reporting procedures and emergency shutdown protocols. Create a laminated checklist posted at each hopper station. Conduct training for all shifts within 30 days, with annual refresher training thereafter. This administrative control ensures early detection of similar hazards.

name: Install Continuous Dust Monitoring and Automatic Evacuation System
description: Install real-time dust accumulation sensors with automatic alerts when dust levels exceed 5 centimeters in critical zones. Pair with automated evacuation systems that trigger vacuum collection when thresholds are reached. Additionally, upgrade the dust collection filter assembly to a high-efficiency HEPA filter with automated self-cleaning mechanism. Install secondary containment beneath collection points. These engineering controls prevent dangerous dust accumulation automatically without relying on manual inspection frequency.

name: Reinforce Static Dissipation and Grounding Program
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all static dissipation grounding cables and bonding connections in the regrind department. Replace all grounding cables identified as corroded, damaged, or non-compliant. Install additional grounding points every 3 meters along the collection system. Implement weekly visual inspection protocol with required sign-off documentation. Install conductive flooring matting in high-risk work stations. Apply anti-static labels to all collection equipment as visual reminders. Provide staff training on static hazards and proper grounding verification. This combination of engineering and administrative controls eliminates ignition sources.

name: Establish Mandatory Dust Collection Maintenance Schedule with Staffing
description: Restore and formalize the dust collection maintenance schedule as non-negotiable, with dedicated staffing allocation. Schedule filter inspections and replacements weekly (every 7 days) during active production, rather than the previous 30-day interval. Create a digital maintenance tracking system with automatic reminders to supervisors and maintenance personnel. Cross-train additional maintenance staff to ensure continuity during staff absences. Allocate budget for contractor support if internal staffing remains constrained. Conduct monthly audits of maintenance compliance. This administrative control ensures consistent execution of preventive maintenance.

name: Implement Mandatory Monthly Pressure Relief System Inspections
description: Establish a formal maintenance schedule for all injection molding machine pressure relief valves with documented inspection records. Each valve will be visually inspected, pressure-tested, and seal integrity verified by certified maintenance technicians. Inspections must be completed before any production scheduling conflicts can override the schedule. Implementation includes creation of a digital maintenance tracking system integrated with production planning software to ensure no maintenance cycles are skipped. Training will be provided to all production supervisors on the criticality of this maintenance.

name: Install Pressure Relief Guard Shields on All Line A Machines
description: Engineering control to install protective stainless steel guard shields around all pressure relief valves on the 8 injection molding machines in Line A. These shields will deflect any steam or hot material release away from operator work zones and direct it safely upward toward ceiling ventilation. Guards will be removable for maintenance access but will be interlocked with machine operation to prevent removal during active molding cycles. Installation timeline is 5 working days with minimal production disruption.

name: Enhanced PPE Protocol for Thermal Burn Protection
description: Issue specialized heat-resistant Kevlar sleeves and upgraded thermal gloves (rated to 250°C) to all injection molding operators on Lines A, B, C, and D. Conduct mandatory training on proper donning, inspection, and care of thermal PPE. Establish a quarterly replacement cycle for gloves and sleeves. While this is an interim PPE measure, it will provide additional protection during the transition period while engineering controls are being implemented across all production lines.

name: Replace All Line D Proximity Sensors with Redundant Detection System
description: Engineering control involving replacement of single-point proximity sensors on all robotic arms in Line D with dual-sensor redundant systems. New sensors will operate on independent calibration checks and the arm will only operate when both sensors confirm target position. This eliminates single-point failures from sensor drift. Implementation includes installation of diagnostic displays showing real-time sensor status to operators and maintenance staff. All robotic arm maintenance staff will receive certification training on the new system.

name: Establish Weekly Sensor Calibration Audits for Robotic Systems
description: Administrative control implementing weekly (rather than quarterly) sensor calibration verification for all automated robotic arms. A certified technician will run diagnostic tests on each sensor's output against known reference positions. Records will be maintained digitally with trend analysis to predict sensor degradation before failure. Any sensor showing drift beyond 2mm tolerance will be immediately replaced. This preventive approach catches sensor issues before they cause operational failures and worker injuries.

name: Clean and Clear Chemical Building Ventilation System
description: Immediate engineering maintenance to clean all exhaust ducts, intake filters, and fan housings in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. A certified HVAC contractor will remove all accumulated plastic particulate and dust, inspect for any permanent damage to ducting, and verify all system components are functioning at design specifications. Post-cleaning airflow verification and air quality testing (using calibrated gas detection equipment) will confirm styrene levels are below 10 ppm. Work will be completed within 2 business days with temporary mixing operations suspended until clearance is provided.

name: Restore and Formalize Ventilation System Maintenance Schedule
description: Administrative control to restore the monthly ventilation system maintenance schedule into the facility management system with redundant backup calendars (printed and digital). The schedule will include: monthly visual inspections of all ducts and vents, quarterly deep cleaning of exhaust systems, and semi-annual professional HVAC system audits with air quality testing. A designated maintenance coordinator will receive notifications 2 weeks before each scheduled maintenance. An automated email system will alert supervisors and the HSE office of any missed maintenance windows. All staff will receive training on the revised schedule.

name: Install Real-Time Ventilation Monitoring Sensors
description: Engineering control installing digital airflow monitoring sensors in critical exhaust ducts and styrene gas sensors at operator breathing zones in the Chemical building. These sensors will continuously monitor system performance and send automated alerts to maintenance staff and the HSE office if airflow drops below 80% of design specification or styrene levels exceed 15 ppm (preventive threshold below regulatory limits). The system will integrate with production scheduling software to automatically halt mixing operations if ventilation system failure is detected, preventing worker exposure.

name: Implement Mandatory Hydraulic System Depressurization Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a critical lockout/tagout procedure requiring complete hydraulic system depressurization, isolation, and verification before any maintenance work begins. All hydraulic maintenance tasks must include: (1) energy isolation at the pump, (2) bleed-down of all accumulators, (3) pressure gauge verification showing zero PSI, (4) lockout/tagout device placement by the technician performing work, (5) written verification signed by supervisor. Conduct immediate audit of all hydraulic equipment and create laminated procedural cards at each hydraulic press workstation.

name: Enhanced LOTO Training and Certification Program
description: Conduct comprehensive retraining on lockout/tagout procedures for all maintenance technicians, with special emphasis on hydraulic system hazards. All maintenance staff must complete updated LOTO certification including hazard-specific modules for hydraulic injection risks. Implement quarterly competency refresher training. Create a roster of certified personnel with expiration dates. Non-certified staff cannot perform hydraulic maintenance. Include actual case study review of hydraulic injection injuries to emphasize severity and consequences.

name: Install Automatic Hydraulic Pressure Relief and Isolation Valves
description: Install redundant automatic pressure relief valves and quick-disconnect isolation couplers on all hydraulic press systems. These engineering controls will prevent accidental pressure buildup and enable rapid isolation of hydraulic lines. Upgrade all hydraulic connections to modern flat-face quick-disconnect fittings that eliminate residual pressure discharge when disconnected. Schedule installation across all hydraulic equipment over 45 days, starting with the highest-risk units. This eliminates the hazard rather than relying solely on procedural compliance.

name: Install Thermal Insulation Guards on Resin Dryer
description: Install high-temperature silicone foam insulation guards (min. 50mm thickness, rated to 320°C) around all external surfaces of the resin dryer unit on Molding Line D. Protective guards must cover all surfaces accessible within 45cm of normal operator reach zones. Use stainless steel mesh backing and secure with stainless steel hardware. Guards must include clear warning labels in English and French. This engineering control eliminates direct contact with hot surfaces during normal operations. Installation completed within 10 days.

name: Relocate Sensor Adjustment Controls and Extend Reach Distance
description: Redesign the sensor adjustment point for the resin dryer temperature control. Move the adjustment mechanism to a location requiring operators to maintain minimum 60cm distance from the hot surface. Install remote adjustment capability or use extended-handle adjustment tools. Provide operators with dedicated sensor adjustment tools with insulated handles. This eliminates the need for reach-across positioning near hot equipment.

name: Implement Comprehensive Chemical Storage Tank Inspection and Testing Program
description: Establish a mandatory annual pressure test and integrity inspection schedule for all large chemical storage tanks (>100L capacity). All tanks must undergo certified hydrostatic pressure testing and visual ultrasonic thickness measurement. Create a color-coded tagging system showing inspection status and next scheduled test date. Maintain digital records with tank serial numbers, inspection dates, findings, and recommendations. Non-compliant tanks must be taken offline until inspection is completed. This administrative control ensures early detection of structural degradation before spills occur.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Automated Leak Detection
description: Install engineered secondary containment basins under all large chemical storage tanks with minimum capacity of 110% of the largest tank volume. Install automated level sensors in containment areas that trigger visual and audible alarms when liquid is detected. Paint containment areas with chemical-resistant epoxy coating rated for epoxy resins. Install absorbent material dispensers at strategic locations. All spills will be contained and prevented from reaching floor drains. This engineering control prevents environmental discharge.

name: Chemical Spill Response Training and Emergency Equipment Upgrades
description: Conduct immediate hands-on training for all production and maintenance staff on chemical spill response procedures. Provide training on proper use of absorbent materials, containment barriers, and personal protective equipment. Distribute quick-reference laminated cards at each workstation. Upgrade spill response kits with larger quantities of absorbent material, PPE, and containment barriers. Conduct quarterly spill response drills. Designate two trained spill coordinators per shift responsible for coordinating response activities.

name: Mandatory Machine Lockout Verification Program
description: Implement a requirement that all machine operators must physically verify lockout/tagout compliance before ANY manual intervention on equipment. Create laminated LOTO checklist cards posted at each injection molding station. Conduct refresher training on LOTO procedures for all production operators within 2 weeks. Establish random audits of LOTO compliance during shift changes. This addresses the root cause of the operator bypassing safety procedures and directly prevents similar incidents involving unplanned machine activation.

name: Hopper System Intake Design Modification
description: Work with maintenance to install a secondary mesh screen at the hopper inlet to prevent blockages from forming. Add a clear inspection window to the hopper side to allow visual monitoring without manual probing. Install automatic shutoff switches that trigger if hopper pressure exceeds normal parameters. These engineering controls eliminate the need for manual intervention in the hopper area, reducing human exposure to the hazard entirely.

name: Edge Deburring Station Implementation
description: Establish a dedicated edge finishing and deburring station in the Regrind Department where all composite parts undergo automatic edge smoothing before reaching assembly operators. Install pneumatic edge finishing tools with safety guards and dust extraction systems. This eliminates sharp edges entirely before parts reach assembly personnel, using engineering controls to remove the hazard at the source rather than relying on worker awareness.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Cooling Systems
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and maintenance program for all cooling water system lines, connections, and joints across all injection molding lines. This will include visual inspections for cracks, pressure testing of all connection points, and replacement of worn seals and gaskets before failure occurs. The program will be documented in the maintenance management system with assigned responsibility to maintenance technicians. Expected outcome is elimination of similar leaks through early detection and proactive replacement of deteriorating components.

name: Install Secondary Containment Trays Under High-Risk Cooling Lines
description: Design and install stainless steel containment trays beneath all critical cooling water supply lines in the Main Production Building. These trays will capture any future leaks before they spread across the production floor, preventing slip hazards and environmental contamination. The containment system will include drain plugs for easy disposal and will be integrated into the equipment maintenance checklist. This engineering control will significantly reduce the impact radius of any future cooling system failures.

name: Establish Safe Mold Storage and Handling Procedures
description: Develop comprehensive written procedures for safe storage, retrieval, and handling of all mold inserts and equipment in the storage mezzanine. Procedures will include proper stabilization techniques, weight limits per shelf, designated storage zones organized by mold type and size, and mandatory use of anti-slip matting on shelves. All employees with access to the equipment storage area will receive mandatory training on these procedures within 7 days, with annual refresher training required thereafter. The procedures will include illustrations and will be posted prominently in the storage area.

name: Install Safety Rails and Edge Guards on Storage Shelving
description: Retrofit all storage shelves in the equipment mezzanine with protective edge guards and safety rails to prevent objects from shifting or falling. Install clear polycarbonate protective barriers on shelf edges where mold inserts are stored. This engineering control will physically prevent objects from sliding off shelves and protect workers' hands when reaching for stored items. Install work platform edge protection on the mezzanine level itself to prevent falls to the lower level.

name: Mandatory PPE Compliance Training and Enforcement Program
description: Implement a mandatory retraining program for all material handling operators focusing on proper use and continuous wear of heat-resistant PPE in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. The training will emphasize that PPE cannot be removed or adjusted during active material transfer operations. Supervisors will conduct daily pre-shift PPE inspections and employees will be required to sign acknowledgment of PPE requirements. Non-compliance will result in immediate removal from the task and disciplinary action. The program will include video demonstrations and practical hands-on training with proper glove and sleeve application.

name: Implement Mandatory Pre-Operation LOTO Checklist
description: Develop and install a laminated LOTO checklist at each injection molding machine requiring operator sign-off before any setup or trial runs. The checklist will include: (1) Energy source verification, (2) Emergency stop function test, (3) Robotic arm position verification, (4) Mold clamping pressure confirmation. All setup personnel must complete CNESST-approved LOTO training before authorization. Monthly audits will verify compliance. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate pre-operation verification.

name: Emergency Stop Button Maintenance Program
description: Establish a bi-weekly emergency stop button testing and maintenance program for all 32 injection molding machines. Maintenance technician Luc Girard will lead creation of a preventive maintenance schedule that includes function testing, mechanical inspection, and electrical continuity verification. Each machine will have a tag showing last test date. Any non-functional E-stop will immediately remove the machine from service until repaired. This engineering control ensures safety-critical equipment functions when needed.

name: Replace Faulty Hopper Level Sensor
description: Immediately procure and install a new capacitive level sensor on the material drying hopper with redundant overflow protection. The sensor will trigger an automated cutoff valve when material reaches 85% capacity, preventing overflow situations. Maintenance technician Luc Girard will verify proper calibration and test cycle. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the spillage by replacing the defective monitoring equipment with a more reliable system that includes fail-safe features.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Priority System
description: Implement a tiered maintenance scheduling system where equipment failures flagged as 'safety-critical' cannot be deprioritized without HSE department approval. Create a monthly review meeting between Production Engineering (UNIT-021), Maintenance leadership, and HSE to assess pending maintenance items. Develop clear criteria defining what constitutes safety-critical equipment requiring mandatory completion within 72 hours. This administrative control ensures that maintenance items affecting worker safety are not postponed for production reasons.

name: Implement Quarterly Ventilation System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive quarterly inspection and maintenance schedule for all ventilation systems in production and post-processing areas. This includes replacement of air filters, cleaning of ducts, and testing of airflow sensors. The program will be documented in the maintenance management system with automatic work order generation. Inspections will be conducted by certified maintenance personnel from the Central Maintenance Workshop and tracked with completion reports reviewed by the HSE department. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate ventilation system maintenance and will prevent future resin fume accumulation.

name: Upgrade Fire Detection System in Post-Processing Area
description: Install additional smoke detection sensors in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment zone to provide earlier warning of potential hazardous conditions. The new sensors will be integrated with the existing BMS system and connected to the main fire alarm panel. Two additional manual pull stations will also be installed for improved accessibility. This engineering control ensures faster detection and response to potential fire or smoke conditions, reducing the time to emergency response. Installation will be completed by qualified electricians from the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop.

name: Calibrate and Install Thermal Overload Protection on All Molding Machines
description: Conduct a comprehensive calibration audit of thermal overload protection systems on all 32 injection molding machines at TechnoPlast. Each machine's heating element controller will be tested using precision calibration equipment to ensure proper setpoints and response times. Additionally, upgrade thermal monitoring with real-time data logging to the predictive maintenance system. This engineering control directly prevents electrical overloads by ensuring temperature thresholds are correctly set. A certified electrical technician will perform all calibrations, with priority given to machines operating above 150 tons capacity.

name: Implement Monthly Electrical Enclosure Inspection Program
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection routine for all electrical enclosures and control panels on production equipment. Inspections will include visual assessment for loose connections, corrosion, proper labeling, and thermal imaging to detect hot spots. A standardized checklist and digital inspection form will be used, with results tracked in the maintenance system. Any deficiencies will trigger immediate remediation work orders. This administrative control ensures early detection of electrical hazards before they can cause fires or arc flash events. Inspections will be performed by trained electrical maintenance personnel.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance for Grinding Equipment Bearings
description: Install vibration monitoring sensors on the regrind processing machine's grinding drum bearing assembly to detect early signs of bearing degradation. Data will be integrated with the facility's existing predictive maintenance system for automated alerts when vibration patterns indicate imminent failure. Schedule bearing inspections and replacements based on condition data rather than fixed intervals. This engineering control prevents catastrophic bearing failure by enabling proactive maintenance before equipment damage occurs. Initial sensor installation will be completed by the Central Maintenance Workshop within 14 days, with bearing replacement protocols updated accordingly.

name: Install Safety Containment Shroud on Regrind Hopper
description: Design and fabricate a polycarbonate containment shroud around the regrind processing machine hopper to capture ejected material during equipment failures or material spills. The shroud will be constructed with quick-release panels for maintenance access and include drain provisions for safe material collection. This engineering control eliminates the projectile hazard from material ejection during equipment failure. The shroud will be fabricated by the Central Maintenance Workshop and installed within 30 days. Material flow testing will verify that normal operations are not impeded.

name: Implement Predictive Hydraulic System Maintenance Program
description: Establish quarterly hydraulic system inspections on all injection molding machines, focusing on accumulator pressure relief valves and isolation mechanisms. Replace suspect hydraulic components proactively based on age and operating hours rather than reactive failure. Install pressure gauges with alarm thresholds on all accumulators. This addresses the root cause of incomplete depressurization that allowed the machine to cycle unexpectedly despite lockout procedures being in place.

name: Enhanced Lockout/Tagout Verification Protocol
description: Revise LOTO procedures to require mechanical verification of zero energy state on all hydraulic systems before commencing maintenance. Implement a checklist requiring operators to manually test mold closing resistance and confirm accumulator pressure release before work begins. Establish a dual-verification system where a second technician must confirm LOTO effectiveness. Conduct refresher LOTO training for all maintenance personnel within 14 days.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Container Inspection Program
description: Implement monthly visual inspections of all hazardous chemical storage containers focusing on structural integrity, weld seams, and corrosion indicators. Establish a rotation schedule for container replacement every 3 years regardless of apparent condition to eliminate age-related failures. Upgrade containment trays with integrated drain systems and leak detection sensors that trigger automatic alerts. Install secondary containment for all solvent storage drums rated for 110% of container volume.

name: Install Continuous Air Quality Monitoring System
description: Deploy wireless acetone vapor sensors in the chemical storage and mixing areas with real-time monitoring connected to the facility management system. Configure automatic alerts when vapor concentrations reach 50% of the OSHA PEL (250 ppm). Integrate system with automatic ventilation escalation protocols. This provides early detection of leaks before they escalate into larger incidents and validates the effectiveness of existing ventilation systems.

name: Implement Sharp Edge Management Protocol in Quality Control Area
description: Establish a designated storage protocol for all mold cavities and machined components requiring them to be stored horizontally or covered with protective edge guards. Install storage racks with slotted compartments that minimize exposure of sharp edges. Apply colored warning tape to all sharp edges on stored components. Require all QC personnel to wear cut-resistant arm sleeves during component handling. Conduct a facility-wide audit of similar sharp edge hazards in other areas.

name: Install Automated Pressure Relief System on Transfer Pumps
description: Replace existing manual transfer pump with a pressure-relieving automated system equipped with dual safety valves set to maximum 15 PSI. Install secondary containment expansion to 150% of largest container capacity in chemical storage room. Conduct monthly pressure system audits and maintain documentation. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of pressurization during solvent transfer operations. Expected outcome: prevention of future solvent spray incidents and compliance with WHMIS 2015 requirements for chemical handling.

name: Enhanced Solvent Vapor Monitoring Protocol
description: Implement continuous atmospheric monitoring in chemical storage using calibrated acetone vapor detectors with alarm thresholds set at 250 ppm (half the OSHA PEL). Install permanent ventilation ductwork with minimum 12 air changes per hour in the storage room. Require quarterly calibration of monitoring equipment and monthly maintenance logs. Train all personnel on vapor hazard recognition and emergency evacuation procedures specific to solvent incidents. This administrative and engineering control reduces inhalation exposure risk.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Drying Equipment
description: Establish quarterly preventive maintenance schedule for all hopper motor assemblies including bearing lubrication, seal inspection, and thermal sensor calibration. Deploy vibration monitoring sensors on critical equipment to detect bearing degradation 30+ days in advance. Integrate maintenance calendar into facility management software with automated alerts for supervisors. Maintain detailed maintenance logs for compliance auditing. This administrative control addresses the root cause of inadequate equipment maintenance. Expected outcome: elimination of premature bearing failures and significant reduction in production downtime.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protection Systems on Hopper Equipment
description: Replace existing thermal cutoff switches with dual redundant temperature sensors (one primary, one backup) set to trigger emergency shutdown at 260°C. Install pressure relief valve in hopper chamber to prevent dangerous pressure buildup. Add visual and audible alarm system to alert operators of thermal anomalies. Test backup thermal systems monthly during equipment operation. This engineering control prevents catastrophic equipment damage and potential fire hazards.

name: Establish LOTO Device Accountability and Tracking System
description: Implement numbered LOTO device tracking with digital log system requiring photo documentation of every device placement and removal. Each device removal must be authorized and logged with employee name, timestamp, and reason. Establish consequence policy: unauthorized removal results in disciplinary action and retraining. Conduct weekly audits of all active LOTO devices during night shift to verify compliance. Assign Electrical Maintenance lead as accountability officer for weekly reporting to HSE. This administrative control eliminates the root cause of missing LOTO devices.

name: Mandatory LOTO Recertification and Competency Testing
description: Require all maintenance personnel who work with electrical equipment to complete CNESST-compliant LOTO recertification training within 30 days. Conduct written competency assessments and practical demonstrations of proper LOTO procedures. Include consequences for improper LOTO handling in training curriculum. Implement quarterly refresher training sessions covering case studies of near-miss and actual incidents. Document all training with employee signatures and scores. This training intervention ensures all personnel understand the critical importance of LOTO compliance.

name: Install LOTO Device Security Boxes with Alarmed Monitoring
description: Install locked security boxes at each major electrical disconnect point with electronic tamper detection. Any unauthorized opening of the box triggers alert to HSE office and supervisor mobile devices. Require dual-key access (technician + supervisor authorization) for all LOTO device removals. Conduct random audits of locked boxes during all shifts. Integrate alarm system into facility monitoring network. This engineering control prevents unauthorized removal of safety devices.

name: Implement Chemical Labeling and Segregation Protocol
description: Establish a comprehensive chemical identification system using color-coded labels, QR codes, and digital inventory tracking to prevent mixing of incompatible additives. Create designated storage zones for different chemical families with physical barriers. Require all incoming materials to be verified against specifications by a qualified technician before being added to inventory. Conduct monthly audits of chemical storage areas. This eliminates the root cause of the incident by preventing human error in chemical selection.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring and Automatic Shutdown System
description: Upgrade the resin compounding equipment with real-time temperature sensors and an automated shut-off mechanism that triggers at 130°C, providing a 10°C safety buffer. Add audible and visual alarms to alert operators of temperature creep. This engineering control directly prevents exothermic reactions from escalating to dangerous levels.

name: Conduct Fire Prevention and Equipment Response Training
description: Mandatory refresher training for all production and maintenance staff on emergency procedures, fire alarm operation, and proper use of the dry powder suppression system. Include scenario-based drills quarterly focusing on chemical-related fire hazards specific to composite materials processing. Document all training completion records.

name: Install Automated Edge Deburring System
description: Install an inline pneumatic deburring tool at the cooling tray discharge point to automatically remove sharp edges and burrs from molded parts as they exit production. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source before operators handle the parts. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in sharp-edge hand injuries on Line B.

name: Redesign Warehouse Dock and Loading Area Layout
description: Increase the unloading bay dimensions and create dedicated, clearly marked forklift operating zones separated from pedestrian areas by safety barriers. Implement one-way traffic flow with designated staging areas for pallets. Paint floor markings and install edge guides to prevent pallet contact with truck bed edges. This administrative and engineering control eliminates the tight workspace hazard that contributed to the incident.

name: Mandate Forklift Operation Refresher and Load Securement Training
description: Require all forklift operators to complete advanced training on load stability, weight distribution, and handling of awkwardly-shaped or shifted loads. Include practical scenarios on tipping hazards. Implement a policy requiring operators to use load restraints (straps or nets) on all lifted materials exceeding 500 kg. Conduct quarterly competency assessments. This administrative control ensures operators understand proper techniques to prevent load tipping.

name: Install Load Tipping Prevention System on Forklifts
description: Equip all propane-powered forklifts with electronic load sensing systems that alert operators when the center of gravity is shifting, combined with mechanical tilt angle limiters that prevent the mast from reaching angles that could cause tipping. Add backup alarms and improved visibility mirrors. This engineering control provides real-time hazard notification to operators.

name: Implement Mandatory Job Rotation and Microbreak Protocol
description: Establish a structured job rotation system rotating assembly operators between stations every 90 minutes to reduce cumulative repetitive strain. Implement mandatory 10-minute microbreaks every 2 hours with ergonomic exercises. Create a checklist system for supervisors to ensure compliance. Provide training to all assembly operators on early warning signs of RSI and proper ergonomic positioning. Expected outcome: Reduction in repetitive strain complaints by 60% within 6 months, improved employee comfort and productivity.

name: Ergonomic Workstation Assessment and Adjustment
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessment of all assembly stations on Line C by external certified ergonomist. Evaluate workstation height, part positioning, gripping requirements, and tool design. Implement adjustments including height-adjustable work surfaces, part fixtures to reduce gripping force, and anti-fatigue mats. Provide ergonomic office chairs with lumbar support for assembly operators. Expected outcome: Improved workstation design reducing strain on upper extremities by 40%, increased employee comfort and efficiency.

name: Install Protective Barriers Around Smoke Detectors
description: Install clear polycarbonate protective shields around all 47 smoke detectors located in maintenance areas, production zones, and chemical handling spaces. Shields will be designed to prevent accidental spray contact while maintaining detector sensitivity. Mark all protected detectors with high-visibility labels. Ensure proper clearance distances (minimum 12 inches) between detectors and work areas. Conduct quarterly inspections to ensure shield integrity and detector functionality.

name: Update Chemical Handling and Maintenance Procedures
description: Revise maintenance work procedures to mandate use of closed-system containment or directional spray nozzles when using solvents near fire detection systems. Require all maintenance technicians to complete refresher training on chemical handling, spray patterns, and equipment proximity. Create laminated reference cards for all maintenance stations listing prohibited spray locations. Implement daily pre-shift briefings in maintenance areas covering relevant hazards. Expected outcome: Elimination of solvent-triggered false alarms and improved chemical handling practices.

name: Install Personal Fall Arrest System for High-Elevation Work
description: Purchase and install permanent anchor points on warehouse ceiling structure above all high-elevation shelving units (areas exceeding 8 feet). Deploy certified fall arrest harnesses, lanyards, and shock absorbers for all personnel accessing elevated inventory. Conduct mandatory competency-based training for all material handlers and warehouse staff on fall arrest equipment use, inspection procedures, and emergency rescue. Implement daily pre-use equipment inspections. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of fall risk during elevated inventory access operations.

name: Implement Enhanced Ladder Safety and Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish comprehensive ladder inspection program with quarterly certification by external safety professional. Implement mandatory ladder placement procedures requiring stabilizer bars, level positioning verification, and 3-point contact protocols. Require non-slip ladder rung covers on all warehouse ladders. Create laminated quick-reference safety cards at each ladder location. Institute monthly refresher training for all staff using ladders. Replace damaged ladders immediately upon discovery.

name: Establish Floor Hazard Control and Drying Procedures
description: Implement standardized floor cleaning procedures requiring commercial slip-resistant floor cleaning compounds and extended drying time. Install anti-slip floor matting in high-traffic warehouse areas. Establish 30-minute minimum drying time after cleaning before warehouse resumption of operations. Install humidity monitoring system to track moisture levels. Create wet floor signage protocols for damp areas. Train all evening and night shift staff on floor hazard management.

name: Replace Chemical Transfer Equipment with Sealed Systems
description: Replace all manual hand pumps with certified sealed transfer systems featuring automated shutoff valves and pressure relief mechanisms. Install drip containment trays beneath all transfer points. Implement quarterly inspections of all gaskets and seals. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of gasket failure and prevents future spills. Expected outcome: Zero chemical spills from equipment failure within 12 months.

name: Implement Chemical Storage Area Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a weekly documented inspection schedule for the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room, including visual checks of all equipment seals, gaskets, and hose connections. Create a maintenance log requiring technicians to record findings and sign off. Schedule preventive replacement of gaskets every 24 months or immediately upon visible degradation. Train all chemical handlers on early warning signs of equipment failure.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Predictive Maintenance Program
description: Install vibration sensors and thermal imaging equipment to monitor all hydraulic hoses and connectors on critical machines. Schedule ultrasonic testing quarterly to detect metal fatigue before failure. Replace all connectors showing corrosion or wear patterns immediately. Maintain replacement hose inventory on-site. This engineering control prevents catastrophic failures through early detection. Expected outcome: Reduction of hydraulic system failures by 90% within 6 months.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Hydraulic Systems
description: Design and install secondary containment trays beneath all high-pressure hydraulic equipment capable of holding 150% of maximum fluid volume. Include drain plugs with collection tanks. Post signage indicating emergency shutdown procedures. Train all production staff on spill response protocols. This administrative control limits environmental damage and protects electrical systems from fluid contamination.

name: Establish Mandatory Machine Lockout During All Maintenance Activities
description: Update the machine startup procedure to require physical lockout via padlock on ALL compressed air inlet lines before any interior mold cavity work. Create visual work permits that must be displayed on the machine indicating 'MAINTENANCE IN PROGRESS—DO NOT OPERATE.' Require two-person verification that all energy sources are isolated before work begins. This administrative control prevents accidental machine startup during cleaning operations.

name: Implement Compressed Air System Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Schedule monthly cleaning and inspection of all compressed air valves on injection molding equipment to remove mineral deposits and ensure proper operation. Replace valve seals every 12 months or upon first signs of stickiness. Install in-line air filtration upgrades to reduce mineral content. Document all maintenance in equipment logs. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of erratic valve behavior.

name: Conduct Refresher Training on Machine Safety and Energy Isolation
description: Provide all machine operators and setters with updated training on proper lockout/tagout procedures, recognizing stuck valves, and emergency response. Include hands-on demonstration of correct padlock placement on compressed air lines. Require competency testing before return to work. This training reinforces administrative controls and ensures employee awareness of hazards.

name: Implement Container Integrity Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory pre-transfer inspection checklist for all chemical containers entering the mixing room. Staff must verify cap integrity, container seals, and label legibility before any transfer operation. Daily inspections will be documented in a logbook maintained at the mixing station. All personnel handling chemicals will receive refresher training on proper container handling within 5 business days. Supervisors will conduct weekly audits of the logbook to ensure compliance. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of improper cap threading and lack of visual verification procedures.

name: Upgrade Spill Response Equipment and Ventilation
description: Install additional spill containment kits strategically positioned in the Chemical Storage Building with larger absorbent capacity. Conduct a comprehensive review of the ventilation system intake location relative to the mixing platform and relocate if necessary to prevent vapor concentration during spills. Upgrade existing eyewash and emergency shower stations with improved accessibility and water flow testing on a monthly basis. Ensure all emergency response equipment meets current CNESST standards. This engineering control will reduce chemical exposure severity and containment time for future incidents.

name: Enhanced LOTO Procedure with Comprehensive Verification Checklist
description: Revise and expand the lockout/tagout procedure to include verification of all energy sources: electrical, pneumatic, hydraulic, and thermal. Create a laminated checklist posted at each molding line requiring operators to physically test and confirm isolation of each energy source before commencing maintenance. Implement a dual-verification system where a second trained employee must sign off on LOTO completion. Conduct mandatory retraining for all 85+ production operators within 10 days with competency assessment. This administrative and procedural control eliminates the root cause of incomplete energy isolation.

name: Install Pressure Relief Indicators and Signage
description: Install high-visibility pressure relief warning decals and indicators on all injection molding machines, specifically marking the location of pneumatic isolation valves. Add illuminated warning signs in the maintenance area stating 'Verify Pneumatic Isolation Before Work.' Conduct facility-wide audit of all equipment lockout points to ensure consistent marking and accessibility. This engineering control provides immediate visual confirmation of energy isolation status and prevents accidental activation.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for High-Temperature Maintenance
description: Provide all maintenance personnel with heat-resistant gloves rated for 300°C+ temperatures and fire-resistant arm sleeves. Update the PPE requirements documentation to mandate these items for any work involving pressurized heated systems. Ensure adequate supply is maintained and inspected monthly. While PPE is a lower-tier control, it provides essential secondary protection when engineering controls are present. Train all relevant staff on proper donning and care of specialized PPE within 7 days.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Resin Dryers
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all resin drying equipment with daily temperature monitoring logs, weekly calibration checks, and mandatory 16-hour maximum continuous operation cycles with 2-hour cool-down periods. Install automated shutdown systems that trigger when equipment operates beyond safe temperature thresholds. Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham will coordinate with equipment manufacturers to establish baseline performance metrics. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of overheating by ensuring equipment never operates in degraded condition.

name: Enhanced Clean Room Ventilation Monitoring System
description: Install real-time monitoring sensors in the clean room ventilation system with alert thresholds for inadequate air exchange rates and fume accumulation. System will automatically trigger enhanced exhaust cycling and alert operators when air quality parameters deviate from ISO 13485 standards. Include monthly third-party air quality verification testing to ensure medical device production integrity is maintained.

name: Hydraulic System Component Replacement and Pressure Testing Protocol
description: Replace all corroded and aged hydraulic hose fittings across the facility with corrosion-resistant stainless steel components rated for 2500+ PSI. Implement quarterly pressure testing and annual full system inspections by certified hydraulic technicians. Install pressure relief guards and secondary containment systems around all high-pressure connection points. Hydraulic Systems Technician Andrei Popov will oversee implementation and maintain inspection logs. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of unexpected pressure release incidents.

name: Mandatory Pressure Equipment Safety Training and Certification
description: Require all maintenance technicians and production operators working with pressurized hydraulic systems to complete advanced pressure equipment safety certification. Training will include recognition of wear patterns, proper disconnection procedures under pressure, use of pressure-release tools, and emergency response protocols. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier will coordinate certification programs with external training providers. Conduct annual refresher training for all certified personnel.

name: Personal Protective Equipment Upgrade for Maintenance Operations
description: Issue specialized heat-resistant and cut-resistant gloves (rated for 500°F and abrasion resistance) to all maintenance personnel working with hydraulic systems. Provide face shields and arm protection sleeves rated for high-pressure fluid contact. Ensure all PPE is properly stored at maintenance workstations and that usage is mandatory during any pressurized equipment work. While PPE is the lowest control priority, it provides essential protection during the implementation of higher-level engineering controls.

name: Ergonomic Redesign of Material Transfer Equipment
description: Modify collection hoppers and hand scoops with padded, recessed handles and guards that prevent finger pinching during loading operations. Install semi-automatic hopper feed systems that reduce manual handling requirements by 60%. Design features will include visual pinch point warnings and ergonomic height adjustment to reduce strain. Engineering department will work with equipment suppliers to implement changes within 45 days.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance for Proximity Sensors
description: Establish a mandatory 2-week sensor inspection cycle with functional testing on all injection molding lines. Technicians will use calibrated test equipment to verify sensor response times and thresholds. Any sensor showing >5% deviation from baseline will be immediately replaced. A digital tracking system will log all tests and alert maintenance leads when intervals are missed. This eliminates the deferral gap that allowed the faulty sensor to remain in service.

name: Mandatory Hazard Awareness Training for Production Operators
description: All production operators on molding lines will receive updated training on machine-specific known issues, including the history of sensor faults on Line B. Training will include recognition of erratic mold behavior and procedures to halt operations immediately. Sessions will be conducted in both French and English, with competency assessment. Documentation will be maintained for compliance verification.

name: Upgrade to Dual-Sensor Mold Safety Interlock
description: Replace single proximity sensors with redundant dual-sensor safety interlocks on all 12 automotive molding lines. This engineering control eliminates single-point failures. If either sensor detects an anomaly, the mold cycle is automatically halted. Installation will be staggered over 60 days to minimize production impact. Validation testing will confirm interlock functionality before each line returns to service.

name: Replace All Coolant System Hoses on Schedule
description: Implement a strict hose replacement protocol for all cooling systems. All hoses exceeding 4.5 years of age will be replaced immediately. A color-coded tagging system will indicate installation date and next replacement date. A digital inventory system will track all hoses facility-wide and trigger automatic replacement orders 30 days before the replacement date. Maintenance staff will conduct quarterly audits to verify compliance.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Pressure Relief Upgrades
description: Install a 1,000-gallon capacity secondary containment basin beneath the primary coolant supply manifold to capture any future leaks before they reach the production floor. Replace all pressure relief valves with new units certified to current standards and install pressure monitoring gauges with automatic shut-off capability at 85% of rated pressure. These engineering controls prevent large-scale spills and equipment damage.

name: Establish Chemical Compatibility Matrix and Pre-Work Review Process
description: Create a comprehensive chemical compatibility matrix identifying all incompatible solvent combinations used in maintenance operations. All maintenance work orders requiring multiple chemical applications will require a pre-work briefing where the supervisor and technician verify compatibility and confirm ventilation adequacy. The chemical safety officer will conduct quarterly audits of work orders. A laminated reference card will be posted at each maintenance station listing high-risk incompatibilities.

name: Install Mechanical Ventilation and Gas Detection in Instrumentation Shop
description: Install a dedicated mechanical ventilation system with 12 air changes per hour minimum in the electrical shop work area, with makeup air and exhaust ducting designed for chemical fume control. Install real-time multi-gas monitors detecting ammonia, chlorine, and hydrogen sulfide with visual/audible alarms at 50% OSHA PEL. Ensure all cleaning stations have local exhaust hoods. This engineering control prevents hazardous gas accumulation.

name: Enhanced WHMIS Training and Chemical Safety Certification
description: All maintenance staff will complete an updated WHMIS 2015 training with emphasis on chemical incompatibilities, gas generation hazards, and respiratory protection. A 2-hour practical workshop will demonstrate proper ventilation use and gas monitor operation. Maintenance supervisors will receive advanced chemical safety certification through an accredited provider. Annual refresher training will be mandatory. Competency assessments will be documented.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and pressure testing schedule for all hydraulic regulators and servo control systems on injection molding equipment. Install pressure monitoring sensors with automated alerts to detect anomalies before failure occurs. Train maintenance staff on hydraulic system diagnostics using vibration analysis and thermal imaging. This engineering control eliminates the root cause by ensuring early detection of component degradation. Expected outcome: reduce hydraulic-related equipment failures by 85% and prevent future near-miss incidents involving robotic arm malfunction.

name: Upgrade Emergency Stop System with Wireless Integration
description: Replace existing hardwired emergency stop buttons with a wireless emergency stop system accessible from multiple locations on the production line. Install additional wireless panic buttons at key workstations and provide safety awareness training to all operators. This administrative control ensures faster response times during equipment malfunctions and increases operator safety. Implementation will include monthly testing protocols and staff certification.

name: Mandatory Maintenance Schedule Enforcement for Resin Lines
description: Establish a non-negotiable preventive maintenance calendar for all resin delivery systems, scheduling quarterly coupling inspections and annual line replacements. Implement a work order management system that flags maintenance tasks 2 weeks in advance, preventing deferral. Create production scheduling that accommodates scheduled maintenance windows. Assign responsibility to Claude Rioux (Electrical Maintenance Lead) to ensure adherence. This administrative control eliminates pressure-driven maintenance postponement and ensures equipment integrity.

name: Upgrade PPE with Heat-Resistant Arm Protection
description: Issue all injection molding operators specialized heat-resistant sleeves (rated to 300°C) and high-temperature gloves as mandatory PPE during all molding operations. Conduct fitting and training sessions to ensure proper wear and awareness. Replace PPE quarterly or upon visible degradation. While this is a PPE control (lowest in hierarchy), the engineering controls above address the root cause. Implement a compliance tracking system in the production log.

name: Install Pressure Release Valve Guards and Line Shielding
description: Engineer protective barriers around all high-pressure resin lines, including perforated metal guards to contain and redirect hot material spray away from operator work zones. Install quick-release safety couplings on all resin delivery lines to prevent catastrophic pressure release. This engineering control physically prevents operator contact with hot material during line failure. Expected outcome: reduce thermal burn incidents by 90% for this specific hazard.

name: Implement Mandatory Equipment Maintenance Certification Program
description: Establish a certified maintenance provider protocol requiring all forklift servicing to be performed by third-party certified technicians with documented hydraulic system expertise. Create a digital maintenance tracking system (CMMS) that logs every inspection, prohibits work order completion until all checklist items are signed off, and generates compliance reports. Require supervisor sign-off before any equipment returns to service. This administrative control ensures rigorous maintenance compliance and eliminates skip-step scenarios.

name: Install Load Cell Safety Monitoring on All Forklifts
description: Retrofit all 8 facility forklifts with load cell sensors and real-time hydraulic pressure monitoring systems that provide audible and visual alerts when system pressure approaches critical thresholds. Integrate sensors with on-board diagnostics that prevent operation if hydraulic integrity is compromised. Train operators on alert interpretation and shutdown procedures. This engineering control provides continuous real-time protection against hydraulic failure.

name: Implement Mandatory Lockout/Tagout During Hopper Maintenance
description: Establish and enforce a strict LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure for all hopper cleaning and maintenance activities on injection molding machines. This procedure will require that the machine be fully de-energized, locked, and tagged before any internal work begins. Training will be provided to all production and maintenance staff. A checklist system will be implemented requiring operator sign-off confirming LOTO compliance before work starts. Inspections will be conducted monthly to verify procedure adherence.

name: Upgrade Hopper Safety Interlocks on All Molding Machines
description: Install electronic safety interlocks on all 32 injection molding machines that prevent machine restart if hopper access panels are open or if internal sensors detect hand/arm presence in the hopper area. These interlocks will provide a secondary level of protection against accidental startup. Retrofit installation will be phased across all machines over 60 days, prioritizing machines most frequently requiring hopper maintenance. Costs include hardware, installation labor, and testing.

name: Enhanced Machine Safety Training Program
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training to all production operators and maintenance technicians on machine hazards, proper LOTO procedures, and emergency response protocols. Training will include hands-on demonstrations of hopper safety interlocks and practice with emergency stop buttons. Training will be mandatory within 30 days of implementation and refreshed annually. Assessment tests will ensure comprehension and compliance.

name: Upgrade Eye Protection Standards for Chemical Handling
description: Replace standard safety glasses with chemical splash goggles with indirect ventilation for all personnel handling mold release agents and working in areas with chemical vapors. The new goggles will provide superior protection against liquid splash and vapor exposure compared to standard glasses. All 85 production and assembly workers will be fitted with properly-sized goggles. Staff will receive training on proper donning/doffing and maintenance of goggles. Existing eyewash stations will be confirmed operational and restocked monthly.

name: Install Material Containment Netting at Mezzanine Level
description: Install high-strength polycarbonate safety netting along all edges of the warehouse mezzanine to contain falling materials and prevent them from striking personnel or equipment below. Netting will be rated for impact loads up to 200 pounds. Installation will include attachment points every 2 feet along the mezzanine perimeter. This engineering control will eliminate the hazard of falling objects from reaching the lower level even if material rolls from storage.

name: Implement Glove Moisture Management Protocol
description: Establish and enforce a protocol requiring material handlers to inspect and dry their gloves before handling elevated materials. Provide absorbent, textured gloves designed for wet conditions as standard issue. Add a drying station with microfiber towels near the mezzanine lift access point. Include glove inspection and drying requirements in the material handling checklist. Conduct toolbox talks on grip security and material handling best practices monthly.

name: Repair Ventilation System and Install Enhanced Monitoring
description: Complete inspection and repair of the ventilation system in the Composite Materials Processing Area with replacement of air filters and recalibration of airflow rates to meet or exceed 12 air changes per hour minimum. Install real-time VOC monitoring sensors that trigger automatic alerts when solvent vapor concentrations exceed 50% of the OSHA PEL. Conduct quarterly maintenance audits of the ventilation system going forward. Expected outcome: maintain safe air quality and prevent solvent vapor accumulation.

name: Floor Maintenance and Hazard Remediation Program
description: Conduct comprehensive facility walk-through to identify and repair all uneven floor surfaces, cracked tiles, and trip hazards in the Composite Materials Processing Area and chemical storage corridors. Implement monthly floor inspection checklist to be completed by Facilities Technician Georges Plante. Mark high-risk areas with anti-slip tape and improved signage. Install additional spill containment pallets for chemical drum storage to prevent lateral movement during transport.

name: Chemical Transfer Procedure and Training Enhancement
description: Revise the chemical transfer standard operating procedure to mandate use of engineered drum handling equipment (drum cart with stabilizing arms) instead of manual dollies for all 55-gallon drum transfers. Require two trained personnel present for all transfers with communication protocols. Implement mandatory refresher training for all production and materials handling staff on chemical handling procedures, spill response, and emergency evacuation protocols within 10 days.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule Verification System
description: Establish a work order verification system requiring documented photographic evidence and technician sign-off confirming that all hydraulic couplings have been properly torqued to manufacturer specifications during preventive maintenance. Implement a digital tracking system that flags maintenance tasks requiring coupling re-verification at the 7-day post-maintenance checkpoint. Conduct re-certification training for all maintenance personnel on proper torque specifications for hydraulic system components.

name: Install Mezzanine Storage Safety Restraint System
description: Install industrial-grade netting and guardrails on all sides of the equipment storage mezzanine to prevent objects from falling to the warehouse floor below. Implement overhead catch trays with impact-absorbing materials on the mezzanine level to capture containers that may shift. Secure all storage containers to shelving using adjustable tie-down straps rated for 1.5x the maximum weight of stored materials. Expected outcome: elimination of falling object hazard from mezzanine storage.

name: Reorganize Storage System and Implement Weight Limits
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all materials stored on the mezzanine, relocating heavy containers (>30 lbs) to ground-level shelving. Establish clearly marked weight capacity limits for each shelf position with signage visible from all angles. Create a storage map identifying approved locations for each material type. Require all warehouse staff to complete storage organization and safety procedures training.

name: Distribute Cut-Resistant Glove Requirement at All Molding Lines
description: Implement mandatory cut-resistant gloves for all part removal operations at injection molding lines. Establish a restocking schedule for gloves at each workstation and add a visual reminder above each mold removal station. Conduct refresher training for all production operators on proper glove selection and fit. Include this requirement in the daily pre-shift safety briefing. Expected outcome: eliminate hand injuries from sharp plastic edges by providing appropriate PPE barrier.

name: Implement De-burring Process for Molded Components
description: Engineer a post-molding de-burring or edge-finishing station where all components have sharp edges removed or smoothed immediately after ejection, before being handled by operators. This engineering control eliminates the hazard at the source rather than relying on PPE. Assign maintenance technician to design and install edge-finishing capability. Train operators on the new workflow. Expected outcome: significantly reduce sharp edge injuries by removing the hazard before human handling occurs.

name: Establish Quarterly Forklift Fuel System Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a mandatory quarterly inspection schedule for all propane-powered forklifts, with documented checks of fuel connection integrity, valve condition, and leak detection. Purchase portable propane leak detectors for maintenance staff. Create a maintenance log to track all inspections and repairs. Train all maintenance personnel on proper fuel system inspection techniques and safe depressurization procedures. Expected outcome: identify fuel system degradation before leaks develop, preventing acute inhalation exposures.

name: Install Dedicated Propane Maintenance Area with Ventilation
description: Establish a dedicated outdoor maintenance bay or enclosed area with mechanical ventilation dedicated to propane equipment service. This removes forklift maintenance from the general warehouse environment and provides engineering controls for vapor dispersion. Install visible warning signage and ensure the area has proper emergency equipment nearby. Relocate all propane fuel system maintenance activities to this controlled location. Expected outcome: eliminate potential exposure of warehouse staff to propane vapors and provide safer working conditions for maintenance technicians.

name: Transition to Electric Forklifts
description: Develop a capital equipment replacement plan to phase out propane-powered forklifts and transition to electric-powered equipment over 18-24 months. Electric forklifts eliminate fuel system hazards, propane exposure risks, and provide superior operational safety. Evaluate vendor options, conduct cost-benefit analysis including reduced maintenance costs. Expected outcome: complete elimination of propane-related hazards as primary fuel source is removed from operations.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Large Chemical Containers
