description: Install engineered secondary containment trays beneath all 55-liter and larger chemical storage locations in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Containment capacity must be at least 110% of the largest single container volume. Ensure containment trays have drain plugs connected to the hazardous waste collection system. Paint clear boundary lines and add warning signage. This engineering control prevents spilled chemicals from spreading across the facility floor. Expected outcome: contain any future chemical spills at the source, preventing environmental contamination and vapor exposure.

name: Implement Chemical Container Stability and Positioning Protocol
description: Establish an administrative control requiring all large chemical containers to be positioned in stable configurations with proper securing straps or cradles. Develop a checklist for equipment setup that includes container stability verification before production operations begin. Include this requirement in the shift handover documentation and daily safety briefing. Train all personnel who handle chemicals on proper positioning and securing techniques. Expected outcome: prevent accidental tip-overs by improving container stability and worker awareness.

name: Enhance Chemical Spill Response Training and Drills
description: Conduct comprehensive chemical spill response training for all personnel working with hazardous materials, covering identification, containment, neutralization, and evacuation procedures specific to the chemicals used in composite processing. Establish a mandatory quarterly drill schedule where personnel simulate spill response procedures in controlled conditions. Update the chemical inventory system to clearly identify which neutralization procedures apply to each chemical. Expected outcome: ensure rapid, effective response to chemical incidents and minimize exposure duration and environmental impact.

name: Implement Enhanced Edge Finishing Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory secondary inspection checkpoint specifically for edge quality and burr detection on all components destined for assembly operations. This will include tactile verification using calibrated edge-detection gauges and visual inspection under magnification for components smaller than 50mm. Quality Control Lab Technician will implement daily calibration checks of inspection equipment and document all findings. Training will be provided to all QC staff on new edge detection procedures within 5 business days.

name: Upgrade Assembly Workstation PPE Requirements
description: Introduce cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 rated) as mandatory PPE for all packaging and assembly operations. Current gloves do not provide adequate protection against micro-burrs and sharp plastic edges. Gloves will be stored at each workstation with quarterly replacement. Employees will receive fitting and proper usage training. Compatibility with dexterity requirements for precision assembly will be verified through trial period.

name: Install Secondary Containment System in Hazardous Waste Area
description: Implement engineered secondary containment platforms with 110% capacity of the largest single container (200-liter drums) to prevent spills from reaching the facility floor. Install drip containment trays with sloped surfaces directing spillage to collection sumps equipped with absorbent cartridge filters. Platform will feature slip-resistant surface and raised edges of minimum 15cm height. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of floor contamination and meets environmental compliance standards.

name: Establish Hazardous Waste Transfer Procedure with Equipment Controls
description: Develop and enforce standardized operating procedures for all hazardous material transfers in UNIT-011, including mandatory use of pump transfer equipment with secured locking mechanisms and spill containment trays beneath all transfer points. All containers must be verified as properly sealed before and after transfer operations. Employees will receive certification training on new procedures with annual refresher requirement. Checklist-based procedure cards will be posted at each transfer station.

name: Upgrade Spill Response Equipment and Training
description: Expand spill response kit inventory to include immediate-response absorbent materials positioned at three strategic locations within UNIT-011, plus portable containment berms and emergency shower access verification. Conduct quarterly spill response drills with all relevant personnel (Materials Management staff, HSE team, Facilities). Document completion of drills and update emergency contact procedures annually. Ensure CNESST-compliant signage indicating spill kit locations and material safety data sheets are readily accessible.

name: Implement Comprehensive LOTO System Redesign for Injection Molding Equipment
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with enhanced LOTO systems featuring mechanical lock-out plates on hydraulic accumulator isolation valves, combined with mandatory pressure relief verification gauges that must register zero before any maintenance access. Install redundant lockout points (both primary pump shutoff and secondary accumulator isolation) with interlocked mechanical blockades. All machines will feature permanent laminated LOTO procedure cards specific to each machine model, highlighting hydraulic de-pressurization as the mandatory first step. Existing LOTO procedures will be revised and reissued within 5 days.

name: Mandatory LOTO Competency Certification and Refresher Program
description: Establish that all production and maintenance personnel performing LOTO procedures must obtain CNESST-compliant LOTO certification within 30 days, with mandatory annual recertification. Certification will include hands-on verification of de-pressurization procedures specific to injection molding hydraulic systems. All current employees will be enrolled in accelerated certification program (available through provincial safety training provider). Failed certifications will result in restricted duty assignment until re-certification is achieved. Documentation of all certifications will be maintained by HSE department.

name: Establish Pre-Maintenance Equipment Isolation Verification Checklist
description: Introduce mandatory pre-maintenance equipment isolation verification requiring a second qualified employee to independently verify all LOTO steps before maintenance work commences. Verification must include pressure gauge readings confirming zero pressure on all hydraulic systems, photographic documentation, and sign-off by both the performing technician and verification employee. Checklists will be filed with daily maintenance logs for audit purposes. This peer-verification administrative control prevents procedural oversights and creates accountability.

name: Implement Mandatory Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish and enforce a quarterly preventive maintenance program specifically for all hydraulic pump systems across the production lines. This includes fluid analysis testing, seal inspections, and bearing condition assessments. Work orders identified by the predictive maintenance software will be automatically escalated to management with mandatory completion deadlines. The maintenance team will track compliance through a digital asset management system. Expected outcome: Reduce unexpected equipment failures by 75% and extend pump service life by 40%.

name: Increase Maintenance Department Staffing and Training
description: Hire one additional full-time maintenance technician and cross-train two production operators in basic hydraulic system diagnostics. Provide specialized certification training in hydraulic pump maintenance and troubleshooting. This addresses the root cause of delayed maintenance work orders due to understaffing. The expanded team will ensure that all predictive maintenance alerts are addressed within 48 hours of identification. Training will be completed through an accredited industrial maintenance program.

name: Replace Stressed Resin Storage Tank with Engineered Pressure Vessel
description: Remove the defective 200-liter resin storage tank and replace it with a certified ASME pressure vessel manufactured from stainless steel with superior corrosion resistance. The new tank will include pressure relief valves, rupture disks, and secondary containment bunding rated for 110% of tank capacity. Installation will include vibration isolation mounts to reduce stress concentrations on weld joints. This engineering control eliminates the recurring hazard of stress corrosion cracking in pressurized chemical storage.

name: Implement Quarterly Tank Integrity Inspection Program
description: Establish a formal quarterly visual inspection and ultrasonic thickness testing program for all resin storage tanks. Inspections will be conducted by a certified pressure vessel inspector and documented in a permanent maintenance log. Any tanks showing signs of corrosion, cracking, or degradation will be immediately removed from service. Staff will receive training on identifying early warning signs. This administrative control provides early detection of hazardous conditions before catastrophic failure.

name: Install Automated Chemical Spill Detection and Response System
description: Install pressure sensors and level monitoring systems on all chemical storage tanks connected to an automated alert system. Any abnormal pressure drop or leak will trigger an immediate alarm and activate automatic isolation valves. Secondary containment areas will be equipped with absorbent materials and spill kits positioned for rapid response. Personnel will receive quarterly training on spill response procedures. This provides defense-in-depth to prevent environmental release even if tank failure occurs.

name: Replace All Defective Storm Drain Valves and Install Secondary Containment
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all drain valves in the Regrind and Recycling Department and throughout the facility. Replace all valves showing signs of wear, corrosion, or leakage with high-grade stainless steel ball valves rated for industrial waste water. Install secondary containment basins beneath all collection bins to capture overflow and prevent environmental release. Drain valves will be fitted with locking handles to prevent accidental opening. This engineering control eliminates the pathway for waste material to enter environmental systems.

name: Establish Environmental Compliance Monitoring and Inspection Schedule
description: Implement a monthly environmental compliance inspection program for all waste collection and discharge systems. Assign responsibility to a dedicated Environmental Compliance Officer who will conduct visual inspections, pressure tests, and functionality checks on all drain valves, containment systems, and waste collection equipment. All findings will be documented and prioritized. A work order tracking system will ensure all identified issues are resolved within 30 days. This administrative control provides early detection and prevents future environmental releases.

name: Implement Warehouse Pallet Stacking Protocol
description: Develop and post standardized pallet stacking procedures with maximum height limits (6 feet), weight distribution requirements, and mandatory use of pallet stabilizer bars. All warehouse staff will receive refresher training on proper stacking techniques. Visual inspection checklists will be implemented daily during shift transitions to verify compliance. This administrative control addresses the root cause of inconsistent practices and will prevent similar near-miss incidents.

name: Install Warehouse Storage Safety Barriers
description: Install yellow and black warning tape and safety barriers around high-stack storage areas to create exclusion zones. Add reflective edge guards to pallet racks and implement color-coded weight capacity labels. These engineering controls will provide visual warnings and prevent workers from entering dangerous areas. The physical barriers will serve as a secondary control to complement procedural improvements.

name: Implement Mandatory Lockout/Tagout Protocol for All Hydraulic Maintenance
description: Establish formal LOTO procedures requiring all hydraulic systems to be depressurized and energy isolated before any maintenance or adjustment work. All machine setters and maintenance personnel will complete recertification training on proper lockout application, verification procedures, and verification documentation. Lockout coordinator Gaétan Laplante will conduct monthly audits of lockout compliance. This administrative control eliminates the hazard of pressurized fluid exposure by ensuring systems cannot be pressurized during maintenance activities.

name: Implement Mandatory Safety Interlock Re-activation Protocol
description: Establish a documented procedure requiring that all safety interlocks must be physically verified and logged as re-activated immediately after maintenance work is completed. Create a checklist system with photographic documentation and mandatory supervisor sign-off. Implement a color-coded tag system (yellow for bypassed, green for active) on all machines. This engineering/administrative control directly addresses the root cause of the incident by ensuring interlocks cannot remain disabled unintentionally. Expected outcome: 100% compliance with safety interlock status verification within 30 days.

name: Enhanced Machine Safety Training and Quarterly Audits
description: Conduct comprehensive retraining for all operators and maintenance technicians on machine safety protocols, including proper interlock function testing. Develop a quarterly audit schedule where trained safety personnel inspect all 32 injection molding machines for proper guard installation and interlock functionality. Create a centralized log tracking all maintenance activities and safety verifications. This administrative control strengthens procedural compliance and creates accountability for safety maintenance.

name: Install Redundant Safety Systems on High-Risk Machines
description: For injection molding machines operating at pressures above 250 tons, install secondary mechanical safety stops that physically prevent mold closure if the primary interlock is compromised. These engineering controls provide an additional layer of protection independent of electronic systems. Prioritize Line A first, then expand to other production lines. Expected outcome: Elimination of bypass-related crush injury hazards on critical equipment.

name: Comprehensive Structural Inspection and Repair of Storage Racks
description: Engage a certified structural engineer to conduct a complete inspection of all mezzanine storage racks and wall-mounted shelving systems. Document all weld integrity issues, rust corrosion, and stress fractures. Replace or reinforce all units with compromised structural integrity using grade 8 welds and additional cross-bracing. Establish new weight load limits for each rack section with permanent placard markings. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of rack failure and falling debris.

name: Implement Storage Rack Load Management System
description: Create a documented inventory management procedure specifying maximum weight limits per shelf, proper load distribution, and prohibited stacking practices. Install a software system tracking inventory location and weight per shelf section. Conduct training for all personnel responsible for material storage. Implement quarterly visual inspections with photographic documentation and signed verification. This administrative control ensures racks are never overloaded beyond design specifications.

name: Restore and Verify Quality Control Deburring Process
description: Re-establish the mandatory deburring quality check as a non-negotiable step in the finishing process. Create a checklist system requiring operators to inspect each part for sharp edges using tactile and visual methods before assembly. Implement a hold-tag system for batches that skip quality checks, preventing them from entering assembly until properly inspected. Train all assembly operators on proper edge inspection techniques and safe handling of parts with sharp edges. This administrative control ensures systematic detection of hazardous sharp edges.

name: Provide Enhanced Hand Protection Equipment
description: Issue cut-resistant gloves (nitrile-coated or leather) rated for handling sharp plastic edges to all assembly operators. Conduct training on proper glove selection and fit. Establish a glove replacement program with monthly distribution. Stock extra gloves at assembly stations for immediate access. This PPE control provides a barrier against sharp edge contact while other prevention measures are implemented. Expected outcome: Reduction of hand lacerations by 80% in assembly operations.

name: Implement Mandatory Two-Person LOTO Verification System
description: Establish a dual-verification protocol requiring both the maintenance technician and a dedicated safety monitor to independently verify LOTO status before work begins on any injection molding equipment. Implement color-coded lockout tags with unique serial numbers and a centralized lock registry system. Require daily LOTO audits on all production lines with documented sign-offs. This addresses the root cause of inadequate lockout verification and prevents unauthorized machine startup during maintenance operations.

name: Install Machine Restart Interlock with Remote Control Disable
description: Retrofit all injection molding machines with hardware interlocks that physically disable remote control restart functions when access panels are open or LOTO devices are engaged. Install visible warning lights and audible alarms that activate during machine maintenance. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of remote restart during locked-out maintenance work by removing the technical capability to operate conflicting systems simultaneously.

name: Mandatory LOTO Retraining and Competency Assessment
description: Conduct immediate mandatory retraining on lockout/tagout procedures for all production operators and maintenance personnel with competency testing and documentation. Training will emphasize communication protocols, verification responsibilities, and consequences of bypass procedures. Include scenarios based on this incident. Retrain all JHSC members on audit responsibilities. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand their role in preventing machine startup incidents.

name: Install Physical Protective Guards Around Fire Safety Infrastructure
description: Install protective cage guards around all sprinkler heads, alarm sensors, and electrical distribution equipment in warehouse areas. Clearly mark protected zones with yellow and black striping and signage indicating 'No Storage Within 6 Feet.' This engineering control prevents accidental contact with critical fire safety equipment during normal warehouse operations and material handling activities.

name: Establish Clear Mezzanine Storage Protocol and Clearance Zones
description: Develop and post clear signage designating no-storage zones around all fire safety and electrical equipment on mezzanine levels. Create a warehouse layout map showing mandatory clearance areas and restricted zones. Conduct toolbox talks with all material handlers on proper stacking procedures and equipment awareness. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand spatial limitations and protects critical safety infrastructure.

name: Replace All Solvent Storage Valves with Maintenance-Free Sealed Units
description: Conduct immediate replacement of all solvent transfer valve assemblies with high-reliability sealed units designed for hazardous chemical applications. Implement quarterly inspection and testing protocols using certified technicians. This eliminates the valve seal failure root cause through engineering control using superior equipment. The new system prevents similar solvent release incidents and extends maintenance intervals significantly.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System with Vapor Detection and Automatic Controls
description: Install enhanced mechanical ventilation system with VOC (volatile organic compound) sensors throughout the chemical storage and mixing area. System will automatically increase fan speed when solvent vapor concentrations exceed 25% of lower explosive limit (LEL). Install emergency ventilation shutoff switch accessible to all personnel. This engineering control ensures flammable vapor concentrations remain below ignition thresholds during normal operations and chemical handling activities.

name: Implement Comprehensive No-Smoking Policy with Enforcement and Monitoring
description: Establish zero-tolerance no-smoking policy within 25 meters of any chemical storage or flammable materials area. Install motion-activated surveillance cameras at chemical storage entrance with recorded monitoring. Implement bi-weekly compliance inspections with disciplinary procedures for violations. Provide designated smoking areas 50+ meters away from facility. This administrative control removes ignition sources from hazardous areas and enforces behavioral compliance through monitoring and accountability.

name: Conduct Chemical Spill Response Training and Quarterly Drills
description: Provide comprehensive hazmat spill response training to all chemical storage area personnel and supervisors, including proper use of Class B fire extinguishers, spill containment procedures, and emergency notification protocols. Conduct quarterly emergency response drills simulating chemical releases with performance evaluation. This administrative control ensures all personnel can respond effectively to chemical incidents and minimizes damage from future spill events.

name: Implement Hopper Inspection and Maintenance Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily pre-shift hopper inspection checklist for all injection molding lines, focusing on lid integrity, clamp security, and overflow prevention mechanisms. All maintenance technicians will be trained on proper hopper servicing procedures including torque specifications for securing clamps. A colored tag system will indicate last inspection date and time. This engineering/administrative control will prevent future dislodgement events by catching wear before failure occurs. Expected outcome: Zero hopper-related overflows within 12 months.

name: Upgrade Hopper Lid Safety Latches
description: Replace all manually-operated hopper lid clamps on Lines A-D with spring-loaded quick-connect safety latches that require two-step engagement to prevent accidental disengagement. These will include visual load indicators showing proper seating. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of improper clamp installation. All operators will receive hands-on training on the new system. Expected outcome: Elimination of hopper lid dislodgement as a failure mode.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Heating Elements
description: Implement a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all industrial mixing tank heating elements, including thermostatic sensor calibration checks and element resistance testing. Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel will develop detailed work instructions with performance benchmarks. A computerized tracking system will flag equipment approaching maintenance intervals. This administrative control ensures early detection of degrading components before failure. Expected outcome: Elimination of temperature-related alarms caused by worn heating elements within two maintenance cycles.

name: Distribute Cut-Resistant Gloves to Assembly Line Stations
description: Issue ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant gloves to all assembly and quality inspection operators working with composite materials. Gloves will be sized individually and stored at each workstation. Training will emphasize proper donning and removal techniques. This PPE control provides immediate protection against sharp edge injuries. Expected outcome: Reduction of laceration injuries during part handling by 85% within six months.

name: Implement Edge Finishing Quality Gate
description: Add a mandatory edge inspection and finishing step immediately after part ejection from injection molds. Workers will use pneumatic burring tools or hand-held sanders to smooth all exposed composite edges before parts enter the inspection/removal area. This engineering control eliminates the sharp edge hazard at the source. Supervisor Maxime Boisvert will establish acceptance criteria and perform daily spot-checks. Expected outcome: Complete elimination of sharp composite edge incidents in the assembly area.

name: Install Secondary Containment System
description: Design and install a secondary containment tray system beneath all chemical storage containers in the Chemical Storage Building. The containment system will have a capacity of at least 110% of the largest container volume stored. This engineering control directly eliminates the risk of environmental contamination from spills by containing leaked materials. Implementation includes concrete floor modifications, drain covers, and regular inspection protocols. Expected outcome: complete prevention of environmental contamination from chemical container failures.

name: Implement Forklift Traffic Control in Chemical Storage
description: Establish clearly marked traffic lanes and designated material zones within the Chemical Storage Building. Install physical bollards protecting high-value chemical storage areas. Require all forklift operators to complete a specific chemical storage area safety briefing before operating in the zone. Operators must maintain reduced speed (5 mph maximum) and use spotters for all container movement. This administrative control reduces the probability of equipment-container collisions. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in forklift-related incidents in chemical storage areas.

name: Upgrade Ventilation Monitoring System
description: Install continuous air quality monitoring equipment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room with real-time alerts when acetone or other volatile organic compound (VOC) concentrations exceed 500 ppm. The system will automatically increase ventilation fan speed and trigger workplace alerts. Add monthly calibration requirements for monitoring equipment. This engineering control ensures early detection of hazardous vapor accumulation before employee exposure. Expected outcome: real-time detection of chemical vapor hazards with automatic response capability.

name: Replace and Upgrade Proximity Sensor System
description: Replace all proximity sensors on Injection Molding Lines A, B, and C with dual-channel safety-rated proximity sensors (SIL 2 rated) that provide redundant mold presence detection. Implement a mandatory 6-month replacement interval (reduced from 12 months) with documented replacement logs. Install an automated alert system that notifies maintenance when sensors approach their replacement date. This engineering control eliminates single-point failure modes in the mold safety interlock system. Expected outcome: elimination of unintended mold cycling during maintenance operations.

name: Implement Machine Guarding Barrier
description: Install perimeter guarding around Injection Molding Line B's danger zone with interlocked access gates. Any gate opening during mold cycling will trigger immediate mold stop and prevent mold closure. The guarding will use yellow and black striping with clear hazard signage. Add emergency stop buttons at each entry point with clear operational instructions. This engineering control physically prevents unauthorized access to the mold danger zone during operation. Expected outcome: complete elimination of hand/finger contact with moving mold mechanisms.

name: Establish Pallet Storage and Placement Standards
description: Develop and implement a visual pallet storage standard requiring all pallets to be stored with edges fully contained within marked storage zones. Paint bright yellow warning lines around all designated pallet storage areas on the shipping dock floor. Install warning signs indicating 'Keep Clear' zones and establish a checklist-based inspection system for dock supervisors to verify pallet placement three times per shift. This administrative control ensures consistent, safe pallet organization. Expected outcome: elimination of pallet-related trip hazards in high-traffic areas.

name: Mandatory LOTO Compliance Verification System
description: Implement a two-person verification protocol for all lockout/tagout procedures on injection molding machines. Maintenance technicians must have a second authorized person physically verify that all energy isolation devices are properly engaged before work begins. Install visible lockout checkpoints on all 32 molding machines with photographic documentation required at each step. Conduct immediate retraining of all 24 maintenance staff on LOTO procedures with written certification required. Implement weekly LOTO audits by HSE department with corrective action for non-compliance.

name: Install Machine Interlocks and Safety Guards
description: Engineer and install mechanical interlocks on hopper access panels that prevent machine operation when maintenance covers are open. Install rotating blade guards on all screw assemblies to eliminate pinch points. Upgrade all molding machines with light curtains at maintenance access points that trigger immediate emergency stop if breached. Retrofit machines with redundant safety systems to prevent unexpected cycling during maintenance operations.

name: Enhanced PPE Requirements for Machine Maintenance
description: Establish mandatory use of cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A5 rating) and reinforced guards for all personnel performing machine maintenance. Issue specialized protective sleeves rated for injection molding equipment hazards. Require anti-entanglement clothing with no loose parts that could catch in rotating machinery. Distribute new PPE to all maintenance staff and enforce compliance through daily pre-shift inspections.

name: Install Secondary Containment Systems
description: Install rigid polypropylene secondary containment pallets beneath all chemical storage drums and transfer stations in the Chemical Storage building. Containment must hold 110% of the largest container volume. Replace manual pumps with certified, regularly-maintained electric transfer pumps equipped with automatic shut-off valves. Install drip trays under all chemical dispensing points. Implement monthly inspections of all containment integrity with documented maintenance logs.

name: Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Chemical Transfer Equipment
description: Develop and implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all chemical transfer pumps and hoses. Schedule seal inspections every 3 months with mandatory replacement every 12 months regardless of apparent condition. Maintain detailed maintenance logs for all equipment. Assign Purchasing Manager Denis Savard responsibility for coordinating equipment service contracts with certified vendors. Train two designated maintenance personnel on pump seal replacement procedures.

name: Enhanced Spill Response Training and Equipment
description: Conduct mandatory spill response training for all warehouse and chemical handling personnel. Distribute spill response kits with absorbent materials, neutralizers, and plugs at all chemical work areas. Install clearly-marked emergency shower stations within 50 feet of chemical storage areas. Create laminated quick-reference guides for common chemical spills. Schedule quarterly spill simulation drills to ensure staff competency.

name: Comprehensive Storage Rack Inspection and Certification Program
description: Engage a certified third-party rack inspection service to conduct full structural assessments of all 47 storage rack systems throughout the warehouse facility. Replace or repair any racks with weld defects, corrosion, or bent components. Implement quarterly inspection schedule with documented certifications. Install load-rating placards on every rack clearly indicating maximum capacity and load configuration requirements. Create a digital asset management system tracking rack condition, repair history, and certification status.

name: Install Rack Safety Barriers and Anti-Collapse Systems
description: Install mesh safety nets or polycarbonate barriers on all elevated storage racks to contain potential falling materials. Add lateral bracing and cross-members to strengthen rack structures. Install column protectors at all rack base points to prevent damage from forklift impact. Retrofit high-risk sections with backup supports and redundant safety mechanisms. Engineer solution must prevent materials falling beyond rack footprint area.

name: Material Storage Training and Load Configuration Standards
description: Develop and distribute comprehensive material storage guidelines specifying proper load configurations for different product types, weight distributions, and rack types. Train all warehouse personnel and machine setters on correct loading procedures. Implement maximum load limits below manufacturer specifications with safety margin. Conduct monthly refresher training with photographic documentation of correct and incorrect loading practices. Establish daily pre-shift visual inspections of all active storage racks by warehouse supervisors.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish quarterly thermographic and visual inspection protocol for all hydraulic fittings and lines across production equipment. Replace corroded or damaged fittings immediately upon detection rather than deferring to scheduled maintenance windows. Create a centralized tracking system documenting all hydraulic component replacements and their service intervals. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of premature fitting failure and prevents future unplanned downtime. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in hydraulic-related equipment failures and zero property damage from fluid leaks within 12 months.

name: Install Fluid Containment and Detection Systems
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all hydraulic-powered equipment on Line B with integrated fluid level sensors that trigger automatic alerts when pressure builds or small leaks are detected. Add absorbent mats rated for hydraulic fluid in high-risk areas. This engineering control provides early warning and prevents fluid from reaching electrical components. Install insulating covers over critical electrical junction boxes on the molding line. Training sessions on containment procedures will be mandatory for all operators and maintenance staff.

name: Implement Chemical Drum Transfer Verification Checklist
description: Develop and deploy a mandatory pre-transfer checklist for all solvent drum movements that requires verification of: bung plug tightness (using torque wrench with calibration certificate), drum integrity inspection (no cracks or corrosion), containment tray placement, and two-person verification signature. The checklist must be completed before any drum movement begins and filed daily. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of the bung becoming loose. Expected outcome: Zero unintended chemical releases from drum handling within 6 months.

name: Upgrade VOC Detection and Alert System
description: Replace existing VOC detection system with real-time automated alert system that sends simultaneous notifications to shift supervisor, on-call maintenance, and HSE department when solvent vapors exceed 50% of OSHA PEL threshold. Install secondary audible alarm in the Material Drying Room with distinctive sound pattern. Implement mandatory response protocol requiring acknowledging and assessing alert within 15 minutes. Test system monthly. This engineering control ensures faster detection and response to chemical hazards.

name: Mandatory Chemical Handling Refresher Training
description: Conduct comprehensive chemical handling retraining for all material handlers, supervisors, and operators with focus on solvent volatility, proper drum handling procedures, emergency response steps, and personal protective equipment requirements for dichloromethane exposure. Include hands-on practice with drum transfer equipment. All personnel must complete training within 14 days and pass written assessment. This administrative control ensures knowledge retention and consistent safe practices across all shifts.

name: Restore and Audit All Machine Safety Interlocks
description: Immediately conduct comprehensive audit of all injection molding equipment to verify all safety interlocks are functional and cannot be bypassed. Install tamper-evident seals on interlock override mechanisms. Establish monthly verification schedule with documentation requirements. Create written procedure prohibiting any bypass of safety interlocks regardless of production pressure, with disciplinary consequences clearly communicated to all shift supervisors and operators. This engineering control eliminates the primary root cause of the incident.

name: Implement Machine-Specific Hazard Zone Training and Signage
description: Develop detailed training module for each molding line specifically identifying all pinch points, crush zones, hot surfaces, and electrical hazards with photographic documentation and laminated hazard zone maps posted at operator stations. Require all operators to complete machine-specific training annually with documented competency assessment. Install high-visibility warning decals on all identified hazard zones with pictograms. This administrative control ensures operators have current knowledge of machine dangers.

name: Establish Production Schedule Coordination Protocol with Safety Committee
description: Create formal process requiring all rush orders or accelerated production schedules to be reviewed by JHSC representatives for safety feasibility before approval. Establish explicit policy that production schedules cannot override safety procedures or require disabling safety equipment. Document all approved expedited production schedules and associated risk mitigations. Conduct monthly review of production pressure incidents and safety compliance. This administrative control prevents future pressure-driven safety violations.

name: Establish Pallet Inspection and Rotation Program
description: Implement quarterly inspection protocol for all wooden pallets in storage and handling areas. Mark each pallet with inspection date and retire pallets showing signs of structural degradation such as splits, warping, or rot. Replace aged pallets with plastic alternatives that have longer service life and are less prone to sudden failure. Maintain inventory log of all pallets with service dates. This engineering control eliminates the hazard source by preventing use of compromised pallets.

name: Install Safety Barriers Around High-Stacking Zones
description: Install perimeter guardrails and warning signage around material storage zones where bundles are stacked above 1.5 meters height. Barriers will restrict access to fall zones and provide visual warnings to material handlers. Implement administrative control designating safe distance from stack areas. Conduct tool-box talks on material handling hazards and recognition of structural pallet failure signs.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Injection Molding Equipment
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance protocol for all servo motors and clamping mechanisms across the three injection molding lines. This will include bi-weekly thermographic inspections, vibration analysis, and lubrication audits. Maintenance technicians will use IoT sensors to monitor temperature and vibration patterns in real-time, generating alerts before component failure occurs. The program will prioritize early identification of bearing degradation and inadequate lubrication issues. Expected outcome is a 40% reduction in unplanned equipment downtime and elimination of catastrophic servo failures that expose workers to sudden thermal hazards.

name: Upgrade Thermal Protective Equipment for Molding Line Operators
description: Replace current standard work gloves with high-performance aramid thermal gloves rated for 500°C contact temperatures and provide operators with long-sleeve aluminized thermal sleeves for the forearms and upper arms. Conduct fit testing and comfort assessments with all Line B operators to ensure proper adoption. Provide refresher training on PPE protocols with emphasis on proper donning/doffing procedures. This engineering/PPE combination addresses the inadequate protection gap identified in this incident and provides better preparedness for future thermal exposure scenarios.

name: Establish Equipment Condition Monitoring Alert System
description: Configure automated alerts within the production management system to flag machines exhibiting the early warning signs observed in this incident: stuttering clamping cycles, servo response delays, and thermal anomalies. When criteria are met, the system will automatically notify maintenance supervisors and queue the equipment for immediate diagnostic inspection. Operators will receive training to recognize and report these warning signs verbally as a secondary safeguard. This administrative control creates a documented early-intervention pathway that prevents progression from minor malfunction to catastrophic equipment failure.

name: Install Rotary Tool Guard Retrofit and Machine Lockout Modifications
description: Retrofit all handheld rotary deburring tools in the Post-Processing unit with enhanced protective guards that reduce exposure of the abrasive wheel to operator hands. Add tactile stop controls that require operators to hold a dead-man switch, immediately halting wheel rotation if hand pressure is detected near the working surface. Install automatic tool disengagement mechanisms that activate if vibration patterns indicate unusual hand contact. These engineering controls directly address the mechanism of injury by preventing inadvertent hand contact with the spinning wheel.

name: Install Temperature Monitoring System with Alarm
description: Implement a redundant digital temperature monitoring system on all 32 injection molding machines with audible and visual alarms set to trigger at 275°C (85% of critical threshold). The system will include automatic machine shutdown at 280°C to prevent thermal runaway conditions. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of uncontrolled temperature excursions. Installation will include sensor calibration, PLC integration, and operator training on alarm response procedures. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of temperature-related thermal burn incidents.

name: Enhanced Thermal Burn Prevention Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory quarterly training for all production operators focused on recognizing signs of equipment malfunction, proper response to thermal incidents, and correct use of emergency eyewash and shower stations. Training will include hands-on simulation of burn response using thermal mannequins. All production staff will demonstrate competency through written and practical assessments. Refresher training will occur before each operator returns to full duties after any thermal incident.

name: Implement Comprehensive Dust Collection System Upgrade
description: Install enclosed dust collection ductwork and HEPA-filtered collection units at all material handling and grinding stations to capture dust at the source rather than allowing it to settle on equipment. Connect existing ventilation systems to the new centralized collection point and establish a maintenance schedule for filter replacement every 30 days. This engineering control eliminates the combustible dust hazard at its origin. Include installation of electrically conductive hose and grounding straps to prevent static discharge. Expected outcome: Reduction of airborne dust concentration to below OSHA PEL and elimination of settled dust on electrical equipment.

name: Establish Daily Housekeeping and Dust Monitoring Protocol
description: Create and implement a daily housekeeping checklist for all maintenance and production areas with specific attention to electrical enclosures, motor housings, and high-voltage equipment. Assign responsibility to shift supervisors to conduct daily inspections using a standardized form documenting dust accumulation levels. Establish a threshold that triggers immediate dry cleaning (no water or solvents) using HEPA-equipped vacuum equipment. Monthly audits will verify compliance and identify trends. This administrative control ensures sustained hazard prevention until engineering controls are fully operational.

name: Enforce Lockout/Tagout Compliance for Jam Clearing Operations
description: Conduct immediate retraining of all regrind and equipment operators on proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures specifically for jam clearing situations. Establish a mandatory written protocol requiring that grinding equipment must be de-energized and locked out before any manual intervention in the grinding chamber. Provide each operator with a personal LOTO kit including padlock, hasp, and tags. Implement weekly audits where supervisors verify LOTO compliance on randomly selected equipment. Any violation will result in immediate retraining and documentation. This administrative control prevents similar incidents by ensuring equipment cannot operate during maintenance.

name: Implement Mandatory Cooldown Protocol for Injection Molding Equipment
description: Establish a standardized procedure requiring all injection molding machines to cool to safe handling temperature (below 60°C) before any manual intervention. Install temperature displays on all 32 molding machines and require operators to log cooldown times. Operators must use thermal imaging guns to verify mold temperature before removal of stuck parts. Training will be mandatory for all production staff within 5 days. This administrative control combined with engineering visibility will prevent similar thermal contact incidents by eliminating the hazard of premature hot mold contact.

name: Distribute Heat-Resistant Work Gloves and Thermal Safety Tools
description: Procure and issue specialized heat-resistant aramid-lined gloves (rated to 250°C) and insulated extraction tools with extended handles to all injection molding operators. These PPE items serve as backup protection while cooldown procedures are being implemented. Place toolkits at each molding machine station with clear labeling. Conduct brief 15-minute safety briefing on proper use. Track glove wear and replace quarterly. This engineering control and PPE enhancement creates multiple layers of protection against thermal burn hazards.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Program for Cooling System
description: Implement vibration monitoring and thermal sensors on all primary circulation pumps to detect early signs of bearing wear and failure. Install the monitoring software integrated with the maintenance management system to generate automated work orders when thresholds are exceeded. Schedule quarterly calibration checks for all sensors. This engineering control will enable early detection of pump degradation before catastrophic failure occurs, preventing unplanned shutdowns and potential safety hazards from overheated equipment.

name: Create Mandatory Preventive Maintenance Schedule and Audit System
description: Develop a formal preventive maintenance (PM) schedule for all cooling system components with specific intervals: pump inspection every 6 months, seal replacement annually, and coolant quality testing quarterly. Assign Thanh Pham (Maintenance Planner) responsibility for tracking all PM activities in the work management system. Implement monthly audits to verify compliance with the schedule. Create consequence procedures for any missed PM tasks. This administrative control ensures systematic attention to equipment health and reduces unexpected failures that could impact production and worker safety.

name: Install Secondary Coolant Circulation Backup System
description: Engineer and install a redundant, smaller-capacity cooling water pump system that can be rapidly engaged if the primary pump fails. This backup system will maintain minimal coolant circulation to critical molding machines, allowing safe controlled shutdown rather than emergency cutoff. Include automatic switchover valve and alarm notification to control room. Test the system quarterly. This engineering control provides defense-in-depth protection against pump failure consequences and ensures operational continuity during maintenance events.

name: Conduct Immediate Equipment Safety Inspection and Deburring of Storage Racks
description: Perform comprehensive visual inspection of all metal storage racks and material handling equipment in the Equipment Storage Room to identify sharp edges, burrs, or protruding fasteners. Schedule professional deburring and edge-rounding of identified hazards within 48 hours. Apply protective edge guards or tape to any remaining sharp edges that cannot be permanently removed. Document all findings and corrections. This engineering control eliminates the source hazard and prevents similar laceration incidents during routine material handling activities.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Checklist
description: A two-part verification checklist will be laminated and posted at each injection molding station. Before any maintenance, cleaning, or adjustment work, operators must physically check and initial the LOTO log confirming that all energy sources are isolated and the machine cannot be started. A supervisor must countersign. This engineering-administrative hybrid control addresses the root cause of incomplete lockout procedures by creating a physical, visible barrier to non-compliance.

name: Quarterly Compressed Air Safety Training Refresher
description: All machine operators and maintenance technicians will complete a 30-minute compressed air safety refresher training session each quarter. Training will cover: proper nozzle grip techniques, pressure limits, PPE requirements, and prohibited uses (air drying skin, etc.). Sessions will be recorded and tracked in the training database. This administrative control ensures all employees remain current on this frequently overlooked hazard.

name: Implement Computerized Preventive Maintenance Management System
description: A CMMS (Computerized Maintenance Management System) will be deployed to track all equipment maintenance schedules, parts lifecycles, and service intervals. Hydraulic hoses will be flagged for automatic replacement at 4.5-year intervals (0.5 years before end-of-life). The system will generate automatic work orders and alert supervisors 30 days in advance. This engineering-administrative control prevents schedule drift and ensures critical component replacements occur on schedule regardless of staffing changes.

name: Upgrade to Redundant Hydraulic System Design
description: The hydraulic press system will be retrofitted with dual pressure relief systems and secondary containment trays beneath all high-pressure connection points. Hoses will be rerouted or shielded where they pass near worker stations. All hydraulic fluid will be changed to a lower-temperature variant to reduce burn severity if leaks occur. This multi-layered engineering control eliminates the single-point-of-failure risk and mitigates consequences if failures do occur.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Protective Apron for Hydraulic Work
description: All employees performing hydraulic system maintenance must wear NFPA-certified heat-resistant aprons and long-sleeved Nomex shirts rated for 500°F contact. The PPE will be stored in a dedicated cabinet in the maintenance workshop and usage will be logged. While this is a PPE-level control (lower in the hierarchy), it provides immediate protection while engineering controls are being implemented. Training on proper donning procedures will be required.

name: Install Pneumatic Lift-Assist Equipment
description: Two pneumatic lift-assist platforms with height-adjustable loading surfaces will be installed in the Raw Materials Warehouse at the primary transfer points. These devices will automatically support loads between 20-30 kilograms, reducing manual lifting strain to near zero. Operators will receive 2-hour training on proper use, load positioning, and safety interlocks. This engineering control eliminates the hazard by removing the need for high-effort lifting of heavy bins.

name: Mandatory Ergonomics and Lifting Mechanics Training
description: All warehouse and materials handling personnel will complete a 90-minute ergonomics training program covering: proper lifting posture (neutral spine), load limits by body region, use of mechanical assistance, and recognition of early strain warning signs. Training will include practical demonstrations with various bin sizes and weights. Annual refresher training will be required. This administrative control ensures all employees understand proper body mechanics before attempting heavy lifts.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Systems
description: Establish and enforce a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all ventilation systems across the facility, with particular focus on areas handling volatile chemicals. This includes monthly filter inspections, scheduled replacements every 60 days in high-risk areas, and calibration of airflow monitoring equipment. Maintenance logs will be tracked electronically and reviewed monthly by the HSE Director. This addresses the root cause of reduced ventilation capacity and ensures continuous adequate airflow in chemical processing areas.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Procedures and Temperature Control
description: Relocate all chemical drum storage to the dedicated Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT area not used currently) with climate-controlled environment maintaining temperatures between 15-25°C. Install temperature monitoring sensors with automated alerts. Revise storage procedures requiring all drums to be inspected upon receipt and every 30 days thereafter. Implement drum rotation system (FIFO) and ensure secondary containment capacity of 110% for all stored quantities. Train all personnel handling chemicals on proper storage requirements.

name: Replace All Compressed Air Hoses and Implement Inspection Schedule
description: Immediately replace all compressed air hoses in UNIT-003 and conduct facility-wide audit of all pneumatic systems to identify hoses exceeding the 5-year replacement standard. Establish a color-coded system where hose installation date is marked with paint, enabling quick visual identification of age. Implement quarterly visual inspections for all compressed air distribution lines, checking for cracks, bulges, leaks, or deterioration. Create a maintenance log tracking all hoses with replacement dates clearly documented. All replacement hoses will meet ISO 1402 standards for food and medical applications.

name: Enhance Equipment Inspection Training for Production Staff
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training to all production operators on identifying deteriorated compressed air hoses and pneumatic system hazards. Training will include recognition of early warning signs (discoloration, texture changes, micro-fractures), proper reporting procedures, and understanding of high-pressure air jet injury hazards. Include case studies of similar incidents and their consequences. All operators will complete this training within 30 days and receive annual refresher training.

name: Procure Ergonomic Heat-Resistant Testing Equipment
description: Purchase specialized testing tongs with rubberized non-slip grips and extended handles (minimum 35cm length) designed for handling small plastic components at elevated temperatures. Acquire heat-resistant gloves (minimum 250°C rated) and require their use for all personnel conducting heat testing. Place equipment specifications in the Quality Control procedure manual and ensure all staff receive training on proper use. Test equipment will be inspected monthly for wear and replaced as needed.

name: Revise Heat Testing Standard Operating Procedure
description: Update the Quality Control Laboratory heat testing SOP to mandate the use of heat-resistant gloves, require the use of approved tongs (minimum handle length and grip specifications), and implement a secondary cooling station positioned to reduce transfer distance. Add a requirement for a safety briefing before each heat testing session. Establish a 'cool-down zone' with clearly marked boundaries where components must fully cool to room temperature before manual handling without PPE. Include first aid response procedures in the written SOP.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Establish a comprehensive preventive maintenance schedule for all hydraulic systems on injection molding machines. This will include weekly visual inspections for leaks, monthly fluid level and condition checks, and quarterly thermographic imaging to detect hot spots. Maintenance technicians will document all findings in a digital tracking system. The program addresses the root cause of accumulated hydraulic fluid leading to fire ignition by ensuring early detection and remediation of leaks before they accumulate.

name: Install Secondary Containment Drip Trays
description: Install secondary containment drip trays beneath all hydraulic fluid reservoirs and connection points on injection molding machines in Line D. These engineered trays will capture any leaking fluid before it can drip onto electrical panels or accumulate on the factory floor. Trays will be sized to contain 150% of the largest potential leak volume and made from chemical-resistant materials. This engineering control prevents hydraulic fluid from reaching ignition sources.

name: Enhanced Fire Safety Training for Production Staff
description: Conduct comprehensive fire safety training for all production operators, focusing on early detection of fire hazards, proper use of fire extinguishers, and alarm procedures. Training will include hands-on practice with Class B and C fire extinguishers and scenario-based drills specific to hydraulic fluid fires. All operators will be certified annually. This administrative control ensures staff can respond quickly and appropriately if signs of fire are detected before systems engage.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for CNC Equipment
description: Deploy vibration monitoring sensors and thermal imaging systems on all CNC milling machines to detect early signs of bearing degradation, misalignment, and thermal issues. Establish automated alerts when vibration signatures exceed threshold values or temperature gradients indicate friction anomalies. Data will be analyzed weekly to schedule preventive maintenance before critical failures occur. This engineering control utilizes technology to identify equipment deterioration in early stages, preventing catastrophic failures like the spindle bearing fracture.

name: Establish Bearing Maintenance and Lubrication Protocol
description: Develop a detailed lubrication schedule for all spindle bearings and drive components, specifying lubricant type, viscosity grade, application method, and relubrication intervals. Training will be provided to all maintenance technicians on proper greasing techniques and visual inspection methods to detect lubrication breakdown. Documentation will track all lubrication activities and bearing condition assessments. This administrative control ensures consistent, proper lubrication to prevent bearing degradation from inadequate lubrication as occurred in this incident.

name: Schedule Major Overhaul of CNC Spindle Assembly
description: Arrange immediate factory-authorized overhaul of the damaged CNC spindle assembly, including replacement of bearing housings, spindle shaft inspection, thermal recalibration, and full load testing. Establish a revised overhaul schedule at 6,000 operating hour intervals (reduced from 8,700) to account for the thermal cycling and stress patterns observed in the TechnoPlast manufacturing environment. This preventive substitution of worn components ensures reliable equipment performance and prevents repeat failures.

name: Install Mechanical Material Handling Equipment
description: Procure and install an electric powered material lift and tilting hopper system for the regrind operation that mechanically raises and tilts collection bins to waist height, eliminating the need for workers to bend and reach into bins. The equipment will include adjustable height settings for operators of varying statures. All operators will receive hands-on training on safe equipment operation. This engineering control eliminates the awkward postures and manual lifting forces that caused Mohamed's disc herniation.

name: Ergonomic Assessment and Workstation Redesign
description: Conduct a comprehensive ergonomic assessment of all material handling workstations in the warehousing area. Measurements will assess reach distances, bin heights, work surface heights, and material weights. Workstations will be redesigned or adjusted to maintain neutral spine posture during all routine tasks. Storage locations will be reorganized to keep frequently handled materials at waist height. This systematic engineering approach addresses the root cause of awkward postures throughout the materials handling operation.

name: Mandatory Ergonomics and Lifting Safety Training Program
description: Implement mandatory annual ergonomics training for all material handling and warehouse personnel, covering proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, recognition of repetitive strain risk, and proper use of mechanical assist equipment. Training will include practical demonstrations with actual equipment and materials used at TechnoPlast. Workers will learn to perform self-assessment of tasks and report ergonomic hazards. This administrative control ensures all staff understand principles of safe lifting and can identify hazardous work practices.

name: Implement Static Grounding Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a monthly preventive maintenance schedule for all static grounding cables and electrical connections in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. This includes visual inspection for corrosion, conductivity testing with a multimeter, and replacement of any cables showing >10% resistance increase. Assign responsibility to the Central Maintenance Workshop to maintain a log of all inspections. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause by ensuring proper electrical continuity and eliminating static discharge hazards during chemical transfer operations.

name: Conduct Chemical Handling Safety Refresher Training
description: Provide all personnel working in chemical storage and mixing areas with updated training on static electricity hazards, proper grounding procedures, and emergency response protocols. Include hands-on demonstration of correct grounding techniques before chemical transfers. This administrative control ensures workers understand the hazards and procedures to prevent similar incidents. Training to be delivered by EHS Coordinator within 2 weeks to all 12 employees with chemical handling responsibilities.

name: Upgrade to Bonded Transfer Equipment
description: Replace the current acetone transfer pump and hose assembly with equipment featuring integrated bonding lugs and self-grounding connectors rated for flammable liquid transfer. Upgrade the storage container to include a dedicated grounding stud with inspection port. This substitution control removes the reliance on external grounding cables by making proper grounding an integral design feature. Equipment sourced from certified industrial suppliers meeting CSA standards.

name: Replace All Mezzanine Storage Shelving Units
description: Replace all existing shelf units on the maintenance workshop mezzanine with new, modern shelving systems rated for 500+ lbs per shelf with clearly marked load ratings. New units must have reinforced mounting brackets with stainless steel hardware to prevent corrosion. Conduct a complete inventory audit to ensure loads do not exceed manufacturer specifications. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of failed infrastructure by replacing aged equipment with properly rated and maintained systems designed for the actual operational demands.

name: Implement Quarterly Shelf Inspection and Load Verification
description: Establish a scheduled quarterly inspection program for all storage racks and shelving throughout the facility. Inspections include visual assessment of mounting hardware, bolt tightness verification, load verification against capacity ratings, and documentation in a maintenance log. Assign responsibility to Central Maintenance Workshop supervisor. This administrative control ensures proactive identification of deterioration before catastrophic failure occurs.

name: Implement Tactile Burr Detection in Quality Control
description: Add a tactile inspection step to the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006) procedure for parts from Injection Molding Line A. All automotive line parts must be inspected using a specialized burr detection gauge and gloved hand touch assessment in addition to visual inspection. Train all QA technicians on proper technique to identify micro-burrs that may not be visible. This administrative control ensures sharp edges are detected and parts with burrs are removed from production before reaching assembly or inspection personnel.

name: Schedule Preventive Mold Maintenance on Injection Line A
description: Inspect and service the injection mold used for automotive parts, specifically the ejector pin assembly and all internal edges. Polish smooth any micro-burrs found, replace worn ejector pins, and establish a preventive replacement schedule for these components every 500,000 cycles (approximately quarterly). This engineering control addresses the root cause by eliminating the source of sharp edges through proactive mold maintenance rather than reactive quality inspections.

name: Install Complete Machine Guarding on All Conveyor Systems
description: Install ANSI-compliant perforated metal guards around all pulley mechanisms, belt drives, and pinch points throughout the assembly line. Guards will be mounted at a maximum 6mm clearance from moving parts to prevent hand insertion. All guards will feature quick-release mechanisms for maintenance access. This engineering control directly eliminates the entanglement hazard that caused the incident. Implementation will include a complete audit of all conveyor equipment in UNIT-005 and across the facility.

name: Establish Mandatory Machine Guarding Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a bi-weekly machine guard inspection checklist to be completed by assembly supervisors. Inspections will verify guard integrity, secure fastening, proper clearances, and identify any new pinch points. All findings must be documented and reported to the HSE department within 24 hours. Non-compliant equipment will be immediately tagged out of service until repairs are completed. This administrative control ensures sustained compliance with machine safety standards.

name: Conduct Intensive Machine Safety Retraining for Assembly Staff
description: Deliver 2-hour mandatory training to all 35 assembly line operators covering hazards of conveyor systems, proper ergonomic positioning to maintain safe distance from moving parts, emergency stop procedures, and incident reporting. Training will include hands-on demonstration of guard features and case study review of this incident. All participants must complete a written competency assessment with 90% minimum score. Karine Cloutier (Safety Trainer) will lead delivery with certification documentation maintained.

name: Replace Hopper Level Sensing System with Redundant Sensors
description: Install dual independent ultrasonic level sensors on all material hoppers in UNIT-016, with automatic alarm triggering at 85% capacity and feed cutoff at 95% capacity. The redundant system ensures that single sensor failure cannot cause overflow. Both sensors will transmit data to the facility SCADA system with real-time monitoring dashboard. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the spill by preventing hopper overfill conditions through automated mechanical safeguards.

name: Upgrade Ventilation and Dust Collection in Material Preparation Areas
description: Install dedicated make-up air units with HEPA filtration in UNIT-016 to handle fugitive dust from hopper operations. Add localized capture hoods above the hopper discharge points connected to a central baghouse collector. The system will maintain negative pressure in the preparation room to prevent dust migration to adjacent areas. All exhaust will be filtered before atmospheric release to comply with provincial air quality standards. This engineering control provides secondary containment of airborne particulates.

name: Implement Pallet Racking System with Load Restraint Devices
description: Replace unstable manual stacking methods with industrial-grade pallet racking system rated for 2,000 kg per shelf. Install load restraint bars, safety pins, and beams configured to prevent lateral shifting. All racks will include warning signs indicating maximum load weights and stacking height limits. Racks will be professionally installed and certified to meet CSA standards. This engineering control eliminates the falling material hazard by providing stable, engineered storage infrastructure designed for the facility's material volumes.

name: Establish Warehouse Material Handling Standard Operating Procedures
description: Develop and implement written SOP requiring that all boxes over 20 kg must be handled using mechanical equipment (hand trucks, pallet jacks, or forklifts). Maximum manual stacking height is set at 1.5 meters. Two-person manual handling is required for boxes between 15-20 kg. All receiving staff must complete competency assessments on proper stacking techniques and mechanical equipment operation. Supervisors will conduct weekly compliance audits with documentation. This administrative control ensures safe material handling practices and mechanical assistance for heavy items.

name: Implement Preventive Hydraulic System Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish and enforce a quarterly hydraulic system inspection and servicing program for all 32 injection molding machines. This includes pressure valve testing, hose integrity checks, and fluid quality analysis. Maintenance records will be tracked in the facility management system with alerts for overdue services. A certified hydraulic technician will oversee all inspections. This eliminates the root cause of the pressure relief valve malfunction by ensuring equipment is maintained per manufacturer specifications.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Pressure Relief Guards
description: Install engineered guards and secondary containment systems around all hydraulic connection points on production lines to capture any fluid discharge and direct it safely away from operators. The guards will be designed to withstand the maximum system pressure while remaining transparent for visual inspection. This engineering control prevents direct contact with pressurized hydraulic fluid in future incidents.

name: Conduct Hydraulic System Safety Training for All Operators
description: Mandatory training for all machine operators on hydraulic hazards, pressure relief system function, leak detection, and emergency response procedures. Training will include hands-on demonstration of pressure gauge readings, identification of abnormal conditions, and proper shutdown protocols. All operators must complete the training within 30 days and pass a competency assessment. Documentation will be maintained in employee training records.

name: Install Redundant Ventilation System with Automated Monitoring
description: Design and install a dual ventilation system for the Regrind and Recycling Department with automatic switchover capability. When primary exhaust fan fails, secondary system activates within 30 seconds. Both units will be rated for the department's maximum processing load. Install real-time air flow monitoring sensors connected to the facility's building management system with automatic alerts when flow rates drop below minimum thresholds. This engineering control ensures continuous ventilation even during equipment failure.

name: Establish Ventilation Equipment Lifecycle Replacement Program
description: Create a preventive replacement schedule for all HVAC equipment based on manufacturer specifications and industry standards. Exhaust fan motors will be replaced every 5 years or upon reaching 8,000 operating hours. Track all equipment installation dates and operating hours in the maintenance management system. Schedule replacements during planned maintenance windows before failures occur. This eliminates single points of failure through proactive asset management.

name: Implement Annual Forklift Operator Recertification Program
description: Establish mandatory annual recertification for all forklift operators including classroom instruction on load dynamics, stability factors, and safe turning techniques. Practical evaluation will assess operator ability to correctly load pallets, maintain center of gravity, and navigate warehouse obstacles safely. All operators must pass both written and practical exams. Documentation will be maintained with certifications renewed every 12 months. This addresses the three-year lapse in operator training that contributed to the incident.

name: Install Load Securing Systems and Capacity Controls on All Forklifts
description: Retrofit all 8 facility forklifts with automatic load-weighing systems that prevent operation if load capacity is exceeded. Install heavy-duty load securing straps on all forklift forks and require operators to secure all loads before transport. Paint clearly visible load capacity markings on each forklift and warehouse floor. Create standardized pallet placement patterns to maintain optimal center of gravity. These engineering and administrative controls eliminate unsafe load configurations and improper weight distribution.

name: Revise Production Scheduling to Eliminate Pressure-Based Speed Requirements
description: Work with production management to establish realistic delivery timelines that do not incentivize operators to bypass safety procedures. Implement a safety audit program where any observed unsafe practices do not result in individual blame but trigger process review and additional training. Communicate to all warehouse staff that no production deadline justifies compromising safety. Establish a 'safety veto' policy where any employee can halt unsafe operations without penalty.

name: Enhanced Mold Release Agent Handling Protocol
description: Implement mandatory nitrile glove replacement every 2 hours during production runs and establish designated hand-washing stations with specialized skin cleansers at each injection molding line. All operators will receive refresher training on proper PPE usage and the specific allergens in current mold release formulations. Post laminated warning signs at each station identifying mold release agents and symptoms of skin contact. Conduct monthly compliance audits and track any skin contact incidents by product line to identify patterns.

name: Install Machine-State Visual Indicators at Injection Molding Lines
description: Install high-visibility LED status lights on all 32 injection molding machines showing real-time operational states: green (running), amber (cooling/standby), red (stopped). Mount indicators at eye level on the front and side of each machine. Additionally, implement a mandatory 'machine state check' procedure where cleaning personnel must verbally confirm machine status with the operator before beginning any cleaning work. Provide laminated pocket cards to all operators and maintenance staff detailing the status light meanings and required waiting times before manual contact with mold surfaces.

name: Deploy Thermal-Protective Gloves for Maintenance Staff
description: Issue specialized heat-resistant gloves (rated to 150°C) to all operators and maintenance technicians who perform cleaning or mold-cavity work. Conduct hands-on training on proper glove selection, donning/doffing, and inspection for damage. Store gloves in accessible heat-resistant lockers at each production line and establish a quarterly replacement schedule. Enforce a visual workplace rule requiring glove visibility during any work involving mold surfaces within 30 minutes of machine shutdown.

name: Comprehensive Hazardous Waste Storage Area Redesign
description: Implement complete reconfiguration of the storage corridor: increase minimum aisle width from 1.2m to 1.8m by relocating container stacks; install high-intensity LED lighting (800+ lux) throughout the area with motion-sensor activation for safety; add bright yellow edge-protection guards and corner bumpers to all container stacks; implement clearly marked one-way traffic flow with floor-mounted directional arrows painted in high-visibility yellow. Install safety railings at all elevated storage areas and implement a new inventory management system to prevent overstocking in aisles.

name: Implement Hazardous Area Material Handler Certification
description: Develop and mandate a specialized certification program for all personnel who work in hazardous waste and chemical storage areas. The 8-hour program will cover: proper navigation techniques in constrained spaces, hazard recognition specific to the area, emergency response procedures, proper lifting and carrying techniques for heavy containers, slip/trip/fall prevention, and use of required PPE including steel-toed boots and reflective vests. Require annual recertification and conduct quarterly refresher training. Establish a competency assessment with practical demonstrations.

name: Deploy Personal Alert System for Isolated Night Shift Workers
description: Issue personal panic alert devices to all 20 night shift employees working in isolated areas including the Hazardous Waste Management Area. Devices will have two-way communication capability, GPS location tracking, and automatic alert escalation if no response within 60 seconds. Install centralized monitoring station staffed by night shift supervisor with emergency response protocols. Conduct monthly system tests and maintain audit logs of all activations. This system will ensure rapid response to incidents and falls in isolated areas.

name: Install Flammable Storage Cabinet with Grounding
description: Replace current open chemical shelving in UNIT-015 with an approved, grounded flammable storage cabinet meeting NFPA requirements. The cabinet will feature proper ventilation, automatic shutoff valves on all containers, and a concrete floor drain system for spill containment.
