All personnel handling flammable materials will receive updated training on proper storage protocols and emergency response. This eliminates the hazard of exposed flammable liquids near ignition sources and ensures compliance with provincial regulations.

name: Implement Heat Source Management Protocol
description: Establish a facility-wide policy prohibiting open flame or active pilot light heaters within 10 meters of any solvent storage or processing areas. Install electric heating systems with thermostatic controls in temperature-sensitive zones. Conduct training for all production staff on hazard recognition and alternative heating methods. Document all heat sources and create a facility map showing restricted zones.

name: Chemical Container Securing and Inspection Program
description: Implement a daily inspection checklist for all chemical storage areas requiring verification of proper container seating, cap integrity, and valve condition. Develop a container securing system using restraining straps on all shelving units. Train Materials Management staff (EMP-00034's team) on proper handling procedures and create a log for weekly audits by the HSE department to ensure compliance and identify potential risks before incidents occur.

name: Near-Miss Reporting System Enhancement
description: Establish a mandatory near-miss reporting protocol where all employees must submit incident reports within 24 hours of discovery, not just immediate occurrence. Implement a digital reporting system accessible via tablets at each workstation, incentivize reporting with recognition programs, and hold monthly team meetings to review reported near-misses. Training sessions will emphasize that near-miss reporting is essential for hazard identification and prevention culture building. Establish accountability metrics for supervisors to track and follow up on all reported events.

name: Revised Collaborative Robot Operating Procedures and PPE Requirements
description: Update all collaborative robot operating procedures to mandate the wearing of fitted lab coats or specialized work garments with snap closures (eliminating loose sleeves) during any maintenance or teach pendant operations. Install warning labels and LED status lights on all robotic equipment showing operational mode. Conduct hands-on training for all maintenance technicians on proper attire and positioning, with specific emphasis for evening and night shift staff who may receive less direct supervision. Require certification before independent robot maintenance authorization.

name: Implement Redundant Preventive Maintenance Tracking System
description: Replace the current single computerized maintenance alert system with a dual-layer system: automated email/SMS notifications plus a physical maintenance log board posted at each production line. Implement mobile barcode scanning for technicians to confirm completion of maintenance tasks in real time, with photographic evidence requirements for critical procedures like hydraulic filter changes. Establish a daily 10-minute shift handover meeting where maintenance status is verbally confirmed between day and night shift supervisors. Monthly audits by HSE will verify compliance and identify system gaps.

name: Upgrade Machine Safety Enclosures with High-Strength Polycarbonate
description: Replace all acrylic safety window enclosures on injection molding machines with impact-resistant polycarbonate rated for high-velocity projectile protection. Polycarbonate provides superior durability and will withstand mold fragment impacts without catastrophic failure. Stagger the upgrade across all 32 molding machines over 90 days, prioritizing high-tonnage machines (200+ tons) that present the greatest risk. Each upgrade includes installation of impact-absorbing frame material and periodic replacement schedule (every 5 years or upon visible damage).

name: Night Shift Maintenance Staffing and Supervision Enhancement
description: Assign a dedicated senior maintenance technician to oversee all night shift (11:00 PM - 7:30 AM) maintenance activities with explicit responsibility for verifying completion of preventive maintenance tasks before shift end. Implement a "maintenance readiness" checklist that must be signed off by both the performing technician and the shift supervisor before production resumes. Provide additional training specifically for night shift staff on critical maintenance procedures, with monthly refresher certifications. Establish peer review protocols where complex maintenance tasks require sign-off from two technicians.

name: Implement Monthly Cooling System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a formal monthly inspection schedule for all cooling water systems across production equipment. Inspections will include visual assessment for cracks, moisture accumulation, corrosion, and pressure readings. Create a checklist and training module for operators to recognize early warning signs. Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham will coordinate with equipment suppliers to obtain technical specifications and establish baseline performance parameters. This administrative control ensures early detection of developing issues before they create safety hazards or equipment downtime.

name: Replace All Aging Compression Fittings on Critical Systems
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all compression fittings on cooling water systems used in post-processing and heat treatment equipment. Prioritize replacement of fittings showing age-related degradation. Use higher-grade stainless steel fittings rated for extended service life and thermal cycling. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the detected hazard by replacing vulnerable components with more robust alternatives. Schedule replacement during maintenance windows to minimize production disruption.

name: Establish Mandatory Crane and Lifting Equipment Inspection Schedule
description: Implement a quarterly inspection program for all overhead cranes, lifting hooks, slings, and rigging equipment. Inspections will be conducted by certified personnel using detailed checklists covering structural integrity, weld condition, load ratings, and operational performance. Develop a tracking system to log all inspections and maintenance activities. Non-destructive testing methods will be used on hooks and welds showing signs of stress. This engineering/administrative control ensures early detection and replacement of degraded components before failure can occur.

name: Replace End-of-Life Lifting Hooks and Install Load Limiters
description: Immediately retire all lifting hooks that have reached 10+ years of service or show any signs of metal fatigue. Replace with modern hooks manufactured from higher-grade materials with improved fatigue resistance. Install electronic load limiters on all overhead cranes to prevent overloading beyond safe capacity. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the near-miss by replacing vulnerable legacy equipment with modern safety-enhanced alternatives.

name: Conduct Refresher Training for All Crane Operators
description: Require all current and future crane operators to complete comprehensive refresher training covering pre-operation equipment inspection, recognition of defects and hazards, safe load handling procedures, and emergency protocols. Include practical demonstration of proper inspection techniques and interpretation of load ratings. Training will emphasize the critical role of operator vigilance in preventing equipment failures. This administrative control ensures operators have current knowledge and skills to identify and respond to equipment hazards.

name: Replace All Chemical Transfer Couplings and Implement Scheduled Replacement Program
description: Immediately replace all transfer hose couplings in the chemical storage and mixing area with stainless steel couplings rated for prolonged solvent exposure. Establish a preventive replacement schedule requiring all couplings to be replaced every 5 years, regardless of apparent condition. Implement a tracking system to document installation dates and schedule replacements proactively. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of corrosion-related failures by using superior materials and implementing planned obsolescence management.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Spill Prevention System
description: Engineer and install a complete secondary containment system around all bulk chemical storage containers and transfer areas. The system will include sloped concrete surfaces sloping to a 2,000-liter capacity collection sump, with valve-controlled drain capability. Install absorbent booms and emergency spill kits strategically throughout the area. This engineering control prevents environmental release by capturing spills at the source and preventing ground and groundwater contamination.

name: Implement Automated Solvent Transfer System with Fail-Safe Controls
description: Replace manual hose transfer procedures with an automated pump-based system that includes automatic shutoff when pressure exceeds safe limits and leak detection sensors. Install continuous vapor monitoring in the chemical area with alarm thresholds. Provide operators with remote control capability to execute transfers from a safe distance. This administrative/engineering control reduces human error exposure and provides automated protection against equipment failures and overpressure conditions.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Safety Sensors
description: Establish a quarterly calibration and inspection program for all proximity sensors and safety interlocks on injection molding equipment. Maintenance records will be tracked digitally with automated alerts when calibration is due. All sensors will be tested to verify they stop machine operation when triggered. This addresses the root cause of delayed maintenance by creating accountability and preventing sensor degradation that could disable safety mechanisms.

name: Install Dual-Channel Safety Interlocks on All Molding Equipment
description: Replace single-channel proximity sensors with redundant dual-channel safety systems that require both sensors to confirm machine status before cycle initiation. This engineering control eliminates the single point of failure that allowed the machine to cycle despite the hazard. Implementation includes testing protocols and operator training on new system indicators.

name: Mandatory Machine Guarding Competency Certification
description: Require all production operators and material handlers to complete a 4-hour certification program on machine guarding, safety interlocks, and emergency stop procedures specific to injection molding equipment. Training will include hands-on identification of safety devices and practice scenarios for various failure modes. Certification must be renewed annually.

name: Install Anti-Slip Floor Mats in Mold Shop Work Areas
description: Place high-traction anti-slip mats at all wet work stations in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop, particularly around cleaning stations where water and cleaning solutions accumulate. Mats will have drainage channels to prevent standing water and will be secured to prevent tripping hazards. This administrative/engineering control directly addresses the wet surface hazard that caused the slip and hand laceration.

name: Establish Automated Ventilation System Maintenance Schedule
description: Implement a computerized preventive maintenance system that schedules filter replacements every 10 months (2 months before the 12-month standard interval) for all regrind and recycling area ventilation units. System will generate automatic work orders for maintenance team and send alerts to supervisors. Monthly visual inspections will verify damper seals and ductwork integrity. This administrative control ensures ventilation equipment remains within optimal operating parameters and prevents air quality degradation.

name: Install Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring System
description: Deploy continuous air quality monitors in the Regrind and Recycling Department that track volatile organic compound (VOC) concentrations and automatically trigger alarms when levels exceed 15% of occupational exposure limits. System will log data for regulatory compliance and alert supervisors to equipment maintenance needs. This engineering control provides early warning of ventilation degradation before worker exposure becomes hazardous.

name: Install Thermal Insulation Guards on Transfer Conveyor
description: Engineering control to prevent direct contact with heated conveyor surfaces. Install removable silicone-based thermal guards around the perimeter of the transfer conveyor belt system, particularly at worker access points. The guards will reduce surface temperature perception and create a physical barrier. Additionally, install warning signage and reflective tape at the 6-inch perimeter around the conveyor. This addresses the root cause of inadequate machine guarding and will significantly reduce burn risk for all material handlers working with this equipment.

name: Implement Mandatory Heat Hazard Awareness Training
description: Administrative control requiring all Material Handlers and warehouse staff to complete quarterly training on heat-related hazards, proper PPE usage including heat-resistant gloves, and safe work practices around thermal equipment. Training will include hands-on demonstration of proper hand positioning and distance maintenance from heated surfaces. Documentation of training completion will be maintained in personnel files and reviewed during JHSC meetings.

name: Implement Mandatory LOTO Verification Protocol
description: Critical administrative control requiring a two-person lockout verification system for all injection molding equipment. Before any production operation resumes following maintenance work, both the maintenance technician and production supervisor must independently verify all LOTO devices are properly applied using a standardized checklist. The checklist will be documented with timestamps and signatures. Additionally, install audible alarm notifications that alert personnel when LOTO compliance is not confirmed before machine startup. This directly addresses the root cause of inadequate lockout procedures.

name: Conduct Comprehensive LOTO Audit and Refresher Training
description: Immediate administrative action requiring all maintenance personnel and equipment operators to participate in comprehensive LOTO procedure audits conducted by an external safety consultant. Each employee will receive hands-on retraining on proper lockout device application, verification procedures, and emergency scenarios. Monthly LOTO audits will be conducted thereafter with results reported to the JHSC. All non-compliance incidents will result in immediate retraining and disciplinary action per company policy.

name: Install Machine Interlock Safety System
description: Engineering control involving installation of an electronic interlock system on Injection Molding Line C that prevents mold closure and material injection unless all LOTO devices are properly authenticated via a networked sensor system. The interlock will include redundant safety circuits and cannot be bypassed without management authorization and documentation. This engineering control provides layered protection independent of human compliance.

name: Replace Ladders with Non-Slip Feet and Secure Anchoring
description: Engineering control to eliminate ladder slip hazards. All mobile ladders in the facility will be replaced with models featuring heavy-duty rubber feet, stabilizer bars, and spring-loaded safety locks. All ladders will be equipped with 6-foot safety tethers for attachment to fixed structures. Ladders will be inspected monthly for condition and tether integrity. Additionally, implement designated ladder storage areas with proper maintenance protocols.

name: Establish Chemical Floor Treatment Safety Protocol
description: Administrative control establishing mandatory procedures for managing wet/slippery floors during and after chemical cleaning operations. Floors must be cordoned with caution tape and wet floor signage for minimum 4 hours post-treatment. Personnel must wear slip-resistant footwear rated for chemical exposure. Air handling systems must be fully operational to accelerate solvent evaporation. The Chemical Safety Officer will schedule floor treatments only during periods when upper storage area access is not required. A post-treatment floor friction test will be conducted before area reopening.

name: Implement Mandatory Fall Prevention and Rescue Training
description: Administrative control requiring all personnel working at heights above 6 feet to complete certified fall prevention and rescue training annually. Training will include proper ladder selection and use, balance techniques, handholds assessment, and emergency response procedures. Employees will demonstrate competency through practical assessments. Training records will be maintained and reviewed during JHSC meetings.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Cooling Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance program specifically for all cooling system components across production lines. This will include quarterly thermographic inspections of heat exchangers and couplings to detect early signs of corrosion and deterioration. Maintenance planners will implement vibration analysis and fluid quality testing to identify degradation before failure occurs. All coupling connections will be upgraded to stainless steel or high-corrosion-resistant alloys. A digital tracking system will monitor inspection dates and maintenance history to ensure no equipment is overlooked.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Heat Exchanger Area
description: Design and install a secondary containment basin beneath the primary heat exchanger on Line C with a capacity of 500 liters to capture any future leaks before they reach the production floor. The basin will include a drain valve with integrated valve to direct spilled fluid to the hazardous waste management area. Sloped flooring around the containment area will ensure fluid flows into the basin by gravity. This engineering control eliminates the risk of environmental contamination and production floor hazards from cooling fluid spills.

name: Redesign Pallet Storage Racking System with Load Limits
description: Conduct a comprehensive engineering review of the warehouse racking system to establish maximum load capacities per shelf level based on structural analysis. Install weight capacity placards on each shelf level with clear visual indicators. Implement a new storage protocol limiting stacked pallet height to three pallets maximum and requiring industrial-grade metal banding (not wooden bands) for all multi-pallet stacks. All materials will be secured with redundant strapping systems rated for 1.5 times the maximum load. New racking will include safety pin systems that prevent accidental shelf removal.

name: Mandatory Racking Inspection and Staff Training Program
description: Establish a monthly inspection protocol where all warehouse racking is visually inspected by trained personnel using a standardized checklist. All warehouse and materials handling staff will receive mandatory training on proper pallet stacking, banding techniques, and hazard identification. Training will include the recognition of moisture-compromised cardboard and the immediate action steps to stabilize or relocate unstable loads. A training certification will be required for all personnel working in warehouse areas, with refresher training every 12 months.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedure Revision and Enforcement
description: Completely revise the lockout/tagout procedures for all electrical testing activities in the instrumentation shop. New procedures will mandate de-energization and physical lockout of all circuits before ANY troubleshooting begins, with no exceptions for 'quick diagnostics.' Personnel must verify de-energization using a multimeter before touching any part of the circuit. All testing must be performed with the main breaker in the OFF position and a locking hasp applied. A certified electrical technician must be present to verify all LOTO steps before work begins. This procedure will be incorporated into the facility's ISO 45001 safety management system.

name: Install Comprehensive Equipment Enclosure Environmental Controls
description: Replace the malfunctioning humidity control system in all electrical equipment enclosures with industrial-grade desiccant systems and active dehumidifiers set to maintain relative humidity below 40%. Install moisture sensors with automatic alarm alerts if humidity exceeds thresholds. Add high-visibility warning labels on all electrical distribution panels indicating 240-volt hazards and LOTO requirements. Install insulated mats beneath all work areas where electrical testing occurs to provide additional protection against ground-path electrical hazards.

name: Implement Daily Equipment Inspection Checklist for Production Lines
description: Establish a standardized daily inspection checklist for all injection molding lines that specifically includes verification of protective covers, guards, and safety equipment. This checklist must be completed before shift start and documented in the production log. Supervisors will conduct spot audits twice weekly. The checklist will be integrated into the morning safety briefing process, ensuring all operators understand which components require verification. This addresses the root cause of the missing protective cover by creating an accountable system that catches maintenance oversights before incidents occur.

name: Install Permanent Fiberglass Material Guards with Quick-Release Design
description: Replace temporary protective covers on all Medical Components production line staging areas with engineered quick-release guards that permanently mount to the equipment frame. These guards will allow operators to access parts while maintaining protected edges for fiberglass material. The new guards will be fabricated from polycarbonate with smooth edges and will be installed on all four injection molding lines within 30 days. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of forgotten cover reinstallation by integrating safety into the equipment design itself.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Warehouse Layout and Storage Optimization Review
description: Engage an external warehouse safety consultant to audit the current layout of the Raw Materials Warehouse, including aisle widths, rack heights, storage density, and overhead clearances. The audit will specifically assess compliance with CNESST guidelines for forklift operation and material storage. Recommendations will include reconfiguration of storage racks to ensure minimum 3.5-meter aisle widths for safe forklift operation, installation of overhead protective netting to contain falling items, and implementation of a first-in-first-out (FIFO) inventory system to reduce storage congestion. Implementation must be completed within 60 days.

name: Mandatory Forklift Recertification and Collision Avoidance Training
description: All forklift operators at TechnoPlast must complete a refresher certification course focusing on collision prevention, load stability, and warehouse navigation in congested spaces. The training will include practical exercises in tight-aisle operation and decision-making scenarios. All operators must demonstrate competency in a written exam and practical assessment. Training will be conducted by an external certified CNESST trainer and completed within 30 days for all active operators. This addresses the human factors contributing to the collision.

name: Install Load Containment Systems and Overhead Protective Netting
description: Engineer and install mechanical load containment systems on all warehouse storage racks, including adjustable side barriers and front-loading restraints that prevent pallets from shifting or falling. Additionally, install heavy-duty polycarbonate protective netting or deflector bars above all forklift traffic lanes to catch any falling items and redirect them safely away from personnel. All systems must meet or exceed provincial manufacturing facility standards. Installation to be completed within 45 days by qualified contractors.

name: Redesign Chemical Storage Racks with Padded Protection
description: All metal storage racks in the chemical storage section will be retrofitted with protective edge guards and padding to prevent sharp surfaces from contacting chemical containers. Existing racks will have foam pipe insulation or rubber edge guards installed on all interior edges and corners where containers could be damaged. New storage standards will require containers to be placed on dedicated plastic pallets with rubber feet rather than directly on metal shelving. All staff will receive training on proper placement procedures. This engineering control eliminates the puncture hazard by removing the sharp contact points that caused the original leak.

name: Establish Monthly Chemical Container Inspection and Rotation Protocol
description: Implement a formalized monthly inspection procedure where all chemical containers in storage are visually examined for signs of damage, corrosion, or leakage. Containers will be rotated and repositioned during inspection to prevent long-term contact with rack edges. An inspection log will be maintained and reviewed by the HSE team. Any containers showing damage will be immediately removed from service and staged for safe disposal. This administrative control creates early detection of container integrity issues before spills occur.

name: Implement Machine Cycle Time Notification System
description: Install electronic digital displays at each injection molding machine showing real-time cooling cycle parameters. Any changes to cycle times must be logged in the system and displayed for a minimum of 24 hours before implementation. Operators must sign off on new parameters before commencing production. This addresses the root cause of inadequate communication regarding process changes. System will be integrated with the existing MES (Manufacturing Execution System) and connected to LOTO procedures.

name: Enhanced Heat-Resistant Glove Requirement for Molding Operations
description: Upgrade personal protective equipment for all injection molding operators to include mandatory Kevlar-lined, silicone-coated heat-resistant gloves rated to 300°C. Conduct fitting and training for all 32 molding machine operators. Replace gloves monthly or when damaged. This PPE measure provides immediate protection while engineering controls are being refined. Create a glove accountability log at each production line.

name: Mandatory Operator Rotation and Fatigue Management Program
description: Implement a maximum continuous machine operation period of 4 hours per operator on high-temperature processes, followed by a 30-minute break. Develop a rotation schedule ensuring no operator works more than 8 hours on injection molding lines per shift. Train supervisors on fatigue recognition and enforce compliance through shift handover documentation. This administrative control reduces human error from fatigue-related inattention.

name: Install Secondary Restraint System for Elevated Storage
description: Retrofit all warehouse shelving units above 6 feet with secondary safety restraint bars and anti-slip mesh matting. Install angle-iron lip guards on all shelf edges. Implement a maximum weight limit of 50 kg per shelf and mark all shelves with weight capacity labels. All items stored at height must be secured with ratchet straps or restraint cables. Conduct a complete audit of all elevated storage areas within 7 days. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of falling objects.

name: Warehouse Storage and Receiving Procedure Revision
description: Revise Material Handler procedures to require that all incoming deliveries be properly sorted and secured immediately upon receipt. Establish designated temporary staging areas separate from main aisles. Create a 'Receiving Checklist' that includes verification of proper shelf placement, security verification, and supervisor sign-off. Conduct monthly audits of all storage areas. Train all Material Handlers (Elif Yilmaz and Salma Haddad) on the new procedures with competency verification.

name: Replace Thermostat with Redundant Dual-Channel Temperature Control System
description: Replace the aging mechanical thermostat in RD-03 (and all other dryer units) with a modern digital proportional-integral-derivative (PID) temperature controller featuring dual independent temperature sensors. Install an independent backup safety cutoff that activates at 180°C, independent of the primary control system. The dual-sensor design ensures that a single sensor failure cannot cause runaway heating. Implement automatic alerts to maintenance staff via email and SMS when temperatures exceed 140°C. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the failure.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Thermal Equipment
description: Enroll all material drying equipment in the company's existing predictive maintenance program using thermal imaging and vibration analysis. Schedule quarterly infrared thermography inspections of all heating elements and thermal distribution systems. Create a maintenance log tracking thermostat calibration accuracy with quarterly calibration verification against a certified reference standard. Any dryer showing temperature drift greater than 3°C must be taken offline for recalibration before resuming production. This administrative/preventive control detects degradation before catastrophic failure.

name: Install Continuous Temperature Monitoring and Alarm System
description: Install networked temperature data loggers on all six material dryer units that continuously transmit data to a central monitoring dashboard accessible to shift supervisors and maintenance personnel. Configure automated alerts for conditions: 1) Temperature exceeds 160°C (warning), 2) Temperature exceeds 190°C (critical shutdown), 3) Thermostat deviation exceeds 5°C from setpoint. Create a night shift protocol requiring visual verification of dryer status every 2 hours. This administrative control provides continuous visibility into equipment health.

name: Implement Daily Chemical Storage Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory daily pre-shift inspection protocol for all chemical storage drums and transfer equipment in UNIT-010. Inspections will focus on valve integrity, spigot positioning, and drum condition. A digital checklist will be implemented using a mobile app that logs each inspection with timestamp and inspector name. Training will be provided to all personnel handling chemicals on proper valve operation and emergency response procedures. Inspections will be conducted by designated trained personnel before any transfer operations begin.

name: Upgrade Chemical Storage Drum Transfer Equipment
description: Replace existing manual drum handling carts with engineered drum handling equipment featuring automatic spigot closure mechanisms and secondary containment trays. Equipment will include drip containment with 110% capacity of largest drum volume. All new equipment will have clear operational instructions and standardized valve designs across all drum types to reduce operator confusion. Procurement and installation will be completed within 30 days.

name: Enhanced Ventilation System Upgrade
description: Install additional local exhaust ventilation in the chemical mixing area with improved air exchange rates to reach 8-10 air changes per hour. Install permanent spill containment sumps with drainage to a dedicated chemical waste tank. Add continuous air quality monitoring with alarm systems that alert personnel when vapor concentrations exceed safe levels. This engineering control will significantly reduce exposure risk during future incidents.

name: Implement Enhanced Housekeeping and Debris Management Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory hourly housekeeping schedule in UNIT-015 requiring removal of all accumulated composite dust and debris. Designated collection zones with sealed waste containers will be positioned throughout the production area. A shift-end deep clean procedure will be implemented where vacuum systems with combustible dust filters collect all fine debris. Housekeeping will be documented on a digital checklist system reviewed by supervisors. All staff will receive training on fire risk associated with debris accumulation.

name: Upgrade Electrical Control Panel Inspection and Maintenance
description: Schedule immediate comprehensive inspection of all electrical control panels in UNIT-015 by a qualified electrician. All loose connections will be tightened, and corroded connectors will be replaced. Establish a monthly preventive maintenance schedule for all control panels including thermal imaging scans to detect loose connections and overheating. Install thermal monitoring sensors on panels operating in high-dust environments. Training will be provided to maintenance staff on proper connector inspection techniques.

name: Install Automatic Fire Suppression System for Production Area
description: Install automated dry powder suppression system specifically designed for composite material fires in high-risk zones near electrical equipment. System will include automatic detection sensors and manual activation controls. Unit will be designed to suppress fires involving composite dust and synthetic resins. All personnel will receive training on system operation and limitations. Regular maintenance and inspection schedule will be established to ensure system reliability.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Ventilation Equipment
description: Establish and enforce a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all ventilation systems in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. This includes motor inspections, filter replacements, and airflow testing. Technicians will document all maintenance activities and alert management when equipment approaches end-of-life. The program will prioritize the chemical storage areas given the high-hazard nature of the work. Expected outcome: Prevention of future ventilation failures and early detection of equipment degradation before failure occurs.

name: Install Continuous Ventilation Monitoring System
description: Install real-time airflow monitoring sensors in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room that trigger automatic alerts when ventilation performance drops below acceptable thresholds. The system will be integrated with the building management system and will send alerts to both the chemical inventory specialist and facilities coordinator. Visual and audible alarms will activate at the work station when ventilation is inadequate. This engineering control will provide immediate notification of ventilation failures.

name: Enhance Chemical Exposure Response Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive training on recognizing early signs of chemical exposure (dizziness, respiratory distress, eye irritation) and immediate response protocols. All employees working in chemical storage and mixing areas will receive this training, with refresher sessions every 6 months. Training will include proper use of emergency eyewash and shower stations, evacuation procedures, and when to seek medical attention. Documentation will be maintained for regulatory compliance.

name: Install Redundant Mold Safety Interlock System
description: Replace the existing single-point safety interlock on all injection molding machines with a redundant dual-channel safety system that cannot be bypassed without formal lockout/tagout procedures and supervisor authorization. The system will include mechanical and electronic safeguards that prevent mold movement when operators are in the pinch zone. Integrate sensors that detect hand presence near pinch points and automatically prevent mold closing. All existing bypass methods will be eliminated through engineering redesign.

name: Establish Strict Lockout/Tagout Compliance Protocol
description: Implement a zero-tolerance lockout/tagout (LOTO) policy requiring that all safety interlocks remain engaged unless maintenance work specifically requires their bypass. Any bypass must be documented with a formal work order, supervisor approval, and a re-engagement checklist before equipment returns to operation. Conduct monthly audits of all injection molding equipment to verify interlock status. Maintenance personnel will receive refresher training on LOTO procedures with quarterly competency assessments.

name: Implement Electrical Panel Preventive Maintenance Program
description: Establish a quarterly preventive maintenance program for all electrical control panels, switchboards, and power distribution enclosures throughout the facility. Maintenance will include visual inspection, dust removal using compressed air and vacuum systems, moisture detection testing, and thermal imaging to identify hot spots. All electrical panels will be photographed and documented with baseline conditions. Any panels showing signs of corrosion, moisture intrusion, or temperature anomalies will be professionally serviced or replaced. Documentation will be maintained in a centralized register.

name: Upgrade Electrical Panel Environmental Controls
description: Install dedicated ventilation for the conveyor control room to maintain proper air circulation and prevent humidity and dust accumulation. Add desiccant dehumidifiers with automatic monitoring to maintain humidity levels below 50%. Install protective covers over all electrical enclosures except those requiring regular access. Upgrade the fire suppression system in the electrical room to use clean-agent suppression rather than water to protect sensitive equipment and product inventory. These engineering controls will prevent moisture and dust accumulation that triggers electrical failures.

name: Conduct Comprehensive Electrical Safety Audit
description: Hire a qualified electrical engineer to conduct a comprehensive safety audit of all electrical systems in the facility, with particular focus on control panels, power distribution, and grounding systems. The audit will identify any additional hazards, code violations, or maintenance deficiencies. Develop a remediation plan with timelines and budget allocations. Provide training to all relevant staff on electrical hazard recognition and safe work practices around electrical equipment.

name: Implement Quarterly Drum Inspection Program
description: Establish a formal quarterly inspection schedule for all hazardous material storage drums, focusing on lug wrench connections, exterior corrosion, and seal integrity. Each drum will be inspected against a standardized checklist and tagged with inspection dates. Corroded drums will be transferred to new containers immediately. This administrative control directly addresses the root cause of connection failure and establishes preventive maintenance practices to eliminate recurring spills.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Drum Storage
description: Engineer and install a secondary containment system beneath all hazardous material storage shelves in the Chemical Storage Building. The system will consist of stainless steel trays with 110% capacity of the largest stored drum, sloped toward a collection point with an isolation valve. This engineering control will prevent environmental contamination in the event of future spills and provide immediate containment. The system will be integrated with the facility's environmental monitoring protocols.

name: Enhanced Environmental Spill Response Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training for all personnel working with hazardous materials, covering spill response procedures, proper use of containment equipment, environmental reporting requirements, and notification protocols. Training will include hands-on drill scenarios conducted quarterly. This administrative control ensures personnel can respond effectively to prevent environmental migration and comply with regulatory requirements.

name: Establish Preventive Maintenance Schedule for Crane Systems
description: Implement a comprehensive preventive maintenance program for all overhead crane systems, including monthly visual inspections, quarterly load cell calibrations, semi-annual wire rope examinations, and annual load testing by certified technicians. Maintenance records will be tracked digitally with automatic alerts for upcoming services. This engineering and administrative control ensures all safety-critical sensors and components maintain proper functionality and comply with CSA B167 standards for overhead cranes.

name: Install Load Cell Status Indicator Display
description: Engineer and install a real-time load cell status display panel at each overhead crane station, showing current load, sensor status, calibration date, and alert indicators for maintenance needs. This visual engineering control provides operators immediate feedback on sensor health and creates a fail-safe reminder system for preventive maintenance intervals, reducing the risk of using equipment with degraded safety systems.

name: Install Permanent Air Hose Management System
description: Engineer and install a permanent overhead hose reel system at the Shipping and Receiving Dock that maintains all compressed air hoses above floor level when not actively in use. The system will include automatic retraction capabilities and clearly marked hose paths for active usage. This engineering control eliminates the trip hazard by removing hoses from the walking surface entirely, addressing the root cause of the incident and preventing recurrence.

name: Implement Daily Dock Housekeeping Checklist
description: Establish a mandatory daily housekeeping inspection checklist for the Shipping and Receiving Dock, conducted at the start of each shift and documented in the facility management system. The checklist will specifically address floor conditions, hose storage and routing, cable management, and spill cleanup. Dock supervisors will sign off on completion, and non-compliance will trigger immediate corrective action. This administrative control ensures consistent maintenance of a safe working environment and prevents accumulation of hazards.

name: Enhanced Fall Prevention and Slip/Trip Training Program
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive fall prevention and trip hazard awareness training for all dock personnel, including identification of common hazards, proper housekeeping responsibilities, emergency response procedures, and the importance of reporting environmental hazards. Training will include video demonstrations of incident scenarios and best practices. Annual refresher training will be mandatory. This administrative control ensures all personnel understand their role in maintaining dock safety and recognizing hazards.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a condition-monitoring program using vibration analysis and fluid sampling to detect seal degradation before failure. Install pressure sensors on all injection molding machines to alert operators of abnormal hydraulic pressure drops. Schedule preventive seal replacements every 3,000 operating hours regardless of visual condition. Provide training to all maintenance technicians on early warning signs of hydraulic component failure. Expected outcome: reduce unplanned equipment downtime by 40% and eliminate hazardous fluid leaks.

name: Install Spill Containment Trays Under Hydraulic Equipment
description: Place secondary containment trays with 110% capacity beneath all high-pressure hydraulic pump assemblies in the production area. Trays will capture leaking fluid before it reaches the floor, preventing slip hazards and environmental contamination. Stock spill kits containing absorbent pads and disposal containers at four strategic locations near molding lines. Train all production staff on proper spill response procedures including immediate area isolation and supervisor notification.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant PPE Requirement and Supply Chain
description: Implement strict mandatory use of silicone-coated heat-resistant gloves (rated to 250°C) for all personnel handling freshly molded parts within 10 minutes of extraction. Install automatic glove dispensers at all molding line workstations with weekly refill audits. Conduct daily pre-shift briefings emphasizing thermal hazard severity. Create color-coded warning tags (red) for all components exceeding 100°C. Expected outcome: eliminate thermal contact injuries and establish consistent hazard awareness.

name: Install Automated Part Cooling System with Temperature Sensors
description: Replace manual part handling with an automated conveyor system equipped with infrared temperature sensors that prevent part removal until surface temperature drops below 80°C. Implement audible and visual alarms if operators attempt to bypass the safety interlocks. This engineering control eliminates the thermal hazard at its source. Train all operators on the new system during mandatory 2-hour safety refresher sessions.

name: Establish Monthly Container Integrity Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a systematic monthly inspection program for all resin barrels and chemical containers in storage, documenting corrosion, seal integrity, and structural damage. Quarantine any drums showing visible corrosion, seam weakening, or structural compromise immediately. Use a standardized checklist and photographic documentation system. Assign responsibility to warehouse supervisors with verification by HSE staff. Train all warehouse personnel to visually identify at-risk containers and report findings within 24 hours.

name: Enhance PPE Requirements and First Aid Preparedness for Chemical Areas
description: Upgrade PPE standards for warehouse personnel to include chemical-resistant aprons, closed-toe shoes with chemical-resistant coating, and nitrile gloves rated for organic solvents. Place eyewash stations and emergency shower within 10 meters of all chemical storage areas. Stock first aid kits with chemical burn treatment supplies including sterile gauze pads, antibiotic ointment, and pain relief tablets. Conduct quarterly first aid refresher training with emphasis on chemical exposure response.

name: Implement Mandatory Pressure Relief Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive pressure relief hazard awareness training for all injection molding operators. Training will cover identification of pressure buildup signs, proper depressurization procedures, use of pressure gauges, and emergency response protocols. All Line A, B, C, and D operators will complete certification within 30 days. Annual refresher training will be mandatory thereafter. Materials will include video demonstrations, case studies from similar incidents, and hands-on practice with pressure relief procedures on deactivated equipment.

name: Install Pressure Relief Warning Labels and Signage
description: Install high-visibility warning decals and plaques on all injection molding equipment indicating pressure release hazards, safe depressurization procedures, and required PPE. Place signage at barrel assemblies, pressure release points, and access panels on Lines A through D. Signage will be bilingual (English/French) and include pictorial representations. All signs will be applied within 5 days and incorporated into the daily equipment inspection checklist.

name: Establish Mandatory Equipment Depressurization Protocol
description: Create a formal work instruction requiring all operators to completely depressurize equipment and engage lockout/tagout before any maintenance, cleaning, or clearing of blockages. Protocol will include step-by-step procedures, equipment shutdown sequence, and verification checklist. All operators must sign attestation confirming understanding. Supervisors will conduct spot-check audits monthly to ensure compliance. Non-compliance will result in documented retraining before return to equipment operation.

name: Implement Segregated Waste Storage System
description: Establish clearly marked, physically separated storage zones in UNIT-018 for (1) warm composite scrap requiring cooling, (2) solvent-contaminated materials in sealed containers, and (3) general cardboard/paper waste. Implement a cooling staging area with forced-air ventilation where hot materials must cool to ambient temperature before removal from the recycling section. Provide color-coded bins (red for solvent waste, yellow for hot composite, blue for general waste) with signage in English and French. Staff will receive training on proper waste segregation within 5 days. Supervisors will conduct daily verification audits.

name: Install Real-Time Temperature Monitoring in Recycling Department
description: Install wireless temperature sensors at three strategic points in UNIT-018 connected to a central monitoring dashboard with audible alerts if ambient temperature exceeds 32°C or local storage zone temperatures exceed 45°C. Sensors will trigger automatic ventilation system activation and alert supervisors via email/SMS. The system will log all temperature data for compliance documentation. Installation and configuration will be completed within 10 days with staff training on alert response protocols.

name: Enhance Ventilation Capacity in Recycling Section
description: Upgrade the existing ventilation system in UNIT-018 to increase air exchange rate from 4 to 8 air changes per hour in the storage/cooling zone. Install additional extraction vents at the waste segregation area. Conduct professional HVAC assessment and install supplementary exhaust ductwork as needed. All modifications must be completed within 20 days and verified by a certified HVAC engineer. Post-installation testing will confirm compliance with Quebec workplace ventilation standards.

name: Install Overhead Hoist System for Mold Handling
description: Install a 500 kg capacity pneumatic chain hoist with 4-meter coverage above Line A work stations. The hoist will be suspended from structural beams and equipped with push-button pendant controls at waist height. This eliminates manual lifting of molds over 20 kg. All operators will receive certification training on hoist operation, load securing, and safety procedures within 5 days of installation. Monthly maintenance inspections will be documented. This engineering control removes the primary hazard source.

name: Mandatory Ergonomic and Lifting Mechanics Training
description: Develop and deliver comprehensive ergonomic training covering proper lifting techniques, back injury prevention, load assessment, use of mechanical aids, and recognition of hazardous conditions. All production operators (minimum 120 employees) must complete the 2-hour interactive training module within 30 days. Training will include video demonstrations, case studies, and practical exercises. Refresher training will be required annually. Training completion will be tracked and maintained in employee records.

name: Redesign Mold Bases with Integrated Lifting Lugs
description: Modify all mold base designs in engineering to include integrated lifting lugs at the center of gravity rated for 1.5x the component weight. All new molds will meet this standard. For existing molds currently in use, retrofit lifting lugs onto the 12 most-frequently-used bases within 14 days. Provide load certification tags on each modified base. This substitution control ensures components can only be moved safely through lifting devices.

name: Enhanced Quality Control Deburring Inspection
description: Implement a mandatory secondary inspection protocol at the Quality Control Laboratory where all composite and injection-molded parts undergo tactile surface verification before release to packaging. Train Quality Inspectors to use standardized touch-testing procedures with cotton gloves to identify sharp edges, burrs, or defects. This engineering and administrative control will prevent defective parts from reaching downstream operations. Expected outcome: elimination of burr-related injuries and product quality improvements.

name: Packaging Station Safety Equipment Upgrade
description: Provide cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rating) to all Packaging and Assembly Operators and make them mandatory PPE at the Packaging and Labeling Station. Conduct a 30-minute training session on proper glove selection, donning/doffing, and inspection procedures. Install a posted checklist at each packaging workstation reminding operators to inspect incoming parts for sharp edges before handling. This administrative and PPE control adds a secondary layer of protection.

name: Cooling System Predictive Maintenance Program Enhancement
description: Implement quarterly thermographic and ultrasonic inspections of all cooling circuit couplings and lines to identify early corrosion before failure. Schedule coupling replacements on a 5-year preventive cycle instead of reactive replacement. Maintain spare couplings and quick-disconnect assemblies in inventory. This engineering control eliminates the root cause by replacing deteriorated components before leaks develop, reducing both downtime and property damage.

name: Install Automated Cooling System Leak Detection
description: Install ultrasonic leak detection sensors at three strategic locations around the injection molding lines with real-time alerts to the production supervisor's mobile device. The system triggers automatic production line shutdown if flow rate drops below 85% of baseline, preventing extended leaks. This administrative and engineering control provides early warning and automatic response, protecting infrastructure and preventing slip hazards.

name: Mandatory LOTO Procedure Enforcement with Automated Verification
description: Implement an automated lockout/tagout verification system on all injection molding machines where technicians must physically install a locking device that integrates with the machine's electrical control system and prevents any cycle start until the lock is electronically verified as removed by an authorized supervisor. Conduct mandatory re-certification training for all maintenance personnel on LOTO procedures within 5 days. Implement a zero-tolerance policy with suspension for any LOTO non-compliance. This engineering and administrative control eliminates the primary root cause by making LOTO failure technically impossible.

name: Disable Automated Machine Restart During Maintenance Mode
description: Reprogram all injection molding machine controllers to require explicit manual restart commands from the operator console after any power cycle or maintenance intervention. Install a maintenance mode switch that disables all automated cycle initiation for 30 minutes after activation. This engineering control prevents unintended machine actuation during maintenance work and adds a critical safety layer independent of human compliance.

name: Enhanced Communication Protocol for Shift Handoff
description: Establish a documented shift handoff protocol requiring the outgoing supervisor to explicitly confirm with the incoming supervisor that all LOTO procedures are in place before the day shift begins. Create a physical LOTO status board at each major equipment station showing active locks and responsible personnel. Implement a brief daily huddle at shift change where all active maintenance work is verbally confirmed. This administrative control ensures communication barriers do not compromise safety procedures.

name: Implement Secondary Containment for Chemical Storage
description: Install permanent secondary containment pallets beneath all chemical storage in the Materials Management area. These containment systems will capture 110% of the largest container volume, preventing spills from reaching floor drains or electrical equipment. All staff will receive training on proper container placement and containment inspection procedures. Monthly audits will verify compliance and equipment integrity.

name: Enhance Chemical Handling and Drop Prevention Training
description: Develop and deliver mandatory training on proper chemical container handling, including grip techniques, weight limits, and drop-prevention practices. All warehouse and production staff will participate in quarterly refresher sessions with hands-on demonstrations using dummy containers. Training will emphasize consequences of spills and proper emergency response protocols.

name: Redesign Part Removal Station Ergonomics
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessment of Line D part removal workstation and implement engineering modifications: lower work surface to proper height (30-32 inches), install padded wrist support rails, add articulating part holders to reduce repetitive bending, and position materials to minimize reaching. Install a footrest to reduce lower back strain. All modifications will be completed within 10 days and validated against ISO 11228-1 manual handling standards.

name: Enforce Mandatory Rest Break Schedule
description: Implement non-negotiable 15-minute rest breaks every 4 hours for all repetitive task operators, with designated rotation schedules posted at each station. This administrative control will be integrated into production scheduling software to prevent compression of break times. Supervisors will monitor compliance daily through sign-in sheets at break areas. Production planners will account for break time in delivery schedules to prevent scheduling conflicts.

name: Establish Ergonomic Job Rotation Program
description: Create a mandatory job rotation system where operators on repetitive tasks rotate to different workstations every 2 hours. This will distribute physical demands across different muscle groups and reduce cumulative strain on specific joints. Rotation schedules will be posted weekly and tracked in the production management system. All involved staff will receive training on proper techniques for each rotated task.

name: Replace Compromised Pressure Relief Valves
description: Replace all three corroded pressure relief valves on the main air distribution manifold with new ISO-certified units rated for 150 PSI with manual override capability. Include installation of new pressure gauges with damping systems to provide accurate readings. All work will be performed by certified technicians following ASME standards. System will be pressure-tested at 125% operational pressure before return to service.

name: Establish Predictive Maintenance Program for Compressed Air Systems
description: Implement a quarterly preventive maintenance protocol for all compressed air distribution systems including pressure relief valves, gauges, and manifolds. This will include visual inspection for corrosion, pressure gauge calibration testing, valve functionality verification, and system pressure logging. A maintenance tracking log will be maintained and reviewed monthly by the Maintenance Manager. Corroded components will be replaced on a 24-month rotation cycle regardless of condition.

name: Install Automated Deburring Station and Cut-Resistant Glove Program
description: Implement an automated deburring process for all molded parts before secondary operations. This engineering control will eliminate sharp edges at the source. Additionally, establish a mandatory cut-resistant glove (ANSI A3 rated) dispensing station at each injection molding line workstation. Conduct training for all operators on proper glove selection and inspection of parts. Monthly audits will verify compliance and effectiveness. This addresses the root cause of inadequate part finishing and insufficient PPE availability.

name: Enhanced First Aid Training and Eye Wash Station Placement
description: Conduct refresher first aid and bloodborne pathogen training for all production supervisors and line workers. Install two additional eye wash and safety shower stations on Injection Molding Line B to ensure accessibility within 10 seconds of any workstation. Post clear signage indicating locations. Update first aid kits with enhanced supplies for laceration management. This ensures rapid response capability and reduces infection risk for future incidents.

name: Mandatory Arc Flash PPE Program and Equipment Upgrades
description: Implement a comprehensive arc flash personal protective equipment program requiring all maintenance personnel to wear Category 2 arc-rated clothing, face shields, and insulated gloves when working on electrical systems above 50 volts. Conduct arc flash hazard analysis on all electrical panels and install updated labels indicating hazard levels and required PPE. Upgrade the control panel latch mechanism to a positive-locking design with tamper indicators. Provide specialized arc flash training to all maintenance staff including incident response procedures.

name: Enhanced Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Audit and Enforcement Program
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all LOTO procedures and practices at TechnoPlast. The LOTO Coordinator will implement monthly compliance audits of all maintenance work activities. Establish a documented LOTO checklist that must be completed and signed before any electrical troubleshooting. Install visible LOTO station signage at all electrical panels. Provide mandatory LOTO refresher training to all maintenance personnel. Implement consequences for LOTO non-compliance. This ensures proper energy isolation before maintenance activities commence.

name: Electrical Panel Design and Access Control Improvements
description: Replace all faulty latches on electrical distribution panels with positive-locking mechanisms that require deliberate action to open. Install key-operated covers on all high-voltage compartments accessible only to authorized electricians. Implement a computerized access log for electrical panel entry. Install advanced warning labels and reflective tape indicating shock and arc flash hazards. Upgrade the panel door interlock system to prevent operation when doors are open. These engineering controls eliminate unintended exposure to electrical hazards.

name: Implement Drum Securing and Pallet Rack Stabilization System
description: Install purpose-built drum racks with secondary containment trays capable of holding 110% of the largest container volume on the receiving dock. All drums must be secured with positive-locking straps and stored in designated locations. Implement a load securing certification program for all forklift operators, requiring demonstration of proper securing techniques before authorization. Conduct monthly inspections of all drum storage areas and securing equipment. This engineering control eliminates the primary hazard of drum tipping and chemical release.

name: Enhanced Ventilation and Vapor Detection Installation
description: Upgrade the mechanical ventilation system in the Shipping and Receiving Dock with dedicated exhaust fans and increased air exchanges (minimum 12 ACH). Install continuous solvent vapor monitoring sensors with alarm thresholds set at 25% of the LEL (Lower Explosive Limit). Connect sensors to the facility alert system to notify personnel when vapors exceed safe levels. Post emergency response procedures and evacuation routes. Conduct quarterly ventilation effectiveness audits. This ensures rapid detection and mitigation of harmful vapor accumulation.

name: Hazardous Materials Spill Response Kit and Training Program
description: Establish dedicated spill response kits at the receiving dock containing absorbent pads, oil-absorbent granules, chemical neutralizers, personal protective equipment, and biohazard waste bags. Train all warehouse and receiving personnel on spill response procedures, proper use of absorbent materials, and decontamination protocols. Conduct quarterly drills simulating chemical spills. Create a laminated quick-reference card posted at the dock. Maintain inventory and replace used materials monthly. This ensures rapid, effective response to future spill incidents.

name: Enhanced Hydraulic System Inspection Protocol
description: Implement a comprehensive monthly hydraulic system inspection program for all 32 injection molding machines, including pressure manifold visual inspection for corrosion, connection point integrity testing, and thermal imaging to detect potential failure points. Require documentation of all inspections and establish replacement thresholds for components showing 50% or greater corrosion. This addresses the root cause of deferred maintenance and provides early warning system for potential failures.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Shielding
description: Install deflector shields and secondary containment trays beneath all hydraulic connection points on injection molding machines to redirect and contain pressurized fluid releases. Additionally provide operators with reinforced heat-resistant gloves rated for 100°C contact and establish mandatory PPE requirements during any hydraulic system work. Training on proper hydraulic fluid handling and emergency response procedures will be conducted for all machine operators.

name: Hazardous Chemical Staging Area Redesign
description: Establish a dedicated, clearly marked hazardous chemical staging zone with secondary containment trays rated for 110% drum capacity, located away from electrical outlets and high-traffic forklift routes. Install fixed racking systems with chemical-resistant drum chocks and tie-down straps to prevent displacement during equipment movement. All hazardous materials must be stored in this designated area only, with signage and floor markings indicating the zone. Implement a hazmat inventory log requiring confirmation of proper storage before any chemical transfer.

name: Advanced Forklift Operator Training and Load Stabilization Certification
description: Develop and mandate comprehensive forklift operator training program covering load stabilization techniques, pressure brake application in tight spaces, and proper turn dynamics with offset loads. Require all operators to complete hands-on certification with testing on load balancing and emergency maneuvering. Establish quarterly refresher training and implement real-time telematics monitoring on all forklifts to track braking patterns and generate alerts for unsafe maneuvers. Training to be completed within 30 days for all active forklift operators.

name: Enhanced Spill Response and Emergency Ventilation System
description: Upgrade the facility's emergency ventilation system to activate automatically upon detection of volatile organic compound (VOC) concentrations above 100 ppm. Install additional extraction fans in warehouse areas and increase air exchange rate capacity by 40%. Establish a dedicated spill response kit location in each warehouse section with absorbent materials rated for isopropanol, neutralizing agents, and respiratory protection equipment. Train all warehouse personnel on spill containment procedures and establish a rapid-response team with assigned responsibilities.

name: Implement Crane Maintenance and Load-Sensing Calibration Program
description: Establish a mandatory quarterly calibration and inspection schedule for all overhead cranes and spreader bar equipment, conducted by certified technicians. Implement predictive maintenance using load-cell monitoring to detect imbalances before drops occur. All crane operators must complete refresher training on load verification procedures and emergency lowering protocols. Create a maintenance log system with automatic alerts for overdue inspections. This eliminates the equipment failure root cause and prevents future load drops.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Program for Chiller Systems
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and maintenance schedule for all coolant circulation systems, focusing on fitting integrity, corrosion monitoring, and seal replacement before failure. A maintenance technician will inspect all chiller connections using pressure testing and visual inspection protocols. Corroded fittings will be replaced proactively with stainless steel alternatives. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of unexpected leaks and extends equipment lifespan. Expected outcome: zero unplanned chiller failures within 12 months.

name: Install Secondary Containment Drip Trays
description: Install metal drip containment trays beneath all elevated coolant supply lines in the production areas. Trays will be sized to capture 150% of maximum line volume and equipped with drain valves for controlled disposal. This engineering control prevents coolant from reaching the production floor and contaminating finished goods during minor leaks. Trays will be inspected monthly for accumulation and proper function. Expected outcome: containment of 95% of potential coolant spills within the first 6 months.

name: Install Load Capacity Labels and Weight Distribution Guides on All Storage Racks
description: Affix permanent labels to each shelf indicating maximum weight capacity, recommended load distribution patterns, and diagrams showing proper bin placement. Labels will specify that heavier items must be stored on lower shelves and lighter items on upper shelves. Laminated weight distribution guide cards will be posted at each warehouse entrance. This administrative control ensures all warehouse personnel understand capacity limits and proper loading procedures. Materials Supervisor Valérie Pelletier will conduct monthly audits to verify compliance with labeling standards. Expected outcome: elimination of improper loading practices within 30 days.

name: Implement Mandatory Strapping and Securing Protocol for High Shelves
description: Require that all bins stored on shelves above 1.5 meters height must be secured with industrial strapping or clips to prevent tipping. Materials handlers will be trained on proper strapping techniques during monthly toolbox talks. Inspections will be conducted weekly to verify all high-shelf items are properly secured. This engineering and administrative control prevents bins from tipping or falling regardless of loading errors. Expected outcome: zero falling object incidents from storage racks within 12 months.

name: Install Automated Mold Temperature Monitoring System
description: Replace manual temperature gauges with real-time digital monitoring systems on all 32 injection molding machines. System will include audible and visual alarms if mold surface temperature exceeds 125°C. Integration with machine control systems will automatically shut down equipment if temperature threshold is exceeded. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the incident—sensor malfunction—and prevents future thermal injuries. Expected outcome: 100% prevention of temperature-related mold burns.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Protocol for Part Removal
description: Implement mandatory use of silicone heat-resistant gloves (rated for 200°C+) for all part removal operations on injection molding lines. Update Standard Operating Procedures to require glove inspection at start of each shift and replacement every 30 days. Include this requirement in daily toolbox talks and monthly safety training. Conduct competency assessments during next safety audit cycle.

name: Enhanced Mold Temperature Sensor Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish predictive maintenance program for all mold temperature sensors with monthly calibration checks and quarterly replacement schedule. Maintenance technicians will log all sensor readings in digital tracking system. This administrative control ensures early detection of sensor drift and prevents recurrence of temperature control failures.

name: Install Secondary Containment Barriers for Acetone Transfers
description: Install hinged polycarbonate protective barriers around all acetone transfer stations to shield operators from splash hazards during pouring operations. Barriers will be positioned 45 degrees to redirect potential splashes away from operator body. Material must be compatible with acetone exposure. This engineering control prevents direct skin contact during chemical handling operations.

name: Implement Chemical Transfer Standard Operating Procedure
description: Develop detailed SOP for all solvent transfer operations specifying: (1) use of funnels with anti-splash design, (2) transfer procedures requiring low flow rates, (3) designation of transfer zones with restricted access during operations, (4) mandatory buddy system for all chemical transfers. Training on new SOP will be delivered to all chemical handling staff within 5 working days.

name: Install Motion-Activated LED Lighting in Warehouse Aisles
description: Install motion-activated LED lighting fixtures (5000K, 500+ lumens) throughout all warehouse aisles, particularly in section A and around blind corners. Lighting will activate when movement is detected, improving visibility for both forklift operators and pedestrians. This engineering control addresses root cause of inadequate visibility and prevents future collision near-misses.

name: Implement Pedestrian-Forklift Separation Protocol
description: Designate pedestrian-only aisles separate from forklift traffic lanes in Raw Materials Warehouse using painted floor markings (yellow and white) and signage. Create one-way traffic pattern for forklifts with mandatory horn sounding at aisle intersections. Establish policy that inventory staff must use designated pedestrian routes and conduct visual sweeps before entering traffic zones. Include protocol in next monthly JHSC meeting.

name: Require Proximity Detection Backup Alarm on All Forklifts
description: Retrofit all 12 propane forklifts with ultrasonic proximity detection systems that emit progressive warning tones when objects or personnel approach within 2 meters of the rear or sides of the vehicle. Sensors must be certified for industrial warehouse environments and require monthly testing. This engineering control provides additional protection against operator blind spot incidents.

name: Install Thermal-Resistant Part Handling Gloves and Extraction Tools
description: Procure and distribute heat-resistant nitrile-coated gloves rated to 180°C for all operators on injection molding lines. Additionally, implement silicone-tipped part extraction tools to reduce direct hand contact with hot components. Operators will be trained on proper use during mandatory machine setup refresher training. Expected outcome: elimination of direct thermal contact hazards during part removal operations.

name: Establish Cooling Time Protocol and Machine Labeling
description: Implement a standardized cooling time checklist posted on each molding machine indicating minimum cooling periods before safe part removal (typically 45-60 seconds for automotive parts). Add visual countdown timers to each press and require operators to wait for 'Safe to Handle' indicator before commencing extraction. Document protocol in updated Standard Operating Procedures and reinforce during daily toolbox talks.

name: Install Mechanical Bag Lift Assist Systems
description: Purchase and install four pneumatic bag lift assist stations in the Material Drying and Preparation Room, capable of raising 50-pound bags to shoulder height with minimal operator effort (less than 15 pounds of lifting force required). Each station will feature safety interlocks and ergonomic positioning. Operators will receive hands-on training on proper use. This engineering control eliminates the hazard of manual lifting of heavy bags and is expected to reduce back injury incidents by 80%.

name: Implement Mandatory Ergonomics Training and Work Rotation
description: Develop and deliver a comprehensive ergonomics training program covering proper lifting techniques, body mechanics, and load assessment. Institute a mandatory 2-hour rotation policy: material handlers will rotate between drying room duties, packaging tasks, and lighter administrative work every 2 hours to prevent repetitive strain. Create a revised Material Handling SOP incorporating these rotations. Train all supervisors on enforcement and monitoring compliance.

name: Establish Post-Incident Medical Support and Return-to-Work Program
description: Develop a structured return-to-work program for Hassan Diallo involving occupational therapy consultation, progressive duty assignments starting at 25% capacity, and weekly medical check-ins. Coordinate with company insurance and occupational health provider. Document all accommodations in Hassan's personnel file. This administrative control ensures proper recovery and reduces re-injury risk upon return to full duties.

name: Implement Mandatory De-Energization Protocol for Electrical Work
description: Revise electrical maintenance procedures to require lockout/tagout (LOTO) of all circuits before any work, including diagnostic activities, even if traditional protocol previously allowed live work. Install new signage on all electrical panels stating 'De-energize before touching terminals.' Update the Electrical Safety Standard Operating Procedure and provide mandatory retraining to all technicians within 5 days. This administrative control eliminates the risk of accidental electrical contact by ensuring circuits are physically isolated.

name: Implement Automated Temperature Monitoring System
description: Install real-time temperature sensors with automated alert systems on all injection molding lines (A, B, and future lines). The system will monitor barrel temperature, cooling water outlet temperature, and mold surface temperature continuously. Alerts will trigger at 250°C (warning) and 270°C (critical shutdown). This engineering control eliminates the reliance on manual checks and prevents thermal runaway conditions. Expected outcome: 100% reduction in temperature-related near-misses and burns within 90 days of implementation.

name: Enhanced Cooling System Inspection Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily visual and pressure-gauge inspection of cooling water systems before each shift. Create a checklist documenting hose condition, connection tightness, and system pressure. Maintenance technician will conduct weekly pressure tests to detect micro-leaks before they become hazardous. Logs will be reviewed weekly by Operations Manager Guillaume Deschamps (EMP-00051). This administrative control ensures early detection of cooling system degradation and reduces thermal incidents by 80%.

name: Install Secondary Containment System for Chemical Storage
description: Install engineered secondary containment trays beneath all mold release agent storage and staging areas. Containment capacity will be 110% of the largest single container (22+ liters). This engineering control prevents ground contamination and reduces cleanup time for future spills. The trays will have sloped surfaces directing any spillage to a collection sump for proper disposal. Expected outcome: containment of 100% of potential spills from container breakage or overflow, eliminating environmental release.

name: Mandatory Container Cap Verification Procedure
description: Implement a two-person verification system for all chemical container transfers.
