This administrative control ensures early detection of sensor degradation before failure occurs. Training will be provided to all operators on recognizing sensor malfunction indicators.

name: Mandate Full-Face Shield and Goggles for All Chemical Handling Tasks
description: Update the Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) requirements policy to mandate dual-layer eye protection: ANSI-rated safety glasses plus a full-face shield with chemical-resistant coating for all personnel handling concentrated epoxy, resins, and hazardous chemical compounds. Issue new face shields to all 45 employees in chemical operations and maintenance departments. Conduct a 30-minute refresher training session explaining the specific hazards of epoxy spray and the superior protection offered by full-face coverage. Create visual signage at all chemical workstations showing mandatory PPE requirements. This engineering/PPE control reduces injury severity even if exposure occurs.

name: Implement Sealed Chemical Storage Cabinet with Automated Inventory System
description: Install a new climate-controlled sealed storage cabinet in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room equipped with integrated humidity monitoring and temperature control (18-22°C, 40-50% RH). All chemical containers will be stored in this cabinet with lids properly sealed and secured. Implement a barcode-based inventory tracking system requiring operators to log all chemical withdrawals and returns. This will prevent unauthorized container storage in unsecured areas and degradation of container seals. Administrative training will emphasize that any chemical container removed from proper storage must be returned within the same shift with verification by a supervisor.

name: Monthly Chemical Safety Audits and Corrective Action Verification
description: Establish a formal monthly chemical safety inspection program where the Chemical Safety Officer will audit 100% of chemical storage practices, PPE compliance, and SOP adherence in the Chemical Storage building. Document findings using a standardized checklist and track corrective action completion rates. Share audit results at monthly JHSC meetings. Create a 'Chemical Safety Champion' recognition program for shifts with zero non-compliance findings. This administrative control creates accountability and continuous improvement in chemical handling practices across all shifts.

name: Replace All Worn Lifting Lugs and Implement Quarterly Inspection Protocol
description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of all injection molds in the workshop and identify those with damaged or worn lifting lugs. Replace 23 non-compliant molds' lugs with new heavy-duty stainless steel lugs rated for 1.5x the mold weight. Establish a quarterly inspection schedule where all lifting lugs are visually examined for cracks, bending, or corrosion. Any lug showing more than 10% wear will be immediately replaced before the mold returns to production. Create a maintenance log attached to each mold documenting lug inspection dates and replacements. This engineering control eliminates the primary cause of the slip-and-drop hazard.

name: Mandatory Spotter Protocol and Load Path Safety Zones
description: Implement a mandatory 'no personnel under suspended loads' administrative control requiring a certified spotter to be present for all mold lifting operations. The spotter must be positioned with clear visibility of the load path and will use hand signals to direct the hoist operator. Paint bright yellow floor markings in a 2-meter radius beneath all workshop hoists indicating 'Load Drop Zone—Keep Clear.' Train all night-shift maintenance personnel (Louis, and others) on the spotter role, hand signal protocols, and positioning requirements. Require competency verification through a brief practical assessment before personnel can perform solo mold handling.

name: Implement Mandatory Predictive Maintenance Schedule for Pressure Relief Valves
description: Establish a quarterly inspection and testing protocol for all pressure relief valves on injection molding equipment, with documented certification required before equipment operation. This includes thermal imaging to detect valve degradation, functional pressure testing at 110% rated capacity, and replacement of any valves showing wear patterns. All maintenance technicians will receive certification training on pressure system diagnostics. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of valve malfunction and ensures preventive detection before failure occurs.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Line C Operations
description: Issue high-temperature resistant gloves (rated to 500°C) and arm guards to all operators working on Injection Molding Line C. Implement a mandatory PPE check-in/check-out system with replacement gloves available every shift. Conduct training on proper donning and inspection procedures. While not addressing the root mechanical failure, this administrative and PPE control provides essential interim protection while the predictive maintenance program is established.

name: Install Automatic Spill Containment Sensors and Secondary Containment Upgrade
description: Replace existing open-top secondary containment with sealed containment system featuring level sensors that trigger automatic alerts when liquid depth exceeds 15 cm. Install drip pans beneath all chemical storage containers with drain valves connected to a closed collection system. Implement monthly inspections of all drain lines and valve connections. This engineering control prevents future environmental contamination by containing spills at the source and enabling rapid response detection.

name: Establish Monthly Chemical Storage Container Valve Inspection Program
description: Develop a detailed inspection checklist for all hazardous material storage containers, focusing on valve corrosion, seal integrity, and outlet condition. Assign material handlers Hassan Diallo and Marwa Saleh to conduct inspections on the first Monday of each month, documenting findings in a maintenance log. Replace any corroded valves immediately and maintain a spare valve inventory for rapid replacement. This administrative control ensures early detection of valve degradation before catastrophic failure.

name: Enhance Ventilation System in Chemical Storage Building
description: Upgrade the exhaust ventilation system to achieve 8 air changes per hour in the chemical storage area, exceeding current ANSI Z9.2 minimum standards. Install real-time volatile organic compound (VOC) monitors in storage and adjacent areas with automatic ventilation boost when thresholds are exceeded. This engineering control addresses inhalation hazard exposure during spill response and normal operations.

name: Install Enhanced LED Inspection Lighting at Quality Control Workstations
description: Replace the existing fluorescent lighting system in the Quality Control Laboratory with high-intensity LED task lighting (minimum 1000 lux at work surface) with color temperature of 5000K for accurate component surface evaluation. Install adjustable LED ring lights around each inspection station to eliminate shadows and provide glare-free illumination of all edge surfaces. This engineering control directly eliminates the root cause by ensuring sharp edges are visually detected during night shift operations.

name: Implement Mandatory Cut-Resistant Gloves for All Quality Control Personnel
description: Issue cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A3 or higher) to all staff handling molded components with unfinished edges. Include proper glove donning training and conduct weekly inspections for glove degradation. Maintain spare glove inventory at each QC workstation. While this is a PPE control (lower hierarchy priority), it provides essential interim protection while deburring process improvements are implemented.

name: Enhanced Edge Deburring Protocol Implementation
description: Implement mandatory secondary edge finishing process for all medical device components using pneumatic micro-grinders with 400+ grit sanding drums. Quality Control Technician Léa Parent will develop a checklist verifying all sharp edges are smoothed to ISO 13485 standards before component release. Training will be provided to all assembly operators on identification of unacceptable edge conditions. Monthly audits will verify compliance with visual and tactile inspection methods.

name: Supply Cut-Resistant Gloves to All Assembly Operators
description: Procure ANSI Level 3 cut-resistant nitrile gloves for all assembly workstations. These gloves provide superior protection against sharp plastic edges while maintaining dexterity for precision part handling. Issue gloves in multiple sizes to ensure proper fit. Conduct training on proper glove selection and usage. Budget includes initial inventory of 500 pairs and replacement stock for 6 months.

name: Implement Hydraulic System Hose Inspection and Replacement Schedule
description: Establish quarterly inspection protocol for all cooling water system hoses in injection molding machines. Replace hoses showing signs of degradation, discoloration, or brittleness. Create maintenance log documenting all inspections and replacements. Maintenance staff will be trained to identify compromised hose material. All hoses will be stored in climate-controlled environment away from direct sunlight. Expected outcome: elimination of pressure-related coolant system failures.

name: Install Secondary Containment and Improved Emergency Response Equipment
description: Install secondary containment trays beneath all injection molding machine cooling systems to capture leaks before they spread. Upgrade emergency eyewash stations with heated water circulation and increase accessibility with signage. Conduct refresher training for all equipment operators on emergency response procedures including immediate shutdown protocols and proper use of eyewash facilities. Install temperature-controlled storage cabinet for replacement hoses.

name: Install Safety Railings and Anti-Slip Treads on All Mezzanine Ladders
description: Install fixed safety railings on both sides of the mezzanine access ladder and add slip-resistant treads to all steps. Upgrade lighting in the storage mezzanine to 500 lux minimum using LED fixtures. Create clear procedural guidance prohibiting personnel from carrying materials that obstruct vision while climbing. Install grab handles at ladder access points. Expected outcome: elimination of ladder fall hazards through engineering controls.

name: Establish Material Handling and Ladder Safety Training Program
description: Develop mandatory quarterly training module covering proper ladder climbing techniques, load carrying restrictions, and awareness of environmental hazards. Training will include practical demonstration of three-point contact climbing method and emphasis on making multiple trips for materials rather than overloading. All warehouse personnel and maintenance staff must complete certification. Training Coordinator Amélie Roy will coordinate delivery and maintain compliance records.

name: Install Mechanical Material Hoist System for Mezzanine Storage
description: Purchase and install electric chain hoist system on mezzanine to eliminate manual carrying of heavy material containers up ladders. The system will include pulley arrangement and safety cutoffs. This eliminates the root cause by removing the need for employees to carry loads while climbing. Maintenance staff will be trained on safe hoist operation and load capacity limitations.

name: Implement Comprehensive Mold Safety Interlock Testing Program
description: Establish a mandatory weekly testing protocol for all 32 injection molding machine safety interlocks, replacing the previous monthly schedule. Each interlock will be tested with calibrated equipment to verify solenoid response time and holding force. Testing logs will be maintained electronically with automated alerts for overdue inspections. Maintenance technicians will receive certification training on proper testing procedures and fault diagnosis. This eliminates the root cause of equipment malfunction that led to the crushing incident.

name: Install Dual-Channel Safety System on High-Risk Molding Machines
description: Retrofit the 15 largest injection molding machines (200+ tons) with redundant safety interlock systems meeting ISO 13849-1 Performance Level d. Each machine will have independent solenoid-based locking mechanisms that must both release simultaneously to allow mold opening. If one channel fails, the machine automatically enters safe state. This engineering control prevents single-point failures from causing injuries. Installation will be phased over 45 days with manufacturer support.

name: Mandatory Machine Safety Refresher Training for All Operators
description: Conduct required 4-hour retraining for all 87 production operators covering mold safety protocols, emergency stop procedures, and proper part removal techniques. Training will include case studies of similar crushing incidents and hands-on practice with machine interlocks. Competency will be verified through practical assessment. All operators must recertify annually. This addresses the human factors aspect and reinforces safe work practices across all shifts.

name: Complete Roof Integrity Assessment and Repair
description: Conduct comprehensive roof inspection of the entire Warehouse and Shipping building (35,000 sq ft) by a certified roofing contractor. Identify and repair all leaks, damaged flashing, and compromised seals. Install additional roof drains in Section C where the incident occurred. Apply protective sealant coating to extend roof lifespan. This eliminates the source of water intrusion preventing future environmental contamination. Work will be completed within 14 days.

name: Install Environmental Monitoring and Early Detection System
description: Deploy moisture sensors and humidity monitoring equipment in all raw material storage areas of the warehouse. Install automated alert system that notifies maintenance staff when humidity exceeds 65% or temperature drops below 10°C. Establish daily monitoring logs reviewed by the HSE department. Install raised storage platforms in warehouse sections to improve drainage and prevent water pooling. This administrative and engineering control enables early detection of environmental hazards.

name: Upgrade Personal Protective Equipment for Deburring Operations
description: Replace existing safety glasses with high-impact polycarbonate safety goggles featuring side shields and indirect ventilation for all finishing operators. Implement requirement for full-face protective shields when working with fiberglass-reinforced materials. Provide training on proper PPE fit and maintenance. Inspect and replace goggles every 12 months or when damaged. This engineering control reduces eye injury risk by 95% based on ANSI Z87.1 standards.

name: Evaluate and Replace Abrasive Brush Specification
description: Conduct material testing on the current abrasive brush product used for deburring medical device components. Work with supplier to identify brush design that minimizes bristle shedding and fiber fragmentation. Implement use of enclosed deburring stations or dust collection systems to capture dislodged particles. Trial new brush specifications on non-critical parts first. Transition entire deburring operation to improved brushes within 30 days. This addresses the root cause of fiberglass fragment release.

name: Hydraulic System Pressure Relief Valve Inspection Program
description: Implement quarterly inspections of all hydraulic line connections and pressure relief systems on injection molding equipment. Maintenance technicians will check for corrosion, wear, and pressure seal integrity. Replace any degraded lines proactively before failure. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of pressurized fluid discharge and prevents future injection injuries. All findings will be documented in the predictive maintenance system.

name: Hydraulic Fluid Exposure Safety Training Refresher
description: Conduct mandatory 30-minute training session for all production operators covering hydraulic fluid hazards, symptoms of injection injuries, and first aid response protocols. Emphasize never reaching into pressurized line areas and proper use of inspection mirrors/tools. Training will be documented and repeated annually with all new hires receiving it during orientation.

name: LOTO Compliance Audit and Equipment Signage Enhancement
description: Conduct comprehensive audit of all LOTO procedures and equipment across the facility. Install high-visibility warning signs on all secondary disconnect switches indicating their criticality to lockout procedures. Implement a checklist system requiring maintenance personnel to physically verify the position of ALL energy isolation points before beginning work. The audit will identify gaps in current procedures and ensure consistency across all shifts and equipment types.

name: Shift Handover LOTO Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory shift handover procedure where the outgoing maintenance supervisor verbally confirms with the incoming supervisor that all LOTO devices are properly secured and all equipment switches are in the correct OFF position. This administrative control creates accountability and ensures continuity of safety practices across shift changes, preventing oversights like the missed secondary disconnect lock.

name: Electrical Safety Training for Maintenance Staff
description: Require all maintenance technicians to complete NFPA 70E electrical safety certification renewal training within 30 days. Focus modules on arc flash hazards, proper LOTO application for multi-point energy isolation, and recognition of electrical hazards. Include practical exercises using actual equipment in the facility to demonstrate correct procedures and common failure points.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System in Chemical Storage Building
description: Install a dedicated mechanical ventilation system with HEPA filtration in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building to ensure air changes meet Quebec environmental standards (minimum 8 air changes per hour). System will include emergency exhaust vents and vapor detection sensors that trigger automatic shutdowns when chemical concentrations exceed safe thresholds. This engineering control directly addresses the root cause of inadequate fume evacuation during the spill.

name: Implement Pallet Securing Audit and Procedure
description: Establish a daily inspection protocol for all forklift-transported pallets, including verification of strap tension, load balance, and container integrity. Introduce redundant securing mechanisms (dual straps rated for 1.5x load weight) and require photographic documentation before transport. Train all forklift operators on proper load securing techniques through monthly safety refresher sessions. This administrative control prevents recurrence of strap failures.

name: Install Secondary Containment Berms
description: Install permanent steel-reinforced containment berms around all hazardous chemical storage areas with capacity to hold 110% of the largest single container. Line berms with impermeable polypropylene membrane rated for chemical resistance. This engineering control will prevent future spills from spreading and contaminating adjacent areas, reducing environmental impact.

name: Install Automatic Cool-Down Interlocks
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with electronic interlocks that prevent part ejection until the cool-down cycle has completed. These mechanical engineering controls cannot be bypassed or disabled without documented maintenance authorization logged in the CMMS system. The interlocks will enforce compliance with safety protocols and eliminate operator ability to circumvent cool-down periods regardless of production pressure.

name: Mandatory Thermal Glove Use and Inspection Program
description: Issue heat-resistant Kevlar-lined gloves (rated to 250°C) to all production operators working with molding equipment. Establish a monthly inspection and replacement protocol for damaged gloves. Create a visual inspection checklist at each machine station. This PPE control provides immediate protection while engineering controls are being implemented, and should be maintained as a secondary layer of protection.

name: Enhanced LOTO Documentation and Verification System
description: Implement a mandatory digital LOTO tracking system where all machine guards removed during maintenance must be photographed, timestamped, and logged in real-time. Require a secondary verification signature from the Maintenance Manager before work begins on de-guarded equipment. Create a visual alert system (red tags with maintenance ticket number) that must be attached to any machine with guards removed. This administrative control ensures accountability and prevents untracked guard removal.

name: Replace Cooling Line with Reinforced Hoses and Fittings
description: Replace the existing single-wall cooling lines on Injection Molding Machines #8-#14 with high-pressure rated dual-wall hoses and stainless steel fittings rated for 350 PSI. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of brittle connection failures due to thermal cycling and corrosion. The reinforced system will include pressure relief valves at critical junctures. Expected outcome: elimination of cooling line failures in this production area, improved equipment reliability, and enhanced environmental protection.

name: Implement Monthly Cooling System Pressure Testing and Documentation
description: Establish a scheduled preventive maintenance protocol requiring monthly pressure testing of all cooling lines and documentation in the maintenance management system. Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand will conduct tests using calibrated pressure gauges and record baseline pressures. Any deviation >5% from baseline triggers immediate inspection and replacement. This administrative control ensures early detection of deterioration before catastrophic failure occurs.

name: Install Redundant Electronic Backup Valve Control System
description: Retrofit the composite material mixing equipment with a dual-channel electronic backup valve control system featuring independent sensor arrays and solenoid valves. This engineering control ensures that if the primary temperature sensor fails, the secondary system automatically engages mechanical lockdown, preventing uncontrolled discharge. The system will be integrated with the facility's SCADA monitoring network to provide real-time alerts to operators and maintenance staff. This eliminates the single-point-of-failure vulnerability.

name: Establish Quarterly Backup System Certification and Testing Program
description: Automation Technician Aya Tanaka will implement a mandatory quarterly inspection, functional testing, and certification program for all emergency discharge valve backup systems on composite processing equipment. Each backup valve will be physically exercised, pressure tested, and cleaned. Documentation will be maintained in a centralized maintenance log with photographic evidence. Any corroded or non-responsive components will be immediately replaced. This administrative control ensures redundant systems remain functional and operational.

name: Provide Intensive Machine Emergency Response Training for Evening Shift
description: Conduct comprehensive training for all evening shift operators on the composite mixing equipment, focusing on emergency shutdown procedures, manual valve operation, and spill containment. Training will include hands-on practice with the mechanical backup valve under supervision of the Chemical Safety Officer. Participants will receive certification cards and must complete refresher training annually. This ensures rapid and effective operator response during equipment failures.

name: Install Physical Interlock Gate on Regrind Hopper
description: Engineer and install a mechanical interlock gate at the hopper entrance of the regrind shredder that physically prevents feed roller activation when the gate is opened. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of unexpected machine startup during manual material clearing. The interlock will be integrated with the existing emergency stop system and require two-step activation (gate closure + button press) to resume operation. This removes the reliance on faulty proximity sensors for critical safety functions.

name: Mandatory LOTO Training and Certification for All Night Shift Equipment Operators
description: Safety Officer Anh Nguyen will conduct intensive lockout/tagout training for all night shift personnel, emphasizing the specific requirements for the regrind shredder and other equipment in Section C. Training will cover proper sensor bypass procedures, tag placement, energy isolation verification, and the absolute prohibition on manual intervention without full equipment isolation. All personnel will be required to demonstrate competency through practical testing and will receive certification. Refresher training will occur semi-annually.

name: Implement Daily Proximity Sensor Functionality Verification Protocol
description: Establish a mandatory daily pre-shift verification process where operators must test each proximity sensor on the regrind equipment using a test card before beginning operations. Any sensor failing the test must be tagged out-of-service and reported immediately to Maintenance Planning. A centralized log will track all sensor testing and repairs. This administrative control ensures malfunctioning sensors are identified and corrected before creating safety hazards.

name: Implement Monthly Pressure System Inspections
description: Establish a mandatory monthly inspection and testing protocol for all hydraulic pressure relief valves on injection molding machines. Create a dedicated checklist requiring verification of valve response time, pressure accuracy within ±5%, and visual inspection for leaks or corrosion. This will be performed by certified maintenance technicians during scheduled maintenance windows. Documentation will be tracked in the maintenance management system with photo evidence of each inspection.

name: Install Pressure Line Heat Shields and Guards
description: Engineering retrofit of all high-temperature hydraulic lines on Molding Lines A, B, and C with insulated heat shields and protective guards to prevent direct contact with pressurized hot fluids. This engineering control will reduce the risk of thermal burns by 90%. Installation includes reinforced stainless steel guards positioned 6 inches from operator work zones and reflective insulation wrapping on all lines exceeding 60°C.

name: Enhanced Operator PPE Requirements
description: Mandate use of flame-resistant aluminized gloves rated for 400°C contact and flame-resistant sleeves for all machine setters and operators working with injection molding equipment. Update the PPE policy to require inspection of heat-resistant gloves before each shift and replacement every 60 days. Conduct training session within 5 days to ensure proper donning, doffing, and care procedures.

name: Install Adjustable Height Retrieval Shelving
description: Replace fixed-height shelving in UNIT-008 with adjustable-height mobile shelving units that allow all frequently accessed materials to be stored between 30 inches and 60 inches from ground level, eliminating the need for overhead reaching beyond safe height parameters. Each unit will include lockable wheels and anti-tip mechanisms. This engineering control directly addresses ergonomic strain from excessive reaching and falling object hazards.

name: Mandatory Ergonomic Training for Warehouse Staff
description: Conduct comprehensive ergonomic assessment and training for all warehouse personnel, covering proper lifting techniques, load limits based on individual capability assessments, and workstation ergonomics. Alain Mercier, Ergonomics Specialist, will lead a 2-hour interactive session for each shift covering body mechanics, recognition of early strain symptoms, and reporting procedures for discomfort. Training will be completed within 10 days with documented attendance.

name: Install Automated Ventilation Monitoring System
description: Install real-time air quality and airflow monitoring sensors in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility that continuously measure air exchange rate, particulate levels, and chemical vapor concentrations. The system will trigger automatic alerts when parameters fall below 80% of design specifications and will log data for trend analysis. Alert thresholds will trigger audible/visual warnings and automatic area evacuation procedures if levels exceed safe limits.

name: Implement Pre-Shift Ventilation Verification Checklist
description: Establish a mandatory pre-shift verification checklist that chemical operators must complete before beginning mixing operations. The checklist includes visual inspection of ventilation hoods, verification of audible airflow sound, measurement confirmation using a handheld airflow meter at designated checkpoints, and documentation of readings. Any readings below 90% of expected baseline must trigger maintenance notification and delay of operations until corrected.

name: Increase Filter Replacement Frequency
description: Reduce the ventilation system filter replacement interval from quarterly to monthly based on the clogging incident observed. Establish a preventive maintenance schedule with automatic ordering system to ensure filters are available. Each filter change will be documented with date, time, visual condition assessment, and new filter installation verification by maintenance personnel.

name: Install Secondary Containment for Chemical Storage
description: Install secondary containment trays and berms under all 55-gallon chemical drums in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Each drum will be placed in a dedicated containment unit with capacity for 110% of the drum's volume. This engineering control directly prevents spills from spreading across the floor and contaminating drain systems. Implementation includes staff training on proper drum placement and monthly containment system inspections to ensure integrity.

name: Enhance Chemical Transfer Procedures and Training
description: Develop and implement standardized chemical transfer procedures requiring two-person teams, inspection of drum fittings before movement, and use of drum carts with securing straps. All Material Handlers will complete updated WHMIS and chemical handling training with specific emphasis on release agent properties and spill prevention. This administrative control establishes clear work practices that reduce human error during chemical handling operations.

name: Upgrade Ventilation System Monitoring
description: Install automated ventilation monitoring sensors in the Material Drying and Preparation Room that detect chemical vapor concentrations and trigger alerts when VOC levels exceed safe thresholds. The system will automatically activate supplementary exhaust fans and notify the HSE office. This engineering control ensures rapid response to any future chemical releases and maintains air quality within regulatory limits.

name: Implement Mandatory Machine Lockout/Tagout for All Mold Changes
description: Establish a strict LOTO procedure requiring all injection molding machines to be de-energized and locked out before any mold access or setup activities. Install high-visibility lockout stations at each molding line with standardized energy isolation procedures. All Machine Setters will complete recertified LOTO training emphasizing that machines must reach safe temperatures before contact with molds. This engineering and administrative control prevents accidental contact with hot surfaces during setup operations.

name: Install Thermal Barrier Guards on Injection Barrels
description: Install insulated thermal barrier guards around the heated barrel sections of all injection molding machines at Line A. These guards will reduce accessible surface temperature to below 60°C through insulation and ventilation, making incidental contact safe even if LOTO procedures are inadvertently bypassed. The guards will be removable for maintenance but will be standard during all production and setup operations.

name: Introduce Long-Cuff Heat-Resistant Gloves as Standard PPE
description: Issue heat-resistant gloves rated for 280°C+ to all Machine Setters and operators at injection molding lines. Establish a replacement protocol ensuring gloves are inspected monthly and replaced every 6 months. While not the primary control, these gloves serve as a backup layer of protection. Conduct training on proper glove use and limitations to ensure employees understand they are not a substitute for LOTO procedures.

name: Install Anti-Slip Matting at Assembly Workstations
description: Install anti-slip rubber matting at all manual assembly workstations in the consumer packaging area where coolant exposure is common. The matting will reduce slipping incidents caused by wet surfaces and provide improved hand stability during fine manual work. This engineering control addresses the root cause of the hand slip that led to the laceration.

name: Provide Cut-Resistant Gloves to Assembly Team
description: Issue nitrile-coated cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rating) to all Assembly Operators working with deburring tools and sharp plastic components. Establish a monthly replacement cycle and train staff on proper glove fitting and use. While PPE is a lower-level control, these gloves will minimize the severity of any future contact with cutting tools.

name: Implement Preventive Maintenance Tracking System
description: Establish an automated maintenance scheduling system using the existing predictive maintenance program to ensure temperature sensor calibration checks occur every 14 days without exception. Create redundant reminder notifications to supervisors and maintenance staff. Add sensor calibration verification to the pre-shift checklist for all injection molding line operators. This will prevent recurrence of temperature sensor drift and ensure early detection of equipment degradation before incidents occur.

name: Install Thermal Protective Barriers on Mold Access Points
description: Design and install perforated aluminum heat shields around all mold cavities on Injection Molding Line A to reduce direct skin contact with hot surfaces during part removal operations. The barriers will maintain airflow for cooling while preventing accidental contact with surfaces above 120°C. Include visual temperature indicator strips on the barriers to alert operators of overheating conditions. This engineering control reduces burn injury risk without impacting production workflow.

name: Enhance Operator Burn Awareness Training
description: Develop and deliver a 45-minute refresher training module focusing on thermal burn hazards specific to injection molding operations. Include identification of malfunctioning temperature controllers, proper PPE selection for heat protection, first aid response for thermal burns, and recognition of equipment degradation warning signs. Train all production operators and machine setters on both day and evening shifts within 30 days. Repeat annually and when new equipment is introduced.

name: Conduct LOTO Compliance Audit and Retraining
description: Perform comprehensive lockout/tagout audit of all grinding equipment in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Verify that all LOTO procedures are properly posted, easily accessible, and that operators can correctly isolate and verify energy isolation. Deliver mandatory retraining to all warehouse staff and equipment operators on proper LOTO procedures, emphasizing that equipment must be fully isolated before ANY manual intervention. Require sign-off on training completion. Repeat audit quarterly for 12 months.

name: Ensure Emergency Stop Button Accessibility
description: Clear and mark all emergency stop buttons in the Regrind and Recycling Department with high-visibility yellow paint and signage. Establish a no-storage zone of 1 meter radius around each emergency stop button. Conduct weekly inspections to verify accessibility is maintained. Add emergency stop button checks to the equipment pre-operation inspection checklist completed by each operator before starting their shift.

name: Implement Workbench Height Adjustment Program
description: Conduct ergonomic assessment of all assembly and setup workstations in Injection Molding Line D and adjust bench heights to accommodate the 5th to 95th percentile of worker anthropometry. For Line D specifically, raise the main setup workbench by 10 cm and install height-adjustable work surfaces for fine adjustment tasks. Provide adjustable footrests where needed. Train all machine setters on proper ergonomic posture at their workstations. Document baseline heights and schedule annual re-assessments to accommodate staff changes and equipment modifications.

name: Establish Mandatory Work-Rest Breaks for Repetitive Tasks
description: Implement a structured work-rest schedule requiring machine setters to take a 10-minute break after every 50 minutes of repetitive fine adjustment work. During breaks, operators will perform stretching exercises targeting wrist extensors and flexors, as defined in the company ergonomics training. Rotate operators between high-repetition tasks and lower-repetition duties where possible. Supervisors will enforce compliance through shift checklists. This administrative control reduces cumulative strain on wrist structures and allows micro-recovery periods.

name: Enhance Ergonomic Training for Night Shift Staff
description: Develop a targeted ergonomics training module specific to machine setters on the night shift, focusing on repetitive strain injury prevention, proper workstation setup, and self-monitoring for early symptoms of nerve compression. Include practical demonstrations of wrist-friendly techniques for common setup tasks. Deliver training to the 20 night shift workers during their shift hours to ensure attendance. Follow up with one-on-one ergonomic coaching for high-risk tasks.

name: Implement Automated Deburring Process for Molded Components
description: Install an automated tumble deburring system in the post-processing area to remove sharp edges and burrs from all injection-molded parts before packaging. This engineering control will eliminate the hazard at the source rather than relying on manual detection during quality control. The system will process batches overnight, reducing manual handling of sharp edges. Implementation includes operator training on equipment operation and maintenance protocols. Expected outcome: 95% reduction in sharp edge-related hand injuries within 60 days of installation.

name: Enhance Quality Control Inspection Procedures for Edge Defects
description: Establish a mandatory three-point inspection protocol using tactile screening with protective gloves and visual assessment with magnification for all components before packaging. Quality supervisors will conduct daily audits of inspection stations to verify compliance. Add specific training module on identifying and documenting edge defects in all quality control personnel. This administrative control complements the engineering solution and provides redundancy. Expected outcome: 100% detection rate of edge defects before packaging, with zero escapes to production floor.

name: Install Automated Jam Detection and Thermal Shutdown System
description: Retrofit all 32 injection molding machines with advanced infrared jam detection sensors coupled to the PLC system. When a jam is detected, the system will automatically reduce barrel temperature to 100°C and halt material flow without requiring manual intervention. Technicians will be trained to wait minimum 15 minutes before any manual clearing attempt. This engineering control eliminates the need for workers to interact with heated equipment during jams. Include annual sensor calibration maintenance protocol. Expected outcome: Zero thermal burn incidents from manual jam clearing within the first year.

name: Mandatory Heat-Resistant Glove Upgrade and Machine Shutdown SOP
description: Replace all standard cotton work gloves with aramid fiber heat-resistant gloves rated for 350°C contact temperature. Simultaneously, develop and enforce a written Standard Operating Procedure requiring machine barrel cooling to below 80°C before ANY manual jam clearing is permitted. Post laminated warning placards at all injection molding stations. Conduct quarterly toolbox talks emphasizing the SOP. This layered administrative control with upgraded PPE provides immediate interim protection while engineering controls are installed. Expected outcome: Compliance rate above 95% within 30 days, verified by supervisor spot-checks.

name: Install Predictive Maintenance Monitoring System for HVAC Equipment
description: Deploy vibration sensors and temperature monitoring devices on all three primary HVAC fan motors. Connect sensors to a real-time dashboard with automated alerts when bearing vibration exceeds normal thresholds or temperature rises 15°C above baseline. System will send alerts to maintenance team 72 hours before predicted failure, enabling proactive bearing replacement. This engineering control provides early warning to prevent future catastrophic failures. Integrate data into the existing predictive maintenance program infrastructure. Training on sensor interpretation will be provided to maintenance technicians. Expected outcome: Zero unplanned HVAC shutdowns due to bearing failure within 12 months.

name: Implement Mandatory Quarterly HVAC Preventive Maintenance Schedule
description: Establish and enforce a quarterly preventive maintenance protocol with digital tracking in the maintenance management system. Maintenance technician must complete bearing lubrication, filter replacement, and performance verification every 90 days (±5 days). Create laminated maintenance cards posted at each HVAC location. Assign specific technician accountability with sign-offs. Document all maintenance activities with timestamps. Supervisor audit will verify 100% compliance monthly. This administrative control ensures equipment is maintained according to manufacturer specifications. Expected outcome: 99% compliance rate and elimination of maintenance-related equipment failures.

name: Deploy Redundant Air Quality Monitoring and Emergency Response Protocol
description: Install a secondary continuous air quality monitor in the Regrind department with independent power supply and wireless alert system that sends real-time notifications to supervisor, safety officer, and shift lead via mobile devices when solvent vapor concentrations exceed 150 ppm (75% of PEL—early warning threshold). Develop a written emergency evacuation and fresh air deployment procedure specific to ventilation failures, with laminated cards at all workstations. Conduct quarterly emergency response drills. This layered administrative and detection control provides rapid notification and structured response capability. Expected outcome: Detection and response time reduced from 17 minutes to less than 3 minutes in future ventilation events.

name: Upgrade Hopper System with Mechanical Interlock Locking Device
description: Install a mechanical interlock system on all injection molding hoppers that physically prevents equipment operation when the hopper access panel is opened. This engineering control eliminates the possibility of auger rotation during maintenance by making equipment operation physically impossible when maintenance access is required. The system will include a visible lockout point that integrates with the LOTO program and will require maintenance personnel to verify both electrical lockout and mechanical interlock engagement before beginning work.

name: Mandatory Re-certification and Competency Assessment for All Equipment Maintenance Personnel
description: Conduct comprehensive re-training and competency assessment for all production and maintenance staff on proper LOTO procedures, focusing on the complete de-energization requirement (not just pausing cycles) before initiating maintenance activities. Assessments will include written exams and practical demonstrations. Only personnel who achieve 100% competency will be authorized to perform maintenance. This administrative control reinforces the critical importance of full lockout procedures and ensures consistent understanding across all shifts.

name: Distribute Cut-Resistant Gloves and Hand Protection Equipment
description: Issue high-performance cut-resistant gloves (ANSI A4 rated) and reinforced palm protectors to all maintenance and production personnel who perform hopper maintenance or equipment servicing. These gloves will be required PPE for all work within 1 meter of rotating equipment. While PPE is a lower-level control, combined with engineering and administrative controls, it provides additional protection during this high-risk task. Gloves will be stored at each equipment station for easy access.

name: Replace All Aging Quick-Disconnect Couplings with Pressure-Tested Components
description: Conduct complete inventory of all quick-disconnect couplings in the Chemical Mixing facility and replace any components older than 5 years or showing visible wear. Install new couplings rated for the specific pressure and chemical compatibility of each application. All replacement couplings will have certified pressure ratings documented in the equipment file. Each coupling will be pressure-tested and certified by a third-party testing service. This engineering control eliminates the root cause of the chemical spray incident by ensuring equipment integrity and reliability.

name: Establish Mandatory Face Shield and Chemical-Resistant Eyewear Requirement
description: Issue ANSI-rated chemical splash face shields and chemical-resistant safety glasses to all personnel working in the Chemical Mixing area. Implement a policy requiring 100% compliance with face shield use during all chemical transfer, mixing, and handling operations. Face shields must meet or exceed chemical splash protection standards and will be replaced quarterly or immediately upon damage. This PPE requirement provides direct eye protection during chemical handling and reduces the severity of any exposure that may occur despite other controls.

name: Implement Job Rotation Schedule for Line B Assembly Tasks
description: Establish a 2-hour rotation system where production operators alternate between part removal (high repetition gripping), assembly tasks (moderate gripping), and quality inspection (low repetition). This administrative control reduces continuous exposure to repetitive wrist motions by 50%, allowing muscle groups to recover during shifts. Rotation schedule will be posted at each workstation and managed by Production Coordinators.

name: Ergonomic Workstation Redesign and Tool Modification
description: Conduct detailed ergonomic assessment of all part removal stations. Install pneumatic assist handles to reduce gripping force requirements by 60%. Adjust workstation height to keep wrists in neutral position during part removal. Provide ergonomic gripping tools with cushioned handles designed for composite material handling. Engineering controls directly reduce repetitive strain hazard at the source.

name: Upgrade Fluorescent Lighting System in Mold Shop
description: Replace all failed and aging fluorescent ballasts and bulbs with high-efficiency LED lighting fixtures providing minimum 500 lux illumination at all workbenches. Install 5000K color temperature LEDs to improve color rendering for mold inspection accuracy. Add task lighting with adjustable arms at each precision work station. This engineering control eliminates the inadequate lighting hazard entirely, improving both safety and work quality.

name: Establish Monthly Lighting Inspection and Maintenance Schedule
description: Create a documented preventive maintenance schedule requiring monthly inspection of all lighting systems throughout the facility. Maintenance staff will document lux levels using light meters at critical work areas and replace any fixtures falling below minimum standards within 48 hours. Administrative control ensures early detection of lighting degradation before it becomes a safety hazard.

name: Implement Predictive Maintenance Program for Hydraulic Systems
description: Establish a comprehensive predictive maintenance schedule for all hydraulic coupling systems across injection molding equipment. Implement quarterly ultrasonic and thermography inspections to detect early signs of metal fatigue and fluid degradation. All couplings will be replaced at 80% of manufacturer service intervals rather than waiting until 100%. Coordinate with equipment suppliers to obtain accurate service history documentation. This proactive approach will prevent coupling failures and associated fire risks.

name: Upgrade Electrical Cabinet Fire Suppression
description: Install automatic wet chemical fire suppression systems in all electrical junction boxes and control cabinets on injection molding lines. These systems activate at 60°C without requiring manual intervention. Additionally, enhance ventilation around electrical components and use heat-resistant cable management to reduce fire propagation risk. Conduct quarterly functional tests of all suppression systems to ensure reliability.

name: Install Secondary Containment System in Chemical Storage
description: Design and install a dedicated secondary containment system with 110% capacity for all stored chemical drums in UNIT-010. The containment will feature sealed concrete floors with sloped surfaces directing spills to a central collection sump. Install high-efficiency ventilation with real-time vapor monitoring. Clearly mark storage zones with maximum occupancy limits and implement rigid racking with anti-slip drum holders. This engineering control will contain any future spills and prevent environmental exposure.

name: Mandatory Chemical Handling Certification and Refresher Training
description: Require all personnel handling hazardous chemicals to complete advanced WHMIS 2015 certification and spill response training quarterly. Training will include proper drum handling techniques, emergency procedures, personal protective equipment requirements, and first aid response for chemical exposure. Specifically address epoxy resin and hardener hazards. Document all training completion and maintain current certifications as a prerequisite for chemical storage area access.

name: Deploy Portable Spill Response Kits at Strategic Locations
description: Position five fully equipped spill response kits throughout the facility, including two in UNIT-010. Each kit will contain absorbent materials rated for epoxy and organic solvents, neutralizing agents, personal protective equipment (chemical-resistant gloves, respirators), and proper disposal containers. Train all shift supervisors on kit location and proper deployment procedures. Inspect and replenish kits quarterly to ensure full readiness.

name: Redesign Material Handling Stations with Ergonomic Controls
description: Conduct a comprehensive ergonomic assessment of all material handling workstations in UNIT-018 using REBA and NIOSH lifting guidelines. Redesign reject bin stations to position work surfaces at waist height (76-81 cm), eliminating awkward bending and twisting. Install adjustable work platforms with anti-fatigue matting. Implement mechanical assists including small electric hoist systems to reduce manual lifting to maximum 8 kg per lift. These engineering controls will dramatically reduce back injury risk.

name: Establish Quarterly Ergonomic Workplace Audits
description: Implement a formal quarterly ergonomic audit program led by the Ergonomics Specialist. Audits will assess all workstations against OSHA ergonomic guidelines, measuring work surface heights, load weights, repetition rates, and worker posture. Document findings and prioritize corrective actions. Engage affected workers in identifying problem areas and solutions. Track injury trends by workstation to identify emerging ergonomic risks before they result in incidents.
